column2: McGill University's notification to Dartmouth that it will send an eight-man skiing team to Hanover, N.H., for the Green's thirty-first annual carnival Feb. 7 and 8 came as good news, especially since it had been announced previously that the Dominion's declaration of war had precluded any possibility of intercollegiate, much the less intersectional, competition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today filing by the Wisconsin Public Service Corporation of a registration statement covering $26,500,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first mortgage bonds, series of 1971; $118,580 of $100 par value 5 per cent series cumulative preferred stock and $13,420 of 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock, series C.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Ten Latin-American students of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute regard motion pictures as a factor in creating "unfavorable impressions" of the United States in their countries.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Legislature completed action today on the increased appropriation for the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in New York City schools as the Assembly passed, by a vote of 135 to 5, the Coudert resolution giving the committee $45,000 more out of the legislative contingent fund.

James A. Gallagher, 43 years old, a lawyer, who gave the home address 443 Beach 137th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens, and who for ten years had been attached to the law firm of Davis, Pope, Wardweil, Gardiner Reed, of which John W. Davis is the senior member, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to two and one-half to five years in Sing Sing.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 22 -- Important political bargains are being negotiated by which the Diet will abandon general discussion on government policies and the government will drop opposed bills, including those for electoral reform and industrial reorganization.

The Rebecca Elsberg Memorial scholarship prizes, awarded semiannually to a girl and a boy pupil graduating from elementary school in Manhattan, were presented yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, to Aurora Falzone and Andrew Di Marco. Each received $150 and a certificate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that the cotton-spinning industry operated in December at 105 per cent of capacity on a two-shift eighty-hour-week basis, compared with 105.9 per cent in November last and 100.7 per cent in December, 1939.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The official Turkish wireless announced tonight that the government "has gathered a great part of its army in Thrace [European Turkey], where it awaits any possible action."

The retreat from the Sudan into Eritrea is plainly a measure intended to prevent in East Africa such disasters as Mussolini's legions have suffered at Sidi Barrani and Bardia, and now face in the assault on Tobruk. These isolated divisions no longer have the strength to maintain themselves in enemy country, and are withdrawing to their rail heads.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- A series of "program" bills, carrying out recommendations made to the Legislature by Governor Lehman, were introduced today in the Assembly under Democratic sponsorship.

Something new in sports promotion will take place at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx on Feb. 12 when the first indoor metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships will be held. According to plans for the meet announced yesterday, everything will be done on a community basis.
OTTAWA, Jan. 22 -- Dissatisfaction with Canada's aircraft production is being voiced loudly in some sections of the Canadian press.

The first of four sessions of the auction sale of autograph letters, manuscripts and rare books collected by the late John Gribbel of Philadelphia realized $21,272 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Luzerne County Gas and Electric Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement covering $7,500,000 of first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, due Jan. 1, 1966, disclosing that the bonds would be offered to the public at a price of 104 3/4. The underwriting commission is to be 2 per cent.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 23 (UP) -- A state of "virtual anarchy" exists in Bucharest and many parts of Rumania, according to reports reaching reliable Budapest quarters tonight. About 30,000 Iron Guards were reported engaged in the fighting in Bucharest alone.

LONDON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- The Australian troops that forced their way into Tobruk, Libya, captured the headquarters of the Twenty-second Italian Army Corps, according to dispatches from correspondents with the Army of the Nile.

BERLIN, Thursday, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Nazi spokesmen said today that "a number" of British planes raided Western Germany during the night, dropping bombs at several points but causing little damage. It was the first report of air attack on German territory since the heavy bombardment of Wilhelmshaven on Jan. 15.

Immediate Federal union of the United States with Canada, the United Kingdom, Ireland, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand was urged last night before 2,000 dinner guests who paid $5 each in the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that the market value of securities sold on all national exchanges in December, amounted to $831,614,773, a decrease of 16.1 per cent from November last and a drop of 6.9 per cent from December, 1939.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- After listening for two days to critics who felt that his Cabinet was not pressing the war to the fullest extent on the economic and industrial fronts, Prime Minister Winston Churchill had the last word today.

The quarter-finals of the men's singles in the Class B Metropolitan badminton tournament were completed last night at the Fifth Avenue Country Club. Seeded players came through with the exception of Cecil Gilman of the Downtown A.C., No. 3, who was defeated by Henry Osten of Garden City, 1 -- 15, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 13.

Harry F. Wolf, the national amateur squash tennis champion, who plays H. Robert Reeve Jr. of the Bayside Tennis Club this evening at 5:30 in the final of the Clyde Martin tournament at the Yale Club, failed to put in an appearance last night for the Class A team match in the Metropolitan League between the New York A.C. and the Columbia University Club.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 22 -Frank Allan of Pittston, Pa., seeking outright possession of the Ponce de Leon Cup in the Winter golf championship of Florida, advanced to the semi-finals today by defeating Jimmy Paul, local ace, 3 and 2.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 22 -Mrs. John K. Strubing Jr. testified here today that she was assaulted and abducted from her home on the night of Dec. 10 by Joseph Spell, who was then her butler-chauffeur and who is now on trial in Superior Court for the alleged crime.

VICHY, France, Jan. 22 -- Several thousand British subjects who have remained in unoccupied France since the break in diplomatic relations between France and Great Britain are being advised from their own government sources to leave.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Thursday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Civil war between Rumanian extremists and soldiers of Premier General Ion Antonescu spread rapidly throughout Rumania today, and news dispatches said several hundred persons probably had been killed in bitter fighting.

Operations of the Procter Gamble Company in the December quarter last year, resulted in a net profit of $5,020,035 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other deductions. This was equal, after dividend requirements on the 5 and 8 per cent preferred stocks, to 76 cents a share on 6,409,418 common shares.

VICHY, France, Jan. 22 (AP) -Despite Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's announcement that his "misunderstanding" with Pierre Laval had been "dissipated," informed sources here questioned the possibility that the former Vice Premier would be included in a new Cabinet to be formed soon.

The total market value of 1,059 listed and unlisted stock issues on the New York Curb Exchange aggregated $8,612,037,861 on Dec. 31, a decline of 14.7 per cent from the valuation of $10,127,920,333 on 1,077 issues at the close of 1939, an analysis showed yesterday.

A heavy volume of orders continues to pour into the sales offices of steel companies despite the industry's efforts to allay fears among consumers as to possible shortages, Iron Age says this week. "With nearly all products booked solid for this quarter, consumers are trying to protect themselves for the second quarter and even the third," it finds.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 22 -- Colonel William J. Donovan, President Roosevelt's personal envoy to Europe, left for Belgrade this afternoon after a two-day visit, during which he had talks with all prominent Ministers and was received by the King. His departure was marred by the loss of his diplomatic passport, which delayed his train for fifteen minutes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Council of State Governments, holding its assembly here, was told today by William S. Knudsen that expenditure of sweat now in the arms production program might save the expenditure of blood in the future.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Favorites, paced by top-seeded Bobby Riggs of Chicago and Frankie Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., breezed through the second round of the Florida West Coast tennis tournament today.

LONDON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- The Admiralty tonight announced the loss of the 1,340-ton destroyer Hyperion, the thirty-fifth destroyer lost since the start of the war, due to damage caused either by a mine or a torpedo.

Contests with two "bowl" teams, Boston College and Georgetown, will feature the nine-game football season for Manhattan in 1941, according to the schedule announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics. Seven major contests are included in the program.

The first upset in the women's metropolitan Class A squash racquets championship occurred yesterday when Miss Caroline Myers of Vassar defeated Miss Frida Scharman of the home club, 15 -- 13, 15 -- 8, 10 -- 15, 15 -- 7, to reach the semi-final round on the Junior League courts.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A metallurgist expressed the belief today that the nation's steel production could be increased as an aid to defense with comparatively little or no expansion of existing facilities through the use of idle Bessemer steel converters.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The German High Command's economic expert told foreign correspondents today that the German taxpayer had paid for about half the cost of German rearmament and the cost of the war to date.

Roy Erickson, competing on his home ice, captured the five-mile metropolitan speed-skating championship at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The event was part of the sixth annual Middle Atlantic Skating Association carnival. The winner topped a field of seventeen, including the defending champion, to take the Leonard Wagner Trophy.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 22 -George Washington University defeated Army in the last few minutes of a fast basketball fray today, 31 to 27.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Boston's complete dependence on New York in stock market matters was underlined today by three members of the Boston Stock Exchange who took the stand at the hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission on the attempt of the New York Stock Exchange to end what it calls "multiple trading."

Six members of the Havana University Medical College faculty are here for a week's visit as guests of the State Department, it was learned yesterday. The physicians are visiting the Cornell University Medical College on an exchange basis, the first sponsored by the government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has no statutory power to require competitive bidding for utility security issues, the National Association of Securities Dealers maintains in a statement issued here today, just before the commission plans to start hearings on a rule to this end as recommended by the agency's public utilities division.

In 1936 the Citizens Committee for the Control of Crime was set up at the suggestion of an extraordinary grand jury investigating rackets and after the effective work of similar committees in Baltimore, Cleveland and Chicago. There was then no common knowledge or unity of effort among the prosecutors and criminal judges of the five counties of the city.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 22 (UP) -The United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., ratified by acclamation tonight a wage agreement compromise with the Ryan Aeronautical Company which prevented a walk-out and tie-up of construction on $10,000,000 worth of war planes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The lifting of the "moral embargo" against Soviet Russia is another illustration of this government's decision that the devil must be fought with fire instead of with firmament. For a long time the President and the State Department stubbornly launched ideals against the realities of the world situation.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- That there is "unrest" in Rumania was tacitly admitted by the Wilhelmstrasse tonight, but official German quarters this noon spoke only of "tension," adding that "the situation is well in hand and never was out of band."

Twentieth Century-Fox's "Tall, Dark and Handsome" will open this morning at the Roxy. The gangster melodrama, which has several new songs, stars Cesar Romero and features Virginia Gilmore, Milton Berle, Charlotte Greenwood, Sheldon Leonard, Stanley Clements, Frank Jenks and Barnett Parker. . . . Monogram's "Pride of the Bowery" is the new attraction today at the Rialto.

ATHENS, Jan. 22 -- According to information available here tonight, an Italian counter-attack, which some foreign reports called the strongest yet launched, was successfully checked. The initiative of the battle was said to remain in Greek hands.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- Frankie the Fox, otherwise known as Frankie the Marvel of Mammalian Mnemonics, found himself today with a strong competitor for the title of star attraction at the Trailside Museum here, a field branch of the American Museum of Natural History.

The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, long a landmark on Murray Hill and the place of worship of many old New York families, will consolidate its work with its East Side branch, the Chapel of the Incarnation at 240 East Thirty-first Street, it was announced yesterday.

The heaviest competitive weekend thus far on the Eastern ski program is carded for Saturday and Sunday, when the first championships of the season will be held. The women's Eastern interscholastic downhill and slalom title races will be staged at Hanover, N.H., and Berkshire County will hold its schoolboy meet at the Pittsfield State Forest in Massachusetts on Saturday.

An underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., will offer today to the public $11,500,000 of Southern Counties Gas Company of California first mortgage 3 per cent bonds, due in 1971. The bonds will be priced at 101 and accrued interest.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- While May wheat acted tight and closed 1/4 cent a bushel higher today on the Board of Trade, there was local and commission house pressure on the new-crop months because of further precipitation in the main producing area and the July and September sold at new low levels since Dec. 23, closing 1/4 to 3/8 cent lower.

This being the time of the year when basketball performers make the astounding discovery that they are in college for education as well as play, activity is at its lowest ebb. Midterm examinations have halted all major competition until next Wednesday, when the last half of the court campaign gets under way at Madison Square Garden.

SOMEWHERE in "The Green Hills of Africa," a neglected book that contains some brisk literary criticism, among other things, Hemingway -- who has just been reading "Sevastopol" --discusses Tolstoy and the great advantage an experience of war is to a writer.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Appointment of a receiver for the Bankers Bond and Mortgage Guaranty Company of America was asked today in Federal Court by four stockholders who on Monday sought receivers for the subsidiary Bankers Bond and Mortgage Company.

The fall of Tobruk yesterday again fixes attention on the peculiar behavior of Italy's portion of that "surging wave of the future" of which President Roosevelt spoke in his inaugural address. This alleged wave began its reputed surging in Italy on Oct. 29, 1922, when King Victor Emmanuel sent for Benito Mussolini to form a Cabinet and the future dictator "marched" into Rome in a first-class railway carriage.

Joe Louis and Clarence (Red) Burman, who will clash in a scheduled fifteen-round battle for the heavyweight championship at Madison Square Garden on the night of Jan. 31, came through with impressive workouts at their respective training quarters yesterday.

It must come with considerable relief to hundreds of New York's air-minded young men, particularly those who always found it uphill work to pass mathematics in school, to learn that a candidate for appointment as a Naval Reserve student aviator no longer has to be on intimate terms with trigonometry and solid geometry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Roosevelt received and acknowledged a letter from Associate Justice McReynolds announcing his decision to retire from the Supreme Court on Feb. 1. He conferred with Senators Barkley, Glass and Harrison and with Governor Harold E. Stassen, of Minnesota, President of the Council of State Governments.

DETROIT, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Buck (Just Call Me Bobo) Newsom, pitching hero of the Detroit Tigers in the 1940 world series, will be paid probably more than $35,000 -- highest hurler's salary ever known -- next season by the American League champions.

Ferries that serve the five boroughs these days find their courses plying more and more between the Scylla and Charybdis of the tunnel and the bridge. These twin menaces slice ferry revenue by the gallon, and matters get worse every time Mr. Moses sees a bit of open water with an approach just waiting to be landscaped.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22 -Pennsylvania, with a spirited drive in the final ten minutes, defeated the Yale quintet, 40 -- 35, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest tonight. For the visitors it was their first victory in three league starts. Yale has lost all three of its circuit encounters.

There are now 4,000,000 armed men guarding the British islands, of whom all but the Home Guard are being rapidly equipped not only for defense but for action overseas, on the Continent of Europe. Not more than 60,000 Britons, half of them civilians, have been killed by enemy action, so that after sixteen months of war this great fighting force is practically intact.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- William S. Knudsen, Director of the Office of Production Management, said today that he had not given up the goal of producing by July 1, 1942, 33,000 military airplanes to be divided between this country and Great Britain. In a first press conference he remarked:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Bigger and broader skulls, lower cheekbones and darker hair are the physical characteristics which distinguish from among the population at large the "best minds" of America, according to Dr. Ales Hrdlicka, Curator of Physical Anthropology of the Smithsonian Institution.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Fourteen corporate and individual defendants in the glazing industry, accused of fixing prices of glass installed in and near Chicago, were fined a total of $31,003 today by Federal Judge Philip L. Sullivan. They had entered pleas of nolo contendere and placed themselves at the mercy of the court.

The 115th annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design will be held at the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, from March 11 to April 9. Work intended for the exhibition must be received at 210 West Fifty-eighth Street on Feb. 25 and 26, from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The moral embargo against the export of airplanes to the Soviet Union was lifted in connection with the export control system later adopted, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today in commenting at his press conference on the agreement announced last night.

The preliminary annual report of the Republic Steel Corporation for 1940, issued yesterday, showed a net profit virtually double the amount shown for 1939, although taxes were more than three times greater. Earnings were $21,113,507, or $3.30 each on 5,670,628 common shares, against $10,671,343, or $1.42 each on 5,833,065 shares, in 1939.

Pedestrian and vehicular traffic were at their height at Fifty-ninth Street and Third Avenue yesterday afternoon when a traffic patrolman, standing on the running board of a racing automobile and waving his revolver, caught up with a fleeing hold-up man and subdued him after a brief struggle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- In "tentative conclusions" on what properties the United Gas Improvement Company can retain under the integration provisions of the Holding Company Act, the Securities and Exchange Commission rejected today the view that the law permits a holding company to control several integrated systems in different parts of the country and sharply limited the U.G.I. system to its original home area of Southeastern Pennsylvania, around Philadelphia, and to margins of adjoining States.

American Woolen Company made official announcement last night of its prices on Fall men's wear worsteds, on which business has been taken for the last week or ten days. The prices show advances averaging 25 cents a yard over those for the Spring, 1941, line, opened last August, and about the same advances over the Fall, 1940, line.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 22 -The richly endowed, scholasticminded University of Rochester announced today that its football coaches, Dudley S. DeGroot and Wilbur V. Hubbard, had signed long-term contracts. The university also pledged intercollegiate athletics its support as long as they do not become a "racket."
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Juan Reyes, Chilean pianist, died at his home here yesterday of poisoning and police said that he had committed suicide.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 22 -- We had a premonition that our luck would run out so far as the North and South Carolina quail shooting was concerned, but we had hoped that the sailfish would remain off this fishing center until we arrived. These are still here, according to the various charter boat skippers, but getting out of the inlet and braving a rather white-topped gulf stream is something else.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22 -After being held in check for two periods, the Yale freshman hockey team caged three goals in quick succession today to overcome the Hotchkiss School by 5 -- 1.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Reports from Bangkok and Hanoi today were interpreted here as indicating readiness by leaders of Thailand and Indo-China to seek a peaceful settlement of the territorial dispute behind their undeclared war.
In reading THE TIMES this morning I recalled a speech made by Demosthenes about 350 B.C. which seems to me applicable to our present situation and the discussions being carried on in Congress.

When Justice McReynolds retires on Feb. 1 he will give the President his sixth appointment to the Supreme Court. Thus Mr. Roosevelt, who since Washington has shared only with Jackson, Lincoln and Taft the distinction of having appointed a controlling number of members of the Court, will with the naming of a sixth member have achieved a record shared by Washington alone.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Certificates of necessity enabling corporations to amortize new plant developments for tax purposes over a five-year period, where such plants are built exclusively for defense operations, were issued to sixty-seven companies through Jan. 15, the National Defense Advisory Commission announced today.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 22 (AP) -- British General Headquarters at Cairo issued this communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Treasury Department announced today the offering through the Federal Reserve Banks, for cash subscriptions at par and accrued interest, of $600,000,000 of threequarters of 1 per cent national defense series Treasury notes.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The British Admiralty tonight issued this communique:

TOKYO, Jan. 22 -- A ten-year population plan designed to give every Japanese family five children and increase the nation from today's 67,000,000 to 100,000,000 by 1960 was submitted to the Cabinet today by the Planning Board and approved.

Dry goods wholesalers are faced with a challenge to prove their worth in the national economy and this is the year in which that challenge is most forcefully presented to them, Henry Matter, executive secretary of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, asserted yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Canada is becoming a thriving arsenal for democracy herself, Vincent Massey, Canadian High Commissioner to England, said today, speaking before the National Defense and Public Interest Committee on the part played by the Dominion in the war -- and also the part played by the United States.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- After opening steady to 10 cents higher today, hog prices declined as much as 10 to 15 cents. Loins were quoted at 16 to 17 cents a pound, a full cent off yesterday's price and nearly $3 a hundredweight under last week's high. The top on hogs was $8.45. Fat cattle trade was slow and steady to weak with some steer sales 25 cents lower.

The industrial problem of defense is a problem of synchronization. Take airplane engines and frames. Each must be turned out to match the other. If motors are not being turned out fast enough to fit the frames, then the production of frames must slow down or possibly stop until motor production has caught up.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Officials of the Selective Service announced today a plan for the delivery Monday of replacements for registrants who were rejected in January's second and third calls. It applies only to local boards outside of New York City.
ROME, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

STOCKHOLM, Norway, Jan. 22 -To cope with the ever-growing wave of sabotage and anti-Quisling agitation, the Governor of Oslo has decreed the creation of a new State police which will be placed under the orders of the man dismissed by the legal Norwegian Government as a traitor to his country, Colonel Sundlo, who was in charge of the defense of Narvik which, on April 9, he surrendered without a struggle to the Germans.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 22 (AP) -Wise Father won the $2,500 featured race at Santa Anita Park today.
ROME, Jan. 22 -- Combatants in the present war who do not already belong to the Fascist party will have another chance to join, it was announced today.

A split in the Socialist party over the issue of aid to Great Britain came to light yesterday when a group of New York Socialists took exception to Norman Thomas's testimony against the Lease-Lend Bill. Those in the group, which said it had strong support in Illinois and Wisconsin and in other States, asked the House Foreign Affairs Committee to give its members an opportunity to express their conviction that the bill should be passed.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 22 -- Domestic stocks were markedly depressed on the Bourse here today on uncertainties relative to the payment of dividends. Likewise, there was some liquidation to meet subscriptions to the new loan. Following, too, the New York trend generally, losses of as much as 9 points were registered.

The City Planning Commission approved yesterday a modification of its original proposal for a master plan of express highways, parkways and major streets on the basis of criticisms expressed at a public hearing on Dec. 11.

Financing for preparedness should be developed and maintained to preserve free enterprise, Fred I. Kent, a director of the Bankers Trust Company, yesterday told financial executives of various industries at a conference conducted by the American Management Association in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Splendid performances by Eugene Rogers of Bayside and Raymond Miller of Jamaica in the 50-yard free-style and 75-yard breast-stroke events, respectively, featured qualifying trials for the city P.S.A.L. senior high school individual swimming championships in the Columbia University pool yesterday.

Fifty firemen required treatment for smoke and gas poisoning as a result of a fire yesterday afternoon in the Wholesale Electric Motor Company, Inc., at 530-36 Canal Street, between Washington and West Streets. The fire raised an extraordinary amount of smoke, that hung over lower Manhattan for hours.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 22 -- The developments in Rumania are regarded here as ominous, particularly the way the Axis is playing up the alleged killing of a German officer, which, according to independent sources, occurred during a brawl for which the German was primarily responsible.

VICHY, France, Jan. 22 -- Count Fernand de Brinon -- he has a right to the title but seldom uses it nowadays -- a financial writer and long before the present war an apostle of Franco-German rapprochement, has received or is about to receive Reichsfuehrer Hitler's reply to the memorandum from Marshal Henri Philippe Petain presented to him on Christmas Day by Admiral Jean Darlan "in a Paris suburb."

Members of the Merchants Association expressed a strong protest yesterday against Mayor La Guardia's proposal to use up to $25,000,000 of the surplus from relief taxes for purposes allied with relief, such as hospitalization and welfare payments.

Stressing that he was going to England as a "private citizen" and that his only plans were "to see, hear and learn what's going on over there," Wendell L. Willkie left for London yesterday morning at 8:30 o'clock aboard the Lisbon-bound Yankee Clipper of Pan American Airways.

Reversing the trend of the last ten days, in which period prices receded more than $1.50 a bale, the cotton market yesterday erased much of the loss. On the New York Cotton Exchange, final prices reflected net advances of 7 to 18 points, with the widest gains in the distant positions.

A pontifical requiem mass for Mrs. Elizabeth Eustace, mother of Bishop Bartholomew J. Eustace of Camden, N.J., was celebrated in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning. Eleven bishops from New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania and more than 200 monsignori and priests were present.
Seven of the ten largest banks in the United States are in New York City, according to the 1941 Roll Call of Largest Commercial Banks, published today by The American Banker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Henry M. Kannee, who has compiled the official record of President Roosevelt's speeches and press conferences in a million or more shorthand hieroglyphics, left the government service today to re-enter private business.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 22 -Morgans and Tuckers Islands in Great Sound, covering about thirty acres, have been leased to the United States for ninety-nine years for use as a flying-boat base, the Assembly was informed today by a message from the Governor.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 22 -- Mr. and Mrs. R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont gave a dinner tonight at their home.

Palestine Jews are facing the paradox of supporting Prime Minister Churchill's war effort completely and yet being at odds with British administration there, it was asserted yesterday by Dr. Bernard Joseph, legal adviser to the Jewish Agency for Palestine, the executive body in that country cooperating with the British Government.

"Lady in the Dark," long heralded as one of the major events of the season, will have its premiere this evening at the Alvin, having been set back a week because of the illness of its star, Gertrude Lawrence. Miss Lawrence recovered in time to participate in three previews this week.

Anew three-year contract covering 235 studio musicians employed in the New York City stations of the three major radio networks was signed yesterday by representatives of the broadcasters and Local 802 of the American Federation Musicians, A.F. of L.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 22 -Production at the West Allis plant of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, which is working on $26,000,000 worth of national defense orders, was stopped this morning by a strike of the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers Union, bargaining agent for the employes.

BELMONT, Mass., Jan. 22 (AP) -William C. Graustein, 52, professor of mathematics and assistant dean at Harvard University, was killed today when his automobile left the road and struck a cement pillar.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A prediction that the Administration's lease-lend bill would become law within sixty days was made today by Senator Barkley, Majority Leader, after a call upon President Roosevelt with Senators Glass and Harrison.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 22 -Assigned to the field artillery for a year's service, 496 trainees left here this afternoon by special train for Fort Bragg, Fayettesville, N.C. They are residents of New York, New Jersey and Delaware called up in the second draft last week and form a small contingent of the thousands of trainees being sent this Winter to the Ninth Division.

Company -- As of Dec. 31: Total admitted assets, $17,970,519. compared with $18,282,457 at end of 1939; bonds and stocks totaled $12,484,106 against $12,645,738; cash, $1,878,947 against $1,979,776; surplus, $12,544,765 against $13,178,371; unearned premiums, $3,173,513 against $2,974,290, and capital unchanged at 1,000,000.

Kirsten Flagstad's dominion extends not only over the Opera House but into the field of the symphony orchestra. As soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night she was a dominating figure. Her presence assured a success for the concert, which was for the benefit of the orchestra's pension fund.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Art Rubin of New York notched his fourth victory against two defeats by turning back Joe Chamaco of Mexico City tonight, 50 to 37, in 38 innings, which tied the best-game mark in the world title 3-cushion billiard tournament.

The 1941 school building program was spurred yesterday by the announcement at the Board of Education that appropriations for the construction of additions to two Queens schools had been approved by the Board of Estimate. Contracts were awarded to the Depot Construction Corporation.

Though all of them except Tommy Harmon are eligible for it, only three men who played in the New Year's Day East-West football game at San Francisco have applied for reinstatement as amateurs, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

A British expedition that started out in Africa on Dec. 9 as a limited and exploratory one with strict orders to retire after three days if its objective had not been accomplished has now, with the capture of Tobruk and reoccupation of Kassala, developed into a march of conquest.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 22 -"Googer Plays the Field," a screen story by Norman Krasna, will be the next production of the Krasna-Frank Ross independent company, which is now filming "The Devil and Miss Jones," with Jean Arthur for RKO, the studio announced today.

Igor Gorin, Russian baritone, gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall as the fifth event in the current Endowment Series of that institution. Mr. Gorin, who has concertized extensively in this country during the last three years, received his musical training at the Conservatory of Music in Vienna, and was a member of the State Opera in Prague prior to his arrival in America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Jackson Day will be celebrated this year on March 29, and Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, hopes to make it the occasion of raising $750,000, of which more than $400,000 would be devoted to wiping out the deficit.

Waves of "enemy" bombing planes surged over the northeastern industrial region between New York and Boston yesterday, and theoretically destroyed large areas of factories, war munitions, homes and public buildings with tons of explosive and incendiary bombs.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 22 -- The Georgetown basketball team made it ten straight today, defeating the Naval Academy quintet by a score of 38 to 18.

I have read and studied the objections to the CIO's aircraft production program. Aside from editorial comment, virtually all of the criticism has been anonymous. Aircraft and automotive industry executives have refused for some reason to lend their names to their printed views.
The two Army induction centers in New York City yesterday took into the service, for a year of training, a total of 440 men. Of these, 320 were from Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.

ORONO, Me., Jan. 22 -- George Allen, for the past four years backfield coach at Brown University, was named head football coach at the University of Maine tonight. He succeeds Fred M. Brice, varsity coach for the past twenty years, who resigned last month.

The 1940 annual report of Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, announced yesterday, shows a net profit of $20,339,241 after charges for depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other deductions. After allowing for dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock, the result is equal to $6.02 a share on 3,136,939 shares of $25 par combined common and common B stock.

Dramatizations of the lives of "minority heroes" to combat intolerance were suggested yesterday by authors and critics to the National Conference of Christians and Jews, which has national unity as its theme this year.

"Worlds Apart," a play with a message, came to Second Avenue last night under the sponsorship of Maurice Schwartz and his Yiddish Art Theatre. The message this morning is that its merits as a problem play are problematical, but it has others to spare.

FORT M'CLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 22 -- The troops of the Twenty-seventh Division, who are training arduously under the mobilization program, have taken to writing in their spare time and today they turned out Vol. I No. 1 of "The 27th Division News," a sixteen-page weekly, tabloid size.

A story of the indomitable courage of a 15-year-old crippled girl who from infancy has been forced to lie on her back, unable to move her arms or legs, was disclosed yesterday when officials of the Board of Education presented to her a diploma in a special grade school graduation ceremony at St. Giles Orthopedic Hospital for Children, 1346 President Street, Brooklyn.

VICHY, France, Jan. 22 -- Some surprise was occasioned here today by a reference in the Italian communique to the presence among the forces attacking Tobruk of "so-called French dissident" armored and motorized formations.

ROME, Jan. 22 -- The news that British forces had broken through the Tobruk defense was given to the Italian public today in a war bulletin. The account made it clear that the situation of the port was hopeless.

Business should be operated on a more democratic basis, with greater representation for labor and other interested groups, Dr. Edwin C. Nourse of the Brookings Institution advocated yesterday in an address before 175 executives attending the public relations institute at the Harvard Club.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- National defense functions are to have absolute priority in the Commerce Department's Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, Secretary Jones said today.

An effort by members of the New York Stock Exchange to retain on the floor of the Exchange the market for large blocks of shares which are being sold off the Exchange after the close of trading to an increasing degree was made in the late hours of yesterday's market and may lead to concerted steps in future instances, it was learned.

The Original Ballet Russe, back at the Fifty-first Street Theatre for seven performances, last night presented the world premiere of "Balustrade," a ballet by George Balanchine set to the Violin Concerto of Igor Stravinsky, with setting and costumes by Paul Tchelitcheff.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 23 (UP) -The United States and Great Britain, by continuous economic pressure on Japan and increased assistance to China, are seeking to exhaust the two Far Eastern nations, Deputy Chuji Machida told the lower house of Parliament in a "preparedness" address yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- More than half of the 5,110,000 unemployed persons who were seeking work in the last week of March, 1940, were concentrated in seven States, including New York, the Census Bureau stated today on the basis of preliminary figures based on a cross-section of the 1940 population census.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway management was confronted yesterday with a controversy over selling its securities through competitive bidding as a result of action taken by Robert R. Young, who is chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, which controls the C. O., and a director of the C. O.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A Federal agency entrusted with the responsibilities of economic defense is being planned by President Roosevelt, it was reported today. One of the main tasks of the unit may be to keep dollar exchange and essential materials out of the hands of the Axis Powers, it was said.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Two bills providing larger benefits under the State's Unemployment Insurance system were introduced in the Senate today by William F. Condon, Westchester chairman of the Committee on Labor and Industry.

Another instance of a more liberal cooperative advertising plan for dealers was revealed here yesterday when Walter A. Bowe, advertising manager of the Carrier Corporation, announced a new set-up on dealer advertising. Last week General Tire and Rubber Company made known that hereafter it would bear the entire cost of dealer advertising in newspapers.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Excerpts from Prime Minister Churchill's remarks in the House of Commons today on man power and the war follow:

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Japan has offered to mediate the border dispute between French Indo-China and Thailand [Siam], and there is a good chance the mediation may prove successful, Domei, the Japanese news agency, said today.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The British have added Tobruk to the empire's battle laurels and the next question is what will happen now Tobruk, of course, was a lost town as far as defense was concerned. Not even the German Air Force, rushed to Italy, was able to interfere with British bombing of that port.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Governor Lehman, speaking tonight at the annual farm dinner of the State Agricultural Society, urged agriculture, and particularly the milk industry, to lay aside internal differences and cooperate with the Federal and State Governments in building up national defense plans.

J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., has withdrawn as trustee for the proposed issue of $15,000,000 of new debentures of the Shell Union Oil Corporation, it was learned yesterday. The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has been named successor trustee.

The stock market enjoyed yesterday a slight respite from its sustained weakness of the last fortnight, and, under the leadership of the railroad issues, values were moderately enlarged in the general list. Sentiment was less pessimistic in Wall Street and this better feeling was reflected in the higher prices, although it is doubtful if the list could have registered such a rally without the lift given by the heavy demand for the carriers.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Suppression of The Daily Worker, Communist newspaper, and The Week, a news letter with a kindred leaning to the left, was defended in Parliament today by Herbert Morrison, Home Secretary, who was almost apologetic for tampering with the press.

The city of Boston yesterday awarded $5,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes to the First Boston Corporation at par, plus a premium of $77, for 0.33 per cent obligations. The notes, dated Jan. 24, 1941, and payable on Nov. 5, 1941, were not reoffered to the public.

Book critics throughout the country have been asked by the Book-of-the-Month Club to select the ten outstanding titles of 1940. Harry Scherman, who heads the club, says it will be interesting to compare the critics' choice with the best-seller tallies, even though the highly praised book in some instances can go begging.

Speaking at the annual luncheon of the Pilgrims of the United States in the Hotel Biltmore yesterday, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, called for a revitalization of the liberal movement under the leadership of English speaking peoples so that the march of progress during the past four centuries can be resumed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The House in almost unanimous approval of the Navy program, passed today the $909,000,000 bill for expanded shipyards, doubling the ordnance facilities and providing for 400 new ships of various sizes. It voted to take up Friday the bill requested by President Roosevelt for $350,000,000 to build 200 new cargo vessels.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission and its president, Paul J. Kern, turned the tables yesterday on the City Council committee inquiring into civil service affairs and began an investigation of the investigators. Sidney Z. Searles, an assistant counsel to the committee, was subpoenaed to appear at noon next Monday before the Civil Service Commission.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- The creation of a Westchester County Airport Authority to build and operate a county airport, using a $550,000 grant offered by the Civil Aeronautics Board for the initial work, was advocated today in a statement by the Federation of Westchester Taxpayers Associations.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 22 -The "extremist," or Codreanist, faction of the Rumanian Iron Guard is in the ascendancy and is gathering more recruits hourly under the battle-cry, "We will take back Transylvania; Legionaries in Rumanian Transylvania, to your battle positions and await orders!"

Daniel Frohman, dean of American theatrical producers, who died last Dec. 26, left his residuary estate in equal shares to two nephews, Daniel P. Davison of 415 Central Park West and Henry Davison of 44 Gramercy Park. The latter was named executor.

Modernization and enlargement of the Pittsburgh Steel Company's open-hearth furnaces and the increase in their operating efficiency have enabled the company to increase its rated annual steel ingot capacity since Jan. 1, 1936, from 806,000 net tons to 1,072,000, according to a listing application filed with the New York Stock Exchange for $6,500,000 first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds due 1950, authorized for listing by the Exchange yesterday.

James V. McGurrin, deputy county clerk, testifying yesterday before General Sessions Judge Goldstein on a motion opposing a blue-ribbon panel of talesmen for a Negro's first-degree murder trial because there are only eleven Negroes listed on the entire panel of 2,500 special talesmen, denied any racial discrimination had been made in the selection of the full panel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -Voicing confidence that "England can whip Hitler," Senator Norris arrived in the capital today to lend his support to the British aid program, with some modifications. Illness had delayed his return to Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- James Clark McReynolds, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court for more than twenty-six years and an implacable foe of the New Deal, informed President Roosevelt today that he would retire on Feb. 1, two days before his seventy-ninth birthday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Numerous charges of coercive price-fixing, boycotting of competitive types of distribution and monopolistic practices in grocery retailing have been received by the U.S. Department of Justice against corporate chains and independent retailers, Corwin D. Edwards of the department's Anti-Trust Division told the members and guests of the National Retailer-Owned Grocers, Inc., voluntary chain group, at its annual meeting in the Hotel Sherman here today.

LONDON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- A single mimeographed sheet edition of the banned Communist Daily Worker appeared in the streets today urgfng workers to "protest in your factories today, organize deputations to the Home Secretary demanding that the ban be removed immediately."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- An "all out" mobilization for national defense purposes of this country's human resources in every field of scientific knowledge and in the professions will become almost automatic on completion of a Federal project which is virtually an American scientific and professional Domesday Book.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 22 -- Five of the seven starters in Hialeah Park's Grade A Handicap, today's feature, drove home heads apart, supplying the crowd of 10,862 the keenest finish thus far of the meeting.

When half a hundred professional book reviewers were balloting some weeks ago to determine America's ten leading "classics" this column advanced the proposition that one of the requirements for a classic should be wide popular endorsement.

AN EAST CANADIAN PORT, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A Nazi air ace rated as one of the three most deadly in Reich Marshal Herman Goering's air force arrived for internment in Canada today with hundreds of other prisoners, most of them airmen shot down over Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Vice Admiral William S. Pye, now commanding the battleships of the Battle Force of the Pacific Fleet, was named today to succeed Admiral Charles P. Snyder as battle force commander, and second in command of the fleet.

The evidence has become compelling that Ludwig Geyer was the father of the great German composer, Richard Wagner, it is concluded by Ernest Newman, perhaps the greatest living authority on Wagner, in the third volume of his "Life of Richard Wagner," which is the comprehensive and definitive biography.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Favorable and unfavorable factors in world trade developments were reported today by the Commerce Department, on the basis of radio and cable reports from its foreign attaches, as follows:

Supplies of all classes of fresh meats were moderate to normal yesterday. Demand continued slow for all classes of traefer meats, and the market generally had a weak undertone, with lamb prices off 50c or more. Veal, which sold at steady to firm prices, was an exception, due more to light to moderate available supplies than to any particular activity in demand.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 22 -- Australian infantry entered Tobruk, Libya, shortly after noon today, successfully completing the battle for that Italian port. A few Italians holding out in the western sector of defense lines were being mopped up by the British imperial and "Free French" forces, but the British controlled virtually the entire area.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Bayne Johnston gave a farewell cocktail party yesterday afternoon at their home, 122 East Seventy-sixth Street, for their niece, Mrs. Eugene G. Hodenpyl, who is leaving shortly to join Mr. Hodenpyl in New London, Conn., where they will make their home.

The awards for the annual exhibition of paintings and sculpture by members of the National Arts Club, which opened on Jan. 8 at the clubhouse, 15 Gramercy Park, were announced last night at a dinner at the club in honor of its artist members.

EXETER, N.H., Jan. 22 -- The New Hampshire freshman basketball team, paced by Sharples and Harris, rolled up 17 points in the second quarter today and then stopped a rally by Exeter to register a 42 -- 36 victory.

Winthrop Rockefeller of Pocantico Hills, and Charles McCarthy, of a Mills Hotel, both volunteers from the same local board, were inducted into the United States Army yesterday for a year of military training under the Selective Service Act.

Because he feared that he would be shot to death if he did not comply with the demands of his brother, Nicholas Ruggiere testified yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court, he signed away his claims to half of the $98,000 Irish Hospital Sweepstakes prize his brother, August, 32-year-old former pugilist, had won last April.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Norman Thomas, national chairman of the Socialist party, and Hanford MacNider, Assistant Secretary of War under President Coolidge, Minister to Canada under President Hoover and one of the early national commanders of the American Legion, contended in testimony before the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that adoption of the Administration's Lend-Lease Bill would imperil the democratic structure of the United States.

The Giants yesterday nudged themselves a little closer to the day when all will be shipshape for the start of the 1941 training season by announcing two more contract signers. The latest to notify Secretary Eddie Brannick that they have accepted terms are Paul Dean and George Myatt.

ROME, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Italians were told today that their broken garrison at Tobruk had had to face "the maximum active weight of the English and French imperialist forces" and that the defenders of the fortified Libyan seaport had been outnumbered almost five to one.

The First National Bank of New York purchased yesterday $600,000 of certificates of indebtedness of the city of Elmira, N.Y., at 0.20 per cent, plus a premium of $151. The certificates, dated Feb. 1, will mature $300,000 on June 1 and $300, 000 on Oct. 1.

A gray-haired, 61-year-old mother of two children, who worked for a Brooklyn business concern for twenty-nine years ostensibly as a spinster and allegedly swindled her employer of $13,000 in a fraudulent check scheme because she had not received a salary rise along with other employes, was held in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday on charges of forgery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Standard Oil Company of Ohio filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to a registration statement giving the names of thirty-three underwriters forming a syndicate for a proposed offering of 150,000 shares of 4 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value.

The Bendix Aviation Corporation and its domestic subsidiaries reported yesterday net profit of $2,835,321 for the three months ended on Dec. 31, 1940, first quarter of the company's new fiscal year. The profit, which is after charges for interest, depreciation, Federal income tax and $2,054,714 provision for Federal excess profits taxes, is equivalent to $1.35 a share on the 2,097,663 shares of capital stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee is reaching the end of its hearings on the President's lease-lend bill for all-out British aid after sessions briefer, more orderly and far less emotional than had been expected. While the democratic and Congressional processes of examination and discussion are being observed, no time thus far has been wasted, and the witnesses and committeemen have stuck pretty well to their lasts.

Robert K. Howse, president of the Johnston Larimer Dry Goods Company, Wichita, Kan., was elected president of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute at the concluding session of the three-day annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday. He succeeds Robert M. Adair of Jones, Witter Co., Columbus, Ohio.

A client of the Kempner Realty Corporation, brokers, has purchased for cash above a first mortgage of $200,000 the six-story apartment house at 2120 Cruger Avenue, the Bronx, from the Jolinda Realty Corporation, which acquired it from Isaac Prussin, the builder, several months ago.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 23 (UP) -- William L. Coffey, chairman of the athletic hoard of Marquette University, announced tonight that Coach Tom Stidham of the University of Oklahoma had agreed to sign a contract as head football coach at Marquette.

The steel industry has budgeted $282,000,000 for plant expansion in 1941, or virtually double the amount budgeted at the beginning of 1940 and 65 per cent in excess of the $171,000,000 actually spent for new facilities last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

New York, New Jersey and Delaware have failed to fill their selective service quotas mainly because estimates of each local board quota included Negroes and the Army is not now taking Negroes, it was said yesterday by persons associated with the Selective Service Administration.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Hogs closed 5 to 10 cents lower today on a few late sales and topped at $8.35. General trade, however, was steady with Wednesday's average. Fat cattle and steer trade was generally weak while fat lambs closed 10 to 15 cents lower. Medium to good grade steers predominated the cattle run, with a top of $13.80 paid for 1,382 pound Colorados.
The cleavage between right and left-wing elements in the local C.I.O. was sharpened yesterday by disagreement over the lease-lend bill for United States aid to Great Britain.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The text of an Air Ministry communique:

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Driving rapidly toward the assumption of "full powers," Prince Fumimaro Konoye, the Premier, prepared today to push a record budget through the lower house of Parliament virtually without debate and to obtain from the upper house a pledge of "no criticism," which would enable the government to take unprecedented measures without parliamentary consent.

The northeastern seaboard of the United States is "vulnerable to enemy invasion by air from the sea," according to Major Gen. T.A. Terry, commanding the First Coast Artillery District, in a statement at Boston yesterday on the third day of the Army's four-day test of its aircraft warning system.
ROME, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

Some of the established marketing and advertising research executives are becoming disturbed by new types of research services and the various claims made for them. They have in mind numerous pre-testing services, which claim that they can determine in advance consumer response to new packages, window displays, radio commercials, advertising copy and almost everything connected with advertising and selling.

The net profit of the Caterpillar Tractor Company for 1940 amounted to $7,839,117 after Federal income and excess profits taxes and other charges, according to a preliminary report issued yesterday by B.C. Heacock, president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- During the week ended Jan. 22 member bank reserve balances decreased $4,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $24,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $8,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by increases of $23,000,000 in gold stock, $3,000,000 in Treasury currency and $2,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit.

Mayor La Guardia discussed the city's fiscal problems with the Republican leaders of the State Legislature yesterday but obtained no commitment that they would support his plea for authority to use the surplus from emergency relief taxes for general welfare purposes.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 -- Battle Colors and Bull Brier, both Flamingo Stakes eligibles, triumphed today in the two divisions of the featured Riviera Purse at Hialeah Park. The former completed a double for Edward Moore's Circle M Ranch, and finished the seven furlongs in 1:23 3-5, two-fifths of a second faster than Bull Brier, who carried the silks of B.F. Lister in the second division of the event over the same distance.

Today's events: "Alceste," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "Let's Sing for China," Town Hall, 3:45; Golden Hill Chorus, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Miriam Solovieff, violin, 8:30.

OTTAWA, Jan. 23 -- For the first time since the French Republic collapsed and the new French State was formed the toast of the "Chef de l'Etat Francais" was proposed by an Englishman and drunk within British territory on Wednesday evening.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Dean G. Acheson, former Under Secretary of the Treasury, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be Assistant Secretary of State.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Sale of twelve cargo vessels from its laid-up fleet to British shipping interests was announced today by the Maritime Commission.

Net asset value of the Bankers Securities Corporation on Dec. 31, 1940, was $14,786,560, equal to $83 a share on 178,136 participating preferred shares, on which there is an accumulation of arrears, against $14,195,594, or $79.52 a share, on June 30, and $14,649,973, or $81.76 a share, on Dec. 31, 1939.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 23 (AP) -- While the main British forces today were completing the consolidation of Tobruk, motorized units darted beyond, making the same sort of reconnaissance that had preceded the general attack on Tobruk. They were reported to have reached positions in the region of Derna, the next important Fascist base to the west, which is ninety-five miles from Tobruk.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., will offer today to the public $25,000,000 of securities of the Shell Union Oil Corporation. The offering will consist of $15,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent debentures due on Jan. 15, 1961, and $10,000,000 of serial notes maturing on Jan. 15, 1942 to 1953.

The 136th annual exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts opens tomorrow evening at 9 o'clock with a private view and reception in the galleries in Philadelphia. The exhibition, which includes original works in oils or tempera and sculpture by living American artists, will continue until March 2.

Evidence indicating that many of the passenger cars used by the New York Central Railroad in its intrastate service in 1940 were "dirty" and "unfit to offer to the public" was heard yesterday by the Public Service Commission at a hearing held at 80 Center Street.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 23 -- Yesterday afternoon, despite a rather fresh wind which made for heavy surf, we decided to try the surf-casting north of St. Lucie Inlet, along Jensen Beach. Ernie Lyons, who was to show us the best spots, decided it might be a good plan to take along a bit of bait, Just in case the surf was too heavy for squidding.

The need for developing social welfare programs that will help the government improve the lot of soldiers in training camps and on leave was discussed yesterday at the fourth annual Metropolitan Conference on Social Group Work and Recreation at the Hotel McAlpin.

The appointment of Dean Acheson to be an Assistant Secretary of State brings a new honor to a man who has earned many honors, and a new public responsibility to a man who has never shirked them. Throughout his career Mr. Acheson has always been ready to put aside his private affairs when public service called.

Purchases of silver by the United States Government last year amounted to 203,100,000 ounces, the smallest annual total since the silver-buying program was undertaken seven years ago, Handy Harman, bullion dealers, said yesterday in a review of the silver market for 1940.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- A new song, called "Thanks, Mr. Roosevelt," was introduced throughout Britain today and it was predicted that the tune would be the most popular of the season since it gives Britons an opportunity to sing and dance their appreciation of American war aid.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Suppression of The Daily Worker and The Week, Communist publications, will be debated in Parliament. Aneurin Bevan, R.T.D. Acland, G.R. Strauss and D. Kirkwood, Laborites, put down a motion today expressing "detestation" of The Daily Worker's propaganda but adding regret for the manner in which the suppression was efected.

Trading was generally slow on all classes of fresh meats yesterday. Supplies were moderate to about normal for Thursday. Asking prices on lamb were around 50c higher, but there was little activity in the trade. Veal and pork loins were weak to lower; other classes barely steady to weak. Kosher lamb foresaddles were firm to 50c higher.

Bruno Walter chose a program particularly suited to his tendencies and sensibilities as a musician when he conducted the Haydn "Oxford" synphony and Mahler's "Lied von der Erde" at the Philharmonic-Symphony concert last night in Carnegie Hall.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Miss Alice Marble suffered her first singles defeat since the 1938 Wimbledon tennis championships tonight when England's Miss Mary Hardwick out-steadied her for a 6-4, 4-6, 6-2 victory before a 6,000 crowd at the Boston Garden.

The 134 mutual savings banks of this State made 20,743 mortgage loans of all kinds during 1940, which totaled $19,840,280, the Savings Banks Association reported yesterday. The gain over the previous year was about 7 per cent in volume.

Continued wrangling between Paul J. Kern, president of the Civil Service Commission and members of the Council Committee investigating the commission resulted yesterday in Mr. Kern's ejection from the Council Chamber at City Hall, and a threat by the committee to lay evidence of an alleged fraud in civil service before District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Two substitutes for the Administration's lease-lend bill were offered in the Senate today as a Foreign Relations Subcommittee met with four Cabinet officers to plan committee hearings on the bill.

Signs of a break-up in the high meat price situation have begun to appear, although meat prices are higher this week than last. Wholesale prices have declined and retail prices are a little lower than they were earlier in the week.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 23 -- British, Australian and "Free French" forces have completed the occupation of the Tobruk area in Libya, although isolated Italian stragglers are still hiding out in deep gulches within the thirty-mile-long perimeter of the captured defenses.

The exercises of the nation's first Air Defense Command, which end today, and Governor Lehman's suggestion yesterday that the Federal Government commence the study of air-raid precautions have invited dramatic attention to the threat of the plane to this country.

Mr. and Mrs. John Williams Morgan gave a dinner last night at Larue for her brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Robert H.R. Loughborough. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. George Frederick Burr Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Edgar T. Appleby, Mr. and Mrs. James N. Carpenter Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Francis F. Appleby, Mr. and Mrs. Madison H. Lewis, Mr. and Mrs. Earl Kress Williams and Pryor Kalt.

A campaign to empty every firetrap in Chinatown was started yesterday by William Wilson, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, when he gave orders to vacate to owners of three buildings that he described as "not fit for human habitation."

Forfeits of $15,000 will be posted today with the State Athletic Commission to bind the world heavy-weight championship battle of fifteen rounds between Joe Louis, the titleholder, and Clarence (Red) Burman, Baltimore protege of Jack Dempsey, at Madison Square Garden a week from tonight.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Jan. 24 -- A taxpayers' meeting called yesterday to discuss an increase of 40 per cent in municipal taxes and license fees ended in a shooting affray in which W.J. Keswick, British chairman of the Municipal Council in the International Settlement, and two Japanese Councillors were wounded by a Japanese taxpayer.

Warners's "High Sierra" is the new screen arrival this morning at the Strand. Humphrey Bogart and Ida Lupino are tarred in the drama, which features Alan Curtis, Henry Hull, Henry Travers, Barton MacLane, Arthur Kennedy and Joan Leslie.

Retail credit collections showed a decrease of 0.79 per cent in December, according to the twenty local stores index, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. Seven stores had increases during the month. The average collection percentage was 45.38.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Governor Lehman will hold his ninth annual "budget school" at the Executive Mansion tomorrow afternoon, for the benefit of newspaper editorial writers throughout the State, and legislative correspondents who will write the news stories about the State budget when it is submitted to the Legislature Monday night.

Metropolitan skiers will have to go far for their sport this weekend unless the weather man lends a helping hand within the next twenty-four hours. Reports yesterday indicated there was little fun in prospect in the Catskills, Berkshires and Litchfield Hills, all near-by ski centers, and the Poconos of Pennsylvania offered poor to good skiing on trails and slopes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Public Health Service renewed today its warnings to the public to take every precaution against colds as it released figures showing that up to Jan. 18, 120,006 cases of influenza had been reported in the United States.

With cash and commodity contributions of $440,000 for home and overseas use during 1940, the Save the Children Federation has enabled 50,000 children in the impoverished rural counties of six Appalachian States to begin or continue their elementary education and has provided "godparents," each contibuting at the rate of $30 a year, to almost 5,000 native and refugee children in Great Britain, Dr. John R. Voris, president and executive director, reported yesterday.

HATBORO, Pa., Jan. 23 -- Plans for immediate construction of a $5,000,000 aircraft plant on a 367-acre tract acquired in this part of Bucks County fifteen miles north of Philadelphia were announced today on behalf of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, which has $125,000,000 worth of orders for its Brewster Buffalo plane.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- A showdown between football and baseball for Ace Parker, one of the most baffling back-scene struggles in sport, probably will come within a week or two, Manager Frank Frisch of the Pittsburgh Pirates said today.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Extra policemen were on duty throughout the International Settlement today after a quarrel between British and United States members of the Municipal Council and Japanese that resulted in the shooting of W.J. Keswick, British chairman of the Council; O. Okamoto, a Japanese member, and K. Ikeda, the Council's Japanese secretary.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, said tonight that he believed "the American people are about to commit suicide" by drifting into a war for which they were "morally and intellectually unprepared."
HORTA, Fayal, The Azores, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Wendell L. Willkie "carried" this island of 20,000 today.

Romance was the dominating note in the hat showing that occupied the attention of luncheon guests in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel yesterday. Hearts were "trumps," for they not only gave shape to many of the hats and ornaments; they also inspired coiffures.

Lovella Burton, 13 years old, walked into the Sheriff Street police station yesterday morning and told the police she had been beaten by her father. After an ambulance surgeon found painful welts and black and blue marks on her back and arms, the father Simon Burton, 49, was arrested on a charge of assault.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Any negotiated peace to end the European war as soon as possible, whether or not such a peace would be considered just by the American people, would be preferable, in the interest of the United States, to prolonging the present conflict, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh told the House Foreign Affairs Committee at its public hearing today.

Eleven years after he began his reign as the head man of amateur squash tennis, Harry F. Wolf went into the court at the Yale Club last night and disposed of one of the best of the young players coming up by the decisive margin of 15 -- 5, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 5, to win the Clyde Martin Memorial Tournament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Leon Henderson, National Defense Commissioner, shook the "big stick" of possible government control in the face of the lumber industry today with a direct threat of price control and conscription of needed requirements if the price of ordinary lumber was not quickly reduced.

Although the increase in commercial loans of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City was only $6,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, on the basis of figures announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the rise lifted the total to $1,925, 000,000, the highest since Dec. 29, 1937.

Captain Scott, who learned to fly in California during the late Nineteen Twenties, had a remarkable safety record as an airplane pilot. Officials of TWA said yesterday that in the seven years of his service with the line, Captain Scott never had an accident or a "near accident."

About a generation and a half ago Japan began to take territory away from her weaker neighbors. She took Korea; then, after an interval, Manchuria; then, after another interval, the northeastern provinces of China. She is now in the fourth year of an attempt to take the rest of eastern China.

How many miles does a very active basketball player cover during a game? On the assumption that somebody wants to know, Ben Beck, coach of the Middlebury College quintet, has supplied the answer by attaching pedometers to his players.

TOKYO, Jan. 23 -- Hopes that Ambassador Kichisaburo Nomura's genial personality and sincere desire for peace would miraculously change Japanese-American relations have faded and his departure today for the United States found the press in a gloomy mood.

VICHY, Jan. 23 -- Despite the meeting last Saturday between Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and Pierre Laval, his deposed heir as Chief of State, it is learned here today that the press in Paris is renewing its attacks on the Vichy government, which it alleges includes "conspirators" and "should be swept away immediately almost in its entirety."

Roy E. Larsen, chairman of the United Hospital Campaign, announced yesterday that recent gifts to it included anonymous contributions totaling $12,914. Among the others were $2,000 from Mrs. William Hale Harkness and $1,000 each from Robert Walton Goelet, Joseph P. Grace, Edmund C. Monell and Moss Estates, Inc.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 24 -- When Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh first began making speeches about international affairs after the war broke out the British press and public expressed regret that he had learned so little about this country during his stay here. After his testimony yesterday before a House committee that he favored a negotiated peace, many Britons expressed the opinion that he had learned nothing about this country or its people.

VICHY, France, Jan. 23 -- Theodore Rousseau, director of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York in Paris, and his wife, the former Princess de Breusil, are leaving Vichy tomorrow, returning to the United States via Spain and liner from Lisbon.

How can one study with a whole mind in the midst of a war upon whose issue depends the continuance of free inquiry and opinion? The annual report of the president of Harvard shows us what is going on in all our colleges and universities. Professors working for national defense; governing bodies seeking to aid the national cause without sacrifice of their essential educational functions.

The three five-story walk-up apartment buildings at 2166-74 Seventh Avenue, on the southwest corner of 129th Street, in Harlem, have been sold by Stanley E. Glauber, operator, to a client of Streiner, Kavanu Ramol, brokers, for cash above a first mortgage of $93,500.
BERLIN, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Long-range German bombers attacked two steamships west of Ireland so effectively today that "their loss must be assumed," it was reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton of the 1940 crop ginned to Jan. 16 amounted 11,931,018 running bales, counting round as half bales and excluding linters, compared with 11,412,432 a year ago, and 11,552,913 two years ago.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Born in Perth Amboy in 1903. William F. Smith was graduated from Columbia University in 1923 with a Bachelor of Pharmacy degree. For three years he assisted his brother in a pharmacy in Perth Amboy and then entered New Jersey Law School, from which he was graduated in 1929.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt this evening attended a dinner given in their honor at the Carlton Hotel by members of the Cabinet and their wives.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The British War Office cracked down hard today on the "Colonel Blimp" school of thought in its modern army and relieved of his command Lieut. Col. R.C. Bingham, who wrote a letter to The Times, London, saying that British officers unblessed by "the old school tie" had fallen down on the job.

Directors of Libby, McNeill Libby will file today with the Securities and Exchange Commission the names of ninety-six investment firms, headed by Glore, Forgan Co., which have been organized into a nation-wide group to underwrite the proposed offering of 3,018,639 shares of the company's common stock, now in registration with the commission.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Friday, Jan. 24 -- The official Bucharest radio said in a broadcast early today that the last of the rebels holding the police barracks and City Hall in the Rumanian capital had agreed to end hostilities. Some border reports estimated the dead at 2,000 throughout the country.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23 -- Mr. and Mrs. John George Simmons were among the hosts at the first Thursday informal party of the season held at the Surf Club tonight. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Thorne of Darien, Conn., son-in-law and daughter of the hostess; Mr. and Mrs. John D. Simmons and Mr. and Mrs. John H. Gerken.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- In the week ended on Jan. 18 further advances in the prices of livestock and meats caused the general level of wholesale prices to rise, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 80.6 for the week, compared with 80.2 for both the weeks ended on Jan. 11 and Jan. 4 and with 79.3 on Jan. 20, 1940.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 23 -- Royal Air Force bombers heavily attacked airdromes at Catania, Syracuse, Augusta and Comiso, on the island of Sicily, an R.A.F. communique said tonight.

British Empire countries sold 7,043 common and 5,484 preferred shares of the United States Steel Corporation in the final quarter of 1940, retaining ownership of 151,270 common and 35,953 preferred shares, the lowest such holdings in many years.
MONTREAL, Jan. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Toronto came from behind to defeat the sixth-place Canadiens, 3 -- 2, tonight and improve its position at the top of the National Hockey League standing.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The Black Hawks broke the spell the New York Americans have held over them for almost two seasons by driving to a 3-to-1 victory in their National Hockey League game tonight.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23 (AP) -- William J. Warrington, who devoted his life to feeding, lodging and counseling thousands of homeless men and boys, died of heart disease last night at the age of 91.

Midseason announcement of four new cars, adding a low-priced line to Buick's five other 1941-model passenger car series, was made to dealers yesterday by the Buick division, General Motors Corporation. Public announcement of the new line's features and price was scheduled for Jan. 31.

Too many "starry-eyed economists," divorced from reality and without practical business experience, are placed in important governmental positions in Washington, Dr. Edwin C.
