Nourse of the Brookings Institution asserted yesterday. He proposed that business recruit some of these theoreticians and place them in practical industrial jobs.

WASINGTON, Jan. 23 -- In an effort to minimize the dangers of inflation and give citizens in all walks of life a chance to participate in the preparedness efforts, the Treasury Department is preparing comprehensive plans for financing a major part of defense costs out of private savings instead of out of bank credit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- On the heels of a warning by Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka that avoidance of war was dependent upon American noninterference with Japan's "greater East Asia" policy, President Roosevelt took another step today to aid China in resisting aggression.

Voters in the old gas-house district on the East Side, formerly a Tammany stronghold represented in Congress by James H. Fay, have been receiving letters since last Monday from their new Representative, William T. Pheiffer, asking their views on the Lease-Lend Bill.

Frederick L. Knauss, confidential investigator to Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens, is "entirely lacking in the basic requirements of honesty, is utterly unfit for public service and should be immediately discharged from the service of the City of New York," accord to a presentment handed up to Judge Charles S. Colden in the Queens County Court yesterday, a copy of which is being forwarded to Borough President Harvey.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23 -- More than 600 colonists gathered tonight at the Everglades Club for a "stump the experts" quiz dinner, after the manner of "Information Please" arranged by Miss Elsa Maxwell, who was master of ceremonies.

TOBRUK, Libya, Jan. 23 (UP) -- A white-faced, tight-lipped Italian admiral in command of this port formally surrendered it to the British Army yesterday. The admiral stood inside a shattered naval headquarters and mumbled a rehearsed speech in English.

Some 79,000,000 board feet of the 400,000,000 feet of lumber salvaged from the New England hurricane of September, 1938, have been marketed by the Eastern Pine Sales Corporation, which took over the lumber from the New England Timber Salvage Administration about three months ago, it was reported yesterday by B.M. Osborne of Boston, vice president and general manager of the sales organization.

The British Iron and Steel Corporation, Ltd., announced yesterday through its office here that to expedite shipments it had agreed to take on blanket licenses for shipments of forty-seven iron and steel products to all parts of the British Empire.

Criticism of tax methods of the government and proposed changes were discussed yesterday at the closing session of a conference conducted by the American Management Association in the Hotel Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Was Department opened today a way by which 2,000 enlisted men might win reserve commissions within the next year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The trading in wheat futures was slow today and prices held within narrow limits. Covering by shorts induced by the strength in securities closed the list on the Board of Trade here at gains of 1/8 to 1/4 cent a bushel. The May sold 6 1/4 cents above the July at one time

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Scores of suggestions regarding a successor to Justice McReynolds on the Supreme Court reached the White House today, but the nomination was still a subject of conjecture at nightfall. Officials indicated that no statement would be made until after the actual retirement of the senior associate justice Feb. 1.

James N. Rosenberg, president of the Dominican Republic Settlement Association, headed a delegation that sailed yesterday on the Porto Rico liner Coamo for a conference in Ciudad Trujillo on Jan. 30, marking the first anniversary of the establishment in the republic of a settlement for refugees.
ROME, Jan. 23 (AP) -Eritish planes last night again raided Catania and another place in Sicily, the Italian High Command reported today, "without causing damage."

VICHY, France, Jan. 23 -- Japan's mediation of the conflict between Indo-China and Thailand [Siam] has been accepted by France, says a communique issued here tonight. Though there had been some hopes of United States intervention in the dispute, these hopes had to be abandoned and the French Ambassador in Tokyo has now been instructed to take up the question with the Japanese Government.

Pointing out that a difficult year faced the world, Mrs. Felix M. Warburg, president of the board of directors of the Young Women's Hebrew Association, declared yesterday in the organization's thirty-eighth annual report that the association members would meet the new problems "with courage and resourcefulness."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- National campaign expenditures in 1940 of the Republican and Democratic parties and their independent allies, exclusive of local and Congressional committees, was $22,740,313, according to the final compilation made by the Senate Committee Investigating Campaign Expenditures.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Further lightening of government security holdings of the Bank of England was disclosed in its weekly statement today. For the week ended yesterday the bank disposed of 9,330,000 of government obligations, reducing the total to 142,983,000, compared with 224,853,000 at the start of the year.

When "The Daring Young Man On a Flying Trapeze" was published in 1934. starting William Saroyan on his hectic way, he wrote an introduction to the short story collection "so that in the event that this book is issued in a second edition I will be able to write a preface to the second edition explaining what I said in the first edition."

TRENTON, Jan. 23 -- State Highway Commissioner E. Donald Sterner announced today that he had recommended to the Governor and Legislature a $14,635,000 State road construction program and a $3,500,000 military road construction program, the latter to be financed jointly by the New Jersey and Federal Governments.

Adoption of a streamlined method for quick action in developing emergency standards for defense purposes was announced yesterday by the American Standards Association. The new procedure, it was explained by P.G. Agnew, secretary of the association, will make it possible to turn out standards for parts and materials used in defense production as rapidly as is consistent with a good technical job.

An underwriting group headed by Drexel Co., Stroud Co., Inc., and Bioren Co. will offer today to the public a new issue of $7,500,000 of Luzerne County Gas and Electric Corporation first-mortgage bonds. The bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1966, are priced at 104 3/4 and accrued interest.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23 -- Three new film projects were announced today by Alexander Korda, Boris Morros and Twentieth Century-Fox. Korda has purchased "Forbidden City," an original story by Ben Hecht dealing with Nazioccupied Paris, and engaged Hecht, who is now in New York, to write the scenario.

Activity in the cotton market slowed down yesterday, but prices held firm. Opening 2 to 8 points higher, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange held within a range of 5 points and closed at net gains of 1 to 9 points. The distant positions showed the most strength.

The Katharine Cornell office yesterday announced that Raymond Massey will appear in Miss Cornell's forthcoming revival of "The Doctor's Dilemma." Mr. Massey, who is recalled for his memorable portrayal of Abraham Lincoln in "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" (1938), will have the role of Sir Colenso Ridgeon, the eminent British surgeon, a part last enacted by Baliol Holloway in the Theatre Guild's revival of 1927.

The Giants' dash to get all their players signed well in advance of the opening of the 1941 training season went into reverse yesterday when Secretary Eddie Brannick received a contract that left him blinking in amazement.

Under the direction of Dr. Leonard Carmichael, workers in more than one hundred and fifty sciences and professions are now being catalogued and mobilized to carry out our program of national defense. Germany and Great Britain have compiled similar rosters. But is this enough?

There will be no need for priorities for some time to come in the rubber industry, as in most instances ample productive capacities exist to keep abreast of the anticipated increased demand, John L. Collyer, president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, asserted yesterday at a regional conference of the company's district and executive staffs at the Park Central Hotel.

Telephones operated by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in ten foreign countries increased 92,013 in 1940, compared with 1939, it reported yesterday. The increase and a rise in long-distance messages transmitted were the largest for any year.

All things considered, the American stage may as well take a bow this morning. For Moss Hart's musical play, "Lady in the Dark," which was put on at the Alvin last evening, uses the resources of the theatre magnificently and tells a compassionate story triumphantly.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 23 -- Only a mile from safety, a big Transcontinental and Western airliner crashed before dawn today as it approached the Lambert-St. Louis Municipal Airport, killing the chief pilot and a TWA employe riding as a passenger and injuring twelve other persons.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23 -- How best to reconcile the immediate demands of a national crisis with the guardianship of eternal values is "the fundamental challenge which these unquiet days set squarely before our universities," said Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, in his annual report to the Board of Overseers.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The Empire State Express, crack train on the New York-Buffalo run, is to be streamlined with the purchase of two complete units, it became known here today through an interchange of letters between Governor Lehman and F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central System.

As the 1941 automobile plates are appearing in the metropolitan area one is struck by the increase of so-called specially numbered plates, particularly in the midtown section of the city. Plates carrying the initials of the owner or a number corresponding to the street number of his residence are of such common occurrence that one begins to wonder how this comes about.

A warning that the independence of the legal profession and even constitutional government is being threatened by Federal administrative agencies, and a demand that the lower Federal courts be empowered to review decisions by such agencies, was made yesterday by Colonel O.R. McGuire, chairman of the special committee on administrative law of the American Bar Association.

The Selective Service Act of 1940, under which millions of young men registered for military training and thousands are already receiving such instruction, was found valid and constitutional yesterday. The propriety of the legislation received its first test in Federal Court here because five young men, indicted for failure to register, had attacked it as illegal.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Articles of incorporation were drawn today for a unique organization whose sponsors believe that each community should do its utmost to take care of its own needy, and should do it voluntarily.

In its ninety-fifth annual report to policyholders, made available today, the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company announced a gain of $42,980,589 last year in insurance in force, to a new high record of $1,084,835,793.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Calling attention of the Senate to the crash today of the TWA airliner near St. Louis, Senator McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, predicted that "this unhappy series of air disasters will continue until the Congress returns the Civil Aeronautics Authority to independent status."

DUBLIN, Friday, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Firemen, after ninety minutes, brought under control a fire that broke out in ancient Dublin Castle early today. Huge clouds of smoke still poured out of the structure, but there appeared little danger the fire would spread.

A vagrant bulbul from far-off East India that mysteriously turned up late last Fall in a Westchester garden will sing its sweet song some time this morning in Fairfield Osborn's home at 207 East Sixty-first Street and engineers in Radio City will try to commit the music to acetate and wax.

The Metropolitan Opera Association has engaged Edwin McArthur, young American conductor, to direct three Wagnerian performances in New York and one in Boston, it was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager.

The Bear Mountain Hudson River Bridge Company will redeem on April 1, 1941, all of its first-mortgage 7 per cent thirty-year bonds outstanding and all of its income 8 per cent thirty-year debentures outstanding. The 7s will be redeemed at 103 1/2 at Brown Brothers Herriman Co. and the 8s will be payable at the same place at 103 1/2, plus interest to April 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The text of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's statement on the Lend-Lease Bill before the House Foreign Affairs Committee was as follows:

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 23 -- Today's Bourse, under the influence of the better tendency in the bond market and New York advices, developed an all-round rally although closing prices were below the day's best level.

Japan is eager to make peace with China on liberal terms in order to free her armed forces for an assault upon Singapore, but the Chinese realize that the respite they might thus obtain would be only temporary, Dr. T.V. Soong, chairman of the board of directors of the Bank of China, said last night at a dinner of the China Society of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

VICHY, Jan. 23 -- Payments between France and Belgium will be adjusted under the terms of the Franco-German clearing accord, it is provided in a protocol signed at Wiesbaden on Jan. 11, published here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Officials of the New York Stock Exchange were largely responsible for the creation of the present Chicago Stock Exchange and for the establishment of the present system of specialist-odd-lot dealers in dually listed stocks, two governors of the smaller exchange declared today at the third session of the "multiple trading" hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 23 -- Two Floridians, Dick Van Kleek and Bobby Walker, will play for the Ponce de Leon Cup and the Winter golf championship of Florida tomorrow on the St. Augustine Links.

Mrs. Victoria Owczerak, who last August kept forty rabbits and forty chickens in the yard of her home at 47-12 208th Street, Bayside, Queens, told Magistrate Soffer in Flushing court yesterday that she had eaten the last of them.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- It is slowly dawning on the people of Great Britain that the continual bombings have brought on a plague of rats with which they must contend. The government has launched a publicity campaign appealing to householders, business men, landowners and farmers to do their best to curb this "menace to national safety" which is doing annual damage estimated at 25,000,000.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 -- Dr. John A. Timm, assistant professor of chemistry at Yale University, has been appointed professor of chemistry, director of the School of General Science and chairman of the division of science at Simmons College. He will succeed Dr. Kenneth L. Mark, whose retirement at the close of the present academic year was announced by President Bancroft Beatley tonight.

There has been much ado about the game in Rockland County. First the deer, then the beavers, now the foxes. Soon it will be the ground hogs, the squirrels, the chipmunks, the birds of the air. We are the intruders; it was their land first.

In other, quieter times it would be the first thing to ask how Thornton Wilder's "Our Town" came to be produced in Mussolini's Rome. Customs and manners in a Now England village and in the ancient capital of Italy seem to be so far apart.

ATHENS, Jan. 23 -- All efforts at effective counter-attack by Italian forces in the last two days appear to have failed, while the Greeks, it was officially said tonight, have advanced their positions on all fronts and have captured a number of Italian strongholds, some of which were well defended and protected with barbed-wire entanglements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- After a meeting at the Treasury today of Secretary Morgenthau and Congressional fiscal leaders it was announced that an Administration bill would be introduced within a few days to raise the debt limit from $49,000,000,000 to possibly $65,000,000,000, remove the "partition" between the statutory limit and the specially authorized defense debt of $4,000,000,000 and provide for taxation of all future Federal securities.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

Lacking any major news developments upon which to base operations, traders bobbed in and out of the stock market yesterday in such fashion as to cause sharp swings in the day's movements. The share list opened on a better tone, then turned easier as motors unsettled the market, but rebounded in the final hour to permit fractional additions in the main body of issues.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) -- With one exception, favorites continued their advance through the third round of the Florida west coast tennis tournament to the quarter-finals today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 23 -- The doctor who examined and treated Mrs. John K. Strubing Jr. soon after she was found wandering near Kensico Reservoir on Dec. 11 testified in Superior Court here today in support of her story that she had been assaulted on the night of Dec. 10 by her Negro servant, Joseph Spell, who is now being tried on that charge.

The United States Lines announced yesterday the purchase of the new C-2 cargo vessel Sea Witch from the United States Maritime Commission for operation in the American Pioneer Line service to the Far East and Australia. Title to the ship was taken at noon and the vessel will sail soon from Gulf ports.

Mrs. Enos Throop Jr. of the Rockaway Hunting Club became the new metropolitan Class A squash racquets champion yesterday when she came from behind to defeat Miss Caroline Myers of Vassar in five hard-fought games, 16 -- 17, 14 -- 15, 15 -- 14, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 14. The match was played at the Junior League.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today a general investigation of the rules of the New York Curb Exchange as they relate to the suspension, expulsion and disciplining of members. A hearing was ordered for Feb. 10 here.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 24 -- The Air Ministry news service tells of six Polish pilots of Hurricane fighters who went hunting Wednesday in daylight, sprinkling Nazi motor boats, army trucks and troops building airports between Dover Strait and the River Somme.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- New York City has a better than even chance of supplanting Chicago as the center for the annual congress of the food industries, which annually brings upward of 20,000 grocery men from all parts of the country to this city during the third week of January, it was learned here yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Prime Minister Churchill was asked in the House of Commons today if he would move for the restoration of the Elgin Marbles to Greece after the hostilities. Clement R. Attlee, Lord Privy Seal, replied in the negative and said:

Effective on March 1, the reserve requirements of all banks and trust companies, private banks, and industrial banks in Manhattan and in Buffalo, that are not members of the Federal Reserve System, will be increased on aggregate demand deposits by 4 3/4 per cent and 3.6 per cent, respectively, in these communities.

Some rigorous relay assignments face local college athletes tomorrow when they journey to the Boston Garden for the Prout Memorial Games of the Massachusetts K. of C. Manhattan, Fordham and N.Y.U. have their work cut out for them in one-mile races and, as a grand climax, they will meet at two miles.

With the arrest yesterday of a third man in alleged frauds totaling $7,000 on two Fifth Avenue store keepers, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey made public details of a Munchhausen tale of a mysterious "liquor deal," involving non-existent "hundreds of millions" of dollars and with John D. Rockefeller Jr. and Mr. Dewey himself pictured to the victims as among the principals in the deal.

The comprehensive Annual Review of the Silver Market by Handy Harman is again useful as illustrating how far we have drifted even from the original purpose of the Silver Purchase Law of 1934. It illustrates also the extravagance into which our Government has been plunged without accomplishing anything for the country beyond creating fresh problems for the future.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 -- Members of the crew of the American freighter Steel Traveler which docked today from the Far East reported that the British had seized the 43,450-ton French liner Ile de France and were converting her into a troop or supply ship at Singapore.

The time has come to end the moratorium on foreclosures enacted into law in New York State in 1933 as an emergency measure, George L. Bliss, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, told stockholders of the bank at their eighth annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

A drop of $40,000,000 in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System to $6,860, 000,000 occurred in the week ended on Wednesday, it was revealed yesterday, with actual reserve balances up $4,000,000 and reserve requirements up $36,000,000.

TOBRUK, Libya, Jan. 22 (Delayed) -- So many Italian prisoners have been taken in the British capture of Tobruk that -- as in other battles of the desert campaign -- handling them is an annoyance not only to the British Army but also to correspondents.

A new nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion has shown a sharp increase in aid-to-Britain sentiment following President Roosevelt's fireside chat and his defense message to Congress, Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director, reports.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 23 -- Colonel William J. Donovan conferred today with Prince Regent Paul, Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch, Foreign Minister Alexander Cincar-Markovitch and Dr. Vladimir Matchek, leader of the Croat Nationalists. Colonel Donovan is in Belgrade as a United States observer.

Executives of leading public utility holding companies controlling utility properties with an asset value of approximately $6,000,000, 000 were virtually of the unanimous opinion yesterday that the "yardstick" integration report issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission against the United Gas Improvement Company would lead to a court test by the utility industry of the constitutionality of the so-called "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Construction of a new central bus terminal at Forty-second Street and Eighth Avenue by the Times Square Terminal, a private corporation, was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate, which plans to connect the terminal with the Lincoln Tunnel through a short vehicular tunnel costing $600,000.

The organization of a student committee to "Stop the Junior Fifth Column" in colleges and high schools was announced yesterday by the National Foundation for American Youth, of which Gene Tunney is chairman.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Yesterday he was Winthrop Rockefeller, scion of a famous family. Today he is Private Rockefeller, hoping to achieve the obscurity the Army expects of men of that grade among the 15,000 here.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- A strike of sixty structural steel workers, attributed in one quarter to a jurisdictional dispute between two locals of the American Federation of Labor, threatened today to delay completion at the Philadelphia Navy Yard of what is planned in the national defense program as the world's largest drydock.

A taxpayer project for New Hyde Park, Nassau County, was announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the entire block bounded on the north by Hillside Avenue and on the east by New Hyde Park Road, by Pilgrim Estates, Inc., to a client of the Investors Realty Service, Inc.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the schools won its legal battle with the New York Teachers Union today when the Court of Appeals upheld lower court decisions in favor of the committee on two principal points involved.

Revivifying many of the customs and traditions of entertainment in old-time Poland, the gala polka ball will be given tonight in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to advance the relief work of the Kosciusko Foundation in aiding refugee Polish professors and scholars.

Lee and J.J. Shubert, theatrical producers, entered the radio music war yesterday by announcing the formation of the Performing Rights Society of the Theatre, Inc., to make available to the broadcasting industry the grand performing rights of songs in Shubert musical productions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Senate campaign fund investigators today listed totals of "family" contributions to various Republican groups. They credited the du Pont family of Delaware with contributing $186,760 and the Pew family of Pennsylvania, $108,525, in final totals. Others included:

Featuring an auction of books written by alumni, and other literary items, the annual open house of the Alumni Association of the School of Journalism of Columbia University will take place tomorrow night from 5 o'clock until midnight at the Columbia campus. More than 500 alumni are expected to attend the gathering, which will include dancing and a buffet supper.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Jay Bozeman of Vallejo, Calif., tonight became the third player to win five games without defeat in the world three-cushion billiard tournament. He triumphed, 50 to 27, over Joe Moriarty of Chicago in fifty-four innings.

Bank clearings for the principal cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $5,845,586,000, a gain of 13.3 per cent over the $5,160,906,000 recorded in the similar week a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The figure for the latest period rose $246,244,000 above that for the preceding week, in contrast with a drop of $695,177,000 between the two similar weeks of last year.

At the request of the National Defense Advisory Commission, the Commodity Exchange, Inc., has started an investigation of the trading in zinc futures on the Exchange, it was announced yesterday. Following a meeting of the board of governors, a special committee was appointed to obtain the information on trading since Jan. 17.

Preservation of the two-party system in the United States is the most important function of the Republican party at present, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey declared last night at the annual meeting and dinner of the New York Young Republican Club at the National Republican Club.

The third session of the auction sale of autograph letters, manuscripts and rare books collected by the late John Gribbel of Philadelphia drew $10,594 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East 57th Street, last night.

Gross revenues of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in 1940 were about $85,619,000, up 2.6 per cent from 1939 to the highest total for any year since 1931, Howard S. Palmer, president, said yesterday. Freight revenues gained 6.3 per cent, but, because of the reduction in coach fares to 2 cents a mile ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission, passenger revenues declined 3.8 per cent.

The Selective Service Act exempts ex-Army men who have been honorably discharged after three years' consecutive service and National Guardsmen after seven years' enlistment. No mention is made of the Navy, Marine Corps or Coast Guard. The latter becomes a part of the naval forces in time of war.

Your editorial "Luxuries Off the Clippers" prompts me to pose the question whether the transatlantic clippers could not now carry first-class mail profitably at less than the present rate of 30 cents a half ounce.

Less than forty-eight hours after he had been inducted into the Army, Private Winthrop Rockefeller was transferred yesterday from Fort Dix, N.J., to Fort Jay at Governors Island and a few hours after his arrival at the latter fort he was transferred to Plattsburg, N.Y., for training with the Twenty-sixth Infantry, a regular Army unit.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 24 -- Using Wednesday's and yesterday's street fighting as a cover for their own ends, some of the more extreme elements of the insurgent Iron Guard in Bucharest implemented the threat to oust the "Jews, Free Masons and the Greeks" from Rumania by killing an estimated 300 Jews they had herded into cellars and then turned machine guns on them.

Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, and Clarence (Red) Burman, Baltimore protege of Jack Dempsey, formally signed contracts at the offices of the State Athletic Commission yesterday for the title bout in which they will engage next Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

Infantile Paralysis Sunday will be observed in the churches tomorrow. Pastors will refer in their sermons to the annual campaign for funds which culminates Thursday with the fifty-ninth birthday of President Roosevelt. In Protestant churches a message will be read from the Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, General Secretary of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that farmers received a total cash income, including government benefit payments, of $9,094,000,000 in 1940. This was an increase of $576,000,000 over 1939.

People in Britain have had several nights almost free from air raids. That would be a chance in normal life for catching up on lost sleep, but it is in the nature of a war of nerves that the intervals of quiet are as trying as the periods of storm.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Reports received today said Josslyn Victor Hay, Earl of Erroll and Hereditary Lord High Constable of Scotland, had been killed in an automobile accident at Nairobi, in Kenya Colony. He would have been 40 years old next May.

A storm area moving northeastward from Texas since Thursday reached New York yesterday afternoon, bringing an inch and a half of snow, sleet and slush to the city by late last night, drifts to suburban areas and heavy snowfalls to northern sections of the State.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 24 -- Three policemen of North Castle, N.Y., bolstered by their testimony today the main theme of the story of Mrs. John K. Strubing Jr. that she was criminally assaulted on Dec. 10 by her Negro servant, Joseph Spell, who is now being tried on that charge in Superior Court.

The writing of new life insurance last month was 7.5 per cent more than in December, 1939, while the total for 1940 was 0.2 per cent above the previous year, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in a report to the Department of Commerce.

What at first appeared to be a fairly attractive issue to the market, the new Treasury three-quarters of 1 per cent fully taxable defense notes due on Sept. 15, 1944, turned out as "pressing the market" closer than any other short-term notes issued in several years.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Bobby Riggs, former national champion from Chicago, rallied to defeat Frank Guernsey of Orlando in the quarter-finals of the Florida west coast tennis tournament today. The score was 6 -- 4, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 4.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of Donizetti's opera, "The Daughter of the Regiment," with Lily Pons and Salvatore Baccaloni in the leading roles, to be given tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies of which Mrs. William Randolph Hearst is founder and president.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Sir Frederick Phillips, Under Secretary of the British Treasury, said today that liquidation of British securities in the United States was "progressing very satisfactorily."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 24 -- Air Minister John McEwen announced this week that Royal Australian Air Force squadrons serving overseas would be more than doubled in the next few months. This increase, he said, will represent only a fraction of the new effort in which Canada, Australia and New Zealand are cooperating.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Jan. 25 -- With Shanghai still aroused by the wounding of W.J. Keswick, British chairman of the Municipal Council in the International Settlement, by an irate Japanese taxpayer, plans were being rushed today for another extraordinary meeting of Shanghai taxpayers.

On the stroke of twelve tonight the big glass doors of the new Airlines Terminal at Park Avenue and Forty-second Street will swing ajar and the world's first "union station of the air" will be formally opened to the traveling public. Although the $5,000,000 structure, which was built by the cooperative efforts of five of the nation's major airlines, has much in common with the railway terminal, there are differences.

Trading in all classes of fresh meats continued slow to only fair yesterday. Supplies were moderate to barely normal. The lamb market was steady to strong at Thursday's late advance. Veal was steady. Pork loins were around $1 lower. Kosher beef and veal prices were mostly steady, with opening prices firm to 50c higher on kosher lamb foresaddles.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- A light supply of 6,000 salable hogs brought active trading today in the week-end cleanup as prices rose 10 to 25 cents. Choice 180 to 240 pound hogs sold at $8.25 to $8.40, topping at $8.45. All classes of fat cattle were weak and generally 25 cents lower, while fat lambs held steady with choice offerings at $10.50.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The market value of total sales on all registered securities exchanges in December, 1940, was $831,614,773, a decrease of 16.1 per cent from November and of 6.9 per cent, compared with December, 1939, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan.24 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

Alfred E. Gluckstal has leased for ten years from Charleston Arms, Inc., Samuel J. Forman, president, at an aggregate rental of $72,000, the apartment houses at 212 and 214 West 108th Street, in a deal arranged by M.C. Elsesser, broker.

MADRID, Jan. 24 -- Incensed by a report that the Vichy regime permitted 150 Spanish refugees, including Niceto Alcala Zamora, first President of the republic, to leave for South America, the newspaper Arriba today issued a warning that the Spanish Government may intercept the ship.

Civic, social and labor groups merged last night in a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Commodore for Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt under auspices of the Women's Trade Union League, of which she is a life member. Amid the applause of 1,000 guests, Mrs. Roosevelt received from Miss Mary Dreier, vice president of the sponsoring unit, an illuminated scroll, the work of Hendrik Willem van Loon, which was dedicated "to Eleanor Roosevelt, lover of mankind."
Willie Mosconi, Andrew Ponzi and Jimmy Cares all scored double victories in the world championship pocket billiard play yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Essex County Tax Board dismissed today $203,015,509 in intangible personal assessments for 1939 filed against twenty-four subsidiaries of the Public Service Corporation by the city of Newark.

After being battered for forty-four hours on her way to Bermuda by a 60-mile gale and 40-foot angry seas that smashed two lifeboats and damaged five others at the davits, the Grace liner Santa Rosa arrived here yesterday a day late.

Frightened by a woman's screams, two armed robbers abandoned the hold-up of a jewelry store at 386 Park Avenue yesterday and fled after snatching a diamond and platinum bracelet worth $3,500 from a showcase.

Land on the northwest corner of Queens Boulevard and Sixty-ninth Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, owned by the Backas family for more than three-quarters of a century, has been sold by Ascan Backas to the Stanwix Assets Holding Corporation as the site for a six-story apartment building with accommodations for 114 families.

Buying of cotton for trade and mill accounts on price-fixing orders imparted yesterday a firm tone to the cotton market. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of futures closed 1 to 4 points higher. Half of the advance was registered at the opening when prices were up 1 to 2 points.

Skiing enthusiasm was running high last night as reports filtered in that it was snowing at many points, the result of the long-awaited storm that moved in from the Southwest. The near-by resorts -- Bear Mountain, the Catskills, Poconos and Berkshires -- were all covered with new white blankets that ranged from one to four inches.

VICHY, France, Jan. 24 -- Supplementing the municipal reform proclaimed Dec. 11, when elections were barred in communities with more than 2,000 population, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain today decreed new regulations for the appointment of town secretaries in rural districts.

The industrial outlook in the United States is tied up so completely with the war outlook that an impressive demonstration by Britain of ability to carry out the war successfully would be a de-decisive factor in the business picture here, according to William R. Kuhns, editor of "Banking," the official publication of the American Bankers Association, writing in the February issue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The House continued its rapid progress in defense matters today. The developments included:

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 24 -- Eighteen horses have been named for tomorrow's Miami Beach Handicap, richest stake in this country run on grass, and the task of naming the favorite for the Hialeah Park feature is a difficult one, not to speak of naming the winner. Turf races are always said to produce long-priced winners, as not many know how a given horse will go on the comparatively strange footing.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 24 -- With the last small nests of Tobruk's defenders successfully mopped up, British mobile armored units today moved farther westward in Libya. But where the British intend to go now still is a matter of conjecture.

MEDIA, Pa., Jan. 24 -- Presenting to the County Court what it called "a story of greed and corruption, of incompetence and mistaken faith," a Delaware County grand jury recommended today the indictment of former State Senator John J. McClure, the county's Republican organization leader, and twelve other persons.
Every Monday morning newspapers carry basketball statistics. These comprise, in the main, salutes to the scorers. That's all right; points win games and athletes who make them deserve plaudits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A summary of the findings and recommendations of the Attorney General's Committee on Administrative Procedure, as prepared by Dean Ackeson, chairman, and made public by Attorney General Jackson, is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Roosevelt expressed the opinion today that the defense picture so far as labor disputes were concerned was encouraging despite the strikes now in progress in plants manufacturing defense materials.

The story of how a million dollar swindler was swindled by a youth half his age was told to Federal Judge Edward A. Conger yesterday by Richard J. Burke, assistant United States Attorney. The account was particularly interesting to Judge Conger because he recently had presided at the trial of Samuel J. Mustain, the older one involved, and sentenced him to three and a half years in prison.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 (AP) -- C.S. Howard's Porter's Cap, closing at 5 to 2, won the Southern California All-Winter Sun Festival allowance race at one mile on a muddy track at Santa Anita today, beating some of the fastest 3-year-olds at the park.

The Appellate Division, in a unanimous decision yesterday, ruled in favor of James C. Petrillo and the American Federation of Musicians in the suit brought by the American Guild of Musical Artists to contest Mr. Petrillo's claim to jurisdiction over instrumental soloists such as Jascha Heifetz, Albert Spalding and Emanuel Feuermann, who are members of A.G.M.A.
Theodore J. Knapp has been elevated to the presidency of the Queens County Jockey Club as successor to the late John E. Cowdin, it was announced yesterday.

HAVANA, Jan. 24 -- The resolution introduced into the United States Congress yesterday by Senator William H. Smathers of New Jersey for admittance of Cuba as a State of the Union brought a quick and unfavorable reaction from Cubans today.

The proposed St. Lawrence seaway project for extending the uses of the water-power of the St. Lawrence River and the Great Lakes, was opposed as unnecessary in the present emergency defense program by speakers at the mid-Winter conference of New York State Commercial Secretaries which opened yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24 -- Twentieth Century-Fox acquired two new story properties today, both dealing with wartime England. "Confirm or Deny," an original story of present-day newsgathering in Great Britain, written by Hank Wales, American war correspondent, and Samuel Fuller, was purchased as a vehicle for Tyrone Power and will precede "The Black Swan" on his schedule, following his current "Blood and Sand."

Yehudi Menuhin, the violinist, became for a moment just an obscure triangle player in a band yesterday when he visited the East Side Settlement House, 540 East Seventy-sixth Street, to say hello to the children, for whom he will give a concert at Carnegie Hall on Monday.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Jan. 24 -- Quick thinking on the part of a bank teller yesterday afternoon enabled the police to arrest a man provisionally identified as Robert Joseph, 43 years old, of Marseille, France, who was attempting to pass 6,550 in British banknotes.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 24 -- Today's Bourse was depressed but a slight rally developed near the close.

New bond financing consummated here this week dropped to $48,530,000 from the $110,375,000 effected during the preceding period. This week's offerings, however, presented a fairly well diversified list of new issues, all of which were reported to have met with a broad investment demand and moved quickly out of the syndicates.

THEY used to call him Bad Bill Werber when he was in the American League, but he is practically Sweet William over in the National League, where, when last seen, he was playing a sprightly game at third base for the Reds as they made off with a world championship. It may be the soothing influence of close association with Mild Will McKechnie.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A comprehensive plan for improving the often criticized procedure of Federal administrative agencies, covering but going beyond the proposals of the Logan-Walter bill, was laid before Congress today by Attorney General Jackson.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 24 -- England's new battleship, the 35,000-ton King George V, a mystery since her launching, was the first naval vessel of a belligerent nation to arrive in this country since the war started.

At one stage of its evolution the Metropolitan Museum of Art was a kind of attic to which few people ever went but in which were some exceedingly valuable relics. For many years now there has been steady progress toward making it dynamic. The work of Henry Watson Kent as the museum's secretary has been recognized everywhere as a contribution to a new and vital theory of museum education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- An experiment in developing more "typically American music" for performance by Army bands will be conducted by Leopold Stokowski, director of the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, in work with an eighty-five piece composite band at Fort MacArthur, Calif., the War Department said today.

RANCHO SANTA FE, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Bill Nary, the home pro, lifted the $3,000 Bing Crosby golf tournament out of the doldrums today, blasting five strokes off par and tying the course competitive record of the Rancho Santa Fe Country Club with a 67 to lead the field in the first stage of this fifth annual event.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- A forecast for a severe cold wave in the main Winter Wheat Belt started shorts to covering in the July and September deliveries today and prices at one time were around 1 cent a bushel higher. The new crop months also received support in the way of closing spreads with the May.

ROME, Jan. 24 -- A warning to Stock Exchange speculators that the Fascist regime will curb their activities by applying "super taxes" on all operations unless they desist from gambling was issued by Virginio Gayda in today's Giornale d'Italia.

The interim report of the Pittsburgh Coke and Iron Company and subsidiaries for 1940 reveals a net profit of $1,000,624 after depreciation, depletion, provision for obsolescence, Federal income taxes and other charges.

Bill Hancock, 23 years old, of Roswell, N.M., and Lawrence Finley, 19, of Phoenix, Ariz., garbed in the costumes they had worn as "cowhands" in the recent Madison Square Garden rodeo, entered guilty pleas yesterday in General Sessions to assault in the second degree.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Jan. 11 was 4,107,330 shares, compared with 3,996,770 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
Your recent editorial, "Paper Money in Germany," calling attention to the rising volume of note circulation in the Reich, suggests a weapon whole possibilities the British may have overlooked.

Calling for an immediate diplomatic break with Germany, Dr. Harwood L. Childs, associate professor of politics at Princeton University, urged yesterday that the United States conduct a vigorous war, either formal or informal, against the Axis powers and establish a Ministry of Propaganda as part of the national defense.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 24 (UP) -- An agreement has been ratified by the New Bedford Cotton Manufacturers Association and independent union employes barring all strikes or lockouts for two years, it was announced today. About 17,000 operatives are affected.

The National Public Housing Conference was warned at the opening of its tenth annual meeting here last night not to try to relate housing too closely with national defense, also that it was a mistake to continue to raise the cry of crime and disease in support of housing.

At the annual meeting of the New York Plate Glass Service Bureau, a division of the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters, the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company was elected to the chairmanship of the supervising committee.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Welker Cochran of San Francisco, former titleholder, posted his fifth straight victory in the world three-cushion billiard tournament today, defeating Joe Moriarty of Chicago in thirty-two innings, a record for the current competition.
Much publicity is being given to the proficiency tests conducted by the United States Eastern Amateur, Ski Association. To our club members these tests have arrived four years late.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Clifford H. Reiter, president of the Cincinnati Stock Exchange, declared today at the Securities and Exchange Commission hearing that the New York Stock Exchange enforcement of its constitution to prevent its members from making markets on other exchanges had placed his organization in a "precarious position."

A capacity throng of some 2,500 persons, including members of the Polish diplomatic and consular corps, men and women prominent in society and civic circles and leading figures of the Polish-American colony, filled the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for the gala Polka Ball, one of the largest entertainments given here this Winter.
In an important prelude to the meeting of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, the Eastern body will convene in annual session this afternoon at the Hotel Vanderbilt.

BERLIN, Jan. 24 -- Official German quarters, commenting today on Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's testimony before the House Foreign Affairs Committee of Washington on the Roosevelt Administration's Lease-Lend Bill, said that his candor was "courageous" and that it called for "Hats off?"

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 24 (AP) -Cheers of British tars aboard the King George V rolled over the dismal waters of Annapolis Roads today -- not for President Roosevelt, but for four "stalled" newspapermen and photographers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Senator Hatch of New Mexico said today that legislation to require the Federal Government to bear all campaign expenses in a Presidential year was preferable to the large campaign funds of today. He said that he was horrified by the expenditures last year, which conservative estimates set at $40,000,000, but which some have estimated at as high as $60,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- At his press conference today President Roosevelt said he would not express an opinion on any proposed changes to the British aid bill, at least until he saw the measure when it came out of committee and could study the specific language of any amendments.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- Negotiated contracts for the manufacture of 462,500 wool service coats for the Army were announced by the Army quartermaster here today. Contracts for the manufacture of 60,000 mackinaw coats for the Civilian Conservation Corps from government materials were also announced.

With each succeeding appearance Miriam Solovieff's violin playing shows a marked increase in artistic growth. The richly gifted young musician, who made her local debut four years ago at the age of 15, was heard here for the second time last season.

The 100-year-old drug business of Hall Ruckel, Inc., will establish executive offices in the Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Association Building at 441 Lexington Avenue. The concern, founded in 1840, is one of the oldest in its line in the country and recently opened a new factory in Westchester County.

Affiliation with the Institute of the Brothers of the Christian Schools, the highest honor that the teaching order can confer, has been accorded to Dr. Michael J. Lynch of New York, it was announced yesterday by Brother E. Victor, Provincial of the New York District.

Rebuffed by the Court of Appeals in their argument that private one-man hearings by the Rapp-Coudert Committee investigating subversive activities in the schools were illegal, five Brooklyn College teachers notified the committee last night they would appear before it and testify.

The Federal food stamp program, which has been operating since last September among Brooklyn home relief families, will be extended to all classes of relief recipients in all boroughs in about a month, Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard announced yesterday in Washington.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Domei, the Japanese news agency, reported from Bangkok that, in accepting the proposal of this government, the Thai Premier and Commander in Chief, Major Gen. Luang Bipul Songgram, agreed not only to mediation but also to an immediate cessation of hostilities.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Shutdown of the $2,000,000 power plant at the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, where production activities have been paralyzed by a C.I.O. strike, was threatened tonight as a result of a dispute between A.F. of L. and C.I.O. leaders.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Horia Sima, leader of the rebellion in Rumania against the Antonescu government, and a strong band of followers are believed hiding in Brasov, in the Transylvanian Alps seventy-five miles north of Bucharest, it was reported here tonight.

In case you do not already know it, you may be interested in knowing that Mario Gonzalez, who plans to go to the United States for this year's amateur golf championship, is a Brazilian. He is the son of the professional at the Santa Amaro Golf Club in Sao Paolo, second largest city in Brazil.

Seven times during the past two weeks branch stores of the Spotless Cleaning Stores chain have been held up by a youthful thug, armed with what appeared to be an automatic revolver. Last night when a hold-up man showed up in the branch at 1649 First Avenue, between Eighty-fifth and Eighty-sixth Streets, two detectives, with guns drawn, were waiting in back.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Rumania emerged tonight from civil war and mass murder of Jews by so-called "gangster extremists" of the Iron Guard after German mechanized troops were rushed to Bucharest and into the thick of the fighting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Total non-agricultural employment in the United States in December was more than 37,100,000, a new high for recent years and 1,000,000 more than in December, 1939, according to Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, who reported today that approximately 540,000 workers were added in non-agricultural employment in the last month of 1940.

Retail trade this week continued well ahead of the 1940 level, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The wholesale division was also active, as retailers ordered in larger quantities and for longer periods than last year. Many producers reported orders in excess of current output, although operations were being stepped up to new highs.

JOHN COLLIER, whose new garland of tart, grotesque, banshee-haunted short stories is called "Presenting Moonshine,"* has -- when he is at his best -- the engaging quality of making his fantastic characters seem as clever as Satan without sounding as serious as the Devil.

While results for the week will depend on the effects of weather conditions upon trade today, department stores through yesterday were estimated as showing an increase of about 7 per cent over a year ago. The showing, however, was somewhat mixed. Ready-to-wear promotions did not fare especially well.

With an clement of uncertainty lending an appeal that the event lacked in the days of an invincible Glenn Cunningham, the Knights of Columbus Mile will be the high spot in the Boston Garden tonight for the annual Prout Memorial Games of the Massachusetts K. of C.

ANNAPOLIS, Jan. 24 -- Until the Presidential yacht Potomac docked tonight it was not known for certain that Viscount and Lady Halifax had gone on board from the King George V. The battleship could not be seen from shore. It was anchored in Annapolis Roads, six miles out, and fog rolled over the choppy bay in dense waves.

The Federal Water Service Company has entered into discussions with representatives of Scranton, Pa., with a view to the possible sale of the Scranton Spring Brook Water Service Company, a federal subsidiary. Under the projected deal, it is understood the Scranton property would be taken over by a public water authority which has yet to be formed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Roosevelt motored to Annapolis, boarded the yacht Potomac and sailed down Chesapeake Bay to meet Viscount Halifax, the new British Ambassador, who arrived on the British battleship King George V. He returned to Washington this evening accompanied by the Ambassador.

The poster contest sponsored by the American Rescue Ship Mission is open for entries until Feb. 12. A prize of $100 will be awarded for the winning poster which will be used in the national campaign to raise funds to send a ship for Spanish refugees in concentration camps in Southern France.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Roosevelt broke all diplomatic precedents today when he drove to Annapolis, rode out on the yacht Potomac to the great new British battleship, King George V, and personally welcomed to America the new British Ambassador, Viscount Halifax.

BERLIN, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The long arm of the German Air Force reached out into the Atlantic yesterday to damage or sink approximately 25,000 tons of shipping bound for Britain, the official German news agency, D.N.B., reported today.

The American Export liner Excambion is due to sail today from Jersey City for Lisbon via Bermuda. Her passengers include Captain H. Martineau, Mr. and Mrs. P.C. Stuart, Miss Gladys Marten, Mrs. W. Harding, Mrs. Mabel Curtis, Mr. and Mrs. Fred T. Caldwell, Count Rene de Chambrun, D.E. Rose, Robert Bult, Ernest Agnew, Kenneth Downs, Edgar Carolan, Mr. and Mrs. Jac S. Worm-Muller, James R. Lewis, Edward C. Stoner and the Rev. Leocade Bauer.

BERLIN, Jan. 24 -- Charging President Roosevelt with "aggression," with having "consciously and systematically poisoned relations between Germany and the United States" and with harboring "plans for Anglo-Saxon world domination," the Foreign Office periodical, Berlin-Rome-Tokyo, today solemnly denies allegations that Germany is planning to attack the United States.
In his letter last week, Ned Irish neatly side-stepped the query as to why Brooklyn College does not play at Madison Square Garden this season.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 24 -- Making one of his rare public appearances as a musician, Dr. Albert Einstein played four violin selections this afternoon at a benefit at the Present Day Club here for the American Friends Service Committee for Refugee Children in England.

In 1933 the New York State Legislature provided that if an individual had put a mortgage on his house before July 1, 1932, the holder of the mortgage could not foreclose and could not require him to reduce the principal amount as long as interest and taxes were paid.

Sixty Dalmatians, of all sizes and ages, of broad vocal ranges, howled and yowled for two hours yesterday in the yard of the Fire Department's School of Instruction, Sixty-eighth Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, while a group of experts selected twenty-five. The twenty-five will participate in a special event at the Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 12.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Although there was little selling in the stock markets today, most groups displayed a dull tendency.

A temporary injunction restraining the operator of a Long Island lunchroom from maintaining a stubborn adherence to property rights that threatened to delay the manufacture of $56,000,000 worth of pursuit planes ordered by the government for national defense was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Francis D. McGarey in Brooklyn.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 25 -- A Thailand-Indo-China peace conference will meet in Tokyo as soon as the local forces have concluded an armistice, the newspaper Asahi reports. Charles Arsene Henry, the French Ambassador, and Phya Sri Sena, Thai Minister, will represent their countries, assisted by technical experts from Bangkok and Indo-China.

The four-day test of the civilian aircraft warning system of the Army's new Air Defense Command ended yesterday with high-ranking Army and Navy officers, who inspected the information center at 140 West Street, announcing plans for a permanent and comprehensive set-up with Army, Navy, Coast Guard and civilian cooperation to "spot" and attack enemy bombing planes in case of war.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 24 -- Rumanian troops were sent out tonight to hunt for Horia Sima, the powerful leader of the Iron Guard, and "every last cutthroat" involved with him in the Guard's four-day rebellion.

The company of "Old Acquaintance" leaves tomorrow morning for Washington, D.C., where a "command performance" of the John van Druten play, starring Jane Cowl and Peggy Wood, will be presented at the National Theatre tomorrow evening in celebration of the President's birthday.

New issues scheduled for sale next week by forty-five municipalities and local housing authorities will aggregate $46,726,081, compared with $46,468,153 this week. The offering of $36,735,000 of notes by ten local housing authorities on Monday and Tuesday will feature the financing schedule.

Maurice Maeterlinck, Nobel Prize winner in literature who, at 78, is one of the war's refugees in this country, revealed yesterday that he would see the first American production in English of the Maeterlinck-Debussy music drama, "Pelleas et Melisande," next Tuesday in Philadelphia.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 24 -- Bringing a confused story of conditions at Martinique but asserting that the people there favored General Charles de Gaulle, seven Frenchmen and eighteen Czechs who escaped from the French Caribbean colony have arrived here en route to Great Britain to take an active part in the war.

There was no orchestra in the pit at the Metropolitan Opera House or any activity on the stage late yesterday afternoon. In Boxes 3 and 5 of the Diamond Horseshoe, however, the dim lights fell on the faces of eleven eager youngsters, who heard Earle Lewis, assistant general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, give instructions on how to listen to an opera.

Reversing the Book-of-the-Month and Literary Guild practice of purveying popular, freshly produced books, a new book club was announced yesterday that will present each month in low-priced editions neglected books of the past, titles that either through poor promotion or public apathy at the time "missed the boat" and are now all but forgotten and out of print.

Murray Vernon of the Downtown A.C., former national handball titleholder, captured the metropolitan veterans' squash racquets championship last night in a long and rough battle on the University Club courts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The contention that prices of scrap and secondary zinc were unduly high was advanced today by the Defense Commission following a conference with representatives of the industry.

The Filmarte Theatre in West Fifty-eighth Street will reopen today, after having been dark for more than a year, with the American premiere of "Hatred," a French picture starring Harry Baur. The opening attraction, which was directed by Robert Siodmak, also features Pierre Renoir, Albert Prejean, Robert Lynen, Dalio and Gabrielle Dorziat. . . .

When Peter Stuyvesant left Holland he carried a sword and a family Bible. That thirteen-pound Bible, printed in 1636-37, was placed on exhibition yesterday at the Dutch colonial heirloom exhibit's preview at Holland House, 10 Rockefeller Plaza.

George Goodwin, 44 years old, of 196 Rockaway Parkway, proprietor of the Howard Steam Laundry, 482 Howard Avenue, Brooklyn, was shot and critically wounded last night when he frustrated an attempted hold-up of the laundry by two young bandits and captured one of them.

One of three owners of an old-law tenement at 302 East Houston Street, in which an aged couple lost their lives in an early morning fire on June 4, 1938, was sentenced to a four-month penitentiary term yesterday by Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions, while the others were ordered to pay fines of $1,000 each.

The coffee dances for this season were concluded last night with the second dance of this Winter's series, held at the Cosmopolitan Club. There will be another dance late in the Spring, proceeds from which will be donated to a war relief agency.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Naval sources today disclosed that the destroyer Hyperion lay crippled in the Adriatic almost under the shore guns of the Italians for two hours before sending out an SOS in order that the warships following her might not be detected.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Informed military and diplomatic circles in London seriously expect the mightiest onslaught in history -- with bombing on an unimagined scale and the use of every modern weapon, including flame-throwers and gas -- to be launched upon the British Isles within three months.

ATHENS, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The famous Italian "Wolves of Tuscany" Division has suffered such heavy losses on the central Albanian battlefield north of Klisura it has been withdrawn and a new commander appointed to reorganize it, Greek reports from the front said tonight.

Paced by John Ezersky, who tallied 15 points, Power Memorial Academy scored its sixth Manhattan-Richmond C.H.S.A.A. basketball victory in as many starts by Crushing St. Ann's Academy, 50 to 32, on the former's court yesterday. Power leads its division.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Tony Lazzeri, the original "poosh 'em up" man of baseball, signed his contract with the Seals today, paving the way for what may be the final and one of the most unusual chapters of his long and brilliant playing career.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 24 -- The Anglo-Turkish staff talks in Ankara ended today, it was announced in British circles, but the British staff officers are not leaving Turkey. They left Ankara tonight to inspect an iron and steel plant at Karabuk, the only works of its kind in this country, which was installed by a British firm and turns out material of great importance in case of war.
There is no need for me to tell you of the Battle of Britain, or how it is being fought.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- The board of directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States went on record here today in favor of lending or giving aid to Great Britain and other democracies, but only with the specific approval of Congress or a bipartisan committee of Congress.

Two of three youths, on probation for a Bronx burglary and wanted for staging a hold-up in police headquarters at Wappinger Falls, N.Y., robbing the local policeman of his pistol and radio car and leaving him trussed up with his own handcuffs, were arrested last night when they returned to this city after their adventures up-State.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 24 -- Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, issued this statement upon his arrival here:,
A furnished apartment of seven rooms in 20 West Seventy-seventh Street has been leased by Dr. Gabriel A. Lowenstein, president of Stewart's Cafeterias, the Apartment Locating Bureau acting as broker.

New high levels in morning and Sunday newspaper circulation were reached at the end of 1940 in the United States, while evening newspapers again approached the peak circulation they attained in 1937, the 1941 International Year Book of Editor and Publisher, out today, reports.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The railroads are making it a "point of honor that we shall discharge in full measure our high responsibility in these times of national stress and danger," Martin V. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, declared here tonight.

Testimony that an audit made by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick's office, covering the period from April 3, 1939, to April 4, 1940, had disclosed a cash shortage of $715 in the office of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, in addition to an inventory shortage of about $8,000, was received yesterday by the City Council committee investigating the commission and Paul J. Kern, its president.
BERLIN, Jan. 24 -- Official German quarters believe the Rumanian crisis is over and are confident that General Ion Antonescu is master of the situation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Passage of the lease-lend bill would place the direction of the world war in the hands of two opposing dictators, Chancellor Hitler directing the totalitarian forces and President Roosevelt the forces of democracies, William R. Castle told the House Foreign Affairs Committee at its hearing today. Mr. Castle was Under-Secretary of State under President Hoover and Secretary Stimson.

James A. Farrell Jr., president of the American South African Line, announced yesterday that work on the company's three new passenger-cargo liners for the South African trade was progressing rapidly and that the first would be launched in June; entering service to Cape Town late in November.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 24 -A hitch-hiking German baron, who escaped from a Canadian prison train carrying Nazi prisoners to a camp in Northern Canada, was in the custody of the Ogdensburg police tonight after paddling over the icy St. Lawrence River in a small rowboat, using his hands as oars.

Evans Van Parr, fourth-seeded player from the Downtown A.C., and Warren Stephens, Old Sixty-ninth, ranked first, became finalists in the men's division as the semi-finals in all five divisons of play were completed in the Metropolitan Class B badminton championships on the Fifth Avenue Country Club courts last night.

Anybody who wants to send a telegram by Postal Telegraph from Grand Central Terminal can do it, a witness testified confidently yesterday in Federal court. The witness, Frank A. Salutt, a chief clerk for the Western Union Telegraph Company, said he knew it could be done because he had done it himself no fewer than ten times.

With an eye to the possible "freezing" of all foreign balances in the United States, Swiss owners of United States securities were reported to be active sellers yesterday. At the same time they converted the dollar proceeds of these sales into Swiss francs, with the result that Swiss currency was traded actively here.

Yesterday, on historic ground, the President of the United States welcomed the new British Ambassador to this country. His extraordinary action in going personally to Annapolis for this purpose will be interpreted everywhere as it was intended to be interpreted: as a tribute to the courageous people whom Viscount Halifax has come to represent and a testimonial of the ties which bind us to them in this time of crisis.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 24 -- Klabin Industries of Parana, Inc., has brought to a realization Brazil's second great industrial dream -- that of manufacture of paper pulp in Brazil. The first Brazilian dream of a steel industry has been brought near actuality by aid from the United States.

TOKYO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Authoritative sources reported today that the Osaka branch of the National City Bank of New York would be amalgamated soon with the Kobe branch because lack of business fails to warrant maintaining separate establishments.
The New York State Bar Association endorsed yesterday the idea of a Pan-American bar group to embrace the bar associations of all the nations of the Western Hemisphere.

In a survey just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion, it is shown that since last Spring a growing number of Americans have come to believe a German victory in Europe would effect their lives and fortunes directly or indirectly; that America's economic security no less than her military security might be at stake, Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director, reports.

The Most Rev. J. Francis A. McIntyre, recently consecrated Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, will receive a "spiritual bouquet" tomorrow morning from 5,000 members of the Knights of Columbus and their families who will partake of holy communion as an intention for the new prelate at the 9 A.M. mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The First National Bank, Portland, Ore., has received the award of $500,000 of School District No. 1 notes of Multnomah County, Ore., on a bid of par, plus a premium of $660 for the notes bearing interest at the rate of 1 per cent. The obligations, dated Feb. 1, will be payable on April 1.

A first mortgage of $400,000 has been arranged with the Troy Savings Bank through Herbert L. Williams, Inc. and Daniel E. Kennedy Company for a group of mortgage certificate owners on the 25-story business building on the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Twenty-eighth Street.

SIDNEY, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- With defense orders of the Scintilla Magneto Division of Bendix Aviation Corporation putting this little Delaware County village in the category of "Boom Town," the Sidney Chamber of Commerce has accepted a Federal Government offer of 250 to 300 trailers as a temporary solution of the housing problem.

A Catskill, N.Y., dispatch to THE TIMES announces that the New York State Bridge Authority plans to refinance its bond structure with a view to reducing the toll rate of 50 cents a car on the Rip Van Winkle Bridge at Catskill, the Mid-Hudson Bridge at Poughkeepsie and the Bear Mountain Bridge.
