FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 24 -- Officers of the Forty-fourth Division here are elated today over praise the division received from General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, and Major Gen. H.C. Pratt, commanding general of the Second Tactical Corps, for the appearance of its troops in the Washington inaugural parade last Monday.

A $1,000,000 loan shark ring that had among its backers members of the Brooklyn murder syndicate and that allegedly devoted most of its profits to paying police for protection of allied rackets was disclosed last night in an indictment obtained by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen of Brooklyn.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 24 -- Eighty thousand German troops have been withdrawn from Rumania since Monday morning, according to information from foreign military sources here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Contracts for more than $100,000,000 worth of war material, announced today by the War Department, included $50,000,000 for new aircraft engine works and one for slightly less to finance a new smokeless powder plant.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- In a story-book finish that included the most amazing goal made on Olympia ice all season, the Detroit Red Wings moved into second place in the National Hockey League tonight by scoring two overtime-period points to defeat the New York Americans, 4 to 2, before a crowd of 5,625.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- In a story-book finish that included the most amazing goal made on Olympia ice all season, the Detroit Red Wings moved into second place in the National Hockey League tonight by scoring two overtime-period points to defeat the New York Americans, 4 to 2, before a crowd of 5,625.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan 24 -- Colonel William J. Donovan, accompanied by the United States military attache and a liaison officer from the War Ministry, visited General Peter Pesitch, the Yugoslav War Minister, at 9 o'clock this morning and talked with him for forty minutes.

SOMEWHERE IN ETHIOPIA, Jan. 15 (Delayed; via Khartum, Anglo-Egyptian Sudan) (AP) -- Haile Selassie, deposed Emperor of Ethiopia, proudly raised the red, yellow and green flag of his former kingdom in a hidden mountain clearing here today, then set off to the interior to head British-aided Ethiopian tribesmen fighting their Italian conquerors.

The efficiency of the New York City administration of the Selective Service Act and the wide public acceptance of the defense measure as: shown by the small number of those who have failed to fill out questionnaires was praised yesterday by Captain Robert B. Coons of the Field Service Section of the National Director, after a two-day inspection of the local organization.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Smiles blossomed as freely as qualifying phrases in London's austere Foreign Office today as spokesmen gleefully (if somewhat prematurely) announced the arrival of Lord Halifax, the new British Ambassador to the United States, in America.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 24 -- Officers of the Forty-fourth Division here are elated today over praise the division received from General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, and Major Gen. H.C. Pratt, commanding general of the Second Tactical Corps, for the appearance of its troops in the Washington inaugural parade last Monday.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Jan. 24 -- James O. Newman was incorrigible as an inmate of Vigo County's Glenn Home for Indigent Children during the incumbency of Benjamin F. Stahl as superintendent. Newman was transferred to the Indiana State Boys School at Plainfield.

Christopher Willibald Gluck's "Alceste" in an altered form of the Paris version of that opera, which saw the light in 1776 and which the composer predicted would last a good 200 years, was staged for the first time in New York and, so far as available records show, for the first time by a major opera company in America, last night by the Metropolitan Opera Association in the Metropolitan House.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 24 -- A "shutdown" of the plant here of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, holder of more than $1,185,000,000 of national defense contracts, was predicted tonight by Howard T. Curtiss, director of the C.I.O.'s Steel Workers' Organizing Committee for the plant, following a "demonstration" this afternoon.

Chief Justice William R. Bayes of the Court of Special Sessions and Chief Magistrate Henry Curran of the City Magistrates Court are seeking salary rises totaling $146,000 for themselves and their associates on their respective benches for the fiscal year 1941-1942, it was disclosed yesterday in budget requests submitted to Assistant Budget Director Lester B. Stone at the Municipal Building.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 25 -- All was quiet on Britain's air front last night and early today. It was the fifth night in succession that Britons had enjoyed complete rest undisturbed by enemy bombers, and it marked the longest period of aerial inactivity since the "Blitz" began.

Nationwide sales of department stores last year showed an increase of 7 per cent over 1939, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board. The report is based on data from stores accounting for approximately three-fourths of the country's total department store business.
Come April and circus weather, there's going to be moaning at the bar. They've streamlined Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey, "the greatest show on earth."

Asserting that the United States was facing an acute shortage of trained engineers for its defense program, Dr. Harvey Nathaniel Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, appealed last night to local draft boards to defer inducting into military service engineers, engineering students and the teaching staffs of engineering.

OTTAWA, Jan. 24 -- Replacing the destroyer Margaree, lost toward the end of October, one of the fifty United States destroyers handed over to Great Britain in exchange for bases has been added to the Canadian Navy and rechristened the Kootenay, Navy Minister Angus L. MacDonald announced today.

Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, revealed in the West Side Court yesterday that he had invoked successfully the section of the penal law used against purveyors of obscene literature to stop the sale here of magazines that specialized in horror and terror stories.

In an effort to convince the Federal Communications Commission that television is sufficiently advanced to merit commercialization, the leading organizations fostering the art staged demonstrations here yesterday of its latest developments for members of the commission.

From the Committee on Education of the Tennessee Senate have come with a favorable report separate bills imposing a tax of 3 per cent on the gross receipts of newspapers and radio stations. It is not clear whether the measure taxing radio stations is to be taken in earnest or just as a device to cloak the hostility to newspapers which prompts the other bill.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 24 (AP) -- J.W. Atkins, regional director for the Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., announced today that its members employed at the Alabama Drydocks and Shipbuilding Company's yards had voted to strike until a wage increase of eight cents an hour was granted.

Oren Root Jr., chairman of the Associated Willkie Clubs of America during the recent national political campaign, has been designated by the Young Men's Board of Trade as "New York's outstanding young man of 1940," according to announcement made yesterday by Frank A. Vanderlip Jr., president of the organization, which is a division of the New York Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- President Roosevelt approved today the recommendations of a Naval Medical Corps Selection Board for the promotion of sixty-three commanders to the rank of captain and thirty-one lieutenant commanders to the rank of commander.

Surrounded by uniformed honor guards from national youth organizations represented in the junior division of the China Emergency Relief Committee -- the Girl Scouts, the Boy Scouts, the Camp Fire Girls and the Girl Reserves -- Chinese children from Public School 23, Manhattan, sang the "San Min Chu I," the Chinese national anthem, at the international chil dren's song festival under the auspices of the division at Town Hall yesterday.

HILLSIDE, N.J., Jan. 24 -- The Edgecomb Steel Corporation, now located in Newark, will erect a $100,000 warehouse and office building on a five-acre tract at Hillside Avenue and Shelton Terrace here, according to a permit issued to D.O. Evans, contractor, who will erect the building.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A coast-to-coast motor trip in Canada without the necessity of crossing into United States territory will be made possible this year for the first time in Canadian history, according to a Commerce Department report.
Recent discussion of the status of drafted players, about which there appears to have been unwarranted confusion, last night led President Ford Frick of the National League to clarify the situation.

The American College Publicity Association (Districts 2 and 3) opened a two-day conference at New York University yesterday, with 100 representatives of sixty colleges in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts and Virginia participating.

NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 24 (UP) -- The name of Steve Owen, coach of the New York Giants, today entered the discussion of possible successors to Tom Stidham, who resigned at the University of Oklahome yesterday to become head football coach at Marquette University.
VICHY, France, Jan. 24 -- By his personal selection of a National Council, announced this evening, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain disproved rumors that his National Revolution was at a turning point.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 24 -- Viscount Halifax arrived at this port late today on the newest of Great Britain's battleships, the 35,000-ton King George V, to take up his duties as Ambassador to the United States, and was met dramatically several miles offshore by President Roosevelt, who steamed out to meet him on the Presidential yacht Potomac in a driving rainstorm.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 24 -- All the signs and portents were opposed to successful sailfishing off St. Lucie Inlet today, but just to prove that you can't make rules in this fishing game the sailfish came to the surface and grabbed baits right and left.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Jan. 25 -- Leo Freisinger, 1940 senior men's titleholder from Chicago, was tied with three others for the lead in the national outdoor speed skating championships at the end of the first day's racing.

LAKE GEORGE -- Today's outstanding Winter sports event is a harness race on the Lake Luzerne ice under auspices of the Luzerne-Hadley Racing Association in cooperation with the Lake George Horse Racing Association. PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 -- Many colonists attended today the first in a series of semi-classical concerts to be given in combination with tea and cocktails at the Everglades Club on alternate Saturday afternoons throughout the season.

Auxiliary Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre of New York presented diplomas to a class of 198 at the semi-annual commencement of Cathedral High School for girls in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. He also presented medals and scholarships to twelve girls.

He has kept a diary since he was 9, and on the 8th of last May -- Wednesday -- he set down the usual kind of boy's record. His 9-year-old sister, Keetje, had a cold and didn't go to school, but he did -- and he had to have a composition on Erasmus written by Friday.

ROME, Jan. 25 -- A unified Italo-German command is to be adopted soon, according to reliable reports in Rome today. This has been strongly hinted recently by Italian commentators and, indeed, has been considered a normal and logical step ever since British pressure in the Mediterranean was intensified.

Declaring that "social and political poisons are being peddled up and down America" in a war on democracy, Governor Robert A. Hurley of Connecticut called yesterday on all States to establish special commissions "to foster good-will and understanding between all our peoples regardless of creed and racial descent."

MADRID, Jan. 25 -- This week, in an article intended to console the Spanish people for the present dire scarcity of food, a Madrid, newspaper recalled that in the seventeenth century there was a famine so widespread that "a lark could not fly across Castille without carrying its own provisions."

IN the third inaugural parade, State Governors and their staffs riding in 140 Ford sedans were reviewed last Monday by President Roosevelt from the White House reviewing stand in broad Pennsylvania Avenue. The gray-painted fleet of cars was provided through the cooperation of Major H.M.T. Cunningham, Washington branch manager of the Ford company.
ATHENS, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Italians, seeking desperately to check further Greek advances in Albania, are massing troops for a counter-offensive against Koritza, dispatches from that city said today.

The Navy has taken an option to purchase the last two of the Albany night boats for use as ferries or as receiving barracks for seamen, it was revealed here yesterday by Samuel R. Rosoff, owner of the Hudson River Night Line. The Navy's option does not mean that the ships definitely will be bought, but only that the Navy is going to examine the ships to determine their naval value.

Three years in the making, New York City's Consolidated Airlines Terminal was opened officially at 12:01 A.M. today. Six airlines that share the building conducted the opening with little fanfare and "business immediately" was the order of the day in the $5,000,000 terminal opposite the Grand Central Terminal.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 25 (AP) -- British armored cars, having fallen upon and broken an Italian tank column, were reported tonight to have reached Derna, Libya, 175 miles beyond the Egyptian frontier, under circumstances suggesting that it had been abandoned by the Fascisti.

Kenneth F. Simpson, for six years chairman of the Republican County Committee in New York and newly elected Representative to Congress, where he had served just twenty days, died suddenly late last night at his home, 109 East Ninety-first Street. He was 45 years old.
THE exhibition of American Indian art that opened in New York last Wednesday brings the Indian to the surface of our reluctant consciousness in a new and compelling way.

HAVANA, Jan. 25 -- Harry C. Nye Jr. of the Southern Lake Michigan fleet sailed the yacht Gale across the finish line first this morning in the initial race of the Bacardi Cup series in the fifteenth International Star Class regatta. His time was 2 hours 1 minute 19 seconds. Walter Etzbach crewed with the victor. Nye won both the Bacardi and Cuba trophies last year.
