Which will be given Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds for the British-American Ambulance Corps.

NO whit detracting from the formality of the occasion, Polynesian tunes, flower leis and native dances play their part in the opening session of Hawaii's Territorial Legislature. And again this year, on Feb. 15, when that body convenes in Iolani Palace, former home of kings and queens, the Royal Hawaiian Band will play in the throne room and mounds of flowers will adorn the workaday desks of political leaders.

MADRID, Jan. 25 -- Spain's ambitions in Latin America were emphasized anew by the Madrid press today in a reply to the news that Senator William H. Smathers had introduced a bill in the United States Senate for the incorporation of Cuba into the United States.

Operations last year of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and its subsidiaries resulted in a net profit for 1940 of $10,815,468, according to the preliminary statement issued yesterday. Charges against the net include depreciation, depletion, interest, Federal income taxes and other deductions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The War Department, it was learned today, will ask Congress soon for about $700,000,000 to build a chain of munitions plants originally intended as reserve, or "stand-by," factories.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 -- While San Francisco regrets the recent tearing down and mutilation of the swastika flag flown by the Consulate-General of Nazi Germany, it would not apologize -- except, perhaps, as a favor to the State Department -- if a German fleet were standing outside San Francisco Bay.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- Governor Lehman pressed his fight today for diversion of grade-crossing ing bond money to the construction of highways and parkways.

PROFESSOR BIRDSALL'S excellent book is far more than a historical examination of a peace treaty which is as dead as a door nail. It is, in its fundamental character, at once a historical study and a polemic. In both its phases it is absolutely first-rate.

Friday marks the end of the two week mid-year examination period at Fordham which temporarily curtailed competition for the Ram sports teams. The track, swimming, rifle and fencing will resume activity Saturday. The basketball team is slated to face Yale a week from tomorrow.

Interest in problems of recreation in the education field has been heightened here during the last week. Following closely in the wake of the third annual conference of recreation leaders, announcement was made yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, which was the conference host, that the university together with the Board of Education would sponsor a two-year study of recreation research.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- From now until the middle of March there will be no dull moments in the Green Mountain ski area. Every week-end has a full schedule of activities, with some in between. Starting this week-end, the Chester Outing Club is staging a carnival, and the Vermont State men's and women's championship in slalom is being run off at Pico Peak, under the auspices of the Otter Ski Club.

UNDER the joint sponsorship of their company and the Board of Education, maintenance mechanics of Pan American Airways are taking courses in engine overhaul, accessory overhaul, sheet metal working and aircraft welding in the airline's hangar on Treasure Island, San Francisco.

MISS PEDLER'S very British stories are always pleasantly written, with credible characters and solid backgrounds. This one is no exception. Melodrama and romance are suitably mingled, and the heroine, not yet 20, follows what looks like a trend in light fiction, marrying a man much older than herself at the end.

BERLIN, Jan. 25 -- The Essener National Zeitung tonight examines the mission of President Roosevelt's special envoy, Colonel William J. Donovan, as well as Wendell Willkie's trip to England. Like the Foreign Office periodical Berlin-Rome-Tokyo yesterday and other German papers today, this newspaper couples its comment with a thinly veiled warning to the United States that any action it may take will find Germany and her partners prepared.

ANY one not Welsh who, like this reviewer, has lived in Wales and so become more than casually acquainted with the Welsh people of both north and south knows that the outstanding characteristics of the race are an inherent poetical quality, an ineradicable mysticism, an innate aristocracy of soul and a hard, stiffening core of realistic perception.

THE new 10/100-plaster nickel coin from Indo-China has just made its appearance among the collections of this country. The San Francisco mint struck 17,580,000 of these nickel pieces for Indo-China during May of last year. The dies were made in Paris.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas -- It remains a very simple matter for the tourist from the United States to travel in Mexico. Although the United States has tightened border regulations by requiring that visitors from Mexico present visaed passports, the Mexican Government has not made any change in regulations concerning tourist travel by American citizens. Entry to Mexico, as before, can be made by tourist card.

Construction of the last link in the first all-cable transcontinental telephone line to be built in the country has been started along a 1,600-mile line from Omaha, Neb., to Sacramento, Calif., it is announced from the offices of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company at 195 Broadway.

THE lesson of those parachute troops that began pouring out of Russian airplanes some years ago and then were used with such devastating effect by the Germans in their conquest of the Lowlands was not lost on this country. The United States Army, after a period of experiment, has just announced that it will train 4,000 to 6,000 parachutists in the new technique of diversion, confusion and surprise during attack.

Six new yacht clubs have been admitted this month into the federation of the American Power Boat Association, according to Vaughn M. Thorne, making even larger this body of some 250 clubs which President John A. Remon has reported had an increase of 15 per cent in its ranks during 1940.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 25 -- Evidence of the success of Princeton University's three-point program for the physical well-being of its students is contained in the annual report of Dr. Wilbur H. York, chairman of the Department of Health and Physical Education, made public today.

QUOTING your Mr. Atkinson's words: "It would take a pretty churlish theatre-goer not to like the merriment and enthusiasm of these young people from Hollywood," the extraordinary correspondent who attacked "Meet the People" in your columns adds: "Well, I'd rather be a plain churl than a Communist or one who gives aid and comfort to the sly agents of Stalin and their fellow-travelers."
The Forty Plus Club of New York has reached a "low water mark" in membership, with only seventy active members, as against the 200 it has had at some times since its founding two years ago.

Visitors at the New York and Brooklyn Botanical Gardens these days are finding plenty of interesting displays. At the former an entirely new arrangement has been set up in the main conservatories, featuring daffodils, primulas, nemesias and stocks. The first of the South African plants also are coming into bloom.

VICHY, France, Jan. 25 (UP) -- German occupation authorities in Paris have taken into custody Roger Langeron, chief administrative officer of the Vichy Government in the Paris region, it was learned tonight.

A few years ago Sir John Orr shocked the British by telling them that they were undernourished. Now our own Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation publishes a report which raises the question whether we have the right to talk of food surpluses and if we are not grossly undernourished.

Dr. Frank H. Sommer, dean of the New York University School of Law, will be honored on his twenty-fifth anniversary as dean at the annual dinner of the school's alumni association Thursday evening at the Hotel Biltmore. Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, will be the principal speaker.

EVER since the election there have been rumors that in Vice President Wallace the public would see the end of Alexander Throttlebottom. The Vice Presidency was to be lifted out of its political dead end and would no longer be an unpublicized fifth wheel of the government.

ATHENS, Jan. 25 -- Germany's position in Southeastern Europe has not changed fundamentally since last June when expansionist Russia grabbed Bessarabia and Adolf Hitler, looking down the Danube Valley which he, like all German imperialists, considered Germany's backyard, found Joseph Stalin's hot breath uncomfortably on his neck.

TOWN HALL, 123 West Forty-third Street, New York City, announces that the Winter term of the new Town Hall Short Course will be devoted to "Great Books of the Years" and will be conducted by William Lyon Phelps, Edward Howard Griggs and Lewis Browne.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 25 -- The Montclair Athletic Club's two teams held half of the top four places in the Class C circuit of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's Jersey division at the close of play today.

A long-honored classical tradition went by the board yesterday afternoon. Albert Spalding, the distinguished American violinist, deserted the hallowed precincts of Carnegie Hall and brought his musical talents to Times Square for the benefit of the current infantile paralysis drive.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Bermuda's fleet of nine international one-design yachts has begun its annual elimination series of weekly races to select a four-boat team to compete against the Long Island Sound team during Yachting Week in the Spring.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- The keel of the 45,000-ton battleship Wisconsin was laid this afternoon at the Philadelphia Navy Yard with a challenge to workers by Rear Admiral A.E. Watson, the commandant, to keep at their tasks with as much enthusiasm as if the country were at war.

WHEN Martha Graham presented "Letter to the World" last Summer at the Bennington Festival she was counseled in these columns to leave it behind her in the hills of Vermont as an ambitious but thankless experiment. It is a pleasure this morning to eat those words.

On the basis of present budgetary requirements, a Federal debt limit of $65,000,000,000 or thereabout is envisioned by Congressional leaders. This is an increase of about $16,000,000,000 from the present debt limit of $49,000,000,000, which comprises the $45,000,000,000 present statutory limit and the $4,000,000,000 authorized by the Defense Tax Act.

Cotton prices eased moderately in relatively dull trading on the New York Cotton Exchange in the short session yesterday. After opening 1 to 2 points off, quotations continued to sag, and final levels were at net losses of 3 to 6 points.

WITH railroad models from all sections of the country on view, the thirteenth annual exhibition of the New York Society of Model Engineers will open on Feb. 7 at 152 West Forty-second Street and continue through Feb. 22.

THE headings of the three subdivisions of this autobiography make plain the span of its author's experience, and even for those who do not know that Dr. Caleb Frank Gates was for thirty years president of Robert College at Istanbul they suggest the spirited substance of his memoirs.

A drive for funds to purchase vitamins to send to the undernourished children of France has been opened by Les Amities Feminines de la France, with headquarters at 284 West Forty-fourth Street. After the recent exemption of these vitamins from seizure by British blockade authorities, the American Red Cross is said to have agreed to handle the distribution in France of all shipments by this war-relief agency.

Plant lovers who at this season are making their plans for the coming year frequently overlook until too late the opportunity of growing their own foliage plants from seed. A surprisingly large number of species can be grown with no more expert care than is required to raise the more common garden flowers, and the expense involved is but a fraction of what it would cost to purchase full-grown plants.

The nation's most talented ice skaters will participate in the 1941 national figure skating championship which will be held in Boston on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. Stars from more than twenty cities are listed in the title competitions.
I AM pained frequently when your drama critic gets out the axe and applies it to a play which should have a few appreciative words said for it.

THE public has responded well to the Metropolitan's plan of giving two Mozart operas with its annual Wagnerian "Ring" cycle, according to Earle R. Lewis, assistant general manager. Some subscribers have been so enthusiastic that they have sent letters of commendation along with their checks.

A CURIOUS feature of this story is that there is no mystery about the identity of the murderer or about his motive. All that is revealed in the very beginning. The only questions that remain to be answered are whether the man will succeed in accomplishing what he has set out to do and whether he will be brought to book for his crimes.

Not many months ago Mrs. F. Hugh Treherne-Thomas was distributing, from centers in South Wales, supplies for civilians and men in the service sent from the United States by the British War Relief Society. Today she is back in America, where she was born, one of the most ardent workers for the society here.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- One of the nation-wide series of dinners sponsored by the Beefeaters of America -- the first of them to be held in Florida -- will be an event of tomorrow night at the Hotel Royal Worth in West Palm Beach, for which the management has donated full cooperation.

The American people need to be informed frankly concerning the progress or lack of progress of the defense program. They need this information for the sake of the program itself. Only through knowledge of where the gaps and bottlenecks and snags exist can their full efforts and cooperation be enlisted to end them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Several hundred spectators, jammed into every available space in the airy hearing room, broke into applause when Joseph P. Kennedy, retiring American Ambassador to Great Britain, completed his testimony on the Lease-Lend Bill one day this week before the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Liberal buying of canned goods and a variety of other food products marked the closing days of the annual food conventions here this week. Wholesalers who were fearful of placing advance commitments for canned fruits and vegetables in the early part of the week lost their timidity as the market held firm and rumors of impending price advances became general.

NOT since W.A. Croffut wrote "The Vanderbilts" in 1886, a year after William Henry Vanderbilt dropped dead in the Grecian library of his garish home at 640 Fifth Avenue, has there been an adequate study of that old corsair, Cornelius Vaderbilt, and his descendants.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Jay Bozeman, talented Vallejo, Calif., entrant, advanced today into a first-place tie with Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia and Allen Hall of Chicago in the world championship three-cushion billiard meet.

THOUGH observing quietly from the sidelines for the most part at the moment, there are indications which point to possible involvement of the nation's 17,000-odd motion picture theatres in the battle of royalties now being waged between the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and Broadcast Music, Inc., the rival agency established by the radio networks.

THE late Oliver Bailey, who managed the Republic Theatre throughout the phenomenal run of "Abie's Irish Rose," once said: "The trouble with New York is it's full of liars." Now I won't go as far as to say that, but I will admit that the average New Yorker, particularly those in the theatrical profession, does change his mind as often as a rain barrel wiggle with the seven-year itch.

Alfred Wallenstein made his fourth and final appearance of the season as guest conductor of the NBC Symphony Orchestra at its concert last night in Radio City, and again was demonstratively welcomed by a large audience. Next Saturday, Arturo Toscanini, the orchestra's regular conductor, will return to the podium after a month's absence.

The trend against classical and philosophical subjects in the American educational system so that education may "pay" practical dividends was denounced yesterday afternoon by speakers at the "Education for Citizenship" program held by the Woman's Press Club in the Hotel Pennsylvania as one of the reasons education did not prevent the present conflict.

Between the Virginia capes, a course followed by famous ships ever since the capes were named in 1607 by the first settlers at Jamestown, sailed last Friday the 35,000-ton British battleship King George V. A warship so new Americans had not known she was in commission, she had aboard Lord Halifax, come to the United States to represent in Washington His Majesty King George VI.

DISTRIBUTION of a pedestrian safety card, designed to encourage safer walking practices on the part of pedestrians and emphasizing the need for drivers and pedestrians to share the responsibility for avoiding accidents, is being tried in Oregon.

Two new lecture courses, one a series of refresher lectures on recent advances in pharmacology and the other on the practice and theory of first aid, have been created for the next semester by the School of Pharmacology and Physiology of Fordham University.

MRS. WILDER'S six books provide an authentic and fascinating picture of American pioneer life during the second half of the nineteenth century. Ever since "The Little House in the Big Woods" appeared in 1932, children have followed with enthusiasm the fortunes of the Ingalls family.

Aid to air raid victim in England is the philanthropic and humanitarian motive of the rectial to be given by Marjorie Lawrence, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, on the night of Feb. 21 at Carnegie Hall. The event is under the patronage of many men and women of prominence, and its net proceeds will be sent to Queen Elizabeth for disbursement among war sufferers through the Air Raid Fund of the Lord Mayor of London.

Officials of the American Export Line, the only American company remaining in the passenger business between New York and European ports, said last week that passengers returning from Lisbon under emergency conditions had no conception of the difficulties under which vessels are operated today.

Staff officers of the New York Guard, the new State militia organized to replace the National Guard while it is Federalized, announcing yesterday that 95 per cent of members of the State's entire twenty regiments would be mustered in by the end of this week, also said the State had obtained 11,522 Lee-Enfield rifles.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 25 -- Three fewer players qualified for invitations to compete in the 1941 Masters golf tournament than last year, but in the field of eighty-six there will be thirteen newcomers, it was announced today by Clifford Roberts, chairman of the tournament committee.

Scotland Yard is naturally interested when a corpse is found in an otherwise vacant apartment, and Inspector Arnold is sent to look into the matter. By a curious coincidence, Arnold's friend Desmond Merrion arrives in London just about this time, and Arnold, who .knows that Merrion likes nothing better than a mysterious murder, invites him to observe the course of the investigation.

Three engineering training courses to prepare men for work on defense contracts in aircraft plants will be given at City College starting on Feb. 4, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Albert Newman, dean of the School of Technology. A maximum of 206 men will be accepted for the courses which have been approved by the United States Office of Education.
RANCHO SANTA FE, Calif., Jan. 25 -- Ed (Porky) Oliver, 1940 winner of the competition, borrowed a set of clubs today and shot the finest round of golf ever seen in Bing Crosby's annual tournament.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 25 -- Sweepida kept his record intact as the leading California-bred racing horse in competition this season when he finished a length and a half in front in the $15,000 added Santa Catalina Handicap today. A crowd of 35,000 fans watched the H.C. Hill gelding come home in front at Santa Anita.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 25 -- Local skippers, with just a hint of sadness in their voices, admitted several days ago that the big run of sailfish had "moved south." But tonight you could go to every dock from the famous Kenny Lighthouse to the bar at the St. Lucie Inlet and find sailfish pennants flying from outriggers.

THE years 1939 and 1940 were crowded with so many momentous events pregnant with incalculable consequences for the future of mankind that they may properly be considered as deserving the immediate attention of the historian.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- The University of Buffalo School of Medicine, which for nearly ninety-five years has been training men and women as physicians, this month began a new service -- education of the public in the latest advances of medical science and various phases of preventive medicine.

Those who are busy now planning color effects for the borders may well keep in mind that tall anchusas play an important part in the early Summer garden picture. First of the bushy background types to bloom, these five-foot giants of the forget-me-not family also lead the Summer procession of dominating blue garden flowers.

EDITOR IN DIPLOMACY: Book reviewers were tackling last week an autobiographical volume entitled "Editor in Politics." It had been written by Josephus Daniels, for nearly eight years an editor in diplomacy, resident of the Renaissance American Embassy in Mexico City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- France and Great Britain went to war with Germany in full knowledge that the United States would not enter the conflict, according to testimony given today before the House Foreign Affairs Committee by William C. Bullitt, former American Ambassador to France.
ROME, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique today said:

Paul Waner, veteran outfielder who was finally cast adrift by the Pirates at the close of the 1940 campaign, is not ready to end his career in the major leagues. In fact, there were indications yesterday that baseball's famous "Big Poison" was almost certain to continue in the National League and that his new uniform would be that of the Dodgers.

LO, the poor Indian got off, I am afraid, to a rather dubious start, so far as cultural appreciation is concerned, in the pages of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow and J. Fenimore Cooper. At least (to introduce a note of personal reminiscence) those writers, however earnestly well-intentioned, nipped in the bud my own childhood potentiality in the way of sympathetic response.
MAURICE HINDUS'S previous novel, "Sons and Fathers," in spite of undoubted merits, scarcely prepared this reviewer for the truly magnificent offering he makes in "To Sing With the Angels."

An emergency tax measure, like the excess profits tax, is not to be expected to operate with the same smoothness of administration as the income tax. Productiveness of revenue is the primary objective of such a tax and its success is mainly measured by that quality.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- To relieve the pressure on clipper accommodation from Lisbon, the Civil Aeronautics Board has authorized Pan American Airways to route westbound flights until May 1 from Europe to the United States via Bolama, Portuguese Guinea; Port of Spain, Trinidad, and San Juan, Puerto Rico.

WAVES of what were described as "oversized scorpions" recently invaded Saude Hill, a suburb of Rio de Janeiro, and stung two children to death before health authorities, armed with insecticide guns, cleaned them out. In ancient times it was held that the sting of the scorpion was more dangerous than that of snakes, since the scorpion will strike repeatedly.
THE Postoffice Department announced last week that a Highway Postoffice Service would be started on Feb. 10, with the first route between Washington, D.C., and Harrisonburg, Va.

The National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin, was heard in the third concert of its current Gabrilowitsch Memorial Series yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. A program, consisting of the Third symphony by Brahms and that composer's piano concerto in B flat major, with Aleksandr Helmann as soloist, was presented.

TEACHERS of the Culbertson system, meeting today in the final session of a three-day convention at the Lombardy Hotel here, are learning that for the first time in six years the Culbertson system of bidding is undergoing basic revision. The teachers receive advance news of the changes, and advance copies of books by Ely Culbertson which are to be published Feb. 15 and March 1.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:
Among the many entertainments arranged this season under the patronage of persons prominent in society there are several fetes with a patriotic motif planned for the near future.

BOSTON, Jan. 25 -- In a drama-laden race that reached its peak of excitement in a furious finish, Walter Mehl beat John Munski by the picayune margin of six inches tonight to win the Knights of Columbus Mile that featured the Prout Memorial Games before 11,500 wildly excited fans in the snow-bound Boston Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The development of dwelling houses of a high type and of stock design was recommended as a basic requirement in filling the needs of the country in the face of rising building costs, in a report published today by the National Resources Planning Board.

IF all the February prospects materialize, a dozen shows can be counted on being submitted for Broadway inspection, a gain of five over the same month last year. While it is not an unprecedented increase, it nevertheless conveys an encouraging sign to the workers in the vineyard and to those who go down the aisles to their seats.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- Army sports teams, competing in indoor areas on the snow-capped plains of West Point, gave commendable accounts of themselves today in a majority of the varsity contests.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 25 -- The depressed tone continued today on the Bourse, with Dutch issues mostly closing at the day's lowest levels, as much as 5 points lower.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- For the first time in three years Pennsylvania defeated the Army in basketball at the Palestra tonight, 28 -- 21, in a rough contest before a slim crowd of 2,500. It was the cadets' fifth setback in six starts this season.

SALEM, Ore., Jan. 25 -- With nearly the width of the American continent separating the swift reaches of the Columbia River from the marble buildings of government bureaus at Washington, Republicans and Democrats in the Pacific Northwest have united in calling for decentralization of Federal authority.

Edward Oppenheimer of the Squash Club, third favored player, advanced a round ahead of the rest of the field as play in the seventh annual Long Island squash racquets championship tournament began yesterday at the Jackson Heights Squash Club.

It is evident from the beginning of this story that Marina Grazie is going to be murdered and that not many will mourn her passing. Marina is a coloratura soprano, once a star at the Metropolitan, but now reduced to accepting, on the strength of her past reputation, an engagement as guest artist with a second or third class opera company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Development of the Jewish National Home in Palestine not only as a refuge for the persecuted and homeless but also as a present bastion of British defense in the Near East and an ultimate Jewish Commonwealth within the British Empire announced as the multiple objective of the $12,000,000 war emergency campaign opened here tonight by the United Palestine Appeal for 1941.

With a casualness and concord that furnished little indication of the far-reaching implications of the matter, the delegates to the annual meeting of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association at the Hotel Vanderbilt yesterday went on record as favoring the proposed stringent amendments to the amateur regulations.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Seashore visitors and residents will combine to observe President Roosevelt's birthday at a ball at the Hotel Chelsea next Thursday, the proceeds of which will go toward the fight against infantile paralysis.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Jan. 25 -- Often-repeated accusations that the private preparatory schools are behind the times in their training of boys for the practical problems of life in a democracy arc challenged at the Lawrenceville School these days by actions and not by mere denials.

President Roosevelt's inaugural address was praised as a spiritual affirmation of democracy by rabbis in sermons here yesterday. Other rabbis emphasized that there can be no appeasement of dictatorship, that the future world must be either slave or free.

THE war has moved into many strange places in the world, but few so wild and colorful as Indo-China and Thailand (Siam). As the European war has brought Singapore and the Netherlands Indies into the picture as possible Japanese objectives, the strategic importance of Siam, now called Thailand, and of French Indo-China has grown. They are now counted among the main danger spots of the Orient.

TORONTO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Canadiens gained their first point of the season at the expense of the Maple Leafs tonight when they held the National Hockey League leaders to a 2-2 tie. In five previous starts the Leafs were victorious each time.

THE English anthem, "God Save the King," was written by an Englishman, Henry Carey, about 1743 and not by Jean Baptiste Lully, as is claimed by the French Government, according to a dispatch of Lansing Warren in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 16.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- Cornell defeated Yale, 45 -- 27, for the second time this season in their Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight. It was the Big Red's fourth victory in five league starts and tightened its lead on second place, behind undefeated Dartmouth.

Crown Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway returned to this city yesterday for a brief visit from Bethesda, Md., where they have lived since the arrival of the Crown Prince from Europe a month ago.

JAMES HILTON has an enormous preoccupation with the past and the hidden, both in terms of civilization and of human beings. Wedded to that preoccupation is a masterly ability to create a mood in his writing which carries the reader along with him.

Otto Klemperer, German conductor, and the New York City WPA Music Project, came to a parting of the ways yesterday afternoon after a stormy session at a rehearsal of the New York City Symphony Orchestra in preparation for tonight's concert at Carnegie Hall.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 26 (UP) -- A single German raider gave a coastal town in West England its first air alarm of the war last night, dropping two high-exposive bombs that demolished a house and two bungalows.

WHO was William Eaton Chandler, now twenty-three years dead? Almost forgotten by his fellow-countrymen, he lies in a New Hampshire cemetery that looks across the valley of the Merrimack where he began the political career in which for sixty years were recorded the currents running through American politics.

BRAZIL has inaugurated its 1941 stamp-issuing program with four commemoratives in honor of the Centenarios de Portugal (Centenaries of Portugal) and two directing the people's attention to the fifth general census begun last September.

ONE-MAN shows of the week presented the usual diversity in subject matter and approach. A first show of paintings by Leontine Camprubi reveals her as a young artist with an individual vision, already working out an individual style, and with an endearing quality of fantasy.

The possibility of shortages rather than fear of price advances necessitates advance buying of important, materials for three to six months in advance, according to the monthly report yesterday of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 25 -- Yale today defeated the strong Rider College swimming team, 51 -- 24, taking five first places to three.

WILLIAM BYRD, the first gentleman of Virginia, was born in 1674 of a young goldsmith's apprentice and his wife, Mary Horsmanden, whose ancestry went back to the Holy Roman Emperor, Charlemagne, "so legend reads."

Mosaics, whether used for important expanses such as walls and floors or the smaller areas of table tops and decorative tiles, are being given new life by modern craftsmen. In this age-old process of making patterns by inlaying tiny bits of colored glass or stone, time-hallowed precedent can be sedately followed or an ultra-modern spirit can prevail.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- The 136th annual exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts opened here this evening with a preview and reception. It opens to the public tomorrow afteroon and will remain current through March 2.

More than 500 business executives have accepted invitations to a dinner to be held under the auspices of the Members' Council of the Merchants Association in the Hotel Astor on Tuesday. Thomas W. Lamont, vice chairman of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., will speak on "The Defense of the Republic."

From the owner of a National Football League team to the slugging outfielder of a champion softball club, from the former bow man on a Pennsylvania varsity crew to a title-winning discus thrower, the sports world already is feeling the effects of the Selective Service Act.

THE Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts opened with a preview in its Philadelphia galleries last evening the 136th annual exhibition of painting and sculpture. This is to remain current there until March 2. A review of the exhibition will be found in the news columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES today.

"DEBUSSY'S "Pelleas et Melisande" will be presented by the Philadelphia Opera Company in an English translation by Henry Grafton Chapman, Tuesday night, at the Academy of Music, Philadelphia. Maurice Maeterlinck will attend, and will hear the musical setting of his drama in its entirety for the first time after having boycotted the operatic form of the work for thirty-nine years.

Along with other members of ASCAP, have hesitated to express publicly any opinion on the fight now being waged between our organization and the radio networks, feeling that such an opinion would naturally be classed as biased.

One little girl sat around sucking her first month in nursery school; then some one thought of letting her play with a white rat and a rabbit, and she changed from a shy, unresponsive and seemingly dull child to one who was gay, delighted and interested.

HAMBURG, Germany, Jan. 25 -- Shipping circles in this capital of the Reich's merchant marine have been sizing up the United States' program of expansion of merchant shipping with an eye to the future, when ships under the United States and German flags will once again compete for trade on the high seas.

The King George V, latest and probably most powerful of British battleships, which arrived in the Chesapeake Friday, is one of nine new British battleships, the first of them just commencing to join the fleet.

RADIO is being rallied to the cause of the classics in England where grave concern is expressed for the future welfare of good music, now seriously retarded in its normal development economically and artistically by the conflict with the Axis Powers.

DETROIT -- Cancellation of the New York National Automobile Show next October was discussed at the annual meeting of the National Automobile Dealers Association held in Pittsburgh last Tuesday and Wednesday.

A COLLECTION of the work of William H. Jackson, one of America's pioneer photographers, is now on exhibition at the Camera Club, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street. The display includes 100 prints of historical interest in photography.

The Art of Practical Thinking: By Richard Weil, Jr. An analysis of the principles governing thought with special emphasis on its application to practical problems arising in the business world. The author is president of L. Bamberger Co., Newark, N.J., and one of the country's youngest business leaders.

TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 26 -- The doctrine that Japan cannot allow any other country to mediate or intervene in disputes between Asiatic nations was reaffirmed in the House of Representatives last night by Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka. A similar claim was promulgated by the Foreign Office spokesman, then Eiji Amau, a few years ago.

With the secondary aluminum, zinc and copper markets thrown into utter demoralization last week by an unprecedented demand and fantastic prices, a committee of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers will meet on Tuesday to canvass the situation, it was learned here yesterday.

HATS are prettier than ever. There's no need of buying one that is not flattering at every point. First of all, the hair must be considered. It must be becomingly coiffured. Have you yearned for a bang, lo these many years, without venturing to wear one? Now's your chance. You can do it without looking too

Greenie, the Persian leaf bird nicknamed a bulbul, had two voice tests yesterday and flunked both. Temperament, not lack of talent, was the explanation by Fairfield Osborn, president of the New York Zoological Society and Greenie's owner.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, guarded by police, made an unexpected appearance tonight at commencement exercises of the South Philadelphia High School for girls.

With their own Spring plantings some months away, farm women and garden club members are joining in a project to send vegetable seeds to Great Britain as a mid-winter activity. The first shipment of approximately two tons will be sent out next week by a committee called American Seeds for British Soil.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Naval Academy played host to some officers, midshipmen and enlisted men of the British battleship King George V before it sailed today, ending a twenty-one-hour visit to Annapolis.

The Manhattan Indoor Polo League championship tourney got under way with a double-header at the Aylward Academy last night. The Red Bank P.C. beat the Hempstead trio, 13 to 11, and the Midtown P.C. triumphed over the Ramapo Valley combination, 17 to 14.

IT was Walt Whitman who thought he "could turn and live with animals, they are so placid and self-contained. . . . Not one is dissatisfied. . . . Not one kneels to another. . . . Not one is respectable or industrious over the whole earth."
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 -- Two tugboats today continued their efforts to free the $10,000,000 liner Manhattan from a shoal on which it ran a few hundred yards offshore here Jan. 12.

IT was a strange genius that died with James Joyce -- one of the strangest in the history of literature. Whatever his ultimate position in that history may be, whatever value future generations may put upon his work, he is certain to be remembered as the author of two of the most singular books ever written.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Losing no time in beginning his new duties as British Ambassador, Viscount Halifax called on Secretary Hull at the State Department at 11 o'clock this morning and, after a talk with Mr. Hull on the international situation lasting more than an hour, he remarked:
NO more significant title could come from the presses in these days when sea power and air power are struggling for dominion of the world than this new book of Harold and Margaret Sprout's.

When Rex Stout brought out his first Tecumseh Fox mystery it was inevitably compared with the Nero Wolfe stories, and it suffered a little by comparison. This new one will easily stand comparison with anything that Mr. Stout has previously written, and that means that it is a top-flight detective story.

One of the most astonishing things about going to Fort Dix on a day when there are lots of visitors is to find this cardinal factor in national defense resembling Parents' Day in a large boarding school for boys. The boys, walking with their families along the sidewalks, have the same proud and sheepish expressions, though in the presence of their girls they tend to swagger a little.

The Winter circuit for women golfers opened at Punta Gorda on Jan. 17 with all the favorites bowing before the onslaught of a new young champion, Miss Louise Sugg, 17, of Lithia Springs, Georgia State champion, who won by 3 and 2 from Miss Elizabeth Hicks of Santa Barbara, 20-year-old Southern champion, in the 18-hole final.

To coordinate and expand the work offered on the adult level, the New York City School system is planning to form an adult education department. The Board of Superintendents is seeking a director to head the new division.

A plea that the budget director and Mayor La Guardia retain the $32,200 item for adult day classes in English and citizenship, recommended by the Board of Education in its 1941-42 budget, was made yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Whalen, chairman of the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations.

DRESDEN, Germany, Jan. 25 -- Bootlegging has been revived in the German farm belt. While Berlin and other cities strain under rigid rationing, the rural areas apparently are living off the fat of the land. Residents of farm hamlets feel sorry for city dwellers who stand in food lines by day and run to air-raid shelters by night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The election mandate of the American people for all aid to Great Britain "short of war," and the steps now being taken by their government to effectuate the mandate, made it inevitable that very soon there would arise the important issue of public information. That first took form this week in the partisan dispute in the House Committee on Foreign Affairs concerning the forthcoming testimony of high Army and Navy officers.

URBANA, Ill., Jan. 25 -- Because of pioneering research started nearly twenty-five years ago at the University of Illinois, thousands of American homes are heated more efficiently and economically today. The research is being increased to cover year-round home air-conditioning.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 25 (AP) -- General Ion Antonescue, Rumania's victorious dictator, offered the leaders of the Iron Guard rebellion today the bleak alternative of suicide or "mass punishment" at the hands of the State.

RUMANIA, after politically affiliating itself with the Axis powers late in 1940, issued twelve commemorative stamps and these arrived in New York last week. A 20-lei plus 5L blue-green semi-postal for air-mail use bears a portrait of Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, the Iron Guard leader who was slain several years ago, and surrounding it is an inscription reading "In 48 de ore dupa biruintavom fialaturi de Axa" and "Roma-Berlin."

When Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, gives his benefit recital tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall, the occasion will serve to launch a Fifteenth Anniversary Fund drive for the East Side House settlement at 540 East Seventy-sixth Street. The campaign for funds has been devised so that the beneficiary may continue its welfare, educational and recreational program for hundreds of underprivileged young people of the district.

Any little trick whereby a girl can impart a fresh appearance to the clothes she bought early this season is all to the good right now. Most girls go through a period of budget deflation after the holidays, when they are saving up for their Spring wardrobes.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 25 -- That the ability to think and act democratically does not develop automatically like the sixth year molar or consciousness of the other say, but must be taught through a living situation, is the belief of the teachers of this city.

Charles J. Hendley, president of the Teachers Union, faced dismissal from his $4,500-a-year job as a high school teacher last night as a result of his disappearance from the city after an order for his arrest had been signed by Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew.

BERLIN, Jan. 25 -- The German warplanes that have gone to the aid of Italy in the Mediterranean were credited by informed German sources today with damage to two British battleships and a cruiser in a "successful attack" on a convoy west of Crete.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A new derivative of sulfanilamide which is said to be less toxic than sulfanilamide itself, yet yields more concentrated solutions suitable for administration orally or by injection, has been synthesized. This is revealed in a patent (No. 2,229,127) issued here to a research team composed of George W. Raiziss, Le Roy W. Clemence and Abraham I. Kremens, all of Philadelphia.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 25 -- "The main Japanese interest at present is the rich Bolivian ores," Ryoichi Mizutani, head of the Japanese commercial mission visiting Bolivia, declared in the press oday. Mr. Mizutani is secretary of the foreign commerce division of the Japanese Commerce Department.

To her excellent biographies of Oliver Wendell Holmes ("The Happy Autocrat"), Ralph Waldo Emerson ("Youth's Captain"), published by Longmans, and Henry Wadsworth Longfellow ("The Poet of Craigie House"), published by Appleton-Century.

A BIG arena, circled by thousands of spectators: colored lights twinkling over the patterned glossy surface of the ice; the whir of flashing, keen-edged skates kicking up a shower of ice chips; skaters, gliding effortlessly, evenly, to the waltz, strains of the band, or leaping and twirling in ice-splintering convolutions.

NORTH AFRICAN short-wave stations have formed a Vichy broadcasting network. For some time "Radio Alger has been tuning up its two transmitters for broadcasting, and occasional bursts from Morocco have been heard.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 25 -- Fast British tanks and armored cars have moved westward into the vicinity of Derna, Libya, with the Bomba seaplane base and the Libyan desert left forty-five miles behind. Among the green hills and valleys where once lived Premier Mussolini's subsidized colonists, British patrols pursued and harassed Italian units that apparently were withdrawing from the region yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Clarence D. Howe, American-born Canadian Minister of Munitions, returned to this continent with Lord Halifax on H.M.S. King George V and brought word with him that this would be a long war, that it had so far inflicted surprisingly little damage on English munitions production, but that a start had been made on the transfer of British industries to Canada.

The appointment of Dr. Conrad M. Arensberg, a member of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology faculty, as chairman of the new Department of Anthropology and Sociology at Brooklyn College was announced yesterday by Harry D. Gideonse, president of the college. Dr. Arensberg's appointment will become effective Feb. 1.

New York dug itself out from under two inches of hazardous ice and snow yesterday while the storm continued northeastward, blanketing the upper reaches of the State and giving most of New England its worst snowfall of the season. While Department of Sanitation officials were predicting clear streets by tonight, Weather Bureau officials came through with an ominous report of more rain or snow for the same period, or for tomorrow morning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission heard fresh evidence today of the opposition of small security exchanges to the New York Stock Exchange's ban on multiple trading.

THE little one-street town of Kanab (pop. 1,700), rimmed in by the multicolored sandstone of Southern Utah, is booming again. It doesn't make much money from its other trades, but it does provide scenery, a commodity for which Hollywood often pays handsomely and even, as in the case of "Western Union," will travel a thousand miles to film -- a sort of cash-and-carry proposition, as it were.

Warren A. Stephens, a tall, rangy 19-year-old youth from the Old Sixty-ninth Badminton Club, was the dominant personality in three of the five final matches of the Class B metropolitan badminton championships at the Fifth Avenue Country Club yesterday.

JOHN STEINBECK'S independent picture, "The Forgotten Village," which was filmed with a nonprofessional cast in the interior of Mexico, is being edited and Spencer Tracy has been loaned by Metro to do the narration for the sound track.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The latest British evacuation scheme under which women and especially children have been moved from London and other big centers to safer places in the country, has succeeded beyond expectation, an investigating committee has reported to Health Minister Malcolm MacDonald.

Plans to interest Westchester clubwomen in vocational education offered in the public schools are being developed as part of the program for citizenship of the education department of the Westchester Federation of Women. New emphasis on this phase of education was reported by Mrs. Mona Mac-Roberts of Larchmont, chairman of the department, at the mid-Winter conference held on Friday at the Contemporary Club in White Plains.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Van A. Bittner, head of the drive of the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee to unionize Bethlehem Steel Company workers, announced today that men who quit work in what he termed a "protest demonstration" would return to their jobs tomorrow.

MR. SASS has unearthed a most dramatic incident from the early history of this country, not even mentioned in the textbooks, and has woven about it a historical romance which has considerable charm, but which lacks the heft that the significance of the episode seems to warrant.

THE most important diplomatic post in Washington, that of British Ambassador, has fallen to an uncommonly tall, lean, gaunt-looking Yorkshireman with a soft voice and a shy manner who probably will find that the translation from the Foreign Secretary's office in London to the embassy here is one from comparative privacy to unaccustomed conspicuousness.

British capture of Tobruk and invasion of Eritrea and reciprocal bombing raids on Malta and Sicily brought the war in the Mediterranean theatre last week to a new peak. The Italian African empire was beset on all sides as the British victories netted more thousands of prisoners, but in the Central Mediterranean German bombers were contesting Britain's control of the inland sea.

In his annual report to the Board of Overseers last week President Conant of Harvard, mentioned one of the mistakes of public opinion. He was emphasizing the guardianship of eternal values as first on the list of the important tasks of a university and he said:

This week has not a great deal to offer in the way of college basketball. But there are a few topflight attractions in the East, perhaps the most notable of which will see Rhode Island State's high-scoring machine desert New England for major circuit double-header tests in New York and Philadelphia.

THE art of etching as Rembrandt handled it is illustrated superbly by these two prints from the collection of the late Felix M. Warburg, recently given to the Metropolitan Museum. Rembrandt, more famous with the larger public as a master of painting, but no less a master of etching, was a pioneer in treating great subjects in this medium.

While weather again hampered retail trade here last week, the increase in sales over a year ago was probably larger than in the preceding week. The department store showing continued somewhat spotty, but estimates indicated an average gain of close to 7 per cent.

WITH the bruising Bruins about to pounce on the cellar-dwellers of the hockey circuit, the star-spangled Americans, it seems that some charitable committee should look into the plight of Red Dutton's hapless hirelings on skates. The poor fellows haven't won a game this year. Their record is five defeats and two ties since 1941 was ushered in with a fanfare of trumpets.
The state of American public opinion as crystallized by the President's recent speeches represents an acceptance of certain important points.

Modern costumes incorporating American Indian designs were among the colorful features of the exhibit of Indian Art in the United States being shown in the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, which drew the special attention of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 -- Much interest is being shown in the Britannia Ball, which will be held at the Surf Club next Saturday night to aid the work of the British War Relief Society, of which Alfred I. Barton, vice president of the club, is chairman of the South Florida regional committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Gearing the defense program to production for total defense demands far more than the procurement of men and guns. Modern war is to a large extent an industrial effort, and as new industries spring into being many thousands of workers must be gathered to man the factories.

THE author of this personal memoir is a Vermont boy who has not yet been up the Statue of Liberty but who as a newspaper reporter learned enough about New York City and some of its wicked ways to win him a Pulitzer prize.

GEORGE SESSIONS PERRY'S new book deserves an all-out recommendation as a warm, rich, absorbing story. No mean achievement in these days, it deals realistically with a year in the life of a desperately poor farmer and is anything but depressing.

HAVANA, Cuba -- When Pedro Arango Navarra first visited the isle of Cuba in 1870, he wrote of future fortunes to be ground from vast fields of sugar cane. Through the years that sea and fortune have fondled and bruised that troubled land, his descendants have worked in proof of his prophecy.

By far the majority of inquiries for industrial properties resulting from the defense program have been for existing plants rather than industrial sites, but, despite the most active trading in factories in nearly ten years, the available supply of unused plant facilities in the East is more than adequate to meet all but specialized needs of the defense program as now planned.

LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Shipping Minister R.H. Cross, in a transatlantic broadcast to the United States, declared tonight that Britain can beat "the U-boat threat," but "we must have your industrial support."

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 24 (AP) -- A 26-year-old German pursuit pilot predicted here today a "knockout blow" against England in March and British capitulation by September. He then left for New York City after having escaped two days ago from a Canadian prison train.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 25 -- Back in December, 1911, Italy, with a view of "putting an end to the intolerable state of disorder and neglect" prevailing in what is now known as Libya, presented an ultimatum to Turkey, requiring her consent to Italian occupation of the territories then known as Cyrenaica and Tripoli.

Last Tuesday afternoon warm sunlight flooded the oval office in the west wing of the White House. President Roosevelt, finishing a cigarette in the familiar holder, was seated behind the cluttered desk. He looked robust and ruddy.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 25 -- The Navy basketball team snapped its losing streak today, scoring an upset at the expense of the crack University of North Carolina quintet, 42 to 34.

THIS is a book about the Burma Road. The Burma Road is its scene, its subject, its reason for being. It would no doubt be its title also if that name had not been quite unjustifiably pre-empted, when the highway first became famous, by an entertaining but commonplace volume of scattered anecdotes in which the Burma Road's appearance was only minimal.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- According to the Maritime Commission, the nation's shipping has prospered during the European war, despite the fact that a area normally accounting for 40 per cent of the foreign commerce of the United States has been closed.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Judge Frank J. Lausche offered a dissertation on "baseball and tomatoes" today in dismissing assault and battery charges against George (Birdie) Tebbetts, Detroit catcher who swung on a grandstand pitcher in a vegetable bombardment at a Cleveland-Detroit game here Sept. 27.

THE first picture is of yucca stalks, upstanding against great rounded boulders, somewhere in California's desert country. And when Mr. and Mrs. Weston set out on the long, rich task of Western photography that had been made possible by a Guggenheim Foundation grant, it was to the desert -- Death Valley, to be exact -- that they went first.

THERE is one point on which Adolf Hitler and his bitterest enemies seem to agree: Europe should be unified. It should not, in their belief, return to its pre-war status as a hodge-podge of nations each seeking its own way, frenziedly striving for self-sufficiency, suspicious of talk of cooperation.

THE path to appointment as Naval Reserve student aviators has been made considerably less arduous for young men between the ages of 20 and 26 as a result of the Navy Department's action in relaxing its requirements as to the amount of mathematics prospective candidates must have studied to qualify.

THE TIMES recent editorial "The National Unity" argues ample ground for compromise on the Administration's Lend-Lease Bill, and that the facts of our situation in no wise compel a choice between signing on the dotted line and failure of maximum aid to Britain.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- A festive air prevailed throughout the Catskills today as yesterday's heavy storm left in its wake snow ranging from nine to twelve inches and skiers started to descend upon the popular ski resorts that dot this region.

For the second year in succession Thomas Wolfe received posthumously the award for the best book of the year by a Southern author at the ninth annual Southern authors luncheon under the auspices of the Southern Women's National Democratic Organization in New York, Inc. yesterday at the Park Lane.

Featured by sharp gains in orders for major home wares in which increased consumer demand and the possibility of delayed deliveries played a part, the initial stages of Spring buying were completed by retailers last week. Increases in the apparel field were more limited, with the earl, call for accessories, however, pushing the gain for the latter types of goods to 10 per cent over last year.

The campaign of the C.I.O. to organize building service employes in opposition to the A.F. of L. suffered a setback yesterday when the State Labor Relations Board refused to set aside a contract between Local 32-E of the Building Service Employes International Union, A.F. of L., and the 1403-05 Rosedale Avenue Realty Corporation.

HERE is the second volume of memoirs of Josephus Daniels. The first came under the title of "Tar Heel Editor." The second volume is published as "Editor in Politics.'' And the second is off the same piece of goods -- plain homespun, all wool and a yard wide, dyed in butternut with the garment cut on the dining room table, hand-sewed and no shoddy.

BEFORE the Postoffice Department develops its early 1941 stamp-making program to the point where vignettes are selected and sent to President Roosevelt for his approval, the department will have the benefit of suggestions, in the form of finished sketches, from some of America's foremost illustrators long associated with the designing of books, bindings, magazines, type faces, posters and other material for publishers and industries.

"JOHN O'HARA," said a friend one day," * * * often looks befuddled -- but his brain never stops working." This estimate was rendered during the Philadelphia tryout of O'Hara's new musical comedy "Pal Joey," and such being the general state of affairs during a musical comedy tryout, any one -- especially the author -- might be justified in looking befuddled.

FOR THE COMING WEEK. Time to make indoor sowings for early vegetables is almost here; seeds, if not already on hand, must be ordered without delay -- tomatoes, cabbage, broccoli, lettuce, eggplants and peppers. Beets, too, transplant readily and make a fine extra early crop. . . Have tender bulbs in storage been examined recently? If not, looking them over now, and discarding any that show signs of decay, may save disappointment later.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Jan. 12 -- I want to tell about our blackout problems this week. Well, being within a ten-mile radius of the east coast (I am actually three miles as the crow flies from the river), my blackout had to be perfect in every detail.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill. -- This city was Abraham Lincoln's home during his period of flower, and the Lincoln birthday anniversary is observed here with especial feeling and reverence. The honors which Springfield will accord on Feb. 12 to the memory of her greatest citizen -- the citizen who in the Springfield estimation was the greatest of the United States -- have a deep cultural and historic meaning for the country.

THAT vocal phenomenon called coloratura, the delight of both operatic and concert audiences for the last 200 years, has revealed its unfailing hold on radio audiences too. However, the next broadcast of Lily Pons, America's favorite coloratura soprano, is not going to show off her singing agility.

The annual list compiled by Miss Mabel Williams, superintendent of school work for the New York Public Library, and her committee of librarians is just off the press. This list is reprinted every year; not only are new books added but changes are made in accordance with careful observation of what the young people who use the public library branches really do enjoy.

An evening of waltzing is in prospect for subscribers to an entertainment entitled "Tribute to Britain," a waltz supper party to be given Wednesday in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center under the auspices of La Victoire Committee.

The Board of Superintendents of the city's school system will issue a call soon for candidates to fill thirteen supervisory positions now open or to be vacated, it was learned yesterday. The board recently nominated seven high school principals who have been passed by the Board of Examiners.

As a German playwright who has had the opportunity of making himself acquainted with the American theatre of today, I have at first to confess that the general opinion in Germany about the American theatre is one of hypocrisy and ignorance. During the last decade there has been little opportunity to revise this opinion in Germany.

AS good a reason as any why democracy fell in Europe may be found in the number and variety of books brought out in the past six months explaining why democracy fell. The explanations are no more in agreement than were the sadly disunited elements which contributed to the fall of their once democratic countries.

Mayor La Guardia and other prominent men and women have sent letters to the American Bureau for Medical Aid to China endorsing the organization's drive for 200 trucks to be used on the Burma Road and later converted into ambulances, it was announced yesterday by Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr., national chairman of the bureau.

FOR years the American who wanted a little camera good enough to take pictures of the baby playing in the back yard or of friends out on a picnic has had quite a choice of inexpensive cameras made in the United States and sold practically everywhere, including the corner drug store.

With the specific view of making available its musical catalogue to the radio public, the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers launched last night a thirteen-week program over Station WMCA that included some of its top-ranking composers and outstanding song hits.

LAKE PLACID -- On the schedule from this week-end through Washington's Birthday are ski races, ski jumping and speed skating races, in addition to a program of bobsled races, all of which will come to a climax in the annual midwinter figure skating carnival over the Washington's Birthday week-end.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- The celebration of President Roosevelt's birthday here has been fixed for Friday night. Owing to the desire of the committee to have the Duke and Duchess of Windsor attend, there had been some uncertainty about the date of the celebration.

BERLIN, Jan. 25 -- A semi-official statement to the effect that German troops in Rumania remained "absolutely in reserve" during the Iron Guard revolt this week and had taken no part in helping General Ion Antonescu to regain control was issued tonight by the D.N.B. news agency.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Professional traders who bought July and September wheat yesterday, as the result of a forecast for a severe cold wave in the Winter wheat belt, started to go out of their lines in the latter part of today's session, due to the failure of the cold wave to materialize.

Year in and year out, the Millrose Games have been a sure-fire attraction, always a sell-out since the meet was moved to the new Madison Square Garden in 1926. Next Saturday will be no exception. A capacity gathering of 15,000 is expected to see the annual show that is the first of five major Garden meets.

Thanks to the banning of ASCAP, lovers of music are relieved, temporarily at least, of the noisy swing blasted out by dance orchestras, and are enjoying a revival of the tuneful, melodious airs that have remained popular because of merit and are not the fulfillment of a conga or rumba impulse of a jitterbug.

Declaring that, as always, the Republican organization of New York County would be on the side of good government at the coming city election, Thomas J. Curran, recently elected County Chairman, said yesterday that he regarded no man as "indispensable" as head of the ticket to prevent the return of a Tammany-controlled city administration such as existed before Mayor La Guardia took office on Jan. 1, 1934.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Governor Lehman urged tonight prompt passage of the lease-lend bill now before Congress and warned that if England was destroyed America could not hope for long to keep the war from her shores.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Thirty-two nurses were named today by the Red Cross to the first nursing unit it is sending overseas in this war.

Buyer arrivals were heavy last week and activity was at a high level in the New York market, it was reported yesterday in a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Advances of from 5 per cent to 20 per cent in retail business were reported in cities where defense spending has been heavy, while other cities fell behind slightly.

Defeated in the Appellate Division in its suit to block the American Federation of Musicians from asserting jurisdiction over Jascha Heifetz, Albert Spalding and other leading instrumental soloists, the executive committee of the American Guild of Musical Artists decided yesterday to take an immediate appeal to the Court of Appeals.

TRADE reports in the week became more irregular, although they continued to tell of substantial gains over last year. The spottiness could be attributed to weather conditions and to the spread of influenza. Home furnishings and appliance sales still feature retail activity, taking the play away from apparel lines.

The American College Publicity Association (Districts 2 and 3) conference closed yesterday at New York University's Faculty Club with a declaration by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase that universities must help define democracy, unencumbered "by a narrow nationalism," but in the realization that they have a duty to civilization, just as civilization has a duty to education.

Sailing has been taught in improvised schools connected with yacht clubs, but it remained for the Community Recreation Service of Boston to take a step much farther. The service has completed plans, it was announced yesterday, to teach the sport to underprivileged youngsters so they may vie with the more fortunate in handling a boat under canvas.

During this season of garden planning the ever popular sweet pea merits its share of attention. Earlier results -- and therefore more certain ones, in sections where extremely hot weather may arrive suddenly in early Summer -- are made possible by starting the seeds under glass six to eight weeks earlier than sowings can be made out-of-doors.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 25 -- The opening of the German Architectural Exhibition in Sofia today was used to demonstrate the close ties between Germany and Bulgaria. Many high officials from Berlin were on hand. These were representatives of the Propaganda and Foreign Ministries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Labor Department estimated today that about 506,000 new jobs would be created by June, 1942, as the result of government contracts already made for shipbuilding. The figure does not include a number of additional workers needed for the proposed emergency ship construction program or private projects.

The theatre party originally scheduled for Tuesday night in aid of the work conducted by the women's auxiliary of the Union Settlement has been deferred to the night of Feb. 4, when subscribers to the benefit will witness the performance of "Mr. and Mrs. North" at the Belaseo Theatre.

THE government of Venezuela has a more than neighborly admirer in the person of that veteran publicist, Henry J. Allen, former Governor of Kansas, special adviser to the State Department, author, traveler, journalist.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25 -- The Missouri General Assembly is giving an illuminating demonstration of how a State Legislature can become so ensnarled in politics that it seems to disregard entirely the duties which it is supposed to perform. The lawmakers are now engaged in protracted legal manoeuvres which have only one objective -- the seating of a Democrat as Governor after he was defeated by a Republican in the election last November.

Final plans have been made for the annual New York Hound Show to be held Friday in the ring of the Riding and Polo Club, 7 West Sixty-sixth Street. Judging arrangements will be much the same as in past years, starting at 10 A.M. There will be the usual luncheon intermission from 12:30 to 2 P.M.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 25 -- Fellows of the Medical Society of New Jersey were on record today as pledging full support to the President's effort to give to Britain all aid short of war.

Granted that the making of sauce takes quite a bite out of a busy woman's day, she who masters the art holds one of the keys to distinguished cookery, and, what is more, has a trick up her sleeve when friends drop in some evening when there is practically nothing in the house for dinner.

Frank Rosenblum of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, a national vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, has notified Philip Murray, C.I.O. president, that he is unwilling to serve on the C.I.O.'s standing committee on unemployment because he does not believe its personnel is representative, it was learned yesterday.

Another chapter will be written in the fighting history of Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, Friday night in Madison Square Garden. The Brown Bomber is scheduled to try his depth charges on Clarence (Red) Burman, Baltimore challenger, who is a protege of ex-champion Jack Dempsey.

Or if he did not have that opportunity, you would take the fact into consideration in listening to him play.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 -- Philip Murray, head of the C.I.O., pressed before 500 industrial leaders of the Tri-State district today his plan for defense industrial councils, declaring that greater representation for labor was needed to expedite defense production

SERVICE CENTER: The Alexandria Fleet Club provides recreation for British sailors in Egypt's chief port. Every day 4,000 meals are served, 12,000 bottles of beer opened. There are singers and dancing girls, lounges, a night club. The Fleet Club occupies an old hospital and was started by a Church of England rector, the Rev. Alan Spender.

UNIQUE in the field it covers, an exhibition of Coptic art has opened at the Brooklyn, Museum. Perhaps the first showing to attempt such scope, either in Europe or America, the material displayed has been assembled strictly for its intrinsic artistic merit.

Twenty consuls representing Latin American countries in New York will be guests of honor at a reception to be given Wednesday afternoon at the Museum of Modern Art by members of the ball committee for the Fiesta Pan-Americana, an event to be held Feb. 10 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the Goddard Neighborhood Center.

Many members of society who already have subscribed to the forthcoming Russian Students Ball are planning to attend the event attired in handsome Russian costumes of authentic native design ranging from the gay gypsy and peasant garb to the elaborate court and Boyar habiliments once seen at gatherings of the former Imperial Russian nobility.

AS to dachshunds, said Ludwig Bemelmans, they are most difficult dogs to train -- "so shy, so trembling, so sensitive, and at the same time so unforgiving." He once bought one for his mother, a wire-haired type -- "they are the worst kind" -- and she could do nothing with it.

EDINBURGH -- Schools in Scotland are on a wartime program. The war clouds broke asunder during my boys' last week of Summer-long vacation. It was a stupendous piece of luck in their young eyes. Holidays had to be prolonged until air-raid shelters were built, according to government order, in sufficient number to hold the full complement of scholars, and had to be built to government specifications, too.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- Starvation was blamed directly for "a certain number of deaths" in French internment camps in reports just received here by the American Friends Service Committee from its investigators abroad.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- The larger share of the recent unrestricted grant of $35,000 by the Carnegie Corporation to Sarah Lawrence College will be devoted to further research into the reaction of students to various courses of study teaching methods, and also a study of alumnae, according to an announcement by President Constance Warren.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 25 -- Horia Sima, Vice Premier and leader of dissident Iron Guards, has been arrested and probably will face a firing squad, it was disclosed tonight. Troops loyal to the government of General Ion Antonescu had been seeking M. Sima since rebellion broke out among Iron Guards three days ago, followed by widespread death and disorder.

A newly completed national survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion, made as Franklin, D. Roosevelt was taking the oath of his Presidential office for the third time, indicates that he has reached the greatest heights of personal popularity ever measured in the seven-year -- eighty-three-month -- Roosevelt "vote of confidence index" kept by the institute, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.

On Feb. 10 Mercury reaches its greatest elongation east of the sun and sets about an hour and a half after sunset. It should be possible to see the little planet for about a week before and a week after the 10th in the evening sky. On that date it will be some 16 degrees above the horizon when the sun sets.

Two metropolitan senior A.A.U. championship events are on the program for the meet to be held under the auspices of the Woman's Swimming Association of New York in its pool at 470 West Twenty-fourth Street today at 2:45 P.M.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- The Democratic national Administration has fostered a hatred between employer and employe and thus has delayed a return of normal employment and has created a distrust of government employers, the Young Men's Republican Clubs of Westchester County charged today in the labor plank of their 1941 platform, adopted at their annual convention in the County Center here.

New York stores devoted heavy advertising linage last week to the promotion of ready-to-wear, but the response was well below expectations, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Little space was devoted to accessories.

HELEN TRAUBEL and Lauitz Melchior will sing at the Wagner concert by the NBC Symphony Orchestra, under Arturo Toscanini, Saturday night, Feb. 22, in Carnegie Hall, for the benefit of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association.

The Medical and Surgical Committee of America announced yesterday that medical supplies and equipment valued at nearly $12,000 had been shipped last week to emergency field hospitals in Great Britain. The committee headquarters are at 420 Lexington Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Orders for mobilization on Feb. 10 of about 20,700 National Guard officers and men of eleven States were announced today by the War Department.

Five hundred Hunter College seniors will begin tomorrow ten days of celebrations and special entertainments the climax of which will be commencement exercises on Thursday, Feb. 6, it was announced yesterday by Miss Mildred G. Cohen, class president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Adoption of a new rule under the Holding Company Act, to exempt the subsidiaries of registered public utility holding companies engaged largely in the petroleum or accessory business, the production or transportation of natural gas, or in the real estate business from certain provisions of the act was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Questionnaires have gone out to 4,000 members of the Women's National Republican Club in forty-two States, seeking information on their fitness for service in the event of a national emergency, and early responses indicate an "enthusiastic willingness" to help, club officials announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON -- Typical examples of how some large cities of the United States cope with a "creeping paralysis" afflicting their street traffic are analyzed in a survey just completed by the Public Roads Administration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Army and Navy are expected to award contracts within the next few days for construction of a chain of eight naval, military and air bases, involving twenty different establishments, on British islands and territories in the Western Hemisphere.

HAVANA, Jan. 25 -- The Cuban Secretary of State, Jose Manuel Cortina, today issued a statement observing that a resolution to admit Cuba as a State of the Union introduced in the United States Congress by Senator William H. Smathers [Democrat, of New Jersey] was contrary to President Roosevelt's foreign policy, to pan-Americanism and to the opinion and decision of all Cubans.
Harry B. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, declared yesterday that Europe's downfall may be partly laid to the forgetting of "private loyalties."

NEARLY 2,500 high school graduates swarmed into White Plains not long ago to be examined for appointment next April as troopers in the State Police, of which the authorized strength is only 900. If records are anything to go by, only about 500 of the 2,500 will make the grade.

With more than the required number of signers necessary to insure its beginning, the $100,000,000 Inter-American Bank will start to function as soon as an Act of Congress can be passed granting a charter and authorizing the necessary minimum $5,000,000 contribution to its capital.
