Graduates of Columbia University's School of Journalism revisited their classrooms last night for the second annual "open house" reunion of the alumni association. With a ban on speeches, they spent seven hours largely in reminiscence and shop talk.

With a greatly extended curriculum, over a hundred courses, many by leading scholars recently rescued from Europe, the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, will open its Spring term on Monday, Feb. 3. The 110 courses will be offered in the fields of contemporary politics, foreign affairs, history, economics and sociology, housing, anthropology, philosophy, psychology, science, literature, art, music and the dance.
DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- Diplomas in "life adjustment" will be awarded to thirty-one boys and girls at graduation exercises of the Children's Village, here, Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Several important measures affecting public education were adopted by popular vote in various States in 1940. They are of three types: (1) constitutional amendments, (2) statutes enacted by popular initiative, and (3) proposed laws approved by referendum.

NEARLY 2,500 high school graduates swarmed into White Plains not long ago to be examined for appointment next April as troopers in the State Police, of which the authorized strength is only 900. If records are anything to go by, only about 500 of the 2,500 will make the grade.

With more than the required number of signers necessary to insure its beginning, the $100,000,000 Inter-American Bank will start to function as soon as an Act of Congress can be passed granting a charter and authorizing the necessary minimum $5,000,000 contribution to its capital.

Graduates of Columbia University's School of Journalism revisited their classrooms last night for the second annual "open house" reunion of the alumni association. With a ban on speeches, they spent seven hours largely in reminiscence and shop talk.

With a greatly extended curriculum, over a hundred courses, many by leading scholars recently rescued from Europe, the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, will open its Spring term on Monday, Feb. 3. The 110 courses will be offered in the fields of contemporary politics, foreign affairs, history, economics and sociology, housing, anthropology, philosophy, psychology, science, literature, art, music and the dance.
DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- Diplomas in "life adjustment" will be awarded to thirty-one boys and girls at graduation exercises of the Children's Village, here, Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Several important measures affecting public education were adopted by popular vote in various States in 1940. They are of three types: (1) constitutional amendments, (2) statutes enacted by popular initiative, and (3) proposed laws approved by referendum.

THE first international conference of the "School of the Air of the Americas" will open Feb. 27 in Atlantic City "to facilitate wider and more effective utilization" of the radio school throughout this hemisphere in supplementing instruction of children.

Unbeaten in their last twelve games in the National Hockey League, the Bruins will skate against the Americans at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Massachusetts athletes, more than ordinarily successful against the New Yorkers this season, are confident that they will experience little trouble in tonight's contest.

DISPATCHES from England last week recounted the results of a mock air duel staged by R.A.F. pilots using a captured and reconditioned Messerschmitt of the ME-110 type and an American-built plane of an undisclosed make.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 25 -- With Rumania counting her dead and the army patrolling the streets of the capital and the larger towns throughout the country to maintain order and suppress the last cells of resistance, a somewhat clearer picture is emerging of what occurred at different points in the country during the Iron Guard's attempt to seize power and overthrow Premier Ion Antonescu.

Creation of a new state police in Norway, under command of the Norwegian who surrendered Narvik without a fight, marks another stage in the struggle of the German invaders against the natural resentment which their conquest has brought upon them. The old police force did not seem to help much.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A message congratulating President Roosevelt on his inauguration for a third term was received from Emperor Hirohito of Japan, the State Department revealed today. A wish for "strengthened" United States-Japanese relations was contained in the communication.

Although the list of "Glen Hazard" books is rapidly becoming a long one, these North Carolina Mountain stories by Mr. and Mrs. Chapman retain their spontaneity and freshness of interest. This latest one deals once more with the Glen Hazard girls. Beth Gillow, Lyn Wayland, Marcia Morgan and Jane Lister, the newcomer to the Glen, all of whom have appeared in the stories immediately preceding this one.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The prepared text of the statement made to the House Foreign Affairs Committee by William C. Bullitt, former Ambassador to France, was as follows:

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York has urged members of Congress to give prompt and favorable consideration to legislation now being studied in committees that would improve ship tonnage conditions in the intercoastal and coastwise shipping industries.

Holding grimly to the auction market method of doing business appears to have settled few problems of the national Stock Exchanges. Some among them now appear convinced that changes must be made if they are to adjust themselves to the times and continue to serve the public.

FOR the past two Sundays I have been reading the letters of irate people complaining of the rudeness of box-office attendants and, although I, too, am on the purchasing side it seems to me that the ledger should be balanced.

NEW ORLEANS -- This Crescent City, also dubbed somewhat romantically "The City That Care Forgot," is preparing for its greatest season. On the basis of out-of-towners already registered at its glittery white building on Camp Street, the Association of Commerce reports an indicated total of visitors for the year 200 per cent greater than in 1936.

Once upon a time a prominent resident of the Western Hemisphere was strolling along the edge of the sea that washes his native shores when he heard loud cries for help from a point some distance out beyond the breakers. Turning in the direction from which the sounds of distress came he saw, sure enough, a swimmer resolutely battling against tide and wind and beckoning for aid from the shore.

A week which saw industrial share prices at their lowest levels since August ended yesterday with prices firm to slightly up on the day, but mixed on the week. Rails, however, registered their high levels for the new year.

Addressing more than 600 members and guests of the New York Wellesley Club at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt in celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the club, Miss Mildred McAfee, president of Wellesley College, emphasized that society retains the right "to expect that college women can and will concern themselves with certain kinds of problems which might not command the interest of every citizen."

Of the four collections of folktales which Frances Carpenter has made (the others are "Tales of a Basque Grandmother," Tales of a Russian Grandmother" and "Tales of a Chinese Grandmother") this latest one has the most vitality and interest.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25 -- John B. Partridge scored his second victory in the Miami Beach Handicap, the country's richest race on the grass, when his Robert L. was up to win by a head today before 14,176 persons, Hialeah's largest crowd this season. It was a popular victory with a great many in the crowd, which wagered $540,856 on the eight races.

The question whether registered public utility holding companies and their subsidiaries should be required to sell new issues of securities in compulsory competitive bidding or be permitted to continue in the traditional manner to negotiate privately with underwriters of their own choosing will be aired tomorrow in a "public conference" before the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington.
Since their homes had been bare of trees or gifts on Christmas Day 500 underprivileged lower East Side youngsters found a real Christmas in January yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The old German Army diet of canned meat, sausage and bread has, in the present war, largely been replaced by foodstuffs in concentrated powdered form, the Commerce Department reported today.

IN all the fifty-seven years of the Metropolitan Opera its leadership in this hemisphere has never been stronger than now, and one of the chief reasons is radio. For the first time, this season Saturday afternoon operas from the "Met" are being relayed southward by short waves for re-broadcasting over a special Latin-American network, from which the music is reaching millions of new listeners in the twenty republics to the south of us.

Astrology is riddled for the nth time by the Boston and Cambridge branch of the American Association of Scientific Workers in a report which is to appear in the Scientific Monthly. It cannot be said that any new arguments against the falacies of the astrologers have been brought out.

Fourteen of the current season's debutantes and 500 children and their parents attended yesterday the annual Children's Carnival of the Greenwich House Health Center, held in the auditorium of Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, and laughed, cheered and applauded the antics of Donald Duck, Mickey Mouse, two clowns, a magician and a mind reader.

With a week of graduation exercises and term examinations in the New York City elementary and secondary schools starting tomorrow, 72,314 students will receive diplomas here prior to the opening of the Spring semester on Feb. 3.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 25 -- A clerk killed a bandit in balking a hold-up early today in a liquor store at 158 Ferry Street here, but was critically wounded by the bandit's partner, who was captured by a rookie patrolman.

OTTAWA, Jan. 25 -- "Invasion is only one of five possibilities, but it is better not to discuss the other four," Defense Minister Colonel J.L. Ralston said today when giving an account of the situation in Great Britain. All these possibilities were being provided for, said the Minister, who has just returned from a two months' visit.

A FIVE-YEAR controversy with the Cherokee Indian Eastern Band of North Carolina, which held up the establishment of the southern terminal site of colorful Blue Ridge National Parkway, that 480-mile recreational link which will connect the Great Smoky Mountain and Shenandoah Valley National Parks, has finally been settled.

At the Venice airport in 1934 two men clasped hands. Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini had met for the first time. Pageantry and State ceremonial surrounded them, fixing the formula for the meetings that have followed, though it was 1937 before they saw each other again.

Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, coordinator of the State Council of Defense, appealed yesterday to employers not to "weaken" the democracy in the interest of which the defense program is going forward by employment policies which discriminate against Negroes and foreign born, naturalized American citizens.

A proposal for the acquisition of Aviation and Transportation Corporation by the Aviation Corporation will be submitted to stockholders of both companies on Feb. 14 and Feb. 17, respectively. Under the plan, voting control of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation as well as the Auburn Central Manufacturing Corporation would pass to the Aviation Corporation.

MAYBE you have already heard of a picture called "Gone With the Wind." Vaguely we seem to recollect that it was somewhat in the news about a year ago, and reports have come to us that during the past twelve months it has reaped a modest harvest of something like $23,000,000 in box-office grosses throughout the land.

Indalecio Prieto, who was Minister of National Defense of the Spanish Republic, announced yesterday that news had been received from Vichy that four former Spanish officials and several other Republican leaders had been seized in unoccupied France by the Petain government and held for extradition to Spain, according to the Spanish Refugee Relief Campaign.

THE fourth revised and enlarged edition of Baker's Biographical Dictionary of Musicians has just been issued by G. Schirmer, Inc., of this city. Gustave Schirmer was chiefly responsible for this new edition, which was placed under the general supervision of Gustave Reese, who headed an editorial staff including Gilbert Chase, Nicolas Slonimsky and others.

Princess Alice, Countess of Athlone, wife of the Governor General of Canada, heads the committee of patrons and patronesses for the supper dance under the auspices of the Canadian Women's Club of New York, which will take place on Feb. 7 at the Plaza to raise funds for the purchase of a mobile canteen unit for England.
POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Sports enthusiasts in the Poconos are finding good snow conditions, with six inches of new granular snow covering a two-inch frozen base, and low temperatures prevailing.

For about three years a spirited controversy has been going on among investment bankers over the desirability of competitive bidding in the underwriting and flotation of new security issues. Now the question seems to be approaching a decision, at least with respect to issues of public utility securities.

A PHILOSOPHY of life is a prerequisite for even the definition of the purpose of education. "We cannot educate intelligently unless we know what we are educating for." And at a time when the old individualism seems unable to solve the day's problems, and the ideas of democracy itself are confused, educators are faced with the need for a new evaluation of educational purposes and life philosophies.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that it had awarded to the Associated Metals and Mineral Corporation, 40 Hester Street, the contract for demolition of the Second Avenue elevated structure between Fifty-ninth and 128th Streets.

Seven young women who found or created opportunities for themselves will tell of their experiences at a meeting on "Crashing New York for a Job" to be held at the American Woman's Association, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, on Wednesday at 8:15 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Virginia Electric and Power Company and its parent concern, the Engineers Public Service Company, today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for the issue of $6,930,000 of bonds and notes, and a proposed increase of capital.

WHEN Miss Emma Thursby died ten years ago, at the age of 86, she had long been well known as a teacher of singing; and every one remembered, when her name was mentioned, that Geraldine Farrar had been her pupil and that her weekly musical receptions had been very famous in social and artistic New York.

Special housing problems of thousands of industrial workers employed under the national defense program were discussed yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and labor and civic leaders at the tenth annual meeting of the National Public Housing Conference at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Joe Kirby returns to his apartment after making the rounds of drinking places in search of a man who owes him money. The man is in the apartment with Joe's own knife through his heart. Also a girl is missing whom Joe had brought to the apartment earlier in the evening after finding her in an alley bruised and half-naked.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 25 -- Three high ranking Italian Army officers have been killed during the last twenty-four hours in Milan and other cities in Northern Italy, according to information this evening from reliable frontier correspondents and diplomatic sources in Belgrade.

LIGHTNING struck in Spain. It would be quite unjust to encourage the inference that prior to his settling in Spain Greco's art had been merely polite and accomplished. But it is true that not until he had left Italy did the pure flame of Greco's genius become articulate.

DESPITE a private conviction that no one, with the exception of a few fanciful folk who always see idealized portraits in mirrors, continued to believe that the "artistic temperament" is directly opposed to everyday common sense, the notion is still expressed with distressing frequency.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- It is Summer in Chile, and Santiago, the nation's capital, is all set to play host to visitors to the fourth centenary celebration of the founding of the city, to be inaugurated on Feb. 12.

THE Columbia Concerts Corporation, one of America's largest booking agencies, has added seven new singers, two violinists, four pianists, a string quartet and a small American opera company to its list for the 1941-42 season.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 26 -- The weather continued as a prominent motive in the grim war picture early today as for the sixth successive night the air-raid sirens in London kept quiet because the guardians of the capital heard no distant unfriendly noises in the sky.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A demand for full payment for time lost in their strike at the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company was made today by the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers of America.

AT the Boy Scout exhibition at Santiago recently Chilean Boy and Girl Scouts abandoned the swastika. They had used it as a symbol of distinguished service for thirty-one years, but now, Scout officers wearing medals with the insignia had become "the object of criticism and protest when parading the streets," it was explained.

With the exception of the library in the new $6,000,000 Hunter College building on Park Avenue, library facilities of the four municipal colleges are inadequate to meet the demands placed upon them, it was declared in a report just issued to the New York Library Club.

Bloomingdale's pet dog show, which annually attracts more than 800 entries, may find itself bigger than ever this year when the tenth annual event starts on Feb. 17. The competition, which is to be concluded Feb. 21, will be conducted on the sixth floor of the store building.

A FIVE-YEAR controversy with the Cherokee Indian Eastern Band of North Carolina, which held up the establishment of the southern terminal site of colorful Blue Ridge National Parkway, that 480-mile recreational link which will connect the Great Smoky Mountain and Shenandoah Valley National Parks, has finally been settled.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Red Star, the official organ of the Soviet Army, today paid high tribute to Britain's war strategy in Europe and Africa and asserted that Germany would be compelled to use "a colossal force" for any attempt to invade the British Isles.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan, 26 -- Fire caused damage estimated at $275,000 this morning to the administration building of the Norfolk naval operating base, headquarters of the Atlantic patrol force and the fifth naval district.

Peoples and nations must be awakened to the reality of the supernatural and to the realization that if they defy God they perish, the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said yesterday in a sermon as guest preacher at the Church of the Holy Apostles, Ninth Avenue and Twenty-eighth Street.

These are certainly lean days for the New York Rovers. The Red Shirts sank deeper into the Eastern Hockey League cellar yesterday when they dropped a 2-to-1 decision to the speedy pace-setting Washington (D.C.) Eagles at Madison Square Garden.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 26 -- Pierre Cot, former French Minister of Commerce and a member of all French Cabinets from 1932 to 1938, and Hugh Wilson, former United States Ambassador to Germany, have been appointed to the Yale University faculty for the second half of the academic year, President Seymour announced.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Japan's Minister to Thailand declared tonight that his country did not expect a reward for attempting to settle difficulties between Thailand and French Indo-China, whose undeclared war continued although both belligerents had accepted Japanese mediation.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 26 -- After you cross the Mason and Dixon line the methods of hunting quail vary. And although you find many means employed in following the dogs you will discover few hunters using the elementary "shanks' mare."
Miss Gloria Callen of the Women's Swimming Association successfully defended the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior 100-yard back-stroke title in a meet conducted yesterday at the W.S.A. pool.

A lasting peace, free of suspicion and fear, can be achieved only through faith in God, Chaplain Raymond C. Knox of Columbia University declared yesterday at the university services in St. Paul's Chapel.

A check for $1,000 to equip a classroom in the Cardinal Hayes Memorial High School for Boys in the Bronx, a gold pectoral cross and a "spiritual bouquet" were presented to the Most Rev. J. Francis A. McIntyre, recently consecrated Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of New York, by the Manhattan and Bronx Councils of the Knights of Columbus yesterday at a communion breakfast in the Hotel Commodore.

Deliveries of "above 100 per cent" on defense contracts are being made by private industry, according to a survey made this month by the committee on national defense of the National Association of Manufacturers, it was reported yesterday by W. P. Witherow, president of the Blaw-Knox Company and chairman of the committee.

The continuity and volume discounts offered by the radio chains are an excellent selling point for the networks, according to an agency executive, but have reached the stage where they practically force advertisers to continue on the air whether they want to or not.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 26 -- Daro of Maridor, the English setter who has had one of the strangest careers in American canine history, this evening was awarded the title of best in show at the twenty-eighth annual exhibition of the Newark Kennel Club in the 113th Infantry Armory.

ROSENDALE, N.Y., Jan. 26 -- Harald Sorensen, one of skiing's most popular figures in this country for the last decade, flashed his customary superb form in outclassing a small but formidable field for the New York State Class A jumping championship today on the Telemark S.C. hill.

Although it appeared through the first period that their recent string of successes wan about to be snapped, the Bruins hit their stride and registered a convincing victory over the Americans by 6 to 1 in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

BERLIN, Jan. 26 -- "No inflation is threatening Germany." Such was the answer authoritative circles made last week through the semiofficial agency, Dienst aus Deutschland, to the rumors that periodically originate abroad and purport to show that currency inflation is imminent in Germany.

Liberal purchasing in anticipation of expansion in Spring volume, both by out-of-town buyers visiting the wholesale markets here and by mail, lifted activity in a wide range of merchandise lines last week. Crowded showrooms yielded fair initial orders, in contrast to the usual note-taking, throughout the apparel markets.
BERLIN, Jan. 26 -- The stock market here was irregularly off last week, with the share index receding to 180.70 on Friday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 26 -- After being tossed through the fuselage wall of a crashing bomber, swimming half a mile despite a head gash and a useless arm and wandering for nearly two days and nights in the desert, a young Royal Air Force rear gunner was able today to tell the story on his hospital cot.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A civil suit charging twelve manufacturers of electric light bulbs with creating a monopoly through licensing agreements will be filed tomorrow in Federal District Court at Trenton, N.J., Attorney General Jackson announced today.
The annual report of Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, director of the Second Region, National Labor Relations Board, follows:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 26 -- The Italian secret police and agents of the German Gestapo have arrested between twenty and thirty persons, "including certain Italian Army officers and Fascist officials" at Milan and Turin, it was learned tonight from high foreign diplomatic sources here.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 26 -- Two trains loaded with the first selectees for the Twenty-seventh Division arrived here today from Camp Upton, L.I., and Fort Niagara, N.Y., and were met by military bands playing bravely in the rain.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 26 -- The Regional Conference of the River Plate will open here tomorrow for a ten-day session, during which it is hoped to work out a program to intensify the commercial and economic relations of the countries in this part of South America in such a way as to overcome, at least partly, the serious problems that have arisen from the European war.
LA CROSSE, Wis., Jan. 26 -- Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis won his second national outdoor speed skating championship in three years when he came in first in the five-mile grind today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 26 -- Dinghy sailors at the Larchmont Yacht Club had a real session of Winter windjamming today. There were twenty-one boats out. A northerly breeze this morning was so brisk it called for weather-rail perching, but it shifted half way around the compass at mid-day and eventually settled into a southeast whisper that was barely sufficient to waft the craft around the courses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A complete code of fair practices for Federal administrative agencies was proposed in a statement of additional views attached to the report of the Attorney General's Committee on Administrative Procedure as filed with, and transmitted to, Congress by Attorney General Jackson last Friday.

ROME, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A mention of Bizerte, French naval base in Tunisia, by Mario Appelius, commentator on Premier Mussolini's newspaper, the Popolo d'Italia, in a restatement of Italian war aims caused foreign observers to speculate whether the Axis chiefs had decided to press France to relinquish that important port.
ROME, Jan. 26 (UP) -- The Rome manager of The United Press talked by telephone today with Enrico Lelli, an Italian journalist he has known for years, in Milan.

James J. Walker, in his first public appearance as impartial chairman of the women's coat and suit industry, was guest of honor last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria attended by 1,000 persons. The event was under the auspices of the coat and suit division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities.

What are the prospects for industry as the defense program gathers headway? Probably the peak of activity has already been reached in such work as the construction of barracks. Will the production of war goods wholly take the place of the cessation of work on new war goods factories, or do we face a slump when the present expansion of industrial facilities is completed?

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 26 -- That Brazil may clamp down on the exportation of crude rubber or at least enact a ruling that rubber exports be made only after the government verifies the needs of the domestic rubber manufacturers, was rumored here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Despite differences of opinion between him and Republican Congressional leaders over foreign policy, Wendell L. Willkie, 1940 Republican Presidential nominee, is scheduled to be the party's chief speaker in New York on Lincoln Day, Feb. 12.

Three basic tax reforms, pending a complete revision of the national tax structure, were recommended yesterday by the New York Board of Trade in a report of its Committee on Taxation, unanimously approved by the directors. They were:

Otis Co. made known yesterday that they had filed a memorandum with the SEC in answer to opponents of competitive bidding, asserting that "competitive bidding for new issues of public utility securities will end the monopoly held by a few Eastern investment bankers on the origination, management and underwriting of such securities."

The chaos of the world today was ascribed to the failure of peacemaking efforts that followed the World War armistice yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The veteran Tiff Denton of Kansas City tonight upset Welker Cochran's hopes of going into a four-way tie for first place in the world three cushion billiard tournament by defeating the San Francisco player, 50 to 44, in forty-eight innings.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 26 -- Military circles here are examining attentively the situation in the Mediterranean in the light of a declaration by General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the "Free French" forces, that German troops were being landed in French Tunisia, preparatory to going to the aid of the Italians in Libya.

Although there is a diversity of opinion among bankers, corporate financial executives, mercantile credit men and accountants on refinements in accounting practices, a majority in each of the four groups of more than 1,500 bankers, executives, credit men and accountants taking part in a survey conducted by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., favors twelve of sixteen accounting reforms suggested in the interest of more complete and reliable corporate reporting.

While Charles J. Hendley, president of the New York Teachers Union, remained unserved with a warrant of arrest, the union's executive board made public last night the text of a telegram to the Rapp-Coudert committee, advising of its willingness to give its membership lists to the committee.

Cornelia Otis Skinner, who is best known for her solo dramas, will make her first starring appearance in a regular Broadway play in "Theatre," which Guy Bolton has fashioned from the Somerset Maughana novel of the same name. It is to open a Spring try-out tour in Washington on Easter Monday, April 14, under the auspices of John Golden.

ROME, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Today's Italian war communique said that German bombers on Friday hit a British battleship and a cruiser with two heavy caliber bombs each, in addition to another cruiser previously reported damaged.

EAST MOLINE, Ill., Jan. 26 (AP) -- E.W. Stahl, superintendent of the strike-bound East Moline works of the International Harvester Company, said tonight that the plant would be reopened tomorrow and that full operation should be reached by Wednesday.

The city's surplus emergency tax receipts, estimated to exceed $11,000,000 by July 1, should be applied to the payment of charges on city debt contracted for relief and allied purposes, and not to finance directly the social welfare activities now carried in the regular expense budget, the Citizens Budget Commission declares in an open letter addressed to legislative leaders in Albany and made public yesterday.

While the impression now prevalent in England is that America is in sympathy with us here in England and trying to help us, the following incident indicates that the American customs are apparently not feeling the same way.

Baron Franz von Werra, who had earlier identified himself as a German flier escaped from Canada who had shot down fourteen British planes in the current battle for England, was at large on $5,000 bail here yesterday pending his appearance before a Federal grand jury in Albany on Thursday.

NOW they are going to toss a fellow named Clarence in against J. Shufflin' Louis. That's right. Clarence (Red) Burman. He used to drive Jack Dempsey's car. That and this meeting with the Dark Destroyer probably will be as close as Clarence (Red) Burman ever will get to championship status.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 26 -- The smaller Continental European bourses last week again reflected divergent tendencies, with local developments apparently the principal influence in the respective trends rather than the international situation. Generally, however, trading activity was on a better scale than in the previous week.

With most of the leaders kept idle by mid-year examinations, a state of affairs which will prevail again this week, the college basketball situation in the East remained virtually unchanged last week. For the most notable developments, it is necessary to turn to the Midwest.

German foreign trade promotion methods, when as mixed with political motives as they are today, enable Germany to profit either way. Yugoslavia, like most of Southeastern Europe, had taken advantage of the markets Germany offered her agricultural products, only to find like the rest that her apparently profitable sales merely resulted in Germany running heavily into her debt.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Rumanian Army troops loyal to Premier Ion Antonescu tonight were reported to have captured Brasov, chief city of Transylvania and Iron Guard stronghold, after a fierce fifty-hour battle with rebel forces barricaded in public buildings.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The British Middle Eastern command at Cairo issued this communique today:

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained unchanged at 86.1. As has been true generally for several weeks, a great many of the changes were in the prices of farm products and foodstuffs. Further rises in livestock, in addition to increases in hay, potatoes and fruits, brought the farm products group up to 71.1, thus continuing the upward trend in this group which began last August.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- While the stock markets fully maintained their confident tone last week, the volume of business slackened noticeably in certain sections following the absorption of funds that were released through the purchase of dollar securities by the British Treasury.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 -- The heavy flow of steel specifications in mills last week continued unabated with incoming orders totaling substantially more tonnage than is currently being shipped or produced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Brig. Gen. William H. Bisbee, retired, oldest officer on the Army rolls, veteran of the Civil War, the Spanish-American War, the Philippine Insurrection and an old Indian fighter, received today on his approaching 101st birthday, which falls on Tuesday of this week, greetings from the Secretary of War and General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff.

The Rev. Ernest R. Palen, pastor of the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street, yesterday stressed the need and importance 'for a quiet hour" in daily life as a means of keeping the world Christian and urged that Christian-minded persons reserve a certain time each day for contemplation of God's law and for thoughts of God's purpose.

LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The eleventh annual Indian "independence day" was celebrated in London today at an India League meeting marked by speeches heaping abuse on British administration in India and demands for the release of political prisoners.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Lehman will transmit his 1941-42 budget to the Legislature tomorrow night and the recommendations he makes will determine to a large extent how long the session is to last and whether the battle of the last two years between the Governor and the Republicans over taxes is to be renewed.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 26 -- The British forces in Eritrea have broken the second Italian defense line, between Bisha and Barentu, and are closing in on the mountain town of Agordat. Bisha, western terminus of the Italian railroad, was captured yesterday and 100 more Italian troops were taken prisoner.

An "operation without benefit of anesthetics" is in store for departmental requests now being submitted in preparation for the city's 1941-42 budget, Mayor La Guardia promised yesterday during an inspection tour of the newly opened Airlines Terminal, Park Avenue and Forty-second Street.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 26 -- The Forty-fourth Division will enter the final phase of its thirteen-week mobilization training program here this week. This program, prescribed by the War Department including the number of hours to be devoted to each activity, has been finished in the main by all units here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period from Jan. 18 to 24 are given in the appended tabulation:

This being one of those years when Washington is to have a major league baseball opening all to itself, the American League will start its 1941 championship season in accordance with its time-honored stagger system, according to the official schedule released for publication today, and with the Yankees breaking away from the barrier twice on successive days.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Corn showed a relatively firm undertone last week on the Board of Trade here, and, while prices held within a range of about 1 cent, the close yesterday showed the May 1/4 cent lower on the week and the deferred months unchanged to 1/8 cent up. July sold at a new high level since last November at one time and the September set a record for the season.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 26 -- In the Class B division of the frostbite races at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today, three skippers tied for first honors, each with 19 points. The fact that Howard Brumley in Sneezy managed to gain a share of the glory was the big note of the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Four different views on the chief present threat to American democracy were presented here tonight in the American Forum of the Air, broadcast by the Mutual Broadcasting System.

Two hundred and fifty graduating seniors of Hunter College will attend the traditional commencement dinner at 7 o'clock this evening in the Empire Room of Long-champs Restaurant, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. Miss Mildred G. Cohen, class president, will preside.

The decline in cotton prices continued through the first few days of last week, but prices subsequently strengthened and final quotations reflected only moderate net changes. At the close on Saturday, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 4 points above to 2 points below those of a week earlier.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- The Board of Trade's index of commodity prices for December, based on 1930 as 100, stood at 148.2, as compared with 146.9 in November and 122.3 in December, 1939.

Concerned over the presence on the city home relief rolls of 66,000 employable persons for whom no WPA jobs are available, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would make a new effort in this session of the State Legislature to obtain favorable action on a bill authorizing localities to conduct their own work relief programs.

NEW LONDON, Wis., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Torger Tokle of the Norway Ski Club, New York, added to his string of American successes by winning the Class A event in the Central United States ski championships today.

ATHENS, Jan. 26 -- Charles A. House, recently appointed executive officer of the American Red Cross in Greece, said today that the list of articles urgently needed for hospitals and dressing stations throughout the country comprised "anything one can possibly think of."
ROME, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique for today follows:

RANCHO SANTA FE, Calif., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Finishing with another sub-par round, Sammy Snead today captured the annual $3,000 golf tournament staged by Bing Crosby. It was Snead's third victory in the five-year-old competition.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 26 (AP) -- British soldiers pushing deeper into Italian Eritrea are within ten miles of Agordat, while the British forces in Libya are fighting the Italians at Derna, it was reported tonight.

Many dinners will be given tomorrow night before the world premiere of the technicolor film, "Virginia," at the Paramount Theatre, from which the Maple Leaf Fund, Inc., the national Canadian organization for British war relief, will benefit.

First reports on the Park Department's policy of keeping precise statistics on the amount of damage done by vandals in the city parks come from Brooklyn, where we learn that such maliciousness in that borough cost the city about $31,000 in 1940. Of this amount, $30,000 accounted for destruction and damage to lighting fixtures.

Two houses in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn will be modernized as the result of the sale by the South Brooklyn Savings Bank of the four-story apartments at 772-4 Union Street. They were bought by an investor and are assessed at $50,000.

The fare at yesterday afternoon's concert of the New Friends of Music in Town Hall consisted of Roger Sessions's string quartet in E minor, Ernst Krenek's song cycle, "Gesaenge des Spaeten Jahres" and Schubert's quartet in B flat, Op. 168.

The first week-day religious school sessions under the Coudert-McLaughlin Law passed last Spring at Albany, permitting students to be released from public school classes an hour a week for religious training, will be held Wednesday, Feb. 5.
DETROIT, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and the Detroit Red Wings tangled in a rough exhibition tonight, with the visitors coming out on top, 2 to 0.

The funeral of Kenneth F. Simpson will be held tomorrow afternoon from St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and East Seventy-first Street. Mr. Simpson, for six years chairman of the New York County Republican Committee and newly elected Representative in Congress, where he had served just twenty days, died suddenly late Saturday night of a heart attack at his home, 109 East Ninety-first Street.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 26 -- The more menacing the German machinations in the Balkans and Italy become, the firmer is the attitude of Turkish opinion and the press. It is fully realized that Germany is now beginning indirectly to threaten Turkey -- for example, through the Budapest radio, which appears to be at the disposal of the Nazis for propaganda purposes.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 26 (AP) -- The national and North American champion, Tuffield Latour, and his brakeman, Paul Duprey, narrowly defeated two youngsters today to win the Adirondack Association A.A.U. senior two-man bobsled title.

Former Representative Bruce Barton and State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr. were said yesterday to be the most likely to receive consideration for the Republican nomination for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, when a special election is called to fill the vacancy caused by the sudden death on Saturday night of Kenneth F. Simpson.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 26 (AP) -- The undaunted editors of The Harvard Lampoon, student monthly, published today their selections of the movie "worsts" of 1940, and sat back to await developments.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Favorable weather conditions prevailed in the Winter Wheat Belt most of last week and, while several cold waves developed, no extremely low temperatures prevailed in the big producting States from Nebraska southward.

A return to totalitarian Christianity was advocated by the Rev. Dr. Horace W.B. Donegan yesterday in his sermon at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-first Street, in lieu of the now prevalent totalitarian forms of government in which the will and mind of the State are supreme and men listen to the voice of a dictatorship that tells them what to do and what to think.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- The New York Rangers lost a chance to regain fourth place in the National Hockey League, bowing to the scrappy Black Hawks tonight, 4 to 1, before 16,608 spectators in the Stadium.

HAVANA, Jan. 26 -- Four of the five United States boats in the fifteenth annual international Star Class regatta for the Bacardi Cup gave a repeat performance in the second race today and the other was dismasted.

That export credit losses of United States manufacturing exporters are negligible is confirmed by the results of a survey, issued for publication today, which gives the experience of member firms of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- This country's policy of maximum aid to Great Britain was approved and the development and establishment of Palestine as a Jewish Commonwealth within the British Empire was urged in resolutions adopted today by more than 2,000 representatives of the nation's Jewry.

The fourth concert of the second series of popular-priced symphonic concerts being sponsored jointly by Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project was given last night at Carnegie Hall. As announced yesterday, John Barnett, young assistant conductor of the New York City Symphony Orchestra, conducted in place of Otto Klemperer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Action by the House last week in passing and sending to the Senate a bill to extend indefinitely the period within which industries operating on defense contracts may obtain "certificates of necessity" is highly important in clearing the way for continued tenders of bids of defense contracts.

The picture of Europe we get today is like the night view of a receding shore line. A flicker of light here and there suggests the location of a familiar landmark -- Paris, Berlin, Rome, Stockholm. Intermittent flares in the stormy sky show where fires break out and are quenched. Oslo and Rotterdam, Prague and Warsaw are just smudges of smoke.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- There were 881 broadcasting stations in the United States and eighty-seven in Canada in operation or authorized for construction on Jan. 1, according to compilations published today in "Broadcasting," weekly trade journal of the industry.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 26 -- Peace once again settled over Rumania today and leaders of the insurrection began to pay -- some with their lives -- the price of a rebellion that failed. Some high-ranking Iron Guard leaders were said to have committed suicide.

C.A. Higgins, president of the Hercules Powder Company, Inc., reported yesterday that net earnings in 1940 amounted to $5,807,769, after all charges, including excess-profits taxes. After payment of a dividend of $524,928 on the preferred stock this was equal to $4.01 a share on the 1,316,710 shares of common stock outstanding, against $3.65 a common share in 1939.

Italo Montemezzi's opera "L'Amore dei Tre Re" will receive its first performance of the season next week at the Metropolitan Opera House. The composer will conduct and Grace Moore and Charles Kullman will sing the roles of Fiora and Avito for the first time at the Broadway house.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Jan. 5 (Delayed) -- Napoleon is credited with the remark "An army marches on its stomach." These words are as true today as they were more than a century ago. But we are all in the "front line" here, and the housewife's task is no light one these days.

The Dunnigan and Devany bills to bar Communists and subversive groups from the ballot were condemned yesterday by the committee on free elections of the National Federation for Constitutional Liberties and by the New York Conference for Inalienable Rights.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- The wheat market broke out of the recent narrow trading range last week, with prices declining to a new low since late in December. The new crop months led the recession as the result of continued wet weather and mild temperatures in the Southwest and a growing belief that the outlook for the new crop has been well maintained in the last two months.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 -- Jean Gabin, French actor who played the lead in "Grand Illusion," has been signed to a term contract by Twentieth Century-Fox and will report early in March, the studio announced. He is expected to leave France next month.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan. 26 -- An assertion that, although business between the United States and South America has picked up rapidly in recent months, the surface has hardly been scratched, was made today by John B. Glenn, president of the Pan-American Trust Company of New York City.

Fordham's football schedule for this year has been cut from nine to eight games, it was announced by Jack Coffey, graduate manager of athletics, yesterday. The reduction is the result of the cancellation of the game with Tennessee, which was slated for Nov. 15, at an out-of-town site which had not been determined.

TOKYO, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka charged today that the United States was abandoning The Monroe Doctrine by extending its defense frontier from the Eastern Pacific to the Western Pacific, and including Australia and New Zealand.

Advices from a correspondent in Europe of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace indicate that the Italian reverses in the Mediterranean have caused a delay in the German plans to strike at Britain and necessitated a restudy of the military and economic situation, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the endowment, said in a statement yesterday.

YARMOUTH, England, Jan. 26 -- The pilot of a German bomber, one of four Nazis captured after the plane made a crash landing on the Norfolk coast, was quoted tonight by the Press Association as saying:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Staggering of the days off of defense workers was recommended as a remedy for the week-end cessation of production activity by Joseph S. McDonagh, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor, in a talk today over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Wendell L. Willkie arrived here today on what he called a purely private and entirely unofficial visit lasting two weeks during which he is to call on Prime Minister Churchill, inspect various bombed areas and study Britain's wartime industrial production.

The report of the Acheson committee seems likely to become a landmark in the history of administrative reform. It turns out to be not at all, as some of the supporters of the Logan-Walter bill had feared, an apologia for present agency procedure, but on the contrary a set of recommendations for far-reaching reforms.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 26 -- Scoring decisive point totals to annex the senior men's and women's crowns, Herman Van Putten and Miss Virginia Jahn shared the spotlight today in the annual interstate outdoor speed skating championships at Bear Mountain State Park.

The fast-growing number of Army enlistments was extended yesterday to the family Columbidae when 125 pairs of prize homing pigeons were lent for breeding purposes to the signal corps at Fort Monmouth, N.J.

ROME, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Charges that wealthy Italians were hoarding and harming the poorer classes by buying up all of the country's available food supplies were made today by Giovanni Ansaldo, writing in Foreign Minister Count Ciano's Leghorn newspaper, Telegrafo, of which he is editor.

The national defense program will benefit from the improved industrial relations fostered by the Wagner Labor Relations Act and the increased disposition of employers and workers to settle their disputes without recourse to strikes or economic warfare, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, declared in her annual report, made public yesterday.

Citing ancient as well as modern mystics who have contributed in changing the course of history, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell advised his congregation yesterday that the best preparation for life is a "mystic conception of God." He preached at morning services at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, of which he is the pastor.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- The "chicken scandal" ended today when the Food Ministry fixed a maximum price of 47 cents a pound for chickens, ducks and geese.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation began an inquiry today into the reported removal of a large number of personnel records of government employes from the Civil Service Commission files.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Lard developed a reactionary tendency last week due mainly to sympathy with the hog market, which lost some of the big advance scored in the previous week. There was a good commission-house demand on the setbacks, and prices held within moderate limits.

Supplementing his previous statement on Britain's dollar resources, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. has submitted to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs additional data supplied by the British Treasury. The new figures clear away whatever questions may have existed concerning the apparently large gap between the present British holdings and the estimated holdings just prior to the outbreak of the war.

ISTANBUL, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Istanbul, ages-old metropolis in the strategic Bosporus-Dardanelles zones of European Turkey, has declared a mock state of war from Tuesday to Friday for the most extensive air-raid drill this city ever has experienced.

Herbert Seidman, captain of the Brooklyn College team, tied for first place in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday, when he beat Joseph Richman in 18 moves in the fourth round.

Members of the congregation at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday were asked by the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg, an assistant chancelor of the Archdiocese of New York, to "imagine yourselves before a firing squad dying for your faith" when the celebrant of the mass intoned the Credo, which is part of the liturgical ceremony.

VICHY, France, Jan. 26 -- Fernand de Brinon, who acts as a link between the German occupying authority and the government at Vichy, has not yet arrived from Paris. The latest report is that he may come tomorrow.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 -- Nervousness over a possible move by the Berlin Axis in the Balkans following the Hitler-Mussolini conference of the previous week-end gave cotton futures a moderate set-back here early in the week, but the market rebounded later to register modest net gains.

When the ribbon was snipped at midnight Saturday to open the new Airlines Terminal at Park Avenue and Forty-second Street, the power and communications serving the offices of Canadian Colonial Airways, Inc., in the building were cut in a dispute over a lease between the terminal officials and the airline, it was learned yesterday.

The financial community, like every one else, divided its interest last week between the more or less conflicting testimony before the House committee on the problem of "aid to England short of war," and the repeated prediction of greatly renewed activity by the Germans in "thirty to sixty days."

Competent management of government business under an efficient merit system is an essential line of defense in view of the existing crisis confronting democracy, the National Civil Service Reform League declared yesterday in making public its annual report for 1940.

Dr. Eugen Steinach is celebrating his eightieth birthday in Zurich, whither he fled to escape the persecution of the Nazis after they had possessed themselves of Austria, land of his birth. Like other imaginative and daring research scientists, he had to bear his share of ridicule.

The strange defeat in detail of the Italian armies in Libya, with the fall of Tobruk, which the British Imperial Army of the Nile "mopped up" last week, presents in retrospect one of the most curious campaign in military history.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Princess Elizabeth grasped the control column of a Royal Air Force Hudson bomber -- while it stood firmly within a hangar -- during a visit to a flying station this afternoon with her parents, King George and Queen Elizabeth, and her sister, Princess Margaret Rose.

YOU print today an Associated Press dispatch from Chicago, quoting me as saying, "Although I have preached pacifism all my life, I am now convinced for the first time that freedom cannot be preserved without military struggle."

ATHENS, Jan. 26 -- There is almost no news from the front today, the General Headquarters communique reporting only "restricted successful operations" and laying claim to "some prisoners," but from such other information as is available it may be gathered that General Ugo Cavallero, the Italian commander, has made another real effort to push his troops forward in an offensive during the last forty-eight hours.

DOORN, The Netherlands, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Wilhelm II, World War Emperor of Germany, will observe his eighty-second birthday tomorrow without a thought of leaving this haven to which he fled after abdicating more than twenty-two years ago.

The war and the national defense program have brought a prospect of far-reaching changes in the economic position of the United States and have presented the much-discussed question of inflation in a new aspect, according to the Guaranty Survey, the monthly publication of the Guaranty Trust Company.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- For many reasons, British bankers this year have been compelled to abandon their annual practice of reviewing current economic events and business prospects both here and abroad. They are confining their statements to greatly curtailed documents issued to shareholders with the annual reports.

The Actors Fund, following its usual custom, last evening put on the greatest Broadway show of the year. It was the fifty-ninth annual benefit performance and, as always, almost every available star of the stage, the screen and the radio was present in informal sketches, or to sing songs or to dance.

Crown Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway, who arrived here from Washington Saturday, were entertained yesterday afternoon by 400 Norwegians and Norwegian-Americans in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Expanded to a three-week basis in an effort to coordinate its varied activities, Chicago's annual Spring market opens officially here tomorrow with apparel showings by the Style Exhibitors, Inc., at a Loop hotel, and by women's, children's and infants' wear tenants at the Merchandise mart.

A call to meet in houses of worship and other places of observance of annual national Brotherhood Week, Feb. 22-28, has been issued by President Roosevelt. This was made public yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, under the auspices of which the "week" will be observed in two thousand communities.

Appointment of Captain Jean Delacour, secretary of the International Committee of Ornithologists and president of the International Committee for Bird Preservation, as consultant on the future development of the Bronx Zoo was announced yesterday by the New York Zoological Society.

THE literary farm problem looks a little less menacing this morning, thanks to George Sessions Perry. For hard as is the lot of the tenant farmer, it has not seemed to Mr. Perry dreary enough to warrant his omitting touches of humor from his novel of Texas farm life, "Hold Autumn in Your Hand."*

CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 26 -- Bills proposing to levy a 3 per cent gross receipts tax on Tennessee newspapers, magazines, periodicals and other publications and radio stations which are being operated for "commercial purposes" appear to be a dead issue in the State Assembly for the present at least.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 27 (AP) -- London at dawn today had passed its seventh successive night free from German raiders, but with the feeling commonly expressed that "Hitler is up to no good."

VICHY, Jan. 26 -- According to a statement by the Minister of Agriculture, Autumn planting, favored by excellent weather conditions, was carried out throughout France in complete fashion, despite difficulties.

City-wide operation of the Federal food stamp program, effective March 1, will enable needy families to spend $30,000,000 a year more on food, while cutting the administrative cost of distributing surplus commodities by $200,000 annually, Welfare Commssioner William Hodson declared yesterday in a report to Mayor La Guardia.

With national defense an influencing factor and changes varying according to locality, especially in the vicinity of military camps, building construction costs now are the highest since 1930. The increase in average cost during 1940, however, was moderate, in view of the larger volume of building and the present and prospective demand under the arms spending program, according to Lyle H. Olson, vice president of the American Appraisal Company.

Two thousand inquiries about the Defense Training Institute, which will open a twenty-week course at 375 Pearl Street, Brooklyn, on Feb. 3 to train 200 high school graduates as junior draftsmen and for other sub-professional work in the aircraft industry, have been received at the institute headquarters at 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, Manhattan, Professor Sampson K. Barrett, the director, revealed yesterday.
Walter P. Reuther, director, General Motors Department, U.A.W.A., in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES says:
ROME, Jan. 26 -- There has been no rioting in Milan or Turin and no German troops are pouring into Italy, it was officially announced here today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The American Municipal Association today proposed an expansion of facilities for the training of public employes to meet the needs of national preparedness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Committee consideration of and action upon the Administration's Lease-Lend Bill is again expected to be the chief business before Congress in the coming week, with consideration of other defense proposals probably occupying two Senate committees.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- "Supper money" allowances to reimburse employes for expenses incurred as a result of working overtime do not constitute remuneration for employment within the meaning of the State Unemployment Insurance Law, according to an interpretation announced today by Milton O. Loysen, executive director of the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance, Department of Labor.

With soft snow falling, a brilliant-hued Chinese dragon marched through the streets of Chinatown at midnight last night to usher in the Chinese New Year, marking the beginning of the year 4639 and celebrating the thirtieth anniversary of the Chinese Republic.

When Ernest Hemingway took his title "For Whom the Bell Tolls" from a passage of John Donne's a rush for the works of the English poet of the days of James I and Charles I began at the book stores. Random House, for instance, had a stock that ordinarily would have lasted well through 1941.

LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Wendell L. Willkie, showing the same exuberance as when he campaigned for the Presidency last Fall, arrived in England today. His spirits were so buoyant on the flight from Lisbon, Portugal, that he could not keep his seat.

BAYONNE, N.J., Jan. 26 -- Employes of the Babcock Wilcox Company, boiler manufacturers, will return to their jobs in the plant here at 7 A.M. tomorrow under terms of a strike settlement approved today at a union meeting. The strike, involving 450 men, was called by Local 439, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C.I.O. affiliate, on Jan. 3 and tied up work on Navy contracts.

CARVER, Mass., Jan. 26 -- Fishing into the pocket of his worn work trousers and bringing out a $1,000,015.25 government check, Andrew Paananen, Finnish-born cranberry farmer and part-time carpenter, ventured the opinion tonight that "there must have been some mistake" by the New Deal agency that sent him the check for sanding cranberry bogs.

In your editorial "Air-Raid Insurance" you state that the premium charged individual property owners is "at the annual rate of two shillings to the pound sterling of net valuation for five years in return for two years' insurance, You say: "This is equal to a premium of between 2 1/2 and 3 per cent."

TOKYO, Jan. 26 -- Declaring that President Roosevelt's most recent fireside talk and Secretary of State Cordell Hull's statement had disturbed world peace, Representative Yoshimichi Kuboi today, in a House Budget Committee meeting, demanded a reply to these declarations by Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Monday, Jan. 27 -- Count Stephen Csaky, Hungarian Foreign Minister, died at 2:34 o'clock this morning. Uremic poisoning was said to have been the immediate cause of death.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Fourteen Negro soldiers of Harlem's 369th Anti-Aircraft Regiment suffered burns or injuries tonight when fire following an explosion swept the supply wing of the administration building at Fort Ontario.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Analyzing the differences between this year's income tax payment and that of last year, a Treasury Department statement today said there were "two arresting facts in the 1940 income tax law," as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight attended what was referred to as a "command" performance of the Broadway comedy "Old Acquaintance," in which Jane Cowl and Peggy Wood had the starring roles.

BOSTON, Jan. 26 -- The sizzling Cunningham-Bonthron rivalry of seven years ago was one of the most memorable chapters in the history of track. But that series of thrillers may be pushed into the background before the current milers are finished with this campaign.

The Brooklyn Diocesan Council of Catholic Women was organized yesterday to cooperate with the National Catholic Welfare Conference in a program of home defense, including first-aid, in conjunction with the American Red Cross.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 26 -- Professor Eugen Steinach, a young man of 80, discoverer of the function of the hormone in what is popularly known as "rejuvenation," but which he persists in calling "reactivation" of the human body, enters his eighty-first year here tomorrow, far from his native Vienna, from which he is a voluntary exile "until better times come back to this earth."

As the British continue their advance from Tobruk, where sand storms delayed the assault, they have left the desert and come into one of the pleasantest and most ancient garden spots of the world. In fact, it was in this "evening land of the westward sun" that the old Greeks located the Gardens of the Hesperides.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- At least 1,200,000 men will be called to meet the selective service quota of 800,000 expected by July 1, because about 400,000 will be turned away owing to physical defects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Senate, without a trace of opposition, passed and sent to the White House today two measures to improve naval defenses. One provides $300,000,000 to protect Navy vessels against air attack and the second permits additional appointments to the Naval Academy.

BERLIN, Jan. 27 (UP) -- United States foreign policy is based on "false impressions and artificially created threats," an authorized Nazi informant said today, and totalitarian nations are wondering "where does the United States' Western Hemisphere really end."
Starting from Lisbon next Sunday morning, the Pan American Airways' Dixie Clipper will begin the first survey flight over the South Atlantic route recently authorized by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

Edwin Fisher, chairman of Barclays Bank, Ltd., of London, urged yesterday at its annual meeting that every individual in Great Britain save all he could for investment in government issues, even to the point of sacrifice, and warned that this method must be followed if the war were to be financed successfully and inflation avoided.

In his budget message the President declared that he was opposed to a tax policy "which restricts general consumption as long as unused capacity is available and as long as idle labor can be employed." This problem cannot be postponed, however, until we have actually reached full employment.

F.W. Hankins, assistant vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad in charge of motive power, has been appointed assistant vice president in charge of operation, it was announced yesterday. H.W. Jones, general superintendent of the Eastern Pennsylvania division at Harrisburg, becomes chief of motive power.

BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The American Academy of Arts and Sciences announced today that it had a prize of $4,000 for a European scientist in recognition of his achievements, but added that he was in a country "unhappily dominated by Nazi invaders" and would not collect the money immediately.

Many companies have started to prepare for the inevitable let-down when the defense program tapers off by searching for new products or hastening the development of those now in the laboratory, marketing research executives reported yesterday.

MONTREAL, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Bill Cowley, Boston Bruins' playmaker, added four assists to his total in Sunday night's game against the New York Americans and stretched his lead in the National Hockey League's scoring race to five points.

A net loss of $516,050 after all charges was reported yesterday by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries, exclusive of European, Mexican, cable and radiotelegraph units, for the first nine months of 1940. The net loss contrasted with a net income, restated for comparative purposes, of $1,118,438 in the first nine months of 1939.

Count Ciano assumed control of Italy's foreign policy when the country had emerged victorious from its Ethiopian campaign. It was a period marked by Italian successes in the diplomatic as well as the military field because many nations were anxious to wipe out the recollection of the roles they had played in the League of-Nations' imposition of economic sanctions.

Events tonight: "Louise," the Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15; the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, Ezio Pinza, soloist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Saidenberg Little Symphony, Daniel Saidenberg, conductor, Bela Bartok and Ditta Pasztory, soloists, Town Hall, 8:30; Gertrude Janssen, song recital, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30.
An around-the-clock snowfall that began Sunday night continued until early today, glazing the city streets with hard-packed slush that hardened into ice as the temperature dropped.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Governor Lehman provided in his budget tonight for $4,000,000 spent or to be spent on State defense, barring unforeseen developments.

OTTAWA, Jan. 27 (Canadian Press) -- More stringent measures to guard against escapes by Nazi prisoners and less consideration for personal comforts of German officers en route by train to internment camps in Canada were foreseen tonight as the result of five escapes last week.

THE savor of a savory State seasons the second volume of the autobiography of Josephus Daniels, "Editor in Politics."* So devoted has the North Carolina editor and present ambassador to Mexico been to the welfare of his State that he could hardly write about his own career without including a great deal about the State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Secretary Perkins's committee on defense bills sharply criticized today five model bills, designed to prevent sabotage of defense activities, which were drawn up by a Federal-State Conference on Law Enforcement Problems of National Defense.

An active campaign to raise funds for British war-relief work was planned yesterday at a meeting of the administrative committee of the American Labor party held at State headquarters in the Hotel Claridge, Forty-fourth Street and Broadway.

For such a vast metropolis, New York at times can be exasperatingly provincial. This narrowness in outlook is particularly evident in basketball discussions. To much of its citizenry New York is without question the nation's court capital. Perhaps it is, but there are worthy rivals for the honor, one of which is Philadelphia.

Under the auspices of a special committee of forty-five leaders in the Protestant, Catholic and Jewish faiths, many of them clergymen, a reception was tendered last night to Professor Abraham S. Yahuda, eminent biblical scholar and oriental expert, who recently arrived from London.

The strange lull in the bombardment of Britain makes Londoners more uneasy than the accustomed hail of fire and brimstone. Since time now runs against Hitler, they figure that any rest must be a prologue to the long-expected and long-deferred knockout blow he must deliver soon or not at all.

In an effort to bolster the forces of the New York Americans, cellar dwellers of the National Hockey League, Red Dutton yesterday effected the first big shake-up in his team since he took over the job of manager six years ago. He announced he was sending his regular goalie, Earl Robertson, and two spare wingmen, Johnny Sorrell and Fred Hunt, to the Springfield Indians of the American Hockey League.
BERLIN, Jan. 27 (AP) -- German troops passing through Milan en route to Southern Italy were reported today to have been heartily cheered yesterday by the Italian population.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Chairman George of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee tonight suggested three amendments to the lease-lend bill.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The House and Senate adjourned today out of respect to Representative Kenneth F. Simpson, who died Saturday night while on a week-end visit at his home in New York.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Allen Hall, Chicago, swamped Tiff Denton of Kansas City under a 50-to-29 score in forty innings today for his seventh straight victory in the world three-cushion billiard tournament. He is undefeated at the top.

A report on the condition of freight cars, issued yesterday by the Association of American Railroads, shows that the percentage in disrepair is being held to a low level. This is in conformity with the policy of the railroads to keep their rolling stock in a condition to meet all demands which may be made of them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Charges of larceny and unlawful removal of government documents were laid before a Federal grand jury today in the case of two men held for alleged theft of confidential personnel files from the Civil Service Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 -- Airplanes equipped with television, flying high above the battlefields and flashing what they see to General Headquarters, were pictured here tonight before the annual Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers by Dean Joseph W. Barker of the Columbia University School of Engineering.

"The Philadelphia Story," starring Katharine Hepburn, has broken all attendance records at the Radio City Music Hall and will equal the mark for a long-run engagement by beginning a sixth week this Thursday.

No one can understand the policy pursued during three critical years by Count Stephen Csaky, the Hungarian Foreign Minister who died yesterday, without knowing the terms and conditions whereby small nations manage to survive in Central Europe. They live mostly by their wits, by their skill and agility in balancing one great Power against another.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 -- Gino Rex Paul Codd's Widener Cup candidate, scored an easy, front-running triumph in the sixth race, the Pompano Purse, mile-and-a-furlong feature at Hialeah Park, today. The program was run under sunny skies.

Miss Valentine Edgar of the Rockaway H.C. went a round ahead of the field as she gained a berth in the final bracket of the women's Class B metropolitan squash racquets championship tournament at the Cosmopolitan Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission heard today in an all-day session, described as a "public conference," arguments pro and con on the recommendation made by its public utility division staff that compulsory competitive bidding for new issues of public utility securities be adopted by the commission.

The School Art League awarded medals yesterday to 103 high school pupils in all five boroughs for skill in draftsmanship and design at exercises in the auditorium of the Board of Education, 110 Livingston Street.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 28 -- British Royal Air Force bombers carried out what officials here called a successful attack on the industrial area of Hanover, in Northwestern Germany, some time between late Sunday night and early yesterday morning.
The elements joined organized skiing in welcoming the Chilean team on its arrival yesterday morning aboard the Grace liner Santa Elena for a two-month competitive tour of the United States.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Verne Marshal, chairman of the No Foreign War Committee, was served today with a Federal subpoena to appear Thursday before a District of Columbia grand jury.

A German submarine has sunk a ship carrying 500,000 doses of the new American influenza vaccine to England, the American Medical Association News said yesterday, according to The Associated Press. The date of the sinking and name of the ship were not given.

Mayor La Guardia will be a candidate for Mayor and the 1941 election will be "very hotly contested," David B. Costuma, Commissioner of Elections, forecast yesterday at a hearing before Lester B. Stone, assistant director of the budget. Mr. Costuma, a Republican, was explaining the need for a $482,220 increase in the 1941-42 budget request of the Board of Elections, which totals $2,366,934.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Congress leaders on the lease-lend bill, and with General Frank T. Hines of the Veterans' Administration and former Senator and Mrs. McAdoo. He canceled other appointments because of a cold.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 27 -- A six-inch snowfall modified but did not halt the Forty-fourth Division training program here today. The chief effect of the snowstorm that started last night and continued until mid-morning was to force postponement of the firing of 155 mm. howitzers by the 157th Field Artillery.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The abandonment of the 1 per cent emergency income tax, as recommended by Governor Lehman in his budget message to the Legislature tonight, would constitute the first substantial relief to New York State taxpayers in the past decade.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Debits to deposit accounts (except inter-bank accounts), as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Jan. 22, aggregated $9,331,000,000.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 27 -- A marked rally occurred today on the Bourse after last week's reaction with the rise being partly due to covering operations among the domestic stocks, which rose as much as 10 points on an increased trading volume.

BERLIN, Jan. 27 -- Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's most recent statement before the Japanese Parliament is commented on today by the German Foreign Office mouthpiece, DiplomatischPolitische Korrespondenz, which gives its full approval.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 27 -- Although the progress of the "New disorder" in Rumania and the movements of the German occupying forces in that country are being closely watched, the focus of attention for Turkey in the Balkans is now Bulgaria.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Retailers were warned today by A.R. Green, advertising director of B. Kuppenheimer Co., Inc., that it would be exceedingly unwise to "adopt a so-called all-wool policy" and publicize that fact, as a result of the recent enactment of the Federal wool labeling bill.
Clark Shaughnessy is afraid he may have helped create a football monster that will menace him and his Stanford team next season.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 (UP) -Too many Americans today are in the position of many Englishmen two years ago in inability to see the dangers ahead, the Assistant Secretary of War, Robert P. Patterson, told the Los Angeles Post of the Army Ordnance Association tonight.
