STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 27 -- Although the Germans have gracefully accepted Major Vidkun Quisling's scheme to form a Nordlund regiment or company to fight against Britain they have not entrusted the command of the unit to these allies.

Pairings for the relay program in the thirty-fourth annual Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night were announced yesterday by Meet Director Fred Schmertz. In the most promising line-up ever arranged for this meet, thirty-one teams from twenty-six schools and clubs will be in the various races.

There is reason to doubt that the Federal Reserve System will make very rapid progress in securing from Congress the extensive powers to increase bank reserve requirements which it asked for in its statement of Jan. 1. But the mere issuance of that statement has already produced some results.

The battle between Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, and the City Council committee investigating civil service was staged yesterday in new surroundings, with the roles of the participants reversed, but with the familiar accompaniment of name-calling, interruptions and general wrangling.

In a letter to THE TIMES Forrest A. Remington describes the tax-exemption of church property as "a great national abuse," and asserts that the time has now come "when this flagrant abuse should be ended."
BERLIN, Jan. 27 -- "Soldat" M. Schmeling still has a pretty high regard for the boxing ability of Max Schmeling, former world heavyweight champion.

PARIS, Jan. 11 (Delayed; Via Berlin) -- The Versailles monument, erected at Versailles in October, 1937, to the glory of the American Army and General John J. Pershing, is crumbling and the two equestrian statues representing General Pershing and General Lafayette are threatening to fall on passers-by.

BERLIN, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Members of the United States commission for the organization of relief in German-occupied territories arrived here today after a five-day tour of Belgium and a two-day trip through the Netherlands to study the food situation.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 27 (AP) -Federal Judge Thomas Glynn Walker reserved decision today after hearing a petition by minority stockholders of the Tobacco Products Corporation of Delaware for appointment of a receiver for the Tobacco Products Corporation of New Jersey, an affiliate.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Governor Lehman recommended to the Legislature tonight in his annual budget message abandonment of the emergency 1 per cent levy on personal incomes and a consequent reduction of $21,000,000 a year in income taxes.

Demand for most classes of traefer meats yesterday was only fair. But prices had a firmer undertone with the exception of pork loins, which were weak. Kosher beef and lamb prices were strong to $1 or more higher. Veal steady to strong. Weather conditions tended to retard trading. Conditions as reported by the Department of Agriculture follow:

HAVANA, Jan. 27 -- Harry C. Nye Jr. of Wilmette, Ill., representative of the Southern lake Michigan fleet, won the Bacardi Cup today by sailing his yacht Gale to a third straight triumph in the fifteenth annual International Star Class regatta.

In THE TIMES of Jan. 24 was a report from Washington by Charles Hurd concerning a conference between the Lumber and Timber Products Defense Committee and Leon Henderson. This interesting situation is worthy of careful analysis and investigation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 27 -- British troops advanced on four fronts in Africa today, in Libya, Eritrea, and Italian Somaliland, but the most important gains were around Agordat in Eritrea, where positions near Bisha fell to the British yesterday.

Further weakness developed in the cotton market yesterday and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 2 to 8 points net lower than on Saturday. The widest loss was in the January, which closed nominally at a decline of 8 points.

FORT ORD, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP) -A WPA worker was shot and seriously wounded when he rushed a sentry who caught the man trying to break into a box car on the reservation, Army Intelligence officers reported today.

Arthur Loesser, music critic of The Cleveland Press, and Beryl Rubinstein, director of the Cleveland Institute of Music, who began playing together on two pianos for the fun of it eight or nine years ago, gave their third New York recital as a two-piano team last night at the Town Hall.

A bright picture of the financial situation of McKesson Robbins, Inc., was drawn before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe in the course of testimony yesterday by William J. Wardall, trustee, and William J. Murray, vice president.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 27 -- More than 200 residents of Palm Beach and adjacent towns attended the Beefeaters of America dinner tonight at the Hotel Royal Worth. The organization is an auxiliary of the British-American Ambulance Corps, funds going to purchase amphibians for the rescue of British fliers from the English Channel.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (UP) -- The National Semi-Pro Baseball Congress announced tonight that the Federal Government will sponsor 16;500 sandlot baseball clubs at Army training camps, bringing the number of sandlot teams participating in the 1941 season to 80,000.
VICHY, France, Jan. 27 (UP) -Hostilities in the undeclared war between Thailand and French IndoChina will cease at 10 A.M. tomorrow, the French Government announced tonight.

TRENTON, Jan. 27 -- Civil suits were filed by the Department of Justice in the Federal District Court here today against twelve concerns accused of having entered into a combination to fixe prices of electric light bulbs. The court was asked to cancel patent licensing agreements under which, the complaints alleged, the defendant concerns fix prices, control the business of independent manufacturers and restrict production.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission today re ported 964 merchant vessels sunk or missing as a result of the war from Sept. 3, 1939, to Dec. 7, 1940. The gross tonnage aggregated 3,619,624.

The Garden City badminton team gained its fourth victory of the season by defeating Jamaica, 5 to 0, according to the results announced yesterday. The unbeaten winner is tied with Central for the lead in the Class A race of the Metropolitan Badminton Association.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -A picture of relief recipients re-frauding Westchester County and the State by concealing private earnings and bank accounts from slipshod investigators was drawn here today by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors special committee on welfare.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- More bewildered than a country boy on his first visit to the big city is the citizen who comes to Washington to deal with government. If he is in business his errand has been increasingly with the executive agencies and commissions which increasingly have been acting as prosecutor, investigator and judge of his case.

The Associated Equipment Distributors yesterday adopted a rental schedule for construction machinery at the closing session of their three-day annual convention at the Hotel Commodore. The association emphasized the point that the schedule was not intended to be price-fixing but merely a guide for construction dealers throughout the country, who are under no compulsion to adhere to it.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 27 -- They call them ridges, those very slight elevations where the palmetto growth is rank and the quail feed on ground oak, but the extent of their elevation over the surrounding terrain is about equal to that of a golf bunker over the fairway.

Herbert Hoover, chairman of the National Committee on Food for the Five Small Democracies, declared yesterday that a report cabled from Brussels by his investigators indicated Belgium faced imminent starvation because "major food supplies to maintain any Belgian ration will be non-existent in a month."

When our armed forces do not need the output of our firearms and ammunition factories those factories are kept from folding up by citizens who buy shotguns, rifles, pistols and ammunition for use on hunting trips and on rifle and pistol ranges.

S.G. Haskins of the Harvard Club, runner-up last year, started another campaign for the Class A metropolitan squash racquets championship yesterday by turning back E.R. Greeff of the Downtown A.C. as play opened at the Yale Club.

Mr. and Mrs. Georg U. Vetlesen gave a dinner last night at their home, 1 Beekman Place, for Crown Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway, who are at the Waldorf-Astoria during their visit here. Later Mr. and Mrs. Vetlesen took their guests to the performance of the Sonja Henie Hollywood Ice Revue at Madison Square Garden.

TRENTON, Jan. 27 -- Governor Charles Edison today chose Frederic R. Colie, prominent Newark lawyer, to succeed Supreme Court Justice Thomas W. Trenchard of this city, who resigned last week. The nomination was sent to the Senate tonight and confirmation at an early date is expected.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Trustworthy reports from Vichy have it that Pierre Laval soon will re-enter the Cabinet, from which he was ousted on Dec. 13, but not necessarily as Foreign Minister.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The text of Governor Lehman's budget message, sent to the Legislature today, is as follows:...

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 8 per cent for the week ended Jan. 25, in comparison with the like period a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, Outside Derna, Libya, Jan. 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- Italian artillery roared today in an effort to stem the British desert army's westward advance across Libya, but it appeared likely that its effort would accomplish no more than a delay in the fall of the town.

A $230,000,000 road construction program for national defense was called for yesterday by John M. Carmody, Administrator of the Federal Works Agency, in a message from his Washington headquarters to the opening session of the annual convention here of the American Road Builders Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Wheeler-Nye resolution calling on President Roosevelt to ask the warring nations to state their war aims, their peace terms and their secret treaties, if any, "for disposition of territorial spoils," was offered in the Senate today by Senator Nye, one of the leaders of the isolationist bloc.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Wendell L. Willkie, who arrived here last evening on a fact-finding expedition, covered London in whirlwind fashion today.

ATHENS, Jan. 27 -- For the sixth successive day General Ugo Cavallero, the Italian commander, tried to get his counter-attack rolling along the Central Albanian front. Two strong thrusts were made against newly captured Greek positions in the region running from the Viosa Valley, in the vicinity of Tepeleni, to the north beyond the Trebesina massif.

ROME, Jan. 27 -- The press today ridicules foreign reports of grave disorders in Turin and Milan. A Stefani communique prints some of the reports broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation yesterday and explains that it does so "in order to acquaint the Milanese and Turinese of what is happening in their respective cities."
The Savage Arms Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents a share. On Feb. 16 last year 25 cents a share was distributed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Authoritative campus sources said tonight that the University of Chicago, which abandoned intercollegiate football in December, 1939, has approached several small Midwest schools for 1941 games.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is opposed to suspension of the forty-hour week for workers in defense industries "as long as we have millions still unemployed."
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 27 -Miss Elizabeth Hicks of Pasadena, Calif., whipped out a startling 74 today that easily won the qualifying medal in the tenth annual Miami Biltmore tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The epidemic of colds and influenza which prevails in the capital reached the White House today and compelled President Roosevelt and three members of his staff to stop work.

BAYONNE, N.J., Jan. 27 -- This city has been chosen as the site for the proposed $10,000,000 super-dry-dock in New York Harbor, according to word received here today from Governor Charles Edison, under whose administration as Secretary of the Navy the project was advocated as a national defense measure last year.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Further indication that the Republican leaders have decided to wait until next year to reapportion Congressional and legislative districts came tonight when Chairman Carl E. Darling of the Assembly Reapportionment Committee introduced a resolution creating a special joint legislative committee to study the subject and report back by Feb. 1, 1942.

The creation of a national propaganda ministry urged by Dr. Harwood L. Childs, associate Professor of Politics at Princeton University, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 25, is so dangerous a proposal that I take public issue with his statement lest it go unanswered.

An event certainly unique in the history of the New York art world entered the calendar last evening, when at 6 o'clock a substantial part of the William Randolph Hearst collection was placed on view at Gimbals Department Store. It was an invitation affair last night, and the private view is scheduled to continue through tomorrow.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan 27 (UP) -- Premier Ion Antonescu today set up a new military regime for strife-torn Rumania and, from a sickbed, ordered sweeping reprisals that may send hundreds of Iron Guard rebels to death before army firing squads.
Stewards of the Grand Circuit held their annual meeting at the Prince George Hotel yesterday. They elected officers and arranged a tentative schedule of light-harness meetings for 1941.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The drug industry now is in a "much better position" to supply medicinal chemicals than during the World War, the first issue of "War Medicine" reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The prospect that some changes will be made in the lease-lend bill during its consideration by Congress was considered virtually certain as the result of a White House conference tonight when leaders of the Democratic and Republican forces in the legislative branch sought President Roosevelt's views on certain proposed amendments to the measure for aiding Britain and her allies.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 27 -The death of Count Stephen Csaky, the Hungarian Foreign Minister, early this morning is deeply mourned here, where he was a popular figure.

The operators of the ill-fated liner Morro Castle, who paid $890,000 to the heirs of 123 persons lost when the ship burned on Sept. 8, 1934, and to others who were injured, will not be able to recover damages from the insurers of the ship, according to a court ruling made yesterday.

Gold from South Africa, which arrived here last week on the United States cruiser Louisville, amounted to approximately $200,000,000 it was learned yesterday. The exact figure will not be reported officially until the Department of Commerce weekly gold figures covering the week ended on Jan. 29 are announced early next month.

The British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday that it had cabled $10,000 to the Royal Air Force Comforts Fund, in addition to $20,000 sent over the week-end to the R.A.F. Benevolent Fund. These donations followed closely the naming of the society by both funds as their official representative in the United States.

New problems facing the National Travelers Aid Association under the national defense program were outlined yesterday by Mrs. John Jay O'Connor, retiring president, in her annual report to the board of directors. The need for increased Travelers Aid service is emphasized daily at points where there is much travel by men hoping to enlist, civilian workmen and families, relatives and friends, she said.

VICHY, France, Jan. 27 -- By a Constitutional Act making all Ministers and other high public officials responsible directly to him for all their acts, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain tonight forestalled any possible recurrence of the controversy arising from his dismissal of his heir apparent, Pierre Laval.

Contract negotiations between the Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the five associations of employers have reached a complete deadlock over the so-called "efficiency clause," it was announced last night.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 27 -- Inaugurating the Regional Conference of The River Plate this afternoon, Dr. Alberto Guani, Uruguay's Foreign Minister, as president of the conference made a stirring speech in praise of democracy and expressing the hope that this assembly would be the forerunner of similar conferences in other regions of the Americas.

Various railroads reported yesterday increased earnings in 1940. In several cases the profits were the highest in approximately ten years. Some of the largest increases were shown by companies which had had only moderate earnings in recent years.

A radical departure from the generally accepted concept of the function of a utility service organization was proposed yesterday by the trustees in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Company system.

ROME, Jan. 27 -- The greatest political development of the war as regards Italy was announced late this evening in a laconic communique saying that the Foreign Minister, Count Ciano, had gone to the front.

With a plea for a positive approach to the world's problems, during which he remarked that Wendell L. Willkie, "in my judgment, is still the greatest living American," Oren Root Jr., organizer of the Willkie Clubs during the Presidential campaign, received yesterday the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce Distinguished Award.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- A $550,000 grant by the Civil Aeronautics Board for the construction of a Westchester County airport that would serve national defense was rejected unanimously this afternoon by the County Board of Supervisors because the allocation was considered inadequate.

One of the largest squads ever taken south by the Yankees will be training under Manager Joe McCarthy at their camp in St. Petersburg, Fla., next month. This was assured yesterday with the announcement that three athletes had been added to the group ordered to report at Huggins Field, making a total of thirty-eight.

Both France and Thailand have now accepted Japan's offer of mediation in the undeclared war in Cambodia. It is reported that an armistice has been arranged. The one present certainty of the situation is that Japan's interests will not suffer in the settlement.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 27 -- Announcement of the agreement by Broadcast Music, Inc., not to engage in practices which the government regards as in violation of the Sherman anti-trust law was made here also today by a representative of the Department of Justice in Federal court.
The annual report of S.H. Kress Co., made public yesterday, reveals a net profit for 1940 of $5,339,160 after depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other deductions.

The annual report of Incorporated Investors, issued yesterday, shows net assets as of Dec. 31, 1940, with investments carried at market quotations, amounted to $38,527,134, equal to $13,86 a share on 2,779,474 shares of capital stock outstanding. This compares with net assets of $39,208,076, equal to $13.73 a share on 2,855,093 shares on Sept. 30, 1940, and with net assets of $48,852,011, or $16.34 a share on 2,990,333 shares, at the close of 1939.

Henry H. Oshrin, theatrical attorney, who has a financial interest in "Tobacco Road," and has dabbled in the theatre on other occasions, aims to become a producer in his own right, having just acquired a farce written by Arthur Goodman and Gale Nandor (pseudonym).

Taxpayers will find good reading in Governor Lehman's annual budget message, sent to the Legislature yesterday. The recommended appropriations are $385,000,000, as compared with a total actually authorized last year of $394,000,000 -- a drop of $9,000,000 if the Governor's recommendations are adopted.

The World War caused a vast extension of the work of the Young Men's Christian Association, both in the field and at home. So now, as the American defense program expands, the Y.M. C.A. is stepping up its activities to meet the problems involved not only among the members of our citizen army but along the home front from which they will be drawn.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 27 -More than half the employees of the Phelps-Dodge Copper Products Corporation failed to return to work after their noon lunch hour here today in what was described as a "protest stoppage of work." The concern is executing orders for copper rods for the Navy.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 27 -Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt told a Yale freshman forum tonight that "the President could take over Mr. Ford tomorrow, if an emergency existed."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -While the House and Senate paid tribute today to Representative Simpson flags on the Capitol fluttered at half-staff in the rain.

Although the world heavyweight championship battle between Joe Louis, the titleholder, and Clarence (Red) Burman of Baltimore was still four days away, Promotor Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. yesterday entertained an offer for a return bout between the pair.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Maria Luisa Bombal, prominent Chilean writer, today shot and seriously wounded Eulogio Sanchez Errazuriz, noted engineer and founder of a secret republican militia. Senor Sanchez Errazuriz, shot at a busy intersection, fell wounded in the chest and abdomen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- S. Clay Williams, chairman of the board of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, is to be named the first American Minister to Great Britain unless President Roosevelt makes a last-minute change, it was reported here today.

Owing to a rush of applicants and the time required to select those to be admitted, the opening of the Defense Training Institute of the Engineering Colleges of Greater New York has been postponed from Feb. 3 to Feb. 10, it was announced yesterday.

Astrology has attained the dimensions of a public menace, in the opinion of Boston and Harvard scientists. Their local branch of the National Association of Scientific Workers has just approved a report which finds the astral cult harmful to scientific progress and to social psychology.

ROME, Jan. 27 (UP) -- It was not disclosed here tonight whether Count Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, sent to the front, would participate in Italian-Greek fighting in Albania or would be attached to the Italian forces in Libya or elsewhere in Africa.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Broadcast Music, Inc., the organization set up by the broadcasting companies recently in their fight against the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, has agreed to refrain from monopolistic practices barred under the anti-trust laws, the Department of Justice announced today.

Emphasizing that the war and economic depression are creating "enormous responsibilities" for the medical profession, Dr. Alfred M. Hellman urged last night that physicians keep an open mind that would see in proposed changes neither a move toward communism nor a blueprint toward salvation.

IT was touching to note the hopeful, dreamy look that came over the amiable countenance of stout Bill Brandt when he began to talk about -- of all things! -- the prospects of the Phillies in the coming National League campaign. Mr. Brandt is the man in charge of the propaganda department of the National League, and, within that circuit, is supposed to be neutral in dispensing his baseball facts, figures and fancies.

Although Augie Ruggiere, 32-year-old former pugilist, was declared the winner yesterday by a Bronx Supreme Court jury in the legal fisticuffs that have embroiled the Ruggiere family since Augie won $98,000 in the Irish Hospital Sweepstakes last April, there is still the little matter of Federal and State income taxes amounting to $52,000, to be paid.
A few days ago you published a dispatch from Vichy stating that the French claimed the air of "God Save the King" was stolen from the French and that the music was composed by Lulli.

Archduke Otto of Austria, head of the house of Habsburg, conferred yesterday afternoon with Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo, former President of the Dominican Republic, on plans for large scale settlement of European Catholics in the Dominican Republic, it was announced by the Dominican Republic Settlement Association.

WITH THE GREEK ARMY in Albania, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The appearance of German-type warplanes and a marked change in air tactics since the first of the year caused Greek officers today to speculate on whether Italian pilots are doing all the bombing against the Greeks on this front.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Secretary Hull was reported to have told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that long efforts to obtain mutual understanding and cooperation between the United States and Japan had been virtually fruitless.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- Joan Leslie, Warner's 16-year-old ingenue, vas named today as Gary Cooper's leading lady in "Sergeant York." She will appear as his sweetheart and later as his wife. Helen Wood, Tennessee radio actress, previously had been announced for the role.

Norman Cordon, American basso, who lost his first big chance as Mephistopheles at the Metropolitan Opera House by being ill when he was scheduled to appear on Christmas Day, got his second chance last night through the illness of Ezio Pinza.

IT was touching to note the hopeful, dreamy look that came over the amiable countenance of stout Bill Brandt when he began to talk about -- of all things! -- the prospects of the Phillies in the coming National League campaign. Mr. Brandt is the man in charge of the propaganda department of the National League, and, within that circuit, is supposed to be neutral in dispensing his baseball facts, figures and fancies.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 -- Bids on large quantities of underwear and other apparel and equipment items for the Army will be opened at the Quartermaster Depot here within the next two weeks. Among the principal items are 5,000,000 sleeveless Summer bleached undershirts, either flat or ribbed knit, and 5,000,000 cotton drawers (shorts), bids on which will be opened on Feb. 6.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Viscount Halifax declared at a press conference in the British Embassy late today that Great Britain's first aim was to win the war, for without that achievement the rest would be academic. But Britain's peace aim after victory was won, he stated, was to join with others in so reconstructing the world that there will not have to be another war.
The Teachers Union of New York City supplied its membership lists yesterday to the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the public schools.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The condition statement of weekly report ing member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 22: An increase of $195,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and decreases of $88,000,000 in United States Government deposits and $51,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

Norman Cordon, American basso, who lost his first big chance as Mephistopheles at the Metropolitan Opera House by being ill when he was scheduled to appear on Christmas Day, got his second chance last night through the illness of Ezio Pinza.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The application of Aviation and Transportation Corporation for an order exempting from Section 17(a) of the Investment Company Act its proposed sale to its controlled company, Aviation Corporation, of all its assets other than its holdings of Aviation Corporation stock was approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

Continuance of the active dry goods buying that got under way last week with the arrival of wholesale buyers brought a stronger tone to finished goods in many lines yesterday. Of interest to many buyers was the fact that some selling houses began to quote unbranded muslin sheets at 35 per cent off the standard list, rather than 37 1/2 per cent.

A total of 10,644 men, of whom 599 are Negroes, will make up the fifth selective service requisition for New York, New Jersey and Delaware, it was announced last night from the Governors Island headquarters of Brig. Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, commander of the Second Corps Area, which comprises the three States.

A banking group headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company won yesterday the awards of four issues of United States Housing Authority notes aggregating $5,255,000. Another issue of $3,850,00O was postponed owing to a legal technicality in the advertising for bids.

The character of Yehudi Menuhin's violin playing was strangely contrasted in his recital at Carnegie Hall last night. He seemed to be almost two different violinists in the course of the evening. At the beginning his playing was tame and lustreless and thoroughly surprising from a musician of his attainments.

Mayor La Guardia was master of ceremonies yesterday morning at the public incineration of scores of copies of twelve lewd magazines and 700 copper engravings of drawings that appeared in them. The public burning took place behind the Municipal Building, on Duane Street, amid cheers of hundreds of spectators who had been attracted by the unusual sight.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 27 -- William E. Sewell, Hudson County's Republican Superintendent of Elections, asked the Supreme Court here today to order the Board of Freeholders to grant his $500,000 budget request for this year in full. Counsel for the board argued that the sum was not justified and that the plaintiff should have applied first to the State Local Government Commissioner.
TOKYO, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Replying to a question today in the House Budget Committee Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye declared:...

The American Museum of Health has leased from the city the $250,000 former Masterpieces of Art Building in Flushing Meadow Park, and after extensive repairs will open the structure with the nation's first permanent health exhibit.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 27 -- The German Army in Italy has assumed complete control of all censorship and all communications in Milan and Turin, where German soldiers and secret police have suppressed, at least momentarily, rioting and demonstrations, it is learned here tonight from foreign military sources and from Rakek, Italy, on the Yugoslav frontier.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A communique of the British Middle East Command said today:

Miss Sarah Jane Fraser, chairman of the debutante committee for the performance of "Louise" tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House in behalf of the Children's Aid Society, will give a dinner in advance of the benefit for her aides, who will wear costumes from "Louise" and will sell corsages and boutonnieres at the performance.

Extremely sharp gains in electrical appliance sales were indicated for this year at the first national convention of the Retail Development League of the General Electric Company which began yesterday at the Hotel Astor. Increases ranging up to 50 per cent over last year were mentioned.

The latest rule adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act whereby registered holding companies' petroleum, real estate and natural gas operations are exempted from certain provisions of the act appears to be a realistic approach to a most perplexing problem.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 (UP) -- A rare 125-year-old picture medal commemorating the victories of the Duke of Wellington in the Peninsular War has been offered by the Duke of Windsor 'for auction at the President's birthday ball here Friday.

The Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia had new paid business of $70,118,000 in 1940, an increase of 5 per cent over 1939, M.A. Linton, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of policy owners.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 28 -- The House of Representatives cheered last night when Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye gave his pledge that he would remain as Premier until the China war was concluded. The Premier was answering a question from Shoichi Miyake, who said that frequent changes in the Cabinet were producing bad effects.

Steel operations this week will bring steel production to a new high weekly record of 1,567,100 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, compared with 1,557,400 net tons last week, the previous record. This will be the fourth consecutive week in which previous records have been eclipsed.

Charles Lauwers, 28 years old, formerly a student of journalism at New York University, who left the United States in 1933 as a cook on the Holland-America liner Statendam, returned yesterday as head of a shoe and clothing factory in the Belgian Congo.

The J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation announced yesterday that coupons due on Feb. 1, 1941, on State Loan of the Kingdom of Hungary, 1924, dollar tranche bonds enfaced in evidence of acceptance of the conditions set forth in the memorandum of Sept. 17, 1937, might be presented for payment on and after that date at the rate of 4 1/2 per cent a year.

Dr. William Lyon Phelps has been appointed director of the Hall of Fame for Great Americans on the campus of New York University. Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the university, announced yesterday after a meeting of the N.Y.U. Council.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 -- The liner Empress of Australia, reported in service recently as a British troop transport, radioed tonight she had been torpedoed and shelled off the West African coast, then she suddenly became silent.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Tass, official Soviet news agency, reported today in a dispatch from Chungking, China, that the Chinese Government's dissolution of its Fourth Army was directed against Communist elements and might lead to civil war in China.

The Saidenberg Little Symphony, in its first local recital last night at Town Hall, gave New York a taste of the musical fare which it has been giving Chicago for the last five seasons. And very welcome the visitors were, for the music chosen and the string orchestra were both good.

There were 132 new cases of influenza in New York City in the twenty-four hours ended at 9 A.M. yesterday, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported. This brings to 206 the total of new "flu" cases reported in the three days since 9 A.M. last Saturday, a daily average of sixty-nine cases. At this time last week, the daily average was fifty-seven cases.

The second of the three private showings of art from the William Randolph Hearst collection was attended by a large and distinguished gathering last evening at the Gimbel Brothers department store Broadway and Thirty-third Street.

Challenging the "brute force" of dictators, Mayor La Guardia, speaking at the Music and Art High School commencement exercises yesterday, told the 1,200 students and parents present that the "destruction of dictatorships is assured."

Securities and Exchange Commission hearings on the New York Stock Exchange's prohibition of multiple trading by its members continue in Washington. Nothing, perhaps, has been so important as one development of the first day, when counsel for the Exchange tried to get the SEC commissioners to reveal which of the thirteen parts of Section 19-b of the 1934 Act was being applied in the hearings.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 28 -- Colonel Philip B. Fleming, Federal Wage-Hour Administrator apologized "publicly and ungrudgingly" today to Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of the General Motors Corporation, for having "misunderstood his attitude" toward the Wage-Hour Law, specifically with respect to payment for overtime work.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Acting to quiet reports to the contrary, the State Racing Commission reasserted today after a conference with track promoters that horse racing would return to New Jersey this year.

The three-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 271 Goldsmith Avenue, Newark, N.J., has been sold by David S. Meister to an investing client of Louis Smith, broker. Sale was for cash above an $80,000 first mortgage held by the Prudential Insurance Company.

A conspiracy to fix prices and production quotas, thus reducing competition in the rug and carpet industry, was charged yesterday to fourteen leading manufacturing concerns, an officer of each, and the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, Inc.

The seedings and arrangements for the running of the three feature short-distance events, the 60-yard dash, 60-yard high hurdles and the 300-yard run, on the program of the thirty-fourth annual Millrose Games to be held in Madison Square Garden Saturday night, were announced yesterday.

In completing plans for their thirty-fifth annual ball, which will be held next Wednesday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, officers and members of the Republican Club of the Fifteenth Assembly District have arranged a varied evening's entertainment highlighted by a Latin-American theme.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 28 (UP) -Vice Premier H.H. Kung said in an interview today that 1941 would be "China's victory year" and expressed the belief that the coming Spring would bring a definite turn in world affairs.
ROME, Jan. 28 -- Two more Italian Ministers have joined the group of fighting politicians, leaving the government with half of its cabinet posts vacant, it was announced this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Roosevelt was sufficiently recovered from a cold to confer with Sir Walter Citrine, secretary of the British Congress of Labor, and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who presented to the President a birthday cake on behalf of the International Confectionery Workers Union.

In Governor Edison's inaugural address, admirable in its general spirit and most of its concrete recommendations, one suggestion seemed doubtful. This was the proposal that in places with a population of more than 25,000 the introduction of voting machines should be submitted to a referendum.
LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The British Air Ministry and Ministry of Home Security issued this communique tonight:

A hard-hitting young Princeton graduate from the Downtown A.C. eliminated the fourth-ranking favorite from the Class A championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association last night at the Yale Club.

An American who believes in America is struck with wonderment by the apparent lack of faith in our own country which is implied in the outpourings of many of the persons who write and talk about America's relation to the present war. They appear to take almost for granted that the United States would collapse like a house of cards under stress of the aggressive propagandist, economic, military onslaught which they direfully prophesy.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- A company of young American singers directed by an American conductor gave a searching, sensitively wrought performance of Debussy's "Pelleas and Melisande" at the Academy of Music here tonight. It was the first performance of this work in English in this country, according to records at hand.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The first phase of a hard-fought struggle over the New York Stock Exchange's ban on multiple trading ended today when the Securities and Exchange Commission finished presenting evidence on the subject.

By dint of some memory-taxing at Farrar Rinehart, it is figured that the novel "Delilah," published and reviewed today, has been twenty years in the making. Philip Wylie introduced Marcus Goodrich to John Farrar and Stanley Rinehart many years ago, but they say the author had "Delilah" on his mind as far back as his post-war expatriate days in Paris.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 28 -- The dull thunderclaps of 155 mm. shells boomed across the snow covered fields of Fort Dix today and the explosions ripped dark blemishes in the whiteness on the artillery range impact area. The 157th Field Artillery, commanded by Colonel Richard P. Hartdegen, was firing service ammunition in its howitzers for the first time in two years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Expanded domestic markets for United States farm products, which compensated in part for lost foreign outlets, were shown in the annual report on surplus removal and marketing agreements activities in the last fiscal year made today by the Surplus Marketing Administration.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Looming as a big threat in the $10,000 San Vincente Stakes Saturday, Breckinridge Long's Nasca came from far behind today to win the $2,500 Inglewood Purse, the featured race at Santa Anita Park.

In an urgent request yesterday to banks, bankers and brokers, not to comply with insistent demands from the German-occupied Netherlands for detailed statements and data concerning accounts held in the United States for corporations and individuals domiciled in the occupied territory, B. Kleijn Molekamp, commercial counselor of the Netherlands Legation, indicated that such demands are not only illegal but are inimical to the interests of the true owners and of the Royal Netherlands Government.

ATHENS, Greece, Jan. 28 -- No Italian counter-attacks were reported today for the first time in a week. The Italians have been carefully feeling out the strength of the Greek lines all over the front, but so far they have apparently failed to discover any weak point.

Asserting that there "is a limit to the time which human beings can stand continuous bombings." Griffith Brewer, president of the Royal Aeronautical Society of Great Britain, last night urged the United States to give speedier help to England "while it would still be of practical use."

In 1927 the voters of this State approved a proposal to spend $300,000,000 of bond money to eliminate grade crossings. Last year the Legislature voted for the proposal to transfer $60,000,000 of this authorization to funds for highways and parkways. The reason is that grade crossings are now a lesser menace, while the dangers of congested and obsolescent highways are a major menace.

Quite apart from their purchases of Government securities, the commercial banks of the country are playing an increasingly large role in the financing of the national defense effort. Evidence of this has been accumulating in the weekly statistics of the Federal Reserve member banks in 101 leading cities of the country.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Whirlaway, Our Boots and Bold Irishman, voted one, two, three among the 1940 2-year-olds, topped a field of fifty-four eligibles nominated today for the $50,000-added Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on May 10.

The number of out-of-town buyers registered in the market last week was 1,000, as against 1,340 in the preceding week and 947 in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals were 351, which compared with 641 for a week ago.

With unfilled orders on the books of the United States Steel Corporation equal to three months' shipments at present rates of delivery, or about 4,600,000 net tons of finished steel products, the demand for steel thus far in 1941 has continued to exceed the rate of shipment, although somewhat below the high levels prevailing in December, Irving S. Olds, chairman, said yesterday after a meeting of the board of directors of the corporation.

The strength of national defense was seen yesterday as dependent not on the quantity of massed men, like the armies of totalitarian countries, but rather in the quality of man power needed to direct and operate more efficiently the machines of modern warfare.

BERLIN, Jan. 28 -- A combination of blockade by sea and bombing attacks by air was described by Grand Admiral Erich Raeder, Commander in Chief of the German Navy, as the method by which Britain would be reduced "until the hour of decision," that would end the war victoriously for Germany.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Wendell L. Willkie, who is here on what he calls a private trip, spent a busy time again today conferring at length with high government officials and notables in other circles as well as eagerly collecting every scrap of information possible on all phases of Great Britain's war effort.

ROME, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Italian troops have driven back a British column in fighting east of Derna, Libya, inflicting losses on the invaders and capturing prisoners, the Italian High Command reported today.

Leasing of many stores for immediate or Spring occupancy and contracts for office space for the United Palestine Appeal of Greater New York, the New York City Housing Authority and other well-known agencies were included in the long lists of business rentals reported by brokers yesterday.

Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands is beginning a broad inquiry into charges of Communist influence in the Department of Welfare, it was disclosed yesterday at the opening of a trial before Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church, at which it was charged that 600 Communists are employed as social investigators and two supervisors were named as Communists.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 28 -Partial suspension of the most-favored-nation clause and organization of a customs union are contemplated in six projects presented by the Argentine delegation at the Regional Conference of the River Plate this afternoon.

Governor Lehman's proposed budget evoked from realty men yesterday expressions of satisfaction at the prospect of a reduction in the total expenditure, and complaints that appropriations for many departments had been increased.

Your editorial pointing out that the emergency which necessitated the original mortgage moratorium law has long since passed and that there are evidences of a need for revision of it fails to note several important factors in the situation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 28 -- General Charles de Gaulle's "Free French" forces, sweeping 825 miles across the wildest wastes of the Eastern Sahara, have driven into the heart of Italian Libya from the south and annihilated Fascist forces at the oasis of Murzuk, it was announced tonight.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- While taxpayers' groups generally welcomed today Governor Lehman's budget recommendation for a reduction in personal income taxes, through elimination of the emergency 1 per cent levy, amounting to $21,000,000, they insisted that the proposed decrease did not go far enough.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- British pressure is being exerted on the United States to stop any leaks in essential war supplies, such as cotton, reaching Germany by way of Russia, but with what result was not immediately apparent today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Nine of the country's more important paint and varnish manufacturers reported consolidated sales in 1939 of $155,515,913 or about 36 per cent of the total value of all such products produced in that year, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

BOSTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins' famed Kitchener line furnished them with the needed edge tonight to pin a 3 -- 2 defeat on the surging Chicago Black Hawks before 13,000 spectators at the Boston Garden, running the Boston unbeaten string to fourteen straight.

College basketball returns to Madison Square Garden tonight after a two-week lull, with an intersectional double-header that will send St. Francis College of Brooklyn against Rhode Island State and Long Island University against Butler of Indiana.

The preliminary report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and its subsidiaries for 1940, released yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $13,048,510 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. The net was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 12 cents each on 33,673,327 shares of common stock and compared with a net of $13,413,636, or 13 cents a common share, in 1939.

Establishment of a priorities board for non-ferrous metals, the first to be set up on a non-voluntary basis, was reported in the local metals market yesterday. According to the information received here but unconfirmed in Washington, all plans for the creation of the board have been completed but the recommendation has not yet cleared through the Office Production Management.

It is encouraging to find Republicans, as well as Democrats, conferring at the White House with President Roosevelt regarding possible modifications of the lease-lend bill. House majority leaders have already indicated acceptance of certain changes; others will doubtless be proposed.
The Hollywood Ice Revue, starring Miss Sonja Henie, closed last, night at Madison Square Garden with its eighth performance, setting a new attendance record for a spectacle of this kind.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company, in an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission declared that its application for exemption from the Public Utility Holding Company Act was submitted in good faith.

PARIS, Jan. 23 (Delayed; via Berlin) -That France will have to make up her mind regarding her relations with Germany within a few weeks or perhaps even a few days is the conviction in Paris political circles.

ROME, Jan. 28 -- The mentality of the American people is so "infantile" as to be "touching," the Aroi, mouthpiece of the Foreign Ministry, said today in a note branding as "pure invention" reports of disorders in North Italy sent by American correspondents to the United States.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Not pounds, not ounces, not feet, but one-quarter of an inch will decide who will claim the coveted Rea Trophy in the annual Silver Sailfish Derby that is now in full cry at this fishing port, providing, of course, that no larger sailfish are taken between this date and the closing of the tournament.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- The Federal Labeling Act was strongly defended by Eugene Ackerman of the National Wool Growers Association as justifiable from the viewpoint of both the wool grower and the consumer and as unlikely to disturb the fabrics markets in normal times.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., seeking his fourth straight Winter triumph, clowned through his first two matches in the University of Miami invitation tennis tournament today.

ROME, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Giornale d'Italia announced today that Italy would retaliate to British "lies" about disorders in Italian cities with a radio counter-offensive of "authentic anti-British news."

Our Government has expressed its sympathetic interest in the Regional Conference of the River Plate by the appointment of official observers at the sessions now being held in Montevideo. The conference hopes to compensate, at least in part, for the loss of European markets by formulating methods of trade between Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -In response to the defense needs of this country and Britain, the American aircraft manufacturing industry in 1940 more than doubled the value of its outpout of planes, engines and propellers, Colonel John H. Jouett, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, nc., reported today.

Leo J. Alexander, 52 years old, an insurance broker of 15 Central Park West, went to trial in General Sessions yesterday on first and second degree manslaughter indictments in the deaths of seven Chinese in a lodging house blaze in Chinatown in the early morning of June 14, 1989.

PANAMA, Jan. 28 -- President Arnulfo Arias signed an order today deporting Edward William (Ted) Scott, editor of the English section of the newspaper Panama American and author of the column, "Interesting If True."

The ten-acre vacant tract at Demott and Frances Avenues, near Rockville Centre, L.I., has been sold through Joseph P. Day to Rockwin Builders, Inc., and will be improved with sixty homes. The property, which was sold by the Keller estate and the E.W.M. Company, Inc., is opposite the old Strathmore development and is one of the last large undeveloped holdings in that area.
Police Inspector Matthew J. McGrath, former Olympic weight-throwing champion, died at 1:35 o'clock this morning in St. Clare's Hospital, 415 West Fifty-first Street. He was 64 years old.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 28 -- While the British armies strengthened their positions in both Libya and Eritrea today, the Royal Air Force continued to attack Italian communications, stores and airdromes. The Eritrean railway between Agordat and Asmara was bombed at two points, Cheren and Adarte.

In all the speculation as to the successor of Justice McReynolds there appears the assumption that the President will appoint some member of his political coterie. Many citizens hope he will not do this.

William Lyon Phelps has moved so long among the famous of his own and other days that he was an obvious choice to head the Hall of Fame. His appointment is one which his friend Dr. John H. Finley, whom he succeeds as director, would have warmly approved.

ROME, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Fascist mass demonstrations marked by anti-American booing and shouts of "Viva Hitler!" were staged in Italy's northern cities of Milan, Turin and Verona today. The demonstrations, directed by Fascist party leaders, were organized as a reply to reports abroad of rioting there between Italians and German troops.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Real estate men throughout the nation are organizing as a group to make a national survey of industrial facilities to meet needs arising from the defense program.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Colonel and Mrs. Harold A. Braman entertained with a dinner at their residence, having Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Worswick, Mr. and Mrs. John H. Morice, Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran, Mrs. Dorsey Cullen, Noel Chamberlain, Pendleton Beckley.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 28 -- Joseph Spell, who is on trial in Superior Court on a charge of assaulting Mrs. John K. Strubing Jr. on Dec. 10, testified today that during the night of the alleged assault he at no time resorted to force or intimidation in his relations with her.

The Joint Dress Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union proposed to the five employer associations yesterday a two-week extension of the current collective agreement expiring next Friday, to permit further negotiations on the union's "efficiency" clause proposal.

We appeal to your readers to help the Lighthouse give adequate service to the blind of our city for 1941. Blindness is a handicap so severe that it renders a person almost helpless when it comes. Understanding and kindly care is necessary to give the training and encouragement needed to make the individual again self-dependent and hopeful.

Georgia O'Keeffe has brought her most recent work to An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue, where it will continue to be shown until March 11. All of the paintings save two were done in 1940, the exceptions being a very delicate "Gray Hills, Ghost Ranch," of three years ago, and another New Mexican subject, contrastingly bold in its powerful simplified treatment of earth forms, painted about a year earlier.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- Bids on 2,000,000 bleached cotton bed sheets for the Army were opened at the Quartermaster Depot here today with sixteen firms offering 3,633,000 at prices showing little change from late Fall quotations. Six items were included in the opening, bidders having the option of making their own choice.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The Daily Worker, Communist organ, which had been suppressed with The Week under the defense regulations, had its day in Parliament, if not in court, today.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 28 -- Again the cheerful tone prevailed on today's Bourse, partly because of favorable Dutch-Indies export figures which generally showed an increase in trading volume. Dutch issues closed at the day's best levels; as much as 12 points higher.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A British headquarters communique issued at Cairo today follows:

Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley of the Bronx asked Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick yesterday to make a "complete investigation" of all charges against the budget of the Law Department for the hire of experts, stenographers and special counsel, as covered by three budget items totaling $330,001.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Disapproval of proposals for anti-strike legislation by Congress was expressed today by the Committee on Manufacture of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States in a report which will be submitted to members of the chamber for concurrence or rejection.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The most exact studies so far made on the composition of the atmosphere of Mars show that it contains less than one-twentieth as much water vapor as does the atmosphere of the earth, the Carnegie Institution of Washington announced today.
ROME, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

ATHENS, Wednesday, Jan. 29 (UP) -- A large-scale Greek offensive, launched as the war with Italy entered its fourth month, early today was reported moving forward along a seventy-five-mile-long front, with Greek troops rushing through Italian barbed-wire entanglements in fierce bayonet charges.

Public offering will be made today of a block of 3,018,689 shares of Libby, McNeill Libby common stock, priced at $6 7/8 a share. All of this stock formerly was owned by Swift Co., so that the offering does not constitute new financing on the part of the company.

The Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B 1940-41 race ended on six fronts last night with the Downtown A.C. team the new champion and second-place honors going to the Cornell Club. Downtown clinched the title last week, but the runner-up post wasn't really decided until the outcome of the Cornell Club-Princeton Club snatches, that were taken by the former, 5 to 0, on the Squash Club courts.

Scene painters working for $18 daily have pushed through union legislation enabling them to do the work of scenic designers whose minimum scale for a three-set show is $1,000, it was charged last night by designers belonging to the United Scenic Artists, an A.F. of L. affiliate.

WE have been hearing a good deal about the sea-borne story of Delilah. Full-rigged models of her have been sailing across landlocked desks. The long, paper-strewn ground-swells of lit'ry intelligence have been bringing in by no means unenthusiastic bits of information about that fighting ship for some time. The pundits said her story was worth hearing, and they were right.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The population of the country is steadily growing older, the Census Bureau reported today.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 28 (AP) -Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek said today his action in dissolving the Communist new Fourth Chinese Army was solely to preserve military discipline and was not prompted by political considerations.

A vigorous denial that Marshal Rodolfo Graziani "is about to be sacked" was broadcast by the official Italian radio yesterday and recorded at the Columbia Broadcasting System's short-wave listening station.

Midday firmness in the stock market gave way yesterday to an easier tendency which embraced all groups, but the losses were well held in check and came when the moderate advance failed to attract fresh buying. Volume was 467,730 shares, against 357,920 on Monday, and made the session the most active since last Wednesday.

COPENHAGEN, German-Occupied Denmark, Jan. 28 -- Following the sentencing of Lieut. Col. T.P.A. Oerum of the Danish Air Force to life imprisonment for espionage after he was caught in a Berlin airport when posing as a passenger in a plane en route to Portugal, three others accused in the same case were dealt with, it was learned today.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Conversations aimed at establishing a united Anglo-American economic front against the Axis are proceeding both here and in Washington. It is known that the views of Harry L. Hopkins, President Roosevelt's personal emissary, have been sought in this connection during his visit here.

Adjustments entering into the computation of excess profits net income which are common to both the income credit method and the invested capital credit method, although stated separately in the law (Section 711 (a) (1) subparagraphs (A) to (F) and Section 711(a) (2) subparagraphs (C) to (E)), are consolidated in the excess profits-tax return (Form 1121).

Clarence (Red) Burman, Baltimore heavyweight, yesterday concluded training for the most important ring engagement of his career. Three rounds of sparring featured his final hard workout for the scheduled fifteen-round bout with Joe Louis, world heavyweight titleholder, Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Industries which reach an agreement, at the request of the National Defense Advisory Commission, on prices of materials needed for national defense will not be prosecuted under anti-trust laws, high Administration officials stated today.

"Land of Liberty" will open this morning at Loew's Criterion. Assembled from 2,000,000 feet of film under the direction of Cecil B. De Mille, the picture traces chronologically the history of America as told on the screen in the last twenty-five years.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Prices of wheat declined 1/2 to 5/8 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade here today and closed at the bottom and in new low ground on the current downturn. Local and commission house selling, especially the latter, were responsible for the easiness, and some stop-loss orders were uncovered late in the session.

Dr. Philip F. Hoffman has sold the property on the southeast corner of Mamaroneck Avenue and East Post Road, White Plains, where he has lived for twenty years, to an investing firm which plans to demolish the dwelling and use the site for a business building adapted to the needs of the ultimate tenant.

Results of test campaigns, instituted three months ago for Aspertane, a new headache remedy, have been so successful that the Blackstone Products Company has set up a $250,000 advertising budget for campaigns on the Pacific Coast, Chicago and New York.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, IN ERITREA, Jan. 24 (delayed) (UP) -- British forces are advancing an average of eleven miles a day through Italian Eritrea in a two-pronged drive toward the Red Sea and already have captured more than 700 Italian troops, including a brigadier general.
The United States liner America will sail tonight with a capacity list of 800 passengers on her first trip to California ports via Havana, the Panama Canal, and Acapulco, Mexico.

Railroads continued to report good showings for 1940 yesterday. While in the case of the Boston Maine an apparent large increase in net income in 1940 resulted from the operation of an adjustment plan, the Southern reported substantial increases both for December and the twelve months.

The speedy passage of the Lease-Lend Bill was urged here yesterday by Thomas W. Lamont, executive head of J.P. Morgan Co., without regard to "the form of bookkeeping to be adopted, be it lend, lease or gift, or all three."

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A strike tying up work on a $1,550,000 expansion program at Wright Field, the Army Air Corps testing laboratory, was ordered tonight by John Breidenbach, president of the Dayton Building Trades Council.

Action against over-the-counter firms under certain sections of the Securities and Exchange Act which more or less parallel the inoperative Rule X-10-B-4 of the Securities and Exchange Commission were discussed by Seymour M. Heilbron in an address yesterday afternoon before the New York Security Dealers Association.

Ezio Pinza, Italian basso, and Jarmila Novotna, Czecho-Slovak soprano, have withdrawn from the cast of Dr. Walter Damrosch's opera, "Cyrano de Bergerac," in which they were to have sung the roles of Cyrano and Roxane on Feb. 20 and 21.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 28 -- Just before the beginning of a German broadcast from Oslo Sunday afternoon the radio station electric current was mysteriously cut off in Oslo and the whole Oestland Province, and it took several hours before the damage could be repaired and the radio as well as the lighting system, tramways and electric trains could function, according to information received here today.
A furnished apartment in 7 East Fifty-fourth Street has been leased to Harlan Logan, general manager of Look, Inc., through Butler Baldwin, Inc., borkers, it was announced yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 28 -There is extensive speculation in Shanghai regarding reports from the south that large Japanese naval forces are at present patrolling off French Indo-China. This Japanese fleet is reported to consist of three cruisers, three torpedo boats and one aircraft carrier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- An effort to induce primary contractors of defense materials to "farm out" their orders among a large number of small plants, including those now being surveyed by the National Association of Manufacturers, will be made by a new division of the Office of Production Management.

Willie Mosconi strengthened his lead in the Pocket Billiard League world championship by taking two blocks from Erwin Rudolph at Doyle's yesterday. Mosconi overwhelmed his foe, 125 to 16, in the first game, which lasted only six innings.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- An electrical power system proof against bombs from above and saboteurs from within, which is being installed at the Portsmouth Navy Yard, was described today before the Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers by C.A. Powel and H.G. Barnett of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.

Wendell L. Willkie was urged yesterday as the Republican candidate for the late Kenneth F. Simpson's Congressional seat by Harvey J. Schwamm, new Republican leader of the Seventh Assembly District, one of the largest units in the Congressional district.

Yesterday's market was slow to only fair for most classes, particularly on steer hinds and ribs, with some sales 50c or more lower. Veal and lamb values were steady to firm, due to a light kill. Kosher steer beef was about steady, although trading was of the usual light Tuesday volume. Kosher lamb and veal prices were steady to firm.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Philip Murray asserted today that the present national defense machinery was incapable of achieving the coordination of the entire iron, steel and tin industry which was urgently required to assure adequate supplies for civilian and military needs.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,599,100 barrels daily, a decline of 12,800 from the 3,611,900 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 8,100 barrels more than the calculation of 3,591,000 daily for January by the Bureau of Mines.

Joseph B. Eastman, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, declared yesterday in an address on the commission's administration of the Transportation Act of 1940, which give to it regulatory control over domestic shipping, that regulating rates and charges would be the body's most formidable task in the future.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 28 -- The chief feature of today's sessions of the convention of the Association of Junior Leagues was a luncheon address by Erika Mann, daughter of Thomas Mann, exiled German author, who gave her views of the position of the United States in the world situation.
BERLIN, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 23 shows the following changes for the week, in thousands of marks:

TOKYO, Jan. 28 -A suggestion that Japan should abandon negotiations with the Netherlands Indies because of the colonial government's stubborn attitude was rejected in Parliament today by Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka. The idea that threats could be employed instead of negotiation was evidently in the interpellator's mind but Mr. Matsuoka knows that physical conditions make it exceedingly difficult for Japan to use any weapon except diplomacy at present.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) -British naval authorities announced tersely today that the big war-converted liner Empress of Australia is "safe in port," and one source suggested that radio messages reporting her torpedoed and shelled might have been "a German trick."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Secretary Morgenthau told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that Great Britain, Greece and China could not continue to fight unless Congress passed the pending lease-lend bill. The Secretary made the statement at the morning hearing and amplified it when the committee reconvened after luncheon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 -- Lester Cowan and Gilbert Miller today signed Ida Lupino to play Ellen Creed, Flora Robson's stage character, in the screen version of "Ladies In Retirement" at Columbia. The producers also engaged Louis Hayward, Miss Lupino's husband, for the part of Albert Feather, which Patrick O'Moore played in the Broadway production.

With but little trading incentive, activity in the cotton futures market continued at a low ebb yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange price movements held to a narrow range and final quotations were up 1 point to 3 off. In response to well-distributed buying orders the opening was firm, with net advances of 2 to 3 points.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Overseas advices reaching Washington have convinced officials vitally concerned with our own national defense that the world is only a few weeks away from perhaps its most critical period, in which Germany will attempt a knockout blow against Britain with no weapons barred.

Antoinette Perry, who in recent years has done much to encourage young stage talent, has been named president of the Experimental Theatre, Inc., it was announced yesterday. The ETI was founded by the Dramatists Guild and the Actors Equity Association to afford young dramatists and performers an opportunity to exhibit their wares in public performances.

VICHY, France, Jan. 28 -His powers increased by a Constitutional Act to a point never enjoyed by any King of France, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain today continued his work of preparing the new regime.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 28 -Anti-German incidents occurred early this week, and Yugoslavs of German origin were wounded in clashes at Zenica and Geronje, according to a report from a German source here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Rear John W. Admiral Greenslade said today that the United States expects to reach agreements soon for South and Central American air and naval bases.

Robert Levine, 38 years old, and Joseph Amorosia, 42, were arrested yesterday morning in a furnished room at 215 Carlton Avenue, Brooklyn, for allegedly posing as manufacturers and collecting medical fees from job applicants who had responded to an advertisement Levine had inserted in newspapers.

VICHY, France, Jan. 28 -- "I have noted that a Belgian newspaper has published the statement that the American Ambassador to France is of the opinion that the British will be defeated in the present war," Admiral William D. Leahy, President Roosevelt's envoy extraordinary to the government of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, said today, and added:...

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, still weak from an attack of pneumonia but as precise as ever, began defense of his world three-cushion billiard championship tonight with a brilliant 50-to-15 victory over young Herbert Peterson of St. Louis.

New shipyards and widespread expansion of existing shipbuilding plants will be required to meet the country's new tonnage program, it was declared yesterday by J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping. He said 100 new ships would come from American shipways this year, a considerable increase over the number expected by the bureau as recently as a month ago.

The allotment of the 175 horse-racing days in New York State this year, one more than last, became known yesterday following a meeting of the New York State Racing Commission attended by Chairman Herbert Bayard Swope and Commissioners John Hay Whitney and John Sloan.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Miss Elizabeth Hicks of Pasadena, Calif., the medalist, and Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta led a parade of favorites through the first round of the tenth annual Miami Biltmore women's golf tournament today.

A bill asking for appropriation of $500,000,000 to speed construction of needed links in the United States military and defense roads network is being prepared for submission to Congress, it was learned yesterday at the American Road Builders Association Convention, which met for the second of five days' sessions in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Bertrand Russell declares in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES that he has never preached unconditional pacifism. He opposed the World War, but while so doing he pointed out that there are justifiable wars, like our own War of Independence.

A majority of American voters favor the lease-lend hill, first returns from a nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion indicate, according to Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Hundreds of Iron Guard rebels were herded before a court-martial today, many to be condemned to death for last week's rebellion, as Premier General Ion Antonescu announced that he would swing Rumania into "closer community'' with the Rome-Berlin Axis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged a combination and conspiracy to suppress price competition in the sale of rigid steel conduit by means of a basing-point delivered-price formula and other practices against the Rigid Steel Conduit Association, the Organization Service Corporation and the National Electrical Wholesalers Association, all of New York, and their officers and some thirty manufacturers and selling companies.

A report that Captain F.S. Alexander, who was head of the Federal Alcohol Administration before that body was absorbed by the United States Treasury Department in the government reorganization of last June, will be transferred to the Federal Trade Commission soon to head a general investigation of the liquor industry, circulated in the industry here yesterday.

One General Sessions juror was understood to have held up a verdict for sixteen and one-half hours Monday night before he voted with the others at 9 o'clock yesterday morning to convict Stanley Cole, 39 years old, an ex-convict, of first-degree murder, with a recommendation of life imprisonment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Perkins, acting under the Walsh-Healey act, today established minimum wage rates ranging from 40 to 60 cents an hour for concerns in the uniform and clothing industry working on government contracts.

Ability of the New York fur market to continue to absorb large quantities of raw furs at higher prices was again evidenced yesterday at the auction conducted by Lampson, Fraser Huth, Inc., when the skins of the Hudson's Bay Company were placed on the block.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip Le Boutillier gave a supper party last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for Mr. Le Boutillier's son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. William A. Wood Jr. Others in the party were Mr. and Mrs. Bronson Williams, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wood, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Dunham, Mr. and Mrs. John Upton, Miss Jean Mackenney, Miss Elizabeth Lefferts, John Richards, Charles Limberg, William Reid and Dikran Sarkisian.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- In a session interrupted by air-raid alarms, not much business was transacted in today's stock markets but the undertone was distinctly firmer.

With the current snow coverage permitting metropolitan skiers ample opportunity to polish technique in their back yard, so to speak, without having to visit resorts hundreds of miles away, it is little wonder that New York City's public parks are receiving the attention of "snow plow" and "stem turn" disciples in particular.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip Le Boutillier gave a supper party last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for Mr. Le Boutillier's son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. William A. Wood Jr. Others in the party were Mr. and Mrs. Bronson Williams, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wood, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Dunham, Mr. and Mrs. John Upton, Miss Jean Mackenney, Miss Elizabeth Lefferts, John Richards, Charles Limberg, William Reid and Dikran Sarkisian.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- In a session interrupted by air-raid alarms, not much business was transacted in today's stock markets but the undertone was distinctly firmer.

With the current snow coverage permitting metropolitan skiers ample opportunity to polish technique in their back yard, so to speak, without having to visit resorts hundreds of miles away, it is little wonder that New York City's public parks are receiving the attention of "snow plow" and "stem turn" disciples in particular.

Although the Italian air force is in obvious need of stiffening, it is not because he is an experienced pilot that Italy's Foreign Minister is sent to the fighting front. Nor is it because he is responsible for a policy that has led to disaster all along the line, from the Adriatic to the Red Sea.

Many dinner and supper parties were given in connection with the premiere showing of the technicolor film "Virginia" last night at the Paramount Theatre for the benefit of the Maple Leaf Fund, Inc., the national Canadian organization for British war relief.

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers has resumed negotiations with the Department of Justice in the hope of concluding a consent decree that very probably would bring an end to the radio music war, it was disclosed yesterday.

Mrs. Genevieve Brady Macaulay wife of William J. Babington Macaulay, Irish Free State Minister to the Vatican, left a net estate of $6,299,000, of which $1,705,719 goes for charitable purposes, it was disclosed in the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Wednesday, Jan. 29 (AP) -Japanese troop transports were reported sighted off the coast south of here today as new Japanese military moves in Indo-China overshadowed the violation of the Thai-Indo-China armistice agreement for which each side blamed the other.

The annual report of the Universal Pictures Company, Inc., and its subsidiaries, covering the first full year under war conditions in many of the principal foreign markets, showed yesterday a consolidated net profit of $2,390,772 for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 2, 1940.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Holding that the recent decision of the Court of Appeals compelling Local 5 of the Teachers Union to turn over its membership rolls to the Rapp-Coudert committee, investigating subversive activities in the public schools, "is to New York organized labor what the Dred Scott Decision was for the institution of slavery."

To speed up snow removal, the Department of Sanitation added 950 extra workers to the regular night crews of 2,500 last night. With the gutters at many crosswalks inches deep in slush, the men were instructed to shove as much snow as possible into the sewers.

James P. Warburg, banker and author, last night advocated immediate passage of the lease-lend bill in Congress to insure the defeat of Hitlerism and the establishment of a new world order with a "peace of justice." He asserted this would be based upon economic and international systems recognizing the same democratic ideals as the political system of the United States, and would mean an extension of our federal principle to the rest of the world.
