LONDON, Wednesday, Jan, 29 -Air warfare returned to London yesterday after eight nights free of raids. Four "alerts" sounded in the capital before midafternoon.

Defense contracts awarded in the period from Jan. 1 to Jan. 15, inclusive, brought the total for the country to $11,315,856,533 for the period from July 1, 1940, to Jan. 15, 1941, according to data compiled by the Office of Government Reports in collaboration with the National Defense. Advisory Commission.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Unerring and Red Dock, preparing for different stakes up ahead, won the feature races before 10,360 at Hialeah Park today. The richer of the two races, the Winter Haven, fell to Unerring, a 5-year-old mare that carries the Woolford Farm silks.

Determined that no financial disagreement should interfere with his campaign to insure his regular berth in the outfield this year, Charley Keller yesterday bobbed up with the distinction of being the first Yankee regular to sign a contract.

During one of his glittering flights the other day Senator Wheeler said that "most historians and students agree that the Treaty of Versailles provoked the present war." Eight teachers of history at Williams College have now joined President Baxter of that institution in protesting that "such an oversimplification is a distortion of history which is grossly misleading."

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Governor Lehman, conferring here this afternoon with members of seventy-five local defense councils throughout the State, called for a further intensification of the State's defense program as an integral part of the nation-wide drive for increased production of military material "not only for our own use but also for the British."

James B. Schafer, promoter of a metaphysical "heaven on earth," which ran into tax difficulties on Long Island, learned last night that even the theatre, as a method of spiritual uplift, is not immune from the modern world of reality.

Continuing his formal testimony on the state of McKesson Robbins, Inc., William J. Wardall, the trustee, said in the Federal court here yesterday that arrangements for the current year, if realized, will produce profits justifying dividends of about $2.71 a share on the new common stock to be issued, if the proposed plan of reorganization is put into operation.

Works by composers of six countries appeared on the haphazard program presented by the Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy, last night in Carnegie Hall, with Ezio Pinza, the Metropolitan bass, as soloist. A special feature of the concert was the first performance in this city of Bela Bartok's new "Divertimento for String Orchestra," whereby Hungary was represented on a list supplied further with offerings of Finnish, Austrian, Italian, French and Russion origin.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Jan. 28 (UP) -Hostilities between Thailand and French Indo-China blazed away almost without interruption today despite preparations for peace talks under Japanese sponsorship tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 - Conflicting views on the question of compulsory competitive bidding for new issues of securities of registered public utility holding companies and their subsidiaries were presented today by the heads of two of the country's leading underwriting houses at a "public conference'" here on the subject before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MADRID, Jan. 28 -Generalissimo Francisco Franco today issued a decree placing all railroads in Spain under government ownership and operation in a drastic move to solve the country's transportation problems.

The prints division of the New York Public Library will open on Saturday an exhibition entitled "Farming," illustrating the duties of the farmer throughout the year. The prints include work by Holbein, Rowlandson, Hollar, Pissaro, Millet, Breughel, Winslow Homer, Clare Leighton, Mahonri Young, Grant Wood and others.
VICTORIA, B.C., Jan. 28 -- The army transport Kvichak grounded on treacherous rocks of the "inside passage" to Alaska late last night.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Leaders of the Association of Junior Leagues of America proposed at its national convention today that the coordination of all volunteer services for women be made the organization's special contribution to defense.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- One group of opponents of the President's lease-lend bill for aid to nations which are resisting the Axis thought it was given arguments in Treasury testimony today before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. This is the group which holds that the drastic measure is unnecessary to achieve the purpose stated, that an outright gift or loan of money will effectively accomplish the same purpose.

If the city and State were to take full advantage of modern scientific knowledge, tuberculosis could be conquered within twenty-five years, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at the dedication exercises of Triboro Hospital for Tuberculosis, New York's new $3,923,404 tuberculosis institution at Parsons Boulevard and Eighty-second Drive, Jamaica, Queens.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Austin Stickney gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Higgins, Mr. and Mrs. C. Wheaton Vaughan, Mr. and Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher, Mr. and Mrs. William Ryan, Mr. and Mrs. C. Douglass Green, Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Williams, Mrs. Jocelyn H. de Grasse Evans and Ferrars H. Tows.

Rhode Island State burst into Madison Square Garden last night with its unbeaten basketball record and its two-points-a-minute reputation and left a gathering of 15,590 well-nigh breathless by traveling at so ferocious a clip that it broke the Garden scoring mark for a single half.

The preliminary annual report of the United States Steel Corporation, and the chairman's remarks at the directors' meeting on Tuesday, threw an interesting sidelight on defense production. It was not less so, in view of the steel trade's general judgment that its present capacity for production is adequate for all requirements.

Seven Chilean journalists will arrive in New York Feb. 10 to take jobs for two months on newspapers in various parts of the United States as a means of developing closer journalistic understanding between the Americas, it was announced yesterday by Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Record-breaking reports turned in at today's final meeting of the President's Birthday Ball Committee and the steadily mounting enthusiasm with which arriving celebrities have been welcomed gave promise tonight of a whirlwind finish tomorrow of the 1941 Fight Infantile Paralysis campaign.

BERLIN, Thursday, Jan. 30 -Headlines in this morning's press announce that Adolf Hitler will speak to the German people at 4:30 P.M. today [9:30 A.M. in New York] on the occasion of the eighth anniversary of the founding of the Third Reich.

PALMYRA, N.J., Jan. 29 -- Two light airplanes which took off within a few minutes of each other from the Palmyra Airport this afternoon collided at an altitude of 2,000 feet, sending one of them spinning to earth and killing its two occupants.

After digging three weeks with spades and a steam shovel, a crew of workmen employed by District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn unearthed yesterday near Lyndhurst, N.J., a body, encrusted with quicklime, that is believed to be that of Peter Panto, an insurgent longshoreman, whose disappearance more than a year ago has been attributed to the Brooklyn underworld murder syndicate.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 29 (AP) -- members of a union charged with conspiracy to dynamite TVA lines serving a strike-bound plant were convicted today in Federal court.

The arrival here yesterday of an estimated $9,400,000 of foreign gold was unofficially reported. The shipments comprised 168 boxes of the metal, of which forty-nine boxes came from Colombia and 119 from India. The Colombian shipment was reported consigned to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 -- A severe earthquake which jarred the Los Angeles area and a number of surrounding cities was recorded at 5:35 P.M. today.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 29 -- A statement that the world needs an ideological offensive against nazism was made by Mrs. Vera M. Dean of New York City, director of research for the Foreign Policy Association, at today's session of the convention of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America.

Falling temperatures and rising winds combined last night to make more difficult the task of the Department of Sanitation and its army of 10,024 men and 1,472 machines, as they battled with the tightly-packed snow and ice on streets, gutters and crosswalks throughout the city.

Joe Louis completed training yesterday for the defense of his heavyweight championship against Clarence (Red) Burman in a scheduled fifteen-round encounter at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. At his Greenwood Lake, N.Y., quarters, Louis boxed two rounds each with Joe O'Gatty and George Nicholson and added four rounds of light exercises.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Frankie Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., and Hobby Riggs of Chicago, who are favored to renew their rivalry in the University of Miami invitation tennis tournament, headed a parade of seeded players into the quarter-finals today.
ATHENS, Jan. 29 -- Tonight's communique states merely that successful local operations occurred on the Albanian front and that no Italian bombing activities were reported within the country.

The key to good government and economic security that would give this country an "enduring national strength" is planned parenthood, the Birth Control Federation of America was told yesterday at its annual meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Six grade school boys decided to play a joke on a substitute teacher by taking sleeping tablets so they would fall asleep in class, but the prank threw a big scare into the entire school, for the potions they took turned out to be a poison.

VICHY, France, Jan. 29 -- Official announcement was made tonight of the creation of a new national body of a militant type, with Marshal Henri Philippe Petain at its head, to replace the old political parties.

PARIS, Jan. 23 (delayed; via Berlin) -- Negro Jazz players who have been entertainers for twenty years in Montmartre night clubs are among the latest batch of Americans who are returning home. One group left Jan. 20; others are expected to leave Jan. 27, Jan. 30 and early in February.

Are our radio broadcasters more or less illiterate? We have the simple English word "air." It is used in such combinations as air attack, air bombardment, air manoeuvres, etc. But our broadcasters scorn such simple language. We have also the adjective a-e-ri-al (pertaining to the air).

An underwriting group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co., today will offer to the public $12,000,000 of first mortgage and first lien 3 per cent bonds, Series B, of the Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company. The obligations, which are dated Nov. 1, 1940, and will mature on Nov. 1, 1960, will be offered at 102 and accrued interest to date of delivery.

The $1,000,000,000 Cities Service Company, which supplies oil, gas, electric and transportation service to an estimated population of 5,300,000 throughout the United States and Canada, registered yesterday as a holding company with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

An estimate of Britain's urgent needs in the way of clothing, knitted garments, shoes, blankets and other supplies for civilians and the armed forces for the next six months, was received yesterday from the American Gifts Committee in London, headed by Sir Ronald Lindsay, by Bundles for Britain, 745 Fifth Avenue.

JAMES HILTON'S "Random Harvest"* is a novel about a man uncommonly haunted by the sense of the past in the years of the Long Armistice, when an uneasy world enjoyed "Goodbye, Mr. Chips" while the Nazis amassed planes that were not intended for a "Lost Horizon."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, reducing claims about one-half, fixed $878,285 today as maximum compensation and reimbursement for expenses in the Missouri Pacific Railroad's reorganization. The allowances, to be paid by the Missouri Pacific, are for all the expenses incurred up to July 9, 1940.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The statutory power of the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 to promulgate a rule to force compulsory competitive bidding for new issues of registered public utility holding companies and their subsidiaries was challenged today by the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 -- The possibility of a dark horse threat for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup loomed at Hialeah Park today when 11,530 persons watched Mrs. Ella K. Bryson's Clyde Tolson win the Grade A Handicap by a head in a hot finish with Mrs. Payne Whitney's Cherry Jam.

Despite a rise in the seasonally adjusted index of new orders received by manufacturers in December, manufacturers' inventories rose only moderately as shipments advanced to a record high, crossing the 1929 level for the first time, according to data compiled by the division of industrial economics of the Conference Board and issued yesterday.

A nine-man field was named by Director Fred Schmertz yesterday for the two-mile run that will be one of the many features of the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. Seven of them have been clocked in 9:06 or better, which is indication enough of how quickly the distance-running brigade has come along.

The number of unemployed workers in the United States declined by 104,000 last month, bringing the national total of persons out of work to 6,961,000, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Jan. 29 -- A violent explosion in the four-story Memorial High School here shortly before 6 A.M. today disclosed the suicide by gas of William H. Lounsbury, 48 years old, supervisor of manual training in this city's public schools. Six hours earlier he had been released in $5,000 bail after being arrested on a statutory charge involving a 15-year-old girl pupil.

Runner-up for the title a year ago, Stanley G. Haskins of the Harvard Club was eliminated from the Class A championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association in the third round last night at the Yale Club.

New York's milliners are quick on the trigger when it comes to translating the inspirational ideas that come to New York into hat trends. On Jan. 22 the exhibition of Indian art of the United States opened at the Museum of Modern Art. Yesterday, just a week later, Sally Victor included in her collection a goodly number of hats based on designs and colors taken from the exhibition.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Evidence that the price control privileges conferred by the various State Fair Trade Acts may pinch a bit under present conditions was offered today in resolutions passed by the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers at the final session of its convention here.

The name that has dominated track and field with greater persistency than any since Paavo Nurmi is missing for the first time in eight years today as Dan Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the A.A.U., made public his 1940 All-America team that appears in the annual Spalding Athletic Almanac, just off the press.

An attendance of more than 2,000 persons is expected tonight at the New Decade Mardi Gras and Ball which will be given in the grand ballroom and adjoining suites of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

Budget Director Kenneth Dayton held a routine public hearing yesterday on a request by the Police Department for an allowance of $66,078,892 in the tax budget for 1941-42. It took Police Commissioner Valentine about three minutes to ask approval of the request, which is for $2,143,281 more than was allowed in the modified budget for 1940-41.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 29 -- The tranquillity of the German forces in Rumania -- reported by the Germans themselves -- during the most recent disorders raises in many Turkish minds the question of what precisely is the raison d'etre of these forces.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Cuban jockey, Eugene Rodriguez, rode four long-shot winners at Santa Anita Park today. They were Get On, paying $33.40 for $2 in the second race; First Choice, $142.60 in the third; Olimpo, $75 in the seventh, and One Shen, $29.20 in the eighth.

TOKYO, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka told the Diet Budgetary Committee today that Japan had sent Admiral Nobumasa Nomura as its Ambassador to the United States to emphasize to President Roosevelt and the American people "what a catastrophe to humanity American entry into the war would mean."

Three British colonial officials, en route to London to take part in conferences on legal and technical aspects of the Western Hemisphere bases to be leased by the United States, were among the nine passengers on the Atlantic Clipper which took off for Bermuda, Horta and Lisbon at 9:14 A.M. yesterday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 29 (UP) -Sam Snead, fresh from victory in the Bing Crosby invitation tournament, and defending champion Jimmy Demaret established themselves as favorites today for the $5,000 Western open golf tournament beginning Friday.

MEDIA, Pa., Jan. 29 -- Twenty indictments were returned today against former State Senator John J. McClure, Republican leader of Delaware County, in connection with the sale of the Chester Water Service Company by which citizens of Chester allegedly were mulcted of $625,000.

Opinion as to whether the United States is indirectly helping Germany through its sales of copper and cotton to Russia was divided among foreign traders here yesterday. Exporters who accepted British official opinion on the subject asserted that the increase in Russia's copper purchases here from 110,000 pounds in 1938 to 45,496,194 pounds in 1939 and a probable 100,000,000 pounds for 1940, cannot be explained in any other way.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 29 -Revenues and attendance at Westchester County parks have been falling steadily for the last eleven years and receipts amounted only to $466,433 paid by 1,575,974 persons in 1940, the Westchester County Park Commission said today in a report covering the period of 1930-1940, inclusive.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- The men's clothing industry is being forced to lead the procession in the trend toward inflation. B.J. Cahn, chairman and president of B. Kuppenheimer Co., Inc., believes. Kuppenheimer Fall clothing prices, he said here today, will be from $3 to $5 higher as a result of rising material and labor costs.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Jan. 29 -- An outbreak of thirty cases of a mild form of measles has resulted in a complete quarantine for 400 enlisted men here and a partial quarantine for about 2,000 others, about half the enlisted personnel at this Army air field.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Treasury Department announced today that Joseph D. Nunan Jr. of Douglaston, Queens County, newly appointed Collector of Internal Revenue for the First District of New York, would take his oath of office on Saturday, filling the vacancy caused by the death of Almon G. Basquin.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Rumania was warned today by her pro-German newspapers to declare immediately a one-year truce in all ideological conflicts "because of the international situation."

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 -- By the time you get down here you hear less talk of sailfish and more of white and blue marlin and amberjack, and the spirit of competition among anglers is spurred on by the glitter of some of the finest trophies and prizes ever offered in fishing.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., sounded warning to all comers today she is "on her game," as she defeafed Miss Louise Suggs, 17-year~old Lithia Springs, Ga., sharpshooter, 3 and 2, in the quarter-finals of the 1VIiami Blltmore women's golf tournament.
Inductions into the Army from this city for a year's training under the Selective Service Act numbered 455 men yesterday. They came from the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

Passage in the House yesterday of an appropriation of $175,000,000 to permit the Army to stock up on clothing and equipment resulted in widespread tightening of textile markets yesterday. Senate concurrence was regarded as virtually certain.

White fox showed an advance of 30 per cent at the sale conducted yesterday for the account of the Hudson's Bay Company by Lampson, Fraser Huth, Inc. These skins had a 100 per cent turnover and sold up to $33. Marten. rose l 10 per cent'to a high of $175, also with 100 per cent turnover.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 30 -London's first night raid in ten days occurred last evening with the usual rumble of gunfire, muffled thunder of bombs, bright flares swinging in the sky, incendiaries flaming to earth and over all the low hum of German planes.

Scrubbings and care replace money in acquiring toys at the Doll Clinic, and 300 doll-clutching little girls who gathered in the Boys' Athletic League Home Recreation Library, 424 West Forty-ninth Street yesterday, contend it's a fine idea. They came to vie for honors for having best tended their sawdust charges, which have become theirs by adoption during the first two months of the clinic's existence.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP) --Champion Willie Hoppe, whose defense of his world three-cushion billiard crown was delayed sixteen days by illness, polished off his second straight foe tonight in his drive to catch the field.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Secretary Morgenthau told the Ways and Means Committee today in speaking for a bill to increase the national debt limit from $49,000,000,000 to $65,000,000,000 that actual and contemplated appropriations for national defense would exhaust the Treasury's borrowing power late in the fiscal year 1942 and might require an additional $3,500,000,000.

A reception was given yesterday afternoon at the Museum of Modern Art for the Consuls of several Latin-American countries by members of the ball committee for the Fiesta. Pan-Americana, a supper dance for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center, which will be held on Feb. 10 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 29 -- The entire American community here -- official and civilian -- is wondering what is behind a sensational story reported this morning in the Japanese paper, Tariku, which declared two Japanese teachers had been denied entrance to the International Settlement by United States Marines stationed at one of the bridges across Soochow Creek.

"Crazy With the Heat," the revue which ran for only seven performances, will have another opportunity of showing its mettle this evening at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre. Since the show closed on Jan. 18 there has been extensive overhauling under guidance of Ed Sullivan, Broadway columnist, who has undertaken the management of the show, and Lew Brown, who is responsible for the "reconstruction" of the sketches and the comedy lines.
ROME, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:
DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 29 (UP) -- Harry Bennett, personnel director of the Ford Motor Company, said tonight that Henry Ford would "never turn his plants over to the government."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A third producer referendum on amendments to the Federal order regulating the handling of milk in the New York metropolitan marketing area was ordered today by Secretary Wickard for Feb. 17.

Negotiating committees representing the National Maritime Union and the American Merchant Marine Institute will meet again today at the offices of the institute, 11 Broadway, in an attempt to reach an agreement on wages for 30,000 seamen who belong to the union and are employed on vessels owned and operated by institute members.

Percy Jenkins, for more than fifteen years with the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company, has been appointed manager of the Boston branch of John A. Roebling's Sons Company, manufacturers of wire, wire rope and other wire products.

The annual dinner of the Color Guard Committee of the Society of Colonial Wars was given last night in the Portrait Room of the Roosevelt Memorial at the American Museum of Natural History. After dinner Michael Lorner's motion pictures on "Marlin Fishing Off New Zealand," were shown, followed by a tour through the museum's Hall of Ocean Life.
SAIGON, French Indo-China, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Armistice negotiations between Thailand [Siam] and French Indo-China opened this afternoon aboard the Japanese cruiser Natori.

The recent lull in German air assaults against Britain is probably partly explained by the bad Winter weather over Britain, but regardless of its cause it enables Britain and Germany to snatch a breathing space for the "push" that may be only a few weeks off.

Wendell L. Willkie, it appeared yesterday, can have the Republican nomination for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District if he will take it. Party leaders expressed belief that the nomination of the former Presidential candidate would be an excellent political move toward filling the vacancy caused by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson, but were without knowledge as to whether Mr. Willkie would consent to run.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Sixty-five hundred employes of the tractor works of the International Harvester Company here were thrown out of work this afternoon by a strike called by Local 101 of the Farm Equipment Workers Organizing Committee, a C.I.O. affiliate.

Margit Bokor, Hungarian soprano, gave her first New York recital last night in Town Hall. Since her arrival in this country Miss Bokor has sung with the San Francisco and Chicago Opera Companies, and she recently substituted as Octavian in a performance of Strauss's "Der Rosenkavalier" given by the Metropolitan Opera Association in Philadelphia.

One-room tenants in the Chinatown lodging house in which seven Chinese died in a blaze in the early morning of June 14, 1939, paid yearly rents of $48 or less, it was testified yesterday in the General Sessions first and second-degree manslaughter trial of one of three persons named as owners.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 29 -- Plans for expanding aircraft manufacture in Australia on a scale immensely greater than any previously propounded will be submitted to the United Kingdom Government by Prime Minister R.G. Menzies when he reaches London.

Our neighbor, The Sun, has made the interesting suggestion, seconded by the new Republican leader of the Seventh Assembly District, that Wendell Willkie be nominated for the Congressional vacancy caused by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson. At first glance the proposal would seem to have several merits both from Mr. Willkie's and the national point of view.

To provide additional copper for national defense purposes, the Metals Reserve Company, a government agency, is said to be inquiring for additional supplies from Latin American sources. A little more than a month ago the agency bought 100,000 tons of copper from United States firms operating in Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission announced today that three cargo vessels, two of the C-1 design and one of the C-3 design, would be delivered to operators by the builders by Wednesday.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 29 -That the definite refusal by Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Soviet Premier and Foreign Commissar, of a German demand that Russia force Turkey to stand aide while Germany carried out her. Spring campaign in the Balkans was the real result of M. Molotoff's visit to Berlin, is asserted by competent observers who have returned here after a visit to Czecho-Slovakia.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Fairly general liquidation developed in the wheat market today and the May delivery dropped 1 1/2 cents a bushel at one time to 82 1/2 cents, the lowest price since early last November and 6 cents under the recent high level.

ATHENS, Jan. 29 -- The death of Premier General John Metaxas in all probability marks the end of a phase in Greek history, although undoubtedly the main precepts of order and discipline for which he stood will be continued, as has already been announced by King George.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Roosevelt received from the Electoral College a resolution of congratulation on his election to a third term, received numerous callers and transacted other official business.

A demand for extensive retrenchment in municipal, State and Federal expenditures not connected with national defense was voiced last night by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, retired, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, Inc., at the commission's annual dinner in the Hotel Biltmore.

Although military aviation rarely is considered constructive, its contributions to the safe and comfortable operation of commercial passenger planes is large and continuing, Colonel A.D. Tuttle, medical director of United Air Lines, told a group of aeronautical scientists last night at the opening session of the three-day annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at Columbia University.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29 -Stirling Hayden, Paramount newcomer, who has played in but one picture, "Virginia," was named today for the lead opposite Dorothy Lamour in "Dildo Cay," which E.H. Griffith will direct, starting in May. Virginia Van Upp is preparing the scenario from the novel concerning a feudal island in the West Indies by Nelson Hayes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Labor representation in divisions of the Office for Production Management is apparently assured, but its extent depends on the outcome of conferences which Sidney Hillman will begin tomorrow when he returns to his office after several weeks' absence because of illness.

This year's first large offering of equipment-trust certificates will be on the market next Tuesday, when the New York Central Railroad will open bids for $10,900,000 of these securities. The certificates are to bear interest in multiples of one-eighth of 1 per cent, according to the specifications.

LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Britain disclosed tonight that she is about to tap her last big nest egg of dollar resources in the United States -- British owned and controlled business enterprise -- to buy warplanes, ships, tanks and munitions.

It is not startling news to learn from the Census Bureau that we are all growing older. In fact, it is a little depressing. But it is a cloud with a silver lining. The bureau also reveals that despite the increasing age of our population everybody now has a chance to live two and a half years longer.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Great Britain took two more long strides today toward mobilization for total war.

With the portfolio calculated at year-end market prices, net assets of the Petroleum Corporation of America at $15,435,615 were equal to $8.05 on each of 1,917,600 shares outstanding on Dec. 31, according to the annual report made public yesterday.

Reflecting easiness in the securities markets, cotton prices turned reactionary yesterday and final quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 6 to 11 points. The opening was irregular, with prices 1 point lower to 3 higher.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Five bills, designed to protect installment purchasers and small-loan borrowers, were introduced today in the Senate by Pliny W. Williamson, chairman of the Banks Committee.

Young women of society headed by Miss Marion H. Sutphen will sell flowers at the special performance of "Lohengrin" tomorrow afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Grenfell Association of America. The occasion is also a memorial tribute to Sir Wilfred Grenfell, founder of he Grenfell Mission in Labrador and North Newfoundland.

Dr. Emil Altman, for twenty-two years a member of the Board of Education's medical division and for the last seventeen years its chief examiner, filed an application for retirement yesterday, effective immediately.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- American millers and bakers will start production at once of vitamin-enriched flour and bread in a move to increase the nutritive and health-giving value of American diets in the defense emergency, the National Research Council made known today.

After binding and gagging an elevator operator and leaving a companion to guard him, two armed men yesterday afternoon held up a bookkeeper in the office of Feshback Ackerman, furriers, on the fourteenth floor of 333 Seventh Avenue, in the busy garment district.

DUBLIN, Jan. 29 -- Eire now is swiftly coming up against the serious consequences of the war. While the people in Britain and those across the border in Northern Ireland had their tea, sugar, butter and bacon rationed out to them, the citizens of this neutral State had no food rationing and only mild rationing of gasoline supplies up to the beginning of this year.

Last year's consolidated operating income of the Marine Midland Corporation and its constituent banks and trust companies, and other affiliates, amounted to $3,912,714, George F. Rand, president, reported at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 29 -Only one point from defeat, Mrs. Gaylord C. Burke of the home club came back to win a thrilling five-game encounter from Mrs. J. Basil Maguire of the Greenwich Field Club, 15 -- 16, 5 -- 15, 16 -- 15, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 11, as the second annual women's Class B invitation squash racquets tournament got under way on the courts of the Bronxville Field Club today.
The Treasury's plan to finance increased defense expenditures through the sale of savings stamps and small-denomination investments is subject to certain defects which are not generally recognized.

A new issue of $35,000,000 of New York City revenue bills, bearing interest at the rate of 1/4 of 1 per cent, was allotted yesterday to a group of twenty-five banks in this city by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick. The bills are dated Jan. 30 and will be payable May 2, 1941.

Bolstered by three new players acquired Tuesday night from the Springfield (Mass.) Indians, the Americans are ready for their National Hockey League contest with the Black Hawks in Madison Square Garden tonight.

Running to less than a hundred pages, "Retreat From Dunkirk," just published by Brentano's is a clear and detailed account of the B.E.F. in France last year. The author is Douglas Williams, London Daily Telegraph correspondent, who accompnied the forces.

Determined to be carefree and happy despite classroom woes, 150 New York City teachers formed a "Don't Worry" Club yesterday. They spent two hours over a full luncheon table at Joe's Boro Hall Restaurant, Brooklyn, listening to speeches, dining merrily, worrying not.

The Shell Union Oil Corporation will redeem on March 1, 1941, at 105 and accrued dividends, all outstanding shares of its 5 1/2 per cent convertible preferred stock, at the office of the New York Trust Company. Holders are invited to present their stock certificates at the bank before that date and receive the total redemption price and accrued dividends to March 1.
HAVANA, Jan. 29 -- President Fulgencio Batista tonight signed a decree designed to suppress totalitarian propaganda in Cuba.

The Schools Motion-Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, speaking last night at the annual dinner of the medical staff of St. Vincent's Hospital, asserted on the basis of what he termed "definite information" that the Federal Government would move in the future for the regulation of life insurance companies.

The election of four executives of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company to the rank of vice president of the company was announced yesterday following a meeting of the board of directors.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Germany will probably seek a military decision this year, before United States aid for Britain can reach its peak.

Walter Damrosch will be 79 years old today. In his annual birthday-eve interview yesterday he said his best present was the invitation from the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York to conduct the new version of "Cyrano de Bergerac," his opera that was produced at the Metropolitan Opera House during the 1912-13 season.

A. waltz supper party entitled "Tribute to Britain" and set in a patriotic decor of red, white and blue was given last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center by La Victoire Committee for the benefit of the British-American Ambulance Corps.

Except for the Dodgers the local baseball beat yesterday would have been a total loss. While Secretary Eddie Brannick of the Giants was perfecting a fool-proof remedy for colds, even as President Ed Barrow of the Yankees was home at Larchmont nursing one, Secretary John McDonald of the Brooklyn club broke the newsless spell with the announcement that both Fred (Dixie) Walker and Pete Reiser had affixed their signatures to contracts.
Favorable earnings were reported by two important steel companies which announced yesterday their annual reports for 1940.

A.W. Robertson, chairman of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, yesterday announced operating results for 1940, in addition to the dividend declarations of $1 each on the common and preferred stocks, both payable on March 5.

The forty-four national advertisers who spent more than $1,000,000 in magazines, radio and farm papers last year had total expenditures of $134,856,999, as against $117,876,880 in 1939, a gain of 15.8 per cent. There were three more million-dollar spenders last year than in 1939, according to Printers' Ink, out tomorrow.

Making use of the electrical conductivity of a soft pencil mark, International Business Machines Corporation has developed a machine which automatically punches tabulating cards where they are pencil-marked, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A bill intended to bar the closed shop on all Navy contracts and require the mediation of all labor disputes affecting them was introduced today by Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Affairs Committee. Under present plans the bill will have a hearing before the committee next week.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 29 -- Proposals calling for a managed paper money standard to replace the traditional gold standard were denounced here today as politically and psychologically "unworkable" by Dr. Edwin K. Kemmerer, Professor of Finance at Princeton University.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Continued faith in torpedo attacks by aircraft was voiced by a naval officer here yesterday. As vindication of this belief, he stressed an action that took place before that of Taranto. Where this took place is not known definitely, but it is reported he was referring to an action of Aug. 22 against Italian ships in Bomba Roads, Libya.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A New York Stock Exchange witness testified today at a hearing conducted by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the Exchange had adopted its rule prohibiting so-called multiple trading after receiving an informal opinion that the SEC had no interest in the matter.
ATHENS, Jan. 29 -- Alexander Korizis, the new Premier of Greece, is known as a conservative and able financer and has often traveled abroad, heading various financial missions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Favorable and unfavorable factors in world trade developments, as reported by cable and radio to the Commerce Department by its foreign attaches, were listed by the department today as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Sales of independent retailers were 8 per cent higher in 1940 than in 1939 and in December the increase over December, 1989, was 6 per cent, the Commerce Department reported today on the basis of information from 23,192 firms.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 30 -Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka told the House last night that he had not yet given up hope regarding Japan's relations with the United States. He stressed the importance of the appointment of Admiral Nobumasa Nomura as Ambassador to the United States.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 29 -Army varsity teams were turned back in two sports today, the cadet hockey forces losing to Princeton's skaters, 6 -- 2, while the West Point quintet dropped a hard-fought contest to the University of Virginia, 40 -- 36.

SANDERVILLE, Miss., Jan. 29 -- Cars of an Indiana National Guard train, one of thirty-three specials on the way to Camp Shelby with troops, overturned near here today, killing A.V. Smith of Meridian, Miss., the fireman, and injuring about twenty-seven soldiers, three seriously.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 29 -- Today's Bourse marked time, and business was almost stagnant as traders awaited the result of the loan issue. Prices crumbled, Dutch issues easing as much as 6 points.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 29 -Presentation of evidence in the trial of Joseph Spell, charged with assaulting Mrs. John K. Strubing Jr., was completed in Superior Court this afternoon as both sides rested. No rebuttal witnesses were called.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- A four-bill "model defense program for States," recommended in August at a Washington meeting of the Federal-State Conference on Law Enforcement Problems of National Defense, was introduced today in the Legislature under the sponsorship of the State Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation.

A new foundry costing approximately $1,500,000 will be constructed at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn as part of a large-scale improvement program which the Navy is undertaking to speed up the present shipbuilding and repair program, it was announced here yesterday.

ATHENS, Jan. 29 -- John Metaxas, the short, fatherly looking general who had dictated the fate of Greece since Aug. 4, 1936, and whose brilliance as a military expert was largely responsible for the successes against Italy, died at 6:20 this morning after a short illness.
The American Export liner Siboney docked at Jersey City yesterday afternoon after a long and rough voyage from Lisbon in heavy seas and high winds.

Percival Lowell, from his observation post at Flagstaff, Ariz., thought he saw evidence of enough water vapor on the planet Mars to make life possible, He went beyond that to believe in intelligent life, expressing itself in the famous Martian "canals."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives voted today to incorporate four amendments in the Administration's Lease-Lend Bill, which it has under consideration. They were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced the adoption of amendments to its general rules and regulations under the Securities Act of 1933 and the Trust Indenture Act of 1939 to provide in the San Francisco and Cleveland regional offices complete facilities for the registration of securities and the qualification of indentures under such acts.
Phillips Petroleum Company convertible 3 per cent debentures due in 1948 have been suspended from New York Stock Exchange dealings. They have been called for redemption under a pre-payment offer.

Songs controlled by Broadcast Music, Inc., have taken the lead in the sale of sheet music throughout the country, usually the most accurate indication of a tune's popularity, according to the weekly surveys printed in yesterday's issues of The Billboard and Variety, trade journals of the entertainment world.
Governor Lehman has again recommended to the Legislature the abolition of so-called blue-ribbon trial juries, now used in the Counties of New York, Bronx, Kings, Queens and Westchester.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 29 -- The Yugoslav weekly news feature magazine, Novi Svet, was officially suppressed early today, and the police confiscated 10,000 copies of the current edition containing an article about Colonel William J. Donovan, President Roosevelt's special envoy to Europe.

A former member of the Communist party testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church that Communists in the Department of Welfare maintained a network through which they could aid party members and sympathizers and bring pressure against fellow-employes who were antagonistic.

DENVER, Jan. 29 -- Fifteen individual and corporate defendants were named in an indictment charging price fixing and unfair trade practices in the food industry returned here today by a Federal grand jury.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 29 -- Although army sources have not announced the capture of Derna, Libya, Royal Air Force planes yesterday strafed retreating Italian troops between Derna and Barce, 120 miles farther west on the road to Bengazi. Such movements indicate that Derna or intermediate positions are being abandoned.

General John Metaxas is the first of the active war leaders to die. Up to the hour of his death he was the most successful of them all, for as head of the smallest and weakest of the belligerents he drove a supposedly powerful invader far beyond the frontiers of his country and thereby destroyed the legend of Axis invincibility and opened the way for the triumphant British offensive in the Mediterranean.

OTTAWA, Jan. 29 -- Controversy over the failure of the Sirois conference on Dominion-Provincial relations has begun to take a form that is regarded by those who have Dominion interests and the prosecution of the war most at heart as at least unfortunate.

"The Saint in Palm Springs," sixth in the adventure series sponsored by RKO, will open this morning at the Rialto. George Sanders and Wendy Barrie are starred in the mystery melodrama and featured roles are played by Jonathan Hale, Paul Guilfoyle, Linda Hayes and Ferris Taylor.

In spite of the tighter steel marketing situation, there is no pressure either from the industry, its customers or the government for the use of mandatory priorities, according to Iron Age, which says "it seems to be the intention of government authorities to permit each industry to work out its own remedies without invoking priorities unless they become absolutely necessary.

ROME, Jan. 29 -- Virginio Gayda in today's Giornale d'Italia accuses the United States of violating its neutrality law steadily. He warns that in doing so it exposes itself to "the legitimate danger of reaction" on the part of the Axis.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 29 -- Camouflaged with snow parkas improvised out of mattress covers by the company tailor, a scout patrol of the Seventy-first Infantry crept today across a snow field unseen by officers on the Juliustown-Lewistown Road.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Although the stock markets as a whole remained fairly quiet today, gilt-edge securities attracted a fair amount of attention. A better tendency also was noted in home rail prior charges.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 29 -- The delegates to the Regional Conference of the River Plate devoted much of their thought and activities today to insisting on the regional character of the sessions and denying reports sent abroad in the last few days that certain delegations were planning to inject political issues that affect nations not represented here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The President of the United States played Prince today to a modern Cinderella, Anna Sklepovich, 13 years old, who came to Washington from West Virginia because of a faked invitation to the White House, and, after a series of misadventures, was received today by Mr. Roosevelt.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 29 (AP) -Royal Air Force headquarters issued this communique today:

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A controversy over employment of four non-A.F.L. electricians today precipitated a strike of American Federation of Labor building trades workers at Wright Field and halted construction on a $1,550,000 Army Air Corps expansion program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Total United States exports in 1940 were larger both in volume and value than in any year since 1929 and general imports increased 13 per cent over 1939 but were still below the 1937 post-depression peak, the Department of Commerce announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- When after exhaustive hearings the Civil Aeronautics Board -- with the President's approval -- granted to American Export Airlines last July two certificates to operate across the Atlantic, the new company confidently approached Congress for the necessary appropriation.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 29 -- A well-balanced Princeton swimming team collected seven first places out of nine to open its season with a 56-19 victory over Rider in Brokaw pool today.

The red beacon lights atop the 700-foot Trylon at the World's Fair grounds still were blinking last night. Wreckers went to work yesterday on what was once the crowning glory of the exposition -- the Theme Center. At the end of four hours a crew had removed two sides of the steel cap of the tower, weighing one and three-quarters tons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The movement of capital between the United States and foreign countries in the four weeks ended Oct. 30, 1940, was marked by activity here in the balances of the Axis powers, the Treasury Bulletin reported today.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Wendell L. Willkie crossed many British paths again today in an indefatigable round of visits and heard and saw at first hand many things about Britain's war effort that he intends to talk about when he returns home.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, presented tonight to the convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers what he described as "a constitution for the American free enterprise system," in the hope that it might be "a worthy contribution to the solution of the complicated problem of preserving our democratic way of life and our free enterprise system in the dark decades ahead."

VICHY, France, Jan. 29 -- A violent reaction of indignation was expressed in official circles here today on the basis of a report that Mlle. Eve Curie was undertaking a series of lectures in the United States in opposition to the sending of supplies to France.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 29 -Because he and his family stayed last Summer in a non-union Sullivan County hotel which employed a non-union band, Jack Rosenberg, president of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, New York City, faces charges of unbecoming conduct brought by Local 809 of Middletown, which has jurisdiction in Sullivan and Orange Counties.

BERLIN, Jan. 29 -- The German High Command today showed its film of last Summer's Western campaign, "Victory in the West," to the German and foreign press. Lasting about two hours, the picture is a documentary history of the operations from the start of the campaign on May 10 to the signing of the armistice in the historic railroad car at Compiegne.

VICHY, France, Jan. 29 -- United States Ambassador William D. Leahy's statement yesterday concerning the issue of the war has not been printed in France, nor is it likely to be. Nevertheless, many in Vichy know today that he gave it as his personal opinion that "the British Government can and will prosecute the present war to a successful conclusion."

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29 -- Members of the Four Arts gathered this afternoon at the galleries for the tea and preview of a loan collection of Gothic and Renaissance art assembled b Mrs. George Luke Mesker which will be open to the public for a fortnight, starting tomorrow.

Today happens to be President Roosevelt's fifty-ninth birthday, but for those who are suffering from infantile paralysis or who may hereafter be exposed to that disease it has an additional meaning. It is the day on which funds are raised to be devoted to the research and experiments which may in time make infantile paralysis as preventable as smallpox.

As scrap metal dealers prepared yesterday to meet with members of the price stabilization division of the Defense Commission in Washington today, they were faced with the possibility of a curtailment of supplies unless they evolved some method to restore order to the disorganized secondary metal markets, it was learned here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today two national defense bills, while the House was approving an Administration request for $175,000,000 for Army clothing and equipment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Representative Fish, Republican, of New York, told reporters today that the House Foreign Affairs Committee had rejected a substitute Aid-to-Britain Bill which he had offered.

HERE'S fun. The baseball clubs are putting all sorts of oddities into their 1941 rosters. It used to be that the club secretary merely listed the vital statistics on the players and previous condition of servitude and let it go at that. Cold figures, dry facts. Now they have special club editors who turn out artistic folders with the heavy statistics in the middle and light reading on the side.

ROME, Jan. 29 -- The death of the Greek Premier, General John Metaxas, is good news for Italy, in so far as it means that a determined and able enemy has been eliminated. Italians blame General Metaxas for the policy that led Greece against them, and while they know that the same policies will be carried on, it is not believed there will be an equal degree of unity and energy.
With superb snow conditions reported throughout the Northlands from the Poconos to the Laurentians of Canada, there will be plenty of both competitive and recreational skiing this week-end.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The House started general debate today on the $1,404,576,838 Independent Offices Appropriation Bill, the first of the regular agency measures. The Appropriations Committee, in its reports, mildly criticized President Roosevelt for his use of the Defense Emergency Fund granted him last year, but it nevertheless approved $200,000,000 in a new emergency fund, plus $25,000,000 in contractual authority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Spokesmen for this government readily confirmed today reports from London that new conversations aimed at united Anglo-American economic action against the Axis were in progress. They insisted, however, that no decisions had been reached or were even imminent.

Because he let a three-week-old puppy shiver on the sidewalk while attempting to sell it, and because he had nine previous convictions for cruelty to animals, Joseph Pisano, 57 years old, of 87 Clinton Street, received a thirty-day work-house sentence from Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Yorkville Court yesterday.

Taking last season's records as a criterion, President Larry MacPhail of the Dodgers yesterday was confident of at least twenty-five victories for Brooklyn in the 1941 campaign after receiving three signed contracts.

Berlin has a new "victory" film. It pictures the conquest of the Lowlands and France last Spring and the accent is on personal heroism. In this it differs from the film chronicle of the Nazi conquest of Poland, in which the emphasis was on machinery.

MY footloose colleague, Ralph Thompson, is now on leave, making a grand tour of Latin America, and (although he has a book: Trollope's Autobiography) I am planning to send him a copy of J.B. Trend's new book, "Mexico: A New Spain With Old Friends,"* in case he decides to stop in Mexico on his way north next Spring.

Former Governor Philip La Follette of Wisconsin declared last night in a radio debate with Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes on the Lease-Lend Bill that the argument that we should furnish dollars and guns while the British furnish men in defense of democracy was a sordid argument that probably did not register well with the British people.

The progress made in the development of the United States Merchant Marine Naval Reserve assures the Navy of "a proper and efficient auxiliary service if and when war, should come," Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, commandant of the Third Naval District, declared yesterday.

One of the largest apartment rentals in recent months was reported yesterday in the building at 778 Park Avenue, where Frederick M. Heimerdinger, partner in the brokerage firm of Emanuel Co., took an entire floor in a transaction arranged by Warren Marks Associates for Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Although the Ford Motor Company submitted the lowest bid for 11,781 Army trucks the contract was awarded today to the Fargo Motor Company of Detroit because, the War Department stated, the Ford company refused to abide by the specifications governing the labor provisions.

A drive to have birth control included in more public health services of the country will be the first aim of the Birth Control Federation of America during 1941, it was reported yesterday at the closing session of the annual meeting of the organization in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Derna, 175 miles westward in Libya from captured Tobruk, has fallen to the attacking British forces in less than half the time it took to occupy Tobruk, and already the army of the Nile is hurrying onward to Bengazi, next and most important of the objectives in Eastern Italian territory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Warning all commandants of naval establishments today of the gravity of the situation, Secretary Knox ordered them to expedite all naval work by farming out orders as much as possible.

Though the Trylon and Perisphere are being taken down and not shot down the spectacle of their naked ribs in a snowy landscape, as shown in published photographs this week, is sufficiently melancholy. It seems just a little while ago that the Fair's spokesmen were explaining to us what the names meant and how the structures were to be tied into the "theme" of the big show.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Testimony was completed today before Trial Examiner Henry Fitts on the Securities and Exchange Commission's request that the New York Stock Exchange reverse its rule prohibiting members from acting as odd-lot dealers or specialists upon any exchange outside of New York City when the securities involved are listed on the New York Exchange.

Marketing research can make a real social contribution under present conditions by anticipating future consumer requirements, so that the post-defense lag can be cushioned through the introduction of new products, Dr. Howard T. Hovde, assistant professor of marketing, Wharton School of Finance and Commerce, University of Pennsylvania, and newly elected president of the American Marketing Association, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the association's New York chapter at the Hotel Commodore.

ROME, Jan. 30 (UP) -- One Rome newspaper attacked both President Roosevelt and Wendell L. Willkie in commenting on Mr. Willkie's visit to London today, while another tried to make it appear that Mr. Willkie had not been impressed by what he had seen.

Inside Germany or outside, no one in the world expects truth from Adolf Hitler. For eight years he has wielded absolute power over a people whose voice is submerged, as it was yesterday at the Sportpalast, by the mechanical clamor of the Party claque. In all that time there is not a single precedent to prove that he will either keep a promise or fulfill a threat.

The Ballet Theatre, which made its world debut last season in an engagement 'at the Center Theatre, announces that its second New York season will open on Feb. 11 at the Majestic Theatre. Performances will be given every evening except Monday, with matinees on Thursday and Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- With every district reporting gains, department store sales for the week ended Jan. 25 were 12 per cent higher than for the corresponding week a year ago and in the four weeks period ending Jan. 25 were 10 per cent higher than for the similar period last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 30 -- Prosecution and defense in the trial of Joseph Spell, who is charged with assaulting Mrs. John K. Strubing Jr., summed up today, with the State using its right to rebuttal on the defense summation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The question of labor discipline in the merchant marine will be considered by the House tomorrow through an amendment to be offered by Representative Dirksen of Illinois to the pending Independent Offices Bill to give shipowners and captains of government-subsidized merchant vessels the sole power of hiring and firing.

Although the weather this week cut down volume on men's wear somewhat, local stores will end the month with fairly substantial gains over a year ago, retail executives said yesterday. The increases range from 5 to 10 per cent with an average of around 7 per cent, it was said.

Asserting that the steel industry is capable of fulfilling any task laid at its door and that no bottleneck existed at any point in his own company's structure, Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, yesterday announced new high records in annual and quarterly earnings, in backlogs, bookings, sales, employment and in rate of pay, following a board meeting in which the directors voted a common dividend of $1.50 a share.

The Blue Ridge Corporation showed net assets at the year-end of $25,464,062, equivalent to $66.18 on each share of preference stock against $67.56 at the end of last September. After deducting the $55 to which preference stock is entitled in liquidation and accrued dividends, the common stock had a net asset value of 56 cents, against 64 cents at the end of September.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 30 -- Syracuse's basketball team broke a four-game losing streak by beating Princeton, 34 -- 24, in the university gym tonight. Dan Dipace, with 12 points, paced the Orange to its fifth victory in nine starts. It was the fifth defeat in ten games for the Tigers.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 30 -- President Getulio Vargas today signed a decree authorizing the creation of the Compania Nacional de Syderugia -- the National Steel Corporation. The capital of 500,000 contos is distributed at 250,000 contos in common shares of 200 milreis each and 250,000 contos in preferred shares at 200 milreis each, guaranteeing 6 per cent yearly interest.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The text of the majority report of the House Foreign Affairs Committee on the lease-lend bill reads as follows:

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Annie Laurine Dodge, widow of Daniel Dodge, and Dr. William A. Lange, a plastic surgeon of Detroit, were married here today by the Rev. Herbert L. Miller, pastor of Emmanuel Memorial Episcopal Church.

Roderic Crandall of California has sold his residence in the Baxter Estates section of Port Washington, L.I., to F.J. Shakespeare, in a transaction arranged by L'Ecluse, Washburn Co., according to Previews, Inc.

Five Boy Scout Troops from the Lexington Avenue district of Manhattan were awarded citations last night at the annual meeting of the Manhattan Boy Scout Council at the Greater New York headquarters, 120 West 42d Street, for acting as guinea pigs on the "Muscle Testing Machine" in the Hospital for Joint Diseases, 1919 Madison Avenue.

The trustees in bankruptcy of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad estimate that the company's gross income will increase 5 per cent to $90,000,000 and its net operating income 17.4 per cent in 1941, the company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- When Viscount Halifax presented his letters of credence as British Ambassador to the United States he was assured by President Roosevelt of the firm determination of this country "to continue on an ever-increasing scale our assistance to Great Britain and to make available munitions and supplies now flowing from the rapidly expanding industrial facilities of the United States."
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Secretary Knox declared here today that once this country's enormous strength is enlisted in the cause of preserving liberty, the ultimate victory is certain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots of America, through its executive board, adopted today a resolution barring from future affiliation all seamen who are Communists, Nazis or Fascists or who are members of any kindred organizations such as the German-American Bund.

Enrichment of white bread with vitamin B1 will be the subject of a number of advertising campaigns in the baking industry starting within a few weeks, according to agency men yesterday. Introduction of the new bread is scheduled to start shortly, as a result of the approval of standards announced yesterday by the National Research Council.

Henry Villard arrived in this country from Germany about 1853 knowing not a word of English. Within a few years he was a leading reporter and for The New York Herald covered Lincoln's post-election months at Springfield. The reporter's day-by-day dispatches of the five months have now been edited into a small book by Villard's two sons, Henry and Oswald Garrison Villard, called "Lincoln on the Eve of '61."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Miss Elizabeth Hicks of Pasadena, Calif., and Miss Grace Amory of Palm Beach moved into the final of the Miami Biltmore women's golf tournament today. They will meet at thirty-six holes tomorrow for the trophy won five times in a row by Miss Patty Berg before she turned professional.
BERLIN, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- Miss Dorothy Schierenberg of the Greenwich Field Club came from behind in two strenuous matches today to reach the final round ahead of the rest of the field in the second annual Class B women's invitation squash racquets tournament at the Bronxville Field Club.
The British freighter Sheaf Crown reported by radio last night that she had sighted a "suspicious submarine" approximately sixty miles east of St. John's, Nfld., according to The Associated Press.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The Atlantic outlook is brightening. For a fortnight I have been sailing thousands of miles out there investigating dangers, assessing possibilities for the immediate future and observing changes and developments in Britain's unceasing fight against the German U-boats across the biggest battlefront of all.

Leopold Stokowski has agreed to appear as guest conductor with the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra of New York during the season of 1941-42, it became known last night. He will be one of a group of eminent leaders who will help the orchestra to celebrate the hundredth season of its existence.

An annual event of interest to many persons of Southern descent or affiliation, and their friends, will take place in he main ballroom of the Plaza tonight when the twenty-sixth Blue Ridge Ball will be given for the benefit of the Blue Ridge Industrial School in Virginia.

Antoine de Saint Exupery, French aviator and author, disclaimed in an interview yesterday any desire to serve on the committee appointed by the Vichy government in France to organize a new national body that would replace the former political parties of France. An announcement of his appointment to the committee was contained in dispatches from Vichy published yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 30 -- Today's Bourse was very quiet and listless Dutch issues easing as much as 2 points. Royal Dutch declined 2 points to 245 3/4 ; Amsterdam Trading, 1 1/2 to 422; Amsterdam Rubber, 1 to 266 1/4, and Philips Lamps, 1 3/4 to 196 3/4.

Communists employed in her district office in the Department of Welfare assured her of preferential treatment in the office if she would join the Communist party, and after her refusal to join subjected her to harassment both in the office and in the union to which she belonged, Miss Ida Watkins of 768 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, a social investigator in the department, testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church.

Demand continued slow for most classes of fresh meat in yesterday's trading, a condition which has shown little change so far during the week. Lamb and veal prices were generally unchanged, due in part to light supplies, Steer hinds and ribs were slow and weak; high choice to prime excepted. Kosher steer beef was steady to slightly stronger and kosher veal and lamb fully steady.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Berlin, announcing that he favored declaration of war against Germany, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that if Germany is victorious "we will meet the first shock of her attack in the countries to the south of us."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The text of President Roosevelt's address tonight on the occasion of his birthday anniversary was as follows:...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Government control over the production and marketing of major farm crops may be extended this year far beyond the scope of the past, Agriculture Department officials said today.

Being a person of unusual compassion, Ed Sullivan, the celebrated columnist, hated to see all the good things going to waste in "Crazy With the Heat," which succumbed to prostration nearly a fortnight ago. With the assistance of Lew Brown, song-writer and beer Jongleur, he revived it last evening at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre in an improved version.

A concerted move on the part of resident buying offices to enlist the immediate cooperation of woolen goods manufacturers in labeling products in conformity with the Wool Labeling Law was endorsed yesterday at a meeting of the Association of Buying Offices at the Hotel Astor.

BOSTON, Jan. 30 -- One of the longest tests in the history of the championship saw Miss Dorothy Lee, 15, a New York high school girl, gain the lead in the women's national junior figure skating competition tonight.

WEST POINT, Jan. 30 -- The Tenth Cavalry, famous Negro regiment, has left West Point. Its second squadron and machine-gun troop, which had been stationed here since 1931, was formally played away in Army style yesterday by the Military Academy Band, en route to Fort Leavenworth, Kan.

Supreme Court Justice Frank E. Johnson in Brooklyn handed down a decision yesterday severely criticizing Children's Court Justice Jane M. Bolin for an "obviously illegal" proceeding in a case involving the custody of a 9-year-old girl.

ROME, Jan. 30 -- Reichsfueher Hitler's speech today caused deep satisfaction in Italian political circles, who expressed themselves as especially pleased to hear the German leader's announcement that large-scale submarine and aerial operations will take place in the near future.

Is there a Wall Street monopoly in the investment banking business? That seems to be the real question at issue in the current hearings before the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington to decide whether compulsory competitive bidding shall be ordered in the underwriting and flotation of new issues of public utility securities.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 30 -- Sixteen hundred employes of the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation plant at Bayway, near here, will go out on strike at 6 A.M. tomorrow to protest the company's failure to recognize a National Labor Relations Board order to hold an election to determine a bargaining agent for the employes.

Nassau County, L.I, will be in the market on Feb. 10 with an issue of $2,500,000 of various purpose bonds, for which officials have asked bidders to specify a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds, dated Feb. 15, will mature serially on Feb. 15, 1942 to 1960.

Mrs. Allen M. Thomas gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Her guests included Mrs. Edwin Gould, Mrs. Ansel Phelps, Princess Constantin Toumanoff, Mrs. Hoppin Pool, Mrs. Sidney W. Fish, Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander, Mrs. Herman D. Kountze, Mrs. Nelson B. Burr, Mrs. William McNair and Mrs. Lewis Gawtry.

The National Maritime Union, at a membership meeting last night attended by 2,000 men, rejected the last wage offer submitted by the American Merchant Marine Institute and instructed its negotiating committee to continue its discussions with the operators.

The Chicago Symphony Orchestra's Golden Jubilee award of $500 for the best orchestral work submitted by an American composer was won by Carl Eppert of Milwaukee, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Eppert carried off the first prize with his "Symphonic Suite."

The thermometer dropped to the lowest point of the Winter -- 9.1 degrees -- at 3:15 A.M. yesterday. The extreme cold turned remaining snowpiles into banks of ice and required the assemblage of the largest snow-removing force used this season.

The cry of "Track!" will resound through the North this week-end when a record throng of skiers descends on slopes and trails where the best snow conditions of the Winter prevail. Reports yesterday indicated that there was sport all over, with skiers having merely to point their wooden runners down the mountainside to enjoy the thrill of keeping up with them.

Because he likes to read books, enjoys the calm life of a history teacher, and wants to pursue a less hectic and more scholarly course, Dr. Nelson P. Mead, acting president of City College for the last two years, is voluntarily retiring from his office today.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Under Japanese mediators, delegates representing Thailand and French Indo-China sped armistice negotiations toward a conclusion tonight to clear the decks for Tokyo talks on final peace and other questions involving their future.

A long-standing conspiracy among the Aluminum Company of America, the great German dye trust, four other concerns and nine individuals was charged yesterday in three Federal indictments handed up here. The effect of the combination, it was alleged, has been to curtail the supply of magnesium both here and in England and to set up arbitrary and excessive prices for the metal, which is one-third lighter than aluminum.

In the event of a national emergency, the greater part of the domestic air fleet of the United States could be mobilized for active service in less than a day, T.B. Wilson, chairman of the board of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., asserted last night before a gathering of aeronautical experts attending the annual meeting at Columbia University of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who addressed the American Youth Congress here a year ago and defended it against charges of "Communist domination," has declined an invitation to speak at a gathering here next month sponsored by the congress.

The Delaware Hudson Company, a holding agency which controls the Delaware Hudson Railroad, the Hudson Coal Company and other properties, reported yesterday a net income of $494,745, or 96 cents a share on capital stock, in 1940. Its statement for the year and the three months ended on Dec. 31 follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Income payments to individuals in the United States last year totaled $74,300,000,000, which was more than in any year since 1930 and 6 per cent more than in 1939, it was announced today by Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones.

Joe Louis, Detroit's famed Brown Bomber, tonight will make the thirteenth defense of the world heavyweight championship he won in 1937 from James J. Braddock when he undertakes his second title bout in less than seven weeks.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30 -- The Pennant horse, Maeda, now 5 and so lightly regarded even by stable connections that he was not nominated for either the rich McLennan or Widener stakes, took the featured Fort Lauderdale Purse at Hialeah Park today to the surprise of many bettors.

Guy J. Swope, who will succeed Rear Admiral William D. Leahy, retired Chief of Naval Operations and now Ambassador to France, as Governor of Puerto Rico, sailed yesterday for San Juan on the Porto Rico liner Borinquen, accompanied by Mrs. Swope and a group of friends who will attend his inauguration on Feb. 3.

Mayor La Guardia revealed yesterday that the Navy Department, as part of its total defense program, was planning to double the capacity of the Navy Yard in Brooklyn by constructing, at a minimum estimated cost of $15,000,000, two new shipbuilding drydocks, in each of which super-battleships of at least 45,000 tons could be built.

Charles F. Noyes added yesterday to his realty investments in downtown Manhattan by purchasing the five-story building at 128 Front Street from the General Realty and Utilities Company through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., in an all-cash deal.

In a struggle that presented the unusual sight of the New York Americans leading their opponents by three goals at one stage, the forces led by Red Dutton managed to squeeze through to victory over Chicago at Madison Square Garden last night. The Black Hawks, on a late surge, whittled the New York lead, but when time ran out the Americans were on top, 5 to 4.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Intergovernmental Committee for the settlement of European refugees in the Western Hemisphere was told today that 1,000 additional settlers would be established this year at the Sosua Colony in the Dominican Republic.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 30 -- Finding themselves snowed under by a volume of work they cannot possibly handle by the time originally set for adjournment, delegates to the Regional Conference of the River Plate took today off, trying to find some way out of their difficulty.

The united support of all American Federation of Labor unions in this city was pledged to the Allied Printing Trades Council yesterday in its campaign to recapture for New York City some of the printing work lost to other centers in recent years.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -- A new and simplified model of the electron microscope, the new super-eye which has revealed to the gaze of man new worlds so minute that they remained beyond the reach of light, was described here today before the annual Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers by James Hillier, A.W. Vance and V.K. Zworykin of the Radio Corporation of America's electronic research laboratories at Camden.

LONDON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's warning of an allout attack by land, sea and air in his speech today was cited in authoritative British quarters today as stressing the need for shipment of all available United States war supplies to Great Britain without delay.

TORONTO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Sweeney Schriner's seventeenth goal of the season, scored within the last three minutes of the third period, brought the first-place Toronto Maple Leafs a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight and ran their National Hockey League lead to 6 points over the idle Boston Bruins.

An appeal to Governor Lehman to reconsider his recommendation to the Legislature of a 2 per cent cut in State aid to education, was made yesterday by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education. Mr. Marshall pointed out, in a letter to the Governor, that the proposed cut. would mean a $1,000, 000 decrease for schools in New York City.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Hog prices were active today closing 15 to 25 cents higher and topping at $8.40. Choice 180 to 240-pound hogs brought $8.15 to $8.35. Fat steer trade continued dull and weak to 25 cents lower with other classes generally steady but slow. Fat lambs were 15 to 25 lower with closing bids as much as 50 cents off.

In response to rebukes from an official spokesman of the Vichy government in France, Mlle.
