Eve Curie elaborated yesterday on her statement printed Jan. 23 in THE NEW YORK TIMES, in which she said that the blockade should be left to Great Britain as a weapon important as a means to aid British victory.
Two Astoria-bound local trains of the Second Avenue elevated line collided yesterday morning at Second Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, injuring three men and shaking up fifty-two other passengers.

Maxwell Low, operator, has purchased from the Mutual Life Insurance Company through Armstrong Brothers, brokers, the three-story business building at 410-414 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx. This is the second deal in the immediate vicinity to be reported by the Armstrong firm in as many days, the Bronx Savings Bank having just acquired for an addition to its headquarters building two parcels of land on the opposite side of East Tremont Avenue.

"Gone With The Wind" played to 33,566 more paid admissions during the first week of its second engagement at the Capitol than was recorded for a similar period during its original showing at the theatre more than a year ago. Metro, distributors of the Selznick production, also reported that the film grossed more for its first week than "Babes In Arms" and "Northwest Passage."

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Jan. 30 -- War finance figures for the nine months ended Dec. 31, announced by Finance Minister Walter Nash, indicate this country has experienced no difficulty in paying its way up to now. Mr. Nash gave the total revenue at $110,000,000, only $2,000,000 short of the previous year's figure; expenses at $110,000,000, compared with $128,000,000 in 1939.

The Playwrights Company is willing to learn for itself what the box office reaction is to Sunday performances. Therefore Elmer Rice's play "Flight to the West" will be performed this Sunday afternoon and evening. Curtain time: matinee, 3; night, 8.
VICHY, France, Jan. 30 -- This seat of government tonight has a case of nerves once more.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -- Dr. Charles E. Beury, president of Temple University for fifteen years, as given the trustees his resignation, effective prior to the opening the 1941-42 academic year.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 30 -- Heinrich Himmler, chief of the Gestapo [German secret police], has arrived in Oslo, Norway, and although officially great secrecy is maintained as to the reasons for his visit, no one in Norway doubts that he has been sent by the German Government to teach the Quislingists the Gestapo technique for breaking opposition and overcoming discontent, according to dispatches received here.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe required fifty-five innings tonight to score his third successive victory in defense of the World three-cushion billiard championship.

Gold holdings as stated in the subjoined table represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title to actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 30, 1934.

Deposits in mutual savings banks in the United States amounted to $10,617,758,621 on Dec. 31, a new high record, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday. However, the gain in the final six months of 1940 was only $27,920,794, smallest for any half-yearly period in recent years.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 30 (AP) -- While the conquering British consolidated their position in Derna, Libya, mechanized units struck on today toward Bengazi. Some of the Italian defenders of Derna -- said to have totaled approximately 10,000 -- were believed to have been able toward the end of the battle to withdraw westward, but of this there was no positive confirmation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. issued a call today for the Republican National Committee to meet here on March 24, when, he said, he would present his resignation as chairman. The executive committee will meet at a luncheon, after which the full committee will consider Mr. Martin's resignation and other matters pertaining to party organization.

Net earnings of the Warner Swasey Company, Cleveland turret lathe manufacturers, amounted to $3,371,283 after all deductions, including provision for estimated Federal income and excess profits taxes, according to the annual report for 1940 mailed to stockholders yesterday.
JUST in case anything important occurs tonight -- like a knockout of Joe Louis by Red Burman -- it might be mentioned in advance that this Burman has some distinctive marks about him.

Men's wear wool goods mills continue to book substantial business on Fall offerings of suitings and coatings during the past week, according to the weekly review of the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Practically all of the business was at the prices named in the week previous which showed advances averaging 25 cents a yard above levels quoted on Spring lines last August.
LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Bank of England bought u106,000 of gold in the week ended on Jan. 29, raising its total holdings to 1,217,000, the bank's weekly statement showed today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 30 -- Ray Brock, NEW YORK TIMES correspondent at Belgrade, and Winston Burdett, Belgrade correspondent of the Columbia Broadcasting System, were barred today from the use of international telephone by a decree of the Yugoslav Foreign Ministry. The suspension is supposed to extend for seven days.

BOSTON, Jan. 30 -- Invitation for bids on 1,600,000 pairs of service shoes, sent out today from the Boston Quartermaster Depot, indicate the Army's willingness to deviate from standard specifications and to accept at least half of these shoes soled with rubber instead of leather.

The additional appropriations voted on Wednesday in the House for the Army for clothing and equipment will be used to contract as early as possible for various supplies for delivery during the 1942 fiscal year at periods that are convenient for the industries concerned, aiming at minimum interruption of commercial production, it was reported here yesterday.

VICHY, France, Jan. 30 (UP) -- A "Free French" force that invaded Libya from the Lake Chad region has destroyed Italy's only airplane base in the far south of Libya and is now roaming the desert on a mission of destruction and conquest that may again bring it into the news at any time, it was reported today.

A steadier tone developed in the cotton market yesterday and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advance of 3 to 4 points. The continued briskness of business in the cotton cloth market and the high operating rate of domestic mills were factors in the moderate price recovery.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Slowing up the pace at which he has been making the rounds of London, Wendell L. Willkie spent a leisurely but profitable day today on his self-appointed fact-finding expedition to war-time Britain.

A poster by Miss Ruth Drucker, showing one of the city's park squirrels poised on a leaning tree trunk and bearing the slogan, "Preserve Your Parks," won first prize yesterday in a competition conducted by the Municipal Art Society in its campaign to curb vandalism in the parks.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 30 -- The state funeral today of Count Stephen Cskay was attended by Admiral Nicholas Horthy, the Regent, special delegations from Germany, Italy and Yugoslavia and the entire Cabinet, the diplomatic corps and representatives of the army and Parliament.

Baseball executives are groping in the dark, trying to figure how hard the Selective Service Act will hit the national pastime. A United Press survey reveals that major league baseball probably will lose more prominent players the coming season than anybody expected last Fall.

The sum of $500,000 has already been raised toward construction and equipment of the $3,000,000 Cardinal Hayes Memorial High School and $1,500,000 is expected before September, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York announced yesterday.

George Scalise, former president of the Building Service Employes Union, yesterday was sentenced to prison for three and one-half years for income tax evasion by Judge Mortimer W. Byers in the Brooklyn Federal Court. The former A.F. of L. official will serve the Federal sentence after he has completed his ten-to-twenty year term for grand larceny in Sing Sing.

Wendell L. Willkie will not run for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District at the special election which Governor Lehman will call to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson.

Today's events: "Lohengrin," special non-subscription performance, 1:45 P.M., and Ballet Divertissement and "Don Pasquale," 8:15, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30: St. Olaf Choir, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Jussi Bjoerling, tenor, Town Hall, 8:30; Midtown Symphony Orchestra, Auditorium of the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street, 8:30; Blanche Winogron, piano, New Studio of Brooklyn Heights, 69 Willow Street, Brooklyn, 8:30.

The nervous state of investors' minds over the war situation was demonstrated further yesterday when the stock market repeated its performance of Wednesday and prices again were reduced more than two points. While the decline did not approach the proportions of the previous session, the selling was on a broader scale and the volume on the Stock Exchange jumped to 775,770 shares, compared with 599,690 for the preceding day.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 30 -- The most significant result of the social welfare activities of Junior Leagues is that participating members become well-informed, civic-minded citizens, Miss Virginia Howlett of New York City, secretary of the Community Service Department of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America, Inc., said today.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- A possibility that W. Kingsland Macy, Suffolk County Republican chairman, might be named to the Board of Regents to succeed Dr. George J. Ryan of Queens, whose term expires this year, was discussed today.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 30 -- The purpose of Japan's insistence that only she was competent to mediate the hostilities between French Indo-China and Thailand was cleared up today when the price of that "mediation" was revealed. Among other concessions, it entails a virtual Japanese monopoly on the purchase of Indo-China's rice crop. [Indo-China is the largest rice-exporting country in the world.]

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Assertions by the Ford Motor Company that fear of union seizure of a plant by a sit-down strike motivated the discharge of members of the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers in 1937 were declared unwarranted today in a government brief opposing a Supreme Court review of a Sixth Circuit Court decision against the automobile concern.

A store at 70 East Forty-second Street has been leased by Rice Hill, and Joseph Schlamp, brokers, to Peterson's Tobacco Corporation. It is in the Lincoln Building, adjoining the new Airline Terminal Building, and was occupied by the TWA before the latter moved to the new terminal.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Again there was little movement in the stock markets today although most sections continued steady.

It would be unfortunate if the plan for manufacturing "500 airplanes a day" proposed by Walter P. Reuther of the C.I.O. were to become a quasi-political issue discussed with all the emotional partisanship that such an attitude toward it would involve. The main issue raised is a purely technical one.

A cavalcade of songs and dances of four decades, beginning in 1901, passed in review before more than 2,000 persons at the New Decade Mardi Gras and Ball, given last night in the grand ballroom and adjoining suites of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A few hours after Secretary Morgenthau had explained at a press conference this morning that the $65,000,000,000 debt limit which he requested yesterday would be sufficient to take care of aid-to-Britain expenditures, under the Lease-Lend Bill, as well as United States requirements, the Ways and Means Committee of the House, by a party vote, rejected a Republican proposal to make the limit $60,000,000,000.

The report of the finance committee of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, made public yesterday by Thomas I. Parkinson, president, showed total assets as of Dec. 31 of $2,564,000.000. This is an increase of $162,000,000 over the preceding year.

PANAMA, R.P., Jan. 30 -- The largest military review ever held in the Canal Zone marked honors paid today to President Arias at Fort Clayton. Fourteen thousand khaki clad and helmeted defenders of the Panama Canal marched past the stand, followed by seventy-eight airplanes at an elevation of only 500 feet.

In a match ranking with the best seen in this city in recent years, Richard Rothschild of the Downtown A.C. narrowly averted defeat at the hands of S. Ellsworth (Sandy) Davenport 3d of the Harvard Club last night in the Class A championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at the Yale Club.

BERLIN, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Adolf Hitler today warned the United States that every American ship attempting to carry last-minute aid to the British "will be torpedoed." Germany and Italy are ready if the United States chooses to plunge into the war and "any one who seeks to destroy Germany will get a rude awakening," the Reichsfuehrer said in defiant answer to President Roosevelt's program of all-out aid to Britain.

Bruno Walter opened the program of the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall with a first performance by this organization of a work by an American -- Emerson Whithorne's symphonic poem, "The Dream Pedlar."

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 31 -- Appatently aimless sporadic raids by single planes over Southern and Eastern England and by a few planes over Scotland, the machine-gunning of a small town after a few bombs had caused some deaths and injuries, and the biggest attack for some time on the Dover balloon barrage, summarizes the Air Ministry's account of yesterday's raids by Germany.

Formation of the Committee for Inter-American Cooperation was announced yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor, with the purpose of promoting closer cultural, political and economic relations with Latin America.

Secretary Morgenthau is right when he insists that the legal national debt limit must be raised. Congress may reasonably debate the question whether it needs to be raised at this time from the present $49,000,000,000 figure to one of $65,000,000,000, or whether a smaller increase will be enough; but a substantial increase is the inevitable result of the Government's previous and present fiscal and political policies.
Two events of considerable significance in widely separated parts of the world occurred yesterday.

I desire to take this opportunity to commend THE NEW YORK TIMES for its able editorial urging that the Lend-Lease Bill be revised in order to bring about a maximum of national unity in the emergency confronting our country.
DETROIT, Jan. 30 -- The Ford Motor Company will refuse to undertake defense contracts containing the National Defense Commission's labor policy restrictions, I.A. Capizzi, Ford counsel, said tonight.

Ministers of religion and leaders of thought in the theological world were censured last night by Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College, for starting propaganda, including the publishing of new magazines, "to persuade the great Christian public of America that war is our inevitable course."

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 31 -- The death penalty for collecting forbidden information is provided in a new anti-espionage bill now before the House of Representatives. The proposed law makes the gathering of political information an offense in certain cases, in addition to military and economic information, which are already drastically protected.

The huge shipment of gold from South Africa which arrived here last week on the United States cruiser Louisville, a shipment on which unofficial estimates ran as high as $200,000,000, has not entered the monetary gold stock of the United States, the weekly figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Kayak II was formally declared out of the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap today, leaving Owner Charles S. Howard of San Francisco with only two candidates for the big purse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Higher prices for food and farm products accounted for an advance in the general level of wholesale prices in the week ended on Jan. 25, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 80.8, compared with 80.6 on Jan. 18 and 79.1 a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -- Negotiated contracts have been concluded by the Army Quartermaster for the manufacture of 730,000 shirts from 4.8 to 5.2 ounce khaki jean cloth and 765,000 from the regular 8.2-ounce khaki cotton cloth, it was learned today.

The French freighter Guadaloupe, 2,876 gross tons and 312 feet long, which was built as the Croisine at Gothenburg in 1936, arrived yesterday with twelve passengers from Marseilles via Oran, Algeria, Casablanca, French Morocco, and Martinique. The vessel was under the command of Captain Julian Mennicotte and docked at Pier 1, North River. She sailed from Marseilles on Dec. 23.
Results of the 1940 competition for the three perpetual challenge trophies offered by Country Life for American dogdom were announced yesterday.

The question of how many Americans share the viewpoint of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh in favoring a negotiated peace between Germany and England, how many want the British to try to make the best peace they can now, instead of continuing the war, has been put to voters in a nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Mainly owing to an increase of non-member deposits, the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $60,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $6,800,000, 000, according to figures made public yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Air Home Security Ministries issued this communique today:

If it were decided suddenly to scrap or close down 53 per cent of our aircraft factories during 1941, how would Congress react? Just what would the people think? Suppose the reason given for such a shut-down was that the Army or Navy didn't like the types of aircraft those factories were turning out.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- A bill, designed to supplement existing Federal, State and local housing programs by providing an incentive to private capital to engage in rehabilitation of slum areas of cities in the State, was introduced in the Legislature today by Assemblyman Mitchell of Manhattan and Senator Desmond of Orange County.

A growing deficiency in the number of men supplied for the draft by New York City Selective Service boards was noted yesterday. Inductions in the third draft call in the Second Corps Area are 1,202 behind schedule. This shortage is greater than the combined deficiencies of the first and second induction periods, according to Army spokesmen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Chancellor Hitler's threat to torpedo all ships carrying United States supplies to Great Britain interpreted in some circles tonight as an attempt to frighten Congress into curbing President Roosevelt's powers under the pending Lend-Lease Bill.

With contract negotiations in the dress industry still deadlocked, Mayor La Guardia announced last night that he had designated Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, as his personal observer in future conferences between the Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.F. of L., and five employer associations.

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers announced two moves on the legal front last night in its fight with the broadcasting industry over music heard on the air. It disclosed that suit had been filed in Federal Court late Wednesday against the Columbia Broadcasting System for alleged use on Jan. 14 of an ASCAP song, "Don't Be That Way," by Benny Goodman, Mitchell Parish and Edgar Sampson, over WEEI, Columbia's station in Boston.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes set up an advisory committee to the bituminous coal division today to recommend a legislative policy and administrative practice. The Bituminous Coal Act expires within three months.

Production of armaments for British use on an "ever-increasing" scale was declared by Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles last night to be "the course least fraught with danger" and most likely to keep the United States out of war. Passage of the Lease-Lend Bill, he said, "would greatly facilitate" such aid.

ATHENS, Jan. 30 -- It can now be stated that yesterday afternoon, just after the Italians had learned of General John Metaxas's death, they began a series of heavy attacks on all fronts with trench mortars, machine guns, infantry attacks and considerable air activity. The entire movement was repulsed.

It will be a pretty impressive set of meet records that the athletes will aim at in the Millrose games at Madison Square Garden tomorrow. Director Fred Schmertz carefully refrained yesterday from prophesying how many would be broken.
BERLIN, Jan. 30 -- Following are textual excerpts from Adolf Hitler's speech today:

A minimum fund of $375,000 will be needed to maintain the Salvation Army's fifty-eight New York institutions and services during 1941, it was announced yesterday as plans for the raising of the money were approved at a meeting of the army's Greater New York citizens' advisory board.

Brooklyn police and medical authorities conducted laboratory experiments yesterday to determine the identity of the body unearthed Wednesday from a lime-lined grave in a desolate meadow near Lyndhurst, N.J., a crew of workmen employed by District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn continued digging the area with spades and a steam shovel in search of more bodies.

BERLIN, Jan. 30 -- Declaring that German military forces on land, on sea and in the air were armed as never before in their history, Reichsfuehrer Hitler repeated to the German people today over a national radio hookup his New Year's prophecy that Germany would defeat Britain in 1941.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 30 -- The Jewish Welfare Federation of New Jersey, including a delegation of more than 100 Jewish War Veterans and their families, made an inspection tour of Fort Dix today. Members of the federation from all parts of the State came to this huge military reservation to get first hand knowledge of the conditions under which the federalized national guardsmen and trainees from the selective service boards are being trained.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Administration's lease-lend bill was reported favorably by the House Foreign Affairs Committee today by a vote of 17 to 8. Speaker Rayburn said that it was planned to start debate on the measure in the House Monday and that efforts would be made to pass it by the end of the week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The market value of total sales on all registered national securities exchanges in the United States decreased in 1940 27.1 per cent from the total during 1939, according to figures made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Check transactions of the principal cities of the nation in the week ended on Wednesday rose 9.7 per cent to a total of $5,549,519,000, from the $5,057,333,000 recorded for the comparable week a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Officials of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania, one of the largest units in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company system, announced yesterday that $20,000,000 of the company's 6 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock had been called for redemption.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday that he had turned over to District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey evidence involving three city employes and the president of a business concern in Queens in a conspiracy to defraud the city of sales tax payments.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Prices of wheat continued on the downgrade today, with May selling at a new low since late last November and September went into new seasonal low grounds. Bearish sentiment predominated from the start, with the weakness in securities having considerable influence.
BERLIN, Jan. 30 -- Authorized Nazi sources said today that they agreed with criticisms of the Vichy regime that had appeared in Paris newspapers.

Stefan Hirsch's last previous one-man show here was held in 1932. Since a period of nine years has intervened, considerable interest attaches to his present reappearance -- a retrospective one-man show that opened this week at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, to remain current until Feb. 10.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday, at a special meeting in City Hall, a contract awarded by the Board of Transportation to the Associated Metals and Minerals Corporation, 40 Rector Street, for demolition of the Second Avenue elevated structure between Fifty-ninth and 128th Streets.

Friendly horseplay between two young men resulted in their deaths yesterday when they fell against the door of an elevator shaft. Their combined weight forced it from its runner and sent them toppling eight floors down the shaft of the loft building at 36 East Thirty-first Street.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday, at a special meeting in City Hall, a contract awarded by the Board of Transportation to the Associated Metals and Minerals Corporation, 40 Rector Street, for demolition of the Second Avenue elevated structure between Fifty-ninth and 128th Streets.

Friendly horseplay between two young men resulted in their deaths yesterday when they fell against the door of an elevator shaft. Their combined weight forced it from its runner and sent them toppling eight floors down the shaft of the loft building at 36 East Thirty-first Street.

What has been one of the most popular events of indoor polo, the annual invitation tournament of the New York Athletic Club, is to be held again this season despite the curtailment in the sport brought about by the closing of armories in the war emergency.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 -- Paramount today signed Elliott Nugent, playwright and director, to direct "Nothing but the Truth," with Bob Hope and Paulette Goddard, which will go before the cameras on March 24, Nugent's last film was "The Cat and the Canary," with Hope and Miss Goddard, which Paramount released in 1939.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Prices of wheat continued on the downgrade today, with May selling at a new low since late last November and September went into new seasonal low grounds. Bearish sentiment predominated from the start, with the weakness in securities having considerable influence.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 31 -- Trampfast, an unheralded white bullterrier swept through his breed in his first appearance in a show ring today and attracted wide attention among the terrier folk at the opening day of the twenty-eighth annual show of the Maryland Kennel Club in the Fifth Regiment Armory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Roosevelt said at his press conference that the government was ready to commandeer if necessary any plant essential to the defense program. He also stated that the late Ambassador Dodd had quoted to him Senator Wheeler as saying that Nazi domination of Europe was inevitable.
BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- Miss Dorothy Goos, 12-year-old representative of the Skating Club of New York, carried off the women's novice crown in the United States figure skating championships tonight.

The Black Diamond Line has sold the cargo vessel Black Falcon to the Luckenbach Steamship Company for service on the intercoastal run, it was disclosed here last night. The Black Falcon was one of the vessels sought in December by British interests, but early last month the Maritime Commission announced its decision to disapprove the sale.

IF you could go to England, as Mr. Hopkins and Mr. Willkie have gone, to see how the Britons are standing up under history's most crucial siege, you might, like them, talk to some of the people who speak in "War Letters From Britain,"* brilliantly edited by Diana Forbes-Robertson and Roger W. Straus Jr., with a foreword by Vincent Sheean.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Federal Trade Commission has ordered the Robinson Clay Products Company of New York City and Russell I. Pinkley and Urban G. Weckesser, trading as Empire Clay Products Company, Rochester, N.Y., distributors of vitrified pipe and other building materials, and twenty-seven dealers selling in the Rochester are to cease their alleged conspiracy to restrain competition by maintaining uniform prices for building materials.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 31 -- After deliberating almost eleven hours in Superior Court, a jury tonight acquitted Joseph Spell, a Negro, of the charge of assaulting Mrs. John K. Strubing Jr. of Greenwich, at whose home he was employed as butler and chauffeur.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The "Free French" commander, General Charles de Gaulle, called today upon the unbeaten French armies under General Maxime Weygand in North and West Africa to throw off their "shameful" inertia and help "complete the conquest of Italian Libya."

Lord Halifax has said that first among Great Britain's war aims is the winning of the war; after this will come political, social and economic reconstruction. It is a courteous way of saying that the British people have more pressing business on hand than that of charting a new world for after the war.

The absence of any sizable special dividends and the decision of several large corporations to defer dividend actions because of tax laws were the two principal factors which brought about a decline in dividends declared last month from the payments declared in the two preceding months, as well as from those authorized in January, 1940.
BERLIN, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

The following table gives the amount of the dealings in the stocks from which the averages, are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

Notably spotty results featured January fur sales in many sections of the country, reports in merchandising circles here yesterday indicated. Stores in some areas showed sharp increases, but these were offset by declines under a year ago in many instances and gave a general picture of "only fair" to "unsatisfactory" volume for the month.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Administration leaders in the House pushed forward today their plans to bring the lease-lend bill to the floor next week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Lake Superior District Power Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment reporting that the public offering price of the concern's 35,000 shares of 5 per cent preferred stock of $100 par value would be $102.50 a share.

New York yesterday sent a record total of 480 men to camp through the two Selective Service induction centers in Manhattan and Jamaica, to make the city's total since Nov. 25, when the first call began, 8,888 men.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 31 -- The Royal Air Force is pummeling the Italian defenses in Libya between Derna and Bengazi. Yesterday, as British ground forces advanced westward from Derna, British bombers swooped down on Barce, blasting hangars and other buildings in a series of raids on the airdrome on the main road to Bengazi.
I watched Seton Hall's basketball team play Villanova, and my verdict is that Seton Hall is a fine team -- on its home court.

Donald Frame, the defending titleholder from the Harvard Club, gained the remaining bracket in the semi-final round of the Class A championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association last night at the Yale Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, directly and through its subsidiary Defense Plant Corporation, has made commitments of more than $62,000,000 to stimulate defense production in New York State.

Joseph Rogers Paull, president of the Standard Meter Company of Hartford, Conn., died suddenly in a hotel here last night after a heart attack. Mr. Paull, who lived in Hartford and was in New York on a business trip, was 69 years old.

In the second phase of their program to test various media for the promotion of denim products, the Associated Denim Producers are starting a newspaper campaign in Baltimore and Youngstown, the organization announced yesterday. The first tests were confined to radio in selected Midwest markets.

Twenty-three 5-year-old boys and girls, garbed in caps and gowns, received diplomas yesterday at the West Side Center of the Children's Aid Society, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street, in a ceremony equal in dignity to any displayed at similar college and university exercises.

In a setting bedecked with thistles, firs and authentic tartans of various Scottish clans, the Scotch Ball was given last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, under the auspices of the British-American Ambulance Corps, to raise funds for four Scottish war relief organizations.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 31 -- Sweetness and light pervades the surface of the men's service club here, but underneath is a seething clash of personalities, Miss Ernestine Latimer, junior hostess, who reported for duty on Jan. 3, has submitted a resignation effective today, but the status of her resignation is indefinite.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 31 -- Dr. Charles V. Chapin, whose theories on public health problems have been adopted throughout the world, and who was Superintendent of Health here for forty-eight years until he retired in 1932, died today at the age of 85.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The lull in the German attack on the British Isles is due to a desperate search for a type of airplane which will outmode all others and complete the otherwise perfected arrangement for an invasion, Secretary Knox told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today during testimony in favor of the lease-lend bill.

An aged, frail and bedraggled beggar, whose plight moved Magistrate Anthony F. Burke to taking steps to help him, turned out yesterday to be a man of such means that the judge ended up by fining him $25 and announcing that if he had the beggar's $25,917 in savings accounts he would "be down in Palm Beach."

Has not the time come for us to rid ourselves of the belief that some supernatural kind of efficiency is inherent in a totalitarian form of government? This myth has been drummed into our ears for fifteen years, but it rests upon the flimsiest kind of base, because a totalitarian system is efficient only when its leader is an extraordinarily capable administrator.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's warning yesterday of a coming increase in submarine warfare is interpreted today by authoritative quarters as indicating an "expansion in quantity and intensification" of the U-boat forces rather than a change in their methods of warfare.

Rabbi Moses Soloveitchik, senior Professor of Talmud at Yeshiva College and an international authority on that subject, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital of complications that followed pneumonia. He was 62 years old.
Despite a sharp reduction in activity, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to advance, and final quotations were 4 to 8 points higher than on Thursday.

MANILA, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Manuel Quezon, Commonwealth President, said today that defense of the Philippines rests with the United States but that Filipinos are ready to do their share if the country becomes involved in war.

In most respects, the statement for December and for the calendar year 1940 emphasized the abnormal influences which shaped our foreign trade. With exports to Continental Europe cut down by the British blockade, it had very lately been supposed that even the United Kingdom's large war munitions purchases would soon fail to counterbalance the loss.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Jan. 28 (Delayed) -- Once again the weekend will have to be a more or less meatless one. Heavy snows and severe cold dislocated traffic. Probably some districts will find they have too much meat. The position is bad for the butcher, as for the customer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Spokesmen for the steel industry conferred at length today with William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, and pledged further enlargement of productive capacity in the current year and realignment of orders and deliveries to yield the greatest over-all production.

VICHY, France, Jan. 31 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's reply to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's memorandum sent at Christmas is still awaited here. Possibly it has not been overeasy to draft, since it calls obviously for a definition of "collaboration."

PORTBOU, Spain, Jan. 31 -- It is conceded on all sides that the war is about to take a new turn, but is that turn necessarily military? There are some observers who believe the change might conceivably be brought about through diplomatic and political channels.

President Fulgencio Batista of Cuba evidently believes that the way to cure a dog bite is to give the patient a hair of the dog that bit him. Senor Batista wants to stop totalitarian propaganda in Cuba. This means, as our Havana dispatch interprets him, "any form of propaganda against the democratic form of government."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Automotive products exported from the United States during December were valued at $26,263,648 as compared with November's exports which amounted to $28,894,555 and with the December, 1939, total of $25,664,629, the Commerce Department said today.
The annual report of the Canada Life Assurance Company shows total assets on Dec. 31, 1940, of $275,583,490, compared with $268,046,507 at the end of 1939.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 31 -- Colonel William J. Donovan, President Roosevelt's special envoy, arrived here by air this afternoon from Athens, accompanied by Colonel Dykes of the British War Office, who has been with him on his tour.

With Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the State Racing Commission, appearing as star witness, the joint legislative committee for the study of the New York pari-mutuel system opened its public inquiry here yesterday by listening to race-track experts who testified unanimously that the first year of legalized betting in New York had been a glowing success for the sport, the public, the tracks -- and the State treasury -- alike.

The New York City Information Center, Pershing Square, is presenting for three weeks an exhibition of plates by the Index of American Design unit of the WPA Art Project. Artists of the unit will give daily demonstrations of the technique employed in recording objects.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in the first month of 1941 dropped to the smallest for any month since last September; it was also the dullest for a corresponding month in twenty-two years, or since January, 1919. Sales last month, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 13,294,670 shares, compared with 18,400,428 in December, 1940; 15,991,105 in January, 1940, and 11,034,661 in January, 1919.

Three hold-up men wearing suede lumber jackets and caps pulled low walked into the Harlem office of the Bronx Brass Foundry, 2 East 137th Street, at 4 P.M. yesterday, disarmed a policeman assigned to guard a payroll and escaped with $1,790 in an automobile driven by a fourth member of the gang.

Led by Paul Vancso, Eastern champion, the Central Badminton Club continued its unbeaten pace in Class A of the Metropolitan Badminton Association by blanking Old Sixty-ninth, 5 to 0, according to the results announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Further gains in sales of washers and ironers during 1941 were predicted today by Joseph R. Bohnen, executive secretary-treasurer of the American Washer and Ironer Manufacturers Association, in announcing sales figures for the year just ended.

Bill Terry arrived in New York, yesterday with his fingers crossed. This was not to give him protection from the barbs he expects to receive tomorrow night at the baseball writers' dinner at the Hotel Commodore. Rather it was an instinctive motion as he discusssed Giant plans and chances for the coming season.

Pointing out that an increase of $120,000,000 in the monetary gold stock of the United States in January was the smallest for any month since August, 1938, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its review of credit and business conditions for publication today estimates that gold held in this country under earmark for foreign account increased about $55,000,000 in the month.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Advance British striking forces operated west of the fallen Italian base of Derna toward Benzagi today, methodically clearing the way for the expected general assault upon that important naval center, which is the capital of Eastern Libya.
A C.I.O. strike affecting $230,000,000 in national defense orders tied up production at the Elizabeth, N.J., plant of the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation yesterday.

Dr. George A. Freyberger, a Weehawken physician, has purchased from Dr. Julius Frederick Zenneck the two-family dwelling at 29 Forty-eighth Street, Highwood Park, Weehawken, N.J., which the seller has occupied for many years. The new owner plans to use the ground floor for offices, J.I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

Eight years ago, when Hitler came to power, people in Germany were vaguely hopeful. The Winter that year was cold and stormy, like this Winter. There were hunger and cold and unemployment, a depression deeper than the crisis engulfing this country when President Roosevelt took office. The German cities were tired of uncertainty and agitation, of political armies, of street fights between Nazis and Communists.
About 60,000 automobile owners in New York City bought their 1941 license plates yesterday in a record-breaking, final rush to beat the deadline for old plates of last midnight.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Aggressive and persistent buying of wheat futures attributed to a leading professional trader gave to the wheat market a firm appearance today. Despite this buying, however, prices refused to advance to any extent, due to pressure from other professionals and to fairly steady selling by housese with Southwestern connections.

Emmett F. Connely, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, has offered to appear before the House Committee on Appropriations to explain the program of public information launched by the association in May of last year.

The volume of new bonds offered here this week fell to the lowest figure for any similar period this year, amounting to $18,240,000, and represented by the appearance of only five individual issues. Last week a total of $48,530,000 in new issues was placed on the market, and offerings during this week last year amounted to $5,340,000.

The continued attack upon Marshal Petain's government by the German-controlled press of Paris, admittedly with support from Berlin, plainly indicates the necessity, from the victors' viewpoint, of bringing further pressure to bear upon that obstinate soldier-statesman.

A new group of 125 one-family homes is planned in Farmingdale, Nassau County, on a thirty-acre tract which has just been purchased by the Bobhan Development Corporation from a corporation controlled by William G. Seip.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- Rhode Island State's winning streak of ten games was snapped by Temple tonight at Convention Hall in a pulsating extra-period battle, 42 to 38, before 10,763 fans, the biggest basketball crowd in Philadelphia in three years.

Wagner's "Lohengrin" received its initial hearing of the season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House at a special performance given in memory of Sir Wilfred Grenfell and for the benefit of the Grenfell Association of America, which is furthering his work in Labrador and Newfoundland.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The first results of the Swedish Government's new alcohol program, by which it hopes at least partially to overcome the stagnation in the forest products industry resulting from the war blockade, are now becoming evident, the Commerce Department reported today.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Milton O. Loysen, executive director of the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance, ruled today that under the Unemployment Insurance Law employes may not be credited with tips as part of their remuneration when the receipt of tips was not contemplated in the contract of hire and "no tipping" signs were posted in the establishment.

A cooperative plan for speeding up the financing of defense contracts has been worked out between the National Defense Advisory Council and the four largest New York banks. The arrangement, which has the approval of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, as well as of the Defense Council, provides for clearing house for defense contract loans, operated jointly by the Chase National Bank, the National City Bank, the Guaranty Trust Company and the Bankers Trust Company.

Painstaking application of known principles of meteorology has made possible the development of a quantitative means of forecasting fog at a specific point at a specific time and in exact density, J.J. George, chief meteorologist of Eastern Air Lines, reported yesterday to the closing session of the ninth annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences.
In some recent observations on racing, John Kieran cited the fact that "Kentucky handled only $10,309,935 through the mutuels in 1940."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Sales of wholesalers in the United States, helped by an acceleration during the last three months of the year, were 7 per cent greater in 1940 than during 1939, it was reported today by the Commerce Department.

Al Regler of Bronx Vocational and Robert Wilburn of Samuel Gompers accounted for vocational high school records in winning city titles in the 12-pound shot-put and the high jump at the Textile High School gymnasium yesterday. Regler retained his title with a heave of 53 feet 1/2 inch, and Wilburn took the high jump with a leap of 5 feet 9 inches.

TRACK fans are stirred up, and not without reason. There are fast milers afoot and it's the mile that draws the crowds and the cheer in the roofed-over running season. Galloping Glenn Cunningham has retired, but the young fellows who are following where he left his famous footprints are a grand lot, and no fooling.

MADRID, Jan. 31 -- Confronted with a growing inadequacy of its own transportation and food distribution system, the government today in effect withdrew from the field and placed responsibility for feeding their workers upon the shoulders of key industrial and mining owners of Spain.

The well-to-do women of America are in a jam. They don't know what to do. They have industriously read your editorial of Jan. 8 "War Tax Policy" for light, but they are no better off. The only weapon they possess beside their knitting needles is their purchasing power. How should they use it?

The swift-moving Millrose track and field extravaganza, a sure-fire attraction every year, will fill Madison Square Garden with 15,000 spectators tonight. It will be the first of five major meets that make New York the foot-racing capital of the nation.

Fifty-three years is a long time for any person to be a teacher, but Miss Margaret J. McCooey, white-haired, her twinkling blue eyes filled with laughter, does not think so. Since Sept. 12, 1887, she has been in the New York City school system, the last eighteen years as associate superintendent at a $12,500 salary.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 31 -- Yale today announced 226 awards in six sports. The list included sixty-one major letters, which went to twenty-seven in football, fourteen in baseball, fourteen in rowing, five in polo and one in cross-country.

The city may use the proceeds of the occupancy tax for any general city purpose and is not required to set the proceeds aside in a special fund for housing subsidies, Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente ruled yesterday in dismissing a taxpayer's suit brought by Mrs. Helen C. Wilmerding to restrain the city from using the proceeds for any purpose other than housing subsidies.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Heavy receipts in the face of the week-end clean-up forced hog prices 25 to 40 cents lower today. Top was $8.15, with the bulk of choice 180 to 240-pound hogs selling at $7.85 to $8.15. With local and outside demand slow, cattle prices dropped to a new low for the week, while sheep closed 15 cents higher than yesterday's low close.

The pronounced weakness of the two preceding sessions of the stock market was checked temporarily yesterday, but the strength failed to hold through to the close and final quotations were mixed. The reduced values brought some bargain hunters into the share list, helping to start the recovery, but the demand was too limited and as soon as the buying dried up a fresh decline appeared.

The decisions the Nazi and the Fascist dictators reached when they met about the middle of last month are still kept secret. The only point that has come to the knowledge of diplomatic observers is that the demands to be urged upon the French Government prominently figured on their agenda.

The American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday that the steel-producing capacity of the United States at the close of 1940 was at a new high record of 84,152,000 net tons of steel ingots and castings annually, compared with 81,619,000 net tons annually at the close of 1939 and virtually 40 per cent above the capacity of 61,021,000 net tons available at the end of 1918.

The Rev. Laurence T. Hosie has taken up his duties as pastor of the Presbyterian Labor Temple, Second Avenue and Fourteenth Street, where for two years he has been the assistant director. Previously he was pastor of the Judson Memorial Baptist Church, Washington Square.
Rhode Island State's appearance at Madison Square Garden was a revelation to old-time metropolitan basketball followers brought up to believe that defense is paramount in a sound game.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 31 -- General Maxine Weygand refused to obey the Vichy government's instructions to return to France to report on the situation in Africa, according to the Dagens Nyheter's Berlin correspondent, who cites as his source Otto Abetz, the German Ambassador in Paris.

"That was the only man I've faced lately, except Tony Galento, who really tried to fight," commented Joe Louis in his dressing room after his triumph over Red Burman last night in Madison Square Garden. "He was a pretty tough guy, and took a good punch on the head."
BERLIN, Jan. 31 (UP) -- The sinking of more than 41,000 tons of shipping around the British Isles in German U-boat and bombing attacks was claimed today.

Sole leather tanners, concerned over criticism of large exports to Russia, which, according to some critics, may be re-exported to Germany, announced yesterday that they will seek to prevent exports in volume that might create shortages for the defense program.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Thrills, spills and ties featured today's opening of the North American speed skating championships, with an Olympic veteran and a young Eastern newcomer deadlocked for the leadership.

The Chase National Bank, one of several Wall Street institutions holding funds and securities of banks, corporations and individuals of the German-occupied Netherlands, has filed suit in the New York Supreme Court to determine whether title to an account of an Amsterdam bank belongs to the original owners or to the Royal Netherlands Government, now resident in London.

Every year the Sanitation Department plays a stubborn schedule with the team of Winter weather gods. Snow, Sleet, Slush, Ice make up a formidable backfield, but the real triple-threat performer is Cold. Because of him the current contest was turned into a veritable Ice Bowl game.

Tonight marks Al Jolson's 157th and final performance in "Hold On to Your Hats" at the Shubert Theatre. Having had a narrow escape from pneumonia recently, Mr. Jolson says the state of his health makes it compulsory for him to close the musical, which has Martha Raye, Jack Whiting and Bert Gordon in the featured roles.

Despite poor shopping weather which held down store traffic this week, sales gains over a year ago were maintained, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Wholesale and industrial buying also remained at their recent levels and deliveries continued to be stressed.

Bruno Landi, Italian tenor, who was a member of the company several seasons ago, made his return to the ranks of the Metropolitan Opera last night when Donizetti's "Don Pasquale" was presented in a repeat performance. Mr. Landi's voice is a light, flexible, lyric tenor and the audience responded enthusiastically to his voicing of the music of Ernesto, the opera's romantic lead.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31 -- A field of twenty-two, the largest of the meeting, has been named for tomorrow's Bahamas Handicap at Hialeah Park. The race will be witnessed by the Governor of Florida, but the Duke of Windsor, Governor General of the Bahamas, is not expected to attend.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Roosevelt said today that William E. Dodd, late Ambassador to Germany, told him in 1934 that Senator Wheeler had expressed the opinion at a Washington party that Nazi domination of Europe was inevitable.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 31 -- Dartmouth's skiers, who have been defeated on two occasions this season, showed signs of regaining their supremacy in the intercollegiate world by leading five rivals at the end of the opening program of the Williams Carnival today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 31 -- If information in certain usually well-informed diplomatic sources here this evening is accurate, relations between the Vichy government and Berlin are on the eve of important developments, probably within the next three days.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- A fifth call for Army training and the quotas for local boards in the State, outside of New York City, which are to be announced separately, were made public today by Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown. The total requisition, for delivery to five induction stations between Feb. 17 and Feb. 28, is 7,944.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that the government was prepared to take over the plants of the Ford Motor Company if, for defense reasons, this was deemed necessary.

Annual Interracial Youth Sunday will be observed tomorrow with an interchange of preachers between different races and groups and with sermons on "Brotherhood." Announcement will be made from many pulpits of the creation of a Christian Commission on Camp Activities, which is already preparing literature to aid churches near camps in approaching trainees and in planning suitable entertainment for them in their time off.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe said yesterday that he would send two alternative plans of reorganization for McKesson Robbins, Inc., to the Securities and Exchange Commission for study. One is to be the plan suggested by William J. Wardall, trustee, and the other that fostered by the committee for preference stockholders.

DUBLIN, Jan. 31 (UP) -- A government defense decree tonight empowered Prime Minister Eamon de Valera to set up courts-martial for civilians "should the necessity arise," such as an invasion of neutral Ireland [Eire].
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The British Middle East command issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- A picture of a gasoline pump monopoly affecting the sale of gasoline in nearly every filling station in the United States was drawn today by a Federal grand jury in two indictments returned before Judge Charles E. Woodward.

Industrial profits in the aggregate will show only moderate changes in the coming year, in the opinion of the management of the Tri-Continental Corporation, Francis F. Randolph, chairman of the board and president, said yesterday in his annual report.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31 -- Mrs. Charles O. Parsons entertained with a luncheon at the Bath and Tennis Club today for Lord and Lady Marrley. Other guests were Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer, Mr. and Mrs. R. Stuyvesant Pierreport, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Glasgow, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Carey, Mrs. George C. White, Mrs. Theodore Frelinghuysen, Everett Colby, George Lovett Kingsland and Captain Alastair Mackintosh.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Senator O'Mahoney, chairman of the Federal Monopoly Committee, said today it was his "personal opinion that legislation providing for Federal regulation of the insurance industry is about as remote as could be imagined at this time."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- A comparative statement of internal revenue collections for the calendar years 1939 and 1940, issued by the Treasury today, indicates that in every important source, except two, more taxes were collected last year than in the year before.
Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn announced yesterday the appointment of eight pastors and the transfer of twelve assistants, as follows:

OTTAWA, Jan. 31 -- How far Canada is behind Great Britain in wartime production was stressed by Munitions Minister C.D. Howe at his first press conference today since he returned from his visit to England.

HAVANA, Jan. 31 -- The yacht Gale, skippered by Harry C. Nye Jr. of the Southern Lake Michigan fleet, today won the fifteenth annual Star Class series for the Cuba Trophy with a total of 19 points for three races. This is the second consecutive year that Gale has won both the Cuba and the Bacardi Trophies.

I should like to know what newspapers look for in judging the newsworthiness of a story. My particular plaint is directed at a startling change of policy on the sports pages in regard to the coverage of pocket billiards.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- "A promissory note" pledging the performance by the Girl Scouts of America of "any required number of hours of community service in the interest of national defense" was presented today to Mrs. Roosevelt for delivery to the President, together with assurances of the eagerness with which 663,000 members of the organization in all parts of the country sought participation in the government's program.
The 115th annual Old Guard Ball was held in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore last night. The feature of the event was the colorful military review at midnight.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Wendell I. Willkie went to Dover, "Hell's Corner," today and stood on the arm of a jetty about twenty miles from German-occupied France. Mr. Willkie was most reticent about his visit to the battered port, where an invasion might come at any time, but it is reported that he saw anti-aircraft guns in action against Dornier "Flying Pencil."

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The State Banking Department announced today that it had received an application from the Nederlandsche Handel-Maatschappij, N.V., of Batavia. Netherlands Indies, for permission to establish an agency in 40 Wall Street, Manhattan.

Although weather conditions made for a spottier showing than in the previous week, retail trade here picked up toward the close of the week. Aided by continued activity in home wares lines, department stores were estimated as running about 5 per cent ahead of the corresponding period last year.

A twenty-inch water main, on the north side of Flatbush Avenue, about 100 feet west of Sterling Place, Brooklyn, burst a little before 5:45 A.M. yesterday, flooding the cellars of homes and stores in that vicinity and the BMT and IRT subway tunnels.

William N. Cohen, former Supreme Court Justice, left a net estate of $4,065,671, of which he left more than $1,500,000 to Dartmouth College, it was shown in the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday. Justice Cohen, who was a friend and adviser of President Theodore Roosevelt, was known for many years as one of the leading trial counsel of the New York bar.

Kennel representatives exchanged the American foxhound best of breed distinction to supply one of the main highlights of the annual New York hound show held yesterday at the Riding and Polo Club before a large fashionable throng of sportsmen and society folk.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe played the record low game thus far of the world three-cushion billiard tournament tonight when he defeated Clarence Jackson of Detroit, 50 to 8, in twenty-six innings. It was Hoppe's fourth successive victory.

ROME, Jan. 31 -- Two great hopes are being offered to the Italian people today as the result of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's speech. The first is that the United States has been frightened into a "more realistic" attitude toward aid to Britain and the second is that victory is certain.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 31 -- Fox announced today that Randolph Scott and Dean Jagger will be co-starred in "Lewis and Clark," an outdoor epic in color to be based on the 1804-6 exploring expedition of Meriwether Lewis and William Clark into the American Northwest. Kenneth Macgowan will produce, and writers will be assigned to prepare a scenario next week.

A priest who rushed into a burning building to lead several persons to safety and a fireman were overcome by smoke yesterday afternoon when flames spread through two old five-story tenements at 2064 and 2066 Seventh Avenue, at the southwest corner of 123d Street, driving ten families to the street.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 -- Henry Ford is ready to produce anything the government needs for national defense without a profit, provided other manufacturers do likewise, one of his company spokesmen said tonight.

At a time when one arm of the Federal Government has been smashing at trusts and monopolies with unprecedented vigor, another has established an iron-clad "monopolistic" control over the price 60,000 farmers in six surrounding States receive for milk sold in the New York City area.

The Treasury's program for financing as much as possible of the huge borrowings for defense by the sale of its obligations to real savers rather than to banks should meet with universal approval. It is not merely sound economics. It is the common-sense, democratic way of doing the job.

The United States Steel Corporation showed profits for 1940 of $8.84 a share, but the corporation feels it can afford to pay the stockholders a dividend of only $1 a share owing to the uncertainties that lie ahead. One of the uncertainties seems to be the fear that they will have to increase wages another 10 per cent.

Willis Steell, author, playwright, and former Sunday editor of the Paris edition of The New York Herald, died yesterday at a hospital in this city after a long illness. He was about 75 years old. His home was at 171 East Eighty-first Street.
LONDON, Jan. 31 UP) -- Sir Pendrill Varrier-Jones was among the physicians who in 1935 endorsed the campaign of Lord Moynihan to legalize death for persons afflicted with incurable disease.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- With the biggest group of the style shows and other merchandising events scheduled to open this coming Monday, the first of Chicago's three Spring market weeks ended today with buyer attendance slightly ahead of last year for the two apparel exhibits, Failure of registrations to come up to expectations at both the Merchandise Mart and Style Exhibitors, Inc., was blamed chiefly on icy roads.

Pledging the "utmost aid" of its 30,000 membership in national defense, the American Road Builders Association, at the final session of its annual convention, called on Congress yesterday for funds and a national program to build strategic highways up to military needs.

PLANTATION KEY, Fla., Jan. 31 -- Although the local weather prophets insisted that the northwest wind was certain to blow itself out by sun-up and leave the bonefish flats unruffled, the wind did not, so we decided to do some plain fishing.

Three times before Michael J. Flanagan, 72 years old, of 657 Second Avenue, had fought off hold-up men who had waylaid him in the street, seeking the hard-earned profits of his grocery a few doors down the avenue at No. 647. He told his customers he would never willingly surrender his money.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Senator Gillette asked Secretary Knox about a speech in which Grand Admiral Raeder of the German Navy recently said that Germany planned to become a world navy power. When Mr. Gillette referred to the speech as "bombastic," Colonel Knox said:

DES MOINES, Jan. 31 -- A revolt of some factions of the Young Republican National Federation against the leadership of Wendell L. Willkie was revealed tonight in a series of proposed resolutions, one of which described him as not qualified to speak for members of the Republican party.

The new month promises a varied assortment of fiction, light and heavy, and non-fiction in all categories, with some outstanding titles. Some of the offerings of publishers who have made known their plans for February follow. Titles are mentioned in the order of their appearance.

Gross revenues of the Pennsylvania Railroad between Jan. 1 and Jan. 23 were about $31,093,000, up 7.8 per cent from the same period last year, according to Washington advices quoting M.W. Clement, president. Freight revenues gained 9.2 and passenger revenues 6.5 per cent in the period.

New securities offered to the public here in January showed a sharp drop from the preceding month, but were larger in volume than a year ago. Bond flotations were the smallest since November, while stock offerings were the smallest since last June.

George T. Slade, former vice president of the Northern Pacific Railroad and chief adviser of the American Expeditionary Force in France on problems of transportation, who died in St. Paul, Minn., on Jan. 24, left 3,000 acres of land to the government for a bird sanctuary and named three institutions among his residuary legatees.

From the financial standpoint one of the most remarkable features of the current defense program is its complete failure to stimulate the stock market. The news is full of large Government contracts, of industries working at capacity and of greatly improved earnings.

The New York State rule restricting the use of armories to military activities is proving to be a blessing in disguise. As a result of this edict, a fine new site for indoor track meets has been uncovered in the New York Coliseum.
A letter from W. Patterson of Hawthorne, Calif., in THE TIMES of Dec. 14 attracted my attention because of its modest claims for soccer as a sport.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Reports that the United States Government planned to trade twenty Navy destroyers for the British battleship King George V were denied today by President Roosevelt, Secretaries Hull and Knox and Admiral Harold B. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Jan. 18 was 2,970,530 shares, compared with 3,996,770 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Trading by members for their own accounts was 16.50 per cent of the total volume, compared with 16.18 per cent the week before.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Senator Wheeler was out of Washington tonight, and his office staff said that they did not know where he could be reached for comment on the President's press conference developments. Mr. Wheeler, who has been suffering from a cold, departed several days ago for a rest, it was said, and left no forwarding address.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The feature of the stock markets today was the recovery of home rails, all junior issues rising 1/8 to 3/8 point. Buying was due to the nearness of dividend announcements and the opinion in the City is that they will be maintained and higher net earnings will be disclosed.

Britain not only expects invasion "soon" but is prepared and even eager for it as well as confident that the German attempt will fail, according to Sir Edward R. Peacock, English banker, and an American observer who arrived yesterday on the Yankee Clipper.

With Walter McDonald and Bob Fitzgerald getting 11 points each, Newtown High School scored its fifth North Queens P.S.A.L. triumph in as many starts by crushing Bayside, 31 -- 16, yesterday. The victors led all the way. Bryant downed Flushing, 45 -- 25, in the same division.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, whom President Roosevelt removed as chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority in 1938, asked the Supreme Court today to uphold him in his fight to declare the Presidential action illegal and to recover back salary.

"Personal Column," a French film starring Maurice Chevalier, will have its American premiere at the Little Carnegie Playhouse today. The film, which in French was known as "Pieges," was completed in Paris in December, 1939, and was directed by Robert Siodmak.

The six-story loft building at 127-131 Mercer Street, between Spring and Prince Streets, has been sold by the 127 Mercer Street Corporation to a client of P. Zaccaro Company, Inc., brokers, for use in his own business. The buyer paid cash above the first mortgage of $14,000 for the parcel, which is valued for taxation at $44,000.

As their annual costume dance and entertainment, members of the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects presented a fete entitled the Cork-screw Cotillion last night in the exhibition hall of the society's headquarters, the Beaux-Arts Institute of Design at 304 East Forty-fourth Street.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- The Narrow Fabric Company, Reading, Pa., today was awarded an Army contract for 3,121,000 yards of cord edge braid at 2.475 cents per yard, less 2 per cent thirty days.

Two boys, Negroes, who for months had held up passing motorists and others and then killed two men in a Harlem store hold-up last September, were permitted in General Sessions yesterday to enter guilty pleas to charges of second-degree murder to save them from facing sentence to death in the electric chair.

Three men were held in default of $20,000 bail each yesterday by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions as material witnesses in the shooting and killing of David (The Beetle) Beadle, boss dock loader more than two years ago after Assistant District Attorney Jacob J. Rosenblum had charged in open court that gangsters, he believed, were trying to block his inquiry by shooting and killing prospective witnesses.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Following is the text of Secretary Knox's statement before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today:

Willie Mosconi of New York, tournament leader, and Jimmy Caras of Philadelphia won double victories in the world pocket billiard championship yesterday. Mosconi, aided by a run of 96 in the second game, defeated Johnny Irish of Syracuse, 125 -- 57 and 125 -- 1, at Syracuse, and tightened his grip on first place.

Your editorial "American Diet" calls attention to a very important and very much neglected phase of our defense program. In the last paragraph of your article you hit the nail squarely on the head when you say: "If ever we had an abuse of science and technology it is in the matter of preparing food for the eye rather than for the stomach."

In London alone, as of Jan. 6, 114 Baptist churches had been destroyed or damaged by German bombs and 181 in England as a whole, the Rev. M.E. Aubrey, general secretary of the Baptist Union of Great Britain, said in a letter made public yesterday at the headquarters of the Northern Baptist Convention, 151 Madison Avenue.

Auxiliary Bishop Stephen J. Donahue was named yesterday by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman as director of the twenty-second annual appeal for Catholic Charities in the New York Archdiocese. Associated with him will be Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, secretary to the archbishop for charities.

RENO, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Joan Kaufman Biddle Wintersteen of the Philadelphia "Main Line" social set married Frank Polk, a wood-carving, jacket-clad cowboy, tonight a few hours after she had divorced Joseph M. Wintersteen of Philadelphia.

Demand for lamb showed yesterday some improvement over that of the first half of the week, but other classes had a limited outlet. Veal supplies were light to moderate, lamb moderate to normal, while there was some accumulation of steer hinds and ribs. The market was about steady on all classes.

Two moves to eliminate Communist influence in the Laundry Workers Joint Board, C.I.O., were announced yesterday. The joint board is affiliated with the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, of which Sidney Hillman, associate director of the Office for Production Management, is president.

The government's investigation of bottlenecks that may hamper production of vital defense materials is continuing, it was learned yesterday, although the grand jury that had been receiving evidence in cases of this sort was discharged Thursday.
HICKSVILLE, L.I., Jan. 31 -- Dragged down when the shrouds of his parachute caught in part of his plane, Matthew Kerr, 42 years old, an aviation instructor, was killed here this afternoon.

Large public utility, State and municipal bond retirements swelled the total of all bonds called for payment in January before maturity, exclusive of United States Government issues, to the highest figure for any month since July, 1936, and to the largest volume for any January in more than fifteen years.
ROME, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 31 -- Today's Bourse continued depressed. Although the turnover was small, there was little liquidation and a resistant tone set in toward the close. Dutch issues eased as much as 5 points.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The text of the minority report of the House Foreign Affairs Committee on the lease-lend bill is as follows:...

The building of two new "super" construction drydocks at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, which was announced Thursday by Mayor La Guardia, will set a shipbuilding and ship repair pace here that has been unmatched in the 140 years' history of the yard and will establish the New York Navy Yard as a naval shipbuilding center second only to the geographically larger Philadelphia Navy Yard, officers here said yesterday.

NEWTON, N.J., Jan. 31 -- Nine leaders and associates of the German-American Bund, including national Bundsfeuhrer G. Wilhelm Kunze, were sentenced to twelve to fourteen months in State prison by Sussex County Common Pleas Judge John C. Losey here today on charges of violating the New Jersey "race hatred" law in speeches at Camp Nordland in near-by Andover Township last June.

Fifty-eight municipalities and local housing authorities are scheduled to offer next week security issues totaling $24,329,061, a decrease of $22,397,020 from sales of $46,726,081 in the current six-day period. Next week's scheduled offerings compare with a weekly average of $34,800,998 for the year to date.

Richard Wright, 32-year-old Negro author of the best-selling novel, "Native Son," which is based in part on the ease of Robert Nixon, a Negro who died in the electric chair in Chicago in 1938 for killing a white woman, was named, yesterday as the twenty-sixth winner of the Spingarn Medal.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Jan. 31 -- Thailand [Siam] and French Indo-China ended four months of undeclared warfare along their 1,000-mile border today with an armistice drafted by Japanese mediators and signed at 6 P.M. aboard the Japanese light cruiser Natori.
On Jan. 22 THE TIMES published a letter from Richard G. Augenblick protesting the Board of Education's ban on certain textbooks used in the instruction of classes in the Italian language.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- By making public today correspondence with Rome, the State Department reminded the Italian Government that it has not forgotten nor forgiven the attack of Italian Army planes on the station of the Sudan Interior Mission at Doro in the Upper Nile Province of Anglo-Egyptian Sudan last Aug. 23, when two American missionaries were killed and two others wounded.
Mrs. Claire P. Barnet has leased a twelve-room apartment in 895 Park Avenue from Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., the agents, through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., brokers.

ATHENS, Saturday, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The taking of Italian positions "of great importance" in mountains nearly 6,000 feet high and the smashing of an Italian tank counter-attack at another point on the rugged Albanian front were announced early today by the Greek High Command.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- As a further step in strengthening Western Hemisphere economy, the Administration is preparing to ask Congress soon, it was learned today, to hasten establishment of an inter-American bank.

Against sterner opposition than he had encountered since he won the heavyweight title from James J. Braddock in June, 1937, Joe Louis last night retained the championship in his thirteenth defense of it.

Another swift greyhound was added to the Navy's rapidly increasing fleet of warships here yesterday at 11 A.M. with the commissioning of the new destroyer Edison at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn by Captain Harold V. McKittrick, captain of the yard.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The House passed today the $1,404,329,838 Independent Offices Appropriation Bill, the first of the regular fund bills to be presented to Congress.

The Chase National Bank, as trustee, will make a distribution, beginning today, at the rate of 50 per cent of the principal face amount of Lincoln Building 5 1/2s due in 1963, as a part payment on account of principal, it was announced yesterday by the Uniform Practice Committee of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc.

ATHENS, Jan. 31 -- Premier General John Metaxas was buried today after a solemn ceremony in the Athens Cathedral, seat of national Greek Orthodoxy, and thousands upon thousands of people stood hatless and silent watching the austere military parade that conducted the dead Premier to his grave.
The Continental Baking Company and its subsidiaries in the year ended Dec. 28, 1940, had a net income of $3,500,331, after depreciation. Federal income taxes and other charges.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

An investor bought from Charles Walzer, operator, the five-story apartment house for forty-six families at 615 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx. Occupying a plot 143 by 100 feet, the building contains suites of two, three, four and five rooms. It was sold for cash over a mortgage of $130,425, which was extended for five years by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
ATHENS, Jan. 31 -- Italian efforts to counter-attack ended in failure, the Greek spokesman asserted today. He added that enemy losses were heavy.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 31 -- A drive for "Midwestern control" of both the Republican party and the Young Republican branch was started today among delegates to the Young Republican National Federation convention.
LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- German raiders flying singly, but in impressive total numbers, subjected London to its third successive daylight assault today.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 31 -- Big Johnny Bulla of Chicago today shot a 66, five under par, to take the lead at the end of eighteen holes of play in the $5,000 Western open golf tournament.
