Assured by the Federal Administration that its erection at this time would not interfere with the national defense program, the Prudential Insurance Company of America announced yesterday that it would proceed with erection of an eighteen-story office building as an addition to its home quarters in Newark, N.J.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 31 -- Bearing a $1,000,000 cargo of food, clothing and medicine, the 5,100-ton freighter Cold Harbor will sail from Baltimore at noon tomorrow for Spain and Marseille.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- A musical event of unusual importance took place at the Berlin State Opera this afternoon, when Tchaikovsky's forgotten opera, "The Sorceress," was produced for the first time outside of Russia and for the first time anywhere in many decades.

All examinations for teaching licenses in the academic high schools of New York City have been canceled indefinitely and no further tests will be scheduled at present, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, disclosed yesterday.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 31 -- The Regional Conference of the River Plate set up a new principle in inter-American economic relations today when it approved a draft convention suspending operation of the most-favored-nation clause in dealings between Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Official comment on the convention approved by the River Plate Conference was not available here tonight, as its exact terms had not been received at the State Department. Privately, however, officials saw nothing in its reported details to arouse any great concern in Washington.

Many dinner parties were given in advance of the annual Blue Ridge Ball for the benefit of the Blue Ridge Industrial School of Virginia which was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The event was attended by several hundred persons of Southern descent or affiliation now living in New York.

HAVANA, Jan. 31 -- Bernardo Menendez, an employe of the Voice of the Air radio station, was shot and killed this morning on a Havana street by unknown assailants. The killers fired a fusillade of shots from an automobile and sped away.

The Appellate Division unanimously upheld yesterday a Supreme Court order requiring the reinstatement as director of menageries in the Park Department of Captain Ronald Cheyne-Stout. Captain Cheyne-Stout was ousted on March 31, 1939, after a departmental hearing on charges.

"Mother" Dallas, known throughout the lower East Side, and particularly, on the Bowery, for her kindness to homeless men and stricken neighbors, will minister no more to the needs of the poor from her own scant savings.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 1 -- London was free of aerial raiders last night and early today after German daylight attacks yesterday had resulted in casualties and property damage on a scale associated in recent months only with night assaults.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Colonel Roscoe Turner, aviator, proposed today the formation of an armada of 200,000 converted "flivver planes" manned by private pilots for home defense.

The other day an anything-short-of-war enthusiast complained bitterly about Ireland. He said the Irish, by refusing to permit the British to use the Irish ports against German submarines, were conducting themselves in a mean and contemptible way.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -- Miss Anne Strobhar, daughter of Thomas S. Strobhar of Brick House, Newton Square, and the late Mrs. Strobhar, was married to Bayard Stockton 3d, a descendant of Richard Stockton, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, this morning in the rectory of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Child, Broad and Duncannon Streets, by the pastor, the Rev. Charles B. McGinley.

THIS is a sequel to Dr. Eisenschiml's best seller of a few seasons past, "Why Was Lincoln Murdered?" It takes up the story where the other book left it, following it through the Booth episode and the trials of the alleged conspirators, and concluding with a chapter on the reputedly unsolved problems in connection with the death of Lincoln.

Housewives in the market for a new maid are facing stronger competition than ever as the opportunities for young women in industrial jobs increase. Symptoms of the situation which the National Council on Household Employment describes as growing more serious from the housewives' viewpoint, are the numerous conferences being called on the question in industrial areas.

IF WE could only figure out how to get along without tin cans we could go a long way toward disposing of one of our war-created problems. Tin, like rubber and a few other products, is one of the essential commodities of which we use more than any other nation, and of which we produce virtually none at all.
ALBANY, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP) -- The $2,000,000 Golden Gate Turf Club opened today after five weeks of postponements caused by rain.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 1 (AP) -- The former national champion, Bebby Riggs of Chicago, defeated Jack Kramer of Los Angeles, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, today to earn the right to meet Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., in the final of the University of Miami tennis tournament tomorrow.

OPENING concurrently with the exhibition of paintings, etchings and lithographs by Goya, the Chicago Art Institute has another show of rare and valuable prints illustrating a century of printmaking from 1400 to 1500. This collection is on view in galleries 58, 59 and 60 in the East Wing.

THE latter part of last year the theatre was taking the playwright to task, claiming that he was turning out no good product, hinting that he wasn't even trying. Let Washington disprove that latter charge this morning.

The Long Island University quintet played without Dolly King for the first time this season, but a sophomore, Dick Holub, filling in for the Negro star, sparked the Blackbirds to a 73-28 victory last night over Montclair Teachers College at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.

Decrying the tendency among modern teachers of biology to de-emphasize field work in the curriculum, Brooklyn College has gone out of its way to make certain that its student scientists will not lack this "essential" study, according to Professor Ralph C. Benedict, in a statement made public yesterday.

The "Magic Flute" overture, with which Arturo Toscanini signalized his return as conductor of the NBC Symphony Orchestra last night in Radio City, came over the air with a special transparency of sound and with the spirit and fantasy with which the extraordinary piece is laden.

AIRPLANES, destroyers, submarines, tanks, guns -- America's defense material. Throughout the country, in large towns and small, inland and on the coast, the wheels of defense industries are turning, in some places twenty-four hours a day. Millions of workers of all ages are streaming into factories and mills and shops to man the machines producing defense equipment.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday the suspension of Henry C. Eberhard, motorman of the Astoria-bound local train of the Second Avenue elevated line that collided with another train at Second Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street on Thursday.

While we are speeding up on the industrial front, nearly two-thirds of our drafted men are being turned back as unfit for service under today's Army standards. As yet this serious and thought-provoking situation has not been considered of enough importance to do anything about it, even to the extent that a national Health Board of Research for Defense be appointed to immediately investigate American diet customs and restrictions.

Developments of the last year in construction of new office equipment and systems, primarily designed to increase efficiency or to add to the comfort and therefore the production of the office worker, will be displayed beginning tomorrow at the National Business Show at the Grand Central Palace.

In the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton on Tuesday afternoon a fashion show and cocktail party will be given to further the work being conducted here by Refugees of England, Inc. The Countess of Abingdon is chairman in America of the relief unit and heads the committee sponsoring the benefit party.

Shipments of medical and surgical supplies to Greece will have to be speeded up if a "major health calamity'' is to be averted in that country, Dr. Haven Emerson, former New York City Health Commissioner and chairman of the American Physicians Committee to Aid Greece, warned yesterday.

HORSHAM, England, Jan. 16 (By Clipper) -- It is known that the British Board of Education is undertaking a wide survey of the whole educational prospect. A similar review was made during the 1914-18 war and resulted in the Fisher Act -- an excellent measure whose permissive clauses have scarcely been given a trial.

Family histories are so important in diagnosing and treating disease that physicians ask about them. Some diseases are hereditary and some, though not actually inherited, do manifest themselves when there is a favorable hereditary predisposition.

The authors of "Mozart, the Wonder Boy," and "Haydn, the Merry Little Peasant." add to their series of musical biographies for younger children a life of America's foremost composer. Making a prodigy seem human and likable is not an easy task, but with the first scene the character of MacDowell is indelibly and pleasantly created.

The "Old Seventh Regiment," now the 207th Coast Artillery Anti-Aircraft Regiment, New York National Guard, comprising about 1,550 officers and men, will attend a special farewell service at 4 P.M. today at St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street before its induction as a Federal Army unit on Feb. 10 and departure on Feb. 19 for Camp Stewart, Hinesville, Ga., for a year of field training.

BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- For the second time within a generation, Belgium faces famine. Famished children of the last war have grown up to see their own children facing starvation in the present conflict. By Feb. 15 supplies of baste foodstuffs in Belgium will be exhausted and the already badly undernourished population will be without food.

STEFAN HIRSCH'S one-man show at the Associated American Artists Galleries is retrospective in that it includes work dating from 1934 to the present time. The changes in style here illustrated do not indicate a definite line of progression so much as a kind of experimental elasticity in the matter of approach.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Wheeler-Nye resolution asking Britain and Germany to state their war aims almost coincided this week with the disclosure that the general staff expected a terrific German attack on Britain this Spring -- an indication of at least one war aim.

Speaking "as a consumer to producers," Major A.J. Kerwin Malone of the Army Air Corps told 100 alumni of the Daniel Guggenheim School of Aeronautics, New York University, at their second annual dinner yesterday in the Hotel Sheraton that they should not be misled by the term "defense" in the national rearmament effort.

A number of cases in which American representatives selling goods here for Japanese companies have experienced difficulties and long delays in collecting commissions for their services were reported among importers here last week. The trouble, which in some instances has led to a sharp exchange of letters and cables between the American companies and Japanese suppliers, is attributed to Japan's stringent regulations against sending funds outside the country.

Eight thousand more persons have paid to see productions at the Metropolitan Opera House during the first half of its present season than paid the first half of last season, Edward Johnson, general manager, announced yesterday in a mid-season report.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif. THE Lobero Theatre of Santa Barbara, known throughout the country for the charm of its architecture, has taken on new life with the organization of the Santa Barbara Civic Theatre. The season was to open late this week with a production of Dodie Smith's "Call It a Day."

The Rutgers University swimming team, undefeated in four meets this season, handed New York University its second setback in three starts yesterday, winning eight of the nine events for an easy 59-16 triumph at the Spence Natatorial Institute.
A five-year program for preparing teachers for the high schools of the city will go into effect with the opening of the Spring semester tomorrow at the School of Education of City College.

After their two-day rise, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned slightly easier in the short session yesterday. Closing prices were unchanged to 5 points lower, with the March and May positions establishing the greatest losses.

"Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" were presented as a double bill for the second time this season before a capacity audience yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. Leonard Warren had the role of Alfio in "Cavalleria," but otherwise the casts were unchanged from the first performance.

DR. HARVEY, who is Professor of Biology at Princeton, gives here what is probably the most complete and most up to date account of what we know about animal luminescence. His book brings together the story of discoveries all over the world by himself and other scientists, particularly since his publication in 1920 of "The Nature of Animal Light," concerning this intriguing and little-known subject.

Hanson W. Baldwin, in a recent article in THE TIMES discussing the actions between Axis aircraft and British warships in the Mediterranean, wrote: "The sinking of the first modern armored ship ever lost in war as a result of air attack was, in the long view, one of the most important events of the European conflict."

THE Ballet Theatre, after two postponements, has finally got its theatre and the opening date of its second New York season settled. It will definitely get under way at the Majestic Theatre on Tuesday, Feb. 11. As has already been announced, it will play every night except Monday, and will give matinees on Thursday and Saturday.

AUBURN, N.Y., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Paul Camillieri, who took part in 1922 in the $90,000 Albert Shattuck jewelry robbery, stepped out of Auburn Prison today and submitted to rearrest for deportation to Spain.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (UP) -- General Robert E. Wood, chairman of the American First Committee, said tonight he had been authorized by eight members of the United States Senate to issue statements of their opposition of the Administration's lease-lend bill.

Jesse Jones as Secretary of Commerce announces that income payments to individuals in the United States last year totaled $74,300,000,000, which was more than in any year since 1930 and 6 per cent more than in 1939.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 1 -- Shunning any talk about Wendell Willkie or the Lease-Lend Bill, Republican leaders from sixteen States, meeting here this afternoon, kept close to questions of party organization and finance.

Declaring that England is the only barrier between America and "the greatest flood of war ever gathered together," United States Senator Josh Lee of Oklahoma asserted yesterday that "the United States Congress is today being assaulted by the greatest campaign of Nazi propaganda which has yet been unleashed" to stop the Lease-Lend Bill, weaken it by amendments or delay it until too late.

The Hayden Planetarium presented the premiere of the "End of the World" at the Planetarium, Central Park West and Eighty-first Street, yesterday afternoon. More than 100 young and old persons witnessed the destruction of the earth five different times in as many different ways.

IN "Verdun" Jules Romains gave us a comprehensive and singularly moving re-creation of the nightmare of 1914-18. Every one recognized that volume to be not only the high point of his "Men of Good Will" cycle but also the best fictional account of World War I in any language.

I have long been a subscriber to Gandhi's periodical, Harijan, the latest number of which has just reached me with the intimation that it is to be the last for the present. Gandhi explains that, having been advised that it ought to be submitted to the censor, he has decided to suspend it rather than make this submission or expose himself and others to prosecution by not making it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- To meet what officials said were the mounting requirements of defense industries, the government's new Metals Reserve Company announced today a second purchase of 100,000 tons of South American copper.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today that 795 of the 883 standard broadcast stations in this country would shift to new frequency assignments at 3 A.M. March 29.

ACCORDING to the latest information from England, which has become the proving ground for modern air warfare, one out of eight potential pilots never reaches the solo stage because he lacks the confidence necessary to convince his instructor that he is ready for his first solo landing.

"THERE are no 'dumb' children, there are merely children with different capacities and different possibilities," Dr. Edward Liss said the other day; and he added, "Probably the most abused words in our vocabulary are 'dumb' and 'lazy.'"

BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- A University of Pennsylvania co-ed, Miss Jane Vaughn, annexed the women's United States senior figure skating crown tonight to carry away the title from Boston for the first time since 1927.

A ceremonial grand march, in which members of the junior group of the Daughters of the American Revolution, led by Miss Elaine Murray-Jacoby, will be escorted by uniformed officers of the Continental Guard of the Sons of the American Revolution, will be a dramatic feature of the Colonial Ball to be given on Feb. 15 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

Seventy per cent of those questioned by the American Institute of Public Opinion believe that aid to Britain contributes to keeping the United States out of war, according to a report made yesterday by Dr. George Gallup, director of the organization.

Activity continued good in New York's wholesale market, it was reported yesterday in a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. Reorders have started already on new Spring merchandise.

Headlines deal in contrasts, and from the United States Steel Corporation's annual report published last week they properly stressed the increase in net profits of nearly 150 per cent in 1940, as compared with 1939. Yet lest such a figure, standing by itself, give a misleading impression, or be too hastily seized upon by that group which is always finding something sinister in "big business," certain other comparisons ought also to be kept in mind.
MARK VAN DOREN, critic and teacher, edited, in 1930, "An Anthology of Three Centuries of American Poetry, 1630-1930," which has become a popular sourcebook for many students in this field.

Real estate interests yesterday were quick to cite the "minor reduction" made in assessed valuations for the coming year as "another indication of a need for a new approach to the property tax problem."

I HAVE just read Mr. Atkinson's criticism of "Cream in the Well." I have read the play in manuscript, and I agree with him that it is a splendidly written play; as for the acting, etc., it is impossible for me to agree or disagree since I was not there.

Three performances of the forthcoming production of the play "The Talley Method," at the Henry Miller Theatre, have been taken over in the interests of various philanthropic enterprises. Due to the facts that the benefit theatre parties have been planned for some time in advance and that the opening date of the production has been postponed several times, arrangement have been made to honor tickets purchased for the originally announced dates for the benefits.

ELECTRICAL IMMUNITY -- Three University of California scientists -- Professor Charles F. Dalziel of the engineering faculty, Dr. John B. Lagen of the School of Medicine, and Joe L. Thurston, senior student in electrical engineering -- reported to the American Institute of Electrical Engineers last week that after having been shocked by electricity again and again, a certain degree of immunity to more shocks is acquired.

BELOVED of hostesses are buffet suppers. They promote informality, they accommodate an elastic number of guests, and they are easy to serve. The preparation of the supper is not always so easy, however.

Reports of the chairman and officers of the executive board of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York will be given at a meeting to be held Feb. 10 at 10:30 A.M., at the federation's headquarters, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. Plans for the International Flower Show will also be discussed.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Thailand will insist on the Mekong River ports of Savannaket, Vien Tiane and Thakek as the price of making peace with Indo-China, authoritative Thai sources said today.

It would be difficult to find anywhere more nearly perfect stories of scientific deduction than the Dr. Thorndyke tales of R. Austin Freeman, nor would it be easy to find any that contain less extraneous matter. There is nothing to distract the reader from the matter in hand, the solution of a crime problem.

Reports of committees on international relations, public health and scholarship will be made to delegates attending the Winter convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, at the Hotel Astor on Friday. Chairmen of the three committees are Mrs. Maxwell Ehrlich, Mrs. Dean Smalbach and Mrs. Thomas H. McClintock.

Despite adverse weather conditions, retail trade here gave a good account of itself last week. Department store volume was estimated as about 5 per cent higher than in the like week last year. Food sales continued to gain, rising about 8 per cent over a year ago.

The New York University Radio Club will participate in the British American Ambulance Corps Friendship Bridge program on Wednesday, marking the first time a college group has made a transatlantic broadcast to England. The program will be heard locally over station WMCA and in England and throughout the United Kingdom via WRUL, Boston shortwave station.

In colonial America there used to be a saying: Watch for Indian attacks when the leaves come out. In 1941 Britain there is a saying: Watch for German invasion when Spring comes. Last week invasion talk mounted, and Adolf Hitler, speaking on the eighth anniversary of his chancellorship, warned that the hour to strike was close at hand.

With conditions in the Far East becoming more acute, Japan is making a determined effort to increase her supply of petroleum both for industrial and war purposes. Despite the embargo placed on some oil products, notably aviation gasoline, Japan is increasing measurably her shipments of crude oil and finished products from the United States.

THOSE who can do so are shoving off for places where the sun shines and life, temporarily at least, is without problems. While the Winter vacation is not the rule, it is less the exception than formerly. Even the "up-by-the-hard-way" employer is beginning to listen to clerks asking for Winter leaves.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Willie Hoppe brushed aside a former champion, Tiff Denton of Kansas City, today in his steady march toward his second consecutive world three-cushion billiard championship.

COLOMBIA has released a new air-mail series, thirteen denominations in six designs. A "Monumento Precolombino" (Pre-Colombian Monument) illustrates 5-centavos gray, 30c deep blue and 80c olive. "El Dorado" (The Gilded Man) is the design on 10c yellow and 40c red-violet.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Distribution of the revenue from the State's taxes on personal incomes, motor fuel and alcoholic beverages for the final quarter of 1940 has been completed, according to Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance.

The Seton Hall Prep School fencing team from South Orange, N.J., checked the bids of Stuyvesant and Barringer for permanent possession of the Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Trophy by beating both to win New York University's eighth annual high and preparatory school team fencing championship at the university's Washington Square College yesterday.

THIS second book of a trilogy designed to show the development of transportation in nineteenth-century America deals with another branch of the Parrott family of "Go and Find Wind," though it is in no sense a sequel.

The exhibition and sale of art works from the $50,000,000 William Randolph Hearst collection will be open to the public tomorrow at Gimbel Brothers Department Store, Broadway and Thirty-third Street, and Saks Fifth Avenue, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

A joint undertaking to emphasize the part Westchester County has played in the evolution of democracy in the United States is being planned by Barnard-in-Westchester and the County League of Women Voters. The first organizing meeting was held last week under the general chairmanship of Mrs. A.J. Scofield of Scarsdale.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- A government anti-trust indictment against two labor organizations and ten of their officials, including the late Mike Carrozzo, head of the Street Sweepers Union, was dismissed today by Judge Philip L. Sullivan in the Federal court in a twenty-page opinion which upheld the union's efforts to keep ready-mixed concrete out of Chicago.

IN this book an English author approaches Mexico by way of Spain. A Professor of Spanish, student of all things pertaining to Spain, and warm friend of the liberal culture of the Spanish Republic, Mr. Trend followed exiled friends, during and after the civil war, to their haven in the Western Hemisphere; in late 1938 and early 1939 he made two visits to Mexico.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- The University of Costa Rica, founded in 1844 but closed in recent years, will be reopened on March 7 and Rodrigo Perera, Director of the Philatelic Office, announces that the "restoration" will be celebrated with stamps for both postage and air mail use.

BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- Last Thursday for the second time since the beginning of this year, Reichsfuehrer Hitler unqualifiedly proclaimed to the world his conviction that the Third Reich will achieve victory in this war in this year of 1941. In the official German view, moreover, this opinion is based upon positive factors without the realm of propagandistic expediency and the most important of which is the striking power of the titanic Teuton war machine.

The threat of invasion drew ever closer to embattled Britain last week as the first month of the "crisis year" ended with Germany's great military strength still husbanded and conserved against "Der Tag."

WRITING in The North American Review, just a century ago, Edward Everett observed that "constitutional law in our day, instead of being the calm occupation of the schools or the curious pursuit of the professional student, has become -- as it were -- an element of real life.

Amateurs who have had difficulty in deciding whether a potted house plant needs watering or not may be interested to know that a small saucer and a wick can be used to do the job automatically. The self-watering pot consists merely of a saucer from which an asbestos or a fibre glass wick conducts water to the soil as needed.

TOKYO, Feb. 1 -- What Germany calls "Lebensraum" Japan calls "co-prosperity sphere." Whoever invented the latter term discovered a method of rationalizing one of the widest and boldest expansionist programs ever planned by any government.

A private musicale, as a tribute to Ignace Jan Paderewski, will be given in the gallery of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie's residence at 2 East Ninetieth Street on the night of Feb. 10. The contributing artists for the occasion will be Artur Schnabel, pianist; Bronislaw Huberman, violinist, and Emanuel Feuermann, 'cellist, who will be heard in a program of trios by Schubert, Beethoven and Chopin.
Sixteen hundred members of the Real Estate Board of New York gathered at their annual dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night.

Columbia University's libraries experienced an increase of 4.5 per cent last year in the use of their books for the period, Dr. Charles C. Williamson, director of the libraries, said yesterday in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

OCALA, Fla. -- A tarpon "strikes" and the water churns into a whirlpool of ocean foam and silver scales. On an inland lake a sailboat swings into the wind, floating across the water like a white cloud. A diver plunges, curving down out of sight in a palm-shaded spring.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Various types of scale attacking hard-wooded plants, such as fruit trees, lilacs, euonymus and the like, are among the most destructive of plant pests but often go unnoticed by the amateur. Winter spraying with miscible oil (one that mixes with water) on any sunny day when the temperature is well above 40 degrees is the standard control . . . .

A FAR cry from those struggling days when it was the film industry's stepchild and Hollywood's flea circus, little independent Republic is today the happiest of picture companies. Republic is in the chips; its spacious lawn is rapidly disappearing under the hammering of carpenters busily building new sound stages, projection and recording rooms and other studio appurtenances.

When horsemen say that "a good horse should be deep through the heart" they are speaking of spirit as well as physique. It is a description which fits all the horses portrayed in Mr. Anderson's companion picture-book to his "Black, Bay and Chestnut," and it would be hard to pick from these brief histories the gamest of the lot.
BERLIN, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Formation in Paris of a new political organization known as the National Pop-

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Senator Clark of Missouri asked Secretary Knox about the status of Colonel William Donovan, now in Europe as an observer, during the hearing of the Foreign Relations Committee today.

When the Westminster Kennel Club opens its sixty-fifth annual bench show in Madison Square Garden at 9 o'clock on Tuesday morning, Feb. 11, a total of 2,548 dogs will be benched in the exhibition hall under the new plan of a two-day exhibition with an entry limited to prize winners of record.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Earnings of Class I railroads in the United States in 1940 amounted to $682,118,487, before interest and rentals, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

A discussion of a Catholic plan for a just peace, based on Pope Plus XII's five-point program in his Christmas Day message, was held yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria in the second day session of the twenty-second annual convention of the Newman Club Federation of New York Province.

Members of the Junior Assembly of Yonkers will present their annual entertainment, known as the Junior Jollities, on March 7 and 8 at the Hawthorne Junior High School in Yonkers. In previous seasons the organization has given the event for the benefit of the assembly's philanthropic fund, but this year the funds realized will be shared equally with Bundles for Britain.

The Ladies Helping Hand Association, founded in 1865 by the late Mrs. William Post, will give its annual benefit bridge tomorrow afternoon at the Allerton House for Women, 132 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Striking employes at the Elizabeth, N.J., plant of the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation were expected to resume work on national defense orders tomorrow as a result of a tentative agreement reached last night at a conference attended by Federal conciliators, company executives and representatives of Local 441 of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C.I.O.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 1 -- A hard-riding Yale polo team took an early lead and held it throughout to defeat Princeton, 13 -- 11, in the indoor riding hall today. It was the opening contest for the Tigers, indoor intercollegiate champions in 1940, and Yale's second victory in three starts.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 1 -- Substantial success of the government's wartime farm production program was described today by the new Agricultural Minister, James G. Barclay. He said the main feature of the program was increase in animal products, which involved raising larger crops.

The problem of loans is one of the most important questions affecting the relations of almost all countries in Latin America, but the importance of settling outstanding loans in a satisfactory way is not always accorded due consideration.

THE dispute between Walter Damrosch and the singers Ezio Pinza and Jarmila Novotna, who withdrew from the cast of his "Cyrano," incidentally revealed that the English version of "The Bartered Bride" to be conducted by Bruno Walter will be given at the Metropolitan in the latter half of the week of Feb. 24.
AMSTERDAM, Feb. 1 -- Trading on today's Bourse was stagnant, but the undertone was generally firm. Dutch issues rose as much as 3 points.

A SPIRITED exhibition of recent oils by Esther Williams has opened at the Kraushaar Galleries. The artist's lively brushwork reflects, both in subjects and surface, very real musical interest which carries over into a certain intrinsic quality in the work, a kind of exuberant lyricism.
TOKYO, Feb. 1 -- Although the China war operations are now comparatively stagnant, the military expenditure continues as high as when the war was in its most active stage.

The belief that Joe Louis is slipping was expressed by many yesterday in the wake of his thirteenth defense of the heavyweight title as boxing followers to a man acclaimed Clarence (Red) Burman, the Baltimore heavyweight who chased Louis through four full rounds Friday night before collapsing under paralyzing right-hand drives to the body in the fifth session.

An increase of $36,467,806, the largest for any borough, is shown by the 1941-42 tentative assessments on real estate in Queens made public yesterday by the City Tax Commission. The total valuation of real estate in Queens is estimated at $2,302,940,906.

Too much "softness" and not enough discipline are to be found in American schools and colleges, William R. Crowley, Brooklyn member of the Board of Education, declared yesterday in an address before 800 teachers and administrators attending the fifth annual luncheon of the Health Education Teachers Association.

DALTON TRUMBO'S new novel includes two remarkable Andrews -- one, young Andrew Long of Shale City, Col., and the other General Andrew Jackson. The tale combines stiff doses of the literal and the fantastical which effervesce into a high-powered satirical cocktail.

THE collection of paintings and sculpture owned by Walter P. Chrysler Jr. is being shown for the first time in its entirety at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts. The exhibition opened on Jan. 16 and will remain at the museum until March 4, after which it will go to the Philadelphia Museum, to be shown there from March 29 to May 11.

The extension of a nation-wide campaign for funds, appealing to hundreds of cities, towns and villages in this country bearing names similar to such communities in England, will be marked by the Namesake Towns Luncheon to be given next Saturday at the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the New York branch of the English-Speaking Union.

The report of the Parker-Wolverine Company for the year ended on Dec. 31 shows net profit of $217,999, after depreciation, interest, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other charges, equal to $1.60 a share on the 135,931 shares of common stock outstanding.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 1 -- The Princeton University swimmers broke the Navy tankmen's winning streak, 43 to 32, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League meet today, taking first places in five of the nine events and breaking two pool records.

THE Metropolitan has apparently excluded Wagner's delightful "Meistersinger" from its repertoire for the current season. This is a situation which certainly ought to be remedied, especially since Mr. Johnson has announced that the emphasis in this season's operatic offerings is to be upon comic opera.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The reaction thus far indicates that Governor Lehman's budget and income-tax reduction program will be adopted by the Legislature substantially as submitted Monday night. Accompanying the "economy" budget of $385,000,000 was a recommendation of an income-tax reduction of $21,000,000, effective on taxes paid next year, through removal of the 1 per cent emergency tax.

Mrs. Bruce F.E. Harvey heads the patroness committee in charge of the plans for the annual supper dance and entertainment under the auspices of the Nightingale-Bamford Alumnae Association to be held on Feb. 14 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- No one can evaluate yet the effectiveness, here and elsewhere, of the attention paid this week to the visit of Wendell L. Willkie to London. On the face of things Mr. Willkie's trip seemed to observers here to symbolize a sense of unity -- or, rather, a will to unity -- which has been growing among the American people almost in direct ratio to their realization of the international crisis.

LAKE ARROWHEAD, Calif. -- Dates for February Winter sports activities in California and Nevada indicate an increasing popularity in the top-flight snow festivities of the Far West despite the fact they must compete with a dozen other sports events of widely different natures.

City College's varsity basketball team returned to action last night after a three-week lay-off and looked impressive in handing Pratt Institute of Brooklyn a 60-to-39 trouncing at the C.C.N.Y. gymnasium.

TANGIER, Feb. 1 -- The Spanish Foreign Minister, Ramon Serrano Suner, accompanied by Miguel Primo de Rivera, Madrid's civil Governor, is expected to arrive here shortly, according to informed circles. The object of his visit has not yet been disclosed.

will see the opening of the annual Winter seminar at the art school in San Miguel Ide Allende, Mexico, a center whose ,outdoor sketching classes and ceramic department are attracting an increasing number of students from the United States.
Mrs. Edgerton Parsons of 555 Park Avenue and her daughter, Miss Leonora Parsons, have left on a motor trip to New Orleans and Hot Springs, Va.

SPLIT, Yugoslavia, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A British submarine sank an armed Italian tug towing a barge in the Adriatic yesterday between the Yugoslav islands of Susac and Lanstovo. The Yugoslav steamer Drava picked up two survivors of the crew of twenty-three and towed the barge to the port of Milna on the Yugoslav island of Hvar.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 1 -- There is an unprecedented trend toward poll-tax reform in Virginia, as evidenced by the fact that all three Democratic candidates for Governor, who have stated their positions on the issue are in favor of liberalization. Two are unequivocally for divorcing the tax from the franchise, with the substitution of a literacy test.

Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew characterized as "corrupt and illegal" yesterday an agreement between The Curtiss Wright Export Company and former Commander James H. Strong of the United States Navy by which the latter was to receive commissions on all airplane materials sold to the Republic of Colombia while he was acting as adviser to the Latin-American government.

SOME of the recent irregularity in trade seemed to straighten out in the week. However, the call for home furnishings is still better than demand on apparel lines. Moreover, automobile and appliance sales together with home building activity are cutting into merchandise expenditures.

TORONTO, Feb. 1 (Canadian Press) -- United States squash racquets players today won the Lapham Cup, emblematic of international squash racquets team supremacy, by defeating a Canadian team, 8 -- 7, in a fifteen-match series. Canada had held the cup for the last two years.
Shipping men in a number of foreign trades expect a general upward revision of freight rates before Spring, and increases already have been agreed to by several lines, it was announced yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1 -- Yale today won a 56-to-19 victory over the Army swimmers. The only first place captured by the cadets was in the 400-yard relay.

Baseball magnates, managers and players, who are treated with respect for most of the year by the baseball writers, will leave their sensibilities at home tonight. For this is the occasion of the eighteenth annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers at the Hotel Commodore.

APPROXIMATELY 100 listening and discussion groups of woolen will be formed in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut areas in conjunction with a new series of broadcasts on "America's Role in Foreign Affairs," which WQXR will present at 3:15 P.M. every Tuesday during February and March.

Dr. Alexis Carrel, French scientist and author, sailed yesterday for Europe on the American Export liner Siboney to study the effects of malnutrition and cold on the undernourished populations of war-ravished nations. He traveled on a French passport and plans to visit Spain first after landing at Lisbon, then will go wherever his studies best can be furthered.

NEW YORK CITY as a Winter playground -- a playground both indoors and out -- took a forward stride recently with the opening of the ice and roller skating rinks in the New York City Building at Flushing Meadow Park.

DALLAS, Feb. 1 -- Showing an utter disregard for political considerations, W. Lee O'Daniel has broken over party lines in filling places on appointive boards and has flaunted Willkie Democrats in the faces of chagrined party adherents.

THIS grim book about the American South is no product of the literary carpetbagger. It was written by Southerners who now live and work in the South and was published by a Southern university press -- which incidentally happens to be one of the best of its sort in the country.

Americans can take heart from the evidence of increasing national unity and solidarity in the face of peril to democracy, Rabbi Louis I. Newman said in a sermon at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday. Sacrifice and activity in the defense of freedom and faith in the future were other sermon topics.

That British imports -- the lifeblood of Britain's resistance to the Nazi onslaught -- were not much lower in December than in some of the pre-war months is no great cause for satisfaction. Britain's needs of foodstuffs have been little reduced by the war, while munitions purchases and purchases of raw materials with which to manufacture other munitions have vastly increased.

Taxable real estate and special franchises in New York City are assessed tentatively for 1941-42 at $16,322,218,281 -- a tentative net decrease of $231,181,697 from the final figures for 1940-41 totaling $16,553,399,978.

SAN FRANCISCO's Chinatown is going to be renovated. A Federal housing project for the district, to cost about $1,500,00 and to provide 250 apartments, has been approved and construction will be under way by next Spring.

An innovation in administrative government was tried out last week in Washington by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Nothing exactly like it ever before had been attempted by this five-man body which administers the laws governing the vast and complex securities business and the extensive public utility industry.

The Centenary Fund Drive of Fordham University, designed to pay expenses under the new policy of expansion and improvement planned as Fordham begins its second century of education, has already received subscriptions totaling $67,341 from alumni of the various schools, it was announced last week by Paul T. O'Keefe, alumni president and general chairman of the drive, and Edward B. Lyman, alumni chairman.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 1 -- Forty-two tons of foodstuffs and tobacco requested by the United States Ambassador to France, Admiral William D. Leahy, for himself and members of his staff were removed from the Red Cross mercy ship Cold Harbor just before the vessel sailed for Spain this afternoon with a $1,000,000 relief cargo for Spain and France.

The American Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society has arranged a "Carnival for Britain" to take place in Radio City on the night of Feb. 21. Proceeds from the fete will augment the society's fund to send emergency air-raid equipment to England.

Before war came to North Africa the Piazza del Re in the Cyrenaican capital of Bengazi used to be a center of social life. The Governor's palace looked out upon the palm-shaded square, and the new Municipal Theatre added dignity. Restaurants, when the soft Mediterranean twilight descended, used to put out tables, and waiters moved about while orchestras played.

ONE of the important out-of-town "regulars" has made its reappearance -- the Pennsylvania Academy's annual in Philadelphia. It opened with a preview a week ago yesterday, and since a report appeared in last Sunday's news columns, it will not be necessary to go over the same ground again today.

THE New Year forecast in this column was that there would be more recordings in 1941 by American ensembles than in any previous year. Columbia had begun this trend in 1940. Victor now carries it forward with the addition of a group of American orchestras to its recording personnel.

PANAMA -- Carnival time in Panama this year will extend from Washington's Birthday until the dawn of Ash Wednesday, Feb. 26, when revelers who will attend the burial of the "Sacred Sardine," will meet the street cleaners sweeping up the confetti and serpentina that will fill the streets like a multicolored tropical snowstorm.

THERE was no sound of cheering among the television showmen six months ago when the Federal Communications Commission decided to send the art back into the laboratory for further development, shattering hopes for quick commercialization.

Compost has become a garden byword and the possession of a compost heap the measure, to a degree, of a gardener's earnestness. So much so that the word has taken on a new meaning to modern gardeners. Literally, fertilizer and other materials could be composted or mixed with the soil. Actually, "compost" has come to mean the material compounded of garden refuse that eventually becomes similar to commercial humus or woods leafmold.
I WOULD be glad to have the names and addresses of people who agree with me on the following:

Thirteen officials, who will serve chiefly in Eastern games, have been signed by the National Football League, according to an announcement made yesterday by Carl L. Storck, president of the circuit. Most of the arbiters have been given contracts for two or three years.

ROME, Feb. 1 -- Candlemas Day tomorrow -- the Feast of the Purification -- will feel the effects of the war, for this year the candles offered to the Pope and those blessed and distributed before the principal mass will be much smaller than usual.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -- Accused of extorting $50 from a registrant with a promise to help him evade Army service, Fred Kaplan, 29, a draft board clerk, was held in $25,000 bail today.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Stocky Leo Freisinger, Chicago Olympian, held a slim lead today in the North American speed skating championships. Close on his trail came big Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -- Captain Paul Kartluke set a fast scoring pace as Syracuse defeated the Pennsylvania quintet, 37 -- 30, before 2,000 spectators at the Palestra tonight to make it six straight over the Red and Blue.

A little back-seat driving on the part of the womenfolk can be detected behind the plan of the North River Power Squadron to arrange for a special series of events for the wives of skippers. The "reformation" will begin on Feb. 17 with a succession of lectures "for women only" at the Downtown A.C.

SOME TIME this month, when the whim strikes him, Lloyd Bacon will celebrate his twentieth year as a motion picture director and his seventeenth as a functionary of Warner Brothers. He hasn't set any date for the celebration, because he doesn't remember the exact date of his entry into the directorial ranks.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A symposium on the lease-lend bill today produced an argument over Wendell L. Willkie.

ONE more for J. Shufflin' Louis, the busiest heavyweight champion the gloved game has known. The prospective victims now waiting in line for samples of what the Dark Destroyer handed to Red Burman are Gloomy Gus Dorazio, Ample Abe Simon, and Osculatory Arturo Godoy, the Kissing Bug of the Andes. After that, if all goes according to form, there will be a Louis-Conn bout.

NOT many days ago the Music Hall held a double preview of a forthcoming film in its studios high above the auditorium. The film was "Cheers for Miss Bishop," adapted from the Bess Streeter Aldrich fable of spinster heartbreak and starring Martha Scott and William Gargan.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 1 -- A gorgeous sable and white collie captured the highest honors this evening at the twenty-eighth annual all-breed show of the Maryland Kennel Club. His name is Champion Cadet of Noranda and is owned by Mr. and Mrs. William H. Long Jr. of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. He was bred by his owners and was shown in the ring by Mrs. Long at the Fifth Regiment Armory.

The glee club of the New York Junior League, assisted by a semi-chorus and quartet from the Yale Glee Club, will give its annual benefit concert on Friday night at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. The procceds will be used to advance the musical therapy work of the Junior League glee club in city hospitals.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Two members of the seeded roster succumbed during the early rounds of the Apawamis Club squash racquets invitation tourney today as a field studded with many metropolitan stars started play in the third edition of this annual fixture.

IT is rather hard to define the nature of this novel about Soviet Russia. It is neither wholly realistic nor wholly satirical, but partakes of the qualities of both; to these is added a dash of extravaganza. It is an excellent mixture -- that is, when it comes off; which is not always the case, by any means.

While the American Congress is shoving through the Lease-Lend Bill to increase this country's aid to Great Britain, Herr Hitler declared in his speech in Berlin Thursday that Germany would defeat Britain this year. He had calculated every chance, he said, and he could only add that, with or without convoy, ships carrying aid to Britain would be torpedoed. In the springtime, he told the world, his submarines would be busier than ever.

MOST of the theatregoers who bask in the splendors of "Lady in the Dark" will not bother their heads over the schoolroom problem of whether it is a musical play or musical comedy. For Moss Hart and his several associates have staged one of the loveliest musical shows of recent years, and Gertrude Lawrence is giving in it the most brilliant performance of her incendiary career.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 14 -- Australia and New Zealand have "an understanding" with the United States covering future events in the South Pacific, it was learned here from a highly authoritative source.

SALERNO, Fla., Feb. 1 -- We have been waiting for more than a week for the right day to fish the reef that runs southward from the mouth of St. Lucie Inlet, and as the wind was quiet at sunrise today we joined Ray Trullinger, another New York rod and gun scribe, and put out from Ed Payette's dock in a boat that was almost an exact duplicate of Ed Buckley's late Naphtha launch.

VICHY, France, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Rumors that Germany desires the use of Bizerte and Sfax, French bases in Tunisia, and Toulon, naval station on the French Mediterranean Coast, have circulated here for the last few days, but it was said tonight that no formal demands of this nature had been received from Reichsfuehrer Hitler.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 1 -- Government and diplomatic sources in this part of South America are convinced that the Regional Conference of River Plate countries, now meeting here, is the beginning of a new method of international cooperation that will eventually make Pan-Americanism vital and practical as a leaguing of the American nations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Chairman Vinson of the House Committee on Naval Affairs will hold hearings next week on his bill designed to allay labor troubles in defense production. This is a wise step because, in the opinion of many seasoned experts in the field, the present draft of the bill will not serve the purpose and may rather aggravate than correct industrial disturbances.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will open to the public Thursday its major exhibition of the Winter, an important show to be called "French Painting From David to Toulouse-Lautrec." Before the German conquest of France the nucleus of this exhibition was assembled abroad by the French Government and sent on a good-will foul of South America.

There is internal evidence that this is an earlier Ngaio Marsh book. It lacks something of the expert plotting and the matured Style that characterize most of this author's other stories. But even so, it is much better than the average run of mystery tales.

"TO go for a walk when you're not writing," said Phyllis Bentley, "is simply exercise. But to walk when you are actually on a job is astonishingly different." She glanced at the pedestrian traffic along lower Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The manner in which Germany is reorganizing the economic life of conquered countries and diverting their supplies and wealth, and the way in which remaining European neutrals have been forced to centralize their economies are traced in a detailed report made public today by the Commerce Department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Expansion of the Army has created a shortage of officers of the rank of major, the War Department said today, when it estimated that 4,000 of that rank must be provided immediately.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Immediate development under Federal direction of a civil defense program for cities of the United States which might be exposed to attack in time of war was urged today in a report prepared by the United States Conference of Mayors.

Since most plants constructed for national defense purposes will operate on three shifts and possibly seven days a week, they will earn depreciation rates as high as 30 per cent and will complete amortization within a comparatively short time, accountants pointed out yesterday.

THE "Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature," of which I sent a preliminary announcement a few months ago, has now appeared. It more than justifies all that was expected of it. The Times Literary Supplement says that no inch of its 3,000 double-columned pages could be spared, and that this is the book of reference which students of English literature have long, consciously or unconsciously, desired.

A far back as 1934 I had made an attempt to lease the former B.F. Keith's theatre for stock only to find that the motion picture industry was firmly entrenched and quite reluctant to even discuss the possibility of rental with me.

ZOLTAN KODALY'S Concerto for Grand Orchestra, written for the fiftieth anniversary of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, will receive its world premiere by that organization under the direction of Frederick Stock this Thursday night and Friday afternoon in Chicago.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Two and one-half million aliens have been conscripted for labor in the Reich, constituting 10 per cent of the total labor employed and contributing $1,275,000,000 annually to Germany's national income and probably $400,000,000 to her war effort, Minister of Shipping Ronald Cross said this week in an overseas broadcast.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 -- Talk of splitting California into two States along the line of the Tehachapi Mountains has been revived by the prospect that readjustments forced by the 1940 census population figures will give Southern California a majority in the lower house of the Legislature.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 1 -- The Japanese-mediated peace imposed on French Indo-China and Thailand, while resulting in the cessation of hostilities, has deprived the authorities of Indo-China of virtually all political and economic control of their country.
Brooklyn real estate is assessed tentatively for 1941-42 at $3,650,174,306, including ordinary real estate of the value of $3,389,830,831 and real estate of utilities valued at $260,343,475.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 1 (AP) -- State's Attorney Lorin W. Willis said today that he was considering an appeal from the verdict of a Superior Court jury acquitting Joseph Spell, 31-year-old Negro chauffeur-butler, of a charge that he attacked his employer, Mrs. John K. Strubing Jr. of Greenwich.

HAVANA, Feb. 1 -- The United States team of four beat Cuba today in the last event of the fifteenth annual Havana competition for Star Class boats. The visitors took four of the first five places to win, 24 points to 12.

Withdrawal of the War Department's request that the canning industry be exempted from the forty-hour-week standards of the Walsh-Healey Act last week was viewed by grocery leaders here yesterday as an indication that the Army will buy only canned goods already packed and will not place contracts in advance of the canning season.

DETROIT, Feb. 1 -- An order for "full speed ahead," with arrangements to make bombing planes or parts in the Rouge plant of the Ford Motor Company, was foreshadowed today with the disclosure that high officers of the Army Air Coprs had completed a two-day conference with Ford officials.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 1 -- Disqualification in the final event, the 400-yard free-style relay, cost the Lehigh swimmers victory in their meet with Fordham tonight. The score was 44 -- 31.

The Monte M. Sterling tournament, annual squash tennis fixture at the New York Athletic Club, which is designed to give the game's future Harry Wolfs a chance to develop, swung into action yesterday with the playing of a dozen or so matches.

Alexander Brailowsky's pianism has grown with the passing years until it has finally attained every quality required to lend it first rate importance, as was convincingly demonstrated at his recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Brailowsky's playing, always technically remarkable, was for the first time here imbued, at this latest appearance, with the emotional warmth and wealth of prismatic coloring formerly felt wanting.

She was very slim and light. She was always tense, often atremble, and never failed to give the impression of being a mass of almost terrible power wrapped in a thin and fragile blue-gray skin. * * * She ate great quantities of hunked black food, and vented streams of gray debris.

To prepare its members for auxiliary services which they might render in the national preparedness program, the Carroll Club is extending its Spring schedule to include greater emphasis on building the health of members and training them as leaders of recreation.

A diversified entertainment with a Latin-American theme has been devised for the thirty-fifth annual ball of the Republican Club of the Fifteenth Assembly District, which will be held Wednesday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

A course to follow developments of the legislative session at Albany is included in a new group of classes to be opened this week by the education department of the New York branch of the Women's Trade Union League.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court was told several things about women's hats today.
I have read with a great deal of interest your re-evaluation of the picture "Gone With the Wind," after seeing it again a year after its first showing.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- The sensitive antennae of the British intelligence service and censorship system reach out into many and sometimes remote parts of the world, particularly to those strategic empire territories lying athwart the trade routes of the seven seas.

TORONTO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Led by their great center, Syl Apps, the Maple Leafs poured a steady stream of rubber at Sam Lo Presti tonight to earn a 3-1 victory over the Black Hawks and an eight-point lead on their National Hockey League rivals.

AT its concerts Friday and next Sunday in Pittsburgh the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, under Fritz Reiner, will perform the "Variations for Orchestra" by Wendell Otey, Pittsburgh composer, for the first time.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1 -- With Princeton leading by a single point and a minute to go in tonight's contest, Captain Johnny Cobb heaved two fouls and Al Seelbach scored on a rebound to give Yale a 49-to-46 triumph, its first this season in five Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League games.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- At ceremonies overshadowed by the tense international situation, the Navy's fighting forces were reorganized today into separate units of the world's mightiest fleet.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- William Gibbs McAdoo, former Senator from California, Secretary of the Treasury under Woodrow Wilson and builder of the Hudson tubes, died here today at the age of 77.

ON the assumption that any measure of relief from double-featuritis (common symptoms: spots before the eyes, headache, knotty muscles, etc.) is better than none at all, this corner gladly passes along the word that Loew's Theatres are about to institute a new policy which will permit moviegoers to have their sleep and entertainment, too.

When the New York Typographical Union -- "Big Six" -- assembles today at Manhattan Center to honor more than 300 "old-timers" whose union membership dates back fifty years or more, eleven active members and five retired employes of THE NEW YORK TIMES composing room will be among those whose names are on the roll of honor.

GREEK peasant women have been toiling beside men to defend their country against Italian invaders. They have labored to keep their armies' roads in repair and free of snow; they have clambered up mountainsides with supplies and ammunition; they have even rolled boulders down on Italian soldiers in narrow passes.
BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- Correspondents inquiring about the German reaction to the allegation that the Reich was planning to use gas in its war on England received a reply today at the Foreign Office.

OTHER one-man shows of the week include marine paintings, Winter and Autumn landscapes of New England and one or two accomplished textural still-lifes by Ernest Albert at Pedac. This is frankly picturesque work of the old school, academic in tenor, sound in construction -- sound if unexciting painting.

Governor Lehman last night commuted a thirty-day jail sentence for Jack Walfish, who formed a "speeding habit" from driving high-powered Army tanks, so that the soldier may go to camp with his National Guard unit.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- An unofficial but well-informed air observer tonight placed the number of airplanes available to Germany for "full operation at any given time" at about 9,000 and said Germany's total air strength, including all types of planes, is about 40,000.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Dartmouth defeated Army at basketball today, 50 to 42, in the feature game of a heavy sport program before 5,000 spectators in the big field house. The contest was hard fought, but Dartmouth's faster floor work and accurate passing were telling factors all the way.

ATHENS RADIO is now broadcasting on the short-wave lengths and loud test transmissions are beginning to reach this country. For months listeners have scanned the dial for word from the Greek battlefronts.

OFTEN we have wondered, while performing our professional chores, what a person who is wholly unfamiliar with American history must think after seeing one of the more ambitious epics which are constantly rolling out of Hollywood.

"IT will be the forty-fifth performance of 'L'Amore dei Tre Re' at the Metropolitan on Feb. 7, but it will be the first time I have conducted there, and so it will be a debut -- a double debut, really, because Grace Moore will be singing Fiora there for the first time, too.

Converting drab grege goods from undyed stiffly sized yardage into soft, flower-showered, vividly striped, or subtly dyed fabrics, is an engaging and amusing vocation, according to Miss Hope Skillman, president of a cotton styling house. The converter is the imaginative middle-man, and in most cases it is a man, who transforms the textile manufacturers' selfless product into the inspiring implement of the couturiers' fancy, and Miss Skillman is among the most gifted.

THE Indian Yellow Wolf was the last of the Nez Perce warriors, and during the years that preceded his death in 1935 he told his story bit by bit to a writer who is himself a passionately devoted friend of the Indians.

WILLIAM L. SHIRER is writing a book in which he will tell of his experiences as a foreign correspondent and news broadcaster, including some of the things that the censors would not let him tell in his radio talks from Berlin.

PAUL ENGLE is a poet and his first novel, "Always the Land," is eloquent proof of this. He has descriptions of corn growing in fertile Iowa soil, of horses and of humans which only a poet could fashion. But emotion and poetry that go into creating a background of beauty are not enough to make a story.

There has been much discussion concerning the immediate problem of this country in relation to the war. There has been very little discussion of our ultimate relation to the peace to come after the war is over.

The United States Maritime Commission announced last week that the United Fruit Company and the United States Lines had offered reduced fares for student and teacher travel between the United States and Central American and Caribbean countries.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Wendell L. Willkie announced today that because he has been asked by Washington officials to submit his views on the Lease-Lend Bill before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearings wind up on Feb. 10, he will leave Britain a day or two earlier than he had originally planned.

NASSAU, British West Indies, Feb. 1. -- Lured by this tropical island's sun spattered, palm fringed beaches, cozy cabanas and the important events that have been planned for this month and March, many Americans from the various sections of the United States have already arrived for the "season," which opened earlier this Winter than usual, and others are arriving daily.

ROME, Feb. 1 -- There has been considerable anger in high Italian circles this week, particularly in quarters which have anything to do with the press and foreign affairs. American newspaper men have been scolded in a friendly but unmistakable tone.

VICHY, France, Feb. 1 -- Reports from Paris today announced the formation of another militant body rivaling the one just created by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, which would have the effect of pitting Paris against the provinces.

INAGUA is the farthest island of the Bahamas, and the book to which it gives its name begins with a Robinson-Crusoe adventure and ends with chapters that may be truly described as the fact-filled essays of a naturalist.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The opinion expressed yesterday by Secretary Knox that the President now possesses legal authority to employ the Navy in convoy work does not affect, so far as could be learned today, the prohibition in the Neutrality Act against the use of United States merchant ships in convoys.

AN all-plastic car 300 pounds lighter than comparable models built of steel and having ten times the impact resistance of steel is near completion in the Ford plant at Dearborn, Mich., Popular Science Monthly announced last week.

Department store and specialty shop items which met with excellent consumer response last week in the three major "test" markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, were listed in a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Senator Wheeler of Montana denied today that he ever attended a dinner at which Senator Glass and William E. Dodd, late Ambassador to Germany, were present and said he did not make the statement regarding German ambitions imputed to him yesterday at a White House press conference.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Sixteen-year-old Wightman (Bud) Washbond and his 298-pound brakeman, Adrian Aubin, shattered the Mount Van Hoevenberg bobsled record to win the National A.A.U. junior two-man title today.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 1 -- Following his failure to obtain a vote of confidence when Parliament met last Thursday, Rashid Ali-Beg Gailani, Premier of Iraq, yesterday submitted his resignation, which was accepted by the Regent, Prince Abdul Ilah, who immediately asked General Taha Al-Hashimi to form a new Ministry, according to news reaching Jerusalem from Baghdad today.

New annuals especially suited for edging and introduced during the last few years may well be termed self-starters. New combinations pop into the mind at the sight of them. Their colors and performance, as we know, have been checked and double-checked.

Preparing to box the North Atlantic in a four-continent series of air routes, the Dixie Clipper of Pan American Airways left La Guardia Field at 8:45 A.M. yesterday for Lisbon, Portugal, with Juan T. Trippe, airline president, as one of six special passengers.

A substantial lease-lend agreement for armaments, which involved the United States, Great Britain and what is now Canada, was effected 143 years ago. In 1798 and 1799, George III, through the government of Nova Scotia, first lent and finally gave, to South Carolina twenty-four cannon and 1,800 shot with which to defend Charleston when alarm over French aggression was prevalent and the United States was woefully deficient in artillery.

PARIS, Jan. 27 (Delayed; via Berlin) -- Speculation in usually well-informed political circles here on Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's choice of officers for his new national council tend to a belief that Cardinal Suhard, Archbishop of Paris, will be selected as its first president.

BERLIN, Sunday, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Authorized sources said early today that six ships totaling 36,000 tons had been "successfully attacked" in the Mediterranean by German bombers on Friday. Another announcement said that a German bomber had blown up a ship "in a Mediterranean harbor."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The United States is about to embark on a merchant marine construction program in many respects different from any comparative program ever undertaken in the history of trans-ocean navigation.

WHILE armies veer uncertainly across the map of 1941, it is sobering to turn to the inspection of other armies moving across the map of other years. For we know now precisely where they started from and who led them and how far they got.

A report from Yale University today describes a meeting between members of the Yale Department of History and representatives of the history departments of twenty-nine preparatory and high schools. From this and other conferences to follow much is expected in the way of an increased awareness of what both the school and the college can do to dovetail and supplement their offerings in history.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 1 -- Merrill Barber, Norwich University's sensational jumper, thrilled a large crowd on Sheep Hill today with two spectacular flights to win this event, but Dartmouth's team regained its intercollegiate ski supremacy with a hard-earned triumph as the annual Williams carnival was concluded.

AGAIN as during the last war the range of human endurance seems to us a miracle beyond comprehension. The will of each individual to keep alive has become as important as anti-aircraft guns and fighting planes.

CHOSEN: Charles Poletti, Lieutenant Governor of New York, is 37 and a Democrat. In 1939 the Young Men's Board of Trade gave him its annual award as "New York's outstanding young man." Last week he presented the award for the "outstanding young man of 1940" to 29-year-old Oren Root Jr. Mr. Root is a Republican.

Nesting inconspicuously on the edge of Harlem's slum area, keeping company with a noisy automobile garage, something that looks like a livery stable of other days kind an unsightly assortment of uninviting shops, is a weather-beaten, drab-looking, pale-red brick building known as the Speyer School.

The attention of holders of Republic of Panama 5 per cent thirty-five-year bonds, Series A, due on May 15, 1963, and certificates of deposit of those bonds, has been called to the fact that the republic has fixed Feb. 24 as the absolute final date for bondholders to accept the offer made by the republic for the readjustment of that loan.

FOR six months weak links in the United States defense highway system have been known to Federal authorities. War and Navy Departments, Federal Works Agency and its Public Roads Administration, State Governments and defense industries now say the situation is urgent, that this network must be built up immediately to "minimum defense specifications."

Although business news remained uniformly good, stocks last week declined moderately but steadily and closed yesterday at the lowest levels since June. There was weakness everywhere. United States Government bonds ended the week at the lows of the period.

THE end of the current radio-music hostilities appeared nearer last week when the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers announced it had resumed negotiations with the United States Department of Justice in the government's anti-trust suit against ASCAP and the radio networks.

One of the more subtle advantages of being a New Yorker is that one is privileged to get into a rut. It is soothing to follow the same streets to work, to go to the same movie house, to eat in the same two or three restaurants and be recognized by the waiters. It gives people a feeling of establishing their own home town in the midst of a rather unwieldy city.

The need for more funds to enable the New York Kindergarten Association to carry on its work among kindergarten children was emphasized in its fifty-first annual report just made public at the annual meeting of the association at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East Sixty-sixth Street.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1 -- Improved methods of teaching history in colleges and preparatory schools are likely to follow a conference just held at Yale University at which an effort was made by representatives of the history departments of twenty-nine prepatory and high schools and members of the Yale Department of History to gain a fuller comprehension of their mutual problems.

Yella Pessl, the harpsichordist, and Elsie Houston, the Brazilian night club singer, gave a joint recital last night at Town Hall as a benefit for the high school which the Little Red School House is in the process of buying in order to extend its progressive theories to secondary education.

STORRS, Conn., Feb. 1 -- A proposed continuation of the current expansion program of the University of Connecticut, together with an accounting of funds received and spent by the university, was given to the Legislature and people of Connecticut by President Albert N. Jorgensen in his report to the board of trustees just made public.
The Bronx, like Queens, shows an increase in its taxable real estate. The net increase amounts to $31,474,610, against $36,467,805 for Queens.
"Il Duce and I are neither Jews nor opportunists. When we shake hands it is the handshake of men of honor."

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 1 -- Dr. Charles H. Kimberly, medical director of the Austen Riggs Foundation at Stockbridge, and Mrs. Kimberly gave a tea this afternoon at their home in honor of Dr. Edgerton McClellan Howard, a new member of the staff, and Mrs. Howard of Cambridge.

Manufacturing points in seven of the ten events, the charges of Coach Charley Scher of De Witt Clinton High registered 26 points to take the team championship at the thirty-eighth running of the city P.S.A.L. senior high tracks and field championships at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 1 -- A series of five public lectures on "The Impact of Totalitarianism Upon the United States" will be presented at Princeton University during the second term by authorities from other educational and research associations, according to an announcement today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 1 -- The Forty-fourth Division is soon to publish its own weekly newspaper at Fort Dix, Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, commanding, has announced. Officers of the division met in his office this week to discuss plans for such a publication and to formulate their ideas.
ON Sept. 7, 1553, the Queen consort of England, Anne Boleyn, gave birth to a daughter who was to become England's most enigmatic ruler. Henry VIII, the father, consulted astrologers and soothsayers.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- A hot competition is going on in the Royal Air Force now operating on several fronts ---over Germany and the Continent, over Britain, over Albania, over Africa.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 1 -- In the course of a trip overseas, Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies intends to visit the United States and to confer with President Roosevelt.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 -- In the nine months since he took office Governor Sam Houston Jones has enacted about all of the governmental reforms he pledged the people of Louisiana when he led the campaign that overthrew the old Huey P. Long machine a year ago.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Employes of Palm Beach estates have organized a British war relief ball for Friday night. Hugh Dillman, president, and the board of governors have donated use of the Everglades Club for the occasion. Employers, Daughters of the British Empire, members of the American Legion, merchants and individuals have cooperated.

The Governor and Legislature of Pennsylvania granted a charter for a university at Lewisburg, Pa., on Feb. 5, 1846, and 12,000 living alumni and friends of that university -- Bucknell -- will celebrate their alma mater's ninety-fifth anniversary on Wednesday of this week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A device for detecting the presence of holes which are invisible to the eye in rolled strips of metal has been developed by the Bethlehem Steel Company, it is disclosed in a patent (NO. 2,229,638) issued here to Alan C. Chamberlin and Henry W. Nieman of Bethlehem, Pa.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 1 -- Encouraged at the outlook for America and Great Britain in the war in Europe, Solomon R. Guggenheim, on the eve of his eightieth birthday, called for better understanding by government of "the great industrialists" of the country.

YOUR prescription for contemporary Broadway -- that the theatre ought to be made available to many more thousands of people -- had its corroboration in an announcement carried without fanfare in the column in THE NEW YORK TIMES paralleling yours last Sunday.

THE tenth anniversary of the University of Chicago's radio series of "Round Table" discussions today is an event of no mean importance, not only in and of itself, but also because it has significant implications for the further development of American broadcasting.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 1 -- Ranging far west of Bengazi, next major goal of the British Army advancing in Libya, bombers of the Royal Air Force last night dropped several tons of bombs in a heavy attack on Italian shipping and seaplanes in the harbor at Tripoli.

DETROIT -- If America's re-armament program sharply limits steel for automobiles, it is possible that motorists will drive cars with bodies made of entirely new materials, in the opinion of George W. Walker, industrial designer.
