While the price of milk at the farm is under rigid governmental control, the city market, which is where the consumer interest enters, is theoretically open to all the forces of free competition. The experience of 1940 showed, however, that the consumer price was almost as thoroughly stabilized as that to the farmer.
With an increase of $2,011,710 on its taxable real estate, Richmond is the third borough to experience a rise in tentative assessments for 1941-42 made public yesterday by the City Tax Commission.

THE wake of the Hurricane wasn't a very wide one -- her beam was only thirteen feet nine and she was forty-five feet over all. At that, when she slid down the ways into a Mississippi bayou, baptized with a splash of local moonshine, she was almost a foot wider and two feet longer than her two young Iowa owners had bargained for.

LAMONT CRANSTON, radio's rich, handsome and well-dressed man-about-town, continues as popular with the thrill-loving set as he was ten years years ago. Still in his thirties, Cranston, who has been described as a "combination of Lucius Beebe and the Thin Man," is a New Yorker, educated at the best schools, widely traveled and a student of the occult sciences.

UNDER the direction of Hans Kindler, the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington, D.C., will make its New York debut Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall. Another visiting symphonic organization will be the Cleveland Orchestra, which will be heard on Wednesday, conducted by Artur Rodzinski.

A NEW type of disembodied spirit -- the collegiate ghost writer -- was recently attacked as a malign influence by Dr. Clarence Linton of Columbia University's Teachers College. This academic shade is an individual who, for a fee, will write any student's themes or theses.

FEET are keeping up with the Spring fashion parade. When you shop for shoes to go with your new woolen suit and crepe dress you'll find that, like your clothes, they are unpretentious as to silhouette but interesting at many points, especially in decoration; and, like every other fashion item, they are having a color whirl all their own.

LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- German raiders slipped through the fog overhanging the Dover Strait on a series of "reconnaissance" raids during daylight today and German long-range guns again pounded the Dover coast from the French shore.

The four-masted Swedish bark Abraham Rydberg, which was launched in 1892, is expected to arrive in Boston harbor today, according to her agents here. She will be the first square-rigged merchantman to visit Boston since the World War, when vessels of every available type were pressed into service.

NEWTON, N.J., Feb. 1 (AP) -- A German-American Bund magazine writer and four trustees of the organization's Camp Nordland at Andover began a week-end in jail as the opportunity for posting $2.000 bail each expired at noon today.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 1 -- What Little TVA, the unofficial name for Nebraska's three PWA-financed hydroelectric developments, failed to do by main strength and awkwardness in the past it now seems in a fair way of accomplishing by finesse.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- General liquidation developed in wheat futures today on the Board of Trade and prices at one time were off about 1 1/2 cents, with May selling at a new low since Oct. 4. July and September also went into new low ground for the season.

IT would be easy to call this splendid novel a portrait of a rugged individualist and let it go at that The type is one familiar in American thinking. We admire him for his enterprise and condemn him for his piracy, often in the same breath.

GOVERNOR LEHMAN'S proposal in his budget message last week to eliminate the 1 per cent emergency income tax on 1941 earnings would not benefit the majority of farmers, wage earners and white collar salaried employes, it was pointed out by Elmer Thompson, secretary of the Automobile Club of America, who said that elimination of one of the emergency gasoline taxes, instead of the income levy, would benefit a large number of people.

FROM his Southern colonial fastness to which he retreated some years ago the redoubtable Charles F. Heartman continues to make rare book history. The latest in his series of monographs is "A Bibliography of First Printings of the Writings of Edgar Allan Poe," compiled by himself with the collaboration of James R. Canny.

The figure that appears on the jacket of this book is a jade statuette called Green Shiver. It has several other names as well, but Green Shiver seems to be the most appropriate one in view of what happens. First the statuette is stolen from the Jade Pavilion in the pseudo-Chinese home of Mrs. Nicholas Vayne, and Professor Theocritus Lucius Westborough is engaged to find it.

Mozart's piano concerto in B flat, with Webster Aitken as soloist, and Erich Wolfgang Korngold's "Much Ado About Nothing" suite figured for the first time on Bruno Walter's current programs with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at last night's concert in Carnegie Hall.

A national crisis is apt to produce a national leader to match it: sick-minded nation, sick-minded leader -- for example, Hitler; healthy-minded nation, healthy-minded leader -- for example, Lincoln. In Winston Churchill the British people have found a leader of the latter type.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Goodwill messages exchanged between President Roosevelt and Foreign Minister Alberto Guani of Uruguay as presiding officer of the River Plate Conference were made public today by the State Department, a move interpreted as intended to dispel fears that the meeting might threaten hemisphere relations.

ROME (by Telephone) LIBYA is Italy's "fourth shore," the colony in which she has taken most pride and expended the most labor and money. It has been especially fascism's colony, for it was Premier Mussolini who set his heart on making it a modal possession.

THE long-awaited Experimental Theatre is about ready to go to work. The latest step in what many consider the most important development in the theatre in a decade is that Experimental Theatre, Inc., now has an office in Room 902 in the Sardi Building at 234 West Forty-fourth Street, with a stenographer on duty from 2:30 to 5 o'clock in the afternoon.

The academic value of organizing a college faculty so that the opinion of all members, regardless of rank, will be recognized is emphasized in the annual report of Dr. Paul Klapper, president of Queens College, to the Board of Higher Education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Completion of the organization of five administrative groups within the Division of Priorities of the Office of Production Management was announced today by E.R. Stettinius Jr., director of the division, with designation of the directors of three divisions.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Only 176 new cars were registered in Great Britain in December, the Ministry of Transport announced today. The far reaching modification of British social habits can be deduced from the fact that in December, 1939, the first war December, 4,688 new cars were registered and 26,018 in December, 1938.

Taxable real estate in Manhattan is valued at $7,556,293,450 on the tentative assessment rolls for 1940-1941, made public yesterday by the City Tax Commission. The total includes ordinary real estate, valued at $6,846,923,350, and real estate of corporations, tentatively assessed at $709,370,100.

HAVANA -- Sports will take precedence over other events during the coming week. The third international feminine track meet will be held next Saturday at Tropical Stadium. An all-star Cuban team will compete with one from Florida.

SOME weeks ago this column dwelt on the difference between books which are written out of an inner compulsion on the part of the author and those which are the product of an idea which the writer has been asked to carry out.

ROME, Feb. 1 -- For the first time in the Libyan campaign Italian armored units are mentioned in today's war bulletin as taking part in the fight against advancing British forces. This must mean that some tanks and armored cars, the lack of which Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, commander in North Africa, cited in his report on the fall of Sidi Barrani, have now been transported to Libya.

SHORTLY after the opening of the 1914-18 was, literature had a triumph. Thomas Hardy's play "The Dynasts," meant possibly for the reader rather than for the stage, was adapted and produced with much skill at a Kings-way theatre, where it drew large audiences.

QUIET BIRTHDAY: In Berlin on Jan. 27, 1916, flags were out everywhere. At General Headquarters there was a holiday bustle as uniformed representatives of Austria, Turkey and Bulgaria came to pay respects to Kaiser Wilhelm II.

A NUMBER of groups throughout the country exist primarily to prepare youthful players for the country's symphony orchestras. It is not so well known that there is a group in this city which prepares youthful singers for the country's churches.

New York University's unique workshop for elementary school teachers will be continued at its Garden City, L.I., center, Dean E. George Payne of the School of Education, announced yesterday. Sponsored in cooperation with the Garden City school system, the workshop is patterned after a plan established for Summer schools by the Progressive Education Association four years ago.
All of the fifty-two Whelan drug stores in this city were closed yesterday by a strike of 800 members of the Retail Drug Store Employes Union, Local 1,199, C.I.O.

Two new songs by Irving Berlin, one termed "a timely spiritual" by the composer, titled, "When That Man Is Dead and Gone," were the highlights of the second radio program by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers last night over WMCA, WNEW and WHN.

IN the beginning, when the Wright brothers were patiently and painstakingly building and testing their first "flying machines" and ignoring the opinions of people who considered them unbalanced, flight by man seemed to be simply a matter of aerodynamics. And perhaps it was.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 1 -- The Chinese municipality of Shanghai and the International Settlement Council today signed an agreement regarding policing of the western area following a long, bitter dispute.

THE aquisition of air bases in the Caribbean Sea by the United States has awakened new interest in British Colonies where American planes will be stationed. Jamaica, the largest of the British West Indies, is one of the most important of the eight bases.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Two ships carrying almost $1,000,000 worth of food left this country this week, one headed for Spain and unoccupied France and the other for Greece. Earlier, other ships have gone to Finland, and in all more than 150 such vessels, bearing supplies running into unestimated millions in value, have crossed the Atlantic from these shores.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- To inspire even this beautiful city with civic pride is a full time job, and Mme. Paulo Bettencourt, who could be enjoying a full calendar of social engagements, sticks to it six days a week. Her work, which she created for herself in 1936, is dedicated to education and public service, but few persons know that hers is the hand responsible for some important public improvements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Certain passage of the Lease-Lend Bill in the House next week was predicted today as Secretary Knox told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that he was "positive" the Axis would invade the Western Hemisphere if Britain were overwhelmed and that "the odds would be against us" in meeting an Axis attack.

United States aircraft production, if Great Britain can hold out until the program is in full swing in 1942, will be ample for our defense and for Britain and will make United States supremacy in the air secure, Colonel John H. Jouett, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce, declared last night.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1 -- A "left-handed" race horse, the King Ranch's Dispose, smashed home first today in the keenest running of the Bahamas Handicap at Hialeah Park, setting a new track record and thrilling the Governor of Florida and 15,000 others.

THE artist colony described in this curious tale is located, apparently somewhere on Long Island, just where does not particularly matter. What does matter is that here are gathered some of the most eccentric and unconventional characters that can possibly be imagined.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1 -- A Blue and White Ball will be given at the Patio Feb. 14 for the Friends of Greece with Mrs. Harrison Williams as chairman.
MONTREAL -- With snow conditions perfect throughout the Laurentian Mountains, crowds of approximately 10,000 have been traveling north on recent week-ends from Montreal.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The important thing about the Middle East campaign from the British point of view is the way Britain has taken the initiative.

Lawrence L. Shenfield, president of Pedlar Ryan, Inc., advertising, one of America's foremost collectors and a student of the stamps, covers and postal history of the Confederate States, will discuss that subject on the "Calling All Stamp Collectors" program of the National Broadcasting Company next Saturday.

HORNS The controversy over the automobile horn has once again reached the public ear. Mayor La Guardia's is the latest official voice raised against the type and tone of horn now in use; but the automobile horn has always been an annoyance to New Yorkers.

HONOLULU, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A quiet reminder that "there is much to be done" replaced the customary roar of saluting guns as Admiral Husband E. Kimmel became Commander-in-Chief today of the United States three-ocean Navy.

PRIVATE fliers and non-scheduled operators last week declared in Los Angeles, home of approximately 3,000 pilots in those categories, that non-commercial, non-military aviation today faces extinction unless adequate facilities for their use are provided promptly.

IT may be of interest to your department to learn that the Gilbert and Sullivan Society of London is not disconcerted by the turn of affairs in the capital of Savoyland but has added to its normal benefactions that of being -- according to its secretary -- "an excellent antidote for war nerves."

Sudden realization by men's wear retailers last week that the much publicized and frequently discounted shortages of fabrics may actually cut into clothing supplies led to frantic demands on manufacturers to ship out Spring goods at once and to offer Fall lines as quickly as possible, producers reported here yesterday.
SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- Plans are now getting under way for the major Spring events. Golf and equestrian activities will top the calendar of sports for February and March.

VICHY, France, Feb. 1 -- The United States Ambassador, Admiral William D. Leahy, who has made more than eighty calls on Ministers, officials and diplomats since he came to Vichy, conferred today with Jean Achard, Under-Secretary of Supplies.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 1 -- Ben Hogan of White Plains, N.Y., shot a 68, three under par, today for an aggregate score of 136 and a joint lead with Johnny Bulla of Chicago at the halfway mark in the seventy-two-hole $5,000 Western open golf tournament.

MICHAEL SADLEIR has based this unusual novel on authentic, personally gathered source material dealing with a phase of nineteenth-century London life which, to quote him, "polite literature of the day preferred to ignore."

A principle of law set forth in a decision of the Circuit Court of Appeals, rendered last month, upon an issue having its origin in the Excess Profits Tax of the World War period will also apply to similar situations arising under the 1940 Excess Profits Tax.
BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Skiers are coming to the Green Mountains in large numbers every week-end now, as the snow piles up on the mountains and makes the trails ideal.
POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- With a new eight-inch snowfall on a four-inch frozen base covering the entire Poconos, all the snow sports continue in full swing.

MUCH has appeared in these columns concerning the problems of refugee musicians in this country. The various viewpoints expressed may even be of use in investigations which are now being made in a systematic way of the entire question.

British holdings of thirty-seven additional American securities have been entirely liquidated, according to a statement issued yesterday by T.J. Carlyle Gifford, special agent of the British Treasury in charge of the British-owned securities in this market.

A book of 1,215 pages coming to rest on a desk in a metropolitan newspaper office and entitled "Farmers in a Changing World" is a reminder, if such were needed, that food and clothing do not grow in stores or in cans, but mainly originate in the ground. Officially, this volume is the Yearbook of Agriculture, published by the Department over which Henry A. Wallace until recently presided.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Wisconsin Public Service Company, Milwaukee, filed an amendment today to its registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to give the public offering prices, names of members of the underwriting syndicate for its proposed issues of $26,500,000 of first-mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, due in 1971, and 132,000 shares 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value.

FOR two decades, inflation has been one of the bogies of our generation. Ever since their fantastic inflation of 1923, when the value of their currency fell to one thousand-billionth part of what it had been, the Germans have dreaded inflation more than war or famine.

SHARON, Vt., Feb. 1 -- Sharp hammer strokes and clear youthful voices echoed today from partly finished CCC barracks in the mountain-locked Downer State Forest in White River Valley. Here young college graduates labor shoulder to shoulder in subzero weather with non-collegiate enrollees from hard-by farms and from large New England cities, preparing Camp William James for an experiment which may drastically alter the Civilian Conservation Corps.

REDUCTION of density in negatives and prints is one of the most misunderstood and mishandled of photographic processes. Most beginners consider it so complex and delicate a technique that they will not use it for fear that they may easily, and seriously, damage negatives and prints.

CHALLENGING with a "small Buick" in price fields below its former range and quickstepping toward 1942 models, General Motors' Buick division introduced yesterday four new cars in the Series 40 Special line. The cars have torpedo styled bodies, three inches shorter wheelbase and a six-inch reduction of over-all length.

ALTHOUGH every boat arriving in Australia from England passes through the war zone, up to the end of 1940 the booksellers and librarians had suffered remarkably few losses through sinkings. Several librarians assured me during my tour of the country last September and October that all their fries of serial publications still being issued were unbroken.

In the days of sailing ships, the eyes of the fleet, the scouts spying out the movements of the enemy, the guardians of merchant convoys and the harriers of enemy shipping were the corvettes, swift, lightly armed war vessels capable of tackling anything less formidable than the mighty ships of the line and able easily to outmanoeuvre and outrun those.

No one would take the lead at the start. Four of them wanted it at the finish. But it was Walter Mehl who won the Wanamaker Mile before 15,000 wildly excited fans at the Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden last night in a strange race of early lethargy and late frenzied sprinting.

After an absence of more than two weeks the New York Rangers will disport on their home ice tonight when they meet the Canadiens of Montreal in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. Not since Jan. 16, when they played a 3-3 tie with the Boston Bruins, have the Rangers appeared at home, and their battle with the habitants promises to attract a large crowd.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Japanese demands for naval bases in Southern Indo-China and Thailand to facilitate possible moves against Singapore or the Netherlands Indies were expected today as the reward for Japan's mediation in the undeclared war between Thailand and Indo-China.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 1 -- A larger area is being covered in this Winter's manoeuvres in the Caribbean than at any time since the entire fleet assembled three years ago to work on Problem 20 under the eye of the President. At that time naval craft, divided, simulated attack and defense of the hemisphere. They ranged far into the Atlantic and south to Northern Brazil.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil Feb. 1 -- Japanese are making increased efforts to capture Latin-American markets. One Japanese firm here is reported to have been trying to corner the mica and quartz market. It also tried to purchase all available hides, and old steamers for scrap iron.

ALGIERS, French North Africa, Feb. 1 (AP) -- General Maxime Weygand, the colonial military commander of the Vichy government, urged his French African Army, estimated at 500,000 men, today to pay no heed to appeals that they enter the war against the Italians.

CHALLENGING with a "small Buick" in price fields below its former range and quickstepping toward 1942 models, General Motors' Buick division introduced yesterday four new cars in the Series 40 Special line. The cars have torpedo styled bodies, three inches shorter wheelbase and a six-inch reduction of over-all length.

ALTHOUGH every boat arriving in Australia from England passes through the war zone, up to the end of 1940 the booksellers and librarians had suffered remarkably few losses through sinkings. Several librarians assured me during my tour of the country last September and October that all their fries of serial publications still being issued were unbroken.

In the days of sailing ships, the eyes of the fleet, the scouts spying out the movements of the enemy, the guardians of merchant convoys and the harriers of enemy shipping were the corvettes, swift, lightly armed war vessels capable of tackling anything less formidable than the mighty ships of the line and able easily to outmanoeuvre and outrun those.

AN old lady in Oxford Street explained one morning that she had not heard the air-raid sirens. "But when I saw the people running and laughing I knew that it must be an alarm." And the English-woman whose letter notes that characteristic episode comments with equally characteristic restraint on the general reaction to the bombing of Britain, "I think Hitler would be dissatisfied."

The Peddie School basketball team rallied in the fourth period to defeat the Brooklyn Poly Prep quintet on the latter's court yesterday. 41 to 31. The triumph enabled the Peddie athletes to go into a tie for first place with Blair Academy in the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League, each with three victories and no defeats.

Keeping pace with expanding national defense expenditures, retail trade in most distributive lines showed substantial gains in January. Total volume for the month was estimated in merchandising circles as probably the best for any January since 1929, with the industrial areas and the South contributing the largest percentage gains.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The Netherlands Government-in-exile instructed its Minister at Tokyo today to inform the Japanese that the Netherlands "rejects any suggestion of having the Netherland Indies incorporated in a new order in East Asia under the leadership of any power whatsoever."

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- The thirteenth annual Sir Thomas Lipton Challenge Cup race, to be sailed over an ocean course off Miami Beach on Saturday, will inaugurate point competition for the Governor of Florida Trophy, presented by Governor Spessard L. Holland.

HAVANA, Cuba, Feb. 1 -- President Fulgencio Batista today called a special session of Congress to begin Tuesday to solve Cuba's acute economic problems and approve measures for defense of the republic. Additional taxes have been asked by the President. It is reported the government is considering imposing an income tax for the first time.

The threat of racing competition from New Jersey, a source of worry to New York racing officials, will become an actuality next Summer, the Joint Legislative Committee for the study of pari-mutuel betting learned yesterday when William H. Cane, New Jersey Racing Commissioner, testified that two Jersey tracks definitely would be established.

ALGIERS, French North Africa, Feb. 1 (AP) -- General Maxime Weygand, the colonial military commander of the Vichy government, urged his French African Army, estimated at 500,000 men, today to pay no heed to appeals that they enter the war against the Italians.

WARNERS have discovered the hard way that there is no subject more laden with discomfort and probable complications than religion. Hartzell Spence, author of "One Foot in Heaven," a biography of his father, is at the studio at the producers' request to cope with the objections which they have received in letters from lay and clerical Protestants who have expressed anxiety over a number of elements in the story.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- The annual report of the Playland Authority covering its 1940 operation of the $11,000,000 county amusement park at Rye is focusing attention here on the dilemma that has beset Westchester County in its business of running roller-coasters, merry-go-rounds and Ferris wheels.

A NATIONAL conference on the application of light to photography will be held March 10 through 14 at Bloomfield, N.J., under the sponsorship of the Westinghouse Lamp Division. Five sessions will be held in the evenings at the Westinghouse auditorium.

A campaign to meet foreign propaganda by dramatizing the principles of American freedom was started last week by a group of leading authors who have banded together under the name of the Free Company. James Boyd, chairman, said the authors would not undertake to reply to alien allegations but merely emphasize what Americans have "to be proud of and believe in."

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Professor M.V.H. Mottram, a dietietic expert, suggests in an article in the current issue of the medical magazine Lancet that Britons go on a diet consisting mainly of whole meal, bread, green and root vegetables, potatoes and oatmeal, "with possibly a small amount of milk, cheese and meat."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The text of the preliminary report of Paul V. Betters, executive director of the United States Conference of Mayors on problems of defense, including material supplied to Mr. Betters by the Federal Air Raid Precautions Committee at Ottawa, was as follows:

Here is a story of Brittany such as we may never have again, but there is, happily, no nostalgia nor regret in it, rather a deeply felt re-creation of its beauty and abundance of life, combined with the high spirits of five very mischievous youngsters.

More than sixty men and women students, representing colleges, universities and theological seminaries throughout the United States, met yesterday at the Shelton Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, to organize a national student committee to cooperate with the National Committee on Food for the Five Small Democracies. Former President Herbert Hoover is honorary chairman of the larger organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (AP) -- College football coaches, still arguing the merits of three major rule changes announced less than a month ago, were confronted today with the likelihood that two more changes will be incorporated into the 1941 gridiron code.

The railroad managements feel encouraged by the report of the Attorney General's committee on administration concerning proposed changes in methods and procedure of the National Railroad Adjustment Board. The Class I railroads had filed with the committee a brief outlining their grievances concerning the policies of the board in settling disputes with labor and in other ways previously had made known their discontent with its operation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A transaction called by Secretary Ickes "the greatest land deal since the Louisiana Purchase," is about to be closed between the government and fifty-three Western railroads.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 1 -- Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Good Turn, such a disappointment as a juvenile that his owner didn't bother to keep him eligible for some of the naiton's leading 3-year-old stakes, won the $10,000 added San Vicente Handicap at Santa Anita Park today and emerged as the colt to watch in the $50,000 added Santa Anita Derby on Feb. 12.
ROME, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

Results in nine classifications of an industrial design competition for home furnishings were announced yesterday by the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, under whose auspices it was opened last September.

THE legislative mills are grinding once more, with a new Congress in session; and new members in both houses have bright, new hopes for making a legislative mark. Most of those hopes will be blighted, for the simple reason that new members, no matter how sincere or persistent, seldom make legislative history the first time out.

WITH that seeming simplicity and entire lack of effort which usually results only from expert artistry and an enormous amount of hard work, E.G. Pinkham tells the story of an elderly widow living on the Salem Road.

ATHENS, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Greek occupation of the key Albanian town of Tepeleni was said tonight to await only cleaning-up operations, and dispatches from the front reported that recent gains had put the Greeks on the threshold of "new big victories."

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Feb. 1 -- A moonlight skating party in costume, in aid of the Nassau Philharmonic Society, has been arranged for Friday evening at the Beaver Dam Winter Sports Club, in Mill Neck, by a committee of the younger married couples of the North Shore colonies.

BUENOS AIRES -- Collectors will do well to be on the alert for postal varieties resulting from new paper being used for printing Argentina's stamps. The government has been experiencing difficulty is getting paper supplies from abroad, due to shipping conditions -- a situation reminiscent of the World War.

From the opening gun which started the 120-yard medley race, the Penn Hall girls' swimming team of Chambersburg, Pa., completely dominated their rivals from the Savage School of Physical Education of New York, as they ran up a total of 47 points against 19 in the American Women's Association pool yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A funeral service for William Gibbs McAdoo will be held Monday morning at Epiphany Episcopal Church here, with the chaplain of the Senate, the Rev. ZeBarney T. Phillips, officiating. Burial will be at Arlington Cemetery.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Although Selective Service officials report that they could now supply the Army with 2,500,000 able-bodied Americans within ten days, only about 100,000 trainees thus far have been inducted into service, fewer than half of the 240,000 scheduled for this date by the War Department.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- Despite the fact that the wars have greatly limited the travel possibilities of the more adventurous tourists, there are still unusual tours available in our own peaceful Western Hemisphere. Such a voyage is the twelve-day trip aboard a small mail packet boat, the Monarch of Nassau, from Miami by way of Nassau to the colorful and remote Bahama Islands.

Today the Women Poets become of age. No fanfare will accompany this twenty-first anniversary, and no festivities will be held in celebration. Instead, the members will devote themselves to a panoramic review of accomplishments of their associates, many of whom are well known to lovers of poetry.

Mr. Tunis's champion is his first heroine, a tennis star who scaled the heights of Wimbledon, and stayed there, not by technique and strength only but, as a champion must, by knowing how to call on the last ounce of fighting spirit.

A RECENT French critic has said that to appreciate Moliere fully one must be either very simple or very complicated. Those who fall between these extremes remain most hostile to the charm of his genius; they also form the group whence Moliere drew most of his models.

YAPHANK, L.I., Feb. 1 -- Lieut. Col. Robert T. Snow, executive officer here at Camp Upton, bought the first stamp today in a brief formal ceremony that marked the opening of the camp's new post-office in the reception center area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The growth of government by commission, which assertedly has led to capricious and unfair decisions by multitudinous agencies, has become so great that even stanch New Dealers admit that some reforms are necessary.

There are now in the stores a lot of new kitchen things that will bear inspection by women who pride themselves on running their household smoothly. Last week, for one thing, the new models in refrigerators began to show up, and it is obvious that great strides have been made.

The gardener who wishes a handsome display for little effort may find great satisfaction by including certain ornamental grasses when at this season he is making up his seed orders. Given rather rich, well-drained soil, plenty of water, and a thick coat of dry leaves or straw in Winter, these attractive plants look after themselves and form highly desirable and effective additions to waterside, lawn or garden.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 1 -- - In a fast and rough game marked by a free-for-all fight and a pair of match penalties, Princeton scored twice in an overtime period to upset Yale, 5 -- 4, in the opening battle in the Quadrangular Hockey League before a crowd of 1,000 in Hobey Baker Rink tonight.

Mrs. Charles F. Junod Jr. has announced that the Service League of Pelham has become the Junior League of Pelham, with its admission into the Association of the Junior Leagues of America. The service group was founded in 1932.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 1 -- The Regional Conference of the River Plate ran into serious difficulties today when delegates of the participating countries found their individual national interest too valuable to be sacrifice for the ideal of group welfare.

VICHY, France, Feb. 1 -- "If we leave France we shall never find her again," said Marshal Henri Philippe Petain on June 11 at Chateau du Muguet, just south of the Loire River, after Winston Churchill and Anthony Eden had come from England by air to discuss the military situation with Paul Reynaud, then the French Premier.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force announced today that several tons of bombs had been dropped on Tripoli, capital of Western Libya and a vital Italian communications center. Tripoli, which has a population of approximately 100,000, is near Tunisia, headquarters of the restless and idle French Army under General Maxime Weygand.
DES MOINES, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Young Republicans voted limited approval of "all-out" aid for Britain at today's session of the national convention of the Young Republican Federation.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Royal Air Force headquarters issued this communique today:

Mrs. Charles F. Junod Jr. has announced that the Service League of Pelham has become the Junior League of Pelham, with its admission into the Association of the Junior Leagues of America. The service group was founded in 1932.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force announced today that several tons of bombs had been dropped on Tripoli, capital of Western Libya and a vital Italian communications center. Tripoli, which has a population of approximately 100,000, is near Tunisia, headquarters of the restless and idle French Army under General Maxime Weygand.
DES MOINES, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Young Republicans voted limited approval of "all-out" aid for Britain at today's session of the national convention of the Young Republican Federation.

Barring early strength in the Swiss franc (commercial) carried forward from the preceding week on reports that the Swiss banking authorities would stop the free flow of remittances from this country excepting those based on commercial requirements, other sections of the foreign exchange market continued in the narrow price groove and light dealings which have become a significant part of the trading in foreign currencies for many weeks now.

VICHY, France, Feb. 2 -- While various parties seem bent on broadening the rift they have created between Paris and Vichy, the situation remained unchanged today and Marshal Henri Philippe Petain appeared as serene as ever as he walked through Vichy this morning before luncheon.

Officials of the United States Lines said yesterday that the liner Manhattan, stranded off the Florida shore near Palm Beach, had been moved 170 feet seaward Saturday night and had another 575 feet to go before reaching deep water.

When he retired as president of the Rockefeller Foundation in 1929 Dr. George Edgar Vincent had rounded out three interlinking careers in the fields of education and philanthropy. He had been successively principal of the Chautauqua Institution, president of the University of Minnesota and head of the world's most militant disease-fighting organization.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- Taking two out of four races, Corny Shields was the leading Class B dinghy skipper today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. He made 72 points with his boat Sissy to 68 for John Nichols in the Snow Drop.

A new school to instruct firemen on air bombardment incendiary problems has been opened at the Fire College in Long Island City, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday. Firemen will study air raid fire fighting methods learned by department members who observed conditions in England recently.

The wage stabilization plan developed by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America has freed the New York clothing market from the "runaway-shop evil," Louis Hollander and Joseph Catalanotti, co-managers of the joint board of the C.I.O. affiliate, declared in their annual report, made public yesterday.

Marilyn Meyer, 15-year-old pianist from Milwaukee, gave her second New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Miss Meyer was first heard here a year ago in a promising appearance at the same auditorium.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Great Britain's exports in December registered a decline of 15,800,000, compared with December, 1939; re-exports fell 1,800,000 and imports were off 13,000,000, making the year's exports drop 26,500,000, with re-exports down 19,800,000 and imports 214,400,000 higher than in 1939.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- Husky Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis sped through the gathering dusk today to win the five-mile race and become the 1941 North American speed-skating champion.

The greatest handicap to clear thinking in the present emergency is the average liberal's conception of a romanticized human nature, Dr. Frank Kingdon, New York chairman of the Commitee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, said yesterday in a sermon as guest pastor at the Community Church in Town Hall.

The city was accused yesterday of trying to disrupt labor relations on its own unified transit system in order to block efforts of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., to negotiate a new collective bargaining contract to replace the agreements expiring in June.

VICHY, France, Feb. 2 -- Pope Pius is convinced that the world aspires to a new order, it was declared today by Pierre Cardinal Gerlier, Archbishop of Lyon, addressing a congregation in the Fourviere Basilica at Lyon after his recent visit to Rome.

Despite an excellent goal-tending exhibition by Bert Gardiner, the New York Rangers subdued the Canadiens of Montreal, 2 to 1, in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Blue Shirts trained a scorching, virtually ceaseless fire on the northern guardian, and managed to beat him just often enough.

Brian O'Mara, young Irish tenor, was heard in his initial New York recital last night in Town Hall. Mr. O'Mara, who appeared extensively in this country and abroad as a former member of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, also has sung frequently on American broadcasts.

VICHY, France, Feb. 2 -- By a decree published today, Baron Eugene de Rothschild, former Admiral Emile Muselier and several Gaullist adherents abroad and in the colonies were deprived of French nationality.

Bills before the State Legislature that seek to deny Communists and Nazis and other groups a place on the ballot are "misguided attempts to suppress the enemies of American institutions" and are attacks on fundamental American civil liberties, the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union declared yesterday.
BERLIN, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

Miss Elsie Mumma, who recently established an unusual insurance record by writing policies in twelve foreign countries on a trip around the world, has become associated with the insurance brokerage company of Monnett Vickrey, Inc., of 1 Cedar Street, it was announced yesterday.

MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 2 -- The strike of 3,400 workers in the two plants of the Alabama Drydocks and Shipbuilding Company was ended today by ratification of a new contract by unanimous vote of members of the C.I.O. Marine and Shipbuilders Workers of America.

Bruno Walter will make his debut as a conductor at the Metropolitan Opera House next week with Beethoven's only opera, "Fidelio," which is being restored to the reper toire after an absence of two years. Kirsten Flagstad will sing the role of Leonora.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- C. M. Loeb Jr. was the major winner of scratch prizes at the traps of the Westchester Country Club today. He took the singles cup with 48 of 50 targets, and the doubles with 46. At skeet, Loeb lost to M. Zilinski 25 -- 24, after a tie at 47.

BERLIN, Feb. 2 -- The recent estimate of the Reich's 1940 tax revenue by Assistant Finance Minister Fritz Reinhardt at twenty-six to twenty-seven billion marks finds support in the treasury's return on tax receipts for the third quarter of the fiscal year -- October through December, 1940.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 2 -- It can't be done, but somebody did it. A four-room house was stolen at Fort Dix. Officers subsequently located the house four miles away from its original site, but they have made little progress in learning how it was stolen or who did it.
BOSTON, Feb. 2 -- The newly crowned United States figure-skating titleholders will be called upon within ten days to compete with a team of Canadians in the biennial North American championships.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 2 -- One thousand striking employes of the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation voted today to return to work at 7 A.M. tomorrow, thus ending a tie-up that threatened to delay $230,000,000 in national defense orders.

ROME, Feb. 2 -- The United States will most likely disregard Reichsfuehrer Hitler's warning that he will sink American ships going to England, Giovanni Ansaldo told the armed forces this afternoon in his weekly broadcast. However, he cheered up his listeners by saying that the German Spring attack would be the greatest ever seen in warfare.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 2 -- Fierce rioting between soldiers and civilians suspected of anti-British sympathies broke out in this capital of the Transvaal Friday and peace was not fully restored until this morning.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 2 -- Continuation of the record inflow of orders, further efforts toward stabilization of the domestic scrap markets, and the focusing of attention on the labor situation, were highlights in news of the steel industry last week.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 2 -- The ghost of the Chaco war hovered over the River Plate conference today as delegates of the five participating countries, Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, mused themselves at Montevideo's race track and at beaches.

Westchester, as a county of both urban and rural areas, offers pointed evidence of the constantly increasing inequalities to which tax-exemption statutes have given rise in this State. The County Tax Commission reports that tax exemptions now amount to $336,762,785, as against a total taxable property valuation of $1,584,844,099.

"AFTERMATH,"* by Jules Romains, is like a section of a great, unfinished fresco, impressive in its superlative drawing and scope but unsatisfying in itself, as would be any single section of so large an undertaking.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 2 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:
Wlliam L. Day, who had been with Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., since 1935, is now with Drexel Co.

Every reported attack with incendiary bombs in the European was has shown an ineptitude and lack of planning that defeats the purpose of fire bombardment, Dr. J. Enrique Zanettt, Professor of Chemistry in Columbia University, declares in a study of "Fire from the Air -- The ABC of Incendiaries," to be published today by the Columbia University Press.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 2 -- After several days of progressively intensified fighting, British and Indian troops aided by the Royal Air Force broke the last Italian defenses at Agordat yesterday morning and completed the capture of that important mountain railroad town in Eritrea.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 2 -- Netherlands financial quarters consider Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau's figures on British balances in the United States as of graver import than generally was expected, because the data indicate that these assets are virtually exhausted, and, as a result the lease-lend bill appears to be the sole measure left to make for support of Great Britain.

Three persons, one of them a young woman, were killed and five others were injured, four seriously, shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday morning when the station wagon in which they were riding at high speed crashed into the center safety curb of the West Side Highway at Gansevoort Street.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The Legislature enters the fifth week of the current session when it reconvenes tomorrow night, with the probability that its standing committees will begin consideration of some of the problems which have arisen thus far. Committee work has been held up to some extent by the epidemic of grippe which swept the Capitol during the last two weeks.
HONOLULU, Feb. 2 -- Somebody should put up signs on all South Pacific islands for the benefit of passing Nazi commerce raiders warning them to "high-tail it" to safer waters.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Feb. 2 -- Winding up his rapid tour of England amid the joyful shouts of crowds that resembled campaign gatherings in the United States, Wendell L. Willkie visited the wrecked city of Coventry and the severely bombed industrial center of Birmingham today and then, after reaffirming his sympathy for the British cause, spent the rest of the day with the Earl of Derby, War Secretary in the World War Cabinet.
BERLIN, Feb. 2 -- The advance in shipping shares was renewed here last week.

The Prison Association of New York proposes in it's ninety-sixth annual report to be submitted to the Legislature today that "the potential man power in correctional institutions be utilized as an aid to national defense." At the same time the organization advocates use of prison labor on highways.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 2 -- Frankie Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., today won his fourth straight tennis title on the Winter circuit when he rallied to defeat former National Champion Bobby Riggs of Chicago in the final of the first annual University of Miami invitation tournament.

OMAHA, Feb. 2 -- Republican leaders from sixteen States bore out advance predictions concerning their week-end talks here and waded into all party questions, including that revolving about Wendell L. Willkie.
LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, will receive the ninety-seventh anniversary award of B'nai B'rith, Jewish fraternal group, for "honor, duty and achievement" at a covenant breakfast of the organization on Sunday, Feb. 16, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Secretary Perkins reported today that demands for skilled labor had resulted in many national defense industries lifting bans against older workers.

An appeal for volunteers to donate blood for an emergency blood bank for the national defense was issued yesterday by General Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 3 -- Bomber and fighter planes of the British Royal Air Force, over Saturday night and in daylight yesterday, attacked docks at Brest, Boulogne and Ostend and maintained an almost constant vigil over the Nazis' invasion coast between those ports and over the Strait of Dover.
TOKYO, Feb. 2 -- Japanese press reactions show that the Japanese Government intends to accept in silence the Netherlands Government's reported refusal to participate in a "new order in East Asia."

ATHENS, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Greek soldiers, fighting what their official spokesman called a "really heroic" action, captured a large and important mountain range north of Klisura today, it was reported tonight.
The German Transocean press service gave out yesterday the text of a communique from Vichy setting forth the Thailand-French Indo-China armistice terms as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Representatives Joe Starnes of Alabama, acting chairman of the House Special Committee on Un-American Activities, declared tonight that the American Youth Congress stood "fully exposed as an un-American and subversive group working solely in the interests of the Communist dictator."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Production workers at the River Rouge and Lincoln plants of the Ford Motor Company "have become organized into unions chartered by the American Federation of Labor," William Green, president of the federation, said tonight.

The Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration will open to the public tomorrow an exhibition of Spanish ornamental ironwork, Italian altar lamps, old French cooking molds, Navajo and Alaskan Indian jewelry and modern American sculpture illustrating "the adaptability of malleable metals to creative design."

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks advanced within two points of third place in the National Hockey League tonight, routing the pace-setting Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 to 1, before 16,660 spectators. The Hawks broke a three-game losing streak and enabled the Boston Bruins to gain two more points in their drive on the league leaders.

I should like to express my appreciation of your editorial, "What Causes History," refuting the often-heard assertion that the Versailles Treaty was a fountain of injustice and the cause of the present war. Denunciations of the Versailles Treaty are made so often that many people seem to accept such statements as axiomatic -- particularly those unacquainted with its terms and not especially well informed as to facts preceding and following its execution.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 2 -- Plunging unclothed into Los Angeles Harbor following a party aboard the 65-foot yacht El Commandee, Dolores Del Mar, 29-year-old Hollywood night club dancer, was drowned early today.

MANILA, Feb. 2 -- Broadening the base of its extensive although secret preparations to defend the Philippines, the United States Army announced today that it would take in 5,000 Philippine Army reservists for a year of additional training.
ROME, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

Early returns from a nation-wide survey conducted by the National Industrial Council, an affiliate of the National Association of Manufacturers, disclosed yesterday that there is a vast amount of idle plant space and partly used machinery and equipment available for defense production.
I am impressed with the difficulty of adjudicating other people's quarrels.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 2 -- Colonel William J. Donovan, President Roosevelt's special envoy, had luncheon today at the British Embassy in Ankara. Tonight he dined with several Turkish officials and army officers whom he met yesterday and today.

After two weeks of hearings and discussion in committee, the House of Representatives will begin today to debate the President's lease-lend bill. This measure was reported from committee by a vote cast essentially along partisan lines. The present indications are that it will be passed in the House by a vote which is just as partisan.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Ted Morton ran 34.09 miles in 13 hours and 29 minutes with an Army general and ten dollars on his mind.

The death of William Gibbs McAdoo brings to a close a truly great career. Had he not been the wartime Secretary of the Treasury, his life would still have been full and significant. He had proved his financial ability by successfully promoting the first Hudson Tunnel at a huge cost in the depression years early in the century.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 -- The Bruins stretched their unbeaten string to fifteen straight games tonight at the expense of the Americans, defeating the oft-beaten New Yorkers, 4 to 1, in a National Hockey League game. Only a spectacular exhibition of goal-tending by Rookie Charlie Rayner held Boston to four goals.

A man may recite an orthodox creed with all the precision and piety of a prelate, but one can far better ascertain what he really believes by observing his attitude toward men and by his reactions in circumstances of good or ill, the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw said in his sermon yesterday in Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, Wadsworth Avenue and West 174th Street.

Two questions immediately occur in relation to Senator Taft's amendment to the lease-lend bill. The first is: To what extent is our national security tied up with the control of the sea and the survival of the British? And the second: If we loan money to purchase supplies, is repayment practical?

Because three weeks ago the newspapers in Kansas carried reports of an influenza epidemic here, William W. Nixon, Commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, decided to remain in Kansas instead of attending a reception in his honor, which was held yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- To appreciate the vastness of the area in which General Sir Archibald P. Wavell's cosmopolitan armies are operating on what may be termed the Northeast African battlegrounds, it is necessary to understand that it is about as large as the Continent of Europe.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 2 -- The Berlin correspondent of the Stockholm newspaper Tidningen described today hew German troops destined to fight in Africa are trained in special "hothouses" situated near Berlin and in Thuringia.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 2 -- A Harvard sophomore who said he once was close enough to Adolf Hitler to call him "Uncle Adolf" declared tonight that he was joining the United States Army to "help defend the way of life that is directly opposed to the ideologies of Hitler and his shifted gangsters."

Reuben Fine and Frank J. Marshall continued their winning streaks in the annual tournament at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. Fine, with the white pieces, won from Harry Fajans in a queen's gambit declined after 34 moves.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- A record trade was transacted in soy bean futures on the Board of Trade here in January, sales aggregating 49,865,000 bushels, compared with the previous record of 31,559,000 in November, 1940. Business in grains, however, slumped to the second lowest for a total month known, aggregating 241,017,000 bushels, compared with 311,316,000 in December and 750,867,000 in January, 1940.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 2 -- The stew Miss Ernestine Latimer stirred up at this Army post with her resignation as junior hostess simmered and bubbled today, but the only official announcement was a bland statement that she had received a leave of absence.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 2 (UP) -- British forces today were closing in on Barentu, Eritrea, drawing a ring about a garrison of 15,000 to 17,000 Italian defenders, whose only hope of escape was to fall back on Tole, some fifteen miles to the southeast, it was reported.

Charley O'Rourke, whose brilliant backfield play helped so much to make Boston College the football power that it was through the season recently concluded, will be the gridiron coach at the new Cardinal Hayes Memorial High School in this city next Fall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The placing of Army and Navy fliers on airliners for advanced training was reported under official study today as a means of meeting a prospective severe shortage of commercial pilots.

BERLIN, Feb. 2 -- According to custom, the Berliner Handelsgesellschaft is the first of Berlin's banking "big five" to publish a report for 1940. Generally the figures confirm the major changes expected for last year in the banking balance sheets.

Unable to stem a furious third-term assault by the invaders, the New York Rovers dropped their sixth straight Eastern Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden yesterday, bowing to the Boston Olympics, 4 to 2. After the Rovers had brought about a 2-all tie at 1:42 of the last chapter, the Olympics drove two straight counters past Gerry Cosby to subdue the locals.

Sharp explosions punctuated the examination hush on many a campus last week as the college basketball campaign slowly gathered momentum for the stretch drive. When the firing was over, there were two fewer undefeated teams and five new major conference leaders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, has arranged to make his first public speech in the United States this month and it may rank as one of the important declarations of British policy on the war and ultimate peace.

PANAMA, Jan. 15 -- Many refugees from Germany, Austria and Poland are arriving in this country with visas that are worthless but for which the refugees have paid as much as 6,000 marks to representatives of certain Central American countries.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Netherland Legation announced today that its government had suspended payment of interest on and redemption of its outstanding debt.

PONCE, P.R., Feb. 2 -- The Ponce Housing Authority today opened the first unit of its housing program under the United States Housing Authority, with George L. Reed, speaking for Nathan Straus, USHA Administrator, declaring the project distinctive in that it carried the lowest subsidy per family and the lowest rentals in the whole $800,000,000 USHA program.

The social activities of baseball's off-season closed on a high and hilarious note last night when more than 1,000 guests packed the grand ballroom of the Hotel commodore for the eighteenth annual dinner and frolic of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association.

Eight hundred members of New York's "Big Six" Typographical Union, attending a dinner at Manhattan Center yesterday evening at which all fifty-year union veterans were honored, applauded a declaration by Elmer Brown, president, that the union is "jealous of its reputation for honesty" and proud of its "freedom from outside influences."
It is a fallacy to describe religion as an emotion, the Rev. Raplh S. Meadowcroft told his congregation yesterday in All Angels Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Creation of local clearing houses similar to those operated by the War Industries Board during the World War was proposed by the Office of Production Management of the National Defense Advisory Commission tonight as a way of assisting in "farming out" huge national defense orders.

Because industrial leaders in Queens have complained about broken springs on their trucks and the resultant damage to cargoes destined to fulfill national defense contracts, 6,000,000 granite blocks will be used to pave every dirt road in the Long Island City industrial area in a project that will be started today, Cyril E. Fyles, Queens Superintendent of Highways, announced yesterday.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., Feb. 2 -- Officers regularly quartered at Camp Upton were adjusting their personal budgets today in anticipation of increased cost of meals beginning tomorrow, when a civilian caterer and civilian personnel will replace enlisted men in the officers' mess halls.

The Peninsula Garage, Inc., of Jersey City bought the one-story factory fronting 125 feet on Factory Street and eighty-seven feet on Whyte Street, Jersey City, N.J., from the Grieff Bros. Cooperage Company of Cleveland, Ohio, which had owned it for forty years.

Professor Samson X. Barrett, director of the new Defense Training Institute, announced yesterday the heads of the departments of the institute, which is a joint enterprise of the eight engineering colleges of New York City and the United States Office of Education for the training of skilled workers in war defense industries.
ATHENS, Feb. 2 -- Italian attempts at a large-scale counter-offensive have failed all along the line, according to official statements tonight.

ADAMS, Mass., Feb. 2 -- Charles McLane, versatile Dartmouth captain, paced the Big Green to the team crown as he won the individual laurels in the annual Massachusetts downhill championship on the precipitous Thunderbolt Trail today. Sixty-nine skiers representing twenty-two clubs competed.

Bruno Walter conducted his third Sunday afternoon concert with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday in Carnegie Hall before one of the largest audiences of the season, for the house was packed and there were 100 standees.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Bestowal of the "Washington Award for 1941," one of the nation's highest engineering honors, upon Ralph Budd of Chicago, president of the Burlington Lines and transportation member of the Advisory Commission to the Council of National Defense, was announced today by Frank F. Fowle, chairman of the award commission.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 2 -- Solomon R. Guggenheim, financier and patron of the arts, observed his eightieth birthday here today at his Winter residence, 9 East Battery. Accompanied by his wife, the former Irene M. Rothschild, and a few friends, he celebrated the occasion quietly.

John A. Payne, president of the Consolidated Coppermines Corporation, in a letter to stockholders, reports that earnings of the company, for the fourth quarter of last year, not only exceeded comparable results for any previous quarter in the company's history but were more than double the amount earned in the entire preceding nine months or the comparable period in 1939.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 -- Mrs. Ernest Hugh Rice entertained tonight with a dinner at her residence for Mr. and Mrs. William John Warburton, her house guests, who leave tonight for New York.

OKEECHOBEE, Fla., Feb. 2 -- Most anglers, when they think of Florida and its fishing, recall only the inlets, surf and offshore waters. While it cannot be denied that the coastal waters offer sport that cannot be equaled in the North, the fresh-water fishing here affords almost equal opportunities.

Members of the National Association of Securities Dealers have been asked to vote before March 2 on a new rule covering the underwriting and distribution of the securities of open-end investment companies, in which about half of them are interested.

A call to Catholic youth to adhere to the moralistic philosophy that has "stood the challenge of the years" was made yesterday by Auxiliary Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre at a communion breakfast of the twenty-second annual convention of the New York Province of the Newman Club Federation.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 2 -- Three cars of an eighteen-car freight train standing on a spur in the Greenville yard of the Pennsylvania Railroad here were derailed at 6:30 o'clock this morning when they were sidewiped by an electric locomotive drawing 105 freight cars.

With all the Whelan drug stores in this city shut by a strike, the Retail Drug Store Employes Union, Local 1,199, C.I.O., sent 100 telegrams yesterday to C.I.O. officials in other parts of the country asking them to enforce a nation-wide consumer boycott against the 1,500 stores and agencies operated by the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman yesterday announced appointments of chairmen and vice chairmen of trade, industry and professional committees within the Archbishop's Committee of the Laity for the 1941 appeal of New York Catholic Charities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Jan. 25 to 31 are given in the appended tabulation:

The "Old Seventh," now the 207th Coast Artillery Anti-Aircraft Regiment of the New York National Guard, attended a special service in St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, yesterday afternoon in anticipation of its induction into Federal service a week from today and its departure a few days later for Camp Stewart, Hinesville, Ga.
Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced yesterday that Barnard College would offer its students the beginnings of a program for national service based upon fundamental needs of modern preparedness.

The indoor track campaign moves over to the Jersey City Armory tonight, with the annual Seton Hall games the immediate objective. A star-studded field, including most of the headliners who participated in Saturday night's Millrose ex-travaganza, has been assembled by the Rev. James A. Carey and a banner turnout is expected.

BERLIN, Feb. 2 -- There is no dearth of German comment on United States affairs in the press or in other mediums of expression these days. The ban that kept virtually all such comment from the newspapers for the last twelve months or more has now apparently been lifted and the plain language of American statesmen and other personalities finds its answer in plain language employed on the German side.
A speeder is usually a skilled driver, and while he brings danger upon himself and other users of the road, it is usually possible to get out of his way.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 102.5 on Jan. 21, compared with 101.8 on Jan. 7, 100.9 on Dec. 31, 91.9 on Jan. 30, 1940, 70.3 at the end of August, 1939, and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The Rev. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, announced at solemn mass yesterday that "according to State law and city regulation," parents of Catholic children attending three public schools in the neighborhood of the cathedral may request that their children in grades three through eight be dismissed from school one hour early every Wednesday afternoon beginning this week to attend classes in religious instruction at the cathedral.

The accounts of Wendell Willkie's visit to England make exciting reading. There are two sides to the English scene. One is the dark picture of wanton ruin and civilian suffering. The other is the inspiring spectacle of a whole people rising magnificently to resist aggression.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The President approved yesterday the promotion of eight commanders in the Supply Corps of the Navy to the rank of captain, and the promotion of twenty lieutenant commanders in the same corps to that of commander.

A "First Young Composers' Concert" was given under the auspices of the League of Composers yesterday afternoon in the intimate and hospitable auditorium that the Forty-second Street Public Library provided for this occasion. It is a good place in which to hear music in an informal fashion.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The hopes of the American people for the freedom of Poland from "oppression and tyranny" were expressed today by Governor Lehman, in a formal proclamation setting Sunday, Feb. 9, as Poland Day.

The City Mission Society, which ministers to the needs of 100,000 persons in New York City's institutions, faces serious curtailment in its activities unless it receives increasing support from church members, the Rev. William E. Sprenger, Superintendent of the society, said yesterday as guest preacher at morning services in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Weakness in hogs and grain started a selling movement in lard last week which more than offset support from cash interests, and while closing trades yesterday were slightly above the low point, net losses on futures for thee week on the Board of Trade were 32 1/2 to 35 cents for 100 pounds.

"The Talley Method," the S.N. Behrman play, which co-stars Ina Claire and Philip Merivale, will open Feb. 15 at Henry Miller's. The show, which closed Saturday night in Baltimore, opens a two-day engagement in New Haven on Friday. Next week there will be five previews, Monday through Friday, before the premiere.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Prices in the Wheat Pit here continued to decline last week, with a record low mark for the season being established by the new-crop months. Likewise the lowest quotations since the middle of October were registered by the May position.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices declined to 85.7 from 86.1. Many of the price decreases took place in the foodstuffs group, which dropped by 1.3 per cent, reflecting principally lower prices for meats. In the farm products group declines in hogs, wheat and eggs were more than enough to offset rises in potatoes, fruits and poultry.

Irvin S. Cobb's autobiography is due next month -- title, "Exit Laughing." Bobbs-Merrill, which will bring out the book, claims modestly that it contains more good stories to the square inch than any other autobiography one can name. Sixteen thousand square inches, the publishers state.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Corn futures declined 1 1/2 to 2 cents a bushel last week, and established a new low price for more than a month, partly in consonance with the trend in wheat and also on scattered liquidation induced by the announcement that the last of the government holdings of corn, estimated at 220,000,000 bushels, in all positions, were for sale.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Feb. 2 -- Two hundred college girls were at Williamstown during the week-end for the annual Williams College midwinter carnival. Skiing is the best of the Winter and several snow trains were run from New York today.

A. L. Cornwell broke 99 of 100 to win the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He added scratch and handicap laurels at 149 targets with 142 -- 4 -- 146. In the handicap shoot at singles, E. Hughes and T. R. Chatfield had full cards, Hughes winning the shoot-off.

DETROIT, Feb. 2 -- Harry Bennett, personnel director of the Ford Motor Company, said tonight he had no knowledge of the American Federation of Labor's claim to majority representation. He reiterated that the company "won't be run by any outside organization."

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 25 -- General Eleazar Lopez Contreras, President of Venezuela, says he will relinquish his power at the end of his present term next April in an effort to give his country a firm foundation for lasting democracy.

The Advertising Club of New York announces formation of a committee on international trade, which aims to take all possible steps to insure the continuation of import and export trade with those countries with which such trade is Presantly feasible.

In Town Hall yesterday afternoon Lotte Lehmann, with the irresistible sincerity, the musicianship and the interpretive skill of the artist that she is, sang the entire cycle of Schubert songs, "Die Winterreise," on the program of the New Friends of Music.
PHILADELIPHIA, Feb. 2 -- Invitations to bid on 40,000,000 yards of cotton cloth from which working suits for the Army will be fashioned later this year were in the hands of the trade today.
OTTAWA, Feb. 2 -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King announced tonight the virtual doubling of the Canadian Army overseas, the Commonwealth Air Training Plan, and the Canadian Navy.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 2 -- Earl Dew, 1940 American jockey champion, died en route to a hospital here today after suffering injuries in a three-horse accident at the Agua Caliente, Mexico, racetrack. Death was due to a cerebral hemorrhage resulting from a fractured skull.
Hans Strand of the Bear Mountain Ski Club yesterday won the Class A jump of the Staten Island Ski Club before 2,500 spectators on the north side of Todt Hill.

Coincident with the downward trend of the volume of fluid milk purchased in New York City, the farmers who produce that milk have been stimulated, by the operations of the Federal farm price control plan, to increase their production.
IT was the mention of the name of Lefty Grove that started it. Big Mose led the American League pitchers on an earned-run basis no less than eight times.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- While squash racquets devotees packed the galleries, Donald M. Frame, metropolitan champion from the Harvard Club, vanquished Germain G. Glidden in an overtime duel today for premier honors in the Apawamis Club invitation tourney.

The Very Rev. Benno Aichinger, confessor to the clergy at St. Fidelis Monastery, attached to St. John the Baptist Church on West Thirtieth Street, celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of his admission to the ranks of the Capuchin Franciscan Friars at a solemn mass of thanksgiving there yesterday morning at 11 o'clock.

Although every man, woman and child in the United States, on the average, used more than a dozen pairs of hosiery last year, the total shipments showed a slight decline from 1939, a fact giving support to those who have contended that introduction of long-wearing nylons would reduce total consumption, Statistics prepared by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers showed that total shipments of hosiery in 1940 dropped for the first time since 1930.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 2 -- The securities markets of the smaller Continental European countries again registered no uniform trend last week. Irregular tendencies on the respective bourses were the rule as local developments in the several nations continued to exert a more potent influence on prices than the international situation, although the expected early accentuation of the war around Great Britain undoubtedly contributed to engendering a generally hesitant tone.

In his sermon yesterday morning in Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick offered testimony of the New Testament as an answer to church critics' charge that Christian faith is but "lovely, comforting fantasy, a pleasant drug."

With the business situation continuing under the domination of the national defense effort, there are two basic influences that are protecting the United States economy against inflationary price rises, according to the February bulletin of the National City Bank of New York.

The estate of Gifford A. Cochran sold 57 East Fifty-second Street, assessed at $39,000, to Twelfth Estate, Inc., which controls a large plot in the rear on Fifty-third Street. Pease Elliman were the brokers and the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company acted as trustees for the seller.

Ready-to-wear markets were active last week, despite the fact that the peak of Spring buying has passed. Some staples were bought for Fall delivery. Satin-bound suits were in demand. Sport coats sold well, and manufacturers concentrated upon classic numbers in camel hair, covert and plaids, because of excellent public response.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 2 -- Max W. Babb, president of the strike-bound Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, refused today a request by R.J. Thomas, international president of the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers, that the company's executive committee discuss company policy with union leaders.

VICHY, France, Feb. 2 -- Interest rates on defense bonds which were reduced recently from 4 to 3 1/2 per cent, have been lowered again to 3.25 per cent. Treasury bonds, on the other hand, have been cut, for the one-year issues, from 3 to 2.75 per cent and for the six-month issues, from 2.50 to 2.25 per cent.

The First Boston Corporation and the Wisconsin Company head a nation-wide underwriting syndicate that will offer today to the public $26,500,000 of first-mortgage 3 1/4% per cent bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1971, and 132,000 shares of 5 per cent preferred stock of the Wisconsin Public Service Corporation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 2 -- Led by Eivind Berggrav, the Bishop of Oslo, all the Norwegian Bishops -- numbering seven -- have addressed to the Education and Church States Councilor, Professor Ragnor Shanke, a document that the Swedish press calls "sensational."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2 -- Negotiations to obtain Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell for the leading roles in Warner Brothers's version of "The Man Who Came to Dinner" neared final stages over the week-end, it was learned from Howard Hawks, who will direct the picture.

The Citizens Budget Commission announced yesterday in its annual report that it would continue to work for a higher rapid transit fare to place the city's unified system on a self-sustaining basis and thereby relieve the budget of a subway deficit approximating $30,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The question of "all-out" aid to Britain, discussed in Congressional committees and in the press for several weeks, finally will go before the Congress tomorrow.
Time seemed to turn backward last week as it was revealed that corvettes -- first of a new class of fighting ships -- were now assisting the hard-worked British Fleet on convoy duty.

France is still a weighty factor in the war. This is clear as the deadlock between Petain and Hitler nears its uncertain end. The position of Laval is said to be the issue, but Laval is only a pretext, a small symbol of the great questions involved in this strange contest of wills between the "old man of Vichy" and the "master of Europe."

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe of New York scored his sixth straight victory in the world three-cushion billiard tournament when he defeated Joe Moriarty of Chicago tonight, 50 to 30, in forty-four innings.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Charles Keough, daring Saranac Lake youth, won his first major bobsledding title today by driving his crew to victory in the National A.A.U. junior four-man event on the Mount Van Hoevenberg run.

After losing ground in the initial dealings last week, cotton prices turned firmer but failed to recover all of their earlier losses. On the New York Cotton Exchange, active future deliveries showed net declines on the week of 5 to 10 points.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Frequent interruptions by daylight air-raid warnings kept the volume of Stock Exchange transactions down almost to a minimum last week, but sentiment continued to reflect confidence. In any case, business doubtless would have remained at a low ebb, owing to the knowledge that, as time progresses, there must be many reminders of the additional tax burdens that the country must expect in order to finance its war effort.
SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Terrorists shot and killed Ching Wo-ting, reporter of the American-owned newspaper Shun Pao early today as he left a dance hall with a party of friends.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Golf's comeback kid with the candy-striped shirts today scored the biggest victory of his young career, winning the Western open tournament.

Drawing a parallel between the biblical encounter of Jacob and Esau and the English speaking nations today, the Rev.
