Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday that the living God is today dealing with an impractical generation, smug and complacent in its successes and forgetful of its spiritual base.

Mrs. Ellwood Beatty of Philadelphia, after winning a strenuous five-game encounter from Mrs. A.W. Paine in the first round, defaulted her second match when she was hit with a racquet as the tenth annual women's invitation squash racquets tournament got under way on the courts of the Junior League yesterday.

The preliminary annual statement of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and wholly owned subsidiaries issued yesterday for the 1940 calendar year disclosed a net income of $86,945,173 after depreciation, obsolescence, interest, Federal taxes and other deductions including a charge of $10,000,000 for special contingency reserve.
BOSTON, Feb. 3 -- Frank Leahy, who in two years coached the Boston College varsity football team to national fame, signed a new five-year contract today.
LONDON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following cammunique today:

A true detective story, with West Point cadets, a middle-aged woman postal clerk and implacable inspectors of the Postoffice Department in its cast, and strange scientific methods in its narrative, was revealed yesterday at the Federal Court House. The postal clerk, Miss Catherine Cox, 54 years old, was released under $500 bail on a charge of pilfering from the mails, a charge she stanchly denied.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 3 (AP) -- General Ion Antonescu's government issued a communique tonight naming as the "big three" of the recent Iron Guard rebellion Horia Sims, Vice Premier and Iron Guard party head; General George Petrovicescu, former Minister of the Interior, and Director of Gendarmes Ghica. M. Sima is still sought and the others are under arrest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Commerce Department figures issued today indicate increased exports of United States rubber products, farm implements an machinery and toys during December and an increase in United States imports of hides and skins during the whole year 1940.

The abhorrence Protestantism feels for "the debasing of human values" by hate generated by totalitarianism will be expressed at a dinner forum Feb. 25 at the Hotel Roosevelt under the auspices of the Protestant Digest Associates, it was announced yesterday by the Protestant Press Association.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- A large number of Italian prisoners were killed last Friday, the Admiralty announced today, when a British ship removing them from the Libyan coast of North Africa was attacked by planes "believed to have been German."
The fourth requisition period for selective service registrants opened yesterday with the third quota call, completed Friday, still short 1,330 men in the Second Corps Area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Litigation over the injunction temporarily restraining Governor Phillips of Oklahoma from using troops to stop the progress of work on the $20,000,000 Red River dam was dismissed by the Supreme Court today in an opinion by Justice Frankfurter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The constitutionality of the Federal Wage and Hour Law, last of the major New Deal statutes to face a legal challenge, was unanimously sustained by the Supreme Court today in an opinion affecting minimum wages for millions of workers.

Tito Schipa, who returned to New York's recital field at Carnegie Hall last night after an absence of several years, adheres to a tradition that was beloved of opera stars in days gone by. It is a tradition in which the singer is listed for a limited number of songs, but adds many encores.
CARRIZOZO, N. M., Feb. 3 -- The Three Rivers ranch of Albert B. Fall, former Secretary of the Interior, has been sold to a syndicate for conversion into a dude ranch.

The Italian retreat in Eritrea, which began as an orderly withdrawal from indefensible forward bases, now begins to foreshadow disaster. The swift British advance, marked but scarcely halted by the capture of Agordat, is already almost halfway to the Red Sea. If the defenses of Asmara, the capital, and Massawa, the chief port, collapse as easily, this oldest colony of Italy's African empire will soon be cut completely in two.

ATHENS, Feb. 3 -- During the day mopping-up operations continued throughout the district north of Klisura and it was officially stated tonight that a region of thirty-nine square miles is now in Greek possession, all resistance offered by the enemy having been silenced methodically by Greek artillery, which is reported to have been especially active.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- Despite charges by the Westchester County Childrens Association that the current investigation of relief in Westchester was a waste of taxpayers' funds, the county board of supervisors approved this afternoon the interim report of its special committee on welfare which criticized the handling of 35.1 per cent of the cases the committee had checked.
The American Foreign Investing Corporation reported yesterday that net assets on Dec. 31, last, were equivalent to $6.32 a share, compared with $6.89 on Dec. 31, 1939.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Five trade associations whose members are manufacturers and jobbers of a large share of the automobile parts and accessories sold in the United States have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease from carrying out agreements which prevent price competition and restrain trade.

A shiny new taxicab stood outside of French Hospital yesterday afternoon with a crowd of several hundred persons, including a number of policemen, gathered about it. At a few minutes after 2 o'clock they began to applaud as Leonard Weisberg, taxi driver who was wounded while trying to disarm a gunman who killed a policeman in the Fifth Avenue holdup on Jan. 14, emerged from the hospital to begin a new phase of his life.

The 258th Field Artillery, which traces its origin back to the "Washington Greys," formed in 1784, which acted as honor guard at Washington's inauguration in 1789, was mustered into Federal service yesterday at its armory, 29 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, by Lieut. Col. Clifford Tate, Regular Army instructor assigned to the unit.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- In a precedent-setting opinion that limits the authority of the National Labor Relations Board to the period in a company's relations with its employes up to and including the signing of a labor contract, the Third Federal Court of Appeals ruled here today that the board lacked the legal right to reinstate an employe dismissed in violation of a contract with a labor union.

The Americans and Rangers will resume their intracity rivalry in a National Hockey League engagement at Madison Square Garden tonight. In the five previous meetings for the William J. Macbeth Memorial Trophy the Americans won only once.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 3 -- The following editorial will appear tomorrow in The Newark Star-Leader: "The Star-Ledger naturally is pleased to have won a unanimous decision in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals against the National Labor Relations Board in the case of Agnes Fahy, but we regret that this matter had to be dragged through the courts.
Strikes were still in progress yesterday at six plants holding defense orders and Federal mediators renewed efforts for settlements, according to The United Press.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 3 -- The main interest on the Bourse today was centered on the new consolidation loan, which, with large dealings, was quoted at 97 3/4. This was considered fairly satisfactory in an otherwise steady bond market. Domestic shares were depressed, with trading dull and prices lower.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Senate today passed the bill appropriating $313,500,000 for construction of 200 cargo vessels, and sent it back to the House with an amendment modifying a stringent House provision against the employment of any person "who advocates, or belongs to any organization which advocates the duty, necessity, desirability or propriety of overthrowing the United States Government by force or violence."

The courage of nine nuns on the teaching staff of the Sacred Heart Parochial School, 379 North Burgher Street, West New Brighton, S.I., narrowly averted a panic in the schoolyard at 12:45 P.M. yesterday when a large dog, partly German Shepherd, ran amok, inflicting five bites on the leg of an 11-year-old girl and frightening 100 pupils playing in the yard during their lunch hour.

MORTON, Wash., Feb. 3 -- Two lumberjacks came out of the forests of this Southwestern Washington region today with word that they had discovered the wreckage of a twin-motored Army bomber, missing over two weeks, smashed and scattered against a rugged and inaccessible hillside.

William McC. Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, must submit to examination in connection with a suit brought by John E. Toolan and thirty-two others for recovery of more than $200,000 lost in stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation, Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin has ruled.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 3 -- Governor James submitted to the Legislature tonight a budget of $542,208,727 for the 1941-43 biennium with the remark that if it were not for inherited obligations "unduly imposed upon this Administration" he would be offering a tax reduction program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A nation-wide system of training within industry has now been established to supply skilled men for defense industries, Sidney Hillman, associate defense director, announced today.

MONTREAL, Feb. 3 -- A letter received in this country three days ago brings further evidence of the virtually unanimous feeling in occupied and in unoccupied France against the German conqueror. That letter comes from a man who always in the past was on good terms with Pierre Laval although he professed to be at variance with that politician over the whole range of domestic and international problems.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A clerk and a former clerk in the American Legation at Oslo, Norway, have been held by German authorities since early in December, on charges of possessing documents hostile to the Norwegian Government, State Department officials said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a Federal district court may impose court costs and an allowance for attorneys' fees against the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Christopher D. Sullivan, leader of Tammany Hall, yesterday summoned Democratic leaders of the Seventeenth Congressional District to meet with him on Wednesday afternoon to select a candidate for the seat made vacant by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson.

Sears, Roebuck Co. purchased from Domenico Zeni the one-story factory at 654-56 Henry Street, Union City, N.J., for $19,500, according to the stamps on the deed. The parcel was acquired for enlargement of its parking plot.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 3 (AP) -- William D. Griffith, president of the American Professional Football League, said tonight his circuit "objects to calling Elmer Layden commissioner of professional football."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 3 -- Bette Davis's next picture at Warners will be "The Widow of Devil's Island," recently purchased newspaper serial by Nichol Smith, the studio announced today. Aeneas Mackenzie has been assigned to prepare the scenario, and the new film will go before the cameras as soon as Miss Davis completes her current "The Bride Came C.O.D."
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The British Royal Air Force, Middle East Command, communique said today:

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (UP) -- The record of Elmer Layden as Notre Dame's football coach includes forty-seven victories, thirteen defeats and three ties. The university's football receipts in 1940 were almost twice as large as when he took command in 1933.

ARLINGTON, N.J., Feb. 3 -- Six structural steel workers were injured, one seriously, at the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydoek plant today when a steel girder dropped on them. The men, employes of the American Bridge Company of New York, were guiding the girder toward a steel truss atop a $200,000 extension of the plant's shipmolding loft when a jack supporting the girder gave way.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 -- The coronation scene from "Boris Godounov," with John Charles Thomas, guest artist, as Boris; scenes from the "Mikado" and an elaborate program of songs comprised "Behind the Scenes With the Romanies," the annual production of the Romany Chorus and Orchestra, tonight at the Paramount Theatre.
LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 4 -- London had a brief air raid "alert" just before midnight last night when a German plane flew over the capital.

The Little Theatre will reopen its doors this evening for the twice postponed premiere of "Tanyard Street," the play by Louis D'Alton, first called "The Spanish Soldier." Two years ago it was produced by the famous Abbey Theatre of Dublin.

Perplexed by the opposition's zone defense in the opening and closing minutes of the first half, Fordham's basketball team solved the problem after the intermission and proceeded to rout the Yale quintet, 62 -- 39, before 1,200 persons in the Rams' gymnasium last night.

Ethel Barrymore's fortieth anniversary as a featured player and star in the Broadway theatre will be observed tonight by a special broadcast over WJZ in which she and her two brothers, John and Lionel, will participate after her performance in "The Corn Is Green" at the National.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The United States shipped 221 airplanes to Great Britain in December and eighty-seven to Canada, according to the Commerce Department. These countries took 83 per cent of the $32,111,229 worth of aeronautic products exported in the month.

The zone defense was the central theme at yesterday's luncheon of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at the Hotel Lincoln. Ken Loeffler of Yale, one of the East's leading exponents of the zone, upheld the system, while Nat Holman of City College, representing the majority view, conducted the rebuttal.

OTTAWA, Feb. 3 -- The government tonight announced the revision of its military training plan. It has now lengthened compulsory military training in Canada from thirty days to four months. The same restriction still holds -- no person can be compelled to serve outside Canada.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The State Department commended today the plan of Panama to service its dollar bonds with the full amount of the increased annuity payable by the United States under the treaty of March 2, 1936, and with the income of the constitutional fund established in 1904.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 3 -- Leslie MacMitchell did it. The boy wonder from N.Y.U. beat both Walter Mehl and John Munski in the Reilly Mile that featured the Seton Hall track games before a gathering of 5,000 in the Jersey City armory tonight.

Officials of the Los Angeles Housing Authority sold yesterday to the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and others $3,850,000 of temporary loan notes at 0.46 per cent plus a premium of $22. The obligations will be payable on Feb. 3, 1942. Associated in the purchase were the Chase National Bank, the National City Bank, the Guaranty Trust Company, the Bankers Trust Company and the Manufacturers Trust Company.
MANCHESTER, England, Feb. 3 -- Wendell L. Willkie wound up his tour of various industrial centers in the English provinces today with visits in which he received tumultuous welcomes wherever he went.

With buyer attendance estimated as 12 to 15 per cent over the initial day last year, the National Notion and Novelty Exhibit opened yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Prices were firm, with few manufacturers quoting beyond April 1. Ninety exhibitors displayed some 200 lines ranging from wardrobe closets and accessories to knitting yarns.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3 -- Although he suffered some bad racing luck in the mile-and-a-sixteenth test, Haliopolis, the English 5-year-old that Elmer Dale Shatter purchased from Lord Derby, failed to cover himself with glory in the Naranja Purse at Hialeah Park today.

Richard Wright, author of "Native Son," is working on a non-fiction book dealing with Negro life in America. With Edwin Rosskam, formerly the editor of the Face of America series of word and picture books at Alliance, the author will do 30,000 words of text closely integrated with pictures in a style set by Mr. Rosskam in "Home Town," "As Long as the Grass Shall Grow" and other books.

OTTAWA, Feb. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Establishment of a four-month compulsory military training period in place of the present thirty days and complete reorganization of the training program to graduate 72,000 recruits a year was announced tonight by Prime Minister William Mackenzie King.

HAVANA, Tuesday, Feb. 4 -- President Fulgencio Batista at 11 o'clock last night took over command of Cuba's armed forces as Colonel Jose Pedraza, Chief of Staff of the Army and Acting Chief of the National Police and Lieut. Col. Angel A. Gonzalez, Chief of Staff of the Navy, resigned, according to an official note issued from the Presidential Palace.

Scholarships for the Spring session have been awarded to twenty-five students, eight of them women, in the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, it was announced yesterday by Dean Carl W. Ackerman. The awards, totaling $3,023, were made on the combined basis of academic standing and individual financial status.

First performance by a symphonic organization of the Mexican song, "Frenesi," brought back from Mexico by Attic Shaw, the clarinet virtuoso, whose swing band popularized the piece, is to be arranged for when Mr. Shaw arrives from Hollywood tonight to attend the Carnegie Hall annual concert of the National Symphony Orchestra, Washington D.C.'s resident symphony, under the baton of Dr. Hans Kindler.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Six saw, file and hand tool manufacturing corporations which did in 1939 almost a third of all such manufacturing in the United States, had in that year a net income on stockholders' equity after provision of income taxes of 8.1 per cent of the stockholders' investment, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Governor Lehman announced today that industries in the State engaging in defense work would be permitted to amortize the cost of expanding defense facilities over the next five years and to deduct such costs from State income taxes.

The Portrait Painters Clearing House, one of the departments of the 460 Park Avenue Gallery, is holding its second annual exhibition. These exhibitions are interrogatively phrased: "Who Will Paint Your Portrait?" As a matter of fact, work by the twenty-five members of this clearing house is continuously on view in a room set aside for that purpose at the Park Avenue establishment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Under-Secretary Robert P. Patterson, speaking for the War Department, declared today that "trivial" labor cases shall not be permitted to stop work on a defense contract or prevent award of one.

Last week the employers' associations and the unions in New York City's dress industry appeared to be deadlocked on the unions' proposal, made through the Dress Joint Board of the I.L.G.W.U., to put an "efficiency clause" into the new collective bargaining contract.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Yoshitsugu Tatekawa, Japanese Ambassador to Russia, has received instructions to resume conversations looking to a general Russian-Japanese trade agreement, it was reported today from Japanese sources.

A program to "defend democracy at home and abroad" by supporting immediate aid to Britain, Greece and China was disclosed yesterday by the administrative committee of the newly formed Student Defenders of Democracy, an organization headed by recent college graduates who believe that "democracy cannot be preserved like peaches, put in a jar and placed on the shelf."

The three articles on milk by Craig Thompson in this newspaper illustrate what happens under a typical bit of governmental "economic planning." At a time when one arm of the Federal Government is smashing at trusts and monopolies with unprecedented vigor, another arm establishes an iron-clad monopolistic control over the price that 60,000 farmers in six surrounding States receive for milk sold in the New York City area.

The New York Junior League Players tomorrow afternoon will launch a new series of four children's radio programs to be broadcast on Wednesdays of this month at 3:45 P.M. over Station WOR. "Hello, the Orgets!" is the title of the series, based on stories by Frances Fullerton Neilson, which are familiar to Junior League audiences through broadcasts of previous years.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 3 -- Forecasting the dissolution of Italy's African empire as the result of her present serious reverses in Libya, the Australian Prime Minister, Robert Menzies, today told the writer that any situation arising in the Pacific would not affect Australia's contribution to the imperial effort in the Middle East.
Last week the newspapers gave unwarranted publicity to my book "L'Italia Nel Passato E Nel Presente," conveying the impression that it had a favorable slant on fascism. May I correct that impression?

Bailey M. Sawyer, yachtsman and explorer, who had been serving as a pilot officer in the Royal Australian Air Force, was killed last Wednesday in a plane crash at a remote flying field at Parks, New South Wales, Australia, according to a cablegram received here yesterday by his sister, Mrs. Helen Sawyer Farnsworth.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 3 -- After moving around this State for the past ten days we are convinced that most of the Northern visitors never see the real Florida. Many of them never leave the beaten path, and the anglers who think the only places for sport are the much-publicized resort towns and cities along the East and West Coasts miss many fine opportunities.

Slaughtering and other activities were temporarily suspended at one of the larger local plants yesterday because of labor difficulties. Most classes of traefer meats continued to find a limited outlet. The veal and lamb markets were steady to strong, with some sales around $1 higher. Steer hinds and ribs were about steady.

SHAKESPEARE may not be better than sleep for most children, but, undoubtedly, he was for Aline Bernstein. Often her actor father would come into her room late at night, stirred by some newly learned lines of Shakespeare's, and recite them to his juvenile audience under the blankets.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Before the House debate began today, Speaker Rayburn predicted that there was a present majority of 100 to 125 votes for the lend-lease bill.

A.W. Paine, Harvard Club, defeated A.B. Sheridan, Bronxville Field Club, in a five-game match which featured the opening of play in the Metropolitan Squash Racquet Association's Class B singles championship at the Harvard Club yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Playing in old-time form, Willie Hoppe of New York tonight registered his seventh consecutive triumph in the world three-cushion billiard tournament.

One long workout and a vigorous, systematized calisthenics drill every day will be the schedule for the Dodgers when they swing into their training campaign at Havana, according to an outline of camp activities made yesterday by Manager Leo Durocher.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 3 (AP) -- One of the final steps leading to the selection of Elmer Leyden as commissioner of pro football occurred here Wednesday, where he had lived seven years before moving to South Bend for another seven-year stay.
The American Republics liner Brazil arrived yesterday from Buenos Aires via Rio de Janeiro with 246 passengers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The War Department announced today approval by the National Defense Commission of about $50,000,000 of contracts for additional facilities to manufacture aircraft and other military supplies.

Developments aimed at combining in single machines numerous operations, making possible the use of labor-saving devices in small as well as large offices, were featured yesterday at the opening of the Thirty-seventh Annual Business Show at Grand Central Palace.

THE ruler of the Reds in baseball is a mild man, an amiable gent. They call him "Deacon" McKechnie. He gives orders in Cincinnati and doesn't take any from Moscow. He just makes up his own as he goes along. And gets fair results.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Hog prices closed 10 to 15 cents higher today as country shipments declined in view of last week's downturn in prices. Top was $8.25 with choice 180 to 240-pound hogs bringing $7.95 to $8.20. Cattle in most classes were slow to 25 cents lower, while sheep were weak. Pork loin prices rose in sympathy with hogs, selling $15 to $16 per hundredweight, a full dollar above last week's low level.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- As a matter of Administrative convenience, the State Department announced today, block allotments of immigration quota numbers are being sent to American consular offices in Canada, Mexico and Cuba from the American Embassy in Berlin under the German and Polish quotas for allotment from these offices.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 29: An increase of $21,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, decreases of $60,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $47,000,000 in United States government deposits, and $110,000,000 in deposits-adjusted.

LONDON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A high Royal Air Force officer expressed the opinion today that the present forays by single Nazi raiders would persist until a break in the weather permitted a return to mass bombing.

Advertising in eight New York newspapers last month failed to reflect the upward business surge, registering a decline of 1.4 per cent from January, 1940, according to a compilation yesterday, based on Media Records figures. Two morning and one evening paper gained, while two morning and three evening papers showed losses.

Combined net earnings of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation for 1940 amounted to $15,705,222, compared with $15,715,169 in 1939, according to the annual report made available today. Last year's figure included the undistributed net earnings of the National Surety Corporation, a wholly owned but unconsolidated subsidiary.

MONTREAL, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A goal and an assist during the past week was enough to maintain Bill Cowley's five-point lead in the National Hockey League scoring race. The Boston center ran his point total to 39 -- ten goals and twenty-nine assists -- while Toronto's Syl Apps also made a goal and an assist for a 34-point total.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- With Justice James Clark McReynolds absent after more than twenty-six years of service, the bench of the Supreme Court presented a new picture today.

Several offers for refunding $29,692,000 of its bonds having been received, directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway are to meet in Richmond, Va., tomorrow to decide on what steps are to be taken at this time.

Tammany resentment over the loss of political patronage brought on the investigation of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, Paul J. Kern, president of the commission, charged yesterday in a talk before the Methodist Ministers Forum at 150 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The bill to increase the national debt limit from forty-nine to sixty-five billions of dollars was made the next order of business today as the House received information on defense expenditures thus far in the fiscal year and an estimate of further needed sums that will require Treasury borrowing far in excess of the present debt limit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, at his press conference today absolved Russia of any plans to attack the United States, as far as official information was concerned. He was commenting at his press conference on a press report from Mexico City of German plans for aggression in this hemisphere.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- The Army Quartermaster today awarded contracts for manila rope, slide fasteners and thread, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Opponents of the Administration's Lease-Lend Bill began assaults on the British-aid measure before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today with Philip La Follette, former Progressive Governor of Wisconsin, and Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader, leading off the attack.

Hitler's "new order" in Europe is another name for a now familiar process. It is the extension over a continent of the "coordination" we have seen operating in Germany. It is, in one word, simply the nazification of Europe -- the abolition of all laws but the Nazi law, of all currencies, economies and cultures but the Nazi system, of all gods but Hitler.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 3 -- As the closing in of British forces threatened to cut off their retreat, the Italians defending Barentu, in Eritrea, quietly evacuated the town yesterday and slipped out along an almost impassable mountain trail leading southeast toward Addi Ugri, on the north-south road to Asmara.

James Flaherty's lawyer failed to appear yesterday when Flaherty went on trial before Judge Thomas Downs and a jury in Queens County Court on a charge of having stolen five fifty-dollar bills from the pocket of Edward McKay of 145-16 Lakeview Avenue, Jamaica, in a Jamaica tavern last Nov. 13.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 3 -- Pledging the Republic Steel Corporation to forego price advances "so long as costs remain what they are," Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the board, said tonight that imposition of increased wages on the steel industry "would greatly increase the cost of national defense" as well as bring a threat of inflation.

Because the Radio City Music Hall is faced with a schedule of ten films awaiting exhibition, the management has decided to terminate the engagement of "The Philadelphia Story" upon the completion of its sixth week tomorrow night.

In a conveyance recorded yesterday title to the five-story building at 714 Fifth Avenue passed from the City Investing Company to Fareco, Inc., Fernand Tourtois, president, for an indicated consideration of $675,000. The property had been held by the seller since Dec. 8, 1927.

Selling agents for mills producing denims and herringbone twills expressed satisfaction yesterday with the Army's policy in permitting 180-day deliveries on orders for 20,000,000 yards of each of those types of fabrics, and predicted that, with some "pinching," they would be able to offer the quantities sought.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- With no objection from Governor Lehman, the Republican leaders decided tonight that the tenure of all emergency defense measures passed at the current session of the Legislature would be limited to April 1, 1942.

Osa Johnson, widow of Martin Johnson, African explorer who died in a plane crash near Hollywood four years ago, was married at City Hall yesterday to her manager, Clark Hallan Getts, by Mayor La Guardia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that she would neither address nor attend the coming sessions here of the American Youth Congress.

A committee of women of society headed by Mrs. Marshall Prentiss has arranged a bundle tea for next Monday at the home of Mrs. Roland L. Redmond, 760 Park Avenue, for the benefit of the Bargain Box, a permanent thrift shop at Third Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street, maintained for several charitable organizations.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 4 -- The reporting of a run on a bank or a rice riot will be a criminal offense under Japan's proposed new national-defense and security law, but correspondents may lawfully report that "rice distribution is not functioning properly."
Textile and apparel firms figured largely in the business leasing yesterday, when a number of the lessees took full-floor units in midtown buildings.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Feb. 3 -- A record crowd of skiers used the ski slopes and trails in the Berkshires the past week-end, it was revealed today by Frank Couch, executive secretary of the Berkshire Hills Conference. Favored with superb snow conditions and accessible to the metropolitan area, the Berkshires attracted a grand total of 15,850 enthusiasts, exceeding the previous record of 11,000 set up in 1938.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 3 (UP) -- An estimated half of Premier Mussolini's East African Army -- about 100,000 men -- was said today to face entrapment in Eritrea, while other Italian forces were reported in retreat from Western Ethiopia and from Ethiopia's southern frontier with Kenya.

The vacant plot comprising six and one-quarter lots at the southwest corner of Grand Avenue and West 174th Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by a client of Jacob Emil Leitner, brokers, and will be improved with a $390,000 six-story apartment house, containing 210 rooms.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Increases of from 10 to 20 per cent in buyer attendance at the dry goods houses, and even larger percentage gains at some of the specialty events featured the opening of the second of the three Spring market weeks here today.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Tuesday, Feb. 4 (UP) -- The United States liner Manhattan, which went aground on a sandbar off here on Jan. 12, was floated late last night and preliminary inspection early today disclosed that the vessel could not make port under her own power.

The HOLC sold the seven-room dwelling on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 109-22 142d Street, Jamaica, L.I., to Joseph Nuss through the Bulkley Horton Company and Felice Di Palma, co-brokers; and the two-family dwelling on a plot 25 by 131 feet at 31-54 Forty-fifth Street, Long Island City, to Isidor Brustein through Wm. A. Krahe Son, Inc., and L.E. Rosenberg, co-brokers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, described as "a ridiculous bluff" today the statement of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, to the effect that the A.F. of L. has organized a majority of employes of the Ford Motor Company Rouge and Lincoln plants.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Shortly after State's Attorney Lorin W. Willis announced he would not appeal a jury verdict, Joseph Spell walked out of Fairfield County jail today, freed of charges that he had criminally attacked his Greenwich employer, Mrs. John K. Strubing Jr.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Argentina is studying application of an ancient Roman rule of international law to requisition idle shipping in her posts to speed delivery of foodstuffs to Britain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision holding constitutional New York Legislation ordering the permanent cancellation of automobile drivers' licenses unless insurance is taken out after one accident in which a court found a driver at fault and gave judgment against him.

Further alarming statements regarding the expected Nazi attempt to invade Great Britain soon, as testimony on the Lease-Lend Bill drags along in Congress, again brought out yesterday new liquidation of securities, and the share list slumped to the lowest levels of the current reaction.

The Spring term of the city's public school system started smoothly yesterday with an estimated enrollment of 1,025,350. The registration showed a decrease in every division except vocational training. The term will end on June 27.

VICHY, France, Feb. 3 -- The establishment of a special national contribution ranging from 5 to 15 per cent of all income taxes is the principal innovation in a complete revision of the system of direct taxation in France, announced today.

An acrimonious debate about the merits of the Rapp-Coudert investigation of the schools, which threatened to throw the gathering into disorder, featured last night's meeting of the delegate assembly of the United Parents Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Six hundred persons attended.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The text of the majority opinion of the Supreme Court in the case against officials of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, who were charged with violation of the anti-trust laws, was as follows:

Henry H. Simmen, president of the Rotary Club of New York, presented Red Cross swimming buttons to twelve crippled children yesterday at the Evangeline Residence swimming pool of the Salvation Army, 123 West Thirteenth Street.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 3 -- Colonel William J. Donovan, observer for the United States, left Ankara for Jerusalem tonight. The United States Ambassador, John Van A. MacMurray, and members of the embassy staff as well as representatives of the Turkish Foreign Office saw him off at the station.

Seven ferryboat passengers, all men, suffered cuts, bruises or sprains, and hundreds of commuters were shaken in a collision between the ferryboats Bound Brook and Lakewood of the Central Railroad of New Jersey at 9:10 A.M. yesterday about 100 feet from the Liberty Street slip here.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 4 (UP) -- Japan will not abandon her program for economic penetration of the Netherlands Indies as a result of British and American pressure, but wishes it to be understood that her ambitions there are economic and not political, Naoki Hoshino, Minister without portfolio and president of the government's Planning Board, told the Budget Committee of the lower house of Parliament yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- State pharmaceutical associations, actively supported by the National Association of Retail Druggists, are planning a drive to place fair trade laws on the statute books of the only four States without them, Theodore O. Christianson, public relations counsel for the drug group, said here today.

PARIS, Jan. 30 (delayed; via Berlin) -- Editorial writers of the Paris press yesterday assumed the task of demonstrating that France had only a few days to make her final decision for or against loyal "collaboration" with Germany. Today the press treats this subject in much the same manner, concluding that "collaboration" is impossible without a radical housecleaning at Vichy to make way for the return of Pierre Laval as Foreign Minister.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 3 -- The Forty-fourth Division will have its mid-term examinations this week. Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, commanding officer, and his staff will conduct a full field inspection of the division starting Thursday, to determine how well the units of this federalized National Guard outfit from New York and New Jersey have learned the lessons taught in the first thirteen weeks of the mobilization training program.

Garden City moved into a first-place tie with Central in the men's Class A division of the Metropolitan Badminton Association tournament by defeating Old Sixty-ninth, 5 -- 0, according to results announced yesterday. Jack Laimbeer and James Ogsbury were the big guns in the Garden City sweep, each accounting for a single victory and then pairing with team-mates to prevail in doubles.
ROME, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Italian armies strung out over war fronts hundreds of miles apart fought tonight to hold back British forces seeking to deflate Premier Mussolini's relatively new empire.

Insertion of a dozen words in one rule of the Securities and Exchange Commission would allow the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange to set up machinery to handle on their floors the large secondary distributions which now have to be made over the counter.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 -- Miss Elizabeth Hicks of Pasadena, Calif., started defense of her Palm Beach women's championship today by winning the medal in the qualifying round with a card of 39, 37 -- 76, four over women's par. She equaled par on the second nine holes.

Promulgation of a rule of compulsory competitive bidding for the new issues of registered public utility holding companies and their subsidiaries, as recommended by the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, would be a definite backward step in American banking, Burnett Walker, a partner in Smith, Barney Co., investment banking firm, declared in a recent letter to Jerome N. Frank, chairman of the SEC.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Senate ratified by a voice vote today a treaty by which fourteen Latin-American nations agree to apportion among themselves their exports of coffee to the United States market. The total to be apportioned amounts to 15,900,000 bags yearly.

The full board of directors of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers plans to go to Washington today to confer with officials of the Department of Justice on the possibility of concluding a consent decree in the government's anti-trust suit against the society.

The trial of Hymie Caplin, prize fight manager, and seven others accused of operating a card sharp ring that allegedly defrauded its victims of $4,000,000 in ten years, started yesterday in Kings County Court. The day was taken up in selecting three jurors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Retail costs of food increased in the period Dec. 17 to Jan. 14, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The agency's index, based on the 1935-39 average as 100, stood at 97.8 for the January compilation, compared with 97.3 in December, and 94.8 on Jan. 16, 1940.

C.T. Jaffray, president of the First Bank Stock Corporation of Minneapolis, in the twelfth annual report, mailed yesterday to Stockholders in advance of the annual meeting to be held on Feb. 11, said net operating earnings of the corporation and its affiliated banks and active companies for 1940 amounted to $2,979,090.

Canadian business conditions in 1940 were profoundly affected by war conditions, but the transformation to war economy was effected without undue dislocation and barometers of business activity practically all recorded expansion during the year, the Royal Bank of Canada stated yesterday in its review of Dominion business during the year.

The enlistment of Wendell Grove in the Army, as reported by The Associated Press from St. Paul, Minn., is one of those arresting minor incidents that repay scrutiny from several angles. Wendell at 26 is, to begin with, a baritone horn player. Upon reading that the Third Infantry band at Fort Snelling needed a man like him, Wendell went to the recruiting office but was told, "Nothing doing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Supreme Court, by a five-to-two decision, today held that disputes between labor unions do not come within the purview of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

Price-cutting among retail grocers has veered from advertised brands to private-label goods in the last three weeks. The change has created consternation among many smaller chains, super-markets and individual stores through the country, food leaders said yesterday, but has brought a longed-for "breathing spell" to manufacturers of nationally known brands of groceries.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Horse racing in New Orleans was saved again today. The rescuers barely got under the wire, though, for the option they held was to have expired today and the seventy-year-old Fair Grounds would have become a real estate subdivision.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Prices of wheat fluctuated in a range of about 1 cent a bushel and closed at the bottom with losses of 3/8 to 1/2 cent. It was the eighth consecutive day of declining prices on the Board of Trade here. Scattered liquidation developed after short covering and buying by mills and cash interests had resulted in a moderate advance in the early trading.

Maxie Berger, 143 3/4 pounds, the Bronx, outpointed Bob McIntyre, 139 1/2, Detroit, in the feature bout of eight rounds at St. Nicholas Palace last night. A crowd of 3,500 attended. McIntyre substituted for Aldo Spoldi, Italian lightweight, who was confined to his bed with a touch of influenza.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Establishment by the War Department of a board of civilian physicians to investigate influenza and other epidemic diseases in the Army was reported today by The Journal of the American Medical Association.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., Feb. 3 -- Thousands of natives witnessed today the inaugural ceremony, at which Charles Harwood of New York was inducted as Governor of the Virgin Islands. The oath of office was administered by Federal Judge Herman Moore.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Eleanor Strubing, socially prominent Greenwich (Conn.) woman whose Negro butler was acquitted last week of charges that he attacked her, said today "the verdict leaves the women of America at the mercy of any one who may seek their ruin."

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The stock markets were cheered today by the news from Eritrea, although the actual turnover was not reflected by this feeling. Gilt-edge issues were quiet. Securities continue slow in responding to the persistent accumulation of surplus funds.

BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- Whatever forms the future economic organization of Europe might assume in case of a final German victory, Berlin official circles stress that intensification of intra-European trade and its gravitation toward the Axis powers, notably Germany, are concrete facts, daily acquiring greater momentum and realizing Reichsfuehrer Hitler's promise, made in last Thursday's anniversary address, that "the year 1941 will see the establishment of a new European order."

While I am very conscious of the multitude of demands on the generosity of Americans for aid in some form for the distressed peoples of Great Britain and Europe in general, I have just received a letter dated Dec. 12 from Sir Herbert J. Haddock, one time master of the Olympic and former commodore of the White Star fleet, which I would like to quote:

Plans were filed yesterday for an apartment house to be erected on West Fifty-seventh Street, Manhattan, at a cost of $150,000, and another costing $270,000 to occupy a site on the northwest corner of 172d Street and Townsend Avenue, the Bronx.
VICHY, France, Feb. 3 -- Pierre Laval will probably be back in Vichy tomorrow, coming from Paris in company with Admiral Jean Darlan, representing Marshal Henri Philippe Petain.

Efforts by the State Mediation Board to end the strike in fifty-three Whelan drug stores failed yesterday when officials of the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation declined to meet with representatives of Local 1199 of the Retail Drug Store Employes Union.

The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company has called for redemption on March 5, at 102, all of its outstanding first mortgage and first lien, 4 per cent bonds, Series A, due on March 1, 1962. Payment will be made at the City Bank Farmers Trust Company.

BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- Developments of the last seventy-two hours, as viewed from the Reich's capital tonight, suggest that Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and the Vichy government of militarily defeated France will in the immediate future be confronted with the necessity of deciding whether or not they wish to cooperate fully with Germany.

TRENTON, Feb. 3 -- Adoption by the Senate of a resolution urging Congress to enact the lease-lend bill and confirmation of Frederic R. Colie of Newark as a member of the Supreme Court was the principal business transacted by the Legislature in a brief session tonight.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 3 -- Guy J. Swope of Harrisburg, Pa., formerly auditor for the island, took office as Governor today, asserting that the gigantic world struggle going on between two widely different political philosophies was particularly important to Puerto Rico because "by geographic position we stand as a sentry post to maintain and protect the democratic way of life in the Western Hemisphere."

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Twelve hundred members and guests of the Advertising Men's Post of the American Legion were divided in applause today at a debate between former Senator Ernest W. Gibson of Vermont, chairman of the Committee to Defend America By Aiding the Allies, and Brig. Gen. Robert E. Wood, retired, chairman of the America First Committee.

Western Union and Postal Telegraph had their own music troubles yesterday, though they were unrelated to the row over tunes heard on the radio. Since Saturday the companies have discontinued use of "Happy Birthday to You" in their "singing telegrams" and have offered a choice between "Yankee Doodle" or "Mary Had a Little Lamb," both in the public domain.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 3 -Dean 2muel W. Dudley of the ,Yal, School of Engineering announced tonight that, in response to increasing undergraduate interest in chemical engineering, as evidenced by the doubling of student enrollment in the past decade and to demands of the rapidly expanding chemical industries, Yale is seeking $1,200,000 for its work in chemical engineering.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 3 -Dean 2muel W. Dudley of the ,Yal, School of Engineering announced tonight that, in response to increasing undergraduate interest in chemical engineering, as evidenced by the doubling of student enrollment in the past decade and to demands of the rapidly expanding chemical industries, Yale is seeking $1,200,000 for its work in chemical engineering.

The Hotel and Restaurant Employes International Alliance, A.F. of L. parent body of fourteen culinary unions in this city with a total membership of 50,000, yesterday suspended all normal functions of the Joint Executive Board of these unions and ordered an investigation of the conflict between alleged Communist and anti-Communist factions represented on the board.

Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Pell gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Her guests were Mrs. Albert Gould Jennings, Mrs. C. Whitney Carpenter, Mrs. Reginald T. Townsend, Mrs. M. Taylor Pyne, Mrs. Jorge R. Andre and Mrs. Robert C. Rand.

Billy Soose, Farrell, Pa., middleweight, who is to meet Ernie Vigh, Newburgh ring favorite, in the feature bout of ten rounds Friday night at Madison Square Garden, arrived in this city last night from Lake Wallenpauk, Pa., prepared to put the finishing touches to his training within the jurisdiction of the State Athletic Commission, as required by the board's rules.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Roosevelt's Lease-Lend Bill for aid to Britain and her allies was started on its legislative journey through the House today with a warning sounded by its proponents that even now Germany and Italy are putting every possible pressure on Japan to start aggressive action against the United States.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that member-firm borrowings at the close of business on Jan. 31 amounted to $413,072,134. No comparison is given because of substantial changes in the scope of the compilation, but since the new method is far more inclusive than the old, a fairly large decline is indicated for January.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 7 per cent for the week ended Feb. 1, in comparison with the like week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the week ended Jan. 25 the bank had reported a gain of 9 per cent.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Feb. 3 -- Horace C. Sylvester Jr., senior vice president and director of Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., investment house, of 63 Wall Street, New York City, was found dead at his home here today. Authorities said Mr. Sylvester, who had been in poor health for a year, had killed himself with a shotgun.

The Citizens Union raises a timely voice against three bills pending at Albany which, as it believes, would impair civil liberties. Two, by Senator Dunnigan, would, in the Union's opinion, "exclude from public offices any one who signs a Communist nominating petition unless he could prove that the presumption of disloyalty created by his signing was false."

By an odd coincidence there appeared in one of your editorials an error of scientific fact regarding the oldest living thing on the same morning that a letter reached me from far-off Australia calling attention to a similar error which I had made in my book, "You and Heredity," and clearing up the mystery of how we both were victimized.

Bob Simmons, the Nebraskan, who is one of America's leading quarter-milers, yesterday became the first entrant for the Buermeyer 500, one of the feature races at the New York A.C. meet at Madison Square Garden a week from Saturday. Paul Pilgrim, in making the announcement, said that the Cornhusker also would run in the 600-yard event at the National A.A.U. championships on Feb. 22.

SPALATO, Yugoslavia, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A concerted British-Greek submarine campaign against Italian military supply routes deep in the Adriatic Sea was indicated today by reports that seven Italian vessels had been sunk recently.

In its ninety-sixth annual report the Prison Association of New York returns to the most familiar and most difficult problem in criminology: how to combine the punishment which society demands for lawless acts with the reform of the criminal. Manifestly, if we cannot reform a first offender we have even less chance with second or third offenders.

Erwin Rudolph and Andrew Ponzi broke even in two world pocket billiard tournament matches at Julian's Academy yesterday. In the afternoon Rudolph prevailed, 125 -- 80, in twelve innings. Last night Ponzi finished on top, 125 -- 47, in five frames. Rudolph had clusters of 75 and 44, while his rival bunched 71 and 85.

A volume announced by Everyman's Library for early Summer publication stands No. 967 on the list. When the project was begun in 1906 the founders had a collection of a thousand volumes in mind. Moving at the rate of very nearly thirty volumes a year, which is the average up to date, it is evident that the original program ought to be realized some time next year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Sympathy for the Regional Conference of the River Plate, in session in Montevideo, was expressed today by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, in response to questions at a press conference.

The excerpts from Hitler's most recent speech you published in your issue of Jan. 31 contained a singular passage about "a wonderful softening of the brain in these democracies." Hitler mentions Vossische Zeitung, once the leading democratic and republican German newspaper, the oldest in Berlin, founded in 1704.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Roosevelt conferred separately with Senator Truman, Governor Adkins of Arkansas, James H.R. Cromwell and Bernard Baruch.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis signed today for the third defense of his title in two months and found the quality of the latest opposition so amusing he laughed right out loud.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The War Department estimated today that the expanding Army, already the largest in the country's peacetime history, would reach a total of 1,418,000 officers and men by June I5, or nearly twice the fores now under arms.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Elmer Layden resigned today as head football coach and athletic director at Notre Dame to accept a five-year contract as Commissioner of Professional Football.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange reacted yesterday after advancing 3 to 4 points above Saturday's close in early trading, and final quotations were up 1 point to off 3 points. The only gain for the session was in the March position. The May closed unchanged.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 3 -- There is a strong inclination in informed quarters here to regard Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's most recent move in the struggle for France's future as a strategic withdrawal "to prepared positions," there to make a last stand for those principles he considers honorable, even for the vanquished.

Charles (Chuck) Leighton, Minneapolis Silver Skates winner, shot out from the pack to take the two-mile intercity Silver Skates championship before a cheering throng in Madison Square Garden last night. The 22-year-old brewer covered the distance in 7:37.4.

Hundreds of Italian troops have ceased fighting against Greek forces in Albania, crossed into Yugoslavia and jubiliantly submitted to internment, Richard Elias, 43 years old, a United States citizen, reported yesterday when he arrived here from Lisbon on the American Export liner Exeter.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 3 -- The delegates to the Regional Conference of the River Plate spent today wrestling with a serious deadlock that has arisen over Bolivia's demand that she receive unrestricted liberty of transit to move immigrants, merchandise and "material of all descriptions" across the territories of the countries participating in the conference.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- British trade returns for 1940 present a clear reflection of the effect of the war on business. Imports increased nearly 25 per cent. An examination of the returns from the commodity angle is rendered difficult because of the suppression of figures, quantities and countries.

Yesterday material from the vast collection formed by William Randolph Hearst was placed on public view at Gimbels, where it occupies the entire fifth floor. At the same time additional objects were brought to the attention of the public on the third floor at Saks Fifth Avenue.
Harry Gross has rejoined Newman Brothers Worms, members of the New York Stock Exchange.

Prizes for photographs of garden subjects were awarded in four classes yesterday at the second annual photographic contest of the Horticultural Society of New York at 598 Madison Avenue. Pictures in the contest, which was open only to members, will be on exhibition from today through Feb. 14.

The excerpts from Hitler's most recent speech you published in your issue of Jan. 31 contained a singular passage about "a wonderful softening of the brain in these democracies." Hitler mentions Vossische Zeitung, once the leading democratic and republican German newspaper, the oldest in Berlin, founded in 1704.
Harry Gross has rejoined Newman Brothers Worms, members of the New York Stock Exchange.

Prizes for photographs of garden subjects were awarded in four classes yesterday at the second annual photographic contest of the Horticultural Society of New York at 598 Madison Avenue. Pictures in the contest, which was open only to members, will be on exhibition from today through Feb. 14.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins scored twice during the first 65 seconds of overtime to extend their string of undefeated National Hockey League games to sixteen straight tonight by topping Montreal's aggressive Canadiens, 5 to 3, before 11,000 at the Boston Garden.

The Hotel Association of New York City has been trying since last Spring to induce the Federal Government to establish branch offices of some of its defense agencies in this city, it became known yesterday.

For the first time in the history of the New York City school system, elementary school children will be excused one hour early from their classes today to attend courses in religious education conducted outside the classroom by leaders of the Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths.

Firmer tendencies were displayed yesterday by the general share list, but continued pressure against the higher-priced stocks pushed them back to the lows of the present weak movement. The many probabilities in the international situation still prevented the market from getting any support from idle funds, and transfers on the Stock Exchange were reduced further to 352,740 shares, a total which hardly could show any conclusive trend, against Monday's dealings of 491,165 shares.

A British War Relief Society campaign to raise $5,000,000 in this country, entirely distinct from both the society's general program and the $5,000,000 drive of its commerce and industry divislon, was opened yesterday under the direction of Mrs. William Armour.

Gene Tunney, leading sponsor of the National Foundation for American Youth, declared yesterday he was delighted with the "fine, patriotic thing" Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt had done in announcing that she would neither address nor attend the "Town Meeting of Youth" to be held by the American Youth Congress in Washington Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Donald M. Nelson, purchasing chief of the Office of Production Management, who has indicated a desire to return soon to private business, will probably remain until May 1, it was reported today after he had called on President Roosevelt.
LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 5 -- Just before dawn yesterday the Coastal Command made the British Air Force's thirty-fifth raid on Brest, Nazi-occupied sea base in France.

Dr. and Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell gave a dinner last night at their home, 161 East Sixty-fourth Street, and afterward took their guests to the benefit performance of "Mr. and Mrs. North" at the l!elasco Theatre. The theatre party was under the auspices of the wemen's auxiliary of the Union Settlement.

THE opinion seems to be practically unanimous that the magnates of the National Football League couldn't have picked a better man than Elmer Layden, the Thin man from Notre Dame, to handle their growing affairs. Just at the moment, that title of Commissioner is a trifle wide for the limited territory he has under control, but it may fit in time.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 -Isaac Lincoln !_errill Jr. of Cam-I den, Me., won qualifying honors in the twenty-third annual OrmondI Beach golf championship today with t a 40, 35 -- 75. Merrill, winner of this I title in 1934 and 1936, runner-up ins 1935 and medalist in 1937 and 1938, I started poorly but played the lncoming nine in one over regulation figures, carding two birdies.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 4 -- The Forty-fourth Division is organizing classes in English for foreigners. There are thirty-five men in the division, officers have discovered, who understand "forward march," "halt," "fall in," and routine military commands, but who smile and shrug a shoulder if a question is directly addressed to them.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Princeton's football team will adopt the new system of numbering football players according to position starting next Fall, according to an announcement today by Head Coach Elton E. (Tad) Wieman. Juniors and seniors on the 1941 eleven will, if they so desire, retain the numbers assigned to them in the past, but sophomores and all other new men will be numbered according to the revised system.

DUBLIN, Feb. 4 -- After his talk with Premier Eamon de Valera today Wendell L. Willkie was asked, "Did you discuss with Mr. de Valera Eire's position should America enter the war?" He replied emphatically, "No, I did not discuss that with him.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Edwin F. Jaeckle, Republican State Chairman, presented to a dinner of party members and leaders tonight the Republican viewpoint on government in the State, using language which left no doubt that he was replying to Governor Lehman's budget message and his message on the state of affairs in New York, at least as far as social legislation was concerned.

JUPITER, Fla., Feb. 4 -- Behind Jupiter, miles from the crowded traffic of the coastal highway, stretching to and beyond Okeechobee, lie thousands of acres of palmetto flats that are cut in weird patterns by natural ditches and dotted by shallow ponds and cypress swamps.

An offering of $11,408,000 of Monongahela Railway first 3 1/4 per cent Series B bonds due in 1966 is to be made today by a syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and Kuhn, Loeb Co. The sale price is 102 1/2. The company is controlled by the Pittsburgh Lake Erie, a subsidiary of the New York Central Railroad, the Baltimore Ohio Railroad and the Pennsylvania Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- General Robert E. Wood, chairman of the board of Sears, Roebuck Co. and acting chairman of the America First Committee, expressed the opinion to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that there was "a possibility" that the United States would be "actively involved in the war in the next ninety days" if the Administration lease-lend bill, on which the committee is holding hearings, should be enacted.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The right of a member of Jehovah's Witnesses to sell religious literature at Forty-fourth Street and Broadway was appealed to the Supreme Court today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 -- Lana Turner was named by Metro to replace Laraine Day in "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" with Spencer Tracy and Ingrid Bergman. Miss Day will be needed for retakes for the Wallace Beery picture, "Badman," after which she will be assigned to another film.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 4 -- The long-expected crisis in the Cabinet came today with the resignation of Ivan Bagrianoff from the Ministry of Agriculture, but it is impossible to say yet whether this will lead to a country-wide split between partisans of this pro-German statesman and those of the present government.

Only those who ignore the vital importance of industrial power in modern warfare will wonder why British planes flying over Sardinia launched their torpedoes on the great Tirso dam, deep in the interior of the island, instead of on the harbor works of Cagliari and the naval units which may be sheltered there.

Thomas Jefferson High School's basketball team recorded its fifth straight victory in Section 1, Brooklyn Division, of the P.S.A.L. yesterday, but had to achieve the triumph in a 3-minute overtime period, 38 -- 36, against Brooklyn Tech on the latter's court.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Prices of wheat fluctuated today in an erratic manner within a range of about 1 1/4 cents a bushel. They advanced early only to break rapidly later on selling induced by reports that the Commodity Credit Corp had sold 1,250,000 bushels of Spring wheat in the Northwest recently.

When 7,500 Hunter College students register for the Spring semester this morning at 10:30, all except the entering freshmen will be asked to act as their own "executioners," if they do not meet the college's academic standards, by withdrawing voluntarily from school.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 5 -- A rupture of diplomatic relations between Japan and the United States must be prevented if humanly possible, said Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka in concluding another explanation of his policy toward the United States in the House last night.

Yesterday's report from London that the Royal Air Force doubts the imminence of a German invasion attempt may not be authoritative, but it seems to accord with the realities of the weather at this time of year.

Representatives of Protestant, Catholic and Jewish groups incorporated a joint agency yesterday to coordinate and finance a national program for providing religious, recreational and welfare services to soldiers, sailors and young employes in defense industries.

George W. Alger and Albert W. Putnam, New York lawyers, have been appointed members of the motion picture industry's national arbitration appeals board by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard, who signed the consent decree settlement of the government's anti-trust actions against five of the eight major film companies last Nov. 20.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 -- Most of the favorites found easy going in first-round matches of the annual Palm Beach women's golf championship today at the Palm Beach Golf Club.

The Norsemen S. C., pioneer ski organization in the East, whose color-bearers have won recognition throughout this nation and in Norway since 1921, will celebrate its twentieth anniversary on Sunday with the holding of its annual invitation jump at Salisbury Mills, N. Y. Towering Norsemen Hill, one of the most beautiful natural slides in North America, will be the scene of what promises to be a thrilling event.

Nothing about "Tanyard Street" is more miraculous than the fact that Barry Fitzgerald is in it. As Louis D'Alton's drama develops at the Little Theatre, where it opened last evening, you realize that the author is primarily interested in the religious aspects of a healing.
The New York Rangers held their city rivals, the Americans, to a 2-all tie in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
Since my article in the current issue of Harper's, "The German Financial Revolution," supplied the direct quotations used in your Jan. 30 editorial, "Hitler as Wizard," I feel free to comment.

In announcing that industries engaged in defense work will be permitted to amortize over a five-year period for income-tax purposes the cost of new plants constructed for defense work, Governor Lehman has taken an effective step to speed up national defense.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 4 -- While Italian troops in Libya continued to retreat westward to the region of Maraua, British forward units yesterday entered Cirene, on the coast road between Derna and Bengazi, isolating the important Libyan airport and seaplane base at Apollonia and establishing the front roughly forty-five miles west of Derna, which fell five days ago.
Completing her maiden world cruise, the trim, gray American President liner President Jackson arrived at the Eighth Street pier in Hoboken yesterday with seventy-three passengers.

Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, former Health Commissioner of New York, was elected president of the Associated Health Foundation, a nonprofit medical service corporation, at its second annual luncheon board meeting yesterday held at the National Democratic Club, 233 Madison Avenue.
Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly lower yesterday in quiet trading and closed near the day's lows at net declines of 3 to 7 points.

The volume of sales of sheets at January clearance sales was so large than many stores have begun to press mills for deliveries on existing contracts and virtually no cancellations have come in, selling agents reported yesterday. This is in distinct contrast with the usual experience, when stores have entered February with stocks large in relation to their expected February-March volume.
LONDON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- Great Britain today recognized Emperor Haile Selassie as the rightful ruler of Ethiopia.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,590,150 barrels daily, a decrease of 8,950 from the previous week's average of 3,599,100 barrels a day, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production, however, was only 850 barrels less than the estimated requirements of 3,591,000 daily for February as calculated by the Bureau of Mines.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Roosevelt and Senator Wheeler of Montana engaged in another exchange of hostile remarks today.

In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES James P. Warburg pleads for the extension of federal principles by sovereign peoples. He bases that plea on a growing common sense of justice and on the conviction that "on the whole, Western man had until recent times advanced fairly steadily toward the development of an order in which the resort to violence became constantly less necessary."
Bishop William T. Manning told 500 members and guests of the Church Club of New York last night that "we cannot be neutral in this conflict without the loss of our moral ideals and of our souls."

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- New York exhibitors in the Chicago wholesale market events are obtaining a generous share of this week's record-breaking business, investigation showed today. At the headquarters of the Style Exhibitors, Inc., Jack Solomon, executive secretary, predicted attendance and sales would break all records.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 4 -- The Bulgarian Cabinet crisis brought about by the sudden resignation of Minister of Agriculture Ivan Bagrianoff is seen in political circles here as clearly making that country one of the vital factors in the development of the war in the Spring.

The concert given by the Washington Symphony Orchestra, Hans Kindler conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall revealed an orchestra of excellent qualities, a conductor of abilities not fully unfolded and an infant phenomenon violinist, very talented, necessarily immature, who should not have been presented on this occasion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Almost $150,000,000 worth of gold transported to this country from South Africa on the United States cruiser Louisville contributed to lift gold imports last week to $166,115,127 -- the largest total for any week since June last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- The British Empire's merchant marine as of Dec. 31 was 261,965 tons greater than its pre-war tonnage, Representative Bartel J. Jonkman of Michigan revealed today in figures taken from a report by Admiral Harold R. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- In a move which may seriously affect Soviet Russia's huge oil-expansion program, President Roosevelt put oil drilling and refining equipment under the export license control system today.

Although the Department of Commerce does not report the disposition of incoming gold, beyond indicating increases in the stock of the metal set aside here under earmark for foreign account, there is evidence that the $150,000,000 recently received from South Africa is held by the Treasury's Stabilization Fund.

Erin O'Brien-Moore, stage and screen actress, wife of Mark Barton, drama editor of The Associated Press, was the principal witness yesterday at the opening before Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck and a jury of the trial of her suit for $50,000 damages for injuries received when her dress caught fire on Jan. 22, 1939, in Lyons Chop House, 102 West Fiftieth Street.

The combined exhibitions arranged, as in past years, by the American Water Color Society and the New York Water Color Club, has been installed in the three main galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.
ROME, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Seven hits on a strongly escorted British convoy in the Red Sea last night by a squadron of Italian torpedo boats were reported today by the High Command.

Schuyler N. Dalton, a former member of the sales department of the Sylvania Industrial Corporation, was found dead in his room at the Yale Club early yesterday morning, his body was hanging by a heavy cord from the bathroom door. The police said that Mr. Dalton, who was 49 years old, had left six notes.

Yussel Goldstein, 153 3/4, Brownsville, continued his string of victories by beating Frankie Britt, 151 1/2, Fall River, Mass., in the feature eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena last night before 4,500 spectators.

David Nadien, a New Yorker by birth, who gave his first New York recital at Town Hall last night, is a mite of a violinist. He is not much more than four feet high and, in a dark, double-breasted, long-trousered suit, he looks even slighter than he is.

Mel Trutt, the former Indiana star who is now teaching school at Des Moines, Iowa, will attempt to bring to an end the long list of two-mile victories amassed by Greg Rice when he starts in the Tous-saint Cup event in the annual New York Athletic Club meet at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 15, it was disclosed yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- W. Kingsland Macy, Republican chairman of Suffolk County, was nominated as a Regent of the University of the State of New York today, in both houses of the Legislature, after a row within the Republican ranks over the selection.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- There is one important possible consequence of the President's Lease-Lend Bill, if passed, which thus far has not been dwelt upon in the debate. But to many experienced production managers who have been busy for some time on British contracts it is a likely consequence and explains one of the chief objections to the bill.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- While the British Admiralty announced today that mercantile shipping losses for the week ended Jan. 26 amounted to seven British ships and two Allied ships, for a total of 33,604 tons, R.H. Cross, Minister of Shipping, told the Royal Empire Society that the solution of many of the problems brought on by sinkings lay squarely with the United States.

Paramount's "Life With Henry," which opens this morning at Loew's Criterion, is the lone newcomer to Broadway screens. The latest in the Aldrich Family series stars Jackie Cooper in the title role and features Eddie Bracken, Leila Ernst -- who makes her film debut in the picture -- Kay Stewart, Hedda Hopper and Fred Niblo Sr. . . .

A special benefit luncheon and fashion show under the auspices of the British Relief Overcoat Committee, were given yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Many womeu of society gave luncheon parties for the occasion, which was arranged to advance the committee's efforts in collecting warm coats to be sent to men of the Local Defense Volunteer Corps in Great Britain -- men over military age who are constantly on patrol duty.

Councilman Walter R. Hart and his Democratic colleagues in the City Council made a sharp attack on the La Guardia administration yesterday on the ground that it had failed to provide sufficient funds for necessary city activities.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- In reply to a question in the House of Commons today by Geoffrey Mender, Liberal, a clarification of British post-war policy in respect to Ethiopia was made by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden.

Seven persons accused with Hymie Caplin, prizefight manager, of operating a card-sharp ring that allegedly defrauded its victims of more than $2,000,000 in ten years, interrupted their trial in Kings County Court yesterday and pleaded guilty to charges of grand larceny.

The American Newspaper Guild announced yesterday that it had requested the National Labor Relations Board to file an immediate appeal in the United States Supreme Court against the decision of the United States Circuit Court in Philadelphia setting aside an order by the board calling upon The Newark Star Ledger to reinstate a member of the Guild.

Under the not too dignified heading, "Stuffed Shirts and Laurel Wreaths," Books Abroad, the international quarterly published by the University of Oklahoma Press, sent requests last Summer to a number of prominent writers and scholars for their nominations for the World's Worst Book.

Officials of San Francisco, Calif., sold yesterday to the Crocker First National Bank of San Francisco $2,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes at 0.20 per cent plus a premium of $12.65. The notes are to be payable on May 10, 1941.

A survey just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion shows that the number who approve the idea of a national referendum, calling for a vote of the people before Congress could send men to fight overseas, has dropped in the past year, Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director, reports.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Drastic changes in the administration and procedure of the National Labor Relations Board, changes which were shelved when the Madden-Smith majority was in control of the board, have now been made effective.

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, was accused yesterday of having violated the civil service laws and of having shown favoritism to personal friends of Mayor La Guardia in a report by Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the City Council committee investigating the Civil Service Commission.

Bound for England, where it will study civilian defense efforts, an American Legion mission headed by National Commander Milo J. Warner, will leave for Lisbon at 8:30 o'clock this morning aboard the Yankee Clipper of Pan American Airways.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Two State Senators asked the Pennsylvania Legislature today to investigate what they charged is "open connivance" between gamblers and the State Athletic Commission.

Mrs. Kitty Pappas, 29 years old, of 1035 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, wife of a grocery importer, was found strangled to death with a man's necktie bound tightly around her neck and with her arms and feet tied together with towels shortly before 10:30 o'clock last night.
