LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The staggering costs of the war were driven home to the British people afresh today when two white papers were published calling on the House of Commons to vote credits amounting to 1,600,000,000 sterling for expenditures in the next few months.

Ethel Barrymore, head of the royal family of the Barrymores, was the recipient last night of unusual honors upon the completion of her fortieth year as a star and featured player of the American stage. Friends and fellow players in her current vehicle, "The Corn Is Green," swamped her dressing room at the National Theatre with flowers and congratulatory telegrams.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 -- Henry Ford has told the War Department that he is ready not only to build parts and subassemblies for bombing planes but that he would like to construct the complete plane on a moving assembly line.

Assistant Budget Director Lester B. Stone, who has been de-deviled by many strange requests in the making of the next city budget, was asked yesterday to approve an appropriation for wire screens to keep eels out of the city water supply pipes.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Challedon, champion of the turf, resumed work today for the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap March 1 under a new trainer, L.T. (Whitey) Whitehill.

First-round play in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's twelfth annual Class B singles championship at the Harvard Club was completed last night when seven matches were run off and another went by default. J. Overton of the Downtown A.C., seeded third, who was scheduled to meet J. Tappin of the Princeton Club on Monday, advanced to the second round by default.

; WASHINGTON, Feb. A-Presldent and /Hrs. Roosevelt held tonight the third state reception of the season, entertaining at the White House in honor of the members of the Senate and House of lepresentatives.

SEATTLE, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Bill Skiff, field supervisor of the Yankees' farm system, made such a good impression on Seattle baseball officials upon his arrival today that they promptly signed him to a two-year contract as manager of the champion Pacific Coast League team.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Representative Wadsworth told the House today that enactment of the aid-to-Britain bill or one very much like it would contribute to the safety of the United States and have "an immediate, dynamic effect" on the morale of attacked nations.
In the spirit of your editorial in this morning's issue on the Lease-Lend Bill let me ask the following questions:

W.P. Hoffman of the Bayside Club, No. 1 seeded player in the Monte M. Sterling squash tennis tournament, yearly fixture for non-Class A tournament winners at the New York Athletic Club, made his debut in the event yesterday.

A plan for the release of thirty-eight Danish freighters now tied up in American continental and island ports is being discussed by Danish and American shipping operators in New York, it was disclosed yesterday.

EAST NORTHPORT, L.I., Feb. 4 -- Traveling at an estimated speed of eight miles a minute in the Army's latest and fastest type of pursuit ship, Lieutenant Sherman E. Denny crashed to his death in a wooded area in the Laurel Hills section near here this afternoon.

Finland, although largely crowded from the news today, continues to press its work of reconstruction. In addition to suffering through the cession of territory to Russia last year, the country remains desperately handicapped by the shutting off of its export markets and by the difficulty of importing adequate raw materials for its industries.

Leaders in social welfare work affiliated with the national council of the Protestant Episcopal Church urged cooperation yesterday among the various agencies in this field to meet the new demands of the defense program.

Alarmed over the possibilities in the latest ruling by Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis affecting major-minor league relations involving the optioning of players, executives of the National League at their annual schedule meeting in the Hotel New Yorker yesterday took steps to have the rule modified or made more flexible.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Applications for the refunding of issues of public utility holding companies henceforth will be scrutinized as closely by the Securities and Exchange Commission as are requests for the approval of new issues, with the object of preventing perpetuation of unsound capital set-ups, the commission announced today.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- A bill designed to check the issuance of "smear" literature during political campaigns was introduced today by Senator Charles O. Burney Jr., Buffalo Republican.

Every corporation in existence during the base period years (1936 through 1939) should ascertain by actual test whether the income basis of credit is the more advantageous method to employ in determining its 1940 excess profits tax. This should be done in the light of possible adverse rulings in respect to any major item entering into either method of reporting.

Lecturing in London (the Ontario London, and therefore not immediately exposed to death from the sky), Professor A.S. Orton of Emmanuel College raised the question this week of what tune it is best to die to. When the Titanic sank in 1912, he said, the passengers sang "Nearer, My God, to Thee."

An all-metropolitan college basketball double-header, the second of the campaign, will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight. The set-up sends St. John's against Manhattan in the opener and N.Y.U. against St. Francis in the afterpiece, with the Redmen and Violets favored to emerge on top.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4 -- Sweet Willow and Sirasia took the feature races at Hialeah Park today, each enhancing his stock for stake engagements. The filly Sweet Willow, who carried the silks of R.W. Collins, is preparing for Saturday's Black Helen Handicap, while Sirasia is W.C. Stroube's eligible for the McClennan Memorial and Widener Challenge Cup Handicaps.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 5 -- Winding up his investigation of Britain's wartime effort, Wendell L. Willkie made a surprise flight to Dublin yesterday for a "frank, free discussion" with Premier Eamon de Valera, returned to England by the same plane for tea with the King and Queen and left London early today for the United States.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP) -Top-seeded Bobby Riggs of Chicago came from behind today to win his second-r0und match in the South Florida tennis tournament, while Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., caught up with the field in two straight-set victories.

Immediate dismissal of a two-year-old indictment accusing Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, and others of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act will be sought in Federal Court, it was learned yesterday.

Events tonight: "Le Nozze di Figaro," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 o'clock; Cleveland Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski, conductor; Jascha Heifetz, soloist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Margaret Speaks, song recital, 8:30; the Guild Singers, Isidore Freed, conductor, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30; Toini Tarsanen, recital of Finnish songs, American Scandinavian Center, 152 West Fifty-seventh Street, 8:30; Frances Hall and Rudolph Gruen, two-piano recital, Manhattan School of Music, 8:30; Charles O. Banks, organ recital, St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, 8:30.

Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute since 1938, was re-elected yesterday at the organization's annual meeting at its offices, 11 Broadway. R.J. Baker, secretary and treasurer; John J. Burns, general counsel, and ten members of the board of directors also were re-elected.
BERLIN, Feb. 4 -- Confidence prevails in informed quarters here tonight that the next forty-eight hours will bring a solution of the internal difficulties in which vanquished French find themselves.

William (Wolfie) Goldis, 44 years old, former small-time racketeer in the teamsters' union, who a little more than six years ago inspired his brother Morris, 39, to shoot and kill William Snyder, president of his local, thus giving Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, racketeer chiefs, full sway over it, was sentenced yesterday by Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions to Sing Sing for a year to eighteen months.

TOKYO, Feb. 4 -- The Netherland Government's refusal to have the Netherlands Indies incorporated in Japan's "Greater East Asia" sphere is treated by the Japanese as an unimportant move by a government whose right to intervene Japan views as highly doubtful.
ATHENS, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Action over the entire Albanian front was restricted to patrol work and artillery fire today because of heavy rain and mist, reports reaching Athens said.

There has just retired from government service at Washington a man of whom one is tempted to speak in colloquialisms. More than any other man in the country he has the American people's number; he made it public not so very long ago and it is approximately 131,400,000.

ROME, Feb. 4 -- Another important step in the strengthening of the Fascist party structure during these difficult times was announced today with a sweeping "changing of the guard" in the Rome hierarchy. Thirty-three officials, of whom a large number had been called or volunteered to go to the front, have been replaced by true and tried veterans of the March on Rome and the earliest days of fascism.

VICHY, France, Feb. 4 -- Navy Minister Admiral Jean Darlan returned to Vichy from Paris this evening alone. In Paris he saw Pierre Laval, now described in German quarters as "the most eminent personality connected with collaboration," and Otto Abetz, Ambassador of the Reich in France.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Rough seas prevented preparation of the liner Manhattan today for a trip to New York drydock for repair of damage wrought when she ran aground three weeks ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Feb. 5 -- The wife and younger son of Rabbi Louis Wolsey were found dead in the garage of the family home in Elkins Park early today, with indications pointing to a suicide pact, police said.

Advertising did not get off to as good a start in January as had been expected, figures now coming out show. Newspaper linage in New York was down slightly, with national copy showing a substantial decline, and monthly magazine linage was also off for the month. Radio billings for CBS and NBC are no longer available, but Mutual's were up sharply last month.

Mrs. Helen Porter Simpson was proposed last night as the Republican candidate for the Congressional seat in the Seventeenth district made vacant by the death less than two weeks ago of her husband, Kenneth F. Simpson, by four outstanding residents of the district.

Fireman Eugene Brennan was fatally injured at 11:15 o'clock last night when a collision between Fire Patrol Truck 8, answering a fire alarm, and a Daily News newspaper delivery truck caused the Fire Department vehicle to overturn at Sixth Avenue and Ninth Street, Brooklyn.

Public governors of the New York Curb Exchange have recommended and the board of governors has adopted a plan to "give full publicity to any and all disciplinary action" taken against members of the Curb, "regardless of whether or not it is felt that the public interest is involved," according to an announcement yesterday by George P. Rea, president.

A major expansion program involving the construction of new plant facilities to cost more than $2,000,000 was announced yesterday by Ben F. Hopkins, president of the Cleveland Graphite Bronze Company, following a meeting of the board of directors, at which the program was approved.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert McCoskry Butt gave a dinner at their home here tonight, later taking their guests to the Everglades Club. In the party were Mr. and Mrs, Robert Oakes Sinclalre, Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Tilton, Mrs. Flynn Stewart, Mrs. McAlptn Bell, Dr. Edmund LeRoy Dow, J. Goode Cabanne.

Mrs. Stewart Iglehart of Westbury, L.I., eliminated Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, the defending champion, 15 -- 12, 13 -- 15, 15 -- 7, 10 -- 15, 15 -- 13, to reach the semi-final round of the tenth annual women's invitation squash racquets tournament at the Junior League yesterday.

Stanley Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, attacked yesterday the annual report of the Citizens Budget Commission, asserting that the report gave the unfair impression that the city administration is wasteful and extravagant.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- Colonel Thomas W. Jones, contracting officer at the Army Quartermaster Depot here, today notified prospective bidders under Invitation No. 477 that the total yardage has been reduced from 40,000,000 to 20,000,000 yards.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- New orders placed with manufacturers were maintained in December at a level equal to the very high October and November totals, the Commerce Department announced today.

HAVANA, Feb. 4 -- President Fulgencio Batista, who assumed personal command of armed forces late last night and forced the resignation of his Chiefs of Staff of the Army and Navy and Chief of the National Police, continued his work of reorganization of the military forces today.

The demand for fresh pork showed some improvement in yesterday's trading, with consequently a firmer market. Other classes of traefer meats generally were steady, with a demand which ranged from only fair to slow. Kosher veal and lamb markets were steady to firm, and steer chucks and plates about steady at Monday's advance.
ROME, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A communique of the Italian High Command today said:

There are now "definite indications of a slackening off" in the incidence of influenza and similar respiratory diseases that have brought discomfort to New York City in the last six weeks, Dr. Samuel Frant, director of preventable diseases in the Health Department, reported yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 4 -- Wendell L. Willkie is occupying the center of the German press spotlight and his unexpected dash to Ireland resulted in the assertion in semi-official quarters that Germany was following Ireland's situation "with watchful interest."

LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Capture within a week of Massawa, Italian Eritrea's only good port and the goal of Britain's biggest push so far into Premier Mussolini's East African empire, was predicted by a British military source tonight.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 4 (AP) -- British general headquarters issued this communique today:

Willie Mosconi, pace-setter in the world pocket billiard championship tournament, and Erwin Rudolph broke even at Doyle's yesterday. In the afternoon Rudolph was the victor, 125 to 100, in twenty frames as he made a run of 76, one less than his rival. Mosconi took the night test, 125 to 28, in fourteen innings.

The range of the German big guns that have been shelling the Dover area in England from emplacements across the Channel has now been extended so that their shells fall some twelve miles farther inland. The German hope is believed to be eventually to drop shells on London.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 4 -- Marked success in the treatment of baccillary dysentery, a disease frequently fatal to young children, is reported at the Johns Hopkins Hospital by use of a new drug known as sulfanilylguanidine.

ROME, Feb. 4 -- An agreement has been reached between Italy and Germany for large Italian exports of vegetables, dates, rice, hemp and milk, the newspaper Resto del Carlino of Bologna announced today. It says the exports will bring a fair and steady return to the Italian producer.

The current European war will not only stimulate the sale of office equipment but will also improve, mechanize and streamline office procedure to a greater degree than ever before, speakers representing the office equipment industry asserted yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Tonight's event in the Broadway theatre will be a play with music written by Philip Barry and entitled "Liberty Jones." It will be presented at the Shubert Theatre under the banner of the Theatre Guild as its fourth subscription offering of the season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A call for national unity behind President Roosevelt's lease-lend bill to aid the democracies was sounded in the House today by Representative James W. Wadsworth, New York Republican, as he offered a formula which, he declared, would bring unity.

The report of the Southern New England Telephone Company for 1940, made public yesterday by H.C. Knight, president, shows a net income of $3,240,736, after all expenses and charges. This was equal to $8.10 each on 400,000 capital shares outstanding, and compares with $3,220,959, or $8.05 a share, in 1939.

A total of 339 New York City men were inducted into the Army yesterday through Selective Service. The precentage of rejections rose from 13.7 on Monday to 19.9 yesterday. The average rejection has been 19 per cent since Jan. 6 last.

Billy Soose, Farrell, Pa., middleweight, yesterday concluded training for his ten-round battle with Ernie Vigh of Newburgh, N.Y., in Madison Square Garden Friday night and impressed a large crowd of onlookers with his form.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 4 -- The Regional Conference of the River Plate made notable progress today despite almost insurmountable difficulties that face it on three important projects.

Remington Rand, Inc., in its preliminary statement for the nine months ended on Dec. 31 last, made available today, reveals a net income of $2,026,372. This is equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 88 cents a share on 1,584,895 common shares.
The insurance companies composing the Fire Association Group of Philadelphia reported yesterday increases in assets and unearned premium reserves at the end of 1940 over the previous year as follows:

DALLAS, Texas, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Federal Judge William H. Atwell held today that firms paying wages or salaries equal to or in excess of Wages and Hours Law minimums in pursuance of genuine contracts are in compliance with the act, regardless of methods of pay.

Small banks throughout the country were urged yesterday by P.D. Houston, president of the American Bankers Association, to facilitate military preparedness by financing production in local plants, thus aiding the government in decentralizing the defense program.

The government must adopt a money policy which will effectively reduce the standard of living of the individual American citizen if the defense program is to be financed without inflation, according to O.M.W. Sprague, retiring as Professor of Banking and Finance in the Harvard Business School, former adviser to the Bank of England and to the United States Treasury.
The annual report of the North American Life Assurance Company as of Dec. 31, last, shows total admitted assets of $67,969,282, compared with $65,001,883 at the close of 1939.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 4 -- Charles Steele, partner for many years in J.P. Morgan Co., left a gross estate of $32,316,518, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed here today with Surrogate Leone D. Howell by David F. Soden, transfer tax appraiser.

BERLIN, Feb. 4 -- Reports that the Rev. Martin Niemoeller, imprisoned leader of the German Confessional Church, had embraced the Catholic faith appeared unfounded tonight after conversations with his nearest relatives and friends. Those questioned insisted the Confessional leader still held the beliefs for which he had been in prison for three and one-half years.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The work of the law revision commission in completely recodifying the consolidated laws of New York State will be finished by mid-Summer, the Legislature was told today.

For the past week or two the press has given special headline prominence to the Australians in the capture of Bardia. If the Australians did capture Bardia alone, although I am in receipt of information which I believe to be authentic, to the effect that New Zealanders did take part in the push on Bardia, why quote the word "Anzac"?

Field Marshal Hermann Goering's iron and steel trust, according to an article by Kurt Lachmann in the current issue of Social Research, has become an instrument to wrest well-integrated properties from the hands of their owners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee filed dissenting views today on the bill to increase the national debt limit from $49,000,000,000 to $65,000,000,000, the next measure to be considered by the House.

RENEE BRAND'S novel, "Short Days Ago,"* is a stark, compelling story about castaways. These castaways are not on a desert island or in an open boat. They are at the center of Europe, on a frozen, desolate strip between the German border and a nameless country's frontier.

Sharp increases in notion volume, exceeding those of last year by a considerable margin, were predicted for National Notion Week, to be held from April 21 to 26, by John Bell, new president of the National Notion Association, at the luncheon meeting of that organization yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Visiting buyer registrations last week numbered 971, as against 1,000 in the previous week and 911 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals were 506, which compared with 315 for a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Defense officials moved on several fronts today to meet the rising deficiency in aluminum, which, conceivably, could become acute during the next few months in certain phases of the preparedness program.
BERLIN, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A 10,000-ton merchant vessel was hit by German bombers off the east coast of England at noon today, D.N.B., official German news agency, said.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe of New York, the defending champion, registered his eighth straight victory tonight in the world title three-cushion billiard tournament, defeating Paul Lewin of Chicago, 50 to 31, in 49 innings.

Dissension in the board of directors of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers resulted last night in renewed confusion in the radio music war, with the Department of Justice threatening to file today in Milwaukee its proposed criminal anti-trust suit against the society.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the State Racing Commission, whose reappointment confirmation has been held up for several weeks by the Senate Finance Committee, has been invited to appear before the committee for an interview on Tuesday, it was announced today by Senator Hanley, Republican majority leader.

Decision of the New York Curb Exchange to give full publicity to "any and all disciplinary action" has not proved popular in Wall Street. The opinion was expressed yesterday that it has "put all other Exchanges on the spot." In the ordinary course of business there are many trivial punishments for purely technical violations of rules.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Government spokesmen declared yesterday that Japan did not expect war with the United States, that a considerable improvement in Russo-Japanese relations had been brought about during the past six months and that a declaration of belligerent rights in the undeclared war with China was under consideration.

Thirty-five mothers of school children attending Public School 36 at Annadale, S.I., took militant charge of traffic direction outside the school during the morning and afternoon hours of pupil transit there yesterday, following the death of a 6-year-old boy Monday as a result of a hit-and-run automobile accident.

In upholding the constitutionality of the Federal Wage and Hour Law the Supreme Court has made a decision of historic importance. For it has specifically overruled a previous Supreme Court decision, which had stood for twenty-two years, holding invalid the Child Labor Law adopted by Congress at that time.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Roosevelt said today that he would send to the Senate Thursday nominations of a new Ambassador to Great Britain and several other diplomats.

Miss Harriet Elliott, consumer member of the National Defense Advisory Commission, gave her support yesterday to consumer protests against the high cost of meat. Asserting that Army purchases of meat were not large enough to justify any increase in price, Miss Elliott said consumers would do well to look for meat substitutes if prices continued to go up.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Notre Dame will continue its policy of choosing its head football coach and athletic director from among its alumni, it was indicated tonight as speculation increased over the successor of Elmer F. Layden.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $1,611,142,502 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price for each share of all listed stocks on Jan. 31 was $27.68, compared with $28.80 at the end of December.

Robert Goldsand, 29-year-old Austrian-born pianist, is the winner of the 1941 Town Hall Endowment Series award, Walter W. Naumburg, chairman of the Town Hall's music committee, announced yesterday. He was chosen by members of the committee from the candidates suggested by the New York music critics and the award consists of a recital, by which his expenses will be paid, in next season's endowment series.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 5 -- The first batch of volunteers of the Nordland Regiment -- about 100 men -- left today from Oslo's airport in big transport planes for Germany.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The value of retail sales in Great Britain for December was 2.7 per cent lower than for December, 1939, according to the monthly statistics issued here today by the Retail Distributors Association and the Bank of England. In view of price rises due to the purchase tax and the effect of limitation of supplies, there must have been a much greater decline in sales volume.

American foreign traders, usually extremely sensitive to disturbances affecting governments in the markets they serve, were relieved rather than disturbed by events in Cuba during the last few days. According to exporters, the flare-up, which resulted in the arrest of Cuban military leaders and the suspension of civil rights by President Fulgencio Batista, has been brewing for several weeks.
BERLIN, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A German High Command communique today said:

Defense demands for various types of lighting and other electrical equipment have tightened the nearby production schedules of most manufacturers and several producers are unable to take orders for delivery within the next four or five months, it was reported yesterday at the opening of the New York Electrical Trade Show at the Hotel New Yorker.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- John Fitzpatrick, fast developing into the giant killer of the world three-cushion billiard tournament, came within a point of defeating Willie Hoppe tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- American business men oppose American involvement "in any foreign war," according to James S. Kemper, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, who testified before the Senate Foreign relations Committee today in opposition to the Administration's lease-lend bill.

Suppose all of us who admire Ethel Barrymore could have been assembled to greet the end of her fortieth year on the stage. How many Madison Square Gardens and Coliseums would have been needed to hold only the persons with tickets to the orchestra? She was a "born artist."

An "era of elegance" for men's clothing, with diamonds and jewelry restored as a major item in the well-dressed male's wardrobe, was forecast yesterday at a preview of men's Spring fashions given at the Hotel Pierre by Tony Williams, representing the New York members of the Merchant Tailors and Designers Association of America.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Lightweight hogs closed fully steady today, but top-heavy receipts of 21,000 head, 6,000 over advance estimates, was reflected in 10-cent decreases in most other classes. Cattle prices were held steady due to meager supply of 6,000 head and sheep sales were weak, with nothing particularly choice offered.

Bernardo Oliveri, 19 years old, of 413 East Sixty-third Street was to be sentenced today in General Sessions in an automobile theft, but that will be put off because he faces a more serious charge on Feb. 14 -- the theft of $5,000 in a bag from the automobile of Dr. Frederick Henschel when it was parked in front of the physician's home at 955 Park Avenue last Jan. 3.

The $29,100,000 refunding program by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, under consideration for some time, will be carried out today with the issuance by the carrier of $24,800,000 of refunding and improvement mortgage bonds, series G-1 to G-25, maturing serially on Feb. 1, 1942, to 1966.

The annual report of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company and its domestic subsidiaries, mailed to stockholders yesterday, disclosed a net profit for 1940 of $5,591,606 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, including $1,400,000 provision for Federal excess taxes.

The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company issued its preliminary annual statement yesterday reporting total admitted assets at a new high level of $1,358,999,648, as of Dec. 31, 1940, a gain of $66,576,833 over the previous year. Cash amounting to $14,298,537 is included.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 5 (AP) -- "It's news to me," Jimmy Crowley, Fordham University football coach, said tonight in commenting on reports that he was the likely successor of his "Four Horsemen" team-mate, Elmer Layden, at his alma mater, Notre Dame.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 5 -- Lieut. Col. Edwin E. Aldrin of Montclair, N.J., accepted today Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein's offer to become manager of Newark Airport at $10,000 a year and was directed by the Mayor to report back in two weeks with a plan for reopening the field, which has been closed since last May.

The Cleveland Symphony Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski, conductor, was the second symphonic visitor in the space of two consecutive days to this city, performing last night in Carnegie Hall. The program for the major part offered material of fresh interest; the familiar item was the Strauss "Heldenleben."

BERLIN, Feb. 5 -- The invasion of Great Britain this year was definitely asserted to be one of the things that the British have in store for them within the next eleven months by the Schwarze Korps, organ of the blackshirted Elite Guard organization, today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- Bids will be opened at the Army Quartermaster Depot here on Feb. 14 on slightly more than 5,000,000 yards of cotton linings for uniforms. The invitation includes: (1) 2,900,956 yards of 35-inch, fully shrunk, unbleached cotton drill; (2) 2,093,640 yards of 36-inch olive-drab silesia uniform lining; (3) 1,369,809 yards of olive-drab, vat-dyed, cotton twill and (4) 2,679,305 yards of olive-drab cotton overcoat lining cloth.

Hunter College will confer degrees upon 618 students in the day session and the evening and extension division at the seventy-ninth commencement exercises, to be held at 8 o'clock tonight in the college's assembly hall in the 695 Park Avenue building.

With a wide variety of exhibits, ranging from a model locomotive weighing only two ounces to a miniature speed boat capable of making sixty-three miles an hour, the thirteenth annual exhibition of the New York Society of Model Engineers Exhibitions, Inc., will open here tomorrow.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5 -- The patience of the veteran George Tappen, lifelong friend and colleague of another famous old-time trainer, Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, got Ship Biscuit home at $51.90 for $2 at Hialeah Park today for the Wheatley Stable of Mrs. Henry C. Phipps.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that eighty-six issues of securities of electric and gas utilities, involving $881,247,251, were offered publicly or sold privately in 1940. This brought the total for the six years ended on Dec. 31 to 431 issues aggregating $5,880,824,432.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 -- Wayne Sabin of Portland, Ore., eliminated seventh-seeded Billy Talbert of Cincinnati, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, today as other favorites reached the quarter-finals of the South Florida tennis tournament.

Margaret Speaks, soprano, gave her first New York recital last night in Town Hall. Miss Speaks, who is a niece of the American composer, Oley Speaks, has gained a large following through her weekly broadcasts during the last five years, and she was heard by a fervently appreciative capacity audience.

The Metropolitan Museum's major exhibition called "French Painting: David to Toulouse-Lautrec," opened with a preview last evening and may be visited by the public beginning today. It is to remain current through March 26. In addition to a large group of notable work from French museums, this show contains paintings borrowed from various museum and private collections in this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today approached the end of its hearings on a suggested rule to require competitive bidding by underwriters on public utility issues with representatives of investment and commercial banks and one utility executive on the stand.

If Senator Wheeler was revealing confidential official figures in his statement of the exact number and types of planes that the Army is alleged to have had on hand on Jan. 1, he was taking upon himself a grave responsibility. If his figures were not authoritative, or were in some way garbled, his responsibility is hardly less serious.
LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Air Ministry early today issued the following communique:

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 5 -- The River Plate Regional Conference today set up a permanent office with headquarters in Buenos Aires to watch over the operation of regional agreements, conduct studies and report on measures for keeping the regional group alive as a vital, functioning organization.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -Representative Johns, Republican, of Wisconsin, told the House tonight that it was with "a heavy heart" that he opposed the Lease-Lend Bill.

Elsa Lanchester, wife of Charles Laughton, will return to the Broadway stage after an absence of ten years, taking the leading role in Max Catto's psychological melodrama, "They Walk Alone," which London first saw in January, 1939. Miss Lanchester last appeared here with her husband in "Payment Deferred.''

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Creditors of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company of this city are justified in refusing to compromise their claims against stockholders of the concern, Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan ruled today in approving the rejection of an offer from the estate of the late Hervey D. la Coste, owner of 888 shares, to settle a $17,760 claim for $5,000.

KEENANSVILLE, N.C., Feb. 5 -While the quail shooting in Western Florida from the vicinity of Punta Gorda northward is holding up fairly well, most of the hunters we met who had been scouring the east coast areas reported that the coveys had been shot down to the minimum.
The preview of the exhibition of French paintings by famous artists from David to Toulouse-Lautrec at the Metropolitan Museum last night was attended by 2,500 persons.

The 1940 annual report of the Hartford Electric Light Company, made public yesterday by Sam Ferguson, president, shows a net income for the year after all charges of $2,837,274, compared with $2,765,060 in 1939. Gross revenues of the company were $8,980,483, against $8,195,590 in the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Through simultaneous establishment of direct contact with newspaper publishers and a more definite check on news correspondents and others dealing regularly with the government, the Administration was moving today toward a virtual war footing in the public relations of those agencies dealing with national defense.

Three new films will be added to the Broadway screen roster this morning. The newcomer at the Radio City Music Hall will be Columbia's picturization of the Clarence Budington Kelland novel, "Arizona." Jean Arthur is starred in the adventure, which is laid in Tucson in 1860, and William Holden, Warren William, Porter Hall, Regis Toomey, Paul Harvey and Byron Foulger are featured.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Wheat continued on the upgrade today in sympathy with securities and on buying induced by independent strength at Kansas City and Minneapolis. May led the advance and closed at the top, gaining 3/4 cent a bushel, while the deferred months were slightly under the top, with closing sales on the Board of Trade here at gains of 3/8 cent.
ROME, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said today that the British aircraft carrier Illustrious, surviving Axis air attacks that had cost her about eighty men killed and twenty bombing planes destroyed in one direct hit by a thousand-pound bomb, had arrived at Alexandria, Egypt, under her own power from Malta.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Two bills designed to cut the State income tax in the interest of the taxpayers were introduced in the Assembly today by Maurice Whitney, Rensselaer Republican and chairman of the Taxation Committee. The measures were submitted by Mr. Whitney on his own initiative and are not party bills.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 5 -- Princeton's basketball team reversed an earlier setback tonight as it defeated Rutgers, 42 -- 33, in a rough game in the university gymnasium. The Scarlet had taken a 43-38 decision in the previous meeting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Proceedings were begun today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to bring about the corporate simplification of the General Gas and Electric Corporation holding company system under Section 11 (b) (2) of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

For the last ten days the cotton trade has been questioning the accuracy of the figures of the Commodity Credit Corporation with respect to repossessions from this season's loan stock. While the figures of the CCC show that only 35,636 bales had been withdrawn through Jan. 30, estimates in the local cotton trade had placed the total at as much as ten times that amount.

Elaine Newton, a 19-year-old art student who supported herself while attending college, will receive the highest academic honors this evening at the Hunter College commencement exercises when she gets her Bachelor of Arts degree summa cum laude.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Ivan Bagrianoff, outspoken pro-German Agriculture Minister whose resignation was accepted yesterday by King Boris, today received a high decoration from the monarch.

On top of the announcement that "fliers" from the Norwegian Royal Air Force located in Toronto would compete in the Norsemen S.C. jump at Salisbury Mills, N.Y., Sunday, came news yesterday from Hanover, N.H., that Norway also will be represented in the thirty-first running of the Dartmouth Carnival tomorrow and Saturday, giving this college event more color than ever.

THE jinx is rearing its ugly head in hockey again. The Stanley Cup custodians, the Rangers, just can't seem to beat the Black Hawks this season. At least, they haven't done so yet and the rivals have met five times on the rinks in this current campaign. The best that M'sieu Francois Boucher and his boys could get out of those five flying conferences on skates was one breathless tie.

Somewhat late, Richard Llewellyn's publishers have received the following message from the Welsh author, sent from the Training Battalion, Welsh Guards, Sandown Park, Esther, Surrey: "Nadolig Llawen a Blwyddyn Newydd Dda," translated as "With Best Wishes for Christmas and the New Year."
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command at Cairo issued the following communique today:

The number of New York City residents inducted into the Army through Selective Service yesterday was 292. Sixty-eight others who were examined during the day were rejected. The rejections amounted to 18.88 per cent of the total, which is about the usual proportion.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The Municipal Court of the City of New York, known as the "Poor Man's Court" because it handles cases involving $1,000 or less, is entirely up with its calendars and actions can be tried without delay, the Judicial Council informed the Legislature today in its seventh annual report.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 -- Acquisition and operation of the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company as a Detroit municipal utility will be voted upon here in the April 7 election. Placing the proposal on the ballot was approved today by the Detroit Common Council.

Joseph H. Tooker, president of the Tooker Lithograph Company, has leased an apartment in the building at 875 Fifth Avenue through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., who also report the rental of quarters in 4 East Eighty-eighth Street to Wheelock H. Bingham, vice president of R.H. Macy Co., and in 123 East Thirtyseventh Street to Bertram D. Quarrie, executive vice president of the Empire Ordnance Corporation, through Gilliam McVay, Inc.

Your editorial "The Shrinking Stock Market" stated correctly the chief reasons for the sick market -- foreign liquidation, fear of continuously higher taxation, war uncertainties, etc. What we need is a remedy, if there is one, to save the stock market and the New York Stock Exchange.

Victory for England in the war and the revival of the League of Nations on a more practical and enduring basis were foreseen yesterday by Seymour Jacklin, for fourteen years treasurer of the League, who arrived in New York Monday aboard the Moore-McCormack liner Brazil after a roundabout trip from Geneva.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 5 -The reserve with which the Nazi press recently started to treat war news is due to the German people's growing desire for peace, according to an article by the Berlin correspondent of the Nya Dagligt Allehanda, a newspaper generally friendly to Germany.

It was suggested in another column on this page yesterday that Marshal Petain today at Vichy may be digging in as he did once upon a time at Verdun. We are within a few days of a quarter-century of Verdun, where the German storm broke on Feb. 21, 1916.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- With a parting message to the people of Britain that he would do everything he could upon his return home to help this country, Wendell L. Willkie left an airport in Western England today bound for Lisbon on the first stage of his return trip by air to the United States.

Morrie Arnovich, one of the big question marks in the plans of Bill Terry, may be able to play the full season for the Giants despite his low draft number. The outfielder, who was purchased from the Reds, yesterday telegraphed President Horace Stoneham that the draft board at Superior, Wis., had changed his classification.
BITOLJ, Yugoslavia, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Italy was reported in dispatches to this border town tonight to be rushing reinforcements by air to help the hard-pressed defenders of Tepeleni.

TOKYO, Feb. 5 -- The Thailand-French Indo-China peace conference will open here Friday, it was announced today. Regarding the conference with great satisfaction as the first fruit of his South Sea policy, Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka will head the Japanese delegation, numbering eleven.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Roosevelt presented the Herbert Schiff Memorial Trophy today to Lieutenant Commander Harold B. Miller, who commanded Patrol Squadron Three, which had the best Navy record for safety in flying during the fiscal year 1939-40.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 5 -Despite torrential rains that have fallen during the day, the waters of the Danube began to recede today after reaching a dangerous stage yesterday, and anxiety has been considerably relaxed.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The British announced today that five planes -- all fighters -- were missing from this afternoon's sweep against Northern France. Combined with the acknowledged loss of four in last night's actions, this would make the total cost of the twenty-four-hour offensive nine planes.

A new apartment project in Jackson Heights, which is to incorporate the first self-contained garage in that community, was announced yesterday in connection with the sale of a blockfront once part of the Jackson Heights golf course.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 5 -- Shanghai's resumed taxpayers' meeting was held without incident today although the race track meeting place resembled an armed camp.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- A skull-masked, black-robed woman arose in the House galleries during debate on the lease-lend bill today and startled hundreds of legislators and spectators by raising her right arm and crying "My Novena! My Novena!"

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 5 -- Dartmouth's hockey team routed Boston University tonight, 10 -- 3, behind the sharpshooting of Captain Fred Maloon, Bob Pelren and Johnny Kelley. The Indians gained the lead before the game was two minutes old on a goal by Kelley and gradually pulled away from a hard-fighting Terrier six led by Captain Paul Brown and Ray Chambers.

On the only vacant site along Central Park South, an apartment house of imposing size soon will rise as a neighbor to the skyscraper residential buildings which are spread out along that valuable stretch of land facing the park.

Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the City Council committee investigating the Municipal Civil Service Commission, was criticized yesterday by Paul J. Kern, commission president, for seeking funds to carry on his inquiry after launching it as a "volunteer'' enterprise.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 5 -- The Princeton swimming team scored a 50-25 victory over Rutgers tonight before 1,000 persons. It was the third straight for the Tigers as the Scarlet suffered its first setback in five meets. Princeton took seven of the nine events, losing only the 100 and the 400-yard relay.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- The unveiling of Army's new coach, Earl (Red) Blaik, took place here today, the occasion being a luncheon at the Officers' Club, where the man who is now to be in charge of West Point's gridiron destinies explained his change from Dartmouth Green to Army Blue and announced his plans for what is hoped will be the rehabilitation of Army football.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Authoritative informants said today they had heard that Japanese troops would arrive here within a fortnight, ostensibly to enforce terms of the armistice agreement between French Indo-China and Thailand.
Winning seven of the nine events, the Brooklyn College swimmers defeated Fordham, 45 to 30, in the Kingsmen's pool last night.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- A bill prohibiting any increase in subway fares in New York City unless city voters specifically give approval at a general election was introduced today in the Legislature under Democratic sponsorship.

No one will speak lightly of Philip Barry's motives. In "Liberty Jones," which the Theatre Guild put on at the Shubert last evening, he has written an elaborate allegory of freedom in America. As it comes close to modern times in the last half of the evening, it frequently breaks through portentous obscurity and creates scenes of beauty that have a pulsing meaning for the world of today.

BERLIN, Feb. 5 -- Wendell Willkie's words to the people of Germany, which the British Broadcasting Corporation transmitted this evening, evoked no immediate comment in official or authoritative German quarters. It was suggested that a reply might be forthcoming soon, but that the Reich was not obligated to comment on every statement by every American, particularly, as in the case of Mr. Willkie, when that American occupies no official position.

The American Rescue Ship Mission has leased a ship and has arranged to transport 450 Spanish Republican refugees from French camps to permanent homes in Mexico within a few weeks, it was announced last night by Dr. Edward K. Barsky, national chairman of the United Spanish Aid Committee.

Before an elaborately designed stage setting decorated with palm trees and tropical flowers to represent a colorful South American night club, the thirty-fifth annual ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club was given last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The British Government announces its recognition of Haile Selassie as lawful Emperor of Ethiopia, no longer a colony but a sovereign nation under British protection. It must have been a particular satisfaction for Anthony Eden to make this announcement in Commons.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 -- Inaugurating a "race" around the country, the golden horse replica of Herbert Haseltine's sculpture of Field Marshal V, champion shire stallion, owned by the late King George V of England, was offered for bids to aid the British War Relief Society at the Wednesday dinner at the Indian Creek Club tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Greek Government, acting through its Minister in Washington, has rejected, at least for the time being, the offer by the United States oil thirty Grumman naval planes how on the aircraft carrier Wasp, Secretary Knox revealed today.

Only extremely severe Winter weather prevented the Greek Army from capturing Valona "and driving the Italians into the sea," Leland Stowe, veteran foreign correspondent for The Chicago Daily News and The New York Post, declared yesterday upon his arrival here aboard the Atlantic Clipper of Pan American Airways.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- An emergency program calling on Congress for two supplementary appropriations totaling $156,750,000, to provide homes for workers in defense areas, and for an amendment to the National Housing Act designed to expedite participation by private industry in the government's defense housing effort, was announced today by C.F. Palmer, Defense Housing Coordinator.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- The undefeated St. Nicholas Hockey Club performed brilliantly at the Play-land Casino tonight in scoring a 9-3 victory over a Yale team which had held it to a 3-3 deadlock at New Haven earlier in the season. The Elis have not beaten the St. Nicholas six in two years.

Mrs. Enos Throop Jr. of the Rockaway Hunting Club became the new holder of the New York Junior League silver bowl when she defeated Miss Hope Knowles of Philadelphia, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 14, in the final of the tenth annual women's invitation squash racquets tournament at the Junior League Club yesterday.

The Port of New York is far better equipped to take its role as an important factor in the nation's defense development than it was twenty-five years ago and has eliminated the "bottlenecks of commerce'' that existed at the time of the last war, Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, declared yesterday.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told 1,200 striking employes of the Leviton Manufacturing Company at a strike rally in Brooklyn yesterday that all workers should join labor unions and that educational projects should be set up for employers as well as workers.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 6 -- German air activity over Britain during the last twenty-four hours has been more extensive than lately, but no more damaging unless one considers the toll exacted from the enemy, who is believed to have lost seven aircraft.

The three-story walk-up apartment house at 96 State Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Bank for Savings in the City of New York to Lucia Gamberg in a transaction arranged by Moses Zinberg. The house is on a plot 26 by 100 feet and is assessed for $10,000, with $4,600 applying to the land, and the buyer paid a cash consideration above a first mortgage which has been reduced to $6,300.
The New York A.C.'s championship Class A squash tennis team extended its lead in the Metropolitan League interclub race last night by notching its ninth triumph in as many starts.

OTTAWA, Feb. 5 -- J. L. Ilsley, Finance Minister, today described as irresponsible the statement made yesterday by General Robert E. Wood before the Foreign Relations committee of the United States Senate that Canadian bonds would depreciate very considerably if the war lasted two years.

A wood-carving mural, "Man and Nature," by Carl Milles, Swedish sculptor, was unveiled yesterday in the lobby of the Time Life Building at Rockefeller Center. The mural, on the west wall of the lobby, represents one of the last steps in Rockefeller Center's art program, and was unveiled by John D. Rockefeller 3d.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 5 -- A once famous Turkish leader had a dramatic homecoming from twenty years of exile last night, dying from emotion at the sight of his native land three hours after setting foot on it.
AMSTERDAM, Feb. 5 -- Today's Bourse showed a slightly better trend, with some speculative activity. Domestics rallied as much as 5 points.

VICHY, France, Feb. 5 -- Official quarters here receive with favor a suggestion in the Portuguese press that Lisbon could be made the distribution center for relief sent to the European area from North and South America.

An oversold condition in the stock market lent itself readily yesterday to a recovery movement and prices rallied 1 to 2 points, mainly under the demand which appeared for the so-called war issues. Just as the selling of the last week had been labeled of poor quality by brokers, the buying of yesterday was termed good.

Nine policemen who saved drowning persons during the last three years were presented yesterday with awards of medals and money by the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York at a ceremony at police headquarters.

One thousand secondary schools and colleges throughout the count try were called upon yesterday by the Medical and Surgical Supply Committee of America, 420 Lexington Avenue, to help raise funds for the purchase of medical supplies and surgical instruments badly needed in Great Britain and Greece.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Administration leaders in the House indicated tonight that they had reached no conclusion on whether to accept all or part of the compromise proposed by Representative James W. Wadsworth, Republican, of New York, to effect certain limitations on the pending lease-lend bill to aid Britain and her allies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Representative John W. McCormack told the House in the debate on the lease-lend bill today that "the real war mongers are those who oppose action and in their blind opposition are attempting to divide our people."

The choice of a new member of the State Board of Regents comes as a fresh reminder of the unsatisfactory character of the present system, which provides for election to the board by the Legislature rather than appointment by the Governor. W. Kingsland Macy, whose election has just been announced, has been State chairman of the Republican party and is now county chairman of Suffolk County.
LISBON, Thursday, Feb. 6 (UP) -Wendell L. Willkie left here at 12:10 A.M. today aboard the Dixie Clipper on the first regular flight to the United States by way of Africa and the South Atlantic.

There are in New York many thousand crippled children who do not limp. They are boys and girls whose hearts have been crippled by rheumatic heart disease. And it is for them, especially those being cared for at Irvington House, that I urge attention.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The government's increasing interest in requiring competitive bidding in the capital market and the coeval trend in that market toward private placement of securities issues are necessarily of the deepest interest to the host of American investors and the managers of capital.

To meet the challenge of external dangers "from without by a powerful foe" as well as the internal problems of the United States, this country must have a government with business men applying group leadership, more equitable taxation and a solution of the unemployment problem, according to Mayor John B. Gage of Kansas City.

Price advances ranging from 50 cents a dozen on low-end styles to $1 each on the better grades will become effective on men's hats at the end of this week, it was learned here yesterday. Sharp rises in quotations on fur available here for making felt are responsible for the advances and the scarcity of white furs here has resulted in the elimination of pastel shades in the $2.95 retail bracket, it was said.

It seems to me that the recent Gallup survey showing that 70 per cent of those questioned believed that aid to the Allies contributes to keeping the United States out of war deserves more than passing attention. This fundamental belief of the American people helps to explain what seems to some of us two contradictory wishes of our public: (1) to remain at peace and (2) to aid the Allies.

A two-year contract, which Owner Dan Topping of the Brooklyn Football Dodgers declared to call for the highest amount ever paid a professional star over two seasons, was signed by Clarence (Ace) Parker yesterday. No end of coaxing could get Topping to disclose the actual terms, but he did state that the National Football League's most valuable player's 1940 salary, exclusive of bonuses, had been doubled.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 -- Defending champion Elizabeth Hicks of Pasadena, Calif., was eliminated from the Palm Beach women's golf championship today in one of the most surprising upsets of the Winter circuit.

ROME, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Assailing Marshal Henry Philippe Petain's regime as "conceited and imprudent,'' the ultra-Fascist newspaper Regime Fascista today warned France that her armistice agreement with Germany and Italy could be annulled within an hour to throw France back into the war.

The steady increase in the membership of State-chartered banks in the Federal Reserve System in its New York District, which began last September, was accelerated yesterday by the admission of two more member banks. This makes a total of nine new members in this district to date this year and seventeen new member institutions here since September.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Prospects for the adoption by the Legislature of the proposal to divert $60,000,000 of grade crossing elimination bonds to highway and parkway purposes have increased materially. Definite support from such counties as Westchester, Erie, Monroe, Dutchess and Putnam has developed, as a result of the parkway program outlined in a companion bill showing how the money is to be spent.

Steer hinds and ribs as well as many major wholesale cuts had a weak to lower trend in yesterday's trading, as demand continued slow. Veal and lamb had a fair outlet at around steady prices. Demand for pork was only fair to slow, and prices were mostly steady. The market on kosher steer beef, veal and lamb offered steady to firm. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Columbia's quintet defeated Army, 33-26, today, before a small midweek crowd. The Lions excelled in floor work and passing, and although slow to get started, they eventually solved the cadets' defense.

Plans are under way to continue and expand the current national advertising campaign sponsored by the Newspaper Publishers Committee, Norman Chandler, publisher of The Los Angeles Times and chairman of the committee, announced yesterday. Ads designed to emphasize and evaluate the newspaper's place in a democracy are now appearing once a week in 335 dailies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The government renewed today its attempt to prove that organized medicine was endeavoring to destroy a medical cooperative set up by a group of Federal employes and, in so doing, was violating the anti-trust laws.
VICHY, France, Feb. 5 -- When Pierre Laval returns from Paris, it is being asked here, just what will his status be?

Without resorting, as yet, to the imposition of mandatory priorities, the iron and steel committee of the Priorities Board is exercising a broader control of the steel indusdry in its relation to defense projects, according to Iron Age. Although the committee has been functioning for less than two weeks, it is reported to have arranged sources of supply and definite shipping schedules for a number of defense projects.
Richard Rothschild of the Downtown A.C. is the new metropolitan squash racquets champion.

The moving finger in this war is often the finger of irony, writing sardonic postscripts to the military communiques. Irony pursues the Italians in their retreats in Africa; for this retreat from empire, almost too rapid to be real, suggests a flight from a mirage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Marion C. Weimer and Ruthye E. Kohler of New York, the former on the General Staff of Sloane Hospital and the latter of Kingston Hospital in Brooklyn, were among nine additional graduate nurses appointed today for overseas duty by Miss Mary Beard, national director of the American Red Cross Nursing Service.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Responsible quarters said today that commercial negotiations with Japan probably would be resumed immediately, now that the Japanese have denied saying they would have nothing to do with the Netherland Government in Exile.
Replying yesterday to Democratic attacks on the La Guardia administration, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, said the criticisms were unsportsmanlike and unfair.

Activity in the cotton futures market improved yesterday, and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 1 point lower to 2 points higher. The 1-point loss was established in March, while the other near months were unchanged. Moderate gains were chalked up in the distant months despite the infrequency of the transactions.

i Payments to American families of . life insurance policies on a monthly or other installment basis aggregated almost $200,000,000 in 1940, a high record, the Institute of Life Insurance announced yesterday. In the last five years these payments have increased 65 per cent, while for the last ten years the increase was 275 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Secretary Cordell Hull said today that consideration was being given to French proposals that some of the French credits now frozen in this country be released for the purpose of acquiring food and medicines for shipment to the destitute in France, but he did not indicate that they would, be acted upon favorably.

In an editorial you say: "Winston Churchill * * * is not a dictator." I would say: "Winston Churchill is a dictator" and then reconcile the two statements by noting that the word dictator has come to be used, as you use it, in a sense very different from its original and proper meaning.

The 1941 Greater New York campaign of the American ORT Federation for $500,000 to help train European Jewish refugees and war victims in trades and agriculture was opened yesterday with a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore at which George Frankenthaler, lawyer and philanthropist, accepted the chairmanship of the drive.

District Attorney Dewey made his first open move yesterday against professional gambling in the city. He had evidence submitted to the New York County grand jury that resulted in the arrest of Louis Schreiber, prominent Republican leader of the Fifth Assembly District South, in the midtown district, and two men with previous police records on charges that they are common gamblers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Requirements as to the content of accountants' certificates were prescribed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission in amendments to rules covering the form of certifications of financial statements filed by companies in registration statements.

Foreign traders seeking information on a variety of questions dealing with export licenses yesterday crowded the newly opened branch office of the Administrator of Export Control in the Federal Office Building at 90 Church Street. Exporters were getting answers to questions which in the past had involved either a trip to Washington or lengthy correspondence with officials there.

Sales of electric ranges by manufacturers last year passed the 400,000 mark, the largest figure on record, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association reported yesterday. The actual figure was 404,239, as against 296,846 in 1939, an increase of 36.1 per cent.

Nine members of the Pastry Drivers Union, an A.F. of L. affiliate, were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct last night for picketing the rectory of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, 409 West Fifty-ninth Street l in protest against a decision by Father Bertrand Conway of the Paulist Fathers, who acted as arbitrator in a dispute between a baking company and the union.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 6 -- British bombs fell Tuesday night upon Duesseldorf, the invasion ports, Nazi airports and naval bases in the heaviest attack the Royal Air Force has undertaken in a fortnight.

Five old Maritime Commission vessels that have been transferred to the flag of Panama will soon start operations in the North Atlantic trade carrying vital goods, including munitions, between the United States and British ports, it was disclosed yesterday in connection with an announcement from the commission that it had approved the sale of the ships to the North Atlantic Transport Company of Panama.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Roosevelt accepted gratefully today assurances of Cuban collaboration at a time of "menace" to the Western Hemisphere from a world at war in receiving Dr. Aurelio Fernandez Concheso for the presentation of his letters of credence as the new Ambassador of Cuba.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 5 -- Apparently retreating at the maximum speed permitted by depleted supply trucks, Italian troops today poured through the Libyan village of Maraua, using the famous Cyrenaican motor road in their effort to reach the comparative safety of Bengazi.

The Commerce Department's official announcement that $149,633,653 gold was delivered on direct shipment from South Africa, most or all of it carried on the United States cruiser Louisville, contributes to the gold movement since the war began another touch of the dramatic.

New York University toppled St. Francis College at Madison Square Garden, 32 to 27, before a gathering of 9,454 last night, which was no surprise. And the St. John's University basketball team beat Manhattan College, which was no surprise either.
BERLIN, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 31 shows the following changes for the week, in thousands of marks:

Edward W. Scott, former editor of the English section of the newspaper Panama American, who was deported last week by order of President Arnulfo Arias, charged yesterday that the Panama Canal is menaced by activities of foreign agents who have found refuge in the republic under its present regime.
WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 5 (AP) -More than 26,000 persons were added to the payrolls of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in 1940, according to the company's annual report to be released next week.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 5 -- The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, nineteen music publishing corporations and twenty-six musicians and music writers were charged with violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in a criminal information filed by the Department of Justice today in the Federal District Court.

An improvement anticipating a demand for store and office space in the Civic Center downtown when the new Criminal Courts Building opens will result from the purchase yesterday by the Park Bayard Realty Corporation, Herbert Baum, president, of the plot 75 by 100 feet at 94-6-8-10 Bayard Street, northwest corner of Mulberry Street.

MADRID, Feb. 5 -- The newspaper Arriba culminated a series of editorials on the food shortage today with a statement that Spain must cease complaining and "break once and for all the blockade with which those within and without are attempting to paralyze us forever.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Roosevelt's intervention has made possible the centralization of authority over defense buying in the purchasing division of the Office of Production Management, it was reported today when it appeared that Donald M. Nelson had won his fight for the powers he had requested in heading the defense purchasing organization.

Four hundred major Federal construction projects involving a total expenditure of $1,800,000,000 already have been undertaken in connection with the national defense program, and "more are on the horizon," William H. Harrison, director of all construction work under the National Defense Commission, reported yesterday.

The activities of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., were essential in combating evils that were proving "disastrous to all factors in the dress industry and were reacting injuriously against the public interest." the guild contends in its brief filed with the United States Supreme Court, which was made public here yesterday.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 5 (AP) -Trailing in sixth place going into the stretch, Mrs. Anita King's Son of War surged forward and beat Lassator by a neck in the feature race at Santa Anita Park today.

Hymie Caplin, the ebullient manager of prize fighters, was depicted yesterday in Kings County Court as having received $180 as his "share" in one of several fraudulent card games allegedly financed by Caplin and conducted by a card-sharp ring that swindled its victims of more than $2,000,000 in ten years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Two Cabinet officers replied "No" in effect today to these two questions arising from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's lease-lend hearing:

James C. Penney, chain-store executive, must account to depositors of the City National Bank in Miami, Fla., for losses suffered by depositors when the bank failed in 1930, Federal Judge John C. Knox ruled here yesterday. Counsel for some of the depositors, who brought the suit, said about $3,500,000 was involved.

The British Press Service, quoting The London Daily Telegraph's military commentator, discloses that the capture of Agordat, in Eritrea, was accomplished by forces transported 1,500 miles across country from the vicinity of Sidi Barrani, Egypt, where they had participated in the initial phase of the African offensive.

Manhattan's swimming team defeated St. Peter's, 43 -- 31, in the Park Central Hotel pool last night. The dual meet, which marked the first victory in three starts for Manhattan, was decided by the Jaspers' triumph in the final event, the 400-yard relay.

Objections to the proposed 185-foot ventilation tower at the Battery end of the Battery-Brooklyn Tunnel were answered yesterday before the City Planning Commission with assurances that fumes from the tower would not affect persons in office buildings on lower Broadway.

The output of pig iron in January, according to The Iron Age, was 4,663,695 net tons, compared with a revised figure of 4,547,602 in December. The daily average in January was 150,441 tons, an increase of 2 1/4 per cent over the December rate of 146,697 tons.

MRS. MINIVER rearranged the fire a little, partly for the pleasure of handling the fluted steel poker, partly, no doubt, because the room was no more sultry than Little America, and then she looked at the book again. It was called "The Glass-Blower, and Other Poems,"* and it was by Jan Struther.

BERLIN, Feb. 5 -- A large-scale British attack on the "invasion ports" along the French coast today ended in an overwhelming defeat of the Royal Air Force, according to German reports. Seventeen British planes were shot down, it is asserted, while the attacking force was split up and driven off over the Channel before reaching its objective.

In adjoining columns of the first page of this newspaper yesterday it was possible to read a Democratic denunciation of our Fusionist Mayor and a Republican attack upon our Democratic Governor. Taken together, these two exhibitions were enough to turn any fair-minded citizen into a Mugwump.

The newest Fordham Flash, John Campbell, the sophomore quarter-miler who may become the fastest middle distance runner the Rams ever had, will make his debut in an invitation special a week from Saturday at the New York A.C. games at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The export trade of the United States reached the high total of $4,022,000,000 in 1940 because of expansion of shipments to British Empire countries and Latin America, the Department of Commerce announced today in a further analysis of previously published totals.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- The American Finance Conference has purchased the records and other equipment of the recently dissolved National Association of Sales Finance Companies and is taking steps to broaden its membership rules to admit companies doing a broad general finance business, Thomas W. Rogers, general manager, announced here today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. John Moffat entertained with a dinner in their Everglades Club apartment, taking their guests later to the Patio. Their party included Prince and Princess Alexis Zalstem-Zalessky, Baron and Baroness Vincenzo Lo Monaco, Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. Townsend Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Balthasar Odescalchi, Mr. and Mrs. Chester J. Laroche, Mrs. George Luke Mesker and Oliver Eaton Cromwell.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 5 -- At Paramount Studios, Alfred Santell was named to direct "Aloma of the South Seas" with Dorothy Lamour and Jon Hall; Victor Schertzinger and Stuart Heisler had previously been scheduled for the Santell assignment.

Praised by Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders as being a "success,'' the first experiment in religious education for public school children in New York City began yesterday, with 3,500 boys and girls attending services in churches and synagogues for one hour during regular classroom time.

The ninety-ninth annual report of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, made available today, shows for 1940 net premium income, exclusive of war premiums, of $5,879,118, against $5,355,643 for 1939.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Dissension broke out in the National Football League today over the appointment of Elmer Layden as commissioner of professional football.

The annual honor citations of the Old Timers of the Young Men's Hebrew Association were awarded last night at a dinner marking the sixty-seventh annual meeting of the association at its headquarters, Ninety-second Street and Lexington Avenue.

The new and widespread interest of the average American citizen in current events is largely attributable to radio, Edgar Bill, chairman of the code committee of the National Association of Broadcasters, declared yesterday at a meeting of the committee at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Pressure was maintained on production facilities of war supplies in the United Kingdom during December, the Commerce Department reported today in a review of favorable and unfavorable trade factors. It was reported that the active campaign for enrollment and training of women industrial workers was the highlight of the activity.
Realty activity in Manhattan yesterday included purchases of apartment properties in the upper West Side and Washington Heights sections by investors.

ATHENS, Feb. 5 -- Advices from the front, according to the Press Ministry tonight, indicate that the initiative of battle continues with the Greeks despite unfavorable weather conditions. It was said that one violent attack made against Italian positions resulted in the capture of heights described as "remarkably significant."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General, commenting today on the complaint filed in Milwaukee against ASCAP, stressed as supporting the contention of the Department of Justice that the society is an unlawful combination in restraint of trade these allegations:

The Erasmus Hall basketball team took undisputed possession of first place in Section 2 of the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. by beating Lafayette, 52 to 26, on the Erasmus court yesterday. This gave the quintet a record of five victories in six starts. Erasmus was ahead at the half, 29-10.

Dairy farmers supplying the New York metropolitan area received a total of $109,721,510 in 1940, according to a bulletin issued yesterday by N.J. Cladakis, Milk Market Administrator under the Federal-State marketing plan. It was the first time since 1930, Mr. Cladakis said, that the dairy farmers of the metropolitan area received more than $100,000,000 in a single year.

Although the sextets will be clashing for the sixth time when they meet at Madison Square Garden in a National Hockey League encounter tonight, the Rangers will be seeking their first victory of the season over the Chicago Black Hawks. A 3-3 deadlock has produced the only point the local squad has gained at the expense of the Windy City six thus far, four triumphs being credited to the visitors.
Jercamp Corp. knit goods, floor In 6g3-5 Broadway Frederick Fox Co. brokers. Floridian Products, Inc, in RK0 Building. m Rockefeller Center: Bentley Gardiner and quinlan, Terry Johnson, co-brokers.

After questioning a score of persons and checking a maze of nebulous clues throughout yesterday, Martin Frank, assistant district attorney, said that no concrete theory had been advanced and that the death of Mrs. Catherine Pappas, 29-year-old Sunday school teacher, was still veiled in mystery.

Twenty-four thousand students will return to their classes at City College today, beginning the last half of the college's ninety-second academic year, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, who took office last week as acting president of the school.

Mr. and Mrs. William Kent Dupre gave a dinner last night at their home, 180 East Seventy-ninth Street, for Rear Admiral Clark Howell Woodward, U.S.N., who is retiring March 1, and Mrs. Woodward. The other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Francis Rogers, Mr. and Mrs. Rudolf Bernatschke, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Proctor Cooper, Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Ryan, Miss Irene Denham and Lieutenant George de Metropolis, aide to Admiral Woodward.

The Tammany Assembly district leaders of the Seventeenth Congressional District met yesterday at Tammany Hall and recommended the nomination of Dean Alfange for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson. His nomination by the county committee members of the Congressional district is expected to follow without opposition.

Tenders will be considered on Feb. 14 by officials of Erie County, N.Y., on a new Issue of $3,700,000 of home relief bonds, for which bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds, dated March 1, 1941, will mature serially on March 1, 1942 to 1951.

In contrast to the usual experience at such exhibits, manufacturers participating in the National Business Show at Grand Central Palace reported yesterday that a substantial volume of orders has been written in the exhibit sections. In recent years exhibitors have been content to obtain the names of prospective buyers and to build good-will.

Today's events: "Das Rheingold," first performance in the matinee cycle, 2:30 P.M., and "L'Amore dei Tre Re," 8:30 P.M., Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Gyorgy Sandor, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Anna Antoniades, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; musicale under the auspices of the Music Digest Novelty Club, Studio 800, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

The pending Dunnigan-Wagner bill, requiring a referendum on any fare rise ordered by the Board of Estimate on transit lines owned and operated by the city was viewed by Mayor La Guardia yesterday as a Democratic move to put the five-cent fare issue back into the political arena.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- A bill to regulate the display of billboards throughout the State was introduced in the Legislature today under bi-partisan sponsorship.
