This is not a moment in world history when men's thoughts dwell much on the past glories of English literature. Present danger presses too insistently upon us. Yet it is good to have Professor Copeland of Harvard emerging at 80 from retirement to remind us of that greatness. He is said to have questioned Harvard freshmen, at his famous annual "reading," on such illustrious works as Gulliver's

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Wendell L. Willkie is reported to be seeking the cooperation of Republicans in Congress to effect an agreement on changing the lease-lend bill so that the Republican party can present an almost united front in support of amendments when the bill reaches the Senate.

The efficiency of defense production industries was criticized last night by E.G. Fremont, president of Emerson Engineers, in a paper read at a meeting of the administration group of the New York chapter of the Society for the Advancement of Management.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 -- Miss Grace Amory of Palm Beach will oppose Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R.I., in the final of the annual women's golf championship of Palm Beach tomorrow afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- President Roosevelt today selected the names for ten cruisers now under construction for the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- "Negotiated" financing arrangements between railroads and investment bankers frequently have cost the railroads exorbitant sums, and in some cases led to their receiving very bad financing advice, the Security and Exchange Commission was told today as it closed hearings on a suggested rule substituting competitive bidding for issues for such negotiated arrangements in the public utility industry.

With meat prices inching downward, complaints about high prices from worried housewives have subsided, according to the Consumers Service of the Department of Markets. The Consumers Service is normally the recipient of complaints whenever any price gets out of line and could draw a fever chart of the reaction of the city's shoppers to food prices.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Secretary Stimson prophesied today that the country would soon see an enormous speeding up of airplane production due to preparatory steps which had been in progress for months, and to which, he said, the British and French had made great contributions.
The National Defense Commission has approved an order for $100,000 worth of industrial diamonds from Brazil, according to information reaching foreign traders here yesterday.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 6 -- Mount Holyoke College students questioned Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today on whether the lease-lend bill gave too much power to the President, and received a reply that the controversy over this point was "a good deal of worry about rather little."

The body unearthed last week in the desolate meadows near Lyndhurst, N.J., by workmen employed by District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn was identified yesterday as that of Peter Panto, an insurgent longshoreman whose disappearance eighteen months ago has been attributed to the Brooklyn murder syndicate, it was announced last night at the prosecutor's office.

Every once in a while an intracity game at Madison Square Garden ends in a lop-sided score, but not often. The double-header there the other night did not look like a good match. St. John's and N.Y.U., supposedly two of the stronger local quintets, were playing Manhattan and St. Francis, two of the lesser lights.

A cause for divorce is to be found in hasty marriage, Miss Mary C. Hanlon, parish secretary at the Little Church Around the Corner, Twenty-ninth Street, east of Fifth Avenue, said yesterday. This is the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today that the registration of the capital stock of A. Hollander Son, Inc., fur dressers and dyers, be withdrawn from registration unless the concern:

With perhaps 4,000,000 men under arms in Germany, about an equal number in Britain and 2,000,000 or so Japanese and perhaps 2,000,000 to 3,000,000 Russians in uniform, the world's armies are constantly increasing in size and complexity.

WINNIPEG, Man., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Twelve persons died today in the crash of a Trans-Canada Airlines plane just a mile from the airport at Armstrong, Ont., where it had been scheduled to make a routine landing.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The old haunting fear of uncontrolled inflation was voiced afresh in the House of Commons today when it granted Sir Kingsley Wood, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, vast additional sums with which to carry on this most costly war in Britain's history.

Arthur V. Davis, chairman of the board of directors of the Aluminum Company of America, led a group of seven men prominent in the metals industries of the country yesterday in pleading not guilty to charges of violating the anti-trust laws. The pleas were entered before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe, who released all the defendants in bail of $1,000 each.

China's morale and resistive power are greater now than when she became involved in the undeclared war with Japan forty-three months ago today, Dr. Hu Shih, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday.

The report for 1940 of the United States Rubber Company, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net profit of $11,425,241 after charges, reserves and taxes. The net was equal, after full dividend requirements of $8 a share on the preferred stock, to $3.58 each on the 1,736,092 common shares outstanding.
WINAMAC, Ind., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Captain Richard S. Freeman was on his way to meet his father and brother when he was killed today in the wreck of an Army bomber near Lovelock, Nev.

Kennel aristocrats and distinguished costumes shared the honors at yesterday's fashion luncheon held in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton. Its title was "A Fashion Preview of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show." So far as the dogs were concerned it was in a measure a dress rehearsal for the show that will open Tuesday at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- President Roosevelt has asked the House Interstate Commerce Committee to study ways and means of augmenting oil transportation facilities in the Southeast.

THERE'S a fine muddle in the middleweight division of the boxing industry and maybe something will come of it. Ken Overlin is recognized as champion by the three military gents -- General John J. Phelan, Colonel D. Walker Wear and ex-Private Bill Brown -- who rule boxing in the New York area. Tony Zale is recognized as champion by the National Boxing Association, which takes in far wider territory.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Government deposits increased $614,000 to $27,618,000 in the week ended yesterday, it was shown today in the weekly statement of the Bank of Canada. Chartered bank deposits increased $10,775,000 to $229,536,000, while notes in circulation increased $3,000,000 to $345,256,000.
ATHENS, Feb. 6 -- Notwithstanding bad weather over the entire fighting area during the last few days the Greeks continued operations, although they were perforce on a limited scale.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Acting on the advice of the Surgeon General of the Army, Secretary Stimson has ordered the vaccination for yellow fever of all troops who may be stationed in the tropical regions of the hemisphere or sent there hereafter.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Although he injured his back and required medical treatment before he could continue, the veteran Heinie Manush put together two good rounds of 72 and 73, for a 145, to win medal honors in the qualifying round of the sixth annual baseball players' golf tournament today.

To avoid duplication of effort and reduce expenses, the Belgian Relief Fund, Inc., yesterday surrendered its State Department license, which was obtained on June 5, 1940, and became a new division of Bundles For Britain, organized specifically to continue aiding 20,000 Belgian refugees in England.

The vigor of the Wednesday recovery was not maintained yesterday by the stock market, although values edged fractionally higher in a slightly reduced volume of trading. The inability of the share list to widen the rally by major proportions lent support to the theory that the about-face of the market was a purely technical operation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Charges that medical cooperatives such as the Group Health Association were economically unsound and unable to provide patients with the care they promised were made as the defense outlined its attitude today in the suit whereby the government seeks to have organized medicine convicted of breaking the anti-trust laws by alleged efforts to destroy the G.H.A.

The 1940 annual report of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company, made public yesterday by James Wilson, president, showed a net income of $2,064,941 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This net was equal to 95 cents each on 2,178,250 shares of capital stock outstanding and compared with a net of $2,304,826, or $1.05 a share, in 1939.

After a twenty-four-hour layover in the tiny Portuguese Guinea town of Bolama, Wendell L. Willkie, who is returning to the United States aboard the Dixie Clipper on its first "proving" flight over a new Winter transatlantic route, is scheduled to take off for Trinidad at noon today.

Warners' "Honeymoon For Three," which opens at the Strand this morning, is the only newcomer to Broadway screens today, Ann Sheridan, George Brent and Osa Massen are featured in the comedy, the cast of which also includes William Orr, Charles Ruggles, Jane Wyman and Lee Patrick. . . . "Hay Que Educar A Nini," an Argentine importation, begins an engagement today at the Forty-eighth Street Theater.
FORT DEVENS, Mass., Feb. 6 -- An alert civilian guard put a brigadier general in the "coop" here, none other than the post commander himself, and has been commended for it.

An attractive twenty-four game schedule, the heaviest in recent years, has been arranged for the Fordham varsity baseball team for 1941, it was announced yesterday by Jack Coffey, graduate manager of athletics and baseball coach at Rose Hill.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Thomas Manville, asbestos fortune heir, reported to the police of the town of Mamaroneck today that burglars broke into his estate, Bon Repos, adjoining this city, before dawn this morning and stole $7,500 in cash, two motion-picture cameras, a set of gold-plated dishes, several solid gold cigarette lighters and some trinkets.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Dr. Wilfred C. Blair, 33, a chiropractor, who was inquisitive about science, was found asphyxiated in his office today. Near by was an unfinished chart recording the heart pulse, respiration and temperature caused by dry ice fumes.

WYANDANCH, L.I., Feb. 6 -- One Army aviator was killed, while another escaped with minor injuries after parachuting to safety when fast, new pursuit planes they were piloting on a routine instruction flight crashed and burst into flames after colliding 9,000 feet over this small village today.

Isidore Sternberg, a rotund, middle-aged man with a fringe of gray hair and a jolly countenance, who recalled wistfully that Hymie Caplin, prizefight manager, had brought him a box of cigars from Havana, testified yesterday in Kings County Court that he saw Caplin receive "about $1,611" as his share in a $10,000 card swindle.

When racial discrimination becomes so flagrant as to provoke an appeal to the Legislature by Governor Lehman to remedy it by the enactment of laws, it may be assumed that the situation is a grave one indeed.

The track tourists, en route to the Boston A.A. meet tomorrow, will stop tonight in Philadelphia for the annual Penn Athletic Club games at Convention Hall. The feature will be the Penn A.C. mile, which will see three of the Big Four in action.

ABOARD A BATTLESHIP, With the British Mediterranean Fleet, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Great Britain's war fleet, out and hunting trouble, has just swept a broad area of the Mediterranean without sighting a single hostile dive bomber or warship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The combined productive capacities of the United States and Great Britain cannot build up an air strength in Great Britain to equal that of Germany, much less excel it, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh told the Foreign Relations Committee today.

Building projects submitted yesterday by architects included plans for apartment houses in Manhattan and Brooklyn to be erected at an aggregate cost of $1,500,000. Plans also were filed for various small dwellings.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Ohio State University placed its gridiron destinies today in a youthful coaching staff dominated by men fresh from high school ranks -- and Head Coach Paul Brown declared "I rise or fall" on the selections.
WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, Near Cheren, Eritrea, Feb. 5 (Delayed) (AP) -- The British are prepar-...

LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Bank of England returned 1,850,000 to circulation in the last week, the bank's weekly statement disclosed today. At the same time, 78,000 were added to gold holdings and reserves were lowered 1,771,000.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 6 -- There was a dramatic incident in Ankara station Monday when Colonel William J. Donovan, President Roosevelt's special envoy in Europe, was to have left by train for Palestine via Syria.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 7 -- The Air Ministry and Ministry of Home Security issued the laconic one-line communiqu last night: "There is nothing to report." Nothing, that is, beyond unofficial word of German planes "believed to have flown over the East Midlands, Northeast England, South Wales, West England and East Anglia during the day."

Trailing twice before the game was half over, the Rangers rallied and went on to blast the Black Hawks into defeat in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Paced by the diminutive Clint Smith, who garnered two goals and two assists, the Blue Shirts buried the Chicagoans by a score of 6 to 2.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Premier Ion Antonescu struck at the rebellious Iron Guard with death penalty decrees today as rumors spread that Horia Sima, leader of the revolt of Jan. 21-23, was plotting a new insurrection as a fugitive.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 -- The two-year court battle between Samuel Goldwyn and United Artists, the distributing company of which he is a fifth owner with Mary Pickford, Charles Chaplin, Alexander Korda and the late Douglas Fairbanks, was brought to an abrupt termination here today when Mr. Goldwyn was granted immediate release from his United Artists contract and negotiations were begun for purchase of his stock in the company.

BERLIN, Feb. 6 -- Although official quarters continue to affect an outward show of disinterestedness in the exchanges going on between Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and Pierre Laval through Admiral Jean Darlan, there is ample reason to assume the Germans are completely "in the picture" and fully prepared for any eventuality that may result from the present Vichy government impasse.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 6 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

Benjamin (Benny the Boss) Tannenbaum, gangster aide of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, fur racketeers, who was held in high bail during the Lepke-Buchalter prosecution to prevent intimidation of witnesses and to shelter him from others of the gang, was shot and killed in a terrific struggle last night as he was minding a friend's 4-month-old baby in a ground floor apartment at 40 Featherbed Lane, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- A strike of 750,000 railway workers is threatened over a demand for vacations with pay, George M. Harrison, president of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, said today after he had conferred with President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The United States and Mexico, it was learned authoritatively today, expect to sign a comprehensive "good neighbor" agreement in the very near future, settling all major economic and financial questions now outstanding.

VICHY, France, Feb. 6 -- "A humane solution" to the problem of camps in France, where foreigners are interned for reasons that range from being suspect to being destitute, is promised today by the Minister of the Interior. There are more than 35,000 such prisoners.

An attempt to clear the muddled situation of the world middleweight title will be undertaken tonight in Madison Square Garden, when Billy Soose, Farrell, Pa., challenger for the title, tackles Ernie Vigh of Newburgh, N.Y., in a struggle scheduled for ten rounds.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- A bill designed to curb the publication and circulation of propaganda by un-American groups was introduced today in the Assembly by Jane H. Todd of Westchester.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee has reported out of committee the proposed constitutional amendment increasing the terms of State Senators from two years to four years. Joe R. Hanley, Senate majority leader, indicated today that it was planned to pass the proposal in the Senate next week.

The first big shipment of British-owned wool consigned to an Atlantic Coast port under the huge wool-storage plan worked out between the British and United States Governments late last year, is expected to reach some New England port Feb. 18 on the American-flag freighter Clevedon, now en route from Sydney under charter to the American Pioneer Line.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 6 -- All passengers on the eastbound Simplon Orient Express this morning were obliged by the Italian authorities to leave the train at the frontier station of Domodossola, and were not allowed to proceed any further, it was learned here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Manufacturers of alleged cures for colds have been notified that such products hereafter will be included in the government's program of enforcement of the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, one section of which is designed especially to prevent misstatement or misrepresentation in regard to the degree of benefit to be derived from the use of such medications.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, radiating confidence that the United States and Japan would remain at peace, arrived to the welcom of high military officials today en route to his new post as Japanese Ambassador to Washington.

Advertising of automobiles, household equipment, tobaccos and radio sets and parts was hardest hit in the advertising decline which the war caused in England, according to recent issues of the Statistical Review. Curtailment of production of the heavy items and the switch in tobacco use from Virginia to Turkish were the chief reasons why linage dropped so sharply.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A series of crashes involving Army planes caused the War Department to state tonight that the number but not the rate of accidents had increased because of the expanded operations of the larger air corps.

Setting a four-year high for the month, raw fur sales during December rose to $2,387,450, an increase of 78.9 per cent over the like month of 1939, according to the detailed report issued yesterday by the American Fur Merchants Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Federal Reserve Board's seasonally adjusted index of department store sales remained unchanged in the month of January as the sales showed the usual seasonal decline, the board announced today. The index, based on the 1923-25 average, was 101, the same as December compared with 100 for November and 92 for January, 1940.

wilThe__ Distinguished Flying Cross l be presented at Mitchel Field, L. I., tomorrow at 10 A. M. to Captain William T. Hudnell Jr. by Brig. Gen. John C, McDonnell for [heroism displayed during an aerial flight over Langley Field, Va., on April 23, 11940, it was announced here yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 -- Mr. and Mrs. Fenn Orletson Stone gave a musicale tonight at their home on Palm Island to aid the Musicians Club of America, of which Miss Bertha Foster, dean of music at the University of Miami, is president. Guest artists were Frank Mellor, tenor, and Warner Hardman, pianist.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses succeeded yesterday in blocking the proposed sale of playground property in Brooklyn owned by the Board of Transportation.

There is no cause for satisfaction in the statistics of death by accident during 1940. The 4 per cent increase reported by the National Safety Council brought accidental deaths for the year to 96,500 and marked the first increase over a preceding year's figure since 1936. Injuries, at 9,100,000, showed an increase of some 300,000 as compared with 1939. The principal categories of motor vehicle, home and occupational accidents all showed marked increases in fatalities.

The plan to wind up the whole American Guide Series of forty-eight State volumes pushes on. At the start of the year there were fourteen to come. On Monday Hastings House will bring out the Colorado book and ten days later Oxford will issue "South Carolina: a Guide to the Palmetto State."

Skiers face another good weekend, according to reports from northern points. With few exceptions, satisfactory skiing should be found by the many thousands who will start tonight for popular resorts extending from the Poconos in Pennsylvania to the Laurentians in Eastern Canada.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 7 (UP) -- A warning to South American nations that they might be unable to repulse a German attack "even with the aid of the United States Navy" if Brtain falls was broadcast across the Atlantic today by the Minister of Shipping, Ronald H. Cross.

Police Commissioner Valentine issued a statement yesterday praising District Attorney Dewey for the cooperation he had given the police in the gambling case against Louis Schreiber, Republican leader of the Fifth Assembly District South, in the midtown district, and two men with police records, accused of running a gaming house in Schreiber's Active Republican Club.

State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr. withdrew yesterday as a candidate for the Republican nomination for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District. A special election to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson will be held March 11.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 -- Production on the long delayed "Let the Rafters Ring," a British war charities film, which RKO will release, will get under way March 3, with Frank Lloyd directing the opening sequences, Sir Cedric Hardwicke, producer of the picture, announced today.

Miss Dorothy Riddell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Riddell, gave a luncheon yesterday at Hampshire House for members of the junior committee of the New York Diet Kitchen Association, who are aiding in the plans for the pre-opening performance of "The Mechanical Heart," with Ina Claire and Philip Merivale, next Monday night at the Henry Miller Theatre for the benefit of the association.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- Some 500 participants in the sixth annual Chicago World Trade Conference here today heard Wayne Chatfield-Taylor, Under-Secretary of Commerce, and other speakers advise American manufacturers to concentrate more heavily on Latin America for export outlets in a world disrupted by war.

Wendell L. Willkie was urged yesterday to lead German-Americans in the path of true democracy and of opposition to Hitlerism in a telegram sent to him by the German-American Congress for Democracy, 295 Madison Avenue.

"Boudoir," a play by Jacques Deval, will have its opening this evening at the John Golden Theatre. It was to have opened last night, but the illness of Else Argal, one of the three leading players, caused postponement. Featured with Miss Argal, who is the wife of Mr. Deval and is making her American debut in the play, are Helen Twelvetrees and Taylor Holmes.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Charles H. Talcott Jr., 31, a New York architect, was held for the Superior Court today on a charge of manslaughter arising from the death of his wife, Hope, in an automobile accident on Dec. 10.

The program presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Bruno Walter, last night in Carnegie Hall, promised more in anticipation than came to fulfillment. Much might rightfully be expected of a list led off by Ernest Bloch's symphonic suite, "Evocations," performed here for the first time, and also featuring the Schumann piano concerto with Josef Hofmann as soloist.

The twelve Federal intermediate credit banks in 1940 extended credit amounting to more than $500,000,000, a new record and exceeding the 1939 volume by more than $40,000,000, according to an announcement by A.G. Black, governor of the Farm Credit Administration.

Stockholders of the Union Potash and Chemical Company will meet on March 11, at Denver, Col., to approve a proposed agreement of merger with the International Agricultural Corporation, which owns 94.89 per cent of the preferred and 55.86 per cent of the common stock of Union Potash.

BERLIN, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A commentary service reflecting German Foreign Office opinion said today that the United States could not escape part of the responsibility for suffering in the occupied territory if it did not seek to make the British lift the blockade against shipments of food and medicine to Belgium, France and Poland.

A goal of $1,000,000 was fixed yesterday for the fund-raising activities of the Friends of the New York State Soldiers and Sailors, an organization established to aid in providing entertainment and recreation for men in military and naval training.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 6 (AP -- Muddy fairways and slick greens at the Willow Springs golf course began baking under a bright sun late today -- and that was all the touring professional band needed to burn up the place on the eve of the Texas open.

VICHY, France, Feb. 6 -- With Admiral Jean Darlan again in Paris, bearing the Petain government's reply to the terms of Pierre Laval for returning to the Cabinet, the trend in official quarters has again veered tonight toward "collaboration" with Germany in the construction of a "new order in Europe."

Mounting governmental expenditures, if continued in this country, will bring confiscatory taxation that will mean the end of savings and other private property and eventually will lead to a state of collectivism, William A. Irwin, educational director of the American Institute of Banking section of the American Bankers Association, declared yesterday.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 6 -Political parties commenced today to line up candidates for the Senate and Chamber of Deputies in the llarch 2 general elections.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 6 -- The National Guardsmen of the Forty-fourth Division paused in their training today while a group of sixty-one officers took the measure of their progress as fighting men since their entrance on Sept. 16 into Federal service as a part of the Army of the United States.

One of the jurors deliberating on the evidence against Max L. Hymes, former Controller of the Movietone News, Inc., charged with grand larceny and forgery in a seventy-two-count indictment, collapsed yesterday evening as the jury returned to the Criminal Courts Building after the supper hour.
In the midst of much current debate on the extent to which American aid should he extended, it seems pertinent to consider several points which should form the basis of such aid.

Detective Francis A. Campbell, known in the Police Department as Dudie and a guardian of the law in Greenwich Village for almost thirty years, retired last midnight, closing a career in the department that began April 14, 1903.

In the New England and Middle Atlantic States public sentiment, as measured by a survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion, is favorable to the President's lease-lend bill by a fair-sized majority, but opinion in the East Central States is much more evenly divided.
John Graham, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, in 24 Central Park South; Pease Elliman, Inc, brokers.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe came from behind twice tonight to maintain his sensational undefeated record in world championship three-cushion billiard tournaments.

VICHY, France, Feb. 6 (UP) -- Richard Allen, American Red Cross director, said today at Marseille that if the British were satisfied with the distribution of the United States shipment of foodstuffs and clothes to France, due on Feb. 19, another relief ship would be allowed to pass through the blockade in March.
BERLIN, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6 -- Leading from start to finish of the featured Country Club Prado Purse, William Woodward's Bolivar triumphed by a length and a half at Hialeah Park today. In gaining his third successive victory on the grass he paid $6.90 for $2.

ROME, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Several hundred students, shouting, "Down with Democracy!" and crying vivas for Benito Mussolini, Adolf Hitler and Italy's King, marched today from the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier through Rome's principal streets toward the United States Embassy but turned into a side street without passing the embassy itself.

Describing the supply of food as a "bright spot" in the defense program, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, told members of the Home Makers Forum yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor that there was an abundance of food, in fact, a surplus.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- While official circles here would not comment for publication on the action of the Belgian Government yesterday in attaching $260,000,000 worth of French gold to replace Belgian gold being surrendered by France to Germany, it was admitted frankly that it was in line with the intention of the United States Government to see that national moneys were not reft from the hands of their rightful owners by force of arms.
ROME, Feb. 6 -- Giovanni Ansaldo told the armed forces today in his bi-weekly broadcast that not everybody on the home front was taking a properly serious view of the war.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith yesterday told business and professional men who will aid the 1941 Catholic Charities Appeal in this city that they must "get busy early and make a special effort this year, because the international situation will be responsible for many small contributors paying their first income tax next month and the bigger fellows will have to meet increased taxes for national defense."

President Ed Barrow of the Yankees yesterday professed greater interest in receipt of a signed contract from Gerald Priddy, rookie infielder, than in news that Joe DiMaggio was returning his contract unsigned. In fact, the veteran executive refused to discuss the possibility of a DiMaggio holdout.

FARGO, N. D., Feb. 6 -- Quadruplets, three boys and a girl, weighing a total of 17 pounds and 9 ounces, were born today in St. John's Hospital here and have a more than even chance of surviving, according to the attending physician, Dr. J. F. Hanna of Fargo.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 6 -- The first regional conference of the River Plate countries closed today after signing nine conventions, one recommendation and sixteen resolutions. Members of the Latin-American diplomatic corps enthusiastically describe the conference as one of the most successful inter-American assemblies ever held.

Net earnings of General Motors Corporation before income and excess profits taxes last year were the highest in the history of the company, according to a preliminary annual report for 1940 made public yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the company.

The Grace liner Santa Rosa will sail today for her regular cruise to the West Indies and Venezuela via Bermuda. Among her passengers are Ralph R. Stubbs, Mr. and Mrs. Nelson C. Holland. Johnston De Forest, Miss Priscilla De Forest, Mrs. Mercedes Lara, Mr. and Mrs. John C. Townsend 2d, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Dean, Campbell Scott and Mr. and Mrs. C.F. Purdy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission having approved previously dissolution of the Aviation and Transportation Corporation and transfer of its assets to its subsidiary, the Aviation Corporation of New York, the latter corporation filed today a registration statement covering 1,445,555 shares of its capital stock of $3-par value.

A business building will be erected in the Rockefeller Center area as the result of an all-cash deal yesterday involving the Waldorf Theatre property at 116 West Fiftieth Street. The site, which is 100 by 100 feet, in the block just west of the RCA Building, was sold by the Greenwich Savings Bank to an investor.

MONTREAL, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings, staging a brilliant three-goal rally in the last four minutes of the third period, gained a 4-4 overtime tie with the Montreal Canadiens tonight to protect their hold on third place in the National Hockey League.

The suit of the National Bank of Belgium to attach $260,000,000 of funds of the Bank of France here as a means of restraining France from delivering to the Germans a like amount of Belgian gold held in Dakar, French West Africa, has disclosed some very interesting facts, which help to illuminate recent events and conditions abroad.

The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday that it had bought the half interest in the American Magnesium Corporation formerly owned by the General Aniline and Film Corporation. As a result of this transaction, the American Magnesium Corporation now becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of the Aluminum Company of America.
Cotton futures fluctuated yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange within a narrow range and closed 2 to 5 points higher. Although trading was quiet the market had a steady tone.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 6 -- With entries from four countries and thousands of visitors from dozens of States, the thirty-first annual Winter Carnival of the Dartmouth Outing Club will get under way tomorrow morning. Today the men of Dartmouth worked long hours putting the finishing touches to the stage setting after weeks of preparation for the event.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Senator George ordered the Foreign Relations Committee room cleared of spectators this afternoon when the audience broke into applause at the close of testimony of Hanford MacNider, who spoke in opposition to the Lease-Lend Bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- One of the most dramatic episodes in the lease-lend fight was a polite battle of wits today between Colonel Lindbergh, opponent of the British aid bill, and Senator Carter Glass of Virginia, who would like to "shoot hell" out of the Nazis.

The public conferences conducted by the Securities and Exchange Commission on the question of compulsory competitive bidding for new securities of registered utility holding companies and their subsidiaries ended yesterday. The SEC probably will take several weeks in reviewing the testimony presented at these conferences, which consumed four and a half days, before making a decision on just what type of rule will be adopted.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 6 -- Maintaining discreet silence, Colonel William J. Donovan, American observer, today affably declined once more to reveal the impressions of his journey so far as political matters are concerned or divulge his small group of newspaper men here.

Back at the desk after two weeks of intensive checking on the Southern hunting and fishing, we are confronted by a stack of mail that brings some punishment for the trip. As usual, there are several letters that bear interesting news now stale, and other letters inquiring about events that are now over.
The stage was set for some particularly good matches in the Monte Sterling squash tennis tourament at the New York A. C. this evening as the brackets were filled in the fourth round last night.

VICHY, France, Feb. 6 -- The last train bearing troops repatriated after internment in Switzerland arrived in France today. The total number of men thus brought back is given as 28,000, but there are still on Swiss soil "non-French elements" whose fate is in the balance. These are mostly Poles.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 6 -- Only a small fraction of the total number of civilians put to death in the parts of Europe where the "new order" reigns can, of course, ever be known. The following is a record, published in the Nazi press, of Nazi killings and death sentences on six days of this month in only four of the thousands of towns and villages under their control. These amount to twenty.

Henry Schnakenberg has completed a set of murals for the postoffice at Fort Lee, N.J., and they will be shown, until Feb. 21, in the large second-floor gallery of the Art Students League, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. The murals are exhibited by courtesy of the Section of Fine Arts, Public Buildings Administration, and through arrangement with the Kraushaar Galleries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- After demonstrating today its ability to write the terms of the lease-lend bill to aid Britain and her Allies, the Democratic side slipped a cog and permitted tentative adoption of an amendment designed to give Congress the power, through concurrent resolution, to rescind at any time any or all powers sought to be given to the President to effect his program.
Pierre Laval does not want to reenter the Vichy Cabinet through a back door and to take a back seat. The Germans are coming out for him in full force.
BERLIN, Feb. 6 -- A German newsreel this week shows pictures taken by a German war correspondent aboard an auxiliary cruiser during many months of operations at sea.

Board of Education officials were much concerned yesterday at the distribution of "question-mark" pins and registration blanks to children who attended the religious education classes that began Wednesday. Steps for the discontinuance of this practice are being planned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The nomination of John G. Winant, New Hampshire Republican, to be Ambassador to Great Britain was sent to the Senate today by President Roosevelt, together with nine other nominations involving shifts or additional duties for key American diplomats.

Three pioneer clubwomen, two living and one dead, were honored yesterday by selection as the candidates of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs for national honors during the triennial of the golden jubilee celebration of the General Federation of Women's Clubs in Atlantic City next May.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 6 (UP) -- Italian motorized columns tonight were reported to be fleeing from Bengazi, Libya, to escape encirclement by Britain's Army of the Nile.

A recommendation that grocery and tobacco dealers of the State support the model unfair sales bill sponsored by the National Food and Grocery Conference Committee, was made here yesterday by Gilbert H. Montague, attorney designated by the grocery and tobacco interests to act as arbitrator and decide what form of "loss leader" bill should be offered by them at the present session of the Legislature.

The winners of the three literary fellowships of $1,200 each awarded annually by the publishing house of Alfred A. Knopf to assist writers with "work in progress" toward the completion of their projects were announced yesterday by Mr. Knopf.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $6,376,944,000, the largest since the first week of this year, according to Dun and Bradstreet, Inc. Transactions in the twenty-three leading cities throughout the United States in the current period increased 17.3 per cent over clearings of $5,436,249,000 in the same week a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate the nomination of John G. Winant to be Ambassador to Great Britain, and other nominations in the diplomatic service; signed the bill providing funds for building 200 cargo ships for the merchant marine, and conferred with George M. Harrison, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Clerks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Chairman Walsh made public today a list of 127 strikes in defense industries during the last year compiled for the Senate Naval Committee by Secretary Knox. The report said that at least a part or temporary settlement had been effected in 100, but twenty-seven were still in progress Monday.

I suppose you haven't walked home with your wife through a Blitz. You haven't seen soldiers with their tin hats slung behind, unwilling to wear them while civilians walked without. You haven't heard wardens discussing football while shrapnel fell around them, or seen policemen and firemen going about their business with dirty, cheerful faces.

Leading a discussion at the monthly meeting of the State Chamber of Commerce at its headquarters, 65 Liberty Street, yesterday, William J. Schieffelin Jr., chairman of the chamber's taxation committee, urged that the high excise taxes on liquor, tobacco and gasoline be reduced if it becomes necessary for the Federal Government to impose a retail sales tax to meet the cost of the national defense program.

BERLIN, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The High Command declared today that German bombers in widespread raids on important military targets in England last night caused many fires and considerable damage to shipping in coastal waters.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Western Pine Association, fifty-nine lumber corporations and fourteen individuals were fined $81,500 today after they had entered pleas of nolo contendere to charges of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

Announcement was made yesterday afternoon in a broadcast over station WNYC that a merger has been effected by which the American Water Color Society and the New York Water Color Club become henceforth one organization, to be known as the American Water Color Society.

A struggle in a dentist's office at 1 Seaman Avenue at 10:30 o'clock last night between four policemen and two alleged hold-up men ended with the latter subdued and one of the policemen accidentally wounded slightly.

LOVELOCK, Nev., Feb. 6 -- A huge, four-motored Army bombing plane, equipped with experimental apparatus to reduce hazards of Arctic flying, smashed into Ragged Top Mountain today, killing its crew of eight.
OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 6 -- With the acceleration of the Commonwealth Air Training Plan, Canada is outstripping the United States in producing trained air crews, Air Minister C.G. Power said today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Hog prices closed 10 cents lower today as receipts of 21,000 head overshadowed demand. Top was $8.10, with the bulk of choice 180 to 240 pound hogs bringing $7.80 to $8.05. Lack of choice offerings slowed cattle trade, with a few weighty steers topping at $13.75. After a slow opening, fat lambs closed actively and 25 to 35 cents higher.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Following is the text of the statement prepared by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh for his appearance today before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee:...

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date, while total bills discounted were at the lowest.

Municipal bond men were advised yesterday that officials of Dade County, Fla., who were prepared to consider yesterday bids on a total of $6,000,000 of new bonds, had deferred action on two proposals submitted until 1 o'clock today. According to information received here no actual bids for the bonds, as offered, were received by the county officials.

By rising $20,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $1,963,000,000 commercial loans of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City touched the highest level since Nov. 24, 1937. These figures, as revealed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, indicated that this was the largest weekly gain since the week ended on Now. 13, 1940.

The young woman who seeks the greatest happiness in life will not make marriage a full-time career, but will look upon it as a part-time job, Dean Herman Feldman of the School of Business and Civic Administration of the College of the City of New York said last night in the baccalaureate address at the seventy-ninth commencement exercises of Hunter College, held in the college's assembly hall, 695 Park Avenue.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- British methods of propaganda are catching up, if they have not already caught up, with those of Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels of Germany and will surpass them in the end, Alfred Duff Cooper, the Minister of Information, told the House of Commons today.
The strong and active dry goods market continued unabated yesterday and new price advances were made without discouraging buyers from adding to their commitments.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 6 -- While Royal Air Force bombers continued their raiding in the area around Bengazi, the British land forces still were pressing the Italians back toward that last Fascist stronghold in Eastern Libya, Although Bengazi does not possess elaborate fortifications like those at Bardia and Tobruk, it is expected that the Italians will make every effort to defend it because it is an important air and naval base.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- While operations today in the wheat market were mainly of a professional character the market was fairly active at times with the new crop months showing relative strength. Prices advanced 5/8 to 1 cent a bushel early, the former on May, which showed 2 1/2 cents above the low on Tuesday.

TRENTON, Feb. 6 -- New Jersey's relief bill for 1940 was $13,738,326, or $5,577,676 less than the State and its municipalities spent in 1939, when the needy received $19,316,022, it was reported today by Charles R. Erdman Jr., director of the State Municipal Aid Administrator.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission, investigating services of the New York Central Railroad, heard today that the system was "continuously improving" its facilities even though it had "suffered a great decline" in passenger traffic revenues.

MADRID, Feb. 6 -- The bread shortage neared a crisis today when the newspaper Madrid admitted that Spain had more bread during the Civil War under the Republican regime and explained that the Republicans had ships to bring in wheat.

Revivifying many customs of entertainment in old Russia, the thirteenth annual Russian Students Ball was given last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza under the auspices of the Russian Alumni and Students Association to aid the Russian Student Fund. A percentage of the proceeds will be donated also to Friends of Greece, Inc., of which the Grand Duchess Marie of Russia is chairman. She was an honorary patroness of the event.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The British have long been prepared for the appointment, announced at Washington today, of John Gilbert Winant as United States Ambassador. They were anxious as to when he would come.

Federal Judge Edward A. Conger handed down a ruling yesterday that may cast doubt on the legality of millions of dollars in loans made by companies operating under the Small Loans Laws of New York State. Judge Conger held that a borrower who took out a new loan from a company to which he already owed money and used part of the second loan to pay off the first, need not repay the second loan.

The decree to enjoin allegedly monopolistic practices by fourteen leading carpet manufacturers, sought by the government and consented to by the manufacturers, was entered in Federal court yesterday by Judge Murray Hulbert The Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, Inc., and an official of each of the corporate defendants also were named in the decree.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 6 -- A surprising strike by 1,500 grooms shut down the $3,000,000 Santa Anita race track today.

ARMSTRONG, Ont., Feb. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Twelve persons died in the dark of early morning when the Trans-Canada Airlines passenger plane plunged to earth today near this small town in Northwestern Ontario, on the north shore of Lake Nipigon.

A total of 453 men were inducted into the Army yesterday at the city's two induction centers for a year's training under the Selective Training and Service Act. This is fifty-two more than were inducted here Wednesday. Of this number 331 were from New York City, and 122 from Westchester, Nassau and Up-State counties.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 6 -- While Royal Air Force bombers continued their raiding in the area around Bengazi, the British land forces still were pressing the Italians back toward that last Fascist stronghold in Eastern Libya, Although Bengazi does not possess elaborate fortifications like those at Bardia and Tobruk, it is expected that the Italians will make every effort to defend it because it is an important air and naval base.

ROME, Feb. 7 -- The Italian people were prepared for bad tidings today when the war bulletin announced that "a violent battle is taking place between our troops and enemy formations in the South Bengazi region." They know by now that that can mean only one thing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The marked acceleration of business activity noticeable at the end of 1940 continued during January, it was announced today by Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones. It was stimulated by the larger volume of defense expenditures, the increased flow of private capital investment and a steadily increasing consumer demand accompanying the rise of employment and income payments.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 7 -- Caught in the jaws of a well-timed British pincer movement, the Italians yesterday gave up Bengazi, the last important Fascist stronghold in Eastern Libya, British headquarters announced today. Australian troops occupied the city in the wake of British armored-car units.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 -- Nearly 1,500 persons, the largest throng ever assembled at the Everglades Club, filled the Orange Gardens, dining hall, patios, lounges and terraces tonight for the British War Relief Ball given by the employes of Palm Beach estates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order today authorizing Clarence A. Dykstra, director of Selective Service, to designate what work of national importance could be given to drafted men conscientiously opposed to non-combatant as well as combatant service, and to assign men to such work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Two New Yorkers told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that entry by the United States in the European conflict would bring on civil war in the country, and that the internal struggle would probably start in New York City.

Willie Mosconi lengthened his lead in the world pocket billiard championship by winning both his matches yesterday. Playing at Scranton, Mosconi defeated Onofrio Lauri, 125 -- 82, in eleven innings and 125 -- 49 in six.

THE routs and victories in the long struggle for American civil liberty, from colonial times to the present, are traced by Mauritz Hallgren in a rambling yet revealing new book called "Landscape of Freedom."

Bonbright Co., Inc., and Lazard Freres Co. offered yesterday after the close of the market a block of 100,000 shares of common stock of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company at 28 1/4 a share. The stock did not represent British-owned securities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The lease-lend bill was denounced and its defeat demanded by the American Youth Congress, which opened tonight three-day sessions here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Twenty of the twenty-four directors of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers talked with Department of Justice officials today about the anti-trust proceedings against the society in Milwaukee. No decision was reached and the conference will continue tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Private bankers with wide interests in Latin America and government officials reached today a "general agreement" on controversial questions involving the charter of the proposed $100,000,000 Inter-American Bank in a three-hour meeting at the State Department.

A fifteen-hour strike of the 600 drivers employed by the North Shore Bus Company in Queens, called yesterday at 4:30 A.M. without warning to patrons of the company's twenty-five lines centering on the rapid transit terminals in Flushing and Jamaica, forced an estimated 195,000 commuters to use emergency transportation, during the rain-drenched morning and evening rush hour periods, to travel to and from their jobs in Manhattan and Queens.

VICHY, France, Feb. 7 -- General Maxime Weygand, in a broadcast from Algiers, has proclaimed to North Africa that France has not agreed to and will never agree to the occupation of Bizerte or any other part of Tunisia.

Twenty-two graduates of the Harlem Hospital School of Nursing last night received, along with their diplomas, the congratulations of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who made the graduating address in the Mother Zion African Methodist Episcopal Church, 140 West 137th Street.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 7 -- A superb performance in the downhill race on Moose Mountain this morning saved Dartmouth from near disaster today as competition started in the thirty-first annual Winter carnival of the Dartmouth Outing Club.

Willie Hoppe playing for the three-cushion billiard championship in February, 1941, sounds in the ears of an older generation almost as if Jean de Reszke were going to sing tonight at the Metropolitan or Grover Cleveland were about to send a special message to Congress.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 7 -- French travelers arriving from Constanta report increasing concentration of German troops south of the Danube. Along a stretch of road only ten kilometers in length between Constanta and Mamaia they passed more than 800 German trucks.

There was a slight improvement yesterday in the general demand for fresh meats. Out trading was spotty; only fair to slow for the most part. The strike at one of the larger local slaughtering plants was still in effect. Steer hinds and ribs grading average choice and setter were steady; other grades, weak.

Benjamin Tannenbaum, a lieutenant of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, who was slain Thursday night in a Bronx apartment as he watched the 4-month-old baby of the family with whom he lived, was linked by police yesterday to the Brooklyn murder syndicate and to local and up-State gambling and industrial rackets.

An emergency campaign for funds to send additional air-raid equipment to Great Britain was organized yesterday at the headquarters of the British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. William Armour, chairman of the women's division of the society, announced that twenty-eight team captains and seventy-three team workers had been enlisted.

Despite the fact that prices of materials and merchandise are tending to rise and a scarcity of some commodities is developing there has been comparatively little "scare" advertising by either manufacturers or retailers, urging the public to buy now.

Construction of subways in New York has necessarily been chiefly through congested sections. Because of frequent delays and the length of time needed for the intricate building operations, much land taken by the Board of Transportation for new subways has thus far been of limited permanent use at the surface.

New York State members of the United States Conference of Mayors began yesterday to rally opposition to the Gittleson bill in the State Assembly, which provides that any Mayor may be examined before trial in any litigation to which his city is a party.

After nearly two hours of discussion the Republican Assembly district leaders and co-leaders of the Seventeenth Congressional District postponed yesterday the selection of a candidate for Representative, to run for the vacancy caused by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson, until after the return of Wendell L. Willkie.

Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, Inc., announced yesterday that directors of the company had declared a dividend of 20 cents a share on the common stock. In 1940 three dividends of 15 cents each were paid. The regular quarterly dividends on the first and second preferred shares also were declared.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A statement that no legislation to cope with labor-industry disputes in the defense industries was required at this time because the situation had been satisfactory so far, was made today by Sidney Hillman, Associate Director General of the Office of Production Management.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's remarks before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, authoritative quarters here said today, revealed the clarity, courage and strength of character of the American airman, not to mention his cleverness.

A torrential downpour of rain, reaching 2.63 inches at 7:30 P.M., swept the metropolitan area and the Middle Atlantic Coast States yesterday afternoon and evening in one of the worst local floods in years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Jan. 25 was 2,743,800 shares, compared with 2,970,530 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

VICHY, France, Feb. 7 (UP) -- Italy sent a secret envoy to Vichy this week with an urgent appeal for aid in removing 80,000 Italian colonists, including 15,000 women and children, from Ethiopia, where they face possible massacre by Ethiopians supporting Britain's invasion of Italian East Africa, it was understood reliably tonight.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 7 -- Snuggled deep in an overcoat he shed during shots, Johnny Dawson, meticulous Hollywood amateur, pulled a three-under-par 68 out of a frigid wind today to lead the Texas open golf tournament's first round.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 7 -- Bulgaria's foreign policy will be continued along the lines laid down by Premier Bogdan Philoff in his Rustchuk speech, Foreign Minister Ivan Popoff declared today in a speech to the majority party of the Sobranje (Parliament).

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Besides the $616,000,000 of marketable securities that Britain still holds in the United States and the $900,000,000 worth of direct investments that it is planned to sell to a syndicate of American investment trusts, the British Government is trying to sell to the American Government for ready cash the plants and tools whose erection they financed in connection with their war orders.

Despite the stand of the American Youth Congress, in session at Washington this week-end, the majority of the young people of America strongly favor the draft, aid to Britain and the principle of the lease-lend bill, according to studies of the American Institute of Public Opinion made public yesterday by Dr. George Gallup, director of the organization.

Retail trade here continued active this week. Most department stores and specialty shops had gains in volume over the like week last year. The average rise for department stores was estimated as better than 10 per cent, with one report indicating a gain of 12 to 13 per cent.

The report of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and subsidiaries for 1940, made public yesterday, shows a net income for the year of $3,035,606, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to $4.63 a share on 656,000 capital shares outstanding, and compares with a net of $2,707,672, or $4.13 a share, in 1939.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- UFA, Germany's leading motion picture producing, distributing and exhibiting concern, reported today that the fiscal year 1939-1940, which ended on May 31 last, was a banner year. The gross turnover was 166,180,000 marks, against 142,410,000 in the previous year, and net profit was 1,700,000 marks, against 470,000.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company and associates bought yesterday a total of $5,824,000 of six-months temporary-loan notes of four local housing authority agencies of the Territory of Puerto Rico at 0.69 per cent. The obligations, dated Feb. 21, and maturing on Aug. 21, included the following: $2,440,000 of Puerto Rico, $1,095,000 of Capital of Puerto Rico, $795,000 of Mayaguez, Puerto Rico, and $1,494,000 of Ponce, Puerto Rico.

The annual father-and-son review of the Knickerbocker Greys, junior military cadet corps of boys from 8 to 14, was held amid surroundings of military reality last evening in the drill shed of the 107th Infantry (Old Seventh) Armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

SEATTLE, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted the Western Washington Wholesale Grocers Association, twelve of its member firms and twelve individuals today on charges of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act by combining to fix arbitrary and unreasonable prices for staple groceries in Washington and Alaska.

VICHY, France, Feb. 7 -- There is every reason to believe that the Moslem world has definitely sided with Britain, at least morally. When the extent of Moslem influence in North Africa is considered, this development has untold possibilities.

Far-reaching revisions in the examination procedure for selection of teachers in the New York City school system, to include greater emphasis on character and personality traits, and the introduction of an internship program were recommended yesterday by the Association of Assistant Superintendents.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Rules Committee deferred action today upon a request to send to the House floor a resolution continuing the Dies Committe for another fifteen months.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Feb. 7 -- Why do our American cousins persist in mailing their friends and relatives in this country food and fruit and such luxuries? Our food supply and rations are ample to subsist on, so why take valuable shipping space for unnecessary luxuries?
Here are some additional notes on boomerangs which might prove interesting to readers of John Kieran's column on them recently:

Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie, who declined to make speeches during her husband's campaign for the Presidency, will take the microphone this afternoon under auspices of the Active Citizens League for her initial public utterance over WABC of the Columbia Broadcasting System, from 2:30 to 3 o'clock.

It seems to be generally recognized that "breakage" in the betting system at our race tracks is an unfair tax on the public. In an effort to remedy the evil it has been suggested to bring the "payoff" down to the nearest penny.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Collaboration among nations after the war should be broader than merely between the United States and Great Britain, John G. Winant, newly appointed Ambassador to the Court of St. James, said today after a conference with President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Major Al Williams said today the United States armed forces possessed no single-seater fighting plane that could "hold a candle" to the British and German pursuit ships clashing in combat over England today.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Newspapers today described John G. Winant as "the first doughboy Ambassador to the Court of St. James."

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- Percy William Olaf De Wet, 28-year-old Englishman, was sentenced to death by the people's tribunal in Germany today after two days of secret trial for espionage. De Wet is the first British spy reported caught by the Germans on Reich soil since the war began.

To honor Ignace Jan Paderewski, more than 7,000 musicians, orchestras, schools and clubs have planned programs during the week of the National Paderewski Testimonial, next Saturday to Feb. 22, it was announced yesterday by the Testimonial Committee organized to further celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the Polish pianist's American debut.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- On the evening of March 17 President Roosevelt will dedicate, almost within the morning shadow of the Capitol dome, a National Gallery of Art which, it is hoped, will some day be one of the great repositories of the art treasures of the world.
Italo Montemezzi, the composer of the last opera of importance to come from Italy, conducted that opera, which is his own "L'Amore dei tre re," last night in the Metropolitan Opera House.

Bearing Wendell L. Willkie homeward after his survey of war conditions in England, the Dixie Clipper made its first take-off from Bolama, Portuguese Guinea, at 12:19 P.M. (E.S.T.) yesterday, according to Pan American Airways at La Guardia Field.

CAIRO, Egypt, Saturday, Feb. 8 (AP) -- A desperate Italian attempt to crash through a British cordon south of Bengazi, Libya, ended in disaster with all Italian resistance wiped out, it was officially reported today.

Still working on the theory that the murderer of Mrs. Catherine Pappas, 29-year-old Sunday school teacher, was a burglar who gained entrance into her apartment at 1035 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, under a subterfuge, the Bronx police have sent out an eight-State warning in connection with the crime.

The Columbia Steel Company announced yesterday the approval of a program for the enlargement of its facilities involving an expected expenditure in excess of $5,000,000, to be begun in the near future. The company is a subsidiary of United States Steal Corporation and is located on the Pacific Coast.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- Scoring his third major victory in the East this Winter, Walter Mehl, the Wisconsin speedster, captured the premier laurels in the Pennac Mile, highlight of the fourth annual Penn A.C. invitation games held before 6,000 fans in Convention Hall tonight.

DENVER, Feb. 7 (UP) -- Representatives of thirteen Western States, at a "Governors' Council on State Rights," voted tonight unqualified opposition to any proposal for creation of "power yardsticks" similar to the TVA anywhere west of the Mississippi River.

Striking differences are shown in the figures on United States exports for the first and second halves of 1940, the line of demarkation being Italy's entry into the war and the French armistice. In the earlier period we were still trading with most of Continental Europe, which took 26.2 per cent of our exports, while thereafter the ratio dropped to 4.3 per cent.

New records for safety were set up by companies operating in this area during the sixteenth annual accident prevention campaign of the Associated Industries of New York State, A.J. Passage, secretary of the Metropolitan Industrial Safety Committee, reported yesterday.

Shipments of United States currency abroad in January amounted to $341,000 and receipts from abroad aggregated $792,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York State found yesterday, on the basis of reports to it from the principal commercial banks.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 7 -- The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company has applied to the Federal Communications Commission for permission to acquire control of the Eastern Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Camden and Atlantic Telephone Company and the Keystone Telephone Company of Philadelphia, Frankland Briggs, vice president and general counsel of New Jersey Bell, disclosed here today.

LOVELOCK, Nev., Feb. 7 (UP) -- The Army flying fortress which crashed yesterday, killing the eight members of the crew, had brushed off most of its tail assembly against a foothill peak a mile and a half from where it finally smashed into a desert mountain and exploded, it was revealed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The limit on defense articles to be sent to Britain and her allies, it was made plain, does not affect the amount or value of goods or services, aside from defense articles, that could be loaned, leased or given under the bill now being considered by the House. There was practically a stipulation to this effect in the debate between the two sides in the House today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A Federal inspector warned in October that there were fire and explosion hazards at the factory of the New Haven Quilt and Pad Company at New Haven in which ten lives were lost by fire Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Roosevelt told reporters today that John G. Winant probably would leave for England, where he will be the new United States Ambassador, in about ten days.
This world is full of surprises.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP) -- B. M. Jewell, secretary of fourteen major railroad labor unions, said today that strike ballots would be sent to 750,000 employes of Class I railroads on Feb. 15. The decision to ask a strike vote on demands for vacation with pay was reached by leaders after George M. Harrison, union head, had conferred with President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The text of a letter by Secretary Stimson, sent to the Foreign Relations Committee today and upholding the policy of furnishing fighting planes to Great Britain, is as follows:

BERLIN, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Germans are paying an annual wartime tax bill of 34,000,000,000 marks out of the 100,000,000,000-mark national income, E.W. Schmidt, director of the Deutsche Bank, reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Roosevelt joshed reporters today about getting "mugged" and fingerprinted for new identification cards that will allow them to enter the White House.
The Franklin and Marshall College swimming squad of Lancaster, Pa., beat City College, 52 -- 23, in the Beavers' pool last night.

As a result of opposition raised by Board of Education officials, no more "question-mark" buttons will be distributed to children attending the weekly religious education classes conducted by the Catholic, Protestant and Jewish groups in this city, it became known yesterday.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Wagner's "Das Rheingold" received its first performance of the season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, as the initial event in the Wagner-Mozart matinee cycle. The prologue to the "Ring" trilogy has always been the least popular part of the monumental work, yet it attracted a sold-out house at this latest presentation, as it always does when presented in these annual uncut productions of the music dramas.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Santa Anita race track resumed operation today after a one-day shut-down brought on by 1,500 striking grooms. With more than 20,000 fans in the park, the day's program went off without a hitch.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 7 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued the following special communique today:

The all-metal, low-wing Airacobra is a single-seated pursuit monoplane said to be the most radically designed in the United States and, perhaps, in the world. Built by the Bell Aircraft Corporation of Buffalo, N.Y., the plane has been accepted as type P-39 by the Army Air Corps. The War Department restricts data on the craft's cost and rate of production.

William Wilson, Building Commissioner, told the Council Committee on Buildings yesterday that he favored the elimination of "special privileges" conferred on Isteg Steel Bar, a patented article, by the Building Code of the city.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Admiral Baron Mineo Osumi, Japanese Supreme War Councilor, has been killed in the crash of a naval plane in Kwangtung Province, China, the Navy Ministry announced today.

"Night Train" will enter its seventh week today at the Globe. . . . "They Met on Skis" begins the eighth week of its engagement at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. With the exception of "The Human Beast." which ran for nine weeks at that house, this is the longest run of any French film there since 1938. . . . "Personal Column" starts a second week today at the Little Carnegie Playhouse.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A united Republican stand on the lease-lend bill seems improbable at this juncture despite the conviction that Wendell L. Willkie hopes for non-partisan action on the measure.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 7 -- Proceeds of the Relief Wings Mercy Ball, which was held tonight at Colonial Inn, in near-by Hallandale, will aid airplane service for disaster relief, sponsored by Relief Wings, Inc., in this country and China.

On Jan. 25 a reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES asked: "Why doesn't the Port Authority offer commutation rates at its Hudson River crossings -- the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels and the George Washington Bridge?" The answer lies in our business judgment based upon experience.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- An eight-inch railway gun set on the first heavy mounting to be built for the Army by a private plant since 1916 left the Baldwin Locomotive Works at Eddystone today for the Aberdeen proving ground.

Because W.E. Hutton Co. and associates in a secondary distribution of stock of the Raymond Concrete Pile Company made stabilizing purchases in contravention of rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission and were careless in their preparation of SEC forms, the New York Curb Exchange yesterday fined the Hutton firm $250 and reprimanded its member partner.

Some time tomorrow a returning traveler is expected to reach this city, bringing with him impressions such as few men have had an opportunity to collect in a short period of time. It is barely two weeks since Wendell Willkie set out on a trip to England that was planned and undertaken almost at a moment's notice.

In the face of warnings by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, three separate acts of violence were reported yesterday in the labor dispute between two associations of poultry dealers and the Poultry Drivers Union, Local 167, of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in January totaled $29,029,588,225, a drop of 5.4 per cent from the returns in December, but larger by 8.8 per cent than in January, 1940. January clearings were the largest for that month since 1937.

The fall of Bengazi marks the end of the first phase of the British campaign in North Africa. It has come more quickly than was generally expected, although, after Derna surrendered and the Army of the Nile moved on, the ultimate fate of the capital of Eastern Libya was sealed. For reasons of prestige if for no others, however, Marshal Graziani was counted upon to make a stand there.

Consumers will pay an additional 50 to 60 cents or more a quart for popular brands of whiskies here Monday, if hopes of retailers, wholesalers and distillers materialize to end the price war which began last August. All divisions of the liquor industry were confident yesterday that the days of the price war were numbered and evidenced a willingness to cooperate in stabilizing the market.

ATHENS, Feb. 7 -- The good condition of the Greek finances at present and also the extent to which British economic aid has made this possible was revealed by Alexander Varvaressos, Governor of the Bank of Greece, in a speech before the general council of the bank made public today.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- Authoritative German quarters continue to preserve discreet silence relative to the negotiations between Pierre Laval and Marshal Henri Philippe Petain. Germans, nonetheless, declare it is "self-evident that both parties to the internal French dispute are keeping the Reich informed" as to their conversations."

The summons and complaint in the Supreme Court suit by the National Bank of Belgium to recover $260,000,000 in gold or its equivalent from the Bank of France, in return for an equal amount of Belgian gold in French hands which is being delivered to the Germans, were served yesterday upon Jean Martial, local representative of the Bank of France.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 8 -- Bad flying weather, marked by fog, overcast skies and southwest winds over the Strait of Dover, appeared to be on Great Britain's side this morning as this country enjoyed comparative peacefulness after a day of sporadic raids yesterday, during which bombs caused several casualties and some property damage.

On his way home after a workout at a neighboring gymnasium, Emil Nizich, 26 years old, an unemployed longshoreman of 426 West Forty-eighth Street, whose friend, Thomas Cunniff, was shot and killed on Jan. 25, was himself slain by a gunman at 8:20 o'clock last night in front of 410 West Forty-eighth Street, between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

Business and industrial activities this week showed little change from the recent record levels, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Retail trade remained at the highest level for the season in eleven years and many stores which until a few months ago favored hand-to-mouth buying were covering on some staples through the year-end.

All eight seeded players remained in the running as the fourth round of the Monte Sterling squash tennis tournament was completed at the New York A.C. last night. William Hoffman of the Bayside Tennis Club, seeded No. 1, scored an impressive triumph over J.K. Fitzgerald of the home club, 15 -- 3, 15 -- 7.

VICHY, France, Feb. 7 -- Those Jewish civil servants ousted from their posts under the law decreed last Oct. 3, whose length of service did not entitle them to a pensions, will receive compensation at the rate of two months' salary for each year they served. The final fraction of service will be reckoned as a full twelve months regardless of what its duration may have been.

Gyorgy Sandor, Hungarian pianist, who appeared in a recital at Carnegie Hall last night, has the temperament and technique to be one of the foremost virtuosi of the day. He made that clear in his first appearance in this city two years ago, and he reinforced the impression in his second New York program last night.

BIZERTE, Tunisia, Feb. 7 -- On the air waves we hear from London, Ankara and New York that the Germans are massing men and planes in Sicily for an attack on Bizerte. From London both the regular British Broadcasting Corporation and "Free French" broadcasters assert that within the next two weeks North Africa will become a hot spot.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Prime Minister Churchill is going to broadcast on Sunday at 9 P.M. [3 P.M. in New York], it was announced here today. The reason for this broadcast, the first worldwide one the Prime Minister has made for some time, was not revealed.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP) -- William Labrot's Stormy Weather was an overwhelming favorite today to defeat four other yachts in the first test of the Winter yachting series, the Sir Thomas Lipton Challenge Cup race to Nassau starting tomorrow.

The executive board of the Woman's Auxiliary of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church began a three-day meeting yesterday at the council's headquarters, 281 Fourth Avenue. They represent the church at large through eight delegates chosen at the triennial meeting last Fall at Kansas City, all but one of the eight provinces of the Church and four national affiliated groups.

The thirty-ninth annual American Toy Fair will be held for wholesalers from March 10 to 15 and for all classes of buyers from March 17 to 29, it was announced yesterday by Horatio D. Clark, manager of the fair. Five floors of the Hotel McAlpin will be occupied by the toy displays, in addition to showings in permanent showrooms at 200 Fifth Avenue and 1,107 Broadway.

Helen Keller announced yesterday that she had resigned, "grieving," as honorary national chairman of the American Rescue Ship Mission, for which she was instrumental six months ago in obtaining the sponsorship of Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt and other outstanding figures.

Samuel Zemurray, president of the United Fruit Company, reported yesterday to stockholders in the forty-first annual statement that net income for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 4, 1941, amounted to $14,920,736 after depreciation and taxes and without United Kingdom or other European earnings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Roosevelt conferred with John G. Winant, newly appointed Ambassador to Great Britain; William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Thomas H. McDonald, Public Roads Commissioner.
