MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 7 -- Seventeen fillies and mares have been named for tomorrow's stake, the newly established Black Helen Handicap, at Hialeah Park, but it is probable that as much interest will be shown in the 1941 debut of Whirlaway held by many to be last year's juvenile champion, as in the stake.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Heavy rains which forced the Golden Gate Turf Club to postpone opening its new $1,500,000 track five times drove the club into Federal court today to seek a moratorium on its debts.

ROME, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Criticism of President Roosevelt's aid-to-Britain program, particularly that by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, took precedence in Italian newspapers today over everything except news of the fighting in Africa.
Britain's war of manoeuvre across the African deserts has achieved a climactic victory. With the fall of Bengazi nearly all of Eastern Libya is in British hands.

Princess Aimee Crocker Galatzine, prominent in society and literary circles during the latter part of the last century and heiress to gold and railroad fortunes, died of pneumonia yesterday in her apartment at the Hotel Savoy Plaza. She was 78 years old.

Race Relations Sunday will be observed tomorrow and annually under the auspices of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, set for the Sunday before Lincoln's Birthday. Sermons in the city's churches will be preached on Abraham Lincoln.

The United States liner Manhattan, which was floated Monday afternoon off a sandbar three miles north of West Palm Beach, Fla., on which she had been aground since Jan. 12, started for New York at 2:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
BERLIN, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The recent prohibition by the Canadian Government of import of certain goods from the United States will cause a certain dislocation of American export trade to Canada but not reduce its total volume, which may be greater this year than ever, according to a Commerce Department statement.

The annual literary sweepstakes between the two Boston publishing houses of Little, Brown and Houghton Mifflin over a course of sales records has been won for last year by Little, Brown. The race turned out with photo-finish closeness, however.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Sharply decreased supply led to rise in hog prices today. With only 6,000 salable hogs in the market in addition to 3,000 shipped direct, prices moved 15 to 25 cents higher in active trading. Top was $8.30. Only 700 salable cattle were available, with little choice in the run.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Skip R.D. Thomson's Schenectady Curling Club rink opened its defense of the Gordon Grand National Medal today by defeating the Caledonians of New York City, 18 -- 4, to reach the semi-finals.

TOKYO, Feb. 7 -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka opened the peace conference between Thailand and Indo-China this afternoon with an emphatic reaffirmation of Japan's Greater East Asia policy. In response Prince Varnaidyakir Srisena invented a new phrase, "Prosperity for each, stability for all," to describe Thailand's conception of Japan's policy.

New York's projected new aquarium in Bronx Park, to replace the antiquated structure at the Battery, will be a new institution, embodying modern exhibition technique to present from an educational, scientific and recreational point of view the panorama of aquatic life, it became known yesterday.

Trust Jacques Deval to entitle his drama "Boudoir." Although he is writing in English he has not forgotten that he is French; and the people who saw his play at the John Golden last evening must try not to forget that he is also the author of "Mademoiselle," "Her Cardboard Lover" and "Tovarich." For "Boudoir" is solemn buncombe, steeped in sin and written in English that sounds like a foreign language.

Civilian residents of the city will be taught the use of gas masks and the control of home fires of incendiary origin under a program announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner McElligott. The Fire Department will begin sessions of its school for control of incendiary and explosive bombs as well as war gas on Monday morning in the Fire College at 32-02 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City.

This has been a big year for the devotees of skiing. Late in starting, the season has turned out to be an exceptionally good one at slopes near New York. Farther afield, where Winter does not greatly change its immemorial habits -- at Saranac, Franconia Notch, Stowe and the other Vermont runs, the Maine ridges and, of course, the famous Canadian slopes -- excellent snow conditions have been steadily available.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 7 -- Plainly stating its "intention" to have horse racing with pari-mutuel betting in New Jersey this year, the State Racing Commission today ordered the Monmouth Park Racing Association to act immediately if it desired to hold the only permit issued for a meeting.

VICHY, France, Feb. 7 (UP) -- A government spokesman said today that Colonel William J. Donovan, President Roosevelt's representative, had been denied a visa to cross Syria en route from Turkey to Palestine because "we don't want any foreigners going through Syria."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court took under consideration today litigation to test whether the City of Indianapolis must assume financial responsibility for obligations of the Indianapolis Gas Company, estimated at $45,000,000 over a period of seventy-seven years beginning in 1935.

A few days ago the second of the Air Corps' flying fortresses to be lost this Winter smashed into Ragged Top Mountain, near Lovelock, Nev., with the loss of the eight officers and men in its crew. Ironically, this particular four-engined bomber had been equipped with experimental apparatus designed to reduce the hazards of Arctic and high-altitude flying.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- United States production of Britain's new Hawker Tornado pursuit plane, one of the most efficient fighters in the world, was reported today to be under serious consideration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- United States exports of iron and steel in 1940 were 25 per cent larger than in any previous year but exports of scrap were less, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Casey Stengel, the team's manager, and Max C. Meyer, Brooklyn business man, will be among the leading stockholders in the Boston Bees, if negotiations between Bob Quinn, president of the club, and a syndicate organized by Stengel are successfully completed.

There appeared in your issue of Jan. 25 an editorial, "The Mortgage Moratorium," calling for a "tapering off" of the situation. May I say that while the editorial is correct in so far as it goes, the situation is far more complex than it appears at first blush.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that he would ask Congress at this session for authorizations to carry out a post-defense public works program designed to lessen the effect of economic repercussions which are expected to follow the end of the war.

March 8 has been set as the closing date at the St. James for "Twelfth Night," in which Helen Hayes and Maurice Evans are appearing. This was announced yesterday by the Theatre Guild and Gilbert Miller, sponsors of the revival.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 7 -- Metro added two new properties to its schedule today: "Johnny Eager," a story of a paroled convict by James Edward Grant, and "Two Women," a modern drama, which Robert Z. Leonard will produce and direct. Leonard, who has been with the studio for seventeen years, has been signed to a new contract.

New bond financing this week aggregated $62,138,000, with the railroad field taking the lead with a total of $34,088,000 in new securities placed on the market. New bond offerings last week amounted to only $18,240,000, the smallest for any period so fax this year, while flotations during this week a year ago amounted to $34,073,000.

ROME, Feb. 7 -- The Ministry of Agriculture, controlling food rationing in Italy, inflicted heavy penalties today on twelve fashionable Rome restaurants charged with serving spaghetti and rice to customers without clipping ration cards.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 7 -- In a driving rain that did not abate all day, the field artillery units, the engineers, and quartermaster regiment underwent field inspection today, the second of a three-day examination of the Forty-fourth Division.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Undefeated Willie Hoppe advanced another step toward his second straight world three-cushion billiard title with a 50-to-38 victory tonight over Art Thurnblad of Kenosha, Wis., in fifty-four innings.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Angel A. Gonzalez, ousted chief of the Cuban Navy, landed at Miami today and declared he had no ill feeling toward President Fulgencio Batista.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 7 -- Four thousand New Zealanders who are receiving preliminary education as air force crewmen resumed their studies this week, it was revealed by Defense Minister M.F. Jones today. This almost doubles the number who were schooling at the end of the year.

Two of the country's better basketball teams, Duquesne and Long Island University, will collide in the feature attraction of the double-header in Madison Square Garden tonight before what may develop into a capacity crowd. Possibly the winner will go on to become the undisputed champion of the East.

The complicated problem of satisfying the immediate requirements of United States Customs regulations regarding the vast amount of foreign treasures exhibited at the New York World's Fair in 1939 and 1940 is "96 per cent completed," an official of the fair's department of imports and exports reported yesterday.

ROME, Feb. 7 -- The United States Embassy was guarded all day today by hundreds of Italian soldiers while students again demonstrated against "the plutocracies" in other parts of Rome. There has been nothing so potentially ominous here since the series of demonstrations that preceded Italy's entry into the war against Great Britain.

Delegates from the country over will assemble in the Far East room of the Hotel Vanderbilt at 1 P.M. today for the sixtieth annual meeting of the United States Lawn Tennis Association. When adjournment is reached, the probability is that they will have enacted some of the most important legislation written into the by-laws in many years.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Prices of wheat fluctuated today within a range of about 1 cent a bushel decline. The market opened on scattered selling by professional operators and then rallied late in the session on short covering and closed 1/4 to 3/8 cent higher.

Charging that the undergraduate newspaper, The Vanguard, at Brooklyn College is run as a dictatorial, closed corporation that follows the policies of left-wing groups at the college, Arnold Rivkin, president of the student council, demands in a special report made public yesterday that a complete reorganization of the paper be undertaken.

Governor Lehman had highest praise for the administration of the selective service in New York State yesterday when he made his first inspection tour of Selective Service Headquarters here and called upon Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, director of New York City Selective Service, 331 Madison Avenue.

It is a good thing that the United States Conference of Mayors under the able leadership of Paul V. Betters is pushing ahead on the problems of passive defense. Preparations for such defense cannot, as he points out, depend on "eleventh-hour improvisation."

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 7 -- After a depressed opening, a recovery set in on today's Bourse under the lead of A.K.U. Dutch issues, nevertheless, closed to 4 points lower. A.K.U. rose 1 point to 102 1/8 after touching 99. Royal Dutch declined 3 1/8 points to 240, Amsterdam Trading, 7 to 411; Amsterdam Rubber, 1 3/4 to 262 1/2, and shippings as much as 4.

The cotton market here held yesterday within a narrow range with trading confined almost entirely to the trade. The market, however, maintained a steady tone and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 3 points off.

While I still have the enjoyable memory of a great sports spectacle before my eyes, I want to say that I think the New York sports writers and sports fans are missing a real treat in professional basketball.

The Appellate Division unanimously denied permission yesterday to Louis S. Levy to appeal to the Court of Appeals from the Appellate Division's action on Nov. 22, 1940, in disbarring Mr. Levy as an attorney in the State courts.

Last year the General Motors Corporation had the best year in its history. After meeting all expenses, including the cost of material, the wages of labor and various other charges, the company had net earnings of $320,600,000, a record high. This was the amount out of which it had to pay normal income taxes and excess profits tax and provide for dividends to the stockholders.

Attired in their skiing apparel, four "riders" of the Royal Norwegian Air Force, accompanied by Captain Ole Reistad, one of Norway's most distinguished all-around sportsmen, arrived yesterday from their training base at Toronto for the twentieth anniversary jump that the Norsemen S.C. will hold at Salisbury Mills, N.Y., tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UP) -- Former President Hoover said today famine and pestilence were on "the march" in Europe and would take a death toll this Winter greater than during all four years of the last war unless some method for feeding the victim nations can be worked out.

The stock market regained yesterday its easier tone after an interlude of two days of stronger prices and, with the volume of trading reduced to the smallest since mid-September, closing values were irregularly lower. A slight firming-up in the final hour, when transfers reached the best totals for any period during the session, saved quotations from ending at the worst points of the day.

Three members of the Brooklyn fur-swindling racket received prison sentences yesterday and two others were fined $500 each by Supreme Court Justice John MacCrate in ]rooklyn. The sentences substantially followed the recommendations of Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen in seeking to aid those who had helped his inquiry.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 7 -- Yale's powerful swimming team toppled Dartmouth from the unbeaten ranks in the Eastern Intercollegiate League series before a Winter carnival crowd today. The score was 47 -- 28.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Another gun in the feud with President Roosevelt was fired today by Senator Wheeler, who suggested that the President urge his "friends" on the Senate Audit and Control Committee to approve funds for a special investigation if he is "so anxious about finding out who is aiding Germany."

Few decisions of the Supreme Court have been of such far-reaching practical importance as that handed down by a four-man majority this week in the case of officials of the carpenters' union charged with violation of antitrust laws. The facts of the case do not seem to be in dispute.

DETROIT, Feb. 7 -- Nearly 10,000 potential fifth columnists have been identified and placed under surveillance, State police revealed today. Cataloguing of 9,374 suspects has been done in the first five months of work by a new division set up "to combat subversive activity," Commissioner Oscar G. Olander said.

The ninety-sixth annual report of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, filed yesterday with the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance, shows total admitted assets on Dec. 31, 1940, of $751,540,298, a gain of $37,622,625 over the figure a year before.

Toward 11 o'clock last night in Madison Square Garden Ernie Vigh discovered the most effective way of fighting Billy Soose of Farrell, Pa., who is feathery on his feet, graceful, and fast with his left hand in ring combat.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 7 -- The shadow of the European war hung over the United States Naval Academy today as 396 graduates received their diplomas four months earlier than usual and heard Secretary Knox say that they were going "to help occupy the western world's first line of defense" against those who would make this "a slave world, subject to the imperial will of ruthless dictators."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A committee for the coordination of inter-American shipping was established today to insure adequate tonnage for movement of products between the United States and other American republics.

David Rosen, manager of the Cosmopolitan Bridge Club when it was raided by Police Commissioner Valentine's confidential squad on Nov. 17, 1939, in a large suite on the second floor of the Hotel Ansonia, Broadway and Seventy-third Street, paid a $500 fine under protest yesterday in Special Sessions to avoid a thirty-day workhouse term on his conviction last Dec. 19 for common gambling.

The engagement of Elmer Layden as a "czar" for professional football is a move that should benefit the game greatly. As a great player and a successful coach, as well as a likeable personality, Layden should command the full respect of his constituency and may be relied on to administer professional football's affairs intelligently and efficiently.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Britain has made her first claim to command of the air by bringing about an entire change in tactics. This week we have started for the first time massed fighter patrols over the Continent, which will now continue without stop until the R.I.F. (Royal Invasion Force) is ready to step in where the Royal Air Force leaves off.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The price of insulin and the control of its manufacture will be investigated by the Department of Justice to see if a monopoly exists, it was stated today in a reliable quarter.

Opposition to the lease-lend bill was expressed yesterday by Mrs. Robert A. Taft, wife of the Ohio Senator, after a talk by Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, former American Minister to Norway, who declared that she was opposed to the isolation of the United States.

The Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, of which the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick is the pastor, will begin tomorrow a celebration of the hundredth anniversary of the church organization and the tenth anniversary of the present edifice on Morningside Heights.

St. John's Prep and Bishop Loughlin scored their ninth triumphs in ten Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. starts yesterday to share the lead with St. Francis Prep again. St. John's routed Brooklyn Prep, 52 -- 19, and Loughlin handed St. Michael's a 25-to-15 setback.
Below are given comparative nominal quotations on standard constructions of carded gray cloths, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Anna Antoniades, Greek pianist, was heard in her first Town Hall recital last night by an enthusiastic gathering. Her exacting program commenced with the Bach-Busoni organ toccata in C major, which was followed by Beethoven's sonata in F minor, Op. 57, and the first book of the Brahms Variations on a Theme of Paganini.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 7 -- In a judgment affecting more than 600,000 trade unionists, the full arbitration court of three judges today unanimously refused to increase the basic wage declared in 1937. Australia's uncertain economic outlook was the reason given, but the court ordered a fresh application be made after June.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company agreed tonight to meet demands of the striking United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., concerning procedure for removing from the plant completed equipment "vitally needed" by the War and Navy Departments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today that a hearing be held at its New York regional office on Feb. 25 to determine whether the Allender Company, Inc., of 42 Broadway, New York, an over-the-counter firm, had violated the Securities and Exchange Acts and if so whether its registration should be revoked or suspended.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The United States and the self-governing Dominion of New Zealand are planning to establish direct diplomatic relations, it was learned today, in a move characterized as presaging closer collaboration in the South Pacific.

ANNISTON, Ala., Feb. 7 -- Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commanding the Twenty-seventh Division, gave frank warning in an address here tonight that the chances are against his men returning to their homes in the Fall after completion of a year's training.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- Without explanation, the Third Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today ordered reopened and reargued The Newark Ledger case in which it held in a precedent-setting opinion on Monday that the National Labor Relations Board did not have the authority to enforce collective bargaining contracts once they had been signed.

ATHENS, Feb. 7 -- The British Royal Air Force has resumed operations over the Albanian front. According to an official announcement, British bombers attacked military targets west of Tepeleni and in the region of Kranas near Berat yesterday Bombs were said to have been dropped on military storehouses, wooden barracks and a concentration of motor trucks.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- The Army Quartermaster today awarded contracts for 500,000 yards of 36-inch olive drab, wind-resistant poplin cloth, bids on which were opened here on Jan. 30.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Administration leadership tonight suggested and the House quickly adopted a sharp limitation on the extent to which, under the lease-lend bill, President Roosevelt may transfer to other nations American military and naval equipment already on hand or appropriated for.

Word has reached Broadway that former Mayor James J. Walker is going to try his hand once again in the field of lyric writing. This time it will be for a musical comedy "Rhapsody of Night" due to be produced in September. The story is by Geza Herczeg and the melodies by Robert Stolz.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- The second and most important of the three Chicago Spring market weeks, ending today, saw an increase in attendance that averaged 20 per cent above last year, with Association of Commerce officials predicting a total registration of 22,500 before the market closed.
BETHPAGE, L.I., Feb. 8 -- Francis Fox, 13-year-old Boy Scout, lost his life today while trying to save an 8-year-old chum from drowning.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The lease-lend bill for aid to Great Britain and her allies, was passed by the House late today on a roll-call vote, 260 to 165.

The Museum of Modern Art's Educational Project now has in circulation twenty-nine rotating exhibitions, to which it is constantly adding new ones. Although this is one of the important activities of the museum, it is little known to the general public, since the work is done directly with the secondary schools and with young people of that age.

Bundles for Britain, the nationwide war relief agency established by Mrs. Wales Latham to send medical and surgical supplies, woolen clothing and other needed articles to Great Britain, will mark the completion of its first year of activity at a gala "First Anniversary Party" Wednesday afternoon in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The fete is under the honorary sponsorship of Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President.

Market activity during the past week centered on staple and semi-staple goods in anticipation of delivery delays, it was reported yesterday in a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A situation in which the United States recognizes Vladimir Hurban, Czecho-Slovak Minister, as the representative in Washington of his country, but does not recognize any existing Czech government was marked this week by the appointment of Anthony Drexel Biddle Jr. to represent the United States in London before four refugee governments.

Police, court, educational and civic spokesmen took issue yesterday with Justice Herbert A. O'Brien of the Domestic Relations Court and William J. Goodwin, Queens Democratic leader, who testified in Washington on Friday that this country's entry into the European war would precipitate civil war at home, beginning possibly in New York City.

AMONG the signs of the times, notice that some writers for the stage are becoming restless with the familiar stage forms. In "Liberty Jones" Philip Barry uses music and dancing to help point a dramatic theme. Moss Hart also uses music and dancing to enrich a psychological study of character in "Lady in the Dark."

Two important specialty exhibitions today will usher in Westminster Week. The Associated Terrier Clubs will give their joint show in the Grand Central Palace, while the Boston Terrier Club of New York will hold its thirty-third annual competition in the Park Central Hotel.

A step forward in strengthening American ideals among foreign-born women is found in the fact that during the last two years seven such organizations were admitted to the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs. They represent several hundred women who, through their club affiliations, are working to acquaint themselves with a better understanding of the language and customs of this country.

The backbone of radio always has been music -- operatic, classical and jazz. On the major networks 50 per cent of the programs are devoted to melody and on the independent stations the percentage is even greater. Experience has shown that there can be just so much talk -- in the form of speeches, plays and quiz programs -- before the radio listener twists a dial in search of song.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Recommendations for the personnel of an advisory committee to cooperate with the State Education Department in planning defense training and National Youth Administration programs came today from the department.

"PEOPLE OF THE VALLEY" is not a novel for every one. One can scarcely imagine its rocketing into the best-seller class, and probably it would not, without a great deal of expert tinkering by script writers, make a very good moving picture.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A total of 5,110,270 persons over 14 in the nation were seeking but unable to find employment on April 1, 1940, the Census Bureau reported today. Of these 963,028 were between 14 and 19 years old, 1,035,474 between 20 and 24, 1,800,567 between 25 and 44, 1,157,428 between 45 and 64 and 153,773 aged 65 or older.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 -- Declaring it to be "foolish and dangerous" to assume that the Axis powers, if victorious in the war, would have "no designs upon this hemisphere," forty-nine persons prominent in Philadelphia business and professional life sent an open letter to Congress today urging it to act "swiftly and fearlessly" in providing effective aid to Great Britain and other countries now "holding the Axis tyrants at bay."

AMID the darkness of our time there is something sublime about a foolish mind. For nearly four decades there has trundled across the American stage a motley-attired fellow whom people call "the perfect fool." Clad in tramp shoes, crazy-quilt coats of brilliant hue and headgear that must have come from the shop of the mad hatter, he has looked upon the mundane antic with the perpetual and delighted amaze of the village idiot.

THIS book was long in coming. The better part of twenty-two years went into its making. Its author, now Professor of Esthetics at Antioch College, has been collecting material for this truly colossal undertaking since 1918 and has been engaged in the actual writing of it for the past five years.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 8 -- Miss Priscilla Alden Egleston, daughter of Major Gen. Nathaniel Hillyer Egleston, in command of the 102d Coast Artillery Brigade, and Mrs. Egleston of Elizabeth, was married to Ogden Winne Sutro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Sutro, this afternoon in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Lytleton E. Hubard performed the ceremony.

JAN VALTIN'S right ear isn't much good. He was slugged on that side, he explained, with a loaded club. He illustrated by slapping his knife against his head. "Cr-rack!" he said, and laughed. The ear looks all right but in order to listen efficiently to an ordinary conversational tone he must turn his head so that his left ear will be in range.

To initiate its legislative work this season, officials of the New York State League of Women Voters will assemble in Albany tomorrow for a two-day legislative conference. Miss Ruth W. Ayres of New York, who was elected last Spring to head the organization, will preside.

WHAT so well-qualified an expert as Motor Vehicle Commissioner Michael Conner of Connecticut has called "the best safety article of the year" has come out of the Gilbert High School at Winsted, the town whence so many oddities of nature used to drift into newspaper offices.

THE largest appropriation ever requested by the Federal Communications Commission -- $4,259,729 -- has been voted by the House of Representatives in passing the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill. This represents an increase of $1,883,000 over the 1941 budget.

THE interviewer chews a pencil and admits the ground has been pretty vell covered by his predecessors; study of the morgue has answered most of the questions he planned to put; but wait, a cloud no bigger than a man's hand shows on his horizon; ah, what about this?

If you chance to be strolling along Lexington Avenue next Saturday after a hearty luncheon and are jostled off the curb at Forty-sixth Street by a small band of Micmac Indians in full war paint, don't mark it down as a figment of your digestion. Just bear in mind that the National Sportmen's Show is opening that day in Grand Central Palace.

Anne O'Hare McCormick's article in a recent issue raises many interesting points on the problem of Russia's position in the war. There seems little doubt that Stalin's most earnest wish is that neither side should win. In any case, a German victory is the last thing he wants.

THIS is a bitter book. Dean Swift's fiercest indictment of humanity was not more painful; since it could, to some extent at least, be discounted because of the savagery of the satire. But this is not satire.

Warning that a serious educational crisis is on the way, and might arrive in this country within the next two or three years, Dr. Donald DuShane, president of the National Education Association proposed yesterday the formation of a teachers' defense commission to ward off threatened attacks on the public schools.

Max C. Meyer, Brooklyn manufacturer who is interested in the purchase of the Bees in the National League, said last night on returning to his home from New England that he had depositd a sum of money in a bank as part of a plan whereby he and Manager Casey Stengel will acquire the stock of Charles F. Adams, who holds a controlling interest in the club.
The Associate Alumnae of Hunter College will hold its annual breakfast in celebration of the college birthday on Saturday at 12:30 P.M. at the Hotel Astor.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 8 -- W.B. Simpson's Gen'l Manager scored a surprising triumph today in the $10,000 added San Carlos Handicap, while the heavily backed favorite, Mioland, ran to defeat for the first time in five starts in the seven-furlong feature at Santa Anita Park before 27,000 turf fans.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Three young American conscientious objectors to military service are working at civilian rehabilitation in England and others are to follow them, Dr. Thomas E. Jones, national director of Civilian Public Service, said in an interview today.

THIS portrayal of Mrs. Bernstein's childhood in the New York of the Nineties goes far toward explaining her career as a leading scenic designer, though doubtless there was no intention to prove that the girl is mother to the woman, or to prove any thesis, for that matter.

Dr. E.U. Condon, associate director of the Westinghouse Research Laboratories, recently told the American Institute of Electrical Engineers that atomic power from uranium has a sporting chance of running our machinery. He spoke of a mad atomic world where "speed laws" were needed to control tiny particles and where "robber" atoms were 140 times more numerous than "producers."

A concert in the interests of the British war relief work being conducted by the New York branch of the English-Speaking Union will be given this afternoon at the headquarters of the sponsoring organization at 30 Rockefeller Plaza. The artists will be Leslie Frick, mezzo-soprano, and Alderson Mowbray, pianist.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Decisions of the Supreme Court such as those of last Monday in the wage-hour and labor anti-trust cases call to attention the great change of view which has come over the court within the past five years.

THE person who is writing this article would have preferred to have had his role as backer of "Arsenic and Old Lace" remain a secret, but there seems to be quite a hullabaloo about it, as though it were a kind of seven-day wonder that this person should part with a little dough once in a while, or take a flier in the world of make-believe.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies Government approved today an export licensing system applicable to thirty countries for the avowed purpose of preventing raw materials from reaching "enemy" nations.

NOT all the Dust Bowl refugees became Joads and moved in on California. More than 450,000 of them have come up here into the Inland Empire, settled on cut-over timberland in Western Montana, Northern Idaho, Eastern Oregon and Washington, and are now doing a pioneering job of major proportions.

Perhaps the fundamental purpose beneath three notable education conferences this month is the desire of educators to bring themselves up to date. They may not agree wholly with a statement once made by Professor Carl Brigham of Princeton, that "people in education are usually from twenty to fifty years behind the crest of the tidal wave of knowledge"; but that they are aware of a lag and the need for overcoming it is apparent.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies -- L.A.L.J. Kusters of the Netherlands Indies Department of Posts, Telegraphs and Telephones has disclosed the effects of the European war on the postal paper of this colony (philately's Dutch East Indies), Surinam in South America and Curacao in the West Indies.

About 150 Japanese, mostly women and children, of the New York colony will return to Japan in March and April, sailing from San Francisco, it was learned yesterday. The local offices of the South Manchuria Railway Company, 60 East Forty-second Street, and of Kanebo, Inc., one of the largest cotton manufacturing companies in the Far East, will close, according to present plans.

"Piute was a hell's broth of a town" that stunned young Cole Armin with its wildness when he arrived there from his Texas ranch. He had been summoned by his "uncle" Craig Armin to become manager of a freighting business that moved 85 per cent of the ore from the surrounding mines.

When, if ever before, has a late and unlamented tone poem of Franz Liszt, "Von der Wiege bis zum Grabe," been performed at a major symphonic concert in this city? Mr. Toscanini, who ever and anon discovers some little known page of a master and introduces it to his audiences, presented this work as the novelty of the concert by the NBC Symphony Orchestra, which he conducted last night in Studio H-8 in Radio City.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- Visitors to the United States Military Academy reservation today found its extensive athletic plant humming with activity as cadet teams faced collegiate opponents in nine branches of sport competition and won six of eleven contests.

Greenpoint, in New York's Borough of Brooklyn, is not one of the city's showplaces. The section was named soon after it was bought from the Indians in 1638, but soot and grime and ugly manufactories have long since obliterated the original greenery. Factories, warehouses, coal and lumber yards line Greenpoint's littorals on the East River and Newtown Creek.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 8 (AP) -- While Seton Hall ran away with the Class 3 and 4 prep school competition, Lincoln High of Jersey City repeated its Class 4 senior high school victory of last year in the annual indoor New Jersey interscholastic track championships at the Newark Armory tonight.

Although vessels of the American Republics Line have a greater volume of commerce than they can handle, and the present need is for ship tonnage rather than business, officials of Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., operators of the route, announced last week that they were planning a long-range campaign in South American countries to increase northbound shipments and improve the trade balances of these countries.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 8 (AP) -- The New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners today granted an extra year to the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company in which to market $3,817,917 in 5 per cent refunding mortgage bonds, originally authorized in 1933.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Feb. 1 totaled 261,208,000 barrels, according to data reported by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the total of the preceding week, this represents an increase of 1,115,000 barrels, comprising increases of 658,000 and 457,000 in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Anxiety over the fore and carry-all language of the President's lease-lend bill has been growing in Congress since the measure was subjected to examination and debate. This anxiety was responsible for the sudden agreement of the Administration to put a ceiling on the quantity of finished armament which may be leased or given in the next fiscal year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- The order issued today by the NLRB demanding that the International Harvester Company cease interference with unionization of its workers and disestablish "company-dominated" employe groups in six plants was regarded today as a major victory for the Farm Equipment Workers Union (C.I.O.) in its dispute with the firm.

OTTAWA -- One or more stamps advertising Canada's war effort are to be issued within the next few months, according to an authoritative source at the Postoffice De partment. W.P. Mulock, Postmaster General, has at least one stamp ready to be released as soon as sanctioned by Parliament, which meets this month.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 8 -- Georgetown sent Yale's basketball team to a 41-39 defeat tonight in a game in which the score was tied at 37 -- all and again at 39 -- all during the last minute. Bud O'Grady's toss from the circle brought the deciding 2 points in the final two seconds.

Charles Weidman's "Opus 51," created for the Bennington Festival in 1938 and given its initial New York presentation later the same year, was presented last night for the first time since then at the little studio-theatre of Doris Humphrey and Mr. Weidman in West Sixteenth Street.

LAST Summer nine Americans from the Middle West were about to start on a fishing trip to Canada when they all received identical telegrams warning them that they would get into trouble if they went near the St. Lawrence River.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Army Air Corps combat units expect to receive this month the first new fighting planes embodying features developed in the European warfare.

A "golden anniversary dinner" in tribute to Albert Morris Bagby, who has just completed his fiftieth year of Musical Mornings, is being planned for the night of May 13 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Besides, its testimonial significance the dinner will have a philanthropic aim as well.
TORONTO, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Terry Reardon broke up a tight game tonight with a goal late in the third period to give Boston a 3-to-2 victory over the National Hockey League leading Maple Leafs.

America was urged to give all possible aid to Britain in sermons yesterday by rabbis, who emphasized that on the outcome of the European war depended the survival of democracy and of religious civilization.

MR. KAYE'S long brown legs stuck out of his loose robe up to the knees. He wore slippers but no socks and his decolletage would hardly have done if his name was Doily instead of Danny. But his just-washed hair had a nice innocent ringlyness that made him look something like a young Roman in a black toga. He sat back, languid.

PASADENA, Calif. -- A new cult of travelers is bringing to the fore a type of touring that is distinctly American. Its watchword is "follow the sun," so it flourishes in the Southwestern States, where Winter weather is moody.

ORONO, Me., Feb. 8-Fresh from front-line duty during the recent influenza siege which sent some 200 to the regular and emergency wards at the University of Maine, nine girls, the first group under the nursing training curriculum, have just gone to major hospitals in the State to begin their two-year tour of duty as student nurses.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 8 -- Great Britain has informed Bulgaria that her military objectives will be subject to aerial bombardment if the German Army crosses into Bulgaria, diplomatic quarters reported tonight.

The Princeton wrestling team ran its winning streak to three straight yesterday, defeating Columbia, 24 -- 8 on the Lions' mats. A record crowd of 1,500 saw the Tigers take six of the eight bouts, three of them by falls.

Soccer in a stream-lined guise will be presented at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, when four local members of the American League will take part in a triple-header. The teams listed to compete are the New York Americans, the Brookhattans, the Brooklyn Hispanos and the St. Mary's Celtics.
LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:
LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 9 -- Quietness hung over Great Britain early today as far as aerial warfare was concerned. Few raiders by day and none by night were reported.

THE task of transferring Clare Boothe's acid satire, "Kiss the Boys Goodbye," to the alkaline side is well under way at Paramount, where the cameras have been grinding for four weeks, with Mary Martin as Cindy Lou Bethany and Don Ameche as Lloyd Lloyd.

OLD POINT COMFORT, Va. -- A St. Valentine's dance scheduled for next Friday evening will be one of the mid-February highlights of a month marked by increased social and sports activity here. The annual Washington's Birthday Ball to be given in the Yacht Room of the Chamberlin on Saturday, Feb. 22, will officially usher in the early Spring season.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Feb. 8 -- Community work will be the theme of a conference, student originated, planned and directed at Bryn Mawr College next Saturday, under the sponsorship of the Bryn Mawr League, cooperating with the Haverford College Service Project and the Swarthmore College Social Service Committee.

IN order to correct certain inferences which might be drawn from a letter of Arthur Austin's published on Jan. 26, 1941, here is a brief record of the NYA Radio Workshop's efforts in behalf of American composers and American music.

The British Broadcasting Corporation, in two broadcasts heard here yesterday, attributed to German sources reports that Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State of France, and Admiral Jean Darlan, Navy Minister, had fled from Vichy to Africa by airplane and that there was rioting in the provisional capital.
Seven Chilean journalists will arrive here tomorrow on the Grace liner Santa Clara to spend two months studying newspaper methods of the United States as guest writers on seven papers.

DAYTON, Ohio -- Better control -- the enigma that stymied the Wright brothers in their early attempts at heavier-than-air flight -- is the object of a new departure in airplane design in a West Side shop, not far from the place where the Wrights built their first flyable plane. George Cornelius, designer of the "Zephyr" and head of the Cornelius-I-Ioepli company, says that the craft should be ready for flight test by April.

TO those who have been following the work of Professor Earl Leslie Griggs for the past decade it was a foregone conclusion that he should be tempted to write a biography of Samuel Taylor Coleridge's talented daughter Sara.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The test of Alfred M. Landon's prepared statement on the British-aid bill, presented today before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, was as follows:

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8 -- The death of former Senator William G. McAdoo has scrambled the Democratic organization in California, and the task of coordination will present many problems to Edward J. Flynn, national chairman, when he visits here next week.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- British military quarters intimated today that with Eastern Libya in the hands of the Army of the Nile and the campaign in East Africa in full swing, Britain had further surprises in store for Italy, but what these were they did not reveal.

FROM academic garden pieces to squatty modernity ranges the annual group sculpture exhibition at the Arden Galleries (till Feb. 15). Richmond Barthe's sensitive head of a Negro child, Cornelia Van A. Chapin's "Penguin" and "Hare," Peter Dalton's graceful "Dancer," Paul Manship's three bears, Brenda Putnam's decorative wall panel, Concetta Scaravaglione's "Girl Sunning Hair" and Mahonri Young's "Burro and Foal" are outstanding among the two score pieces in this highly diversified show.

Mrs. Robert L. Hoguet Jr. heads a junior committee aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "The Bartered Bride," with Jarmila Novotna and Charles Kullman in the leading roles, on the afternoon of Feb. 28 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Scholarship Fund of the Smith College Club of New York.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Feb. 8 -- Active student interest is characteristic in the planning and participation of the half-hour chapel services held at Wesleyan University two mornings each week. These chapel services form a part of an integrated religious program.

A new policy on the scholastic requirements necessary to obtain a Bachelor's degree in either the arts or sciences courses at Fordham College was introduced this week by the Rev. Lawrence A. Walsh, dean of the college. The official announcement of the change contained three deviations from the traditional method of testing senior students for their scholastic worthiness which will go into effect immediately.

Half a million Poles from the Russian-occupied belt of the former republic, east of Warsaw, have been deported to Siberia in the first year of the Russian occupation and dumped there to get along as best they can or to perish if they are not strong enough to survive.

THE Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives will soon begin hearings on funds for airports in the coming year, and it is to be hoped that the matter will not be slighted in the rush of other legislative business. The development of more new airports is tremendously important.

Unless the private schools and colleges adjust themselves to realistic present-day conditions, a danger exists that within the next decade -- by 1951 -- the government may take them over, together with all education, Dr. James McConaughy, president of Wesleyan University, warned yesterday.

ROSENDALE, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- Gus Cornell, 28-year-old carpenter, gave a remarkable demonstration of endurance and skiing technique in winning the Telemark S.C.'s annual cross-country race today under most exacting conditions. The home club veteran, who put on his hickory blades last week for the first time this season, traversed the grueling ten-mile course in the sparkling time of 58 minutes 3 seconds to win the race for the second time.

TWENTY-SEVEN attractions, out of a total of thirty, will celebrate Lincoln's Birthday on Wednesday by offering holiday matinees. The exceptions are "Claudia," which opens Wednesday night; "Cabin in the Sky" and "Liberty Jones." "The Man Who Came to Dinner" and "Crazy With the Heat" have substituted a holiday matinee for their regular Thursday afternoon performance.

Numerous proposals have been advanced here and in Great Britain lately for the establishment by the United States of a Government agency to direct what is variously called economic warfare or economic defense against the Axis Powers. Since economic factors are of vital importance in total war, it is argued that a logical extension of our program of "all-out" aid to Britain would be measures to bring economic pressure to bear upon Britain's enemies.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 8 -- Realizing that educational values are changing and that getting into college is no longer a simple problem of accumulating fifteen Carnegie units, Tower Hill School has in recent years been giving attention to the special needs of seniors.

One of the minor problems brought to Great Britain by the continuous German air raids has been a woman's problem -- how to combine a certain measure of protection to life and limb with the requirements of fashion that forbid femininity to walk abroad looking like a perambulating bolster or a medieval knight in armor.

SIMPLE, quiet, sturdy, not in any way sensational, "Like a River Flowing" is a story of life in the North Carolina mountains from antebellum days to the turn of the century. Though there is nothing, perhaps, to distinguish it very markedly from other pioneer novels, it has a good, honest ring to it and is soberly appealing.

WITH a serious reduction of pilots facing the nation's airlines through calls to reserve duty, renewed attention is being given to Senator James M. Mead's proposal for the creation of an "airline pilot reserve" organization under which all flight personnel of the transport companies would be required to give one month's time each year to military training at a special center to be set up as a separate establishment of the Army.

The Chefs de Cuisine Association of America held a "Jubilee Nocturne," otherwise its twentieth annual supper dance, at the Hotel Pierre last night. More than 450 members and guests of the organization assembled in the Grand Ballroom for a meal which had Georges P. Gonneau, executive chef of the Pierre, on his mettle: he knew this was no crowd to trifle with.

VICHY, France, Jan. 16 -- Even the Information Section here bewails the lack of interest presented by the French press and urges that it depart from a monotonous uniformity which, it is too evident, has reached the point of utter boredom.

The Clyde-Mallory Line freighter Ozark sailed yesterday afternoon for Houston, Texas, the last ship of the company to operate in the 74-year-old service between New York and the Texas port. The company announced some weeks ago that it was abandoning the Houston run because it was no longer profitable, and that the extension of its New York service to Boston also would be dropped.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 8 -- In a speech broadcast to the rural population today Premier Bogdan Philoff outlined the law passed by the Sobranje [Parliament] yesterday giving pensions to farmers over 60.

The eighth annual Butlers' Staff Ball, sponsored by the Staff Club, 10 East Fifty-second Street, whose membership is composed of butlers serving the prominent families in New York, will be held Thursday night at the Hotel Commodore. Harry J. Beney, butler to Herbert L. Satterlee, is president of the club.

Maine is going after the sports tuna fishing business in a big way this year, and according to the plans of the Sea and Shore Fisheries Commission of that State 1941 is going to put Maine at the top of the tuna fishing list.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 -- Manhattan used two complete teams to defeat La Salle at Convention Hall tonight, 53 -- 44, in an exciting climax of a college basketball tripleheader, the first ever played in Philadelphia, before 9,071 spectators.

Is this a murder case, or is it not? Hazlitt George Brendan Woar, once of Scotland Yard, believes that it is. His wife, nee Katheren Maynard, hopes that it is not, and in any case, she hopes that her husband will keep out of it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- How artificial wool fibers can be made from peanuts is revealed in a patent (No. 2,230,624) awarded here to Andrew McLean of Saltcoats, Scotland.

NINETEENTH-CENTURY explorers' and travelers' tales of the inevitable creeping forward of the American frontiers and the pushing back of the forests are the most romantic and enthralling chapters of our development.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 8 -- A filly described by her owner as having "the smoothest and swiftest action of any horse I have ever seen" won the initial running of the Black Helen Handicap before Hialeah Park's largest 1941 crowd, 15,899, today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The propriety of exhibiting two live rattlesnakes to a jury in a Los Angeles trial was defended this week before the Supreme Court on the ground that they were "one of the agencies employed in a fiendish plan to commit murder for profit."

Collectors and dealers organized last week a philatelic committee officially identified with the British War Relief Society and will solicit the aid of philatelists throughout the United States in raising funds to be used to purchase mobile food kitchens for the bombed areas of Great Britain.

Today's foreign correspondents run risks and encounter difficulties greater than their predecessors ever knew. On the one hand, they are permitted not only to share the dangers of civilian populations in bombed cities, but also, on occasion, to go to sea in warships, fly in military planes or advance, as in Libya and Albania, with victorious armies.

Mrs. John Edward Mullins of 1160 Fifth Avenue gave a tea dance yesterday in the Pent House of the St. Regis to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Hope Stockbridge Carroll. The hostess and the debutante, assisted by the latter's grandmother, Mrs. Edgar Emery Zielian, received in a bower of cybotium ferns and Spring flowers.

N.Y.U. fencers defeated Fordham, 23 1/2 to 3 1/2, and the Violet freshman basketball team won from the Kips Bay Boys Club, 68 -- 50, yesterday on home floors. The varsity swimmers bowed by 54-21 to Lafayette at the Spence Natatorial Institute.

The best of the city-wide entries in the fourteenth annual National High School Art exhibition will be on display at the fifth floor galleries at Macy's, Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway, beginning tomorrow and continuing through Feb. 21.

Don't let the title deceive you. The hero of this tale is the same Dick Marlow who stopped so frequently for brandy in Mr. Bentley's earlier story of his adventures, and he has changed very little. It is true that he does choose wine, but only on rare occasions.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 8 (AP) -- The United States and British Governments are spending $282,000,000 with E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for construction and operation for one year of powder and chemical plants. This estimate is contained in a du Pont annual report to be released in a few days.

In preparation for the time when supplies of vital raw materials will be cut off or rationed, manufacturers in industries which may be classified as nonessential have started a wide campaign of redesigning both products and packages, executives and product engineers reported here last week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Senator Byrnes of South Carolina, chairman of the Committee on Audit and Control, denied today that any concerted effort was being made to withhold funds for the investigation of German patent and other business controls in the United States.

HARRY is 5. Unmercifully he teases his 3-year-old brother Joe -- grabbing the apple Joe is happily munching, giving him a push when he thinks no one is looking, fetching Joe a well-placed kick under the table.

Outside the Libyan city of Bengazi, which the ancients had called Hesperides, Italian soldiers landed from their boats. There were brief skirmishes, a brilliant infantry charge, and then above Bengazi's minarets the Tricolor of the House of Savoy replaced the Turkish Crescent. The calendar read Oct. 19, 1911.

THE second annual American Music Festival of WNYC will open Feb. 12 with a concert at the Hunter College auditorium and continue until the 22d. During the eleven-day cycle approximately forty hours of melody made up of more than 200 works are scheduled to be broadcast in six programs daily.

IT can hardly be said that the nineteenth century has been permitted to become a "forgotten" century. In even the frenetic rush of our own era, with values in a persistent state of flux, we have somehow found time and inclination to review -- turning them this way and that -- the art developments of the momentous hundred-year span that forms an immediate background for the modern scene.

ROME, Feb. 8 -- The series of student demonstrations in Rome ended today when small groups of exuberant youths were broken up at their schools by the police before they could get started. Orders were out to stop the demonstrations.

IT has been said before -- and can be said again -- that this country needs many small operatic companies which will train singers, produce new works, encourage native composers and perform operas for people who would otherwise never have a chance of hearing them.
ROME, Feb. 8 -- It is not Italy that is being directly attacked in the war. It is Italy's new empire, the one she fought for in 1935 and 1936, added to in 1939 and hoped to expand through this war.

A gold badge of membership in the Society of the Cincinnati that belonged originally to General Philip Van Cortlandt, who fought in General Washington's army, was sold for $1,000 yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- The War Department plans to ask Congress soon for more than $2,000,000,000 with which to order 15,000 more planes to place its projected air fleet at about 40,000 planes.

Storm clouds continued to scud above the Pacific last week as Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, new Japanese envoy to Washington, arrived in the United States, while his countrymen struck a new blow at China and planted their flag at Saigon and Camranh Bay.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 -- An elaborate program marked the opening in West Palm Beach tonight of the new Norton Gallery and School of Art. Huger Elliott, director of the Metropolitan Art Museum's educational department, made the dedicatory address.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- One of the series of midseason tournaments will be held this week when golfers gather for the annual Everglades Club invitational event. Qualifying play will be tomorrow and the finals will be on Friday.

DETROIT, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers today announced the outright release of the veteran Earl Averill, 37-year-old utility man, to make a place on the roster for Walter (Hoot) Evers, newly signed 19-year-old outfielder.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 8 -- Two new pool records were set today as Harvard University, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League meet, defeated the Naval Academy swimmers, 50 to 25.

In a speech that was the highlight of the thirty-first anniversary celebration of the Boy Scouts of America President Roosevelt declared last night that while the government was assuming "major responsibility" in the national defense program, it "cannot and should not preempt those fields of private endeavor that have become an indispensable part of life in America."

The strike of 800 employes of the Whelan drug stores began its second week yesterday, with all the fifty-three stores still closed and no move on the part of the management to reopen negotiations with Local 1,199 of the Retail Drug Store Employes Union, C.I.O.

Acting on Army plans which call for the building of a reserve supply of clothing and equipment large enough to meet the needs of a force of 2,000,000 men in 1942, the National Defense Advisory Commission has begun a study of the ability of the various supplying industries to provide the goods without disturbing commercial operations, it was learned here last week.

MADRID, Feb. 8 -- Argentina has agreed to provide Spain with 120,000 bales of cotton as a prelude to a "more extensive plan of commercial relations," under which Spain expects to acquire later large quantities of wheat, meat and other Argentine products, it was announced tonight.

Breaking 97 out of 100 targets, T.H. Lawrence took the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In the handicap event H. Hammer was the winner with a card of 90 -- 9 -- 99, Lawrence also scored in the shoot at 149 targets, winning a leg on the handicap prize with a card of 139.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Officials here breathed sighs of relief at the apparent solution of the Cuban crisis this week, but set to work to draw what morals the confused and typical Latin situation seemed to provide. The developments in Havana, while not wholly unforeseen, occasioned further headaches to those Washington functionaries charged with mapping the military and economic defense of the Western Hemisphere, under the ambitious plans now current here.

This is a historical novel of the opening up of the Western plains between the Mississippi and California by means of wagon freighting and the Pony Express. Its period is, roughly, the years between the war with Mexico and the Civil War.

EMMITSBURG, Md., Feb. 8 -- "President Fulgencio Batista is a convinced believer in democracy," says the report of Dr. Joseph F. Thorning, Professor of Sociology and special representative of the National Catholic Welfare Conference News Service, after a month's survey of social and economic conditions in Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Secretary Knox, in a plea for the protection of military secrets, asserted tonight that "a sentence spoken or printed might wreck an arsenal, sink a battleship or destroy the lives of many who are working night and day to make America secure against all enemies, potential or otherwise."

MOSCOW, Feb. 8 -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda said today that "the phenomenon known in science as delirium tremens was spread all over America recently" by publication of "the silly calumny" that Soviet Russia plans to invade Alaska.

MEXICO CITY -- The Winter bullfighting season is now in full swing and there are major events every Sunday afternoon. Americans attending for the first time are apt to find the proceedings on the violent side.

THE current number of The Bookseller tells a distressing story. The ring of fire around St. Paul's on the night of the great raid caused more loss and damage to the book trade, it reports, than has been suffered, proportionately, by any other trade since the war began.

Andre, his son, is the boy who amazed those who heard him last year at his debut in Town Hall when he played thirteen of his own compositions.

When Winston Churchill some weeks ago in making an appeal to the Italian people told them the British would chew their African empire to pieces, Rome retorted that it was just a bit of braggadocio propaganda. Now Rome knows more about it.

Two song recitals will be given here in the near future to raise funds for British war relief work. The first will be that to be presented by Miss Marie Williams, British-born soprano, next Sunday afternoon in the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The food plans of the British Government published this week include introduction of a national wholemeal bread made from brown wheatmeal of 85 per cent extraction. There is no intention, however, of making consumption compulsory to secure a wide market for the wholemeal bread, however.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- St. Valentine s Day will provide plenty of entertainment for local visitors. There will be parties and dances at many of the resort hotels.

A five-year jurisdictional dispute between the International Longshoremen's Association and the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, both affiliates of the American Federation of Labor, has been settled by negotiation, it was announced yesterday by John J. Scully, secretary of the latter union.
BERLIN, Feb. 8 -- The German air force yesterday staged actions against the British Isles in which the swastika bombers ranged far up into Northern Scotland, it was reported here.

IF we cannot get a recording of Verdi's Requiem Mass directed by Arturo Toscanini, the new version put out by Victor under the leadership of Tullio Serafin would seem to be the next best. The album enlists illustrious soloists -- Maria Caniglia, soprano; Ebe Stignani, contralto; Beniamino Gigli, tenor, and Ezio Pinza, bass. It also has the services of the chorus and orchestra of the Rome Royal Opera.

FORCED out of the Radio City Music Hall due to previous commitments last Wednesday night after six record weeks, "The Philadelphia Story" had grossed $594,000, or more than half of its total Broadway earnings as a play during a year's stand at the Shubert Theatre between March 28, 1939, and March 30, 1940.

THE Foreign Relations Committee is one of the three most exclusive units in that organization which is often called the most exclusive club in the world -- the United States Senate. Just why this is so is unclear, for the role of the committee is unimportant in nineteen years out of twenty; but there seems to be a tradition that a Senator automatically gains in stature upon assignment to this unit.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Diplomatic quarters here heard today that a British note of warning had been handed to the Bulgarian Foreign Office by the British Minister to Sofia. They said it was intended to head off the long-rumored German attempt to strike at Britain's allies, Greece and Turkey, through Bulgaria, or perhaps to attempt by the same long route to come to Italy's aid in the Middle East.

MONTREAL, Feb. 8 -- The Montreal Canadiens, battling to hold sixth place from the challenging New York Americans, maintained their three-point margin in the National Hockey League standings by playing a 3-3 draw with the New Yorkers before a crowd of about 7,000 tonight.

WHEN Paul V. McNutt, Social Security Administrator, and the committees advising him on nutrition and American food habits swing into action within a month or so the housekeepers of the nation will be called to the colors.

Two Columbia University students will be honored with awards Wednesday at events celebrating the university's thirty-fourth annual Alumni Day, it was announced yesterday. The day's festivities, on the theme of "Preparing America for Defense," will be dedicated to Columbia's Graduate Schools of Political Science, Philosophy and Pure Science.
BERLIN, Feb. 8 -- If the United States is to become a factor in the European war then Germany and the German people should know more about it and be prepared.
AFTER all these years John Donne has become a best seller and all because Ernest Hemingway chose a quotation from Donne as the title of his latest novel, "For Whom the Bell Tolls" (Scribner's).
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 8 (AP) -- British headquarters announced today that "operations south of Bengazi are proceeding satisfactorily." However, the next phase of the Libyan drive is problematical.

IF the popularity of the recently opened skating rinks at Flushing Meadow Park may be taken as a criterion, the park itself, when it is completed, will prove to be one of the most important links in the city's great system of recreational areas.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Accommodations for 3,000 more refugee families from Europe will be built in Palestine by the Jewish National Fund, it was made known today as Zionist leaders gathered here for the tri-State conference of Mizrachi, Zionist organization.

The tale concerns certain adventures of Rainbow Ripley and Grumpy Gibbs, that brace of salty range detectives celebrated by Bliss Lomax in some of his earlier novels. A Nevada rancher old enough to know better had been lured into Mexico by the old "Spanish-prisoner" hoax.

THE Crimson Horseshoe was the 240-mile loop of the Sierra and Western, in the foothills of the Bajadas, when its rails caught the glare of the setting sun and reflected it to the high pass. It was thus that Jim Allard saw it as he rode his claybank into Arizona, a penniless fugitive from justice with a price on his head.

FORT MYERS, Fla. -- Fort Myers will pay tribute to the memory of its most distinguished citizen, Thomas A. Edison, in a weeklong program beginning on Tues day, anniversary of the birth of the inventor.

PULL up a chair alongside Edgar Stehli and in a very few minutes you can learn a lot about acting on the radio. Or, more particularly, about acting on the radio as compared to acting on the stage. For Mr. Stehli has spent the last fifteen years or so skipping nimbly from footlights to microphone and back again, absorbing a tidy knowledge of each along the way.

This is a season when the commuter is more than usually preoccupied with his furnace, and it may be just as well not to interrupt him. His temper now is shorter, his relations with his wife less enthusiastic, his general outlook less cheery than at any other time. The condition may have its genesis in nothing more disagreeable than the receipt of fuel bills for his automatic heat.
SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 8 -- W. Lawson Little plodded along in snow, deep slush and finally sunshine today to create one of golf's masterpieces, a 62, nine under par.

American foreign traders were enthusiastic here last week over accomplishments of the River Plate countries at their first regional conference at Montevideo. Uruguay, As viewed by exporters here, the conference was the first step in a movement which is bound to spur the interchange of goods among the Latin-American nations and put their economies in a more balanced state.

The road shows over, the all-star track cast will settle down to a four-week run at Madison Square Garden beginning with the New York A.C. games on Saturday. The Winged Footers always have staged a spectacular affair and there is every expectation that that tradition will be carried on in America's oldest carnival.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 8 -- Dartmouth's basketball team, paced by Gus Broberg, defeated Princeton tonight, 55 -- 40, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game before 2,500 students and Winter Carnival guests. This was the Indians' fourth circuit victory.

Half of the sixty new cargo carriers ordered here by the British Government last December are to be built in a type of yard that is unusual in the United States for the construction of commercial vessels of this size, it was disclosed here yesterday.

THE late Dr. Francis R. Hagner of Washington, D.C., spent over twenty years gathering his library of what is loosely termed Americana. He was no Herschel V. Jones, and his interest was not confined to rarities.

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was unusually quiet in the short session yesterday with prices moving in a narrow range. After opening unchanged to off 1 point, the best recovered moderately, and final quotations were at net gains of 1 to 3 points. Steady buying by the trade in the March position resulted in that month showing the greatest gain for the session.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 8 -- The exportation of raw materials, chemical products, machinery and tools will be subject to an export permit to all countries except the American nations, it was ruled by President Getulio Vargas today.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 8 -- The reign of Dartmouth's Winter sports teams at their own Winter Carnivals came to a close in an icy setting today as the thirty-first meet of the Dartmouth Outing Club moved through its closing events. Yesterday's rain was succeeded by cold that covered the near-by slopes with ice, forced the transfer of this morning's slalom to Woodstock and brought glare conditions for the afternoon's jump.

THIS is a curiously planned book, written in a style that attempts the dramatic but is turgid and dull to the point of confusion. Mr. Burlingame says that he "has not attempted to write the biography of Eli Whitney.

Unquestionably hardy phlox can be called the queen of all Summer perennials. And well deserved is this honor since no other flower can boast the same combination of brilliancy of bloom, sturdiness, grace of plant structure and long flowering season which promises gardens a glorious display from early June until frost.

A growing tendency to encourage gifted students in interior decoration is reflected in two current exhibitions which have the added virtue of offering many useful ideas to the practical home decorator. These showings of student-decorated rooms which have won awards for excellence have further significance in that they indicate present trends in decoration.

BRAZZAVILLE, West African base under the rule of General de Gaulle's forces, was picked up recently broadcasting English news from the Middle Congo. The move is described as a counter-measure to match English transmissions from the Vichy contingent at Dakar.

Today is Poland Day. As Governor Lehman said in his proclamation designating its observance in New York, we "share with the Polish people here and in the suffering homeland heartfelt prayer that deliverance from their oppression and tyranny will soon come." We need not condone the shortcomings of the Polish Government which went out of existence with the Nazi and Communist invasions.

GRIDIRON CZAR: The ten teams of the National Football League last season played fifty-five professional games before 1,300,000 fans. A play off game between Washington and the Chicago Bears champions of the league's Eastern and Western divisions.

The one hundred and twenty-first anniversary of the birth of Susan B. Anthony, pioneer suffragist and leader in the feminist movement in this country, will be observed at a luncheon to be given on Saturday by the committee on international affairs of the National Council of Women. The luncheon will be held at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East Sixty-sixth Street.

As announced some time ago the plans of the All-America Selections Committee -- which for several years has conducted advance trials of new varieties of annual flowers -- have been extended to include roses. The test gardens are scattered from New England to Florida, California and Oregon and each rose goes through a two-year test.

St. Francis College, playing on its home court, returned to the victory column in basketball last night at the expense of St. Peter's College of Jersey City. The Terriers won by 50 -- 44, Carl Malfitano leading the attack with 12 points. Vonderleith and Lynch of St. Peter's also scored 12 each.

VICHY, France, Feb. 8 -- Pierre Laval has declined Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's offer to restore him to the French Cabinet as a Minister of State, it was officially announced tonight. The offer was made "in the spirit of the policy of European collaboration outlined by the Marshal and Herr Hitler at Montoire," the communique declared.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 8 -- The Forty-fourth Division three-day field training inspection was ended this noon after the inspection of the 119th Medical Regiment, the special troops and the 157th Field Artillery. Inspecting officers saw, for the first time, the 157th "Blitzkrieg'' command post.

IN that suggestive and illuminating book on the art of fiction which he published under the title of "Aspects of the Novel" E.M. Forster discusses in his final chapter some of the possible means by which the novel might be enhanced as a form of art.

WORLD-SHAKING events, such as wars, are apt to bring people to a sudden realization that society has been changing more rapidly than they had ever suspected. This sharp and rather uncomfortable realization is always accompanied by a constructive effort to take stock in many fields -- in government, in education, in medicine.

ATHENS, Feb. 8 -- The Italian forces made attempts to break through the Greek lines at several points along the battle front north of Klisura today, but according to the Press Ministry they met with utter failure.

A RADICAL change in the system of automobile licensing, which may be the key to eventual standardization in other States, is proposed in a bill to be introduced at the current session of the Delaware General Assembly.

In a review of the port situation as affected by the war the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that despite the increase in exports to the United Kingdom there was no accumulation of cargoes awaiting shipment in the harbor.

John G. Winant, Ambassador-designate to the Court of St. James, yesterday predicted victory for democracy in the war, but warned that it would then be necessary to "conquer the peace" by building a "democratic world of tomorrow" based upon social justice and economic security.

The General Shoe Corporation in its report for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31 shows a net profit of $722,884, after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, equivalent to $1.09 a share on 627,716 shares of common stock, after preferred dividend requirements.

Despite an announcement by Secretary of Commerce Jesse H. Jones that January business continued at peak levels, despite the continuance of strong steel demand with 1940 exports 25 per cent above the old high mark, despite motor car sales well above the mark set in January, 1940, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange saw volume at the lowest level since Sept, 14.

They cut them pretty fine at Madison Square Garden last night. Duquesne beat Long Island University with a field goal in the final forty seconds of the second game, 36 to 34, and the City College toppled Fordham with a foul shot in the very last second, 41 to 40.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- As the Civilian Conservation Corps nears the eighth anniversary of its founding it finds itself, strangely enough, approaching this milestone under more criticism than since the first year of its establishment.

About five years ago four plants of the Christmas Rose (Helleborus niger) were set out on a hillside under two large mimosa trees in the Fort Worth Botanic Garden. The soil, predominantly alkaline, was medium rich, with fertilizer added.

Ten days before he was inaugurated for a third term Franklin D. Roosevelt sent Congress a bill that Americans promptly called historic. With its provisions for authorizing the President to lease or lend "all-out" aid to Britain, the bill -- H.R. 1776 was its label -- brought an intensifying national debate on foreign policy to a head.

THE trump card of the Soviet propagandist is to represent pre-Bolshevik Russia as a howling wilder ness, politically, economically and culturally. Confronted with overwhelming proof of administrative brutality or general poverty, the believer that all is for the best in Stalin's world habitually falls back on the line of defense:

THE annual awards of the Veteran Wireless Operators Association will be made Tuesday at the Hotel Astor during the organization's yearly dinner. The ceremonies are to be broadcast from 11:05 to 11:30 P.M. over WJZ's hook-up.

AS a teacher and writer I have always found THE NEW YORK TIMES indispensable for the study of contemporary world affairs. I was therefore surprised to discover in the Book Review section of Jan. 26 that reliance on THE NEW YORK TIMES by diplomatic historians is regarded as reprehensible by Michael T. Florinsky.
