The powerful Benjamin Franklin High School basketball team recorded its thirty-first straight triumph over a two-season span and notched its twelfth of the current campaign by trouncing a lower Manhattan P.S.A.L. foe, Stuyvesant, 49 to 23, in one game of the third and last schoolboy quintuple-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

EVERYTHING in the show business is a little cock-eyed, according to Raymond Massey, alias Abe Lincoln in Illinois, and to entertain any preconceived idea about the theatre, radio and screen is very dangerous. Preparing himself to be Lincoln once again on the "Cavalcade of America" program on Wednesday over the WEAF network, the Canadian-born actor confessed himself very much interested in radio work on account of its strange one-dimensional quality.

So long as capital gains and losses are taxable as income under the income tax almost any change in the method of taxing such transactions precipitates litigation. This is due to the refinements of interpretation governing distinctions between capital and ordinary transactions.

A good-will tour of Girl Scout centers in fifteen Central and South American countries, in which the Carnegie Foundation for International Peace is cooperating, has been planned for Mrs. Arethusa F.G. Leigh-White, director of the world bureau of the organization. The Girl Scouts of the United States which announced the plans is sponsor for the tour.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 8 -- Six essential factors for a liberal education that is "to prepare the student for 'the good life' in a democratic society" are prescribed by Theodore M. Greene, Professor of Philosophy at Princeton University, in a discussion of the university's divisional program in the humanities appearing in the current issue of The Princeton Alumni Weekly.
Columbia's basketball team moved back into Eastern Intercollegiate League competition last night and found its stride in the second half to beat Harvard by 42-28 at the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

MR. SCOGGINS'S new book might have come straight from Hollywood, with all characters tailored, photographed and censored for the screen. "Lost Road" is a movie rather than a novel, and an entertaining movie at that, with airplanes. Indians, Peruvian gold mines, love interest and a happy ending.

The marriage of Miss Mary Pepperrell Dana, daughter of Mrs. Richard Henry Dana and the late Mr. Dana, to Arthur Leffingwell Shipman Jr., son of Mrs. Arthur L. Shipman of Hartford, Conn., and the late Mr. Shipman, took place yesterday afternoon at the Dana home, 340 East Seventy-second Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Henry Evertson Cobb in the presence of near-relatives and a few close friends.

District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx yesterday declared that the authorities have a "complete description" of a man they are seeking as a suspect in the murder of Mrs. Catherine Pappas, who was strangled in her apartment at 1035 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, last Tuesday.

The Board of Transportation and the city were temporarily enjoined yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder from leasing 250 buses for replacement of the existing trolley cars on the Fulton Street line in Brooklyn.

Much interest has been manifested in an address "Should Americans Fight Europe's War?" which I delivered recently to the faculty and students at Notre Dame University. As excerpts were quoted in THE TIMES, may I correct a few misconstructions of my thesis on the part of some readers?

Mrs. Langbourne M. Williams Jr., a member of the board of trustees of the Community Service Society and former president of the New York Junior League, will speak on the society's welfare work Wednesday afternoon at 3:45 over radio Station WOR in connection with the Junior League Players' children's radio program. "Hello, the Orgets!" which is being broadcast Wednesday afternoons this month.

It is an old military adage that successes at the periphery are often dangerous because they may divert attention and resources from the center. In estimating the steadily growing victories of the British forces against the Italians in Africa we cannot afford to lose sight of this principle.

To the girls working in anti-aircraft units at lonely outposts on the English coast the British Y.W.C.A. is now sending clubs-on-wheels. The first of these vans have recently been put into service, according to reports which reached the organization headquarters here last week, and they have had such a success that more will be sent on tour as soon as they are made available.

MARY MELLISH sang minor parts for seven seasons at the Metropolitan Opera, and has sung also in operetta and concert. But she says that she has never had a career, in the sense of a conspicuous life work. And until she was 19 years old she had never heard a big orchestra, attended a concert, or, as she puts it, "feasted on an opera."
MRS. STEVENS was the clever, breezy sort of woman, pretty as well as witty, whose dull daughter was forever inquiring, "What ever will you say next, Mother?"

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- Nearly every house in the park, also the club, is filled with week-end guests, many of whom attended the dinner dance which Mrs. Frederic F. de Rham gave tonight for her daughter, Miss Madeleine F. Butt, to celebrate her twenty-first birthday. Miss Butt made her debut two years ago at the Autumn Ball here.

In last night's performance of Verdi's "Rigoletto" at the Metropolitan Opera House, Josephine Tuminia made her debut as Gilda in a cast headed by Lawrence Tibbett in the title role. The youthful soprano, born of Italian parents in St. Louis, Mo., made her first appearance on the operatic stage as Rosina in "The Barber of Seville" in 1935, and since has been heard with the Chicago and the Cincinnati Opera Companies.

Another aspect in the conflict between the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and Broadcast Music, Inc., flared into the open yesterday when it became known that thirteen prominent composers of popular tunes had filed a petition with the Federal Communications Commission at Washington charging that the three major radio networks by threats and intimidation had coerced radio performers to use BMI music exclusively.

IT is a pleasure, in conversations with our friends, to encounter from time to time a stiff opinion opposed to the general tenor of the press comments upon the Metropolitan production of Gluck's "Alceste," and concerning "Alceste" itself.

EXHIBITS at the National Sportsmen's Show, which opens on Saturday at the Grand Central Palace for its annual one-week run, cover a wider range of territory than ever before. There will be the Eskimo family hailing from a corner of North America whence they can look across the Bering Strait and see Siberian territory; they will demonstrate native ways of hunting and fishing in the Far North.

CHILE, will celebrate on Wednesday the 400th anniversary of the establishment of Santiago del Nuevo Estremo, today's capital city Santiago, by Pedro Valdivia, favorite aide of Francisco Pizarro, the Spanish conquistador. Five stamps commemorating the event were received last week from Santiago.
To encourage towns in the United States to "adopt" English towns of similar names, the namesake towns committee of the English Speaking Union held a luncheon at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

Two novel features will mark the final performances of the Westminster exhibition Wednesday. These will be the spectacular exposition of obedience training which will be given afternoon and evening by members of the New England Dog Training Club, and the judging of Dalmatian dog mascots from twenty-five of the city's fire stations.

NEW YORK has developed the technique of making good clothes at moderate prices. Style is within the reach of every woman. It is this fact that gives New York's garment center its outstanding character and has made it unique in the world.

Announcing January sales to dealers in the United States 32.5 per cent ahead of last year and the highest in the history of the company, the General Motors Corporation yesterday also made public data on payrolls showing that, in this respect, as in the case of sales, net earnings and taxes.

In "White Reindeer" Mass James, who has herself spent six months in Lapland (described in her "Petticoat Vagabond Among the Nomads"), tells a straight-forward, lively tale of a Lapp boy and his pet reindeer. When a baby fawn is deserted by his mother, 10-year-old Pirak feeds him, tames him and names him Urpu.

THOMAS BURTON has ability and material to fashion good novels, but, judging from "Bloodbird," he lacks discipline and consistency of direction. There is enough in this volume to give impetus to several novels. Under a mature hand this wealth of material might have been integrated, a difficult task at best, but as it stands it sprawls both technically and dramatically.

MIAMI, Feb. 8 -- Mrs. Edward S. Moore, wife of the financier and turfman of New York and Wyoming, was robbed of jewelry estimated to be worth $250,000 by two bandits in the Bay Front section late this afternoon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Workers who refuse to cross picket lines to get to their jobs, and thus become "unemployed," must go without jobless insurance under a new ruling of the State Supreme Court.

Inaugurating an entirely new type of dog show, the Westminster Kennel Club will open its sixty-fifth annual exhibition in Madison Square Garden Tuesday morning at 9 o'clock, to continue it through Wednesday evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Unless through the intercession of their friends or some unpredictable turn of events President Roosevelt and Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana are brought together, the country may see an almost exact repetition of the bitter duel that the two men waged over the President's court-enlargement bill just four years ago.

An elaborate pageant depicting a tour by a group of young Americans through the twenty-one Pan-American countries will be the principal feature of a varied entertainment program arranged for the Fiesta Ran-Americana to be given tomorrow night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins will be two of the prominent persons who will lecture at Hunter College during the Spring semester, which begins tomorrow.

Snow fell one day last week over provincial Vichy, capital of unoccupied France. Softly, silently, it drifted against the Hotel du Parc, headquarters of the government that took over in the chaotic days of the June surrender. Inside, important decisions were in the making.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Maryland Jockey Club moved today to make the Pimlico Special a "super" horse race, bringing together the winners of twenty-four of the richest and sportiest events in the country for an "all-America" contest.

YUGOSLAVIA, has released four semi-postals for the benefit, as an inscription shows, of the "Zveza Bojevnikov Ljubljana" (Association of Veterans of Ljubljana). St. Peter plaza in Ljubljana, a town in the district of Slovenia, illustrates a 50-paras plus 50p light green.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- While every one is wondering when and where the war will break out once more in its full destructive fury, men here are talking about reconstruction. London's bomb-torn vistas lend point to their discussions, though physical changes are only one aspect of a broad social program for a new and better Britain.

IN a big push a gun is apt to bog down in the mud when it is needed most. Against that evil moment the field artillery practices in peacetime an exercise called "difficult traction." The cannoneers drive a prime mover hauling a howitzer or a French 75 into a ditch and let the wheels plow deep into the soft earth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The position of Counselor which Mr. Moore, a distinguished legislator, attorney and authority on international law, occupied is co-equal in the State Department with that of Under-eeretary.

HERE is a little problem which has bothered this corner for some time. It has to do with the proper critical designations for the various and sundry pictures which have their locales in the great American West. Of course, there is always the straight generic term "Western" to cover the lot, but sometimes that has its shortcomings in that it doesn't adequately state the case.

ROME, Feb. 8 -- The stunning news that Bengazi, Libya, has fallen is broken to the Italian people in today's war bulletin. It is the greatest and most bitter defeat in twenty years of Fascism, but the press takes the line that it is not decisive. In fact, the Lavoro Fascista states bluntly that the British could drive up to Tripoli and that the war would go on.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 8 -- The arrival of the first baby gibbon at the Free Range primate colony on Santiago Island is reported by the School of Tropical Medicine. It is one of the few gibbons known to have been born in captivity. So far the sex is undetermined since no one has approached close to the cage for fear of frightening the mother.

WINIFRED GALBRAITH has lived in China for fifteen years, an English missionary, teacher, Y.W.C.A. and Red Cross worker. When Changsha was burned she moved with a roll of bedding to the outskirts of the city and then as the fire came nearer moved again.

Detroit was enrolled in the American Football League yesterday, increasing the membership of that professional circuit to seven clubs. This news was the major development on the opening day of the league's two-day meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.

MIAMI, Fla. -- The second annual Miami horse show will be held Thursday, Friday, Saturday and next Sunday in the Orange Bowl Stadium. There will be $500 in prize money in the five-gaited class and the same amount in the three-gaited division.

Ever since the Securities and Exchange Commission handed down its decision in the celebrated Consumers Power Company case more than a year ago, the public utility industry has been patiently, but perhaps somewhat fearfully, awaiting the commission's interpretation of what constitutes a "sound and conservative" capitalization for utility properties.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8 -- Raymond Parker is being held in Stockton on a charge of abducting William R. Williams, an Oakland taxi driver. Parker is accused of threatening Williams with what the driver thought was the muzzle of a revolver and forcing him to drive eighty miles.

It is perhaps never possible wholly to separate the problems of domestic and foreign policy. It is certainly impossible at the present time. Preparations for the contingency of defensive war must, like war itself, be total. The personal lives of all Americans are affected -- our fundamental institutions are subjected to unusual strain and social changes are accelerated, retarded or redirected.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Feb. 8 -- A teacher education program centered around Furman University has evolved democratically in Greenville County and is proving most effective in coordinating all resources of the community.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sunday, Feb. 9 -- Germany has taken over ten torpedo boats that were part of Denmark's small fleet, the Stockholm newspaper Dagens Nyheter revealed today. This infringement upon Danish independence had been rumored here for several days, but had lacked confirmation.

Palestine today offers a haven more than ever before for thousands of unfortunate Jews forced from their own countries by "oppression, violence and intolerance," it was asserted yesterday by Governor Lehman in a plea for the widest possible support of the $12,000,000 War Emergency Campaign of the United Palestine Appeal.

TRADE volume was steadily maintained in the week in the merchandise lines, despite soaring sales for automobiles. Some sections reflect the ebbing of the influenza epidemic in their retail totals. Thus, Coast cities have jumped well ahead of last year's figures as shoppers are free once more to go about their purchasing.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 9 (AP) -- United States naval circles here denied today a report printed in the Tokyo newspaper Nichi Nichi that Admiral Thomas Hart, Commanderin-Chief of the United States Asiatic Fleet, had called a conference of United States naval officials in the Far East.

DETROIT, Feb. 8 -- The United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) warned its members today against "mob tactics" and apologized to a foreman of the Hudson Motor Car Company who was beaten and thrown from the plant by nearly 100 unionists in a demonstration on Jan. 26.

Warning that America will have little chance of remaining at peace if Great Britain should fall, Governor Lehman, addressing the Albany Society of New York, declared last night that threats of the dictator nations against further aid to Britain should be met with "only one answer -- increased aid and full steam ahead."

GEORGES SUAREZ, to whom we owe masterly biographies of Clemenceau, Herriot, Poincare, Briand, has just published a life of Le Marechal Petain (Plon), which, in spite of its comparative shortness, offers all that ought to be known of the soldier, gentleman and statesman, with penetrating insight into character and the virtues that make up a great chief in war and in peace.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 8 -- Governor Robert A. Hurley, presenting to the General Assembly this week his executive budget calling for the largest expenditures in the history of the State, asked legislators, while considering it, "to keep in mind certain social trends of recent American history, required by the times and approved by the great majority of our people."

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Willie Hoppe, the defending champion, continued his triumphant march in the world three-cushion billiard tournament today, turning back Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia, 50 to 31, in thirty-three innings. It was the New York expert's twelfth victory in a row.
AFTER a somewhat uneventful February the bridge tournament calendar will show considerable activity beginning in March and continuing through the Spring.

DALLAS, Texas, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Nine men and a youth, victims of a fire which transformed a Salvation Army hotel from a wintry refuge into a death trap, will be buried in a mass funeral next week. The services were set tentatively for Monday or Tuesday, but the death list may grow before then.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Robert Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, said tonight that the Philippine Army "might conceivably become the bulwark that would preserve civilization."
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Frank Kovacs finally lost a Florida tennis match today after winning four tournaments in a row.

George Cummings, veteran University Club professional, who has his name twice inscribed on the bowl that goes to the winner in the open squash racquets doubles annually featured by the Heights Casino Club in Brooklyn, yesterday made a start toward what he hopes will be a third victory.

MAURITZ HALLGREN is a versatile fellow. Perhaps it is because he has spent half his life in journalism -- as a reporter, foreign correspondent and editorial writer. In any case, he has written a variety of books that seem to prove his versatility.

CONCERNING this matter of the American composer finding himself and contributing to the culture of his country, I think that Paul Hindemith, a great and significant artist of the Old World, has made some important observations on this subject which are of importance to every young composer aspiring to create great music.

Ken Overlin will have to wait awhile. The fighter who is recognized here as the world middleweight champion was to have been matched with the winner of Friday night's Billy Soose-Ernie Vigh bout in an effort to clear up the muddled situation in the 160-pound class, but there has been a change in plans.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 -- Mrs. Elliott F. Shepard, vice chairman of the Miami Beach district committee of the British War Relief Society, Inc., will be hostess at a fiesta next Saturday to aid the cause. South Sea Island scenes will be depicited in the gardens of her estate, which she is opening for the event.

DETROIT -- While what has been dubbed the government invasion of the River Rouge is still occupying much of the headline space in Detroit papers, there still is news of importance that is getting less prominence.

THE prominence to which propaganda has been lifted during the war through the use of powerful radio beams has resulted in a general mobilization of short-wave facilities in which the American broadcasters are playing an ambitious part.

ROME, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Italian forces retreating from the Bengazi sector are fighting fierce rear-guard actions while hastily preparing a new line of defense along a 309-mile-long strip of desert, it was reported tonight.

POVERTY is an expensive luxury in Hollywood. Whenever a script calling for down-at-heels backgrounds and characters goes into production, department heads promptly tilt their budget estimates. If Jeeter Lester and his family, for instance, had been a mite more fastidious and a mite better off, "Tobacco Road" wouldn't have been so expensive to make.

Mr. Huey, who has had much practical experience with children in his classes at the Calvert School in Baltimore, and whose "Child's Story of the Animal World" is one of the best zoology books ever written for young people, now provides a first physics book for the boy or girl of elementary school age.

Organized labor in New York State was warned last night by Thomas J. Lyons, president of the New York State Federation of Labor, that it must exercise unrelaxing vigilance through the present war "hysteria" to preserve the gains that have been won by labor on the statute books.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Malcolm MacDonald, who, at 41 years of age, is the youngest of Britain's Ministers, will leave the Ministry of Health to become High Commissioner to Canada, it was announced at Downing Street today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Construction costs for a standard house were 1.7 per cent higher in December than in November and 5.5 above December, 1939, Federal Home Loan Bank board economists reported today.
Purchases of Lincoln and Washington autograph letters are increasing. Prices have not reached the peak of boom years, but the autograph markets reflect the current business upturn.

IN a week when nearly forty exhibitions open, covering many fields of art, the limitations of space and time work an injustice on most of the exhibiting artists, comment by the harried reviewer becoming necessarily somewhat perfunctory. A number of the shows noted herewith deserve more extended notice than is at this time possible.

NO legend has as yet cluttered up the fame and achievements of General Sir Archibald Wavell (pronounced Way-vell), unless to be known as "Archie" even by the 90 per cent of his armies, who have never done more than see him in the distance, is a sign that a legend is beginning to take shape.
BERLIN, Feb. 8 -- In "rolling attacks" on Malta last evening the German Air Force pounded airports, seaplane bases and the harbor at Valletta, the High Command announced today.
BOSTON, Feb. 8 -- That Max C. Meyer, Brooklyn business man, is interested in purchasing the controlling interest in the Bees was confirmed today by President J.A. Robert Quinn.

Through the use of the drama closer cultural relations are being developed between school children in this country and our South American neighbors. A special theatre arts program, based on the lore and life of Brazil, has been introduced experimentally in sixteen school systems in the United States.

Domestic tyrants, male or female, have always been fair game for writers of detective stories. They are ideal murder victims because the reader wastes no sympathy on them and is able to concentrate upon tracking down the murderer.

WHEN Arnold Lunn was a somewhat rebellious student at Harrow soon after the turn of the century he kept a journal for a specific, indeed also a practical, cause. Boys, he remarks, were "crude realists who lived in a world of fact.

A threat by the general executive board of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers to revoke the charter of the Brooklyn district council unless it reinstates Jacob (Jake the Bum) Wellner, an ex-convict, as business agent has confronted the American Federation of Labor with the first test of the anti-racketeering resolution adopted at the federation's New Orleans convention last November, it became known yesterday.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- Two small brothers were drowned and two other children, cousins of the dead youngsters, narrowly escaped a similar fate this afternoon in a coasting accident here attributed indirectly to yesterday's heavy rain.

DETROIT, Feb. 8 -- A demand for a wage increase of 10 cents an hour and other concessions was proposed today by the executive committee of the International General Motors Council of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., at a conference of 139 delegates from seventy General Motors plants.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- As a result of Supreme Court decisions this week, accompanied by developments in the national defense program, organized labor appears to be headed for wider status and greater responsibility.

The temper of the British people under a rain of Nazi bombs is splendid. Sometimes, however, one cannot help wondering if the stories of British behavior and, even more, the pictures of Britain under fire are not a bit too much on the cheerful side.

Setters, Scotch terriers and cocker spaniels will be well represented at Bloomingdale's tenth annual pet dog show which will be held on the sixth floor of the store from Feb. 17 through Feb. 21, it was announced yesterday. As a result of a great deal of out-of-town interest, setters lead in the early entries but close rivals to these breeds are the Scotties and cockers, most of which have been entered by city residents.
SCRANTON, Pa., Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Luzerne County Orphans Court was asked today to stop the transfer of $71,667 to German-dominated Poland to be used for the care of aged Jewish men and women.
BERLIN, Feb. 8 -- The Province of Coblenz-Trier on the Upper Moselle River, opposite the former Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, has been renamed Moselland by a decree of Reichsfuehrer Hitler.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 -- After three years of trial with a centralized public assistance set-up unprecedented in the nation, Pennsylvania has before it a proposal to "decentralize" relief administration.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 8 -- When the Ford Motor Company failed to become the successful bidder on a $10,298,128 order for 11,781 Army trucks recently, a situation was created which threatens to take America's largest single production facility out of the defense program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- State Department officials were interested tonight in a statement by the Mexican Government that an announce ment that "all major problems" have been solved would be made jointly next week by the American and Mexican Governments.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- Playing a deliberate game and wasting few shots, Cornell's basketball team defeated Pennsylvania, 43 -- 31, in Barton Hall today as a record Junior Week crowd of 4,200 looked on.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 8 (AP) -- John Dewey and his Saranac Lake bobsled crew shot down the Mount Van Hoevenberg slide in fast time today to capture the second running of the Joseph R. Linney four-man novice race.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- How $4,000,000 worth of bananas was bought by the British Government from Jamaican and other colonial growers to keep the industry alive and the bananas were then discarded for lack of ships to carry them to England is related in a review of war effects on the trade of the British Empire, appearing today in the Foreign Commerce Weekly of the Commerce Department.
"Our first job of defense," Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie told members of her first radio audience yesterday, "is to see that all groups, creeds and races realize that they are dependent on each other."

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Throughout the Middle East the Axis is on the defensive to a degree that did not exist before. If the initiative in that important theatre of the war is to be wrested from the British, it is clearly up to Hitler to do it, because Mussolini has shown his incapacity and impotence to save the situation.

THERE is a fine integrity in story of Newfoundland, born of the author's knowledge of the country, her liking for its people and her interest in human nature. She avoids long descriptions and explanations; in fact, the reader learns to know the O'Hagen family as he learns to know people in real life, by what they say and do, the opinions they hold and their relations to one another.

An exhibition of flower arrangements for patriotic occasions will be a feature of the first invitation exhibition and indoor garden party to be held by the Women's Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden in cooperation with the nine garden clubs of Brooklyn.

Two Newark detectives went to the Bronx yesterday in an effort to find what they could about Benjamin (Benny the Boss) Tannenbaum, the 28-year-old gangster who was killed Thursday night while tending the 4-months-old daughter of some friends with whom he lived at 40 Featherbed Lane.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- There is closer cooperation between the State legislative and executive branches than at any time in recent years. This is true despite the lack of a declared political truce and despite public continuation of political activity, such as Governor Lehman's criticism of the Legislature in his annual message and State Chairman Edwin F. Jaeckle's attack on the Governor at a Republican gathering here this week.

The 34-year-old Portuguese liner Lourenco Marques, one of the vessels withdrawn from other trades and assigned by the Portuguese Government to the Lisbon-New York refugee route, arrived here yesterday with 305 passengers, including six United States citizens.
Mrs. Dudley Gilroy, a friend of Miss Gertrude Lawrence, wrote her recently a letter enclosing "The Perfect Warden," a list of qualifications for a successful air raid warden in Britain these days.

A deepening of the fear of defeat among Germans and a diminishing of their anxiety over the consequences of defeat must be the object of any military, moral or political attack upon Germany, Dr. Hans Simons, Professor of Political Economy at the New School for Social Research, declared yesterday.

Syracuse University's swimming team handed Fordham its fourth defeat in seven starts, winning by 48 -- 27 yesterday in the Rose Hill pool. The visitors took six of the nine events, all but the 100 and 440 yard free style and the back-stroke.

AN enterprising venture is the publication of "5 Young American Poets" by the New Directions Press ($2.50). They are as young as the average age of 28, their poetry has been published in magazines, but not till now in book form.

Science made its first great contribution to war with gunpowder. But since gunpowder can be used effectively only in suitable firearms, science also had to develop the iron and steel that were required to manufacture muskets and cannon on a huge scale. To this day metallurgy receives much inspiration from war.

IT must be a pretty difficult job to write a good-humored and even humorous novel about the problem of increasingly high taxes in these United States. It must also be rather a ticklish thing to discuss that problem these days without even a passing nod toward the staggering expenses of national defense.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 8 -- This city was warned today that if its private builders did not provide 1,500 dwellings needed for defense workers the Federal Government would send trailers and "knock down houses" here to serve housing purposes.

The detective who figures in this story is Lace White, a spinster of 50 or thereabouts. Strictly speaking, she is neither an amateur nor a professional. She is a lieutenant in the State police, but her appointment appears to have been honorary, conferred upon her because of her work on another case.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- A senior at Elmira College, who is one of the library proctors, has devised a plan to increase interest in recreational reading and to help direct the students in selecting books which they wish to read in leisure time.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Leopold S. Amery, Secretary of State for India, warned in a speech today that "the Nazi tiger is crouching in his thicket, collecting himself for his next murderous and desperate spring."

A number of bills involving civil liberties, introduced at this session of the Legislature, will be actively opposed by the Women's City Club, following a vote of its board of directors last week. Letters explaining their stand are being sent to members of the Senate and Assembly, including those who have introduced the measures. In adopting this action, the board followed the recommendations made by its committee on civil liberties.

BOSTON, Feb. 8 -- A smart Princeton hockey team won a close game at the arena tonight from a fighting but outclassed Harvard sextet, 4 -- 3, to strengthen its lead for Hobey Baker Memorial Trophy and its first Quadrangular League. The smallest crowd for a Harvard-Princeton game in many years looked on.

Now that the annual Motor Boat Show is safely behind them, the skippers of the New York Power Squadron are settling down for serious Winter business, all the while keeping a weather eye open for those March days when Spring overhauling will commence, on those April week-ends when paint and varnish brushes will be drawn and, at last, on those May days when the cruisers will be skidded down the railways for another season afloat.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 8 (AP) -- In the wake of negotiations which opened the way to the removal of urgently needed Army and Navy defense equipment from the strike-bound Allis-Chalmers manufacturing plant, company and union officials announced that they had been summoned to Washington.

Conclusion of the alliance with Germany and Italy plunged Japan into an entirely new situation where advantages and disadvantages are interwoven in a complicated manner, in the opinion of Makio Asada, expert on foreign affairs, writing in "Chuo Koron," or the Japanese Central Review, a publication of high rank.
The American Export liner Exeter sailed with ninety-two passengers yesterday from Pier F, foot of Exchange Place, Jersey City, for Lisbon via Bermuda.

Facing an early opportunity to testify on the lease-lend bill before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Wendell L. Willkie was flying to New York last night aboard the Dixie Clipper of Pan American Airways. The plane, which took off from San Juan, Puerto Rico, at 8:53 o'clock (E.S.T.) last night, was expected to arrive at La Guardia Field around 6:45 o'clock this morning.

The following advertised merchandise drew excellent consumer response last week in three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports:

WASHINGTON -- Present plans for the promised air-mail series call for denominations of 6, 10, 15, 16, 20, 30 and 50 cents and $1, with the possibility there will be 12c and 25c values. According to a Postoffice Department spokesman, regulations do not permit illustrating specific types of planes and the final vignette will probably show a "composite" commercial transport.

For some time in poor health, Mr. Moore continued actively on duty in the State Department until Dec. 13. Before his State Department ser,ice he was a member of the ntional House of Representatives from Virginia, where he and r. HuH became fire friends.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- Court tennis and racquet enthusiasts gathered today to witness the opening rounds of a double-header tournament at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club. Play started in both the annual Gold Racquet court tennis event and the annual Gold Racquets tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Former Governor Alfred M. Landon, Republican candidate for the Presidency in 1936, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that he had parted company with President Roosevelt's foreign policy, which he had previously supported, over the administration lease-lend bill.

IF only for the sake of his last chapter, Mr. Stevers deserves well of the reader for having written this book. A history of human intelligence is, after all, only a history of civilization. And of these there are many, from Buckle to the present day.

The appointment of Colonel Arthur W. Little as an unsalaried military aide to Mayor La Guardia, to assist in the handling of matters connected with the Selective Service Law, was announced yesterday at City Hall. Colonel Little, who is chairman of the advisory committee on WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station, already has been assigned to an office at City Hall.

READERS who remember "Sister Carrie" and who know of its author's stubborn insistence on writing his own kind of novel, in his own way, with his own personal pity and imagination, will want to be patient with Theodore Dreiser.

VICHY, France, Feb. 8 -- The Journal Official this morning confirms the report of this correspondent on Nov. 30 that henceforth all French youth must serve for eight months in special camps on reaching what was heretofore military age.

Girls who are smart enough to be able to sew their own clothes are lucky people this year. The new fabrics in the yard-goods departments have probably never combined so successfully those valuable and often elusive qualities -- unusual and rich-looking designs and reasonable prices.

UTOPIA, Glanville Smith remembers, was an island. And although the islands with which his book is concerned are not Utopian -- being neither more or less than the West Indies -- a certain wayward grace of imagination has touched his wanderings and justifies the use of the beautiful Shelley quotation as the title of a travel book.

RATS SERVE AS PILOTS FOR CATTLE -- Rats are teaching the cattlemen of Florida how pasturage should be improved and nutritional deficiencies corrected. A few months on a ration will produce results in rats that require years to establish with steers and cows.

RADIO, according to accumulating evidence, is nearing its musical maturity. Capable musicians on the air never were more plentiful than now, nor more versatile. Studio sound technique has reached new heights of excellence.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa, -- Buck Hill Falls, one of the oldest Winter resorts in the United States, has provided ski instruction for nearly three decades, and Pocono Manor, a Winter resort for more than twenty years, retains the services of an instructor who is a graduate from the Innsbruck School in Austria.

Changes in the preambles of the Securities Act and the Securities Exchange Act are being discussed by financial leaders and the Securities and Exchange Commission. Their effect would be to make the commission responsible not only for the regulation but for the encouragement of security markets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced today that FBI agents had obtained a confession from Raymond Parker, 52 years old, convicted bank robber and forger, that he was the man who attempted to extort $10,000 from the Countess Marc de Tristan of Hillsborough, Calif., last year.
Benito Mussolini's prestige among the residents of Little Italy, New York's oldest Italian colony, whose main thoroughfare is Mulberry Street in the lower East Side, has suffered a sharp decline.

VICHY, France, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Marshal Henri Philip Petain has resisted German demands -- reported to bear on French bases in the Mediterranean -- with something of the stubbornness that first became apparent to the Germans at Verdun twenty-five years ago.

REPETITION: When the famous D. W. Griffith film "The Birth of a Nation" was being shown to movie-goers a quarter century ago, the film was criticized, sometimes banned, as inciting race hatred. Last week a revival of the famous old movie ran into similar criticism.

AIKEN, S.C., Feb. 8 -- The members of the Winter colony here have centered their interest in the raising of funds for the British and Greek War Relief. Miss Dolly yon Stade is chairman of the relief committee with Miss Barbara Rutherfurd acting as secretary for the newly formed organization.

The Misses Patricia Bull, Sheila Redmond and Barbara Mallory have been appointed as a junior committee to assist at a tea and package party to be given tomorrow afternoon at the home of Mrs. Roland L. Redmond, 760 Park Avenue, for the benefit of the Bargain Box, a thrift mart at Third Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- How the war is changing the quantity, character and direction of American foreign trade, and consequently changing the economy of this country, was revealed by the final export and import figures for 1940, published here this week.

WHEN Ellen Coit Elliot's husband came into the kitchen in Ithaca, one day in 1891, and suggested that they move to California, she just went on cooking the dinner. Going to California had been one of their jokes, and this, she supposed, was the joke's latest appearance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- With strong condemnation of "fence-sitters," who he said refused to face the fact that Christian civilization was threatened with destruction by Nazis and Fascists, Dr. Maurice S. Sheehy, head of Catholic University's Department of Religious Education, announced to a nation-wide radio audience today that he was joining "the fighting forces of our nation" as a naval chaplain.

OTTAWA, Feb. 8 -- Major R.J. Waterous of Brantford, Ont., director of Canada's national salvage campaign, today pointed to the Dominion's 1940 export of bones to the United States as "an amazing instance of what Canadians can do with cast-offs to help win the war."

Of 581 men and women who have earned doctoral degrees at the New York University School of Education during the last decade, sixteen are today college presidents, according to a survey just completed by Dean E. George Payne.

A survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion indicates majority support throughout the nation for the lease-lend bill pending before Congress, according to a report yesterday by Dr. George Gallup, director of the institute. Fifty-four per cent of those questioned, he said, declared in favor of the measure.

MOST spy stories in the past have followed a definite pattern with the enemy spies pictured as deep-dyed villains and the secret agents (they are seldom called spies) of the home country depicted as high-minded heroes whose efforts are chiefly confined to counter-espionage and who never stoop to sabotage or murder.
ROME, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

BOSTON, Feb. 8 -- It may be that the great future predicted for 20-year-old Leslie MacMitchell, the popular N.Y.U. junior, already has arrived. For tonight at the local Madison Square Garden he literally ran away from the field in the famed Hunter Mile and scored a clean-cut victory over Walter Mehl and Chuck Fenske in 4:10.7, figures that represent his fastest winning eight furlongs.

John F. Gehan, vice president of the American Export Line, announced yesterday that the company would have four sailings for India during February and that this volume of tonnage assigned to the trade was believed to be a record.

A WAR correspondent of The London Daily Mail tells in this book the exploits of Squadrons 1 and 73 during the days when the Royal Air Force was operating from French bases. It is above all a study of the personality of air fighters, no two of whom, according to the author, were alike.
FIVE new 16mm. sound movie projectors, designed to meet a wide range of school, industrial and home needs, have been announced by the Eastman Kodak Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered the International Harvester Company today to abolish what it called "company dominated" unions at its six major plants. Some of the company's plants have contracts for material for defense.

An all-day conference on consumer problems is being planned for Saturday, March 1, by Queens College. Directed by Dr. Persia Campbell of the college's Department of Economics, the conference will bring together many community leaders concerned with the problems facing the consumer, as well as authorities in the field of consumer economics.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Here is the text of the British aid bill as amended by the House:

SANFORD, Fla. -- Blue jeans, cowboy boots and a ten-gallon hat are in the wardrobes of many who have come this Winter "way down West in Florida." As part of Florida's booming cattle business, dude ranches are springing up in regions where the cowboys ride herd on their little dogies.

The long list of resignations from the American Rescue Ship Mission, including those of Miss Helen Keller, former national honorary chairman, and Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, was increased yesterday when Harold Riegelman announced his withdrawal.

OTTAWA, Feb. 8 -- What discontent there is with Canada's war effort is due primarily, if not entirely, to every Canadian's desire to be doing more, to be pushing production to the utmost, to be working harder and faster for victory than, it is alleged, has been the case.
The text of John G. Winant's address before the New York City League of Women Voters follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Selective Service registrants are liable to induction into the service regardless of age, draft officials said today in response to inquiries whether a man was automatically exempt after reaching the age of 36.

An Associated Press dispatch of Feb. 5 tells the story of thirty-five irate mothers who, following the traffic killing of a 7-year-old schoolboy, established their own traffic control at Annandale, S.I., and by that act forced the posting of a regular traffic cop to protect the children.

IT has long been a recognized fact that P.G. Wodehouse possesses an especial English province of his own, the inhabitants whereof are slightly and delightfully mad in an entirely English way. Bordering on this province are others, several slightly connected with it, like that of Angela Thirkell, others more or less closely related.

ROME, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Students at Ancona on the Adriatic coast and at Syracuse in Sicily paraded today with Fascist officials and townspeople as a "protest against stupid stories about Italy spread by the British." The demonstrations were touched off by foreign reports of disorded in Italy.

PREDICTIONS that the war would end all interest in pleasure travel appear to have been premature. Discovery that the travel horizon, even with Europe blacked out, is far from circumscribed and still holds exciting adventure has been made apparent by an increasing number of travelers, travelers pushing out to Hawaii and the Philippines, to Alaska, to the Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico and Panama.

PUCCINI'S "Sister Angelica" will be sung in English on the last half of the program to be given by the National Orchestral Association on Monday, Feb. 17, in Carnegie Hall. The opera will be the second presented by the organization as an experiment in the field of "music plays."
Yesterday was a dark day for the amateur tennis player accustomed to following the sun wherever invitations call almost the year around, with all expense paid.

AN exhibition than which there never was hereabouts has opened at the Philadelphia Museum. The exhibition itself is not so unusual. It is the tenth annual put on by the Art Directors Club of Philadelphia, and -- exemplifying a year's activity -- in most respects resembles the annuals presented by the Art Directors Club of New York.

IT is a London suburb. A fishmonger holds up kippers for inspection by one of his oldest customers. The customer nods his assent, and the fishmonger calls to the clerk behind the desk, "40 Limes Avenue, kippers tenpence."

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- In a steadily increasing flow the great dominions and colonies composing the worldwide British Empire are supplying the motherland with fighting men, ships, war materials, foodstuffs and money with which to help win this conflict.

A forceful reminder that Germany is sparing no effort to obtain every ounce of monetary gold possible, despite protestations by German spokesmen that the world's time-honored gold system is hopelessly outmoded, was given last week when representatives here of the Belgian Government in exile went to court to prevent the loss of $260,000,000 of French-held Belgian gold to Germany.
RIVER VALE, N.J., Feb. 8 (AP) -- The New York Rovers triumphed over the River Vale Skeeters, 4 -- 3, tonight to end the home team's run of five victories on home ice in the Eastern Hockey League.

NEW SALEM, Ill. -- To recede from a thriving grist-mill village in 1830 to a deserted village in 1840, to a decayed and vanished village after 1860 and to reappear, restored in every detail, in 1941 is the unique history of this town.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The French Ambassador, Gaston Henry-Haye, discussed France's food situation with President Roosevelt at the White House today and, on leaving, expressed the hope for a "quick understanding" with the United States Government to facilitate shipment from here of food to meet France's most pressing needs.

Industry is now providing increasing competition for retailers in obtaining employes, with the result that retail businesses are experiencing a constantly tightening labor market, according to the results of a survey made by the personnel group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

THE measure of Ernest Newman as a scholar and writer of scrupulous fairness has never been so eloquently underscored as it is in the third volume of his splendid and definitive biography of Richard Wagner. He finished the text in the Spring of 1940 after his own country, Britain, had gone to war once more with Germany, whose Nazi leader venerates Wagner above all other composers.

IN calling up some 800,000 young men for military training in the year 1941 country will barely tap its vast human resources. The force that will be put into uniform will be only about one-seventieth of the male population. It will comprise only about one-twenty-fifth of the men between the draft ages of 18 and 36.

IN the Autumn of 1860 the young journalist Henry Villard was sent by The New York Herald to Springfield, Ill., to report on the day-by-day activities of the President-elect. Mr. Villard had met Abraham Lincoln during the course of the Douglas debates and had "found him most approachable, good-natured, and full of wit and humor."

DETROIT, Feb. 8 -- The impact of defense production upon the automotive industry's normal output, if manufacturing of cars were suddenly to cease, would result in the surplus stocks of 1941 models being cleaned out in six weeks, it was said here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Protest against the adoption by Congress of the lease lend bill was presented by officials of the American Youth Congress to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee this morning and to President Roosevelt this afternoon as 6,000 members of the organization assembled at the Washington Monument for an open-air meeting addressed by Representative Marcantonio.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 -- Disqualification of the Princeton free style relay team prevented the Pennsylvania swimming team from reaching an all-time low in Hutchinson pool today, the final score of the Eastern Intercollegiate League meet being 61-14.

As its midwinter production the Amateur Comedy Club, Inc., will present performances of Eugene O'Neill's play, "Ah, Wilderness:" next Thursday, Friday and Satur-I in the Hunter College audi-I day torture. It will be the club's first! appearance at that locale, the productions having been given for l years at the Heckscher Theatre.

OF all the subjects the average amateur movie maker seeks to put on reels, children are the most popular and the most cherished. In fact, if any one ever measured the exposed film of children during a single year the sum, undoubtedly, would be staggering.

Republicans opposed to the leadership of John J. Knewitz, Bronx County chairman, announced yesterday they had changed the name of their organization from the Independent Republican Committee to the Committee for Republican Reorganization in Bronx County as a result of the decision of Supreme Court Justice McGeehan barring use of the former name.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The deaths of at least twenty-seven Army fliers in airplane accidents in less than two months has prompted the air corps to undertake an intensive study of safety records and crash-prevention measures.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Interdenominational support by clergymen and prominent laymen for the Administration's lease-lend bill was voiced today in a letter sent to Senator George, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

Al Shean returns to the theatre this evening in a comedy entitled "Popsy," by Frederick Herendeen, who tells the story of a mathematics professor looking forward to retirement. Other in the cast are Sylvia Field, Edith King, Eva Condon, Robert Allen and Percy Helton. Rowland G. Edwards directed and Tom Adrian Cracraft designed the scenery.

QUEBEC, Feb. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Police used tear gas "to some extent" during an hour-long street fight with members of the Highland Light Infantry unit stationed here, Lieut. Col. G.F. Berteau, Assistant Adjutant and Quartermaster General of Military District No. 5, said tonight.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9 -- A "streamlined" omnibus amendment to the National Labor Relations Act will be offered in Congress soon, it was reported today by a spokesman for the American Federation of Labor. The A.F.L. executive council of nineteen members will open its Winter meeting here tomorrow with the arrival of President William Green.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9 -Fifty nominations for 1940 were announced tonight by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences as the list from which awards in ten categories will be voted on by 12,000 members of the film industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The battle over the Administration's lease-lend bill for aid to Britain and her allies moves this week to the Senate side of the Capitol, with the immediate conclusion expected to be a favorable report on the modified House measure from its Foreign Relations Committee before or by the end of the week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Tax refunds during the 1940 fiscal year totaling $65,226,738, including one of $838 to former Vice President John N. Garner, were reported to Congress today by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- A Britain "incomparably stronger" than even that of last September does not need United States armies "this year, nor next year nor any year that I can foresee," Prime Minister Winston Churchill said tonight in a broadcast that brimmed over with vitality and confidence.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- No comment has been aroused by the announcement of the arrival of a huge amount of gold in the United States from South Africa.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Total retail sales in United States in 1940 amounted to $45,500,000,000, a gain of $3,476,000,000, or 8 per cent over 1939, it was announced today by Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., Feb. 9 -- The new War Department theatre, opened here tonight, hung up the S.R.O. sign for the first performance, which was held immediately after Lieut. Col. Robert T. Snow, executive officer, cut a ribbon across the foyer.

Two trends -- secularism and intellectualism -- are endangering our civilization today, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 9 -- The Germans' seizure of ten Danish torpedo boats, in violation of their pledges, has created strong feeling against them in Denmark, reports received here today indicate.

The failure of house trailer sales to multiply as rapidly as many prophets had hoped, back in the middle Thirties, may have more serious implications than first appears. Mr. Blackburn Sims, in a recent article in our Sunday travel and resort section, discussed this failure and intimated that certain shortcomings of human nature as well as the trailers themselves might be responsible.

Another link in his sensational chain of major triumphs was added by the famed Ch. Royal Kid Regards last night to conclude the highly successful thirty-third annual Boston Terrier Club of New York specialty show staged at the Park Central Hotel.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- With the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club crowded today with several hundred visitors from New York, Robert Grant 3d, sensational racquets star, gained the final round in the annual Gold Racquets tournament and later proved his skill at another game by reaching the final in the annual Gold Racquets court tennis tournament.

MADRID, Spain, Feb. 9 -- Although the morning newspapers featured the announcement that Argentine wheat, cotton and meat would soon reach hungry Spain, a dispatch describing conditions in French Africa may turn out to be of more immediate importance.

SAUGUS, Mass., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Laurence G. Hanscom, aged 34, State House corespondent of The Worcester Telegram, and Dr. Anthony V. Carbone, 34, chiropodist, of Cambridge, were killed today when a single-motor biplane nose-dived to earth out of control.

If last week's jumbled college basketball results prove anything, it is that all the leading teams of the East are vulnerable, with the possible exception of Dartmouth, which, in the Eastern League at least, appears immune to defeat in its drive toward its fourth straight title.

At its concert in Town Hall yesterday afternoon the Roth String Quartet devoted its program to works by Marthe Servine, with the composer at the piano. The compositions performed consisted of a piano quintet in B flat major, another piano quintet in E flat major, entitled "Spring," and a sonata for violin and piano. In the last-named offering the violin part was played by Feri Roth, the quartet's leader.

Two of National Distillers products which set new sales records last year, Old Crow bottled-in-bond whisky and deKuyper cordials, will be backed by greatly expanded advertising campaigns this year, the company announces. Old Crow will be promoted with an enlarged program in newspapers and magazines.

The Women's Prison Association of New York, which maintains the Isaac T. Hopper Home, 110 Second Avenue, announced yesterday in its annual report that it had been more successful during 1940 in finding employment for girls than in several years past.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 9 -- Lawson Little, national open champion, shot a 67, four under par in the afternoon round today to win the annual $5,000 Texas open golf tournament with a total of 273, eleven under par, for seventy-two holes.

Financial markets recovered slowly last week, though only after average stock market prices had fallen 6 points in less than a month, and had touched on Tuesday the lowest figure since last June. That was the month in which the low average of 1940 was reached.

LONDON Feb. 9 -- American insurance companies which have refused to accept risks not acceptable to British companies were cited today by J.C. Wilmot, Parliamentary Private Secretary to the Ministry of Economic Warfare, as an outstanding example of the kind of voluntary help most needed.

BERLIN, Feb. 9 -- Reports circulating in Berlin last week that Pastor Martin Niemoeller, imprisoned Confessional Church leader, had embraced the Roman Catholic faith brought the church question in totalitarian Germany once more to the foreground for a brief moment.
MOSCOW, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Amid reports of growing tension in the Far East between Japan and the "Anglo-American bloc," Soviet Russia opened negotiations today for a trade treaty with Japan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Further substantial additions to bank reserves arising from gold imports and an increase in bank loans and investments were reported by the Federal Reserve Board today in a review of 1940.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- The Willard Gibbs Medal, one of the highest distinctions in chemical science, has been awarded for 1941 by the Chicago section of the American Chemical Society to Dr. Edward A. Doisy of the St. Louis University School of Medicine, who first isolated pure Vitamin K, the blood-clotting principle.

The executive board of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, has notified the 27,000 members of the union employed on the rapid transit and surface lines of the city's unified transit system that it will seek to negotiate with the Board of Transportation a new labor contract calling for a general wage increase of 33 1-3 per cent, it was disclosed yesterday.

For the tenth time since negotiations began Jan 9, representatives of the National Maritime Union, a C.I.O. affiliate, and the American Merchant Marine Institute will attempt to reach an agreement on a wage scale for seamen on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts when committees representing both groups meet today at the offices of the institute, 11 Broadway.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 9 -- It is stated in some circles here that the usefulness of the Burma Road to China is about ended. The Japanese state that their naval and military bombers have effectively reduced all the bridges across the Mekong River and its tributaries to wrecks that, in most cases, are a mile or more downstream from their original positions.

The City Council committee's investigation of the Municipal Civil Service Commission and Paul J. Kern, commission president, was assailed as politically biased and unfair and intent on discrediting the administration of Mayor La Guardia, in statements issued separately yesterday by Councilman Robert K. Straus, Fusion member of the committee, and the executive board of the United Neighborhood houses.

Orville S. McPherson, publisher of The Kansas City Journal, came here yesterday to announce the launching of United Americans, a new nation-wide, non-partisan organization to unite the "rank and file" of Americans behind the foreign policy of President Roosevelt -- even if it means war.

The lack of faith in God will lead ultimately to the decline of America, the Right Rev. Malcolm E. Peabody, Bishop Coadjutor of Central New York, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9 -Columbia has purchased screen rights to George Abbott's current Broadway production, "Pal Joey," and has signed Mr. Abbott to produce the film version. The music for "Pal Joey" was written by Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, and the book by John O'Hara.

The plant of the White Motor Company on an entire city block in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by the Ford Instrument Company, which intends to expand its working area to cooperate under the national defense program.

Five hundred persons attended last night the second annual dinner of the Catholic Laymen's First Friday Clubs at the Hotel Astor. Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre presided at the dinner at which the Rev. James M. Gillis, pastor of the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, was guest speaker.

STANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 9 -- According to well-founded reports from Bulgaria today, the issuance of a German ultimatum demanding the right of passage of troops to attack Salonika is not likely to be delayed more than two weeks and may well come within a few days.

A major problem in military welfare is now confronting scores of little communities all over the country. Major Gen. Lloyd R. Fredendall, commanding general at Fort Benning, Ga., hinted at this problem in a talk he made in Columbus, Ga., nearest town to Fort Benning.

The International Game Fish Association, which has brought big game fishing out of its previous "record-claiming chaos," has made public a list of the present record-holders for various fish. This list, while complete, may not be up to the very minute, as the association may now be in the process of checking the affidavits on a catch that will set a new mark in some classification.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Speculative interest in the wheat market continues at a low ebb, with professional operators talking bearishly and pressing the selling side from time to time, but without any great enthusiasm, as it is admitted that the only pressure comes from the short sellers.

The Manhattan Chess Club championship changed hands yesterday when Albert S. Pinkus, undefeated in eight games, drew his last match with Jack Soudakoff, lone conqueror of Arnold S. Denker, titleholder for the past year.

Religious art, rare books and cult objects illustrating religions from primitive African worship to modern Christianity will go on display Wednesday in Columbia University's Low Memorial Library in connection with the celebration of the thirty-fourth annual Alumni Day.

BERLIN, Monday, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Nazi long range bombers in an attack on a British convoy in the Atlantic west of Spain yesterday were reported by informed Germans today to have sunk three merchantmen, caused the total loss of three others and badly damaged an additional three.

The united front of dress manufacturers in opposition to the "efficiency" program proposed by the Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union was broken yesterday when three of the five employer associations in the $350,000,000-a-year dress industry reached a tentative agreement with the union on all major provisions of a new collective-bargaining contract, including measures to enforce efficient management.
Following is the text of the address broadcast by Prime Minister Winston Churchill yesterday as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Branding the lease-lend bill "hysterical madness," Amos Pinchot yesterday urged President Roosevelt to accept an amendment which would require him to appear before Congress for oral questioning on his execution of aid to Britain whenever a majority of the members request his presence.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- For the first time in some years, farmers in the southwestern part of the Winter wheat belt are complaining of the muddy condition of the grain fields, in striking contrast with the urgent need of rain that had been the normal condition in many sections since 1934.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Italian General Annibale Bergonzoli has been captured at Bengazi, Libya, it was reported here today. This was the second time that he had been trapped by the British in the North African campaign. On the earlier occasion he managed to escape from Bardia. The most popular theory is that the general boarded a motor launch and escaped past the British naval units offshore.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- How Fred MacDuff of Seminole, Okla., gave a carload of scrap iron to Great Britain and thus started a movement in which the whole State has now enlisted was related by Representative Lyle H. Boren of Oklahoma over a National Broadcasting Company chain tonight.

VICHY, France, Feb. 9 -- Admiral Jean Darlan became the directing member of the French Cabinet today through a double appointment by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain as successor to Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin and as Vice Premier.

Supreme Court Justice Hugo L. Black, Dr. Albert Einstein, Brig. Gen. Benjamin O. Davis and Jack Benny, the comedian, were among white persons and Negroes whose names were added yesterday to the Honor Roll of Race Relations for 1940.
Net income of E.L. du Pont de Nemours Co. in 1940 was 7 per cent less than in 1939, although the volume of business rose 20 per cent, according to the annual report reaching stockholders today.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 9 -- That Japan is more than willing to conclude some sort of anti-aggression pact with Soviet Russia is shown by Japanese efforts in Manchuria and North China to act on suggestions from Moscow, according to foreign sources here in Shanghai.

WOODSTOCK, Vt., Feb. 9 -- Burt Porter of the Otter Ski Club of Rutland nosed out Edgar Bering of Boston's Ski Club Hochgebirge by two-tenths of a second to win the tenth annual Woodstock Ski Runners' Fisk Trophy slalom race on Suicide Six today.

An attractive residence in the Gramercy Park section of Manhattan changed hands when A.P. Keasbey, president of the Robert A. Keasbey Asbestos Company, sold the house with a frontage of twenty-four feet at 140 East Nineteenth Street. It has a two-story living room forty feet deep overlooking a garden. The buyer is a New Yorker who intends to occupy the house after minor changes. Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers in the sale.

BAHIA BLANCA, Argentina, Feb. 9 -- Twenty persons were stabbed tonight in a wild riot at an Italian Red Cross festival in which members of the Italian colony and Argentine youths fought with clubs, bottles and knives.

BERLIN, Feb. 9 -- That Germany's national debt has more than doubled since the beginning of the war was made known last week by Fritz Reinhardt, Assistant Minister of Finance, who said that the Reich's obligations at the end of 1940 amounted to 79,000,000,000 marks, this sum including the outstanding tax certificates.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Two agencies of the Federal Government today announced further plans to utilize civilian facilities for training men in defense activities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A.G. Black, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, anounced today that the twelve district banks for cooperatives and the Central Bank for Cooperatives would reduce the interest rate on new facility loans from 4 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent, effective on March 1.

The plan of eight metropolitan area engineering colleges for meeting the war industries' demands for trained personnel was put into operation this morning as 385 young men started upon twenty weeks of intensive college training in sub-professional engineering.

Separated from their parents for six months or more, eighteen British refugee children joined their kin yesterday for a few minutes over the transatlantic air ways in a two-way broadcast from, England and Scotland to the United States and Canada.

The passage in Winston Churchill's speech yesterday which bears most directly on the problem engaging the attention of this country was the emphatic statement that the aid needed by Britain does not include man power and will not involve sending armies to Europe next year, the year after, or in any year that he can foresee.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The British Admiralty issued the following communique today:

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 -- Governor Keen Johnson of Kentucky and Mrs. Johnson, who are at the Wofford, were honor guests here tonight of Dr. and Mrs. John Patterson of Miami at a dinner. Miss Judith Johnson, daughter of Governor and Mrs. Johnson, and Miss Mary Elizabeth Patterson were in the luncheon party of Miss Crutcher Field at the home of her brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Crawford, in Coconut Grove.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Full protection was granted to all but 1,686 of the 1,133,379 depositors of banks closed or merged with Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation financial aid in the calendar year 1940, the FDIC announced today. The total deposits of these banks were $438,625,000, of which nearly 98 per cent was promptly made available to depositors.

Opposition to the dismissal of public school children for religious instruction during school hours was expressed yesterday by the Rev. John H. McComb in his sermon in Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway at 114th Street.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices declined to 85.4 from 85.7. Most group indexes showed moderate decreases. Building materials, however, experienced a decline of 2.5 per cent due to a reduction in lumber prices. Again there were several individual changes in the farm products and foodstuffs groups, but in each the decreases slightly outweighed the increases, bringing the indexes down to 70.6 and 83.9 respectively.

Replying to charges of Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley that certain special counsel and experts in the Law Department are illegally employed at excessive rates, Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler in a report to Controller Joseph McGoldrick denied yesterday that expense bills had been padded and that the persons were overpaid.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A survey showed today that $1,200,000,000 of new factories and plant expansions had been sponsored by the War Department for the armament program.

Frank Kovacik Jr., 23 years old, of 108 East 124th Street, walked along the bank of the Hudson River in the vicinity of 160th Street yesterday, doing one more eight-hour stretch in a vigil that began Jan. 20, when his father disappeared.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- The broad secondary benefits of the defense program upon consumer goods industries were illustrated today by statistics released by the Folding Paper Box Association of America, showing that 1940 shattered all previous records for the industry in both orders booked and shipments made.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Feb. 9 -- In a move to maintain stability in the Dominion's important meat-production industry the administration has decided to guarantee to all buyers of export meat that it will be purchased ultimately by the New Zealand Government, irrespective of any final agreement that is negotiated with Great Britain, it was made known here officially today.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 9 -- Trading interest in cotton futures here quieted down last week with the price range the narrowest in several weeks. The securities market gave no incentive, while many traders held aloof in hopes of getting further clues on government intentions toward the new crop soon to be sown.

These are days which test the devotion of those who "go down to the sea in ships." To make the way a little easier the American Merchant Marine Library Association collects books and magazines for the sailors to read in their leisure hours. It is the universal testimony of our merchant mariners that no voluntary service gives them greater satisfaction and enjoyment.

Breaking 97 out of 100 target, E.C. Monell won the high scratch trophy at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. There was a tie between J.V. Higgins and T.R. Chatfield for the handicap prize, each with 100 full targets.

The marble high altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral that has been the focal point of all solemn ceremonies in the church since 1879, and before which the present Pope and virtually every American prelate has knelt in prayer, will be replaced by a new one, which "it is hoped will be ready for service within a year," Archbishop Francis J. Spellman disclosed yesterday in an announcement read at all masses at the cathedral.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Lowell Bennett of South Orange, N.J., a corporal in the "Free French" forces, and Enid Walker, an employe at the club for the American Eagle Squadron, were married yesterday.

The mechanical skills of America's army of workers, largely unwanted during the years of depression, have been turned by the threat of war into the nation's most important resource for defense. From industries throughout the country the cry has gone up for more and more trained men. But there aren't any more trained men.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 9 -- A week after the inauguration of Governor Guy J. Swope, the new Legislature elected in November will convene tomorrow. It is controlled by an entirely new party by the narrowest margin.

MONTREAL, Feb. 9 -- New France, which was established on this continent more than 400 years ago and has been incorporated in the British Empire and under the British Crown for a hundred and eighty years, knelt today in all its churches in prayer "for victory, without which there can be no lasting peace."

The one hundredth anniversary of the founding of the congregation that worships now in Riverside Church, and the tenth anniversary of the dedication of the present church edifice, were observed yesterday afternoon in a special commemorative service.

HONG KONG, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Chinese Central News agency declared today that important documents exposing a Japanese plan to launch a southward push were found in the wreckage of a plane in which Admiral Mineo Osumi, Japanese Supreme War Councilor, was killed in Kwangtung Province, China.

Measures taken during a period of war often have a considerable effect on the possibilities of achieving stable political and economic conditions after the war is over. Among the measures which it is desirable to avoid, so far as possible, are any which have as a consequence the creation of huge international debts, like the allied war debts which plagued the years following 1918.

A saving of at least $6,000,000 annually for consumers in New York City would result from the operation of the proposed Union Fruit and Vegetable Terminal Market between Piers 22 and 30, off West Street in downtown Manhattan, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, said yesterday at the twentieth annual convention of the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The average layman spends a good deal of time these days attempting to guess at what rate or in what numbers the fighting air fleets of the world are being increased. Even the experts disagree among themselves, sometimes by as much as 200 per cent.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- While a few small lots of government-owned cash corn have been disposed of recently, it is understood that the trade as a whole has failed to endorse the idea of taking any large volume of this grain owing to the relatively higher price than that which obtains in the open market for the 1940 crop.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Heinz Krebs, veteran German Ski Club member of New York City, hurtled down precipitous Whiteface Mountain in 2 minutes 44.8 seconds to capture the New York State downhill ski title today.

OTTAWA, Feb. 9 (Canadian Press) -- The appointment of Malcolm MacDonald, a British Cabinet member, as High Commissioner to Canada is a "clear indication of the importance the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom attaches to the representation of the Government of the United Kingdom in Canada," Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King said tonight.

CEDAR GROVE, N.J., Feb. 9 -- Two New York City girls were killed and their escorts were injured early this morning when they were struck by a speeding automobile that was being pursued by a police patrol car on Pompton Turnpike here.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 9 -- No one could make a greater mistake than to think of the French here, or for that matter anywhere else, as considering themselves vanquished by the Italians. They are far from such thoughts. They are actually much addicted to speculation as to what might have happened had the Allies seen through Premier Mussolini's "neutrality" in time and had fallen on him.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said in a special report today that completion of the St. Lawrence waterway project would open new shipbuilding facilities in the Great Lakes States which would be needed for "a long period to come."

Rossini's "Il Barbiere di Siviglia" will be presented next week for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House. John Charles Thomas, who will sing Figaro, will make his first appearance of the season and Salvatore Baccaloni will sing Dr. Bartolo.
