By the new air express service for live birds, a pair of varied thrushes, the first ever exhibited at the Bronx Zoo, were lodged safely in their new quarters twenty hours after having been sent by airplane from California, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- In a daring penetration of the waters that Italians regard as exclusively their own, a powerful force of British warships heavily bombarded Genoa, Italy's fourth city, chief seaport, site of an important naval base and possible invasion port for an attack on Bizerte, at dawn today, the Admiralty announced here this afternoon.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 9 -- Four Soviet officers arrived by air at Sofia today, according to a Sofia report received by a Belgrade newspaper. Further details and confirmation of the report were lacking and could not be confirmed from official sources.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- Twenty-three gunners one of the largest squads of the Winter, took part in the shoot at the Westchester Courtry Club today. At singles the winner was H. Heming, who broke 47. W. Shorten took the handicap trophy with 49.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Feb. 9 -- Forty-three North American concerns are represented in El Salvador by German and Italian agents, according to a preliminary, incomplete survey made here, it was revealed today. Virtually every one of them must contribute to the propaganda of the Nazi and Fascist parties, which are largely anti-American because of United State's aid to Britain.

Pan American Airways is now building land planes that it plans to introduce into transatlantic service, possibly in 1942, it was disclosed yesterday by Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American, on his arrival here on the Dixie Clipper, which also brought Wendell L. Willkie and his party.

The official Athens radio yesterday broadcast "the new Fascist alphabet, prepared for the use of Italy by the institute of imperial instruction in Rome." The broadcast was recorded here by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 9 -- The securities markets of the smaller Continental European countries last week reflected even greater reluctance to enter on new commitments than in the previous week, with the conviction gaining ground among traders that the coming Spring, just as last year, will witness a renewal of violent military activity of perhaps finally decisive importance.

That romance and dogs are interwoven was demonstrated yesterday at the Grand Central Palace, where the Associated Terrier Clubs held their annual exhibition. In the show of the United States Kerry Blue Terrier Club the winner was Buskin of Kenmare, owned by James M. Austin of Old Westubry, L.I.

The "ten outstanding books of 1940," as determined in a nationwide poll of 159 literary critics by the Book-of-the-Month Club, were announced yesterday by Dr. Henry Seidel Canby, chairman of the club's editorial committee.

VICHY, France, Feb. 9 -- The question of supplies still holds first place among the government's problems, and new measures have been taken on the subject. After Feb. 15 no transfers of the principal foodstuffs could be made from one zone to the other without a special permit from the Minister of Supplies or his representatives.
A furnished apartment of fourteen rooms and six baths in 625 Park Avenue has been leased by Richard C. Bondy Jr., to the Baron and Baroness Eugene de Rothschild through Douglas Gibbons Co.

An arbitration agreement prohibiting strikes or lockouts in the local and long-distance trucking industry for the next two years was accepted yesterday by representatives of three employer associations and three locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- A hearing on the proposed 1941-42 State budget will take place on Wednesday of this week, in the Assembly chamber, with some 125 speakers scheduled to present their views on increased or decreased State spending.

laris, piloted by H.P. Shreeve of the Lake Hopatcong Ice Boat and Yacht Club, won the Class X championship and Ott Loree's Doss of the Greenwood Lake Ice Boat and Yacht Club captured the Class D title as the annual regatta of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association was resumed today on Lake Musconetcong.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Feb, 9 -- An informal program of military training has been started at Lawrenceville School, it was announced here today by Dr. Allan Heely, headmaster of the school. The program will be voluntary and for members of the senior class only.

The only hope for the Christian church in the world today lies in the fact that Jesus Christ is coming again, the Rev. Dr. W.H. Rogers declared yesterday in opening the first session of the Prophetic Bible Conference at the morning service of the Central Baptist Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

An agreement to cease using wild bird plumage for any purpose, including millinery and decorative usage, was announced in a joint declaration yesterday by the National Audubon Society and the Feather Industries of America, Inc., which is composed of 90 per cent of all the manufacturers, dealers and jobbers in the industry.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Two detectives and a patrolman stood watchfully near today as 15-year-old Leonard Pluto came home from his Siberian adventure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Several opposition Senators reiterated today that they were concentrating On defeating the lease-lend bill rather than seeking to amend it. This group included Senator Johnson, Republican, of California, ranking minority member of the Foreign Relations Committee, and Senator Wheeler, Democrat, of Montana.

SALISBURY MILLS, N.Y, Feb. 9 -- In one of the keenest ski jumping competitions in the history of the sport in the East, 19-year-old Jay Rand of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds showed his triple-grooved hickory blades to an international field to win the twentieth anniversary meet of the Norsemen S.C. under superb conditions today.

Emanuel Feuermann, cellist, and Albert Hirsh, young American pianist, gave the first of two Beethoven sonata recitals yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall under the auspices of the New Friends of Music. They played the first and the last of the five cello and piano sonatas, the one in F major, Op. 5, No. 1, and the one in D major, Op. 102, No. 2. They will present the three intervening ones next Sunday.
ATHENS, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Greek High Command issued a communiqu tonight as follows:

AGORDAT, Eritrea, Feb. 8 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Italians are using a brigade rushed from Addis Ababa, capital of Ethiopia, to reinforce positions at Cheren, in the path of the British offensive. These reinforcements launched a counter-attack, which the British appear to have repulsed, inflicting heavy losses on the Italians.

Cotton prices fluctuated narrowly last week and at the close of business on Saturday showed little net change. On the New York Cotton Exchange, active futures contracts were 4 points lower to 2 points higher for the week.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 9 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued the following communique today:

Declaring it would create a preferred class in the Army and be unfair to those drafted from civil life, the Merchants Association recommended yesterday the rejection of Governor Lehman's proposal, made in his annual legislatize message, to pay city and State employes drafted under the Selective Service Act the difference between their military and civil compensation.

Fifty-five hundred Catholic Boy Scouts, celebrating the thirty-first anniversary of the founding of the Boy Scouts and the seventh annual Boy Scout Sunday of the Archdiocese of New York, yesterday afternoon marched from Madison Square Garden to St. Patrick's Cathedral, where their colors were blessed.

The Poles of New York State observed yesterday, proclaimed as Poland Day by Governor Lehman in memory of their country's "30,000,000 martyred and persecuted men, women and children," who had become victims of the present European struggle.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 -- A three-hour fire following an explosion of uncertain origin destroyed a one-story storage shed and mixing department at Frankford Arsenal early today.

The most significant lesson we can learn from Lincoln today is the necessity for religious tolerance if the unity of the nation is to be preserved, the Rev. Dr. Louis W. Pitt, rector of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, declared yesterday morning at a Lincoln anniversary week service for members of the National Republican Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Placements of workers in private industry by the various State employment offices totaled 3,200,000 persons in 1940, an all-time high since the service was established in 1933, the Federal Security Agency reported today.

ROME, Feb. 9 -- Giovanni Ansaldo, editor of Foreign Minister Count Ciano's newspaper, Telegrafo of Leghorn, minces no words in telling his readers what a blow Bengazi has been, and there is criticism as well as implied doubts for the future of Tripolitania, Libya, in his editorial in the Telagrafo and his broadcast to the armed forces.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 9 -- The projected visit of General Henri Dentz, French commander in the Near East, to Damascus, Syria, this week is considered here as aiming to align Syria with Vichy's policy and to avoid repercussions from the Paris-Vichy exchanges.
ROME, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The new tomb of Pope Plus XI, carved from a block of marble weighing two and a half tons, was consecrated today in the grottoes of St, Peter's,
The appointment of Harold M. Salkind as executive director of the Beth David Hospital, Lexington Avenue and Ninetieth Street, was announced yesterday. He will take over his new duties March 15.

From Saturday to Saturday the leading as well as lesser lights of the nation's track athletes had their fill of competition. Four meets were held in a span of eight nights. From the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden the scene shifted to the Seton Hall, Penn A.C. and Boston A.A. program. The Hub meet was the best of the campaign.

Seven new films are scheduled for Broadway premieres this week. The first arrival will be "Back Street," a Universal remake of the Fannie Hurst story, which was first filmed in 1932. Charles Boyer and Margaret Sullavan are co-starred in the film, which will open tomorrow at 7 P.M. in the Rivoli Theatre. The schedule for the remainder of the week follows:

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Britain's rapidly advancing Army of the Nile, its speed apparently unchecked, reported today it had smashed almost one-third of the way between captured Bengazi and Tripoli, Libya's capital and last major stronghold.

Seven thousand students start their classes today at Hunter, beginning the college's seventy-second academic year. Forty-five hundred girls are registered at 695 Park Avenue and 2,500 at the Bronx Buildings, among them 1,001 freshmen who attend classes for the first time.

BERLIN, Feb. 9 -- The military quiescence of Germany continues, to all external appearances, to be undisturbed. How long it will remain so is open to question. In the official German view such a period of inactivity is an integral portion of the German military and political strategy.

One of the greatest defects in the field of administrative law, as was pointed out in the recent Acheson report, is the difficulty that confronts persons dealing with an administrative agency in knowing what the law is. An example of this defect has lately been supplied by the Securities and Exchange Commission, in connection with its regulation of the over-the-counter market.

The nineteenth annual pet show staged yesterday afternoon in the gymnasium of the Madison Square Boys Club at Twenty-ninth Street and Second Avenue was a helter-skelter, deafeningly raucous occasion. When the last yap had subsided, a 5-year-old Boston toy terrier named Peggy -- three times a champion -- emerged as heroine of the day.
Why is it that we all have to wear a label even if it is invisible?
ROME, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issue this communique today:
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe got a breathing spell today in the world three-cushion billiard championship tournament, so he spent the day practicing.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 9 -- Despite the vigilance of British and Greek air patrols in the Adriatic, the loss by the Italians of Porto Edda and considerable destruction caused in Valona by Royal Air Force bombing raids, the Italians are building up a large new army in Albania in the hope they will be able to reverse the persistent Greek advance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The American Youth Congress reiterated at its closing session today its opposition to all dictatorships of whatever class or kind, and to "imperialistic wars" in which, whatever their declared aims, it held that the masses of people suffered much and gained nothing in the end.
The Bureau of Internal Revenue issued a statement yesterday defining losses on stock transactions in connection with the filing of a Federal income tax return.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A statement by Jerome Frank, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, that "I was one of those who believed Western Hemispheric isolation was not only desirable but achievable, but the harsh realities of violent change have compelled me long since to admit the futility of my hopes," was a highlight of an American Forum of the Air broadcast tonight on "Is War Inevitable for the United States if Britain Falls?

With the game not half over, the New York Americans found themselves trailing the Canadiens of Montreal, 3 to 0, in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. When the battle was over the Canadiens still had those three goals, but the Americans had the amazing total of six.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 10 -- London yesterday afternoon had its first daytime air raid in nearly a week. Last evening the alarm sounded again, breaking the series of quiet nights since Wednesday. Neither of these attacks -- as was the case with other Nazi excursions over Britain in the past twenty-four hours -- amounted to anything.

Wendell L. Willkie, returning from "the most stimulating experience in my life," brought back from Great Britain yesterday the firm conviction that for the United States to give aid to Great Britain would be likely to enable us to stay out of war, and that to withhold aid from Great Britain would probably involve this country in war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Certificates of necessity for plant expansion under the national-defense program were issued to fifty-one corporationse from Jan. 16 through Jan. 31, the National Defense Advisory Commission announced today.
DETROIT, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The amazing Bruins, currently the hottest team on ice, extended their undefeated streak to eighteen games by rallying to gain a 2-to-2 tie with the Red Wings tonight.

The outlook for the New York Rovers is much rosier. The Red Shirts gained their second triumph in as many days yesterday when they blanked the powerful Washington Eagles, 2 to 0, in the Eastern Hockey League battle featuring an amateur double-header at Madison Square Garden.

ROME, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Giovanni Ansaldo, the editor, said today that the best tactics for the Italian forces in Libya seemed to be to keep all available forces in Tripolitania and have others flown there from Italy.
Harold (Peewee) Reese, young shortstop, sent word to the Dodger offices yesterday that his signed contract was in the mail, according to an announcement by President Larry MacPhail.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Until the news became known over the week-end of the British capture of Bengazi, the stock markets had presented a somewhat jaded appearance. The causes of this hesitancy and slight depression were readily found in the further huge credits asked by Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and the resultant pictures of still heavier taxation, and all-'round fiscal sacrifice.

In one of the pictures of the "Battle of Fifth Avenue" after the Esposito brothers ran amuck, a man's felt hat can be seen lying beside the prostrate body of Patrolman Edward Maher. If any one looking at this picture gives the hat a second thought it is probably to say, "The owner of that hat was in such a hurry to get away from there he didn't stop to pick it up."

Justice Van Devanter was nominated to the Supreme Court by President Taft, who was himself later to become Chief Justice. Both men were definitely in the conservative tradition, but Justice Van Devanter lived into a period which made him seem by contrast even more devoted to the standards of the past.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 9 (AP) -- A trust set up for Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell of Somerville, N.J., under the will of her father, James B. Duke, received an income tax refund of $111,828 during the 1940 fiscal year, the Bureau of Internal Revenue reported today.

The adventurous trip of two American women missionaries over the dangerous Burma Road last December is described by Miss L. Emma Brodbeck, former Chicago school teacher, in letters released here yesterday by the Woman's American Baptist Foreign Mission Society.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's speech was hailed tonight by proponents of the lease-lend bill as "reassuring" and "magnificent," while "non-interventionists" challenged his declaration that Britain would not need American troops in her struggle against Germany and Italy.

ATHENS, Feb. 9 -- No change of importance took place on the Albanian front during the last twenty-four hours. Greek troops, however, were officially stated to have continued mopping-up operations in regions that recently fell into their possession and to have destroyed Italian forces attempting to dislodge them.
United States Attorney John T. Cahill has submitted to President Roosevelt his resignation as Federal prosecutor for the Southern District of New York, it became known yesterday.

The capture of Bengazi and the final humiliation and virtual destruction of Marshal Rodolfo Graziani's thoroughly beaten Libyan Army were the highlights -- in the Mediterranean theatre -- of the war last week.

Soccer as an indoor sport will be introduced in Madison Square Garden tonight with a triple-header in which four leading metropolitan professional teams of the American Soccer League will participate. It will he a streamlined version of the game, seven players on a side instead of the usual eleven.

Volume orders and reorders kept the market unusually active last week, despite the fact that fewer buyers were intown. Redingotes and one-piece print and solid navy frocks with lingerie trim were favored items in all price brackets in the dress market. Suits of all types were very much favored and business in this field is ahead of that of last season.

Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs considers the completion of the Forty-ninth-Ninety-second Street section of the East River Drive as his most important accomplishment last year, he declared in a fifty-eight-page illustrated report given to Mayor La Guardia yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The experience of this government in placing its Indian population on an increasingly self-supporting basis is to be drawn upon by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia in the hope that the lessons may be used to improve the conditions of the nomadic Bedouins of that land, the Bureau of Indian Affairs announced today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- Twenty-one sailing dinghy skippers and crews defied a lumpy northwester this afternoon at the Larchmont Yacht Club, Howard D. McMichael, with his Class B boat Ordeal, and Scotty Isdale, with his Class X Queen Mary, came through to victory.

AFTER listening to a flood of baseball oratory at the Winter meetings, including dinners, there is a feeling in this corner that the National League has it all over the American League in the production of sound effects around the corridors and from the speakers' platforms. If they could talk their way into victory the National League magnates would walk off with the world series every year.

EIGHTY-YEAR-OLD newspaper dispatches might seem a trifle too cobwebby to whet the average reader's appetite today. So it is surprising to discover how much genuine interest survives in press correspondence that has reached the maturity of fourscore years.

Scholarships for orthopedic nursing training were awarded to seven nurses selected by the National Organization for Public Health Nursing, under grants made to it by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis last October, it was announced yesterday by the foundation's president, Basil O'Connor.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 9 -- The Forty-fourth Division's ski patrol, augmented by Harald Sorensen, a former Olympic coach, entrains Tuesday for Old Forge, N.Y., and a period of intensive training in the Adirondacks. Expert skiers all, the patrol will develop the purely military phase of its activities.

With love as its most potent force, the next form of world order will be based on a brotherhood of man, Bishop Herbert Welch said yesterday in his sermon at Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb, 9 -- Vincent J. Murphy, Newark director of revenue and finance, will tell the Essex County Tax Board tomorrow that this city's 1941 ratables are $53,138,834 below last year's.

Debate in the House of Representatives on the lease-lend bill has made one fact abundantly clear, and it is important that this fact be realized both in London and Berlin. Despite the partisan vote by which the measure was adopted, there was clear evidence of practical unanimity in the House on the question of aid to Britain.
An irregularly lower tendency in the free pound sterling highlighted the business in the foreign exchange market last week, London cables selling down to $4.02 3/4, lowest since Oct. 24 last.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- The New York Rangers gained their second straight victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 2 to 1, before 15,870 spectators at the Stadium, enabling them to take sole possession of fourth place in the National Hockey League.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 9 -- Despite strong efforts being put forward by the steel companies to control in some degree, the heavy volume of incoming business, orders to the mills last week were in even greater volume than in the week before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- United States imports of cattle and beef in 1940 were 20 per cent less than in 1939, the Department of Agriculture announced today. Beef cattle imports were down 16 per cent. Canned beef imports declined 29 per cent.
ROME, Feb. 10 -- Seventy-two persons were killed and 226 wounded in the shelling of Genoa yesterday morning by the British Fleet, it was announced in today's war bulletin.

Two things came along yesterday to disturb President Edward Grant Barrow of the Yankees on an otherwise quiet day. One was revival of talk of the sale of the club to former Postmaster General James A. Farley. The other was the suggestion that perhaps President Barrow would like to say something about the unsigned ball players with whom he has to contend, otherwise crudely known as holdouts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull urged today the fullest possible production of military supplies to meet Prime Minister Churchill's idea to "give us the tools and we will finish the job."

Among the 182 passengers who arrived from Europe yesterday on the American Export liner Excalibur was Colonel Charles Vickers of the British Army, here on a secret mission for his government. He was accompanied by Captain Bartholomew Playdell-Bouverie.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Tribute to Willis Van Devanter, who died Saturday night, was paid by the Supreme Court today. As the court met, Chief Justice Hughes spoke of the "deep grief" felt over the passing of the 81-year-old retired justice who spent more than twenty-six years on the highest bench.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Six witnesses concluded the opposition case against the lease-lend bill before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today as that body planned to close its hearings tomorrow by hearing Wendell L. Willkie, President Conant of Harvard and possibly Mayor La Guardia in final testimony supporting the measure.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 10 -- Frank Strafaci of Great Neck, L.I., took medal honors in the qualifying round of the fourteenth annual national amateur championship of golf club champions today with a one-over-par 37, 36 -- 73. A high wind handicapped the field going out.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Opposition has decreased to the confirmation of Herbert Bayard Swope as chairman of the State Racing Commission and of Milo R. Maltbie as chairman of the Public Service Commission, it became known tonight in advance of the appearance of the two men before the Senate Finance Committee tomorrow.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 10 -- The Balkan Peninsula was teeming with rumors and alarms tonight as Britain broke off her tenuous diplomatic relations with occupied Rumania, as fifth-column and semi-military German units began to filter into Bulgaria in quantity and as various indications were received of Italian preparations to get a large-scale drive under way in Albania.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 10 -- The New Jersey State Board of Public Utility Commissioners ruled today that the Tri-County Rural Electric Company, Inc., organized under the auspices of the Federal Rural Electrification Administration in 1937, was subject to its jurisdiction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Secretary Morgenthau, back from a holiday in Arizona, told his press conference today that he was still optimistic regarding the chances for realization of the Treasury plan to extend to all belligerents the present freezing order against the funds of conquered countries.

Universal, which scheduled a program of sixty-one productions for the 1941-42 season at its annual sales convention in Chicago yesterday, became the first major studio to announce the features it plans to produce, since the outlawing of "block-booking and blind-selling" by the consent decree settlement of the Federal antitrust suit against five of the eight leading film studios.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 10 -- Governor Charles Edison forwarded to the Legislature tonight a budget of $40,662,095 for operation of the general State Government during the fiscal year beginning July 1, next, and a budget of $49,537,356 for the Highway Department for the current calendar year.

Major Vidkun Quisling, regarded as a traitor by the great mass of Norwegians, is finding out that as a Nazi agent he has not been sufficiently tough. His fellow-countrymen scorned his edicts as Hitler's Gauleiter in Oslo, ignored his propaganda efforts and booed his public meetings. He had to appeal to Berlin for help.

August S. DeAugustinis, '41, of Tuckahoe, N.Y., right halfback on the Columbia football team, has been named the winner of the Class of 1913 Football Cup for scholastic excellence, it was announced last night by university authorities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Crude oil production in the United States in 1940 amounted to 1,351,847,000 barrels -- a new high record. Last year's output was 87,500,000 barrels more than the 1939 total.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, at Soluch, Libya, Feb. 9 (Delayed) -- General Annibale Bergonzoli of Italy's shattered North African Army today told the amazing story of a fierce tank battle waged amid the screams of women and children on a battlefield strewn with perambulators and toys.

With expanding national defense expenditures playing a major role, sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an average increase of 12.2 per cent for January over the like month last year, according to a compilation yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- The improved sentiment in Stock Exchange circles here found expression today in a rise in British Government securities. Contributing to the more cheerful outlook were Prime Minister Churchill's speech, the continued advance on Libya and the naval attack on Genoa.

CHICkGO. Feb. 10 (AP) -- HeaVy supply of 19,000 hogs in addition to 7,000 billed direct to packers caused drops of from 15 to 25 cents in hog prices today. Top of $8.15 v-as paid sparingly, while good to choice 180 to 240 pound hogs brought $7.85 to 88.10. Wholesale pork loin prices remained firm despite the drop, selling at 151 to 16 cents a pound.

Estimating that 60,000,000 woman-hours of work were saved daily in this country last year through the use of more ready-to-serve foods and better cooking devices, Lewis W. Waters, vice president in charge of research of the General Foods Corporation, predicted yesterday that 10-minute meals and foods designed for the aged or middle-aged might be outstanding among the food research developments of the future.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 10 -- Norman Spieden, curator of the Edison Museum here, said on hearing today of the death of Francis Jehl that Mr. Jehl worked in Thosas A. Edison's Menlo Park laboratory from 1879 to 1882, and then went to Europe as an expert on the installation of electric lighting systems based on Edison inventions.

An exhibition of Greek art, composed for the most part of handicraft, ancient and modern, lent by Lady Edgerton and Gilbert Sheldon for the benefit of Friends of Greece, Inc., has opened at the new War Relief Information Center, 435 Park Avenue and will continue through Saturday.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10 -- Curious Coin, the colt that had chased the record-smashing Dispose home in the recent Bahamas Handicap, just galloped away from six other 3-year-olds in the seven-furlong Miami Shores Purse at Hialeah Park today.

The Connecticut General Life Insurance Company, according to the annual report of Frazar B. Wilde, president, showed on Dec. 31, 1940, assets of $289,448,516, an increase of $24,129,112 in the year. Liabilities of $272,518,128 were represented largely by policy and claim reserves, plus policy holders' funds on deposit with the company.

Two policemen were injured and nine pickets were arrested yesterday in an all-day series of clashes, several times verging on riots, between pickets and workers in Battery Park at the entrance to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel now under construction.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- Vincent Sheean, author and foreign correspondent, and members of his family leaped to safety from upper floors of their sixteen-room residence at 17 Wood End Lane, on the Bronxville-Mount Vernon boundary, before dawn this morning after fire had swept through the dwelling and cut off other means of escape.

Del Monte's will celebrate its golden jubilee and Libby, McNeill Libby its seventy-third anniversary this year with extensive advertising campaigns due shortly. The former will use double pages in colors in three national weeklies, starting March 14, and billboards in 250 markets, while the latter will promote the offer of a serving fork and spoon in two magazines distributed with Sunday newspapers and in other key city newspapers.

Recent issues of the newspapers carried the report that the Axis powers -- Germany and Italy -- were withdrawing their funds from the United States. Reference was made to the January Treasury Bulletin. Specifically, Germany took out $3,393,000, compared with $3,140,000 sent to the United States in September.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- That Great Britain would follow her breaking off of diplomatic relations with Rumania today by also severing diplomatic ties with Bulgaria was forecast in informed diplomatic circles here as Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador, told reporters that Prime Minister Churchill's statements yesterday regarding Bulgaria constituted "a grave warning" to that country.

With almost one-half of the present cotton season gone, indications are that cotton exports from the United States for the twelve months ending on July 31, next, may not be much more than 1,000,000 bales. So far this season, exports have amounted to 700,905 bales.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- In the text of the President's lease-lend bill, as passed by the House, there occurs a section which reserves to Congress the right, at any time before the life of the law expires, to terminate it by concurrent resolution. If the views of several constitutional lawyers expressed to this correspondent are as well-founded as their unanimity and vehemence would indicate, this section is not worth the paper it is written on.

LINDEN, N. J., Feb. 10 -- Edward F. (Eddie) McMahon, who insists he is not related to Douglas (Wrong-Way) Corrigan, was home today with the story of a wonderful adventure. He said he had gone swimming off the Jersey coast on Jan. 31, landed in a motor boat and wound up -- via truck -- in Jacksonville, Fla.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Important changes in the Federal farm program are being worked out in the Department of Agriculture, with the encouragement of President and Mrs. Roosevelt, in an effort to cope with the price and market disturbances due to the war and to ease the economic and social effects of the war emergency on low-income farm groups, high officials said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- The Army Quartermaster today awarded contracts for 1,999,300 bleached cotton bed sheets, bids on which were opened here on Jan. 28. Twelve concerns shared in the award, as follows:

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- About 4,700 visitors, most of them members of the Future Farmers of America, visited the New York State Colleges of Agriculture, Home Economics and Veterinary Medicine today as Cornell University opened its thirty-fourth annual Farm and Home Week.

TORONTO, Feb. 10 -- An air force is never any better than the men who fly and maintain its planes. And while British and United States aircraft factories are working day and night to produce the sinews of the Royal Air Force, the great heart, mind and nervous system of that combat organization are being fashioned and conditioned here in Canada.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A special Senate investigation of defense contracts, to get to the bottom of "rumors rife in this city" of irregularities "inside," favoritism and lack of ethics and common sense in awards, was demanded in the Senate today by Senator Truman of Missouri.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Italian Government denied flatly that its bombers were responsible for the killing of two and the wounding of two other members of an American missionary group in Sudan last August, in a second note on the subject made public today by the State Department.
The details of three new apartment house projects were submitted yesterday, one each in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 (UP) -- The Nazi High Command today reported that its bombing planes attacked Iceland, had sunk 24,500 tons of enemy shipping off the Portuguese coast and that other German forces had repulsed an attack of British torpedo planes on Norway, turned hack British raiders over the Channel, hit a British mine sweeper and bombed military objectives in London and Southeast England.

ATHENS, Feb. 10 -- It was officially stated tonight that the military situation in Albania continued to be "highly satisfactory." Were it not for the bad weather still prevailing over the fighting area, the Greeks would no doubt be able to claim greater successes than the repulse of four separate Italian attacks during the last twenty-four hours.

It is not supposed that Winston Churchill's absorbing story of the aircraft carrier Illustrious and the 150 Nazi dive-bombers will definitely put an end to the debate on sea power versus air power. Thus it might be argued that Mr. Churchill failed to mention the large British cruiser which the dive-bombers did destroy in the opening attack on the British convoy in the Sicilian straits.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- With a protracted trial in prospect and more than fifty lawyers scheduled to take part, Judge George A. Welsh began hearing testimony today in Federal District Court in two suits brought by stockholders of the Pennroad Corporation for an accounting of Pennroad operations and reimbursement to stockholders of losses of $95,500,000.

Plans to complete University Hall, eyesore of the Columbia University campus that has remained unfinished since 1902, have been approved by the board of trustees' committee on buildings and grounds, together with plans for a new gymnasium to augment the cramped and ancient athletic quarters that have chagrined Columbia men for years.

The increasing flow of business, stimulated by the armament program, is increasing the demand for new manufacturing plants throughout New Jersey, according to C. Armel Nutter of Camden, president of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards.

Admiral Somerville's attack on Genoa is a spectacular demonstration at once of British strength and Italian weakness. Under the ordinary conditions of modern warfare, such a naval assault on a well-fortified port is theoretically impossible. Nothing like it has been attempted in the present conflict, not even in the confused naval actions off Norway.

Long Island University's one and only intracity test, against Brooklyn College at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium tonight, will be closely watched by future opponents of the Blackbirds and talent scouts for the national invitation tournament which will culminate the basketball season here late next month.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Senator Austin, Republican, of Vermont, counseled the Republican party today against "blind opposition" to the lease-lend bill.

HAVANA, Feb. 10 -- President Fulgencio Batista sent a message to the Cuban Congress this afternoon asking authorization to obtain financing from the Export-Import Bank in Washington on surplus production of 400,000 tons of sugar of the 1941 crop, now being ground.

On the 78,000 miles of the strategic road system which the Public Roads Administration has designated as most vital to national defense, bridges represent a serious problem. In many cases they have not kept pace with the modernization of the roads themselves, particularly on the heavily traveled highways in the East.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Considerable quantities of war supplies are reaching the interior of China through secret routes from the east coast, thereby lessening China's dependence on the Burma Road, informed foreign sources said today.

Tonight's opening is a comedy entitled "Out of the Frying Pan," which tells a story of stage-struck youth and their attempts to gain a foothold in the theatre. The author is Francis Swann. His play is being presented by Alexander Kirkland and William Rogers Deering at the Windsor Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- General Walter G. Krivitsky, former Red Army Chief of Intelligence for Western Europe and member of Josef Stalin's tight inner circle, was found dead on his bed in a fifth floor room of the Hotel Bellevue near Union Station, early today with a .38 calibre bullet in his right temple.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- The British Government today followed up Prime Minister Winston Churchill's solemn warning to the Balkans last night by announcing that it had severed diplomatic relations with Rumania. Sir Reginald Hoare, the British Minister, and his staff, as well as all consular officials, are expected to leave Rumania within a few days.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 10 -- Nineteen thousand men will be drafted for service with New Zealand's expeditionary force under the compulsory service law when the fourth ballot is held shortly, National Service Minister Robert Semple announced today.

Two Americans who speak not a word of English, and who must register for the draft but cannot join the Army, were interviewed yesterday at the Grand Central office of the Travelers Aid Society, after arriving from Morocco in Brooklyn on the Finnish cargo boat Inha.

Steel operations this week will duplicate the high mark of 97.1 per cent that was set two weeks ago, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, a gain of 0.2 point and 0.2 per cent over last week's slightly lower rate, which thus becomes the third best week on record.

ATHENS, Feb. 10 -- In an interview published in the Athens newspaper Vradini, General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, British commander in the Middle East, told the correspondent that there were four main reasons for the eminent success of the campaign in the Western Desert.
SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, Feb. 10 -- Powerful formations of Royal Air Force bombers left Singapore today to reinforce advance air bases in Northern Malaya.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Notification of Britain's severance of diplomatic relations with Rumania was made today by Sir Reginald Hoare, the British Minister, in an interview with General on Antonescu, the Premier. Sir Reginald's meeting with General Antonescu was characterized by friends of the envoy as "exceedingly painful."

WINSTON SALEM, Feb. 10 -- A Federal grand jury for the middle United States District Court of North Carolina today indicted two trade associations, sixty-four corporations and thirty-six individuals on charges of violating the anti-trust laws by price fixing and con spiring to suppress competition in the $200,000,000 fertilizer industry.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 10 -- Three Italian tugs and two barges laden with war materiel put into the harbor at Bratch Island, in Yugoslav waters, Saturday night and remained there over Sunday, according to a report to the Belgrade newspapers tonight from Dubrovnik, on the Southern Yugoslav coast, which, however, was not published.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A woman's plan to appeal directly to President Roosevelt to keep her 15-year-old step-son in the Army struck a snag today when Senator Mead of New York informed her that it would be impossible to arrange an interview with the Chief Executive "because of the press of his official duties in this emergency."

LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Professor Arthur Lloyd James, English-language specialist charged with slaying his wife, was found guilty, but insane, today and ordered kept in custody "until the King's pleasure could be known."

The one-story taxpayer containing seven stores at 3302-08 Bergenline Avenue, Union City, assessed for $92,400, has been sold by the 662 Bergenline Avenue Corporation to the Kaymar Realty Corporation of Newark. Revenue stamps on the deed indicated a consideration of $36,000 above a $75,000 first mortgage held by the Home Life Insurance Company.

With an enrollment of 385, including one housewife who is the mother of three children, the first Engineering Defense Training Institute in the country, operated by a group of metropolitan engineering colleges in cooperation with the Federal Government, was opened yesterday at Brooklyn Law School, 375 Pearl Street, Brooklyn.

Systematic attempts to complete the demoralization of Poles in German-occupied Poland were described here yesterday By Dr. Josef P. Junosza, Warsaw high school teacher who escaped in October and came here via Austria, Switzerland, England and Portugal a few weeks ago.

Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the City Council committee investigating the Municipal Civil Service Commission, charged yesterday that the commission had spent $10,000 and two years on an examination that produced only one qualified candidate for the $1,800 post of radio announcer in WNYC, the city broadcasting station.

The New York Adult Education Council held a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Parkside, 18 Gramercy Park South, to celebrate what its members consider the most important action taken by the Board of Education in a generation -- the development of a coordinated non-vocational adult education program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 -- Anne Shirley and Adolphe Menjou were named today by RKO for the leading roles in "Father Takes a Wife," which Jack Hively will direct. The photoplay was written by Herbert and Dorothy Fields.
Phelps, Fenn Co., either alone or as head of a group of bankers, received yesterday the award of a total of $2,765,000 of local housing authority bonds of ten different agencies.
LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

I was startled to read in your editorial "Gold by Warship" that "The increase in last month's gold imports, especially from South Africa, is simply a measure of England's effort to accumulate dollars here for war expenditure. Naturally, particular reliance has been placed on the Transvaal mines, which broke all of their own records in 1940, and which are controlled by the British Government."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Secretary Stimson told an American Youth Congress delegation, which picketed the War Department today in protest against alleged discriminatory treatment of Negroes, that equality of opportunity for Negroes in the Army was a part of his defense program.

Scoring two victories in singles and one in doubles, Huguenot beat Gramatan Hills, 3-2, in a Metropolitan Badminton Association Class A match, according to results announced yesterday. Leading the winners was Stig Larsen, who turned back Albert Frost, 15-7, 15-12.

Fred C. Moffatt, former president of the New York Curb Exchange, heads the new board of governors elected yesterday by that institution. Elected with the new chairman, who will serve one year, were ten others, including five Class A or "member" governors, four Class B or "partner" governors and one trustee of the gratuity fund, all to serve three years.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 10 -- Borrowing tactics of the German Army, the first effort to coordinate infantry and artillery units of the Fourty-fourth Division into regimental combat teams will be made here tomorrow.
OTTAWA, Feb. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Forty-five corvettes and thirteen minesweepers have been launched by Canadian shipyards to date, Munitions Minister C.D. Howe announced today.

Aggregate short interest in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange was 498,427 shares on Jan. 31, against 459,129 on Dec. 31, according to an announcement yesterday by the Exchange. Short positions in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers, which are not included in the figures, were 74,102 shares at the end of January, compared with 68,568 at the end of December.
BERLIN, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- An appropriation of $375,000,000 to continue Federal work relief through the last four months of the current fiscal year was the major item in two supply bills, aggregating $1,534,000,000, reported to the House today by the Appropriations Committee.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Governor Lehman proclaimed the week of Feb. 16 to 23 today as "Bill of Rights Week:" The State Board of Regents will have children attending the public schools observe the week with special study and pageantry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Recommendation of a monopoly subsidized by the government to carry on American transoceanic mail service was made to the House today by the Appropriations Committee in announcing that it had rejected President Roosevelt's recommendation, as contained in his budget message, for funds to start a new air line to Europe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The House voted today to increase the maximum limit on the national debt from $49,000,000,000 to $65,000,000,000 and declined, because of the urgencies of the world situation, to give any promise that the "ceiling" would not be moved even higher.

Carl W. Loreday of the Montclair A.C., seeded No. 1, gained the quarter-finals of the ninth annual metropolitan badminton championship as two rounds were completed on the courts of the Fifth Avenue Country Club last night.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 10 (UP) -- The British Libyan Army s spearhead of tanks, hard on the heels of Marshal lodolfo Graziani's fleeing, shattered forces, was believed today to be well past El Aghcila on the Gulf of Sidra, moving across the Tripolitanian soil, and there were increasIng indications that General Sir Archibald P. Vravell might push on toward Tripoli, 425 miles away, without a pause.

I have often meditated on the inadequacy of the term "dictator" in connection with modern totalitarian rulers. But the proposal of W.F. Willcox in your issue of Feb. 6 to substitute "tyrant" for "dictator" is based on an erroneous interpretation of terms.

A financial statement covering the operations for slightly more than a year of Bundles For Britain, Inc., showed yesterday that this war relief organization, with headquarters at 745 Fifth Avenue and more than 700 branches throughout the country, received $1,654,086 in cash gifts and contributions of clothing, hospital supplies and knitted articles.

The trial of two contractors and three paving companies in Queens, accused of defrauding the city, was ended suddenly yesterday when the defendants pleaded guilty to an amended indictment charging them with conspiracy to violate the general business laws in a manner to restrain free trade.

Indoor soccer, enlivened by the fiercest free-for-all fight seen here in many a moon, was introduced at Madison Square Garden last night. Long before the triple-header was completed two players were patients at Polyclinic Hospital and at least a dozen others were nursing painful bruises.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 10 -- British troops, moving south along the Red Sea coast from the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan into Italian Eritrea, have launched what might be considered a new drive by capturing the port of Taclai and the town of Karora after considerable fighting, it was announced here today.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Paul M. Wald Jr., secretary of the J.S. Wald Company, Inc., a trucking firm, who leased an apartment at 565 West End Avenue through the Apartment Locating Bureau, brokers.
NEVER mind the sprinters and hurdlers. Let the middle distance stars run for Sweeney. There's more fun at a mile! The leaders are making it a merry-go-round and the fun isn't half over yet.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- Lack of support was largely responsible for a sharp recession in prices of wheat on the Board of Trade here today. Prices started downward shortly after the opening and continued to recede under scattered professional offerings and liquidation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A sweeping reorganization of the Japanese Embassy staff here has been directed by Tokyo to set up a "new order" in diplomatic representation under Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, the new Ambassador, who will arrived in Washington tomorrow.

Publishing plans for the firm of Wilfred Funk were announced yesterday, but later in the day a message from Mr. Funk said that too late for the catalogue, because it had come "right off the Clipper," was another book -- "They"ll Never Quit."

LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Britain's severance of diplomatic relations with Rumania today was characterized authoritatively as a pointed warning to other Balkan nations. The break does not "necessarily" Continued on Page ]Fou'

Few public men were more diligent in their attention to public affairs than Reed Smoot, Senator from Utah for the thirty years from 1903 to 1933. He made himself a powerful personage at Washington in the days when the chairman of the Senate Committee on Finance, always an influential figure, had a weight proportionately greater than now attaches to his post.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Reliable diplomatic quarters reported tonight that the special Russian envoy, Arkady Soboleff, had informed the Bulgarian Government that Russia would not interfere if Germany demanded passage of her troops across this country.

While retailers are buying somewhat further ahead, particularly in dry goods and domestic lines, there is little or no speculative buying of merchandise, in the opinion of resident buyers here. With respect to advance commitments, they said yesterday, the general rule is ninety days.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Harry L. Hopkins, who came to England on a special mission for President Roosevelt, left here today surrounded by the same secrecy that shrouded his arrival and stay.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A charge by the National Labor Relations Board that the Ford Motor Company coerced and intimidated employes at the River Rouge plant was automatically upheld when the Supreme Court declined today to review the appeal of Henry Ford from the Sixth Circuit Court decision sustaining the board.

VICHY, France, Feb. 10 -- Spain's Chief of State, Generalissimo Francisco Franco, accompanied by his brother-in-law, Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suner, will pass through France tomorrow. According to sources that would necessarily have to be informed, they will proceed to Italy.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 10 (AP) -- The State Racing Commission acceded today to a request by a Trenton sportsman-industrialist that no immediate action be taken on possible rescinding of a track permit issued conditionally to the mon-mouth Park Racing Association.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe won his thirteenth consecutive victory in the world championship three-cushion billiard tournament tonight, defeating Art Rubin of New York, 50 to 38, in fifty-eight innings.
BERLIN, Feb. 10 -- Yesterday's address by Prime Minister Winston Churchill evoked lengthy but not particularly illuminating comments in the German press.

The American Abstract Artists are holding their fifth annual exhibition, the locale this time being the Riverside Museum, 310 Riverside Drive, where the large show opened with a preview Sunday (the museum is closed on Mondays). The exhibition will continue until Feb. 23, and a symposium on abstract art is slated for next Sunday afternoon at 2:30 -- the speakers, Hans Hofmann, Carl R. Holty and Harry Holtzman.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- The Assembly got its State defense legislation under way today when the Committee on National Defense acted favorably on the Ostertag bill setting up a statutory State Defense Council.

HAVANA, Cuba, Feb. 10 (UP) -- President Fulgencio Batista tonight asked Congress to authorize the Cuban Institute for Sugar Stabilization to negotiate a $12,000,000 loan with the Export-Import Bank of the United States. Under the proposal for financing the sugar industry, he said, the loan would not run longer than five years.

Something about the sound of that title was a warning. What would a play entitled "Popsy" be like? Last evening it was produced at the Playhouse with Al Shean in the featured role, and the warning has turned into a dreadful reality. "Popsy" is one of the worst plays ever written.
SAIGON, French Indo-China, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Japan appeared today to have established a military foothold in this chief sea and air port of Southern French Indo-China by unheralded infiltration.

The Army had its biggest induction day since the World War here yesterday, with 533 New York City men accepted at the two induction centers. It was announced that New York, New Jersey and Delaware would be called upon to furnish 10,000 men for the induction period beginning March 3 and ending March 15.

Paramount Pictures acquired yesterday at a reported price of $283,000 the screen rights to "Lady in the Dark," the current Broadway success by Moss Hart, Kurt Weill and Ira Gershwin in which Gertrude Lawrence is starred. The figure is said in trade circles to represent a record for the purchase of either a play or a novel for the films.

VICHY, France, Feb. 10 -- Admiral Jean Darlan, Minister of the Navy and of Foreign Affairs, tonight was appointed next in line of succession to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain as Chief of State, "should he be prevented from exercising his duties." Should Admiral Darlan in his turn be prevented from exercising his duties, the Council of Ministers by a majority vote would designate a successor.

I question the testimony of Justice Herbert A. O'Brien and William J. Goodwin, Queens Democratic leader, before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, as reported in THE TIMES, that tension engendered among foreign-born groups might result in a civil war in this city should the United States take up arms in defense of those democratic principles on which our nation was founded.

The board of directors of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers has approved in principle a proposed consent decree ending the Federal Government's anti-trust suit against the society, and only a few points remain to be worked out with the Department of Justice, it became known last night.

"Back Street," Universal's remake of the Fannie Hurst novel, will have its local premiere at the Rivoli at 7 tonight. The film, which Felix Jackson and Bruce Manning adapted from the novel, co-stars Margaret Sullavan and Charles Boyer, and features Richard Carlson, Frank McHugh, Tim Holt, Frank Jenks, Esther Dale, Samuel S Hinds and Peggy Stewart.

i Demand for most classes of fresh meats showed yesterday some improvement, although trading was only fair to slow. The [ strike at one of the larger slaughteringI plants was still in effect, whleh tended to reduce available supplies. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to firm. with some sales 150 cents or more higher than at the close of last week.

Defense Housing Coordinator Palmer has asked Congress for $156,750,000, of which $150,000,000 would be used to build 37,000 dwelling units for defense workers and enlisted personnel in sixty areas. The rest of the money would go for temporary shelters. Some careful thinking ought to be done before the larger sum is expended.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 -- Many colonists entertained at tonight's auction sweepstakes dinner at the Everglades Club, given in conjunction with the annual club invitational golf tournament for men and women which opened today.

The rehabilitation of the Lamport Manufacturing Supply Company Building at 365-67 Broadway, occupying the entire block front on the north side of Franklin Street, between Broadway and Franklin Alley, is now complete, according to Charles F. Noyes.
ROME, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

Indications of an even wider theatre of war than now exists in the world, as Great Britain severad diplomatic relations with Rumania, produced a further tightening yesterday in transactions in the securities markets. With trading on the Stock Exchange falling short of the 300,000-share mark, to make the session the lightest since Sept. 16, the dealings contracted to 294,610 shares, compared with 341,100 on last Friday.

SANTA CLARA, Calif., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Coach L.T. (Buck) Shaw, highly successful football mentor at Santa Clara University, said today he had asked that his name be withdrawn from further consideration for the position of head coach at Notre Dame.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Senate unanimously confirmed today the nomination of John G. Winant to be Ambassador to Great Britain.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Lady Howard, a native of Hungary and the wife of Lord Howard of Effingham, heir to the Earl of Effingham, has been detained under the defense regulations by a Home Security Ministry order, it was announced today. Details concerning her retention were not divulged.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 10 -- Princeton's hockey team defeated Dartmouth tonight on Davis Rink, 2 to 1, winning in an exciting last period which saw the Indians remove their goalie and put six men forward in a vain attempt to force a tie.

Sales of the F.W. Woolworth Company reached a new high last year of $335,474,819, according to the annual report for 1940 announced yesterday by C.W. Deyo, president. The volume, which includes that of stores operated in the United States, Canada and Cuba, represents an increase of $16,635,156 over 1939.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Excerpts from the majority and dissenting opinions of the Supreme Court today in the picketing case involving the Milk Wagon Drivers Union of Chicago and the Meadowmoor Dairies, Inc., were as follows:

BERLIN, Feb. 10 -- The radius of action afforded to the German Air Force by its bases along the European coastline from the northern tip of Norway to the Bay of Biscay was demonstrated yesterday when simultaneous attacks were launched against a British-occupied airport on Iceland and on a British convoy in the Atlantic Ocean 300 miles west of Portugal.

Interest in the mile race, one of the features of the metropolitan intercollegiate indoor track and field championships at the Bronx Coliseum tomorrow night, was added yesterday when Pete Waters, Manhattan College coach, declared that Andy Neidnig definitely would be one of the starters against Leslie MacMitchell of New York University.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Official, diplomatic and resident members of society turned out today in full force for the last of Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's Musical Mornings at the Mayflower Hotel.

LONDON, Feb. 10 (Canadian Press) -- The belief grew in responsible British quarters today that Japan was planning to make a southward move, possibly against the Malay Peninsula and the Netherlands Indies, in the Spring to coincide with a Nazi offensive in Europe.

The question before the United States today is not whether we shall aid Britain but how far we shall go in that aid, Senator Robert A. Taft declared last night at the 135th dinner of the Economic Club of New York at the Hotel Astor.

Something has happened in this war, something as palpable as a change in the direction of the wind. It whistled through the inflections of Winston Churchill's speech on Sunday. It is felt in the quickened pace of action and expectation as the week opened with the rupture of diplomatic relations with Rumania.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Congressional leaders on the legislative program, discussed National Youth Administration appropriations with a group of House members and conferred on the world situation with Secretaries Hull, Knox and Stimson, General George C. Marshall and Admiral Harold R. Stark.

Trading in municipal bonds, which accounts for a large percentage of the daily turnover in unlisted securities in Wall Street, is to receive additional stimulus through the advertised posting of prices.

ROME, Feb. 10 -- Virginio Gayda, chief Fascist mouthpiece, makes a long answer today to Prime Minister Winston Churchill's speech of yesterday. As a matter of fact, however, the Italian public has not been allowed to read anything of the scathing and barbed remarks that Mr. Churchill directed toward Rome, but other parts of the speech are carefully summarized with polemics and denials interspersed and it is this portion that Signor Gayda answers.

A banking group headed by the National City Bank and including Harriman Ripley Co., Inc.; Lazard Freres Co., and the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis, received yesterday the award of $2,500,000 of various purpose bonds of Nassau County, L.I., on a bid of 100.1899 for 1.90s. The bonds, dated Feb. 15, 1941, will mature serially on Feb. 15, 1942 to 1960.

The entire holdings of International General Electric Company, amounting to $10,000,000 face value for participating debentures of Siemens Halske, A.G., the largest electrical manufacturing concern in the world outside of the United States, were sold a few months ago to a private individual for cash, in United States dollars, at a price in excess of face value, it was disclosed yesterday.

LEWES, Del., Feb. 10 -- Singing 'Roll Out the Barrel," forty-seven members of the crew of the British freighter Ramon de Larrinaga slid down the ice-coated sides of their capsized ship early this morning to safety in the three boats of the Lewes Coast Guard station.

Your recent editorial with reference to Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature seemed to place the stamp of approval on the proposal to divert $60,000,000 that has already been set aside for elimination of grade crossings to construction of additional highways.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- When the lease-lend bill passes, Great Britain will obtain at once about $500,000,000 worth of the United States war "tools" which Prime Minister Churchill called for yesterday in a radio address.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Howard O. Hunter, Acting WPA Commissioner, told Congress today that twenty industrial areas, with a little over one-fifth of the country's population and a smaller percentage of the total number of Work Projects Administration workers, had received about 75 per cent of the defense contracts.

Ossy Renardy is not merely a coming young violinist but one who manages to make his local appearances interesting for their program content. At Carnegie Hall last night he introduced to this country a concerto for violin and fourteen wind instruments by Josef Blatt, with the composer conducting. The other works on his program, with the exception of the Mendelssohn Concerto, were also marshaled to achieve variety.

The Drelimtnary report of the El Paso Natural Gas Company and its subsidiaries for 1940, made public yesterday, showed consolidated net income of $2,077,311, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. The net was equal, after requirements on Dreferred dividends, to $3.2 a share on 601,594 common shares and compared l with $2,358,198, or $3.75 a common l share, in 1939.

Price movements on the /Vew York Cotton Exchange yesterday were the narrowest in several months, fluctuations being held in a 3-point range. Volume also was small and business was largely of a routine character. Final quotations showed net gains of 2 points.

Sixteen judges, working in as many rings, will start at 10 o'clock this morning the task of sorting out the candidates for honors in the sixty-fifth annual all-breed dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which will continue through tomorrow evening at Madison Square Garden.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP) -- The closest competition in the eight-year history of the event was forecast today on the eve of the 184-mile Miami-to-Nassau yacht race.

A layman might reasonably be forgiven for thinking that it should be simple to determine just how many new workers must be trained to produce the instruments of war that the nation needs. But the layman would be very wrong.

New York City had a surplus of $14,720,955 on Dec. 31 from emergency relief tax collections aggregating $433,351,359 in the last six years, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick said yesterday in the first comprehensive report on relief financing made by his office.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Denis Nowell Pritt, member of Parliament for North Hammersmith, a leader of the movement known as the People's Convention and an advocate of close relations between Britain and Soviet Russia, was requested today by the executive committee of the North Hammersmith Labor party to resign his seat in the House of Commons. Mr. Pritt replied that he had no intention of resigning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Seven of the most important manufacturers of engines, turbines, water wheels and windmills in the United States reported to the Federal Trade Commission a combined net income in 1939 on the average corporate net worth investment after provision for income taxes of 10.2 per cent on the stockholders' investment, it was announced today.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A British General Headquarters communique said today:

OTTAWA, Feb. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Because of wartime demands on industry, Canada's economic graph soared steadily in 1940, with only six of forty-six divisions showing a recession from 1939, the Dominion Bureau of Sta tistics reported today in a final review of Canadian business conditions last year.

With the rapid growth of skiing interest throughout the Northeast, there has been a proportionate increase in improvements as well as new developments in the Poconos, Catskills and Adirondack Mountains, the Berkshires, Green and White Mountains and the Laurentians this season.

A gala Fiesta Pan-Americana was presented last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as the annual benefit ball for the Goddard Neighborhood Center, a settlement at 599 First Avenue which conducts a widespread social service program among underprivileged families of the middle East Side.

A realty firm which last August was appointed managing agent of a newly vacated seven-story midtown building reported yesterday that it has arranged leases with five concerns for complete occupancy of the structure. This is one of a number of announcements from brokers and agents of the full rental of business and loft buildings.
Operating results for 1940 were announced yesterday by two leading snuff companies.
MONTREAL, Feb. 10 (Canadian Press) -- A goal and three assists during the week widened the lead of Bill Cowley of the Boston Bruins to eight points in the National Hockey League scoring race.

During the past two months we have had many letters on the subject of the proposed firearms registration measure that is being considered by various State and Federal Legislatures. Some of those who wrote to oppose such legislation were shooters.

Wendell Willkie, returning from his visit to Britain, emphasized once more that he had made his trip as a private citizen and that his testimony on the lease-loan bill will represent his own opinions. Literally this is true; but actually Mr. Willkie in his trip and in his testimony stands in the position of envoy and observer for many millions of his fellow-citizens.

The performance of Gluck's "Alceste" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, one which evidently impressed the large audience assembled, presented a new Alcestis, in the person of Rose Bampton, and a change in the part of the High Priest, which on account of the illness of Leonard Warren, was taken by Francis Valentino.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The right of labor to picket was sharply limited when the Supreme Court, by five to three, held today that State courts were constitutionally entitled to issue injunctions where the picketing was closely associated with violence.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 14 per cent for the week ended Feb. 8, in comparison with the like week a year ago, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 11 -- The British Royal Air Force struck swift, hard blows again through yesterday at French Channel ports used as Nazi bases.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Citizens and business concerns were warned today by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, not to divulge information regarding national defense or other matters to persons calling themselves special agents of the F.B.I. until they have clearly established their identity.

The Dvonch Symphonietta, led by its founder-conductor, Frederick Dvonch, made its formal New York debut last night at Town Hall. The ensemble, which is the outgrowth of informal musical evenings among friends, is made up of seven violinists, two violists, two 'cellists and a contrabassist, all, like their leader, in their twenties.

An ex-Communist who formerly was chairman of a local of the Workers Alliance testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church that he saw a large group of Welfare Department employes at a Communist meeting in Madison Square Garden, and identified a supervisor in the department as a Communist.

A leasing deal announced yesterday involving the occupancy of aI building under construction at 13 39 West Forty-second Street by John David, Inc., men's clothiers, is reported to call for an aggregate rental outlay by that firm of about $6oo,ooo.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 10 -- The decree issued by President Getulio D. Vargas last Friday, subjecting to export license more than 200 items of Brazilian raw materials, is the first of a series of steps to be taken to conserve resources for national defense and also for the defense of the Americas, it is believed by political observers here.

Seven Chilean newspapermen, six of whom saw New York City for the first time yesterday morning from the deck of the Grace Liner Santa Clara, began a two-month visit to this country by getting a quick impression of the city -- luncheon in one skyscraper, cocktails in another -- and finished the day by talking in a short-wave broadcast to their homeland and her sister Latin-American republics. lics.

An agreement was reached yesterday by the National Maritime Union and the passenger and dry cargo companies under which the unlicensed personnel employed on American flag vessels will receive an increase in emergency wages.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Senator Barkley, majority leader, during the Foreign Relations Committee's hearing on the lease-lend bill today, asked Mayor La Guardia if he placed any credence in reports given to the committee Friday by Judge Herbert A. O'Brien of the Domestic Relations Court in Queens and William J. Goodwin, Queens Democratic leader, to the effect that civil war was brewing in New York because of frictions between various groups of foreign-born residents.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A Royal Air Force communique today said:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11 -- Paramount scheduled a remake of George Ade's "Back Home and Broke," today as a vehicle for Bob Hope, to follow "Nothing But the Truth" on Hope's program. Paulette Goddard, who will play opposite Hope in "Truth," also may appear with him in the George Ade story.

A new course of study designed to teach pupils how to oil and repair bicycles, sewing machines, roller skates, electric irons and other common household appliances is to be introduced in the junior high school division next term, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt held tonight the last State reception of the season, entertaining in honor of the Army, Navy and Marine Corps.

The Cunard White Star liner Georgic, which has led what members of her crew termed "a charmed life" since she was last here nearly a year ago, arrived in port yesterday morning with 587 passengers, the first group of its size to come here since the middle of last November.

VICHY, France, Feb. 11 -- Although overshadowed by international developments dependent on meetings of Chiefs of State, French internal affairs cannot be excluded from the picture. As Marshal Henri Philippe Petain leaves Vichy this evening to meet Generalissimo Francisco Franco, the situation is this:
A Federal indictment accusing Joseph P. Ryan and a group of other leaders of violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum.

Net profit of the G.C. Murphy Company, chain store system, and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Mack Realty Company, amounted to $3,363,535 after depreciation, amortization, interest, Federal and State income taxes and $313,800 provision for Federal excess-profits tax, according to the report for 1940, issued yesterday.

Persons reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters in this city included George Mount, vice president of the Otis Elevator Company, who leased an apartment in 447 East Fifty-seventh Street through Hickernell-Romeyn, Inc., and Wm. A. White Sons.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Members of the Legislature are becoming increasingly concerned over both the governmental and personal problems created by the Dunnigan-Devany bills which would bar Communists from elective public office and the Communist party from the ballot.

A conscientious objector who had refused to register under the Selective Service Act last October was convicted in Federal court yesterday by a jury of eleven men and a woman, who deliberated less than a minute before announcing their verdict. The trial took fifty minutes.

BERLIN, Feb. 11 -- Revaluation of the United States dollar in relation to the European currencies is already seen as a primary post-war necessity in a report on prices, currencies and world trade published by the government-owned Reichskredit Gesellschaft, whose annual surveys of Germany's economic position were widely quoted before the war for their reliability and conservative judgment.

The Matson Navigation Company, which is building four fast cargo carriers for its New York-Honolulu freight service, announced yesterday that the first of the four, the Hawaiian Planter, would be launched on Friday at the yards of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company in Virginia.

Business quarters on Madison and Fifth Avenues figured largely in the leasing activity yesterday. Some of the late rentals call for full floors, and a number of the reports listed many renewals of leases for space now occupied.

Henry Parish 2d of Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co. was elected vice chairman of the board of the New York Curb Exchange when the governors met yesterday for their annual organization meeting. He will serve in that capacity for one year.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 11 -- Hundreds of German men, dressed in civilian clothes and carrying light baggage, have been filtering into Bulgarian Dobruja during the past forty-eight hours, according to reliable reports received from Varna, Bulgarian Black Sea port.

Twelve charitable or religious institutions receive more than $1,000,000 in outright bequests and the residuary estate of Miss Caroline White, daughter of the late James Lloyd and Margaret Whitlock White, who died Feb. 4, leaving an estate formally valued at "more than $600,000."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Mayor La Guardia told the Foreign Relations Committee today that he, as chief executive of the largest city on the Atlantic Coast, could not afford to theorize about the date and probability of a Nazi invasion in the event Great Britain should be defeated, and that for that reason he favors immediate passage of the lease-lend bill.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 11 -- Four metropolitan amateur aces advanced to the second match-play round in the fourteenth annual national amateur championship of golf club champions on the St. Augustine Links today.

At their annual meeting on March 17, shareholders of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will be asked to approve pension agreements for three vice presidents of the system who are scheduled to retire soon. Stockholder approval of the pensions is necessary because of a resolution adopted by stockholders in 1939 restricting pension payments to employes earning more than $25,000 a year unless recommended by the board of trustees and ratified by stockholders.

New York City again topped yesterday its previous high mark for the number of local men inducted into the Army in one day under the Selective Training and Service Act of 1940. Six hundred New York City men were inducted at the city's two induction centers.

Columbia University's thirty-fourth annual Alumni Day is expected to draw 4,000 graduates to the campus today for a crowded reunion program headed by a luncheon meeting in John Jay Hall at 12:20 on the theme of "Preparing America for Defense."

BERLIN, Feb. 11 -- The Royal Air Force yesterday and last night lost twenty-seven planes in a series of raids extending from Norway to the Channel coast of France and including attacks on nine different points in Northern Germany, according to German reports.

With national defense the keynote, the Veteran Wireless Operators Association held its sixteenth annual dinner and "cruise" here last night at the Hotel Astor and gave various medals, scrolls and testimonials to high officers of the Army and Navy, to James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, and others.

The seven Chilean newspaper men who arrived here on Monday for a two-month good-will visit, during which they will work with newspapers in this country, were entertained at luncheon yesterday in the penthouse atop the International Telephone Building at 67 Broad Street.
