The largest number of Sabbath performances since they were started last November will be offered next Sunday, when eight matinees and twelve evening performances will be made available for the Broadway theatregoer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- A greatly accelerated expansion of plants manufacturing defense articles during the last month was indicated today by the National Defense Advisory Commission, and a further expansion in the plants manufacturing magnesium for use in military planes was being sought by two agencies.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, apologized yesterday to Councilmen Walter R. Hart of Brooklyn and Louis Cohen of the Bronx, both Democrats, for having called them "un-American" last week after they had criticized the budget policies of the La Guardia Administration.

Don, student or visitor on Morningside Heights has many comely objects to look at, but 200 feet or so north of the library there stands a low, hideous structure, ghastly with smokestacks. It might be a steam sawmill or sausage factory. In 1914, tired of its shame, it must have set itself afire. Unfortunately, the fire was put out.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- Contracts for 925,500 yards of tricot and Nottingham mosquito netting for the Army and 80,000 pairs of chopper mittens without inserts, for the Civilian Conservation Corps, were awarded at the Army Quartermaster Depot today, as follows:
The auction sale of Americana, autograph letters and books, brought $11,559 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon.

ROME, Feb. 11 -- All foreign diplomats were notified today that they might not leave Rome without permission. This drastic order, which was conveyed to United States Ambassador William Phillips orally this morning and will be put formally into writing within a few days, is a startling sign of the times.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Merchant shipping losses announced by the Admiralty for the week ended Feb. 2 -- fifteen ships with a total of 57,263 tons -- showed an upward swing.

President Roosevelt's letter to Winston Churchill introducing the bearer, Mr. Wendell Willkie, went on to express sympathy and encouragement for Great Britain's cause. In doing so Mr. Roosevelt quoted a few lines from an American poet. He was not the poet whom one would expect offhand from a forward-looking and precedent-breaking President.
Back from London, I am able to add up the score on invasion from the standpoint both of the British and of recently arrived travelers from Germany with whom I talked in Lisbon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Treasury plans to move $500,000,000 of refined gold from its San Francisco mint to Denver, Col., for safekeeping in the fiscal year starting on July 1.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11 (UP) -- Roe Wells of New York reported to police today that $475,000 in cash and jewelry valued at $300,000 were missing from the Winter residence he and his wife maintain on Star Island.

The number of out-of-town buyers reported in the market last week was 1,184 as against 971 in the preceding week and 1,201 in the same period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Buyers registered yesterday totaled 478, which compared with 506 for last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Crowds unparalleled at any Capitol hearing within the memory of employes now working there struggled today to force their way into the caucus room of the Senate's Office Building to hear Wendell L. Willkie urge the Foreign Relations Committee and the Senate to pass, as nearly unanimously as possible, the leaselend bill, with slight modifications which he suggested.

Among the rewarding group shows of the week is the one that opened yesterday at the Buchholz Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain current through March 8. This is made up of sculpture and sculptors' drawings. These are the participants: Rodin, Degas, Renoir, Despiau, Maillol, Kolbe, Lehmbruck, Barlach, Marcks, Laurens, Picasso and Brancusi.

OTTAWA, Feb. 11 -- The accusation that "Canada does not lease-lend," which is being used in the United States as an argument in Washington against the lease-lend bill, is condemned here as an unfair presentation of Canada's case. It is stressed that Canada does not lease-lend because she gives.

Several thousand teachers and parents, representing nearly every educational organization in New York City, are going to Albany this morning to protest the 2 per cent cut in State aid to education advocated by Governor Lehman. A number of the leaders will speak against this proposal at the open budget hearing.

Willie Mosconi, leader in the race for the world pocket billiard championship, easily turned back Joe Procita twice at McGirr's Academy yesterday. Mosconi, with a high run of 113, won in the afternoon, 125 to 21, in ten innings, and registered his eighty-sixth triumph at night, 125 to 25, in twenty frames.

Large quantities of materials that had been used in the construction of the World's Fair are being sold to the United States Army and Navy and to manufacturing companies engaged in national defense work, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Representative Joseph A. Gavagan, Democrat, New York, introduced today a bill to award a gold medal to Leonard Weisberg, New York taxi driver, who helped in the capture of two slayers recently. Mr. Weisberg conducted himself "with conspicuous gallantry at the risk of his own llfe," Mr. Gavagan said.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11 -- Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Turnure gave a cocktail party this afternoon at which they honored Mrs. David Turnure of Santa Barbara, Calif., their guest, and Messmore Kendall.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 12 -- Military observers here interpret the British strengthening of air forces in Northern Malaya as intended to forestall Japanese acquisition of bases in Thailand or Southern Indo-China as the outcome of the Tokyo mediation conference.
LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The British Admiralty issued the following communique today:

Mayor La Guardia announced the suspension of seven oil burner inspectors in the Fire Department yesterday on charges that they had exacted gratuities from installation companies as a condition of issuing official city permits approving the installations.

The gravity of the European situation as pointed out yesterday by Wendell L. Willkie before a Senate committee considering the lease-lend bill threw a real scare into the stock market and selling of sizable proportions in the final hour broke the price structure fractions to 2 points.

The metropolitan outdoor intercollegiate track and field championship meet is a thriving affair. But the indoor title tests are new to the board floor business. How well they will do at the gate will be demonstrated at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx tonight at 8 o'clock, when the first local collegiate indoor championships ever held get under way.

The concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, was devoted in greater part to music by contemporaneous composers. The triumphs of the evening, however, were those of two classic masters, named Haydn and Mozart.

WHAT is still not known about the war's diplomatic background would fill a volume -- indeed, it will probably fill a library before the last word is said. But what is already known presents enough to fill a rather large and enormously interesting book -- and Frederick L. Schuman, Woodrow Wilson Professor of Government at Williams College, has written it.

Captain Granville Conway, district manager of the United States Maritime Commission, which has been collaborating with the American Red Cross and the British Ministry of Shipping in moving vast quantities of relief materials to England and allied countries, declared yesterday that 45,000 tons of material had been shipped abroad by the Red Cross and that only 500 tons had failed to arrive at its destination.

Nine years ago a play written by a then unknown playwright, Rose Franken, quietly slipped into the Booth Theatre under the title of "Another Language" and went on to success. Tonight "Claudia," Miss Franken's second effort on Broadway, will be presented at the same stand.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- General liquidation in small lots engulfed buyers of wheat futures today and prices dropped steadily from the opening with the close at the bottom at losses of 1 1/4 to 1 3/4 cents bushel. Numerous stop-loss orders were uncovered on the way down, with the May selling at the lowest price since last September and the July and September went into new low ground for the season.
Your editorial "Recreation for Soldiers" is timely. Would not this afford an opportunity to reinstate the WPA Theatre Project?
AMSTERDAM, Feb. 11 -Today's Bourse again was dull. Dutch shares lost as much as 4 points.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The text of Wendell L. Willkie's formal statement before the Foreign Relations Committee in behalf of the British-aid bill was as follows:

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Bulgarian police seized an American diplomatic courier's passport today and the United States Legation announced that "energetic protests" had been made to the government by United States Minister George H. Earle.
LONDON, Feb. 11-Diplomatic circles here were uneasy today because there was a general feeling that big things were afoot but with ignorance as to what they might be.

Back on their home floor, the Long Island University Blackbirds came through with their most impressive performance of the basketball campaign last night, crushing the highly regarded Brooklyn College quintet by a 64-47 count before 1,000 persons at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy.

To have heard the audience roaring at the Windsor last evening you would have thought that "Hellz-a-poppin" had been crossed with "You Can't Take It With You" and betrothed to "Charley's Aunt." For "Out of the Frying Pan," by Francis Swann, is a piece of vertigo about young actors who are trying to keep body and soul together in a barren apartment and to get jobs on Broadway.

The Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the public school system has subpoenaed the membership lists of the College Teachers Union, Local 537, of the American Federation of Teachers, it was learned yesterday. The action came three weeks after the Court of Appeals ordered the Teachers Union -- Local 5 of the federation -- to give its rolls to the committee.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 12 -- In one of the biggest bombing attacks -- if not the biggest -- thus far made by the Royal Air Force in this war, many squadrons of British planes pounded the industrial district of Hanover, home of many varied factories, for six hours Monday night and yesterday morning, leaving it a sea of blazing fires, according to reports given out here.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Freshening winds sent nine racing yachts along at a lively pace in the 184-mile Miami-to-Nassau race tonight, with Henry Fownes's Escapade striving to increase its brief lead over the closely-bunched field.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Dr. Matthew W. Perry said today that Representative Dies was "worn out" and would go to a private hospital for a week of rest. Dr. Perry was called after Mr. Dies had collapsed in his office. Mrs. Dies said that when her husband returned to his office after the floor debate he felt weak and fell.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- A declaration that "the United States must pledge itself to insure the defeat of the Axis powers" as the only sure method of preserving "the free way of life" within its borders was made by James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, in testifying today before the Foreign Relations Committee in favor of the lease-lend bill.

With Harry L. Hopkins, homebound personal envoy of President Roosevelt to Great Britain, among its thirteen passengers, the Yankee Clipper landed for a day at Bolama, Portuguese Northwest Africa, thus delaying its scheduled arrival at La Guardia Field until 6:45 A.M. Friday, Pan American Airways said here yesterday.

ARDMORE, Pa., Feb. 11 -- The chances of a United States victory in the North American figure-skating championship appeared today to rest upon the performance of 20-year-old Eugene Turner of Los Angeles, present national titleholder.

The Italians never got anywhere near the Suez Canal, but for many months they seemed to be on their way. The British garrisons in Egypt, as Mr. Churchill now admits, took a very grave view of the danger to the lifeline as long as the Fascist legions and their much-touted air fleets were still untested.

Trotting nonchalantly up and down the show ring in Madison Square Garden yesterday, Champion My Own Brucie repeated his victory of a year ago as the best cocker spaniel in the all-breed exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Club.

The decision of the New York Newspaper Guild, announced by John F. Ryan, general organizer, to call a strike on The Jewish Day, a Yiddish daily, because of alleged dismissals and salary reductions, was welcomed yesterday by Dr. Samuel Margoshes, editor-in-chief of the paper.

Events today: "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 P.M.; "Masters of Viennese Music," sixty-five members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Emmerich Kalman, Robert Stolz and Oscar Straus conducting their own compositions, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Yehudi Menuhin, violin recital, Town Hall, 8:30; opening concert of WNYC American Music Festival, Hunter College Auditorium, 3; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Mascagni Grand Opera Company, Verona Theatre, 7:45.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 11 -- A jury in Middlesex County Court here awarded tonight damages totaling $50,000 to the parents of a child born an idiot in a suit they filed against Dr. William Klein of 85 Bayard Street, this city.

ROME, Feb. 11 -- The indignation that is felt over the shelling of Genoa by the British Fleet on Sunday morning comes out in full today in the Italian press. A marble monument is going to be erected to commemorate what one newspaper calls "this cowardly attack." "Vile, piratical and iniquitous," are some of the other adjectives used.

Metro's "Maisie Was a Lady" is the new arrival this morning at Loew's Criterion. Ann Sothern again is starred in this latest of the "Maisie" series, and Lew Ayres, Maureen O'Sullivan, C. Aubrey Smith, Edward Ashley, Joan Perry and Paul Cavanagh are featured in the supporting roles. . . .

The Lincoln's Birthday preview performance of "The Mechanical Heart" tonight at Henry Miller's Theatre will be a benefit for the work being conducted by the Citizens Housing Council in improving the housing, neighborhood and health conditions of underpriviledged families throughout the city.

BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Boston's burly Bruins equaled the New York Rangers' year-old record of going unbeaten for nineteen straight National Hockey League games tonight when they shut out the Detroit Red Wings, 4 -- 0, before a crowd of 15,000 at the Boston Garden.

To Clarence S. Stein, New York architect who has specialized in community planning and housing, has been awarded the annual medal of honor of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects for his "high professional achievement" in these fields.

Mayor La Guardia awarded yesterday afternoon two one-year scholarships in Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, to two young men whose work was judged "best in show" at the National High School Art Exhibition now being held on the fifth floor of Macy's department store, Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway.

LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A "Free Italian" Committee appeared in London today, bolstered by facilities of the British Ministry of Information, and pledged to seek the upset of Benito Mussolini and help the British toward victory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Wendell L. Willkie, in a White House conference lasting more than an hour and a half tonight, gave to President Roosevelt a review of his trip abroad. The discussion covered British war production methods, Mr. Willkie's private conversation with President Eamon de Valera of Eire and the British and international situation in general.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The Senate confirmed by unanimous vote today the reappointment of Herbert Bayard Swope to the State Racing Commission after Mr. Swope had appeared earlier in the day before the Senate Finance Committee.

VICHY, France, Feb. 11 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, who left Vichy by train tonight for his villa on the Riviera, will probably meet Generalissimo Francisco Franco of Spain after the latter's visit to Italy.

Prior to the enactment of the Revenue Act of 1938 the term "capital assets" included generally all property, whether or not connected with the taxpayer's trade or business, except stock in trade or other property included in inventory, or property otherwise held for sale to customers in the course of the taxpayer's trade or business.

Meetings and observances commemorating the ninety-fourth anniversary of the birth of Thomas Alva Edison were held yesterday throughout the United States and Canada, while in New York the Edison Pioneers, men who worked with the inventor, joined with his widow and son, Governor Charles Edison of New Jersey, to pay tribute to the man whose inventions influence the daily lives of peoples the world over.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Following is a transcript of the questions asked of Wendell L. Willkie by members of the Foreign Relations Committee today and his replies:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Sixteen of the more important leather boot and shoe manufacturing companies in the United States had in 1939 a combined sales volume of $332,940,474, or slightly less than 44 per cent of the total output of such products in that year, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

BERLIN, Feb. 11 -- An economic expert of the German High Command said today that Germany had no intention of devoting so much of her food reserves to relief that the Nazi war effort would suffer in any way.

Gertrude Stein's first novel in eleven years will be published Saturday, and, coincidentally, candor in publishing will get a big boost. Miss Stein wrote recently to Bennett Cerf of Random House that "Ida" was about the Duchess of Windsor.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. ll -- Constance Winant, 20-year-old daughter of John G. Winant, newly appointed American Ambassador to Great Britain, eloped Sunday with a Peruvian, Carlos Valando, 22, and they were married at Chincha.

LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The British naval attack on Genoa at dawn Sunday completely surprised the Italians and it took their shore batteries fifteen minutes to open up, the Exchange Telegraph Agency's special correspondent with the fleet said in a delayed dispatch received today.

A few minutes before 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon a group of men, all wearing white aprons, all at least 5 feet 8 inches tall and weighing at least 150 pounds, lined up before the time clock in the Vocational School at Summer and Ellison Streets, Paterson, N.J. By 4 o'clock every one of them had punched the clock.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- While there was no change in the number of factory employes in the State in January, payrolls increased 0.4 per cent in the month, Frieda S. Miller, New York's Industrial Commissioner, reported today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Two men were blown through a wall into the elevator shaft and fell twelve stories to death and another was fatally crushed today in an explosion of a giant pressure kettle in the Edwal Laboratories, a commercial chemical manufacturing company on the twelfth floor of the Borland Building, on the southern fringe of the Loop business district.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 11 -- Indications that the pledges made by the Popular party during the last election campaign would be followed by specific acts were given today at the opening of the Legislature, an occasion which saw Governor Guy Swope read his first legislative message.

Heavy orders for men's Fall furnishings, substantially larger than those of a year ago, were placed by stores throughout the country this week, in anticipation of rising prices, manufacturers and resident offices reported here yesterday. The items chiefly in demand were heavy underwear, wool hose and gloves.

TOKYO, Feb. 11 -- Facing, in the words of Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye, "the most dangerous situation since its foundation," when the issues of war or peace are held here to be in the balance, Japan today celebrated the 2601st anniversary of the founding of the Japanese Empire.

Gregor Piatigorsky, 'cellist, and Hugh Ross, director of the Schola Cantorum of New York, have been added to the faculty of the Berkshire Music Center, it was learned yesterday with the publication of the catalogue for the Center's second season, which will open on July 7 and continue for six weeks.
SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Five types of American warplanes were demonstrated today to answer the question of whether American aircraft are up to European standards.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- Three gas explosions wrecked four South Philadelphia dwellings today, killing five persons and injuring more than thirty.

Bishop Henry St. George Tucker of the Protestant Episcopal Church, urged his associates in the National Council of that denomination yesterday to join in the work "of preparing the world to meet a crisis." He addressed the opening session of the quarterly meeting of the council at the headquarters, 281 Fourth Avenue.

Mayor La Guardia was chided for his association with Democratic machine leaders in the Presidential election by Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman, in a speech yesterday before the Republican Committee of 100 in the Hotel Beekman, 575 Park Avenue.
Two buildings and a considerable parcel of land in Long Island City, L.I., have been acquired by purchase and lease by Combined Motors, Inc., through Lehr Benes, brokers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The metropolitan police remained convinced today that General Walter G. Krivitsky, former Red Army spy chief, took his own life yesterday in the Hotel Bellevue here.

To those who have glib answers to all questions Abraham Lincoln has never made a great appeal. But upon those of us today who are deeply disturbed by the question, What is the meaning of the agony through which the would today is passing? Abraham Lincoln makes a profound impression.

The field for legitimate strike insurance is vast. Its need is immediate and perpetual. The cost, placed squarely upon the price of commodities and services, would quickly go on the backs of the consumers -- where it rightfully belongs. The public tolerates and by its intermittent apathy and sympathy supports the strike system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Principal owners, officers and directors of corporations gave away millions of dollars worth of securities in December, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today in a summary of transactions for the month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Roosevelt said today that the movement of United States war supplies to Great Britain would not be hampered if the United States became involved in a Far Eastern war. He indicated, coincidentally, that he did not consider such a war likely.
The league-leading New York Athletic Club Class A squash tennis team virtually clinched the title in the Metropolitan League last night by gaining its tenth straight victory of the season.

Production of crude oil in the United States last week averaged 3,617,650 barrels daily, an increase of 27,500 over the 3,590,150 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 11,250 barrels more than the calculation of 3,628,900 daily by the Bureau of Mines for February.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 11 -- The presidents of Harvard and Yale joined tonight in a plea to the universities of the nation to provide the moral and scientific background for a strong national defense. The heads of the two universities spoke at a forum at Yale on "The Universities and National Defense."

Banks and insurance companies figured as sellers in most of the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday. The Central Savings Bank closed deals for two East Side properties and the Mutual Life Insurance Company also figured in two of the sales.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Roosevelt has invited President General Higinio Morinigo of Paraguay to send his 10-year-old son to Warm Springs, Ga., for treatment for infantile paralysis, it was disclosed tonight.

In the two decisions on picketing handed down on Monday, what was most immediately dramatic was the first important division of opinion among the "Roosevelt members" of the Supreme Court. Justice Frankfurter, speaking for the majority, held that State courts were constitutionally entitled to issue injunctions "to enjoin acts of picketing in themselves peaceful when they are enmeshed with contemporaneously violent conduct which is concededly outlawed."

With imports of essential oils from the south of France cut off and stocks here approaching exhaustion, the high-grade perfumery industry in this country is practically "living from day to day" so far as these basic components are concerned, H. Gregory Thomas, associated with Bourjois, Inc., and chairman of the raw materials and essential oils committee of the Toilet Goods Association, said in an interview yesterday.

A nation's choice of heroes tells much of what the nation is and more of what the common man wants it to be. Abraham Lincoln persists in our affections because what he said, and did, and was, expresses something that we deeply value. We have no right to say that if he could be alive now he would support this or that course of action or this or that party.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Favorites almost without exception survived the first round of match play in the Everglades Club's sixth annual mixed foursomes golf tournament today, but several well-liked teams had narrow squeaks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- In the delay before the Supreme Court came to decision in the Meadowmoor Dairies case, and in the spirited language of the majority and minority opinions, there are signs of a deep inner struggle in the court over the issues involved.

Bankers' dollar acceptances increased $4,118,000 in January to a total of $212,777,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This marked the fourth consecutive monthly gain, according to these statistics, which cover the nation.

Moving irregularly over the widest range in several weeks, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday unchanged to 4 points lower. Trading in the distant months, which was probably the most active since they were admitted to the list, was mostly of a speculative nature.

Mrs. Elizabeth Auterhoff, 56-year-old widow, who several weeks ago was ordered to move from her barge, the Elizabeth, which was moored at Mill Basin, off Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, because she had violated the city charter by tying up a boat to a city-owned dock, had a new champion yesterday in the Brooklyn Council of Sea Scouts, a branch of the Boy Scouts of America.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Heavy receipts of 16,000 salable hogs, in addition to 3,500 shipped direct to packers, caused another drop in hog prices today. Although the close was active, hogs 230 pounds and down dropped 10 to 15 cents, topping at $8. Choice 180 to 240 pound hogs brought $7.75 to $8.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- More than one-third of the New Jersey properties on which the Home Owners Loan Corporation gave loans have been taken over by the HOLC, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

An agreement just drawn between the National Audubon Society and the Feather Industries of America promises to put an end to the use of wild bird plumage for millinery and other purposes. The agreement is contingent on expected legislation. It provides for the disposition of present stocks over a six-year period and for the filing of complete inventories with the State Conservation Department.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11 -- Flamingo Stakes eligibles filled the eye at Hialeah Park today as 11,084 rain-swept spectators saw tiny Apprentice Conn McCreary, who weighs only 98 pounds, take four races. The best event was the Seminole Purse, McCreary riding the winner in Cleaveland Putnam's filly Moja, one of those likely to go to the post in the $20,000 added race set for Feb. 22.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Great Britain's Home Fleet, perhaps envious of the achievements of the Mediterranean Fleet, shelled the Belgian port of Ostend before dawn this morning.

With the official opening of the National Sportsmen's Show at Grand Central Palace at the first hiss of the twelve-o'clock whistle this Saturday, the formal dinner season of dozens of local and near-local hunting and fishing clubs will also be launched.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, the champion, suffered his first defeat in the world three-cushion billiard tournament tonight, losing to Welker Cochran of San Francisco, a former titleholder, 50 to 40, in 50 innings.

Jacob C. Klinck, president of the Kings County Savings Bank and former Grand Master of Masons of the State of New York, was re-elected president of the Steuben County Society last night at the organization's forty-sixth annual dinner at the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center.

Testimony that Hymie Caplin, manager of Lew Jenkins, world's lightweight boxing champion, had boasted that he would win his trial on grand larceny charges arising from the operations of a $2,000,000 card swindling ring because of "my connections in the District Attorney's office" was given yesterday in the County Court in Brooklyn.

Surveys by the American Institute of Public Opinion completed after more than a month's national discussion of the lease-lend bill, indicate that four out of five sections of the country are in favor of the bill -- one of them by an overwhelming majority -- while in the fifth section the division of sentiment is so close that the final verdict for that area is in doubt, according to Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director.

ATHENS, Wednesday, Feb. 12 -There was so little life, if any, in the Italian attacks launched on the Albanian front during the last twenty-four hours that it might almost be said they had not tried to attack at all. This, in effect, was what the official spokesman announced last night, and he suggested that those few remnants of a once offensive spirit existed more for political reasons than for strategy.

Seeking to preserve the historical flavor of the small communities that make up the city, Chief City Magistrate Henry H. Curran announced yesterday that he had abandoned numerical designations for the Magistrates' Courts and substituted the names of the sections they serve.

THE better the day, the better the deed. This being Lincoln's Birthday, it's timely to take up the recent Landis ruling in baseball that has the slave owners of the ivory industry in a dither. For Judge Landis, in the wake of the Great Emancipator, is out to break the shackles that bind a set of slaves, the poor peons of the professional diamond, who are bought, sold and traded like cattle.
Churchill has at last said -- in his speech as I read it in THE TIMES -- what 40,000,000 Italians have been whispering for months: "Mussolini is the Italian Quisling."

Welfare Commissioner William Hodson, testifying yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church, declared that "there is no Communist domination in the Department of Welfare" and said he did not believe there were any Communists among the supervisors and administrators or in his own immediate staff.
First of the changes brought about by the mechanization of the Stock Clearing Corporation will take effect tomorrow, according to an announcement made yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 11 -- The breaking off of British-Rumanian diplomatic relations is treated as the most important event of the day in the German press. But even that is treated as a matter of course here, for the Germans declare London's purpose is purely propagandistic and that the British are departing from Rumania because Premier Ion Antonescue has cleaned up the nation and there is no further possibility of their carrying on activities against Germany.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The War Department awarded an $18,040,429 contract today to the General Electric Company of Schenectady, N.Y., for airplane superchargers.
ROME, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

Politeness paid dividends yesterday to a number of New York children in the form of an announcement that they had won high ranking or honorable mention in a courtesy contest conducted by the WPA-directed Junior Inspectors Club of the Department of Sanitation.

Fordham's sophomores, getting a bit slicker with every appearance, polished off Colgate, 59 to 37, for their tenth victory of the campaign before 3,000 in the Ram gymnasium last night. It was a month to the day since the New York Maroon beat the up-State Maroon, 59 to 32, but this was perhaps a more thorough job because the Red Raiders had upset rugged Syracuse in the game before this one.

Four of the world's outstanding light-heavyweight boxers yesterday were designated by the State Athletic Commission to take part in an elimination series designed to produce an undisputed champion for the 175-pound class against the day when Billy Conn, holder of the title, surrenders it for a chance at Joe Louis's world heavyweight honors.

Governor Charles Edison of New Jersey and his mother, Mrs. Mina Edison Hughes, widow of Thomas A. Edison, went aboard the new destroyer Edison in the Navy Yard in Brooklyn yesterday on a brief tour of inspection, during which the Governor addressed the officers and crew of the warship while they stood at attention on the main afterdeck.

The booksellers of the country, through whose hands pass, or on whose hands remain, the thousands of titles brought out each year yesterday made their awards for their favorite books of 1940 and named their choice of a neglected book. The awards were made at the book and author luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 11 -- The $600,000 allotted by the WPA for Newark airport will be used to extend the main runway several hundred feet to conform with minimum requirements for a Class 4 field, improve the field's surface and build auxiliary runways, it was explained here today by Lieut. Col. Edwin E. Aldrin, manager of the field.

LONDON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- A mechanized "Free French" force, striking 350 miles across the southern Libyan desert in another daring assault, has wiped out Italy's Kufra air base and inflicted heavy losses on the Fascist defenders, the headquarters of General Charles de Gaulle said tonight.

The Columbia and Pennsylvania basketball teams tonight will renew a 39-year-old rivalry when they meet for the first time this season in the feature event of the thirty-fourth annual midwinter Alumni Day celebration on the Morningside Heights campus.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 12 (UP) -- The Royal Air Force, in its biggest sustained offensive since September, heaped destruction on the Nazi "invasion front" early today. For the sixth consecutive night invasion ports were being ripped by tremendous explosions that rocked houses on the English shore of the Channel.

There was little material change in prices of most classes of fresh meats in yesterday's trading. The market on veal and lamb hindsaddles was slow, with an easier tendency. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to firm. Kosher steer chucks and plates were about steady in the usual quiet Tuesday trading.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., of New York City has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to cover the issuance of 148,991 shares of $100-par-value cumulative preferred stock and full and fractional warrants as evidence of the rights to subscribe to the shares, according to an announcement today by the commission.

The question of whether priorities will become necessary in distribution of sulphuric acid, of which some 12,000,000 tons will be needed this year for defense and commercial uses, occupied the attention of producers and users yesterday. Producers felt that there was little question but that priorities must be invoked, but some large buyers asserted that conversion of existing facilities, plus some plant construction, might well bring the present production rate up to the required amount.

The Republic Steel Corporation filed yesterday with the Cleveland office of the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $90,000,000 of new securities. Dillon, Read Co., Glore, Forgan Co. and Lehman Brothers will head the underwriting group of 139 members which will offer the issues.

MONTREAL, Feb. 11 -- The Canadiens, showing new vitality all along the line, flashed to their first National Hockey League victory in eight starts tonight in the Forum with a 6-2 triumph over the Rangers. The winners increased their hold on sixth place to 3 points over the idle Americans.

Extensive alterations are being made at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue. Seven new units are being added to the present quarters, bringing the total number of exhibition rooms to fifteen. Many innovations are being embodied in the construction plans.

Before a gathering of 10,000 highly excited boxing fans Tami Mauriello, young Bronx middleweight last night made an auspicious return to the Bronx Coliseum. Engaging in his first battle in six weeks, or since he sustained the first defeat of his career at the hands of Billy Soose, Mauriello knocked out Wild Bill McDowell, Texas, in the sixth round of their scheduled eight-round feature.

Torger Tokle, unassuming 21-year-old Norwegian who has made the breaking of ski-jumping records almost a habit since coming to the United States two years ago, arrived yesterday at La Guardia Field in a United Airlines plane from Leavenworth, Wash., where he set a new American record of 273 feet last Sunday.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Governor Lehman warned tonight that the public must "foot the bill" for any proposed extension or creation of social services by the State.

All of the principal securities and commodity exchanges throughout the United States will be closed today in observance of Lincoln's Birthday. The New Orleans Cotton Exchange which, in other years, has always remained open on Feb. 12, will be closed today.

Net operating loss of the New York Curb Exchange last year was $126,310, against $102,714 in 1939, according to the report issued yesterday. Before depreciation and amortization, the institution had a slight profit, for these items totaled $127,453.

BERLIN, Feb. 11 -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, was the principal speaker at a mass meeting held in the Berlin Sportpalast this afternoon. He described German war aims concisely as the "winning of 'Lebensraum' for the German nation as well as a share for the German people of the riches of the world."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11 -- Creation of machinery similar to that of the World War National War Labor Board to adjust labor disputes on defense projects was advocated today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

While preparing to head southward tonight, President Larry MacPhail of the Dodgers yesterday announced that Luke Hamlin and Whitlow Wyatt, veteran right-handed pitchers, who figure prominently in Brooklyn's plans for 1941, and Southpaw Howard Mills had agreed to terms.
The outbreak of influenza that has been discomforting New York City for the last two months now seems definitely waning, according to statistics made public by the Health Department yesterday.
BERLIN, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

Mount St. Michael High, defending city C.H.S.A.A. ruler, yesterday dropped its first contest in its last thirty-two regularly scheduled games over two seasons. Mount St. Michael bowed to St. Simon Stock, 37-36, in a thrilling Bronx-Westchester clash on the former's court. Mount St. Michael had won eight straight league engagements before yesterday and continues to show the way in its section.

The Ballet Theatre has done it again. The opening of its second season at the Majestic Theatre last night exhibited both expert craftsmanship and a markedly welcome freshness of viewpoint. Respecter of tradition, it has nevertheless not forgotten that its title contains the word "theatre" as well as the word "ballet."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Wendell L. Willkie backed the lease-lend bill today, with a call for some modifications, and told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that if Britain falls America inevitably will be at war a month or two later.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, announced today the appointment of an Interdepartmental Advisory Committee, the establishment of twelve Federal Regional Advisory Councils, and the designation as Regional defense Coordinators of the twelve regional directors of the Social Security Board.

Wendell Willkie gave his eloquent and persuasive support yesterday to the formula which, from the very start, has pointed the right way to action on the lease-lend bill: an immediate and necessary increase in the authority of the President, within limitations which will safeguard those powers of Congress which are essentially legislative in character.

Freedom, tolerance and other ideals characteristic of Abraham Lincoln will be accentuated against the present world background of oppression, in addresses and exercises today commemorating the 132d anniversary of the birth of the Great Emancipator.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- After an acrimonious debate, which was followed by the collapse of Representative Dies of Texas, the committee's chairman, the House voted today to extend for fifteen months the life of the committee investigating un-American activities. The vote was 353 to 6.

For the second day frequent clashes between police and picketing sandhogs yesterday marked the jurisdictional dispute between two A.F. of L. unions over control of jobs on the construction of the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn-Battery tunnel.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Sixteen of the finest 3-year-olds campaigning in the West were named today for the seventh running of the $50,000 added Santa Anita Derby tomorrow and once again lucky Charles S. Howard boasted the top contender for one of Santa Anita Park's fabulous purses.

The electric iron industry appears to have been the only one in recent years encouraging trade-ins to any extent and this trend is emphasized in a new campaign by the Proctor Electric Company, Philadelphia. The company's sales last year rose 114 per cent and with the new drive further gains this year are expected.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 11 -- Heavy bombers of the Royal Air Force again dropped several tons of bombs yesterday on the Calato airdrome on the island of Rhodes, destroying ten planes on the ground and setting many machines and buildings afire.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 11 -- Swedish press reorts form well-in-formed Oslo sources that the German occupation authorities have informed Major Vidkun Quisling's government that it must not count on the re-establishment of Norway's independence even after a German victory.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Major Gen. Raishiro Sumita, head of the Japanese military mission in Indo-China, flew from Saigon to Bangkok today. French sources said he went to try to end continued fighting along the Thai-Indo-Chinese border.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Feb. 12 -- Michael J. Coyle was maintenance superintendent of the Hudson County Boulevard thirty-five years, a former member of the Hudson County Board of Freeholders, a member of the New Jersey Assembly between 1892 and 1894, and for ten years before the turn of the century, Democratic leader in this city.

After keeping away from the theatre for nine years, Rose Franken has popped back as author of "Claudia," which was put on at the Booth last evening. In 1932 she made her theatrical debut as author of "Another Language," which was crowded with characters.

An attack on the Board of Education's released time bill, which provides an hour a week during school sessions for children of all faiths to attend religious education classes, was made yesterday by Newbold Morris, President of the City Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- On the first test vote taken by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today on the lease-lend bill, an amendment by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan was rejected by 13 to 10, and Administration leaders in the Senate gained the impression that this represented the maximum committee strength which the opposition could muster.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Office of Production Management today took steps to safeguard the nation's supply of aluminum and magnesium, and one result may be a smaller supply of aluminum products on the shelves of retail dealers.

The New York Retail Milk Distributors, Inc., a group of about 200 men who operate door-to-door milk routes as independent business men, is contemplating the formation of a distributors' cooperative to deal directly with farmers in the purchase of milk supply, Edwin Stephen Schweig, attorney for the group, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Roosevelt today had as his guest at the White House for a two days' visit Grand Duchess Charlotte of Luxembourg, her consort, Prince Felix, and their son, the Grand Duke Jean.

The 1941 national bread advertising campaign, which will be started this month by the department of nutrition of the American Institute of Baking, under the sponsorship of Standard Brands, Inc., will have as its theme "America Goes Forward."

Oscar Straus, Emmerich Kalman and Robert Stolz, the latter-day Viennese waltz kings, shared the same podium last night to direct sixty-five members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in their own composition at a concert at Carnegie Hall in aid of "Bundles for Britain," "Artists in Need" and the Greek War Relief.

MANILA, Feb. 12 (UP) -- A special commonwealth prosecuting attorney is investigating Japanese landholdings in the Province of Davao on Mindanao Island alleged to have been acquired illegally through the use of Filipino "dummies."
Investments in Manhattan realty were scattered yesterday.

Contract lettings for engineering construction continue in volume far exceeding the awards for last year, and the figure for the current week is 151 per cent higher than that for the corresponding period of 1940, according to The Engineering News Record.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Still seeking more votes for the lease-lend bill administration leaders in the Senate today offered its opponents a surprise concession which, they said, would give Congress firmer financial control over the aid-to-Britain program.

Boston's sizzling Bruins, already having tied the National Hockey League record for an unbeaten streak, will seek to assume sole possession of the mark when they skate against the Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight. The battle promises to attract the largest crowd of the season to the Eighth Avenue arena, for it will show the Bruins in action against the team whose mark of sustained successes they hope to beat.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Favorable and unfavorable factors in world trade developments, as reported by cable and radio to the Commerce Department by its foreign attaches, were listed by the department today as follows:

TWO hundred and forty years ago England faced a peril so like the present one that the remembrance of what she then survived may steady our belief that this too will be overcome. "The apparent danger of an invasion, briefly represented in a letter to a Minister of State, by a Kentish gentleman," was written in 1701, and contains this passage:

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- Participants in the personnel conference of the American Management Association opening here today were warned by Leo Wolman, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, that a cycle of increasing wages, frequent labor disputes, and intensive unionization drives is ahead of them. Said Dr. Wolman to his audience, which included some of the nation's foremost business executives:

A new and highly flexible process of petroleum cracking, intended primarily for production of motor gasoline, was announced yesterday by W.S. Farish, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, and F.A. Howard, head of the Standard Oil Development Company, a subsidiary.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 12 (AP) -- British reinforcements were reported today to be pounding down the northern coastal plain of Eritrea for an assault on besieged Cheren.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- On the authority of Prime Minister Churchill, the British Embassy today denied that he had ever said "America should have minded her own business and stayed out of the World War," or made any similar utterance.

A group headed by Gene Sarazen, the noted professional golfer, has organized the Lakeview Country Club, Inc., and has acquired from the Interlaken Realty Co., Ernest Iselin, president, the former Mount Vernon Country Club property with its eighteen-hole golf course comprising 122 acres on White Plains Road, Route 22, in the Town of Eastchester, Westchester County.

The editorial in THE TIMES of Feb. 9 quoting the predictions of a writer in Scribner's Magazine in 1879 regarding the airplane reminds me of the predictions of Erasmus Darwin in his book, "The Botanic Garden," published in 1791. In Canto I he foretells airplanes in the following stanza:
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 12 -- Sixty German bombers passed over Budapest and the neighborhood today, flying in the direction of the Rumanian frontier, according to Hungarian sources here tonight.

Pliny H. Powers, Superintendent of Schools at Youngstown, Ohio, has been appointed chairman of the Department of Administration and Supervision at the New York University School of Education, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the university.

WHAT is about to happen on ice is something that might have been cooked up in the overheated brain of an imaginative playwright. It's really hot stuff. Last season the Rangers, on a tear, went through nineteen straight games without losing. The Bruins tied that record the other night when they knocked over the Detroit Red Wings.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 13 -- Widespread raids Tuesday night by British planes, embracing Hanover, which was attacked for the second night in succession, as well as Bremen and points in the Netherlands, Denmark, Norway and France, were announced by the Air Ministry.

Scoring forty-three of his forty-six points in the second half, Jules Kasner led the Brooklyn College basketball team to a 77-to-21 triumph over Yeshiva on the winner's court last night. Kasner's total is the highest ever made by a Brooklyn player while the team score is the greatest ever recorded on the home court.

The First Avenue Association, Inc., has adopted and forwarded to State and city official a resolution protesting "excessive assessments" and calling for the establishment of a State Board of Assessment Review.

BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- Evidence crops up every now and then that the German forces of occupation in the Netherlands, whether civil or military, are meeting with passive resistance on the part of the population.

Little of architectural beauty but another landmark will be lost to New York with the passing of the Aquarium at the Battery. Commissioner Moses has marked it for demolition in connection with the improvement of Battery Park and the completion of the vehicular tunnel to Brooklyn.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 12 -- Two long lifts in the third period gave a hard-skating Andover team a 2-1 victory over Exeter at the Boston Skating Club today in the twenty-seventh annual match between the schools, oldest prep school hockey rivals in the country.

Tropical products are being purchased by Soviet Russia through New York as a result of the disruption of trade brought about by the war, it was learned here yesterday. Cocoa, a variety of vegetable oils and tropical woods, formerly purchased through London, are being bought here by Amtorg Trading Corporation, American exporting and importing organization for Soviet Russia, according to exporters.

BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Two army pilots, Second Lieutenants J.E. Kinsey and Wilbur P. Broemel, were killed today when their planes crashed, and a third, Folmer Sogaard, parachuted to safety into the sea when the engine of his plane caught on fire.

The General Motors Corporation yesterday began the distribution of $8,063,840 in cash and common stock to almost 35,000 employes in the United States and Canada who are participants in the company's Employes Savings and Investment Plan. Of the sum being disbursed, $4,230,410 was contributed by the employes and $3,833,430 by the corporation.
A group of leases for large apartments in East Side buildings is reported by the Madison Realty Company, brokers.

Albert Ericsen has sold to an investing client of the Colonial Realty Company, Inc., the four-story apartment house at 344 Fifty-ninth Street, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, for cash above a first mortgage of $35,000. The house contains sixteen apartments and is assessed for $42,000.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (AP) -- General G. K. Zhukoff, who gained military prominence in the fighting in Outer Mongolia in 1938, was appointed Vice Commissar of Defense and Chief of the Red Army's General Staff today.

ATHENS, Feb. 12 -- Again today there was no Italian activity along the Albanian front, according to official sources. The supposition here is that the Italians have been forced to realize the futility of assaults upon the Greek Army.

An obscure major in the British Royal Signal Corps, now retired, whose "passionate" interest in sand drove him all over the world to study it, won recognition yesterday as a hero of the spectacular British successes in North Africa for his painstaking research on the terrain of the desert campaign.
ROME, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12 -- The Princeton University campus has been rocked by a long-planned and neatly executed practical joke, the details of which became known today. In the greatest display of gullibility in New Jersey since the "Martian Invasion," a large number of the student body was victimized.

A study of community employment problems under the defense program led yesterday to the publication of a memorandum by the Council of Democracy, 285 Madison Avenue, declaring that the formation of local councils throughout the country is essential if the job of the National Defense Commission in Washington is to be carried out effectively.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 -- There has come a notable improvement in Soviet-Japanese relations. Around Christmas time they were not too good and there was momentarily a startling hitch in negotiations for renewal of the fisheries agreement, which is vital for Japan.

THE TIMES published recently an article headed "Mayors Fight Bill on City Litigation." It seems to me that the article failed not only to set forth the practical results which would follow the passing of the Gittleson bill, which would permit examinations before trial of municipalities as well as permitting an examination of police blotters, but also failed to present a litigant's side of the picture.

With "Die Walkuere," the Metropolitan Opera moved into the heart of its annual matinee cycle of the uncut "Ring des Nibelungen" yesterday afternoon, and once more there was no mistaking the sovereign power of Richard Wagner's music.

The small Panamanian freighter Calanda, flying both the Swiss and Panamanian flags, arrived in port yesterday afternoon with 2,500 tons of valuable Swiss cargo that had been loaded at the Italian port of Genoa and examined for contraband at the British port of Gibraltar.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 13 -- Although the Japanese Army and Navy habitually proclaim that they do not interfere in politics, high officials of the War and Navy Offices yesterday virtually gave the House of Representatives instructions on how to vote on a crucial domestic issue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- "Arethusa arose from her couch of snows in the Acroceraunian Mountains," sang Shelley of an incident of the Mediterranean Spring in the age of mythology. Now Spring is, coming to the Mediterranean in the age of total war, and there are some military experts who believe that in this theatre, rather than beside the English Channel, the next great event of the war will occur.

This State once had a Governor who liked to "look at the record." Today, with certain species of salt water fish showing not only a marked decrease in numbers but a tendency to avoid our shores, the sportsmen are beginning to realize that it is just about time they followed this Governor's example.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 -- Rosalind Russell replaced Hedy Lamarr today in the lead opposite Clark Gable in "The Uniform," which will go before the cameras tomorrow, with Clarence Brown directing. The story by John Kafka and Melchoire Lengyel deals with a British officer turned confidence man.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- The Army Quartermaster today awarded contracts for 5,870,000 pairs of wool socks, thereby increasing by 870,000 pairs the quantity called for in Invitation No. 428, bids on which were opened here on Jan. 24. Most of the socks will be knitted from all-foreign wool.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce and Federal Loan Administrator, told his press conference today that there was no reason why Federal loans could not be made to American investors who might wish to purchase British holdings in this country which are to be liquidated by the British Government to obtain dollar exchange for war purchases.

ARDMORE, Pa., Feb. 12 -- In the keenest contest in the history of the North American figure-skating championship, Ralph McCreath, 21year-old Canadian titleholder, captured the men's crown by a fraction of a point.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Supplies of skilled and semi-skilled building trade workers continue to meet the demand in most States despite the large volume of construction work begun during the past few months, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, stated today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Additional legislation to prevent profiteering from hampering the national defense effort was recommended today to the Temporary National Economic Committee by Thurman W. Arnold, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Anti-trust Division.

The jurisdictional dispute between two A.F. of L. unions over control of construction jobs at the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn-Battery tunnel resulted yesterday in a three-round battle in which eggs, stones and other missiles hurtled through the air and policemen and picketing sandhogs rolled on the icy ground exchanging punches.
Knudsen's Aspirant Engineers are making a name for themselves on the campuses of the engineering schools of the Pittsburgh district.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- President Roosevelt has expressed the conviction that Britain will win the war within five or six months -- if the nation can hold out until Summer, it was said here today by Bertram Cruger, American banker, who is the London representative of the British War Relief Society in the United States.

Election of a reform slate of officers to head the Hotel Service Employes Union, Local 32-A, of the Building Service Employes International Union, A.F. of L., was announced yesterday by George West, chairman of the elections committee.

Three new films will be added to the Broadway screen roster today. Columbia's "This Thing Called Love" is the new attraction at the Radio City Music Hall. The comedy stars Rosalind Russell and Melvyn Douglas, in support of whom are Binnie Barnes, Allyn Joslyn, Gloria Dickson, Lee J. Cobb and Gloria Holden.

BERLIN, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Combat planes concentrating on British supply lanes sank a 7,000-ton merchant vessel and damaged two others, the German High Command reported today. The time of the operations was not specified.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Legislation increasing the Federal debt limit to $65,000,000,000 was approved today by a Senate finance subcommittee.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 12 -- Attacking for five hours, Royal Air Force bombers last night dropped loads of high-explosive and incendiary bombs at twenty-minute intervals on Comiso and Catania, on the island of Sicily, home nests of the Nazi dive-bombers that have been attacking British shipping in the Mediterranean and the British base at Malta.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (UP) -The Supreme Soviet today announced the appointment of General G. K. Zhukoff to be Chief of Staff and a Vice Commissar of Defense. General Zhnkoff commanded tank detachments against the Japanese in ;Outer Mongolia in 1939.
Enactment of the lease-lend bill will result in British orders for steel estimated at from 3,000,000 to 4,000,000 tons, according to Iron Age.

Columbia retrieved a bad start in its thirty-fourth annual Alumni Day celebration by winning a sensational uphill basketball battle against Pennsylvania in the Lions' gymnasium last night before a highly appreciative crowd of onlookers, many of them old grads.

Decisions of major importance for the future of Europe are at least implied in the conferences between Mussolini and Franco on one hand and Franco and Petain on the other. The big question behind this triangular meeting, agitating the West while the Nazi military machine rumbles in the East, centers in the role played by Mussolini.

MADRID, Spain, Feb. 12 -- Conversations today between General Francisco Franco, the Spanish Chief of State, and Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy resulted in "a complete identity of views" regarding "all problems of a European character interesting these two countries in the present historic moment," stated a communique issued late tonight.

"Popsy," which came to. Broadway on Monday night, with Al Shean in the name role, was taken off after last night's performance at the Playhouse. Altogether, the Frederick Herendeen comedy, staged by Rowland G. Edwards, had chalked up only four performances.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Fourteen of the most valuable small paintings have been removed from the Kaiser Friedrich Museum in Berlin and shipped to the United States by way of Siberia and the Pacific Ocean, according to the Ministry of Economic Warfare.

WHAT is a novel? Some famous controversies have raged over the answer to that. It depends, to some extent, on whether you are talking about Jane Austen or Zola, Tolstoy (there's that King Charles's Head!) or Gertrude Stein.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Official circles here professed today still to be in the dark about what is going on in the Balkans and in the reported conferences between Premier Mussolini, Reichsfuehrer Hitler, General Francisco France and Marshal Henri Philippe Petain.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 12 -- Not even the military strategists of the Forty-fourth Division can prevent an "attack" on their financial resources by the United States Internal Revenue Department, for tomorrow afternoon four deputy collectors, commanded by Harry S. Litle of the income tax division of the Internal Revenue Department at Camden, will "invade" this fort to tell 20,000 men stationed here how much they should pay to the government in taxes.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 12 -- Military salutes fired from the army garrisons in the city early this morning inaugurated the festivities of the fourth centennial of the foundation of Santiago. Military bands played in all the plazas and public buildings and private residences displayed flags and banners.

The English Royal Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret Rose expressed their thanks for Christmas gifts, sent to them on behalf of "the children of America," in a letter just received by Miss Nancy Ryan, daughter of Mrs. William Rhinelander Stewart of 435 East Fifty-second Street.

Shouts of approval of 10,000 enthusiasts in Madison Square Garden last night greeted the announcement that the marvelous black cocker spaniel Ch. My Own Brucie established a new record in the annual show of the Westminster Kennel Club.

Yehudi Menuhin made his third local appearance of the season last night at Town Hall in a recital given as the sixth event in the current Endowment Series of that institution. The violinist attracted an enthusiastic capacity audience so large that the entire stage was filled with the overflow of eager listeners.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- The 1940 "battle of the budget," staged when the State was threatened with a $15,000,000 tax increase, was re-enacted today before the joint hearing of the Ways and Means Committee of the Assembly and the Finance Committee of the Senate, but on a much smaller scale, in the Assembly Chamber instead of the Albany Armory.

CARTERET, N.J., Feb. 12 -- Work on a large national defense order at the local plant of the Foster-Wheeler Corporation was halted today by a twenty-four-hour "protest stoppage," which will be continued tomorrow as a strike.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Thomas E. Dewey, one of the leading candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination last year, speaking tonight at the Capitol's Lincoln Day dinner, advocated passage of the lease-lend bill with such reservations as would unite the two major parties and the country on the Administration's all-out aid to Britain policy.

Featured by a patriotic entertainment program, a "First Anniversary Party" was given yesterday afternoon in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria to mark the completion of the first year of activity of Bundles for Britain, Inc., nation-wide war relief organization with headquarters here at 745 Fifth Avenue.
AMSTERDAM, Feb. 12 -- Today's market continued to be dominated by slight offerings and a minimum in turnover.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman appealed yesterday for the support of 2,000 representatives of Holy Name societies throughout the archdiocese in preventing the defection in the lists of "practical Catholics" in the membership of the church.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Thursday, Feb. 13 (UP) -- The 72-foot yawl Escapade, owned by Henry Fownes of Stamford, Conn., arrived here shortly before last midnight -- the first boat to cross the finish line in the eighth annual Miami-to-Nassau sailing race.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 12 -- Swiss newspapers this afternoon draw diverse conclusions from the meetings of General Francisco Franco of Spain with Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy and with Marshal Henri Philippe Petain of France.

VICHY, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A dispatch from Marseille reported today that two leaders of pre-Hitler Germany, Rudolf Breitscheid, former leader of the Social Democrats in the Reichstag, and Rudolf Hilferding, former German Finance Minister, were arrested Monday and delivered to the German authorities.
LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The British Air Ministry issued this communique today:

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Lord Balfour of Burleigh told the House of Lords today that he feared the "vicious spiral of inflation" already was in operation and he estimated the gap between expenditure and revenue at between 600,000,000 and 700,000,000 for the current fiscal year.

Seeking new outlets for the meat products formerly sold in parts of Europe now cut off by the war, Argentine meat producers are planning an active drive to develop sales in neighboring countries in Latin America, according to information cabled here to the Argentine Information Bureau, Inc., from Buenos Aires yesterday.

The U.S.S. Illinois, 43-year-old battleship that resembles a huge "box car" as it stands locked to the shore at 136th Street and the Hudson River, lost yesterday the last remnant of a long and active Navy past. The ancient warship has received a new name so one of the projected 50-55,000-ton new ships of the line may carry her historic designation to sea once again.

Nowhere else in the world could one duplicate the scene and the moment in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearings when Senator Gillette asked Mr. Willkie if he was "a candidate for President last Fall." Mr. Willkie was indeed a candidate, as quite a few people know.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- In an unusual northwest wind that sent forth hardly enough breeze to move the sailing dinghies today at the Larchrnont Yacht Club there was a switching of crews to lighten the boats, and out of it grew protests over the scale of weights.

Rene d'Harnoncourt will lecture at 9 o'clock tonight in the Museum of Modern Art. His subject will be "Indian Tribal Arts and Traditions." An admission fee of $1 will be charged to the public-at-large and 25 cents for members. The museum galleries, however, will not be open tonight.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP) -- A $675,000 "robbery" investigation on Star Island, a residential section of Miami Beach, turned today into a treasure hunt for lost jewelry and cash.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- About 28,000 officers and enlisted men of the National Guard will be inducted into Federal service next month, the War Department said today, and an additions 6,000 Guardsmen will begin their year's training in April, and about 500 in June.

Free French forces pushing up through Libya from equatorial Africa have demonstrated that if the British decide to march on Italy's last remaining stronghold at Tripoli, the desert that lies ahead will offer no insuperable barrier to General Wavell's army. Two French raiding columns are operating over a sandy wilderness without even the vestige of roadways; yet they have already covered more than twice the distance the British must travel to reach Italy's Libyan capital.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe came from behind tonight to defeat Chicago's Allen Hall, 50 to 48, and strengthen his hold on first place in the $20,000 world three-cushion billiard tournament. The match went fifty-six innings.

Retail sales in New Jersey in 1939 totaled $1,580,401,000, an increase of 31 per cent over 1935, according to the report issued yesterday by the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce. The total was still 13 per cent below the dollar volume reached in 1929, when the general level of consumer goods prices was substantially higher.

The Medical and Surgical Supply Committee of America, which has sent $130,000 worth of medical and surgical supplies to Britain since August, issued an appeal yesterday through its advisory chairman, Dr. Carnes Weeks, for further supplies of sulfathiazole, the latest of the sulfanilamide group of chemicals that has proved itself the most effective so far in the treatment of a number of serious bacterial diseases and infections.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12 -- A pair of long shots by Captain Dan Carmichael and Dick Mayo in the first minute of the overtime period gave Princeton's basketball team a 36-32 victory over Harvard in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest tonight.

Registering its fifth consecutive monthly rise, the Fairchild retail price index advanced 0.3 per cent during January to 94.2 (Jan. 2, 1931, equaling 100), it was announced yesterday. The index figure, as of Feb. 1, compared with 93.9 on Jan. 2 and 92.3 a year ago.

TOKYO, Feb. 12 -- Temporary relief from apprehensions that have been daily growing more somber about the future in the Pacific is shown in the Japanese reception to President Roosevelt's remarks on the occasion of the arrival in Washington of the Japanese Ambassador, Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, the new Japanese Ambassador, paid his first ceremonial call on Secretary of State Cordell Hull today after his arrival yesterday to assume his duties. The meeting lasted exactly four minutes, one of the shortest on record for an initial call.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 12 -- German men dressed in civilian clothes are now supervising between fifty-three and sixty aircraft observation posts in Bulgaria, it is learned from responsible sources here. Many of these posts are [section censored].

Dorothy Thompson's sweeping picture of the strategic situation in Europe, in yesterday's Herald Tribune, shows one serious flaw. Her usually sure grasp on realities fails her with respect to the correct situation in "Alice in Wonderland." Miss Thompson said yesterday:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Travers and their daughters, the Misses Genevieve, Mary Ann and Millicent Travers, were honored at a cocktail party given this afternoon by Mr. and Mrs. Frank Speno Jr. at Pleasant View Cottage.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Renewed activity was shown in hog trading today as prices went up 10 to 15 cents. Supply was cut to 12,000 head in addition to 3,500 billed direct to packers, and top rose to $8.20, 20 cents over yesterday's level. Choice 180 to 240 pound hogs brought $7.85 to $8.15, with 240 to 270 pound butcher hogs selling up to $8.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 12 -- Charles S. Howard, the Midas of the turf world, did it again today.

The Rapp-Coudert committee's inquiry into "subversive activities", in New York City's public schools has not been a happy experience for any one concerned. It has been least happy, one supposes, for teachers who have been playing with red fire and are now trying to hide their burned fingers.

The government faces no emergency serious enough to require it to take over control of the radio, James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, declared yesterday at a Lincoln's Birthday luncheon, of the American Civil Liberties. Union in the Hotel Commodore.

In the presence of 2,000 students, teachers and guests, Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday received the Lincoln Award for "distinguished service" to the City of New York, at exercises held at the Abraham Lincoln High School, Brooklyn.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 12 (AP) -- The shake-up in the ranks of New England's Ivy League football coaching circles appeared almost completed today when J. Neil (Skip) Stahley, chief assistant to Dick Harlow at Harvard for the last six years, was appointed head coach at Brown University.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- The majority of the defense orders should be financed through normal credit channels and not by the government, P.D. Houston, president of the American Bankers Association and chairman of the American National Bank, Nashville, Tenn., today told 200 delegates to the golden jubilee convention of the American Warehousemen's Association here.

Seven colleges in the metropolitan area embarked on a new venture in the New York Coliseum last night, the first annual indoor metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships. With some 5,000 enthusiastic fans in the stands and highly exciting races on the boards, the meet proved to be a financial and artistic success from every standpoint.

The unusual record of Hudson Strode's course in creative writing at the University of Alabama in producing writers whose works are published has resulted in a contest. Yesterday J.B. Lippincott announced a prize contest of $1,000 (half outright award, half advance against royalties) to go each year to the author of the best full-length novel written under Professor Strode's direction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- It may be wise, even desirable, that the lease-lend bill, H.R. 1776, should include the House Amendment from the Committee on Foreign Affairs to the effect that nothing in this act shall be construed to authorize or to permit the authorization of convoying vessels by naval vessels of the United States.

The Dies Committee seems to have become almost a permanent fixture in Congress. It was on May 26, 1938, that the House by a voice vote passed the resolution providing for the appointment of the seven-man committee investigating un-American propaganda in the United States.

Harry Bridges, lanky West Coast Maritime Union leader and associate of John L. Lewis in the Congress of Industrial Organizations, has been a center of deportation proceedings since 1938, after several years of industrial strife in West Coast shipping.
Several apartment house properties changed hands in Bronx realty trading announced yesterday. In a number of the deals investors figured as principals.

The second festival of American music to be conducted by the city's radio station WNYC was opened yesterday afternoon with a public concert in the new auditorium of Hunter College. The concert was attended by 3,000 persons and another 2,000 were turned away because there was no further room in the hall.

A plan for a study of the policies, administration, methods of appointment and tenure of the New York City public schools and colleges, to be conducted by members of the faculties of two Eastern universities, was outlined by Paul Windels, counsel to the joint legislative committee investigating the educational system of the State, to Assemblyman Herbert A. Rapp, chairman, and Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr., vice chairman, in a letter made public yesterday.

A Royal Air Force pilot's fiancee and an R.A.F. wife are among eleven passengers on their way to Lisbon, Portugal, aboard the Dixie Clipper, which left La Guardia Field yesterday morning. A United States Education Office specialist in industrial labor training also was en route to England to study aircraft, shipbuilding and machine-tool training methods.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Rear Admiral Emery S. Land, Chairman of the Maritime Commission, was assigned by President Roosevelt today to the task of fully coordinating facilities for ocean transportation. He will continue to perform his duties as head of the Maritime Commission.
WINNIPEG, Feb. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Despite an increased lack of trading interest, all futures prices advanced on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange today.

BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- Professor Viktor Bruns, German authority on international law, contends that Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson's assertion that the Kellogg anti-war pacts grant signers the right to assist attacked States with all means, including war material as well as armed forces, is false.

In a recent issue of THE TIMES appeared an editorial, "Mobilizing Science," in the course of which, after referring to the work of Dr. Leonard Carmichael in cataloguing scientists and technicians in behalf of national defense, it was said:
Sales of the Chain Belt Company in 1940 were the largest in its history, C.R. Messinger, president, reported yesterday.

A campaign to protect New York dress manufacturers against "destructive competition" from unorganized shops out of town was undertaken yesterday by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.F. of L. Announcement of the organizing drive coincided with acceptance by the fourth of the five employer associations in this city of all major provisions of the new collective agreement proposed by the Dress Joint Board of the I.L.G.W.U.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP) -- National Champion Dick Chapman and Mrs. E.G. Schaefer of Philadelphia formed a winning combination today as they advanced to the semi-finals of the Everglades Club mixed foursomes golf tournament.

An ancient silver oar, the historic symbol of the jurisdiction that the United States District Court exercises as a court of admiralty, will be presented to the court in a brief ceremony when it opens tomorrow morning in Room 506 of the United States Court House.

BENGAZI, Libya, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Cyrenaica is settling down under British rule. Mottoes on the buildings here extol the new Roman empire, but the Union Jack hangs from the Bengazi city hall and British and Australian soldiers walk in the streets.
