ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- A bill designed to stop up-State consumers from taking advantage of liquor "price wars" in New York City was introduced today in the Legislature under Republican sponsorship.

The two Army induction centers in New York City accepted yesterday 554 draft registrants for a year of training under the Selective Service Act, and established a new low in the percentage of rejections for any single day in the city area since the draft began.
Holders of $5,000,000 of bonds of the Prudence-Bonds Corporation have nominated the following candidates as voting trustees for election on March 1:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Administration leaders in Congress are planning to introduce in the next few days another "emergency" tax bill, this time not to raise additional revenue but to extend relief to taxpayers in hardship cases, which are mounting rapidly under the Excess Profits Tax Law passed last Fall.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- Torger Tokle came tearing down the 450-foot-long inrun at tremendous speed and soared effortlessly to cover 180 feet and break the hill record today while winning the Franklin D. Roosevelt Trophy ski-jumping competition for the second time in three years.

For the second time within three weeks, Patrolman William Parr of the Central Park Precinct yesterday afternoon rescued a youngster who had fallen through the ice of the Seventy-second Street lake in Central Park. Patrolman Parr, after falling through the ice himself, pulled 8-year-old Joan McGrath to safety.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Today's stock markets were under the influence of uncertainties in the Balkans and most sections were dull.

ROME, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Asserting that continental Europe will be self-sufficient after the war, the newspaper Messaggero said today that the Axis expected to close European markets to American industry, agriculture and commerce. Referring to the United States as an enemy of the Axis, the paper said:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Development of a Federal glider pilot training program to meet the needs of America's fast-growing aviation industry was proposed today by two New York members of Congress.

Yesterday being a partial holiday, with most wholesale houses closing early, trading was only fair to slow. Prices of traefer meats were generally unchanged, but demand showed some improvement in contrast with the dullness of the past several weeks. The kosher markets opened slow but generally steady. One large slaughtering plant continued closed on account of strike.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands visited a British port today for her first inspection of a Netherland warship, described as "formidable," that just managed to escape falling into German hands by sailing from its home base in the dead of night last Spring.

It was Father's Day at the progressive Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University, yesterday, and 150 fathers, mostly professional and business men, took a turn at the daily school work of their children. The result was that middle-aged men played softball with 10-year-olds, donned aprons for cooking lessons and puttered with shop tools.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 12 -- It was Conn McCreary and Devil's Crag in the Lincoln Purse at Hialeah Park today. McCreary, the little lad who rode four winners yesterday, was so popular this afternoon that the James B. Campbell color-bearer went to the post the public choice in a field of six that included Corydon, conqueror of Bimelech in the Withers last year.
BERLIN, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it has postponed until Feb. 24 the effectiveness of Rules X-8C-1 and X-15C2-1 under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 regulating the hypothecation by members, brokers and dealers of securities carried for the account of their customers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 12 -- The British column advancing southward in the Eritrean coastal area toward Massawa has occupied Elghena, southwest of Taclai, the British command announced today, and is continuing a drive that may bring this force and that now around Cheren together, either at Massawa or Asmara.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 12 -- Jack Ryerson of Cooperstown, N.Y., eliminated the former metropolitan titleholder, Frank Strafaci of Great Neck, 2 and 1, today in the second round of the fourteenth annual national amateur championship of golf club champions on the St. Augustine Links.

ROME, Feb. 12 -- The extent of the British threat to Italian Somaliland is revealed by the Italians themselves today in a war bulletin that states: "An enemy mechanized column supported from the air occupied Afmadu." This town is a road junction in Southwestern Somaliland, more than eighty miles from the Kenya frontier and a little less than seventy from Kismayu, the second most important port of the country.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 12 -- An Inter-American celebration of the 450th anniversary of the discovery of America, to be participated in next year by the United States and all Latin-American countries, will be proposed, soon by the American Federation of Labor, William Green, its president, said today.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 12 -- Representatives of several concerns who will join to make tenders for the construction of the United States defense bases here arrived yesterday by clipper plane and conferred today with Major Donald White, head of the survey department of the Army engineers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP) -- John T. Flynn, columnist, charged in a statement submitted to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that Secretary Morgenthau had given Congress misleading statements about British finances in order to make "as strong as case as possible" for the pending British-aid bill.

Secretary Edward T. Brannick led the Giants' first baseball group out of the city yesterday as the Orange Blossom rolled out of Pennsylvania Station. Hal Schumacher, Irving (Bump) Hadley, an added starter, and Ken O'Dea were the principal parties, flanked by Tony Cuccinello, Jersey City pilot, and Southpaw George Bausewein, who is the property of the Little Giants.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Roosevelt put before Congress today a $898,392,932 program for additional naval ship construction and for bomb-proof shelters and other defenses for the nation's farflung outposts, including Guam.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 12 -- A refinancing program involving more than $125,000,000 and believed to be the largest financial transaction ever undertaken in Georgia was announced today when the Georgia Power Company applied to the Georgia Public Service Commission for permission to call in all its outstanding bonds for redemption and refinance them with bonds bearing a lower interest rate.

After coming from behind in two matches, John P. Laimbeer and Julian H. Burgess of the Garden City B.C. won the sixth annual Middle Atlantic doubles championship on the courts of the Manhattan Badminton Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Attorney General Jackson gave orders today that new deportation proceedings be started against Harry R. Bridges, West Coast C.I.O. leader who has been a center of controversy for years.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 12 -- A refinancing program involving more than $125,000,000 and believed to be the largest financial transaction ever undertaken in Georgia was announced today when the Georgia Power Company applied to the Georgia Public Service Commission for permission to call in all its outstanding bonds for redemption and refinance them with bonds bearing a lower interest rate.

After coming from behind in two matches, John P. Laimbeer and Julian H. Burgess of the Garden City B.C. won the sixth annual Middle Atlantic doubles championship on the courts of the Manhattan Badminton Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Attorney General Jackson gave orders today that new deportation proceedings be started against Harry R. Bridges, West Coast C.I.O. leader who has been a center of controversy for years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Some quarters here expressed a belief today that Wendell Willkie's recommendation to send England five or ten destroyers a month had met with a favorable response in some Administration circles. There was speculation that there might be sent to the British some of the forty-five destroyers which the Navy converted into minesweepers, minelayers and transport ships at the beginning of the emergency defense program.

Asserting that he would not permit "this group of thieves to get away on technicalities," Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato denied yesterday defense motions to dismiss grand larceny charges against Hymie Caplin, widely known prize-fight manager and alleged financier and behind-the-scenes operators of a $2,000,000 card swindling ring.

OTTAWA, Feb. 12 -- Before Adolf Hitler shifted the world's interest in airplanes from commercial to military models the Royal Canadian Air Force had about 3,500 men and not more than 300 airplanes of all types. Only a relatively small number of its men were pilots and many of its planes were near obsolescence.

An epic of the war was written when turbaned "Free French" desert fighters again swept half way across the world's greatest desert to raid the Kufra Oases in Southeastern Libya and, according to unconfirmed reports, to capture Ghadames, only 285 miles from Tripoli.

Active Lincoln's birthday trade was reported yesterday by merchants here. Comparisons were affected by the fact that the holiday this year occurred on a Wednesday against a Monday last year. Gains ranging from 50 to 150 per cent over the ordinary Wednesday of last year were reported by some department stores.

CAGNES-SUR-MER, France, Feb. 12 -- Although nothing has transpired here to disclose its tenor, the indications tonight were that the talks of General Franco with Premier Mussolini today will he the prelude to events of high importance to Europe.
LAKE PLACID, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Big Bill Linney, last year's bobsledding sensation, came out of semi-retirement today to retain his North American four-man championship.

VICHY, France, Feb. 12 -- Under a deal that has been under negotiation for some months Spain has agreed to an amnesty for nearly all of the 140,000 Spanish refugees still in the occupied and free zones of France, according to a dispatch from Madrid published today in Paris.

Peter Cooper, inventor of the first steam locomotive in America in 1830, was honored yesterday on the 150th anniversary of his birth by the alumni association of Cooper Union, the free educational institute he founded in 1859.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Prime Minister Churchill replied to advocates of an immediate and detailed government statement on British war aims in the House of Commons when he stated that there was no demand for them from the United States.

Dr. Ordway Toad, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, declared yesterday that unemployment after the defense boom would require the government to go into fields of business it had not entered yet, and advised new workers to join a union or professional association at once as a step toward the perpetuation of the essentials of American democracy.

Canadian indignation over the argument that even Canada does not "lease-lend" to Britain, an argument used by some opponents of the measure before Congress, is easy to understand. Across the border they see in the assertion what was probably never intended; that is, a slur on Canada's war effort.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 12 -- Acting Prime Minister A.W. Fadden yesterday told a deputation in the Australian Council of Trade Unions protesting the Arbitration Courts' refusal to increase the basic wage that if Parliament passed the necessary legislation child endowment would begin in July. It would be financed by employers', not employes' contributions, he said, and would apply to all children under 16 years.

Several parties were given in conjunction with the preview performance of "The Mechanical Heart" last night at Henry Miller's Theatre to augment the fund of the Citizens Housing Council for improving neighborhood conditions for the underprivileged of New York.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 12 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- Regarding the conversations between Italian and Spanish leaders the Germans announced today that nothing would be said from here. The Italians are the spokesmen in this instance, it is explained. None the less, in the German view the conversations between Premier Mussolini and General Francisco Franco of Spain are "no surprise."

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced yesterday to 250 Barnard College alumnae that Professor Ida Olgivie, chairman of the Geology Department, would retire at the end of this semester after thirty-eight years with the college. The announcement was made at the annual reunion luncheon in Hewitt Hall, 116th Street and Broadway.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 12 -- Installment selling is unlikely to exceed its 1929 peak despite the defense boom, Carl N. Schmalz, controller of the R.H. Stearns Company, Boston, and former chief of the Bureau of Business Research of Harvard University, said in an address here today before the Massachusetts Department of Education of the university.

An appeal to Republicans to cooperate in achieving national unity on adequate and speedy aid to Great Britain was made last night by Wendell L. Willkie, who on the preceding day had urged the immediate sending of destroyers and bombing airplanes to the British.
The Home Insurance Company in its annual statement, released today, shows the largest total of admitted assets in the company's history at $123,726,916.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 12 -- Yale's swimmers, in defeating Brown by 56 -- 19 tonight, set a world record of 3:30.1 in the 400-yard free-style relay, breaking the mark of 3:30.7 made just a year ago tonight by Yale.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- One of the most accomplished players of racquet games developed in this country, Robert Grant 3d, threatened today to carry off the Tuxedo gold racquet in both court tennis and racquets -- a feat that no amateur has achieved in forty years of competition here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Metropolitan police tonight wrote off the death of General Walter G. Krivitsky, former Soviet military spy chief, as a suicide, but left the way open for further investigation by deciding to impanel a coroner's jury to consider any additional evidence in the case.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 12 -- The Dartmouth quintet, again sparked by Gus Broberg, downed Yale tonight, 63 -- 41, for its fifth-Eastern Intercollegiate League triumph in as many starts this season. The victory enabled the Big Green to stay in first place.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- President Roosevelt has placed a control on all oil and gasoline exports to Japan in a roundabout manner, it was disclosed tonight, by requiring export licenses for the shipment of metal containers of more than five-gallon capacity regardless of whether they are empty or contain a product.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Feb. 12 -- In this back-country setting of sand dunes and loblolly and long-leaf pines the War Department is constructing hastily but on orderly schedule the largest of its permanent defense establishments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A two-faced effigy -- one showing President Roosevelt and the other Wendell Willkie -- was hanged from a wall on the British Embassy grounds today by a group of women who said they represented the Women's Neutrality League and Paul Revere's Sentinels.
IN came Al Schacht, the Clown Prince of Baseball, with a book under his arm. From this it was suspected that he had just left Prof. Moe Berg, who probably had forced the book upon him.

The gold medal for distinguished services to advertising, feature presentation of the Annual Advertising Awards, was awarded to Henry T. Ewald, president of Campbell-Ewald Company, Detroit, at a dinner last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 13 -- Turkey's loyalty to all engagements and her unalterable decision to protect her "zones of security," which had been constantly defined as including Bulgaria and Salonika, are again emphasized in several newspapers.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 13 -- Braving formal prohibition by the police and the church department, pastors in scores of Norwegian churches read from their pulpits the circular collective letter addressed by all seven Protestant Norwegian Bishops to the congregations in an effort to warn the country of the dangers of the Quislingist ideology and administration.

Twelve Barnard College girls, dressed neatly in new mechanic's overalls, huddled around a work bench in a public garage last night while an automobile mechanic explained the intricate parts that make a car go.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Friday, Feb. 14 -- Responsible Bulgarian Foreign Office circles last night confirmed reports that Germany intends to march her army through Bulgaria at least as far as the Greek frontier with the idea of assuming absolute control of Southeastern Europe by absorption and forcing peace on Axis terms between Greece and Italy or pushing her military might still farther south if Athens rejects the terms.

It is doubtless appropriate that THE TIMES should caution its readers against over-optimism as the result of the British victories in North Africa, as it has done in the editorial "The African Campaign." That the British are not deluding themselves in this matter was, by a curious coincidence, made plain in Mr. Churchill's radio address delivered only a few hours later.

The Ballet Theatre in its two performances at the Majestic Theatre yesterday added four ballets to its season's repertory. Two of them, which made their bows at the matinee, were standard works -- Fokine's "Les Sylphides" and the Petipa "Blue Bird" pas de deux from "The Sleeping Beauty."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Imports of gold into the United States, which decreased in December, were up again in January, according to a statement today by the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Department store sales for the week ended Feb. 8 were 19 per cent higher than for the corresponding week last year and in the four weeks' period ended Feb. 8 were 12 per cent higher than for the similar period last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
Budget Director Kenneth Dayton received a budget request of $36,176,416 from the Hospitals Department yesterday, which sought an increase of $6,399,605 for the next fiscal year.

BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- In the second massed attack on British shipping within three months, German warships patrolling in Atlantic waters yesterday were reported here to have sunk thirteen armed British freighters out of a "large convoy" sailing to England, among them several "ocean liners" whose tonnage, it was stated, probably exceeded 20,000 tons each.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Anti-trust laws as they affect labor unions may be one of the subjects considered by the House Judiciary Committee in a projected "re-examination" of the field of anti-trust enforcement, Representative Hatton of Texas, chairman of the committee, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Contracts aggregating $34,618,000 were awarded today by the War and Navy Departments for construction work on Atlantic bases leased or given by Great Britain to the United States in exchange for fifty destroyers.

LONDON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- A moderate rise in circulation of the Bank of England raised the total outstanding to 602,032,000 last week, the Bank's weekly statement showed today. The figure compared with the high record of 616,904,000 in December.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 14 (AP) -- leliable foreign sources declared today that Anglo-Japanese relations in the Pacific were approaching a crucial stage as a result of Japanese assistance to Nazi sea raiders and Japan's military pressure to!ward Singapore, Britain's great i Far Eastern naval base.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Confronted by a series of warnings of an impending labor shortage, participants in the industrial relations conference of the American Management Association devoted a large portion of today's sessions to a discussion of employee training and cooperation.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Fear that the European War might spread to the Orient "at any moment" was voiced in high Occidental diplomatic quarters today and appeared to be based on a belief that Japan would join Germany and Italy in a simultaneous "knockout" offensive against the British Empire.
Lady Joan Moore, Roger Prevost, through Bing Bing, Inc., in 220 E 73d St; John F. Hoban Co, broker.

The Army inducted 577 New York City men yesterday at the city's two induction centers. The number examined was 674 and the percentage of rejections was 12.5, or about 4 points higher than the previous day's low rejection record of 8.4.

Mr. and Mrs. Dwight C. Harris of Mayfair House gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis. Their guests included the Earl and Countess of Gosford, Mr. and Mrs. Clifford N. Carver, Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Tinker, Mr. and Mrs. John Davis and Mr. and Mrs. Donald Stoneham.

Strong favor is being shown navy in both early consumer reaction and retail reorders for suits, it was reported yesterday. Suit volume is increasing and these garments promise to be highly important for the Spring season. Plaid effects, beige and several of the pastel shades are also outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The text of the Senate committee's version of the President's lease-lend bill, now available, shows that the measure has been further improved from its original form and that greater safeguards of the Congressional function have been inserted.

"Back Street," the Rivoli's current tenant, has broken all attendance records for the first two days of its stay at that house, according to John Wright, the managing director. Universal's picturization of the Fannie Hurst novel was seen by 24,401 persons for the two-day period.

Today's events: "Fidelio," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Thomas Negro Composers Study Group, Town Hall, 8:45; Frederick Marantz, piano, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30.

Professor Viktor Bruns said in Berlin this week that Secretary Stimson is wrong in supposing that the terms of the Kellogg anti-war treaty justify the United States in sending aid to Britain. The learned doctor cites Secretary Stimson's speech of Aug. 8, 1932, as proof.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, via Berlin, Feb, 13 (AP) -- German authorities ordered all non-Jews out of the old Jewish quarter of Amsterdam around Waterloo Square today, raising the possibility of a moated ghetto of 50,000 inhabitants.

The United States can support a national defense program of $15,000,000,000 a year, or more if necessary, without checking savings or reducing the standard of living of the people, provided punitive and destructive taxes are not saddled on the country and private industry is not hampered by bureaucratic control and excessive restrictions, according to a report and addresses last night at a dinner of the American Taxpayers Association in the Hotel Astor.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- The battle for control of a public utility system between Floyd 13. Odium of New York, president of the Atlas Corporation, and Frank J. Lewis, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, broke out anew today at a special master's hearing.

Joseph Monaco, 18 years old, of 7805 Eighteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, did not answer to his name in Adolescents Court in that borough yesterday to plead to a charge of grand larceny growing out of his theft of an undertaker's hearse the night of Feb. 4.

The threat that the expected Spring offensive may be an offensive on all fronts begins to take the shape of reality. The possibility that all the aggressors might strike at once and together, not in concert but in collusion, each out to rake in his own plunder in a general orgy of plunder, has long loomed as the logical finale to the desperate gamble for world dominion in which they are now so deeply involved.

In what was understood to be a unanimous decision, the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday not to extend trading hours. It took this action by adopting the report of the special committee headed by Edgar Scott, which was based on answers to a questionnaire which showed more than half the members opposed to change.

ATHENS, Feb. 13 -- According to all reports, official and otherwise, Greek troops repulsed Italian efforts along the Albanian front today to regain positions from which they had recently been ousted -- positions, incidentally, which the Greeks found elaborately fortified.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- To meet demands for power occasioned by defense needs in addition to peacetime requirements, President Roosevelt asked Congress today for an additional appropriation of $10,000,000 for the Tennessee Valley Authority, and Secretary Ickes announced "a wholesale expansion" of the production program, designed to speed it up "not by weeks or months but by years."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- During the week ended Feb. 12 member bank reserve balances increased $29,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from a reduction of $70,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and increases of $43,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $8,000,000 in gold stock, offset in part by increases of $38,000,000 in money in circulation and $53,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

Following testimony yesterday before the City Council Committee investigating the Municipal Civil Service Commission, Morris S. Novick, director of Station WNYC, denied that the city station had ever broadcast radical radio dramas.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 13 (UP) -- Seeded stars advanced to the quarter-finals of men's singles in the seventeenth annual mid-Winter tennis tournament today, but the favored Miss Valerie Scott of London was eliminated from the women's play.

More than 300 prominent families of New York and the metropolitan area, subscribers to the Butlers' Staff Ball, had early dinner last night so that their household staffs could attend the ball at the Hotel Commodore.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

Limited skiing is in store for metropolitan enthusiasts this week-end unless the snow squalls forecast for tomorrow develop into a real storm, thus providing new surfaces for the trails and slopes throughout the Northeastern United States. Reports yesterday indicated that unbreakable crust and hard packed snow conditions make for spotty running in most of the popular ski centers, while granular surfaces and settled powder coverages provide good fun at scattered points.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- The Army Quartermaster today awarded contracts for 9,000 Army nurses' white caps, 312,200 pairs of working gloves with leather palms, for the manufacture of 200,000 mosquito bars, and for quantities of thread and gimp. Those awarded contracts were:
Since "French cooperation" in Africa and the Mediterranean cannot be relied upon, the things General Francisco France and his government have in their gift fast assume for the Axis an enhanced value.

Production of twelve one-minute screen trailers designed to stimulate recruiting for the Army have been completed by the War Department and will be released for showings in theatres within a week or so, according to an announcement from the Motion Picture Committee Cooperating for National Defense.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 13 -- The United States Government will not be harsh in collecting income taxes from men recently inducted into the military service, it was announced here tonight. Harry S. Litle, chief of the Income Tax Division, Department of Internal Revenue, at Camden, N.J., disclosed that soldiers "financially embarrassed" would get eighteen months to pay the tax on their 1940 incomes.
Now that the draft denies an individual the right to protest entrance into the Army excepting conscientious ob jectors, all others are compelled to comply with the law.

Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's city-wide investigation into a paving racket that defrauded the taxpayers of $1,000,000 in the last four years virtually completed its first phase yesterday as eleven corporations and two individuals pleaded guilty and paid fines totaling $18,500.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The "defense importance" of labor relations and the importance to the nation of continuing and improving good labor policies during mobilization of its defense resources, was urged upon Congress in an annual report of the Wage and Hour Division of the Department of Labor submitted today by Colonel Philip B. Fleming, Administrator.

HAVANA, Feb. 13 -- Instructions were issued today to the armed forces and to Mayors, Governors and postal employes throughout Cuba by the Ministers of National Defense, Interior and Communications for application of the recent defense decree prohibiting totalitarian propaganda.

Alfonso XIII never abdicated as King of Spain but merely signed a manifesto on April 14, 1931, in which he said the elections held two days previously "made it clear that I no longer have the love of my people." Predicting that the republic would not last, he added:

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 13 -- Royal Air Force bombers have raided airdromes on the Italian island of Rhodes for the fourth day in succession, blasting hangars, supplies and planes at Marizza, Calato and Katavia, the R. A. F. command announced today.

Dr. S. Ansbacher of the Squibb Institute for Medical Research announces in Science that he has discovered a new vitamin in the "B" complex. Since at least two new vitamins turn up every year, we rather expect biochemists to add to the formidable number we already have.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a farewell dinner tonight for the Grand Duchess Charlotte of Luxembourg who, with her consort, Prince Felix, and their son, the Grand Duke Jean, has been their house guests since Wednesday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 13 -- The story of British mechanized raiding columns that traversed the great sand sea of inner Libya for months, attacking Italian forts and communication lines, was told here today by the men in charge, all of whom formerly made a hobby of desert exploration.
ROME, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

It is sheer coincidence that the lease-lend bill was favorably reported to the Senate yesterday, on the very day that the news pointed to a sudden intensification of the war and a fresh assault by the aggressor nations on widely scattered fronts. But behind this coincidence lies the compulsion of events themselves.

The Peoples Light and Power Company will notify today holders of its collateral lien bonds, Series A, due on Jan. 1, 1961, that all bonds outstanding have been called for redemption on April 1 at par. Payment will be made at the Chase National Bank.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary, said that the contracts awarded by the War Department today for work at the Atlantic bases were on a fixed-fee basis and that fees averaged 3 to 4 per cent. The contracts and the total estimated costs of the various projects included these:
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Concern was manifested in diplomatic quarters today over developments in the Far East that pointed to a possibility that Japan might be undertaking a further movement in her southward expansion, this time aimed more closely toward the Netherland Indies or the British base at Singapore.

Private welfare agencies are an important factor in the period of transition brought on by the war, Dr. Frank Kingdon, chairman of the Emergency Rescue Committee, declared yesterday at the annual meeting and luncheon of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies held in the Hotel Plaza.

OTTAWA, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Air Minister C.G. Power announced today that a system of airports through Alberta and British Columbia leading to Alaska is being established by the Canadian Government at a cost of approximately $9,000,000.
AMSTERDAM, Feb. 13 -- Slight bear covering developed today on the Bourse. American issues rose as much as $1.50. United States Steel closed at 65 1/8.

BEDFORD, Pa., Feb. 18 (UP) -- After deliberating only an hour and fifteen minutes today, a jury convicted Albert L. Russell, former A.F.L. union leader, on dynamiting charges growing out of labor trouble on the Pennsylvania Turnpike.

BUCHAREST, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Rumania began moving her civilians out of her German-dominated oil fields today as a precaution against possible British air attacks. The civilian exodus also was under way from Constanta, on the Black Sea, and Giurgiu, on the Danube just across from Bulgaria -- both major oil-loading ports -- and from other towns on the Danube facing Bulgaria.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 13 -- A warning to the people of Australia that "the war has moved into a new stage of the utmost gravity" was issued today by Acting Prime Minister A.W. Fadden and John Curtin, leader of the Opposition, after a meeting of the Advisory War Council.

Henry C. Eberhard, a motorman on the IRT division of the New York City Transit System, was found guilty yesterday by the Board of Transportation after a departmental trial on the charge of "carelessness" in connection with a collision of two trains on the Second Avenue elevated line two weeks ago.

A further increase in commercial loans, in the amount of $17,000,000, was shown by reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- A broad trade was on in wheat today with prices around 1/2 cent a bushel higher in the early trading on short covering induced by reports of dust storms in the Southwest. However, liquidation in small lots through commission houses developed and the market weakened gradually with the May selling off around 1 1/2 cents from the early high and at a new low price since last September.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Great Britain early today appeared to be approaching a break in diplomatic relations with Bulgaria as anxiety mounted that Adolf Hitler might be preparing to strike across Bulgaria against Greece.

The unbeaten Benjamin Franklin basketball team, defending city champion, stopped Seward Park, 28 -- 12, on the losers' court yesterday to insure at least a tie for the Lower Manhattan P.S.A.L. group title. Bob Wanzer and John Bailey, with six points each, starred for the winners, who led at the half, 13 -- 4.

The first real upset of the tournament occurred last night when John P. Laimbeer of the Garden City B.C. defeated the third seeded player, George Harris of the Central B.C., 15 -- 10, 15 -- 12, to reach the semi-final of the ninth annual metropolitan badminton championship on the courts of the Fifth Avenue Country Club.

The Associated Actors and Artistes of America, A.F. of L. parent of the performer unions, assumed operation yesterday of its newest branch, the American Guild of Variety Artists, after the resignation of Dewey Barto, guild president, and the ouster of Hoyt S. Haddock, Guild executive secretary.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Hog receipts were 4,000 head over advance estimates today and prices dropped 10 cents despite an advance in pork loin prices to the best level in three weeks. Supply included 3.000 head shipped direct and 16,000 salable hogs. Western receipts, however, totaled 66,800 compared with 71,800 a week ago.
BERLIN, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Two vital areas for which New York City has been developing impressive plans in the last few years will advance one step nearer their ultimate form if the Board of Estimate approves today Mayor La Guardia's proposal to remove the ugly train sheds at either end of the Brooklyn Bridge.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Following is the test of the majority report of the Foreign Relations Committee on the lease-lend bill:

Your recent editorial "The Unhappy Stoker" could have been inspired only by the personal experience of its author. But the sufferings he so graphically portrayed of the preoccupied commuter shoveling in the coal and shoveling out the ashes from his furnace while eyeing furtively his frail budget and dreaming of Florida, are really unnecessary.
I find it difficult to pass by a recent article in THE TIMES, "U.S. Security Seen in Birth Control," setting forth the views of Dr. Alan Valentine of the University of Rochester among others.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- A bill calling for reapportionment of the State's Congressional districts by June and aiming to give New York City two additional seats in Congress was introduced in the Senate today by Peter T. Farrell, Queens Democrat.

H. Robert Reeve of the Bayside Tennis Club, third in the seeded group, met with unexpectedly stiff opposition from E.L. Kilroe of the Columbia University Club yesterday as the invitation squash tennis tournament of the Whitehall Club got under way.

By a 6 to 1 vote, the Board of Education elected yesterday Dr. Frank J. O'Brien, director of the Bureau of Child Guidance, as an associate superintendent of the New York City school system for a six-year term at $12,500 a year.

The New York Athletic Club is a conservative organization. It does not guarantee records for its track meet. But yesterday Paul Pilgrim, its athletic manager, scanned the list of the best performances made at the games and let them hint at what might be expected in the Winged Foot carnival at Madison Square Garden tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A suggestion that the Administration, in return for the aid to Britain contemplated in the lease-lend bill, should seek assurances that Britain would present this country's views in the eventual peace conference and also agree to cooperate more closely in preserving "our stake in victory" was voiced in the Senate today by Senator Austin, assistant Republican leader and a supporter of the bill.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Mrs. Beatrice M. Stern, assistant secretary of the National Labor Relations Board since its creation in 1935, has been chosen to fill the new post of executive secretary.

MONTEREY, Calif., Feb. 13 -- Ten-year-old Laddie, his canine heart weakened by grief, died today at the Monterey Presidio-four days after the 2,000-mileflight which brought him to his master, a private at Fort Ord.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Steps for the protection of the American people from the consequences of intensive air raids and war emergency in general, as the result of Britain's experience, are being developed by the United States mission sent by the War Department and former Advisory Committee on National Defense to observe British methods.

In many cities bank clearings for the latest week were affected by the Lincoln holiday observance. Volume fell sharply below that for the preceding full week, although it showed a continued rises above the same week last year, despite a slight falling off at New York.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 13 -- Amid hustle, bustle, long-distance phone calls and what not, the vanguard of the Giants assembled today for the opening of the 1941 training campaign tomorrow. Even the weather, unruly these many weeks, suddenly caught the spirit of the occasion. A clear sky and blazing sun greeted the baseball tourists.

The Juilliard Institute Opera Players, composed of students of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music, made their first appearance as members of the Columbia Theatre Associates of Columbia University in a double bill composed of Arthur Benjamin's "The Devil Take Her" and Vittorio Giannini's "Blennerhassett" last night at Brander Matthews Hall, Columbia University.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 13 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor decided today to appoint a committee to investigate the dispute between the general executive board of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers and those members and officials of the Brooklyn Painters District Council who are opposing the assumption of Jacob (Jake the Bum) Wellner as business agent of the Brooklyn organization.

Headquarters detectives confiscated sales records from two stores of Brenner Brothers at 2 West Fourteenth Street and 128 West 125th Street last night, after the arrest of a man described as the manager of the Fourteenth Street store in an alleged attempt to bribe an accountant from the Controller's office who had been checking sales tax payments to the city.

VICHY, France, Feb. 13 -- In anticipation of a regulation that was issued today, forbidding the open sale of clothes, shirts, linen and clothing materials, the past few days had seen a run on tailors, department stores and dressmakers throughout the unoccupied zone of France.
No more tragic and shocking news has come from Vichy than a dispatch printed this morning that the Petain Government has surrendered to Adolf Hitler Rudolf Breitscheid and Rudolf Hilferding.

After three days of conflict between picketing sandhogs and the police at the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn-Battery tunner, leaders of the sandhogs gave assurance at a City Hall conference yesterday that there would be no more fighting on the picket line.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, by a vote of 15 to 8, reported favorably today a slightly amended version of the administration lease-lend bill which the House passed last week. Leaders planned to bring it to the floor on Monday.

Further gains by the Hong Kong and Shanghai currencies, together with a small improvement in the Canadian dollar, featured yesterday an otherwise dull foreign exchange market. The Hong Kong dollar rose 15 points on the day to 24.37 cents, the highest since last October, and the Shanghai rate at 5.65 cents was up 10 points.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- Robert J. Boltz, who, until his disappearance in October, was regarded in local financial quarters as a shrewd market operator, faces indictments which would make him liable, on conviction, to prison sentences totaling more than 1,900 years.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Montreal's rookie-studded Canadiens celebrated Goalie Wilf Cude's return to the ice tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 to 5, in a National League hockey game before 7,108 spectators.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 13 -- Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch and Dr. Alexander Cincar-Markovitch, the Foreign Minister, went to Germany today to meet Reichsfuehrer Hitler. The Yugoslavs left Belgrade by special train at noon.

The A.O. Gilbert Company of New Haven, Conn., manufacturers of toys, has leased the seven-story office building at 1 West Twenty-fifth Street and 202 Fifth Avenue, facing Madison Square, from the Stephenson Estate in a transaction involving $100,000.

MIAMI, Fla. Feb. 13 -- A rummage tea will be given tomorrow by the Miami Junior League at the Miami Beach home of Mrs. H. Strongman Miller of New York. Entrance fees will be packages of rummage for resale at the league's thrift shop to aid its welfare fund. Mrs. Charles McClellan is chairman and Mrs. Frank R. Rice is in charge of refreshments.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- The restoration of bus service in this mile-square community, which three months ago exercised its rights under a Court of Appeals decision to halt service on the New Rochelle-Yonkers line that passed through here, was recommended today by the advisory transportation committee of Bronxville.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 13 (UP) -- It was disclosed today that former King Alfonso XIII of Spain, under an agreement with General Francisco France, had renounced all claims to the throne in favor of his 27-year-old son, Prince Juan.

The herculean task of getting under way a program to train the industrial workers needed to build American defense has not been accomplished without criticism. And some of the critics have been pretty hot.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The House made quick work today of the annual supply bill for the Treasury and Postoffice Departments, passing the $1,146,000,000 measure with but little change. Funds were included for paying the operating expenses of these two departments for the fiscal year 1942, as well as for improvements in the Coast Guard.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The text of the Administration's lease-lend bill, H.R. 1776, as reported to the Senate today by the Foreign Relations Committee, was as follows:
In Paul Runyan's book, Sam Snead is the greatest golfer of all time.

A survey of steel markets by the American Iron and Steel Institute discloses that if the peak annual domestic demand for each of the seventeen principal classifications of steel products had occurred in the same year, the industry could have filled this demand by using only 80 per cent of its present steel-making capacity.

BOSTON, Feb. 13 -- Acute shortages and delayed deliveries in strategic and critical materials because of the needs of the defense program are noted in the monthly business survey report of the New England Purchasing Agents Association, issued today.

Nothing could be more tragic than the lot of many former leaders of the German Republic, now fugitives from the Hitlerized Reich. In no European country are they safe. The cases of Rudolf Breitscheid, once Social Democratic leader in the Reichstag, and Dr. Rudolf Hilferding, former German Finance Minister, are typical.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Wendell L. Willkie and Thomas E. Dewey are regarded by some Republican members of Congress who have talked with them and analyzed their recent speeches on pending questions as active candidates for the Republican nomination for President in 1944.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Combinations of labor unions among themselves and with employers are levying tribute from the lowest brackets of the income groups of the United States by raising the price of necessities, said Thurman W. Arnold, Assistant Attorney General, in testimony today before the Temporary National Economic Committee.
ROME, Feb. 13 -- Neither war nor peace has come out of the conference between Premier Mussolini and General Francisco France of Spain.

Price changes in yesterday's market were limited, most classes of traefer meats selling at around steady rates. Demand ranged from only fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were barely steady to easier, veal about steady. Lamb chucks were active at strong prices, but hindsaddles had a limited outlet.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 -- Charles Laughton's first picture under his new RKO contract will be a screen version of Ferenc Molnar's "The Play's the Thing," which was produced on Broadway in 1926 with Holbrook Blinn. RKO acquired the property from Paramount and has engaged Samuel and Belle Spewack to prepare the scenario.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 13 (AP) -- America's golf wizards warmed up for the start tomorrow of the $5,000 New Orleans open tournament with a pro-amateur competition today.

At the luncheon to be given by the Metropolitan Opera Guild Tuesday at the Plaza Hotel in honor of Bruno Walter, guest conductor at the Metropolitan this season, Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan, will introduce Mr. Walter and new artists of the opera company, and Kerstin Thorborg will present a program of vo cal numbers.

The net profit of the Lima Locomotive Works in 1940 was $87,007, against a net loss of $134,326 in 1939, Samuel G. Allen, president, reported yesterday. Sales billed in 1940 were $6,801,764, against $5,291,496 in 1939. Orders for fifty-one locomotives were booked in 1940, compared with fourteen in 1939.
PALM BEACH. Fla., Feb. 13 -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Seward Webb gave a dinner at their home in Gulf Stream tonight.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The veteran yacht Stormy Weather, queen of the Miami-to-Nassau racing fleet, extended her reign to five straight years today by winning the eighth annual 184-mile dash across the Gulf Stream.

MANILA, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Netherland merchant ship Tjitjalegka returned unexpectedly to Manila after sailing earlier in the day for Hong Kong. Passengers said the vessel turned around because of the presence of Japanese ships in the China Sea.

Mrs. Betty Compton Walker plans to institute divorce proceedings against former Mayor James J. Walker in Dade County, Fla., next week, at the expiration of the ninety-day residence period required in that State, it was learned here yesterday.

Curious persons who pause each hour in Herald Square to watch Stuff and Guff beat the stuffings out of the deep-toned bell are due for a disappointment now after 10 P.M. Minerva, the bellringers and the blinking owls are off the twenty-four-hour standard.

COLLEGE STATION, Texas, Feb. 13 (UP) -- The Army and the New York Yankees are bidding for the services of John Kimbrough, the all-America football player, and it looks as if Uncle Sam holds the trump card.

From nearly forty small property owners or their representatives, who attended a public hearing at City Hall last night, the Joint Legislative Committee on Assessment Review heard testimony that the city was overassessing, by margins of 20 to 60 per cent, residential properties in almost every section of Brooklyn and Queens.

The First National Bank of Boston has purchased $1,000,000 of temporary-loan notes of Lowell, Mass., at 0.423 per cent. The obligations, dated Feb. 13, will mature in installments on Nov. 21 and Nov. 28, 1941.

Even the rebel H.L. Mencken tells Knopf, his publisher, that the second volume of his reminiscences on which he is now working will be called "Newspaper Days," but that It will contain none of "the portentous whim-where of many of the recent volumes of journalistic experience."

Deliveries of copper to domestic consumers in January reached a new monthly high of 119,736 tons, the Copper Institute reported yesterday. The total compared with 112,671 tons in December, the previous high, and 91,428 in January, 1940.

Four organizations of professionals specializing in planning have combined in an effort collectively to assist the national defense program, it was announced yesterday by the American Institute of Architects.

The proposed refinancing program of the Georgia Power Company involving the redemption of some $125,000,000 of outstanding debt should prove to be one of the most comprehensive financing deals on a Southern utility property under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

John Barbirolli returned last night, after a vacation, to conduct the concert given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society in Carnegie Hall. He was welcomed warmly by an impressive audience. He played purely orchestral music by Rossini, Mozart and Respighi.

While the suggestion has been made in retail circles that it might be advisable for the fur trade to hold earlier openings of Fall lines this year, the deadlock in the labor situation may bring about showings of new lines later than usual, reports in the industry yesterday indicated.

VICHY, France, Feb. 13 (UP) -- The Maharana of Kapurthala, one of the wealthiest women in the world, was revealed today to be in a German concentration camp near Besancon, France, where British women rounded up in France have been interned.

BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- Yugoslav Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch and Foreign Minister Alexander Cincarmarkovitch are expected in neutral diplomatic quarters here to arrive in Germany tomorrow. As usual when important diplomatic conversations involving Germany are concerned, official confirmation of this information could not be obtained in Berlin.

Standing room only will be in force at Madison Square Garden tonight for the twelfth college basketball double-header of the season. Glamorous Notre Dame, a sure-fire attraction in New York, will meet N.Y.U., and that always is the signal for a box-office stampede.

The Martin Beck Theatre will say farewell on March 8 to "Cabin in the Sky," the Negro musical fantasy starring Ethel Waters and featuring Todd Duncan, Rex Ingram and the Katherine Dunham dancers. The show has been on view at the Beck since Oct. 25 and will have been performed 156 times when it departs.

Influenced by the uncertainties in the foreign situation, particularly in the Far East, prices of cotton followed yesterday the security markets downward. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices moved in a comparatively wide range on an increased volume of business and closed at net losses of 4 to 6 points.

The town meeting way of finding answers to national problems was praised yesterday by Mrs. Ogden Reid, vice president of The New York Herald Tribune; Mrs. William Henry Hays, president of the Women's National Republican Club; Stanley High, president of the Town Hall Club, and Samuel F. Pryor Jr., vice chairman of the Republican National Committee.

Directors of Chrysler Corporation voted yesterday a dividend of $1.50 a share on the common stock, payable on March 14 to stock of record on Feb. 24. This compared witch $1.25 a share ordered a year ago. Dividends paid in 1940, including a year-end distribution of $1.75 a share amounted to $5.50.

MADRID, Feb. 13 -- The press announced this afternoon that General Francisco Franco, the Spanish Chief of State, and Ramon Serrano Suner, his Foreign Minister, after receiving a farewell call from Premier Mussolini left Bordigheria, Italy, this morning on their way back to Spain.

A full-floor lease in the garment district which will give to the tenant 23,000 square feet was reported yesterday with Harry Drescher, manufacturer of men's clothing, who took a unit in the Lefcourt Clothing Center, in a transaction negotiated by Adams Co., Inc.

Improvements costing $80,000 are being made at the Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L.I., for next season's harness racing meetings, it was announced yesterday by Robert G. Johnson, Old Country Trotting Association president.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 14 -- Repetition by the United States consulate yesterday of advice to United States nationals that they leave the Far East for home served to heighten the nervousness felt in all quarters here over the prospect of war between Japan and the United States.

The government is buying eggs again, holding prices where they are and preventing a big drop. The egg-buying program began in a small way early this month and this week came to a climax with heavy government buying at wholesale markets in New York and Chicago.

MONTPELLIER, France, Feb. 13 -- Matters relating to the prosecution of the war rather than to peace overtures are believed to have formed the subject of a three-hour conference at the prefecture here this afternoon between Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and General Francisco Franco.

Like Bacon to Baconians Chief City Magistrate Curran is a lawyer with a fat substratum of poetry. Also, as becomes a native New Yorker, he cherishes the piety of his native place and loves its history. He wishes to keep in honor its names of old wont. Some of the Magistrates Courts have only a numerical name.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The program of the Republicans in the Legislature relative to the State budget of $385,000,000 has not been formally settled, but the trend of thought among the party's principal leaders has become apparent and if carried out will involve these steps:

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The thirteenth was not an unlucky day for Norman J. Brabson, who was saved from the electric chair in Sing Sing by a stroke of Governor Lehman's pen. Brabson was to have been executed tonight for the killing of Police Sergeant Timothy Murphy of Astoria, who was shot during a hold-up in a Greenwich Village speakeasy.

OTTAWA, Feb. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Active note circulation on Dec. 31, 1940, was $94,600,000 greater than at the same date in 1939, according to the annual report of Graham F. Towers, governor of the Bank of Canada, made public today.

The President's lease-lend bill has received increasing sentiment in its favor during the past ten days, a new nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion has shown, according to Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director.

BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- Traffic through the Suez Canal has been seriously hampered as a result of German air attacks, the German High Command reports today. Two vessels have been sunk in the middle of the canal, the Germans assert, while the canal itself and harbors and freight yards have been extensively damaged.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- There was no improvement in the turnover in today's stock markets, and, in the absence of new buying, most groups remained dull.

The government inquiry into the grounding of the United States liner Manhattan off the Florida beach on Jan. 12 was opened yesterday before an inquiry board of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) --The Federal debt climbed above $46,000,000,000 today while Congress considered raising the legal debt ceiling.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The general level of wholesale prices continued to drop last week, largely because of further weakness in the prices of agricultural commodities, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 80.5 for the week ended on Feb. 8, against 80.6 on Feb. 1, 80.8 on Jan. 25 and 78.5 on Feb. 10, 1940.

About 2,000 members of the National Maritime Union, meeting last night in the Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, voted to accept the recent wage adjustments effected by the union negotiating committee and the American Merchant Marine Institute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that the issue of transferring more American destroyers to Great Britain would not be settled for some time and denied that differences of opinion on the matter existed among himself, Secretary Knox and Wendell L. Willkie.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Jerome N. Frank, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was nominated today by President Roosevelt to be judge of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals in New York to succeed Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Destruction of Britain's fortress of Singapore was recommended today by Fukuichi Kawabata, Japanese Far Eastern expert, as the quickest means of ending the Sino-Japanese war. Writing in the newspaper Miyako, he contended that Singapore authorities were actively cooperating in the continued flow of seaborne supplies to aid China via the Burma Road and thus were prolonging the conflict.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Spring oozed from the earth of London today. But with the chirping of birds there mingled the grim speculations of statesmen and soldiers as the time for campaigning approached. In all their discussions, in which the Balkans, Spain and France played a prominent part, it was Japan and the United States that figured most prominently.

GEORGE JEAN NATHAN'S contribution to St. Valentine's Day, "The Bachelor Life,"* discusses marriage frequently, bachelorhood occasionally, and a diversity of other matters -- metropolitan, bucolic and theatrical -- that Mr. Nathan has been discoursing upon for years and years.

The Washington Gas Light Company announced yesterday that it had a net income in 1940 of $1,313,942, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.52 a share on the company's 425,000 shares of common stock outstanding, and compares with a net of $1,231,797, also equal to $2.52 a common share, earned in 1939.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 13 -- Conn McCreary rode three more winners at Hialeah Park today, while Don Meade and Wendell Eads were getting one each, thus making the race for riding honors tighter than ever. At the end of the program Meade still held a slender lead, with twenty-nine winners.

Throughout most of yesterday the interior of Grand Central Palace had much in common with Noah's Ark, for the animals came in "two by two," and also "one by one," and when the National Sportsmen's Show opens its doors at noon tomorrow all will be in readiness.

Santiago, capital of Chile, is observing its 400th birthday; it is twenty-five years older than the oldest permanent settlement in the present United States. There are a few South American cities older than Santiago by approximately half a dozen years, one way or the other -- Cartagena, Lima, Bogota.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Senator Wheeler of Montana, who will probably act as floor leader of the forces opposed to passage of the lease-lend bill, charged today that radio commentators in discussing the measure had been "quite one-sided on the great issue."

Twenty National Hockey League games in a row without suffering defeat is the record the Bruins now flaunt. The Boston skaters established this world standard of hockey consistency by trouncing the world champion Rangers, 5 to 3, at Madison Square Garden last night in a game which each sextet wanted bitterly to win.

Max Weber's last previous one-man show in New York was held in 1937 at J.B. Neumann's New Art Circle. It was retrospective, and composed entirely of still-lifes. The exhibition of his work now in progress at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, is diversified on the subject side, containing figure themes, landscapes and still-lifes.

Officers were re-elected, a hunts committee appointed and dates for the Spring and Fall approved yesterday at a meeting of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association in its offices, 250 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Great Britain with her dominions and possessions accounted for most of the licenses issued in December for the export from the United States of arms, ammunition and implements of war, according to the monthly report of the State Department.

City Councilman Joseph Clark Baldwin was named yesterday by the Assembly District leaders in the Seventh Congressional District to run for Representative at the special election to be held on March 11 to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The world three-cushion billiards championship became a strictly private affair tonight between defending champion Willie Hoppe and Jake Schaefer, iron-nerved Cleveland star and king of the balkline cue game.

The principle that workers and employers alike have much to gain from cooperative effort to stabilize their industry, provide for efficient management, encourage the modernization of production units and insure adequate annual earnings and fair conditions for labor has been written into the new collective agreement for the New York dress industry, Julius Hochman, general manager of the Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.F. of L., disclosed yesterday.

Experiments indicating that the mysterious "anti-gray-hair" vitamin, preventing premature graying and restoring the natural color in the fur of black and piebald rats, is identical with a well known common chemical substance used in the making of novocaine and other anesthetics, are reported in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Another young man who had refused to register with the millions of other youthful Americans under the Selective Service Act came up for sentence yesterday in Federal court. He was William Allen Winslow, 24-year-old social service worker, who formerly lived in Albany.

CARTERET, N.J., Feb. 13 -- The plant here of the Foster-Wheeler Corporation, which reportedly has contracts from the United States Navy for boilers and condensers totaling more than $15,000,000, was shut down today, the first day of a strike called by the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C.I.O. union.

Three defense motions for a mistrial were denied yesterday by Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato at the trial of Hymie Caplin, prizefight manager, on grand larceny charges arising from the operations of a $2,000,000 card swindling ring.

A marked upturn in new mortgage financing in Manhattan during January has left brokers wondering if this activity was just "a flash in the pan" which will not be maintained in the months just ahead, or whether it marked the beginning of a new period of larger loan volume.

Because New York City still has many "horse and buggy streets" in a modern era of automobiles, Police Commissioner Valentine said last night that in the future all mercantile houses, hotels, office buildings and other large structures will have to include built-in garages to provide off-street parking to ease the traffic problem.

Transfers of three New York Stock Exchange seats were approved yesterday. They were from the late James W. Bowen to Harry MacDonald of MacDonald Co., from Joseph J. Magrane to Ellis A. Gimbel Jr. of Gimbel, Levy Co. and from Harold M. Iseman to Morton Wohlgemuth of Ernst Co. Appointment of Stanley J. Halle as a floor alternate for George M. Sidenberg Jr. of Halle Stieglitz also was approved.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Charles S. Howard emerged from a delightful state of doubt today and mapped the immediate future racing plans of Porter's Cap.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 14 -- All was quiet on the British air front early today. It was comparatively quiet also yesterday when sporadic raiders appeared in small numbers over the southeast coast, East Anglia, Northeast England, Southeast and East Scotland during daylight, and East Anglia and Northeast Scotland after nightfall.

OTTAWA, Feb. 13 -- From now until next July the British Commonwealth Air Training Plan, the British Empire's largest agency for producing air crews to man its fighting planes, "will be on thin ice, very thin ice." C.G. Power, Canadian Minister for Air and Associate Minister of National Defense, informed this correspondent today.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 13 -- Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, N.J., and Jack Ryerson of Cooperstown, N.Y., were eliminated today in the quarter-final round of the fourteenth annual national amateur championship of golf club champions on the St. Augustine Links.

Accepting the advice of Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder to set a "good example" to other unions and waive technicalities, the College Teachers Union yesterday agreed to withdraw its pending motion and cooperate with the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the local schools, to the extent of producing its officers for subpoena today.

Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. yesterday announced that eight matches for Madison Square Garden had been definitely signed, one of them a championship battle. In addition, Jacobs discussed contests arranged for or contemplated in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Washington, D.C., Chicago, Detroit and Buffalo.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- An investigation of a prominent corporation manufacturing precision instruments for the Army and Navy, especially an airplane bombsight, has been started by the Department of Justice, it was learned today. Subpoenas have been issued for books, papers and other data which it is understood will be presented to a Federal Grand Jury in New York City.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- To Herschel V. Johnson, counselor of the American Embassy in London, was given today the honorary rank of Minister during his incumbency in that office.

Mayor La Guardia is scheduled to open the National Sportsmen's Show at Grand Central Palace officially at noon today. Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne is expected to arrive from a quail-shooting trip in the Carolinas for the ceremony.

The presence of a great conductor made history last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. May it also prognosticate future history, written by an institution which has been singularly oblivious of the necessity of an artistic personality of commanding stature in the conductor's chair.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura presented his letters of credence as the Ambassador of Japan to President Roosevelt today in a cordial personal atmosphere with Secretary of State Cordell Hull making the formal presentation. All three then joined in a conversation on international affairs that lasted for twenty minutes.
LONDON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Air and Home Security Ministries issued this communique today:

In an address at the annual luncheon of the Jewish Teachers Association on Feb. 12 Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, attacked the bill providing an hour a week during school sessions for children of all faiths to attend religious education classes. Mr. Morris branded the law as the "saddest thing" that has happened to this city, because it is "un-American in principle'' and tended to divide children into separate religious groups.

ROME, Feb. 14 -- British soldiers set foot on the Italian peninsula Monday night for the first time since the war started in a dangerous parachute attempt to sabotage communications and water works in Calabria, according to today's war communique.

Many thousands of our Negro fellow-citizens must feel pride and satisfaction in the observance of Negro History Week, which comes to a close tomorrow. Those of other racial stocks may feel pride and satisfaction too. The news of the 1940 choices for the Honor Roll of Race Relations, announced by Dr. Lawrence D. Reddick of the Schomberg Collection of Negro Literature in the New York Public Library, was broadcast not only here but in England.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 14 -- Harry L. Hopkins, returning from his special mission in Great Britain, got a step nearer the White House and President Roosevelt tonight, thanks to a Navy PBY plane that flew him from Trinidad after the Pan American Yankee Clipper was ordered held for twenty-four hours owing to unfavorable weather ahead along the Atlantic coast of the United States.

ROME, Feb. 14 (AP) -- German planes bombed British air bases in Libya "intensely" again yesterday and joined Fascist bombers in attacking air and naval bases at Malta, the Italian High Command reported today.

"Boudoir," the Jacques Deval play, is tonight's only Broadway closing; it leaves the Golden Theatre after playing eleven performances there. Closing on the road is "The Philadelphia Story," its tour terminating in an obvious place -- Philadelphia -- at the end of one of the most successful Broadway-road-screen careers in years.

MIAMI, Feb. 14 -- A record field of twenty-five for the $10,000 added McLennan Memorial Handicap to be run tomorrow at Hialeah Park has presented a problem to the management of the Miami Jockey Club which may result in the nine-furlong event being contested in two divisions.

HAVANA, Feb. 14 -- Delay in the approval of an agreement between Cuba and the United States for the financing of the 400,000-ton surplus sugar production by the Export-Import Bank of Washington was seen tonight as opposition in Congress appeared to be increasing.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Loyola University's basketball team, which always has to work for anything it gets on the Coliseum floor, followed the same pattern tonight in its game against Nat Holman's City College of New York quintet.

LANSING, Mich., Feb. 14 -- Governor Van Wagoner today sharply criticized the United Automobile Workers of America (A.F.L.) as having fostered a strike in the Motor Wheel Corporation plant here, which has made 2,500 men idle. The corporation is engaged on a large defense order to manufacture shell casings for the government.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Light supply in the week-end clean-up stimulated a 10-cent increase in hog prices today. Top was $8.20, with the bulk of choice 180 to 240 pound hogs bringing $7.90 to $8.15. Classes up to 320 pounds showed most of the increase and sold generally at $8 up. Cattle prices were held steady due to meager supply.

Cotton futures declined sharply yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The break was the widest in almost a month. Opening 1 to 3 points lower, the list was under pressure all day and closed with net losses of 8 to 11 points.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Willie Hoppe of New York retained the world three-cushion billiard championship tonight with a 50-to-34 victory over Jake Schaefer of Cleveland.
I wish to congratulate THE TIMES on the complete coverage of the testimony of Mr. Willkie before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Five New York agriculturists, including the first bachelor to receive the honor in thirteen years, hold new Master Farmer awards conferred by Governor Lehman.

TOKYO, Feb. 14 -- Reflecting the doubts and uncertainties shared by all of Japan, the newspapers today are divided between fears that the United States is prepared to force a showdown if Japan's southward drive goes too far and hopes that President Roosevelt's attitude, expressed on Tuesday, may have been largely bluff.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Britons who have become accustomed to use less of this and that in order to win the war will have to do with less cotton beginning April 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Investigation of the whole system of letting defense contracts was planned by the House Military Committee today after disclosure that a member of a New York firm holding an $11,000,000 construction contract draws a $6,500 salary as a member of the Army's Construction Advisory Committee.
BERLIN, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:
BERLIN, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The German High Command reported today that Nazi planes had "effectively" attacked British airports on the island of Malta and bombed British positions in North Africa.

In today's wars the employment, housing, provisioning, transportation and state of mind of the civilian population have equal importance with those of the armed forces. They may even present a more difficult problem, because civilians are not under Army discipline.

The billion-dollar Canadian air-training enterprise, counted upon to play so large a part in British war plans when they come to maturity, will be proceeding "on very thin ice" until July next, Air Minister Power tells our correspondent in Ottawa; there may be a shortage both of airplanes and instructors.

Senator Wheeler would do better if he learned to distinguish between a propagandist and a policeman. The Senator is much disturbed by "pro-war" propaganda among radio commentators and newspaper writers and on the screen.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- County executive William F. Bleakley of Westchester wrote today to David C. Adie, State Commissioner of Social Welfare, asking for an investigation by Mr. Adie of the Westchester County Department of Public Welfare, which is under criticism from the Board of Supervisors' committee on welfare here for allegedly failing to detect relief "chiselers" and evict relief "floaters."

"Compliments of Mr. Flow," a French film starring Louis Jouvet and Fernand Gravet, will have its American premiere at the Filmarte today. The comedy-romance was directed by Robert Siodmak and also features Edwige Feuillere and Vladimir Sokoloff.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Ralph A. Bard of Chicago, investment banker and industrialist, was nominated for the post of Assistant Secretary of the Navy today by President Roosevelt. He is a Republican, and an old friend of Secretary Knox.
MIAMI, Feb. 14 -- Larry MacPhail's big holdout headache this year is not his fancy first-baseman, Dolph Camilli (although Dolph still is unsigned), but Arnold (Mickey) Owen.

The National Self-Government Committee has petitioned the New York City Board of Education to provide in each of our high schools "a teacher responsible for the direction of student activities." By "activities" the committee means government. Its recent survey of 1,431 high schools and junior colleges having some form of student participation in government showed that 86 per cent of them were subject to the veto power of the principal.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 14 -- Due weight is given here to yesterday's warning by the War Council of danger in the Pacific, but there are reassuring factors in the local situation.

A strike against The Day, Jewish-language daily, was started yesterday morning by the New York Newspaper Guild, C.I.O. affiliate. Guild spokesmen claimed that forty-one employes had walked out in support of the Guild's protest against discharges or pay cuts involving thirteen of its members.

The liner Manhattan was making twenty-one knots when she went aground on a Florida shoal on Jan. 12, according to testimony given yesterday before the United States Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation, which is making a preliminary investigation of the accident to determine whether the officers of the vessel should be placed on trial.

MADRID, Feb. 14 -- A new plan for distributing the $400,000 worth of flour, milk and drugs that the United States has donated to Spain was worked on today at a conference between the American Red Cross commission and officials of the Spanish Red Cross and the Auxilio Social, the Falangist relief agency.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Wheat showed today considerable resistance to selling pressure and, while prices dipped at one time to within a small fraction of a cent a bushel of the lowest level of the season on the new crop months in sympathy with securities and soy beans, there was good support on the way down.

Subpoenas calling for the membership rolls and financial records of the College Teachers Union were served yesterday upon Dr. Robert K. Speer, president; Dr. Robert C. Challman, treasurer, and Dr. Bella V. Dodd, legislative representative, by the Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the local schools.

The campaign of the Young Men's Christian Association of New York City has received $219,200 from 8,511 contributors, according to an announcement made yesterday by Richard W. Lawrence, president, at a final campaign luncheon for 250 campaign workers at the Hotel Commodore.

A strong desire on the part of the Northeastern States to legislate on vehicle and highway control for themselves rather than incur further Federal regulations was voiced yesterday at the opening here of the sixth regional conference on highway safety and motor vehicle problems called by the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation and the Council of State Governments.

While Far Eastern tension brought some nervousness to traders in minor commodities originating in the East Indies here yesterday, there was a distinct lack of panic or rushing to cover. The pepper futures market was active and prices edged up to new highs for the current season, but spot offerings were available at prices even with those quoted earlier this week, and near-by months on the open market were stronger on somewhat limited offerings.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 14 -- Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch and Dr. Alexander Cincar-Markovitch, the Yugoslav Foreign Minister, signed no agreement with Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Foreign Minister, in Germany today, but will arrive in Belgrade late tomorrow to report to the Regent, Prince Paul, it was declared by high political and diplomatic quarters here tonight.

BERLIN, Feb. 14 -- Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch of Yugoslavia and Dr. Alexander Cincar-Markovitch, his Foreign Minister, conferred today with Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop at Berchtesgaden, it was announced tonight in an official statement.
