SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 14 -- Frank Leahy, 33-year-old Boston College coach, is going home to Notre Dame.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 -One of the largest events of midseason was the Blue and White Ball for the Friends of Greece at the Patio, transformed into a bower by flowers sent by Greek florists from this city, New York and Chicago.
ROME, Feb. 14 -- Foreign newspaper men in Italy, all of whom are concentrated in Rome, were notified today that they might not leave the capital without permission.

The main ballroom of the Plaza, decorated in the Victorian tradition of St. Valentine's Day with red and white hearts and a profusion of flowers, was the setting last night for the annual supper dance of the Nightingale-Bamford School Alumnae Association.

Favored by much better weather conditions than a year ago, retail trade here again made a good comparative showing this week. Department store volume was estimated as running 12 per cent better than in the like week of last year.
Total admitted assets of the Home Life Insurance Company rose to $112,982,358 on Dec. 31 from $106,922,369 at the close of 1939, the concern reported yesterday.

Sentiment in investment banking circles reached a low ebb yesterday, with little support in evidence for any type of securities, a break of about 3 points in one of the stocks recently offered over the counter upon the dissolution of the underwriting syndicate, and obvious increased tension over the international picture.

OTTAWA, Feb. 14 -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King, on the eve of the opening of Parliament, has moved to confine business in the House of Commons to essential war effort. The government, according to the motion he has presented, will have precedence at every sitting and other members will be deprived of their privilege of priority in certain matters.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente, in a decision handed down yesterday, condemned the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for what he termed an erroneous interpretation of the Martin act, the State law relating to the sale of securities.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 15 -- Anti-aircraft guns rumbled angrily in London last night and in other parts of Great Britain early this morning, signaling the warming up of aerial warfare with Germany ever this country after a short period of comparative inactivity.

A group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $3,700,000 of home relief bonds of Erie County, N.Y., on a bid of 100.336 for 2s. The bonds, dated March 1 and maturing serially on March 1, 1942 to 1951, were reoffered at prices to yield 0.40 to 2 per cent, according to maturity.

The preliminary report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for 1940, made public yesterday by Roy B. White, president, showed a net income of $3,621,581, after all expenses and charges. The net was equal to $3.46 each on 1,045,592 shares of capital stock outstanding and compared with a net of $1,380,114, or $1.32 a share, in 1939. Gross revenues were $99,704,353, against $95,660,403.

Fred Weber, general manager of the Mutual Broadcasting Company, replied yesterday to Senator Barton K. Wheeler's charge that radio commentators had shown bias on public issues. The reply was in answer to a letter from the Senator received by the Mutual company yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The War Department has started surveys with a view to possible expansion of the Army to more than three million men.

NOW for the Winged Foot fun! With Leslie MacMitchell coming forward so fast, the Baxter Mile in the New York A.C. meet at Madison Square Garden tonight should be a thriller. Should be, but not if the competitors are bashful about taking the lead at the start. That first-lap chattering caucus in the Wanamaker Mile took the edge off the event.

The progress that is being made in the training of defense workers for industry varies in different parts of the country. In some industrial centers the training program is just getting under way; in others it already has accomplished much.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -- Bids were opened at the Army Quartermaster Depot here today on 9,043,710 yards of uniform and overcoat-lining cloth, including the following items: (1) 2,900,956 yards of 35-inch cotton drill; (2) 2,093,640 yards of 36-inch olive drab silesia; iS) 1,369,809 yards of olive drab cotton twill, and (4) 2,679,305 yards of olive drab overcoat lining.

VICHY, France, Feb. 14 -- A communique issued tonight speaks cryptically of "certain trouble makers" in France's unoccupied zone who have recently distributed tracts calculated to provoke regrettable incidents against the "foreign control commissions."

A series of nightly conferences at which retailers of Bronx, Manhattan, Richmond and Queens will receive first-hand instruction on the manner in which the Food Stamp Plan will operate here after March 1, was opened here last night in fourteen educational centers by the Surplus Marketing Administration here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Fewer than 400 of the 2,800 bombers and pursuit planes produced in the United States in 1940 were delivered to the Army Air Corps. Most of them went to Great Britain and France.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 14 -Bobby Walker of Jacksonville, Fla., the defending titleholder, was eliminated today by Dick Van Kleeck of Ponte Vedra, Fla., 2 and 1, in a semi-final match of the fourteenth annual national amateur championship of golf club champions, held on the St. Augustine Links.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 15 -- Assurances which the public can interpret as a pledge that Japan will never have to fight the United States and Russia simultaneously were given the Diet last night by Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 -- Errol Flynn's next vehicle at Warners will be "Dive Bomber" by Commander Frank Wead, which Michael Curtiz will direct, the studio announced today.

ATHENS, Feb. 14 -- Greek forces today engaged in a large-scale offensive along the entire front, it was reported here tonight. The Italian lines were said to have been broken at many vital points, while an artillery bombardment that lasted forty-eight hours preceded the drive.

Urging immediate reapportionment of the Assembly, Senate and Congressional districts in New York State, the Chamber of Commerce, Borough of Queens, said yesterday the new census figures disclosed "flagrant violations of the first principle of democracy -- namely, that every voter shall have an equal voice in the management of his government."

The executive committee of the New York County Committee of the American Labor party announced yesterday that it had designated Eugene P. Connolly, county chairman, for nomination for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District and that Mr. Connolly's formal nomination would take place at a meeting of the county commiteee members of the district Monday evening in Galicia Hall, Columbus Avenue and West Sixty-sixth Street.

This year's Bread Loaf Writers Conference, under the sponsorship of Middlebury College in Vermont, will be held in the latter part of August, it was announced yesterday by Theodore Morrison, its director. The sessions make it possible for inexperienced writers to get the advice of older professionals, of editors, agents, critics and skilled teachers.
CAIRO, Egypt Feb. 14 (AP) -- Royal Air Force headquarters issued this communique today:

DETROIT, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Detroit honored Jack Adams tonight for fourteen years as hockey manager, and the finest gift came from his own Red Wings, who defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 to 1, in a National League game before 8,082 spectators.

Last Saturday I read a letter in THE TIMES suggesting a mechanical pace-maker for milers. This would not only be impractical but also foolish, for surely no human being would give chase to such a thing.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- While the Bulgarian Legation here was busy today denying reports of a large-scale German infiltration into its country, the British were still guessing whether Adolf Hitler was planning a Balkan offensive or just using that part of Europe in the war of nerves to screen his real objective.
Detailed plans for the improvement of traffic facilities at the Brooklyn end of the Brooklyn Bridge were submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn.

The Senate has now joined the House in approving a bill which increases the national debt limit from $49,000,000,000 to $65,000,000,000. There is not much else for it to do. It can be argued, and has been, that a lower limit would suffice for next year; but to raise the limit in installments would not change the fundamental situation.

A two-day conference on legislation for democracy, sponsored by the New York Conference for Inalienable Rights, opened last night in Mecca Temple with each of a list of speakers denouncing a published report that the group was a link in an interlocking chain of organizations composing the Communist front.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 -- Craig Wood of Mamaroneck, N.Y., led the field in the first round of the $5,000 New Orleans open golf tournament today, but the spectacular play was provided by Ellsworth Vines, who a few years ago was the world's top tennis player.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- President Roosevelt welcomed today seven Chilean newspaper men who came to work on American newspapers for several weeks, anti called the idea perfectly splendid, since it provided a vehicle for an exchange of information between this country and South America.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The House Naval Affairs Committee decided today to call Admiral Harold R. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations, for secret testimony tomorrow on the reasons for the Navy's desire to establish a new air base in Samoa.

An attempt by the New York City Tunnel Authority yesterday to publicize the passage of the 1,000,000th automobile through the Queens-Midtown Tunnel resulted in some confusion concerning times and names and created a definite impression of a prearranged publicity stunt that went astray.
We just received a bulletin from the Fish and Wildlife Service in Washington reporting elation at the increase of the whooping cranes on the Arkansas refuge in Texas.

New York City has furnished 13,395 selective service men to the Army since the Selective Training and Service Act of 1940 became operative Nov. 25, last, it was announced yesterday from the office of Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City director of selective service, as the fourth induction period ended with a total of 583 men taken into the Army yesterday at the city's two induction centers.
The Southern Pacific Steamship Lines, known as the Morgan Line, announced yesterday that it would no longer operate its 55-year-old passenger and freight service between New York and New Orleans.

If the celebrated author of the best-seller of our generation ever has time in prison to write another book, it should be an expert treatise on the art of making enemies. As the forecast of a campaign, "Mein Kampf" lost value when Hitler veered from the track he had mapped out and found himself leading Germany where he had declared it should never go again -- into war with Britain.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Immediately following the announcement of President Roosevelt's acceptance of the resignation of Lewis Compton as Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Governor Edison offered Mr. Compton appointment as Finance Commissioner of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Senate approved today, with slight changes, the House bill to raise the national debt limit to $65,000,000,000, a ceiling which, according to Administration spokesmen, will suffice until June 30, 1942, at least.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Major crimes in the State decreased 14 per cent in 1940 as compared with the 1939 records, John A. Lyons, Commission of Correction, said today in his annual report to the Legislature. According to the report, there were 35,880 major crimes in the State last year and 38,766 the previous year.

BERLIN, N.H., Feb. 14 -- Many of the nation's foremost skiers arrived today in this pioneer New England snow center for the competition sanctioned by the Federation Internationale de Ski, which will open tomorrow with a cross-country race and close with the ever-colorful jump on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Senate voted today, on motion of Senator George, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, to make the Administration lease-lend bill its pending business, just before it recessed until Monday. This insures that no other legislation can come formally before the Senate until a vote has been taken on the lease-lend bill, except by unanimous consent or by the adoption of a motion to displace it.

Swagar Sherley, who died in Washington Thursday, was a great lawyer who had earlier shown rare capacity and achievement as a public servant. Sent to the House of Representatives by the Louisville district in 1903 when he was but 30, his first study was to master the rules of the House and the roll of parliamentary precedents.

America's defense effort requires a middle course which will unite labor, agriculture, business and government in a full recognition of domestic and foreign problems, according to Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly business review which will be released to members today.

The American Iron and Steel Institute published this week its yearly and monthly estimates of steel output for January. It gives opportunity for interesting comparisons with preceding years, back to 1917, and thus shows the extent to which this country's capacity for steel production has moved forward during that period.

Beginning today, all the land will make music next week for Ignace Paderewski. Hundreds of orchestras and thousands of music clubs will unite in a symphonic paean of praise in honor of the golden jubilee of the debut in the United States of a great musician and a great man, now an honored guest in this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- An increase in total registrations under the Securities Act to $2,124,429,000 in 1940 from $1,815,046,000 in 1939, or about 16 per cent, was reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. This was the first time since 1936 that registrations had gained over the preceding year.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 14 -- The 190 employes and executives in the office of William E. Sewell, Hudson County Superintendent of Elections, did not receive today their semi-monthly salary checks totaling $19,000 as a result of their legal controversy with the Democratically controlled Board of Freeholders.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Guy Serean, a virtually unknown youngster from Nampa, Idaho, scored a major upset tonight by beating Petey Scalzo, the National Boxing Association's featherweight champion, on a technical knockout in the eighth round of a non-title fight.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 14 -- It is reported here by foreign military attaches that the Soviet fleet has been carrying out manoeuvres in the Black Sea, but the extent, location or duration of such manoeuvres seems to be a carefully preserved secret.

Flotations of new bonds here this week were in the smallest volume in many months, amounting to only $8,265,000, compared with $62,138,000 in the preceding period. During this week last year new bond offerings amounted to $126,532,930.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Clarence Willett, president of the Independent Workers Union at the West Pullman Works of the International Harvester Company, declared tonight that his organization would join the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Reflecting heavy military and civilian demand for textiles, consumption of raw cotton by United States mills was reported today by the Census Bureau to have reached a total of 843,274 bales in January, establishing a new record for a month. The previous record was 776,942 bales, established in March, 1937.

Cooperation of retailers in extension of the cotton stamp plan to farmers for voluntary reduction of cotton-growing acreage below the 1941 national acreage allotment was promised yesterday at meetings held at the offices of the Institute of Distribution and the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

My indignation is running so high that it will spill over unless I release it immediately. This all has been caused by John Kieran's recent column in which Bill McKechnie of Cincinnati discussed his team's chances of winning another pennant.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Donald M. Nelson, chief of the purchasing division of the Office of Production Management, was designated today to clear all Army and Navy defense contracts. The arrangement had the approval of the OPM and the Army and Navy and provided for their cooperation.
ROME, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Italian High command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The last of the shipyard contracts to provide for the construction of 200 emergency ocean cargo ships was signed today by the Maritime Commission and the building of the 200 "ugly ducklings," as they are called in shipping circles, will begin in a few weeks.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 14 -- Further obstacles and restrictions are likely to be imposed on Occidental trade here, it was considered more than probable today, because the foreign banks of Shanghai refuse to deal with or accept the currency of the newly established Bank of China, which is under control of Wang Ching-wei's Nanking regime.

Nature and religion were the principal themes of the ten winning poems of the Camp Fire Girls' sixth annual poetry contest, as announced yesterday by Ted Malone on his "Between the Bookends" program over the National Broadcasting Company's Blue Network.

Van Camp's, said to be the oldest national advertiser of canned pork and beans, will celebrate its eightieth anniversary this year with an enlarged advertising campaign offering the public a patriotic pin through grocery store purchases of the company's products.

The nineteenth annual Front Page Ball of the New York Newspaper Women's Club was held last night on the Starlight Roof of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, was the special guest of honor.

Two hundred courses for New York City teachers -- a record number -- will be provided this term under the auspices of the Board of Superintendents, Dr. Jacob Greenberg, associate superintendent, announced yesterday. These courses are offered without charge, to help teachers improve themselves professionally.

Leslie MacMitchell has scored three straight mile victories this year, two over that new and thriving organization, Master Milers, Inc. Tonight the twenty-year-old prodigy from N.Y.U. will seek his first Madison Square Garden victory of the year when he toes the line in the Baxter Mile that will feature the New York Athletic Club games.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- New stock corporations chartered in New York State in January numbered 1,630, a decrease of 188 from January, 1940, but an increase of 314 over December. Of the January formations, 694 had an aggregate capitalization of $16,581,587, exceeding the January, 1940, total by $286,527. Stock of no-par value was issued by 935 companies.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 14 -The capture of Afmadu and Bullo Erillo, both in Italian Somaliland, by British East African troops was announced today. Afmadu was taken Tuesday and Bullo Erillo on Thursday, a communique said. [Italy already had acknowledged the loss of Afmadu.] The communique indicated the British columns had advanced about 130 miles into Italian territory.

Sermons will be preached tomorrow in tribute to George Washington, whose birthday is next Saturday, and to Abraham Lincoln, whose birthday was last Wednesday. There also will be discussions of the lease-lend bill. A number of Episcopal churches will hold special "Aid-to-Britain" services.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Governor Lehman opposed in an address today before a Farm and Home Week audience at Cornell University, reduction of school, health and social programs as an economy measure in a time of emergency.

As one of those "educated young men" who have "consolidated themselves into a force of resistance and negation,'' in the words of your correspondent Professor Ralph Barton Perry, permit me to reply briefly. With a great deal that he says I feel a hearty sympathy, but I fear there is a fundamental point of disagreement on which unity will be difficult.

Councilman Robert K. Straus, Manhattan Fusionist, precipitated a lively session of the Council Committee on Rules at City Hall yesterday when he sought approval for his resolution changing the make-up of the Council committee investigating the Civil Service Commission.

Andrew Mills Jr., president of the Dry Dock Savings Institution since Jan. 1, 1929, will observe today as the twenty-fifth anniversary of his affiliation with the bank. Mr. Mills became a trustee of the bank in 1916, vice president in 1920, and in 1932, three years after assuming the presidency, the bank merged with the United States Savings Bank.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Congress will be asked in the near future to appropriate about $250,000,000 to finance a nation-wide health and welfare program in areas adjacent to large military and naval training centers and defense industries.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 14 (Canadian Press) -- Despite sharp drops during the German advances in Western Europe last Spring, the New York quotation on the Canadian dollar at the end of 1940 was only 2 1/2 cents below the Dec. 31, 1939, level and the British pound was quoted 9 cents higher than at the end of 1939, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14 -- Harvard's varsity basketball team kept just ahead of a rangy Cornell five to win its first victory in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, 30 -- 28, in the Harvard gym tonight.

The Isthmian Steamship Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, announced yesterday that a contract had been signed with the United States Maritime Commission for the purchase of eight C-3 type cargo vessels for its round-the-world service.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Legislation to block the Commodity Credit Corporation's plan to reconcentrate government-owned cotton on the basis of competitive warehouses bids was approved today by the Senate. It now goes to the House, where cotton-State members promised speedy action.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Negotiations are under way between certain Spanish Republican refugee elements and monarchist groups for the formation of an alliance to overthrow General Francisco Franco and prepare the way for a conservative republic or a restoration of the Bourbon monarchy.

The annual Junior Promenade of Barnard College was held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria with 110 students and their escorts present. Dancing took place in the Jade and Basildon Rooms, and supper was served in the Astor Gallery.

John Steel, 48 years old, of 1341 Stebbins Avenue, the Bronx, and William Flannagan, 38, of 1633 Parker Street, the Bronx, ripened a chance meeting into real friendship recently as they lolled away their time in the Harlem jail. Although neither had anything in common with the other except that both admitted numerous arrests for various minor offenses, they did hit on a common plan.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The British diplomatic mission left by special train from blacked-out Bucharest shortly before midnight en route to the port of Constanta.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 14 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, told for the first time today the story of a secret meeting with Harry H. Bennett, personnel representative of the Ford Motor Company, and of his efforts to persuade the motor car official to look kindly on the efforts of labor to organize Ford employes into A.F. of L. unions.
Mayor La Guardia reappointed yesterday four trustees of the Brooklyn Public Library for new five-year terms without salary.

When Mrs. Beatrice Liss, 33 years old, was sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions to an indeterminate penitentiary term up to three years as a shoplifter, a probation officer's report revealed she was the criminal associate of Emanuel (Mindy) Weiss, the henchman of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The fact that Senator Walsh attended the meeting of the opponents of the lease-lend bill today came as more than a mild surprise to those who have kept tab on the development of the controversy. The word that he would throw his prestige as chairman of the Naval Committee behind the amendment in question was almost a sensation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Roosevelt invoked Section 10 of the Railway Labor Act today to delay for at least sixty days the threatened strike of employes of the Rutland Railroad Company which he said "now threatens substantially to interrupt interstate commerce within the States of Vermont and New York.

After inspecting five plants in Brooklyn and Long Island City where national defense products are being manufactured, William Knudsen, director-general of the Office of Production Management, yesterday expressed satisfaction with the progress that is being made on these orders.

VICHY, France, Feb. 14 -- Regarding the surrender to the German authorities of Rudolf Breitscheid, one-time leader of the Social Democrats in the German Reichstag, and Rudolf Hilferding, former German Finance Minister-it is-pointed out here that the armistice terms are imperative. It is not within the province of the Vichy government to inquire what will happen to those handed over.

A heap of brilliant playing was lavished on a program of less than earth-shaking import last night as Carnegie Hall when the Boston Symphony Orchestra and Serge Koussevitzky, its conductor, paid their third evening visit of the season.

Last Monday St. John's played Providence at the Redmen's gymnasium. The game was none too important, so no basketball writers were there to watch it. That was too bad, because something happened which may go completely unnoticed for good, unless this note has some effect.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Production of military planes in the United States rose to a total of 1,002 in January, doubling the output of a year ago.

CARTERET, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Neil Brant, international representative of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, was arrested here this afternoon on a charge of publicly mutilating and defiling the American flag at a meeting last Wednesday during which union and non-union employes of the Foster-Wheeler Corporation's Carteret plant voted to strike.

Notre Dame took the lead for the seventh and last time with ten minutes left to play at Madison Square Garden last night and before a roaring crowd of 17,831, the seventh capacity crowd of the season, toppled N.Y.U., 41 to 38, for its fourteenth victory of the basketball campaign and its tenth straight.
The net income of the New York Central Railroad in 1940 was the best in years, F.E. Williamson, president, said yesterday.

Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, said yesterday that his institution was "too intellectual and too academic" and required greater development on the side of physical education of its students.

Members of the Washington Square Methodist Church, 133 West Fourth Street, stepped back into by-gone days at the celebration of the eightieth anniversary of their church building last night. More than 150 guests forgot the surrounding neon lights that advertise night life in Greenwich Village.

Complaints that criminals were being used in the current strike of the poultry drivers' union led last night to the arrest in District Attorney Dewey's office of Frank G. Mastroicore, 27 years old, an ex-convict, as a fugitive from Baton Rouge, La., in a murder.

THE TIMES published recently an article, "Mail Censorship Mill in Atlantic," by E.T. Sayer. I read it with deed interest -- hoping it would throw some light on what has happened to the air-mail service between the United States and England in the last three months.

MIAMI, Feb. 14 -- Although inconvenienced by being forced to conduct a workout in a public playground-dodging itinerant showers, and also by the prospect of a serious holdout situation, Manager Bill Terry managed to launch the Giants' Spring training campaign today with a remarkable display of cheer and enthusiasm.

A cow, Rocco D'Alessio said, "is just a factory. If you stoke her she gives milk. What does she care about green fields, and pastures, and pure country air? All she wants is good food, clean living conditions, and then she likes to produce."
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Alonzo Clark Mather, who died Jan. 25 in Los Angeles at the age of 92, left nearly four-fifths of his $5,000,000 estate to charity, according to his will filed today.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Boston College authorities today released Coach Frank Leahy from his new five-year contract to enable him to return to Notre Dame. Leahy will sign his new contract in South Bend tomorrow afternoon.

Demand for most classes of traefer meats in yesterday's trading was only fair to slow. The market on steer hinds and ribs was about steady, although some sales were 50c lower. The market on veal hindsaddles had a weak undertone, while the lamb market was barely steady. The fresh pork trade was moderately active at fully steady prices. Trading in kosher meats was fair at generally steady prices.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Japanese correspondents here declared today that Japanese warships were patrolling the entire French Indo-China coast and also the Thai shore as far west as Bangkok.

Swift-moving events in scattered parts of the world, all of which implied a further widening of the war area, brought out yesterday the heaviest liquidation of the year to date, and prices were reduced 1 to 5 points. The selling reached its peak in the final hour, when transfers exceeded the full total for Monday and brought the volume for the day to 933,740 shares, compared with 642,940 shares on Thursday.

Lester W. Harris, 41 years old, of 509 West 110th Street, who as president of the Carburetor Combustion Corporation, formerly at 2,122 Amsterdam Avenue, defrauded numerous persons in 1938 in a scheme to sell coal from Pennsylvania mines at low cost, pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday for himself and his concern to charges of obtaining money by false pretenses.

The first small contingent of the 207th Coast Artillery (Anti-aircraft Mobile), the old Seventh Regiment of the New York National Guard, left yesterday for Camp Stewart, Hinesville, Ga., for a year's training. The bulk of the regiment will leave next Wednesday.

The plans of the American Rescue Ship Mission to transport 450 Spanish Republican refugees from French camps to permanent homes in Mexico struck another snag yesterday when the steamship Lovcen, which the mission had chartered, was placed on the British blacklist.

The Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will observe in the Spring three anniversaries in the life of the Right Rev. William T. Manning, tenth Bishop of New York. These will be the twentieth year of his episcopate, the golden jubilee of this ordination and the seventy-fifth year of his birth.

The Alumnae Association of Hunter College will hold its annual breakfast at 12:80 P.M. today in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Astor, to celebrate the seventy-first anniversary of the founding of the college.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 14 -- Although there were no official reports of British activity in Libya, rumors persisted today that Tripoli had been bombarded or captured, or both, by the British fleet. This is purely grapevine information, but similar stories in the past frequently proved to have been based on fact.
DU QUOIN, Ill., Feb. 14 -- Seven men were blown to their deaths this morning by a terrific explosion at the Fidelity Mine of the United Electric Coal Companies six miles west of here.

Reporting results for the year 1940, M.J. Sullivan, president of the American Can Company, informed stockholders that last year established a new record in sales at $197,515,224. This is an increase of 4.3 per cent over the previous peak of $189,434,614 recorded in 1939.

Net profit of the General Steel Castings Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries in 1940 amounted to $1,106,196 according to the report issued yesterday. Charges against the net include depreciation, interest, amortization, Federal and State income taxes and other deductions.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Officials of the New Jersey Highway Commission and the War Department will confer here next week with Army officers on a program for improving county roads leading into the reservation, Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, commanding general, disclosed today.

Stockholders of the Aviation and Transportation Corporation approved yesterday recommendations of the directors regarding the proposed sale and transfer of substantially all the assets of the company to its subsidiary, the Aviation Corporation.

Today's events: "L'Amore dei Tre Re" 2 P.M., and "Madama Butterfly,'' 8:30 P.M., Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 11 A.M.: Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; Gary Graffman, piano, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; WNYC American Music Festival, Museum of Modern Art, 2 P.M.; Isaiah Seligman, piano, MacDowell Club, 8:30 P.M.

Frank R. Hanson of the Columbia University Club, L.H. Sonneborn of the Yale Club and J.K. Fitzgerald of the New York A.C. advanced to the second round of the invitation squash tennis tournament of the Whitehall Club yesterday.

Thomas Jefferson High's basketball team assured itself at least a tie for the Section 1, Brooklyn P.S.A.L., title by crushing Boys High yesterday, 62 to 29, on the former's court. It was the thirteenth success this season for the victors, who also have six loop decisions to their credit.

THE style of "Reflections in a Golden Eye"* suggests an improbable collaboration between Cocteau and William Faulkner. The scene, a nameless, peacetime, Southern Army post, is strew with goings-on calculated to sweep waves of apoplexy over the General Staff. The characters, for the most part, are as bizarre a clutch of peculiarities as recent researches in the grotesque have disclosed.

The most comprehensive and exacting manoeuvres ever held in the United States in peacetime are planned for the First Army this Summer and when they are held this Army may be expected to be trained for combat and will have most of its combat equipment, Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the First Army, announced yesterday at his headquarters on Governors Island.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The G.C. Murphy Company, McKeesport, Pa., operator of retail chain stores, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 52,500 shares of no-par common stock.

BERLIN, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A previously reported attack by warships on a British convoy in the Atlantic resulted in the sinking of fourteen armed and loaded merchantmen totaling 82,000 tons, the daily war bulletin said today. The toll had been listed yesterday at thirteen vessels.
Retail activity continued upward this week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Wholesalers were busy filling reorders which were already coming in at a brisk rate for new Spring merchandise.

IN honor of the current National Testimonial to Paderewski the first of six concerts forming the special series of the National Symphony Orchestra, scheduled for this afternoon at 4 o'clock in Washington, D.C., will be dedicated to the Polish pianist and statesman. Charles O'Connell will appear as guest conductor and Jean Tennyson, soprano, will be the soloist.

Unified national support of President Roosevelt in preparations for national defense was urged yesterday by United States Senator James M. Mead in a speech at the Saturday Afternoon Forum of the National Democratic Club.

The grand award of the fourth Scholastic Salon of Photography conducted by the American Institute Science and Engineering Clubs was announced yesterday at the opening of an exhibit in Education Hall of the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

With the publication of this handsome book in the United States the Good Neighbor Policy proves to be a beneficent boomerang, for this winner of a prize awarded by the Children's Literary Committee of the Brazilian Ministry of Education has been published here through the cooperation of that Ministry as a gesture of good-will.

TO most of us who scurry around town these February days it is Winter, and a determined Winter not likely to be dislodged by anything a groundhog has to say. An old custom for overcoming the lassitude brought on by too many dreary Winter days was to take, if you could take it, a tonic to put you into proper form and mood to greet the Spring.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that a bill to authorize the city to issue equipment trust certificates to finance the purchase of rolling stock and other equipment for use on city-owned and operated transit facilities, including buses, would be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow night.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Draft deferment to students in approved medical schools to supply the need for about 3,500 new physicians annually in the government's five-year preparedness program was urged here today by a joint conference of three leading medical groups.

A THIRD of a century ago a young New York experimenter received word from Washington that a patent had been issued to him for an unimpressive-looking device. It was a miniature gadget, unlikely to interest the casual observer, yet today it is recognized as perhaps the nearest approach to an all-powerful genie that man has created.

Whether or not economically sound, at least it is consistent for the courts to hold that the measure of value of property taxable as a gift, under the Federal gift tax, is the cost to the donor of such property and not the amount realizable thereon.

Expenditures for new construction and improvements to plant and equipment throughout the Associated Gas and Electric Company system will amount to approximately $28,000,000 for 1941, the trustees in reorganization of the $1,000,000,000 utility system announced yesterday.

The three-masted auxiliary schooner Vema, one of the largest and most luxurious sailing yachts still in service, has been sold by Mr. and Mrs. Georg Unger Vetlesen of 1 Beekman Place, to the United States Maritime Service, it was disclosed here yesterday.

As the first step in the revision of the "democracy" by-laws of the Board of Higher Education, the presidents of the four city colleges -- Brooklyn, Hunter, City and Queens Colleges -- have requested faculty members at the institutions to criticize the regulations under which they teach and to suggest changes, it was learned yesterday.
BERLIN, Feb. 15 -- The German press today is evidencing an increasing interest in United States-Japanese relations, and in the German view the United States appears to have a case of "jitters."

The first official recommendation by the Office of Production Management last week that nondefense industries substitute plastics for metals and the order that scrap aluminum be returned by airplane factories to producers caused serious concern among executives in the metal industry.

FEW more exciting places can be found today in the Western Hemisphere than the International Pan American Airport on Biscayne Bay, Miami, where the flying clippers come in from and leave for ports on the Caribbean, the capitals of South American countries and the near-by islands of the West Indies.

FIVE-A-DAY Vaudeville is probably as dead as it's going to be, and even where it exists it is likely to be described as "Amateur Night" or "Gala Stage Show." However, in certain forthright instances it does go on frankly as five-a-day, and it has a public, as loyal as it is peculiar. Even if one doesn't belong to this eccentric band it is frequently worth staying after the feature and watching the proceedings.

After opening on a steady note and holding virtually unchanged for about an hour yesterday in the short trading session, easiness developed on the New York Cotton Exchange, and the final quotations reflected net losses of 5 to 7 points. Recessions of 6 points in the March, and 7 points in the May, carried these two positions to the lowest levels since the last week in December.

Fifteen members of Columbia University's first contingent to train under the Civil Aeronautics Board have completed their ground and flight courses and will receive private pilot's certificates, it was announced by Reynolds Benson, coordinator of the university's CAB program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The growing tension in the Balkans and in the Far East has apparently decided Administration leaders in the Senate to resist with all force any attempt to amend the lease-lend bill so as to enumerate, specifically or by general description, the countries which might be aided under its terms, as was suggested by Wendell L. Willkie.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 15 -- R.M. Evans, A.A.A. administrator, was telling an assembly of Iowa farmers recently that they could not depend on preparedness prosperity, that control of production was mow more imperative than ever, and that, for the future, stricter measures of control rather than relaxation might be necessary.

Today is the beginning of "Bill of Rights Week," set aside by Governor Lehman under a legislative act passed last year for the study in the schools of "the purpose, meaning and importance of the Bill of Rights article in the Federal and State Constitutions." Governor Lehman has urged that press, radio and civic groups join in the week's observances.

THE daily Athenian short-wave transmission directed to Great Britain, identified by the opening signature, "God Save the King" and the Greek national anthem, is being picked up here. The call, SVM, is flashed in dots and dashes, after which music, talks and rapid code signals are heard.

Labor must participate in management and control of industry, and is in a strong enough position to press this issue, Philip H. Van Gelder, secretary-treasurer, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers (C.I.O.), declared yesterday before 200 persons attending the annual luncheon of the League for Industrial Democracy at the Hotel Commodore.
Speakers at the Hunter College alumnae breakfast at the Hotel Astor yesterday stressed education as the first line of defense of our American way of life.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 15 -- Two benefit dances will be given here simultaneously next Friday night under the sponsorship of the Merchants and Associated Employes Division of the Port Washington Committee of the Scottish Clans Evacuation Plan.

In an appeal for immediate help for the stricken civilians in the bombed areas of Greece, the Greek War Relief Association made public yesterday a report submitted by Premier Alexander Koryzis and others after an inspection tour that disclosed "greatest suffering and privation."

TO attempt a seriously representative exhibition of Goya's work without the possibility of drawing on the collections of the Prado is a risky undertaking. To succeed in it demands a choice of available examples that will both indicate the breadth of the artist's accomplishment and suggest what should fill in the inevitable gaps.
HAVANA, Feb. 15 -- Two years ago Harold (Pete) Reiser was the boy wonder of the Dodgers' training camp, his batting feats grabbing the headlines on every New York sports page.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 15 -- Taking off tonight on the last lap of his air journey home, Harry L. Hopkins, President Roosevelt's personal observer in Great Britain, is ex pected to report to his White House chief some time tomorrow.

People who live alone in New York and dread coming down with a cold or any other ailment that keeps them home without attention are now able to avail themselves of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service. This particular venture, which Henry Street has been developing, is not a charity.

Twenty thousand young girls scattered over the country are learning to do radio and electrical repairing, welding, and sheet-metal work and other types of machine shop operations, getting ready for the time when enough men are called out of the skilled trades and into national defense to make it necessary for women to take their places.

BERLIN, Feb. 15 -- The silence of official quarters continues to mask the true import of yesterday's meeting at Berchtesgaden between Premier Dragisha Cvetkovich and Foreign Minister Alexander Cinkar-Markovitch of Yugoslavia and Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop.

HONEST music -- this was Igor Stravinsky's comment on Ballet Theatre's new approach to the music problem -- a problem so acute that it could actually affect the life of ballet in a modern theatre world. And what is that new approach?

A plan to aid Chinese war orphans and offer Americans work by representative artists at moderate prices will be tried here next month in a large exhibition of pictures and sculpture for sale under the auspices of the China Aid Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The United States, in a step toward closer collaboration with Great Britain in the development of new war weapons, today sent Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, on a mission to London to exchange scientific information of vital interest to the two nations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Events of the last ten days have shown more clearly than mere words could describe it the state of confusion in which the Republican party finds itself today.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York, at its monthly meeting last week, received a report on proposed freight rate increases on water and rail-water transportation between the Eastern trunkline territory and the Southwest, and adopted a resolution asking the Interstate Commerce Commission to give shippers an opportunity to present their views before the rates are accepted by the commission.

HAVANA, Feb. 15 -- Cubans and Americans today jointly observed the forty-third anniversary of the sinking of the United States battleship Maine in Havana harbor. Commemorative services were held at the monument located on Malecon sea drive.

Shifting from his former position as an isolationist who was opposed to the lease-lend bill to aid Great Britain, Councilman Joseph Clark Baldwin, contender for a seat in Congress from the Seventeenth Congressional District with Republican support, sees safety for the United States in the measure as amended, he said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- A "hedge hopping" tractor has been invented by Henry Ford, it is disclosed in a patent (No. 2,231,710) awarded to the auto manufacturer.

B.M. Higginson and A.S. Cornhill tied for the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, each with 96 out of 100 targets. In the shoot-off, Higginson won, 24 to 22.

MONTREAL, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Before a crowd of 11,862, largest of the season in Montreal, the Boston Bruins extended their sensational unbeaten streak to twenty-one consecutive National Hockey League games tonight with a 5-to-0 shutout of the Montreal Canadiens.

MOST of those who have spoken their minds on this presently popular subject of what is wrong with the theatre have been like war communiques, correct as far as they have gone. They have not gone far enough, speaking of theatres as a small world by itself rather than in relation to the whole framework of human existence.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas -- "Remember, a Charro never sleeps." That was the admonition given to hard-fisted Phil Sheridan by pioneer cattlemen, when he hung his saber in a cool adobe hut beneath a brace of Royal Palms, pulled back the matting from his south window and looked speculatively out across the murky Rio Grande to the country below the border.

THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine published recently an article by Professor Commager of Columbia, entitled "Our Beginnings." As a student of history I am compelled to take exception, not to what Professor Commager has to say, but to certain things he has omitted.

Progressive education, for near a quarter of a century a controversial issue in school system throughout the country, yesterday received unqualified approval from a committee of ten nationally known educators established a year ago to evaluate the work in this area.

THE TIMES on Feb. 9 printed a cartoon by the famous English artist Low, who had drawn Liberty with six instead of seven points in her crown. This may appear unimportant, but to the scholar and student of symbology it means much.

This book is by no means intended solely for children, but it is such a rich treasury of animal pictures that it deserves mention in a department devoted to those who have not yet outgrown the firm conviction that animals are people too, especially as the collection of drawings and photographs has been made with a special emphasis upon expression.

Rudolph Ganz presented his fifth child prodigy of the season yesterday morning at the Philharmonic-Symphony Society's Young People's Concert at Carnegie Hall. She was 11-year-old Ellen Berg of Detroit, a coloratura soprano. The girl, according to reports, has had a mature soprano voice since she was 9, but yesterday marked her New York debut.

A number of business men and women, including personnel and employment managers, will participate in a vocational conference planned for young women of the Girls Service Club, to be given on Tuesday and Wednesday evening this week under the sponsorship of the New York League of Business and Professional Women.

RAPID progress is being made on the building of the Wilbur Cross Parkway, in Connecticut. The first section of this parkway, which acts as a continuation of the Merritt Parkway, was opened on Labor Day of last year, and provides a direct connection with the Boston Post Road, at Milford.

Bottlenecks in a defense program can be of two kinds -- temporary, caused by a lack of synchronization between the production of one element or part and that of another, and more permanent bottlenecks, caused by a serious or absolute shortage of some product.

ALTHOUGH primarily occupied at the moment with the "Carnival for Britain," Vinton Freedley is not overlooking next season. He expects to have Cole Porter and Herbert Fields put together a musical in time for Fall presentation.

INTEREST is steadily increasing in censored covers. Even the layman must realize that there is a constant diminishing of territory to which he can send a letter without that letter's being inspected by some war authority. New avenues in this field are thus opening up for the specialist.

Three new groups of Westchester women following the example set by the Materials Conservations Committee of Greenville have undertaken to make household collections of scrap metals to be sold for the benefit of war relief work. In Hartsdale, Dobbs Ferry and Scarsdale, campaigns are under way by letter and telephone, and centers have been set up where residents may deposit their contributions.

ATHENS, Feb. 15 -- A simple soldier serving at the front in the Greek Army wrote on a scrap of paper torn from a book a message addressed "to THE NEW YORK TIMES and through it to the Army of the United States." The message, possessing a human and patriotic appeal reminiscent of some of Walt Whitman, comes from "Somewhere at the Front" and is dated Jan. 23.

BERLIN, Feb. 15 -- The two new provinces -- or officially two provinces renamed -- on Germany's western border, recently have focused attention on the reshaping the geographical outline of the Third Reich within the scope of the general "new order" Reichsfuehrer Hitler is introducing in Europe.

"WHAT'S the best way to go about it?" Gilbert Miller genially inquired about six weeks ago. It was an innocent question. It was directed at a handful of men assembled in his Radio City office on a foul Winter afternoon.

After a day of speeches and discussion, the New York State Conference on Legislation for Democracy ended its session in the Hotel Edison last night with the adoption of more than a score of resolutions dealing with labor, social welfare, housing and education, most of them based on the general theme of further taxing the rich to help the poor.

In the years that preceded the outbreak of the present war I expected that I should be opposed to it, as I was to the war of 1914-18. Various circumstances, however, have led me to alter my view. This alteration is not as to any fundamental principle.
ROME, Feb. 15 -- Former King Alfonso XIII of Spain, who resides in Rome, had another heart attack last night. He was reported tonight as gravely ill.

Expenditures for national defense added to Federal and municipal expenditures for large work projects and elaborate improvements threaten to produce a collapse of our capitalist system and force the government to take over most of private enterpise as it has in Germany and Italy, John T. Flynn, author and economist, told members of the Long Island Real Estate Board last night.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Columbia's basketball team strengthened its hold on second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League when it scored a 44-39 victory over Princeton today in the university gymnasium. Chuck Winston of the Tigers and John Cerrone, who tied for high scoring honors with 15 points each, led the rival quintets through a nip-and-tuck contest.
Fordham's swimmers turned back N.Y.U., 49 to 26, yesterday in the Rose Hill pool. It was the third victory of the season against four defeats for the Rams.

PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Although three years have passed since the maximum of the current sun-spot cycle, spot activity is still greater than at the peak of the preceding cycle, according to Dr. Seth B. Nicholson of Mount Wilson. The astronomer said today that the current cycle was perhaps the most active of record and apparently produced the greatest magnetic storm.

AT the Hayden Planetarium in New York are being shown the various ways in which the earth may perish. Planets are like human beings. They are born, they reach maturity and they die. The earth is still young -- only two or three billion years old -- and it has been calculated that, in so far as the sun is concerned, it has fifteen billion more years ahead of it.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 15 -- What happens to Indianapolis youth after they are graduated from high school has been the subject of study by local school officials. At the instance of DeWitt S. Morgan, superintendent of schools, the high school principals have made a follow-up survey of the boys and girls who were graduated ten years ago.

Hyman Caplin, dapper manager of prizefighters among whom at present there are two world's champions, was found guilty yesterday by a jury in Kings County Court after trial on an indictment containing two counts of first-degree grand larceny.

LONDON, Feb. 15 (UP) -- German warplanes roared over Britain from the Kentish coast to Scotland tonight after resumption of mass daylight raid tactics that British authorities warned might precede an invasion attempt.

I HAVE just seen Elmer Rice's "Flight to the West" and have been aroused by this stirring drama, with its realistic plot, its superb cast and its clarifying philosophy. Yet, when the final curtain fell I was surprised at the moderate volume of applause.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Several sparkling performances marked the extensive and diversified sports program at the United States Military Academy today. Cadet varsity squads faced intercollegiate foes in eight events and won half of them.

"THE GOLDEN BOUGH" was first published in 1890, and it has been a part of the literature of knowledge (and also, in its lucid and noble prose, of the knowledge of literature), thus, for half a century. But we have known little of its author: "the facts of Frazer's life consist essentially of a list of his works," his biographer remarks now.

Vital functions, including the inspection of signals on rapid transit lines, have been impaired because of budget economies enforced upon it by the La Guardia administration, the Transit Commission declared yesterday in its annual report to Governor Lehman and the Legislature.

Injunctions permanently restraining five New York concerns from further violations of the Fair Labor Standards Act and directing restitution of about $6,400 in back wages and unpaid overtime to 354 employes, were filed here yesterday by Arthur J. White, regional director of the Wage and Hour Division, United States Department of Labor. Federal Judge William Bondy signed the injunctions.

"Once the dust of Mexico has settled on your heart, never can you rest in any other land." This was the proverb which Priscilla, the pale young librarian from New England, laughed at when her frivolous aunt took her on a jaunt south of the border.

A new technique for bringing together the divergent economic beliefs of capital, management, labor and government, developed in a series of conferences since 1939, will be utilized to determine the extent to which the defense program may lead the country into inflation.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Mrs. Peter J. Fick, 28 years old, of 85 Windsor Road, Tenafly, who played the role of the daughter, Marge, in the Myrt and Marge radio series, died today in Englewood Hospital a few minutes after the birth of a son, Donald, at 12:42 A.M. The child was said to be well this afternoon at the hospital.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The round of parties, dances, concerts and movies of the Winter season here will be climaxed by the Washington's Birthday celebration this week.
Next Saturday and Sunday the Eastern Dog Club will give its twenty-ninth annual exhibition in Mechanics Building, Boston. This will be the last all-breed show of the month in the Eastern section.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The United States has supplied to the British more than 755,000 tons of cargo ships since Oct. 26, 1939. Of this total 694,617 tons was transferred to British registry and 60,985 tons to Canadian registry.

THIS season New York will have had the first opportunity in its history to hear Bruno Walter as conductor of opera as well as symphony. He is as eminent in the former branch as he is in the symphonic field. A musician of uncommon culture and intellect, his sympathies with both forms of music are well defined.

ONE fine Spring day in 1898 over by the East River at Sixty-sixth Street John J. McHugh borrowed a pistol, fired it in the air, and started a group of runners pounding down a track. He has continued starting runners on their way for more than forty years.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Reorganization of the Chicago Great Western Railroad Company, the second major carrier to conclude such proceedings, will be virtually completed by next Wednesday, when the system's properties will be transferred to a successor corporation.

MADRID, Feb. 15 -- The impression that the policy of Spain will continue on its present lines was strengthened today by the tone of the Madrid press, which gave its first comment on Generalissimo Francisco Franco's interview with Premier Mussolini.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 15 -- United States Minister George H. Earle announced this afternoon that the wallet of Colonel William J. Donovan, President Roosevelt's special envoy in Europe, which had been lost in Sofia on Jan. 23, as Colonel Donovan was preparing to depart for Belgrade, has been recovered.

Patrolman Leon Fox of the Coney Island precinct was fatally wounded last night by gunmen who snatched a brief case containing $750 from a theatre manager he was escorting to a bank in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn. The thugs escaped in an automobile.
BABY reaches for his toys with either hand until he's six months or so, then may show preference for one hand; parents usually notice it when he begins to eat with a spoon (between 1 and 2).

A definite lag in the anticipated enrollment of trained nurses in the First Reserves of the American Red Cross, from which appointment are made to Army posts, has left unfilled numerous vacancies in hospitals in the post camps, it developed yesterday.

THE tripartite alliance between Germany, Italy and Japan last September clearly documented what had long been clear to thoughtful observers: the close connection between the war in Europe which began with the German invasion of Poland and the war in Asia that began with the Japanese invasion of China.

One of England's foremost bankers turned over his home in Kent for the accommodation of children evacuated from London. The following letter was received by a New York business man from his sister, who is in charge of the establishment:

On the eve of the conventions of the Progressive Education Association and the National Education Association, it is evident that the public school systems of the country are as much concerned with stocktaking in their own field as the colleges are in theirs.

DETROIT -- Domestic new car and truck registrations for 1940 place that year right among the top-ranking years in the history of the industry. While it is true that the total of 3,992,232 units gives it only fourth place in the standing, the margin by which it was crowded out was very slight.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15 -- The Woodvale Farm's Haltal and the Circle M Ranch's Big Pebble were the winners of the McLennan Handicap at Hialeah Park today, the race being split into two divisions of twelve horses each. Both winners were surprises to the season's largest crowd, 20,829, Haltal paying $12.80 and Big Pebble $46.90 at the end of their nine furlongs run over a fast track.

Joe Louis monopolizes the limelight in Eastern fistic circles this week in his fourteenth defense of the world heavyweight title. The Brown Bomber makes his stand tomorrow night in Philadelphia for Promoter Herman Taylor, against Gus Dorazio, Philadelphia Italian, in a bout scheduled for fifteen rounds.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Feb. 15 -- The new army which is being created by the United States differs from its forerunners in two basic ways. It must be composed, more than ever before, of specialists; at the same time, a strong effort is made in training units of a mass force to retain individuality.

MR. SMITH, who delivered these three lectures, is both a practicing politician and a professional philosopher. He is a member of the House of Representatives as Congressman at Large from Illinois and is Professor of Philosophy at the University of Chicago.
FUNCHAL, Madeira, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Six ships from a British Atlantic convoy attacked by German raiders have reached this port.

The Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, minister of the Broadway Tabernacle and "convenor" of the Covenant of Peace Group, which advocates "peace without victory now," announced yesterday that "nearly 700 leading churchmen in all parts of the country" have sent their signatures to Dr. Chalmers indicating their agreement with the aims of the peace group.

FACTORY workers and craftsmen in industry are the new commuters. Between home and plant they often travel by automobile more than 100 miles a day. This fluid form of transportation is proving vital to the national defense manufacturing program, which thus draws personnel from an area of 100 miles around any plant.
TOKYO, Feb. 15 -- Three items of news reported today appreciably lightened the strain that the Japanese public has been feeling because of fears that a clash in the Pacific was imminent.

THE relative skill of men and women bridge players will remain an unsettled question perhaps as long as contract bridge is played and for an equally long period there will be occasional efforts to establish the superiority of one sex over the other.

IT has leaked out that you have employed Norman Bel Geddes to streamline your already superlative circus. But I have seen no announcement that you intend to restore to its rightful place a feature that was from the very beginnings of the American circus more than a century ago an institution at least as important as the leaper, the equestrian and the elephant-namely, the clown.

Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti and Milton Diamond, of the law firm of Diamond, Rabin, Botein and Mackay, conferred yesterday in Washington with Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General, and Mr. Arnold's aides in the anti-trust suit against the American Society of Authors, Composers and Publishers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Treasury is ready to start immediately on a campaign, officials said today, to tap the savings of children, housewives and small-salaried workers for a sizable part of the $9,000,000,000 it must borrow in the next twelve months to finance the defense program.

A halt, whether or not it proves only temporary, was called yesterday to the steady successions of declines in the stock price structure, and the week's trading ended on a firmer note, with the leading issues up fractions to a point. The meager support accorded the market on scattered occasions in the week was enlarged sufficiently to turn the trend, but more important was the drying up of the heavy liquidation of Friday.

A leadership laboratory for those working in the field of adult education was outlined last week in two new ventures to be sponsored by Town Hall, Inc. Representatives of fifty-one national organizations attended a luncheon at Town Hall at which the Town Hall Leadership School, a three-week course scheduled for May 12 through May 30, and the First National Town Hall Conference, to be held May 7 through May 9, were described.

ROME, Feb. 15 -- A strong attack upon false stories issued about the Pope and the Holy See, including one that the Pontiff is anti-democratic and another that conditions of the Catholic Church in Germany have improved, was made today in the Osservatore Romano.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 15 -- Increased activity is evident in work on the United States defense bases, which is expected within a week or two to switch from the survey phase to actual construction.

The opening discussion in a series of seven informal forums on current events by members of the history department of Hunter College will be held Friday at 4:30 P.M. in the student lounges at 695 Park Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Professor Helen L. Young, chairman of the department.

I HAVE been reading with interest the articles and letters on the problem of refugee musicians. Obviously, your correspondents have viewed the situation with different prejudices and they have not observed the same particular cases, so they have come to quite different conclusions.

THE much debated question, Is photography art? has been raised again and answered in the affirmative, so far as the Museum of Modern Art is concerned. That institution, unhampered by crusty -- and dusty -- traditions, is setting up a department of photography to take rank with sculpture, painting and architecture and the other principalities of the muses which enjoy unchallenged standing as fine arts.

Willie Hoppe, at 53 monarch of all he surveys in the three-cushion billiard world, is due back in New York tomorrow morning. On Tuesday night the perennial "Boy Wonder" will be honored at a reception at the Metropolitan Billiard Club, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street, just as he was a year ago when his record-breaking achievement of twenty victories without a setback brought him the crown.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 15 -- Negotiations toward the forced sale to Germany of the French-owned Bor Copper Mines of Yugoslavia are nearing their conclusion in Paris, it was learned tonight from mining circles in Belgrade.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- The annual promenade of the junior class of Vassar College was held this evening in a hall of the Students Building, which was decorated with valentines and red and gold balloons.

IT would be indeed hard today to find a photographer who does not know the texture screen. The device is something of a latecomer in photography, but there are already more than half a dozen versions of the mechanism on the market.

THERE has never been a heroine of fiction whose story has approached, in tragedy, in poignancy and in appealing beauty, that of Marie Antoinette. It has every thing: a background of terror; a teeming multitude of as assorted a cast as ever peopled the stage of any of life's dramas; haunting mystery.
The course of Soviet foreign policy in the past few years has caused outside observers to say, customarily, that Russia's attitude and intention a are an insoluble riddle.

Because of lower real estate tax assessments and declining general fund revenues the city will face a "grave problem" in trying to balance its budget for the fiscal year 1941-1942, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick declared yesterday in a report submitted to the Board of Estimate and the City Council.

With the defense industries drawing experienced and capable executives from companies in other less-essential fields, the Forty Plus Club of New York, a cooperative group of men of 40 years of age or over engaged in finding employment for men in those brackets, is proving successful in providing replacements for these executives, Homer S. Curtis, a member of the public relations committee of the club, reported yesterday.

CHALMA, Mexico -- The visitor, to Mexico in February is fortunate. Gay fiestas in every village precede the Lenten season. The month's most important religious event, yet the one least attended by "Norte Americanos," is the Pilgrimage to Chalma which reaches its climax on the first Friday in Lent, Feb. 28.

WAYS STATION, Ga., Feb. 15 -- Henry Ford said today the United States should give England and the Axis powers "the tools to keep on fighting until they both collapse." He is making his annual visit to his plantation and experimental farm here, and said in an exclusive, copyrighted interview with Harold Martin, staff writer of The Atlanta Constitution, he "sincerely hoped" that neither England nor the Axis powers would win the struggle.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The raid by British parachute troops on Southern Italy, announced in Rome yesterday, was confirmed officially here today.

THAT enterprising young artist, Don Freeman, has brought out another of the quarterly editions of his unique one-man magazine, Newsstand. Mr. Freeman writes the sketches of New York life which appear in the publication and illustrates them with his own sketches.

ROME, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Italy halted freight traffic on several Southern Italian rail lines today while all the Fascist Blackshirt formations in the zone south of Naples hunted down British parachute dynamiters who are intent authorities, said, on disrupting communications.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15 -- Yale swept into full possession of second place in the Quadrangular Intercollegiate Hockey League tonight by defeating Dartmouth, 5 to 2.

INDUSTRY'S work on defense production will be explained in weekly "reports to the nation" over WEAF and affiliated stations, beginning Feb. 22 at 7 P.M., when "Defense for America" is to be introduced. The thirty-minute programs, to be presented in cooperation with the National Association of Manufacturers, will consist of visits to plants where tools of national defense are now being turned out.

AN interesting communication from the well-known English bookseller John Carter describes the effects of the war on the antiquarian book trade in London. It is worth reproducing, because it is the latest authentic account of conditions abroad and it answers questions that bookmen have been asking.

New York Athletic Club skippers will pay homage this afternoon to Commodore-elect Mel Hayes and the other new 1941 officers at a reception at Travers Island, beginning at 4 o'clock. F.S. Shumaker of Rye, chairman of the entertainment committee of the Yachting Department, has arranged for the presentation of the flag during the festivities.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 15 -- Harvard's varsity swimmers defeated Dartmouth tonight, 50 -- 25, in the Harvard pool, gaining their ninth straight victory of the season and third in Eastern Intercollegiate League competition.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 15 -- Bill Stark of Jacksonville, Fla., defeated Dick Van Kleeck of the same city, 5 and 3, for the fourteenth annual national amateur championship of golf club champions today on the St. Augustine Links.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Nineteen thousand young Americans are entering the third and final part of the 1940-41 Civilian Aeronautics Administration's program for civilian pilot training in 907 training centers, according to an announcement today by Colonel Donald H. Connolly, Administrator of Civil Aeronautics.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Recent discussion in the United States again has brought up the question of the possibility of a negotiated peace. This sort of talk was serious at the start of the war, when former Prime Minister David Lloyd George was its most ardent protagonist.

Tension and excitement prevail today in Australia, in Singapore, in the Netherlands Indies and in the Philippine Islands. It is feared that Japan, living up to her sworn adherence to the Berlin-Rome-Tokyo tripartite alliance, is about to make a southward thrust, and by so doing prove at least a serious nuisance to her European allies in their struggle against England.
SIX times a day people say to me: "You were wrong to open 'Meet the People' on the same night with 'Pal Joey.' You should have postponed and got the first-string critics."

A STAMP-COLLECTING professor, who heads the history department of an Eastern university and who when writing about the hobby hides his identity behind the pseudonym George Van Den Berg, has inaugurated a movement to organize the American Philatelic History Society "for the purpose of bringing together and disseminating information on the history of stamp collecting in the United States."

Favored by better weather thanI was the case a year ago, retail trade here made good gains over last week. Department store volume was estimated as showing an increase of 12 per cent or more, with specialty shops also faring well.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Senator Austin, the assistant Republican leader, suddenly arose in his place this week and made a speech which was important for two reasons. It brought to the surface a strong undercurrent of Congressional opinion that Great Britain should make some statement of its peace aims. And it helped to explain why no satisfactory substitute for the President's lease-lend bill has been forthcoming.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The journey in state this week of Spain's dictator, General Francisco France, and his Foreign Minister, Ramon Serrano Suner, to meetings first with Premier Mussolini, then with Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, drew attention to the singular plight in which Spain finds herself.

What appears to be a final, or at least a semi-final, reorganization plan for McKesson Robbins, Inc., has been drafted by William J. Wardall, trustee, and representatives of the three security holders protective committees, according to authoritative sources.

DESERT warfare has even less to recommend it than war that is conducted across a more kindly and more fertile territory. Those engaged in it suffer almost every extreme of discomfort that human beings can be called on to endure, and what few compensations it has to offer are either emotional or esthetic.

A large advance subscription indicates that a capacity throng will attend the all-Wagner concert to be presented by Arturo Toscanini and the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra Saturday night at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, emphasized that British forces in the Far East had been increased "quite substantially" and Dr. A. Loudon, the Netherland Minister, declared that "the Dutch East Indies will fight any aggressors" after separate conferences with Secretary of State Cordell Hull today.
DETROIT, Feb. 15 (UP) -- The Chrysler Corporation is developing an airplane engine which it hopes will propel planes 500 miles an hour.

To make a newspaper story convincing to the hardened reader of light fiction, all that seems to be necessary is to provide a blood feud between rival sheets. This novel picks a Western city, somewhat resembling Denver, and sets up two fairly filthy rags in com petition.

VICHY, France, Feb. 15 -- Interior Minister Marcel Peyrouton has resigned. His action conforms with expectations of the concentration of power in a few hands, the triumvirate of which there has been so much talk.

As it approaches the half century mark, Pen and Brush is surrounded with an air of satisfaction and prosperity. The first emotion comes from the recent election of Miss Ida M. Tarbell to her twenty-eighth consecutive year as president and the second from a bank account which reveals an enviable financial standing.

INDIVIDUAL musicians have been doing their bit in England. Betty Humby, young British pianist, who will play on the Radio City Music Hall on the air at noon today, before she left England organized groups of musicians who traveled like theatrical troupers from town to town, using ancient English cathedrals and modern motion picture theatres as concert halls.

To say a man is a doctor nowadays does not give a clear picture of him. He may be a high priest of science, a devotee of research, a narrow specialist or a kindly general practitioner. As the Lieferants have proceeded with their novels of medical men, it appears that they have come to the conclusion about which type of medicine does the most good to the public.

Celebration of Bill of Rights Week, which begins today by proclamation of Governor Lehman, is important to national defense because the American people's determination to uphold civil liberties is the "driving force" behind the defense program, the Citizenship Educational Service declared yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla. -- A feature of the seventh annual Sunburn Dinghy Regatta of the Biscayne Bay Yacht Club, to be sailed on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday over the club's "inside" bay course of three miles, will be the inaugural races of the Comet class in Florida waters.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 15 -- The First Call will be symbolic of the eager readiness of the Forty-fourth Division to respond to every "first call," Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, commanding general, said this morning in hailing the initial edition of the division's newspaper.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 15 -- A solo dash by Dick Faxon at 16:2l in the final period gave Princeton a 5-4 victory over Harvard in the Hobey Baker Rink tonight and gave the Tigers a commanding lead in the Quadrangular Hockey. League.

The Journal of Educational Sociology, published yesterday at New York University, devotes its issue this quarter entirely to the problem of presenting education to the radio audience. The situation revolves fundamentally around two conflicting opinions.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 15 -- The terrific impact of the German Wehrmacht seems about to descend across the Balkans, bringing with it either war or serfdom. Martial sounds are coming down the Danube. Soon they will spread southward.
