NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Employing a new technique embodying the use of recording instruments and a public address loudspeaker, Rutgers University has begun special training in telephone use and speech as an additional function of its already wide program of public speaking and debating.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 15 -- Clayton Heafner of Linville, N.C., who never won a major golf tournament, and the veteran Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., both bettered the City Park course record today to tie for the half-time lead in the $5,000 New Orleans open.
KURT VALENTIN has assembled a very interesting group of sculpture at the Buchholz Gallery. "From Rodin to Brancusi" he calls this show, which will be current through March 8.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Princeton University's renewed emphasis upon delving into vital questions of the day, as part of its revitalized program of "Education for Democracy," will be extended to alumni next Saturday. A faculty-alumni forum on the question, "Can the Americas Stand Alone," will be one of the featured events of Alumni Day, traditionally held here on Washington's Birthday.

An invitation extended by an official German short-wave radio station to American listeners to cable, collect, their choice of future propaganda talks brought at least one rebuff yesterday. Harold Norman Joseph, 251 West Eighty-ninth Street, a member of the War Relief Association of American Youth, revealed that he had sent, at German Government expense, the message:

The annual report of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, for 1939-40 is being sent to more than 7,000 members of the museum here and abroad. The report, presented in thirty-six pages, is illustrated with photographs and drawings.

February and March are the dreary months when a girl most needs a new dress and a new hat to bolster her morale. But just then along come income-tax bills and usually there's no fund for finery. There is one good way to beat this situation and that is via costume jewelry.

SOME idea of how the trade increase will run now that the post-season lull is about over was disclosed by retail figures in the week. The first week in February brought an upturn of 19 per cent in department store sales over last year for the country as a whole.

Efforts to have the British rescind the blacklisting of the steamer Lovcen, upon which the American Rescue Ship Mission expected to transfer 450 Spanish refugees from France to Mexico, were made known yesterday at a press conference at 425 Fourth Avenue.

TRAVEL on credit, introduced on American rail lines early last Summer, gives every indication of becoming a permanent feature of the domestic travel scene. Major airlines of the country will announce shortly that they, too, will sell tickets on the "installment" plan. One steamship line has already adopted the scheme and others are expected to follow suit.

In a plea for a united front among Protestants, Catholics and Jews against the common foe of paganism, Dr. Moses R. Lovell, pastor of the Central Congregational Church, Brooklyn, declared yesterday that the three faiths must be prepared to counsel eventually for a negotiated peace in the European war so that a "peace without victory" could be attained.

A Science Service report published in THE TIMES of Jan. 28 referred to a proposal by us for "a new language to be created" so that "the people of all the Americas will be speaking the same language:" Though doubtless well intentioned, this phrasing was unfortunate.

Efforts are being made to bring together again the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and the United Palestine Appeal, which last year conducted a joint campaign as the United Jewish Appeal, but which since have planned to undertake separate drives, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- President Roosevelt was reported today to be "well satisfied" with the aid-to-Britain bill approved by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and to be anxious that it be finally enacted in substantially its present form.

Mayor La Guardia signed yesterday a local law authorizing the appointment of an additional justice of the Court of Special Sessions, and at the same time announced the appointment of Magistrate Frank Oliver of the Bronx as a member of that court to fill a vacancy.

A study just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion gives a sharp setback to the widespread notion that the sinking of American merchant ships by German U-boats at some future date would automatically awing American opinion irresistibly toward war, according to Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 15 -- The United States Supreme Court's rejection on Feb. 10 of the Ford Motor Company petition for a review of a Labor Board decision ordering the company to desist from alleged unfair labor practices, has opened the door for unionization of the big Rouge plant.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- The annual Washington's Birthday Ball, an outdoor barbecue and skating parties head the holiday program planned at Buck Hill Falls for more than 500 guests and cottage colony members. Skytop Club announces that over 300 club members and their friends plan to enjoy the holiday there, where indoor and outdoor program plans have been arranged.

Bernie Mayer of Morris High and Irving Mondschein, Boys High star, were victors in the interscholastic field meet sponsored by the Brooklyn Diocesan high schools at the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High gymnasium in Brooklyn yesterday. The program, the first of its kind held locally, attracted 125 athletes from the metropolitan area.

"MARK'S OWN" is a first novel of great distinction. In it Sarah Atherton tells the story of eighty years in the life of a mine. During the eight decades many changes are wrought in the lives of the people dependent upon the fortunes of Coldspring Mine, upon the owners as well as the workers.

The Long Island University basketball team completed another undefeated season on its home court by overwhelming Rider College, 63 -- 41, in the Brooklyn College, of Pharmacy gymnasium lat night. The Blackbirds, whose record for the season now stands at seventeen won and two lost, have not been beaten at home since Marshall of West Virginia turned the trick three years ago.

ON the flap of this novel Bennett Cerf states somewhat evasively that though he admires Miss Stein "from the bottom of his heart," he rarely has the faintest idea of what she is talking about. This statement, we feel, does not do full justice to Gertrude Stein.

THE winners of the Alfred A. Knopf Literary Fellowships for 1941 are Mrs. Berenice DuRae Thorpe in fiction, Professor W.E. Binkley in history, and Professor Mitchell V. Charnley in biography. Mrs. Thorpe is a Seattle housewife and teaching fellow at the University of Washington.

"THANK you most respectfully for your lordship's great favor in letting your humble wife go out of the house." It was the phrase Sumie Seo Mishima had heard constantly when she lived as a child in her aunt's samurai household in Tokyo.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 15 -- Irvan Cary, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, A.F. of L., asked the federation's executive council today to assign organizers to meet the demand for membership in his organization from employes of the Ford and other automobile companies.

THE name of Ernest Rhys, now in his eighty-second year, is a relatively obscure one; yet the English-speaking world owes him an immense debt. That it is scarcely aware of it in any intimate sense is due to the nature of the achievement, a colossal one, nevertheless.

A new British blacklist of neutral vessels that the British Government warns all shippers and charterers to avoid, has been made public here by the British Consulate General. Two lists containing a total of twenty-eight names were obtained last month from the British Press Service in Rockefeller Center, the first published here since the war began.

ACAPULCO, currently taking on a certain fame as a Mexican resort on the Pacific Coast, is a popular stop-over for cruise passengers. Its diving boys plunging from perilously high, jagged rocks are a dramatic sight; its night bathing parties in phosphorescent water an innovation.

THE years develop and change our mental outlook and our analyses of ourselves, as our work becomes sharper and clearer to us. I think this is especially true of the creative artist. Many years ago, in 1913, Gatti-Casazza gave my opera on Rostand's "Cyrano de Bergerac" its first performance at the Metropolitan Opera House with a very sumptuous setting.

THERE is a new front line of defense in Britain -- a front line on the nation's rooftops. Its enemy is fire. When the sirens wail in the night the first raiding planes overhead drop incendiaries, vicious little bombs that scatter flames upon the buildings below.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Faced with a threat of revocation of their charters on charges of fostering practices inimical to democracy, leaders of three New York City locals of the American Federation of Teachers asserted here today that the federation's executive council was "going through the motions" of granting them a hearing and that it had already decided to oust them.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla. -- The highlight of the social season in Ormond Beach will be the Washington's Birthday Ball at the Hotel Ormond on Saturday. This event has been long anticipated by guests and Winter colonists alike and many parties have been planned for the occasion.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 15 -- The Bourse was adversely affected today by advices from Wall Street and developments in the Far East. Dutch issues declined as much as 12 points and Dutch-Indies shares, particularly, were weak, though trading was small.

TRANSFORMER HUM -- Electric transformers have "confessed" to Hans Fahnoe, Westinghouse engineer, the reason why they hum to themselves. "It has been definitely established that magnetostriction in iron cores of transformers is the principal source of this noise," says Mr. Fahnoe.

WASHINGTON -- America must be armed with vitamins as well as guns if it is to meet the challenge of total defense, in the opinion of Dr. Louise Stanley, chief of the United States Bureau of Home Economics, who is expected to have an important role in the far-flung home-defense program.

A program that would make it possible to collect 25,000 liters of blood from 100,000 donors in ten cities over a period of six months for the national defense in case of emergency has been worked out at the request of the American Red Cross by the Blood Transfusion Association, it was revealed in the first official report of the association yesterday.
"VERMONT, Wednesday, July 13 -- We bought the farm!"

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Wheat registered moderate resistance to pressure in the early trading today with some buying reported to have been based on the relatively firm undertone in securities, but most of the deals were for local account. Late in the session certain among the leading professional operators began to liquidate and the turn uncovered a lack of outside interest which resulted in a reaction of about 3/4 cent from the earlier high levels.

STUART, Fla. -- Cock fighting is still a diversion unadvertised but provided clandestinely by Florida for Northerners ready to bet on anything. Outlawed by the State, it flourishes in out-of-the-way places with semi-jungle or Everglades setting. The season for what was once a half-tolerated sport began on New Year's Day and will last for three months.

A program of instruction in classical languages, designed to include within its scope many different types of students, is rapidly being developed at Queens College. Though all work in the department of classical languages is offered on an elective basis, the courses have been so grouped that students who are not necessarily majoring in Latin or Greek will find materials of value to their field of concentration.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 15 -- Prince Regent Paul received Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch and Dr. Alexander Cincar-Markovitch, the Yugoslav Foreign Minister, at the Royal Palace tonight for a complete report on their conversations with Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Foreign Minister, in Austria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Settlement of the strike at the Milwaukee plant of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, which has tied up 8,000 workers and an estimated $40,000,000 of defense production for twenty-five days, was announced tonight by the Office of Production Management.

The Black Diamond Steamship Lines have sold the freighter Black Gull to the Luckenbach Steamship Lines for the latter company's intercoastal service, it was reported yesterday in shipping circles. This is the sixth vessel of the Black Diamond Line's former fleet of eight transatlantic freighters, which formerly operated in the United States trade to Antwerp and Rotterdam.

Into each life, as the poet says, some rain must fall. Right now it is showering on the fly-tyers, amateur and professional, who are trying to figure what domestic fowl will produce a feather similar in color, strength and quality to that of the vermillion-crested dimwhit, which is employed in making the body of a fly known as the Whimsical Fancy.

Bills introduced by representatives from New York and California for the training of glider pilots deserve careful consideration by Congress. Successful use of motorless aircraft to teach fundamental airmanship to military fliers has played a substantial part in providing both Germany and Russia with flying personnel.

Coat, suit, dress and accessories departments were well patronized last week and sell-outs were noted in some instances, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. The following advertised merchandise met with excellent consumer response in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles:

SUMMER, 1937 . . . By ordinary theatrical standards, a long time ago: but with war in between, it's like looking through the wrong end of a telescope. Miles away, very small, I can see my wife and myself sitting on a sunny lawn near Maidenhead, reading the reviews of a recent play of mine.

As its first project to raise funds for British war relief, the recently organized War Relief Association of American Youth, Inc., will give a large "Victory for Britain" cocktail party and dance on March 1 at the Pierre. Expecting an attendance of nearly 2,000 persons, the sponsoring organization has reserved the entire ballroom suite for the party, which will be set in a patriotic decor.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Representatives of the Monmouth Park Racing Association, holder of the lone horse-racing license thus far issued by the State Racing Commission, for a track at Elkwood Park near here, are scheduled to meet on Monday with the State Commission in the hope of arranging financing details which will permit racing here this summer.

ARTURO TOSCANINI will conduct the Chicago Symphony Orchestra for a single concert in Chicago on April 24. It will be an unprecedented step for the maestro. In the years that he has been conducting in this country he has led only three American symphony orchestras, the New York Philharmonic, the Philadelphia and the NBC with which he is now connected.

GALVESTON, Texas -- The "Pageant of the Americas" will be a feature of the annual Mardi Gras in this Gulf Coast city from Feb. 21 to 25. Letters will be sent by Governor W. Lee O'Daniel to Governors of forty-seven States, urging them to attend. Sponsors of this year's fete say many high dignitaries will be present.

There is probably no other single subject which perplexes the city gardener to the extent soil does. To the average novice soil is soil and fertilizers come in little bags. To the country gardener soil is a live, fertile compound which, with little human aid, grows flowers, fruits and vegetables.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The United States has been requested by the Italian Government to close its consulates at Naples and Palermo, giving as a reason its desire to keep foreigners out of danger, the State Department revealed today. The consulates have not yet been closed, the State Department said, but presumably they will be, as it is not this government's policy to keep offices open where they are not wanted.

A volunteer service bureau has been set up within the last fortnight by the College and University Women's Center. Although its functions will be adjusted to the flow of events in this country, its primary purpose is to provide from a vast membership volunteer workers for recognized relief agencies.

THERE is talk in Washington that the Vice Presidency is to be rated as a full-time job, that it is no longer to be regarded as the butt of cartoonists. So it seemed eminently proper to talk to Mr. Throttlebottom about it. Mr. Throttlebottom, of course, is Victor Moore, whose term as the perplexed Vice President in "Of Thee I Sing" ended some years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general, proposed today that the Supreme Court be asked to reverse some of its previous anti-trust decisions in cases involving the Clayton and Sherman acts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- How the countries of Latin America increased their buying from the United States 50 per cent in the first year of the war to replace European supply sources, but have found exchange controls, financial aid from the United States, marketing agreements and promotion of inter-Latin American trade an inadequate substitute for European markets is described in a review by the Department of Commerce in the current issue of Foreign Commerce Weekly.

THERE has been an immense recrudescence of interest in recorded music, and the recent price reductions by the major companies have stimulated the renewed interest. It has also brought new record collectors into the market, and in such a field there is always bewilderment and confusion for the person who does not know his way around music, performers and equipment.

OUT of England comes a steady stream of fashion material. Undaunted by the hardships that beset them the designers carry forward their creation of suits and dresses; the manufacturers continue the making of their fine tweeds and suitings; and those who produce the many accessories such as sweaters and leather goods which we are accustomed to receive from England are still sending them over.

WHEN you have finished reading "Sweepstakes" you are likely to feel that the sale of sweepstakes tickets is a charitable project -- not because of the benefit to the sponsoring hospital but because of the spiritual lift that goes with taking a chance.

A unique honor has come to a young Negro, aged 22. Julian Dempsey has the distinction of having designed an evening gown for Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, which she has worn this year upon two formal occasions at the White House.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 15 -- An announcement from Washington published here today that the island of Vieques was to become a major Eastern Caribbean Navy base and that $35,000,000 for its development is included in the new $900,000,000 Navy emergency bill came as a complete surprise to most residents of Puerto Rico.

Callers were numerous at the White House last Jan. 9. Cabinet members came to talk with the President, and so did Democratic leaders of the Congress. That the talks had to do with foreign policy was evident, for the ranking members of both Senate and House Foreign Affairs Committees were among the callers.

IN admittedly the most critical days England has seen since the Battle of Hastings, English authors manage to snatch precarious moments to record something of the life and temper of a people fated daily to face death in an immense struggle for national survival unprecedented in its history.

A gala performance of Dr. Edgar Stillman-Kelley's "Pilgrim's Progress," enlisting many well known choral groups and soloists, will be given March 4 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria in behalf of the Junior Scholarship Fund of the National Federation of Music Clubs.

For a generation the world has been obsessed with the fear of monetary inflation. Today in Britain not even the thunder of falling bombs and the ever-present apprehension of invasion can submerge that old fear. Lord Balfour of Burleigh rose in the House of Lords the other day to warn the Government that the "vicious spiral of inflation" was already in operation.
LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

Magistrate Anna M. Kross, addressing the 500 kindergarten teachers who attended the twenty-fifth annual luncheon of the New York Public School Kindergarten Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, said that this country's first line of defense lay in the building of the biggest, strongest and sanest educational system in the world.

Nazi rule in Norway is taking off its mask. The fair promises with which it sought at first to make conquest palatable, and lessen opposition by the conquered, are being cast aside; they have served their purpose. Now it is admitted that German victory in the larger war will not mean the restoration of Norwegian independence, which Major Quisling, the willing instrument of aggression, has been promising his dupes.

Intensification of effort on the part of commercial banks throughout the nation to assist the defense program by financing industry, is now beginning to make an impressive showing. In New York City and in other financial centers of the country, current totals of "commercial, industrial and agricultural loans" are now at, or near, to record high levels.

Lights were cowled last week on streets once walked by Swift and Thomas Moore, by Parnell and Edmund Burke, by William Butler Yeats. There was no black-out along the Liffey's banks, but Dublin was in semi-darkness against attacks that might draw Eire into Europe's war.

That running automaton from South Bend, J. Gregory Rice, stole the show from one of the most spectacular mile finishes ever unreeled at the New York A.C. games before 14,000 roaring fans in Madison Square Garden last night. The man who flits over the boards with even more tireless speed than the Finns broke the world two-mile record with one of the most astounding performances in the history of foot racing.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- A victory in his specialty, the 220-yard dash, plus a second place in the mile, today enabled speedy Ted Ellenwood of Amsterdam to take opening-day honors in the New York State speed-skating championships.

The findings of the American Legion mission studying civilian defense functions in England will determine the defense program of the American Legion after the voluntary national defense registration of the nation's 1,078,119 legionnaires next Saturday, Commander George K. Johnson of the Board of Education Post of New York said yesterday.

PUBLIC libraries usually have a rich, stirring odor of much-read books mixed with a fugitive scent of dampness. The Fifty-eighth Street Branch of the New York Public Library with its drama section, has this and something more.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Free competition must be restored as the fundamental element of the economic life of the United States, or government price control is inevitable, the Federal Trade Commission reported today to the Temporary National Economic Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The current attempt at the quick organization of an all-Western Hemisphere front has brought the United States face to face with a variety of political, economic and psychological problems, some expected and some unexpected.

RESEARCH in the petroleum industry has expanded 539 per cent in the past eleven years, Dr. William A. Hamor, associate director of the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research at Pittsburgh, says in a survey reported in Industrial and Engineering Chemistry, journal of the American Chemical Society.

With forty-six State Legislatures in session, many measures bearing directly or indirectly upon retail installment selling are being introduced, reports in retail credit circles here indicated last week. Some were regarded as of a "stop-gap" nature pending completion of broader regulatory bills, while others were held well-intentioned but likely to have adverse effects from a social standpoint as well as imposing unnecessary handicaps upon business.

NOT the least stirring phenomenon in the present strange and tragic state of the world is the fact that two of the nations now paying most dearly for the sacrifices they have made in the cause of freedom make their appeals for political and remedial action not through political leaders or propaganda but in the names of their most representative musicians.

THE story last week was not of tourists and surf-board riders and the bright sun upon the mile-long rollers racing in to break in fluted sprays of foam upon the shining sands of Waikiki. The story last week was of fighting ships and fighting men and guns.

A novel program featuring a dress "song parade" of music identified with each branch of the United States military service will be presented at the entertainment and supper party to be given Wednesday at the Algonquin Supper Club for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.
Mrs. Fielding Lewis Taylor has arrived at the Vanderbilt from Winter Park, Fla.

The uncommon brilliancy and interest of the concert given by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hail was due, of course, to the conductor and orchestra and also in considerable part to the choice of new as well as old music to be performed.

DEVELOPMENT of a new style and employment of new subject-matter are both evident in the recent paintings by B.J.O. Nordfeldt, who is currently showing at the Lilienfeld Galleries. Gone are the dramatic semi-abstract landscapes of earlier days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- One hundred and eighty-six national defense projects, aggregating $41,066,918 in WPA funds, were approved in January, Howard O. Hunter, Acting WPA Commissioner, announced today.

A STEP toward the development of cooperative film production on a basis comparable to the drama's group theatre movement is being taken by four local documentary film-makers who have banded together under the corporate title of Film Unit, Inc., to produce independently feature-length pictures for theatrical distribution.

OFFERING an excellent opportunity to the average young man between the ages of 20 and 27 who is about to choose a career, the United States Army Air Corps has started an intensive country-wide campaign to secure more prospective "flying cadet" candidates.

VICHY, France, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Following the resignation of Marcel Peyrouton, Interior Minister, today, it was reported that the Chief of State, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, might convoke the Council of Ministers early next week to effect further changes in the Cabinet.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 15 -- President Getulio D. Vargas received many congratulatory telegrams today from coffee growers and exporters on the three-year financing plan announced yesterday.

ATHENS, Feb. 15 -- Along the entire Albanian front, from Lake Ochrida to the sea, Greek offensive operations continued successfully throughout the day, according to an official statement made tonight. The Greek troops are said to have taken several objectives, inflicting heavy losses on the Italians.

As a means of bringing about better cooperation and understanding between Americans and Britons, a mission of American religious leaders to England was proposed by Rabbi Israel Goldstein in a sermon at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, west of Broadway, yesterday.

FOR the first time since the period from 1852 to 1870, when Napoleon III ruled as the French Emperor and the postal paper of France was inscribed "Empire Francais," a French stamp has appeared without the wording "Republique Francaise," or the abbreviation "Repub. Franc." or the letters "RF."

Foreign traders dealing with the Far East were suffering from the severest attack of "jitters" at the close of last week that they have experienced since the siege of Shanghai as they awaited word of new developments. While both exporters and importers are hoping the latest crisis will evaporate as have so many in the past, they agree that conditions in Japan are such that her future actions are unpredictable.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Discovery of a magnetic "knee" between North America and Europe, which accounts for poor radio transmission, was reported here today by Dr. H.E. Halborg, an R.C.A. engineer, who spoke at a symposium on earth's magnetism held by the American Philosophical Society.

ASIDE from the legal expenses of a two-year court fight, Samuel Goldwyn's release last week from his United Artists distributing contract cost him no less than $300,000 and according to some estimates, a good deal more.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -- Two field goals by Chuck Viguers in the last minute of play gave Pennsylvania a 40-36 victory over Yale tonight, the Red and Blue's second over the Elis this season in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

WHEN an actress who has achieved the success of Helen Menken on the legitimate stage deserts Broadway for more than two years and turns her back on lucrative Hollywood offers, yet continues at the microphone, It indicates that radio has gained common footing with its sister arts as a dramatic medium.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- The addition of a new class of racing power boats and the probability of several trials against world records for the mile are giving added interest to the annual Washington's Birthday Regatta at the Palm Beach Yacht Club to be held next Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

At last night's concert of the NBC Symphony Orchestra in Radio City, Arturo Toscanini devoted the first half of his program to two works he had never directed before anywhere. They were Haydn's "Toy" symphony and the "Joachim" symphony of Schubert.

High excitement prevailed yesterday in the offices of the No Foreign War Committee as Verne Marshall, its chairman, called his first press conference in weeks to announce that he had just discovered that "London is in the Western Hemisphere" and that President Roosevelt might use a "joker" in the Selective Service Act to send "an army of 4,000,000" to England.

Teachers of the English language, if they have their heart in their work, should be busy clipping from the newspapers and filing for reference and study. A great deal of good English is being spoken at the present moment in both big English-speaking nations.

With fifteen schools represented, the annual Public Schools Athletic League fencing tournament got under way on the strips of the Washington Irving High School yesterday. Seven teams are participating in Division 1 and the remainder in Division 2.

SO great is the rapidity of events in Europe, according to Fred Bate, NBC's London correspondent since 1933, that any opinion on the present situation is apt to be old-fashioned soon after it has been expressed. Recently arrived from abroad, Mr. Bate carefully measured every word he said, and then often added "this is off the record."

Commenting on the way in which two prisoners arriving recently at Rikers Island penitentiary had exchanged sentences and one had been released after nine days before the fraud was discovered, Harry T. Ashworth, Acting Warden, said yesterday that fingerprints are taken of arrivals to make certain of the prisoner's identity when discharged.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Feb. 15 -- At 9 o'clock this morning this military reservation was a beehive of activity with final preparations for the presentation of a Distinguished Flying Cross to Captain William T. Hudnell Jr. The 3,500 men taking part were being formed into units ready to the parade grounds, 350 officers were at their places and fifty-four of the latest Curtiss P-40 camouflaged pursuit planes were on the line.

Copies of historical American documents will be presented to various institutions this week in patriotic ceremonies arranged by the women's division of the Committee of Americans. The events have been planned to mark Bill of Rights Week as designated by Governor Lehman.

MARITIME ART -- which its editor, Walter Abell, believes to be Canada's first art magazine -- is the newest publication in the field received here. It is the organ of the Maritime Art Association: an association of museums, college art departments, art clubs, etc., in the three so-called "Maritime Provinces" -- Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island.

AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 15 -- Alumni, faculty and students of Massachusetts State College are united this Winter in a series of moves which may result in the most significant period of progress the college has ever known.

PATERSON, N.J. -- After nearly half a century at one career, Miss Grace Ann Comstock, 70 years of age, embarked on another Tuesday when she resigned from the Quackenbush Company Department Store to become the wife of Russel Kimble, 74 years old, of Pompton Plains.

The United States Gypsum Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1940, net income of $7,052,974 after depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and provision of $1,340,000 for excess profits tax and other charges.

MARCUS GOODRICH worked as steadily as possible on his novel "Delilah" from 1926 through most of 1940. Now, as he thinks about his book, his manner is somewhat like that of Balboa on the peak at Darien.

FOR years the Canadian "bush" flier has been engaged in some of the most spectacular commercial flying known to aviation without much recognition. Ferrying heavy mining machinery and equipment into the wild "Down North" section of Canada, carrying mining engineers and prospectors to spots accessible only on foot or with dog teams, and maintaining supply lines between isolated mining camps and civilization during the bitter Winter months was strictly routine.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15 -- A major event of the season was the opening of an exhibition of contemporary American art at the Four Arts with a tea and preview for members this afternoon and a large reception tonight. The exhibition includes ninety-five canvases from museums exhibits and dealers in this country and Canada.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 15 -- The sun was out for the first time during Middlebury's annual Winter carnival today as Rog Simpter, Dartmouth junior, gave one of the finest exhibitions of the local season, making two jumps of more than ninety feet on the seventy-five-foot Chipman jump to give Dartmouth victory over a valiant Middlebury team in one of the closest ski meets of recent years.

The board of trustees of the Polytechnic Institute (Instituto Politecnico) of Puerto Rico will hold its annual meeting after dinner tomorrow at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Roswell Miller Jr., 9 East Ninetieth Street. Since thirteen of its eighteen trustees live in the United States proper, the annual meeting is always held in New York.

MOSCOW, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Communist party opened its eighteenth all-union conference in the Kremlin tonight amid Soviet press predictions that it would play an "historical role" in bolstering Soviet might.
ROME, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 15 -- Coaching at Notre Dame is a "dream come true" for Frank Leahy.

TORONTO, Feb. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Tentative dates for the Stanley Cup play-offs were set today at a meeting of the National Hockey League's board of governors, at which President Frank Calder reported that the league had shown a 10 per cent increase so far this season in gate receipts compared with last season.

The Chamber Music Guild Quartet will give a benefit concert on Friday night at the Town Hall for the newly organized Belgians in Britain Division of Bundles for Britain, Inc. It will be the first benefit for the division which was formed last week upon the liquidation of the Belgian Relief Fund, Inc.

SIX months after the death of Sir Hubert Spain his son, Roger, who has been exploring in Tibet, becomes convinced that his father was murdered and he sets out to find the man who did it. He has only a tenuous clue to the man's identity and no idea as to the motive for the crime, but his determination makes up for his lack of definite information.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Hundreds of Indians from every part of the United States are voluntarily joining the armed forces of the country, according to reports received by John Collier, Commissioner of Indian Affairs. In addition to these, many others are preparing or defense service in technical capacities.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 15 (AP) -- At least three persons were killed and scores injured today when the sudden onslaught of a hurricane, sometimes blowing 100 miles an hour, crumpled houses and sank the giant British Airways flying boat Clyde in the Tagus River.

WILLIAM BILLINGS, who lived from 1746 to 1800, belongs among the first American composers. A tanner by trade, he was self-taught in music and in time he instructed in and theorized about the art. He was a Yankee and a patriot; his friends were Sam Adams and Paul Revere who was his engraver.

Members of society and theatrical circles are collaborating in final plans to present Friday night in Radio City a gala "Carnival for Britain." A special midnight program in the Radio City Music Hall and other divertissements in adjacent Rockefeller Plaza resturants will offer subscribers to the fete a varied round of entertainment.

RECENT years have brought evidence that Bronson Alcott was very much more than the transcendental father of Louisa May Alcott. He was a great pioneer in the field of American education, as well, and our knowledge of this is now fortified and deepened by Miss Dorothy McCuskey's "Bronson Alcott, Teacher."

FAILURE or refusal of stations or networks to broadcast certain programs provoked seventy-one complaints to the Federal Communications Commission during 1940, the largest number in any class, while news programs drew fifty-nine protests, it was learned from a transcript on executive hearings before the House Appropriations Committee.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 15 -- The British forces operating in Italian Somaliland, after having taken Afmadu on Tuesday, joined with the South African Air Force and the navy yesterday and assaulted and captured the port of Kismayu, the British command reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb 15 (AP) -- Development of Guam and Samoa, Pacific islands, as naval aviation "lookout stations" was recommended unanimously late today by the House Naval Committee after it heard secret testimony from the Navy high command regarding the Far Eeastern situation.

The N.Y.U. fencing team won its second meet of the season yesterday, stopping St. John's, 14 -- 13, on the Washington Square strips. With the score tied at 12 -- 12, Arthur Franck and Tony Lombardo registered saber victories for N.Y.U.

Now in the midst of grim discussion of defense and armament it is pleasant to be reminded of another side of Army life. There have been a few books about the Army for young people, but this one tells of the easy-going, friendly post life as Army children know it, with its closely knit ties. all the more valued for their transiency.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Dr. Frank C. Jordan, 75, nationally known astronomer and director of Allegheny Observatory at the University of Pittsburgh, and his wife, Harriet, 72, died in a fire in their North Side home tonight.

Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins said yesterday that defense needs might compel a limitation of the production of certain types of foods and other domestic supplies, for which housewives may have to find substitutes. She was a speaker on the "Calling All Citizens" program of the Active Citizens' League, broadcast by Station WABC and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The International Flower Show, to be held at the Grand Central Palace from March 17 to 22, will have as a general theme "Pan-America," with colorful gardens and exhibits from South and Central America, Mexico and Canada on display on the main floor and throughout the other three floors of exhibition space.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Feb. 15 -- Ohio State and Indiana of the Big Ten and Nebraska's Big Six champions swept almost everything in sight tonight as four meet records fell during the eighteenth running of the University of Illinois Relay Carnival.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Yale swimmers outclassed a game Ohio State University team today to win a dual meet, 51 1/2 to 23 1/2.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -- Robert J. Bolts, who has confessed operating a so-called investment system in which clients lost between $1,000,000 and $2,500,000, will be arraigned Tuesday in Quarter Sessions Court to answer to 186 State indictments charging embezzlement and fraudulent conversion.

VICHY, France, Feb. 15 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain had two pairs of shoes, both worn, and needed a third. They were delivered to him yesterday for the current price after he had filled out a blank filed at the City Hall in Vichy to be passed upon by a special commission with power to demand the presentation of all shoes belonging to the applicant.

A GIRL on hospital ambulance service learns a lot about the nature of man that is outside the experience of a philosophy professor. She discovers that the Bowery tramp whose head she sews up in a precinct station is more grateful than any other patient she will ever have if she lives to practice until she is 80.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Feb. 15 -- Wesleyan defeated Amherst in a Little Three basketball game before a large week-end crowd today, 43 to 25.

BERLIN, Feb. 15 -- An official German news agency dispatch from Paris carried excerpts from an article in the Nouveaux Temps by the French expert on international law, Louis Le Fur, who is reportedly to charge that the United States "misuses" 3,200,000,000 gold francs left in the United States when the armistice was signed between France and Germany last June.

A SOUTHEAST COAST ENGLISH PORT, Feb. 15 -- The British disclosed today that they are utilizing a system of sea fortresses begun nearly a century and a half ago against the threatened Napoleonic invasion as a part of the complex defensive network set up to keep Reichsfuehrer Hitler's forces away.

Mrs. Thomas Shaw Hale heads the group in charge of the plans for a supper dance to be held on March 5 in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center to augment the camp fund of Greenwich House. Proceeds will be used in the maintenance of Camp Herbert Parsons at La Grangeville, N.Y., a project of Greenwich House, which provides vacations in healthful surroundings for 400 needy children of New York.

ONCE more the American Institute of Graphic Arts has made through its annually appointed jury a selection of the Fifty Books of the Year, chosen from among the hundreds submitted by the trade publishers and the university and other presses as outstanding examples of good book-making.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 15 -- Miss Peggy Klipstein of Greenwich Academy won the championship in the midwinter junior riding competition at the Round Hill Stables today. Miss Kathleen Jennings, also a student at the Greenwich school, was awarded the reserve.

Further expansion of American aid to Britain is shown by the December export figures of aircraft shipped from the United States. The 308 airplanes exported in that month to Britain and Canada exceeded the total for all previous months except last August. December shipments were at the rate of 3,700 a year.

FOR a while it seems that all of the Royal Air Force stationed in Egypt is going to fall in love with Veronica. She is one of those serene, natural charmers with no tendency to flirtation, and the gayer ladies of the force resent her, while the men fall in shoals.

"FINLANDIA" is the inevitably right title for this biography, for, as Elliott Arnold makes plain, Sibelius's music is the expression of a people and a country. This is the first biography we have had for young people of a contemporary musician, and though it would have been welcome at any time, its subject has a special significance now.

The proposed refinancing program of the Republic Steel Corporation has attracted considerable attention in investment circles, not alone by its size, but principally because of a general "streamlining" of indenture provisions pertaining to sinking fund payments and of the mortgage itself.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 15 -- Cornell's hard playing quintet took a 1-point lead in the first minute of the second half tonight, then spent the rest of the time turning back Dartmouth rallies to win, 31 -- 27, The Big Green tried vainly to break through the Ithacans' defense.

A four-cylinder taxicab is one of five new models just added by Willys-Overland of Toledo to its 1941 lines. The company also announced a Speedway coupe recently, adding to its Americar line of passenger cars. The new units are a Speedway sedan designed as a companion model to the coupe, a station wagon, cab pick-up truck, cab-over-engine panel truck and the taxi.

BERLIN, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The flotilla of German warships that has reported in the past two days sinking fourteen British ships in one Atlantic convoy left one of the vessels afloat to serve as a rescue ship for crews of the others, D.N.B., official German news agency, said today.

The Ballet Theatre last night presented Antony Tudor's "Jardin aux Lilas" for the first time this season at the Majestic Theatre and thereby put us all again in its debt. Surely this is one of the great ballets of our time, extending the range of its medium away from the brilliant and trivial into the intuitive and compassionate.

THE sixth season of the Ravinia Festival at Ravinia Park, near Chicago, will open July 1 and continue for six weeks. Sir Thomas Beecham will conduct the Chicago Symphony Orchestra during the opening fortnight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Mortgage foreclosures on city homes declined 25 per cent last year to the lowest level since 1936, the federal home loan bank board reported today.

I am wholly pro-British. It is possible that Great Britain cannot defeat Germany without our aid; but it is certain that we cannot defeat Germany without British aid. If Great Britain loses the war, the United States will probably cease to be a first-class power and become, at best, a second-class power.

LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 16 -- German warplanes dropped high explosive and incendiary bombs on widely scattered parts of Britain early today, following considerable activity during daylight yesterday and at night, when they visited many districts of England, Scotland and Wales.
LACONIA, N.H., Feb. 15 -- Four men were drowned and a fifth was rescued after two automobiles plunged through the ice on Winnisquam and Merry Meeting Lakes today.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 15 -- Omelet, a 14-to-1 shot, captured the $10,000 added Santa Margarita Handicap over a sloppy track before a comparatively small crowd at Santa Anita Park today.

THIS is the year that marks an important anniversary for Iceland, now that seven centuries have slipped by since the death of its great historian, Snorre Sturlason. Possibly the plans begun some years ago for a proper observance of this event have not been wholly disrupted by the war.

Those old friends of warm Summer evenings at the Fair, the Polish, Iceland, and Swedish restaurants, have moved into town bag and baggage. The Polish Restaurant, indeed, had opened in New York before the Fair and had moved from town to Flushing for the duration.

TORONTO, Feb. 15 -- Gordie Drillon, out of action for three weeks with a shoulder injury, returned to the National Hockey League wars tonight to give the second-place Toronto Maple Leafs a 4-3 decision over the world champion New York Rangers.

MISS COVERT'S homely, folksy, deeply felt story of some of the people of an Oklahoma town and the farming country around it is a novel of sensibility, sentimental but on a realistic plane. Friends and publishers should save storytellers from their "Forewords."

Bedrooms in pink, blue and other pastel shades, so popular in the early Nineteen Hundreds, are reappearing in our more sophisticated age as a foil for too much shining modernity. Even the most determined career woman is likely to strike the note of femininity in the decoration of her bedroom, and the young daughter of the house as a rule casts her vote for daintiness rather than tailored severity.

Opportunities for consumers to pose a variety of questions to representatives of industry and to hear replies and discussion on the topics in which they are particularly interested are included in a day-long program to be given on Tuesday under the auspices of the Advertising Women of New York.

DALLAS, Texas, Feb. 15 -- The embattled forces of the railroads and motor trucking interests of Texas have again carried their fight over the truck load limit law into the Legislature at Austin, with the railroads seemingly on the losing end.

WITH this novel, "West to North," Compton Mackenzie rounds out the first 2,000 pages of what it is fair to assume he regards as his master work, his enormous fictional biography of an Englishman of his own generation.

The sale of scrap iron to Japan by the United States was cited yesterday by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt as an example of this government's policies that calls for more active participation of women in running the country.

ROCKLEIGH, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Opening its competition in the fourth annual polo tournament of the New York Athletic Club, Westchester, led by Gordon Wright, tallied three goals in the last two minutes of play to beat Pegasus, 13 to 11, at the Pegasus Arena tonight.

TRAVEL Lines: A Washington's birthday cruise is announced by the Colonial Steamship Company, leaving on Feb. 21 at 6 P.M. for Providence, R.I., returning on Sunday. Shipboard entertainment and a tour of the historic landmarks of Providence are included in the price. . . .

THE Federal Communications Commission issued orders last week to 795 standard broadcast station licensees, informing them of what changes in frequency assignments are contemplated in keeping with the North American Regional Broadcasting Agreement and the recommendations adopted in the commission's resolution of Jan. 31, 1941.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Three years ago Colgate University's introductory course in Greek had only two students, and officials were pondering the feasibility of offering the class only in alternate years.

THE word is getting around that there are odd goings on over at WOR these nights, come 6:45. From Mondays through Fridays a brash young man by the name of Henry Morgan, an announcer turned humorist, is striking a droll note in radio comedy.

LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- A correspondent of Reuters, British news agency, who explored deep in the wilderness of Ethiopia, has brought out a story from the East African jungle of how adventurous Britons are turning the natives into potent allies against Italy.

MADISON, N.J., Feb. 15 -- A four-year required program of physical education with letter-grades and a final examination has been adopted by the faculty as integral part of the curriculum of Brothers College of Liberal Arts. No student will be graduated from Brothers College until he has demonstrated a playing knowledge and a knowledge of the rules of four-team-games and of seven non-team games.

THE Folmer Graflex Corporation has just announced the Graphic View Camera. This 4x5 camera is made entirely of metal. It has been designed to supply the photographer with a view camera, flexible, strong and of the highest craftsmanship.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Feb. 15 -- The leadership which American educational institutions, particularly of a technical nature, have taken in cooperative research projects with industry is being illustrated at Purdue University.

LET us make no mistake about it: the abstract artists are tremendously in earnest. Some of the art they produce may seem to you screwy, and on an emotional count it may be true that no spectator's pulse is affected in the slightest by any of the art the abstract artists give us.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15 -- After writing three suicide notes, Edgar Logan Hill, 58, a Winter resident of Miami Beach and formerly assistant general manager of the Erie Railroad, shot himself to death yesterday in the bathroom of his home. He had been in ill health for some time.
Norman Blackman, saber star, took the final bout yesterday against M.I.T., to give the Columbia fencers their first victory of the campaign. The Lions prevailed, 14 1/2 to 12 1/2, on the home strips.

Having heard two performances of "Alceste" at the Metropolitan Opera House recently, I cannot help but compare this production with others heard abroad and also the interpretations of Miss Lawrence and Miss Bampton with the one of Germaine Lubin at the Paris Opera.

LAST Thursday Postmaster General Frank C. Walker announced that the 3-cent stamp to be released on March 4 to commemorate the admittance of Vermont to the Union on March 4, 1791, will be purple and will illustrate the Capitol in Montpelier. Under the picture will be inscribed "Vermont 150th Anniversary of Statehood" in two lines.

AS a theme for a novel, the adventures of a Methodist farm family in a Methodist college town do not, perhaps, sound very promising. One would be inclined to expect a tale on the drab and dour side -- or another attack, even, upon Middle-Western bigotry.

MOBILE, Ala. -- Spring comes suddenly to the Gulf Coast, and a flood of color ushers it in. The most spectacular colors are those of the azalea, the flowering shrub which in the Mobile area reaches tree-like dimensions. For most of the year the azalea is merely a bush modestly covered with dark green leaves.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -- An assertion that Pennsylvania industry was "pacing the nation" in the defense program was followed today by a warning to 500 industrialists of this area that they must prepare to double or triple their efforts.

Steamship operators in the United States-South Africa Conference are planning to increase freight rates in the trade by 15 per cent, effective March 15, it was disclosed yesterday. The rise will come at the peak of the service's traffic volume and will follow a general upward trend in shipping rates elsewhere.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 15 -- Nat Holman's City College of New York Basketball team called upon Al Goldstein in the final minute tonight and the diminutive star's shot defeated Xavier University, 41 -- 39, before 3,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Debate in Congress on the bill to aid Britain is revolving about the issue primarily, not of aid to Britain, but of the powers of the President. Upon this issue the Senate this coming week will continue the debate. The question before the Congress and the country which has evolved relates not so much to the objective of aiding Britain as it does to the means for attaining that objective.

NOW that the feasibility of flying the Atlantic non-stop between Africa and the northern tip of South America has been demonstrated by the clippers, a rapid expansion in transatlantic air service is promised. An increase in the number of flights will be made by Pan American Airways throughout the Spring and Summer with the delivery of each new flying boat.

BERLIN, N.H., Feb. 15 -- Running with daring and skill throughout the grueling course, Wendall Broomhall, Finnish athlete from the Chisholm Ski and Outing Club of Rumford, Me., easily triumphed over a formidable field in the Federation Internationale de Ski's sanctioned eighteen-kilometer cross-country race today.
Referring to James P. Warburg's interesting letter in THE TIMES of Feb. 2, I am sorry to say that the solution that he advances seems not fully adequate, although he came pretty close to it.

WHEN John Pored was a young man in Russia in 1903 he caught his first glimpse of motion-picture film in a Moscow camera shop -- a thirty-foot strip of celluloid showing a train in motion. He said to himself then: "That is what I like and what I will do.

Wall Street, since the start of the second World War, has superseded all other great centers as the financial cross-roads of the world. But, while the outside world has conceded this honor, it is purely a nominal title, since Wall Street itself is scraping the bottom for stray crumbs of profit.

Operations last year of the Childs Company and all subsidiaries resulted in a net loss of $719,153 after depreciation, interest, amortization, taxes and other deductions. The net loss for 1939 was $272,983.

ANY one who thinks that this book's title connotes mere sentiments of encouragement must disabuse his mind at once of that mistaken idea. "China Shall Rise Again" is a remarkable book; and in nothing is it more remarkable than in its clear definiteness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Two lawyers representing the Columbia Gas and Electric Company admitted today before a Senate committee investigating wire-tapping that "certain conversations" in the office of counsel in a rate case in Ohio against the utility had been recorded, but said they did not know how it had been done.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 15 (UP) -- The first of twenty-six huge four-motored long-range bombers built by the Consolidated Aircraft for Great Britain took off from Lindbergh Field today on the first leg of a flight to England.
The Brooklyn College swimming team registered its fifth consecutive victory of the season yesterday, defeating the University of Connecticut mermen by 50 -- 25 at the Brooklyn pool.

As a result of largely increased imports during 1940 this country is assured of at least a year's supply of jewels for national defense purposes. Jewels, because of their hardness, make perfect bearings for use in aviation instruments, fire-control apparatus, watches, chronometers and other precision instruments.
LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 16 -- A heavy attack on Channel ports -- Calais, Dunkerque and Boulogne -- was reported by watchers on the British coast last night.

PORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Miss Doris Hart, 15-year-old Miami star, scored an upset today in the annual Fort Lauderdale midwinter invitation tennis tournament by defeating Miss Pauline Betz of Rollins College, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, in the semi-finals.

An exhibition and sale of paintings to be conducted this week under the auspices of the American Auxiliary Committee de I'Union des Femmes de France, Inc., will be opened tomorrow at the headquarters of the Committee of Mercy, 435 Park Avenue.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 15 -- Three hundred and thirty-four German men in civilian attire arrived in Varna yesterday, according to reports received from that Black Sea port of Northern Bulgaria.

French eighteenth century bronzes brought high prices yesterday at a sale of these and other art objects of the period from the collection of the late Mrs. F. Gray Griswold, formerly contained in her residence on Park Avenue. A total of $46,972 was received at the close of the sale, held in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -- The bootleg coal miner, a sociological phenomenon who has given Pennsylvania Governors headaches and insomnia, who has drawn condemnation from officials of neighboring States and who has won the sympathy of court juries in the hard-coal region, is to have a chance to go back into legitimate industry.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 15 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 15 -- The Naval Academy basketball team defeated William and Mary College, 51 to 32, today before 4,500 fans, including a number of the new reserve midshipmen sent here for ninety days of training under the defense program.

The gradual price advances taking place at wholesale have tended to simplify the retailer's pricing problem, at least for the present and probably up to the end of June, comment in well-informed merchandising circles last week indicated. Price increases for the most part are being averaged, price lines are being maintained, and any increase in expenses is running behind the rise in dollar volume and faster turnover.

IT could scarcely have been expected that the Publishers' Circular's census of books published in the United Kingdom during 1940 would give much occasion for cheerfulness. The best one can say is that, all things considered, it might have been worse.

With lengthening days, gardeners are beginning to look forward to the first brave blooms of Spring, and among these none are more welcome than the spreading gay masses of the Mountain or Moss Pink, listed in catalogues as Phlox subulata.

Mayor La Guardia cut the blue ribbon strung across the steps at Grand Central Palace officially to open the sixth annual National Sportsmen's Show at noon yesterday, and then the vanguard of the thousands that were to make it one of the best-attended opening days streamed into the building.

A national drive for funds to aid the "free French" in England and Africa will be launched by France Forever, a de Gaulle war relief organization here, on March 3, with its first benefit undertaking, the American premiere performance of the French film "Pepe Le Moko," at the World Theatre.

"HOW TO GET A JOB IN AVIATION," by Charles S. Mattoon. Wasting no words, the author of this book, who is personnel director of Curtiss airplane division of Curtiss-Wright, and the contributors have packed into ninety-six pages a wealth of counsel on the first steps in aviation careers.

JOHN GILBERT WINANT, chosen by the President to be Ambassador at the Court of St. James, is a new kind of envoy for that most important of American "listening posts" overseas. In being no professional diplomat, in having independent means and in standing well with the traditional officialdom of Britain, he resembles his predecessors of late years.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15 -- Opening a new athletic rivalry, Yale and Harvard held their first indoor track meet in the Coxe Field gymnasium today. Yale led throughout and won by 56 to 35. The times made and distances achieved will stand as records in future meets at Yale, notable among which will be the first annual Yale-Princeton contest scheduled for next Saturday.

AN acute shortage of airport facilities in the New York City area for private plane owners as well as for operators of schools and non-scheduled passenger services has developed in the past year with a rapidity which threatens to bring such activity in this region to a virtual standstill.

The 154th meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers will open here tomorrow at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, and will continue through Thursday. More than 2,500 mining engineers, metallurgists, geologists, geophysicists, geochemists, finders of ores and petroleum and other experts in metals are expected to come from many parts of the United States, Canada, South and Central America and other countries to attend the sessions.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 15 -- Hunger within three or four months apparently threatens all of Norway. In the southern part of the country the food situation is described in reports today to the Swedish press as "critical," while in the northern provinces conditions are called "tragic."

Activity in New York's wholesale market was good in most departments last week, it was reported yesterday in a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

BACK in school -- Marymount, at Tarrytown-on-Hudson -- Rosalind Russell was the long-legged, snappy-eyed youngster who played all the games the hardest. Also, she was the one who didn't need any cod-liver oil. The problem was one of toning her down, rather than toning her up.

With reference to your obituary notice of His Highness the Maharaja Sri Krishnaraja Wadiyar Bahadur in your issue of Aug. 4, permit me to point out that it is not right to call him the "second wealthiest Indian prince." It would be more correct to say that Mysore is the second wealthiest State.

THERE can be no doubt that the Ballet Theatre got off to a fine start last week. The opening performance of its second season dashed along with such freshness and spirit that those who may have been wondering if the company was really as good as they thought it was last season received a quick and convincing answer.

WHEN a man becomes famous there is considerable scurrying around to find how and why he got that way. The detectives dig into his past. Look what they've turned up on Frank Leahy, the new head coach at Notre Dame. (Frank is athletic director out there, too, but that part can be skipped for the purposes of this essay.

A year ago, when the frosts and snows of 1940's Winter still held Europe in their grasp, fear that Spring would bring wider war spread across the Continent. Scandinavia, then untouched by Blitzkrieg, grew anxious. The Balkans stirred uneasily as reports told of German troops moving toward the Danube border of the Reich.

JOHN HAY -- he was Secretary of State then -- wrote in his diary in June, 1904, about a conversation he had had with a Cabinet colleague, Attorney General Philander C. Knox. "Knox," he recorded, "says that the question of what is to become of Roosevelt after 1908 is easily answered.

The United States Army has sufficient motorized equipment at one camp to form a highway column ninety-seven miles long if it moved at one time, H.E. Hilts of the Federal Public Roads Administration said yesterday in urging States to take immediate steps for handling and routing military traffic on tactical or emergency manoeuvres.

OMAHA, Feb. 15 -- Eight Indians from the Sac and Fox reservation near Tama, Iowa, attached to the 18th Iowa Infantry, will be trained to operate walkie-talkie radio units and field telephones for vital communication between front lines and battalion and regimental headquarters.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- What is war costing the world this year? How does it compare with the cost of the World War a quarter of a century ago?

PREDICTING that 50,000 jobs will be available in aviation this year for young men "who are willing to roll up their sleeves and climb into overalls," Carl Friedlander, president of Aeronca Aircraft, Inc., declared last week that the industry's present need is for production men.

THAT most excellent monthly, Theatre Arts, is celebrating, with the current issue, its twenty-fifth anniversary. While devoted primarily to the world of the theatre, this publication makes it a point to reproduce, year in and year out, a great deal of pertinent art.

CALIFORNIA'S gold rush, which in 1849 and the years following brought the world to the Pacific Coast, has its hitherto untold aspect in the story of the mines, lost or legendary, which always served as a will-o'-the-wisp to bring prospectors to the desert.

The State Insurance Fund experienced its most successful year in 1940, Nicholas W. Muller, executive director, said yesterday in making public figures of operations for the twelve months as filed with the Superintendent of Insurance.

BERLIN, N.H., Feb. 16 -- Extremely hazardous conditions marred the Federation Internationale de Ski tournament today on the lightning-fast 700-foot long Nansen S.C. Hill. The 350-foot high tower was covered with an almost icy surface, the result of today's freeze on top of yesterday's mixture of rain and wet snow, while a 50-mile per hour wind that swept up the valley made for the most dangerous sort of jumping.

John Lowry, president of the Merchants Association of New York, made public yesterday the report of an analysis by the association's research bureau, asserting that, if the budget reduction plan presented to the State Legislature by the association and backed by many taxpayers' groups was accepted, it would be possible readily to bring about the reductions in the stock transfer tax proposed in the Coudert-Mitchell bills.

Food and weather keep thrusting themselves into the war news, insistent reminders that this is not only a contest of air fleets, navies, arsenals, propaganda, third-degree diplomacy, but of people, people whose lives and attitudes are less affected by military and political events than by elemental human needs and the vagaries of nature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A new working arrangement for the operation of the priorities system under which the Army and Navy Munitions Board will determine priority ratings for a "critical list" of military items such as guns, tanks, airplanes and ammunition and the Priorities Division will administer the general field of civilian and commercial needs, was announced today by E.R. Stettinius Jr., Director of Priorities for the Office of Production Management.

Three hundred officers and enlisted men of the "Old Seventh," now the 207th Coast Artillery (Anti-Aircraft) Regiment, attended the first Roman Catholic mass ever to be celebrated in their armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, yesterday morning at 8 o'clock on the occasion of the regiment's departure this week for a year's training at Camp Stewart, Hinesville, Ga.

ROME, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Count Ciano's newspaper, the Telegrafo of Leghorn, today invited President Roosevelt to send an observer to North Africa to investigate Italy's rights to the colonies that have become battlegrounds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Retail sales in New York State totaled $5,578,159,000 in 1939, an increase of 19 per cent over 1935, according to a report by the Bureau of the Census, Department of Commerce. However, the total was 20 per cent under the dollar volume reached in 1929, when the general level of consumer goods prices was substantially higher.

Nothing is more conducive to indigestion than a diet of words and, although we do our best to avoid such fare, today finds us quite satiated as a result of a couple of paragraphs from a last week's column that we have just eaten. We have only one small consolation, which arises from the fact that the hale and hearty Warden of Westchester, Ed Townsend, is also trying essence of peppermint.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Roosevelt's amended lease-lend bill is slated to be called up for debate in the Senate tomorrow under a special Administration urge for haste, with its passage expected to be the signal for further and possibly sweeping reconstruction of the defense set-up in Washington.

Announcement by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission yesterday that strong public support is being received in behalf of the bill to finance a survey of the proposed parkway route between the George Washington Bridge and the Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park was followed by disclaimers from Rockland County officials.

VICHY, France, Feb. 16 -- That department of the French State which has charge of supplies has had its powers steadily extended. It does not confine itself to encouraging the production of certain products under the system previously described in these dispatches.

A drive by the C.I.O. to organize New York City's 14,000 Sanitation Department employes was announced yesterday by Joseph Curran, president of the C.I.O. Greater New York Industrial Union Council and a national vice president of the C.I.O.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 16 (AP) -British General Headquarters issued the following communique today:

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at the previous week's level of 85.4, with no individual changes of more than moderate proportion. Declines in the prices of various hides caused the hide and leather group to fall by 1.4 per cent.

Greg Rice and Les MacMitchell, Les MacMitchell and Greg Rice -- the order doesn't matter -- were the talk of the town yesterday wherever track fans gathered. Those who were at Madison Square Garden Saturday night and those who weren't still were marveling at two of the greatest performances in track history, and if the principals could have heard half the words of praise, they probably would he bushing a week from now.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 16 -- The Archbishop of Zagreb is intervening at the Vatican, seeking the freedom of Catholic priests detained in Croatia in connection with the circulation of political literature, according to information from usually well-informed Croat political circles tonight.

Governor Lehman has recently said, referring to his budget recommendations, that there never was a time when we should make "our resources carry us as far as possible and at the same time as advantageously as possible." The Governor is quite right. Now is the time when we should all be willing to make sacrifices to conserve what we have for the widest common use.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 16 -- British sources reported tonight that they had received information that a scheme for the redistribution of Balkan territories had been offered to Yugoslavia during Reichsfuehrer Hitler's talk with Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch.

Faced with the ever-increasing problem of assisting European Jews both in their native countries and in transit to freedom via far-flung routes along which many have been stranded, the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee held an extraordinary meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday that will serve as a springboard for its 1941 campaign.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Scattered liquidation developed in the lard future market last week and prices declined moderately, with the smaller packers on the selling side presumably hedging. An increase of around 13,000,000 pounds in the supply of lard in cold storage in the United States in January was a surprise to the trade and had some effect on sentiment, as trade reports indicated there had been little or no gain.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- The text of Herbert Hoover's speech here tonight follows:

The distribution of free Federal surplus foods to relief families through Department of Welfare depots and retail food stores will be discontinued on Feb. 28, William Hodson, Commissioner of Welfare announced yesterday.

While the 5.8 per cent gain registered in newspaper advertising linage last month was encouraging to publishers, they were particularly pleased by the increase of almost 12 per cent in classified copy. Classified has always been regarded as a good indicator of advertising trends in newspapers and the January upswing is considered a forecast of gains in other classifications.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- Although there will be five more regattas before Spring officially sets in, the mid-Winter sailing dinghy series at the Larchmont Yacht Club has ended, with Arthur Knapp and his Class B boat Four Deuces and George Isdale with his Class X Queen Mary, the high scorer's.

Miss Helene Rains, N.Y.U. freshman, annexed the senior women's metropolitan A.A. U.220-yard breast-stroke swimming championship yesterday in the London Terrace 75-foot pool. Timed in 3:17.6, Miss Rains took the measure of her Women's Swimming Association team-mate, Miss Lorraine Fischer, who lost the crown she had held for two years.

The Metropolitan Jockey Club, which conducts the racing at Jamaica, will spend more money on stake events during its Spring meeting this year than it did last, it was announced yesterday. Part of this increase will be due to the addition of a new stake, the $10,000 added Grey Lag Handicap, and the increase in value of the Excelsior Handicap.

In an urgent plea for service to mankind that recognizes no differences in race, creed or color, Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, yesterday emphasized the importance today of a spirit of brotherhood, of tolerance, of understanding and of good-will, at the covenant breakfast of District Grand Lodge 1 of B'nai B'rith at the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW SMYRNA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 (AP) -- His tiny craft droning around the course like a bumblebee, Paul Wearly of Muncie, Ind., dominated the annual New Smyrna Beach regatta ending today by annexing Class B. and C honors.

TOKYO, Feb. 16 -- While reassuring the Japanese public regarding the immediate outlook, the government under the lead of the fighting services is steadily clearing the decks for action in an emergency.

Stephen M. Foster has been appointed economic adviser to the New York Life Insurance Company, according to an announcement by George L. Harrison, president. For ten years Mr. Foster has been economist in the investment department of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, specializing in factors affecting money markets and business activity.
Cohu Torrey will open today in their larger quarters at 1 Wall Street. They had been at 14 Wall Street since 1939.

Sad days, indeed, have befallen the once proud New York Rangers. Winners of the Stanley Cup and the hockey championship of the world last April, the Blue Shirts now find themselves unable to win an ordinary National League game.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Germany has "taken over completely" in Rumania with about 350,000 Nazi troops there, Sir Reginald Hoare, recalled British Minister to Bucharest, said today upon his arrival here with his staff aboard the chartered steamer Ismir.

Elmer Rice's play "Flight to the West" is announced to close March 1 at the Guild Theatre after seventy-two performances. The play may tour in the Fall as a subscription offering of the American Theatre Society. The next tenant of the Guild Theatre may be the Orson Welles-John Houseman production of "Native Son," by Richard Wright and Paul Green, which enters rehearsal today, with Canada Lee in the chief role.

The fifty-first annual service of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York was held yesterday afternoon in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street, to commemorate the birth of George Washington and to honor the memory of the fifty-eight members of the society who died during the last year.

The annual report of National Distillers Products Corporation for 1940, signed by Seton Porter, president, shows a net profit of $6,711,962, or $3.28 a share on 2,045,451 outstanding shares, compared with $7,007,124, or $3.43 a share, earned in 1939.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator and former United States High Commissioner in the Philippines, tonight urged the United States to adopt a "strong policy" in the Far East and increase its economic aid to China in the war against Japan.

A plan for improving the flow of traffic near the Manhattan end of Brooklyn Bridge, widening the approaches to the bridge, and at the same time improving the appearance of the bridge plaza by removing the elevated station structure was announced yesterday by Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Borough President.

Strength in the Chinese currencies as represented by a steady upward movement in prices to culminate in new highs for the year, and a firm undertone in the Canadian dollar stood out as the most interesting developments in the foreign exchange market last week.

Seventeen airlines of the United States will make available on March 1 a new monthly installment payment plan for passengers taking air trips costing $50 or more, the Air Traffic Conference of America announced here yesterday.
BERLIN, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Today's communique of the German High Command follows:

BERLIN, Feb. 16 -- A widespread attack by the British Royal Air Force on German bases along the Channel coast last night was repulsed with a loss of five British planes, according to the German High Command's report today.
