Three of the planes shot down were bombers, it was stated, and the others escorting pursuit craft.

WASHINGTON, N.J., Feb. 16 -- Confined to a hospital bed in near-by Phillipsburg, Herman K. Petty, who claims the world's record for non-stop attendance at Sunday School, kept that record intact today when a meeting of the Washington Methodist Sunday School was held in his semiprivate hospital room.

BERLIN, Feb. 16 -- In answer to an alleged British report on the ill effects of food rationing on German mothers and babies, the semi-official German news agency tonight states that not only does the mortality of mothers and new-born babies continue to decrease, but there is a general continued decrease of children's as well as adults' diseases in the Reich.

Denunciations of Mussolini and fascism and affirmations of loyalty to American democracy were applauded vigorously yesterday by 1,500 Italians and Italo-Americans who heard four prominent Italian educators call for the rejection of all totalitarian ideologies at a meeting sponsored by the Mazzini Society at Cooper Union Hall, Sixth Street and Astor Place.

Another scene reminiscent of wartime days was enacted in Pennsylvania Station yesterday afternoon when 1,000 men, women and children gathered at the train gates to watch the departure of an advance detachment of the 207th Coast Artillery (Anti-Aircraft), New York National Guard, the old Seventh Regiment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- In a last-minute counting of noses, supporters of the lease-lend bill said they had listed 14 Republicans, 7 Democrats and Senator La Follette, Progressive, as definitely against the measure, with 2 Democrats and a Republican in the "doubtful" category.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 17 -- Herbert Hoover's plan for supplying small German-occupied countries with food, as enunciated in a Chicago address last night, came as no surprise to the British Government since Mr. Hoover outlined the scheme to Ambassador Halifax a few days ago and was told of some serious objections it would entail, it was said in authoritative quarters today.

Emanuel Feuermann, with Albert Hirsh at the piano, completed the cycle of Beethoven's works for the 'cello and keyboard combination, yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, in the second of two recitals devoted to these compositions. The recital, which was the fourteenth event in the current Town Hall series of the New Friends of Music, was devoted to compositions representing all three periods of the composer's creative career.
DETROIT, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Red Wings squared accounts with the sixth-place Canadiens by winning a National Hockey League game, 2 to 1, tonight before 7,079 spectators.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16 -- Total steel orders slackened slightly in volume last week but were still somewhat in excess of both shipments and production.
Alice Duer Miller's long narrative poem, "Forsaking All Others," which was first published in 1931 and is now out of print, will be put back in circulation on Feb. 25 by Simon Schuster.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 16 -- The Italians lost their last foothold in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan yesterday when continued British harassing forced the garrison to evacuate Kurmuk, just west of the border in the Blue Nile region. British forces reoccupied the town soon after the Italian withdrawal.

In behalf of the Episcopal Actors Guild of America, a card party and entertainment will be held on the afternoon of Feb. 25 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The funds realized will further the many philanthropic activities of the organization, which although it is maintained under the auspices of the Protestant Episcopal Church, is non-sectarian in its membership and ministrations.

THE two Great Big Baers, Maxie and Buddy, are due in New York this morning, and tonight in Philadelphia the heavyweight champion of the world, J. Shufflin' Louis, will have a little debate with one Gus Dorazio. Ho-hum. Maybe it's time to sit down and curl up with a good book.

BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 16 -- Kenneth Kennedy, 21, and Doris Ann Thomas, 21, University of California students, were found dead today in the wreckage of a small monoplane in the Berkeley Hills near Skyline Boulevard. They had been missing twenty-four hours on an announced "joy ride."

Formal nominations by the three legal political parties for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District for the vacancy in the House of Representatives caused by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson are scheduled for tonight. The nomination in each case will be made by members of the county committees within the Congressional district.

A forecast that the shadow of war will turn women to shorter hair styles to save time, material and labor was made last night at the "Hair and Hat-box Revue," presented at the Pennsylvania Hotel by the New York State Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- President Roosevelt was asked today to make it possible for the United States to feed as well as arm the nations fighting the Axis powers.

The surrender by the Vichy government of Dr. Rudolf. Breitscheid, onetime leader of the Social Democratic party in the Reichstag, and Dr. Rudolf Hilferding, former German Finance Minister, to the Nazi regime has come as a shock to their American friends who secured for them United States visitor visas and tried everything humanly possible to free them from the trap in which they were caught by the collapse of France.

Dartmouth's first defeat, by Cornell, and Columbia's rise in the Eastern League, Notre Dame's triumph over N.Y.U., the snapping of C.C.N.Y.'s winning streak, L.I.U.'s recovery and the continued success of Duquesne, Georgetown, George Washington, Rhode Island State and Baltimore were outstanding developments in Eastern basketball last week.

After holding generally steady in the early dealings last week, cotton prices subsequently weakened as selling pressure increased. At the close of the market on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines for the week of 18 to 23 points.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Liquidation of wheat futures by smaller speculators was largely responsible for a further decline in prices last week, with the May position dropping to new low level since late in September; the new-crop months went to a new seasonal low.

CHICAGO, Monday, Feb. 17 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Teachers, after thirty-five hours of almost continuous discussion, adjourned its sessions early today with no official intimation of what action it would take on charges calling for the revocation of the charters of three New York City locals on the ground that they had fostered practices inimical to democracy.

The steel industry has virtually completed a comprehensive refunding program that has resulted in substantial savings in fixed charges and will make its position more secure at the conclusion of the current period of high operations and extraordinary orders for exports and national defense.

TONYPANDY, Wales, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Communists and other malcontents in Great Britain are playing Adolf Hitler's game by trying to destroy the nation from within, Clement R. Attlee, Lord Privy Seal and Labor leader, told an audience of Welsh miners today.

Closely guarded by special and city police, the first of twenty-six twenty-ton high-speed long-range bombing planes built for Great Britain by the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation at San Diego, Calif., arrived at La Guardia Field shortly before 8 A.M. yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- The New York Americans, sinking deeper into the National Hockey League cellar, dropped a 5-4 decision to the Black Hawks in overtime tonight and lost the services of Wilf Field, star defense man, for an indefinite time.

New York State employers owe at least $18,000,000 in unpaid unemployment insurance taxes, the State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance declared in its annual report sent to Governor Lehman and the Legislature yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 -- Dr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Gant of New York, who were among those entertaining at the Surf Club today, were hosts to a group at a luncheon in honor of their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Hoge Jr. of Frankfort, Ky.

The concert given under the auspices of Mayor La Guardia and the WPA Music Project, with Frieder Weissmann as conductor of the New York City Symphony Orchestra, last night in Carnegie Hall had novel features. Not the least arresting of these was the appearance as soloist with the orchestra of the present Superintendant of the New York State Police, Major John A. Warner, in the performance of Rachmaninoff's First Piano Concerto.

Three of the nine new films arriving on Broadway this week will open tomorrow. These are: "Road Show," a Hal Roach production featuring Adolphe Menjou, Carole Landis, Patsy Kelly and Charles Butterworth, at the Rialto; "Six Lessons From Madame La Zonga," with Lupe Velez, Leon Errol and Helen Parrish, at the Palace, and "Queen of Crime," with Genevieve Tobin and Noel Madison, at the New York Theatre.

The landing of British parachute troops on the Italian mainland does not appear to have been merely a dramatic but useless gesture, as the first communique from Rome sought to imply. Apparently sufficient damage was done to make it necessary to halt main rail traffic between Naples and Taranto and Brindisi.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 17 -- With a southerly gale raging over the Strait of Dover and creating a difficult barrier in the path of German air raiders that take off from French bases on their visits to this country. Britain had a quiet night, officials said early today.

Scattered news bulletins indicate a pause in the British operations in North Africa and a corresponding intensification and speed-up in the diversified campaigns to the southeast. The pause in the north may be more apparent than real. Undoubtedly a large job of mopping up and clearing the ground became necessary after the fall of Bengazi, and a certain amount of reorganization of the main forces would be desirable before resuming the advance westward.

LAKE PLACID, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Curtis Stevens, veteran bobsled driver, took over the wheel of Francis Tyler's Sno Bird sled today and captured the Lowell Thomas International Trophy for four-man teams on the Mount Van Hoevenberg slide. His total time for the four one-mile heats was 4:33.65.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 16 (AP) -- British sources tonight privately expressed the view that Chile's decision to operate three blockaded Danish freighters under the Chilean flag was "hasty" and commercial circles speculated on what use Chile would make of the ships, which formerly sailed between Valparaiso and New York.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The huge credit votes recently asked by the government have come as significant reminders of the immense financial effort that lies before the country and its consequent effect on taxation. The country has been warned in the last few days that the taxpayer will have to contribute still more to the nation's war bill, and the shadow of the April budget is falling over the markets.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 16 -- Staff officers of the Fifty-seventh and Eighty-seventh Infantry Brigades worked overtime today completing a series of tactical problems for regimental combat team exercises starting tomorrow. Until now the infantry and artillery have trained as separate units.

Lack of coordinated cooperation by physicians, civic and business leaders in New York City has made the progress of medical expense insurance not "wholly satisfactory," Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, declares in a second installment of his annual report to the State Legislature, which will be made public today.

Business continued at an active pace throughout the dress market last week. Navy dresses, redingotes and prints were ordered and reordered in all price ranges. The coat and suit market was in full swing, with both sports and dressy suits in popular demand. Quantity orders were still being placed on sportswear, while orders and reorders on blouses were particularly heavy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Harry L. Hopkins returned from London tonight and hastened to President Roosevelt with the findings of his four-week survey of British war-making -- a survey that led him to conclude that the British were "desperately in need of help."

FLORAL PARK, L.I., Feb. 16 -- Anthony T. Fattorosi, 26 years old, an attendant at the Veterans Hospital at Northport, was shot by the police today after he had been captured in a wild 75-mile-an-hour chase on Jericho Turnpike in which he crashed into two other automobiles, one a taxicab containing three passengers. None was seriously hurt.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 16 -- Although the share markets in the smaller European nations last week presented a spotty picture, their bond lists registered an almost uniform firmness. This was attributed to the fact that investors, for the present, are turning to the fixed-interest securities, because equity shares, under the current strict commodity-price controls, and facing, as they do, heavier taxation burdens, are gradually losing their appeal.

HAVANA, Feb. 16 -- There was an unwonted quiet in the Dodger camp today. The only explanation for the peaceful calm must have been that President Larry MacPhail had nothing to say, for the squad went through a workout as usual at Tropical Park.

The Christian church is the world's greatest hope today because it has the secret that will bind men of all races and nationalities together in equality, peace, good-will and brotherhood, Bishop Herbert Welch declared in his sermon yesterday morning at a service commemorating the eightieth anniversary of the Washington Square Methodist Church, 133 West 4th Street.

A special dinner dance, entitled "Party for Plymouth," will be given Feb. 28 at Le Coq Rouge to augment a fund now being raised for the relief of victims of bombing in Plymouth, England. An entertainment program will be a feature of the dinner dance.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 17 -- The new advice of British authorities that Britons "who have no good reason for remaining" should leave Shanghai emphasized anew today the continued gravity of the relations of the United States and Britain with Japan.

Financial markets, both for stocks and bonds, declined sharply last week. On Friday, the average for stocks had fallen 4 5/8 points in the week and domestic bond averages 1 1/2 points. Sales of stocks on Monday were only 294,000 shares, the smallest five-hour day this year; but on Friday they were 933,000, the largest since December.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 16 -- A violent hurricane that swept across Portugal from the Atlantic, killing and injuring hundreds and causing millions of dollars in damage, spent its fury today in Northern Spain, where more were killed and entire provinces were isolated.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 16 (UP) -- Frank Leahy, who yesterday signed a contract, reportedly for five years, as athletic director and head football coach at Notre Dame, toured the campus of his alma mater today, discussed plans for his coaching assistants, then left on an evening train for his Boston home.

VICHY, France, Feb. 16 -- As the outcome of a decision taken this morning by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, sitting in council with his Ministers, Admiral Francois Darlan now holds the following posts:

STANHOPE, N.J., Feb. 16 -- Ray Ruge of the Hudson Highlands (N.Y.) Ice Boat and Yacht Club piloted his Charet II to the open championship of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association in the final race of the annual regatta on Lake Musconetcong today. He succeeds Phillip E. Habler of Rumson.

What your reporter says about the shortage of Italian foodstuffs in and about Mulberry Bend is quite true. It also is true that Benito Mussolini is losing, day by day, the almost godlike admiration which Italians both here and abroad had for him. Nevertheless, like Caesar, the inestimable "good" he brought to the Italian peninsula shall be "interred with his bones," his defeat and humiliation, brought about by his ambition, "shall live after him."

Somebody has described February as a bridge that is broken at both ends. In other words, it is hard passage from Winter to Spring. Its spells of mild weather arouse false hopes that frequently end in grippe. For many, its chief recommendation is the fact that it is the shortest month in the year.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 -- Mrs. George Luke Mesker entertained with a dinner tonight at the Everglades Club for Mr. and Mrs. Morin S. Hare of New York, who joined her today.
Your editorial "The Unhappy Stoker" contained more truth than fiction; and having been through the experience of burning coal and oil, I believe I am competent to write on the subject.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The British announced tonight that they were taking steps to strengthen the defenses at Singapore. It was one more indication of their concern over the Far Eastern situation, which has been a source of worry recently in Australia, New Zealand and the United States, as well as here.

As the site for an eight-story apartment house to contain eighty-four suites, a plot of 17,000 square feet at the northeast corner of Park Terrace East and West 215th Street, in the Inwood section of Manhattan, has been purchased by the R.F.M. Construction Corporation, I. Freisler, president, from Thomas Dwyer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Physicians of the United States Indian Service report that they have discovered a remarkably short and successful treatment of the sight-destroying disease, trachoma, with sulfanilamide. News of this in medical circles has brought a deluge of inquiries from a large part of the world.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16 -- Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., staved off a gallant bid by Ben Hogan of Purchase, N.Y., today to win the $1,200 first prize in the $5,000 New Orleans open golf tournament.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The addition, last week, of one hour to the daily trading session of the Stock Exchange here failed to produce any increase in the volume of transactions, although the move was in keeping with the general trend among business houses toward longer working hours.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 16 (AP) -- The newly formed National Committee of Stock Exchange Partners started a movement today to take control of the New York Stock Exchange from Wall Street and put it in "Main Street."

The fact is allowed to become public (this is the way one must state the matter, since no official publicly sponsors the announcement) that production of military planes in the United States rose to a total of 1,002 in January. As this compares with production of 799 military planes in December, announced by Mr. Biggers of the Defense Commission, the result is on the surface gratifying.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Ted Ellenwood, 21-year-old Fort Johnson speedster, won the New York State speed-skating title today to increase his 1941 victories to five.

MIAMI, Feb. 16 -- The International Allied Printing Trades Association, consisting of five printing crafts unions claiming a membership of 200,000, will press Congress for enactment of legislation aimed to restrict drastically the sale of commercial time on the air to no more than 25 per cent of available radio time and to impose heavy taxes on the income of broadcasting stations.

An English version of "The Bartered Bride," by Friedrich Smetana, will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House next week. The opera, which has not been presented for four years, will be conducted by Bruno Walter and Jarmila Novotna will sing the title role.

TO Southerners who want to understand themselves and to Northerners who would like to fathom Southern psychology, W.J. Cash has made an important contribution called "The Mind of the South."* This is a significant addition to those books which the South has given the nation's readers in recent years -- an addition which helps to interpret those other books.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 16 -- Albanian patriarchs living in exile in Balkan capitals addressed an urgent plea today to Prime Minister Churchill to declare Britain on the side of Albanian independence when and if there is a British victory.

The Ballet Theatre's nightly novelty, without which it apparently considers no program complete, last night found Anton Dolin once more looking backward. This time what he unearthed for the repertory at the Majestic Theatre was a work with only curiosity value, the famous "Pas de Quatre" presented for a single performance before Queen Victoria in 1845 with Taglioni Grahn, Grisi and Cerito constituting its cast.

The building of a new and better world will not rest on economic or social blueprints but on a simple and wholesome faith in God, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo said yesterday in his morning sermon at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

If Christians depart from the principles in which they profess to believe by descending "to hate and malice and simple vengeance" in their search for justice, the survival of the human family may not be possible, the Rev. Dr. Robert Bruce, State superintendent of Congregational and Christian Churches, said in a sermon yesterday morning.

Reporting on operating results for 1940, Frederick D. Corley, president of Marshall Field Co., informed stockholders that each division of the business again increased its net operating profit for the year. Profit from operations before interest and Federal income taxes amounted to $8,416,031, compared with $6,432,058 for 1939.

A gift of $10,000 to the Boy Scouts of Greater New York by the Charles Hayden Foundation was announced yesterday by Phillips R. Turnbull, chairman of the Scouts' 1941 expansion campaign, who reported Thursday that $106.023 had already been contributed toward the campaign goal of $430,400.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 16 (AP) -There was no official report today on activities on the North African front, where the British last were reported driving toward Tripoli, capital of Libya.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A special defense tax of 10 per cent on all income paid to individuals, so as to put the defense program on "substantially a cash basis," was advocated today by the National Economy League.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW JERSEY, Feb. 16 -- The epic story of a "lost battalion" from a New York City branch of the Army, which reportedly took a wrong road while advancing across neutral New Jersey toward a military objective in [one word censored here], but finally managed to find itself and rejoin its main forces, was disclosed in official communiques today.

BUFFALO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Army lifted the cloak of secrecy today and permitted thousands of workers from this city's warplane plants to inspect the finished product of their handiwork -- the latest model fighter ships.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Feb. 16 -Two hundred enlisted men, organizing what is believed to be the first Holy Name Society among the armed forces in the East, attended an induction mass in the new chapel at Mitchel Field here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 -- Michele Morgan, RKO's acquisition of last year from the French cinema, will make her American debut in "Joan of Paris," a screen story which the studio has purchased from Jacques Thiery and Georges Kessels.

MOSCOW, Feb 16 (UP) -- A violent attack on top-heavy bureaucracy and "buck-passing," blamed for slowing down Soviet industrial output, was delivered before Joseph Stalin and the entire Bolshevist hierarchy at the first national Communist party conference held in two years.

BERLIN, Feb. 16 -- The Reich's wartime expenditures at the present time are approximately 5,500,000,000 marks a month, according to accepted German financial experts. Although the government does not publish the actual figures, this estimate is conclusively based on tax and other regular revenues which average about 2,500,000,000 marks a month, and on the Reich's monthly borrowings at the rate of 3,000,000,000 marks.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Twenty-five persons were reported drowned at Alhandra, ten miles up the Tagus River, when a boat sank during yesterday's hurricane -- the worst in the eighty-seven years of history of the Central Observatory.

Roger Aubert, Swiss pianist, who made his local debut two years ago, gave his third Town Hall recital last night. The program contained as its principal numbers Bach's Tocccata and Fugue in D major, Beethoven's sonata, Op. 111, Liszt's "St. Francis of Paula Walking Upon the Waters" and Ravel's "Alborado del Gracioso."

Any ideas the River Vale Skeeters might have been entertaining as regards a successful final appearance at Madison Square Garden this season were rudely shattered by the New York Rovers yesterday afternoon. The Red Shirts were the Rovers of old as they virtually blasted their Eastern Hockey League rivals off the ice, 5 to 0.
UNION CITY, N.J., Feb. 16 -- The Passion play "Veronica's Veil" began its twenty-seventh season here today, its script intact but its cast hastily revised as a result of the Selective Service Act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- There were about 2,350,000 births in the United States in 1940, according to preliminary Census Bureau figures. This was the largest number for any year since 1930. It was 100,000 greater than in 1939 and lifted the national birthrate from 17.3 to 18 live births per 1,000 of population.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 16 -- The tension in the Balkans during the last week seems to be greatly eased as a result of the visit of the Yugoslav Premier and Foreign Minister to Germany, and such news as has gradually leaked out about this visit indicates that events in the Balkans have again been postponed.
ATHENS, Feb. 16 -- Throughout the day the Greeks were reported to have continued their general advance along the whole Albanian front. This was the fourth day since the advance started.

The Rev. Ralph S. Meadowcroft, rector of All Angels' Episcopal Church, in his sermon yesterday morning told members of his parish that "we can spiritualize our payment of relief taxes just as we spiritualize our patriotism." He added:

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, declared today that the medical profession was "pitifully underfinanced" by the government in carrying out its "essential and gigantic task" in the national defense program.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16 -- Manager Bill Terry brought down two tardy contract signers with one fountain pen today, to reduce the total of Giants outside the fold to eleven. The two to come in, both pitchers, were Clydell Castleman, who is to make another bid for a comeback, and Ace Adams, young right-hander drafted from Nashville last Fall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Wendell L. Willkie spoke to about 400 today at a reception and tea of the National Women's Press Club at a downtown hotel. When he appeared about 200 women jammed the hotel lobby and sidewalk outside in an effort to see him.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- The apparent agreement by all authorities that home relief costs to the State and its subdivisions during the 1941-42 fiscal year will again be well over $100,000,000 has served to emphasize in the minds of legislators that no business boom, regardless of its proportions, is going to put an end to home relief expenditures.
ROME, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique for today follows:
LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The British Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Former President Herbert Hoover disclosed tonight that a plan had been submitted to the British and German Governments for supervised feeding of 3,000,000 Belgians as a test for possible extension to other occupied European countries.

The evil forces that are the scourge of the world today may be used by God to force mankind into a civilization that will be closer to His desires than has yet existed, the Rev. Dr. John A. Mackay, president of the Princeton (N.J.) Presbyterian Theological Seminary, asserted yesterday in his sermon at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Mayor LaGuardia's bill to authorize the city to finance the acquisition of rolling stock and equipment for its transit lines by means of equipment trust certificates will be opposed by the Citizens Budget Commission if a study of the measure discloses that it is unsound from a business viewpoint or merely a device to evade the constitutional debt limit, Harold Riegelman, counsel for the commission, declared yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A vast Nazi-dominated party aimed at damaging the United States was reported here today as operating from the Canadian border to the tip of South America.

Smilingly confident that "Hitler can't lick the British," Harry L. Hopkins returned here yesterday on the Yankee Clipper with a warning for the American people that Great Britain needs our help "desperately" and needs it "now." He added that the British deserve our help and that he was sure they would get it.

The cadet chapel choir of the United States Military Academy at West Point took part yesterday afternoon in the evensong service at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, while on an annual visit to New York.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 16 (AP) -South African Headquarters issued this communique today:

If any of the visitors to the National Sportsmen's Show who packed the aisles of Grand Central Palace yesterday thought they had stumbled into a gigantic sporting goods store gone mad, they had plenty of justification for their delusion.

Reduction of city expenditures to meet the "grave problem" described by Controller McGoldrick in his report containing preliminary estimates of revenue and expenses during the next fiscal year was urged yesterday by Major General Dennis E. Nolan, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission.

VIENNA, Feb. 16 (Via Berlin) -- In a room where Beethoven first presented his revolutionary Eroica to the world Vienna's haute couture in the realm of women's dress this afternoon opened a four-day presentation of the newest Spring and Summer fashion models, their first 1941 exhibition of timely styles, in the House of Fashion in Vienna.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 17 (UP) -- The newspaper Nichi Nichi reported in a dispatch from Los Angeles today that shipping sources had revealed that captains of American ships on the Far Eastern run were carrying sealed orders to be opened upon government, wirelessed instructions in event of the "worst development."

We are most sympathetic with any attempt to lessen the raucous noise of the modern automobile horn, but it nevertheless should be emphasized that the fundamental reason why, as you say, "the horn is a nuisance" is that it is sounded unnecessarily. It thus becomes not only a nuisance but a menace to safety.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 -- Although the home town boy's chances of making good are about as bright as an old shoe, a new local indoor fistic record may be set for Joe Louis's heavyweight title defense against Gus Dorazio tomorrow night.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- Torger Tokle of the Norway Ski Club, holder of more course records than any other skier in this country, had little difficulty winning an invitation jumping tourney today. About 9,000 watched the event.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 102.5 on Feb. 4, compared with 102.5 on Jan. 21, 101.8 a month before, 91.9 on Feb. 13. 1940, 70.3 at the end of August, 1939, and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 16 -- Bolivia will never forsake the principle of free unrestricted transit, which is complementary to her sovereignty, said Forein Minister Alberto Ostria Gutierrez in an interview today, commenting on the outcome of the recent River Plate conference.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Corn prices held within narrow limits here last week and averaged slightly lower in sympathy with wheat. Outside interest in corn is said to be at a minimum, partly because of the belief that the government's offer made recently to sell its holdings of more than 220,000,000 bushels of cash corn has put a ceiling over the market.

An inspector's funeral will be held today for Patrolman Leon Fox, killed in a hold-up in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn Saturday night. The services, at 11 A.M., will be in the Flatbush Memorial Temple at 1,283 Coney Island Avenue and burial will be in the plot of the Shamrim Society, a Police Department religious organization, in Montefiore Cemetery.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 -- The Philadelphia Inquirer is publishing a story that it has learned "on high authority" that Dies committee agents have found evidence of the recent operation in a Philadelphia suburb of a school for "storm troopers," which sent disciples of Nazism into strategic posts in defense industries in Southeastern Pennsylvania.

Judge James Garrett Wallace in General Sessions yesterday ignored the life-term recommendation of the jury that convicted Stanley Cole, 36 years old, an ex-convict, of first-degree murder, and sentenced him to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing in the week beginning March 24. Judge Wallace held the law made it optional with the court to accept a clemency recommendation in a first-degree murder conviction.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Royal Air Force planes carried out their longest operational flight of the war Saturday night when, without bombs, they flew to Poland and dropped leaflets on Cracow and Katowice.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A communique of the British Middle East Command said today:

The three New York City locals of the American Federation of Teachers "will fight every step of the way" the recommendation of the executive council that their charters be revoked, their leaders said on their arrival from Chicago yesterday.

George C. Bateman, Controller of Metals of the Canadian Ministry of Munitions and Supply, who delivered the principal address yesterday afternoon at the opening general session of the 154th annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, said Canadian industrialists and other elements of the Canadian people were lending their support so whole-heartedly to the war effort that "the profit motive is no longer a dominating factor in our industrial life."
The 60,000 dairy farmers in the New York milkshed voted yesterday in another attempt to regulate milk prices.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Reports from Haiphong tonight said that 300 more Japanese infantrymen had landed within the past forty-eight hours, further increasing forces in Northern Indo-China already reported at more than double the 6,000-man maximum set by the Tokyo and French colonial agreement. They have unstated amounts of mechanized equipment and planes.

A.K. Morgan, general superintendent and engineer of the Palisades Interstate ParkCommission, asserted yesterday that therewas no intention on the part of thecommission to encroach on authority of localcounty boards in planning the proposedPalisades Interstate Parkway, and that theproject, if it should materialize, would notcreate any tax problem for the countiesaffected.

Members of the Social Democratic Federation reported yesterday that during the last week-end the federation offices and the editorial room of The New Leader, federation organ, both at 7 East Fifteenth Street -- were mysteriously invaded.

The Allied Civics of Forest Hills and Vicinity, an organization representing twenty-eight civic groups, won last night the first round in its fight to prevent or at 1east postpone the construction of a $404,500 sewer under Yellowstone Boulevard and other sections of Forest Hills.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- Close to the water's edge, 200 feet below the cliff top, on the Canadian side of the Niagara River, the first piece of the great mass of steel which will form the new Rainbow Bridge between the Dominion of Canada and the United States was placed in position this morning.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 17 -- While the possibility of a South Pacific crisis simmered, New Zealand today moved her preparedness plans steadily ahead.

The technical rebound of Saturday was furthered yesterday in stock prices, but the volume of trading was too small to draw the conclusion that the list had been righted after the declines of last week. The turnover, in fact, was the lightest in a week, as transfers on the Stock Exchange sank to 356,720 shares, against the Friday total of 933,740.

Confusion among manufacturers of defense items as to the proper source to obtain priority ratings on vital materials or tools was cleared up yesterday with issuance of a bulletin by the Office of Production Management, according to purchasing agents.

The first of a projected series of annual exhibitions of the Federation of Modern Painters and Sculptors, Inc., will be held at the Riverside Museum from March 9 to 23. Exhibitions by the group have been held at Smith College, Yale and the New York World's Fair.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 -- With hardly as much effort as he would expend in a training camp sparring bout, Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, tonight defended his crown for the fourteenth time with his twelfth knockout as titleholder, his third within the space of three months.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses warned yesterday that some park and playground areas in the city would require major replacement unless budget funds were provided this year to staff them and keep them in repair.

Last night three candidates for Representative in Congress from the Seventeenth District were nominated. Mr. Eugene P. Connolly, American Laborite of the Left, may be regarded as a demonstrator, a formal rather than a serious contender. The contest is between Councilman Baldwin, Republican, and Dean Alfange, Democrat. Each supports the lend-lease bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. l7 -- Thirteen of the more important petroleum producers and refiners in the United States had consolidated sales of $3,632,257,441 in 1939, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 17 -- Bulgaria and Turkey have signed a declaration of friendship and non-aggression, it was announced tonight, in an effort to avert extension of the European war into the Balkans.

Sam Hiat, 43 years old, of 262 Second Street, who described himself as a concessionaire, was sentenced to a six-month workhouse term in Special Sessions yesterday for tampering with a State witness who appeared against thirteen members of the International Fur Workers Union.

MOSCOW, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Formal conversations for a trade treaty between Russia and Japan were started today and Japanese informants said that most of the problems between the two nations already had been solved or were in a process of settlement.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Medical leaders from several States demanded today that draft authorities grant a blanket deferment to all medical students until they have completed their studies. The demand was made during a discussion at the annual Congress on Medical Education and Licensure.

They do not play in Madison Square Garden and they stay pretty much in their own league, so Columbia's quintet perhaps receives less attention from the public than a basketball team of its status deserves. The fact is that Paul Mooney has fashioned one of his finest teams in the comparative obscurity of Morningside Heights.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics today predicted continued improvement in the demand for farm products, despite the small likelihood of change in industrial demand and consumer income.
ATLANTA, Feb. 17 -- Unrestricted recruiting of athletes has the blessing of the Southeastern Conference -- but the dollar sign is out.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Bishop Edwin O'Hara of Kansas City said tonight that the first revision since 1749 of the English translation of the Catholic New Testament would be published in May.

BOSTON, Feb. 17 -- Prices about 2 per cent lower than those at which 1,840,000 pairs of Army service shoes were bought last December prevailed today when bids on 1,600,000 pairs were opened at the local Army base. The price range at which contracts were awarded last December was $3.10 to $3.45.

For the second year in a row, Trudie Rougette, a honey-colored Pomeranian owned by Mrs. Hubert Ring of Forest Hills, L.I., won toy laurels as the tenth annual pet dog show opened at Bloomingdale's yesterday.

More than a thousand Italians and Americans of Italian descent assembled on Sunday at Cooper Union to voice their "unalterable opposition to fascism." This was the first meeting of a series to be held in many American cities under the appropriate sponsorship of the Mazzini Society.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Wightman (Bud) Washbond, Keene Valley High School student, and his 298-pound brake, Adrian Aubin, broke the single and four-heat records for the Mount Van Hoevenberg run today to win the Lowell Thomas international two-man bobsled title.

While 2,500 Department of Sanitation employes worked through the night to clear the streets of two inches of snow that fell here yesterday, sand was spread over the main traffic arteries, which had become glassy and treacherous when the slush froze after sundown.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Mayor La Guardia asked the Legislature today for "emergency passage" of a bill legalizing the leasing of buses in Brooklyn and also permitting the Board of Transportation to buy subway cars in the amount of $30,000,000 outside the city debt limit by means of equipment trust certificates.

Baseball practice started at Fordham yesterday when nine pitchers and three catchers reported to Coach Jack Coffey in the Rose Hill gymnasium. The rest of the squad will begin practice March 3, when the entire squad will move outdoors, weather permitting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A bill designed to protect the vast army of destitute workers migrating into defense "boom towns" in search of employment was introduced in the House today by Representative Tolan of California.

Denunciation of former President Herbert Hoover's plan to feed the inhabitants of the small European countries overrun by Germany's armies on the grounds it would weaken Britain and strengthen the Nazis was made last night by speakers at a rally of the Committee to Aid America by Aiding the Allies at Mecca Temple, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street.
MIAMI, Feb. 17 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor approved today an agreement for the reaffiliation of the International Typographical Union with the federation.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Wendell Eads and Conn McCreary, the two leading young riders of the Hialeah Park race meeting, ran into all sorts of hard luck during today's program.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 17 -- Germany has obtained the controlling shares and assumed almost full command today of the formerly French-owned Bor Copper Mines in Yugoslavia, the largest copper producing property in Europe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Two hundred amphibian tanks, each capable of carrying thirty-six fully equipped Marines over land or water, were ordered by the Navy today at a cost of $3,240,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The total round-lot volume of the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Feb. 1 was 3,203,220 shares, compared with 2,743,800 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Diplomats here today believed that Reichsfuehrer Hitler would act swiftly to "Nazify" Bulgaria and push southward to place German armed forces in the Greek Aegean seaport of Salonika as a result of the Turkish-Bulgarian declaration of non-aggression.

Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the Council committee investigating the Civil Service Commission, said yesterday that the commission had approved Milton M. Weston, a Negro, as a relief supervisor despite his membership in the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The power of the State of Iowa to collect a 2 per cent use tax on the mail order business of Sears, Roebuck Co. and Montgomery Ward Co. between customers within land branches of the companies outside the State borders was upheld today by the Supreme Court in a 5-to-2 decision.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- A State and county tax levy for 1941 of $12,066,551 was apportioned against the five cities and eighteen towns of Westchester County this afternoon by the Board of Supervisors. This compares with $12,568,408 last year, or a drop of $501,857.

BERLIN, N.H., Feb. l7 -- Veteran skiers and residents of this pioneer American snow settlement had an interesting discussion today regarding the Federation Internationale de Ski jumping of Sunday, in which only eight of a field of eighty stars participated.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 18 per cent for the week ended Feb. 15, in comparison with the like period a year ago, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The percentage rise is the largest for any weekly period since the Christmas peak on Dec. 28.

MADISON, N.J., Feb. 17 -- The Madison Assemblies, which were features of social activity here a few decades ago, will be revived Friday night with an anniversary costume ball in the Madison Assembly Rooms of the James Building. The dance will be a benefit for the Madison Public Library and the rehabilitation of the James Building, the latter having been a gift of the late D. Willis James to the community.

After being tied with the Bayside Tennis Club for first place in the Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis tournament for two weeks, the New York Athletic Club gained undisputed possession of the lead yesterday, beating the Princeton Club, 4 -- 1, while Bayside was bowing to the City A.C., by the same margin.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Wheat felt the effect of rather persistent commission house selling today. Scattered liquidation developed on the way down and there was some pressure from houses with Southwestern connections, which was said to have been in the nature of hedging sales.
BERLIN, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The German High Command issue this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Activity in industry throughout the United States continued at a high level in January, the Federal Reserve Board made known today. The board's adjusted industrial production index rose a point in the month to 139 based on the 1935-39 average as 100.

Belgium and Norway are seeking to make arrangements to continue bread rations for the next thirty to sixty days, but the two countries, together with Finland, arc in the greatest difficulties because of a lack of meats and fats, according to an analysis of food conditions abroad cabled yesterday to W. Hallam Tuck, vice chairman of the National Committee on Food for the Small Democracies, by members of the committee's staff abroad.

The schedule of major prospective financing deals, including those of the Republic Steel Corporation and Philip Morris Co., Ltd., was disrupted yesterday as officials of the borrowing companies and the respective underwriters viewed with no little concern the current condition of the securities markets.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Debits to deposit accounts (except interbank accounts), as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Feb. 12, aggregated $6,923,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Roosevelt began to set up administrative machinery today to extend the swiftest and most efficacious aid possible to Great Britain as soon as the lease-lend bill is enacted. His attention has been devoted practically exclusively to this particular problem ever since the arrival of Harry Hopkins from London late yesterday.

An improvement in his "swing" and his adherence to training rules were reasons Willie Hoppe gave yesterday, upon his return from Chicago, for his winning the world three-cushion billiard championship for the second consecutive year.

Receipt of contracts from Atley Donald and Marvin Breuer, twentieth and twenty-first players to sign, was announced yesterday by President Edward G. Barrow of the Yankees. With the first squad scheduled to report to Manager Joe McCarthy at St. Petersburg, Fla., on Sunday, fourteen recalcitrants, virtually all regulars, remain to be heard from.

LONDON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Vernon Keough of Brooklyn, N.Y., a member of the American Eagle Squadron of the Royal Air Force, which got its first taste of action during a German raid last week, was posted tonight as missing.

The National Orchestral Association's second experiment opera was a production of Puccini's "Sister Angelica" at Carnegie Hall last night. As at the association's first presentation, "Pagliacci," there was a drop for a setting, and behind the drop were conductor and orchestra.

European Writers, the recently formed organization of European authors now in the United States, will be reconstituted soon as the European P.E.N. Club in America, Ernest Angell, executive secretary, announced yesterday. The group will hold a symposium and general discussion tonight at the Friendship House Auditorium, 1010 Park Avenue, at which several authors, including Raoul Auerheimer, Ivan Goll and Carl Zuckmayer, will read from their work.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Despite the best wholesale dressed pork prices in nearly a month hog prices dropped 5 to 10 cents today. Receipts of 19,000 salable hogs in addition to 8,000 shipped direct to leading packers were 10,000 head above advance estimates. Pork loins brought 16 1/2 to 17 1/2 cents a pound, one-half cent over last week's level and the best price quoted since Jan. 21.

Although the knotless tapered leader of synthetic gut is yet to be produced for the market, trout fishermen and those who use the fly rod bug or fly for bass will now be able to get their Nylon in coils rather than the twenty-inch lengths.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 17 -- On the face of it today's Joint declaration by Sofia and Ankara would seem to have brought at least a modicum of tranquillity to the rumor-ridden region just north and south of the Dardanelles, it was believed here today.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- The sixth call for 7,600 registrants in counties outside of New York City to be delivered for selective service training March 3 to 7 and March 10 to 14, was announced today by Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State Director of Selective Service.

Seven officers of the Brazilian Army arrived here yesterday on the American Republics liner Uruguay to attend classes at the Army War College at Washington. The Uruguay arrived from Buenos Aires via Montevideo, Rio de Janeiro and Trinidad with 278 passengers and a 6,169-ton cargo, including the first 1941 consignment of fruit from Argentina.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- German quarters declared today that the Reich would place no hindrances in the path of relief action for Belgium such as was outlined yesterday by Herbert Hoover. It was recalled that similar action had been carried out in Poland last year and furthermore that the Reich did not confiscate any part of the American deliveries made then, all of them reaching only the Polish people for whom they were destined.

ATHENS, Feb. 17 -- The mountains in the region of Buzi, between Tepeleni and Berat, in Albania, resounded with the roar of mighty motors, as a full formation of British bombers, escorted by fighter planes, supported the Greek forces in driving the Italians out of their strongholds yesterday.

ROME, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Four new Under-Secretaries of State were named today to carry on the work of superiors or predecessors called to active military service. The appointments constituted the first disclosure that four high members of the government had joined those already in active service.

Councilman Joseph Clark Baldwin and Dean A. Alfange were named formally last night by district conventions as the Republican and Democratic candidates, respectively, for the Seventeenth District Congressional seat made vacant by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson.

Jan Ciechanowski, newly appointed Ambassador to the United States from the Polish Government in Exile at London, arrived in Jersey City on the American Export liner Excambion last night on his way to Washington, confident that an eventual British victory would be assured with the aid of American war supplies.
VICHY, France, Feb. 17 -- Once again Admiral Francois Darlan is on his way to Paris this time as Vice Premier with greatly enhanced powers.

As one of those who had been threatened by Article XIX of the French-German armistice, but who succeeded in escaping from France, I am deeply impressed by the surrender of Rudolf Breitscheid and Rudolf Hilferding to the German authorities.

OTTAWA, Feb. 17 -- Describing the "rapid crystallization of opinion in the United States in favor of actively assisting the democratic countries in their struggle against aggression" as the most important event of these past months, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King today warned the Canadian Parliament and the Canadian people that "a very critical stage in the war must yet be passed before the full aid of the United States becomes available."

A cash transaction was announced yesterday in which the Beck, Hazzard Corporation, shoe concern, sold its former warehouse, the eight-story structure at 324-8 Lafayette Street, running through to 159-161 Crosby Street, to S.B. Shankman, an investor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The House passed twelve minor bills on the unanimous-consent calendar in sixteen minutes today, quickly approved the Senate amendments to the bill raising the national debt limit to $65,000,000,000, and started general debate on the Gathings reapportionment bill.

LONDON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Imperial Tobacco Company (of Great Britain and Ireland) Ltd., leading British tobacco and cigarette maker, in one of the first important earnings statements covering the period of intensive war, showed for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31, a profit of 8,372,828 after charges and general reserve of 500,000.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 17 -- The Senate tonight passed a bill providing $6,663,000 as the State's share of 1941 relief costs, with municipalities to be reimbursed for from 10 to 60 per cent of their expenditures. Last year when reimbursements ranged as high as 75 per cent, the State paid out $11,000,000.

TOKYO, Feb. 17 -- An official declaration that Japan pursues her southward policy by peaceful means only was accompanied today by a charge that last week's scare was caused by erroneous information from London. This will obtain publicity in the Japanese press and millions of readers will again sleep soundly.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Reports of a group of retail stores for January indicate that men's clothing sales last month averaged 10 per cent ahead of 1940 on a nation-wide basis, Myer Kestnbaum, president of Hart Schaffner Marx, said today.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Some members of the colony who have subscribed to the third annual Miami Jockey Club Dinner Stakes, to be run on Monday at Hialeah Park, today began leasing horses which they will enter in the race in their names in accordance with regulations governing entries by non-stable owners in this most important race event of the season in the Miami area.

The Rangers, striving desperately to snap a four-game losing streak, will oppose the Americans in a National Hockey League encounter in Madison Square Garden tonight. It will be the seventh meeting of the season between the teams, the Rangers already having clinched the William J. Macbeth Trophy, emblematic of intracity supremacy.

MONTREAL, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Boston's great center, Bill Cowley, who is shooting for the National Hockey League scoring championship and a new record for assists, virtually clinched both honors last week.

Forty women in the factory of My Girl Dresses, Inc., 519 Eighth Avenue, near Thirty-sixth Street, were felled yesterday by carbon monoxide fumes, released when twelve gas pressing machines consumed the oxygen in their workroom.

Seymour Feister, president of Feist Fabrics, Inc., has taken quarters in the recently-completed apartment house at 737 Park Avenue through Pease Elliman, Inc. and Frances R. Jaffin, broker. Miss Jaffin also reports leasing for the Gresham Realty Company to Elizabeth Day a unit in the Southgate Apartments, 414 East Fifty-second Street.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- The arrival of the new Japanese Ambassador to Berlin today was more in the nature of a homecoming than anythings else as General Hiroshi Oshima had gained the reputation of being one of the most popular members of the diplomatic set here when he was still a military attache.

ROME, Feb. 17 -- The renunciation of his rights to the throne of Spain, which former King Alfonso made in a manifesto last week, today received solemn confirmation at a meeting in the sick room of the former monarch, where Juan, Jaime, Victoria and Alfonso's Chamberlain, Count de los Amdes, gathered.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 -- Paramount purchased "Cupid With a Beard" by Michael Uris today as a vehicle for Bing Crosby and engaged Uris to adapt the story to the screen. Crosby will appear in the film as a "Caribbean vagabond," according to the studio, and the picture will go before the cameras after he completes "Birth of the Blues."

The one-story taxpayer on a plot 51.6 by 120 feet at 1945-51 University Avenue, the Bronx, was purchased by Joseph L. Ennis Co., Inc., operators, through the Herman A. Acker Corporation, brokers. This is the first sale of the building since it was erected in 1922.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Alarmed over ship losses described as apparently due to information leaks, Great Britain is launching a new campaign to ferret out spies and still tongues that drop tips to Axis agents.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 17 -- "In a desperate effort to protect their tottering regime," it is stated, Norway's Quislingists have decided to arm even the Unghirden, the children's branch of Hirden, the Norwegian Nazi Storm Troopers. On a recent visit to Oslo, Heinrich Himmler, head of all German police, is said to have provided forty small rifles for the use of boys from 10 to 16 years old.

The five-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 150 feet at 330 Mt. Prospect Avenue, Newark, N.J., was sold by the New York Life Insurance Company to a client of James Felt Co., Inc., brokers. Sale of the property, which contains forty suites, was subject to a $138,000 mortgage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A sharp rise in the number of dwelling units for which public funds have been allocated and sustained activity by private industry were the highlights of the defense housing program during the week ended Feb. 8. Charles F. Palmer, Defense Housing Coordinator, said today.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 18 -- Gravely concerned about developments in the Far East, which are inducing some Japanese quarters to urge upon Japan immediate steps to "meet the worst eventualities," the Japanese Government, through its official spokesman, Koh Ishii, today issued a statement suggesting termination of all war and offering Japan's services as mediator if such services are called for.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Teachers recommended today that the charters of the New York Teachers Union, Local 5; the New York College Teachers Union, Local 537, and the Philadelphia Teachers Union, Local 192, be revoked on the ground that their existence is "detrimental to the development of democracy in education."

There are many noble passages in Winston Churchill's war speeches, but none more striking than his tribute to the fliers of the R.A.F.: "Never in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few." The Prime Minister was thinking of the people of Great Britain, but the debt of gratitude which he describes is owed by Americans too.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- United Aircraft Products, Inc., of Dayton, Ohio, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 75,000 shares of 5 1/2 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, $20 par, and 100,000 shares of common stock, $1 par.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The fact that no drastic steps to control the securities exchanges of the United States were necessary when Germany invaded the European Lowlands last Spring was largely owing to the control of these exchanges vested in the Securities and Exchange Commission, it intimated today in its annual report.

Personal contacts and published statements convince me with many others that we have, unhappily, a number of compatriots who fear, or think they fear, the President of the United States more than they fear the Fuehrer of Nazi Germany. This amazing attitude invites, even if it does not deserve, rebuttal, especially as these strange malcontents accuse us others of causing disunity in our country.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 -- Bids were opened at the Army quartermaster depot here today on 20,000,000 yards of 36-inch khaki cotton herringbone twill, or a similar yardage in indigo blue, fully shrunk, white back denim. Twenty-four mills offered a total of approximately 35,000,000 yards of both fabrics, about equally divided as to yardage.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 17 -- While British troops counted the guns and other materiel taken with the capture of Kismayu, important Indian Ocean port of Italian Somaliland, advance units continued to force the Italians to retreat northward along the Juba River toward Ethiopia, British headquarters here announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Leon Henderson, head of the Price Stabilization Division of the Defense Commission, set by order today a ceiling on prices of second-hand machine tools and threatened to extend the government's powers further to "protect the public interest against those seeking to profit exorbitantly on defense requirements."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Billy Jurges, upon whose trim shoulders and damaged left ear drum may be said to hinge whatever pennant chances the Giants may have this year, had his first workout today. It was, to say the least, a wholly satisfactory performance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Occasionally, when objecting to reports in the press, the President has based his complaint on the loose use of words. He has protested that it is inaccurate and misleading to write that he or the administration is "considering" a plan when the plan is merely in the discussion stage among subordinates, however trusted and influential.

Bertrand Russell's reasons for giving support to the war against Hitler, as set forth on this page last Sunday, include one rather grim bookkeeping item. It consists in balancing the horrors of war against the horrors of subjugation. It was generally expected, says Mr. Russell, that a new war would be even more terrible than the World War.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Pleas of guilty by seven defendants today left W. M. Harvey of New York, 68-year-old investment broker, to stand trial alone on mail fraud charges in the government's $1,000,000 "front money" case.

Affixing his signature to two contracts yesterday, John Kimbrough, the Texas A. and M. fullback star, assured himself of an income of $37,500 until the end of 1941. Confident that Kimbrough will not be called for Army service for at least one year, the New York Yankees of the American Football League agreed to pay Jarrin' John $12,500 for his gridiron activities.
ROME, Feb. 17 (AP) --- The Iaian Hig Oomand issued the following oommuniqu6 today:
LONDON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Most of the estate of Howard Heinz, food company executive, who died Feb. 9, will go to the Howard Heinz Endowment, terms of the will to be filed today for probate disclosed.

KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 17 (UP) -- Violet Halling Walker, who was known on the musical comedy stage and in the motion pictures as Betty Compton, filed suit for divorce in Circuit Court today against James J. Walker, to whom she was married five months after he resigned as Mayor of New York.

HAVANA, Feb. 17 -- Van Lingle Mungo, only man now with the Dodgers who played under the late Uncle Wilbert Robinson, and whose future has appeared to be getting farther behind him in each succeeding year of the past four, took his first steps on "the long road back" today -- and didn't stumble.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Lady Halifax, wife of the British Ambassador, invited the ladies of the press to "a real English tea party" today and showed them one of her souvenirs from England.
ROME, Feb. 17 -- New and drastic measures to restrict the use of gasoline are announced today.

CARTERET, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Neil Brant, international representative of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C.I.O. union, was held in $1,000 bail for the action of the Middlesex County grand jury after arraignment in Police Court here this morning charged with defiling the American flag at a meeting last Wednesday when Foster Wheeler Corporation employes voted to strike.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 17 -- The Turkish-Bulgarian agreement is viewed with much skepticism and distrust by pro-Ally circles here despite its apparently noncommittal wording as regards the belligerents. Some observers believe it will presage a similar Yugoslav-Bulgarian agreement.

Max Baer, who is scheduled to battle Lou Nova in a twelve-round bout at Madison Square Garden on April 4, arrived yesterday from Sacramento, Calif. Also in the party were his brother, Buddy, and their manager, Ancil Hoffman. Buddy has a date March 26 with Tony Galento at the Garden.

Mayor La Guardia, wearing a wrecker's helmet, goggles and gas filter, wielded an acetylene torch yesterday to burn out the first rivet starting demolition of the Second Avenue elevated line north of Fifty-ninth Street, and then assailed the Citizens Budget Commission as an organization blocking demolition of the Brooklyn Fulton Street elevated for "selfish reasons."

ALBANY, Fob. 17 -- After a brief debate the Assembly passed tonight by a vote of 136 to 1, the Ostertag bill establishing the New York State Council of Defense and authorizing cities and counties to establish similar bodies to help in promoting State and national defense. The bill is the first defense measure of the session.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Bulgarian-Turkish non-aggression statement issued here tonight was interpreted by reliable informants to mean that Greece was in danger of being left out on a limb and might have to sue for peace with Italy or suffer the consequences of a German thrust against her.

M. Gettleman, Furs, Inc., manufacturers and retailers, with shops in Atlantic City, Hollywood, Fla., and Pittsburgh, will enter the wholesale field, featuring mink garments exclusively, on March 3, when showrooms will be opened in the Equitable Building.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The people of Brighton had a real gas test today when tear gas in a mild form was released on one street.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 17 -- It appears unlikely that Japan can be in a position for at least some weeks and possibly months to make another major move in her southward advancement program such as an attack on Singapore or the Netherlands Indies, seasoned analysts of Far Eastern affairs here believe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. l? -- Wendell L. Willkie is against a factional fight over the chairmanship of the Republican National Committee and has asked Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. to withhold his proposed resignation as head of the committee when the national committee meets here March 24.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Opening hearings today on several bills to prevent strikes and lockouts in defense industries, the House Judiciary Committee heard Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general in charge of anti-trust law prosecutions, assert that some labor union practices were hampering defense efforts by imposing unconscionable costs upon consumers, chiefly in the housing and food distribution fields.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- Authoritative quarters declared tonight that "Germany observes with pleasure" the conclusion of a Bulgarian-Turkish non-aggression pact. It was said the pact was in line with the Reich's policy of continental consolidation and lent impetus to the reorientation of the Balkans according to the principles of the Axis's "new order" in Europe.

Prices of cotton fluctuated irregularly yesterday and final quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 3 points higher. After opening 1 to 3 points down on sales by Bombay and the South the market moved up, with May selling at one time at 7 points above Saturday's close.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Tommy Goodwin of New York, who has collected most of the medals in Palm Beach golf tournaments in the last ten years, won another today when he matched par 70 in qualifying for the annual South Florida championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Feb. 17 -- Never in its 100 years of French rule has Algeria played such a capital role as now.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a dinner tonight entertaining sixty guests, headed by the Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. Morgenthau, and including among others Harry Hopkins, former Secretary of Commerce, who returned to the White House yesterday from London; Mrs. George Gellhorn of St. Louis and Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick of New York.

Captain George V. Richardson, master of the United States liner Manhattan, which went aground on a Florida shoal on Jan. 12, entered a plea of not guilty to charges of negligence brought against him yesterday before a board of Inquiry of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation, 45 Broadway.

As the last step in a program designed to obtain tenure of office for all employes of the city's four municipal colleges, the Board of Higher Education voted civil service classifications last night for 366 custodial employes at Brooklyn, City, Hunter and Queens Colleges.
DETROIT, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Katharine Cornell returned to the stage tonight in her own production, a revival of George Bernard Shaw's "The Doctor's Dilemma."

Announcement is expected to be made either today or tomorrow of flotation of the first issue of securities of a government agency on which the interest will be subject to Federal income taxes under a bill recently passed by Congress and now in the hands of President Roosevelt for signature. Previously these securities have had immunity from such taxation.

Willie Mosconi added two more victories to his string in the world pocket billiard championship by beating Erwin Rudolph at Doyle's yesterday. In the afternoon he won, 125 to 10, in six frames and the night score was 125 to 45 in fourteen innings.
IN the wake of the stirring finish of the Baxter Mile and the amazing performance of Greg Rice in the Toussaint Two-Mile at the New York A.C. meet, the track promoters may be open for a suggestion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Is the "non-aggression" pact concluded by Turkey and Bulgaria to be compared to the famous German-Soviet pact which told the world, with dramatic suddenness, that Russia had shifted her resources and influence to the German scale of the balance? Is Turkey drastically altering the course of her policy at the very moment Germany threatens to attack Greece, her ally?

VICHY, France, Feb. 17 (UP) -- French spokesmen commented enviously today on the resumption of Spanish shipping through the British Mediterranean blockade, hinting broadly at hopes that eventually Great Britain would agree to the shipment of foodstuffs to France from Africa and the Americas.

ROME, Feb. 17 -- An understanding that may mark a turning point in the history of the Italian Navy's participation in the war was reached between Grand Admiral Erich Raeder, Commander in Chief of the German Navy, and Raffaelo Riccardi, the Italian Navy Chief of Staff, in "comradely conversations" last Thursday and Friday, it was announced tonight.

The proposed increase in the legal limit for the national debt inevitably raises the question of how far the defense program must be financed by loans. The general assumption is that a great increase in the national debt cannot be avoided. Yet a recent study by Harold G. Moulton of the Brookings Institution challenging this assumption suggests that alternative methods deserve greater consideration than they have been given.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Earl Russell Browder, general secretary of the Communist party in the United States and its candidate for President last year, must serve a four-year sentence for passport fraud, the Supreme Court unanimously decided today.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The stock markets started the week quietly, but prices in most sections were fairly well maintained. The outstanding feature was a demand for home rails. This burst of speculative activity was in anticipation of Wednesday's dividend announcements and sent stocks up sharply. Most market opinions were that the dividend actions are still decided, but buyers today were taking an optimistic view of the prospects and supporting all the junior shares.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Directors of the Republic Steel Corporation declared today a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, an increase of 10 cents over the dividend voted in November. Payment will be made April 2 to holders of record of March 10. The l dividend in November was the first to holders of the common since 1930.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Telephone communications from this city and Sofia, Bulgaria, to Istanbul, Turkey, were interrupted today in the midst of the announcement of the new joint Turkish-Bulgarian statement of neutrality and non-aggression.

A lockout of 25,000 dressmakers employed in 700 contractor shops of the United BetterDress Manufacturers Association wasthreatened yesterday as a result of theassociation's conflict with the Dress JointBoard of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union over the signing of a newcollective agreement.

Mushing through the snow and slush in Lexington Avenue yesterday, visitors to the Sportsmen's Show in Grand Central Palace learned something about the outdoors in Winter even before they entered the hall where nature in her many forms is presented, in more of a Miami temperature than that of Old Forge.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A witness in a Securities and Exchange Commission proceeding against the New York Curb Exchange related unhesitatingly today how he had received a fortune in commissions paid by his firm to supposedly independent brokers who acted as "virtually my employes."

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Authoritative sources expressed the opinion today that mounting tension in the Far East was caused by pressure by Germany on her Axis partner, Japan, for aggressive military action in the Pacific.

The directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. declared yesterday a dividend of $1.75 a share on the common stock, payable on March 14, the same as paid in the four preceding quarters, and ordered the regular quarterly dividend of $1.12 1/2 a share on the preferred stock, payable on April 25.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit for 1940 of $10,309,788 after depreciation, interest, subsidiary dividends, Federal income taxes and $1,000,000 reserve for contingencies. This compared with net profit of $9,838,797, in 1939, after deducting $1,791,602 foreign exchange adjustment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Before galleries that had to be admonished repeatedly against demonstrations but to a Senate that sat in grim silence, proponents of President Roosevelt's lease-lend bill opened debate on the measure in the upper body today by proclaiming the intent behind it as defeat for Adolf Hitler through aid to Britain and her allies, even at the risk of war for the United States.

Defense contracts already placed were estimated yesterday to have passed the $12,000,000,000 mark, on the basis of data issued by the Office of Government Reports showing that contracts placed in the last half of January, amounting to $266,616,680, had brought the total for the period from July 1 through Jan. 31 to $11,987,594,336.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The raging storm that lashed Spain and Portugal yesterday, leaving fire and flood in its wake, forced 30,000 in the Bay of Biscay port of Santander to flee their homes. Meager reports coming from the Spanish city by way of a ship's radio in the harbor estimated the property loss between 100,000,000 and 150,000,000 pesetas.

Edwin MacArthur appeared last night for the first time as a conductor in the Metropolitan Opera House, when Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" was sung with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior in the title parts. The other singers were Kerstin Thorborg as Brangaene and Julius Huehn as Kurvenal.

J.F. Hartlieb, president of the Continental Can Company, Inc., reported yesterday in his annual statement to stockholders, consolidated net profit for 1940 of $8,953,632 after deducting all charges and $3,281,989 for Federal, State and foreign income taxes. This is equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.82 a share on the 2,853,971 shares of no par common stock.

Serge Semenenko, chairman of the reorganization managers of the Brown Company, manufacturer of pulp and paper, announced yesterday that consolidated operations of the company and its Canadian subsidiary, Brown Corporation, for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, 1940, showed an improvement of more than $4,000,000 over the previous year, after reserve for income and excess profits taxes but before deferred bond interest.

With a full inspector's funeral, the Police Department's highest honor to a policeman, Patrolman Leon Fox, who was shot last Saturday night in a futile attempt to prevent a hold-up by two gunmen at West Twelfth Street and Surf Avenue, Coney Island, Brooklyn, was buried yesterday at noon in the Shomrim Field of Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield, Queens.

The Theatre Guild is withdrawing a "Liberty Jones," Philip Barry's "allegory of freedom in America," with a musical accompaniment by Paul Bowles, from the Shubert Theatre on Saturday night. It will have been performed twenty-one times.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 17 (AP) -- To determine his fitness for the $100,000 classic March 1, ailing Challedon will lead a small field to the post tomorrow in the first training race ever staged at Santa Anita in conjunction with the day's regular program.

A large increase in traffic accidents and the number of persons injured in New York City last week and week-end compared to the same periods in 1940 was reported yesterday by the safety bureau of the Police Department. There was, however, a slight drop in fatalities.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Colonel and Mrs. Harold A. Braman gave a dinner today at their home for Mr. and Mrs. Addison W. Closson, Mr. and Mrs. Van Lear Black Jr., Mr. and Mrs. C. Henry Buhl and Werner Said-Reute of Paris and New York.
Dr. and Mrs. Robert MacLean of 112 East Seventy-fourth Street gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis to celebrate the tenth anniversary of their marriage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Capitol police arrested Mrs. Elizabeth Dilling of Chicago, author of "The Red Network," on a charge of disorderly conduct today when she participated in a demonstration with a score of other women outside the Senate chamber at the opening of debate on the lease-lend bill.
