Buyers' concern over the possibility that deliveries may become tightened, and the likelihood either of price advances or changes in quality resulting from fitting individual items into fixed retail ranges, overshadowed other considerations at the opening of the fifteenth semi-annual domestics and linen show at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

President Roosevelt announced yesterday his selection of Mathias F. Correa to succeed John T. Cahill as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, most active of the Federal court districts.
Plans for $550,000 apartment house in Forest Hills and one costing $120,000 for the Bronx were filed yesterday. The details of these and other projects follow:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today suggested that people begin thinking about doing without various commodities such as new automobiles and aluminum kitchen utensils when present stocks are exhausted.
SOFIA, Bugar, Feb. 17 -- The text of the Turkish-Bulgarian friendship declaration, as issued here tonight, follows:

Certain politicians have advanced the idea that a new social order, built upon brotherhood, will be established when the war is over. This theory, when dissected, is about as visionary as the desert mirage, assuming that the conflict is fought to bitter conclusions.

In an effort to acquaint American women with proper home-laundering methods, the Easy Washing Machine Corporation will inaugurate an extensive campaign in newspapers, magazines and on the air next week to promote its home laundry clinic, a complete display set-up for store.

The first sizable decline in steel operations since March, 1940, is scheduled this week, reflecting mainly shut-downs for repairs. For six months straight the industry has done better than 90 per cent of its rated capacity and, while this gave effect to relinings of furnaces here and there, there has been no "bunching" of repairs up to the present time.

The Supreme Court has unanimously upheld the conviction of Earl Browder, the Presidential nominee of the Communist party in 1940, on a charge of using a passport obtained by false statements. Mr. Browder's case has had a full, open hearing and a fair trial. The facts have been established beyond dispute, and they show that Hr. Browder violated a Federal law.

The board of directors of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers approved yesterday a consent decree terminating the Federal Government's anti-trust suits against the society. Formal announcement of the decree by the Department of Justice was expected to be made within the next few days, possibly today.

The Canadian dollar rose 1 3/8 cents yesterday in the free market here to 85 cents, its highest level since Jan. 21. Following that date, the Dominion's currency unit declined as a result of "inflationary" interpretations by market professionals of a formal speech by the Canadian Prime Minister, who mentioned currency expansion.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company petitioned the United States Circuit Court of Appeals today for an order to restrain the Interstate Commerce Commission from submitting its reorganization plan to bondholders until disposal of the road's court appeal of the plan.

"Non-aggression pact" has become an ominous phrase in recent years, and the accord announced yesterday between Bulgaria and Turkey is on the surface anything but reassuring. It seems to mean that if German troops march into Bulgaria Turkey will do nothing to oppose them.

The selective draft brings the question of syphilis again to the fore. With thousands of young men drilling in training camps, a problem which is as old as war cries out again for solution. Dr. Haven Emerson re-examined it before the Regional Conference on Social Hygiene, not from the standpoint of military exigency but from that of public health.

Three new films will arrive on Broadway today. At the Rialto the newcomer will be "Road Show," a Hal Roach production based on the Eric Hatch novel of the same name. Adolphe Menjou, Carole Landis, John Hubbard, Charles Butter-worth, Edward Norris, Patsy Kelly and George E. Stone are featured in the comedy, which has a carnivals background. . . .
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Federal Trade Commission cannot police trade methods within a State even though the practices compete with interstate business, the Supreme Court decided by 5 to 3 today.

The Pressed Steel Car Company has received an order for 300 automobile cars from the Canadian National Railways, according to the magazine Railway Age. The Greenville Steel Car Company received orders for 100 flat cars and the Magor Car Corporation for 200 gondola cars from the same company. Greenville also has received the award of orders for twenty box cars from the War Department and thirty-three box ears from the Navy Department.

Mike Kaplan, 145 1/4, Boston, and Tony Marteliano, 147 3/4, East Side, boxed to a ten-round draw in the main bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. It was a keenly waged fight. Kaplan scored repeatedly with jolting left jabs, but the East Sider had an edge in the infighting.

LONDON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- British-Japanese relations are "decidedly easier," Japanese diplomats said tonight following a conference be tween Japanese Ambassador Mamoru Shigemitsu and Richard Austen Butler, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of the Foreign Office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A program by the Cities Service Company to increase its investments in certain subsidiaries, engaged principally in the oil and gas business, by a maximum of $12,000,000 over the next year was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Emanuel Vardi, who made his New York debut at the age of 7 as a player of the piano, last night at the Town Hall at the age of 25 made a second debut as the player of an instrument that is far less frequently heard at solo recitals -- the viola.

Although raw wool consumption reached the highest level on record during the last quarter of 1940, wool textile mill activity in the year as a whole did not exceed that in 1939, according to the current issue of Monthly Statistics issued yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- It is the fixed policy of the United States Government that the German Government is responsible for the material welfare of the people of regions occupied by Nazi troops, Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles declared today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 18 -- After lively aerial activity yesterday and last night -- when at least two Nazi planes were destroyed during raids on London, East and Southeast England and North Scotland -- there was a lull on Britain's sky front early this morning, somewhat to the surprise of many who had expected the incessant, if sporadic, bombing attacks to keep up.

The action of President Roosevelt at the end of last week in invoking the Railway Labor Act to forestall a threatened strike on the Rutland Railroad served to direct attention again to the proposals that have been made for government action to prevent strikes from interfering with the defense program.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 17 (AP) -- A new group of sportsmen, with Joseph M. Roebling of Trenton and Harbourton as their spokesman, advanced revised plans today to erect a horse race track at the site of the old Elkwood Park track at Oceanport, Monmouth County.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 17 -- To restrict gasoline consumption further, the government has proposed to abolish the oil companies' cartel and substitute a pool, but at the companies' request has agreed to alternative conditions achieving the same results. While the companies retain their identity, the gasoline sold under present trade names will be standardized, making one type for the whole Commonwealth.

The four relay events in the National A.A.U. indoor track and field games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday have attracted a total of thirty-two teams, Daniel J. Ferris, director of the meet, announced yesterday. There will be relays at 880 yards and one mile and medleys at 1,000 yards and one mile and seven-eights.
VICHY, Feb. 17 (UP) -- If Vice Premier Francois Darlan succeeds in reopening negotiations with the occupation power in Paris, six major problems await settlement:
BERLIN, Feb. 17 (AP) -- D.N.B., official German news agency, reported tonight that a ssmall number of German combat and observation planes took off for England.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- President Roosevelt recommended to Congress today a new $150,000,000 defense housing program, while John M. Carmody, Works Administrator, outlined management policies for the government projects.

The Arkansas Supreme Court paved the way yesterday for one of the largest refinancing programs to be undertaken in one operation in the State and municipal field in several years. By validating Act No. 4 of 1941, recently passed by the State Legislature, the State Refunding Board was placed in a position to proceed with the issuance of $136,330,557 of State of Arkansas refunding bonds to refund outstanding highway obligations.

ROME, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Virginio Gayda, editor of the authoritative Giornale d'Italia, claimed in an editorial today that Britain's Balkan policy was a complete failure, as the Balkan nations had reached an understanding with the Axis powers and Russia.

Declaring the organization of all business to cooperate with the government was vital to protect democracy in the present world crisis, George H. Mead, president of the Mead Corporation, paper manufacturer, said yesterday that a new law similar to the NRA, with certain alerations, "might be to the best interests of the country and to industry itself."

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Confusion was added to confusion in London tonight when it was announced that Turkey and Bulgaria had signed a declaration proclaiming that Turkey and Bulgaria intended to live together in an atmosphere of peace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover said today that he favored a bill to legalize wire-tapping by Federal agents provided use of that method of investigation was limited to cases involving such major crimes as espionage, sabotage, kidnapping and extortion.

Assistant Attorney General Arnold testified at a hearing before the Temporary National Economic Committee that combinations of labor unions among themselves and with employers are levying tribute from the lowest income brackets, that such practices are thus far limited to a small minority of labor unions and restricted to the construction and trucking industries.

The management of the Detroit Edison Company issued yesterday a proposal to stockholders calling for an increase in the amount of capital stock of the utility outstanding from 1,272,260 shares to 6,361,300 shares. The proposed increase in stock outstanding, amounting to a five-for-one split-up, would be accompanied by a reduction in the stated par value of the stock from $100 a share to $20 a share.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A range finder with the speed of an electric eye is directing the fire of Britain's anti-aircraft guns in what has been described here as an entirely new type of coordinated air-ground warfare against night bombers.

A new method for locating oil and natural gas deep below the surface, so sensitive that it determines the presence of hydrocarbon gases in small samples of soil in quantities as minute as two parts in a billion, was described here yesterday before the annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Engineering Societies Building.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Roosevelt has taken steps virtually to isolate from all but the armed forces of the United States eleven islands and one bay which are regarded as keys to the American defense system in the Pacific, Alaskan and Caribbean areas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The House Rules Committee sidetracked all other legislation today to make way for the Vinson bill, which authorizes the expenditure of $242, 373,500 for the expansion of American naval bases, and seeks Congressional approval for President Roosevelt's destroyers-bases deal with Great Britain.

ATHENS, Feb. 18 -- According to information available here tonight, the Greek offensive along the Albanian front continued satisfactorily. Commenting on the day's developments, the spokesman mentioned the "stubborn resistance" that, he said, the Italians had generally offered.

Store leases in the Madison and Lexington Avenue districts of Manhattan formed an imposing part of the commercial rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Tailors, book dealers, women's wear firms and a restaurant were among the concerns represented by the deals.

The ranks of unsigned Yankee ball players thinned yesterday with the defection of the biggest single unit in the brigade. Ernie (Tiny) Bonham, all 215 pounds of him came into the fold. President Edward Grant Barrow made the announcement as soon as the contract fluttered from the morning mail after a journey from Sacramento, Calif., where Bonham makes his home.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company issued $1,708,837,245 of paid-for life insurance in 1940 and paid to policyholders and their beneficiaries the record amount of $608,993,958, according to Frederick H. Ecker, chairman of the board, and Leroy A. Lincoln, president.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- At the request of the State Banking Department, Senator Williamson and Assemblyman Stephens, chairmen of the Banks Committees in the Legislature, introduced a series of bills designed to afford "greater protection to banking institutions against certain losses resulting directly or indirectly from the war in Europe."

By a vote of 15 to 2 yesterday the City Council defeated Mayor La Guardia's proposal to request the National Selective Service Administration to defer city policemen and firemen from military service under the draft act.

Jimmy Webb, St. Louis light-heavyweight, and Tommy Tucker, East Rockaway, L.I., star, will conclude training today for their fifteen-round battle Friday night in Madison Square Garden. The bout will be the first in a series of three to determine a successor to Billy Conn as 175-pound champion of the world. Conn is expected to surrender the title before meeting Joe Louis for the heavyweight crown in June.

The General Baking Company reported yesterday for the fifty-two weeks ended on Dec. 28 a net profit of $1,923,926 after Federal income taxes and other deductions. The company said it did not expect to pay an excess profits tax for 1940.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- One hundred men and women skiers from thirty clubs, by far the largest and strongest entry in the meet's history, assembled tonight at the Lake Placid Club for the Sno Birds' annual competition starting tomorrow and ending Saturday.

Full American aid to Britain has been, and is being, attacked in this country by two opposing groups whose arguments tend to rebut each other. One group says that the British Empire is in fact as well as name imperialistic, that it is aristocratic and that it is therefore not worth saving.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 18 -- The new Ambassador to Great Britain, former Governor John G. Winant, appeared before a joint session of the Legislature in his home city today and pleaded for "all out" aid "short of manpower" for England against forces "which are opposed to our form of democracy."

Homer M. Adkins, Governor of Arkansas and chairman of the State Refunding Board, was a Wall Street visitor yesterday in connection with the State's forthcoming $136,330,557 refunding program. Coming from Washington, where he had discussed details of the plan with officials of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Governor Adkins attended a series of conferences here with prospective underwriters of the new loan and with executives of numerous large institutional investors.

Steve Belloise got revenge last night. In a stirring duel before 12,000 fans in the Bronx Coliseum, he knocked out stout-hearted Andre Jessurun in the seventh round of the scheduled ten-round feature, thus ending dramatically one of the greatest middleweight battles seen here in recent years.

ROME, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Premier Mussolini's newspaper, Popolo d'Italia, asserted today that "something very big" is about to occur in the Mediterranean war zone which may entrap the formidable British and Australian forces now scattered over the African fronts.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Following is the text of a report of the minority of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee opposing the Administration's British aid bill:

In celebration of having aided the 18,000th boy in its thirty-six years of service, the Big Brother Movement, Inc., held a dinner last night in the Hotel Commodore. Mrs. Wilton Merle-Smith, wife of the late pastor of Central Presbyterian Church, in whose home the movement was founded, was the guest of honor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Jerome Chester Cuppia said today that so far as he knew no customer of his brokerage firm had suffered through the manner in which he had distributed business for execution on the floor of the New York Curb Exchange.

A group headed by E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc., received the award yesterday of $1,800,000 of city of Pittsburgh (Pa.) refunding and funding bonds on a bid of 101.15 for 2s. The bonds, dated Feb. 1, and due in installments of $90,000 annually from Feb. 1, 1942 to 1961, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.40 to 2 per cent, according to maturity.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A pair of goals by Art Jackson offset two scored by Syl Apps tonight when the Boston Bruins stretched their new National Hockey League unbeaten record to twenty-two games by gaining a 2-2 overtime tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs before 16,2O9 at Boston Garden.

DUBLIN, Feb. 18 -- Sean MaCentee, Minister of Industry and Commerce, addressing the annual conference of Eire's industrial leaders here this evening, did not mince words in depicting for them the serious economic position in which this State finds itself as a result of the war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Departing from his text in the debate today on the lease-lend bill, Senator Clark of Missouri said:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A meeting of members of the aluminum industry under auspices of the National Defense Advisory Commission disclosed today that some manufacturers were withholding large stocks of the metal in expectation of future shortages.
New fashion ensembles were shown yesterday by Zoe de Salle, Spring and Summer millinery by Henri Bendel and styles for youth by Lanz of Salzburg.

Bruno Walter, who made his debut as a conductor at the Metropolitan Opera House last Friday, was the guest of honor at a luncheon given yesterday by the Metropolitan Opera Guild at the Hotel Plaza. Lucrezia Bori, honorary chairman of the Guild, presided.

Mayor La Guardia, in a now familiar role, handled an acetylene torch day before yesterday to start the razing of the upper Second Avenue elevated line. Thereafter, in an equally familiar role, the Mayor accused the Citizens Budget Commission of publishing "lies" to block the demolition of the Fulton Street "L" in Brooklyn.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 -- Manufacturers of gift wares and cooking utensils, here to attend the eighth annual New England Housewares Show in the Parker House, report that there is already a shortage in aluminum and that shortages are impending in brass, chrome steel and possibly in cast iron.

RIOM, France, Feb. 18 -- Edouard Daladier and Leon Blum, former Prime Ministers; Maurice Gustave Gamelin, former Commander in Chief, and Guy La Chambre, former Air Minister, are still under detention at Bourassol, a few miles from this town, indicted for responsibility in bringing about both the war and defeat.

Switching from support of his own bill in Albany, Mayor La Guardia joined with the Democratic majority of the City Council yesterday in urging the Legislature to adopt speedily the Steingut bill which would validate the city's contract for the leasing of 250 buses to replace the service of seven street-car lines in Brooklyn and permit prompt removal of the Fulton Street elevated line.

Visiting buyer registrations last week were 940 as against 1,184 in the previous week and 1,018 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Buyers recorded yesterday totaled 523 which compared with 478 for a week ago.

DETROIT, Feb. 18 -- Present methods of administrating the priorities system in defense operations threaten to disrupt the tank-building program around which the Army has built its plans for development of mechanization.

"Meet John Doe," the first film made by Frank Capra and Robert Riskin as independent producers, will have a simultaneous world premiere at both the Rivoli and Fifty-first Street (formerly Hollywood) Theatres here about the middle of March, it was announced yesterday by Warners, distributors of the picture.

A realty man who has long been identified with home developments in Westchester has now turned to the New York market for the first time in twenty years with the purchase of two business properties in midtown.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- A proposal was made in the Senate today to aid Great Britain by having the firearms taken from criminals by police in the State sent to England instead of being destroyed, as is now the case.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Reynolds Metal Company, Richmond, Va., obtained from the Federal Power Commission today a day-rate basis for the purchase of government-generated electric power at Bonneville dam on the Columbia River for the production of aluminum to be used in the national defense program.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 18 -- An authoritative editorial today in the government party newspaper Magyar Orsag heralds the Bulgarian-Turkish treaty of non-aggression as a harbinger of peace and order in the Balkans under the aegis of Germany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Places of amusement operated commercially for profit took in about $1,000,000,000 in 1939, or close to $30 for each family in the country, the Census Bureau stated today on the basis of a survey showing the existence of 44,917 such places of amusement in this country.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Wednesday, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch or another high Yugoslav official is expected to come here soon for consultations, and some Bulgarian circles expect a new Yugoslav-Bulgarian non-aggression declaration to result, along the lines of the Turkish-Bulgarian accord.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads reported today that eighty-seven Class I railroads had estimated operating revenues of $307,911,354 in January, compared with $284,650,775 in January, 1940. These eighty-seven roads provided 82.4 per cent of total operating revenues of all Class I carriers.

Roland Hayes, the Negro tenor who made his New York debut at Aeolian Hall on Jan. 30, 1919, gave a recital last night at the Town Hall. As one of his encores, he sang a work that appeared on his first program, "Le Reve" from Massenet's "Manon."

Since Adolf Hitler has exploited the "essential weaknesses" of capitalism to prepare the way for Blitzkrieg in his world revolution, Ernest G. Draper, member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, asserted last night, the democracies "must forge a counter-weapon" against this Nazi technique.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 18 -- The general opinion prevailing the day following the signing of the Bulgarian-Turkish agreement is that neither of the two countries wants to go to war and that the treaty proves it. The joint declaration has of necessity caused endless speculation and any number of interpretations in the world press, but opinion here prefers to believe that it affects only the two nations directly involved and is to their benefit.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Feb. 18 -- Carter Goodrich, United States Government representative to the International Labor Office and chairman of its governing body, has informed the governing body and the State members of the I.L.O. of John G. Winant's resignation as director in the following note just issued here:

The Continental American Life Insurance Company, Wilmington, Del., in its thirty-third annual statement, reported total admitted assets on Dec. 31 of $26,953,093, the highest on record. They compare with $24,858,492 at the end of the preceding year.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Wednesday, Feb. 19 -- Authoritative word that German planes are flying daily over Greek territory came from Greece coincident with reports that the Nazis had advised Athens to make peace with Italy lest German armies enter the Albanian conflict on Premier Mussolini's side.
Winning eight of the nine events, the Brooklyn College swimming team scored a 54-to-21 triumph over Manhattan in the winners' pool last !night. This was the sixth victory for the undefeated Xingsmen.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Verne Marshall, chairman of the No Foreign War Committee, said today:

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 19 -After another day of skirmishes over Great Britain in which the Germans were said to have lost four planes and the British none, the people of this country enjoyed a quiet time of it once again early today. Britain's enemies on the European Continent got a similar respite because the Royal Air Force withheld its fire because of adverse flying weather.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18 -- Paced by Tommy Goodwin of New York, the medalist, most of the favorites came safely through the opening round of match play in the South Florida golf tournament at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.

One is never tired of reading in translation of the old gods and heroes and saints of Ireland. The only complaint that can be made is that their names are naturally unpronounceable. In the few specimens of transliteration given by the translators one is likely to jump at the doubtless erroneous conclusion that silence is a characteristic of Gaelic consonants.
BERLIN, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The German High Command said in a communique today:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 18 -- High waters ravaged peasant villages tonight in Croatia and Montenegro and the Yugoslav Army posted engineers in the northern reaches of the Danube as the belief grows that the Hungarian floods will extend to this country.

Undefeated this season, Captain Fran Powers of Harvard assumed first place in the race for individual scoring honors in the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League by scoring two victories in the recent meet with Dartmouth, according to statistics released yesterday. Powers now has a total of 30 points as a result of half a dozen triumphs.

Japanese bombing planes that raided the Burma Road on Oct. 26 missed an American mission hospital in Namkham, Burma, two miles from the Chinese border, according to a letter just received here from Dr. Gordon Seagrave, the medical missionary in charge of the institution.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- While September wheat dipped to a new seasonal low in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today there was no material pressure on the market and a rather firm undertone was in evidence from the start.
LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The United States turned a cold shoulder today to the assertion of Koh Ishii, Japanese official spokesman, that his government's intentions were peaceful, that Japan was ready to mediate in any conflict in the world and that this country should confine its "warlike preparations" to the Western Hemisphere.

A field goal made in a second overtime session by Bill Holroyd enabled Eastern District to upset the Thomas Jefferson High School basketball team, 47 to 46, in a Section 1, Brooklyn P.S.A.L. game on the winner's floor yesterday. It was the first league defeat for Jefferson, which is assured of a tie for the group title.

The Corps des Pages Association composed of former pages at the court of the Czar, gave a dinner dance last night at the Casino Russe in West Fifty-sixth Street for the benefit of the organization's emergency fund. Present members of the association were officers of the Russian Imperial Army and are veterans of the World War.

Improvement in traffic and shopping conditions along Fifth Avenue through reduction in the number of parades, elimination of "tin can" solicitation of funds for "charitable organizations" and repaving and widening work was reported to the members of the Fifth Avenue Association at its annual meeting yesterday in the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Admiral Harold R. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations, and Rear Admiral Robert I. Ghormley on naval aid to Great Britain, and with W. Averell Harriman, whose appointment to go to London and act as "expediter" of the British end of the lease-lend program he announced later at a press conference.

Plans were announced yesterday for a new sixty-eight-family apartment project in Farmingdale, Nassau County, where a shortage of housing has developed as the result of the rapid expansion of the several airplane plants there which are busy with defense orders.

Legal action to prevent the executive council of the American Federation of Teachers from going ahead with its proposed referendum to determine whether the charters of the two local teachers unions shall be revoked is being considered, Charles J. Hendley, president of Local 5, one of the locals, said yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Food Minister Lord Woolton again warned the British today that they would have to tighten their belts further and make a still greater effort to live off their own produce.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The Senate by unanimous vote passed today and sent to the Governor the first defense measure adopted at this session, the Ostertag bill establishing the New York State Defense Council and authorizing cities and counties to set up and appropriate funds' for local defense councils.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Minister of the Interior Miguel Aleman announced today that foreign capital would be permitted to "participate" in the exploration and exploitation of new oil fields after the settlement of the expropriation question with foreign interests, principally United States and British, who lost their properties in 1938.

Reversing the trend of last week, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday advanced 4 to 11 points, but the recovery was more the result of a decrease in selling rather than any aggressive revival of buying. The opening was strong, with prices 3 to 5 points higher than Monday's final quotations.

Despite a verbal Blitzkrieg launched against Adolf Hitler by his American ill-wishers, with every blast at the expense of the German Government, the appeal for criticism was renewed last night in an announcement from Germany picked up here by the Columbia Broadcasting System's short-wave system.

If the weekly figures on brokers' loans to be published Friday morning show an increase after three successive weeks of declines, it will probably be due to borrowings by government security dealers in connection with the acquisitions of Treasury bonds and notes which are to be refunded as of March 15.

Wendell L. Willkie passed his forty-ninth birthday yesterday without any special observation on his part. Friends and admirers marked the occasion by sending him about 7,000 cards, letters, telegrams and gifts, which all but overwhelmed his staff at his apartment, 1010 Fifth Avenue, and his headquarters in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Congress, by enacting the lease-lend bill, is about to reverse the foreign and the domestic policies which have guided the United States since the days of George Washington, three opponents of the measure told the Senate today in their first inning in the debate.

Miss Rose Tevel, whose letter on Italy you published, has a slight misconception of the origin of the Mafia in Sicily. Like the Camorra in Naples, that organization began as an effort of oppressed and lowly people against the tyrannies of certain governing groups. When the populace gained power, as in the case of the Masaniello revolution in Naples in the seventeenth century, they went to extremes and had to be suppressed.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 18 -- Turkish newspapers lauded the Turkish-Bulgarian declaration of non-aggression today as an assurance of peace in the Balkans. They emphasized that the declaration in nowise conflicted with agreements with other countries -- meaning Turkey's alliance with Britain.
Making his first appearance in a dog show, Brian, a Kerry Blue terrier, won top honors as the tenth annual Bloomingdale's pet show was continued yesterday. A total of ninety-eight terriers competed.

From Forty-second Street to Coney Island may be a long subway ride to the average passenger but it was never long enough for George Adam Ruge who says that for three years he spent each night sleeping in the cars after begging a nickel for fare.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Challedon demonstrated today that he still could be ranked as a big contender in the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap on March 1.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Hog prices showed life at the opening today but closed with practically all the advance lost. Activity in early trading sent prices up 10 to 15 cents and the top to $8.20. Late top, however, dropped to $8. Pork loins remained steady at 16 1/2 to 17 1/2 cents a pound, with choice 180 to 240 pound hogs getting in under the late decline at $7.90 to $8.15.

ROME, Feb. 18 -- Four Ethiopian Rases are rallying their tribesmen to fight under the Italian flag against the British, it was stated today in a Stefani dispatch from Asmara, Eritrea, Gugsa, Seyoum, Mangasha and Ayelu Burru are the chieftains named.
MADRID, Feb. 18 -- Mrs. Alexander W. Weddell, wife of the United States Ambassador, today donated 10,000 pesetas for the relief of the victims of the disastrous fire at Santander.

EVERY so often Promoter Ned Irish drops around to talk about basketball. He has some to sell. He sells it in large quantities, too, at Madison Square Garden. It must be a good article because the customers yell for it.

Although the average native of South America is now well disposed to the United States, pro-Nazi sentiment is in evidence in certain quarters of Brazil and Bolivia, Hubert Herring, director of the Committee on Cultural Relations with Latin America, declared here yesterday.

A check for $40,000 for the purchase of mobile field kitchens for England was presented yesterday to the British War Relief Society by the Jewish Section of the Inter-Faith Committee to Aid the Democracies as the first installment of funds the section is raising for this purpose.

With 300 persons in attendance, the Metropolitan Rod and Gun Editor's Association held its fourth annual dinner at the Ruppert Bierstube last night. A feature of the affair was the presentation to Dr. John B. Vernaglia of Medford, Mass., of the organization's trophy for the "most outstanding angling achievement of 1940."

BERLIN, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A magazine article, which had the approval of the German High Command, said today that the United States could "make the same mistake as Russia and China" in underestimating the fighting strength of Japan.

A skit written by Mayor La Guardia designed to help educate New York grocers in the operation of the Federal food stamp plan, which is to go into effect for the entire city on March 1, will be presented Feb. 26 before an audience of retail food merchants at the Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street near Eighth Avenue.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Most sections in the stock markets were dull today, with several gilt-edge securities slightly easier. Home-rail buyers lost some of their enthusiasm, and, with little profit-taking, prices of juniors were mostly lower.
SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, Feb. 18 -- An Australian imperial force many thousands strong reached Singapore today.

The first piece of steel has been fitted into the new $4,000,000 Rainbow Bridge which is to span the gorge of the Niagara River below the Falls. Though not exactly on the same site, it will replace the famous Honeymoon Bridge that was swept away in an ice jam several years ago.

After a trip through heavy weather which necessitated art unscheduled landing at Port Etienne, Mauritania, French West Africa, the Dixie Clipper landed at the marine terminal of La Guardia Field at 10:27 A.M. yesterday to complete a flight from Lisbon over the southern route that Pan American Airways flies during the Winter.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 18 -- Wall Street's overnight improvement and especially the marked relaxation over the Far East situation, coupled with the Turkish-Bulgarian pact, created strength in today's Bourse. The close was decidedly cheerful, with Dutch issues mostly to 10 ]uoints higher.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Neutral diplomatic quarters said today that the most important effect of the Turkish-Bulgarian nonaggression declarations was that it excluded the possibility of Turkey's making a military move when Germany invades Bulgaria.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18 -- "He will start Saturday, barring injury." This was the terse reply of Warren Wright after his crack colt, Whirlaway, had been so beaten off at seven furlongs in today's Arcadia Purse at Hialeah Park as to arouse speculation about his going to the post on Saturday in the $20,000 added Flamingo Stakes leading 3-year-old race of the meeting.

The legislative committee of the New York State Bankers Association, of which Orie R. Kelly, president of the Lawyers Trust Company, is chairman, is sending to members of the association circulars urging that the State's mortgage moratorium be ended by the State Legislature.

Carmine J. Marasco, Democrat, easily won a seat in the State Senate from the Fourth Brooklyn District yesterday at a special election. He will succeed Philip M. Kleinfeld, who was named recently to the Supreme Court bench in the Second Department.

With almost every page reflecting in some measure the profound changes of the last twelve months, the 1941 edition of "Political Handbook of the World" makes its appearance today under the joint imprint of the Council on Foreign Relations and Harper Bros. Walter H. Mallory, the editor, says the sources through which the handbook has been compiled are many and varied, with many private channels augmenting the official.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 -- "World Premiere," an original scenario by Earl Felton dealing with a carload of film celebrities who arrive in a small town for the opening of a picture, was scheduled today to go before the cameras March 10 at Paramount with Otis Garrett directing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A "two faces" disease, one of the rarest of medical anomalies, has just been reported from two hospitals of the Veterans Administration. One side of a victim's face changes in appearance until it becomes essentially that of another person.

Prices of most classes of traefer meats yesterday were about in line with Monday. Trading was only fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were steady. The cow and bull beef markets were steady to firm. Veal hindsaddles were steady; lamb hindsaddles, fully steady. The fresh pork market was unchanged. Kosher veal and lamb markets were steady to firm.

The National Committee for Planned Parenthood, 501 Madison Avenue, began yesterday a campaign to raise $623,000 to finance the program of the Birth Control Federation of America and its affiliated groups, according to an announcement by Mrs. Margaret Sanger, chairman of the committee.
R.A. West of the Princeton Club distinguished himself with a strong challenge to Frank Iannicelli of the New York A.C. yesterday in the invitation squash tennis tournament at the Whitehall Club.

Within the past ten days several references to the stock market have appeared on your editorial page. One, "The Shrinking Market," another by Arthur Krock, another by Bruno Pinkney, and still another. I made up my mind they should be answered.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, in Libya, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The destruction of nearly 500 Italian airplanes on the ground stands out as one of the chief reasons for the success of Britain's Egyptian-Libyan campaign.

Another sharp advance in the Hong Kong and Shanghai currencies occurred yesterday, reflecting the heavy trading being clone in the Orient. The Hong Kong dollar rose 9 points on the day to 24.69 cents, the highest level since early in February, 1940, and the Shanghai dollar advance 8 points on the day to 5.89 cents, the highest rate since mid-December.

BERLIN, Feb. 18 -- Official sources here continue to refrain from comment on recent developments in France. D.N.B., the official news agency, reports from Paris tonight that Admiral Francois Darlan again arrived there today and began conversations with Fernand de Brinon, Vichy's representative.

No enthusiasm will be evoked by the suggestion of the Japanese official spokesman that the present war be terminated by peace negotiations under the aegis of Japan. Nor is acceptance of the offer likely, for several good reasons. One is that Japan as a mediator has not been, to put it mildly, an outstanding success.

The officers of the New Jersey League of Surf Anglers are to be congratulated for the work they have done and are doing at the Sportsmen's Show to bring home to the sporting public the need for additional protection of certain salt water fish, especially the striped bass.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Victor Devilliers, 54, a New York financial promoter, collapsed and was carried from court today as he and seven other men appeared to be sentenced for fraudulently obtaining money from business enterprises which needed capital.

The Ballet Theatre opened its second week at the Majestic Theatre last night with a revival of one of its most distinguished productions, the Eugene Loring-William Saroyan "balletplay," "The Great American Goof." This experimental piece, combining the spoken word with the usual ingredients of ballets, is inevitably controversial, and it is safe to say that dyed-in-the-wool balletomanes will never take it to their hearts.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- On the heels of the bus bill introduced yesterday the La Guardia administration sent to Albany today its long-awaited measure to permit the city to divert excess revenues from its unemployment relief taxes to other social welfare purposes, thus relieving part of the strain on the normal city budget.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The Assembly passed today and sent to Governor Lehman the Bewley-Whitney bill which allows the State Tax Commission to extend in its discretion the time for corporations to pay the State corporation taxes. The bill had been passed by the State Senate.

While volume in the paper industry this year is likely to run ahead of the record set in 1940, the industry has the capacity to meet all war and consumer needs if speculative buying is avoided, J.L. Riegel, president of the American Paper and Pulp Association, said yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the Salesmen's Association of the Paper Industry, held in conjunction with the annual convention of the A.P.P.A. at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Looking beyond the National A.A.U. track and field championships on Saturday at Madison Square Garden, where their scoring potentialities are light, and gazing instead at the I.C. 4-A title tests a week later, Columbia, Penn and Princeton will engage in their seventh annual Polar Bear meet on Columbia's South Field track this afternoon at 2 o'clock.

The 207th Coast Artillery, New York's old Seventh Regiment, will leave today for Camp Stewart, Hinesville, Ga., where it will undergo a year's training. It is an anti-aircraft mobile unit and was inducted into Federal service recently. Preparations for departure were completed yesterday at the armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

With the start of a new Old Gold campaign yesterday, the first handled by the J. Walter Thompson Company, newspapers are beginning to get a good share of cigarette advertising again. Lucky Strikes is one of the major brands not now in papers and Pall Malls are also out, until campaign plans have been worked out by Ruthrauff Ryan.

Production of crude oil in the United States last week averaged 3,638,100 barrels daily, an increase of 20,450 over the 3,617,650 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The output was 9,200 barrels more than the calculation of 3,628,900 daily by the Bureau of Mines for February, with an increase of 25,600 barrels daily in Kansas, the most important change.

BERLIN, Wednesday, Feb. 19 (UP) -- The entire German press, led by Adolf Hitler's Voelkischer Beobachter, today hailed the Turkish-Bulgarian non-aggression accord as a smashing defeat for Britain's efforts to obtain a foothold on the European Continent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- W. Averell Harriman, New York banker and defense official, will leave in ten days or two weeks for London to take up the post of "expediter" of American war materials to be lent Great Britain for use against the Axis powers.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Japanese Navy units in the Gulf of Siam were reported heavily reinforced today and a Netherland authority forecast land and sea blows at Singapore, Britain's Far Eastern Gibraltar, and at the Netherlands Indies in the "very near future."

HAVANA, Feb. 18 -- A lot of Cuban confusion enveloped the Dodgers today and before they struggled out of it Manager Leo Durocher was in a rage, Secretary John McDonald in a state of extreme nervousness and President Larry MacPhail in a mood to start a revolution of his own.

MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Demands for a reorganization of Communist party units to wipe out "bottlenecks" that have slowed down Soviet industrial output were made today by a dozen high leaders before the first national Communist party conference held since 1939.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The House passed today by 210 to 143 a bill to reapportion the House seats under the 1940 census by the "equal proportions" formula, which gives the 435th and final seat in the chamber to Arkansas. Under the "major fractions" method now in use the seat would go to Michigan.

Three new apartment houses are planned in Brooklyn and a number of small home groups are projected in the same borough and in Queens, according to plans filed yesterday. The multi-family buildings are to occupy sites on Ocean Parkway, Lenox Road and East Eighteenth Street. Their cost is estimated at $220,000, $200,000 and $105,000 respectively.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works, inluding the Midvale Company, reported for 1940 a consolidated net profit of $1,944,072, or $1.75 a common share, compared with $542,026 in 1939. The company's share in the Midvale earnings in 1940 was $1,984,750, against $1,047.942 in 1939.

With the trading volume in stocks on the Stock Exchange the second smallest of the year, price fluctuations yesterday were narrow and meaningless and the closing was irregularly lower. The intricacies poised by the Balkan and Far Eastern situations continued to restrict business to mere routine transactions.

TOKYO, Feb. 18 -- This morning's statement by the Cabinet spokesman that Japan was willing to serve as mediator to end present conflicts and his urging of Britain and the United States to refrain from alarming reports concerning Pacific tension receives two interpretations here.

Sweden has made arrangements with both the British and German Governments for the passage of vitally needed merchandise and equipment through the blockades of the warring governments to ports in Sweden, exporters reported yesterday at a round-table session on foreign trade problems by members of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Godley gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Norman Harrower, Mrs. Albert C. Burrage, Mrs. George McM. Godley, Henry Stimson and Edward F. Swenson.

The League of New York Theatres, the organization of Broadway producers, entered the radio music war yesterday, demanding a share in the royalties that music publishers receive for use of musical comedy songs on the air.

A long time has passed since the day last May when Mr. Roosevelt at his press conference declared that there was no reason for the country to become "discomboomerated" by the defense program, and that our women need not give up their cosmetics, lipsticks and chocolate sodas because of it.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 18 -- Nations at war have at first lengthened and then reduced working hours to achieve maximum production, Dr. Mollie Ray Carroll, government labor economist and author, said here today.

The "rent differential" plan under which the cost of an apartment would be adjusted to the tenant's income and his "ability to pay" will be utilized to some extent by the New York Housing Authority in the selection of families to occupy East River Houses.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Occidental sources in Saigon, the "Winter capital" of Indo-China, reported today that the T. hailand-[ Indo-China peace conference in Tokyo Virtually had been suspended following French charges that Thailand was not living up to the terms of the armistice agreement reached last month under Japanese mediation.

A disbarred lawyer and a man who once escaped punishment for criticizing Adolf Hitler in Germany were accused yesterday of obtaining $850 from a German refugee to whom they promised a job in "Arthritis College."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 -- Robert T. Boltz, investment counselor who until October was hailed as a financial genius by many of his clients, pleaded guilty in Quarter Sessions Court today to 180 indictments charging embezzlement and fraudulent conversion.

After a partisan debate yesterday on the merits of the Council committee investigating the Civil Service Commission, the City Council blocked a minority move to replace the present membership of the investigating committee as well as its counsel, Emil K. Ellis.

"Hellzapoppin" will have the distinction of being the first Broadway show this season to be performed in an Army camp. Next Monday the company of the Olsen and Johnson revue, which omits Monday night performances here, will be picked up at the Winter Garden by Army trucks and taken to Fort Dix, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Inherent in the two-headed set-up of the Office of Production Management were waste, duplicated effort and complaints from within and without. All three have come promptly. When speaking off the record there are important officials in Washington outside OPM who have few good words to say about its contribution.

The Aviation Corporation, following a meeting of directors, announced yesterday that, subject to the registration statement becoming effective, it would proceed with the offering of 1,445,555 shares of its authorized and unissued capital stock to its stockholders at $3.50 a share. Subscription rights will be mailed to stockholders of record on Feb. 24 and will expire on March 10.

Magistrate Thomas Aurelio yesterday characterized as "shameful and disgraceful" the actions of two women who carried a coffin while picketing yesterday morning in front of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., a textile firm at 43 Leonard Street.

Justice John E. McGeehan in a twenty-eight-page decision handed down yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court, declared invalid the Police Department regulations that sought to exclude interstate and interurban buses from the midtown area on the grounds that the act was unreasonable and the Police Commissioner had proceeded beyond the power conferred upon him by the City Charter.

Ratification of the proposed eight amendments to the Federal-State Milk Marketing Orders by dairy, farmers of the New York City milk-shed was indicated yesterday when it became known that the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association and other large groups had voted affirmatively in the second referendum.

Dr. Ernst Mayr, associate curator of the Whitney-Rothschild collection of the American Museum of Natural History, and Dr. Edgar Anderson, Professor of Botany at Washington University, St. Louis, and geneticist of the Missouri Botanical Garden, have been named Jesup lecturers in the Department of Zoology at Columbia University, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Plans to put "every ounce of energy and efficiency" behind New York State's production of defense material were discussed here today at a meeting of Governor Lehman, legislative leaders and representatives of seventy-five manufacturers.

The thrust and fire of Nathan Milstein's violin playing show no diminution with the seasons. In his Carnegie Hall recital last night he played with the flashing temperament of a youngster, without abandoning the sensibilities of a mature musician.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18 -- Eighteen changes in the Yale University faculty, including the retirement of Frank Schlesinger, astronomer and director of the Yale Observatory since 1920, were announced today by President Charles Seymour.

TRENTON, Feb. 18 -- Counsel for Edward L. Bartley of Brooklyn, N.Y., who has been in the Ocean County Jail at Toms River, N.J., for more than two years in default of $25,000 bail, began an attempt today in Chancery Court here to obtain his freedom by a reduction of the bond to $5,000.

BERLIN, Feb. 18 -- The statement by Sumner Welles that Germany was wholly responsible for feeding the populations of occupied territories was termed by authoritative German quarters today an attempt on the part of the American Under-Secretary of State to blame the Reich for the relentlessness of the British blockade policy.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The Admiralty today cushioned its latest report of British merchant shipping losses with a statement of German and Italian vessels captured, sunk or scuttled since the war began.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18 -- Because of the tardiness of the local city authorities in completing the job of renovating Miami's ball park, the Giants have been struggling along here under considerable difficulties in their efforts to whip their mound corps in shape for the early exhibition tilts with the Dodgers that will begin in Havana a week from next Friday.

Ratification of the proposed eight amendments to the Federal-State Milk Marketing Orders by dairy, farmers of the New York City milk-shed was indicated yesterday when it became known that the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association and other large groups had voted affirmatively in the second referendum.

Dr. Ernst Mayr, associate curator of the Whitney-Rothschild collection of the American Museum of Natural History, and Dr. Edgar Anderson, Professor of Botany at Washington University, St. Louis, and geneticist of the Missouri Botanical Garden, have been named Jesup lecturers in the Department of Zoology at Columbia University, it was announced yesterday.
A row of four five-story apartment houses in the Bronx changed hands in one of the deals reported yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18 -- The Venetian Room of the Breakers was the setting tonight for a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Henry McSweeney in celebration of his eighty-sixth birthday. Guests were seated at a long table adorned with roses, white lilacs and other Spring flowers and lighted by white tapers in silver candelabra.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A study of vital defense industries showed today that of 394 plants, 116 were working six days a week and sixty-eight seven days.

ROME, Feb. 18 -- There is great rejoicing here today over what is considered Turkey's decision to adapt herself to Axis domination in the Balkans and not to make a move when or if the Germans occupy Bulgaria.

Just prior to the enactment, on Oct. 8, of the Second Revenue Act of 1940, it was reported in joint conference of the Congressional Tax Committees that Section 722 of the act, which provides for general relief for the adjustment of abnormalities affecting income or capital, would be rewritten and submitted to the new Congress early in January.

Shipments of expensive flower seeds, some of them more valuable than gold, have been arriving in this country from German-occupied Holland and Denmark on around-the-world journeys by way of Russia and Japan, it was learned here yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Nazi air raiders started explosions in an industrial section southeast of Hull, England, yesterday and fired an oil depot on Moray Firth, North Scotland, the German High Command said today.

VICHY, France, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Admiral Francois Darlan, conferring in Paris today in another effort to break the two-month deadlock in French-German relations, was reported to have offered to Pierre Laval the post of Minister of the Interior in the Vichy government.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State Director of Selective Service, stated today that legal assistance from the Federal Government would be available to any local board examining physician or medical advisory board member against whom any suit might be brought.

Mrs. Mabel McKay, 51 years old, a teacher of cooking at Public School 16, Tompkinsville, S. I., and her husband, William, 67, a retired exporter, were found dead as a result of gas poisoning yesterday in their home at 47 Fort Hill Circle, New Brighton, S. I.

DETROIT, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Two men engaged in investigations for the National Labor Relations Board were arrested today, and Harold A. Cranefield, attorney for the board's regional office, accused the police tonight of failing to heed requests for protection of witnesses.
One Manufacturers' Association Fights Union -- Mayor Sees 'New Era' for Industry

INDIA might naturally seem more than a hemisphere away when you are reading about it beside a window that looks down a snow hill and across a New England pond, yet in a book* that is already ranked as one of the outstanding modern autobiographies, Jawaharial Nehru, the distinguished Indian Nationalist leader, makes the color of India as real as the black-and-white Winter landscape outside.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 18 -- British interests were the highest bidders today for two naval colliers of 19, 000 tons displacement which are easily convertible into cargo carriers. The ships are the Proteus and the Nereus which the Navy has certified are no longer needed by the United States service.

Wall Street is like a great chameleon that takes its color from the background of world events. Just now it is wearing the deepest shades of indigo. In spite of favorable earnings reports and rising business indices, stock prices, on the average, are almost down to the lows they reached last June when France collapsed.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Apparently determined to preserve the suburban character of this community, the Village Board voted 4 to 1 in an executive session tonight against the restoration of bus service through here by the New Rochelle-Yonkers bus line. Mayor Frederick L. Devereux was the only member of the five-man board to vote in favor of the line.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18 -- Mr. and Mrs. George Gale Foster of Greenwich, Conn., will be hosts at the Saturday night gala dinner dance at the Surf Club, which is in celebration of Washington's Birthday.

Going into the lead only 37 seconds after the start, the New York Rangers registered a decisive 5-to-2 triumph over the Americans in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Red Dutton's skaters, hoping that they would be able to add another defeat to the Rangers' unenviable string of four straight, waged a game enough battle, but superior numbers as well as their misplays proved too much for them.
ROME, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 18 -- Federal, State and Army officials concluded today a two-day series of conferences at which the Fort Dix Spring campaign against "General Mud" was planned. At the conclusion of the conferences Major Oliver F.W. Cromwell, acting construction quartermaster, announced that twenty miles of new hard surface roads would be installed before the end of Spring.

Visitors to the National Sportsmen's Show at Grand Central Palace usually make several discoveries during the course of an afternoon or evening, either from inspecting the assortment of sports equipment, watching expert flycasters in action, or listening to the answers given in the sportsmen's quiz at the New York State booth.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Secretary Jones told the House Currency and Banking Committee today that the United States is "in the war, or at least nearly in the war" and is "preparing for it."

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter, in a decision read from the bench at the conclusion of a six-week trial, ruled yesterday that trustees of the Reynolds Investing Company and the Continental Securities Corporation, investment, trusts, should recover approximately $2,000,000 taken in 1987-35 from the two companies by a group then buying control of Reynolds Investing, In order to raise the purchase price of the controlling stock which they bought.

The arbitration machinery for settling disputes between motion-picture producer-distributors and theatre operators was set in motion yesterday afternoon when fifty-three local business and professional men not associated with the industry were formally appointed by C.V. Whitney, president of the American Arbitration Association, as arbitrators for cases in the New York area.

When N.Y.U. and Fordham sport teams clash, the rivalry is always intense. There will be no exception to this rule in Madison Square Garden tonight when Violet and Ram meet in the twenty-second basketball game of the series.

The Socony Vacuum Tanker Men's Association, an independent union including on its membership rolls many seamen who were formerly affiliated with the National Maritime Union, has won an important run-off election conducted by the National Labor Board, it was announced last night.

Two paintings by William Thoeny (one a portrait of Cardinal Jean Verdier of Paris, the other a painting of Notre Dame) are on exhibition and sale until Feb. 22 at the War Relief Information Center, 435 Park Avenue, for the benefit of the Quaker Milk Fund.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Representative Maas of Minnesota urged the Rules Committee today to set up a special group to check negotiated national defense contracts, asserting that otherwise "a scandal will break" involving the Defense Commission.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- David C. Adie, State Commissioner of Social Welfare, announced here tonight that acting on the request of William F. Bleakley, Westchester County Executive, he had ordered a complete "study and appraisal" of the entire relief set-up in Westchester.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Emerson W. (Spike) Nelson, Yale's first non-graduate football coach, tonight named his staff of seven assistants, four of them hold-overs from the last regime.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A new system of home defense, in which the services of women and men outside the draft age limits will be used, is to be worked out in a week or two, President Roosevelt disclosed today.

Marked decreases in the incidence of influenza and pneumonia were reported in New York City during the week ended last Saturday, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, was told yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records in the Health Department.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 19 -- Bulgaria's foreign policy has undergone no change and this country has no intention of threatening anybody, and it will refrain from any kind of attack, Premier Bogdan Philoff told the Sobranje [Parliament] today in a statement accompanying the reading of the text of the Bulgarian-Turkish non-aggression agreement.

The National Maritime Union charged yesterday that bona fide union representation had been denied its members in the run-off election held on ships of the Socony Vacuum Oil Company, the results of which were announced Tuesday night.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A bill requiring motorists involved in traffic accidents to show their financial capacity to meet possible judgments against them or face mandatory revocation of license by the Motor Vehicles Commissioner was introduced in the Legislature today by Assemblyman Floyd E. Anderson, Broome County Republican.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 -- Mark Hellinger, associate producer at Warners, has resigned as a result of a long disagreement with Hall Wallis, executive producer, it was learned today. Mr. Hellinger refused to discuss the reasons for his action.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Roosevelt signed today the bill raising the Federal debt limit to $65,000,000,000 from $49,000,000,000, and authorizing for the first time in the country's history the issuance of taxable Federal securities.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Arturo Toscanini will conduct in concerts again this Summer in South America. But this time he will not take the NBC Symphony Orchestra. He will make the trip by himself to conduct six concerts with the orchestra of the Colon Theatre in Buenos Aires.

For almost five years a committee of Catholic Bishops and a board of distinguished scriptural scholars have been working on a revised translation of the New Testament. The translation revised was that by Dr. Richard Challoner, Bishop of Debra, of which the first edition appeared in 1749.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 19 -- It is increasingly indicated that Germany hopes to accomplish a bloodless conquest of the Balkans this Spring and is well on the way to success.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The annual value of the turnover in private industry, engaged in production, distribution and merchandising of goods and services, increased more than $67,000,000,000 during the seven years from 1933 to 1939 inclusive, the Department of Commerce reported today.

While opposing war, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday, there were "some things" worth dying for and indicated that it might be better for this country to go to war if it were necessary to save Britain from defeat.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 19 -- The soldiers of the 113th Infantry turned out in a formal review at retreat here tonight under their commanding officer, Colonel Julius Ochs Adler, to honor three former officers of the regiment who are no longer in active service.

Count Jacques de Sieyes, representative in this country of the "Free French" forces, left for London yesterday morning on the Lisbon-bound Yankee Clipper of Pan American Airways. Count de Sieyes said he would confer with General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the "Free French," as "to how 'Free France' may best be served in the United States."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Lumber consumption, including defense requirements, for the first quarter this year will amount to 7,458,000,000 feet, an increase of 20 per cent over the corresponding period last year, according to estimates in the quarterly report of the Lumber Survey Committee issued today by the Department of Commerce.

Billy Rose and the Group Theatre will Join hands in the sponsorship of the Clifford Odets play, "Clash by Night," which has been somewhat delayed in getting under way. Rehearsals will start next week, and the cast will include Sylvia Sidney, Luther Adler and Lee J. Cobb, under the direction of Lee Strasberg.

LONDON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A great German undersea offensive this Spring with 600 submarines let loose against British shipping warn predicted today by a neutral naval source. It might either prepare the way for an invasion or serve as a temporary substitute.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- As the outgrowth of an investigation begun in June a Federal grand jury here indicted today twenty-four surgical manufacturing companies, the American Surgical Trade Association and twelve officers or former officers of the association for alleged conspiracy to violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 20 -- South Wales was attacked by German raiders last night. They came to that area from many directions. For several hours reports of German planes in different parts of this country made it uncertain where they were bound, but the Air Ministry announced that German activity had stopped before midnight everywhere in Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura expressed the personal belief today, at the first press conference he has held since he became Japanese Ambassador, that there would not be a war between the United States and Japan, provided the United States did not take the initiative in the fighting.
HAVANA, Feb. 19 -- Things continue to happen to the Dodgers that interfere with their training activities.

The Chinese, according to legend, invented gunpowder and used it only to make a noise. The fisherman who invented the artificial sandworm which is being displayed at the Sportsmen's Show had quite a shock yesterday when he dropped in at a neighboring bar to find that his dream child was being employed in a manner calculated to make it a nightmare.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Legislative leaders decided today to go along with the La Guardia bus bill sent here on Monday, but only to the extent of validating the lease of buses which the city needs to take the place of trolley cars on the Fulton Street line in Brooklyn.
BERLIN, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 15 shows the following changes from the report of Jan. 31, in thousands of marks:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- G. Howland Shaw of Boston, veteran career diplomat and now chief of the Division of Foreign Service Personnel in the State Department, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be an Assistant Secretary of State. He will have charge of administrative work in the department.

Eighty-three per cent of the graduation class at New York University's Washington Square College of Arts and Science advocate passage of the lease-lend bill, according to the results of the annual poll of graduates made public yesterday by William Klein, editor of The Album, senior yearbook.

TOKYO, Feb. 19 -- If and when the inner history of yesterday's Japanese mediation offer by the Cabinet spokesman is written, it will be found that its essential importance lies in the fidelity with which it showed to the world the leading ideas of Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Africa, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The British issued the following communique tonight:

Members of the City Council committee investigating the Civil Service Commission considered the possibility yesterday of asking District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey to look into charges that service rating records had been altered in the case of a city engineer.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Today's stock markets still were quiet, but prices mostly were maintained.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Navy Department said tonight that telegrams had been sent by Secretary Knox and Admiral Emory S. Land of the Maritime Commission to all commercial shipyards having government contracts requesting them to keep current wages and working conditions until the Shipbuilding Stabilization Committee is able to complete an investigation it is making of the effect wage increases would have on the shipbuilding program.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A series of bills designed to protect volunteers and trainees inducted into Federal military service was introduced in the Senate today By Roy M. Page, chairman of the Senate National Defense Committee.

ROME, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Formidable masses of British tanks and armored cars -- apparently poised for a final thrust into Western Libya -- are being assaulted by German dive- bombers, official Italian reports said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Ignoring an official Japanese warning that the United States should confine its "warlike preparations" to the Western Hemisphere, the House passed and sent to the Senate today a $245,228,500 bill authorizing the expansion of naval bases from Newfoundland and Trinidad in the Atlantic to Guam, 1,352 miles from Tokyo in the Pacific. The bill also provides for improvements of the outpost of Samoa.
BERLIN, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

The isolationist "illusion" must be destroyed once and for all "if America is to fulfill her destiny," James P. Warburg, banker and author, declared last night at a meeting sponsored jointly by the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies and the Riverdale Committee on International Affairs at Public School 7, 232d Street and Kings-bridge Avenue, the Bronx.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 19 -- The town of Cheren, Eritrea, and near-by objectives have been heavily bombed by Royal Air Force planes supporting two British columns assaulting the defenses of the mountain-hemmed Italian stronghold, the British announced today.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The question of New York City's right to divert excess relief tax revenues toward relieving the city's financial crisis came formally before the Legislature today with the introduction of the Moffat-Coudert bills, carrying out the city's plan, as announced yesterday.

Pat Rooney, the dapper dancer and songwriter who has had a leading place in the entertainment world for more than fifty years, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal Court. Most of his debts, according to the petition, were for sums ranging from $25 borrowed from Ollie Olsen up to $1,000 obtained from George Sidney.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 19 -- Fifty thousand acres of rich farmland in the Northern Bachka and Banat of Yugoslavia are under flood waters tonight and more than 300 dwellings are damaged or destroyed by ground water, which has undermined their foundations.

F.D. Layton, president of the four companies of the National Fire group, announced yesterday following the annual meeting that net premiums of the group amounted to $18,249,281 in 1940, an increase of 9.6 per cent over 1939.

LONDON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Japan's mediation offer to Britain was pictured by the British press tonight as an Axis diplomate "peace offensive." Informed quarters said it was handed to Richard Austen Butler, Foreign Under-Secretary, for delivery to Anthony Eden, the Foreign Secretary, by Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Ambassador, at the Foreign Office Monday.

SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, Feb. 19 -- Additional British reinforcements reached this strategic British outpost today to aid in defense of the great tin and rubber producing areas of Southeast Asia and British authorities said it might be assumed that the balance of air power in the Far Eastern area now was swinging in Britain's favor.

Francis T. Green, assistant director of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, predicted a new SEC rule in an address before the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., at a meeting yesterday afternoon at the New York Chamber of Commerce.

There is much conjecture in Wall Street over the vacancy to be created on the Securities and Exchange Commission when Jerome N. Frank leaves Washington to take up his new duties as a Federal judge. Many believe the vacancy will be filled by some one outside of the commission, although Washington rumors indicate that several staff members of the agency are in the running for the post.

MIAMI, Feb. 19 -- The International Association of Machinists threatened today to stop paying dues to the American Federation of Labor for its 200,000 members unless the executive council reaffirmed its jurisdiction over millwright work as against the claim for that work by the Carpenters Union.

Claudio Arrau the Chilean pianist, enthralled the audience at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall with a series of performances that could hardly be excelled for imaginative detail, wealth of exquisite color effects anti technical virtuosity.
Seedings were made by Dan Ferris, meet director, yesterday for the 600 and 1,000 yard heats at the fifty-third annual National A.A.U. track and field championships at Madison Square Garden Saturday.

The city of Birmingham, Ala., will be in the market on March 12 with an issue of $1,350,000 of refunding bonds, for which bidders are asked to name the rate of interest. The obligations, to be dated April 1, 1941, will mature serially from April 1, 1946, to 1961.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Printed notices that the Ford Motor Company would "cease and desist" from discouraging organization work among its employes by the United Automobile Workers-C.I.O. and otherwise comply with an order of the National Labor Relations Board were posted today in departments of the company's plants.

Fifty-six drawings and watercolors have just been added to the exhibition, "French Painting from David to Toulouse-Lautrec," which will continue at the Metropolitan Museum through March 26. Like the paintings which form the nucleus of the exhibition, these drawings and water-colors were included in the original good-will exhibition sent from France to South America in 1939, but were not included when the paintings were shown in San Francisco.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 19 (AP) -- British headquarters here today issued this communique:

Most of the Manhattan realty activity announced yesterday covered properties along the West Side. A tall loft building, a plot of land used for storage of building materials, and several residential properties which have been or are to be altered by the new owners, were among the parcels traded.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19 -- The horse that looks like the Wheatley Stable's best bower for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup on March 1 was seen in a useful race at Hialeah Park today when Snow Ridge went whipping past the finish post a length to the good at the end of a mile and a quarter, the Widener distance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- William S. Knudsen, director of the Office of Production Management, today told the House Judiciary Committee that no legislation was needed to deal with labor strife in defense dustries and positively advised against it.

The Maritime Commission has issued an order suspending until June 28 the proposed $1 increase in eastbound lumber rates on ships of the Intercoastal Steamship Freight Association, it announced in a ruling received here yesterday. The Commission issued the order in Washington on Tuesday.
Congestion of orders at steel mills is forcing steel companies to put into effect more rigid controls of their own devising, according to Iron Age.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Ethiopian warriors in revolt against their Italian rulers in untamed Gojjam Province are driving ahead as British soldiers elsewhere in Ethiopia advance in an offensive that may put Addis Ababa, the capital, under siege within a month.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 19 -Navy's fast stepping basketball team, paced by Bill Busik's 19 points, defeated the University of Pennsylvania quintet, 43 to 34, today.

Governor Lehman has endorsed the candidacy of Dean Alfange, Democratic candidate for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, it was announced yesterday at Mr. Alfange's campaign headquarters, 2181 Broadway.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Two high officials in the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers Union withdrew from negotiations in the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company strike late today and left Milwaukee after implying that the month-long strike might be extended to the company's plants in four other cities.
