The dress industry in this city, with a turnover of more than a million dollars on every working day and an employment roll of 85,000 organized workers, has taken a long step forward with the signing of a new kind of contract between the Joint Dress Board of the I.L.G.W.U. and three employers' associations.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 19 -- A Japanese military spokesman asserted today that the landing of Australian troops at Singapore "may interfere with the successful outcome" of the Thailand-Indo-China peace conference and accused Britain of having taken "belligerent action."

Mrs. Henry Martyn Alexander, president of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 4 Sutton Place, for members of the association's tractor committee which, in cooperation with the British-American Ambulance Corps, is endeavoring to raise funds to send six tractors to England.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- Approximately $80,000,000 will be expended by the Army Quartermaster Depot here for the purchase of wool goods next month. This sum will be increased considerably, no doubt, if the Army exercises its option of increasing or decreasing by as much as 50 per cent the quantities to be awarded the successful bidders.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Mr. and Mrs. John Moffat gave a dinner tonight in their Everglades Club apartment.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- Foreign reports of the mass deportation of Jews from Vienna to Poland appeared to be confirmed today by reliable sources, although the forced migration does not seem to have reached the extent reported abroad.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A $200,000,000 bond issue, to be expended over five years in building up the State's highway system, is sought in a bill introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Wicks of Ulster County and Assemblyman Reoux of Warren County.

For more than three hours yesterday 300 wholesale fruit dealers crowded the main salesroom of the New York Fruit Auction Corporation on Pier 20, North River, where the first large shipments of fresh fruit from South America this year went on the block.

Coming to life in the second half with a blistering rally, N.Y.U. hauled itself back from the brink of an upset before 10,161 in Madison Square Garden last night and vanquished a surprising Fordham quintet, 41 to 35. The Violet poured in twelve points in a row to turn a onesided rout into another one, except that it went in a different direction.
Wisconsin Public Service Corporation first mortgage 4 per cent bonds due in 1961 have been suspended from New York Stock Exchange dealings, as they have been called for redemption.

The New York Americans, struggling desperately to gain a play-off berth, will engage the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League encounter at Madison Square Garden tonight. The cellar-dwelling Duttonmen are five points behind the Montreal Canadiens.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Representatives of between 10,000 and 12,000 C.I.O. steel workers will meet tomorrow "to decide on action to combat the lockout of employes" at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Lackawanna plant, Lorne H. Nelles, international representative of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, announced tonight.

The possibility of a Japanese attempt to seize Singapore is a threat to which the United States cannot afford to remain indifferent. Singapore is the great gateway to the East. Whoever controls it controls, for all practical purposes, the trade that passes between those nations, like our own, that rim the Pacific, and the ports that lie beyond on the route through the Indian Ocean and the Suez Canal to the Mediterranean and Europe.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Hog prices declined today l0 to 20 cents over yesterday's average despite active trading and firmness Of dressed pork prices.

The market on steer hinds and ribs warn slow and draggy yesterday with a weak undertone. High choice to prime grades were scarce. Veal hindsaddles were about steady, lamb carcasses and traefer cuts fully steady, although demand was only fair. Cow and bull beef prices were strong, with a fair demand for the limited supplies.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Thursday, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Japanese sailors at this South China Sea base stayed close to their posts and Japanese officials rushed about in an atmosphere of excitement today, despite professions that nothing was known here about heavy Australian reinforcement of the Singapore base.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- A Netherland Government spokesman said today they were investigating a report that Dirk Jan de Geer, the 78-year-old former Premier of the Netherlands, was a victim of Nazi treachry.

With major financing operations in the corporate field being postponed or called off because of unsettled market conditions, there continues to be a fairly active market for new issues of equipment trust certificates.

Seven years ago, when the powers-that-be inaugurated the event and decided to call it the "Polar Bear" meet they weren't fooling. In freezing temperature, embellished by a biting wind, Matty Geis's Princeton track athletes yesterday proved themselves the hardiest at snow-covered South Field and outscored Pennsylvania and Columbia for the third year in a row in this annual prep for the forthcoming I.C.A.A.A.A. championships.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19 -Extremes met tonight when the leading Dartmouth five defeated Yale, occupant of the Eastern Intercollegiate League cellar, 51 to 50.

The Niles-Bement-Pond Company of Hartford, Conn., has declared a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share, the same as paid in the three preceding quarters. The directors elected George Herbert Day of the law firm of Shipman Goodwin of Hartford a director of the company.

The drastic steps taken by Latin-American countries to protect their exchange positions by curbing imports shortly after the European war broke out are beginning to bear fruit, according to credit executives of foreign trade establishments who attended the monthly round-table discussion on credit and exchange conditions abroad at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

James C. Petrillo president of the American Federation of Musicians, has fixed March 1 as the deadline for instrumental virtuosos in the American Guild of Musical Artists to join his union, it was made known yesterday. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court recently upheld Mr. Petrillo's right to organize the instrumentalists, who include Jascha Heifetz, Efrem Zimbalist and Albert Spalding.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Love has found a way, or rather the thoughtful British Postoffice has devised a code for sending tender messages at bargain rates from this country to troops overseas.

Net profit of the Walworth Company, Inc., for 1940, after all charges, including Federal income taxes, amounted to $1,123,156, compared with a profit of $205,900 in 1939, according to the annual statement issued for publication today by W.B. Holton Jr., president.

MADRID, Spain, Feb. 19 -- Taking drastic action to reduce the tremendous number of railroad wrecks that have occurred in the past three months, General Francisco Franco, the Spanish Chief of State, today gave military courts complete jurisdiction.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Further changes in the French Cabinet of Marshal Petain are expected as the result of the Paris visit of Vice Premier Darlan, the German official news agency said today in a dispatch from Paris.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Plans for construction with Federal funds of American tin smelter and a plant for the manufacture of magnesium, both products needed in the defense program, have been tentatively or wholly completed, Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce and Federal Loan Administrator, told a press conference today.

VICHY, France, Feb. 19 -- Rudolf Breitscheid, former leader of the Social Democrats in the pre-Hitler Reichstag, and Rudolf Hilferding, former German Finance Minister, who were handed over to the German authorities under the armistice terms here last week, had intended to seek refuge in the United States, it was learned tonight.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 (UP) -- German bombers today sank a merchantman off the mouth of the Humber and destroyed buildings and communications facilities in low-flying attacks on ports, air fields, railroads and troop camps in various parts of England, according to the official D.N.B. news agency.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Twenty-year-old Ray Wrisley, St. Lawrence University sophomore, and Miss Marilyn Shaw, 16-year-old national combined titleholder from Stowe, Vt., won the slalom races that opened the annual Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' skiing tourney today. Both gave flawless exhibitions under exacting conditions.

ATHENS, Feb. 19 -- The bitterest fighting took place during the day on all sections of the Albanian front and according to information available here the Greeks again succeeded in advancing their lines.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Nearly 5,000,000 aliens were registered in the four-month period between Aug. 27 and Dec. 26, Attorney General Jackson announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The National Labor Relations Board reversed today a decision made two and a half years ago when J. Warren Madden and Donald W. Smith were members of the agency. Edwin S. Smith, the only remaining member of the board as then constituted, dissented from the decision of Chairman H.A. Millis and William M. Leiserson.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Captain Fritz Wiedemann, German Consul General, was sued today by a woman who said she made a trip to Germany at his request to see if he still was in the good graces of Adolf Hitler.

The top on full silvers continued to rule at the previous day's level of $100 at the sale conducted yesterday by the New York Auction Company. The demand was active, with almost all of the first part of the full silver offering sold. Three-quarter and half silvers will be offered today.

The planets Jupiter and Saturn will approach each other tonight in the southern sky, the last of an unusual series of conjunctions, to form an unusually brilliant spectacle, according to an announcement made yesterday by the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Senator Lister Hill of Alabama told the Senate today that a victorious Germany would join forces with Japan to place the United States in the "jaws of a gigantic pincers movement," using South America as the "handle through which the pressure will be applied."

The four-story factory building at 346 Carroll Street, fronting also on First Street, in Brooklyn, and containing about 110,00O square feet of floor space, has been purchased by Jack Pressman Co., manufacturers of toys and games, for expansion.
Harold A. Thomas, in 1215 5th Ave; Tilly Schanzer, in 50 Park Ave; Albert E. Labouchere, in Hotel Ambassador; Amos J. Mace, in 227 E 57th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, brokers.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 19 -- Acting Prime Minister A.W. Fadden, speaking at the annual dinner of the Royal Automobile Club tonight, summed up the War Council's warnings on the Pacific situation as indicating that the war might suddenly spread and bring the conflict overnight near or even to Australian shores.

Commander Ratcliffe C. Welles U.S.N., and Mrs. Welles gave a dinner last night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Commander Harry T. Chase, who is leaving soon for sea duty, and Mrs. Chase. Among the other guests were Commander and Mrs. Russell S. Smith, Commander and Mrs. Stirling P. Smith and George Williamson.

The Park Department's annual snow sculpture competition has just been concluded and medals will be presented to sixteen of the 540 amateur artists who competed. The designs, most of which were made in city playgrounds after the heavy snowfall four weeks ago, were judged from photographs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today filed a complaint under the Commodity Exchange Act charging Nichols Co., Inc., Boston wool merchandising concern, with "manipulating" prices of wool-top futures on the Wool Associates of the New York Cotton Exchange.

Because Sally, the Seeing Eye shepherd dog of blind Robert J. Losch of 21-18 147th Street, Whitestone, Queens, has been barred from the city-evened subways, the Whitestone South Community Council will demand that the City Council pass a special bill allowing properly trained dogs of the blind to travel on the subways, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Senator Bailey of North Carolina, who was opposed to American involvement in the European war during the debate on repeal of the arms embargo late in 1939, came out today for full American intervention in all wars against totalitarian aggression.

The $175,000,000 appropriation recently voted by Congress for a supplementary program of advance buying by the Army will be used to build a reserve supply of clothing and other equipment, and this buying will not interfere with or necessarily reduce purchases under the 1941-42 fiscal year normal appropriations, Brig. Gen. C.L. Corbin of the Army Quartermaster Corps said here yesterday.

Columbia University Press discovers from the annual book production figures prepared by Publishers Weekly that university press publishing continues to expand, with Columbia doing its important bit. The P.W. statistics, which list the output of all houses that issue five or more titles, show that universities produced 427 books in 1935, 481 in 1939 and 541 last year.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., Feb. 19 -- The second annual Southern Pines horse show, to be held here on Friday, will be a benefit for British war relief. More than one hundred entries already have been received from show ring exhibitors of Southern and Eastern States.

EVEN when a cold wind is whipping flurries of snow around the corner, there comes a feeling of pity for those who live in the warmer sections of the country, the inhabitants of the simmering Southland, the dwellers in the land of palm and long-leaf pine. Maybe they are lucky in some ways, but they don't have all the luck. For one thing, they miss some stirring hockey games.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Operating revenues of the gas, electric and transportation subsidiaries of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey amounted to $140,327,251 in 1940, an increase of $6,428,506 over 1939, but net income last year was $23,188,424, a drop of $2,534,304 from 1939, it was indicated in the annual report to stockholders, made public here today.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- New York State's death rate last year, 11.1 per 1,000 population, was equal to the low record, shown previously in 1938 and 1939, and its birth rate, 14.6 per 1,000, was the highest in seven years, according to the annual report of the Department of Health submitted to Commissioner Godfrey.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 19 -Long Island University defeated Michigan State College, 24 -- 23, in a slow basketball game tonight, after coming from far behind.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Although wheat prices fluctuated most erratically today as a result of conflicting influences in the Pit here, the breaks appeared to draw in a good class of buying, some of which, too, was for professional and cash interest account.

STOCKHOLM. Sweden, Feb. 19 -- Whether the Norwegian Lutheran Church will be altogether forced into inactivity by Major Vidkum Quisling's regime against which all Norwegian Bishops took a stand, first in a letter to the Minister of Education and then in an open letter to their congregations in which they denounced the regime as one of terror and violence, is the paramount question dominating Norwegian life today.

Tokyo resents the arrival of Australian reinforcements at Singapore as a belligerent move and even an act of aggression. This is perfectly in line with the new Axis language which will become compulsory for everybody under the new Axis world order.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19 -- With the second squad of players due to report to Manager Bill Terry tomorrow a final showdown on the holdout situation in the ranks of the Giants is almost at hand. That a ball club that finished as badly as did the Giants last year should have any holdout situation at all is, perhaps, in itself most unusual, but then unusual things are always happening to the Giants.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- The lid was taken off editorial comments on the United States in the German newspapers today. All sections of the press charge in lengthy and not always restrainedly phrased harangues that there is an officially directed campaign to cause a "panic psychosis" among American citizens.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 19 -Army made it three in a row at basketball today, beating the University of West Virginia by 44 to 37. The cadets staged a thrilling rally to turn back the Mountaineers, a fast and accurate passing team. The score was tied at half-time, 16 to 16.

In defense contracts awarded through the end of January New Jersey retained its lead as the State receiving the largest dollar total at $1,337,234,014. Only two other States, New York and California, had received contracts in excess of $1,000,000,000 by the end of January.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Tommy Goodwin of New York, medalist in the annual South Florida golf championship, today eliminated Smiley Quick, West Palm Beach, one of the outstanding threats in his path to the final, 2 and 1.

Because of an increase in public donations and an income from investments, both of which amounted to $103,267 in 1940, the Children's Aid Society was able to extend its services to the city's underprivileged children and also assisted several committees in the care of refugee children, it was announced yesterday at the society's annual meeting in the board room of the Bank of New York, 48 Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Deliveries of planes to the Army and Navy and the British during January totaled 957, out of a total production of 1,036 craft of all types, William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, reported today.

Declaring that "such decisions may change all my personal future plans," Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that the city would appeal the decision of Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan invalidating the Police Department regulations that would bar all intercity buses from the midtown area east of Eighth Avenue.

Since Sept. 5, 1929, the Bank of England has a fixed price for bar gold of 168s per fine ounce, which is the highest on record. Prior to outbreak of war on Sept. 1. high record was 150s 5d on Jan. 4, 1939.

Jesse Isidor Straus, former president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., and former United States Ambassador to France, left a net estate of $7,958,699 when he died on Oct. 4, 1936, it was shown in the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday. The gross estate, before deduction of debts and expenses, was valued at $9,025,100.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Senator Connally, pleading for national unity in support of the Administration's British aid bill, told the Senate today that the democracies of the world "must all hang together or they shall hang separately."

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 19 -- Warning against neglect of education while efforts are bent on preparation for war, Harold Benjamin, dean of the college of education at the University of Maryland, in giving the opening address this morning at the eighth annual convention of the Council of Guidance and Personnel Associations at the Chalfone-Haddon Hall, said "the primary defense of our people is here."

The cotton futures market resumed yesterday its upward movement as offerings from the South declined further. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices opened up 3 to 8 points and after a 4-point recession recovered to close at net gains for the day of 2 to 8 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Receipt of four bids for the charter of four vessels to be operated between Atlantic ports and South and East Africa for a one-year period was reported today by the Maritime Commission.

Forced to relinquish his crown a year ago when an injured ankle put him out of action, Robert Grant 3d of New York started in quest of the national amateur racquets championship again yesterday as the tournament began at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

In high spirits at the prospect of spending the rest of the Winter in the South, 1,428 officers and men of the old Seventh Regiment, now the 207th Coast Artillery (anti-air-craft) Mobile, marched yesterday from the regimental armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street and entrained for Camp Stewart, Hinesville, Ga.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 19 -- A definite move to refute Axis propaganda that tries to make out that the Bulgarian-Turkish declaration means a fundamental change of the Turkish attitude toward Great Britain and a diplomatic victory for the Axis is noticeable in the Turkish press today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Clarence Bettman, former chairman of the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange, testified today at a hearing by the Securities and Exchange Commission that while commission-splitting "is detrimental to the best interests of the Exchange, the public is not hurt by it."
LONDON, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Britain, after consultation with the United States, will reject a Japanese peace proposal which has been received from Tokyo, it was understood tonight.

Fire Commissioner John. J. McElligott said yesterday that his department was 500 men short of the number needed for efficient operation and criticized the action of the City Council on Tuesday in opposing draft deferment for firemen and policemen.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Rutgers will attempt to blaze a trail for colleges of the country by scheduling a major football game with an Army camp team, according to George E. Little, director of athletics.

A new issue of 37,500 shares of La Plant-Choate Manufacturing Company, Inc., cumulative convertible $1 dividend preferred stock is being offered today at $20 a share by an underwriting group headed by Schroder Rockefeller Co., Inc., and including F.S. Yantis Co., Inc., Scott McIntyre Co., Murdoch, Dearth White, Inc., Dempsey-Detmer Co., Barrett, Herrick Co., Inc., Quail Co., and Sutro Co. La Plant-Choate manufactures land-clearing equipment.

A highly efficient natural gold digger that extracts gold from soils where it is present in amounts too minute for extraction by other means and also detects the presence of gold in larger deposits deep down, was described here yesterday before the annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Despite the successes in the war in the Mediterranean, there is considerable disquiet among the people here lest all possible toward winning the war is not being done. Partly this is a reflection of the effect of war nerves and a long period of brooding, threatening calm.

Immediate concern over unemployment problems "for the next twenty years" is the duty of all citizens, particularly city dwellers, in view of the lack of work we may expect after the European war is over, Mgr. Luigi G. Ligutti, secretary of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference, declared yesterday in an interview.

Three days of firmer prices failed to restore any confidence in the stock market and a new wave of selling engulfed the share list yesterday as values were reduced 1 to 2 points. The selling subsided in the afternoon, however, and permitted most issues to close above the lows of the day.

A bronze of the head, shoulders and outstretched arms of a baby, modeled in London under the influence of the Blitzkrieg, has been sent here on behalf of the bombed babies of Britain by Jacob Epstein, whose work for the last thirty years has moved some critics to call him the greatest sculptor who ever lived, and has moved others to mutilate some of his public monuments in rage.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 19 -- On today's colorless Bourse Dutch issues generally showed changes to 1 point either way, but shipping, especially Dutch-Indies Lines, continued firm to 3 points better while tobaccos advanced as much as 5.

A dress "song parade" of music identified with each branch of the United States military service featured an entertainment and supper party given last night at the Algonquin Supper Club for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club, 283 Lexington Avenue, a home and recreational center for enlisted men on leave.

The average cost of living of wage-earners and lower-salaried clerical workers in New York City was slightly higher in 1940 than in 1939, and 1.3 per cent above the level of January, 1939, according to an annual survey made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (UP) -- A warning that Russia must "keep her powder dry and spare no means" to gear her economy to wartime conditions and maintain a state of preparedness was before the national Communist party conference today, the official Tass news agency reported.

The New York Athletic Club's unbeaten Class A squash tennis team clinched its Metropolitan League group title last night for another year by defeating the Bayside Tennis Club, 4 to 1, at the victors' courts. It was the eleventh victory in a row for the N.Y.A.C.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The salary claim of Oscar Vitt against the Cleveland Baseball Club, which dismissed him after the 1940 season, has been approved by Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis, it was announced today by that official's secretary, Leslie O'Connor.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 19 -- Royal Air Force units operating in the Sudan gradually are winning over suspicious natives who regard British activities as akin to black magic but when an R.A.F. surgeon wanted to anaesthetize a Sudanese baby to remove a cartridge case the child had stuck in its nose, the consent not only of the father but of the tribal chief was required.

The W.T. Grant Company, whose main office is at 1441 Broadway, has leased for a long term the third floor, consisting of about 11,000 square feet, in the Wurlitzer Building, at 120 West Forty-second Street, for use as offices, through Clarence S. Ellen, agent.

ABERDEEN, Md., Feb. 19 -- Brig. Gen. J.B. Rose, commander of the Aberdeen Proving Grounds, expressed "extreme satisfaction" today at first tests of a new 8-inch railroad gun hurling 260-pound shells eighteen miles out into Chesapeake Bay.
ROME, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

Repudiating the position of Norman Thomas and of the Socialist party, which he heads, in opposition to the lease-lend bill under debate in the Senate as not representing the viewpoint of "genuine Socialists devoted to the preservation of democracy," Louis Waldman and other speakers for the Social Democratic Federation demanded last night that the bill be passed not only as a means of aiding England but as an integral part of this nation's national defense.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 19 -Featuring the one hand corner shooting of Charlie Winston, Princeton defeated the Harvard five, 40 -- 26, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at the Harvard gym tonight. In complete command of the backboard and with a clever penetration of the Crimson zone defense, the Tigers held the upper hand throughout.

There is a considerable volume of unused production capacity among the machine shops of the city, according to the results of a survey just completed by the Merchants' Association of New York. The association's findings have been sent in the form of a report to William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Managment in Washington.

MARSEILLE, France, Feb. 19 -- More than one thousand school children have been designated by their teachers to go to the harbor in a body at the end of this month, each with an American flag to be waved in greeting when the freighter Cold Harbor, now reported in Cadiz, Spain, takes her moorings at the Joliette docks.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- Professor Alvin Enrich, acting dean of the School of Education of Stanford University, told the national annual convention of the Progressive Education Association today that so much evidence in favor of modern education had been accumulated that its critics had better either collect some equally good evidence against it or keep still.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Entertaining at today's luncheon fashion revue at the Surf Club were Mrs. E. Mead Johnson, Mrs. Howell Ross Hanson, Mrs. Frank Hawkins, Mrs. George A. Bell, Mrs. Finis P. Ernest Jr., Mrs. W.L. Milner, Mrs. William J. Wemmer, Mrs. Edwin C. McCullough, Mrs. Peter T. Potts, Mrs. Andre E. Rickmers, Mrs. James J. Archbold and Mrs. Joan Moore.

Marvel Biddle, American soprano, who made her Town Hall debut last night, has a voice of natural beauty. When it is well produced, it has a delicate and glowing quality. It has the potentialities of a fine-spun lyrical instrument. Nor is it limited to sensitive expression.

VICHY, France, Feb. 19 -- Vice Premier Francois Darlan may return from Paris on Friday after having renewed contact with the German occupation authorities in the person of Otto Abetz, Reichsfuehrer Hitler's delegate.

What "Jackie" Goodsell of Hitler's Ameradio station in Berlin asked for from his American listeners was "suggestions as to our program as a whole." This request might be interpreted as referring to the radio program only. He may merely have wanted to find out whether or not we would like to have him louder and funnier.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Britain's military moves in Singapore and elsewhere in Southeast Asia are part of a joint British-American plan to "strangle Japan" and will be countered with "appropriate measures," Japanese spokesmen here said today.

A large private residence with a blockfront plot in the old Cord Meyer section of Forest Hills, Queens, has been sold to a developer who is now razing the building to clear the site for another large apartment structure.

Charges of discrimination against Negroes, both in the nation's armed forces and in defense industries, were made yesterday at the thirtieth annual meeting of the National Urban League at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 20 (UP) -- General unofficial Japanese reaction today to the plan of the United States to fortify Guam and Samoa was that it represents part of an Anglo-American scheme to "intimidate" Japan which is certain to aggravate Japanese-American relations.

The appointment of W. Averell Harriman as special defense liaison officer in London to expedite the flow of aid to Britain under the lease-lend bill is an excellent move. The efficient functioning of the "arsenal of democracy" calls for close coordination and exchange of information between the Administration and defense officials here and those in the front line of the fight in Britain.

Three new films will be added to the Broadway screen roster this morning. The Roxy is scheduled to open at 8 A.M. for the world premiere of Twentieth Century-Fox's version of "Tobacco Road." The theatre will remain open continuously for forty-two hours thereafter, until 2 A.M. Saturday, to accommodate an anticipated increase in business.

Rossini's "Barber of Seville" was given a Joyous and brilliant performance in low comedy vein last night in the Metropolitan Opera House and an immense audience was delighted by the singing and the show.

If Governor Herbert R. O'Conor of Maryland is in a story-listening mood tomorrow, when he is to inspect his home State's large exhibit at the National Sportsmen's Show in Grand Central Palace, he should see Captain Josh Bunting.

The third session of the tenth annual Bloomingdale's pet dog show was devoted to working dogs and working dog puppies, with the smallest entry list thus far taking part in the exhibition. Only fifty-eight owners and their pets were able to get to the event yesterday as inclement weather and the icy condition of the roads made it impossible for many to put in an appearance.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 19 -- A shutdown of the Lackawanna plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation was threatened today by Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., in a telegram to the National Defense Commission unless the company discontinues its "unlawful and discriminatory practices."

Miss Fanny M. Cottenet will give a tea, the first in a series, this afternoon at her home, 1150 Fifth Avenue, for members of the arrangements committee working toward the success of the vaudeville show to be given in behalf of the scholarship fund of the Rollins Studio at East Hampton, L.I., on the night of March 2 in the ballroom of the Beekman Tower by members and graduates of the studio.

The report of the Sun Oil Company and its subsidiaries for the 1940 calendar year shows current assets of $43,025,672 and current liabilities of $20,473,370 on Dec. 31 compared with $45,891,879 and $16,046,846, respectively, at the end of 1983.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- A Japanese offer of mediation has been addressed formally to the British Foreign Office, Richard Austen Butler, Foreign Under-Secretary, revealed in the House of Commons today. He stated that it was under study.

A sound democratic system should be sufficiently flexible to do two things in a crisis. One is to permit prompt and effective action by granting to the Executive whatever emergency powers are needed. The other, complementing this, is to permit the Executive to be held continuously accountable by the legislative branch for the proper exercise of those emergency powers.

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers formally announced yesterday the acceptance of a consent decree settling the Federal Government's anti-trust suits against the society and possibly paving the way for a resumption of negotiations with the broadcasting industry to end the radio music war.

President Roosevelt's use of a quotation from Longfellow's "The Building of the Ship" in a message to Winston Churchill brings to mind an incident related in Carl Sandburg's "Abraham Lincoln: The War Years."

Although the general tenor of the collect radiograms to Berlin, authorized by the German broadcasting organization, led yesterday to an interchange of messages between the Germans and the Radio Corporation of America here, the radiograms were still being accepted and transmitted last night.

A Founder's Day celebration in memory of the Rev. Dr. Isaac Mayer Wise, founder of Hebrew Union College, Cincinnati, and also of the general Reform Judiasm movement in this country, will be held on Friday evening, March 21, at the Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

PARIS, Feb. 14 (delayed; via Berlin) -- The latest blast in the anti-American campaign unleashed by the Paris press in the past few weeks is the charge by Marcel Deat in an editorial in this morning's Oeuvre that the United States is an accomplice of Great Britain in "starving out" France.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The War Office today eliminated the censorship that for several weeks has been imposed on the mention of the train ing of British parachute troops.

Winds from the west carried colder temperatures to this area yesterday as midwinter weather arrived for at least a short Stay in all States east and south of the Great Lakes. The frigid mass of Arctic air stretched from Western Canada into Michigan, and forecasters said it would move south and east toward New York and New England.
Building projects submitted yesterday by architects included plans for an apartment house on West Fifty-fifth Street to cost $200,000. Details of these and other plans follow:

Unless the committee appointed in Washington on Tuesday to find a workable solution for the current chaotic markets in scrap zinc and aluminum finds a quick answer, the government will set a ceiling on scrap and secondary prices and demand weekly reports on stocks and sales, waste material dealers reported yesterday.

The College Teachers Union, subpoenaed by the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the city school system to turn over its membership lists and financial records, will refuse to do so and is planning to go to the Federal courts for redress, union officials announced yesterday.

The difficulties that the Chrysler Corporation is having with its program to produce 1,000 twenty-five-ton tanks a year are not peculiar. What is once more graphically illustrated is the enormous specialization necessary for turning out the great bulk of our new weapons. In this case a book of plans a foot and a half thick had to be drawn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A group of five modifications of the President's lease-lend bill has been suggested in quarters favorable to the legislation but disturbed over the breadth or vagueness of some of its sections. Yet the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations took up seriously only one.

A continuous educational campaign, stressing the concept of capitalism in which each company is regarded as a cooperative enterprise of stockholders and employes, was urged yesterday by R.A. Hayward, president of the Kalamazoo Vegetable Parchment Company, in an address at the labor forum of the annual convention of the American Paper and Pulp Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The battleship Washington, the second of six battleships of 35,000-ton displacement each which are under construction, will go into commission May 15, seven months ahead of the commissioning time specified in the original contract.

Directors of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company voted yesterday to pay on April 10 $12,909,832 pro rata on secured contingent interest on its indebtedness, under a plan for modification of interest charges and maturities dated Aug. 15, 1938. It was explained that no payment of unsecured contingent interest could be made.

A proposal that all Americans adopt "a new Hippocratic oath" for the amelioration of "the ills of the world through human fellowship and brotherhood" was proposed yesterday by former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer on behalf of the national conference of Christians and Jews.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Standing without an overcoat in freezing weather, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, inspected today a detachment of the 207th Coast Artillery, the famous old Seventh regiment of the New York National Guard, with which he served in 1917-18 with distinction.

Newspapers in industrial cities are showing greater than average gains in advertising linages, with the smaller industrial centers registerng the largest percentage increases, according to an analysis of Media Records reports for January. Whereas, the gain for the country as a whole last month was 5.8 per cent, these cities enjoyed increases up to 16 per cent.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Phyllis Brewster, daughter of Mrs. Robert S. Brewster of 100 East Seventieth Street and Mount Kisco, N.Y., and the late Mr. Brewster, to John Randolph Burke, son of Mrs. Nicholas P.T. Burke of Dover, Mass., and the late Mr. Burke of Alexandria, Va.

I see in your issue of Feb. 17 that the International Allied Printing Trades Association will urge Congress to restrict the sale of commercial time on the air to 25 per cent of available radio time and to impose heavy taxes upon the income of broadcasting stations.

Doggy decorum reached new heights yesterday afternoon when several of the most prominent dogs in New York attended a tea given by Ginger, a Cairn terrier, at his home, 137 East Seventy-third Street, also the residence of his owners, Mr. and Mrs. H.O. Milliken.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Swift steps will be taken to strengthen American air power in the Pacific, it was reported here today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 20 -- The War Cabinet today extended the current militia training period in camps throughout Australia from seventy to ninety days and ordered that at least half of the strength of the Australian military forces be kept in training continuously.

Chiefly because of government spending and a sharp decline in nonmember deposits, the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System were increased $110,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $6,440,000,000, according to figures revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Treasury today wiped out Federal tax exemptions for all its future issues of securities, from $25 baby bonds to $1,000 units of standard bills, notes and bonds, and prepared to issue about $2,000,000,000 of new taxable securities within the next two months.

An appeal to the technicians of the paper industry to take steps to avert a potential shortage of pulp this year was made yesterday by C.D. Everest, member of the industry's advisory committee to the National Defense Advisory Commission, in an address at the luncheon closing the annual convention of the Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper Industry at the Hotel Roosevelt.

A Women's Swimming Association trio composed of the Misses Gloria Callen, Lorraine Fischer and Mildred O'Donnell captured the Metropolitan A.A.U. 300-yard medley relay crown in the Downtown A.C. pool last night.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Mounting tension in the Far East was believed responsible for another rush of buying in the tin market today. Metal for spot delivery was bid up 7 10s (about $30) to 279 (about $1,125) a ton. Future delivery was up 6 15s at 275.

The sons of two of the finest players in the history of American racquets met in the national amateur championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday. The best match of the tournament thus far resulted, with Clarence C. Pell Jr. the winner over Reginald Fincke Jr. by 15 -- 6, 11 -- 15, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 3.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 20 (UP) -- A Foreign Office source intimated tonight that Turkey's new non-aggression accord with Bulgaria would be repudiated if German armed forces were permitted to use Bulgarian territory as a base for attacking Greece.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that its trading and exchange division had begun a study of off-the-market trading by members of exchanges in stocks listed or admitted to unlisted trading privileges on securities exchanges.

Overwhelming approval by dairy farmers in the New York milk shed of the proposed revision of the Federal-State milk marketing price order was indicated yesterday when N.J. Cladakis, milk marketing administrator her, made public a preliminary tabulation of last Monday's balloting in the Federal-State farmers' referendum.

VICHY, France, Feb. 20 -- Vice Premier Francois Darlan returned to Vichy from Paris this afternoon, somewhat earlier than had been expected. He was received by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, with whom he remained nearly two hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Declaring that strikes were "a rare exception'' in the defense industries and that the time lost was often made up in overtime work, Sidney Hillman, Associate Director of the Office of Production Management, told the House Judiciary Committee today that passage of anti-strike legislation to cover these industries would be unwise and might do positive harm.

A new fruit that is a combination of grapefruit, orange and tangerine is creating a lot of excitement in the delicacy shops along Madison Avenue, where this week it puts in its first appearance of the season. It comes from the British island of Jamaica and a few samples showed up last year.

HAVANA, Feb. 20 -- Sitting in the shade of the stands today while the assorted Dodgers were doing their conditioning chores under a torrid sun in Tropical Park, President Larry MacPhail took a terrific mentel workout.

The Ohio State Teachers Retirement System purchased yesterday $608,400 of city of Columbus, Ohio, deficiency bonds at a price of 103, 007 for 2s. The bonds, dated March 15, will mature on Sept. 1, 1945 to 1949.

VICHY, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Friends of Pierre Laval said today a proposal for reaching a French-German understanding without restoring M. Laval to power in the Vichy government had been rejected by Otto Abetz.

WASHINGTON, Feb 20 -- For the first time since such statistics have been kept, outlays by United States travelers in Europe and the Mediterranean in 1940 were exceeded by receipts from visitors to the United States from that part of the world, Secretary Jones reported today.

The German official radio last night set a period to its offer to pay for radioed criticism of its propaganda programs to the United States, announcing that no further messages will be received after midnight tomorrow.
ATHENS, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Little activity was reported today from the Greek-Italian war front in Albania except for artillery dueling and consolidation of minor Greek gains in central sectors.
The search for a qualified successor to Billy Conn as world light-heavyweight champion gets under way tonight in Madison Square Garden.

Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions granted yesterday a motion for the substitution of Irving J. Tell, former assistant District Attorney, and Morris J. Dickman as defense counsel for William and Anthony Esposito, ex-convict brothers, instead of the six lawyers previously appointed by the court.

United States Senators Burton K. Wheeler and Gerald P. Nye told a capacity rally of 3,500 persons at Mecca Temple last night that the lease-lend bill could still be defeated if the people in America who "did not want war" would rally behind them and the other Senators who were opposing the measure's passage.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 21 -- Developments in French Indo-China that would require an active protest from Japan are being reported with increasing frequency by Japanese correspondents from Hanoi. Thus while the Thai-Indo-Chinese peace conference in Tokyo is proceeding in secret, the newspapers are printing numerous messages from Japanese sources purporting to reveal unfriendly acts on the part of the French authorities.

The setback administered to Georgetown by Penn State the other night stamps the Nittany Lions as the prize spoilers of the major basketball circuit. The term is not meant in any derogatory sense but more as an explanation of a team that fails just a mite short of being a standout but has beaten some of the top-ranking quintets of the East.

Three professors in Teachers College, Columbia University, have been retired and fourteen other faculty members have received promotions, it was announced yesterday by Dr. William F. Russell, dean of the college. The retiring educators, each of whom was designated professor emeritus, are Dr. J. Ralph McGaughy, former head of the Department of Elementary Education; Dr. Wilbert L. Carr, Professor of Latin, and Dr. Allan Abbott of the English Department.

Domei, Japanese official news agency, said in a broadcast from Tokyo yesterday, recorded here by The Associated Press, that "Japanese public opinion continues to protest energetically against any attempt to connect Japan with international mediation action" in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- For reasons of high administration defense policy, the recent anti-inflation recommendations to Congress of the Federal Reserve System have been silently dropped into the waste-basket. There was no "bitter battle," no "row," between the Federal Reserve and the Treasury, though both were freely predicted when, Jan. 1, 1941, the recommendations were suddenly made public by Governor Eccles.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 20 -- Hussein Caid Yalchin writes in today's Yeni Sabah:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The United Gas Improvement Company indicated today to the Securities and Exchange Commission how far it might he willing to go in compliance with the "death sentence" clause of the Holding Company Act.

The first of what is expected to be a series of price advances on major electric appliances, as a result of rising material costs and scarcity of metals, was made known yesterday when three of the leading refrigerator manufacturers raised quotations $5 to $10 a unit.

Favorable weather conditions have spurred the sale of Spring millinery at retail and have produced an increasing volume of reorders. Reports indicate that hats reflecting the Chinese influence are now moving in volume in the middle price brackets.

Your recent very interesting series of articles on the Federal-State Milk Marketing Administration told of a farmer who had profited to the extent of $600 through its operations in 1940. I have seen the other side of the picture. The money for the benefit of some farmers and for the maintenance of the administration comes out of the pockets of other farmers.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- The National Labor Relations Board, through its general counsel, argued before the Third Circuit Court of Appeals here today that the board's jurisdiction in a labor dispute continued indefinitely, even for many years after the signing of a collective bargaining contract between an employer and a labor union, if it felt that the public interest was affected.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Persistent buying of May wheat attributed to mills and cash interests and a letup in scattered liquidation resulted in the market showing a firm undertone. Strength in securities was also a factor, and professional traders who had been on the bear side for some time were good buyers to cover short sales.

TORONTO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs climbed back to first place in the National Hockey League standing tonight by beating the Canadiens, 2 to 1, in a hard contest before 10,656 fans. The victory put Toronto 1 point in front of the idle Brutus.

PARIS, Feb. 13 (AP) (Delayed, via Berlin) -- A German rationing system was imposed upon Paris as a clothing distributing center today. The reaction among the individualistic French may be described as one of incredulity. At first at least, both merchants and customers were disposed to take the system with a grain of salt.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 20 -- The arrival of Australian troops at Singapore is believed here to have given pause to Japanese plans for a lightning drive on that British base and the Netherlands Indies, although Japanese squadrons continue to patrol the waters near French Indo-China and Thailand.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- More than $200,000 was spent in the Democratic Senatorial campaign in Maryland last year, whereas the State law permitted each candidate to spend less than $3,000, Senator Tobey, Republican, of New Hampshire, charged in a minority report made public today as a supplement to the yet unpublished report of the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures.

Reporting yesterday for 1940, Theodore P. Walker, president of the Commercial Solvents Corporation, informed stockholders that consolidated net earnings amounted to $2,387,321 after all charges, including provision for estimated Federal normal income and excess profits taxes.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20 -- Tommy Goodwin of New York felt the sting of the medalist jinx today in the South Florida golf tournament when W.A. Pagan of West Palm Beach beat him, 1 up, in the semi-final round. Goodwin, who shot a 38, was 1 down at the end of the first nine holes when Pagan fired a par 35.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Glenn L. Martin disclosed today a program tripling his airplane factory facilities. He said that his plants would "be producing $36,000,000 worth of airplanes a month by June, 1942."

Wagner's "Siegfried" was presented yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House as the third offering of the current matinee cycle. According to the custom which maintains at all of the presentations of the works in the "Ring" trilogy at the annual cycle, the music drama was given without cuts.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton spinning established a new high record in January.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- Roaring down the lightning-fast Rimrock Rim course on Mount Jo, 23-year-old Eugenio Errazuriz, rain of the visiting Chilean team, showed his slashing steel edges to a crack field in winning the downhill race today in the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' twentieth annual Washington Birthday ski meet.

Francis H. Phipps, division engineer in the Public Works Department, told the Council committee investigating the Civil Service Commission yesterday that he had altered the service rating cards of Henry G. Bacon, a departmental inspector who sued in 1938 to obtain the post of mechanical engineer.

The recent declarations of British Cabinet members to the effect that a statement of British war aims at the present time would be unwise seem to me to be clearly and seriously mistaken. The argument is a double one: first, that "America knows what Britain is fighting for," and second, that haggling over details of post-war settlement while the future of civilization depends on decisive action now to win the war would be extremely quixotic.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 20 -- Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch continued tonight a series of Ministerial conferences and inter-party talks that is linked in reports to a prospective revision of the Cabinet. Opposition strength appeared to be growing and Prince Paul, the Regent, is said to favor a consolidation government to cushion the shock of recent events in the Balkans and to meet any future crisis.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan issued a formal statement yesterday defending his recent decision invalidating the ban placed by Police Commissioner Valentine against operation of interstate and interurban buses in much of the midtown area.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 20 -- The principles on the whole of the American Youth Congress are defended in a report to the National Association of Deans of Women, holding its annual convention here at the Chalfont-Haddon Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Contracts given by the Navy Department today for plant expansion included DeLaval Steam Turbine Company, Trenton, $350,000, and Quimby Pump Company, Inc., Newark, $134,000.
The average yield of all stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last year was 5.7 per cent, the highest since 1932, according to an article appearing in The Exchange, house organ of the institution.

With WPA workers going into private employment faster than replacements can be recruited from home relief, the Work Projects Administration has ordered a drop of 11,000 in the number of WPA jobs assigned to New York City for next month, Oliver A. Gottschalk, acting WPA Administrator, announced yesterday.

Sterling Products (Incorporated), in its annual statement for 1940 made available today, reports a consolidated net profit of $9,229,230 after all charges including provision for Federal and foreign income and excess profits taxes. This is equivalent to $5.30 a share on 1,740,870 shares and compares with $9,140,026 or $5.25 a share for 1939.

The announcement of Mexico's Interior Minister inviting the participation of foreign capital in the development of new oil fields in that country confirms earlier indications of a more hospitable Mexican attitude toward foreign business interests. The present proposal of Senor Aleman apparently implies no thoroughgoing return to the old days of largely unrestricted foreign operations in Mexico.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- National income of the United States, as distinguished from income payments that already had been made the subject of a report, showed a substantial increase in 1940 over 1939 and so did retail distribution, consumer credit and employment, Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, announced today.

At midnight tonight the American Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society will present its "Carnival for Britain" entertainment in Radio City Music Hall to aid the British air-raid victims. The show, one of the largest benefit performances to be given here, has been arranged by Vinton Freedley and George S. Kaufman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- With the commodity markets comparatively quiet, the general level of wholesale prices remained unchanged last week, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average was 80.5 for the week ended on Feb. 15, the same as for the week ended on Feb. 8, and compared with 80.6 on Feb. 1, and 78.3 on Feb. 17, 1940.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 21 -- London had three air-raid alarms during the night. Reports early today listed some bomb casualties and damage. The anti-aircraft guns were busy in the first "alert," which ended in mid-evening, and the two others that came after midnight.

Serious bottlenecks in the transportation of petroleum are facing the three Axis powers, the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers was informed here last night by Eugene Holman, director of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

A news-fickle stock market responded yesterday in telling fashion to some favorable developments and the widest recovery for the year and since Nov. 7 was registered by the price structure. Following the formula carried out so far this year, the rally was accomplished in a comparatively small volume of business, as values were marked up 1 to 3 points.

Two novelties marked the Ballet Theatre's pair of performances at the Majestic yesterday, with the season's first presentation of Adolph Bolm's "Peter and the Wolf" at the matinee and Antony Tudor's "Judgment of Paris" in the evening.
Mr. and Mrs. William A.M. Burden gave a dinner and dance last night at their home, 10 Gracie Square, in celebration of the tenth anniversary of their marriage.

Senator Bailey of North Carolina voted for the repeal of the arms embargo in October, 1939, because he believed at that time that the cash-and-carry plan would isolate us from the consequences of a foreign war. In a stirring speech in the Senate on Wednesday he defended the lease-lend bill as an act of intervention.

A taxpayer building to serve the needs of a community of small homes which has recently sprung up in the neighborhood of 184th Street and Horace Harding Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, is planned by Jerome C. Mayer and Millard Shroder, who have just acquired a site there.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Japan is bringing increasing pressure to bear on French Indo-China and is prepared completely to occupy that country if necessary, occidental diplomatic sources said today.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 21 -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka has warned British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden that a continuation of British military moves in Southeast Asia may compel this country to take "counter-measures," the newspaper Asahi said today.

One million children in 3,000 public and private high schools of this country are being taught to develop critical, questioning attitudes of what they read in the newspapers, hear on the radio or see in the motion pictures through monthly bulletins, teaching guides and other materials prepared for classroom use by the Institute for Propaganda Analysis.

Advertising appropriations this year, especially those for newspapers, will be increased 15 to 20 per cent, in the opinion of members of the Association of National Advertisers, according to Henry W. Roden, president of Harold H. Clapp, Inc., and chairman of the association's board, who has just left for a vacation in Hawaii with Mrs. Roden.

In lieu of symphonic music, a brilliant Philharmonic-Symphony audience listened last night in Carnegie Hall to the "premiere," in concert form, of the revised version of Walter Damrosch's opera "Cyrano," libretto by the late William J. Henderson.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that by Feb. 18, 709 investment advisers had been registered under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940.

It has been learned here that Christopher George, one of the airmen killed Wednesday in the crash of a Lockheed-Hudson bomber at St. Hubert airport, Montreal, was the son of a Bulgarian general, Kosla Gheorghieff, who was assassinated by alleged Communists in Sofia, Bulgaria, in 1925.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Appointment today of a Production Planning Board, with Harry L. Hopkins as a member, lent credence to reports that further far-reaching changes in the defense set-up awaited only the enactment of the lease-lend bill.
I have before me a copy of an item taken from THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 11 and referring to the present sulphuric acid situation in the United States.

The ability to wage, or withstand, war in which psychological tools are the greatest weapons probably will determine the winner in the international struggle, leading psychiatrists declared yesterday when the American Orthopsychiatric Association began a three-day convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Rex, a 2 1/2-year-old rust-colored chow owned by Peter Belles of New York City, carried off the top honors in Bloomingdale's tenth annual pet dog show during the afternoon session yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The arrival of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and General Sir John G. Dill, Chief of the Imperial General Staff, in Cairo, announced in Cairo today and confirmed here, raises several questions.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 20 (AP) -- An offering of 3,000 shares of Travelers Insurance Company stock at $400 a share, involving a total of $1,200,000, was made today in the over-the-counter market by Putnam Co.

"Strawberry Blonde," Warners' remake of "One Sunday Afternoon," which opens this morning at the Strand, is the sole newcomer to Broadway screens today. James Cagney is starred in the romantic comedy, which features Olivia de Havilland, Rita Hayworth, Jack Carson, Alan Hale and George Tobias.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 20 -- Secretary Knox, addressing Mayors of more than 150 cities of the United States and nine from Canada at a regional meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors this afternoon, said the world was in the throes of an irreconcilable conflict between those who believe in personal liberty and those who regard the rights of the State as superior to those of the individual.

Wendell L. Willkie said yesterday that he had told City Councilman Joseph Clark Baldwin, Republican candidate for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, that he would support him actively for the seat made vacant by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped 5 to 10 cents today after a strong opening had lifted the top to $8.15 and sent prices 10 cents higher than yesterday's average. Supply of 13,000 salable hogs in addition to 6,000 billed direct by leading packers was fully 5,000 head over advance estimates and caused demand to slacken despite the firm tone of dressed pork.

BELGRADE, Feb. 20 (UP) -- British forces designed to resist any German attack on Greece's Aegean seaport of Salonika or the vital Dardanelles were reported tonight to have occupied and to be hastily fortifying the strategic Greek island of Lemnos in the Upper Aegean.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20 -- Mr. and Mrs. Van Lear Black Jr. entertained with a cocktail party at their home for Mrs. Carver Havemeyer of New York, who is their house guest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission adjourned today its hearing in a disciplinary proceeding against the New York Curb Exchange after George P. Rea, its president, had defended the manner in which the Curb handled charges of fee-splitting among members last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The War Department slashed today the fees of an agent retained to acquire the site for a $10,000,000 ordnance plant in Iowa and took steps to revise downward other commissions paid in connection with land purchases. Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary, named a committee of War and Justice Department officials to undertake revision of the agreements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Department store sales continued active during the week ended Feb. 15, rising 19 per cent above those in the corresponding week of 1940, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Sales in the previous week were also 19 per cent over the like week a year ago.

VICHY, France, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Although the French press continued today to echo the German interpretation that the Turkish-Bulgarian non-aggression accord was a Nazi diplomatic victory, the Turkish Embassy here explained that the pact between Sofia and Ankara was "not a new development, nor was it brought about by German pressure or by German initiative."

Yesterday's TIMES had a picture of tears as open and unashamed as any that the war has so far brought forth. It was the picture of the Frenchman in the crowd at Marseille weeping as the regimental colors went by before permanent demobilization.

Joseph Lordi of the New York A.C., Frank R. Hanson of the Columbia Club, R.H. Reeve of the Bayside Tennis Club and Frank Iannicelli of the Bayside tennis Club entered the semi-finals of the Whitehall Club's invitation squash tennis tournament yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 20 -- The thesis that the United States is really not interested in a British victory and that when the war is over and the balance made President Roosevelt will prove to have been the biggest winner, is argued by the New York correspondent of Field Marshal Hermann Goering's Essener National Zeitung in a cabled dispatch from New York today.

Tales of adventure were the keynote of Aviation Day at the National Sportsmen's Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday. Noted fliers were among hundreds who gathered to view the planes on exhibition as well as the other phases of the show.

Gifts from the collection of Washingtoniana in the William Randolph Hearst collection on sale at Gimbel Brothers' store were received yesterday in behalf of their organizations by officers of the Sons of the Revolution, Sons of the American Revolution, Daughters of the American Revolution and Daughters of the Revolution. The gifts were presented by Frederic A. Gimbel, managing director of Gimbel Brothers.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 20 -- Manager Bill Terry's preparations to whip his Giants into shape for the invasion of Cuba next week took on an even more businesslike aspect today with the arrival of most of the players of the second contingent.

"Tanyard Street," the Irish play by Louis D'Alton, featuring Barry Fitzgerald and Margo, will close at the Little Theatre after giving its last two performances on Sunday. In all, the Jack Kirkland offering will have been performed twenty-three times.

BERLIN, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Thirteen merchant ships in the service of Great Britain and a British destroyer have shuddered to the crash of torpedoes and bombs in the Atlantic and English waters within the past forty-eight hours, according to a compilation tonight of German reports. Twelve of the merchant ships are known or believed to have been lost.

Mayor La Guardia has made a sound decision in announcing that the city intends to appeal the decision of Justice McGeehan invalidating police regulation of midtown bus traffic. As it stands, this decision leaves the city powerless to solve a very real and growing problem.

The two-family dwelling at 1554 Thirty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Wilfred Openhym for occupancy to a client of the Colonial Realty Company, Inc., brokers. The property is assessed for $9,500.

An exception to the recent upward trend in railroad earnings was provided by the Union Pacific Railroad yesterday in a report that showed decreased net operating income in January despite increased gross. Expenditures for maintenance of way and structures increased 45.8 per cent in January, compared with January, 1940, and expenditures for maintenance of equipment by 50.4 per cent.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Britain, it was reported today, is sounding out the United States on new measures to prevent Japan from building up further strategic material reserves for possible use in war against the democracies.

Conceding that the $10,000,000 cold storage unit of the Bronx Terminal Market could not be profitably operated, the Board of Estimate decided yesterday to devote the space to storage of records of the Education Department and the Board of Elections.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The fifth increase in bullion in as many weeks raised gold holdings of the Bank of England to 1.520.000, the highest amount since last July, the bank's weekly statement disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The former transatlantic liner George Washington was taken over by the Navy today for use as a transport. This acquisition gives the Navy total facilities to "transport comfortably" more than 28,000 officers and enlisted men.
BERLIN, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

The 11,000-ton American President liner President Hayes, which was launched at Newport News five months ago under the sponsorship of Mrs. Cordell Hull, wife of the Secretary of State, is expected to enter New York Harbor for the first time tomorrow.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 21 -- Japanese troop transports were reported steaming southward today from Formosa and Japan herself, headed presumably for Hainan Island -- a likely way station in any drive that might be made upon Singapore -- or for Northern French Indo-China.

More than seven hundred members of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, meeting last night in the Hotel Astor, gave formal ratification to the consent decree, announced Wednesday, which ends the Federal Government's anti-trust suits against the society.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 20 -- German Army engineers have begun erecting pontoon bridges across the Danube River, and, according to reports circulating in both Belgrade and Sofia tonight, Rumania and Bulgaria have been linked in at least three places.
We know today the origin of the negotiations that ended last Monday in the signing of the Turkish-Bulgarian pact of non-aggression.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 20 -- Four sergeants of Company K, 174th Infantry here, are going to lose their chevrons, Colonel Joseph W. Becker, commanding officer, said this afternoon. That was one definite fact that stood out in a welter of confusing stories about what happened yesterday in the 174th.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- In spite of the Supreme Court's decision in the Apex Hosiery Company case, labor unions can be held under the Sherman Anti-Trust Act for conspiracy to restrain trade where no labor disputes are involved, Judge J. Cullen Ganey ruled today in the Federal District Court.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- The resignations of Dr. Randall Thompson, director of the Curtis Institute of Music, and Fritz Reiner, head of its orchestra department, were announced today and accepted "with regret" by Mrs. Mary Louise Curtis Bok, founder and president of the institute.

WASHINGTON Feb. 20 -- Senator Tobey told Congress today that "an important Washington political leader," whom he did not name, used "pressure and influence" in an attempt to block the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee from investigating "fraudulent elections" in the stronghold of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City.

VICHY, France, Feb. 20 -- Mrs. Uhlman, aunt of Henry S. Waterman, United States Consul at Bordeaux, has died in a French concentration camp at Gurs in the Basses Pyrannes, according to a report received here today.

Check transactions in the major cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday rose 43.5 per cent above clearings for the preceding holiday week, and 21.2 per cent over the volume for the corresponding week a year ago.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Theatres in England and Wales soon may open for Sunday audiences if steps in that direction taken today in Parliament by Herbert Morrison, Minister of Home Security, meet with approval. But it is expected that the Sabbath ban on stage shows, which dates from the time of Charles II, will be vigorously defended.

Defying subpoenas issued by the legislative committee investigating subversive activities in the schools, the New York College Teachers Union refused yesterday to surrender its membership list and other office records, thus throwing the whole question of the committee's powers into the courts again.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Besides her troop transport service in the World War, the George Washington, acquired by the Navy today, took President Wilson and American members of the peace conference to France and transported the King and Queen of the Belgians on their visit to the United States in 1919.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Feb. 20 -- Mount Holyoke College seniors will hold their annual formal dance tomorrow evening in Chapin Auditorium. Miss Marion Richards of Toronto, vice president of the class of '41, is chairman of the event, the last dance to be given by the senior class. Nearly 200 couples are expected to attend.
Washington's Birthday will be celebrated tomorrow in New York with rallies, parades, dinners and dances arranged by patriotic, civic, religious, fraternal and veterans' organizations.

War restrictions have forced thousands of private automobiles off the highways in all parts of the world except the Western Hemisphere, George Quisenberry, editor of The American Automobile, overseas edition, told members of the Overseas Automotive Club at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Lincoln yesterday.

The Greater New York Fund, a cooperative organization of business concerns and employe groups, has raised $11,000,000 for 400 voluntary social welfare and health agencies during the three years since it was established in 1938, according to announcement made by James G. Blaine, president of the fund, at the annual meeting of officers and rectors yesterday at organization headquarters, 52 Wall Street.

Virginia Kendall, in 230 Central Park South; Emil Bacarach, through Edgar Ellinger, Inc., in 31 E 12th St; Dudley Jay Morton Jr, in 71 W 12th St; Mrs. Rosalind Dunn, in 66 W 53d St; Anna Rabinowitz, in 166 2d Ave; Page Golsan, through Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, in 40 5th Ave; Ettore Luzzato, in Hotel Croydon, 12 E 86th St; Wm A. White Sons, brokers.

State Senator Edward J. Coughlin of Brooklyn was critically injured this morning in a fall down a stairway that sent him crashing through the glass of a doorway at 1030 Union Street in the Bedford section of Brooklyn. The accident occurred at about 1:10 A.M.

Some of the dispatches from various baseball headquarters give us the distinct impression that the players are not the hardy, violently healthy iron men they once were. An Associated Press dispatch from St. Louis reports, for instance, that Sam Breadon, president of the Cardinals -- once a very good team as Western teams go -- has decided to try to restore his athletes to championship vigor by feeding them B1 vitamins.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 20 -- If the Bulgarian-Turkish declaration was intended to calm the atmosphere here it has failed in its objective, because since its announcement rumors have been running wild and today bets are being made as to whether or not the Germans will have occupied Bulgaria by the end of the month.

MADRID, Feb. 20 -- General Francisco Franco again disclaimed today any intention by Spain to reimpose her own rule in Latin America in a speech welcoming Herman Figuaroa Anguita, the new Chilean Ambassador to Madrid. Insisting anew upon the unity of "Hispanism" -- a term for "Spanish civilization" -- General Franco declared:

Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., is expected to file today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement covering 148,991 shares of cumulative preferred stock, to be offered by the company to present holders of common stock, showing that the new preferred will carry a 4 1/4 per cent dividend rate and that the price of the preferred stock to the common stockholders will be $100 a share.
MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (UP) -- The Soviet press gave prominence to the arrival of Colonel P. Pamon Montri, first Thai diplomat to come to Moscow since the Bolshevist revolution.
The New York Americans must be firm believers in the truism "no news is good news."

Commercial loans of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose above the $2,000,000,000 mark in the week ended on Wednesday for the first time since the "big loan days" of the Nineteen Twenties. Figures released yesterday showed the gain to be $22,000,000, the largest for any week since that ended on Nov. 13.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Fifteen tons of foreign propaganda from unregistered sources abroad, largely in Germany, Russia and Japan, have been held up as unmailable during the last two months by the Postoffice Department.

Those who are counting the days until "ice-out" in Maine may be encouraged by Jack Williams's prophecy that the ice should break up, in northern Hancock County at least, about a week or ten days earlier than last year.
Fashion collections by B. Altman Co. and Bonwit Teller were presented yesterday, the latter group inspired by gowns worn in the last century by a famous singer, Emma Thursby.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Air and Home Security Ministries issued this communique today:

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 20 -- After several days of hard fighting British troops yesterday crossed the Juba River in Italian Somaliland, the British announced today. The British forces drove off Italian counter-attacks and began to move forward on the northeast side of the big stream.

The Hartford Fire Insurance Company, in its annual statement for last year issued yesterday by Richard M. Bissell, president, reported total admitted assets of $122,127,486, as of Dec. 31, 1940, a record. The total on Dec. 31, 1939, was $116,033,221.

After lengthy correspondence with Bermudian skippers, Cornelius Shields, chairman of the International Class of sloops on Long Island Sound, yesterday sent to owners in the class a proposition for a continuance this Spring of the annual racing in Bermuda, which the sailors there are eager to carry on.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- About 150,000 official positions and jobs in county, town and village governments in forty-four counties would be brought under civil service by Dec. 31, 1942, by a bill introduced today in the Legislature by Assemblyman Fite, Dutchess County Republican, and Senator Bechtold, Monroe Republican.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20 -- William LeBaron, who resigned this month as managing director of production at Paramount, was signed today by Twentieth Century-Fox as a producer, continuing the decentralization of studio authority. LeBaron will be the only full producer on the lot, except for Darryl F. Zanuck and Sol M. Wurtzel, and will have full authority over his own pictures, from original story selection to editing, according to the studio.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- While Senator Reynolds of North Carolina was declaring his opposition to the lease-lend bill as "a step toward war" in the Senate debate today, General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, told the Senate Military Affairs Committee that aid to Britain could be speeded up by passing the measure.

The Whitney Museum will be closed tomorrow (Washington's Birthday) and reopen on Sunday. The 1941 annual exhibition of sculpture, water-colors, drawings and prints will remain on view through Feb. 28. The museum will present on March 11 an exhibition entitled "This Is Our City," consisting of paintings, water-colors, drawings and prints.

VICHY, France, Feb. 20 -- The dissolved Communist party is continuing its clandestine activity in the unoccupied zone of France and each day steps are taken to repress it. Marcel Peyrouton, the Minister of the Interior who resigned this week, was in the forefront of this repression, and there is every indication that his successor, Admiral Francois Darlan, will not depart from that policy.
