Once a year Dan Ferris brushes the dust off his crystal ball, peers intently for a while and then prophesies a number of probable record-breakers for the National A.A.U. track and field championships that will be held tomorrow in Madison Square Garden.

AN ironic paradox of this strange moment in the country's history is the fact that the more that is done to arm and prepare the nation the safer it is for America's conservative and radical isolationists to say that the danger to America is being vastly overexaggerated.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Two quite different services which modern education might contribute to the world were suggested today at the annual convention of the Progressive Education Association.

IF the situation is correctly grasped in this corner, there are four "logical contenders" for the light heavyweight crown that Bill Corm doesn't want any more and two of the aforesaid "logical contenders," Jimmy Webb and Tommy Tucker, will meet at Madison Square Garden tonight. Later on Gus Lesnevich will meet Anton Christoforidis and the winners of these two bouts will fight for the title.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Mayor F.H. La Guardia of New York proposed today, particularly to Mayors of East and West Coast cities, that they take up the immediate problem of preparing for the possibility of bombing attacks.

The United States decides to fortify Guam and to reinforce its Pacific fleet; Great Britain lands Australian troops at Singapore -- and Japan complains that this strengthening of the defenses of their own territories by the American and British governments constitutes an act of "provocation."

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Long Island's Blackbirds and De Paul's Blue Demons tonight wound up the annual basketball double-header series with a game that thrilled a crowd of 5,000 before the New Yorkers scored a hard-earned 44-to-40 decision.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- General Marshall, in his testimony before the Senate Military Affairs Committee, was described as having discussed at length the reports that American planes had proved inferior to foreign types in actual combat.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Feb. 20 -- New York's old Seventh Regiment, now the 207th Coast Artillery (anti-aircraft), arrived in four troop trains here today and encamped at this 600-square-mile cantonment for a year's military training as Federalized National Guard.
ROME, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:
SAG HARBOR, L.I., Feb. 20 -- Pierson High School's 450 boys and girls will move through the school day tomorrow under harsh dictatorship.

Wool goods markets last week were quick to react to the announcement that the government would soon open bids on large quantities of wool products for the defense forces, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday in its weekly review.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 20 -- Market Wise made it two in a row at Hialeah Park today, winning the featured Lake Worth Purse at seven furlongs as 14,755 persons watched an eight-race program which marked another surge in the betting.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Administration spokesmen continued today to maintain official silence on the Far Eastern crisis but eyed developments warily.

A key force of 8,000 men to prevent and detect sabotage in large commercial buildings and to coordinate the efforts of the occupants until the arrival of regular fire-fighting units is being developed by the Fire Department as another step in the local defense program, it became known yesterday.

"Adoption" of nineteen bombed London hospitals, which will receive money to replace damaged surgical equipment and to enable them to carry on under war conditions, was announced yesterday by Bundles for Britain, Inc., 745 Fifth Avenue.

DETROIT, Feb. 20 -- Ben O. Shepherd, chairman of Local Draft Board 23, in commenting on a Detroit Free Press story that Hank Greenberg was asking "occupational deferment" from the draft, said tonight:

World consumption of petroleum and its substitutes in 1940 was 2,006,000,000 barrels, about 21,000,000 less than in 1939, according to an estimate made by V.R. Garfias, R.V. Whetsel and J.W. Ristori of the Cities Service Company at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers.

Pittsburgh Steel Company first-mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1950 and Detroit Edison Company general and refunding-mortgage Series H 3 per cent bonds due in 1970 are to be admitted to the New York Stock Exchange list today, subject to the effectiveness of registration statements.

Gross operating revenues of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago in 1940 were greater than in any previous year, aggregating $154,805,524, against $145,873,845 in 1939, and net income of the utility increased to $29,170,756 from $25,414,590 the year before, according to the annual report of the company made public yesterday by its chairman, Charles Y. Freeman.

Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent, offered yesterday approximately $25,000,000 of Federal Intermediate Credit Banks three-quarter of 1 per cent consolidated debentures. The obligations, maturing in six and ten months, were priced at a slight premium for both maturities.

HAWTHORNE, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- Red, the star bloodhound of the New York State Police kennels here, was retired from active service today after six years of tracking down murderers, amnesia victims and lost children. The retirement came because of an injury suffered by the dog twenty months ago while searching in the mountains of Maine for a lost Boy Scout.

Continuing to move upward for the third successive day, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday at net gains of 4 to 8 points, bringing quotations to approximately the levels of ten days ago, when a drop started. The greatest gains for the day were in the near months, in which there was a steady influx of trade buying.

The six-story store and loft building on a plot 37.6 by 100 feet at 10 West Twenty-ninth Street was sold by the Chase National Bank, as trustee of the Knapp Estate, to the Times Square Corporation, Samuel Kaufman, president. It is assessed at $78,000 and was sold for cash through Irving Judis, broker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Preliminary census figures issued today show that the rural non-farm population of the United States increased by 10.5 per cent in the ten years preceding April 1, 1940, while the rural farm population remained practically stationary and the urban population increased 7.9 per cent.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 20 -- It is learned from reliable sources that the Germans resident in Turkey are now more or less the prisoners of Franz von Papen, the German Ambassador.

Plans for reorganization of McKesson Robbins, Inc., drug company which has been in trusteeship since the defalcations of F. Donald Coster were discovered, entered their last stage yesterday. In the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York Judge Alfred C. Coxe issued an order adjudging the recently amended plan of the trustee, William J. Wardall, worthy of consideration and referring it to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

TOKYO, Feb. 20 -- In a statement to this correspondent Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka today disContinued From Page One claimed that Japan had made any offer to mediate in the European war, as was announced yesterday in the House of Commons by Foreign Under-Secretary Richard Austen Butler.

The purchase of a large East Side residence and plans for converting it into an apartment building of small suites were announced yesterday when Albert Klein bought the five-story dwelling at 2 East Seventy-fifth Street from the Hoyt Estate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Preliminary census figures issued today show that the rural non-farm population of the United States increased by 10.5 per cent in the ten years preceding April 1, 1940, while the rural farm population remained practically stationary and the urban population increased 7.9 per cent.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 20 -- It is learned from reliable sources that the Germans resident in Turkey are now more or less the prisoners of Franz von Papen, the German Ambassador.

Nearly 5,000 residents of Brooklyn and Long Island attended last night the annual ball of the Emerald Association in the grand ball room of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The proceeds, expected to reach $35,000, will be turned over to the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum Society of Brooklyn for the maintenance of various Catholic orphanages in the Brooklyn Diocese.

Four quaint century-old fire engines were added to the Harold V. Smith collection yesterday while street crowds watched apprehensively as the apparatus was hoisted from the sidewalk outside of the Home Insurance Company building at 59 Maiden Lane to the museum on the twelfth floor.

Alfred Duff Cooper, British Minister of Information, said at Oxford last night that the best British propaganda in the United States was "to let them have the news, the whole news, and nothing but the news, and let them have it with as little delay as possible," according to a British broadcast recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

I have just returned from a seven months' stay in occupied France. During this time, in my capacity as a physician, I talked to hundreds of people in all walks of life. The following facts will perhaps be of interest:

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Wendell Broomhall, 21-year-old star from the hills of Rumford, Me., demonstrated once again why he is the peer of cross-country skiers in this part of the country, if not in the nation, by capturing the ten-mile langlauf today against a small but formidable field.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- An outline for democratic education, an expression of alarm over a basic lack of understanding between men and women in this country, and brief reports on some of the successes of the eight-year plan of the Progressive Education Association were among the conspicuous points brought before the association's annual convention today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Large increases in Soviet imports of American sole leather, wheat and cotton and an "astonishing" rise in imports of refined copper are reported for the calendar year 1940 by the Division of Regional Information of the Commerce Department, in a review in the current issue of The Foreign Commerce Weekly.

How many American public men or leaders of nations anywhere could stand up under the difficult honor of having an octopus named after them? It testifies to the enormous hold of President Roosevelt on his people that he is not afraid of the test.
LONDON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Dispatch of German Army relief units to Santander marks the first open Nazi armed penetration of Spain, well-informed quarters believed tonight.
LONDON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies of Australia said today that Australia had "accepted specific responsibilities for a share in the defense of Singapore."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- Fordham kept pace with the Temple quintet for nineteen minutes at Convention Hall tonight, but could not stop the long shots of Angelo Musi and Howie Kahn and lost to the Owls, 49 -- 37.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 21 -- Hialeah Park's big race for 3-year-olds, the $20,000 added Flamingo Stakes, will be run tomorrow. It has drawn one of the most interesting fields in the history of the nine-furlong event which began life as the Florida Derby. Fourteen have been named, but most attention is focused upon Whirlaway, Dispose, Curious Coin and The Rhymer.

An all-star cast instead of the usual handful of invitation specials will be presented tonight in the fifty-third annual National A.A.U. track and field championships at Madison Square Garden. The country's crack performers will battle for seventeen titles.

WHAT the stylish-stout Mr. Daniel J. Ferris of the A.A.U. is talking about at the moment is "two miles for the price of one admission." That's his quaint way of pointing out that there should be two good mile races in the National A.A.U. indoor championships at Madison Square Garden this evening. Man and boy, Dan Ferris has been involved in track athletics for thirty-five years and he should know whereof he speaks.
BOSTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 21 -- Thirty homes have been destroyed by floods in the Sombor sector in Northern Yugoslavia and 209 other dwellings are undermined and will have to be abandoned, according to reports from the flood zone tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges, who failed to graduate from West Point, was named today to be Chief of Infantry of the American Army with the temporary rank of major general.
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Hundreds of Irishmen and women meeting in London today pledged themselves to oppose Eire's neutrality and to support the war aims of Great Britain and her Allies.

The market for new State and municipal loans will be enlivened next week with the sale, scheduled for Thursday, of $136,330,557 State of Arkansas refunding bonds. This proposed loan lifts the total tax-exempt financing slated for the coming week to $144,248,488, compared with only $8,774,925 for this week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it was distributing for criticism and suggestion tentative drafts of two simplified forms for the registration of securities by smaller corporations which have no subsidiaries and no record of insolvency or succession for three years before date of registration.

Wallace Groves, a financial operator here, and his brother, George S. Groves, an industrial banker, were convicted yesterday of mail fraud and conspiracy in Federal court. Wallace Groves was jailed by Judge John W. Clancy, while his brother was freed in bail of $10,000.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Tony Zale, staging a sensational rally, retained his National Boxing Association middleweight championship tonight by knocking out Steve Mamakos of Washington in the fourteenth round of their fifteen-round battle at the Stadium. Zale weighed 159 pounds to 157 1/2 for his opponent.

The chairmanship of the Securities and Exchange Commission is about to become vacant once more, at a time when the responsibilities of that post are extremely heavy. The most spectacular phase of the SEC's work is probably past. While occasional upcroppings of original sin are still to be encountered in the financial markets, the reforms ushered in by the SEC have been pretty well established.

Buildings along Fifth, Madison and Park Avenues are attracting new tenants, according to lists of rentals announced yesterday by brokers and managing agents. Renting extended to the Greenwich Village section, and agents said many of the new tenants would occupy their apartments early in the Spring.

Patrolman William L. Curtin was found guilty yesterday of murder in the second degree for shooting his wife, Elizabeth, by a jury in Bronx County Court after deliberation of four and a half hours. Judge Lester W. Patterson set March 7 as the day for sentence. Second degree murder carries a jail term of twenty years to life.
Robert Grant 3d of New York and J. Richard Leonard of Tuxedo, finalists in the Gold Racquet tournament, will meet again today for the national amateur racquets championship.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 21 -- The National Mediation Board may soon offer its services to mediate the dispute between fourteen standard railway unions and the country's Class One railroads, it was reported here today after J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, conferred with George M. Harrison, president of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks.
Newbold Morris, Acting Mayor and President of the City Council, rode part way up the City Hall steps shortly after noon yesterday in a military "jeep" car demonstrated for the first time in the city.

After watching Greg Rice set a two-mile record at Madison Square Garden last Saturday night, I am convinced that the little Notre Dame graduate could beat any of the present milers at the shorter distance.

The Manger Hotels, Julius Manger Jr., president, have signed a contract to purchase from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company the twenty-one story Hotel Vanderbilt and plans to take over the management of the hostelry on March 1, it was learned yesterday.

Warning that education, particularly of the handicapped, might be "submerged" by demands on public funds in the national emergency, State supervisors of special education pleaded yesterday for adequate provisions for the training of youth as "a contributing member of the democracy which we are called upon to maintain and defend."

TOKYO, Feb. 21 -- The Japanese press accused the United States and Britain today of heading a "four-power" scheme intended to "encircle" this country, and Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka expressed the hope that "the Anglo-Saxons" would withhold "any measures tending to excite Japanese public opinion."

Led by Midshipman Gordon Wiley, the Navy swimmers sent Columbia down to its fourth consecutive Eastern Intercollegiate League defeat, 46 -- 29, last night in the Lions' tank. Wiley won the 50-yard and century free-style dashes handily, then returned to anchor the victorious free-style relay team.

ROME, Feb. 21 -- The newspaper Popolo di Roma in a full-page review today attempted to prove that the United States was militarily weak. Accompanying the review were several pictures of United States troops with girls. One bore the caption, "Auto column laden with nice looking girls arrives at Fort Dix.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 21 (AP) -- The State Racing Commission rejected today a proposal by a group of wealthy sportsmen to help solve the difficulties of financing a proposed horse race track at Oceanport in Monmouth County by substituting wooden stands for steel and concrete structures.

In your issue of Feb. 9 you printed a letter from an Englishman who points out that as a British subject with first papers he would be eligible for the United States Army, but is excluded from working on munitions.
Brian, a 2 1/2-year-old Kerry Blue owned by Richard Wafdelich of New York City, won the silver cup for best in show as the tenth annual Bloomingdale's pet dog fixture closed yesterday.

A German refugee was convicted in Federal court yesterday of conspiring with four other men to smuggle cigarette-lighter spark-wheels into this country, in a scheme alleged to have cost the government nearly $150,000 in unpaid import taxes.

A successful free throw by Dick Murphy, a sophomore, gave Manhattan a 48-47 decision over St. Bonaventure in an overtime basketball game last night on the Jaspers' court. The deciding point was tallied with twenty seconds left in the extra frame.

DES MOINES, Feb. 21 -- The American farmer has a tremendous stake in the maintenance of his markets in Britain and Continental Europe, threatened with virtual elimination by a totalitarian victory, Dean Acheson, Assistant Secretary of State, said tonight in an address before a session of the National Farm Institute.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- Maxim Litvinoff, former Foreign Commissar, who fought for British-Soviet friendship and advocated full cooperation with the democracies, has been expelled from the Central Committee of the Communist party for "inability to discharge obligations," it was revealed today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Top on hogs dropped to $7.95 today, the first time in more than a month the high has declined below $8. Heavy supply in view of the week-end clean-up and holiday forced hog prices 25 cents lower. Pork loins prices also fell, selling at 16 to 17 cents a pound, a cent below yesterday's level. Choice 180 to 240-pound hogs brought $7.60 to $7.90.

HAVANA, Feb. 21 -- The complications of training a baseball club in Cuba seemingly are never ending. Things that ought to be done are promised with politeness and celerity, but as for actually doing the job, well, that's something else again.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Senator Tobey of New Hampshire said today that the inquiry of the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures into the last Presidential election had shown that the Hatch act had failed to prevent extravagant use of money in elections. He added that the committee's report to be made public next week would indicate that about $35,000,000 was spent in the last election.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Feb. 21 -- A bright sun and temperature of 68 degrees warmed today New York's old Seventh Regiment, the 207th Coast Artillery (anti-aircraft), as the 1,543 enlisted men completed their second day at this cantonment.

The news item in today's paper in which a letter from a former marine is quoted and which prompts the President's statement that there is work for every one on our national defense suggests the question: What is a veteran 42 years old to do under my circumstances?

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Led by a sharp upturn in Middle Western sales, where the impetus of defense orders is beginning to be felt in earnest, retail furniture sales for January rose 17 per cent above the like 1940 month, the monthly report of the control and management division of the National Retail Furniture Association showed today.

In THE TIMES of Feb. 9 under the heading "Soviet Is Accused by Banished Poles," Frederick T. Birchall charges the Soviet Government with having deported to Siberia 500,000 Poles from the eastern border provinces of former Poland, now under the Soviet rule.

A "substantial proportion" of the social science textbooks now used in the high schools of this country tend to criticize our form of government and hold in derision or contempt the system of private enterprise, Dr. Ralph West Robey, assistant professor of banking at Columbia University, said yesterday in summarizing his personal conclusions from abstracting the textbooks for the National Association of Manufacturers.

A five-ton truck, southbound on Park Avenue, skidded and crashed through the guard rail at 158th Street, the Bronx, at 10:30 o'clock last night, plunged forty feet to the New York Central Railroad tracks, and was soon a blazing mass of wreckage.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- Germany's strategic plan for a showdown with Britain is a simultaneous attack on the British Isles and on British possessions in the Mediterranean, according to an authoritative statement issued here tonight.
John Pasternack, a 40-year-old window-cleaner, and his wife, Mary, of 29 Avenue C, recently purchased a farm in Pennsylvania, paying $1,600 down on the $2,000 price.

The new Penn "Squidder," with everything but hot and cold folding doors. This reel is going to have a lot of appeal for the average surfcaster, and has what the maker calls a "convertible" star drag. In other words, it can be fished with or without drag at the will of the angler.
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Pending further developments in the Far Eastern situation, caution was the keynote in today's stock markets, and, with business at a low ebb, prices moved in narrow limits.

Sounds foreign to the ears of sophisticated New Yorkers echoed through Grand Central Palace last night as farmers, woodsmen and other hardy outdoor folk participated in the annual crow-calling contest at the National Sportsmen's Show.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 21 -- The Giants today became owners of six holdouts, an unusual condition for a ball club that stumbled home a bad sixth in the preceding campaign. But, then, the Giants in recent years seem to have drawn more than their share of the unexpected.

TRENTON, Feb. 21 -- Hudson County's Republican Superintendent of Elections and two judges of its four new criminal district courts won today in Supreme Court here their fight to force the Democratic Board of Freeholders to provide funds for them in this year's budget.

Columns of motorized Nazi troops rolling south across Rumania and testing pontoon bridges across the Danube make it increasingly clear that what is going on in the Balkans is a battle for a battlefield. The Turkish-Bulgarian pact is by no means the end of the story.

The world has caught up with Washington. As the Spring approaches, the American capital reproduces the atmosphere that enveloped European capitals this time last year. There is the same undercurrent of anxiety, the same surface eddies of uncertainty and confusion and in-between the same thick haze of waiting and suspense.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- The eleventh annual competition for the F. Wayland Ayer Cup, which is awarded by N.W. Ayer Son, Inc., for excellence in newspaper typography, press work and makeup, will be held this year during the week of March 3, it was announced here today.

New York University's injury-riddled wrestling team offered little opposition to an undefeated Temple University squad last night, bowing by 24 -- 8 at the Washington Square School of Education. It was Temple's fifth straight triumph of the season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Administration will probably ask Congress soon for about $225,000,000 to construct recreation centers for soldiers and sailors stationed near small communities unable to provide such facilities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The mounting tension in the Pacific area was reflected here today in many rumors of new measures for impressing upon Japan the gravity of the situation, but officials commented vaguely or indefinitely on them, evidently to prevent exact information from reaching the Axis.

Trading was somewhat spotty yesterday due to the holiday today, when all slaughtering plants and wholesale houses will he closed. The market on all classes of traefer meats was generally unchanged, with demand fair to slow. The kosher beef, veal and lamb markets were about in line with Thursday's late trading, the kill being light.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Feb. 8 was 2,403,290 shares, compared with 3,203,220 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Interstate Cigarette Merchandisers Association of Newark, N.J., and five member associations have filed an answer to a complaint by the Federal Trade Commission that they engaged in agreements and combinations in restraint of trade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A contract providing $9,150,000 on a cost-plus-fee basis for construction of a naval air station at the Bermuda base was awarded by the Navy today jointly to the Purdy Henderson Company, Inc., of 45 East Seventeenth Street, New York City, and F.H. McGraw Co. of Hartford, Conn. Work will begin immediately.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Great Britain was reported today to be moving additional air force units to Africa, Greece and the Far East to counter German aerial assistance to Italy and asserted Japanese threats in the Pacific.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Lewis A. Wilson, associate State Commissioner of Education, who has been directing the State's program of vocational education for national defense, was named today deputy commissioner by the Board of Regents.

LANSING, Mich., Feb. 21 -- For the second time within twenty-four hours the Fisher Body Corporation here ceased operations just before noon today, and the Oldsmobile division of the General Motors Corporation, dependent upon it for materials, curtailed its activities.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Feb. 21 -- Some 300 New York City business men, constituting a traveling class in military strategy and tactics, came to Mitchel Field in a special train today to get instruction in the aviation phase of national defense.
Utility consumers throughout the State paid $3,275,600 less last year to companies under regulation than they paid in the preceding year, the Public Service Commission reported yesterday.

Master plans of the city prepared by the City Planning Commission were criticized yesterday by Jacob A. Freedman, vice president of the City Title Insurance Company of 32 Court Street, Brooklyn, as "radical" and extravagant in view of the city's budget problem this year.

Because of contrasting business conditions in the various markets, the advantages of selectivity, flexibility and coverage offered by newspapers are more vital today than ever before, according to a folder entitled "For 1941 -- More Efficient Advertising" issued yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, A.N.P.A.

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers yesterday appointed the committee that will talk to the broadcasters when negotiations for the use of the society's music are resumed. It also sent word to the National Association of Broadcasters that it was "ready and anxious" to consider again the problems that led to the withdrawal of A.S.C.A.P. tunes from much of the air on Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission directed the United Gas Improvement Company today to show why it should not immediately begin divesting itself of far-flung utility properties in compliance with the so-called death sentence clause of the Holding Company Act.

This is to comment on Alexander G. McCabe's communication in last Saturday's NEW YORK TIMES on Joe McCluskey. Joe is one of our great distance runners and a perennial champion, but I would like to call attention to the daddy of all national championship winners, Bud Goodwin, all-around swimming and water polo star of a few decades ago.

St. John's Prep and Newtown High today stand as champions in their respective basketball leagues as a result of scoring victories yesterday. Paced by Captain Al Lucas, who made 18 points, St. John's downed St. Augustine's, 47 -- 38, to clinch the Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. crown, and Newtown retained the North Queens P.S.A.L. laurels by crushing Long Island City, 30 -- 9.

EDINBURGH, Feb. 21 -- Once an Englishman's home (by Englishman, of course, I mean Briton) was his castle, meaning that access to its precincts was on invitation only. There was no such thing as sharing one's hearth with any but one's own kith and kin -- maybe near friends did creep in once in a while, a neighbor almost never and certainly only when invited to do so.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 21 (UP) -- The United States and Mexican Departments of Agriculture have concluded an agreement for intensive scientific experiments in rubber production with a view to developing Mexico into one of the largest rubber-producing areas in the world.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 22 -- London throbbed and rattled to the tune of a heavy anti-aircraft barrage for a brief period early today while German air raiders were ending their third successive night's fire-bombing in South Wales, the principal area of their latest attacks on Britain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The belief that Europe's war is on the threshold of a momentous new phase brought redoubled efforts by Administration leaders today to get the lease-lend bill on President Roosevelt's desk by next weekend.

The New York Stock Exchange authorized yesterday listing of 1,445,555 additional capital shares of the Aviation Corporation on official notice of issuance. An offering to stockholders is to be made at 3 P.M. on Monday, when subscription rights to be issued will entitle holders of present shares to buy one share at $3.50 for each three shares held.

More than 3,500 children from the schools of thirty-six New Jersey communities attended the performance of Bizet's "Carmen" given yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, under the sponsorship of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

A patriotic parade, combined with a motor cavalcade and a historical pageant will be the principal features of a Washington's Birthday celebration in the Washington Heights and Inwood districts today under the auspices of the George Washington's Birthday Joint Committee of the Washington Heights Chamber of Commerce and seventy other community organizations. J. Conrad Scheider, chairman of the arrangements committee, will act as grand marshal of the parade.
ROME, Feb. 21 (AP) -- All available native and Italian man power in Eritrea, Ethiopia and Italian Somaliland is being called to the defense of the East African empire against the British.

RKO's "It Happened to One Man," co-starring Wilfrid Lawson and Nora Swinburne, will have its American premiere today at the Little Carnegie Playhouse. The film, which was produced in England from a play, "A Gentleman of Adventure," by Roland Pertwee and John Hastings Turner, features Marta Labarr, Ivan Brandt and Reginald Tate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Commodity Exchange Administration said today that a study of futures trading in wool tops indicated need for a "broader" wool market which would trade also in raw wool futures.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Two new rules under the Investment Company Act of 1940 which concern disclosure of the source of dividend payments or distributions made by registered management investment companies were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The twelve district banks and the Central Bank for Cooperatives extended in 1940 credit to farmers' cooperatives amounting to approximately $126,000,000, compared with $86,100,000 the previous year, S.D. Sanders, Cooperative Bank Commissioner of the Farm Credit Administration, reported today.
VICHY, France, Feb. 21 -- "Collaboration" remains the key to Franco-German relations. In this connection an editorial in l'Effort today is illuminating.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Charged with bringing into the United States negotiable articles in violation of an executive order issued by President Roosevelt last April 10, two seamen of the liner Excambion were held for a further hearing in $5,000 bail each tonight by United States Commissioner Joseph F. Holland.

VICHY, France, Feb. 21 -From a financial advertisement appearing in the newspaper Temps this evening, the French public learned that the Bor copper mines in Yugoslavia, which were operated by a French corporation, are about to pass under German control.

Judging from A.W. Ruddick's letter, an oil burner seems to have made a happy home owner out of a cussing, slaving and tortured coal user. I too consider myself an authority, but an unbiased one. My company sells coal and fuel oil and installs both oil burners and automatic stokers. We favor neither one nor the other but try to point out the advantages of each.
Perhaps your readers will be interested in this unique information I herewith present: There are four Johnsons here in New Haven who have set world records in various sports events.

Taking first in six of the nine events, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute defeated Fordham's swimmers by a one-point margin, 38 -- 37, yesterday in the Rams' pool. The home mermen were able to win only the 50 and 100 yard free-style events and the 400-yard relay, but their numerous second and third places made it a close contest all the way.

The Sixteenth Infantry, which has come to be known as "New York's Own" by virtue of its participation in many functions of this city during the more than eighteen years it has been stationed at Fort Jay, Governors Island, was reviewed yesterday morning on the fort parade grounds, in preparation for its departure early Monday for Fort Devens, Mass.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Negotiations for settlement of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company strike were broken off late today as a deadlock was reached between company officials and officers of the striking C.I.O. United Automobile Workers Union.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran, whose memoranda to the judges of his courts or to the public at large generally contain a few well turned phrases or may contain products of the classics or even Scripture, sent a communication to Magistrate Court clerks yesterday that left them all slightly dazed.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Feb. 21 -- Old William Beebe toiled up the hill to Pierson High School after sun-up today, a solitary figure in the wintry landscape of this old whaling town. He knocked the fire out of his pipe at the school door. "Blust'ry day," he said, by way of neighborly greeting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Rear Admiral S.C. Hooper, representing the Navy, told the House Merchant Marine Committee today that it would be "advisable" for Congress to look into the question of subversive activities in the merchant marine.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Harvard overcame a 9-point lead tonight to win an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game from Cornell, 43 -- 40, in the last minute, and virtually eliminate the Big Red from the title race.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 21 (AP) -- German pontoon bridges span the Danube in considerable numbers, a leading Balkan diplomat said tonight, and he declared that the movement of a Nazi expeditionary force from Rumania into Bulgaria was thus "a matter of days, if not hours."

All securities and commodity markets in the United States, as well as all banks in this country, will be closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday. As customary on this holiday, many livestock markets will be open. All Canadian markets and all other foreign markets that normally are open on Saturdays will continue business as usual today.

Two plays are ending their Broadway runs over the week-end. Tonight the Theatre Guild closes its production of Philip Barry's "Liberty Jones" at the Shubert Theatre after twenty-one performances. Tomorrow night "Tanyard Street," the Louis D'Alton play, departs from the Little Theatre, after having played twenty-three times.

The mysterious disappearance of a wooden case containing ten Thompson submachine guns destined for the British Army from a heavily guarded Cunard Line pier on the Hudson River was being investigated yesterday by squads of police, detectives and agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 21 -- Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins forecast tonight an increase of job opportunities "by the thousands" for women in connection with the defense program, warned against the problems that will arise when the emergency ends and advocated equal labor standards for men and women.

"National Unity and Democracy Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in the churches and "National Unity and Democracy Sabbath" will be observed today in the synagogues. The observance will be under the auspices of the National Conference of Christians and Jews and will inaugurate annual "Brotherhood Week" as sponsored by the conference.

In the last few months we have seen the strange spectacle of rapidly advancing business combined with a sharply falling stock market. It is clear that more than one factor must be involved in any explanation of these conflicting trends. In spite of military victories in Africa, there has been rising concern in the markets regarding the ability of Great Britain to withstand the attacks of Hitler in the Spring.

The first five railroads to report for January showed a decrease of 9.6 per cent in net operating income from the total for January, 1939. This resulted from decreases reported by the Union Pacific Railroad and the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, the former having a decreased net despite a larger gross and the latter decreased returns under both headings.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 21 -- An appeal probably will be taken to the Court of Errors and Appeals from the Supreme Court's decision today ordering the Hudson County Board of Freeholders to appropriate funds for two of the four new Criminal Courts in the county and increase the appropriation for the Superintendent of Elections, it was indicated this afternoon by J. Emil Walscheid, county counsel.

The one fact in George Washington's life that most of us are likely to think about today is his Farewell Address, and the one passage in that speech which seems to concern us most is the one in which he urged his countrymen to "steer clear of permanent alliances with any portion of the foreign world."
OTTAWA, Feb. 21 -- The question of Canada's representation at Washington was raised during question time in the House of Commons yesterday by Opposition Leader R.B. Hanson, who said:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- A military airline from Minneapolis through Canada to Fairbanks, Alaska was proposed today by Representative Edmiston, Democrat, of West Virginia, as a means by which Great Britain could compensate the United States for materials of war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Three experts of the Department of Agriculture proposed today to the Temporary National Economic Committee that large food distributing organizations should receive semi-public utility status and suggested that Federal incorporation of firms engaged in interstate commerce might be the best means of establishing such control.
VICHY, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Marshal Petain, striving to weather the crisis arising from deadlocked French-German relations, was expected tonight further to reshuffle his Cabinet within the next few days.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Hugh Thompson, C.I.O. regional director, announced today the settlement of an eleven-day strike affecting 400 workers at the Vanadium Corporation of America plant here, which has extensive defense contracts.

ATHENS, Feb. 21 -- A slight improvement in the weather on the Albanian front permitted a limited resumption of activity today, and it was reported that the Greeks were able to achieve minor successes, especially in the central sector.
Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned reactionary yesterday in the late trading and finished 6 points higher to 7 points lower than on the previous day.

Fascism is like an Aladdin's lamp dangled before a people suffering from political and economic insecurity and because it is based on fantasy it must fall eventually, carrying with it Hitler and Mussolini, the eighteenth annual meeting of the American Orthopsychiatric Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania heard yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Three Senators, two Democrats and a Republican, told the Senate today that passage of the lease-lend bill would certainly lead the United States into war.

Erich Leinsdorf, Wagnerian conductor at the Metropolitan Opera House, warned youthful musical aspirants yesterday at the High School of of Music and Art, Convent Avenue at 135th Street, against seeking "careers of fame" at the sacrifice of "pleasure and enjoyment in and through musical study."

The annual statement of the S.S. Kresge Company and its subsidiaries for 1940, issued yesterday, disclosed a net profit of $10,070,389 after depreciation, interest, Federal and Canadian income taxes, excess profits taxes and other charges. The result is equivalent to $1.82 a share on 5,517,882 shares of $10 par common stock and compares with $10,450,624 or $1.89 a share earned in 1939.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Buying by mills and cash interests here and in other markets gave the wheat market a firm undertone in the early trading today but when the professional element turned to the selling side later, partly to even up for the double holiday, the early upturn was lost.
ROME, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Feb. 21 -- New Zealand's national free medical care will start March 1, the Health Ministry announced today. The plan represents a new effort by the government to break down the doctors' resistance to the program legislated almost two years ago, which has never operated fully.

The American Export liner Excambion is due to sail today for Lisbon via Bermuda. Her passengers include Mr. and Mrs. Richard Kemper, Reggie Connelly, Mrs. Olga A. Braun, Dr. A.H. Brum, Howard Elkington, Mrs. Guiliette Treves, S.R. Williams, Mrs. Ralph H. Ackerman, Eric Biddle, Harold Eastwood, Kay Hoffman, Martin F. Dahlen, Miss Medeleine Richoux, Mrs. Elizabeth Segg, Miss Madeleine Cuenod, Borge C. Rugaard and George Paraschivesco, Rumanian Minister to Japan.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21 -- Nearly 200 members of the Old Guard Society of Palm Beach golfers and their guests attended their annual banquet tonight in the grand loggia of the Breakers, preceded by cocktails in the Venetian Room.

The most pressing obligation resting upon American schools today is to instill in their students a "thorough understanding of the meaning of democratic institutions and the free way of life," Dr. James Rowland Angell, president emeritus of Yale University, said last night at the annual dinner of the New York Alumni Association of Williston Academy.

One of the "old Bolsheviki" who once helped Joseph Stalin hold up trains to get money for the revolution, Maxim Litvinoff was the leading diplomat of the Soviet Union :until shortly after Adolf Hitler seized Czecho-Slovakia. He had supported a program of collective security, the League of Nations, disarmament and cooperation with Great Britain and France against German and Italian aggression.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Award of these contracts was announced by the War Department today:

Departmental budget requests for the next fiscal year must be cut at least $50,000,000 to keep the 1941-42 city budget within balance, according to estimates made yesterday by Budget Director Kenneth Dayton and Assistant Director Lester B. Stone.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Wendell L. Willkie said today that he believed the swing of Republicans to the support of the lease-lend bill was symbolical of a trend within the party away from isolationism.
WASHINGTON -- Senator Barkley is insisting upon five-hour daily sessions to make a final vote on the lease-lend bill possible next week, probably Friday.

The short, powerful punches of Jimmy Webb, St. Louis boxer, claimed stout-hearted Tommy Tucker of East Rockaway, L.I., as a victim last night and, with a thoroughness that could not be denied, eliminated one of the four candidates for the world light-heavyweight title, which Billy Conn is expected soon to renounce.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Pierre de L. Boal, counselor of the embassy in Mexico City, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be Minister to Nicaragua, and Wesley Frost, until recently counselor of the embassy in Santiago, Chile, was nominated to be Minister to Paraguay.

MADRID, Feb. 21 -- Advance liaison officers of the German Army arrived late today in Santander to prepare for the imminent arrival of technical units of the Reich's armed forces on a "peaceful mission" to alleviate suffering in that devastated city of Northern Spain.

A plan for disposal of a large part of the 9,000,000-bale raw cotton surplus, providing for steady operation of cotton mills and building reserves for three purposes, has been proposed by Samuel C. Lamport, cotton goods exporter, and has met with favorable comment in Washington, Mr. Lamport said yesterday.

Bound for a year's training in the South, 688 men and forty-three officers of the 212th Coast Artillery, pioneer anti-aircraft regiment in New York State, left yesterday on two special trains for Camp Stewart, Hinesville, Ga. Another group of 175 men left with the guns and heavy equipment five days ago and were due at the camp yesterday. The regiment was sworn into the Federal service last week.

While not showing the heavy percentage increase of the preceding week, retail trade here nevertheless had a healthy gain this week over the comparative 1940 period. Estimates put department store sales here at 12 per cent ahead, which would compare with 20 per cent last week.
YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- A tax rate 7 mills lower than last year's is provided under this city's 1941 budget adopted by a 3-to-2 vote of the Common Council this afternoon.

There was a greater-than-seasonal gain in retail trade this week, despite weather which was unfavorable to the promotion of new season merchandise, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Heavier trading also developed in the wholesale markets and retailers continued more liberal in their purchasing policies.

Asserting that John H. Vogt, $6,000-a-year assistant engineer in the Brooklyn Borough President's office, had applied for retirement in an attempt to circumvent his possible removal from office on bribery charges, Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen instituted disciplinary proceedings yesterday "to render this device ineffective."

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 22 (UP) -- Japan is concentrating more troops and warships in Southeast Asia to back up her claim to a dominant position in French Indo-China and Thailand [Siam], according to reliable reports today. Occidental diplomatic informants said it was still "touch and go" as to whether there will be a collision bringing the European war to the Far East and involving the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President Roosevelt today condemned as injurious to the national defense the action of the press and radio in making public what information they had been able to obtain concerning the increase of American air strength in the Pacific as provided in testimony given yesterday by General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, before the Senate Military Affairs Committee, meeting in executive session.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 21 (UP) -- In his press conference today Major Akiyama accused Britain and the United States of a deliberate effort to foment war in the Far East by preventing a peace treaty between Indo-China and Thailand and strangling Japan's effort to create an Asiatic economic bloc.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- While controversy continued unabated between the White House and its critics over steps for strengthening national defense through greater material aid to Britain, the Senate Military Affairs Committee unanimously approved today a resolution ordering an investigation of alleged discrimination in awarding rearmament contracts.

Sale to the Public National Bank and Trust Company of the New York Stock Exchange property at 39 Broad Street is now under negotiation. The figure is reported to be in the neighborhood of $400,000, representing a $1,800,000 loss from the price of $2,200,000 paid by the Exchange in August, 1933.

I would like to thank THE TIMES for printing Herbert H. Hinman's letter Feb. 15. He expresses well what very many Americans believe about war -- that it can serve no good purpose; but he makes no attempt to indicate what we should do about it.

In a session devoted entirely to routine operations, the stock market recorded yesterday the second smallest turnover in five months with final prices irregularly higher. The slightly firmer tone in the share list followed a weak spell in the morning hours but the net result was hardly worthy of discussion.

The Chamber Music Guild Quartet gave a concert last night in Town Hall for the benefit of Belgians in Britain, a division of bundles for Britain, Inc. A distinguished audience was on hand and demonstrated its warm approval of the highly accomplished performances of the ensemble, which had donated its services for the occasion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Reinstatement and back pay for 142 employes of the Ford Motor Company plant at Richmond, Calif., were ordered today by the National Labor Relations Board. The board also ordered the company to cease discouraging membership in the United Automobile Workers Union, C.I.O., to bargain with the union upon request and to embody any agreement in a signed agreement.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Advisability of drafting men between the ages of 18 and 21, rather than 21 and 35, for selective military service was suggested today by the Midwest regional meeting of the United States conference of Mayors.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Governor Lehman renewed his request today that interest rates on small loans granted by licensed lenders in the State be reduced from the present monthly interest charges of 3 per cent on loans up to $150 and 2 1/2 per cent on the balance up to $300, to 2 1/2 per cent on loans up to $100 and 2 per cent on balances up to $300.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The British people are not getting enough calcium, which is an essential constituent of the diet throughout life, according to an article in the current issue of The British Medical Journal.

As part of his program for making the Bronx a borough of culture as well as "the Borough of Universities," James J. Lyons, the Bronx Borough President, is sponsoring a Bronx Symphony Orchestra, he disclosed yesterday. The group, with Professor Philip James of New York University as its conductor, will give its first concert Monday evening in the auditorium of the Theodore Roosevelt High School, 500 Fordham Road, near Third Avenue.

"The American Theatre's Carnival for Britain" took place this morning at the Radio City Music Hall, where more than 6,200 persons settled down at midnight to see the show organized by the American Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society.

BERLIN, Saturday, Feb. 22 (AP) -- British warplanes carried out "disturbance" flights over German-occupied territoy and Helgoland last night, but did no important damage, informed quarters said today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 21 (UP) -- British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden is expected to arrive in Ankara soon from Egypt for consultations on measures to be taken under the Anglo-Turkish alliance in event of a further German thrust through the Balkans, it was understood tonight.

A century-old residence in Morris County, N.J., passed to new hands with the sale of Mershon Homestead, in Washington Township, to Charles C. Ort, a real estate broker. It was owned and occupied for sixty years by the late Aaron Mershon.

Immediate erection of a six-story elevator apartment building on a blockfront in Forest Hills, Queens, will result from the sale yesterday of the east side of 108th Street (Continental Avenue), from Sixty-eighth Drive to Sixty-ninth Avenue, by the Cord Meyer Development Company to the Broadwood Corporation.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 22 -- The absence of the Premier, Prince Fumimaro Konoye, from the Diet on a plea of illness was the subject of comment today by the important newspaper Asahi, which said that "there seems to be room for criticism of his continued absence and his occasional illnesses at the most critical times."

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 21 -- The British forces in Italian Somaliland forced their way across the Juba River yesterday at a point north of the original crossing effected the day before, British headquarters announced today. The advance now is continuing from both bridgeheads.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 21 -- Reports from Bulgaria tonight were to the effect that regular units of the German Army had begun entering the country, presumably across the pontoon bridges flung over the Danube River yesterday. Upon thorough investigation, it would appear that they are as yet unfounded or premature.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies of Australia said at a conference today that Australia was prepared to defend herself in and around "the ocean in which there are elements of danger in 1941 that did not exist in 1914."

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Soldiers of the Forty-fourth Division completed their military duties for this week this afternoon, and tonight hundreds of them were on the way home for the week-end. The Washington Birthday holiday tomorrow gives them an extra half day free of duty and many of them took advantage of the added time by starting on week-end passes at once.
LONDON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Ministries of Air and Home Security issued the following communique today:

Irving Storch, 39 years old, of 306 East 171st Street, the Bronx, accused as one of the "actual operators" of gambling in the Active Republican Club at Eighth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, surrendered at the District Attorney's office yesterday on a misdemeanor charge. The place was raided Jan. 14.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- The Westchester County Parkway Police and a mechanized force of the United States Army came to grips at noon today on the boundary between New York State and Connecticut, east of here, with each side later claiming partial victory.

On Monday Dial Press will publish Harlan Cozad McIntosh's psychological novel, "This Finer Shadow." The book has a stormy and tragic history. Its young author, after early training as a psychiatrist and a job in an insane asylum, went to sea for seven years, coming to New York in 1933.
Four seeded entrants were early round casualties as play in the sixth annual Eastern badminton championships opened at the Fifth Avenue Country Club last night.

The following are passages from the abstracts of the 600 social science textbooks prepared by Dr. Ralph W. Robey for the National Association of Manufacturers. Dr. Robey cited these books as being derogatory of the American form of government and critical of free business enterprise.

About 200 persons suffered tear-filled eyes from a mysterious ammonia leak that drifted over the Grand Central subway station yesterday afternoon at about 5:45, the height of the subway rush on the East Side trains. An ambulance from City Hospital responded but none required treatment.

The Grand Duchess Charlotte of Luxembourg and the Prince Consort Felix, with some 400 members of the Luxembourg colony in the United States, will attend the solemn mass at 11 A.M. tomorrow in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Madrid reports that a few German technical army units had entered Spain upon the invitation of Foreign Minister Serrano Suner caused concern here today, although they were not confirmed by any official advices.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Florida East Coast Railway moved a step nearer reorganization today with appointment of Scott M. Loftin as trustee and Edward W. Lane as co-trustee.

South Carolina will enter the market on March 11 with $2,500,000 of State highway certificates of indebtedness, for which bidders are to name the rate of interest. The issue, dated March 15, 1941, is to mature on March 15, 1943 to 1952.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Formation of a special committee empowered to investigate all phases of the defense program was recommended to the Senate today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 21 -- Scarcely had the ink dried on the declaration of Ankara, which included provisions for a press truce between Turkey and Bulgaria, when a new polemic was launched by the Sofia newspaper Zora.
New bond financing this week aggregated $10,132,125, consisting mostly of tax-exempt issues, compared with only $8,265,000 last week, and with $54,802,000 during this week a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Immediate purchases of South American canned beef will be made to augment domestic meat supplies for the expanding forces of the Army and Navy and incidentally to strengthen "good-neighbor" relations with Argentina among other meat-producing countries.

On Feb. 19 the State Supreme Court of Missouri in a unanimous decision ordered the Legislature to seat Forrest C. Donnell, Republican, as Governor. In the November election he had a plurality of some 3,600 over Lawrence McDaniel, Democrat. But the Democrats of the General Assembly were apparently determined to reverse the verdict of the people.

The National Youth Administration, which has just finished adding 13,000 unemployed young people to its rolls in New York City and Long Island, received orders from Washington yesterday that 13,000 are to be laid off -- 7,000 at once and 6,000 more by June 30.

IN "The Jervis Bay Goes Down"* Mr. Fowler continues a custom as old as the memory of man. It goes back to earliest antiquity, to the days when verses recited around a fire or in the market-place told the story of a battle or a love affair, a tribe's wandering or a legend's prophecy.

Dr. Walter Cramp, surgeon and former president of the Colgate University Alumni Corporation, who died in Doctors Hospital last Tuesday at the age of 62, bequeathed one-half of his residuary estate to Colgate University at Hamilton, N.Y.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sunday, Feb. 23 -- United States Minister George H. Earle's arm was injured today when he was struck by a wine bottle said to have been thrown by a German in civilian clothes at a restaurant near the American Legation.

CHARLESTON, S.C. -- Spring comes early to the island-fringed coastal country of the Midsouth. In late February the jonquils' yellow candles are pushing up in leafy old courtyards of Charleston and other coast cities. The dogwood, locust and redbud glow down forest aisles against the crisp green of pine and the gray velvet of Spanish moss, while the glory of azaleas and magnolias is just around the corner.

It is perhaps only heroes who can talk with heroes, and this seemed especially evident last night when Arturo Toscanini conducted the NBC Symphony Orchestra in a Wagner program which he discoursed unforgettably in Carnegie Hall, with Helen Traubel and Lauritz Melchior of the Metropolitan Opera Association as assisting soloists.

Professional interior decorators are discovering in the exceptionally fine picture a basic aid for creating a beautiful room. Frequently it is made to serve as a source for the room's color scheme; a more recent development is to emphasize a fine painting by modifying the architecture so that it becomes an integral part of the room's decor.

A new project in the interest of British war relief with wide possibilities has recently been undertaken by clubwomen in this State. It concerns the growing of medicinal herbs to allay the increased sufferings wrought by aerial warfare and to replace crops in England destroyed by bombings and fire.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- A smashing victory in the 400-yard free-style relay, final event of the meet, carried Princeton from behind to a 40-to-35 triumph over Harvard in their annual Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League match in Brokaw Pool today.

In last Sunday's issue of THE TIMES there appeared a letter from Professor William Lyon Phelps which expressed the wish that "ministers, priests and rabbis, in the sermons, would stop talking about the war."

Power projects of the Roosevelt Administration, the TVA and the Bonneville, Grand Coulee, Boulder and Santee Dams, have justified themselves by their usefulness to national defense, John M. Carmody, Federal Works Administrator, declared yesterday in a speech at the Saturday Afternoon Forum of the National Democratic Club.
VALPARAISO, Chile, Feb. 22 -- With the Congressional elections only seven days off, the political field continues to present a confusing picture.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 22 -- The meaning of Valley Forge with its suffering for Washington's army in the Winter of 1777-78 was translated into present day terms today at services in which perhaps 10,000 pilgrims took part.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Rutgers University's College of Engineering is considering a plan to accelerate training of men vitally needed in the national defense emergency, President Robert C. Clothier announced today.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The British issued this communique today:

A case history of industry planning for defense that achieved the three-fold result of providing skills and machinery to meet defense needs, holding prices for the consumer at virtually unchanged levels and avoiding the development of plant capacity and employe-training that could not be readily used after the defense program was provided last week by Roy A. Cheney, president of the Underwear Institute, who outlined what that industry had done.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Hampered by a variable, puffy westerly wind, the Hudson Highlands Ice Boat Club's first annual regatta for the interstate challenge pennant got under way on Lake Tiorati today. Toward the close the wind became extremely light, and it was necessary to shorten the second heats in order to complete the elimination program.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 22 -- While many sections of the country find themselves overbuilt with school houses, due to the shift in population, California is facing an acute shortage of such facilities. This is due to the extensive development of the national defense program in this State and applies especially to the vicinities of the new Army camps and the rapidly expanding airplane manufacturing industry.

The following letter from London was written by a former Master of one of the famous Liveried Companies of England, a recipient of the Order of the British Empire. It tells, in part, of the damage wrought by Nazi bombers on some of the ancient Guild Halls, which were architectural masterpieces of the British capital.

It is nice to have a little herb plot in the garden handy to the kitchen door. And if there is no kitchen door and no garden, the herbs may be grown in a window box. A small package of assorted seeds now comes with directions for sowing and cultivating, for harvesting and drying the herbs, as well as for their use, once they are safely gathered.

Letters from German refugees, Jews and Christians alike, who have been interned in French concentration camps, have been received here and are telling the stories of thousands of unfortunate men, women and children who, although they have never taken part in actual warfare, are detained behind barbed wire.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Forty New Yorkers have been commissioned as second lieutenants in the Marine Corps Reserve after completion of an intensive basic course in the Marine Corps Schools at Quantico, Va.
WASHINGTON -- The House of Representatives has approved a $165,000 reduction in the Budget Bureau's recommended Postoffice Department appropriation for stamps, stamped envelopes, etc.

AS A.P. Herbert says in the first of these papers, the question in this war is not, "Do you like the Germans better than the English," or "Do you approve of the Treaty of Versailles?" but, "Would you rather see Slavery or Freedom win?"
BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Dartmouth won the annual Intercollegiate Ski Union meet today, edging out the University of New Hampshire by a fraction of a point.

THE preservation of the sacred fire of liberty and the destiny of the republican model of government are justly considered as deeply, and perhaps finally staked, on the experiment entrusted to the American people.

TOKYO, Feb. 22 -- Not to have war with the United States if it can possibly be avoided is one of the fixed points of Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's foreign policy, as stated and restated in recent parliamentary debates. It is a fixed point because of high strategic reasons.

BURIED towns used to be regarded as quarries for works of art. Antiquaries were systematic tomb-robbers. When Pompeii was first excavated, men simply dug into the temples and the houses around the market-place, where they were fairly sure of finding statues, coins, gems, graceful ornaments, or even transportable paintings.

The track meet with a flavor all its own, the Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. championship carnival, will move into Madison Square Garden on Saturday for its twentieth annual showing. Unless all signs fail this will be a wide-open affair, with N.Y.U. hard-pressed to defend the team title it won a year ago.

THE dive bomber, most spectacular instrument of warfare developed in this conflict, is technically an old story in this country, where it was first employed by the United States Navy fliers. It is a swift, deadly weapon when used properly, devastating and terrifying in its effect.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith upset radio quiz program procedure yesterday when he shed his role as grand master and scorer on a program to aid a distraught woman contestant who was puzzled by a sports question.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 22 -- A bruised dove of peace already twice rebuffed -- once by the Greeks when they said, "We will continue the fight until we have driven the Italians from the Balkan Peninsula," and again by the Italians when they said, "It is a point of honor that we defeat the Greeks alone" -- continues to flutter in the neighborhood of the Greek-Italian conflict in Albania.

SINCE story-songs were the common property of all wandering tribes in the Heroic Ages, the same ones were known over great areas, and we find them recurring again and again, from century to century, accumulating lichen-verses from time to time.

NEXT Thursday David Sarnoff will be 50 years old. Just about the time he was born, a bearded German scientist demonstrated that there were other waves besides those of light traversing the ether. A few years later a lean Italian constructed a device for using these waves for telegraphic communication.

Although more than half of its member countries are within the war zone, officials of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women have completed plans for the observance of International Day following a custom of six years.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 -- Receding run-off waters and sunshine alternating with clouds today gave the Los Angeles area a rest from more than a week of almost continuous rain. The Weather Bureau reported, however, the approach of two more storms from the Pacific, the first due tomorrow night or Monday.

THIS composite work of forty-two exiled Italians, most of them professors, publicists, authors and scholars, possesses both the advantages and the disadvantages of the symposium. There is considerable variety both of subject-matter and of treatment.

THE secret of making successful clothes for the woman is to keep them young and at same time wearable. Talk to some of New York's designers and you'll hear them say: "Above all, you must see to it that the clothes have good lines."

THE Second National High School Salon of Photography, open only to students who attended a day high school during or after the 1940 Fall term, has been announced. The salon, which will be shown in New York during April, has set March 10 as the closing date for entries.
UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Ardsley and Utica won their way into the Allen Medal curling final tonight and will meet for the trophy at noon tomorrow.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Golf will be prominent on the program at this resort during the coming fortnight. The twenty-first annual seniors' tournament will be held at the Pinehurst Country Club from March 3 to March 6. There will be qualifying and final rounds of eighteen holes.

Two New York City textbook writers defended their social studies book, in use in high schools, against the attack on it made by Dr. Ralph West Robey, Assistant Professor of Banking at Columbia, who has completed a survey of 600 textbooks for the National Association of Manufacturers.

A PARTY of nature lovers will leave for the Chincha Islands off Peru's southern coast on March 14 aboard the Grace liner Santa Elena. While these guano isles are the first objective, the journey extends to the Chanchamoyo Valley and other centers where bird species are numerous.

Whether the railroads or the manufacturers of equipment for the railroads have contributed the most toward the improvement of this form of transport is a question which has been raised from time to time, and more particularly of late, in discussion of railroad efficiency and its importance to the safeguarding of the nation.

Carl Loveday, No. 4 in the national rankings, reached the final round of the sixth annual Eastern badminton championship tournament at the Fifth Avenue Country Club last night. After defeating Harry Hackett of the Penn A.C. in the quarter-finals, 14 -- 17, 15 -- 2, 15 -- 7, Loveday eliminated Harold Seavey of Framingham, Mass., 15 -- 3, 15 -- 7.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Torger Tokle, dynamic 22-year-old Norwegian skier, continued his record-smashing career today when he soared through a snowstorm 243 and 238 feet, shattering the nine-year-old Olympic sixty-five-meter jumping record on both flights.

Money in the Air People are much less interested than they were a few years ago in the question whether this is a different country with a different temper from once upon a time. In the first place, people have less time than formerly for abstract problems.

IT has been too long -- several years -- since Eric Hatch's last light-hearted novel. The latest of a long line of happily hilarious tales is warmly welcome at this time of year, for it is laid in Florida, with just a flying trip to up-State New York for snow contrasts.
CAMP STEWART, Ga., Feb. 22 -- New York's 212th Coast Artillery Regiment moved into this cantonment today, 800 enlisted men on two troop trains arriving to begin a year's military training.

DES MOINES, Feb. 22 -- Vice President Wallace told a session of the National Farm Institute tonight that the United States, for its own self-preservation, must give full assistance to Great Britain, since it might be unable to withstand the economic pressure in the Western Hemisphere that would follow a German victory.

IS murder a comic topic? Some theatregoers are seasoning their enjoyment of "Arsenic and Old Lace" and "Mr. and Mrs. North" by asking themselves that ethical question. For "Arsenic and Old Lace" regards poisoning as nothing more than a regrettable foible, and "Mr. and Mrs. North" looks upon assassination as a startling interruption in the affable social life of a Greenwich Village couple.

I wish to demur to the views expressed by my good friend Charles Warren with regard to Congress's power in the matter of convoys. Mr. Warren argues that Congress would have no power to prohibit the President from using the Navy to convoy British merchantmen. It seems to me that the contrary is the case, particularly because of Congress's power to declare war.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22 -- The University of Baltimore quintet battled all the way with the Long Island University five before 4,400 fans tonight at the Coliseum, but left the floor with its season-long winning streak finally shattered. The score was 43 to 37.

With two Kings County club-women entered as candidates, the presidency of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs will be contested this year when the elections are held to choose a successor to Mrs. Fordyce Charles Deitz of Farmingdale.

BERLIN, Feb. 22 -- The German High Command reported today the sinking of the British freighter Canadian Cruiser in the Indian Ocean while flying the United States flag. Tonight German quarters, claiming that the High Command was in possession of "unassailable proof of the vessel's identity," foresaw the possibility of a diplomatic sequel to the incident.

Slopes and meadows that once grew fir trees and pastured cattle are now vast beds of narcissus, iris and tulip plants. The Pacific Northwest, long the lumber capital of America, has also become the principal source of the nation's bulb supply.

The 1942 Brown University varsity football team will see action in eight games, according to the schedule released recently by Thomas W. Taylor, director of athletics, at the annual assembly of the Alumni Advisory Council at the Faunce House in Providence, R.I.

THE nicknames of the sixteen major league baseball teams, now getting ready for Spring training in the South, have become an integral part of the nation's sports vocabulary. Their origins are as varied as the names themselves.

NEW YORK'S fount of classic melody, Station WQXR, is five years old. It is celebrating its birthday by spreading the gospel of good music to the less cosmopolitan districts through its comparatively new 5,000-watt transmitter.

Acting to meet a shortage in the supply of registered nurses, professional organizations are sending out a call to those who have retired from the field to return and retrain. Arrangements have been concluded to start courses for this group of women in seven local hospitals, beginning next month, under the direction of the New York State League of Nursing Education.

In connection with the beautiful exhibition of the work of American Indians now assembled at the Museum of Modern Art, it might not be amiss to remind your readers that, stimulated by its directors and particularly by its president, John Sloan, the Society of Independent Artists first exhibited the creative work of Indians in a group display in 1920.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 22 -- The National Acme Company, manufacturer of machine tools, in its twenty-fifth annual report shows record earnings of $2,199,148 for 1940. This is equal to $4.40 each on 500,000 shares of the company's stock, and compares with a net of $57,994 earned in 1939.

The enactment of the lease-lend bill is looked upon as the likely occasion for any major changes in our defense organization, because of the new powers that the bill gives the President and the necessity for putting these powers immediately to use. One step was taken last week in the announcement of the appointment of a Production Planning Board.

More than 1,000 persons bought standing room yesterday at Washington Birthday matinees of the Broadway shows, as only four of the twenty-eight current attractions missed sell-outs. The post-1929 record for standees had previously been 681, set on Dec. 28, 1938.
PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Paterson's defense industries, chief among which is the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, are facing a problem in connection with the drafing of men for the Army.

To the long list of practical jokes conceived in the fertile minds of college students add the great Princeton electric-bill hoax. A group of students distributed bogus bills in the name of the "University Power Plant" -- demanding immediate payment for "extra electricity" used in dormitory rooms.

PERHAPS it was by something more than just the merest chance that five of the new pictures shown around and about Broadway last week were definitely of the order which has come to be known as slapstick. Perhaps, in fact, it was by way of indicating a new cycle.

WASHINGTON -- Three Civil Service Commissioners are beating a hectic trail between conferences and desks these days behind the scenes in the Central Civilian Recruiting Office for the Defense Program. One of these executives is Commissioner Lucille Foster McMillin.

SPRING extension of the British Broadcasting Corporation's short-wave programs to North America marks the third big step in London's program development since last June. Beginning last Sunday the BBC amplified its transmissions to the United States by more than a half hour, added new speakers to the show and stepped up its English news service.
