ORLANDO, Fla. -- While the Northern birds are wintering in warmer climes the roseate spoonbill is already well advanced with its nesting. This delicately tinted tropical bird, with its spatular bill, is still classed as one of the rarer Florida birds, even though it has been quite regularly observed nesting in the southern part of the peninsula during recent years.

The Orange County Field Trial Club has scheduled its thirtieth anniversary meeting for April 25, 26 and 27. As in recent years, the trials will be held in the covers of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club in Verbank, N.Y.

Inasmuch as this is a time of war, this week has produced at the convention of the Progressive Education Association and elsewhere considerable discussion involving the word propaganda or the idea connoted by that word. At the convention Professor Harold Hand started things off by suggesting that teachers were too much influenced by a Fascist press, and other discussions followed.

In Europe and Asia the war was rapidly moving toward a new climax last week. The German moves in the Balkans, the approach of Spring weather with the expected intensification of the campaign of Britain, and the Japanese and British moves around the Malay peninsula were all prefatory to the bitter battles that 1941 is certain to produce.

THE road to glory does not always coincide with the road of good business, but for Glenn Miller the two seem to be one. The tall and athletic orchestra leader, only 30 years old, had a gross income of $800,000 last year.

SWANSEA, Wales, Feb. 22 (UP) -- This coal town's army of homeless scratched through the ruins of former homes today in an effort to salvage any belongings not destroyed by three successive nights of devastating attack by the German Air Fleet.

In large measure, both administrators and students in American junior colleges strongly support the foreign policy of this country, favoring all possible aid to Britain and disapproving a negotiated peace between the European belligerents at the present time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- A program under which new shipbuilding plants may obtain their first forces of supervisors from men trained in the old line private yards and Navy yards was announced today by Secretary Knox as a result of a conference between representatives of shipbuilding contractors, the Navy Department and the Maritime Commission.

MR. THIELEN is unusual among the satirists of these years in that he seems not too discontented with fairly obvious material. No urge for extreme subtlety pushes him beyond the bounds of acceptance by a large number of readers.

Prices and deliveries threatened to become a major problem in the wholesale market last week, it was reported yesterday in a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. While the majority of retailers are willing to order and receive goods farther ahead than usual, they object to paying increased prices now in anticipation of possible future shortages on such goods.

Two ambulances will be presented to the Greek War Relief Association at 3 P.M. today following a special service for Greek students and their friends at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. The services will be conducted by Dr. Raymond C. Knox, university chaplain.

Emphasizing the responsibility of a democratic society for educating handicapped children, speakers at the nineteenth annual meeting of the International Council for Exceptional Children outlined yesterday the opportunities for vocational training for the mentally retarded.
The possibility that the 40,000 underground vaults in Manhattan may be useful as air-raid shelters is being explored by the WPA and city officials, it was announced yesterday.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 22 -- Led by Stub Pearson, who shuttled between guard and forward, the Dartmouth basketball team gained ground in its quest of the Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball title by trouncing Columbia, 49 to 36, before a capacity crowd tonight.

LONDON (By Wireless) LONDON, too, has its sky-writing, a grim record of aerial attack, pursuit, combat and death, written across the skies by planes so high they are invisible to earth-bound watchers. When atmospheric conditions are right -- the upper air must be saturated with moisture -- the fighters leave a trail that outlines every twist and turn in the course of action.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today he had asked Congress for 700 additional special agents immediately to protect the defense program against spies and saboteurs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana described as a "deliberate lie" today an assertion by Dr. Frank Kingdon and Herbert Bayard Swope that a recent New York rally of the America First Committee and the Keep America Out of War Congress was "un-American."

DERIVING its humor from the seemingly myriad complications that threaten marital bliss, "Uncle Walter's Dog House" provides a common meeting place on WEAF's wavelength Tuesday nights for men whose diplomatic relations with the "little woman" are temporarily strained.

There are signs that the traditional war between hairdressers and women is about to be concluded. One sign is that in discussing the new styles in hair-do's, some of the town's leading hairdressers refuse to be arbitrary. They have ideas about how women might like to wear their hair if they are tired of the long casual bob, but the hairdressers are only advancing suggestions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UP) -- Pork chops, beefsteak and lamb roasts will take a larger share of the family food budget this year, Agriculture Department economists said tonight.

WINNETKA, Ill., Feb. 22 -- New Trier Township is located in the suburbs of Chicago along the shore of Lake Michigan a few miles north of the city limits. The four villages in the township are entirely residential suburbs, 70 per cent of the graduates of New Trier High School going on to college.
LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Current efforts to get Congressional authority for completion of the $200,000,000 cross-State canal are being regarded by Floridians with both skepticism and apathy.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo (by mail) -- The German invasion of Belgium has interfered with the replenishing of stocks of this colony's postal paper, normally supplied from Malines, Belgium, and A. Paelinck, Chief of the Service of Posts and Telecommunications, announces he has turned to the Union of South Africa to have Congo's stamps printed during the emergency.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The soft coal industry, with production up 14 per cent above a year ago, may hear demands for higher wages and shorter hours when it meets with representatives of the United Mine Workers Union in New York next month to consider a new working agreement.

The Black Hawks, who have been unexpectedly formidable foes for the Rangers throughout the National Hockey League campaign, will try conclusions with the Blueshirts for the last time when the teams collide in Madison Square Garden tonight.

Protestant women of fifty-one nations will join in a World-Wide Day of prayer next Friday for "the end of war between the nations of the world." The general topic will be "Thy Kingdom Come." The prayer meetings will begin in New Zealand and follow the sun across Asia and Europe to the United States.

The 209th anniversary yesterday of the birth of George Washington, celebrated here under gray skies, was for the most part a solemn occasion, with speakers all over the country comparing the present crisis to those faced by the first President and recalling that he had said: "To be prepared for war is one of the most effectual means of preserving peace."

SCULPTURE of the widest possible diversity appears in two of the new exhibitions. At the Sachs Gallery, 817 Madison Avenue. has been assembled a remarkable collection of African sculpture, including two heads found in Nigeria with very peculiarly scored faces and one of them possessing something curiously suggestive of the Burmese in both facial expression and in the head ornament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- What is said to be an extremely sensitive method for detecting and measuring the molecular dimensions of viruses, disease toxins, poisons and other substances suspected but not known to be present in small proportions in liquids has been developed (Patent No. 2,232,539) by Dr. Irving Langmuir, Nobel Prize winner in chemistry and research head of the General Electric Company, Schenectady, N.Y.

TRAINLOADS of our young men are leaving for training camps to learn to become soldiers. From the farms, from the main streets of the villages and from the cities' sidewalks they go, in numbers that will reach almost a million a year. They are not going to war -- at least not immediately.

DIPLOMAT'S LIST: On Sept. 7, 1939, a Netherlands steamer put in at the British port of Gravesend. Aboard was an Englishman with a long, lean face and a dark mustache. He looked tired and ill. War was the reason.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S acceptance of the motion-picture industry's invitation to address the Academy Awards banquet on Thursday, though it will be delivered over the radio, has impressed Hollywood almost as much as if the President were going to attend in person.

LOS ANGELES -- The United States Army Air Corps, the Navy's air arm, and Britain's Royal Air Force today eye a sprawling factory located at San Diego in the southwest corner of America -- Consolidated Aircraft Corporation -- where long-range land and sea bombardment planes are rushed to completion under new hurry-up schedules:

OTTAWA, Feb. 22 -- Throughout this first week of the resumed session the whole trend of the debates in the House of Commons and of a large section of newspaper comment has been for the necessity of a Cabinet revision and the formation of a National Union Cabinet or at least the inclusion in the government of other than Liberal Ministers.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- Professor Harold Rugg of Teachers College, Columbia University, defended "modern historians" today against attacks made on their textbooks and their teaching in an address before 2,500 persons at the closing session of the Progressive Education Association.

AS Spring approaches, bringing with it good flying weather, sportsmen pilots and those who want to learn how to fly are busy forming private clubs all over the country. The club idea is according to many flight experts, one of the most practical and economical ways of earning a pilot's license or building up hours in the air.

HOLLYWOOD wants new faces, but it doesn't want them to do new tricks. The old act with a new actor is more apt to find favor at the studios, for the producers endeavor to keep specific talents in duplicate on their player rosters.

BERLIN, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The German radio's offer to take collect radio messages from Americans for radio program suggestions had cost the Propaganda Ministry $9,000 up to noon (5 A.M., Eastern standard time) today, broadcasting authorities said.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 22 -- Carrying a letter from President Roosevelt to President Getulio D. Vargas, former Postmaster General James A. Farley arrived here today from Buenos Aires on a ship with 300 American tourists who will help celebrate Rio de Janeiro's carnival.

Save the Children Federation, Inc., an organization that for the last nine years has aided needy children in neglected areas in this country, made known yesterday that it was seeking $1,000,000 for the care of British and refugee children in England.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The first open threat of filibustering tactics against the Administration's lease-lend bill in the Senate was made from the floor at the close of today's session by Senator Wheeler of Montana and Senator Clark of Missouri, two of the five informal committee of managers of the opposition to the bill.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 22 -- The much discussed youth problem came in for more discussion in its various phases at a series of meetings of educators' groups here today.

Projects arranged to alleviate suffering among war refugees in China are enlisting the support of several organizations and committees composed of men and women of prominence. Three events in behalf of this cause will take place here within the near future.

The Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 108d and 104th Streets, has placed on exhibition in the J. Clarence Davies Gallery the most important gift received by its print department during 1940. This is a unique copy of an early view of New York City given by Mrs. William Sloane of this city.

DETROIT -- The suggestion made last week by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt that Americans should buy fewer cars, refrigerators and the like and invest their money in government bonds, has stirred no small tempest in the automotive teapot.

In simple language Mayor La Guardia yesterday told 750 Bronx school children, aged 8 to 15, what America means to them, and with one notable exception, when he mentioned the privilege of going to school, they approved enthusiastically.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- After the lease-lend bill is out of the way, the next Congressional battle against Administration policy may develop on a proposal to set up an agency which, according to critics, could become a propaganda agency of the government. The agency is the Office of Government Reports, of which Lowell Mellett is director.

MR. REXPROTH, with one foot in the Wasteland and an eye fixed both mournfully and wrathfully upon a war-torn, value-distorting world, writes poems of statement. He has moved away from earlier poems in which he made use of much purely personal and subjective imagery, to give us in this volume long free verse poems concerning the hungers and the unwisdom of men.
Scholarships available for the 1941-42 school year at the College of Mount Saint Vincent, New York City, were announced this week. The college offers:

ISLAND retreats still lure those who want to get away from it all once in a while. Today, particularly, such haunts as the out islands of the Bahaman group, the isles off the Panama coast and off the coast of South America have their amateur discoverers playing at Robinson Crusoe.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Skytop Club plans to entertain a group of more than 150 Lafayette College alumni at a Winter sports house party sponsored by the Easton, Pa., chapter of the Alumni Association, for all Lafayette College men and their families over the week-end. Plans are also being made for a hockey match between Lafayette College and Lehigh University the same week-end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- War-torn China substantially increased both its export and import trade in 1940, according to the Far Eastern Section of the Division of Regional Information of the Department of Commerce.

ONE of the remarkable exploits of the war in North Africa has been the raids by Free French forces on the oasis strongholds of the Italians in Libya. The surprise assaults were led by tough soldiers of the French meharistes, or Camel Corps, who came up from Lake Chad, where the desert meets the jungle.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- From the bottom of her heart Lady Halifax is grateful to American women for their British war relief program.

The wide expansion of Federal control over purely intrastate affairs was halted in one direction last week by the Supreme Court decision in the Bunte Brothers case, in which the Federal Trade Commission was ruled as having no jurisdiction over unfair trade practices which are local, leading lawyers agreed here yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 -- Old grads back for Alumni Day festivities at Yale today roared approval as the Eli teams attained several impressive triumphs and achieved a world record-breaking performance in the swimming pool.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- Harvard concluded its most successful Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball trip in years by beating Pennsylvania tonight at the Palestra, 44 -- 34, and moved into fifth place in the circuit, while the Red and Blue dropped to sixth.

THE scheduling of the No. 1 feature on double bills at 9 P.M., introduced in thirty-one Loew's and thirty-two RKO theatres hereabout in the last two weeks, is apparently working out to the satisfaction of all. Out of 29,890 patrons queried by Loew's managers, 95 per cent endorsed the plan.

AIKEN, S.C., Feb. 22 -- Aiken colonists will take to the fairways of the Aiken golf course Monday for the benefit of British and Greek relief. Playing in the benefit flag tournament will be Mr. and Mrs. George H. Bostwick, Dunbar W. Bostwick, Charles von Stade, William Post, William Duncan, George N. Owen, Mrs. J. Barney Balding, Mrs. G.H. Clarke, Thomas Laughlin and W.B. Winans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- A poll of the Senate disclosed fifty-two certain votes today for the British-aid bill, with some uncommitted Senators indicating that they would vote for it when the roll was finally called.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 22 -- For issuing a proclamation calling on Puerto Ricans not to register under the Selective Service Act, R. Medina Ramirez, acting president of the Nationalist party, was indicted today on a charge of obstructing registration.

Should factory hands work longer hours to meet the demands of war or national defense? To answer the question Great Britain made some classic studies of munition workers during the last war, only to reach the conclusion that long hours meant fatigue and mistakes.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Threescore sailors set forth today in the two-session Winter sailing regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club, which topped the cold canvas-trimming season.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- Workmen have just completed erecting the new brush, hurdle and timber jumps at Southern Pines's new one-mile training course for steeplechase horses. Already several vans of hunt-race horses have arrived and are being trained for the meet of Saturday, March 15.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 22 -- Nazi General Staff officers in civilian clothes, their black military boots shining under their raincoats, began establishing themselves in Sofia this afternoon. From the city's leading hotel they peered quietly out at groups of angry students shouting against "the German occupation of Bulgaria."

At the meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers Dr. Hans Lundberg astonished his hearers by telling them of a new method of discovering gold by looking for it in the minute amounts absorbed from the soil by a leaf, and Dr. Leo Horvitz explained how oil and gas deep below the surface are detected by analyzing small samples of soil for hydrocarbons.

MIDDLEBURG, Va. BITTER cold and snow have canceled many foxhunts in the rolling Piedmont of late but local weather is of small moment compared to the anxieties which the international climate has imposed on American sportsmen.

In a protest against the lease-lend bill, women pickets of the New York Council of the American Peace Mobilization demonstrated yesterday before the homes of United States Senator Robert F. Wagner and Representative Sol Bloom.

PHILADELPHIA. THE presentation of Richard Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" as unspecialized, even routine, opera by a resident Philadelphia organization is an aim of the Philadelphia-La Scala Opera Company, now in its second season.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 22 -- Informed by telephone from this capital tonight that Marshal Henri Philippe Petain was reported to be seriously ill and awaiting surgical intervention for an unspecified reason, Dr. Menetrel, the Marshal's private personal physician, announced it was news to him.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 22 -- As a consequence of the recent crop of wild rumors here, the police today arrested a number of persons accused of spreading unfounded reports and they have been interned in remote places in the country. These measures are taken with the aim of calming the atmosphere, which has been tense in spite of the Bulgarian-Turkish declaration of non-aggression of last Monday.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- With tension in the Balkans mounting as Nazi divisions are reported to filter into Bulgaria to threaten the Greeks' eastern flank, the British Admiralty today warned shipping that the whole 150,000 square miles of the Central Mediterranean were dangerous for navigation.

THERE is probably nobody who does not recall occasions when his mother has given him a birching "for his own good," protesting the while somewhat tearfully that it hurt her more than it did him. It is in this parental frame of mind that this department approaches the Ballet Theatre this morning.

I'D like to say a word about the less expensive seats to plays. I do think it a shame that most theatres have so few cheap seats -- seats which people like myself can afford. And it also strikes me that it would pay in the long run to cut down the number of expensive seats, and add to the less expensive ones.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22 -- A head on the post decided the issue at Hialeah Park today in the $26,250 Flamingo Stakes, run before Florida's greatest race crowd, 29,541 persons, who watched the King Ranch's Dispose outlast Curious Coin in the nine-furlong event.
With the planning of next Summer's garden now occupying the thoughts of most homeowners who have a bit of ground, consideration may well be given the advantages offered by the various annual vines.

THANKS for a very nice notice. However, I want to call your attention to the fact that the Jimson Weed, in "Jimson Weed, Pink Hills and Pedernal," is not an enlarged flower. A really healthy Jimson Weed is often larger than I have painted it.

A great emergency is facing this country or it would not be necessary to call a million men away from their homes and business, nor for the government to spend twenty billion dollars. Any obstruction to a prompt effort for preparedness to meet this emergency is to be heartily condemned.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- George R. Meyercord was chairman and former president of the Haskelite Manufacturing Company, which has been experimenting in making airplane parts from plastics, and a member of the advisory board of the Illinois Manufacturers Association.

More than 200 Hunter College day session students took advantage of the new "self-execution" system on last registration day, Feb. 5, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Mary Belden James Lehn, registrar and chairman of the committee on promotion of students.

RESIDENTS of the New York area bought 82 per cent more new automobiles from dealers in this territory during January than they did in the same month last year, according to E.B. Shumate, head of Nash Motors of New York, Inc., branch of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, 3280 Broadway.

A dictatorship has an appeal to every one in some measure, for, by re-establishing the dependency of childhood, it relieves the individual of many responsibilities a freer civilization imposes, a thousand delegates to the closing session of the eighteenth annual meeting of the American Orthopsychiatric Association were told yesterday.

MONTREAL, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The sixth-place Montreal Canadiens, showing power all along the line in one of their best performances of the season, whipped the Chicago Black Hawks, 7 to 3, tonight to take a tighter grip on the last playoff spot in the National Hackey League standings.

THE present cooperation between England and the United States in international policies has inspired in some quarters the hope of a rapprochement in other respects also. One of our most clear-sighted journalists believes that this new unity of the two English-speaking nations will have some very interesting results in literature.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 22 -- Next Fall Harvard will inaugurate a program designed to integrate its 500 or more commuting undergraduates more closely into the college program, Dean A.C. Hartford of Harvard College announced this week.
ROME, Feb. 22 (UP) -- The Italian press was jammed tonight with warnings to the United States and defiance of Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Institute for Propaganda Analysis is under investigation by the House Committee on Un-American Activities headed by Representative Dies, J.B. Matthews, chief investigator for the committee, said today.

The suggestion made by Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox and the Maritime Commission chairman, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, that commercial shipyards maintain present wage scales and working conditions has brought a protest from the International Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians, it was announced yesterday.

The WPA household training project in this city has been ordered to stop buying caviar and other delicacies following charges by a dismissed project superintendent that "luxurious" parties were given in project quarters at government expense, it was learned yesterday.

YOUTH: President Roosevelt named last week a new United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. He picked a young man, 30-year-old Mathias F. Correa, who had been chief assistant in the attorney's office. The historically minded tried to recall when one so young had filled the $10,000-a-year job.

CRAZIER AND CBAZIER -- Dr. Oscar Kaplan, University of California psychologist, has just completed a study in psychopathology which shows that if present trends are maintained we face a considerable increase in the number of insane.

Bamboo is not usually listed among evergreens, nor is it commonly considered as such in the North. Nevertheless, Arrow Bamboo or Arundinaria japonica (also known as Bambusa metake) is a thoroughly reliable hardy evergreen in the vicinity of New York and Long Island and, in sheltered locations, even as far north as Boston.

THE American Opera League, founded last Summer by Thomas L. Thomas, baritone, opens its first tour next month in Boston. It plans to present operas in various centers in New England and also will appear in New York.

THE South, according to Mr. Cash, is "not quite a nation within a nation, but the next thing to it." For, in spite of all its intellectual and material progress of recent years and in spite of all its physical and social divergencies -- and these are in some ways enormous -- there can still be traced throughout the late Confederacy "a fairly definite mental pattern, associated with a fairly definite social pattern."

The President Harrison of the American President Lines arrived yesterday from a three-and-a-half month voyage around the world and docked at Pier 9, Jersey City. Among the 110 passengers on board were forty-six sailors returning from Karachi, India, where they had delivered a tanker, the Ceylon, and a barge for the Texas Oil Company of California.
The Yankees' official training camp party departed yesterday for St. Petersburg, Fla., and the preparatory campaign by which Manager Joe McCarthy hopes to rebuild on a championship scale.

ISTANBUL, Feb. 22 -- The signing by Bulgaria and Turkey of the declaration of Ankara this week has caused a greater sensation than the instrument's words warrant. The Bulgarians are treating it as a license to let the Germans use their country as a corridor to menace Greece, without running the risk that Turkey's obligations will cause Bulgaria to pay any penalty.

MEXICO CITY -- The archaeologist has always been the trail blazer for the traveler, and in recent years Americans have profited greatly from the work of scientists who are still trying to solve the riddle of the great pre-Columbian civilizations in this hemisphere.

It was "cabbage night" again last night at the studio-theatre of Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman, where on one week-end of each month a pair of "popular theatrical" programs is given. Last night's bill introduced several numbers that have not been presented before, but in the main confined itself to established material such as Miss Humphrey's "Square Dances" and "The Shakers," and Mr. Weldman's "Portraits of Famous Dancers" which made their public bow last month.

A recital by Guiomar Novaes invariably proves a provocative and interesting experience. The Brazilian pianist's performances at her latest appearance, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, was no exception in this respect, as was attested by the ardent acclaim with which her performances were received by a large and representative gathering.

Major A.L. Boyce, who trained more than 30,000 men for the last war as Boyce's Tigers, has organized a new training school called Boyce's Tigers 1941. The classes, held Tuesdays and Thursdays at 5 o'clock at P.S. 179, 140 West 102d Street, are open without charge to all who desire training from men with extensive military experience.

The people of Poland were praised last night for their contribution to American history by Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr., former Ambassador to Poland and soon to become the United States Minister to the governments in exile in London. Mr. Biddle spoke at a dinner of the Manhattan Society, a Polish-American group, held at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton.

The real hero of this story is Danny Coyle, a square-shooting gambler of whom it is said that he will bet on anything. It is he who pieces together the extraordinary series of events which begins with the deliberate loss to him of $125,000 by John Martin of Texas.

BALZAC is the master of the modern novel. His Comedie Humaine is the headspring from which flow the works of fiction writers in France from Flaubert to Zola, in England from Thomas Hardy to H.G. Wells, in America from Henry James to Dreiser.

THE future "Crazy House," described as "a full brother to 'Hellzapoppin,'" now is to open the end of August, and it is to boast the services of the Messrs. Ole Olsen and Chic Johnson, current tenants of "Hellzapoppin." Carmen Miranda will be in it, too.

The new passenger-cargo liner President Hayes, the third in a series of seven round-the-world liners constructed by the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Virginia, arrived from the builder's yards yesterday and docked at Eighth Street, Hoboken.

Washington's democratic ideals, especially the principle of religious freedom, must be preserved today from the onslaught of totalitarianism, rabbis declared in Washington's Birthday sermons yesterday.

A hundred clergymen and leaders in church work have issued a statement appealing to their fellow-citizens to join them in urging defeat of the Devany-Hampton and Dunnigan bills, designed to bar the Communist party and other allegedly subversive groups from the ballot, the Rev. John Howard Melish, rector of the Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, announced yesterday.

THE visitor in the New York Zoological Park these days is likely, in the course of his rambling, to stop, stare, rub his eyes and look around quickly for the nearest tall tree. For suddenly he comes in sight of a half-dozen lions and lionesses loose and at play on a rocky hillside, chewing one another's ears, and prevented by nothing that he can see from bounding down the hill to chew him.

A CONSIDERABLE sense of satisfaction is communicated when the annoying ghost of a mistatement resulting from scholarship gone awry is laid, to the relief of musicians and those who love their art, and a further satisfaction is experienced when the man principally responsible for the debunking process is among us.

IT seems to be still impossible to write about Maximilien Robespierre without prejudice. Either one is violently against him or violently for him It all depends on one's political persuasion. Ralph Korngold, whose life of the Incorruptible's Death Angel, Saint-Just, appeared some seasons ago, now offers in "Robespierre and the Fourth Estate" a biography of Robespierre that presents the stern little ascetic of Arras as a veritable hero indeed.

As a special tribute to George Bernard Shaw, dramatist, Mrs. Messmore Kendall, general chairman, and a committee representing the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry have chosen for the annual Spring theatre party benefit for that institution the performance of Shaw's play "The Doctor's Dilemma" on the night of March 17 -- St. Patrick's Day -- at the Shubert Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- As a means of effecting a considerable saving in the purchase of canned and non-perishable foods for the expanding Army, the War Department announced today that purchasing would be centralized at the three Quartermaster Depots in New York, Chicago and San Francisco. The products will then be delivered to Army stations throughout the country.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 22 -- Reports that Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, is coming to Ankara, which began to circulate as soon as it was known that he had arrived in Cairo, have at present no foundation. In British official circles it is said that nothing has been decided in this respect.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 22 -- Dartmouth's hockey team defeated Harvard in a Quadrangular League contest tonight, 5 to 4.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- British observers of Europe's intricate food problem, turning back the pages of history to the last wax for guidance and some salient points -- one of them being Herbert Hoover's relief program -- have arrived at interesting conclusions with a direct bearing on the present situation.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Seton Hall Prep won the annual national Catholic interscholastic swimming championship meet at Villanova College today, ending the four-year reign of St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Penn State triumphed over Army today at basketball, 31 to 27, before 5,000 spectators in the big field house after trailing at the half, 20 to 12. It was one of the fastest and hardest played contests of the West Point season.
A crowd that went indoors for a glimpse of the great outdoors jammed Grand Central Palace yesterday.

To help individuals adjust themselves to society by showing how they appear to others, is the central idea of the "self-evaluation laboratory" at the Division of General Education of New York University. For three years the laboratory has been successfully maintained, and yesterday Miss Alice Rice Cook, director, declared it might be expanded to provide classes in which men and women could meet together.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Dr. Clarence A. Dykstra, president of the University of Wisconsin and director of Selective Service, today called "the establishment of a peaceful and a democratic world" the greatest challenge to education and said the nation could have an "eventual" democracy by guaranteeing peace.

Two thousand recently naturalized citizens and hundreds of school children, guests of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York at exercises yesterday morning in Carnegie Hall, in commemoration of the 209th anniversary of the birth of George Washington, were urged to unite in the fight for national defense and the preservation here of the principles of democracy.

The evils that beset the world can be overcome only when mankind adopts the teachings of Christ, the Rev. John J. Hartigan of St. Joseph's Seminary, Dunwoodie, N.Y., told 5,000 members of the New York chapter of the Knights of Columbus at the Washington's Birthday pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

That marvel of marvels, J. Gregory Rice, cracked another world record last night as he hammered his own three-mile mark down a few more notches before the awed gaze of 14,000 spectators at the fifty-third annual national A.A.U. track and field championships in Madison Square Garden.

TRENTON, Feb. 22. -- A jury in Oyer and Terminer Court here today convicted George Foulds Jr., 23 years old, of first-degree murder in the hold-up shooting last Dec. 27 of Samuel Cominsky, president of a Trenton manufacturing concern in which Foulds formerly had been employed.

LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 23 -- Twice yesterday the Germans, reverting apparently to their tactics of last Fall, tried to carry out daylight raids against London, but both times they were driven off by fighters of the British Royal Air Force after furious battles in the sky high over Kent.

Addressing 750 members of the Manhattan College Alumni Society at the seventy-second annual dinner of the society at the Hotel Astor last night, the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, urged Manhattan to take heart, "for the immediate future was never less predictable."

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The port of Gumbo, near Kismayu at the mouth of the Juba River in Italian Somaliland, has fallen to South African troops, it was announced officially today. An Italian "brigade staff and one full colonel, together with a number of European and native prisoners," were reported to have been captured and "considerable quantities of guns and materials" taken.

About two years ago there was considerable discussion on the subject of so-called "parabolic" fly rods, and a number of the individual rod-makers spent considerable time in experimenting with various calibrations to find the proper formula for obtaining this action.
THIS is Harlan Cozad McIntosh's first and only novel, written over a period of years, rejected and rewritten; again rejected and rewritten again. Last year the author committed suicide. He was 32.

With more than 3,500 students taking courses in biology at City College, the department is emphasizing scientific method rather than "cook-book dogma" in the teaching of biological sciences, it was reported last week by Professor Axel L. Melander, chairman.

Word that Ambassador John G. Winant will not leave for England before the middle of next week quieted conjecture yesterday that he would board the Dixie Clipper, which was held at La Guardia Field by a "maintenance delay" and rescheduled to take off at 8:30 A.M. today.

The Todd-California Shipbuilding Corporation announced yesterday at its New York office that work had already started on the new national defense magnesium plant near San Francisco, for which contracts were signed with the government last week.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- A strong belief in the understanding and faith of youth toward American democracy in the face of worldwide confusion was expressed here today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, in an address to 1,000 Princeton alumni and parents of undergraduates.

Although the percentage increases were not as sharp as those of the two preceding weeks, retail trade here gave a good account of itself last week. Department store sales were estimated as showing a gain of 12 per cent or more over last year.

IT no longer is surprising to any one that events occurring on the sands of Libya might have reverberations in West Forty-fourth Street. In fact, we have all had dinned into us so much the contention that the whole world has become one small locality that there is a tendency to look for sharper reactions to foreign developments in the lives of New Yorkers than are likely to take place.

Repeating his victory of the Gold Racquet final at Tuxedo, Robert Grant 3d of New York defeated J. Richard Leonard of Tuxedo yesterday to win the national amateur racquets championship for the fourth time.

A SERIES of Belgian parcel post stamps, comprising overprinted provisionals, which reached New York last week, has behind it a wartime story. During the confusion that attended the German invasion of the Low Countries last year quantities of Belgian parcel post stamps were stolen from various postoffices.

BACK in the days beyond compare there was a music hall artist who, with an air of prodigious slyness, used to sing a ballad of his own, "I Can't Say More Than Wot 'E Is -- E's -- the -- My-sterious -- John Doe!" You just knew the fellow was holding something back.

Though the Willow Pattern china is perhaps less in evidence today than it was a generation ago, children are familiar with its miniature blue and white landscape and no doubt some of them still ponder on the meaning of the three little figures hurrying across the bridge, the boat, and the two birds affectionately greeting one another at the top of the picture.

FLINT, Mich., Feb. 22 -- Eighty-two employes at Plant No. 1 of the General Motors Fisher Body division have been discharged, causing a row between the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., and the management, it was made known today.

IN spite of war activities, Bermuda continues to put on its usual lively sports program for the amusement of visitors as well as for the local citizenry. Yacht races always bring out a big crowd and the yearly Spring race with Long Island yachtsmen is preceded by a series of elimination contests among local boats.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22 -- With the start of the major league baseball season almost two months away, training camp activities of the various clubs will be speeded up during the coming week. Many of the players are already on hand in some of the camps, while others will report within the next few days.

The annual conference of the Grand Lodge of Elks, with Past Grand Exalted Rulers present from all over the country, meeting yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore, adopted a four-point program for national defense, and discussed for future action other points of cooperation by the Elks with the Army and Navy and other patriotic organizations.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 22 (AP) -- A new step in the use of oxygen for high-altitude flying which may mean increased safety for the war pilot as well as greater manoeuvrability or armament possibilities for his plane was announced today by Professor John Akerman of the University of Minnesota.

British statesmen, in appeals made public yesterday by Sylvan Gotshal, executive chairman of the Greater New York Campaign of the $12,000,000 War Emergency Drive of the United Palestine Appeal, called for the support of American Jews in making Palestine a stronghold of British defense in the Middle East and utilizing it for the solution of the problem of Jewish refugees.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The first World War started American farmers on a prosperity spree that ruined many of them. The present war has created problems of its own that are now the deep concern of the very highest officials in Washington.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 22 -- South African Air Force bombers assisting the advancing British forces in Italian Somaliland have attacked troop concentrations on the banks of the Juba River, the British announced today. Truck transports in the Gelib area and near Mogadiscio, the only good seaport in the colony that remains in Italian hands, also were bombed.

TORONTO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs tightened their hold on the National Hockey League lead tonight and at the same time blasted Johnny Mowers's hopes of winning the Vezina Trophy when they trounced Mowers and the Detroit Red Wings, 6 to 2.

Who would try to catch a pike with tackle made for trout? That is one of the questions to which Mr. Tolefree must find the answer if he is to solve a puzzling murder mystery. It is not a case of murder when Tolefree is first called in.

Acting on a telephone tip from an anonymous caller early last night, the police went to a vacant lot on West Fifteenth Street -- two blocks from Cunard Line Pier 54, where a case containing ten unassembled Thompson sub-machine guns destined for the British Army were stolen Thursday -- and found the guns, wrapped up in three burlap bags, all assembled and ready for use.

LEAVE it to Branch the Non-Alcoholic Rickey to think up something different in baseball. Branch has ordered a supply of Vitamin B-1 for consumption at the Cardinal training camp in St. Petersburg. His pitchers lacked something last year. It might have been Vitamin B-1. On the other hand, it might have been a good curve ball.

THE historical background of Mrs. Kent's books is always honest and thoughtful, and as her tales succeed one another the plots steadily improve in plausibility and interest and the characters become more lifelike.

HOW many feathers has a hen? How many toothpicks can be cut from a cord of white birch wood? If one of your best dishes was to be broken would you prefer having your maid do it or would you rather do it yourself?

IN Georgia the great Okefenokee Swamp fans out for untracked miles -- a sinister and primeval wilderness. Black waters flow sluggishly through it, their banks lined by cypress and by impenetrable thickets. Panthers and gators, deer and coons and otters and treacherous deadly snakes make the swamp both a paradise for hunters and a menace to them.

WE have had some good novels about the American Revolution in the past decade -- a few of them better than good. It is a reasonable conjecture that several of their number will wear as well as the works of Scott and Cooper, and contribute as much to popular notions in history and amuse generations after our own in much the same way.

CLEVELAND, Ohio -- The world's largest airplane landing gear "drop-test" apparatus will be placed in operation here soon with the completion of the new $100,000 research laboratory constructed by the Cleveland Pneumatic Tool Company, one of the nation's largest producers of pneumatic struts.

BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- With an entry surpassing that of a year ago, the Eastern Dog Club today opened its twenty-ninth annual all-breed fixture in Mechanics Building. Competition will continue through tomorrow evening, when best in show will be awarded by William Prescott Walcott of Milton, Mass.

LOSS of a Saturday for business! due to the holiday may have cut down the trade increase last week, but the gain over I last year was still substantial, ae!cording to all reports. Camp centers are being added to industrial and shipbuilding centers as high spots for trade activity.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 22 -- The Dartmouth track team defeated Harvard, 66-42, today, taking nine of twelve events.

Breaking 100 straight targets, A.S. Cornhill won the George H. Lyon Memorial Trophy, one of the outstanding Winter events, over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The holiday brought more than eighty gunners from various metropolitan clubs to the Winged Foot grounds.

THE theme of Mr. Tarkington's new and very characteristic novel is American Youth vs. The Depression. In Hatcher Ide's particular case there are further complications which result from his falling in love with an enchanting lady a good deal older than himself, and one whose relations with his own father seem not merely mysterious but even suspicious to the bewildered Hatcher.

The "darkness" of the title is that of the Dark Ages. In Rome, in the middle of the sixth century, one little man, one only, knew that Justinian would soon set about the destruction of civilization. He knew, because he was a modern American, in tweeds, with a pipe and wrist watch and travelers' checks and stout English shoes, who had been struck by lightning and knocked back in time to 533 A.D.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Defending Champion A. Willing Patterson of Philadelphia battled his way into the quarter-finals of the national squash racquets championships at the Penn A.C. today.

HOUSTON, Texas -- The opening of a new airline route between this city and Memphis, Tenn., on Saturday will offer a new and scenic route for rapid transit between Eastern and Southwestern points. The route will be opened by the Chicago Southern Air Lines, and will come from Memphis via Pine Bluff, Ark., and Shreveport, La.

MIXED in small quantities with natural rubber, a new compound called Duramin prolongs the useful life of tires and other rubber products by toughening them to wear and slowing their deterioration, the B.F. Goodrich Company announced last week.

VICHY, France, Feb. 22 -- A list of twenty-nine Jewish banking firms, among which are several of the largest or most of the long-established banks in France, is published today in the official journal as having been placed under "Aryan" direction.

WHEN the New Friends of Music orchestra joins with the Schola Cantorum on Wednesday evening, Feb. 26, in "The Passion According to St. John," by Johann Sebastian Bach, we will try to present the work as much as possible as the Cantor of Leipzig himself may have performed it.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation announced here yesterday that its affiliate, the Oregon Shipbuilding Corporation of Portland, one of the new shipyards set up with the aid of the government to construct the 200 "ugly ducklings" for quick additions to the merchant marine, had started excavating for its new plant and that the site was being cleared at the rate of 5,000 cubic yards a day.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 -- Support of the principle of military training for all able-bodied men in periods of intensive summertime service was voiced by President Charles Seymour of Yale University today in his annual address to the 1,500 graduates gathered for the twenty-eighth annual alumni day events.

C.S. FORESTER, the English novelist, said that he often congratulates himself for having chosen one of the few professions in which it is possible to do most of one's work while lying on one's back. He describes himself as "lazy, indolent."
The Brooklyn Botanic Garden has on display in house No. 3 of the conservatories a number of house plants demonstrating the results of hydroponics, or gardening without soil.

The greatest financial effort since the days of the World War is about to get started in the United States. It is the financing of the national defense program. The President has called for an enormous expansion of our armed forces; Congress has passed billions of dollars of authorizations and appropriations; the War and Navy Departments have already placed $12,000,000,000 of orders.

NELLIE MITCHELL was born in Melbourne, Australia, May 19, 1861. This vital statistic may not be generally well remembered; nor the fact that Nellie Melba, the name and personality made famous by the body and spirit of Nellie Mitchell, died Feb. 23, 1931.

The newly organized Committee for Crippled Children's Aid, an independent group of women supplying shoes and braces to children attending the clinic of the Post Graduate Hospital, will be the beneficiary of a cocktail party and entertainment to be given Tuesday afternoon at Hampshire House.
TOKYO, Feb. 22 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's alleged offer to mediate between Britain and Germany has aroused Nazi diplomatic representations and increasingly vocal criticism at home.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 22 -- Many members of society in Fairfield County are assisting as committee members in preparations for the "Mad Hatters Ball," which will be given at the Shorehaven Country Club here next Saturday night for the benefit of the British-American Ambulance Corps.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 22 (AP) -- James M. Costello of Lisbon, Ohio, retired railroad conductor, who distributed $5,000 checks to twenty-one cousins in 1937, died today at the age of 84. He retired twenty years ago after forty years' service with the Erie Railroad.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Taxable motor fuel sales in the State continued the eight-year upward trend in 1940, reaching a record of 1,836,976,683 gallons, Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, reported today. The gain was 4 per cent over the 1939 gallonage of 1,768,288,521.

In 1933, when the taxation subcommittees of the Congress and the Treasury were studying methods of preventing the avoidance and evasion of income-tax laws, a plan was submitted to the Ways and Means Committee with reference to limiting the deductability of depreciation from the adoption of which it was estimated an increased annual revenue of $85,000,000 would result for a period of three years.

THE vision of world peace was part of the liberalization of ideas, as is more or less well known, which characterized French thought in the Age of Enlightenment. What is not nearly so well known is that this vision had found expression in France through more than a hundred and fifty years preceding the latter part of the eighteenth century.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- A report prepared by Dr. Frederick Strauss, economist of the Agriculture Department, which was revealed in part today, gives facts and figures to show that the conquered nations of Europe could feed themselves under war conditions if permitted.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- A record number of boxes and club seats have been sold for the sixteenth annual Kiwanis benefit for underprivileged children, to be staged at the Paramount Theatre tomorrow night. As in former years, Arthur Hammerstein and Sam H. Harris, the producers, have assembled a large cast of radio, screen and stage stars and George Jessel will be master of ceremonies.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 22 -- The curriculum based on 100 great books, now in its fourth year at St. John's College here, has been adapted to a rapidly expanding adult education program.

MARKING the fiftieth anniversary of the Empire State Express, the New York Central will transform its famous flier into what it plans to be the finest streamlined day train in the world. The new equipment will cost between $2,000,000 and $2,500,000, and it is expected to be in service late this Summer.

Drawing and scale models in an exhibition, "Our Fellow Mammals," at the Brooklyn Children's Museum are introducing boys and girls to the ways of the wart hog, the wallaroo and the wombat and many another fascinating creatures mostly known to adults through cross-word puzzles.

IT was not anything like a century ago that S.N. Behrman, whose latest comedy, "The Talley Method," which opens at Henry Miller's tomorrow night, decided to be a playwright, a whole playwright, and nothing but. Having decided it, he tore up the ticket which within a few hours would have taken him to an instructor's job in a fresh-water college-and went, grimly, back to work.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Feb. 22 (AP) -- The University of North Carolina successfully defended its Southern Conference indoor track championship by winning the final event, the mile relay, in the twelfth annual meet tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Local officials of the country soon will receive a model bill prepared by Federal authorities as proposed legislation to prevent rent increases that may jeopardize defense efforts, according to a letter sent by Harriet Elliott, Consumer Commissioner in the Council of National Defense, to Audley H. Stephan, chairman of the New Jersey Defense Council.

THE strategy of Europe is the strategy of geography, raw materials and terrain. It is the immutable strategy of distances, of oil and coal and bauxite, of woods and mountains, forest and plain; of the Essens and Birminghams, where the machines of men make the machines of war.

THE first international conference concerning the world's largest radio "classroom" brings together here and at Atlantic City this week more than 1,000 representatives from all the countries of the Western Hemisphere. The particular radio programs the delegates are to discuss comprise not only education but Pan-American unity and understanding as well.

VICHY, France, Feb. 22 -- France rejected today a Japanese-sponsored proposal which, reliable informants said, was a demand that approximately one-third of them western Indo-China Provinces of Laos and Cambodia be ceded to Thailand.

As the lengthening days indicate that Spring is on the way, it is well to keep in mind the publications of the School Nature League. Founded in 1917, this association has performed a valuable service in increasing the knowledge and appreciation of nature among teachers and children in the elementary public schools of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Count Jerzy Potocki, who resigned in December as Ambassador from Poland, predicted tonight that the United States would become the center of world power after this war and said that he intended to remain here to work for American support of Polish independence.

Members of the nation's armed forces are visiting New York in such increasing numbers that for the first six weeks of this year more than 28,000 service men a week used the facilities of the New York Young Men's Christian Association and attended special events provided for them, Richard W. Lawrence, president of the association, reported yesterday.

As reports of the first robin come in Mary Curtis's "From Robin to Junco" is a timely and useful book. The illustrations are noteworthy; there are twelve delightful color photographs (made by Professor Arthur A. Allen of Cornell University), and lively black and white drawings on nearly every page which catch to a remarkable degree the animation and activity of bird life.

Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will bless the new Moore-McCormack liner Rio de la Plata at launching ceremonies at the yards of the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company in Chester, Pa., next Saturday.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark. -- The influx of visitors to this spa has reached the highest point in the last decade, a survey just completed indicates. The resort's business barometer -- the thermal baths which Uncle Sam has owned for over a century -- has taken a spurt to reach the highest mark since 1929.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 22 -- Temple University's quintet played sensationally today to turn in its twelfth triumph of the season at the expense of the Naval Academy. The score was 48 to 36.

THE quest of serenity in America forms the theme on which thin book's diverse chapters are strung; and it was neither the demand for personal peace of mind nor the sense of seeking the generally impossible that motivated Webb Waldron in his search.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 22 -- Lanky Horton Smith of Chicago and the 1940 winner, Lloyd Mangrum, another Chicagoan, shaved three strokes from par with 69s today to gain the lead in the sixth annual $3,000 Thomasville open golf tournament.

THIS does not read like a first book. It is written with too sure and deft a hand for that. All that the publishers tell us about Mr. Baker is that he is English. At any rate, his Miss Hargreaves is a delightful invention. Norman Huntley made her up, with some slight assistance from his friend Henry, with whom he was having a holiday in Ireland.

This is an anthology of the famous classic tales which for hundreds of years have been the heritage of the English-speaking child. It is intended for the use of boys and girls of all ages, ranging from The Three Bears to The King of the Golden River.

DETAILS of the forthcoming Spring program of the American Petroleum Institute's lubrication committee were revealed last week by R.A. Ludlow, committee director. The program has been designed further to inform the motoring public on the importance of periodic lubrication, both as a measure of personal safety to the motorist and protection for his car investment.

The gold and silver production of the world last year again established new high levels. With the United States offering about the only market for these two metals and also having high record stocks of both, the question of their importance in the monetary system of the world after the conclusion of the present war is of vital interest to the United States.

Mayor La Guardia indicated yesterday that it would be necessary to curtail city services unless the city were permitted to use its surplus of about $14,000,000 in emergency relief taxes for purposes allied to relief during the 1941-42 fiscal year. This opinion was expressed while he was attending a Washington's Birthday Americanism luncheon at the Bronx Elks Lodge, Grand Concourse and Burnside Avenue.

"AUSTRALIA'S view of her position in the Pacific?" the Right Honorable Richard Gardiner Casey, D.S.O., M.C., first Minister of His Majesty's Australian Legation in Washington, smiled at the very broad question. Then he said, "Perhaps the simplest way to answer it is to show you a map."

BOTH group and one-man shows of the week which fell to the lot of this reviewer included -- without undue excitement -- a number of attractive offerings. Also included were several exhibitions given over to the more extreme phases of modernism -- chiefly, I think, explorings of blind alleys.

ROME, Feb. 22 -- Direct participation of the United States in the European war will "automatically" call for Japan's intervention, Zembei Horikiri, Japanese Ambassador, said in an interview published today by the Gazetta del Popolo. Ambassador Horikiri, the newspaper said, stressed that Japan had "no aggressive intentions" against the United States, and that there were hopes for an improvement of Japanese-American relations.

"Orphan" investment trusts entered the Washington spotlight last week with a pronouncement by Chester T. Lane, general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, that they must register under the Investment Company Act of 1940 if they desire to continue to redeem their certificates.

THE first thing to be said about Mr. Marquand's new novel is that although we have here the third book in which he has probed satirically into the recesses of New England character, one's interest remains undiminished. If you have read "The Late George Apley" and "Wickford Point" there is no reason under the sun why you should not be equally entertained and moved by "H.M. Pulham, Esquire."

LAKELAND, Fla. -- Now at its peak, Florida's Winter season offers an interesting study in variety of diversions, though there does not seem to be the usual fanfare. Diversions have increased because permanent residents learned several years ago that visitors required much more than an opportunity to bask in the sun, and the fanfare is not so intensive because events once extolled as innovations have now become accepted as seasonal fixtures.

Camp de Gurs, Nov. 11, 1940. . . . Thank you for the 50 francs which were enclosed in your letter. You can hardly imagine what a joy this has been to me. Such a thing reacts like a ray that brightens everything suddenly.

Welfare Commissioner William Hodson has refused to permit the American Rescue Ship Mission to take up a public collection as part of its project to transport 450 Spanish Republican refugees from France to Mexico, it became known yesterday.

RICHARD SYLVESTER MANEY has been at large for twenty-seven years. In fact, this piquant allay-foozee has been inflating the egos of Broadway's mice and men ever since Anna Held was dunked in a creamy bovine brew.

NO county in England is so uncompromisingly English as Yorkshire. Of its essence are wool and the forthright breed that has built up the woolen industry during a century of vicissitude. Thomas Armstrong, Yorkshireman of stock that for many generations has had to do, in one way or another, with wool, had not to look about him for a subject for his first novel.

Boat shows are getting to be the vogue in inland cities as well as along the seaboard, and folks who ought to know, such as Ira Hand of the National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers, are quick to aver this trend means a rapidly growing interest in recreational boating.

We begin with an axe murder. The victim is a woman, and beside her body is a blue geranium and a broken flower pot, but no axe. The place is a dressing room belonging to the swimming pool of the Hotel Quillan near Santa Monica.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Expenditure of billions of dollars "effectively and efficiently" is making the United States Navy "the most powerful protective force in the world," and it will not fail "in the event of foreign attack," according to a monograph by Secretary Knox which was published today by the American Council on Public Affairs.

TIME for Mary's medicine, and there's a balky look in Mary's eye. "Um . . . this is good," mother says gayly, measuring the dose. She feels far from gay, but knows she's got to get this remedy inside her child even if driven to say that the nauseous stuff is strawberry syrup or orangeade or anything else she can think up in a hurry.

THE Postoffice Department has made available a photograph of the design of the 3-cent purple stamp to be issued on March 4 to mark the sesquicentennial of the admittance of Vermont as the fourteenth State in the Union.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 22 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:

I WAS extremely interested in the review of Joseph Stella's recent exhibition at the Associated American Artists. If, as the reviewer said, the show was rather disappointing, wasn't this possibly due to the overcrowding of the pictures?

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Lord Marley, now touring the United States, accepted in behalf of Great Britain here this afternoon a Revolutionary War cannon ball, fired by the Redcoats in the Battle of Monmouth, N.J., in 1781, and now being returned to England "to be used in the defense of our democracy and the American democracy."

THE Metropolitan Opera Association has booked thirty-three performances in six cities for its annual Spring tour. This means that this year's tour will be as large as last and, if negotiations are completed with three other cities, it will be larger.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Francis Tyler, burly local policeman, drove the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds to victory in the National A.A.U. four-man bobsled championship today on the mile-long Mount Van Hoevenberg course before a crowd of several thousand, the largest to witness an event here since the Olympic meet.

DALLAS, Texas, Feb. 22 -- The cotton industry in the Southwest, hard hit by the drying up of the export trade and the freezing of cotton in government loans, can see little chance for improvement in its business resulting from the operation of the lease-lend bill.

For nearly four years, reports Dr. George Gallup, director of the American Institute of Public Opinion, ever since the Japanese invasion of China, the institute has taken frequent soundings of United States sentiment toward Japan.

IN face of all the complaints thrown against the New York City school system, the improved design of our new school buildings seems to have gone almost unnoticed. You and I pay for these schools ($8,802,750 for the four opened this term); they are built for the education of our children.
CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Livestock prices steadied today after the week's decline in the hog and cattle departments that reflected slightly increased supplies and curtailed shipping demand.

READERS of contemporary fiction have observed that with increasing frequency they are informed by the author in a brief note prefacing his story that the characters which appear in it are fictitious and are not to be identified with any living person. In a foreword to his new novel Mr. John P. Marquand expands the usual formula with the intention, he tells us, to explain the meaning and purpose of such statements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Administration Senate leaders discussed among themselves today the question of accepting two amendments -- one suggesting that the President consult legislative leaders from time to time on operation of the British aid program, and another naming Britain, Greece and China as the countries to be aided under the bill.

Reverting to the old thesis that marriages are made in heaven, or at least that there is just one boy meant for every girl, this artful story tangles the lives of three youths and maidens and then sorts them out into their destined pairs.

WHEN war interposes itself between a teacher's dream of unharried world wanderings and the actual arrival of her sabbatical year, she need not accept complete disappointment. Nor, Kathleen Lynch of the Mount Holyoke faculty decided, need the reasonably adaptable individual feel that the only possible roads are those which lead to the Caribbean and points south.

The Treasury financing scheduled for this week will mark the first large operation under the Public Debt Act of 1941, which was signed by the President last Wednesday and which provides for taxable instead of tax-exempt Government bonds. As such, it will provide the first clue to the probable course of Government bond prices under the new plan.

BY the death of Frank Bridge a few weeks ago England lost one of its finest musicians, whom no one contacted without learning to respect his knowledge and mastery, wrote William Glock, music critic of The London Observer, in a recent eulogy of the composer.

VICHY, France, Feb. 22 -- With the armistice between Thailand and French Indo-China expiring on Tuesday, the impression gathered strength here today that France would resist if Japanese "mediation" required too great a cession of territory.

TWO well-deserved honors have come to Louis Adamic within the past few weeks. He has been presented with the sixth annual John Anisfield Award of $1,000 for his book "From Many Lands" (Harper Brothers), as the outstanding book of the year on racial relations, and he has received the honorary degree of Doctor of Letters from Temple University in Philadelphia for his "distinguished contribution to the field of literature."

THIS is frankly an "escape book" of light-hearted travel in Canada, and it is a book of really unusual taste, humor and charm. The author and her husband traveled about Quebec Province in their trailer, accompanied by an inquisitive Sealyham terrier and well supplied themselves with a smiling and friendly interest in their fellow-men. They were interested in history, too.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- New York University suffered its fourth basketball defeat of the season when Syracuse scored a 48-to-46 victory tonight in a sensationally-played game. The victory evened matters for the Orange, which had lost to the Violets in New York two months ago.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Saturday, when the twenty-eighth annual Biscayne Bay power boat regatta will get under way and the annual $50,000-added Widener classic at Hialeah Park will be run, is awaited by members of the Winter colony as one of the red-letter days of the season.

LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- A Reuters [British news agency] correspondent, writing from "somewhere in Ethiopia," said today that the Italians were retreating from the "outlying escarpments" about Burye and Gondar, in the Lake Tana area. Burye is about eight-five miles south of Lake Tana and 160 miles northwest of Addis Ababa; Gender is north of the lake.

BLACKSBURG, Va., Feb. 22 -- Virginia Polytechnic Institute will graduate a group of its 1942 class of electrical and mechanical engineers in March, instead of June next year, to free men at the earliest possible moment to meet the critical shortage of technical workers in the nation's defense industries, Earl B. Norris, dean of engineering, announced today.

An American girl, Rowan Wilde, becomes the lone tenant of an isolated cottage in Dorset and discovers upon her arrival that there is a corpse in the house. Other startling events crowd upon one another's heels so rapidly that she has no time for clear or coherent thought.

PITTSBURGH -- The first link to bind Pittsburgh's Golden Triangle with a trio of two-level superhighways was completed recently with the opening of the new Water Street Roadway along the Monongahela River waterfront.

THE fifteenth annual Eastern Championships will begin next Saturday afternoon at the Park Central Hotel and will last through Sunday, March 9. All afternoon sessions will begin at 2 o'clock and all evening sessions at 8:30.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Ted Ellenwood, slim Amsterdam speedster, scored a double triumph today to assume a commanding lead for the combined Northeastern and Northern New York skating title.

Despite the fall of France, Le Cercle Francais, undergraduate French society at Manhattan College, has created a rebirth of interest in the native language, it was disclosed yesterday by Professor Frank J. Fabinski, moderator.
MADRID -- Nationalist Spain is carrying on a determined campaign to purge foreign phrases from the language.

American industry's quickening shift toward a war economy is marked today by pinches in raw material supply for non-defense use and business preparations for wider government control over strategic commodities, according to The Associated Press.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The butter ration in Great Britain will be increased from two to four ounces a person beginning March 10, but the present total fat ration will remain at eight ounces, it was announced today. If four ounces of butter is consumed the remainder can be taken either all in margarine or two ounces of margarine and two ounces of cooking fats.

THE centenary exhibition of Thomas Hardy at the Grolier Club last year was one of the best performances put on at that worthy institution. It packed more surprises to the square inch and revealed more about the history and bibliography of its subject than any similar show within memory.

Over the south door of the Senate Chamber in the United States Capitol are three red and three white lights. The red lights flash on when the Senate meets in executive session. The white lights, sign that the chamber is open to the public, were lit last week. Debate on the lease-lend bill to give all-out aid to Britain was under way.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Nearly 700 persons thronged the Everglades Club tonight for the "Back to the Farm" ball with which Washington's Birthday was celebrated.

Moderate increases have featured buying for Spring by retailers, according to the results of a survey among leading department and specialty stores throughout the country completed last week by the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and announced by T.L. Blanke, manager of the division.

WE have just hammered into place the last paling in a hypothetical fence around our population of aliens. Through the workings of the Alien Registration Act of 1940 we now have the names, addresses, occupations, origins, fingerprints and police records (if any) of nearly 5,000,000 non-citizens living in our midst.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Average hourly earnings in manufacturing industries in the country rose to 68.3 cents in December, an increase of about 2 cents, or 3.9 per cent, since December 1939 and the highest rate reported since the Bureau of Labor Statistics began computing hourly earnings in 1932, according to a report today by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins.

WITH prodigally laden fish markets, Lenten menus present practically no problem at all to New York housekeepers. In fact, the delicious variety of fish which comes finning its way to Fulton Street may cause Lenten fish days to lose all quality of penitential fasting and become feast days instead.

The only evening performance this season of Wagner's consecrational festival music drama, "Parsifal," set for April 9 at the Metropolitan Opera House, has been taken over by a committee organized in behalf of the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement at 8 Pitt Street on the lower East Side.

The Far Eastern Division of the State Department looks out upon the lawns and ancient trees of the White House grounds. A nine-room suite on the third floor of the famous Mullet creation accommodates the division's thirty workers. In an adjoining suite, among maps and books and telephones, sits Stanley K. Hornbeck, Far Eastern adviser to the Secretary of State.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Colonel Bill Terry mopped his perspiring brow at the close of a blistering three-hour workout with his Giants today and forthwith pronounced himself eminently pleased with the manner in which his 1941 training campaign has progressed.

A large subscription has been re- ported for the performance of "The Talley Method," with Ina Claire and Philip Merivale in the leading roles, on Friday night at the Henry Miller Theatre for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Gardner School Alumnae Association.

BOHUSLAV MARTINU, Czech composer, is on his way to New York, and will arrive in the next few days. He comes from unoccupied France, where he has spent the last seven months following a dramatic flight from Paris, his adopted home for the last eighteen years.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Larry MacPhail, president of the Dodgers, said today, "the draft as it is going to affect our young baseball players is definitely unfair."

Final approval for reorganization of the Brooklyn College evening session, including the introduction of a new associate in arts degree to be granted upon completion of a two-year course, has been voted by the Board of Higher Education.

CADIZ, Spain, Feb. 22 -- With members of the American Red Cross Commission working until dark tonight the American freighter Cold Harbor, with food for Spain from the Red Cross, is trying to unload its flour and milk despite flood conditions. Unloading has been considerably delayed by heavy rain all this week.

THERE were two things the matter with the Maginot Line, and although the first alone would probably not have been fatal, the second certainly was. The first weakness was overconfidence. The second was incompletion.

DURING the past thirty-five years few practitioners of nonprofessional photography have been as highly respected or widely known as Dr. D.J. Ruzicka. His tolerance and ability as a photographer and judge is legendary.

A shortage of unlicensed merchant seamen that may become a serious problem for the merchant marine is rapidly developing and causing concern to operators engaged in trades vital to the national defense, it was disclosed last week.
HAVANA, Feb. 22 -- Launching of a noble experiment by the Dodgers, previously forecast in these dispatches, will take place Monday, with the 22-year-old Harold (Pete) Reiser the subject of the test.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- "I hate prophecies," wrote Rochefort, one of France's leading journalists. "Either they are obvious or they are wrong."

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Nearly 600 sophomores at Princeton University will make their first visits to the sixteen upper-class eating clubs tomorrow afternoon as the first step in the new system of elections begun this year by the board of trustees.

A BUREAU sponsored by the Maine Development Commission opened last week at 30 Rockefeller Plaza will fill a long-felt want for up-to-date information about the State's recreational, commercial and industrial facilities. The office has a large variety of booklets, maps and pictures of life and activities in different parts of the State and a staff equipped to answer questions about the various phases.

The United States Treasury expects to undertake this week the first major financing operation under the so-called Public Debt Act of 1941, signed by President Roosevelt on last Wednesday. In addition to lifting the statutory direct debt limit of the government to $65,000,000,000 from $49,000,000,000 this legislation provides, among other things, that the income from future issues of securities of the Federal Government and its various agencies will be subject to Federal income taxes.
The British are suffering frightfully today from the German "Blitz" bombing attacks, but anybody who thinks they could consider making a compromise peace is mistaken.

To look behind the bare figures of the 1940 highway traffic toll, with its record of more than 35,000 deaths and 1,320,000 injuries, is to be impressed once more with the dominant role that human error plays in this sad drama. The Travelers Insurance Company has performed a useful service by examining the nature of the accidents which made the year a discouraging one.

AMONG the mass of mad missives on the hectic affairs of Hollywood daily deposited in this department by mail, telegraph, footman and even (!) carrier pigeon, we have discovered frequently in recent weeks communiques from sundry documentary film producers.
