The nation-wide survey to locate unused machinery, machine tools and plant space available for defense production in American factories, begun about a month ago by the National Industrial Council under the sponsorship of the National Association of Manufacturers, has shown highly encouraging results, according to a preliminary report issued yesterday by Walter D. Fuller, president of the N.A.M.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- An undercover investigation of land prices charged the government for defense projects was disclosed today in an announcement that for the second time fees of War Department land agents had been slashed.

IN its two thick volumes "The World of the Thibaults" now brings to the American public that entire series of eleven books, published separately in France over a period of eighteen years, which make up the novel that won the Nobel Prize for Literature for Roger Martin du Gard.
OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 22 -- A bid for Farm Belt support for the lease-lend bill and the policy of all-out aid to England is seen in two recent developments in Washington.

MR. GEORGE JEAN NATHAN'S reveries of a bachelor begin with the mythology of the species and end with an Emily Postscript. In between he has set down facts, articles of faith, confutations, choice bits of memory and also choice bits of malice, and withal some perfectly delightful words.

Of all the countries brought under the domination of Nazism by tank and bomb, the conquered land that was Poland is in the saddest plight. After the conquest it was divided into three sectors. Germany kept for herself the industrial west, which was valuable, and annexed it to the Reich.

Rolling up a record total of 70 points, the Seton Hall athletes of South Orange, N.J., turned in the "hat trick" yesterday in winning the prep school team championship at the eighth annual national interscholastic indoor track and field games at Madison Square Garden.

The place of forums and discussion groups in education will be considered at the annual metropolitan conference of the New York Adult Education Council next Saturday at the Hotel Edison. Prominent speakers and leading experts in the field of adult education are on the all-day program.

THE Victor catalogue for 1940-41 is now off the press, and as usual it contains not only what you would expect in such a volume but a good deal of additional information. Our eye was caught by "the Victor records purchased most often."

The time may come soon when this country would require for its own direct needs or for aid to England a larger merchant tonnage than is at present available. Building of new ships takes time. There are now in the United States harbors merchant ships of foreign registry which are laid up for the duration of the war.

LAST week a group of engineers went aloft on several test flights in an American Airlines plane to observe the performance of a new type of fuel called "Engine Builders Special." If flight tests prove this fuel successful, according to the engineers, a vast supply of gasoline, which was previously deemed unfit for aviation use, will be released for national defense purposes.

KINGSTON, Jamaica -- The pioneers of American commerce and transportation once used wagon trains and schooners but now this writer has seen modern pioneers push the American flag over new routes in the Caribbean on a giant twin-engine flying boat of the American Export Lines.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Feb. 22 -- Principal E. Raymond Schneible of the Pierson High School here, who conducted an experiment in "learn-by-doing education" with a Dictator Day for his pupils yesterday, received numerous congratulatory messages today from several States and also the principals of the Shelter Island, L.I., and Mineola, L.I., High Schools.
CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 22 -- A new effort by the Chinese Government to rebuild a united front with Chinese Communist groups was revealed by the official Chinese news agency tonight.

AS chief of the United States Biological Survey, Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson has been largely responsible, among other things, for the establishment of great areas of land and water as wildlife refuges. But any one is mistaken who thinks that a book on wildlife conservation deals only, or even chiefly, with such achievements as that.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 -- Challedon ran seventh as Mioland raced to victory today in the $10,000 added San Antonio Handicap against a crack field of eligibles for next Saturday's $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap.

The facilities of Le Coq Rouge Restaurant, 65 East Fifty-sixth Street and its dance orchestra have been donated by the management for the "Party for Plymouth" to be given next Friday night under the uspices of Bundles for Britain, Inc. The fete will be in the form of a dinner dance and will be featured by a floor show and other divertissements.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 22 -- Employment in industrial establishments in Bridgeport went to a record high in January, according to the monthly business survey of the Chamber of Commerce released here this week.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 22 -- The Fort Dix recruit reception center, the streamlined machine under command of Lieut. Col. Holmes G. Paullin that takes civilian trainees from the induction centers and turns them into recruit soldiers in three days time, has handled 20,234 men to date.

THOUSANDS of farmers are overhauling their buckets and spiles. They are looking to the barrels that are used to haul in the sap. A small percentage of the farmers have pipe lines strung through the maple grove which convey the "sweet water" to the evaporator in the sugar house.

THIS is the dramatic story of a great man, greatly and dramatically told. Second only to Gandhi in the leadership of India's 350 millions toward independence and freedom, Jawaharlal Nehru gives us in this impressive autobiography both the mental and spiritual record of his own life and an absorbing account of India's slow-sure progress in the achievement of independent nationalism.

Modification of the present bylaws governing the four municipal colleges, to insure greater flexibility to meet local conditions and less diffusion of administrative duties, is urged in the annual report of Dr. Paul Klapper, president of Queens College, which has just been made public.
Spring begins on Thursday, March 20, at 7:21 P.M., when the sun, moving toward the north, crosses the celestial equator and enters Aries.

The Federal Reserve's "industrial production index" has touched another high mark in our history. For January the index, based on the 1935-39 average as 100, reached 139. It was 138 in December, highest of 1940, and, according to the Reserve Board's calculations, it did not go above 120 in 1937 nor above 114 in 1929.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- British financial opinion on the possibility of the war spreading into the Pacific has undergone a series of somewhat sharp changes the last few days. Japan's truculence, to be sure, led to an initial scare, but Tokyo's subsequent change of tone produced a feeling of diminished pessimism as the week drew to a close.

ATHENS, Feb. 23 -- Continued rainfall and fog are said to prevail along the entire Albanian front, bringing military operations to a virtual standstill. Only the most limited patrol and artillery activity is reported and appears to have come from the Greek side only.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- Sun Fox of Mayfair, a wire-haired fox terrier bred and owned by John E. Haslam of Cambridge, Mass., and handled by Robert N. Snodgrass, tonight was awarded best-in-show honors at the twenty-ninth annual all-breed exhibition of the Eastern Dog Club in Mechanics Building before a large gathering of enthusiastic fanciers.

Although gross operating revenues of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and subsidiaries increased last year by $5,757,201 to an aggregate of $256,928,608, sharply higher taxes and operating charges in the year eliminated virtually all of the gain with the result that net income for 1940 was $36,454,864, compared with $36,428,119 in 1939.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Speakers at the fourteenth annual Animated Magazine of Rollins College, which was presented this afternoon on the campus before an audience estimated at 7,000, contrasted the Florida sunshine and the peace of America with war-torn and blacked-out Europe.

Last week's foreign exchange market duplicated that of its precedessor in continuing strength in the Chinese and Canadian currencies. Buying was in good volume in each, being sponsored by the political tension in the Far East which helped to lift the Chinese units, while the Dominion currency rose on what appeared to be the collapse of the market professionals' interpretation of the Canadian Prime Minister's remarks on currency three weeks ago.

BERLIN, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The English seaport of Hull was pounded by German bombers last night, the High Command reported today. D.N.B., the official German nears agency, amplifying the report, said, great fires were started along the seven miles of docks that line the Humber River inland from the North Sea.
The New York Americans defeated the Paterson F.C., 3 -- 1, in an American Soccer League game before 3,000 at Starlight Park yesterday.
ROME, Feb. 23 -- The text of Premier Mussolini's speech delivered today follows:

Criticism of the "traditionalism and formalism" which is said to prevail in the Army is voiced in an article published in the current issue of The Infantry Journal. It comes from the pen of Lieut. Col. Thomas R. Phillips, one of the Army's most capable thinkers. In his opinion:

FREEHOLD, N.J., Feb. 23 -- A contract for sale of the former Brakeley canning factory property here to A. M. Karagheusian, Inc., of 250 Broadway, New York City, with a large rug mill here, has been signed, a spokesman for the latter firm announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The national executive board of the National Lawyers' Guild, which has sometimes been assailed as a Communist front organization, made public today a resolution attacking pending legislation and administrative proceedings to deport Harry Bridges, West Coast C.I.O. leader. The resolution said:

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- At ceremonies ending Bill of Rights Week in St. Paul's Episcopal Church at East Chester, near here, the Rev. W. Harold Weigle, rector of the church, announced today the launching, on March 10, of a campaign to restore the old church as a national shrine because of its association with the Bill of Rights.

KHARTUM, Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, Feb. 23 -- An attack by crack Sudanese archers using "incendiary arrows" was reported today to have set ablaze the Italian military base of Asosa, in the Blue Nile region of Western Ethiopia.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23 -- The United States was Argentina's leading customer in January, taking 41.3 per cent of all the republic's exports, compared with Great Britain's 29.4 per cent, according to figures just published by the National Bureau of Statistics.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- The Bruins blasted Goalie Charlie Rayner with a total of sixty-three shots to gain a 3-1 victory over the crippled New York Americans tonight before a crowd of 10,000 at the Boston Garden.

VICHY, France, Feb. 23 (UP) -- The government is nearing the end of its program, started three months ago, to prepare a new series of refugee centers to which 36,000 inmates of existing camps will be moved by March 15.

Accusing Congress of "fiddling while the world burns." Bishop Ernest M. Stires of the Long Island Diocese of the Episcopal Church, called yesterday for the immediate passage of the lease-lend bill as the only effective means of preserving "Christian civilization" and the "freedom of humanity."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- A review in the Department of Commerce of the economic record of the United States in 1940 emphasized today that the defense program since last May has been the chief influence on industrial activity.

THIS is the story of Joe Brown, the boxer who turned sculptor. About a dozen years ago Heinie Miller was the coach of the Temple football team and Joe Brown was one of his halfbacks. Joe was a pretty good football player, but around the campus they thought more of him as a light heavyweight boxer. He fought many bouts for Temple in college competition and never lost a decision.
The reports of the week-end indicate that German infiltration into Bulgaria is progressing at such a pace that open occupation of that country may come at any time.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 23 -- Some painstaking work by Newark detectives and employes of the State Motor Vehicle Department resulted in the arrest this morning of Charles E. Crocker, 20 years old, a Negro, of 213 Grove Street, Elizabeth, who is accused of fatally injuring two persons with his automobile and leaving the scene.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The British found Premier Mussolini's speech today interesting for several reasons. These were not so much for what he actually said as for what could be read between the lines.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 23 (UP) -- Germany is "moving heaven and earth" to induce a Japanese attack on the British Empire in the Far East, simultaneous with German attacks in Europe, Africa and the Near East, but British forces are ready for anything that may happen, Victor Purcell, Director-General of Information and Publicity, said today in a broadcast address to the peoples of Southeast Asia.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- Lief Hansen, a 23-year-old stranded Norwegian sailor, put on a pair of skis today for the first time in three years and showed the way in a field of sixteen to win the Telemark Ski Club invitation trophy tournament on the Bear Mountain jump. Hansen displayed good form in spite of a 45-mile per hour northwest wind which kept his best jump down to 125 feet.

Cotton prices moved into higher ground last week, and active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the period with net gains of 12 to 24 points. The greatest gains were made by the distant months.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 23 -- British troops and Ethiopian patriots in rebellion against the Italians have captured Shogali, Ethiopia, on the Blue Nile in the Kurmuk area, the British announced today. Later the invading forces repulsed an Italian counter-attack, killing 150 of the Fascist troops.

DETROIT, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Goalie Johnny Mowers, Red Wing rookie, got back in the running for hockey's Vezina Trophy by shutting out the National League-leading Maple Leafs, 3 to 0, tonight before 11,338 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The War Department announced today that the February quota of 325 nurses to staff hospitals at Army camps at Fort Devens, Mass.; Indiantown Gap, Pa., and Camp Forrest, Tenn., had been reached and that the quotas of Army nurses for the whole nine corps areas would apparently be reached on the required dates.

Many of us are not convinced that an adequate program has yet been set in operation for keeping America out of war. It is fear, of course, that can push us into this war: the fear that if Hitler wins we shall be squeezed into an uncomfortable, perhaps an intolerable, position in international trade, that our democracy may be undermined by Nazi pressure, even that our own country may actually be bombed.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Feb. 23 -- On their first Sunday in this military cantonment hundreds of soldiers from the three federalized National Guard regiments encamped here attended church services this morning.

The Sportsmen's Show is now over, but it will continue to pay dividends to thousands of sportsmen who crowded the aisles of Grand Central Palace during the past nine days. If the show did nothing else, it most certainly stimulated many anglers and hunters to take a fresh interest in these sports.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 24 (UP) -Germany's full-force military occupation of Bulgaria may begin today, according to information reaching authoritative British quarters, for the purpose of forcing Greece to submit to a dictated peace with Italy.

VICHY, France, Feb. 23 -- Well-informed circles here expect a general German offensive against Britain before the end of this month or early in March, before the end of the short period when the tides and currents in the English Channel are more favorable than at any other time of the year.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 23 -- In military circles here it is believed that German troops will formally occupy Bulgaria this week and that Britain will sever relations with that country on Tuesday or Wednesday of next week and immediately afterward open air hostilities on the invader on Bulgarian soil, if not against the Bulgarian troops as well.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 23 -- The markets of the small Continental European countries last week showed small trade volume pending further development of the political and military situation, with buying activity restricted mainly to pure investment purchases, while continued liquidity curtailed offerings.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 23 (AP) -- United States Minister George H. Earle said tonight that a German Army major "threw a champagne bottle which just missed my head" in a cafe skirmish last night when the Nazi officer objected to the orchestra's striking up his requested number -- "Tipperary."

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 23 -- A khaki-clad artist, a private in the 113th Infantry at Fort Dix, hopes to paint a 12 by 50-foot mural in the new War Department Building in Washington. With the cooperation of officers. Private Ludwig Mactarian, a commercial artist in civil life, is feverishly working to complete sketches and a detail color painting of his conception of a military theme for the mural.
LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Lord Beaverbrook, Minister of Aircraft Production, told Canadians in a transatlantic broadcast today that Nazi war planes had lost their terror.

Two ambulances for the Greek Army, one the gift of students and staff members of Columbia University and the other bought with contributions from colleges and universities throughout the United States and Canada, were presented yesterday to the Greek Government in an outdoor ceremony before 400 persons on the wind-swept Columbia campus.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Firing faultlessly through two more sub-par rounds, Harold (Jug) McSpaden won the $3,000 Thomasville open golf championship today with 207 -- nine strokes under standard figures and eight ahead of his closest competitors.

HAVANA, Feb. 23 -- The Dodgers have been charged with many oddities of behavior, but nobody ever accused the Flatbush athletes of being esthetes. Yet today, having been excused from practice by Manager Leo Durocher, nearly 90 per cent of these brawny ball players spent much time admiring the beauties of nature.

Because of lack of space the newspaper room at the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street will be closed on March 15. The 35,000 bound volumes of newspapers will be transferred to the library annex at 137 West Twenty-fifth Street.

We cannot have a kingdom of God until we put our hands to it and make it our own, the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill, pastor emeritus of the Brick Presbyterian Church, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Twelfth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Two Philadelphians, H. Hunter Lott and Charles Brinton, battled their way into the final of the national squash racquets championship today, as a third Philadelphian, defending champion, A. Willing Patterson, fell by the wayside.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 23 -- With the nation-wide ASCAP-BMI row apparently about to subside, a brand new musical controversy-strictly local in scope but none the less sizzling -- began to brew here today. The new and virtually unknown State song is the center of the storm, which may be tentatively initialed the battle of NJLS versus JHOTFEAM.

A glance at the map of Europe will show that the Mediterranean area announced by Great Britain as "dangerous for navigation" is almost as large as the North Sea. In the last war it took the combined efforts of the British and American Navies to lay effective mine barriers across the North Sea, and operations had to be continued up to the time of the armistice.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., and subsidiary report for the year ended on Nov. 30, 1940, a consolidated net profit of $10,831,971, or $18.05 a share, nearly four times the profit of $2,884,197, or $4.81 a share, earned in the preceding year. Net sales were more than double at $60,970,774, against $27,866,658.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 23 -Balkan tension has not decreased and German Army officers continue to enter Bulgaria from Rumania in small numbers, wearing mackintoshes and boots, according to Sofia diplomats. However, the fundamentals of the situation remain unchanged.

The desperate need for binoculars to be used by airplane spotters on roofs in Great Britain has been emphasized in a letter received by C. Suydam Cutting, chairman of the American Committee for Defense of British Homes, 10 Warren Street, from R.W. Cotton, an American business man living in Bideford, North Devon, England, it was announced yesterday.

Several books about publishing endeavor have just appeared. Two are on the physical side of bookmaking and two are guides for authors. Leonard Winans, who heads Grosset Dunlap's book-planning department, has written "The Book -- Its Origin and Evolution," published by The Retail Bookseller.

Twenty-five hundred youths participated in the annual Quinquagesima Pilgrimage for young persons of the Diocese of New York yesterday afternoon to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. One thousand adults also attended the special pre-lentian service, which was conducted by the Very Rev. James P. De Wolfe, dean of the cathedral.

Transatlantic flying boat service, principally for mail but with occasional special passengers, will be resumed by Airways Atlantic, Ltd., a British company, late in April or early in May, it was revealed at La Guardia Field yesterday by Paul Bewshea, the company's representative here.

At a time when, after the Turco-Bulgarian pact, the attention of the world is focused on Greece and the general question is being asked, What is she going to do? we Hellenes answer in the words of the famous Greek general, Epaminondas, "The best omen is to defend the Fatherland."

MONTREAL, Feb. 23 -- Sir Frederick Banting, Nobel prize winner for his share in the discovery of insulin, was missing tonight with three other persons in a military airplane being delivered by a civilian organization.

A larger measure of protection for those involved in automobile accidents in this State should result from enactment of the Anderson bill, which has been introduced in the Legislature. Drafted by the committee on automobile accident prevention of the State Bar Association and approved by the New York Board of Trade and other organizations, the bill embodies many of the most desirable features of the so-called "New Hampshire Plan."

Richard Feier, author of "Elements of Economics," one of the textbooks asserted by Dr. Ralph West Robey in a survey financed by the National Association of Manufacturers to be unduly critical of elements in American political or economic institutions that Dr. Robey thinks are integral in the American system, replied to his critic yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23 -- Total steel demand expanded last week, sales volume having matched previous weekly totals. The influx of business continued to be in excess of either shipments or production, consequently unfilled tonnage volume was increased.

After more than twenty years at 677 Fifth Avenue, the Aeolian Skinner Organ Company of Boston, Mass., manufacturers of pipe organs, will move to 4 East Fifty-third Street, where the concern has leased the entire fifth floor for showroom, sales office and organ service headquarters.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- London's men, women and children, who have been warned that clouds of death-dealing gas may herald a springtime German invasion, prepared tonight for their first "gas war" rehearsal amid the debris of some of the metropolis's worst air bombings.
Philip Du Boff, in 139 E 35th St, from the Tishman Realty Construction Co; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, brokers.

ROME, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Former King Alfonso XIII of Spain who was believed to have had little chance to see the dawn, still was propped up in an arm chair tonight in his hotel room where he had listened to the broadcast speech by Premier Mussolini.

Reporting to stockholders in a preliminary statement of earnings, C.M. Chester, chairman of the board of the General Foods Corporation, announced that in 1940 the company sold the largest tonnage of food on record.

A demand for labor that "will certainly exceed the number of unemployed persons in the labor market" has been brought about by recent major increases in America's defense program, it was concluded in a revised survey made public yesterday by a research staff of the Twentieth Century Fund.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Corn prices dipped last week to a new low level for the current downturn, but there was no material pressure on the May contracts which gained ground on the July, with cash interests on the buying side. While country offerings of cash grain were somewhat larger because of more favorable weather conditions, this was offset to some degree by a better shipping demand.

It often seems before a two-day holiday as if the American people were the most restless in the world. Everybody seems bent on travel. Bus lines are booked to capacity. The railroads put on extra sections. The aviation companies are at their wit's end to take care of traffic. In addition, millions of automobiles roll out of their garages for a family outing.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- Dave Collins sailed his Class D boat Blue Bird to a runaway victory in the first match for the Interstate Challenge Ice Boat Pennant today in the two-day regatta conducted by the Hudson Highlands Ice Boat Club and the Bear Mountain Sports Association on Lake Tiorati.

Despite the precarious times and the "serious damage" the war has inflicted upon recent advances in education in the United States, Fordham University is going ahead with its projected expansion and improvement program, the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president, said yesterday in his annual report to the trustees.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 -"Journey Into Fear," a new novel by Eric Ambler, will serve as Michele Morgan's first American vehicle, postponing "Joan of Paris," which RKO announced for her last week. The French actress will make her debut here as an espionage agent operating in Turkey.

From Ovid down, poets concerned themselves with gout. "Drink wine and have the gout; drink none and have the gout," sang Thomas Cogan in the sixteenth century. In the nineteenth Robert Browning could write rather wistfully of "the fortieth armchair" in which "gout and glory" would seat him. After Hawthorne, with his reference to gentlemen who "love the pleasant titillation of the gout," the literary references taper off to zero.

ATHENS, Feb. 23 -- The town of Corfu, on the western Greek island of that name, which has been bombed at least fifty-four times by the Italians, with sometimes 400 bombs dropped on it in a day, is the subject of a report of American authorship to the administrative committee of the American League for Aid to Greece.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 23 (AP) -- February orders are heavier than January's for most steel plants despite the shorter month, the magazine Steel said today in reporting a "tight situation" in several raw materials.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Eight enemy supply ships totaling more than 35,000 tons have been sunk in the Mediterranean by British submarines in recent weeks, the Admiralty announced today. The Admiralty also reported that German planes had made two unsuccessful attempts to bomb the British hospital ship Dorsetshire in the Mediterranean, despite the fact that the vessel had the clear marking required under international law to guarantee her immunity.
LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The British Admiralty issued the following communique today:

The four-motored twenty-ton B-24 bomber that arrived here non-stop from the Pacific Coast a week ago was flown yesterday by a United States crew to an unnamed point in Canada, where it was turned over to the Canadian government. Pressumably it soon will be on its way to England.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- With a reception and a birthday party, complete with a 100-candle cake, this city paid homage today to Henry Lilly, commander of the State's Grand Army of the Republic on his hundredth birthday.

BERLIN, Feb. 23 -- The Berlin stock market reflected a depressed tone all last week with the volume of transactions shrinking to a new low level. The stock price index, too, receded to 180.99 on Friday, with most of the leading shares registering losses of 3 to as much as 5 points.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 23 -- Domestic trade and Bombay buying found the cotton futures market here void of hedging pressure most of the last week, so that active positions had gained about $1 a bale by late Thursday. Some liquidation for the week-end double holiday and for tendering of March 1 notices on Monday accounted for setbacks of 4 to 7 points in the closing period.

ROME, Feb. 23 -- Premier Mussolini broke his accustomed silence today and in one of the most passionate speeches of his career assured his people of victory and told the world that Italy would fight to the last drop of blood.

The official Britsh wireless said yesterday that formal entry of German troops into Bulgaria appeared to be "imminent," and found significance in German stories, said to have been printed in Bulgarian newspapers, that "affect concern about a non-existent British landing in Salonika."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23 -- The Yankees officially opened their training camp today. The party, led by Manager Joe McCarthy, was greeted by warm sunshine, Al Lang, the city's baseball ambassador, and a gathering of several hundred tourists and natives, when it arrived to start the grind which is calculated to steer New York's American League baseball craft back on the championship course.

Current discussions emphasize rumors that our fleet may aid in the defense of Singapore and the Netherlands Indies. The main American battle fleet is said to be at Hawaii, with a part of the fleet in the Atlantic. We have at Manila two light cruisers, a dozen or more destroyers and about the same number of submarines and a small air force.
The annual report of the Insurance Company of North America shows total admitted assets on Dec. 31, 1940, increased to $113,765,492 from $111,121,152 at the close of the previous year.

ROME, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Premier Mussolini, in an unheralded broadcast to the Italian people, defended today the Fascist regime's handling of the Libyan campaign, announced the arrival of German air and armored detachments in Sicily and Libya, and declared that "Italy, whatever happens, will march with Germany to the end."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- In a period of unprecedented national crisis when other sections of the community are accepting modifications of their liberty, organized labor should curb its right to strike in the defense industries, Senator Ball of Minnesota and Representative Hoffman of Michigan declared tonight.

Although they're no great shakes on the road, the New York Rovers are proving more effective on home ice. Yesterday they gained their third straight home triumph by handing the Boston Olympics an 8-to-3 pasting in an Eastern Hockey League battle at Madison Square Garden.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Colonel Bill Terry's preparations to invade Cuba for a series of hand-to-hand conflicts with the Dodgers late this week took on an impressive appearance today. There was a nine-inning battle between two Giant squads. Mel Ott and Frank Demaree, to the delight of some 2,000 onlookers, exploded two home runs.

Sidor Belarsky, bass cantante, whose singing has long been favorably known in this city, was heard in a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. In an elaborate program, composed of selections in six languages, Mr. Belarsky again impressed by the emotional fervor of his interpretations and the sincere, intelligent nature of his work in general.

Despite price increases and withdrawals of lines on some types of merchandise, business continued good in the wholesale market last week. More reorders on Spring apparel were received than during any other week this season. Untrimmed dress coats and suits continued to lead on reorders.

A new clubhouse, tennis courts and outside patio will be erected by the Seaglades Bath Club, Inc., which has purchased an additional plot of 60 by 170 feet adjoining the club property on the ocean front, east of Jefferson Boulevard, Atlantic Beach, L.I.

Long Island University's triumphant tour through the hinterlands and Dartmouth's spirited response to the challenge of its rivals in the Eastern League provided the basketball highlights of last week, as several other of this sector's leading quintets found the going far from smooth.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23 -Colonel and Mrs. Harold A. Braman gave a tea and cocktail party at their home. Mrs. J. Terry West, Mrs. William Russell Huntley and Mrs. G. Horton Glover assisted at the tables.

VICHY, France, Feb. 23 -- As the result of an accord recently affirmed between French and Italian economic delegations in a meeting at Rome, a decree has just been issued setting forth minimum tariffs in favor of Italy on all goods entering France.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The stock markets here again are presenting an exceptionally somber picture, which is scarcely surprising in view of the increasing uncertainties potent in the near course of events in the Balkans and the Far East. Also, the intentions of the government regarding taxation and further extension of control over trade give pause to sentiment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Consideration of the Administration's lease-lend bill will move into the crucial period before Congress this week, with Administration leaders pressing for expedition of debate and the beginning of the consideration of amendments on Wednesday.

Mozart's "Don Giovanni," which has been absent from the repertoire for two years, will be presented next week at the Metropolitan Opera House. It will be conducted by Bruno Walter, and will reintroduce Tito Schipa, Italian lyric tenor, who has not sung here in opera for six years.

So far as concerned the course of war, few weeks have presented more of a problem in disentangling news and rumor. Both from the Balkans and the Far East, successive day's dispatches were contradictory; perhaps intentionally so. No one could frame from them a clear picture of what were actually the purposes, for instance, f Tur- key or Japan.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Continued tension in the Far East sent tin prices to 282 10s a ton last week. Since the start of the advance, ten days ago, quotations have gained 26 5s. The cash quotation here after being lower than the three months' forward price since August, 1940, is now 5 15s above it.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- New factors have commenced to make themselves felt as a price-making influence in the lard market, with the Far Eastern situation and its threat of curtailing imports of cocoanut and other vegetable oils which offer a great deal of competition with lard, inducing some buying of the latter.
Nine new films are scheduled for Broadway theatres this week. The program, barring last minute changes, stands as follows:

In a brief filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Port of New York Authority has charged that discrimination in favor of competing ports has damaged severely the grain transportation business here, it was announced yesterday.

The Rangers encountered surprising opposition from the badly crippled Black Hawks in the first two periods of their National Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden last night. In the third frame, though, the superior manpower of the New York aggregation made itself felt, and the Blue Shirt machine rolled on to a 4-to-1 triumph.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 23 -Turkish Foreign Minister Shukru Saracoglu declared tonight that "Turkey would be unable to remain indifferent to foreign activities that might occur in her security zone." His statement apparently referred to the German Army's expected occupation of Bulgaria.

An addition to the list of Madison Square Garden college basketball double-headers will be staged tonight, with City College and Brooklyn College meeting in an intracity game after Long Island University opposes Canisius, starting at 8:15 P.M.

VIENNA, Feb. 23 -- Germany is keeping the war away from the Balkan States and they should therefore give up military preparations and unnecessary mobilizations and instead apply all their energies to food production, which is showing dangerous signs of a decline in the coming crop year.

VICHY, France, Feb. 23 -- It is learned with satisfaction that, contrary to reports last week, negotiations with regard to the sending of foodstuffs to France are continuing in Washington. It is not here alone that it is hoped to diminish the privations which the whole French people is enduring without complaint.
Sixteen strikes were listed by The United Press as in progress last night in plants holding contracts for more than $60,000,000 worth of defense materials.
AFTER reading Holman Hamilton's book, "Zachary Taylor: Soldier of the Republic,"* one may well be puzzled that so worthy an American should have been overlooked so long by America's busy biographers.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 24 -- German fighters and fighter-bombers, numbering about twenty, crossed the south coast of England, flying four abreast at a high altitude with great speed, yesterday afternoon, apparently testing the British defenses.
Negotiations looking toward a settlement of the Whelan drug store strike are under way for the first time since 800 employes walked out Feb. 1.

Contrary to the belief of a scattered minority of track followers, Greg Rice is in no way interested in running a mile race against Leslie MacMitchell and Walter Mehl. Content to concentrate on longer routes, Rice, who on Saturday night accounted for three world records, two en route and one at the finish of the National A.A.U. three-mile championship test at Madison Square Garden, returned to South Bend yesterday.

Even in the closing hours of the nine-day run of the National Sportsmen's Show last night the story tellers were going strong at the Grand Central Palace as thousands of curious city inhabitants swarmed through the aisles and boosted the attendance mark to record proportions.

"The Talley Method," a comedy by S.N. Behrman, opens this evening at Henry Miller's Theatre, with Ina Claire and Philip Merivale in the leading roles. The action of the comedy "takes place in the upstairs living room of Dr. Talley's office residence in an old brownstone house in the East Sixties in New York City," according to the program.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 85.4 to 85.9. The sharpest gain occurred in the building materials group, which rose 2.3 per cent because of a rebound in the price of lumber. Despite rather substantial increases in livestock prices, the farm products index rose only 0.3 per cent, because of offsetting declines in eggs, wheat and oranges.

Nazi advances in the Balkans, making it imperative that Jews be moved from countries there to Palestine, are spurring the most extensive campaign for funds for Palestine ever conducted here, it was announced yesterday by Nathan Straus, chairman of the United Palestine Appeal of Greater New York, preparatory to the launching of the campaign today at a citywide conference.

"The Philadelphia Story," playing a second-run engagement at Loew's State on Washington's Birthday, did the largest single day's business in the theatre's twenty-year history, the management announced last night. The film, which two weeks ago closed a record six-weeks run at the Radio City Music Hall, where it drew 850,000, played to 20,198 persons at the 3,327-seat capacity of the State between 8 A.M. Saturday and 3 A.M. Sunday.

John Barbirolli, in the course of one of the best concerts he has conducted here, led the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall in the first performance of Mischa Portnoff's Piano Concerto. The solo part was played by Nadia Reisenberg.

Unless the nations of the world form a federation that will be based upon the "good of the whole," the one nation that is strongest and best organized will achieve for itself a "union without liberty, a world state without democracy,'' the Rev. Dr. Frank Oliver Hall, pastor emeritus of the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street, warned in a sermon at the church yesterday.

Twenty-five hundred persons heard the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick say in his sermon yesterday morning that the war of nerves always has gone on in human experience, and obviously a man who does not win that cannot win anything else.

TORONTO, Feb. 23 -- Sir Frederick Banting, co-discoverer of insulin, who was today reported missing on an airplane journey in Eastern Canada, had planned to go shortly to Great Britain and report extensively on the widespread medical research that is being carried out in Canada as part of the war.

VICHY, France, Feb. 23 (UP) -France will fight with all the resources at her command any effort to impose an unjust peace on Indo-China in that country's border conflict with Thailand, an official spokesman declared tonight.

After an emergency dash by air from Trinidad to combat growing symptoms of hunger strike and cannibalism, at the Bronx Zoo, an "understudy" colony of parasol ants was firmly established yesterday in the Reptile House and will be on public view today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23 (UP) -- Russia's armed forces stand ready at a moment's notice to "annihilate any one violating our sacred frontiers," Marshal Semyon Timoshenko, Defense Marshal, warned today in an order of the day celebrating the twenty-third anniversary of the Red Army.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 23 (UP) -- The Japanese military mission in Indo-China is watching with growing concern warlike French preparations going on in North Indo-China adjacent to military bases granted to Japan under the French-Japanese agreement of last Fall, the Japanese official Domei news agency reported today from Hanoi.
ROME, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

There were 28,413 fires in the city in 1940, causing damage estimated at $9,637,375, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday. Although there were 4,041 fewer fires than in 1939, the money loss was $1,036,831 greater.

I am sitting at my desk gazing at a picture which appeared in THE TIMES on Feb. 20. It consists of two units captioned "Passing: Liberte, Egalite, Fraternite." The top picture shows a troop of poilus staging their last color parade through the streets of Marseille. The bottom half shows a close-up of a group of the parade's spectators.

HOOPPOLE, Ill., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Louis C. Kolls, American League baseball umpire for eight years until his release last Fall, and four other persons were killed tonight when two automobile were in a head-on collision near here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The defense program and heavy British Empire purchases have not only provided substantial direct demand for durable goods in the United States but have also induced a large increase in almost all types of capital formation, the Commerce Department reported today.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 23 (AP) -The police halted all automobile traffic in the Sofia district early this afternoon and began a nationwide hunt for Bulgarians spreading anti-German leaflets. These were among accumulative signs of impending Nazi military entrance into this country.

With the time for filing independent nominating petitions for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District expiring tomorrow, it appeared yesterday that no independent anti-war candidate would be named to run at the special election on March 11 for the seat made vacant by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson.

The President raised at his press conference last week what he called an interesting problem involving ethics, morals and patriotism. Specifically, should members of Congressional committees disclose to anybody what was said in "secret" in these meetings? If they did, should newspapers and the radio publish what they were told under such conditions?

Large increases in local, State and Federal taxes in recent years, far outstripping rises in annual revenues, have made it progressively more difficult to obtain reductions in gas, electric, telephone and water rates, the Public Service Commission declared in its annual report to Governor Lehman and the Legislature made public yesterday.

Pleading for the support of "all who wish to save and develop the world's cultural heritage in these critical times with the rest of the world torn by the horrors and hatreds of war," Katharine Cornell, the actress, took over the leadership of a national committee of 100 American artists and art patrons for the 1,750th Performance Celebration of Junior Programs, it was announced yesterday.

Visualizing the huge cost of rearmament, the Guaranty Trust Company in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey expresses the belief that the newly increased national debt limit of $65,000,000,000 will be reached or exceeded before the present program is completed.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 23 -President Roosevelt played a part today in extending financial and through it moral aid to the Church of England, which has been hard hit by total war both with respect to its activities and income.
BERLIN, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique follows:

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- While the confidence of holders of wheat futures has suffered a severe blow in the last few weeks, as reflected in a decline of about 10 1/2 cents from the high point recently, at the same time the market has shown ability to rally on the development of the slightest encouragement.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 23 -- Against a background of 12,000 educators assembled for the seventy-first annual convention of the American Association of School Administrators a conference of the School Book Publishers National Association today objected strongly to criticisms of textbooks made by Professor Ralph W. Robey of Columbia University and others.

Carl Loveday of the Montclair Athletic Club and Miss Mary Hagan of Old Sixty-Ninth won the singles titles in the sixth annual Eastern badminton championships, which were completed at the Fifth Avenue Country Club yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 23 (AP) -- German "victory of weapons" must be followed by "a victory of children," said a new magazine that appeared today under the patronage of Heinrich Himmler, chief of all German police organizations.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell yesterday warned the congregation of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, that "a pleasure-loving, undisciplined democracy will never be a match for disciplined totalitarianism."

Men's wear retailers are currently setting up appropriations for Spring advertising and promotion on a basis at least 10 per cent greater than a year ago, according to advertising managers. Active business in December and good results since Jan. 1 give them reason to believe that Spring volume will also be brisk.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The British Military Headquarters in Cairo today issued this communique:

Asserting that the State judiciary has remained "independent of censure and independent of discipline" because removal procedure is "cumbersome, expensive and inept," the City Club recommended yesterday in a report the transferring of trial and removal of judges from the Legislature to a special court of impeachment to consist of one judge of the Court of Appeals and six justices of Appellate Divisions.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- The trends of the legislative session, entering its eighth week tomorrow, have shaped up sufficiently to permit the leaders to begin planning for adjournment as soon after April 1 as possible. Everything should be disposed of in time to permit adjournment before Easter, April 13, under present plans.

Lauding the efforts of Secretary of State Cordell Hull at the Lima Conference as a step toward awakening the "nobility that lies dormant in human life," the Rev. Dr. Henry Everston Cobb declared yesterday that an increasing sense of responsibility to our neighbors can be seen in the United States today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The recently formed Joint Army and Navy Committee on Welfare and Recreation, a civilian group, will meet here Tuesday with Army and Navy morale officers for a four-day discussion of recreation, education, community service and general welfare of the men in the nation's armed forces.

Twelve songs by Schubert sung by Alexander Kipnis, the Metropolitan bass, and Artur Schnabel's Fifth string quartet performed by the Galimir Quartet formed the program presented late yesterday afternoon at the fifteenth concert of the current Town Hall series of the New Friends of Music.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 23 -The Air Raid Shelter of St. Martins in the Fields, London, will be the beneficiary of the Hands Across the Sea Sale to be held at 12 Prospect Place, this city, March 4, 5 and 6. This model shelter of its kind is located in the heart of London at a point of greatest need and usefulness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- An indication that the Administration might accept some further amendments to the British aid bill appeared today when Chairman George said majority members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee would meet this week to discuss "three or four" proposed changes.

Approximately $1,000,000,000 of outstanding bonds, including United States Government issues, has been called for payment in March. Excluding the Federal retirements. $319,000,000 of prepayments has been scheduled so far, marking the largest amount for any March in more than fifteen years and comparing with $116,640,000 in March, 1940.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- An issue of $110,000,000 of short-term notes will be sold tomorrow by State Controller Morris S. Tremaine. The notes are to be dated Feb. 25 and are to mature June 30. The interest rate will be 0.20 per cent, payable at maturity.

SUMMERVILLE, Pa., Feb. 23 -Sadly relating the story of his horse being killed by a train, Merle Martz, 13, who delivered newspapers by horseback in this Western Pennsylvania farm country, wrote a letter to the president of the New York Central Railroad, asking him to "help me out."

During the debates over American foreign policy in the past few years, and now over the "lease-lend" bill, certain technical terms of international law have been used in such a way as to produce much confusion in popular thinking, which has a difficult enough task before it without this added confusion.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Bimelech's winning race yesterday after his long lay-off makes him more than ever the outstanding contender for the $50,000 Widener Challenge Cup which will cap the Hialeah race meeting next Saturday, the closing day.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 23 -Torger Tokle, 22-year-old skiing ace, wasted little time in breaking his second hill record in two days as he won the nineteenth annual invitation open jump today on the 65-meter Brattleboro Outing Club slide, one of the oldest in the country.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- In an effort to eliminate some confusion in the minds of houses that are planning to bid on the large supplies of woolen cloth sought by the Army next month, interested leaders in the industry have made certain suggestions to the War Department in the last few days, it was learned today.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 24 -- The woods above Sailor's Pond on the Wrightstown-Jobstown Road were dotted with fox holes, observation posts, concealed trenches, hidden machine gun emplacements, and double apron and concertina barbed wire entanglements today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Westbrook Pegler, newspaper columnist, testifying at the House Judiciary Committee's inquiry into defense labor conditions, said today that the government's labor laws "drive men into unions and give them no protection from union bosses."

American-made merchandise, offered at a lower price but rivaling or exceeding the quality of goods formerly imported from Continental Europe, featured the New York Gift Show, which opened yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. About 500 lines are on display on the third to sixth floors, inclusive, of the hotel.

ABOARD A BRITISH BATTLESHIP, in the Mediterranean (Via Alexandria), Feb. 24 -- German dive-bombers clashed twice today with British warships engaged in a broad sweep of the Mediterranean, only to be decisively repulsed in one attack and to leave the intended prey steaming on unscathed after the other.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Feb. 24 -- New York's three National Guard regiments in training here, the 207th Coast Artillery and the 212th Coast Artillery of New York City and the 209th Coast Artillery of Buffalo, will begin tomorrow a thirteen-week intensive training course in fundamentals.

The Custom Cutters Club of New York, composed of the leading tailors here, turned its attention to the young American yesterday and decided that he should be as well dressed as his more affluent older brother or father.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Ten important manufacturers of business machines and typewriters made a net income of 10.7 per cent on their corporate net worth investment in 1939, after providing for income taxes, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Secretary Morgenthau announced today that on March 15 the Treasury will offer bonds and notes to refund $1,221,577,650 of bonds and notes called or falling due on that date.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The text of President Roosevelt's message of transmittal to Congress of the report of his Committee on Civil Service Improvement was as follows:
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 24 (AP) -- British General Headquarters here issued the following communique today:

William J. Wardall, trustee of McKesson Robbins, Inc., filed suit yesterday in Supreme Court for $1,241,370 against the legatees and trustees of the estate of the late Oliver Gould Jennings, who was a director of the company from Sept. 28, 1928, to April 28, 1936. He died on Oct. 13, 1936.
LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 25 -- Another lull came early today in the hostilities over Britain.

The refinancing program of the Georgia Power Company, involving redemption of approximately $125,000,000 of the public utility's outstanding debt, will be done on a "private placement" basis, it was disclosed yesterday by Justin R. Whiting, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, parent concern of the Georgia company.

Increasing shortages in steel, nonferrous metals and alloys, as these materials are more and more reserved for defense projects, will "play havoc with the production of numerous commercial items of manufacture", the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reported yesterday in its monthly survey.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 3 per cent for the week ended Feb. 22, in comparison with the like week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Major Gen. F.G. Beaumont-Nesbitt, recently appointed British military attache to the United States, called upon Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the First Army, at Governors Island yesterday morning on an official visit during which the two soldiers discussed not only the European war but the days long past when a British regiment garrisioned Governors Island.

Before going to England I had thought that the British might be exaggerating the likelihood and imminence of an invasion attempt on the United Kingdom by Reichsfuehrer Hitler in order to solidify public opinion and so stimulate war production.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Tension here over the Far Eastern situation appears to be somewhat relaxed tonight following today's conversation of Prime Minister Winston Churchill with the Japanese Ambassador, Mamoru Shigemitsu. The general trend of speculation is less truculent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- An appeal for "more nurses" to meet the needs of the armed forces of the nation, at Army posts, naval stations, cantonments, training camps and service hospitals in the United States, Alaska, Hawaii and Puerto Rico and at sea was made today at Mrs. Roosevelt's press conferen by representatives of the Army, the Navy and the Red Cross.

Ash Wednesday, ushering in the forty days of Lent, will be observed tomorrow more widely than ever because so much of the world is "in ashes" as a result of the war. There will be services in all Roman Catholic, Protestant Episcopal and many denominational churches.

Young women and men aiding in the plans for the Victory for Britain cocktail dance to be given Saturday in the ballroom of the Pierre under the auspices of the War Relief Association of American Youth, Inc., met yesterday afternoon at the cafe Pierre to further arrangements and expedite the sale of tickets for the benefit.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 -- Big Hank Greenberg, back from a Honolulu vacation today, found himself a central figure in baseball's biggest problem, the military draft.

ROME, Feb. 24 -- The hope and confidence that Premier Mussolini conveyed in his speech yesterday were immensely fortified by Reichsfuehrer Hitler in his address today to the Nazi party. Italians, above all, can take comfort from two things that Herr Hitler said, for they are taken to mean without doubt that German naval and armed forces are coming into the Mediterranean to join the Italians.

The Chesebro-Whitman Company, subsidiary of the Patent Scaffolding and Ladder Company of Long Island, bought from Alexander Brunner the industrial building at 748-50 South Twelfth Street, Newark, N.J. Louis Schlesinger, Inc., was the broker.

In a step to obtain wider participation by the membership of the New York Stock Exchange in "secondary" distributions of listed securities, it began yesterday a policy of printing on the stock ticket approvals given by the Committee on Member Firms to participations of members and member firms in sales of large blocks of listed stocks "off the Exchange," after the close of regular trading.

DESPITE German submarines and bombing planes, England is still able to export one of her characteristic products -- humor. A shipment of the light, frothy variety has just arrived here between the covers of Angela Thirkell's new book, "Cheerfulness Breaks In."*

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Confirmations by telegraph received today by Controller Morris S. Tremaine resulted in his awarding the $100,000,000 issue of State short-term notes to ninety-four banks and bond houses. The allotments are in various amounts, the largest, $2,600,000 each, going to a group of New York City banks and bond houses.

The Army will induct 10,500 men under the Selective Service Act between March 17 and March 28 in the Second Corps Area, comprising New York, New Jersey and Delaware, it was announced yesterday by Brig. Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, commander of the area.
HAVANA, Feb. 24 -- Cuban baseball fans, 2,233 of them, got their first glimpse of the season of major league baseball at Tropical Park today, but a great part of it was strictly bush-league stuff.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 24 (UP) -- Owner W. L. Brann said today Challedon would be a "definite starter" in the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Mordecai Ezekiel, economic adviser to the Department of Agriculture, laid before the Temporary National Economic. Committee today a series of proposals which he said he believed would permit modification of "our capitalistic economy so as to make it capable of maintaining full employment and full production even after the defense expenditures come to an end."

MOSCOW, Feb. 24 -- Things have indeed changed in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. The Communist party conference was finished in five days instead of the week or ten days that had been expected. Most of those five days was spent in finding fault and aiming higher, instead of in self-praise for the big progress of the last five months.

The liberalization of Princeton University Press under the editorship of Joseph Brandt will reach its high point on April 7, when the press will issue its first book of fiction. It is "The Gang's All Here," by Harvey Smith, a satire on academic life.

SOFIA, Feb. 24 (AP) -- With British citizens leaving Bulgaria today in expectation of a German occupation, an officially inspired Turkish newspaper commented that the Axis powers were "going to try to occupy the whole Mediterranean."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A slight lessening of tension in the Western Pacific was reported by Richard G. Casey, the Australian Minister, today after a conference with Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The authority of the New York City Council to conduct one-man hearings in its investigation of the Municipal Civil Service Commission was challenged in the Court of Appeals this afternoon by Paul J. Kern, president of the commission.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 -- A capacity audience filled the Paramount Theatre tonight for the sixteenth annual benefit for underprivileged children of the county. As in former seasons, Sam H. Harris and Arthur Hammerstein were co-producers and George Jessel master of ceremonies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 19: Increases of $44,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $164,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $176,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $109,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

A group headed by the Bankers Trust Company and including the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Chicago, and Roosevelt Weigold, Inc., received yesterday the award of $1,500,000 Commonwealth of Massachusetts Metropolitan Water District bonds on a bid of 102.76 for 1 3/4s.
England as theme and British artists as protagonists figure rather prominently just now in the local art panorama.

The St. Agatha School for Girls, Protestant Episcopal School at 553 West End Avenue, at the southwest corner of Eighty-seventh Street, will close after commencement exercises this year, according to an announcement last night by John Erskine, president of the board of trustees.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Creation of a National Labor Defense Mediation Board to mediate strikes in the defense industries is being discussed in labor circles and among officials connected with the Office of Production Management.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, conducted by John Barbirolli, will feature three new American works on a program to be played Saturday night, March 8, and repeated the following Sunday. The only composition preventing it from being an all-American program will be the Schumann Piano Concerto, which will be played by Beveridge Webster, an American pianist.

Grocery interests here yesterday cool in their reactions to were suggestions by United States Department of Agriculture experts Friday that large food processing and distributing corporations be given semi-Public utility status through legislation requiring their Federal incorporation to do an interstate business and empowering their control by government.

A proposed amendment to the State Education Law that would require the retirement of teachers found to be mentally or physically unfit was submitted yesterday to James Marshall, president of the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Diplomatic conversations between the Soviet Union and the United States are not going as well as usual from all indications today. Whether this points to a fundamental coolness in relations could only be conjectured, but it was considered significant, if not serious, that Russia now suspects the good faith of the United States in the negotiations.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 -- "Sunshine squint" costs tournament golfers more strokes than all links hazards combined, says Byron Nelson, P.G.A. champion and former national open titleholder.

The deal whereby the Pubic National Bank and Trust Company bought from the New York Stock Exchange the nine-story bank building at 35-41 Broad Street, which was erected by Lee, Higginson Co., in 1929, was formally completed yesterday, according to an announcement by E. Chester Gersten, president of the bank.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Arne Anderson, veteran Minneapolis heavyweight, died tonight in the ring without regaining consciousness after being knocked out by Lou Thomas of Indianapolis in the seventh round of a scheduled ten-rounder.

Frank Iannicelli won the invitation squash tennis tournament of the Whitehall Club yesterday. In the final round, before a crowded gallery, the wiry, dark-haired youth from the New York A.C. gave an exhibition of almost errorless squash to defeat Frank R. Hanson of the Columbia University Club, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 3.

Yesterday's trading was only fair to slow, but prices were generally unchanged on all classes of traefer meats, following the holiday on Saturday. Steer hinds and ribs of high choice to prime grades were fully steady, others about steady. Veal and lamb prices were unchanged. The kill was about normal in most plants and while opening kosher trade was slow prices were generally in line with last Friday.

In the last of four "farewell" speeches delivered last night, Earl G. Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, notified a mass meeting of party members that Robert Minor, a leading member of the party since its beginning, had been designated to succeed him when he begins serving a four-year term in a Federal prison for violating the passport laws.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 24 -- The setting up of four regional boards to stabilize wages, hours and working conditions in the shipbuilding industry was advocated today by John Green, president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, an affiliate of the C.I.O.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Decisive results from United States production of war materials can be expected next September, Sir Walter Citrine, General Secretary of the British Trades Union Congress, said today.

Differences over whether oleomargarine competes with butter for a place on the tables of those in low-income groups featured the Federal Trade Commission hearing yesterday in its complaint against Best Foods, Inc., maker of Nucoa oleomargarine for alleged misleading advertising.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for $150,000,000, to remain available until expended, for providing housing and community facilities in defense centers where there exists or impends an acute shortage which might impede the progress of the defense program.

LONDON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- It was understood that Prime Minister Churchill, in his separate talks with the Turkish and Greek envoys today, informed them of the "real intentions" behind the flying mission to the Near East of Foreign Secretary Eden and General Sir John Dill.

The largest Spring newspaper advertising campaign ever released by the Sherwin-Williams Company has been scheduled for 166 key cities, C. M. Lamperly, advertising director, and L. W. Dasbach, in charge of advertising for the S-W branches, announced yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- London had its first dress rehearsal today of what to do if the Germans bring poison gas to the caiptal, and all concerned agreed it was a flop.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Chairman Louis A. Reilly of the State Racing Commission said today "big money" was becoming interested in New Jersey horse race tracks and meets in 1941 were still possible.

Mr. and Mrs. George S. Piroumoff gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. W. Griffin King of Cleveland, Mr. and Mrs. Wadsworth C. Dunn, Mr. and Mrs. W. Ifnowlton Hoag and Fairfield Raynlond.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 24 -- Mark C. Honeywell of Wabash, Ind., president of the Committee of One Hundred, will be host to the other members of the committee and their friends at his island estate, Boca Chita, eighteen miles down Biscayne Bay, at the annual Southern outing of the committee on Thursday.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 24 (UP) -- A demand that Turkey deliver a "vigorous protest" to Germany against the Nazi claims of a diplomatic victory in the week-old Turkish-Bulgarian declaration of non-aggression was made tonight by the well-informed newspaper Yeni Sabah.

Spurred by an outburst of buying in wheat futures that skyrocketed grain prices almost 4 cents a bushel, a late demand entered the stock market yesterday and values were generally improved a point. All of the heavy demand for stocks was confined to the final hour of business, and came on the heels of the sharpest upturn in months in the Wheat Pit in Chicago.

LANSING, Mich., Feb. 24 (AP) -- A tentative agreement for a settlement of the strike in the plant of the Motor Wheel Corporation here, was announced today. It is to be voted upon tomorrow by members of the A.F.L.-United Automobile Workers, and, if accepted, will result in the return to work Wednesday of 2,500 workers idle for twelve days.

A new sports organization came into being last night when the American Olympic Association changed its twenty-year-old name to the United States of America Sports Federation in order to gain jurisdiction over the Pan-American Games, the first of which are scheduled for Buenos Aires in November, 1942.

Proceedings under the New York Constitution for the removal of judges have been infrequent and usually ineffectual. In a comparatively recent case there was evidence of considerable public dissatisfaction at the result. Governor Lehman recommended to the Legislature this year that the Court of Appeals have the sole power to remove judicial officers.

The names of twenty-two members of the Commission to Study the Base, of a Just and Durable Peace were announced yesterday by the Federal Council of Churches. Seven other groups have been invited to select two members each for the commission. The first meeting of the group will be held March 21.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 24 -- British forces driving into Eritrea from the north yesterday routed Italian defenders holding positions at Cubcub, forty miles north of besieged Cheren, taking a number of prisoners, and today continued their drive southward.

ATHENS, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Greek Army in almost four months of war has captured 20,000 Italians and "will not cease fighting until the Italians are out of Albania," a government spokesman said tonight.

TOKYO, Feb. 24 -- Denying that Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's recent note to British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden had had any adverse effect upon Japan's relations with Germany and Italy. Chuichi Ohashi, Foreign Vice Minister, today repeated in answer to an interpellation Mr. Matsuoka's explanations of last week.
An English translation of excerpts from Herr Hitler's address in Munich, made by the National Broadcasting Company in New York, follows:

The establishment of Palestine as a center of Jewish life was urged last night by Dr. Albert Einstein in a message sent to a rally of the junior division of the United Palestine Appeal of Greater New York held at the Free Synagogue, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.
TRENTON, Feb. 24 -- With the Legislature in recess until March 10, the Joint Appropriations Committee began hearings today on the annual money bills for operation of the State government.

Forging to the front with a 15-point scoring spree in the first half and repulsing a late challenge by its rivals, City College vanquished Brooklyn College, 49 to 40, for its fourth straight intracity basketball triumph at Madison Square Garden last night.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The smallest supplemental budget in recent years was submitted to the Legislature tonight by Governor Lehman. It asked $573,479.40, putting the total budget at $385,693,453.07.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The first mandatory industry-wide priorities to be imposed under the defense program were put by the Office of Production Management today upon producers of aluminum and builders of machine tools, the two items most needed to speed armament production.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Only the giltedge securities wholly resisted the general dull tendency on the Stock Exchange today, although there was no marked response among the prime investments to the payments today for dollar securities taken over by the Treasury last month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Senator Wheeler threatened again today to filibuster against the British aid bill if the Administration seeks to speed its passage with morning or night sessions "in an effort to put pressure on us."
BERLIN, Feb. 24 (UP) -- The sinking of 217,300 tons of additional British shipping, including "auxiliary cruisers," was reported here today.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Officials of the United States Legation said tonight they were trying to track down repeated reports that a German injured by Minister George H. Earle was dying of a skull fracture.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Debits to deposit accounts (except interbank accounts), as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Feb. 19, aggregated $10,045,000,000.

VICHY, France, Feb. 24 -- A complete reorganization of the structure of the French Cabinet was announced by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain tonight in which the conduct of negotiations with Germany will be centralized under the direction of a single representative.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 24 -- Bette Davis and Mary Astor will be teamed in Warners' recently purchased "The Gay Sisters," a new novel by Stephen Longstreet, the studio announced today.

Hitler so regularly uses words to mask his real purposes that it would not be safe to draw the conclusion, from his speech at Munich yesterday, that the great German offensive of this Spring is to be primarily a sea and not a land war. But of one thing we may be certain.

It will be N.Y.U. and Fordham, old rivals, as main contenders for the twentieth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championship at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, with Pitt, Penn State, Princeton and Penn the outside choices to break the metropolitan monopoly.

Reporting to stockholders for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, 1940, Sydney G. McAllister, President of the International Harvester Company, said that the net income amounted to $23,161,110 after all deductions, including depreciation and provision for Federal income tax.

The general public may have read with casual interest the news that the newspaper room at the Central Branch of the New York Public Library is to be closed. For a considerable number of library patrons, many of them with much leisure on their hands and little in their pockets, the announcement had its poignancy.
The members of a British good-will mission to South America arrived here yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Lucia after a four-month tour of ten Latin-American republics.

Wallace Groves, financier who was convicted of mail fraud in Federal court last Friday, was sentenced to two years in prison yesterday and released a few hours later in the record ball of $125,000. His brother, George S. Groves, described as a secondary figure in the $750,000 fraud, was released in $50,000 bail, after receiving a sentence of eight months.

Suspecting that a hold-up of ten drivers of the Comprehensive Bus Company, at 46 Oliver Street, on the lower East Side, had been staged by neighborhood youths, Detectives John Calhoun and Frank Manco of the Oak Street station made a thorough canvass of the district yesterday and within a few hours had rounded up four persons who subsequently were said to have confessed.
Buyers for Gertz Jamaica recently acquired by Allied Stores Corporation, will see salesmen each Tuesday morning at the Allied Stores office at 1440 Broadway.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Despite the new extension of the armistice between this French colony and Thailand, reported today from Tokyo, official sources expressed the belief that final agreement was "virtually hopeless" and that hostilities ultimately would be resumed.

DETROIT, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The C.I.O.-United Automobile Workers today accused the Ford Motor Company of violation of a recent National Labor Relations Board "cease and desist" order and charged that the company had made "wholesale discharges" of union men employed in its glass plant.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 24 -- Twenty-four sophomores at Princeton University have withdrawn from the upper class eating clubs' Bicker Week activities and will form an independent club to be run on a cooperative basis, it was learned today.

The National Association of Manufacturers issued last night a six-page statement dissociating itself from Dr. Ralph West Robey's criticism that a "substantial proportion" of the social science textbooks used in American high schools speaks unfavorably of our form of government and holds is the system of private enterprise in derision or contempt.

OTTAWA, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Sir Frederick Grant Banting, one of the great benefactors of mankind as co-discoverer of insulin, was killed along with two other men in a military plane that crashed in the snow wastes of Newfoundland last Friday while en route on a secret war mission to Great Britain, it became known tonight.

One of the principal penalties which mounting government spending, debt and taxation place upon the economic system is the extent to which they render that system inflexible. This process is well illustrated by a point made in the annual report of the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Senator Ellender's amendment to the lease-lend bill, for which greater strength is claimed than for any other, specifies that the measure does not add any executive powers to those which now may exist to sanction the use of United States naval or land forces outside the Western Hemisphere plus outlying possessions and territories, including the Philippines.

Another 11 1/2 per cent vacancy ratio in private houses in revealed in a study by Pease Elliman of the area bounded by Sixty-second and Eighty-sixth Streets and Park and Madison Avenues. The same vacancy ratio was revealed by a previous study of the area between the same streets, but between Fifth and Madison Avenues.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 -- Contracts were awarded at the Army Quartermaster Depot here today for large quantities of textile supplies including the following items: 9,043,710 yards of drill, silesia, twill and cotton linings; 4,035,000 sleeveless Summer undershirts; 3,563,000 pairs of Summer cotton drawers (shorts); 1,000,000 pairs of canvas leggings; 474,600 black silk neckties; for the manufacture of 245,000 one-piece work suits, and for quantities of bias binding, buttons and slide fasteners.

Golden Gloves semi-finalists in various divisions, survivors of a series of preliminaries among the leading amateur boxers in the metropolitan area, attracted a crowd of 6,000 persons to the Bronx Coliseum last night.
