WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- Continuance of toll collections on the Cross-County Parkway for twelve years and the use of $1,500,000 of the proceeds for the improvement of that parkway and the construction of center islands on the Hutchinson River Parkway was advocated here this afternoon by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Roosevelt was at Hyde Park. The White House sent to Congress the President's report and recommendations of a special committee studying the civil service; and messages requesting $3,812,311,197 for additional Army appropriations and authorizations, and for $150,000,000 for community facilities in towns and cities adjacent to defense projects.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Prices of wheat turned upward in the late trading today after a dull and easy opening. Prices advanced around 4 cents a bushel from the early low on a wave of general buying and carried the market to the highest level in about a month.
ROME, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique today said:

Joseph W. Burden, 56 years old, investment adviser and over-the-counter securities dealer, and grandson of the founder of the famous Burden Iron Works in Troy, N.Y., which helped build the Monitor in the Civil War, was sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions for two to four years.

The board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday that the seats of three suspended members and two deceased members were to be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of the constitution of the Exchange and that it had directed that these memberships be sold at the discretion of the board.

The press has carried a number of letters on the projected removal of the Aquarium from Battery Park. It seems that when this news broke there was not a dry eye at the Knickerbocker Club, all the shades were drawn at the Century Association, and heartrending sobs issued from the dusty diggings of the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society.

It would be too much to say that Sir Frederick Grant Banting conquered diabetes, but there is no doubt that his discovery and application of insulin robbed the disease of its ancient terror and made it possible for its victims to prolong their lives and to go about their work with much of their old energy.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Ralph Budd, president of the Burlington Railroad and the transportation industry's representative on the National Defense Advisory Commission, disclosed tonight the estimated size of the load which the railroads will bear in 1941 and 1942.

Showing the greatest gains in a single day since early in January, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday at the highest levels for the session and 4 to 14 points above Friday's finals. Prices now are only 10 to 24 points below this season's highs, established at the beginning of January.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 24 -- Officers of the National Education Association have been working toward the organization of the National Commission on the Protection of Democracy Through Education, it was disclosed today as the controversy over whether textbooks of subversive character are in use in the schools continued to occupy delegates to the national convention of the American Association of School Administrators here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Administration took two far-reaching steps today toward speeding the production and procurement of weapons for the United States and Great Britain.

The Federal Government has more than a million civilian employes, receiving a billion dollars a year in salaries and wages. About three-fourths of them are under competitive civil service ratings. President Roosevelt has carried forward on a number of fronts -- though not all the available fronts -- the campaign to put public employment on a merit basis.

BERLIN, Feb. 24 -- There will be no world boom in the present war comparable to that of the World War, but only an armament boom in the United States, possibly followed by minor boomlets in war essential metals, according to the diagnosis of Dr. Joseph Winschus, German enonomic writer.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has been elected by the directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston and New York to represent those banks on the Federal Open-Market Committee, the New York bank announced yesterday.

Pierre Luboshutz, Russian pianist, and Genia Nemenoff, French artist, who were married in October, 1931, and made their debut as a two-piano team five years ago, gave their annual New York recital last night as the seventh event in the Hurok series at Carnegie Hall.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 24 -- Addressing a general session of the American Association of School Administrators, whose 12,000 delegates heard 100 speakers here today, Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, declared: "The issue between democracy and dictatorship can now be resolved only as the representatives of one or the other of these irreconcilable principles are in a position to dictate a settlement.

Efrem Zimbalist will succeed Dr. Randall Thompson as director of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, Mrs. Mary Louise Curtis Bok, its president, announced yesterday, Mr. Zimbalist, who has been head of the institute's violin department since he joined the faculty in 1928, will take over his duties early in May, when Dr. Thompson's resignation becomes effective.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The Senate tonight passed and sent to the Assembly the Coudert bill to make the voting hours for special elections 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. instead of 6 A.M. to 6 P.M.

SOFIA, Feb. 24 -- It was learned from reliable sources tonight that King Boris might receive leaders of the former political parties in a special audience at the palace tomorrow. The motive is believed to be an exchange of views at a critical moment.
Property in three boroughs figured in the city realty trading reported by brokers and covered by deeds recorded yesterday.

Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., gave yesterday to holders of common stock rights to subscribe at $100 each for 148,991 shares of cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value, 4 1/4 per cent series, at the rate of one share of new preferred for each six shares of common held. Subscription warrants are to expire on March 6.
Three new films will arrive on Broadway screens today. "Meet Boston Blackie" is the newcomer at

A committee of debutantes under the chairmanship of Miss Mary Patricia Richter will assist this afternoon with various features on the program of a bridge party and entertainment to be given in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Episcopal Actors Guild, a philanthropic organization which has its national headquarters in the Guild Hall of the Church of the Transfiguration.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Britain rejects any suggestion of Japanese mediation in the European war and still is not satisfied with Japan's declarations regarding her peaceful intentions in Southeast Asia, reliable informants said tonight after a long conference, between Japanese Ambassador Mamoru Shigemitsu and Prime Minister Winston Churchill at 10 Downing Street.

DETROIT, Feb. 24 -- Completion of the refunding of the $18,000,000 debt of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit was announced here today by Archbishop Edward Mooney. The action puts the entire indebtedness of all parishes in Southeastern Michigan on a new and centralized basis.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- The public will have an opportunity at the general election in November to decide whether New York State will seek to regain the skiing leadership that it formerly enjoyed in the Northeast or remain in fifth place, where it is now stationed.

IT'S high time to hang up a warning sign on the field of sports. It would be rather embarrassing to all concerned to find a flock of famous sports figures tabbed as unfit -- or worse still, unwilling -- to aid in the defense program of their own country. But the way things have been going, some of the big boys are going to get a "bad press," to use the language of the diplomats.

Although S.N. Behrman may believe that it is no time for comedy, it is. It is certainly time for him to stick to his last. In "The Talley Method," which finally arrived at Henry Miller's last evening, he writes comedy like a master and philosophy like a mystic.

Benefit payments last year to policy holders and beneficiaries by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States amounted to $205,432,000, or an average of $561,290 daily, according to the society's annual report for 1940. At the end of 1940 the society had $4,772,825,860 of ordinary life insurance in force and $2,364,094,782 of group insurance, a total of $7,136,920,642.

OTTAWA, Feb. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Dean C.J. Mackenzie, acting president of the National Research Council, tonight described the insistence of Sir Frederick Banting on getting back to Great Britain with new medical knowledge from Canada and the United States as indirectly responsible for the scientist's death.

The annual report of the St. Joseph Lead Company and subsidiaries for the year 1940, made public yesterday, reveals a net profit of $55,111,942 after depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and $254,745 excess profits tax provision, equal to $2.61 a share on 1,955,680 shares of capital stock, excluding 41,160 shares in treasury.

With the green and white colors of Egypt flying from her stern, the thirty-two-year-old liner Zamzam, named for a Mohammedan sacred well near Mecca, arrived at Pier F, Jersey City, yesterday after a two-month passage from Alexandria by way of the Cape of Good Hope.

Many parties will be given at the luncheon and card party for the benefit of St. Vincent's Hospital to be held today in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The funds realized will be used to provide additional medical and surgical supplies and to assist with the maintenance of the hospital's ambulance service.

Sales of the Electric Auto-Lite Company last year set a new record at $72,973,177, an increase of $16,627,144, or 39 per cent, over the volume shown in 1939, according to the annual report made public yesterday.

KHARTUM, Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, Feb. 24 (UP) -- British and "Free French" forces, including six-foot Senegalese warriors from Western Africa, have captured the fortified Eritrean town of Cubcub, north of Cheren, in a two-day battle, it was announced today.
MONTREAL, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Toronto's Syl Apps made the pursuer's role the most interesting in the National Hockey League scoring race last week.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Picking up where he left off yesterday, Charley Brinton, Princeton University junior from Philadelphia, won the national squash racquets championship today.

The Long Island Lighting Company had net income in 1940 of $1,572,630 after all operating expenses, taxes and charges, but before the setting aside of $576,000 from income, by order of the Public Service Commission, which was invested in new utility plant, Edward F. Barrett, president of the utility, disclosed yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.
ATHENS, Feb. 24 -- Retorting to claims made by Premier Mussolini in his speech yesterday, an official Greek spokesman said tonight that, of about 20,000 Italians taken prisoner, 551 were officers.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Tall Trees Stables' Bill Farnsworth splashed around a muddy track today to capture the $1,000 Mayor Leo McLaughlin Handicap, featured event on the initial program of Oaklawn Park's thirty-day racing season.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Hog prices held mostly steady with last week's close today, dropping 5 to 10 cents in spots. The top was $7.90, with choice 180 to 240-pound hogs bringing $7.60 to $7.85. Steers were weak to 25 cents lower, compared with last Thursday's trade. Light steers topped at $14.65 but little was offered above $13.

Indictments charging Joseph Doto, alias Joe Adonis, underworld figure in Brooklyn, with kidnapping, extortion and assault were dismissed yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court at the request of Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen on the ground that virtually the same evidence had been unacceptable to two juries that tried Sam Gasberg, co-defendant with Adonis.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Ways and Means Committee proposed today temporary relief for the high-bracket corporate taxpayer.

Lawrence M. Orton, member of the City Planning Commission, will be the principal speaker at a meeting of the local chapter of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers to be held Thursday night at Schrafft's Restaurant, 13 East Forty-second Street, at 6:30 P.M. Mr. Orton's subject will be the Master Plan recently submitted by the City Planning Commission, from the viewpoint of its relation to New York City real estate.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Under unusual conditions the Yankees inaugurated Spring training today at Huggins Field.

The Public Service Company of Oklahoma filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed issue of $16,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first mortgage bonds, Series A, due Feb. 1, 1971, and 83,500 shares of $100 par value of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock for a total of $24,350,000.

When Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka suggested yesterday that the white races cede their possessions in Oceania to the Asiatic races he did not make clear the area he had in mind. But his limiting of it to a region with dimensions of 1,200 miles by 1,000 miles indicated he was thinking of only a small part of Oceania as it is usually understood by geographers.
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 24 (UP) -- Southern boys in two widely separated CCC camps were charged today with rebellion and in each case ringleaders were sent to county jails by Army officers in command.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- Recommendations made by an eight-man committee headed by Supreme Court Justice Stanley Reed that classified civil service be extended to all Federal Government positions except "policy-determining" jobs and those requiring Senate confirmation were transmitted to Congress today by President Roosevelt.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 24 -- The British Legation began destroying confidential records today and evacuated members of its staff to Turkey as signs multiplied rapidly that the German Army was ready to begin its large-scale occupation of Bulgaria.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 25 -- Government spokesmen, in an effort to reassure nervous Deputies, gave a limited outline of foreign policy in Parliament yesterday during which Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka expressed the opinion that the "white race" eventually must cede thousands of islands in the central and south Pacific Ocean to Japan.

The Maple Leafs, at the top in the National Hockey League race, and the Americans, in the cellar, clash in Madison Square Garden tonight. Battling against tremendous odds for a play-off berth, the Americans, seven points behind the sixth-place Canadiens, are hopeful of swinging an upset.

In the same speech on Sunday Mussolini included a denunciation of democratic liberalism, warm praise for "the collaboration offered by the Fuehrer" and a complimentary allusion to Garibaldi and Mazzini.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Sumner Welles, acting Secretary of State, announced today that the State Department was seeking information concerning German charges that a Canadian merchant ship was carrying the American flag and colors when sunk in the Indian Ocean last week.

BERLIN, Feb. 24 -- Twenty-four hours after Premier Mussolini in allied Italy had delivered what is authoritatively termed here a "great speech," Reichsfuehrer Hitler addressed the National Socialist old guard gathered at the Munich Buergerbraeu Cellar and, over a national hook-up, the German nation for exactly ninety minutes this afternoon.

Gardner Jencks, American pianist, who made his Town Hall debut last night, took time for seasoning before making his bow, and as a result his playing had more depth and maturity than is common among newcomers. His performances bespoke a sensitive, orderly mind.

BUFFALO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A C.I.O. leader, accusing the Bethlehem Steel Company, which has $1,500,000,000 of defense contracts, of "endangering" the nation in its preparedness program, said today that the company's labor difficulties at the Lackawanna plant "are bound sooner or later to spread" to other plants.

The government, in its first offering of taxable securities for refunding purposes, has given a nervous and hesitant market a much-needed stimulus. Definite indications were apparent in the market yesterday that Treasury officials would confine the refunding securities to relatively short maturity and that some sort of choice would be offered to holders of the maturing obligations.

Washington Heights detectives seemed satisfied yesterday that Colonel Michael Borislavsky, former officer of the Russian Imperial Engineers, met his death on St. Nicholas Terrace on Sunday night while trying to ward off hold-up men.

The American Communist party has control over half the 4,000,000 members of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and can jeopardize national unity in a time of crisis by creating discord among labor, Benjamin Gitlow, former secretary of the Communist party, declared yesterday in an address at Town Hall.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Wallace Edmonds Conkling, 44-year-old Pennsylvania clergyman, was consecrated Bishop of the Chicago Diocese of the Protestant Episcopal church today.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Fade, a fast and game filly owned by Mrs. Payne Whitney, defeated fifteen other 2-year-olds in the first division of the Miami Jockey Club Dinner Stakes as the final week of the forty-six-day Hialeah meeting began today.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, acting as Foreign Secretary in the absence of Anthony Eden, received the Turkish and Greek envoys today.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Governor Lehman and Chairman Moffat of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee conferred late this afternoon on the proposal to divert $60,000,000 of grade-crossing funds to parkway and highway projects.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- As general Senate debate on the lease-lend bill continued from opposition sources today, Senator Wheeler, a leader of the opponents, announced that if the measure were passed he would head a group of opposition Senators in stumping the country against American entry in the war.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 -- Robert J. Boltz, attorney and financial agent who, his books indicated, had accepted more than $2,000,000 of his clients' money for investment and had paid them "dividends" out of their principal, was sentenced today in Quarter Sessions Court to serve twenty to forty years in the Eastern State Penitentiary.

"It Happens on Ice" will close its run at the Center Theatre March 8, after its 180th performance there. New material will be added during a tour which is to start in Chicago on March 12, and on April 3 the second edition will open at the Center.

Wendell L. Willkie called for an end of isolationist thought in America in a speech last night at the Hotel Astor at a dinner in honor of William Allen White, editor of The Emporia (Kansas) Gazette, and former chairman of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies.

Representatives of the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that they had called a public hearing on the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway for Friday at 10 A.M. in the auditorium of the Port Authority Commerce Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

Mrs. Hugh R. Wilson of Washington, D.C., and Hampshire House, wife of the former United States Ambassador to Germany, entertained with a luncheon yesterday at Hampshire House. Among the guests were Mrs. Seton Porter, Miss Julia Berwind, Mrs. Reginald Foster of Boston, Mrs. James W. Gerard, Baroness de Kleist, Mrs. Hare Lippincott, Mrs. Henry Fletcher and Mrs. William von Ropp.

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, reported yesterday a net asset value of $12.26 each for 2,723,047 common shares at the close of 1940, compared with $11.43 a share on June 30, 1940, and $12.80 on Dec. 31, 1939. Dividends of 50 cents a share were paid in 1940.

of the Thai-Indo-Chinese frontier dispute are not entirely clear. The return to Thailand of districts ceded to the French protectorates of i Laos and Cambodia since 1893 would include the Luang-Prabang district west of the llekong liver at the extreme north of Thailand.

Surprising though it may seem, the New York Americans held the pace-setting Toronto Maple Leafs to a tie in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Undermanned, and with three of their star players crippled, the Dutton Dusters nevertheless tore at their vaunted foes as though the Stanley Cup depended on the outcome, and shocked the visitors by earning a 4-to-4 overtime deadlock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Naval Affairs Committee rushed through the House today an $84,302,883 bill for the expansion of naval shore stations and announced that the United States now had the right under certain circumstances to assume military control over British islands where it is establishing bases.

A 14-point rally early in the second period helped Fordham erase a 26 -- 20 half-time deficit and eased the Rams into a 62 -- 41 triumph over the Canisius College five last night in the Rose Hill gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A Federal grand jury concluded its inquiry today into expenditures in the 1940 political campaign, but found no evidence justifying indictments under the law. The grand jury stated in its report, however, that excessive sums were expended "deliberately in a manner calculated to circumvent the spirit of the law without violating the letter of the Hatch act."

An underwriting syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co. is expected to offer to the public after the close on the Stock Exchange tomorrow, subject to market conditions and the registration statement becoming effective, 52,500 shares of no-par value common stock of the G.C. Murphy Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Roosevelt expressed the belief today that proposals for peace in Europe must await a British victory. The first thing is to win the war, the President declared in a press conference held after his return to the White House from Hyde Park.
DETROIT, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Forty men went back to jobs in the Ford Motor Company's glass plant today, but differences persisted between the company and the U.A.W., a C.I.O. affiliate.

Robert Moses on the subject of the Aquarium building is like most of us weak mortals. When he has made up his mind not to like something, he won't like it even if it is good. He thinks the old Castle Garden was a monstrosity when Jenny Lind sang in it under the management of P.T. Barnum.
The pamphlet report of the Rustless Iron and Steel Corporation issued yesterday showed net sales amounted to $11,583,924 in 1940, compared with $6,388,496 the year before, an increase of $5,195,428.

ATLANTA, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A bill to prohibit labor unions from collecting any money from workers on Federal emergency defense projects in Georgia was passed by the State Senate today. The vote was 35 to 11, with five Senators absent.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 25 -- British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden took a special train for Ankara tonight after reaching Turkey by plane from Egypt for talks that may have an important effect on the Balkan crisis.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Political fuel was added to the legislative session today with the introduction of a bill which would bar future Governors, Lieutenant Governors, Attorneys General and Controllers from engaging in any profession or business enterprise, for gain "on the side."

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 26 -- The "compromise" Japanese plan for a border realignment between Thailand and Indo-China would restore to Thailand all the territorial acquisitions made since 1893, leaving earlier changes intact.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Four of the more obscure Widener Cup candidates had their last heavy trial for the $50,000 race Saturday when they ran in the featured Jacksonville Purse before 13,477 fans who wagered $625,650 at Hialeah Park today.

BOSTON, Feb. 25 -- The Boston Bruins' record unbeaten string in the National Hockey League was cut at the twenty-three-game mark tonight when the late-spurting New York Rangers took full advantage of two third-period penalties imposed on Captain Dit Clapper to gain a 2-0 shutout before a crowd of 16.086 at the Boston Garden.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 25 -- The British Consul General, Godfrey Haggard, and Mrs. Haggard of New York, will be honor guests tomorrow night at a dinner to be given by Mr. and Mrs. Kent G. Colwell at their home here. The dinner will precede the benefit ball at the Old Mill Inn, Bernardsville.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Two sandy-haired, 14-year-old boys from Paterson, who had embarked on a career of crime, "shot it out with the cops" early this morning at a cabin beside lonely Echo Lake, near here.
VICHY, France, Feb. 25 -- Details issued today of the reorganization of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's government, announced last night, make two points clear:

Before proceeding against the authors of "un-American" textbooks, abundantly though they deserve attention, would it not be well to define what the word means? Otherwise the proceedings will be, from the start, a mere calling of names and slinging of mud.
Edwin Otterbourg, known to many New York anglers as an inveterate fisherman and dog fancier, has the kind of luck most anglers dream of but seldom find.

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey announced yesterday, following a meeting of the board of directors, that the quarterly dividend on the company's common stock had been cut from 60 cents a share to 55 cents a share. In 1940 the utility paid 60 cents each quarter, or a total of $2.40 for the year.

Thirty-five prominent physicians of New York and other cities have sent a statement to President Roosevelt declaring themselves "unalterably opposed" to former President Hoover's plan to feed the conquered nations under Germany's control. Although they agreed with Mr. Hoover in regarding the distress in Europe as "heartrending," they held that this program would help the Nazis and prolong the suffering of their victims.

Many parties were given yesterday at the luncheon and fashion show held in the Terrace Room and Palm Garden of the Plaza under the auspices of the American Fund for British War Aid to purchase vitamins for children and civilians in England.

The permissibility of filing corrected returns for the base period years of the excess-profits tax, 1936 through 1939, was discussed in the tenth installment of this series (issue of Jan. 8), in which it was suggested that errors in such returns may be corrected so as to obtain the benefit of the actual income earned in the period.
The Ballet Theatre opened its third week at the Majestic Theatre last night with the season's first presentation of Antony Tudor's "Dark Elegies" as the special feature of the evening.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Agreement on the enactment of the Steingut bill validating the lease of buses in Brooklyn in order to permit the removal of the Fulton Street elevated line was announced today.

A challenge to prove or disprove charges that Communists control relief in this city, that subversive groups play an important part in public education and that racketeers dominate the Department of Sanitation was given to the grand jury of New York County yesterday by Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division, First Department.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Cranston Williams, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, said today in an address before the Englewood Rotary Club at the Englewood Golf Club that a "smear campaign" was being waged against the newspapers of the country, but that it would not prevent them from telling the truth about the progress of the national defense program.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- After March 10 it will be illegal to have a meal in a British hotel, restaurant or other catering establishment consisting of more than one of the following: Meat, fish, poultry and game, eggs or cheese. Lord Woolton, Minister of Food, today issued an order which, he said, aimed to "protect food supplies and to achieve social equality."

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The British people were told today that they must steel their nerves for a worse ordeal by bombs than any that has already taken place, because no amount of work has yet yielded a clue on how to defeat the night raider.

Tightening control of the government over export shipments of materials important to defense was discussed here yesterday in a list of about forty items on which the government now requires information in addition to that supplied in regular applications for export licenses.

Referring to the lease-lend bill not only as "legislation for war giving the President unlimited, unprecedented and unpredictable powers," but as deficient in providing aid for Great Britain, Mrs. Robert A. Taft, wife of the Senator from Ohio, yesterday directed the attention of 350 women attending the Tuesday lecture luncheon series in the Brooklyn Academy of Music to the $2,000,000,000 direct loan bill before Congress as a more straightforward, less war-tempting alternate.

A squad of twenty battery candidates will report to Coach Andy Coakley tomorrow to inaugurate the veteran baseball mentor's twenty-sixth Spring training session in preparation for Columbia's season opener against C.C.N.Y. on April 2.

ROME, Feb. 25 -- The most terrible Spring that the world has ever seen is promised by Giovanni Ansaldo in the Gazetta del Popolo today after an analysis of the speeches of Premier Mussolini and Reichsfuehrer Hitler.

VICHY, France, Feb. 25 -- Ten to twenty years at hard labor and confiscation of their property formed the sentences imposed today on four Army and Navy officers by the summary military court at Gannat, near here.

Rising costs of leather and increases in other cost factors in production of shoes probably will not result in any appreciable increases in retail shoe prices during 1941, it was indicated in discussions yesterday with both manufacturers and retailers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Fanned by reports of administrative delays in speeding up of the defense program and of continuing labor strife in some of the country's leading war industries, the movement for a wholesale investigation of defense preparations gained sudden headway in the House today.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Joseph C. Mackey was quoted by residents of lonely Musgrave Harbor tonight as declaring that he had ordered Sir Frederick Banting and two other men to "bail out" of the plane he was piloting, and that only after it crashed did he discover that all three had met death by remaining with him.

New buses to be placed in operation on city routes will incorporate features designed to bar all finger and toe holds for children and youths who like to hitch rides, Justice Stephen S. Jackson, director of the Bureau for the Prevention of Juvenile Delinquency, announced yesterday after a conference with manufacturers who supply most of the buses used here.

A generally slow trade, due in part to the approaching Lenten season, resulted yesterday in a weak to lower market on steer hinds and ribs, lamb and pork. The veal market was slow but about steady. Kosher steer chucks and plates were about steady, veal foresaddles barely steady, lambs mostly 50c-$1 lower than Monday's opening trade.

Officials of Milwaukee County, Wis., announced yesterday their intention to sell on March 17 an issue of $3,800,000 of corporate purpose notes, for which bidders are to specify the rate of interest. The obligations, dated April 1, 1941, will become payable on April 1, 1942, subject to call on and after Feb. 1, 1942.

Three-quarters of the World's Fair construction has been demolished, a survey disclosed yesterday. Under the terms of the contract between the Fair Corporation and the city, demolition was to have been completed by tomorrow, but Commander Howard A. Flanagan, vice president of the corporation, said the city had granted an extension until April 27.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- In its second play acquisition of the month, Paramount bought "Louisiana Purchase" today for $150,000. The studio had acquired Moss Hart's "Lady in the Dark" Feb. 10 for $285,000. B.G. De Sylva, producer and original author of "Purchase," will film it at Paramount, where he is now head of production.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 25 -- The Forty-fourth Division simulated today an attack on the Naval Air Station at Lakehurst, according to the terms of a combat team problem, the first in which all units of the combat team, infantry, artillery, engineers and medical detachments participated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Abuses and deficiencies in the organization and operation of investment companies were detailed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission in another section of its reports to Congress under the authority of the Holding Company Act on this problem.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 25 -- Occupation of the ancient Indian Ocean port of Brava was announced today by British Empire forces in a lightning drive up the coast of Italian Somaliland that placed them within 110 miles of Mogadiscio, the capital. This advance, credited by a Nairobi communique to West African fighters, represented a gain of 160 miles beyond British-occupied Kismayu.

Thirty-four college educators and twenty-two teachers' unions have pledged their support to the New York College Teachers Union in its fight against the attempt of the American Federation of Teachers executive council to revoke its charter, Dr. Robert K. Speer, president, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Senate Naval Affairs Committee today unanimously approved a $242,000,000 naval expansion bill, including authorization for $4,700,000 of limited fortification work at Guam.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Treasury announced today that its exchange refunding offer on 2 per cent bonds of 1948-50 and of three-quarter of 1 per cent notes, Series D, 1943, will expire at the close of business tomorrow, except for the receipt of notifications from holders of $10,000 or less of the securities eligible for exchange.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Representative Howard W. Smith of Virginia urged the House Judiciary Committee today to bar the closed shop in the defense industries and so destroy "the racket that has been a disgrace to the country" in the construction of Army cantonments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The General Telephone Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 40,000 shares of $2.50 preferred stock and 80,000 shares of common stock of $20 par value.

Two new films will make their appearance on Broadway screens today. At Loew's Criterion, Paramount's "The Mad Doctor" will be the new attraction. The drama stars Basil Rathbone and includes Ellen Drew, John Howard, Ralph Morgan, Hugh O'Connell, Martin Kosleck, Billy Benedict and Hugh Sothern in some of the supporting roles...

OTTAWA, Feb. 25 -- Leighton G. McCarthy of Toronto, a former member of Parliament, has been named Canadian Minister to Washington to succeed Loring Christie, who has been compelled by ill health to seek leave of absence, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King announced in Parliament this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Representative Robert F. Rich, Republican, of Pennsylvania, interrupted a peroration on the virtues of economy in the House today to demand that George H. Earle, United States Minister to Bulgaria, be recalled for "throwing a champagne bottle" at a German in a Sofia night club last Saturday.

Successful creation of a new world order is dependent on the participation of the United States in establishing that order, it was agreed yesterday by eight speakers at the fifth annual forum on world affairs held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music under the auspices of the Brooklyn Section of the National Council of Jewish Women.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 25 -- Questions asked in the Egyptian Parliament have revived the controversy going on since 1924 concerning the Suez Canal Company's obligation to pay dividends on its shares and interest on its bonds in gold francs, which began as a fiscal matter but now is considered in the domain of national defense.

OTTAWA, loeb. 05 (Canadian Press) -- In announcing the appointnlent of Leighton G. [cCarthy as Canadian A'linister to lArashington today. Prime Minister 3{ackenzie ]{in. also announced that Air. iV/cCartily had been recommended to the Cvernor-eneral for appointment to the Canadian Privy Council.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Lee Thompson Smith, director of the Bureau of Real Estate of the Board of Estimate, who leased an apartment in Town House, 108 East Thirty-eighth Street, through N.A. Berwin Co., Inc., brokers.

The release, with his consent, of part of the testimony of Mr. Stimson at an executive session of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is a welcome step forward in apprising the American people of the state of our defenses. The Secretary of War declares that, including 300 planes of the National Guard, the Army Air Corps now has approximately 4,000 planes altogether.

In your editorial "Policy in the Pacific" you state that "Japan complains" that the fortification of Guam "constitutes an act of provocation." In what terms has the Government of Japan addressed this complaint to that of this country? None, I think.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 25 -- With only three of the five Commissioners present the City Commission here adopted today a budget totaling $40,880,425 after one of the stormiest public hearings in many years.

The progress of industry, agriculture and marketing in the Northwest area of which Spokane, Wash., is the center, was described yesterday by Ralph E. Dyar of The Spokesman-Review and The Spokane Daily Chronicle at a luncheon in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria for several hundred representatives of newspapers, advertising and sales corporations.

BOSTON, Feb. 25 -- Orders 2 per cent greater than in December were booked during January by Massachusetts mills and factories, according to the monthly index of orders compiled by the Associated Industries of Massachusetts. This increase was achieved despite a decrease of approximately 17 per cent in orders received by the metal trades, a decrease explained by the fact that December orders were far in excess of productive capacity.

WITH the publication of "Summer 1914"* we have at long last a full English version of Roger Martin du Gard's tremendous mural, "The World of the Thibaults," a magnificent novel in the grand manner that won for M. Martin du Gard, even before he finished his story, the Nobel Prize.
The financial statement of the General American Life Insurance Company shows total admitted assets of $127,133,546 at the end of 1940 compared with $128,415,949 on Dec. 31, 1939.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Roosevelt favors the use of wire tapping to combat sabotage or espionage against the United States, and kidnapping and consequent extortion, but only when the Attorney General deems it necessary, and he "would confine such legislation to the Department of Justice."

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- A possibility that extension of State aid to kindergartens will be included in the Republican budget plan has cropped up. The practical effect of adoption would be equal to a restoration in part of the cut in State aid recommended this year by Governor Lehman.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Princeton's undefeated swimming team registered its eighth straight victory tonight, downing Fordham, 55 -- 20, in Brokaw Pool.

Nearly six months have passed since Adolf Hitler told a wildly cheering crowd in Berlin's Sportpalast that an invasion of the British islands was imminent. "The people of England," he said with scorn, "are very curious and ask: 'Why in the world don't you come?'"

The Museum of Modern Art reports that an average of 1,343 people daily have attended the current exhibition, "Indian Art of the United States," since its opening on Jan. 22. Only two other exhibitions have exceeded this in daily attendance since the museum moved into its new building two years ago.

A serious and deeply moved Emporia editor, in no mood for those homely bucolic pleasantries which have often delighted his readers, spoke yesterday at a dinner given in his honor by The Churchman. The medal he received he had merited by intelligence and, above all, by character.

Jose Iturbi has a sure-fire stunt at his disposal and he makes shrewd use of it. He is a first-rate pianist, and in the eight seasons that he has also been conducting he has appeared frequently as piano soloist and conductor rolled into one. As guest leader with the visiting Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night he performed what might be called his two-in-one turn.
Adolf Hitler's warning of intensified warfare against the British arteries of trade is already being implemented.

BERLIN, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The sinking of more than 250,000 tons of shipping in "the past few days" by German sea raiders attacking convoys was announced by the High Command today. Of this figure, more than 200,000 tons were said to have been destroyed by submarines in "cooperative" attacks.

Production of crude oil in the United States last week averaged 3,629,650 barrels daily, a decrease of 8,450 from the 3,638,100 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The output was only 750 barrels more than the calculation of 3,628,900 daily by the Bureau of Mines for February.
LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 26 -- Royal Air Force squadrons made fresh and successful demonstrations of their attacking prowess yesterday and Monday night, according to the Air Ministry.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 25 -- A statement by the Union County grand jury today calling for a ban on all games of chance, including bingo, had its first effects tonight when three places here where bingo games were scheduled remained closed.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 25 -- After three weeks' proceedings a German military court at Bergen, Norway, sentenced to death yesterday ten Norwegians found guilty of spying for Great Britain, reports from Oslo revealed today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 25 -- The Minister of External Affairs, Sir Frederick Stewart, in a broadcast today said the official Japanese spokesman had assured the Australian Minister in Tokyo within the last few days that Japan's intentions were essentially peaceful and that she would not initiate any aggressive policy in the Pacific.
BERLIN, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The German High Command communique said today:

R.C. Champollion of the Harvard Club, the second-seeded contender, was eliminated from the Class C championship of the National Squash Tennis Association at the Harvard Club last night by Nat Cohen of the Shelton Club, 15 -- 13, 7 -- 15, 15 -- 10.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that 164 companies with assets of about $63,800,000 and debts totaling $53,200,000 had been the subject of reorganization proceedings started in the last half of 1940 under Chapter X of the Bankruptcy Act.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 25 -- This part of the Middle West is just beginning to get its teeth into the defense program. It is becoming a second line of defense in the national mobilization of industry.

Another intracity basketball double-header will be offered to local court followers when New York University clashes with St. John's and City College takes on Manhattan at Madison Square Garden tonight. For both the Violets and the Beavers these are important engagements for more reasons than one.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The International Rubber Regulation Committee today fixed the rubber export quota for the three months ending June 30 at 100 per cent of basic quotas to meet "special requirements'' of the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 25 -- Under the second heading of the theme the national convention of the American Association of School Administrators -- "to provide for the common defense, to promote the general welfare, to secure the blessings of liberty" -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, criticized today American industrialists for refusing to raise wages from defense profits.

A fund of $1,000,000 for the relief of British retailers and their employes will be sought in a drive to be conducted by the National Retail Dry Goods Association among its members on behalf of the Drapers Chamber of Trade of Great Britain and Ireland, it was announced yesterday.

An investigation of all social studies textbooks now in use in the New York City school system that have been termed by Dr. Ralph West Robey as un-American, critical of our form of government and system of private enterprise, or "subversive," was ordered yesterday by Dr. John E. Wade, acting Superintendent of Schools.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson has advised the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the strength of the Army Air Corps is nearly 4,000 planes.

After an ownership of more than twenty years, Vincent Astor has sold the twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 105-9 West Seventy-second Street, between Broadway and Columbus Avenue to the Siegel Land and Improvement Company Solomon Siegel, president.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Congressional leaders on the legislative situation as it concerns the lease-lend bill and at a press conference expressed his opposition to peace negotiations until the war is won.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 25 -- Despite the usual crop of rumors that the Germans have now actually entered Bulgaria in force, the situation there appears to have eased slightly tonight, and some Sofia sources predict that military occupation may be postponed for some time.

The current controversy over high school textbooks in social science offers the public an opportunity to clarify its thinking on an important subject. Certain propositions may be offered as a possible guide to such thinking.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Discussion in this space of an amendment proposed by Representative Dewey of Illinois to H.R. 1776 and rejected in the House, has produced numerous letters in some of which it is contended that the measure will not achieve the purpose for which it is designed.

Frank Gold, 35 years old, an aide of George Scalise in Local 32B of the Building Service Employes International Union of scrubwomen, porters and elevator operators, was found guilty yesterday by a General Sessions jury of eight women and four men, with a woman foreman, of extorting $5,950 in three years from three real estate men.

In one of the largest leasing transactions in the financial district in the past ten years, the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company has leased four major floors, comprising more than two acres of floor space, in the Manhattan Company building at 40 Wall Street.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25 -- The Yankees' reconstruction campaign has claimed Ellsworth (Babe) Dahlgren, first base successor to the old Iron Man, Lou Gehrig, as its latest victim.

The loss taken by the New York Stock Exchange for 1940 was $981,348, although the actual cash loss was only $43,000, according to the annual report submitted yesterday by William McC. Martin Jr., president. While the gross income of the Exchange and its subsidiaries declined by $246,816 from the 1939 figure, expenses were cut $461,956, thus reducing the total loss to the current figures from the $1,149,373 in 1939.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Defend the Balkans with British troops or march on Tripoli and mop up the Italians in Africa -- that is the decision the British Government will make in a few days. The government probably will act when it has received the recommendations of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and General Sir John G. Dill, chief of the Imperial Staff, now on tour in Turkey and the Near East.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist organization of America, announced yesterday that it would ship five tons of surgical instruments, clothing, medical supplies and vitamins to Palestine to meet the needs of its vastly increasing war emergency health program in that part of the Near East.

From the tips of their toes to the crowns of their hats the manikins who paraded in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton yesterday at the luncheon hour were carefully "ensembled." They stepped out in I. Miller's shoes. Each pair of shoes told a story of good-looking Spring footwear.

The Thomas Jefferson basketball team, with Harry Boykoff leading the attack with 32 tallies, clinched the Section 1, Brooklyn P.S.A.L. title by crushing Alexander Hamilton, 72 to 27, at Jefferson yesterday. Boykoff, in eight P.S.A.L. games, has accumulated a total of 138 points.

The stock market made yesterday a further marked extension of its gains in the last few minutes of business. The basis for the late rise was the passage by the House of amendments designed to liberalize certain provisions of the excess profits tax law.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The five "model" defense bills, sponsored by the Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation, were opposed today at a public hearing by representatives of both the A.F. of L. and the C.I.O.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Shooting one under women's par, Miss Jane Cothran of Greenville, S.C., finalist in the 1940 national, today annexed medal honors in the sixteenth annual South Atlantic championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 26 (UP) -- The Japanese Government "is not pessimistic regarding the future of its diplomacy toward the United States," Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye said today in a formal statement.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- C.I.O. workers at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Lackawanna mill set a strike deadline for 9 P.M. tomorrow and heard a leader assert that the union was well enough organized to "close every plant Bethlehem has."

Seeking to end litigation over the status of war veterans now holding provisional appointments in the Welfare Department, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that civil service examinations would be given to qualify the present jobholders.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The House passed by voice vote and sent to the Senate today a bill to remove inequities from the Excess Profits Tax Act passed last Autumn.

Coming on March 4 from the firm of Wifred Funk is a novel about the Civil War entitled "Hang My Wreath." The author is Ward Weaver. Current reports are that Mr. Weaver and F. Van Wyck Mason, who has been doing a series of novels published by Lippincott about the Revolution, of which "Stars on the Sea" is the latest, are so closely connected that they may be the same person.

PARIS, Feb. 20 (delayed; via Berlin) -- Sixty per cent of the Bank of France's gold reserves -- approximately 60,000,000,000 francs was sent to the United States and the remaining 40,000,000,000 francs was sent to Dakar, Senegal, the newspaper Matin reveals today.

Instead of closing its Broadway career Saturday night at the Guild, Elmer Rice's "Flight To the West" is to take a week's vacation and then reopen a week from Monday at the Majestic Theatre and at popular prices. Its sponsors will be a triumvirate -- the Playwrights' Company, producers of record; Lee Shubert and Louis Schaffer.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 25 -- People of the United States and all over the world are "sick" of politicians and are "through or about through with catch phrases that comprise the equipment of the mind political," Wendell L. Willkie, 1940 Republican nominee for President, told a crowd which crowded the chamber of the House of Representatives today.

Godfrey Haggard, the British Consul General here, and Mrs. Haggard will be guests of honor at the dance to be given Friday night at the Savoy-Plaza by members of the Elmira College Club of New York. Net proceeds from the party will be applied to the club's fund for supplies to be shipped to England through the British War Relief Society, Inc.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill has informed Japan's Foreign Minister that "there can be no question of compromise or parley" in Britain's war with the Axis, a cheering House of Commons was informed today.

Playground facilities are being planned to cover the sewage treatment tanks at the proposed Owls Head sewage treatment plant in Brooklyn, it was disclosed yesterday when a model of the plant was placed on exhibition in the Department of Public Works offices in the Municipal Building.

CADIZ, Spain, Feb. 25 -- The provincial orphanage at Seville yesterday completed arrangements in advance of other beneficiaries and served its 4,000 children the first whole-wheat bread made from flour the United States has given to the people of Spain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Mehmet Nunir Ertegun, the Turkish Ambassador, conferred today with Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, for what was believed to be the purpose of explaining the Turkish-Bulgarian non-aggression pact, in view of conflicting views published regarding it in this country.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Feb. 25 -- New Zealand's industries continued to expand in the first six months of the war, the Industries and Commerce Minister, D.G. Sullivan, reported today. More than 108,000 persons were employed last year at wages of the equivalent of $73,000,000 and products sold for $421,000,000, a record.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The strike vote at the Lackawanna plant of Bethlehem Steel stimulated activity on the part of officials of the Office of Production Management today in the move to set up a national mediation board for the defense industries as soon as possible.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 25 (UP) -- British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and General Sir John Dill, Chief of the Imperial General Staff, arrived in Turkey late today for consultations on joint defense of the Dardanelles and perhaps Greek Salonika against Germany's threatened Balkan sweep.

Four Eastern "riders," led by Torger Tokle, 22-year-old Norwegian sensation, are flying today to the Pacific Northwest, where they will seek national ski-jumping championships this week-end. In addition to Tokle, who will carry the colors of the Norway S.C., those who left last night aboard a United airliner for Seattle were Arthur Devlin, Jay Rand and George Sherwood, representatives of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds, and their manager and coach, Stanley Benham.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25 -- The lake front garden at Thatchcote was the setting for a luncheon given today by Mrs. Benjamin Rogers for Mrs. Helen Appleton Read of New York, who lectured on art late this afternoon at the Four Arts Galleries.

The Socony Vacuum Tanker Men's Association, an independent union that won bargaining rights in a run-off election conducted by the National Labor Relations Board, announced last night that it had opened negotiations with the Socony Vacuum Oil Company for a wage and working agreement for approximately 1,000 men employed on thirty-four tankers.
BERLIN, Wednesday, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A number of British bombers dropped explosive and incendiary bombs at random in Western Germany last night, D.N.B. [official German news agency] declared today.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Most sections in the stock markets remained dull today, the turnover being small. Gilt-edge securities were 1/8 point lower where changed. Buyers still refused to be tempted by large home-rail yields, and junior shares all went lower again.
SAN DIEGO, CALIF., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Four Navy fliers perished in the crash of two dive bombers last night, one on land and one at sea.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 -- An itinerant shower cracked down on this tropical resort with a fine fury during the early hours today and among other things raised considerable havoc with the Giants' training activities. For the rain deluged the ball park and made it impossible to play the nine-inning ball game which Manager Bill Terry had mapped out as the day's major event.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The State Income Tax Bureau offered today a set of definitions on the difference between stock dividends and dividends from stock. It was disclosed that a stock dividend is a dividend paid to shareholders in the form of certificates of stock; a dividend from stock is a dividend paid to shareholders in cash or property.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Unattached Syracuse came down to Ithaca tonight to defeat Cornell's Eastern League basketball team in an overtime thriller, 33 to 32.

If the person who lost a brand new Jefferson nickel in front of 1772 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, will call at the Property Clerk's office at Brooklyn Police Headquarters and properly identify the coin, it will be returned to him. However, if the nickel is not claimed within six months, it will become the property of Louis Posner, 42 years old, a postman who found it while making his rounds yesterday. That's the law.

A need for new housing facilities for defense workers employed at the Brooklyn Navy Yard is reported by Oliver A. Gottschalk, Acting WPA Administrator in New York, on the basis of figures contained in a housing survey of the district carried out as part of a WPA research project.

Citations honoring four men and a woman prominent in varied fields for their activities in combating racial and religious intolerance were awarded last night at a dinner forum held under the auspices of the Protestant Digest Associates at the Roosevelt Hotel.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 25 -- Uneasiness over the possibility that negotiations between Canada and the United States over the St. Lawrence development scheme may result in proposals harmful to Canadian interests has been repeatedly shown during the past two days by speakers in the debate on the external affairs estimates, and today this expressed uneasiness drew from Prime Minister King the statement that the government "would not permit the alienation of power from Canada."

The number of out-of-town buyers reported in the market last week was 1,026, as against 940 in the preceding week and 776 in the same period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Visiting buyers recorded yesterday totaled 334 which compared with 523 for last Tuesday.

It is seldom that a young player who wins the Naumburg Foundation reward is lacking in talent or in adequate preparation for his public debut. This was demonstrated anew when Thomas Richner, the latest pianist to win the Foundation's award of a public recital, made his appearance under its auspices yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

The vacant plot 60 by 96.8 feet at 21 Bay Twenty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased from Ethal King Comstock by the Eden Construction Company, which will improve it with one-family dwellings. Slomka Brothers, Inc., were the brokers.

The Treasury yesterday made its first offering of fully taxable bonds under the terms of the new Public Debt Act of 1941. It was an operation that had been awaited with a good deal of interest in financial circles, as providing the first clue to the course of Government bond prices under the new conditions.

William White, presiding yesterday at an annual meeting of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad for the first time since he was elected president, told the stockholders that the company was investigating its leases to determine what property could be retired for economy.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Moderate supply of 18,000 head of hogs met with fair demand today, prices advancing 5 to 10 cents in nearly all classes. Top of $8 was paid sparingly, however, and most medium weight hogs brought $7.65 to $7.90, the same as yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 25 -- Wendell L. Willkie told the Legislature today that no man could say with any finality that our way of life would survive its present ordeal.

Interest on margin accounts is carrying the average New York Stock Exchange commission house, according to a survey made by the management engineering firm of Stevenson, Jordan Harrison and published in the current issue of The Exchange, house organ of the institution.

LONDON, Feb. 25. -- Five ships -- four British and one allied -- totaling 23,986 tons were known to have been destroyed by a German sea raider off the Azores on Feb. 12, the British Admiralty stated today. The engagement was the one in which, according to Berlin, the Nazi raider sank fourteen vessels totaling 86,000 tons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- After a conference today at the White House with President Roosevelt, Administration leaders in the Senate decided to make their test stand on the lease-lend bill in opposition to the Ellender amendment designed to prohibit the sending of American troops beyond the limits of the Western Hemisphere. They expect to win and also to defeat any other amendments that would substantially tie the hands of the President in foreign policy.

Imposition of formal priorities on aluminum, announced on Monday by the Office of Production Management, had wide repercussions throughout American industry yesterday, although the step was not unexpected.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 25 -- Government instructions to all provinces continued today to direct the adoption of all measures, under the military control already decreed, to maintain order during the general elections to be held next Sunday.

OTTAWA, Feb. 25 -- Replying to a question regarding Canadian relations with France, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King this evening said that it was the desire of his government to maintain with the people of France as friendly relations as possible.

Senior class students in law schools and medical schools who have received deferment from military service to the end of their academic year, as provided in Selective Service Regulations, may obtain an additional deferment to enable them to complete State bar or medical examinations, it was announced yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, director of selective service for New York City.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The campaigns of 1932, 1936 and 1940, as well as developments since the last election, were refought today as the Assembly passed, by a party vote, the Wilson bill making Thanksgiving Day the last Thursday in November.
While the number of stake races at Saratoga will be reduced next Summer, the value of the more important events will be substantially increased.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday consolidated net income of $13,433,387, after all operating expenses, taxes and other changes, for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31, compared with $13,499,459 in the corresponding period a year ago.

DETROIT, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Hank Greenberg's draft board placed the hard-hitting Detroit Tiger outfielder, most valuable player in the American League at a salary said to be $36,000 a year, in Class 1 today -- with those available for immediate military training under the Selective Service Act.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- A resolution introduced in the Senate today called on the Appellate Division of the Second Department to undertake a "thorough and complete investigation'' of alleged un-American activities and conduct of Herbert A. O'Brien, justice of the Domestic Relations Court in Queens. The author was William J. Murray of Manhattan, a Democrat.

A number of advertising concerns and women's apparel establishments were among the firms leasing new quarters in the activity reported yesterday. Leading leases called for space along and near Madison Avenue and on Fifty-seventh Street.
LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The text of an Air Ministry announcement today follows:

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Wednesday, Feb. 26 (AP) -- France bolstered her military establishment in Indo-China today with a detachment of naval, army and air force officers from Dakar, Senegal, West Africa.

With color as its main theme the Museum of Costume Art, in the International Building of Rockefeller Center, has staged an unusual exhibition of gowns of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Selected from the richly stocked storerooms of the museum they represent styles from America, France, England and Austria.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Feb. 25 -- Eleven thousand Federalized National Guardsmen in training here, including members of three New York regiments, were roused at 5:40 o'clock this morning and called our for assembly twenty minutes later as the thirteen-week intensive training program in fundamentals began.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 25 (UP) -- Acting Prime Minister A.W. Fadden said today that Australia was fully prepared to defend herself and warned that "the further south certain people move, the further north Australia will move."

An influential correspondent criticizes, as politically inexpedient, the "timing" of my advocacy in your issue of Feb. 18 of maritime cooperation with Great Britain on the ground that only 17 per cent of our people want immediate war. But 17 per cent of such hotheads is an amazing figure, for surely no one ever wants war at any time.

The epidemic of measles that began in New York City about Jan. 1 touched a new high last week, when 4,072 new cases were reported, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, was told yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the Health Department.

MOSCOW, Feb. 25 (UP) -- The Supreme Soviet tonight endorsed a 26 per cent increase in Russia's military budget because of "the tenseness abroad" and doubled the income taxes that millions of peasants must pay for a speed-up of arms production and defense measures.

Attendance at motion picture theatres in the United States showed a drop of 5,000,000 persons weekly during 1940, according to the annual fact-finding report of the Motion Picture Theatre Producers and Distributors of America, headed by Will H. Hays.
HAVANA, Feb. 25 -- Both pleasure and pain came to the Brooklyn training camp today.

TOKYO, Feb. 25 -- Criticisms of Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's unconventional personal approach to British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden regarding British-Japanese problems are silenced tonight by satisfaction over the response of Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

Wholesalers, chains, voluntary groups, supermarkets and retail grocers' associations have rushed to the defense of Maine's potato branding law and potato tax legislation, currently under fire from politicians in the State, and their endorsements are being run in an advertising campaign appearing in Maine papers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Prices of wheat started to decline at the opening today and at no time were they above the finish of the previous day. The market was regarded as showing the effect of the heavy short covering of the previous day and many professional traders who covered their short lines yesterday showed a disposition to put them out again today.

KHARTUM, Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, Feb. 24 (Delayed) (UP) -- Capture of the village of Cubcub by a British column driving southward into Eritrea from the Sudan today gave the British forces control of almost half of Eritrea's 46,000 square miles after a month of fighting.

Trailing until eight minutes of the second half had elapsed, Columbia's basketball team staged a belated spurt and turned back Yale, 38 -- 31, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League encounter before 1,000 persons at Morningside Heights last night. By winning the Lions gained undisputed possession of second place, breaking a tie with Cornell.

PARIS (Delayed; Via Berlin), Feb. 21 -- After Admiral Francois Darlan's lightning visit to Paris, where he spent twenty-four hours seeing the heads of big business as well as receiving a delegation of representatives of the principal labor unions, the Paris press expressed its bitter disappointment and has taken up once more the violent anti-Vichy campaign.

IT is taken for granted in this corner that, whether it's a ball player, boxer, skilled mechanic or day laborer whose number comes up in the draft, the draft board officials, with all the evidence at hand, are the best judges of whether the man in question should be inducted immediately, receive reasonable deferment for some particular reason or be rejected on general principles.

The radio industry may suffer an aluminum shortage seriously affecting consumer products as a result of the Office of Production Management's action Monday in reserving first call on the metal for the expanding defense program, inquiry in radio circles disclosed yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 25 (UP) -- Premier General Ion Antonescu today proclaimed a three-day nationwide plebiscite, beginning March 12, to "express approval or disapproval" of his military dictatorship, which has been strengthened since the Iron Guard rebellion and anti-Jewish disorders last month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Establishment of local civic "financial clinics," underwritten by small government grants, to aid small enterprises in defense industries or other businesses was advocated today before the Temporary National Economic Committee by Sumner T. Pike of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday 2 to 8 points in moderately active dealings on support from the trade in the near months and from professional traders in the new crop options. The feature of trading was the irregular movements of the distant months, which backed and filled on changing sentiment on the possible effects of farm legislation that may be enacted by the present Congress.

Adoption by the House yesterday of amendments to the corporation excess profits tax is a cause for genuine encouragement. These were proposed by the Ways and Means Committee, an encouraging fact of it self. In the last year the increase in corporate taxes has been a drastic one.

Directors of Remington Rand, Inc., in addition to declaring yesterday a 20-cent dividend on the common stock with the regular quarterly dividend of $1.12 1/2 on the preferred, authorized an increase of 158,000 shares in the company's outstanding $1 par value common stock to a total of 1,742,895 shares.
AMSTERDAM, Feb. 25 -- The Bourse was stagnant today and the ] trend was irregular, though toward I the close a firmer tendency devel -- I oped. ]

Three hundred and fifty young persons in a number of American colleges, including Smith, Vassar and Hamilton, have forwarded to Representatives in Congress a petition asking for "full American support to the forces fighting nazism."

A fifty-five-minute interval between the mile run and the two-mile relay in the twentieth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. championship meet at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night is regarded as sufficient for Leslie MacMitchell to be at his best in both events.

On Alumni Day President Seymour told the brethren that John Milton Berdan, a member of the Yale faculty since 1903, a professor since 1923, Emily Salford Professor of English Literature since 1927, would retire in June. More than a generation of Yalensians have heard this news with affectionate regret.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 25 -- De Ormond (Tuss) McLaughry, recently appointed head coach of football at Dartmouth, speaking before a sports night gathering held in his honor tonight, announced his entire coaching staff.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 25 -- This city is gayly decorated tonight, and all preparations have been made to receive Dr. Alexander Cincar-Markovitch, the Yugoslav Foreign Minister, who is due to arrive at 9 o'clock tomorrow morning to return the visit made to Yugoslavia by Count Stephen Csaky, the late Hungarian Foreign Minister.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26 -- The oldest Yankee of them all in point of service came to terms with the former champions today. Catcher Bill Dickey at last is in the fold, three days overdue at this training base.

HISTORY may or may not repeat itself -- but historians, as Philip Guedalla once observed, invariably repeat each other. One historian who will certainly be quoted when the unfolding diplomatic history of these decades is written is William E Dodd, whose diary as America's Ambassador to Nazi Germany from 1983 to 1938 is published today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 26 -- Culminating an amazing two-month campaign and an even more amazing two-day advance, the British forces in Italian Somaliland have occupied Mogadiscio, the colony's capital and only good seaport excepting Kismayu, which fell on Feb. 14.

MILFORD, Conn., Feb. 26 -- Thomas A. Edison Lake, son of Simon Lake, one of the inventors of the submarine, said today that discussions are underway with the United States Navy Department for the construction of a test model of an aero-dynamic torpedo boat which he has designed.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26 -- Henry Picard, the golfing stylist from Hershey, Pa., led a wholesale assault on par in the $5,000 St. Petersburg open today with a first round 66.

Nigeria, British West African colony, has sent 10,000 troops, consisting of infantry and artillery, to the East African front, Colonel Arthur S. Mavrogordato, Police Commissioner of Nigeria, revealed yesterday on his arrival from Jamaica. British West Indies, on the United Fruit steamship Veragua.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 26 -- Yale scored a 55-20 victory over Columbia in an Eastern Intercollegiate ate Swimming League meet tonight to tie Princeton for the lead in the title race. The Elis and Tigers both are undefeated in four meets.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, and General Sir John G. Dill, chief of the British Imperial General Staff, met diplomats and Turkish leaders here today in conferences that are expected to determine the course of British-Turkish action in the Balkan crisis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Senator Norris of Nebraska, one of the six Senators who voted against the declaration of war by the United States in 1917, declared in an address over the networks of the National Broadcasting Company tonight, that he was in favor of the lease-lend bill as "necessary to keep us out of war."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Congress learned today that construction work at the military reservation at Pine Camp in Northern New York would cost $20,214,098 instead of $5,623,650 as estimated by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP) -- The Temporary National Economic (Monopoly) Committee received today a 447-page report indicating that the vast assets of life insurance companies "are only available for big business."

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Viscount Halifax, Ambassador to Washington; Sir Samuel Hoare, Ambassador to Madrid, and Sir Stafford Cripps, Ambassador to Moscow, are serving without salary, according to a White Paper issued today. But they receive "expenses," for which the grants are: Washington, 16,250; Madrid, 6,625, and Moscow, 6,250.

A strong technical position enabled the stock market to make yesterday a further extension of its previous gains, but it was with considerable difficulty that the additions were retained. Whenever there was a drying up of demand, it was noticeable that the list showed a tendency to revert to ease.

Sharpest department store sales increases for cities on which data late available were recorded in January by Norfolk, Va., with volume 51 per cent ahead of a year ago, and Springfield, Ill., with a gain of 50 per cent, according to figures issued by the Federal Reserve Board.

ANKARA, Feb. 26 (UP) -- The prime objects of the visit to Turkey of British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and General Sir John G. Dill, Chief of the British Imperial General Staff, according to information here, are:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 26 -- The most alarming sort of reports continue to emanate from Bulgaria, but as far as can be discovered after careful check-ups with diplomats and responsible persons both in Belgrade and Sofia they still appear greatly exaggerated.

Ten jurors had been chosen yesterday for the General Sessions trial of Milton B. Logan, 50 years old, in $65,000 in alleged frauds on patrons of the now defunct American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., when Judge Owen W. Bohan adjourned the proceeding until today.

In the biggest upset to date in the ever-unpredictable intracity basketball series, St. John's vanquished N.Y.U. before the startled gaze of 11,533 spectators in Madison Square Garden last night and did it in mighty thorough fashion. The Redmen, red-hot all the way, toppled the Violets by 58 to 41 for their finest performance of the campaign.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- When Controller Tremaine, who has been ill, awakes tomorrow morning at his home in Buffalo he will find at his bedside a huge floral offering from the attaches of his office, indicating that his seventieth birthday has not been forgotten.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- In January, a total of $415,699,000 of securities became effectively registered under the Securities Act of 1933, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. This compared with $322,618,000 for December and with $146,482,000 for January, 1940.

Two gasoline station properties in separate Nassau County communities, now operated by the Cities Service Oil Company, together with two adjoining vacant plots, have been sold by an estate and immediately resold.

BERLIN, Feb. 26 -- The German High Command today announced for the first time the participation of German troops in the North African campaign. A German motorized advance patrol made contact with a British motorized patrol in Libya, it is stated, and in the ensuing skirmish a number of British armored cars were destroyed and several prisoners taken.

George Mount, vice-president of the Otis Elevator Company, has leased an apartment in the building at 447 East Fifty-seventh Street through Hickernell-Romeyn, Inc., broker, and Wm. A. White Sons, agents.

OTTAWA, Feb. 26 -- With a plain statement of facts and figures, admitting some failures and claiming that in most instances production was up to and beyond schedule, Munitions Minister C.D. Howe this afternoon replied in Parliament to the barrage of criticism that has been leveled against his department in the press and in Parliament during the past two months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Lowell Mellett, director of the Office of Government Reports, told the House Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Department today that the Administration has "absolutely no plans" for censorship of the press or radio either now or in time of war.
College graduates and undergraduates are getting more and better-paying jobs, according to the figures of the Bureau of Occupations at Hunter College, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Today's British Air Ministry communique said:

Robert C. Stalney, chairman of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., issued yesterday a statement in which he said that nickel supplies available to the United States "have been brought to record heights" but they are not sufficient to meet immediate demand.

The City Planning Commission approved yesterday the plan submitted by Borough President John Cashmore for the improvement of the Brooklyn approach to the Brooklyn Bridge and included the project in a general plan of civic improvements in that section of the borough.
ATLANTA, Thursday, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The list of passengers aboard the missing Eastern Airlines sleeper plane overdue here was announced by the airline as follows:
