MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 -- Mrs. Alfred Stone of New York is chairman of the Highlanders Ball, which will be given at the Blackstone Hotel on March 8 to assist the British War Relief Society. A reception and tea for the committee was held at that hotel today.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 26 -- The spread of clashes between Kuomintang and Communist forces in North China was reported today in a Domei [Japanese news agency] dispatch from Taiyuan, Shansi Province. Domei said two battles occurred recently in Southeast Shansi between Nationalist and Communist forces numbering several thousand on each side.

Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, retiring commandant of the Third Naval District, yesterday threw all formality to the winds when he was inducted into the Dexter Fellows Tent, Circus Saints and Sinners Club of America, as a "fall guy."

Over the protest of David B. Costuma, Republican member, the Board of Elections rejected yesterday the nomination of Eugene P. Connolly, named by the local and county organizations of the American Labor party as candidate for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District to run for the vacancy caused by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson.

Affirming a statement made earlier in Chicago concerning his draft status, Hank Greenberg, Tiger outfielder, said: "I'll go when they call me," as he stepped from an American Airlines plane at La Guardia Field last night.

The Kips Bay Boys Club, which has provided recreation and citizenship training for boys from needy homes for twenty-six years, will have its annual benefit at the return performance of Ruth and Paul Draper on March 30 at the Guild Theatre.

As commander of the U-35 and U-139, Lothar von Arnauld de la Periere claimed to have sunk in six days in August, 1916, 93,000 tons of shipping. It is believed that altogether he was responsible for the sinking of 200 ships totaling more than 500,000 tons.

BOSTON, Feb. 26 -- Harvard's hockey team gained its second victory of the season tonight at the Garden at the expense of Army, which is expected to become a regular rival of the Crimson in the future. Army recently was elected a member of the Quadrangular Ice Hockey League, which will become a pentagonal circuit, but its admission to the group has not been announced officially.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26 -- Rita Hayworth was named today for the feminine lead in Columbia's long-delayed "Our Wife," which John M. Stahl will produce and direct as his first picture at the studio, starting about April 1. The scenario, which has been in work at Columbia since August, 1938, is based on a play by Lillian Day and Lyon Mearson, staged with Rose Hobart and Humphrey Bogart in 1933.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- A public hearing on the bills to carry out Governor Lehman's recommendation for the diversion of $60,000,000 from the grade-crossing fund for improvement and reconstruction of highways and parkways in the State and on the counter-proposal for a $200,000,000 highway-parkway bond issue to be spent over the next five years will be held on Wednesday.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 27 -- Total acceptance by French Indo-China within this week of Japan's proposals for a new frontier with Thailand is demanded in the Japanese press this morning with strident warnings against delay or evasion or interference by third powers.

A warning against "revival of appraisals which are too high and loans which are excessive" was issued by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, at the conference of realty appraisers of the metropolitan district held yesterday in the Commodore Hotel under the sponsorship of the New York State Society of Real Estate Appraisers.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The combined force of London and New York insurance companies is supporting the British blockade of Germany, German-occupied countries and Italy, it was disclosed here today.

An Eastern Airlines sleeper plane en route from La Guardia Field to Brownsville, Texas, with thirteen passengers and a crew of three was overdue at Atlanta, Ga., early this morning more than two hours after it was scheduled to arrive at that city at 12:55 A.M.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26 -- A long session at batting practice, a six-inning intra-mural game and a final fielding drill wound up Colonel Bill Terry's preparations today as his Giants embarked for Havana. On Friday they will open a three-game series there with the Dodgers.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 26 (AP) -- An official British announcement said today:

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 27 -- All day yesterday and again last night British planes pounded away at the invasion bases in the German-occupied Channel ports. According to the Air Ministry, one squadron leader reported that "the sky over the Channel was full of planes -- all British."

ROME, Feb. 26 -- John T. Whitaker, Rome correspondent of The Chicago Daily News, was requested by the authorities today to leave Italy. No specific complaint was made except that "the general tone of his dispatches was displeasing."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The House Rules Committee balked today at approving new defense housing legislation which some members said might mean that industrial workers would have extra "frills" at their homes which were not given the men in uniform.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 27 -- Large numbers of German planes flew over Great Britain yesterday, coming on in a steady flow long after dark, yet so much territory did they cover that nowhere was a heavy raid reported. For several hours in the evening it was feared that they would converge on some town, but midnight found the great majority of raiders back home.

Eight settlements have been reached in the Prudence-Bonds Corporation difficulties, according to a reliable source, and a hearing has been called for tomorrow before the United States Circuit Court of Appeals to approve them and other settlements which are expected to save the bondholders several hundreds of thousands of dollars.

BERLIN, Feb. 26 (AP) -The signatories of the Axis tripartite pact -- Germany, Italy and Japan -- are ready to strike back at any American armed intervention in their "lebensraeume" (living spaces), the

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 26 -- Fifteen years' freedom during which he married and became the father of a son ended here today for Frank M. Lang, 42 years old, a fugitive from Clinton prison, Dannemora, N.Y. He waived extradition before Judge Edward A. McGrath and started immediately for Dannemora.

Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council, yesterday accused Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes of having made false statements about him on Tuesday night in an attack on opponents of President Roosevelt's foreign policy. Mr. Hart's statement follows:

Since Torger Tokle, 22-year-old Norwegian sensation, started his record-smashing career on jumping hills throughout this country the question has often been asked, "How far can a jumper travel through the air and how fast is it possible to travel on skis?"

Lew Jenkins and Lou Ambers, who will meet in a ten-round over[the-weight bout at Madison Square :Garden tomorrow night, were re[ported ready for their encounter following long workouts yesterday. Both refrained from donning the i gloves, but Ambers had twelve rounds of floor exercises at Summit, N. J., while Jenkins did ten rounds of similar work at Pompton Lakes, N. J.

Letters have been sent to member stores by the Mutual Buying Syndicate urging them to protest against changes in terms which several woolen blanket mills have announced. The communication advises the stores that these mills have changed their "accustomed" terms by approximately 1 1/2 per cent, or more than 2 per cent on sales, which was held to represent a "hidden price advance."

Who is likely to make chief use of the Public Library's 35,000 bound volumes of newspaper files in their own separate home away from the main building? Lawyers frequently find it necessary to consult old newspapers, but the steadiest customers may turn out to be the historians.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Five contracts aggregating $22,255,000 for plant expansions for airplane propellers and ammunition cups and cartridge cases had been cleared by the Office of Production Management, the War Department stated today.

According to THE TIMES, former Justice Joseph M. Proskauer proposes that Americans adopt "a new Hippocratic oath," the idea being that we should, at this time, consecrate ourselves to the ideals of tolerance and human fellowship.
The 23-year-old passenger liner Orizaba was sold by its owners yesterday to the United States Army for transporting troops and cargo, it was disclosed last night.
The liner Siboney of the American Export Line will arrive today from Lisbon and Bermuda. On board are Paul A. Tierney, Garcia Arias, Princess Croy, S.X. Wu, Chan Saopong and Wau Saopong.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 26 -- A portrait of Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, former acting president of Smith College and a member of the board of trustees, was unveiled today at a special session of the Smith College Alumnae Council. Gift of Mrs. Williams V. Schevill, '00, the portrait is a pastel drawing made by Mr. Schevill.
BERLIN, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The German High Command said in a communique today:

DETROIT, Feb. 26 -- The Ford Motor Company, which has millions of dollars worth of national defense contracts, is virtually the only major unit of the automobile industry which does not have some form of contract with labor unions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The gigantic size of America's arms production job was emphasized today by a survey indicating that contracts already placed totaled about $15,000,000,000, more than six times the estimated value of the automobile industry's entire output for 1939.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Increasing labor disputes in the steel, automobile, textile and coal industries were viewed with anxiety today by defense officials lest the nation's rearming effort be hindered.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Commander Theodore Gordon Ellyson, who risked his life in the first plane ever projected from a catapult, was honored posthumously today when the Navy announced that the new auxiliary field at the Pensacola (Fla.) Naval Air Station would be named for him. One of the new destroyers now under construction also will be named the Ellyson.

After opening unchanged to 4 points above Tuesday's close and advancing a few points further, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday developed an easier tone and final quotations were up 1 to off 3 points. The range of price movements narrowed to 6 points and trading decreased.

ROME, Feb. 26 -- The thesis contained in a book on racism, "Erbpflege und Christentum" ["Race Culture and Christianity"] by the German writer I. Koltz, is branded by the Osservatore Romano as defensible only "in a system of vulgar materialism and brutal paganism."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Military Affairs Committee reported today the start of an investigation into the Army's defense program as the House began debate on a $1,533,439,702 bill providing funds for the construction of the Army's training camps and the Navy's expanding bases in the Atlantic and Pacific.
BERLIN, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 22 shows the following changes from the report of Feb. 15 in thousands of reichsmarks:

GENEVA, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- Asserting that he would welcome "active service with the Marines" and prefer a return to teaching to continuing "in any college presidency," Dr. William Alfred Eddy, president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges, showed his support today of the stand taken yesterday by two members of the faculty who resigned and another who said he would not accept reappointment.

Dr. Edward K. Barsky, chairman of the United American Spanish Aid Committee, announced yesterday that its subsidiary project, the American Rescue Ship Mission, had made another appeal to the British Government to issue a sailing warrant for the steamship Lovcen to transfere 450 Spanish refugees from French Morocco to Mexico.

WASHIGTON, Feb. 26 -- Jesse H. Jones, speaking as Federal Loan Administrator, stated today that the $8,500,000 government-owned tin smelter designed to smelt low-grade Bolivian ore, bought by the government for its strategic stock pile, would be erected at Texas City, Texas.

Hitler's "great news" of the sinking of 215,000 tons of British shipping within two days, amended later by the official German news agency to 217,000 tons and qualified still later by the High Command to the more general figure of "250,000 tons recently," comes down considerably when checked with British sources.

At Catskill yesterday there was a birthday celebration shared by so many people living elsewhere that it might almost be called national. George Cole Stebbins, maker of hymn tunes, was 95. An Orleans County farmer boy whose first musical studies were in an old-time singing school, he came to be a director of church singing.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 26 (UP) -- German Ambassador Edmund von Thermann, who returned from Berlin several days ago, warned Argentina tonight that her trade relations with the United States have no future and that American aid to Great Britain is only a British "dream."
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Governor and Mrs. Lehman will give their annual dinner for the judges of the Court of Appeals at the Executive Mansion tomorrow night.

The rate at which steel orders are being received indicates to the steel companies that they may be entirely sold out for the year by May 1, according to Iron Age, which finds that "on most products, books are almost completely filled for the second quarter and there have been large bookings for the third quarter and some for the fourth quarter.

ROME, Feb. 26 -- Premier Mussolini's speech of last Sunday continues to monopolize comment in the newspapers. The authorities are determined that the Italian people will realize its importance to them and will hence accept its arguments, promises and warnings.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Complete agreement on the details for establishing a division of commerce for New York State has been reached, and a bill carrying out the ideas of Republican legislators and Governor Lehman will be introduced tomorrow by Assemblyman Ives, majority leader.

HAVANA, Feb. 26 -- Today's report is somewhat in the nature of a mild word of warning to President Fulgencio Batista. His capital is on the verge of invasion by one Arnold (Mickey) Owen, recent member of the once-dreaded Gas-house Gang of St. Louis.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Germany's Channel invasion coast was ablaze with ragged flame early today as the Royal Air Force smashed at Nazi U-boat lairs and ports in a round-the-clock offensive. Some British quarters believed the raids might be the forerunner of "Coventry-type" British vengeance for massed German raids on British cities.

The Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation of 70 Pine Street has paid off the mortgage on Monticello, the home of Thomas Jefferson at Charlottesville, Va., which the foundation acquired in 1923 at a cost of $500,000, it was reported yesterday by Stuart G. Gibboney, president of the foundation.
Institutions and estates figured as sellers in most of the real estate deals reported in Manhattan yesterday. Several HOLC properties wore sold in the Bronx.

From early morning yesterday until after 9 o'clock last night a steady stream of Roman Catholics poured into St. Patrick's Cathedral for the distribution of ashes, in keeping with the Ash Wednesday practice of all Catholic churches. So large was the throng at the noon mass, when persons came from near-by places of business to worship and receive the ashes, that the great edifice was filled almost to overflowing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission acted today to prevent what it called "unreasonably high" steamship freight rates.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- C.I.O. workers at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Lackawanna plant, working on defense orders, struck tonight as last-minute efforts to avert the walkout failed.

An organization to mobilize the loyalty of Americans of German birth or German ancestry, similar to one that rendered effective service to the nation in the World War, will hold its first national conference here Sunday, with speakers representing the Federal Department of Justice, the Department of Labor and the Attorney General of New York State.

ROME, Feb. 26 -- German land forces have gone into action in Libya, it was announced in the Italian and German war bulletins today. Nazi motorized units clashed with British forces southeast of Agedabia, Libya. Thus the promise in both Premier Mussolini's and Reichsfuehrer Hitler's speeches of a greater German part in the Mediterranean is already coming true.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands (via Berlin), Feb. 26 -- Six civilians were killed and a number wounded today in clashes between the police and "disturbers of the peace," it was officially announced tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- The Army Quartermaster today awarded contracts for 15,500,000 yards of 36-inch herringbone twill cotton cloth. Bids on 20,000,000 yards of this material, or a similar quantity of blue denim, were opened here on Feb. 17, and twenty-four firms offered approximately 17,500,000 yards each.

Fresh from their great victory over the Bruins on Boston ice, where they snapped the greatest string in league history, the Rangers will oppose the Canadiens at Madison Square Garden tonight. Only 2 points behind the third-place Red Wings, the Rangers will launch their drive for that position in the National Hockey League at the same time that the Detroit sextet will be battling the Black Hawks at Chicago.

Defense is a state of mind as well as a state of the armed forces and of the forces of production. The United States of America in order to achieve a united state of defense must have a united state of mind -- a mind united for the purpose of defense.
MIAMI, Feb. 26 -- America is trying today to re-establish faith in our ability to do things, Charles F. Kettering, vice president of General Motors in charge of research, said here today.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, announced yesterday the appointment of a sponsoring committee for the "Presiding Bishop's Fund for World Relief," which was authorized by the last General Convention of the church It will carry on relief work among war refugees in all parts of the world.
The Standard Oil Company of Kentucky had a net profit for 1940 of $3,818,408 after depreciation, Federal and State income taxes and other charges, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 26 -- The industrial mobilization of this city for defense operations consisted largely of surveys of facilities to determine three facts. These have been finished, and they answer to a large degree these important questions:
The names of four new tenants were added yesterday to the rosters of buildings in Rockefeller Center.

New capital financing in behalf of the Cleveland Graphite Bronze Company will be carried out today with an offering to the public of 30,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value by F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., and Prescott, Jones Co., Inc.

Mogadiscio is the first Italian colonial capital to surrender to the British. A forlorn town of 30,000, it is not much of a capital. But it is the nerve center of an area of 194,000 square miles, with a population of more than a million. The coastline of Italian Somaliland reaches 1,500 miles from Kenya to the eastern horn of Africa on the Gulf of Aden, and the area is an empire in itself.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP) -- None of this country's merchant vessels can be spared for Great Britain, Maritime Commission officials said today.

Pablo Suarez y Roig, Cuban Consul General at New York, entertained with a reception yesterday afternoon in the Casino-on-the-Park of Essex House for members of a recently formed committee of consuls general of Latin-American countries.

VICHY, France, Feb. 26 -- Admiral William Leahy, United States Ambassador, will attend a banquet to be held at the University of Clermont-Ferrand March 15 as a part of a French-American demonstration of thanks to President Roosevelt for the relief that is being sent to France.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission amended today its plan of reorganization for the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to include the Old Colony Railroad in the reorganized New Haven system.

Argentina ranks as one of our best customers in Latin America, but her trade with this country is sadly out of balance. Last year, for example, we sold Argentina $107,000,000 of goods but bought only $83,000,000. With European trade dislocated, it becomes extremely difficult to balance this uneven trade, and Argentina is faced with a critical economic situation.

The proposal to shatter a tradition by admitting women to rooms in the Harvard Club of New York, which hitherto have been reserved strictly for the men members, has been voted upon favorably by an overwhelming majority of the club's members, according to announcement made yesterday.

Net profits of all member banks of the New York Federal Reserve District in ratio to capital funds averaged 4.3 per cent in 1940, compared with 4.0 per cent in 1939, Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, announced yesterday in the bank's annual compilation of the operating ratios of member bank.

Speaking as a member of a committee of life insurance executives, E. E. Rhodes, vice president of the ]/Iutul Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark, said yesterday that the suggestion in the report submitted to the Temporary National Economic Committee to the effect that life insurance funds be invested as venture or risk capital in new enterprises had been a matter of discussion for many years.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- Defense production at the General Electric plant was inspected today by William S. Knudsen, director of the Office of Production Management.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The first emission of New York State bonds for the financing of low-rental housing projects was scheduled for Tuesday, March 11, in an announcement today by Controller Tremaine. The securities will be fifty-year serial bonds, to a total of $19,600,000.

A survey was begun yesterday under the direction of Mayor La Guardia into the so-called "slave markets" in the Bronx, where women domestics and young boys, mostly Negroes, gather daily on a number of the borough's main thoroughfares in search of day-to-day housework.

Emanuel Feuermann, 'cellist, and Richard Borelli, Metropolitan Opera baritone, have been appointed to head respectively the chamber music and vocal departments of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, it was learned yesterday.

Egon Petri, the eminent Dutch pianist, gave his first recital of the season last night at Town Hall as the seventh event in the current Town Hall Endowment Series. Mr. Petri brought an evening of distinguished playing to an electrifying climax with a colossal performance of the six "Paganini Studies" of Liszt, which must go on record as one of the Winter's most exciting and brilliant musical achievements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Miss Virginia Frayser Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dorrance Yerkes Smith of Plainfield, N.J., was married here this afternoon to Wesley Vansant Disney, son of Representative and Mrs. Wesley E. Disney of Tulsa, Okla.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26 -- A selling plater, Betty's Bob, who could have been claimed for $1,600 or less in any of his previous dozen races, earned $1,850 today when he captured the $3,000 Lynwood Purse on the turf course. Mrs. R.E. Wingfield's 4-year-old son of Big Brand was a strong favorite with a big midweek crowd of 15,112 and finished the two miles in 3:31 1-5.

Contract pulp prices will remain unchanged for the next quarter, according to official announcement yesterday by Rayonier, Inc., largest producer of dissolving pulps and one of the largest producers of pulp for the paper industry. Similar action by other companies is anticipated.

OUT of the White Sox training camp at Pasadena, Calif., came the news that Manager Jimmy Dykes had banned ice skating by his players. Florida publicists should make something of that. From a distance, it seems like a knock at the California climate. But if the Pasadena Chamber of Commerce demands an explanation, doubtless Dykes will oblige.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 176 Broadway, was directed yesterday by Surrogate James A. Delehanty to post a $350,000 bond pending an appeal to the Appellate Division from his decision surcharging the company $689,652 in its administration of the estate of Cornelius J. Ryan, builder and real estate operator, who died April 20, 1911.

Isidore Grossman, president of Pitkin Dry Goods, Inc., 1679 Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn, must discharge his 22-year-old son, Bernard, from the employ of the store under an arbitration award by Aaron L. Solomon, 570 Seventh Avenue, in a dispute with the Retail Dry Goods Employes Union, Local 1102, C.I.O.
A protest by unionized employes of the Welfare Department against the city's investigation into alleged Communist domination of the department was rebuffed yesterday by Commissioner William Hodson.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 26 -- It was learned in well-informed quarters here tonight that Sir Stafford Cripps, British Ambassador to Moscow, was en route to Ankara, Turkey, by plane to see the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, and General Sir John G. Dill, chief of the British Imperial General Staff, sometime tomorrow or early Friday to report on the Russian attitude in face of the Balkan developments of the past three or four days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Acting upon the assurances of Senate and House leaders that the lease-lend bill will be passed without further substantial amendment, President Roosevelt took steps today looking to the transfer to Great Britain of all war supplies from the present stores of the Army and Navy which could be spared without crippling the American armed forces.

TOKYO, Feb. 26 -- Japan's part in the next phase of Axis policy is now being discussed in Berlin, it was learned today. Lieut. Gen. Hiroshi Oshima, Ambassador to Germany, spent Sunday at the villa of German Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop, and Zembei Horikiri, Ambassador to Rome, arrived at Berlin yesterday.

The Coordinating Council for French Relief was formed yesterday by fifteen organizations that have been raising funds to aid French children and prisoners of war at a meeting held at the French Chamber of Commerce, 4 East Fifty-second Street.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 -- Miss Jane Cothran of Greenville, S.C., medalist, won her first-round match in the sixteenth South Atlantic golf championship on the Ormond Beach course today from Mrs. T. Schluderberg of Baltimore, 3 and 1.

"So Ends Our Night," the Albert Lewin-David Loew film version of the Erich Maria Remarque novel, "Flotsam," will open this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. The story, which is set in contemporary Europe, stars Fredric March, Margaret Sullavan and Frances Dee.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 26 -- Thomas Gallagher, 31 years old, of 44 Beverly Road, Kensington, L.I., was held without bail for action of the grand jury when arraigned this morning on a first-degree manslaughter charge in the fatal shooting of John Gormley, 34, of 136-14 Thirty-fifth Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- Dismissal of the Apex Hosiery Company's $1,171,957 damage suit against the American Federation of Hosiery Workers and its Philadelphia branch was asked of Common Pleas Court today by the defendants, on the ground that the issue should be arbitrated under the contract between the company and the union.
BERLIN, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Germans emphasized the heightened tempo of their sea warfare toay with accounts of new blows against British shipping.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- As a result of the market's reaction to recent moderate receipts, hog producers cut supplies again today sending prices 10 cents higher. An $8.05 fop was paid sparingly, and most choice medium weight hogs sold at S7.75 to $8. Pork loin demand failed to revive, reflecting the opening of the lenten season, and prices remained at the two week's low of 15 1/2 to 16 1/2 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The National Forest Reservation Commission recommended today that the Federal Government provide for the eventual acquisition of 23,672,222 acres of privately owned forest land located near publicly owned forest lands.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26 -- Princeton moved into a fourth-place tie with Harvard in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight by downing Penn, 39 -- 36, in a closely contested game in the university gym. Captain Dan Carmichael and Paul Busse paced the winners' scoring with ten points apiece.

Radios and flatirons have the highest saturation point of any electric appliance, with refrigerators at 64 per cent moving ahead of vacuum cleaners into third place in 1940, according to an analysis issued yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

The increasing shortages of important raw materials, which will affect production of consumer goods to some extent, may reduce advertising of certain industries but the over-all volume for the year should register a good gain over 1940, according to opinions expressed by advertising agency executives yesterday.
Theodore Badman, real estate and insurance agent, who managed many large apartment houses, died Tuesday of a heart ailment in his home at 260 West End Avenue. He was 57 years old.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The British Admiralty and War Office announced tonight that the Italian Island of Castellorizzo, fitted as a seaplane base in the eastern Mediterranean, about eighty-five miles east of the Italian Island of Rhodes, was occupied by British forces yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 (AP) -A luncheon club and six manufacturers of redwood lumber were indicted today and fined $20,000 for price fixing.

ATHENS, Feb. 26 -- Again today weather conditions along the whole Albanian front remained too unfavorable to admit of more than the most restricted operations. However, the Greeks continued mopping up and their artillery has been lively in certain regions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Plans for a large reserve of men and women medical technicians for the Army were disclosed today by the War Department. The Red Cross will cooperate in the plans, which call for a reserve to meet an eventuality.

ATHENS, Greece, Thursday, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Greek quarters early to-! day hailed the British seizure ofi the Italian island of Castellorizzo, close by Turkey's southern coast, as "the first of many such exploits'' against the Italian Dodecanese.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP) -- Virtual wartime precautions to protect the Capitol were taken today with the assignment of 24-hour guard duty at all entrances.

Though yesterday was the first day of Lent, the millinery showing held at Franklin Simon's in the afternoon suggested Fifth Avenue on Easter morning. There were hats with diaphonous veils tied in butterfly bows under the chin for frivolous young things and brimmed hats with luscious flower trimimngs for smart matrons.

Manhattan's baseball campaign got under way yesterday when ten pitchers and five catchers reported for their first workout in the Jaspers' gymnasium. Johnny Balquist, beginning his third season as coach, welcomed the battery candidates, explained his program of drills and then sent first-string aspirants through short limbering-up routines.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 26 -- The United States naval authorities rented today practically the whole of the Elbow Beach Hotel in Paget to accommodate technicians who are soon to arrive to work on the naval base in the Great Sound. At the other end of the islands United States Army engineers are occupying the St. George Hotel.

The proposed study of all phases of our defense preparations by a special Congressional committee would be desirable from every point of view. Its first function would be to give the public, and Congress itself, a clear picture of the present state of the program. As one member declares: "Congress is giving hundreds of millions of dollars to the defense departments and we don't know a thing about how it is being spent.

BENDIX, N.J., Feb. 26 -- Twenty automobiles were destroyed and a like number scorched or otherwise damaged this evening as flames from a grass fire spread into a row of several hundred automobiles in a parking lot adjoining the local plant of the Bendix Aviation Corporation.

Among the nation's principal manufacturing concerns receiving defense contracts in the first half of February, seven currently have such orders from the government equal to 28.4 per cent of their entire 1939 sales, according to a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A plan for cushioning the shock of unemployment after the defense program is completed was proposed today by Isador Lubin. Commissioner of Labor Statistics, who advocated before the Temporary National Economic Committee that a dismissal wage fund be set up by companies doing defense work.

The second section of Golden Gloves semi-finalists went into action before a crowd of 7,000 persons at the Bronx Coliseum last night. The amateur boxing hopefuls were aiming for spots in the finals, which are to be presented at Madison Square Garden on Monday night.

An enterprising dramatist with only one Brooklyn tryout to his previous credit scored an emphatic success in his Broadway debut last night when F.H. La Guardia of New York and Prescott, Ariz., presented an original one-act play, with musical adornments by Irving Caesar, before 4,000 persons at Manhattan Center.

Miss Helen M. Harris, National Youth Administrator for New York City and Long Island, served notice yesterday that she wanted no help from the American Youth Congress in her fight against cuts in the local NYA rolls.

Coincidentally with the first day of Lent, Bach's "Passion," accord-to St. John, was performed last night at Carnegie Ball by the New Friends of Music, Fritz Stiedry conductor, with the assistance of singers from the Schola Cantorum chorus and seven soloists.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- After negotiations lasting some months between Great Britain and Spain regarding the situation in internationalized Tangier in Morocco, Richard Austen Butler, Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, announced in the House of Commons today that an agreement for the duration of the war had been concluded.

Frederick G. Frost, president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, announced yesterday the second annual competition for the $1,200 Arnold W. Brunner scholarship. Applications will be received at the chapter's headquarters, 115 East Fortieth Street, until April 15 and the winner announced after June 1.

Elmora Court, the five-story apartment house at 327-38 Elmora Avenue, Elizabeth, N.J., has been sold for cash by the Commercial Title Guarantee and Mortgage Company of Newark to the 333 Elmora Corporation in a transaction negotiated by the C.B. Snyder Realty Company, broker.

Total gross income of the Radio Corporation of America and subsidiaries last year was $128,491,611, against $110,494,398 in 1939, a gain of $17,997,213, while net income for the year amounted to $9,113,156, compared with $8,082,810 the year before, according to the company's twenty-first annual report to stockholders released yesterday by its president, David Sarnoff.

While urging "utmost aid" to Britain "without further delay," Bishop William T. Manning, at Ash Wednesday services in Trinity Episcopal Church yesterday, declared that material measures alone would not save the democracies and that the greatest need was human spirit and a trust in Divine help.

Total gross income of the Radio Corporation of America and subsidiaries last year was $128,491,611, against $110,494,398 in 1939, a gain of $17,997,213, while net income for the year amounted to $9,113,156, compared with $8,082,810 the year before, according to the company's twenty-first annual report to stockholders released yesterday by its president, David Sarnoff.

While urging "utmost aid" to Britain "without further delay," Bishop William T. Manning, at Ash Wednesday services in Trinity Episcopal Church yesterday, declared that material measures alone would not save the democracies and that the greatest need was human spirit and a trust in Divine help.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics today replied to the brief presented by the National Association of Retail Druggists to the Temporary National Economic Committee criticizing statements made by the bureau in the TNEC's Monograph No. 1, "Price Behaviour and Business Policy."

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 26 -- Rounding out discussions of criticisms of school textbooks and attacks on schools that have occupied much of the time of the national convention of the American Association of School Administrators, Dr. Alexander J. Stoddard, Superintendent of Schools of Philadelphia, declared today that, while education welcomed the "normal processes of public appraisal of the schools," these processes "are being hampered and diverted by a new situation."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 26 (UP) -- As the call for the strike at Bethlehem Steel's Lackawanna plant was issued, John Riffe, assistant to Van A. Bittner, predicted that sympathy strikes involving 60,000 workers would follow soon in other corporation plants at Sparrows Point, Md.; Bethlehem, Johnstown and Pottstown, Pa.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that 99 per cent of the New York milkshed dairy farmers who voted in a referendum Feb. 17 had approved the issuance of amendments to the Federal order regulating the handling of milk in the New York metropolitan marketing area.
CATSKILL, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- George C. Stebbins, only survivor of the Evangelistic group headed by Dwight L. Moody, observed his ninety-fifth birthday anniversary quietly at his home here today.

This evening, as the last opening of the month, Mary Louise Elkins and Clarence Taylor will offer "Brooklyn Biarritz" at the Royale Theatre. The play is by Beatrice Alliot and Howard R. Newman, and its action takes place on the beach at Coney Island.

The fourth performance in the annual matinee cycle of the uncut "Ring" brought the Metropolitan Opera yesterday afternoon to "Goetterdaemmerung," of course. Here the genius of Richard Wagner is at flood-tide, and it requires interpreters of heroic capacities to companion the composer.

Brisk activity continued to mark the New York Gift Show yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Buyer registration dipped slightly to 965, but the total for the three days was reported as in excess of 3,600, a gain of 10 per cent over the like period of last year.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, agreed yesterday not to interfere with the regular program of Albert Spalding, violinist, on Sunday afternoon over the Columbia Broadcasting System. Mr. Spalding's program had been expected to provide the first test of Mr. Petrillo's rule that instrumentalists must join his union by Saturday or face a boycott by the organized musicians.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 26 -- Lenten services were held here tonight at the War Department Theatre. Catholic services, conducted by Major George J. Crone, were held at 7:15 o'clock and the Protestant service, conducted by Chaplain John Sagar of the 174th Infantry, were held at 8:15 o'clock. A Protestant service will be held each Wednesday evening during Lent.

Students of the opera department of the Juilliard School of Music last night at the school gave a witty, ingenious and excellently sung performance of Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" in a new English version written especially for them by George Mead, New York organist and choral conductor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- At the end of many months of official unrealism -- partly the product of third-term politics, partly of a true love and longing for peace -- the Administration is squarely facing the prospect of war. It is conceding, almost openly, that the United States cannot give to Great Britain the degree of assistance required to defeat the Axis and deny, as during the campaign, that war can be a consequence.

Cancellation of the wholesale liquor license of Calvert Distillers Corporation was announced here yesterday by the State Liquor Authority, which at the same time announced it would make a claim for the penal sum of the $5,000 bond which the company was required to put up at the time its license was issued.

On the publication day of the diary of Ambassador William E. Dodd, who served in Berlin from 1933 to 1938, word is received that the second volume of the memoirs of Hugh R. Wilson, who succeeded Dr. Dodd at that post, will be published on March 27.
DETROIT, Feb. 26 -- The C.I.O.'s United Automobile Workers filed today formal notice of intent to strike at the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge, Lincoln and Highland Park plants, all in this area.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Frederic Thomas Manley, retired vice president of the Texas Company, died here yesterday at the age of 60.

When we dropped in on Uncle Dan the other day we found the old gunsmith grumbling and consigning amateur gunsmiths to a locale where they would stand in need of asbestos gloves in order to touch a gun barrel. On the bench in front of him reposed a re-blued Krag barrel and action and a new sporting stock.

Yesterday's trading was generally slow and draggy on all classes of traefer meats, due in part to the beginning of Lent. The market was uneven, but the general trend was lower. Kosher steer chucks and plates were weak, kosher lamb weak to mostly $1 lower, veal fully $1 lower, with some sales off more.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 26 -- The Canberra government has discovered that large landowners are attempting to increase their wheat acreage to obtain larger payments from the fund designed to stabilize industry which was provided by receipts exceeding the government's guaranteed price of 3 shillings and 10 pence a bushel f.o.b.

It is possibly with an eye for the dramatic that the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. always has scheduled the one-mile relay as the final event on its program. Often in the past the team title has hinged on this race and it may depend on it again when the twentieth annual I.C. 4-A championships are staged in Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

With the league-leading New York A.C. team idle for the evening, the Bayside Tennis Club defeated the Yale Club, 4 to 1, on the Eli courts last night to assure itself of at least a tie for second place in the Class A squash tennis championship of the Metropolitan League.

The Knoedler Galleries, in connection with the publication of the forthcoming book on John Singer Sargent by Martin Birnbaum, are opening on Monday an exhibition of water-colors by Sargent. These are for the most part impressions of Italy, Tyrol and France.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (UP) -- The fighting capacity of Russia's Red Army and Navy "must be strengthened in every possible manner," the Supreme Soviet was warned today in a recommendation that the 1941 defense budget be increased another 250,000,000 rubles.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 27 -- The Dartmouth hockey team outscored Army in every period tonight to win by 6 to 2 at Davis Rink. Netting the puck once in the first period, twice in the second and three times in the third, the Indians held the lead throughout.

Families and business associates of the New York survivors of the Eastern Airlines plane crash in Georgia received first word of their escape and reassurances of their safety yesterday from the passengers in telephone conversations from Atlanta hospitals.

The City of Providence, R.I., will be in the market on March 7 with $3,000,000 of unemployment relief bonds, it was announced yesterday. The securities, to be dated April 1, will mature serially on April 1, 1942 to 1961.

Mrs. Harold S. Vaughan gave a luncheon yesterday at Mayfair House for Mrs. John Sutherland Bonnell, wife of the Rev. Dr. Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. The other guests were Mrs. John French, Mrs. Charles F. Darlington, Mrs. Robert S. Kilborne, Mrs. Winfield Scott Schley, Mrs. Nathaniel A. Campbell, Mrs. Katherine H. Mosle and Mrs. Richard Ewell Brown.

The prosecution began submitting evidence yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Milton B. Logan, 50 years old, of 416 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, in alleged thefts of $65,000 in auction sales of paintings, art objects and rare books by the now-defunct American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., when Logan was its president in 1939.
BERLIN, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Retail credit collections showed an increase of 0.04 per cent in January, according to the index of twenty local stores, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage was 51.07 for the month, against 51.03 for January, 1940.

Contributions of $81,450 were announced yesterday at the first report meeting of the metropolitan New York committee of the National Committee for Planned Parenthood at headquarters of the committee, 501 Madison Avenue. The national committee is seeking $625,740 to finance a nation-wide program of the Birth Control Federation of America, and the New York group is seeking a quota of $346,740.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 27 (AP) -Ginger Rogers tonight won the annual academy award for her performance in "Kitty Foyle." James Stewart was voted 1940's outstanding actor for his work in "The Philadelphia Story."
Fifteen candidates answered Coach Andy Coakley's call for batterymen yesterday in one of the largest turnouts of pitchers and catchers in Columbia baseball history.

Concentrations of German troops in Sicily, apparently awaiting transport to Africa, and the first clash, reported yesterday, between German and British land forces in Libya, indicate that the African war is approaching a new stage.

As today is the second fast day in Lent and fish is due to show up on many dinner tables this evening and many evenings through the Lenten season, the Fish and Wild Life Bureau of the Department of the Interior discussed yesterday suggestions for housewives on fish.

The report on insurance company practices which has been prepared for the Temporary National Economic Committee under the direction of the Securities and Exchange Commission takes the position that a great portion of the country's savings held by life insurance companies is being sterilized by investment in bonds instead of going into equity investments which would finance new enterprises.

A plea that manufacturers supplying equipment to the dairy industry should be ranked immediately after the munitions industry in alloting stainless-steel supplies under a priority system, has been made to the government by a special committee of the Dairy Industries Supply Association, members were informed yesterday at their annual convention at the Hotel Commodore.

VICHY, France, Feb. 27 -- There has been talk of abolishing the censorship of the French press, but the question remained in abeyance while Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's Cabinet was being reconstructed. Now that the information section has been modified, it is understood that the matter will be considered again.

William C. Bullitt, former Ambassador to France and Soviet Russia, declared in an address last night that the United States had "done worse than any man had reason to expect" in providing war materials for its own defense, Britain, China and Greece, and urged the proclamation of an immediate national emergency, if necessary, to speed action.

Wool piece goods markets during the past week were only moderately active, as most buyers, finding themselves unable to obtain the deliveries they sought, more or less withdrew from the market for the time being, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday in its weekly review.
VIENNA, Feb. 27 -- Whether thousands of Vienna Jews are to be transferred to Poland or enabled to emigrate to other countries is purely a question of money, it is learned.

The letter of Mr. Volk-Wilkinson in your issue of Feb. 22 describing the character and origin of Polish deportees creates the impression that the Polish element of Eastern Poland (West-White Russia and the Western Ukraine) consisted largely of disbanded soldiers who were settled by an imperialistic government in districts habitated by minorities in order to denationalize the latter.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 27 -- The War Department has ordered a survey of housing facilities in the vicinity of Fort Dix. This order was interpreted today by some officers on the post as an indication that additional housing for the families of men on duty here might be constructed with Federal funds.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 27 (AP) -The American Association of School Administrators ended its seventy-first annual convention today with a resolution endorsing material aid to Great Britain "consistent with our own ultimate safety."

ST. PETTERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 -- A new Lefty Gomez, free of pains, aches, nervous and mental strain, was unveiled at Huggins Field today in the first test the veteran Yankee southpaw has had this year on the pitching mound.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 28 -- British Royal Air Force bombers struck furiously over Wednesday night at Cologne, Germany's third largest city and, as an industrial and railroad center and Rhine River port, a key point in the Nazis' war system.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 27 -- In the Balkans preparations for the extension of the war to new fronts quickened today, while reports from Rome frankly predicted an imminent Italian counter-offensive in Albania. This, it is said, would be directed through Koritza and Florina to Salonika and simultaneously toward Yanina, capital of Epirus.

BOSTON, Feb. 27 -- Anticipating that the opportunities for New England industries to engage in defense production will be greatly increased in the near future, the New England Council today recommended to chambers of commerce and boards of trade throughout the industrial Northeast the adoption of the so-called Rhode Island plan by which work can be quickly shifted from overloaded plants and communities to those with unused facilities.

The plans of the New Friends of Music for its series of sixteen concerts next season in Town Hall were announced yesterday by Ira A. Hirschmann, the organization's founder. For the first time solo piano music will figure on the programs. Arthur Schnabel will introduce this new departure with his performance of ten piano sonatas by Schubert and that composer's "Moments Musicaux" and "Impromptus." The sonatas will be presented as a cycle.

Expressing contempt for the use of "pious platitudes and cliches" in discussions about tolerance, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, told the National Conference of Christians and Jews last night that "prejudice is on the rise in the United States" and it is time to "fight it with more than mere righteous indignation and petty exchanges of meaningless compliments."

D. Stewart Iglehart, president of the Grace Line, announced yesterday that the company would inaugurate a new freight service between Gulf ports of the United States and western ports of South America to carry raw materials for the new government-owned tin smelter at Texas City, Texas.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 27 -- Britain and Turkey reached "full agreement on all points" today concerning the Balkans and the Eastern Mediterranean, a British spokesman announced, and observers expected a discussion of the relations of Turkey and Soviet Russia to follow.
LONDON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique issued today said:

Among those injured in the wreck of the Eastern Air Lines plane in Georgia, Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker won distinction in the World War as the leading American "ace," receiving official credit for having shot down twenty-one German planes and two balloons. He won the Congressional Medal of Honor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Department store sales for the week ended Feb. 22 were 7 per cent higher than for the corresponding week last year and in the four weeks period ended Feb. 22 were 14 per cent higher than for the similar period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

"Brooklyn Biarritz" is well meant. If it were cheap-minded or cleverly phrased, a reviewer might find a point of attack that would at least provoke an argument. But Beatrice Alliot and Howard Newman have written an amiable discursion about Coney Island that never rouses itself into drama.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Italy led foreign countries which were busily selling off American securities toward the close of last year, the Treasury reported today. For the four weeks ended on Nov. 27 net liquidation amounted to $16,976,000. In the preceding month it had been $23,767,000.

ROME, Feb. 27 -- The announcement that Germany and Italy have signed an economic accord is greeted today as another great step in what the authoritative commentator Virginio Gayda calls "the coagulation" of the two countries. The agreement is called one of the most important of the series of measures hinted at by Premier Mussolini and Reichsfuehrer Hitler, which are giving Germany an even greater part in the life of Italy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The wreck of an Eastern Air Lines plane near Atlanta led to an order today for a public inquiry next week by the Civil Aeronautics Board, assurance of an investigation by a special Senate subcommittee and demands in the House and Senate for a return to the Civil Aeronautics Authority and Air Safety Board.

A young American baritone, Robert Weede, who had prepared himself with uncommon care and thoughtfulness for the occasion, made his second appearance in the Metropolitan Opera House, and his first in the part of Rigoletto, last night, with conspicuous success.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The War Department is strengthening Pacific air bases by sending two squadrons of planes to the Philippines and six to the new base in Alaska.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 27 (UP) -Further details were obtained in Ankara today of the British seizure of the Italian fortified island and seaplane base of Castellorizzo on Turkey's southern Anatolian coast on Tuesday. This action may have been the first move of a large-scale British attack on Italy's Dodecanese group lying at the entrance to the Dardanelles.

In The Saturday Review of Literature out today Mr. Rex Stout unfolds a secret that will cause wonder and discussion and wrath perhaps in the vast reaches of Sherlockia. Mr. Stout, a descendant of the famous English mathematician Isaac Todhunter, seeks to prove by mathematical probability, by mystic numbers, by significant passages from the books of St. Conan, by acrostic, by elimination and by divers other processes, that Dr. Watson was a woman.

A syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co. offered yesterday after the close of the market 52,500 shares of no-par-value common stock of G.C. Murphy Company at $62 net a share. The stock, which had been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission, included 50,000 shares from the estate of the late J.S. Mack, former chairman of the board of the company.

John Gilbert Winant, recently appointed United States Ambassador to Great Britain, left for his new post in London yesterday morning aboard the Lisbon-bound Atlantic Clipper. Mr. Winant was beginning his seventeenth crossing of the Atlantic by Pan American Airways clipper.

The twenty-second annual appeal of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York got under way yesterday as the special gifts committee began its solicitations. Some of its forty subcommittee chairmen already were able to report contributions at a committee meeting held in the afternoon in the Empire State Club in the Empire State Building.

Members of the New York State Racing Commission, convening at their offices yesterday, re-elected Herbert Bayard Swope chairman, approved dates for 1941 hunts meetings to be held on Long Island and decided to forward several suggestions to the State Legislature concerning the pari-mutuel statute.

A group of twenty-seven small residences are projected on 192d Street between Fifty-fourth and Fifty-sixth Avenues. Flushing, Queens, where Twentieth Century Homes, Inc., has purchased from the Lawrence Estates Flushing, Inc., fifty-four building lots 20 to 100 feet each.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The government has plans to reduce the time taken for British merchant ships to unload, load and proceed to sea by 40 per cent, Ernest Bevin, Minister of Labor, said today.

PORT MERCER, N.J., Feb. 27 -- The preserve shooting season went out with a literal bang in at least one New Jersey pheasant farm today, and although the misses were frequent the birds were plentiful, so everybody had to admit that it was one of the finest closing days they ever put in.

Overstocking of vital raw materials, such as aluminum, is just as prevalent among manufacturers with defense contracts as among makers of civilian goods, several executives in metal-using industries charged yesterday. As a matter of fact, they said, under the unofficial priority plan of recent months, some manufacturers, such as plane companies, have been building up stock piles far beyond their immediate and near future needs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -Senator Danaher of Connecticut told the Senate today that Wendell L. Willkie pledged support for "all-out" aid to Britain at a pre-election dinner at the New York home of Mrs. Ogden Reid.
ROME, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

BERLIN, Feb. 27 -- The case of United States Minister George H. Earle 3d in Sofia, which has not yet been mentioned in the German press, evokes a caustic commentary on American diplomats tonight in the Deutsche Diplomatisch-Politische Korrespondenz, organ of the Foreign Office.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 27 (AP) -Charges of bribery against T.J. Pendergast, deposed political boss of Kansas City, and R.E. O'Malley, former State Insurance Superintendent, were dismissed today soon after a jury had been selected for the trial.

DETROIT, Feb. 27 -- Governor Murray D. Van Wagoner instructed the State Labor Mediation Board today to be ready to arbitrate points of dispute in a threatened U.A.W.C.I.O. strike at three plants of the Ford Motor Company if consultation with Federal defense officials, the company and the union showed that the plants named were engaged in manufacturing for national defense orders.

The Mesta Machine Company earned in 1940, after taxes and all charges, $3,083,032, equal to $3.08 each on the 1,000,000 outstanding shares of common stock, according to an annual report by Lorenz Iversen, president, for release today. Earnings in 1939 amounted to $2,715,427, or $2.71 a share.

Defense contracts awarded in the period from July 1, 1940, through Feb. 15, 1941, totaled $12,377,053,247, according to data issued yesterday by the Office of Government Reports. The same source put orders in the first half of February at $357,310,395.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 27 -Metro announced the acquisition of two new properties today, "Men From the City," by Maury Grashin, and "Enemy Within," by J. Walter Ruben and Wells Root. Robert Sinclair was assigned to direct the former story, which deals with a wanted man who hides out in a small town.

Heavy construction in the United States this week crossed the billion-dollar mark, eclipsing by a substantial sum the best previous record. From the beginning of 1941 to Feb. 27 engineering construction awards amounted to $1,019.950,000, well over double the awards in the 1940 period and one-third greater than corresponding awards of $761,616.000 in the first nine weeks of 1929, the previous record year, according to Engineering News-Record.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $100,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures disclosed yesterday. This makes a total increase of $230,000,000 in the last three weeks and reflects, mainly, continued Treasury disbursements.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 28 -- France must accept Japan's mediation proposal in the border dispute between Thailand and French Indo-China today or face the consequences of Japan's determination to assert her leadership in Greater East Asia, Koh Ishii, official spokesman of the Cabinet Information Board, declared at a press conference at noon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The dollar cost of motion-picture production at the end of 1939 had increased almost three-fold in twenty years, according to a report issued today by Vergil D. Reed, acting director of the Census. More than half the cost was salaries and wages, principally salaries.

With five $10,000-a-year administrative posts in the city school system vacant, Board of Education officials announced yesterday that they would accept applications for the positions until March 15 at the board offices, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- A.P. Herbert and fifty other members in the House of Commons today tried to get the government to do something to curb the activities of Dr. Frank Buchman and his associates of the Oxford Group in the United States and Canada. It was moved:

Colonel Terry, smiling and affable, said that Harry Danning, Burgess Whitehead and Joe Orengo, his remaining holdouts, were going to Miami soon, "and it won't be long now." Meaning he was confident of signing all three.

HAVANA, Feb. 27 -- Coincident with the arrival of Colonel Bill Terry and his Giants today, Roaring Red MacPhall chose to set off a few fireworks. The explosions, however, were not in honor of or directed at the Stoneham athletes.

Eugene P. Connolly, New York County chairman of the American Labor party, filed yesterday in Supreme Court an application for an order requiring the Board of Elections to show cause why the certificate nominating him as the Labor party candidate for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District should not be declared valid.

ROME, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Oxygen is being administered to former King Alfonso of Spain, who remains "extremely weak" after a series of heart attacks during the past forty-eight hours, his physician, Dr. Giovanni Collaza, reported tonight.

The technical recovery of the last five sessions in the stock market was arrested yesterday as continued pressure on the steel issues unsettled the entire list. Trading bogged down as fresh nervousness invaded the market and transfers on the Stock Exchange dipped to 312,010 shares against 382,970 on Wednesday.

The savings banks of New York State again will seek the right to offer small personal loans, according to an announcement made yesterday by Myron S. Short, chairman of the legislative committee of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, who is vice president of the Buffalo Savings Bank.

TOKYO, Feb. 27 -- Japan, as mediator in the border hostilities between French Indo-China and Thailand, has proposed that Indo-China award Thailand 30 per cent of her claims, and the Thai delegates are willing to settle on that basis, but the French refuse to concede more than 10 per cent, it became known today.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 27 -- Workers required in defense operations already allocated to the St. Louis area will more than offset the registered number of employable unemployed.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The State must resort to the issuance of bonds to meet an emergency situation on State highways, the Legislature was told today in the final report of the State Highway Survey Committee, headed by Senator William H. Hampton of Utica.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Diplomatic conversations looking to an improvement in relations between the United States and Russia were resumed at a long discussion late today between Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, and Constantin A. Oumansky, the Soviet Ambassador.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 27 -- The two 14-year-old boys who fired more than 100 shots at police officers before they were captured Monday night were sentenced today to indeterminate terms in the Jamesburg Reformatory on charges of juvenile delinquency. Sentences were imposed in juvenile court by Judge Robert I.i. Davidson.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

An entertainment entitled "Carnival in Rio" will be given Sunday night at the Copacabana, 10 East Sixtieth Street, in aid of the Bethlehem Day Nursery. It is being sponsored by the "American Way" committee headed by Brooks Mendell. Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti and President Newbold Morris of the City Council are co-chairmen for the event.

Vera Nemchinova, star of the Russian ballet in the Diaghileff days, was guest artist of the Ballet Theatre last night for a single performance in "Swan Lake" at the Majestic Theatre. Mme. Nemchinova had not previously appeared with this company, but she danced the same role twice earlier this season with the Original Ballet Russe.

The Rangers won convincingly enough in their National Hockey League game with the Canadiens at Madison Square Garden last night, but the Blue Shirts knew they had been in a battle when everything was over. The world champions turned back the Montreal team, 5 to 2, in a thrilling, bone-crushing encounter that held the interest of the crowd of 6,830 to the end.

The two top-seeded players, W.D. Hoag of the Yale Club and W.P. Hoffman of the Bayside Tennis Club, advanced to the third round yesterday as the annual veterans' squash tennis championship got under way at the Yale Club.

ROME, Feb. 27 -- Stefani, official Italian news agency, disclosed today that Italy, claiming she had spent 7,500,000,000 lire [the lira is quoted at 5.05 cents] aiding the insurgents in the Spanish civil war, had presented a bill to Spain for 5,500,000,000 lire to be paid in twenty-four annual payments.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 27 -- In an interview with British and American journalists this evening British Minister George Rendel, speaking with unaccustomed bluntness for a diplomat, let it be known that relations between Great Britain and Bulgaria were not very far from a crucial stage but that they had not yet reached the breaking point.

The five-story store and tenement building at 148 Lenox Avenue was sold by Louis H. Pink, as Superintendent of Insurance, to Saco Properties, Inc., Milton R. Cohen, president, for cash above a purchase-money mortgage of $18,800. The property is assessed at $28,000. John J. Dickerson, Inc., negotiated the deal.

The draw and dates of play for this year's indoor intercollegiate polo championship were made public yesterday in an announcement from the United States Military Academy, which is to serve as host for the college polo players.

Bank clearings of the major cities of the nation amounted to $5,337,282,000 for the five days ended on Wednesday, or 11 per cent above the $4,806,888,000 reported for the similar five-day period of last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

MONTREAL, Feb. 27 -- When Canada entered the war many feared that its popularity among Winter sports enthusiasts would fade, but quite the contrary is true, as a tour of the Dominion's resorts, extending from Shawbridge to Mont Tremblant, the highest point in the Laurentians, revealed.

THERE is a touch of the Clarence Day spirit in "Hudson Valley Squire,"* a genial memoir of life in the Nineties, dominated by one more thunderbolt of a father. What John Marquand would do in presenting the same milieu is another matter.

Paul H. Brattain, vice president and general traffic manager of Eastern Air Lines, said yesterday the cause of the airplane accident near Atlanta early yesterday could not be determined until an official investigation was made and a report filed.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 27 -- While the Japanese press has launched an anti-British campaign, New Zealand has pushed ahead with defense preparations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Senate Finance Committee unanimously voted today to report a House-approved bill to remove "inequities" in the Excess Profits Tax Law through an amendment permitting taxpayers to file returns under both the invested capital and average earnings methods of computing the tax.

About 400 new subway cars are urgently needed for the city's unified transit system, and the shortage on the IND division is now so acute that failure to provide 200 new cars before next Winter will create a "desperate" situation, according to a departmental survey made yesterday.

A part of a program to enrich the experiences of the city's school children, Board of Education officials during the past year conducted 1,729,433 children in the public and parochial schools to places of educational interest in New York, it was reported yesterday.

One does not have to read between the lines of the news describing the necessary removal of certain publication files from the main building of the New York Public Library to the Twenty-fifth Street Annex to be shocked by the implications.

Boris Karloff must leave the cast of "Arsenic and Old Lace" this Summer to fulfill a motion-picture contract with Columbia Pictures, Howard Lindsay, co-producer of the play, and the film concern disclosed yesterday. Columbia Pictures said Mr. Karloff is expected to go to Hollywood in June to play with Peter Lorre in a film entitled "The Boogie Man Will Get You."

LONDON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The statement of the Bank of England issued today disclosed the addition of 101,000 in gold in the last week, raising total holdings to 1,621,000, the highest since early July last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Although employment in non-agricultural industries declined 956,000 in January, it was 1,868,000 higher than in January, 1940, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins reported today.

Pointing out that the economic data collected by the government in its census last April is already outmoded through population shifts resulting from the defense program, Norwood Weaver, president of Magazine Marketing Service, declared yesterday that good marketing research must not only be deep and thorough but continuous enough to keep up with changes.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 27 -- Today's Bourse was slightly higher under the lead of Royal Dutch, which rose 2,% points to 217I, and Amsterdam trading 1 to 39!. Otherwise, change: vere only fractional. American steels were moderately firm. United States Steel closed at 61. Bonds were irregular.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 27 -- Closing its seventy-first annual convention here today, the American Association of School Administrators heard from a German political refugee a warning against Nazi disruption of the Americas from within, from a Canadian Opposition leader a tribute to American aid in the war for democracy and from the Chinese Ambassador to the United States a declaration that a new world order already is in process of creation.

SOFIA, Feb. 27 (AP) -- George Rendel, the British Minister to Bulgaria, asserted tonight that "the forerunners" of a German invasion of Bulgaria already were in the country "by hundreds -- no, I should say thousands." He declared:

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 27 -- Seventy-one men and women were indicted under the postal laws by a grand jury today as a lottery ring alleged to have operated on the Atlantic seaboard from Massachusetts to Florida and to have had a total income of millions of dollars.

Support of an amendment designed to "put teeth" into the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act as a means of checking diversion of trade from retail stores was urged on all retailers in the State yesterday in a bulletin issued by the New York State Council of Retail Merchants, Inc., Albany, N.Y.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Dr. Karl Becker, a German business man, identified himself today as the other principal in the cafe altercation with United States Minister George H. Earle 3d last Saturday night. He asserted the American diplomat had called him "You damned Nazi" and attacked him "without provocation."

BERLIN, Feb. 27 -- The German Air Force, according to reports received here, struck another smashing blow at British shipping yesterday 300 miles west of Ireland over the open Atlantic waters. Sixteen British ships, totaling 102,000 tons, were said to have been sunk or seriously damaged in a single attack by German long-range bombers.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Belting Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., and Herman Barron of White Plains, N.Y., shot into the 36-hole leadership in the $5,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament today as Henry Picard's score zoomed in a high wind.

An investing client of Sidney M. Wittner, attorney, has purchased from the Jores Holding Corporation for cash above a first mortgage of $161,550 the six-story automatic-elevator apartment at 3366 Decatur Avenue, the Bronx, in a sale negotiated by Rubin Nason and Samuel Ginsberg.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Showing little change for the fifth consecutive week, the general level of wholesale prices in the week ended on Fb. 22 was 80.4, according to the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, based on the 1926 average.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 27 (UP) -Great Britain and Turkey have reached "agreement on all points" on means of bolstering their alliance against Germany's threatened sweep through the Balkans, it was stated tonight by members of the mission of the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- President Roosevelt declared tonight that the lease-lend bill was "an all-important factor in hemispheric defense" and remarked that its "early enactment by the Congress we confidently anticipate."

The strike of C.I.O. workers at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Lackawanna plant and the filing of formal notice by the C.I.O.'s United Automobile Workers of intent to strike at the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge, Lincoln and Highland Park plants indicate how serious the strike situation in defense plants could easily become.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Festivities to mark the Widener week race finals began this afternoon with a luncheon given by Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener in the board room of the Miami Jockey Club.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 27 -- The voluntary and wholesale surrender of Fascist forces in Italian Somaliland, apparently as demoralized as their comrades were in North Africa after the British attack there, was officially reported today by the British.

New kidnapping charges were made yesterday against two youths now serving prison terms for demanding $30,000 from the parents of Peter David Levine, 12-year-old boy who was abducted and murdered three years ago in Westchester County.

With Sergei Rachmaninoff giving a resplendent performance as piano soloist in his own "Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini," and John Barbirolli doing the best conducting of his local career to date in the same composer's symphony in E minor, last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall assumed a gala nature.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Soviet Russia was reported tonight to have done an about-face and raised strong objections to a German thrust through Bulgaria to Greece, leading to a speed-up of military preparations by Yugoslavia, the country that might offer a second-choice pathway to the Nazis.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 -- The large inner patio of the Everglades Club was the setting for a cocktail party given today by Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. Townsend Jr.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 27 -Seven persons were killed and nine injured, several of them seriously, when the new $120,000 twin-motored Douglas 14-psssenger "Mexico Silver Sleeper" of the Eastern Air Lines crashed five miles from Candler airport here about 1 o'clock this morning.

The Joint Distribution Committee and the National Refugee Service announced the opening of their joint campaign here yesterday for funds to finance the overseas relief and refugee aid program of the two organizations during 1941.

St. John's cannot win the metropolitan championship this year but, rated off its performance against N.Y.U. at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, the Redmen are the best team in town. Their brilliant exhibition the other night was the finest to be seen around these parts all season.
PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 27 -Dr. Walter S. Adams says that he has found evidence that the atmospheres of the largest stars are boiling at a terrific pace.

On Sunday you printed an interesting dispatch from David Anderson, in London, entitled "British See Food Relief as Direct Aid to Nazis." It contains so many errors that in the interest of historical accuracy I am taking the liberty of commenting upon it.

After a brief show of strength at the opening when prices were up 1 to 4 points, quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange worked downward steadily yesterday and at the close showed net losses of 1 to 6 points. Trade support in the near months accounted for the initial advance.

Drexel Co. and associates will offer today $8,000,000 of Philadelphia Reading Terminal Railroad Company first mortgage bonds, of which $3,500,000 is serial bonds and $4,500,000 is sinking fund bonds. The serial bonds, which bear coupons ranging from 0.50 to 2.625 per cent, are dated March 1, 1941, and are to mature on March 1, 1942 to 1951.

Today's events: "The Bartered Bride," 2 P.M., and "Lohengrin," 8 P.M., Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, 2:30; Victor Roche, tenor, Town Hall, 8:30; Julius Grossman, violin, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30; Felix Salmond, 'cello, benefit recital for the Foster Parents' Plan for War Children, National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, evening; Geon Choral Ensemble, Beekman Towers Hotel, 8:30.

Commercial loans of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City declined $13,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This was the first decline since the week ended on Nov. 20 last and the first decline of this magnitude since the week ended on July 31, last.

Charging that the Teachers Union and College Teachers Union here are Communist-dominated, twenty-five prominent New York City educators yesterday supported the recommendation of the executive council of the American Federation of Teachers that the charters of the two locals be revoked.
BERLIN, Feb. 27 -- British agents landed by parachutes or speedboats at night may be partly responsible, German spokesmen hinted today, for strikes and fatal clashes in the Netherlands.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference today that, now that the Treasury's first refunding operation of the year had been successfully started, his department would proceed to build a separate organization to handle the proposed "popular" financing of part of the nation's defense requirements.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Governor Lehman announced today that from last Summer to Feb. 1, Federal defense orders placed in New York State had amounted to $1,273,231,152.
