BUFFALO, Feb. 27 -- Acceptance of a formula advanced by the Office of Production Management for settlement of the C.I.O. strike at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Lackawanna plant will be recommended to the strikers at a mass meeting tomorrow afternoon by Van A. Bittner, regional director of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 (UP) -- The Russian Army organ Red Star today described an intensive German-British struggle for "the last remaining Balkan neutrals" as British Ambassador Sir Stafford Cripps flew to Turkey to join in Anglo-Turkish defense talks under way in Ankara.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Miss Elizabeth Hicks, 20-year-old star from Long Beach, Calif., the defending champion in the South Atlantic golf championship defeated Mrs. J.C. Shorb of South Bend, Ind., in the quarter-final round today, 3 and 2.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill challenged his House of Commons opponents today with a demand for a vote of confidence in his government and the House responded with a resounding and unanimous "yes."

It is now the turn of the Dutch to taste the full measure of Nazi oppression. They have remained obstinate and unbroken in their refusal to work for their new masters. Now "strikes and disorders" have resulted in the killing of six civilians, the wounding of others and the arrest of a greater number "responsible for disturbances or having participated therein." This last group faces prison sentences, possibly execution.
NAIROBI, Kenya Feb. 27 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:

Bernard C.M. Van der Hoop, one of the victim in the plane crash near Atlanta yesterday, was vice president of the Tin Processing Corporation and was on his way to Brownsville, Texas, to open tin smelting plants for his company. The family lived in Delft, the Netherlands, until nine months ago, when they came to this country because of conditions imposed by the Nazi invasion.
The report of the Federal Insurance Company for 1940, made public today by Hendon Chubb, president, shows net premium income at $6,083,084, against $4,463,614 in 1939.
Despite the objections of Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn, the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to change the location of the city's new Fire College from Brooklyn to Queens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation bought all of the $136,330,557 of State of Arkansas tax-exempt highway refunding bonds offered for sale today at Little Rock. Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, said the 3 1/2 per cent interest rate demanded by a nationa-wide syndicate of bankers which originally considered participating in the loan to the extent of $90,000,000 was too high.

Tradition has decreed that meet directors make a survey of their assembled talent on the eve of the track and field games and then venture predictions of record possibilities. Asa Bushnell, always a conservative, guessed yesterday that a half dozen marks would go at the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. championships at Madison Square Garden tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A great naval base, which is to include the largest graving dock ever built in the United States, is to be established at Bayonne.

This is the day RKO had scheduled for the world premiere of Orson Welles's first production, the controversial "Citizen Kane," release of which has been protested by representatives of William Randolph Hearst, the publisher. According to spokesmen for the studio, no new release date has yet been set for the film.

Active leasing is reported in 10 Downing Street, the 130-apartment structure being erected by Milton Kleban on the southwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Downing Street, in Greenwich Village, which will be ready for occupancy about April 1.

Concrete evidence that there was much burning of the "midnight oil" in Washington, D.C., last year is contained in the annual report of the Washington Railway and Electric Company for 1940 made public yesterday by A.G. Neal, president of the company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Possible conversion of some golf courses in the New York City area into landing fields for warplanes is under study by the War Department as a part of general precautionary preparations for all emergencies. An Air Corps board has been ordered to make an official survey of the more than 200 courses there.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Reversing the 1935-1939 trend, when the number of farmers borrowing from the land banks and the Land Bank Commissioner was declining, long-term mortgage loans made in 1940 by the twelve Federal Land Banks exceeded the 1939 totals by nearly 28 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- As key officials proceeded with details of plans to rush more materiel to Britain immediately after enactment of the lease-lend bill, further acknowledgment came from the government today that it regarded its own preparedness efforts as immediately linked with those of the British.

The Women's Council for Service in the 1941 campaign of the Greater New York Fund, holding its first meeting on the stage of the St. James Theatre yesterday afternoon, heard speakers emphasize the need for a greater drive for funds to meet the demands of the city's needy.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Prices of wheat declined around 1 1/2 cents a bushel in the early trading today on selling by local professionals who were influenced by the easiness in securities and additional precipitation in the Southwest. The offerings, however, were mainly in small lots and it took but relatively little buying to bring about a fair rally.

New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from Howard S. Filston to Mark A. Haas, from Percy H. Johnston Jr. to Chester S. Fairgrieve of Libaire, Stout Co. and from the late Emile de Planque to Henry Upham Harris of Harris, Upham Co.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Senator Van Nuys, Democrat, of Indiana, issued a statement supporting the lend-lease hill tonight and opposing any amendments prohibiting the dispatch of American troops to foreign countries because, he said, such a restriction would "encourage the invaders to go ahead and complete their dastardly ambitions."

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped 10 to 20 cents today as supply of 19,500 head, including 12,000 salable arrivals, proved too heavy for trade demand. Top was $8, 5 cents under yesterday's best time, and good to choice 180 to 240-pound hogs brought $7.65 to $7.90.

March 8 will be the hundredth anniversary of the birth of the late Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes of the Supreme Court. Harvard University Press has chosen that as the appropriate date for the publication of Holmes's correspondence with Sir Frederick Pollock, the great British legal authority.

A clear picture of what Army training can do for men was presented yesterday afternoon at commencement exercises for twenty recruits who since Dec. 12 have been in training for service in the overseas discharge and replacement depot of the New York Port of Embarkation, Brooklyn.

OTTAWA, Feb. 27 -- The extent to which personal, political and press freedom may be limited in wartime was debated this afternoon in the Dominion House of Commons. Members alternately cheered Minister of Justice Ernest Lapointe and those who criticized his department's methods and activities.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- A bill empowering the State Traffic Commission to make a study of State highways and draft a plan for the "rapid and safe" movement of Army trucks and equipment and other defense material was introduced today in the Legislature under the sponsorship of the New York Committee on Interstate Cooperation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A proposal, which it was hoped would settle the strike of Bethlehem Steel Company employes at Lackawanna, N.Y., in twenty-four hours was sent to the company and the Steel Workers organizing committee tonight by William S. Knudsen, Director General, and Sidney Hillman, associate director of the Office of Production Management.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) -Officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission will make tomorrow specific recommendations to the Temporary National Economic (Monopoly) Committee on a report on life insurance companies.
Directors of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share. Payments in 1940 were 25 cents in March, 50 cents in June and September and 75 cents in December.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Governor Lehman took steps today for the preservation of law and order in the strike at the Bethlehem Steel plant in Lackawanna. He sent telegrams to the Erie County Sheriff and to the Mayors of Buffalo and Lackawanna, warning them of their duty to protect life and property and pointing out that they had authority to swear in additional deputies and police.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 -- As Play House won the featured Ponce de Leon Purse today at 3 to 1 at the end of nine furlongs the Hialeah meeting experienced another upward surge which will put final figures close to the record high marks of a year ago.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 27 -The discharge of fireworks as a ruse to distract police failed to save Joseph Lopata, 43-year-old former inmate of several State prisons, from arrest on a burglary charge here, and when arraigned this afternoon before Police Justice B.W. Folger he was held without bail for action of the grand jury.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The seventh call for delivery of 3,469 selective service registrants to be sent by local boards outside of New York City was announced today by Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State director of selective service. The induction stations at Buffalo, Syracuse, Albany, Manhattan and Queens will receive 8,410 seventh call selectees between March 17 and 28.

FLINT, Mich., Feb. 27 -- Best in show laurels at the eighth annual all-breed fixture of the Genesee County Kennel Club ,went to the fawn Great Dane Ch. King V. Leonhart tonight. The winner, owned by Mr and Mrs. C.H. Ferber of Cincinnati, was handled by Colonel R.L. Davis.

BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 27 -- A United States Army bomber of the B-18 type fell into Panama Bay tonight and burned. Search failed to disclose a trace of its seven-man crew. Witnesses said that two men leaped with parachutes.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Clinton H. Crane, president of the St. Joseph Lead Company, and Andrew P. Fletcher, vice president, both of New York, were in a hospital here today with critical injuries received in an automobile-truck collision.

Moby Dick's Friends Local police the other day made the acquaintance of a citizen who never heard of Adolf Hitler. We all have our blind spots. There are probably hundreds of persons in New York City who are not aware that the 1939-40 World's Fair is over. They may even be planning vaguely to go and have a look some day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Some days ago the House Appropriations Committee deleted a budget item of about $1,200,000 annually to subsidize additional transatlantic transport by the American Export Airlines. The existing company, the Pan American, can give the extra service more cheaply, said the committee, and there must be economy whenever possible.

William McChesney Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, has received a 1-A physical rating from his local draft board and expects to be called for service before the end of May. He will resign his $48,000-a-year position, effective on the day of his induction.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31, made public yesterday, shows a net income after all expenses and charges, of $23,092,020. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.40 a share on the corporation's 5,503,193 shares of common stock outstanding, and compares with a net of $25,769,691, or $2.90 a common share, in the twelve months to Jan. 31, 1940.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The Merchants Association of New York has notified the legislative leaders of its opposition to the La Guardia administration bill which seeks for the city the right to divert excess revenues from its emergency relief taxes to other welfare purposes, so as to relieve the city's difficult budget situation.
NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Hugh Noyes Mulcahy was ready and willing tonight to give up a year of his big league pitching career to do his bit for Uncle Sam.

Lou Ambers, former lightweight champion of the world, will attempt to show that he is still a power in the boxing world when he tackles Lew Jenkins, current ruler of the 135-pound division, at Madison Square Garden tonight. Although the battle will not have title signicance because Ambers will weigh more than 135 pounds, it has aroused unusual interest.

MAYBE clarinet player always are in danger of sudden attack, but one in particular is on the spot at the moment. That's Signor Luigi D'Ambrosio, owner and operator of a silver-studded clarinet. He toots a sweet tone on his chosen weapon. But Signor D'Ambrosio, instead of tooting away in his music room or his Herkimer backyard, has put aside his lovely clarinet.

Many reservations have been made for the performance of "The Talley Method" at the Henry Miller Theatre tonight for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Gardner School Alumnae Association. The fund will also receive the proceeds from a supper dance in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador after the performance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Two public utility companies, the Indiana Associated Telephone Corporation and the Kansas Electric Power Company, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission registration statements covering the issuance of new 5 per cent preferred stocks the proceeds of which are to be used to retire higher dividend paying preferred stocks outstanding.

TOKYO, Feb. 27 -- The Japanese Government does not intend to publish the statement given to Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Ambassador in London, by Prime Minister Winston Churchill or to comment on it at present.

DETROIT, Feb. 27 -- The automotive industry is already making substantial progress in filling defense requirements and it will be ready to increase production sharply as new plants and facilities become available this Spring and Summer, the Automobile Manufacturers Association said today in a "progress report."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 28 (AP) -- With a brief lifting last night of the ban on outside calls to Sofia, there came news -- tinged with forebodings -- of long talks between Premier Philoff and King Boris and between Mr. Philoff and the Russian, Turkish and Italian Ministers to Bulgaria.

The exact correspondence in time between the Japanese demands on Indo-China and the development of a new German threat in the Balkans is no mere coincidence. It was foreshadowed in the Japanese-Italian-German military alliance announced last September.

OTTAWA, Feb. 28 -- Canada will do nothing that might be construed as an effort to influence the free and independent judgment of the American people in the present crisis, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King declared in Parliament this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- In two identical decisions today the Third Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that once a labor union has been chosen by a majority of employes to be their exclusive bargaining agent it must be considered the sole agent even after losing majority support, if the loss of the majority results from unfair labor practices by the employer.

Revocation of the charter of Local 156 of the Individual Window Cleaners Union was announced here yesterday by William L. McFetridge, president of the Building Service Employes International Union, A.F.L.

VICHY, France, Feb. 28 -- Social legislation will be one of the principal concerns of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's government in the immediate future. The trend had become evident in recent weeks, and it is emphasized tonight in a communique reporting decisions taken at a Cabinet council attended for once by the full roster of Secretaries of State.
BERLIN, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

New bonds offered to the public during February were in the smallest volume for any month since last May and the smallest for any February since 1935. Stock flotations, while more than in January, were the smallest for a February since 1938.

Opposition to the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway project was voiced yesterday by a score of business groups, trade associations and civic bodies at a public hearing by the port protection committee of the New York Port Authority at 111 Eighth Avenue.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Burst real estate development "bubbles" in New Jersey have left enough land to supply more than a million 50 by 120 foot vacant lots -- one for every family living in the State -- the Planning Board estimated today.

Operations of the General Electric Company last year resulted in a net profit of $56,241,000 after depreciation, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other charges, according to a preliminary statement made yesterday by Charles E. Wilson, president, following a meeting of directors.

In thousands of churches in this country tomorrow the first Sunday in Lent, pastors will appeal for the relief of war sufferers. This announcement was made yesterday by Leslie B. Moss, executive director of the Committee on Foreign Relief Appeals in the Churches, with headquarters at 297 Fourth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Following is the White House statement on the report on steel production capacity made by Gano Dunn, of the Office of Production Management:

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- The capitulation of Yankee holdouts went on apace today. Charley (Red) Ruffing and Johnny Murphy, relief pitcher, agreed to terms, completing the nineteen-man hurling staff. Twinkletoes George Selkirk and Tommy Henrich, outfielders, also came into the fold, Manager Joe McCarthy announced after a phone call to President Ed Barrow in New York.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 28 -- The Forty-fourth Division will send a composite brigade of about 2,500 men representing all the arms of the division, except observation airplane units, to the Army Day parade in New York City on April 5, according to tentative plans agreed upon at a conference between Brig. Gen. Ralph K. Robertson, acting commander, and Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the First Army on Governors Island, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senator Wheeler, starting a prepared address against the lease-lend bill today, reiterated his previous charges that it was the beginning of a dictatorship and that it gave blanket authority for the President to commit many and varied acts of war any place in the world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senator Glass of Virginia said today that he had asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to determine who was financing "the unpleasant visit" of a group of about thirty women headed by Mrs. Elizabeth Dilling of Chicago, who staged a "sitdown" demonstration in front of his office this morning.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 28 -- Mighty Challedon was cast in the role of second choice as seventeen horses, headed by the powerful entry of Mioland and Porter's Cap, were named to battle it out tomorrow for the richest prize in turfdom -- the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap.

One of The World-Telegram articles on the work of New York's health centers a few days ago discussed tuberculosis. It pointed out that in the years 1929-33 the death rate from this disease for the whole city was 66 for every 100,000 of the population, but in East Harlem, with a predominant Negro and Puerto Rican population, the rate was 131, just double the city average.

Though the cause of the airplane accident near Atlanta still remains to be determined, it seems clear that radio is at best an imperfect instrument for the guidance of an airplane. To be sure, pilots apparently find no difficulty in gliding down a beam in a fog and landing safely.

BERLIN, Feb. 28 -- Bulgaria will become the seventh signatory of the Three-Power Pact in an official ceremony in Vienna some time over the week-end, but most probably tomorrow. As usual, however, no confirmation can be obtained in official German quarters tonight.

Warning of the huge sums which must be spent for national defense, the First National Bank of Boston in its current New England Letter points out that at the beginning of the World War in 1914 governmental costs of all kinds in this country constituted only 9 per cent of the national income, compared with 28 per cent in 1940.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Senator George and Representative Woodrum, held his regular press conference, at which he stated that steel production capacity was adequate to supply civilian and defense needs, canceled other appointments and retired to his study suffering from a cold.

Several times each week the mail brings a letter from some angler or hunter who complains that the New York sportsman doesn't get his day in court. Usually, the records show, these complainants are sportsmen who believe certain regulations should be changed, but lack the interest to appear at a conservation hearing to express this belief.

MONT TREMBLANT LODGE, Que., Feb. 28 -- North America's outstanding ski races of the year, the renewal of rivalry between women's teams from Eastern Canada and Eastern United States and that of Dartmouth and McGill, old intercollegiate foes, will start tomorrow at this Winter sports development and end Sunday.

VICHY, Feb. 28 (UP) -- The French Government, "in the interest of peace," has sent a conciliatory reply to the "final" compromise plan proposed by Japan for settlement of the border conflict between Indo-China and Thailand; it was understood tonight.

ATHENS, Feb. 28 -- A formation of British Hurricane and Gladiator fighter planes on patrol over the southern sector of the Albanian front today met a greatly superior formation of Italian aircraft, and in the combat that ensued shot down twenty-six of the Italian planes, it was officially announced by the British tonight.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- The first step toward State mediation in the threatened strike at the Ford Motor Company's plants in the Detroit area was taken today when a statement was issued by officials of the company that it was now engaged in producing $122,000,000 worth of defense materials.
SAIGON, French Indo-China, Feb. 28 (AP) -- French authorities here and elsewhere in Southern Indo-China began taking air-raid precautions tonight as the crisis gripping East Asia became more tense.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 28 -- The British column that drove down from the north to join the siege of Cheren, Eritrea, was officially reported today to have made contact with the Italian forces holding outlying positions north of the town. The British forces west of Cheren drove forward and bettered their positions.

TRENTON, Feb. 28 -- Governor Charles Edison announced today his decision to appoint William L. Dill of Paterson as successor to State Highway Commissioner E. Donald Sterner of Belmar and Albert G. Waters of Perth Amboy to succeed State Purchase Commissioner Frederick A. Brodesser of Elizabeth.

PANAMA, Feb. 28 -- Search for the crew of seven men of the Army bomber of the BM type which crashed in flames in the Pacific last night will be started tomorrow when a Navy derrick barge passes through the canal from the Atlantic.

Lew Jenkins did it again last night. The skinny boxer from Sweetwater, Texas, holder of the lightweight championship of the world, knocked out Lou Ambers of Herkimer, N.Y., in the seventh round of their scheduled ten-round encounter at Madison Square Garden, and in doing so duplicated his performance of last May, when he stopped the same Ambers to win the 135-pound crown.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- A foul goal by Substitute Arthur Gurfein, his only point of the game, gave Long Island University a sensational overtime basketball victory over La Salle at Convention Hall tonight, 42 -- 41.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Eighteen, including Bimelech, have been named for tomorrow's sixth running of the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup race, feature of the concluding day of the Miami Jockey Club's forty-six-day meeting at Hialeah Park.

Two building organizations in separate deals have assembled plots of land on the same square block in Rego Park, Queens, and plan to erect there three six-story apartment buildings, on one of which work has already begun.

The Daily Worker, Communist newspaper, announced yesterday that Miss Anna M.W. Pennypacker of Philadelphia had succeeded the late Mrs. Caro Lloyd Strobell as a co-owner of the paper with Mrs. Ferdinanda W. Reed and Mrs. Susan H. Woodruff.
The five-story residence at 38 West Seventy-fourth Street, with a four-story extension in the rear, has been sold by Alice M. Metz to a client of L.J. Phillips Co., brokers.

Pointing out that Treasury receipts and disbursements were the dominant factor affecting the reserve position of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in February, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its March 1 review of credit and business conditions said that if the present tendencies of other factors continue, the prospect is that a downward trend of excess reserve may be expected this year.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- The Army Quartermaster opened bids here today on 2,000,000 pairs of wool gloves. Only eleven mills participated, and their total offerings were 1,905,000 pairs at prices ranging from 72 to 88 cents per pair. It was felt in trade circles here that the paucity of bidders was due to the new clause in wool goods bids setting forth penalties for over emphasis of foreign wool offerings.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 28 (UP) -- John G. Winant, new United States Ambassador to Great Britain, and his assistant, Benjamin Cohen, arrived here today at 3 P.M. [9 A.M. New York time] aboard a transatlantic clipper en route to London.

VICHY, France, Feb. 28 -- The first forewarning of the impending serious shortage of wheat and bread in France was given in an announcement today from the prefecture of this district that, beginning tomorrow, the bread ration is to be reduced 20 per cent.

Price trends were mixed in yesterday's trading in most classes of traefer meats. Some sales of steer hinds and ribs were weak to 50 cents or more lower. Veal hindsaddles were weak to $1 lower. The lamb market was steady to 50 cents or more higher. Fresh pork prices generally were unchanged, but the market on some cuts had an easier undertone.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Professional baseball players subject to military conscription were reminded today by Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, New York State Director of Selective Service, that they could avoid a midseason draft and subsequent loss of their services to their teams in the middle of a pennant fight by volunteering now.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Argentine Exchange Control Commission will inaugurate an "auction" system to provide foreign exchange for imports, particularly from the United States, on March 7. Auctions will be held every two weeks.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- The sale of The Daily Reporter, a newspaper published in this city since 1917 by W. Lee Tuller and Walter V. Hogan, to officers of the J. Noel Macy chain of newspapers in Westchester County, was announced tonight. The last edition of The Daily Reporter was published this afternoon.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- The Association of American Correspondents in London announced today that it had censured by resolution the disclosure of confidential information by newspaper men returning to the United States from Great Britain.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Aided by sharply reduced supply, hog prices held fully steady today and showed spot gains of from 5 to 10 cents. Practical top reached $7.90, although an outstanding load brought $8. Most 180 to 240 pound hogs sold at $7.65 to $7.90.

The reason given by the Vichy government for banning "Jean Christophe," by Romain Rolland, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES dispatch, is that it does not give due credit to monarchy in the history of France and exaggerates the contributions of the French Revolution.

Because tomorrow is "Foreign Relief Appeals Sunday" pastors will preach sermons asking their parishioners to contribute generously to their sister churches in war-torn countries. Tomorrow being the first Sunday in Lent, clergymen will suggest to their parishioners that the money saved by sacrifices they may make during the penitential season be contributed toward foreign missions now bankrupt because their home churches can no longer send maintenance.

"Brooklyn Biarritz," the Beatrice Alliot-Howard Newman play about Coney Island, will close its Broadway engagement after this evening's performance at the Royale Theatre. It will have given only four performances.

Declaring that Father Divine, Harlem cult leader, was "evading collection of his debts" and "flouting the mandates of the court," Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook granted yesterday an application by Mrs. Verinda Brown for a body attachment directing imprisonment of the cult leader for failure to pay a $5,949 judgment she obtained against him last year.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 28 -- An extended war in this part of the world now appears to be virtually inevitable, and possibly very imminent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A list of fixed fees ranging from $2,000 to $1,128,030 paid to New York firms and individuals for defense work has been furnished to the House Appropriations Committee by the War and Navy Departments.

NEW BERN, N.C., Feb. 2B -- Mrs. Arthur Knox Jr. of 123 East Thirty-seventh Street, New York City, was killed and her mother, Mrs. G.M. Hubbard, 629 Eli Avenue, Pelham Manor, N.Y., sufffered a dislocated shoulder and shock this afternoon when the car, which Mrs. Knox was driving to Florida, overturned several times near Belgrade, twenty-three miles south of here.

North winds laden with snow lashed the New York area last night as storms of much greater intensity struck the Atlantic Coast from Southern Maine to Northern Virginia. While New York was being spared from the full force of the blizzard that was centered 150 miles south of Block Island, coastal areas in New England and Southern New Jersey were being battered by a gale of almost hurricane proportions.

A whirlwind second-half offensive gave Fordham's basketball forces a 53-to-42 victory in their gymnasium last night and seriously damaged Georgetown's hopes of meriting a bid for the coming national invitation tourney to be held in Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Additional short-covering came into the wheat market today and prices showed an advance of 1 3/4 cents a bushel from the early low level, the rise carrying the market up more than 7 cents from the low mark on Feb. 18 and into the highest levels since late in January.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in February dropped to the lightest volume since last August and showed the smallest total for any corresponding month in twenty-six years or since 1915. Sales last month, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 8,971,205 shares, compared with 13,294,670 in January, 13,465,355 in February, 1940, and 4,380,591 in February, 1915.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, new offered by dealers:

One March 15, Standard Brands, Inc., will introduce its Stanbi film-developing service to the mid-West, and on Decoration Day will start a test campaign in various sections of the country, which will run through Labor Day. The company will open a new $175,000 film-finishing and developing laboratory in Chicago, which has a capacity of more than 1,000 rolls of film an hour to service the mid-West section.

Young Women, Headed by Mrs. Lawrence M. Pritchard, Sell Corsages at Benefit Many luncheon parties were given before the special performance of "The Bartered Bride," with Jarmila Novotna and Charles Kullman in the leading roles, yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Smith College Club of New York.

The lease-lend bill in its present form will give to President Roosevelt the power to set up a censorship of news and opinion unjustified by any defense need, Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism warned yesterday in a telegram to five Senators urging an amendment to the bill to safeguard freedom of expression.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 28 -- It was believed here tonight that the next few hours will prove whether Bulgaria is to be the scene of battle in a conflict between British planes flying north from their Greek bases to raid German lines of communication and German forces pushing southward.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Sam Snead of Hot Springs, Va., overcame chill and gusty winds from the Gulf of Mexico today to win the $5,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament with two strokes to spare.

Manufacturers' shipments, new orders and inventories continued to increase in January, according to preliminary indexes for the month issued yesterday by the Conference Board. Shipments rose 5 per cent over December to a point 33 per cent higher than in January, I940; new orders increased only 1 per cent in the month, but the slight rise established a new record high, and inventories expanded 2.2 per cent.

Fordham's swimmers closed their season yesterday by routing Manhattan, in the Rose Hill pool, 66 -- 9, the most decisive margin ever recorded by a Maroon swimming team in collegiate competition. The Rams won four and lost seven contests during the year.

In his January message to the State Legislature Governor Lehman indicated his intention of continuing his efforts toward the reduction of the rate of interest charged to borrowers of small amounts. He recently moved to effect such a reduction in a message to the Legislature which was accompanied by a special report on the subject by State Superintendent of Banks William R. White.

A wide range of products developed for peacetime requirements have been adapted to military uses and are now being produced for defense purposes , according to the B.F. Goodrich Company's annual pamphlet report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Quietly and within his official family President Roosevelt has been setting up machinery for cooperative rearmament efforts of the United States and Great Britain to follow enactment of the lease-lend bill.

F. La Guardia, a qualified elector of the City of New York, was highly annoyed yesterday over finding that his signature had been removed from a county reform petition last year because he was listed in the registration books as Fiorello H. La Guardia.
The Columbian National Life Insurance Company of Boston in its annual statement for 1940 shows assets of $50,370,405, a gain of $2,231,620 over the previous year.

The Canadian dollar as bid up to 85.75 cents yesterday in the free market, the highest level since Jan. 20. Month-end settlements accounted for part of the increased demand, together with Winter tourist requirements. The rate closed at 85.62 cents, in terms of the United States dollar, up 1/2 cent on the day.
Hattie Danziger, through Pease Elliman, Inc, agents, in The Buchanan, 155 E 47th St; Warren Marks Associates, brokers.

What might have been one of the most active weeks in many months in respect to new bond financing turned out to be one of the slowest of the year this week, when only $9,950,000 principal amount of new bonds was formally placed on the market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Sales of wholesalers, based on reports from 2,732 firms, were 18 per cent greater in January than during the corresponding month of 1940, the Department of Commerce announced today. Dollar sales amounted to $211,550,000 in January and were 3 per cent below December, 1940, the smallest seasonal drop in five years.
ATHENS, Feb. 28 (A.P.) -- British Royal Air Force headquarters issued this communique today:

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday the organization of a committee consisting of representatives of twelve social agencies and one of his prosecuting aides to assist in the formulation of legislation to end what he described as a "chaotic situation" in dealing with youthful offenders in the city's criminal courts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28 -- Representatives of Howard Hughes and Leo McCarey today confirmed reports that a deal is under way for Katharine Hepburn to star in the Hughes company's next picture, which McCarey will produce and direct for Twentieth Century-Fox distribution.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- Taken into Federal Court from his cell at the Eastern State penitentiary, Robert J. Boltz, once highly respected financial adviser, pleaded guilty today to an indictment of twenty counts charging mail fraud and violation of regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
ROME, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Former King Alfonso died this morning in Room 35 of the Grand Hotel, propped up in an arm chair with purple cushions, a fur coverlet wrapped around his lean, always frail body.

The Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, organized by the late Cardinal Hayes in the first year of his archbishopric, has begun its twenty-second campaign. In spite of obvious new demands upon the purse of the community, there is good reason to hope that this wise and experienced helper of so many social needs will be provided generously with the means of carrying on its multiform beneficence.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 28 (UP) -- Although he may lose the sight of his left eye, Captain Eddie Rickenbacker, World War "ace," improved rapidly today from injuries he suffered in yesterday's crash of an Eastern Air Lines plane in which seven persons were killed and nine injured.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 1 -- Although France has not yet accepted Japan's proposals for settling the border dispute between French Indo-China and Thailand, despite the fact that Tokyo insisted that Vichy had to assent no later than last midnight, the Japanese took no drastic action today.

S.G. Haskins and L.S. Haskins of the Harvard Club rallied against J.B. Maguire and G. Lindsay Jr. of the Greenwich Country Club to gain the semi-final round in the metropolitan invitation squash racquets doubles tournament last night at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

Seven more patrons of the defunct American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., testified as State witnesses yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Milton B. Logan, 50 years old, former president of the concern, on the indictment charging that he helped victimize them and others of $65,000 in sales of paintings and art objects entrusted to the concern.

The highest and lowest experiences a man can have in New York City were packed into a brief two hours yesterday by Marcelino Soule, an Argentine gaucho, who began his day auspiciously with a reception by Mayor La Guardia in City Hall and ended it as a prisoner in the Jefferson Market Court detention pen for refusal to pay a cab bill of $1.10.

Dr. S.S. Goldwater, president of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, a non-profit corporation providing hospitalization insurance at 3 cents a day, forwarded yesterday to member hospitals the outline of a new plan that would extend the service to include individuals and families of low-income group that cannot afford to pay the present rates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- "Strenuous prompt efforts" to strengthen State machinery for regulating and supervising life insurance companies, and the institution of Federal supervision limited primarily to advisory and informative functions "to plug the gaps where State regulation cannot do an effective job," were recommended today to the Temporary National Economic Committee by Sumner T. Pike, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Gerhard A. Gesell of the SEC legal staff.

Officials of Eastern Air Lines reported yesterday that literally bushels of letters and telegrams were pouring into the airline's offices in Rockefeller Plaza and at La Guardia Field wishing Captain Rickenbacker a speedy recovery from the injuries suffered Thursday when the Eastern Air Lines sleeper plane crashed near Atlanta.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Feb. 15 was 2,888,780 shares compared with 2,403,290 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
AMSTERDAM, Feb. 28 -- With the turnover again at a minimum, a depressed tone developed on today's Bourse, Dutch issues losing as much as 5 points.

A delightful opera, Smetana's folk-comedy, "The Bartered Bride," was revived yesterday afternoon by the Metropolitan Opera Association, in English, under the baton of Bruno Walter. The performance gave much pleasure. Its sovereign virtue lay in the orchestra pit, where Mr. Walter conducted with warm feeling and lyricism and evident love of the score.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Roosevelt stated today that American steel production facilities were adequate to meet any actual or prospective demands for civilian use, the defense program and exports, and no priority system was necessary.

No new films are scheduled for initial showings on Broadway today, with "Night Train" entering its tenth week at the Globe and "They Met On Skis" beginning an eleventh week at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. The latter had been scheduled to be replaced by the French picture, "The Mad Emperor," but because of an increase in business "They Met On Skis" will continue indefinitely.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 -- The Hon. Mrs. George Cavendish-Bentinck of London, who arrived today from New York, and Mrs. William A.M. Burden were honor guests at a luncheon given today by Mr. and Mrs. Martin von Dehn at their home, where Mrs. Cavendish-Bentinck is a guest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- When Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, visited the Near East last October he assumed personal responsibility for the offensive on Marshal Rodolfo Graziani's army, which was started Dec. 7. Will Mr. Eden's trip to Turkey be attended with equally fortunate consequences?

Under the three-cents-a-day plan, subscribers for the Associated Hospital Service may enter any voluntary hospital in New York for twenty-one days, there to be treated by their own physicians in semi-private rooms. The system of medical practice in this State closes the free wards to the service.

At Farm and Home Week recently at Cornell University THE TIMES reported E. H. Thomson, president of the Federal Land Bank, Springfield, Mass., as saying that real estate taxes "threaten the very existence of rural homes in the Northeast," where, he continued, two-thirds to three-fourths of all State and local income was derived from real property.

BOSTON, Feb. 28 -Dr. Briggs, the author of the Massachusetts "Briggs law" requiring mental examination before trial of all persons indicted for murder wa a constant advocate of betteff treatment of the mentally ill.

New financing scheduled for next week by forty-four States and municipalities totals only $16,787,339, compared with $146,898,488 for this week. The sharp decline is attributed largely to the elimination from the calendar of the $136,330,557 State of Arkansas bonds which were sold on Thursday to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company is expected to file soon with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to a registration statement filed on Wednesday, lifting the amount of proposed bonds from $65,000,000 to $110,000,000.

A majority of the board of directors of the Brooklyn Church and Mission Federation has voted approval of the Hoover plan for sending food to five small democracies in Europe, the Rev. Dr. J. Henry Carpenter, executive secretary, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Farm leaders from the Cotton, Corn, and Wheat Belts urged Congress today to raise their incomes through price-supporting government loans and testified that this was preferable to any attempts at direct government price-fixing.

Bonds called for payment in February before maturity aggregated $139,186,000, compared with $440,973,000 in the preceding month and with $76,545,000 in February, 1940. Although the smallest monthly figure since October, last month's prepayments were the largest for any February since 1937.

On behalf of the Esco Fund, of which Mrs. Frank Cohen is president, and Karen Ami, a Jewish charitable organization, Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the American Jewish Congress, presented an $18,000 gift of vitamins to the American Red Cross during ceremonies in the headquarters of the New York Chapter, 315 Lexington Avenue.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 28 -- William (Blackie) Zupkosky, 31 years old, of Philadelphia, was sentenced here this evening by Judge Dallas Flannagan of the Essex County Court of Common Pleas to die in the electric chair the week of April 11 in the State Prison in Trenton.

ROME, Feb. 28 -- The shocking news that Mogadiscio, capital of Italian Somaliland, had been evacuated was broken to the Italian people today by the war bulletin, which said that a fierce struggle continued north of the city. After Bengazi this is the hardest blow that the Italian Empire and the Italian pride have received in the war.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 28 -- Behind the phrasing of a brief communique this afternoon, summing up the results of British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's visit, is concealed a momentous new development in the Anglo-Turkish alliance.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 28 -- Having completed his negotiations in Turkey, the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, will shortly visit Athens to round out Britain's system of alliances in the Balkans and the Near East and to develop the existing pacts between Turkey, Greece and Britain into a tripartite entente, according to diplomatic sources here.

The announcement yesterday by President Roosevelt that the steel-making capacity of the country has been surveyed and found ample to meet the requirements which will be made upon it is welcome news in more than one respect. It provides assurance that the program of national defense and of aid to Britain will not be hampered by deficiencies in this vital material, while at the same time all normal civilian demands can be met.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Federal Government took a hand today in the jurisdictional dispute between James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, and the American Guild of Musical Artists, headed by Lawrence Tibbett.

The public utilities section followers of the stock market seized yesterday upon the suggestion of an SEC official that insurance companies could invest "a good sum" in the common shares of sound operating companies, and this group led the share list into better territory.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- William S. Knudsen, who told the House Judiciary Committee last week that no legislation was needed to deal with labor strife in the defense industries, has changed his mind.

MANILA, Feb. 28 -- Carefully avoiding any alarmist tone that might create war hysteria here, High Commissioner Francis B. Sayre today disclosed that American authorities have been planning a civilian defense program since last October for use if war should strike the Philippines.

TAUNTON, Mass., Feb. 28 -- Walter E. O'Hara, 44, former managing director of the Narragansett race track, was killed this afternoon when his car crashed head-on into another on the Providence-Taunton highway about two miles and a half from the center of this city.

Alfonso of Spain was one of the last relics of the institution of monarchy. Following up his family tree, one came to Maria Theresa, who married the Golden King, Louis XIV of France; and finally one reaches Ferdinand and Isabella, who drove out the Moors and sent Columbus to find the New World.

Wendell L. Willkie in a statement yesterday characterized as "amusing" the assertion of Senator John A. Danaher of Connecticut that he had pledged support for "all-out" aid to Great Britain at a pre-election dinner at the home of Mrs. Ogden Reid, vice president of The New York Herald-Tribune.

With New York University favored, but with Fordham, Pitt, Penn State and a few others close enough behind to keep the pressure on all the way, the team competition promises excitement tonight when the twentieth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor track and field championships are staged in Madison Square Garden.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb, 28 (AP) -- This Balkan capital shut itself off from the outside world last night and today by establishing a police cordon that made exit from the city impossible, mysteriously suspended telephone communications for twenty-three hours and began a round-up of "men with British connections."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Assignment of Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart to command the Eighth Naval District at New Orleans has been canceled and he will become commandant of the Navy. Yard at Brooklyn.

Al Dente tossed a field goal and Benny Doctor a foul in the last ninety seconds as Erasmus Hall beat New Utrecht, 32 to 30, on the latter's floor yesterday and clinched the Section II, Brooklyn P.S.A.L. basketball championship. It was the final Section II battle for both teams, which had been tied for the lead with eight successes and one reversal.

Dividends declared last month were the largest for any February since 1931. The total of $382,052,074 for 1,005 corporations, of which $6,179,750 represented sixty-three banks and insurance companies, compared with $243,112,222 for 986 companies in the preceding month, when $24,795,266 was for 246 banks and insurance institutions.

William F. Bull, secretary of the Southern Pacific Company since 1933 and in its service since 1900, has been nominated for election as director at the annual meeting on April 9 in Spring Station, Woodford County, Ky.

John Kieran's reaction to the latest Landis ruling that no rookie signed by a major league baseball club can be sent out on option or returned for further minor league experience without benefit of waivers from all other clubs of the same league came as a surprise.

Alfonso XIII was born King of Spain May 17, 1886, and reigned until April 14, 1931, when the establishment of the republic forced him into exile. After his flight with his family he never returned to the country of which he had been king.
LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Air and Home Security Ministries issued this communique tonight:

Your Feb. 21 editorial "Misrepresenting Canada" seems to justify, for the clarification of the record, an adversion to a circumstance attendant on the creation of the federated nation that is today Canada. At the same time it is appropriate to reflect on the anomalous uses to which the words "dominion status" are often put.

Graduation exercises for the second class at the United States Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School aboard the U.S.S. Prairie State were held yesterday morning, with 434 receiving commissions as ensigns, culminating an intensive three-month training course.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 28 (AP) -- British Army Headquarters issued this communique today:

LONDON. Saturday, March 1 -- Britons, living in expectation that the approach of Spring will bring them devastating air raids such as they experienced before Winter set in, breathed easily early today as no Nazi fliers were reported over the country.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- There was a definite feeling of optimism today in London about the entire Balkan situation.

BERLIN, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Germans claimed for their Air Force today the sinking or damaging of twenty-nine ships in the last two days. Informed scources declared "it will be a little more lively next week."

In cooperation with the Federal Government, the Museum of Modern Art will open a new program to improve relations between the United States and the Latin-American republics through the interchange of art and culture, John Hay Whitney, president of the museum, announced last night at a meeting initiating a new inter-American educational program.

The first step to determine the validity of the so-called Recap plan of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, promulgated by H.C. Hopson and associates in 1933, was taken yesterday when Stanley Clarke, trustee for the Associated Gas and Electric Company, instituted proceedings in the Federal Court against the trustees of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The secret movement of $8,500,000,000 worth of gold from New York to Fort Knox was completed today, it was learned authoritatively, and the Kentucky vault now holds $14,000,000,000 worth -- the largest treasure ever assembled under one roof.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Second Lieutenant Charles Standish Vereker, 29, only son and heir of Viscount Gort, former commander of the British Expeditionary Force on the Continent, was found dead yesterday with a service revolver at his side, it was disclosed today.

One of four men, who according to the police, attempted to prevent Janet Welch, 16 years old, of 364 West Fifty-seventh Street, from entering her home early this morning, was shot in the left leg by her father, Patrolman John Welch of the West Fifty-fourth Street station.

Colonel Lloyd B. Magruder, in charge of recruiting here for the Second Corps Area, announced yesterday that for the first time since selective service began last November the number of inductions in this area apparently had exceeded the quota.

As a Saratogian naturally interested in the improvement of the breed of horses, I have been giving considerable thought lately to the problem of getting race horses to run faster and I think I have hit on a couple of good ideas.

VICHY, France, Feb. 28 -- France's attitude toward the settlement of the Indo-China question with Thailand was defined at tonight's Cabinet meeting. The Japanese Government, acting as mediator, has been informed, but the communique issued here gave no information about the French position.

Declaring that many fire insurance rates charged to municipalities were "unjustifiably exhorbitant," Mayor La Guardia wired yesterday a request to the Temporary National Economic Committee in Washington asking for a study of such rates.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- The Red Wings scored three goals in five minutes of the third period tonight to defeat the Americans, 5 to 4, and regain sole possession of third place from the idle Rangers in the National Hockey League.

John H. Vogt, an assistant engineer in the Brooklyn Bureau of Highways and Sewers for thirty-seven years, was dismissed from office yesterday by Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn after a departmental hearing on bribery charges brought by an Amen grand jury investigating a city-wide paving and sewer constructton racket.
Cynthia Kuser Herbst has sold the three-story flat with three stores at 521 Ocean Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., to the Mortgage Corporation of Newark.

ROME, Feb. 28 -- Former King Alfonso's amazing struggle for life ended peacefully at 11:50 o'clock this morning in his room at the Grand Hotel in the presence of his wife, former Queen Victoria; his two sons, Don Juan and Don Jaime, and one of his daughters, Princess Beatrix.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE NETHERLANDS INDIES ARMY, BANDOENG, Java, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. G.J. Berenschot, Commander in Chief of the Netherlands Indies Army, disclosed today a hitherto unknown military expansion program designed to create a 3,000-mile chain of fortresses along the Equator in these rich islands.

The Pennsylvania Railroad had a net income of $2,962,894 in January, against $2,500,233 in January, 1940, M.W. Clement, president, said in Washington yesterday. He estimated that gross revenues from Feb. 1 to 23 were $31,650,000, up 15.7 per cent from the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- To Ciro Alegria, exiled Peruvian novelist, was awarded today the $2,500 first prize in the Latin-American novel competition or his "El Mundo es Ancho y Ajeno" [Broad and Alien is the World].

The 1940 annual report of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, made public yesterday by J.D. Creveling, president, showed after all expenses and charges a consolidated net income of $4,548,324, compared with a net of $4,363,399 in 1939.

The 1940 annual report of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, made public yesterday by J.D. Creveling, president, showed after all expenses and charges a consolidated net income of $4,548,324, compared with a net of $4,363,399 in 1939.

A report of Hotel Lexington, Inc., for the six months ended on Dec. 31, 1940, shows a net profit of $96,118, of which an amount equal to 2 per cent on the $3,120,000 of outstanding collateral mortgage income bonds, or $62,400, is being applied in full payment of interest for the half-year ended yesterday.
I would like to say a few words in tribute to a great basketball coach, Clair Bee of Long Island University, who year after year turns out teams that rank with the nation's best.
ROME, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

ROME, Feb. 28 -- Bulgaria will join the Three-Power Pact in Vienna tomorrow, it was learned today, and with this step the Axis will have completed the diplomatic work preliminary to its forthcoming military strategy in the Balkans. Bulgaria's adherence, it was pointed out, rounds off the isolation of Greece on the continent and brings the Axis forces to her northeastern frontiers.

Two thousand employes of the Hearn Department Stores, Inc., ratified last night at a special membership meeting of Local 1250 of the Department Store Employes Union, C.I.O., a last-minute contract negotiated with store officials earlier in the day, providing for a five-day 40-hour week.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- The manoeuvrability of the Army's new "midget" reconnaissance truck and its ability to absorb abuse was demonstrated today to a group of officers as the dwarf fighter unit reached the volume production stage at the Ford Motor Company plant in Dearborn.

Strengthened by a steady flow of buying orders from the trade and mills, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed at net gains of 4 to 6 points Hedge-selling, which had been a factor in the recent two-day decline, fell off.

The stockholders of Standard Statistics Company and Poor's Publishing Company will meet next week to vote on a proposal to consolidate their organizations. Since both organizations are closely held, the vote will be purely an official ratification of the merger, of which the terms are not disclosed.

Detective Cloutiere J. Divver, 41 years old, of the Beach Street Station, killed himself by a shot from his service pistol in the men's room on the ground floor of the Criminal Courts Building shortly before noon yesterday. A few minutes earlier he had left Judge James G. Wallace's part of General Sessions, where he was about to be called as an important witness in a hold-up murder trial.

Welfare Commissioner William Hodson began the sale of food stamps to relief recipients yesterday in thirty-two district relief offices. In a report to Mayor La Guardia, Mr. Hodson said 200,000 families were immediately eligible to participate.

The March floods of the book trade are about to be released. As usual, the offering covers a wide range. In the following listing are some of the main offerings of publishers who have listed their plans.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- A strike marked by violence, in which at least three union members were hurt, was called today at the International Harvester Company's McCormick works by the Farm Equipment Workers Organizing Committee, a C.I.O. unit.

THE track meets that are different are the intercollegiate championships, indoors and out. There the great cry is: "Team! Team! Team!" The onlookers keep feverish accounts of the points as they are scored and the rivalry is on a broad basis; the big prize is the team championship.

Production rates rose to new peaks this week, while retail spending on a daily basis continued at recent high levels, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday Regional reports on civilian demand indicated a wider sharing of the expansion.

While sales were cut by yesterday's snowstorm, which may also have some bearing on volume today, retail trade here continued to make a good showing during most of this week. Volume had been runing 10 per cent or more ahead for leading stores early in the week. Both home wares and main floor merchandise fared well during the week.

BUFFALO, Feb. 28 -- Striking C.I.O. workers at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Lackawanna plant began to return to work today, clearing the way for resumption of full production on millions of dollars in national defense orders.

The city of Lincoln, Neb., received yesterday bids on two issues of bonds aggregating $800,000, official award of which is expected to be made on Monday. Wood, Struthers Co. submitted the high bid for $500,000 of refunding bonds, due on March 1, 1942 to 1951, optional for call after five years, offering 101.57 for 1 1/2s.

Many Americans believe that even though Britain successfully withstands a German invasion the subsequent military defeat of Hitlerism on the Continent would be infinitely difficult and long drawn out, if not almost impossible of accomplishment.

Continuance without change of the American system of broadcasting was recommended yesterday to the National Broadcasting Company by its advisory council, which met at Radio City to discuss radio's role in national defense. NBC established the council fourteen years ago to guide it in matters of public policy.

Under the distinguished patronage of Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister to the United States, and Lady Campbell, a benefit dinner dance entitled "Party for Plymouth" was given last night at Le Coq Rouge under the sponsorship of Bundles for Britain, Inc.

Frederick V. Goess, receiver for the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, which closed its doors in 1933, announced yesterday that he would sell the remaining assets of the bank at public auction on March 21. The auction will be held at 10 A.M. in his office at 100 Park Row, which is a branch office of the Manufacturers Trust Company, of which Mr. Goess is a vice president.

A total of $1,520,301 goes to charity out of the $1,765,345 net estate left by James Ulmann, who died March 10, 1940, it was shown in the estate tax appraisal filed yesterday. The gross estate was valued at $1,873,816 before deduction of debts and expenses.

Anthony Esposito, who with his brother, William, is a prisoner in the Tombs awaiting trial on two first-degree murder indictments in the hold-up shootings of Traffic Patrolman Edward F. Maher and a civilian at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street last Jan. 14, has gone on a hunger strike.

NEWARK, N.J., March 1 -- Revision of New Jersey's 97-year-old Constitution, as advocated by Governor Charles Edison in his inaugural address, has enlisted the active interest of thousands of New Jersey clubwomen, led by the State League of Women Voters.

Fordham's foot-racing forces rode the inspirational waves to their first Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championship before the startled gaze of 12,000 spectators in Madison Square Garden last night. The Rapid Rams picked up every stray point in sight, clinched the meet on the next to the last event and strode masterfully through to a smashing triumph.

This is the first story for boys and girls of their contemporaries in wartime England and one which may be unreservedly recommended, for they will find in it much of the gay courage and matter-of-fact acceptance of conditions which their parents have found in "Mrs. Miniver" and "Letter from England."

AT a time when specific racial problems are more than ever in the minds of sociologists and students of population this latest novel by Mrs. Millin, dealing, like her memotable "God's Stepchildren," with the miscegenation of South African blacks and Europeans, will appeal particularly to readers with a predilection for fiction that reflects contemporary issues.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Soviet Union has protested formally to the United States against the seizure of mail coming into this country, Secretary of State Cordell Hull revealed today. The protest was delivered by Constantine A. Oumansky, the Soviet Ambassador.
PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -- Twenty-five thousand civilian and service employes at the Philadelphia Navy Yard will soon be put in training for defense against gas attacks.

Practical experience in handling the problems of organization and management of an industrial enterprise is the term assignment of thirteen seniors at Manhattan College majoring in industrial engineering. Under the direction of Prof. Julius C. Seidl, the seminar project is an integration of all the class and laboratory subjects covered in the three-and-one-half years of the engineering course.

Gaining a commanding lead midway in the opening half and retaining it thereafter, Brooklyn College's basketball players closed their season brilliantly in their gymnasium last night by downing St. Francis, 53 to 41.

The armies of Reichsfuehrer Hitler are again on the march. German troops were in Sofia, capital of Bulgaria, and at Varna, Black Sea naval base and most important Bulgarian port, last night, and they had made at least their preliminary moves without Bulgarian or British opposition.
DENVER, March 1 -- Honesty has triumphed after a twenty-nine-year battle and a Denver druggist had received payment today of a 2-cent debt with 150 per cent interest -- in the form of a shiny nickel.

As Friday's gale swept out to sea with its snow-laden clouds thousands of men and machines went into action yesterday along the Eastern Seaboard from Maryland to Maine to clear the snowdrifts that brought death to twenty-seven persons and disrupted transportation and communication facilities.

CHESTER, Pa., March 1 -- Blessed by Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, the passenger liner Rio de la Plata, 17,500 tons, slid into the Delaware River this afternoon at the plant of the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company.

One thousand three hundred boys and girls from twenty-two independent schools of Manhattan and the Bronx will sing for the benefit of the Greater New York Fund in Carnegie Hall next Friday evening under the baton of Hugh Ross, conductor of the Schola Cantorum.

The latest Mignon Eberhart story is a big step ahead of its recent predecessors -- which should be good news for the Eberhart fans and even better news for the readers who have feared that this highly competent writer's inventive talent might be permanently bogged in quicksands of sentimentality.

Inspiration for the colors in a room's decor now comes from widely varied sources. The eyes of the hostess, her hair and her favorite gown hues will all be taken into consideration by the versatile decorator who thinks of a home as a setting for its occupants.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 2 -- Efforts to save the Tokyo conference to "mediate" the border dispute of Thailand and French Indo-China from a breakdown continued throughout yesterday and will be renewed today. The French Ambassador, Charles Arsene-Henry, received lengthy instructions from Vichy last night and after these have been decoded and studied he is expected to see Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka to explain the delay in replying and to present terms embodying Vichy's second thoughts.

LONDON, March 1 -- Ambassador John G. Winant, who was accompanied by James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, and others, landed in this country today. His arrival was marked by a historical precedent because he was greeted by King George VI before he reached London after his arrival at Bristol by airplane from Lisbon, Portugal.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 1 -- Five Army squads scored victories in as many branches of sports today, the swimmers and gymnasts downing Navy and the boxers, indoor polo team and pistol-shooting forces gaining verdicts over Cornell.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 1 -- The German Army and Air Force started what is apparently an occupation of all strategic bases in Bulgaria today when that country joined the Berlin-Rome-Tokyo pact in Vienna.

IN America there is no better gauge for measuring the success of the "melting pot" than popular music. The first immigrant generation will stubbornly retain the popular music in vogue in the land of its birth at the time of emigration, disregarding all changes of taste that may have taken place in the fatherland.

IMAGINATIVE press agents abound in radio work and the foregoing sketch is a composite sample of their technique as displayed in a pair of recent releases. Thus, with disarming candor, and sparing no adjectives or details, they present their client to the public.

What this country needs is a simple word or phrase describing the right to disagree with or criticize a minority. We have plenty of words or phrases to describe the right to criticize a majority. When a few people say harsh things about most of the people it is free speech, or freedom of conscience, or the Bill of Rights, or just plain liberty.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., March 1 -- This community is ready for "Der Tag." In fact, it expects an "invasion" in the Spring. Defense units of various agencies and organizations are busy preparing for the "invasion," which is to be in the form of a rehearsal to test the preparedness plans.

THIS is a novel about a man's failure, told intensely, with a hard, almost uncanny, feeling for the drab and depressing. And yet without any sentimental twist a bright last scene grows from it organically, interpreting if not justifying all previous desperation.

I Am appealing to you, as a friend of the theatre, for a fairer treatment to us purchasers of the lower-priced theatre tickets. For quite a few years, when business was bad, the theatres tried every way they could to entice us. Now that things are better we are being kicked around again.

THIS fascinating and, in places, amusing book presents a vivid picture, documented and convincing, of the Hawaii that includes much more than palms, pineapples, coral lagoons and native music; more, too, than the typically American business enterprise and tourist affluence which have been superimposed upon the lazy, colorful archipelago.

IN September, 1929, according to Frederick Lewis Allen's "Since Yesterday," the average price of a radio set was about $135. Crooners in that year were in full cry, but "not yet has the technique of the variety show been perfected nor can you listen in on a world-wide broad."

VIENNA, March 1 -- Bulgaria signed with the Axis today in the presence of Adolf Hitler, and German Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop predicted that "more and more" nations will follow Bulgaria's example.

IF there are two menus to be planned on the fast days of Lent, housekeepers are sometimes put to it to supply the all-important variety. Even a family really fond of fish may balk at sea food twice a day. Luckily it won't be necessary for them to go hungry at the lunch hour, as there are all kinds of luncheon dishes which call for neither meat nor fish.

Twelve paintings from the collection of the late J. Horace Harding, banker, of this city, were sold for a total of $124,300 yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. The total for the entire sale of 131 lots was $183,152.50.

Although Norway has been occupied by the Nazis since last April her people continue to wage war, mostly within the country itself. Reports tell of daily demonstrations against the regime formally headed by the Norwegian Nazi, Major Vidkun Quisling.
HONOLULU, March 1 (AP) -- Ten alien-owned fishing sampans were seized by customs officials today in Honolulu's harbor, center of the United States mid-Pacific Navy and Army defenses.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 1 -- The Naval Academy basketball team rolled up one of its highest scores of the season today to defeat Army, 48 to 36, before 5,000 fans. The triumph enabled the midshipmen to even the 18-year-old series at nine games apiece and broke Army's three-year domination of court play.

FANFARES are generally the order of the day when opera impresarios travel. Yet recently this city was visited by the director general of the second great opera house of the Western Hemisphere, the Teatro Colon of Buenos Aires, and though he stayed more than a month, scarcely any one knew he was here except singers and a few musicians.
TEACHING as many teen-age Americans as possible to fly en masse in gliders is the objective of several bills currently before State and Federal lawmaking bodies.

The committee appointed by the State Board of Social Welfare, at the request of Westchester authorities, to investigate relief expenditures in that county, will hold its first hearing at 11 A.M. on Friday in the County Building at White Plains.

When you want lots of bacon have you ever thought of baking it? The bacon is laid on a wire rack in a dripping pan and it is not usually necessary to turn the slices. After about ten minutes in a hot oven they will be flat, brown and evenly cooked. . . .

THAT major disaster for the book lover -- Moving! -- has only one silver lining, it may bring to light forgotten treasures. Among the trove cast up by this particular catastrophe, are three tiny, quaint pamphlets published by Stephen M. Crane, in 1847, who conducted a "Juvenile Bookstore" at 374 Pearl Street, and boasted he was successor to Mahlon Day, who had founded the business in 1819.

Parents faced with the problem of permitting their children to attend the current double-feature billing of motion pictures at neighborhood theatres have for a long time endeavored, without success, to have their local showings arranged so that the offerings would not be objectionable at those times when children attend the theatres.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1 -- Taking every first place, including both relays and conceding only three seconds, the Harvard varsity swimmers defeated Pennsylvania, 62 -- 13, in an Eastern intercollegiate meet in the Harvard pool tonight. It was Penn's fifth setback in the league this season.

THE author of this stimulatingly informative book has been well known and very active in the personal phases of this country's industry for a number of years. She was a member of the economics faculty at the University of Chicago; her study of "Unemployment Insurance in Great Britain" was published just ten years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- When the Federal food stamp plan of distributing surplus farm products to relief clients at government cost went into effect in New York City today, sponsors of the plan in the Department of Agriculture felt that this marked definitely the end of the "experimental" period of this novel New Deal program.

A musical event under the sponsorship of a distinguished national committee composed of patrons of the fine arts and other men and women prominent in society and musical circles will take place in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Tuesday night, when a special performance of Dr. Edgar Stillman-Kelley's "Pilgrim's Progress" will be presented as a benefit for the junior scholarship fund of the National Federation of Music Clubs.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Feb. 28 -- Good news has come to the kitchen front: Our weekly butter ration will be doubled. Instead of two ounces of butter and six ounces of margarine, we are to have the option of picking up four ounces of butter and four ounces of margarine, the basic eight ounces remaining stationary.

MONTREAL, March 1 -- The New York Rangers, spotting the Canadiens a goal in the first two periods, came from behind with a last frame drive for a 3-1 victory tonight that moved them into a tie for third place with the idle Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League standings.
CHICAGO, March 1 -- Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president, hinted today in an interview printed in The Daily Maroon, school paper, that the University of Chicago might de-emphasize basketball.

MRS. HALPERT has tried to illustrate every significant phase in the first American folk-art exhibition to be held in the Downtown Gallery's new quarters at 43 East Fifty-first Street. From her very extensive collection the items here included have been drawn.

Among the trout streams being studied by the Conservation Department is Crystal Creek, in the northern part of the State, and the findings during the first two years of a five-year study of this water are very interesting.

TWO university presses are entering the fiction field this Spring. On March 29 the University of North Carolina Press will issue "First, the Fields," a story of the North Carolina tobacco country by Charles Wood; and in April Princeton University Press will bring out "The Gang's All Here," by Harvey Smith.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, March 1 (AP) -- Three Japanese warships steamed close to shore today off Cap St. Jacques, forty miles south of this South Indo-China city and added to the nervousness of officials tormented by conflicting rumors of Japanese intentions.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 1 -- A survey of about 1,000 freshmen, sophomores and juniors enrolled in engineering and related technical courses at the Pennsylvania State College has revealed general approval of a proposed national defense plan to expedite the graduation of such students by curtailing their vacation periods.

THE eighth international salon of the Pictorial Photographers of America will open on Thursday at the American Museum of Natural History. As usual, the big show -- 597 prints -- will be presented in the museum's Hall of Education.

Techniques developed in the education of physically handicapped children may change teaching methods for normal children, Dr. Adela J. Smith, assistant director in charge of special schooling of such children in New York City, declared yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 1 -- Cornell University brought its four-day Conference on Religion in Modern Life to a successful close this week with a lecture before a capacity audience by Dr. Kirtley Mather, head of the Department of Geology at Harvard University.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Roosevelt met today in conference with four Cabinet officers most concerned with plans to speed American aid to Britain. Despite a head cold confining him to the mansion, the President felt it essential to confer with Secretaries Hull, Stimson and Morgenthau and Acting Navy Secretary Forrestal in his only engagement of the day.
A chorus composed of workmen from the quarry region near Poultney, Vt., will give a concert here in Town Hall on March 15 to aid the British War Relief Society.

NEW LONDON, N.H., March 1 -Rural social service work has become an extracurricular activity at Colby Junior College where a group of students organized as the deputations commission of the Y.W.C.A. is carrying on a wide program. Every week one group of four students conducts a crafts and recreational period for the 23 children in the North Sutton community school about four miles from the college.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- In common with many other government agencies, the Civil Service Commission is struggling with complex problems arising out of the defense program.
