It is having to deal with a larger number of employes in the classified service than ever before and faces the task of finding personnel to fill thousands of jobs which are opening up daily in countless government offices as the armament program speeds up.

Labor representatives and shipping interests presented an almost unanimous front in Washington last week in opposition to the merchant seaman bill introduced in Congress by Representative Everett M. Dirksen of illinois, under which the hiring of seamen would be confined exclusively to government hiring halls, at which shipmasters or their representatives would appear to sign on their crews.

In gratitude for the hospitality with which they have been received in this country, Polish exiles who succeeded in reaching the United States after the occupation of Poland by Germany and Russia have prepared a testimonial of thanksgiving addressed to President Roosevelt.

Mayor La Guardia, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, and six former Health Commissioners will be among the leaders in medicine, public health and civic affairs who will participate Wednesday afternoon in exercises celebrating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the establishment of the City Health Department.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 1 -- Bay View, an unsung 4-year-old, humbled turfdom's royalty today with a startling upset triumph in the world's richest horse race -- the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap.

THERE is no end to the lost generations. A new one, seemingly, crops up every year -- to confute Mr. Hemingway or possibly to confirm him. The current model, according to Howard Coxe, was born toward the end of the last war and has come uneasily to maturity during this one.

DETROIT -- With the Lansing factory of Oldsmobile back at work again last week following a shutdown caused by labor troubles at the Fisher Body plant and Packard expected to get into swing again this week following trouble at the Motor Wheel plant, the automotive picture in Detroit seems much better.

Preparations for the launching tomorrow of the city-wide campaign to obtain $375,000 for 1941's activities in New York were completed yesterday by the volunteer workers in the Civilian Mobilization for the Salvation Army, it was announced yesterday at campaign headquarters, 120 West Fourteenth Street.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 1 -- Syracuse won its seventy-ninth basketball game with Colgate tonight, 47 to 41, thus squaring this year's home-and-home series with its traditional opponent. The victory closed the Orange season and gave Syracuse a record of thirteen triumphs and five defeats.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 1 -- The suddenness with which Bulgaria became a signatory to the tripartite pact took Sofia completely by surprise, as it was learned that the German "invitation" to the Bulgarian statesmen to go to Vienna to sign the treaty was received only yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Income payments to individuals in January of this year amounted to $6,500,000,000, an increase of more than $400,000,000, or 7 per cent, over the corresponding month of 1940 but substantially below the December total of $7,400,000,000, Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones announced today.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark. March 1 -- Bucking, under the handling of Kenneth McCombs, won the feature Memphis Day Handicap in a field of seven at Oaklawn Park today. Maechance was second and Forever Prince third.
LONDON, March 1 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

In your comment "The Other Italy," on the recent gathering in Cooper Union, you appropriately emphasized the sentiments expressed by Professor Salvemini in advocating aid for Britain. What he so eloquently proclaimed is a caustic rebuke to the local Italo-American apologists for Mussolini and his regime: they would deny all aid, both moral and material, on the oft-repeated ground that "Italians owe nothing to England."

Doris Humphrey presented a reviral of her "Life of the Bee" last night as the novelty of the current week-end's bill in the repertory season which she and Charles Weidman are giving in their studio-theatre in West Sixteenth Street. The work had its first performance twelve years ago, and in a medium that has grown as rapidly as the modern dance, that is a long time.

"The Dog" was an extremely pleasant pub in an English village, with a dignified and sophisticated business woman as its proprietor, her honest young brother as assistant manager, and varied group of likable men and women as the nightly patrons -- club fashion -- of its lounge bar.

BOOKS about cities like Akron, Ohio, if written by sociologists, are likely to begin nowadays with references to some primitive tribe. This one opens its first chapter with an account of how class divisions arose among the Tanala of Madagascar when the practice of growing rice on dry soil was supplemented by the improved method of growing it on wet or irrigated soil.

In Atlantic City last week various persons attending the annual convention of the American Association of School Administrators tried to find a single theme of that meeting of 12,000 key schoolmen and women. On the program the theme was stated in words taken from the preamble of the Constitution of the United States.

I read with a great deal of interest in THE TIMES of Feb. 17 the Census Bureau report that there were about 2,350,000 births in the United States in 1940. This number, we are told, was 100,000 greater than in 1939 and the largest since 1930.

THE best-selling novel of 1940, Frederic G. Melcher, editor of The Publishers' Weekly, commented across the luncheon table, was not "For Whom the Bell Tolls," nor was it "Oliver Wiswell." "I wonder if any of you here have ever heard of the novel that was the best seller.

Album. Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Eugene Ormandy. (Victor, three twelve-inch records, $3.50.) This album, which celebrates the seventy-fifth anniversary of Sibelius's birth, is somewhat belated, for the birthday occurred in December.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The present defense effort of the United States will be threatened as was that of the World War, by serious power shortages if power needs continue to be underestimated as they have been within recent months, the Federal Power Commission said today.

The Spring has been traditionally Adolf Hitler's time. It was on March 7, 1936, that he sent German troops into the Rhineland in violation of the Treaty of Versailles. It was on March 12, 1938, that he rode triumphantly into his native Austria. A year later, March 15, he slept in Prague in the ancient palace of the Bohemian kings.

The Alcoa Steamship Company, preparing for its part in transportation of supplies to United States naval bases in the Atlantic and Caribbean, expects to operate twenty-five ships, nine of them newly constructed, at the completion of its $21,000,000 building program, it was announced yesterday.

Outside his own New England Ethan Allen is one of the least-known heroes of the American Revolution, yet that trumpet-voiced giant, with his marvelous strength, of character as well as body, his ignorance of fear and his inexhaustible capacity for hardship, is a figure to hold his own beside Boone, Crockett and others who have long since become part of our heroic folklore.

LAKE PLACID CLUB, N.Y., March 1 -- With excellent conditions prevailing for skiing, figure skating and other outdoor Winter diversions, the current week-end at this Adirondacks resort finds many persons of prominence from Eastern States participating in the sports programs.

NATIONAL defense and population policy may not seem to be directly related, for it is apparent that there are adequate numbers of men available to supply our military and naval establishments and to provide for our second lines of industrial preparedness.

Albert Spalding, prominent American violinist, announced yesterday that he had resigned from the American Guild of Musical Artists and had applied for membership in Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 1 -- The Japanese trade commission touring South America in search of raw materials arrived yesterday at Porto Alegre, where a spokesman declared that Japan was keenly interested in concluding a barter agreement with Brazil similar to the one just signed in Argentina.

Two years ago today Cardinal Eugenio Pacelli, on his sixty-third birthday, became the 262d successor to St. Peter and the spiritual leader of 350,000,000 persons. The new Pope took the name of Pius XII. The spiritual titles to which he acceded were Vicar of Christ, Successor of St. Peter, Bishop of Rome, Archbishop and Metropolitan of the Roman Province, Primate of Italy, Patriarch of the West, Supreme Pontiff of the Universal Church.

Because "the standard of living of the Dutch people is declining rapidly and steadily," disaffection and sabotage are increasing from day to day and "the Nazis look upon Holland as the spearhead of anti-Nazi agitation in Nazi-occupied territories," it was asserted in a report issued yesterday by Dr. Joseph Tenenbaum, chairman of the Joint Boycott Council of the American Jewish Congress and Jewish Labor Committee.

LONDON, Sunday, March 2 (UP) -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler has made good his threat of greatly intensified submarine warfare against British shipping by more than quadrupling the number of U-boats in the Atlantic, a reliable source said today.

City College's basketball team scored a 54-45 victory over the Diplomats of Franklin and Marshall College last night to shatter the visitors' eleven-game winning streak. This was City's thirteenth victory in seventeen games and F. and M.'s third defeat in sixteen.
Educators are truly in a state of flux and ought to centralize their ideas in some clearing house of education so that the man in the street may know what education is all about.

FROM Quito comes word that Ecuador will release on March 10 a series commemorating the "discovery" of the Amazon by Francisco Orellana four centuries ago. The world's largest river in volume, it was actually discovered in 1500 by Vicente Yanez Pinzon, a companion of Columbus; he ascended to a point about fifty miles from the sea.

Paced by Jack Miller, sophomore sprint star, the St. Joseph's swimming team from Philadelphia defeated Manhattan, 51 to 23, in the Park Central pool yesterday. This was St. Joseph's fifth victory in eight starts.

UNDER its tragically suggestive title, this little book is made up of sixteen letters from a family deep-rooted in the soil of the West Frankreich Province -- and in those last three words the whole tragedy which lies in the book's title is given its inclusive significance.

March came in like a lion yesterday, on the radio as well as the weather. A severe black-out of overseas and transcontinental short-wave circuits, which began about 9 o'clock in the morning, continued throughout the day to block long-distance communication channels.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 -- Yale scored in every period to defeat Harvard's sextet, 8 -- 2, tonight before 3,600 spectators in the first game of their annual hockey series. The Crimson, however, has fifty-three victories to Yale's twenty-eight, with four ties in the series.

THIS is a moderately successful attempt by a distinguished historian and biographer to do for Louisiana, especially the New Orleans area, what Margaret Mitchell did for the Atlanta district in "Gone With the Wind."

MIAMI, Fla., March 1 -- For the first time in the history of the Widener Challenge Cup an owner was one, two at the finish today. Edward Moore's Circle M Ranch entry of Big Pebble and Get Off finished a head apart in that order at Hialeah before 21,499 persons who bet a record amount of $160,878 on the mile and a quarter classic.

The Commerce Department's latest weekly report of gold imports shows strikingly the decrease in such shipments. The $5,779,000 received in the week ending Feb. 19 was, with two exceptions, the smallest in more than a year, and it followed a steady weekly decrease.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 -Under the noise of Japanese warplanes and exploding Japanese bombs, students in the Middle School of Yale-in-China have learned English by a new system which has become so successful that the poems of the young Orientals have been sent back to the home university to be studied for their charm and beauty.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 1 -- The streets of this old capital city and towns and villages from Arica to the Strait of Magellan were alive with parades, loudspeakers and other forms of political excitement tonight, for tomorrow Chilean voters go to the polls in the quadrennial Congressional election.

Fourteen out of fifteen ships carrying packages of rationed food-stuffs to Great Britain have been safely convoyed across the Atlantic from New York, officials of the British-American Trading Corporation disclosed yesterday.
EXETER, N.H., March 1 -- Exeter's basketball team, leading most of the way today in a spirited contest with Andover, recorded a 41-to-37 victory.

"I DON'T want to mention names," said Gene Kelly, picking his words, "but I have been bored in shows. Please believe me, I have. When you get lyrics that are just June, moon, Miss Calhoun, above, love -- why, however good a showman you try to be, the time comes when it is very hard to give.

NO composition has developed such a wealth of legend as "Don Giovanni." Mozart and his librettist, Da Ponte, wrote this great comedy and tragedy of human passion in a white heat of fantasy, and the opera so captivated the imagination of Europe that in the lifetime of the composer fanciful tales were related about it.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- The first week of training for the 1941 model Yankee baseball machine ended on Huggins Field today and found Manager Joe McCarthy highly satisfied with the physical condition of the batterymen, infielders and outfielders under his direction, but with his worries far from ended.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 1 -- Strict enforcement of Delaware's 200-year-old Sunday "blue laws" tomorrow has been ordered by James R. Morford, State Attorney General. Instructions went out to police officials after the House of Representatives had rejected an amendment, already passed by the Senate, to permit every community to decide for itself the extent of Sabbath observance.

THE roots of history, remarks Professor Peattie of Ohio State University, "run deep into the ground." And whether or not he so intended it, this sentenee from the fifth chapter of "Geography in Human Destiny" can be read literally and figuratively as a text for his suggestive and provocative book.

Despite large-scale movements of war supplies to Britain and defense materials for United States military bases, freight traffic through the Port of New York is being handled with virtually no congestion, a survey made here yesterday indicated.

I LOVE a stage snowstorm! It's the only thing left in stage effects which still gives me a thrill. So, the other night when I saw "Old Acquaintance" and Jane Cowl drew aside the curtain of the window and showed us a sure-enough good old paper snowstorm, a wave of nostalgia gathered me up and swept me back to some of the "good old days."

THE ode as a much practiced form of English poetry prior to this century has seldom received from scholars the study it deserves. And perhaps the reason is not far to seek. It was originally a classical poetic invention, restricted in subject-matter to sonorous themes and highly specialized in craftsmanship.

Promoting the "good neighbor policy" and bringing the warm hues of the tropics to minimize New York's March winds, the International Flower Show will have as its theme this year Pan America. There will be colorful South and Central American gardens and exhibits from Mexico and Canada.

SAID to be the greatest mass-delivery in light-plane history, 200 engines were recently shipped from the Lycoming division of the Aviation Manufacturing Corporation at Williamsport, Pa., to the Taylorcraft Aviation Corporation in Alliance, Ohio.

The sight of the mew crop of Spring clothes for children is enough to make a girl wish she were 6 again and could wear these wondrous things -- so much more attractive they are than what the unprotesting young once put up with.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Ernest Bevin, British Minister of Labor, declared in a message to America today that industry and labor were organizing in England "not merely to withstand Hitler's onslaught but to make the great offensive which will cause his destruction."

Architectural studies for the new cancer hospital and clinic to be constructed by the city at 163d Street and Fort Washington Avenue, and to be known as the Nightingale Hospital, are nearly complete, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

A benefit exhibition, planned to illustrate by data and photographs the work of the Brooklyn Navy branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, will be held from Wednesday through March 15 at the Committee of Mercy War Relief Center, 435 Park Avenue, this city, under the auspices of the association's ladies' auxiliary headed by Mrs. Lawrence Copley Thaw.

THE Ballet Theatre has only one novelty to announce for its fourth week at the Majestic Theatre. That is the first performance this season of Michel Fokine's "Carnaval" on Tuesday evening after several postponements. Rehearsals are being supervised by Fokine himself, and Edward Caton will be seen as Pierrot and Fernando Alonso as Pantalon for the first time.

Flip, in spite of his four white socks, which old horsemen would deplore, is as engaging a colt as ever grazed on Kentucky blue grass. He grows, in Wesley Dennis's spirited pictures, from grace to glory, kicking, bucking and twisting with coltlike gusto.

How much of the German attack on British merchantmen, lightships and trawlers washes back on the English beaches is shown by Sir Godfrey Baring's report on the work of the Royal National Lifeboat Institution. Already in the present conflict this service has saved 3,300 persons from death at sea, as against 5,322 rescued during the entire four-year course of the World War.

A MODERN realistic artist, who died a century ago, and a newcomer to New York who makes use of semi-abstract approach in his vigorous landscapes are current attractions at Henry Kleeman's. The former is Goya, who is represented by twenty of the "Caprichos," twenty of the grim "Disasters of War" series and ten of the famous bullfighting etchings.

The long-awaited thrust of the German Army into Bulgaria has now become a reality. German troops crossed the Danube yesterday, almost at the moment that the hard-pressed Government of that country was going through the formal and empty motions of "aligning itself" with the Axis Powers.

IN 1935, Robert Hakim, French film producer, met d'Ashelbe, an ex-commissioner of the Paris police, who told him a strange story about a "super-criminal" who had eluded the French police for many years by hiding out in the Casbah, or native quarter, of Algiers.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A study of five cities especially affected by national defense activity, made public today by Secretary Perkins, stated that outside of a considerable advance in rents the changes in the cost of living were similar in most respects to those in larger communities of the country.

SOME hard hockey players come from Alberta, Canada, and plenty of hard wheat, too. This came up in a conversation with Tommy Anderson, the injured forward of the downtrodden Americans of the hockey circuit. The Dutton Dusters being where they are -- skating around in the dark of the National Hockey League cellar -- it was felt that it would be polite to talk of something else.

MADISON, Wis., March 1 (AP) -- The American Bandmasters Association doesn't agree with Leopold Stokowski, on his suggestion that military music be rescored and Army bands be rearranged to give the fighting forces more spirit in battle.
BERLIN, March 1 (AP) -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's own newspaper, Voelkischer Beobachter, today listed the Axis pact signings as among the "bloodless victories of Adolf Hitler."

THERE is every indication that the theatre has become a lively subject for book publishing. It is a regular practice now to publish well-prefaced plays and anthologies in excellent format. Books on playwriting and play production, biographical and critical studies and reviews of special periods roll off the college and trade presses.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The national labor defense picture is like a continuous performance. Almost every day strikes and labor disputes are settled, but new difficulties arise until the spectator is inclined to say: "This is where I came in."

In an effort to stimulate more rapid progress in training and to provide greater incentive for that progress, a memorandum entitled "The Competitive Spirit," which sets up a system of individual and unit awards for the First Army, was issued last week to that Army.

DESIGNED to show how industrial research and constantly advancing industrial techniques contribute to the vigor and to the strength of the nation, a newly designed traveling exposition was formally opened at Miami last week by General Motors, launching a nation-wide tour.

WHETHER or not events draw this country into the present war, says Harry Scherman, it is plain that "the world is in an era of war, and with all the other peoples of the world we must pay the price that war forever has exacted."

Orchids, fascinating and glamorous, are scarcely plants one expects to find growing, to say nothing of flowering, in a New York City apartment. But P.F. Rolph, a business executive whose hobby is orchids, has created conditions agreeable to orchid plants in his apartment and used discrimination in choosing those he wished to grow there.
An alarm asking the police to be on the lookout for Dr. Otto Klemperer, internationally known orchestra conductor, was broadcast yesterday by the police of Rye, N.Y.

In line with a general trend throughout the country toward vocational studies, entering students at City College have chosen engineering and business pursuits as the careers they would like to prepare for while in college, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Daniel F. Brophy, director of the Personnel Bureau.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., March 1 (AP) -- A young flying instructor and his student were killed today when their light, two-seater plane crashed in a thicket on a near-by farm.

IN "Where the Apple Reddens" Alexandra Phillips has written a satiric comedy with overtones of thought and feeling, the story of a lion-hunting lady and a literary lion who were to become each other's Nemesis.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today the application of eight subsidiaries of the Associated Gas and Electric System, which is in receivership, for the transfer of the assets of five of them to the Southland Public Service Company, created for the purpose of the acquisition, and the subsequent sale of the securities of Southland to Dallas Rupe Son of Dallas, Texas.

"EVERY American boy has a God-given right to enlist in the Navy," declared one insistent papa. "It is more difficult to enlist in the Navy than to enter college," some one else has rather startlingly averred.

SINGAPORE, "City of the Lions" to the ancients, appears now to be approaching the destiny for which Britain has been preparing it for seventeen years. As Japan makes new moves in her grim chess game, as Britain lands strong reinforcements for Singapore's already formidable defenses, it becomes more than ever the strategic focus of the East.

BOSTON, March 1 -- For eleven consecutive years a most significant academic event, this year Boston University's Founders' Day celebration on Wednesday and Thursday, March 12 and 13, will center upon the battle for freedom of the press in the United States and will be attended by leading editors, publishers and educators from all sections of the country, according to the report of Dr. Daniel L. Marsh, president of the university.

BERLIN, March 1 -- The failure of the Roman god Mars to bring victory to the banners of the Fascist legions in Greece and North Africa was a subject which, excepting for the daily publication of Italian Army communiques, for many months simply was not discussed in the German press, on the radio or by the public speakers.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Chester C. Davis, member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, and Emil Schram, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, have been elected presidents of the St. Louis and Chicago Federal Reserve Banks, respectively, by vote of the members of the boards of the banks.

There has been a great deal of surprise and incredulity in the United States about England's stand in this war. In the beginning of the war American friends were constantly telling me that the German war machine would be the end of us, and when I laughed them down they looked uncomfortable, thinking it mere blind loyalty on my part.

Miss Lutie at 63 could well be called a "dainty rogue in porcelain.'' And readers of "Our First Murder" will remember how easily -- not to say eagerly -- she took to the business of being a New York detective when a surprising legacy thus strangely transplanted her and her elder sister from their native village in Maine.

A STRIKING reminder of the days of sail, when every blue-water port was dominated by the masts and yards of the square-rigged windjammer, came with the arrival at Boston recently of the Swedish four-masted bark Abraham Rydberg.

THIS book is to be welcomed not only for its own sake but because it may point the way for others in its field. In the past few years biography for the high-school age has increased steadily in quality and scope, but though there have been several excellent lives of musical figures, this is the first full-length biography of an artist.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 2 -- Two decrees recently issued by President Getulio Vargas have kept the Axis diplomats on tenterhooks. One decree outlawed all newspapers printed in Brazil in foreign languages. Six months were given them to cease operations.

Because of the heavy snow only ten gunners were able to reach the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. A high wind whirled the blue rocks into impossible shooting angles and as a result the high-over-all scratch trophy was taken by B.M. Higginson with a card of 90 out of 100 targets.
WILDWOOD, N.J., March 1 -- A snow plow was used to clear the way for an ambulance today to rush to a hospital a fisherman who was suffering from blood poisoning.

In its fight against the Hitler tyranny, democracy has at its disposal one powerful weapon which has received insufficient attention, both on the British fighting front and within the American arsenal. This weapon consists in a pronouncement of war aims.

EXTENDING its radio beams around the globe, the German Kurzwellensender now enters five short-wave bands with evening programs for North and South America. The Spring turnover, coming at a time when the Northern European radio lanes daily are becoming more suitable for clear reception in America, results in better Berlin reception here than has been noted since late last Fall.

THE plans of Carnegie Institute for next Fall call for another type of exhibition of American painting, due to the fact that the international must again be omitted because of European conditions. The new exhibition will open on Founders Day, Oct. 23, and will continue through Dec. 14.
DALLAS, Texas, March 1 (AP) -- Big Bill Lee, Cub hold-out pitcher, followed the hounds today but his mind was on baseball.

Mrs. Rushmore Patterson, chairman of the women's division of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, has announced that plans have been completed for a nation-wide poster campaign to fortify further defense spirit in the United States.

DETROIT, March 1 -- The twenty-sixth annual show of the Detroit Kennel Club opened today with an entry of 1,083 dogs representing fifty-nine breeds. Local kennels had a large and representative collection of St. Bernards, which were judged by Enno Meyer of Milford, Ohio.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 1 -- Citizens of Mount Vernon discussed today plans to transform this community into a "model" and "exemplary" city as an example to municipalities throughout the country "in the common effort to contribute to national defense."

BUSINESS on the road has shown an increase of 20 to 25 per cent since Jan. 1 and is apparently directly attributable to the national defense appropriations, according to Marcus Heiman, president of the United Booking Office and of the League of New York Theatres.

Reports on retail trade here last week were favorable. The snowstorm cut volume to some extent, but leading department stores had sizable increases in sales during the earlier days of the week. Home furnishings and a variety of ready-to-wear items fared well.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- The Winter that has struck Paris is the worst that the capital of France has known since the Middle Ages. It is harder than the Winter of 1789, when, told that the people had no bread, Queen Marie Antoinette said: "Why don't they eat cake."

Celebrating the 400th anniversary of the beginning of the Society of Jesus in September, 1540, former students of twenty-eight of the Jesuit colleges and universities in the United States and Canada -- a number estimated at 125,000 -- will be represented at corporate holy communions and communion breakfasts in 300 localities in the two countries on March 23.

A national championship event in early March instead of the customary time in September was the decision the other day of the 91-cubic-inch class ringleaders. The place will be St. Petersburg, Fla., and the time next Saturday and Sunday.

The first county caucuses to propose a slate of officers for the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs will be held this week. Presidents of affiliated clubs in Queens will meet tomorrow at the Jamaica Y.M.C.A. with Mrs. Claude K. Hunter, county representative, presiding.

OF the story it is necessary only to say, as Miss McCullers announces in the first two pages, that it tells of the events leading up to a murder on an Army post in the South; that the principal people involved in the tragedy are two Army officers, a major and a captain; two Army women, their respective wives; a private soldier, a Filipino house boy and a horse.

RADIO listeners generally have more musical intelligence and appreciation than some of the sophisticated concertgoers attending Carnegie Hall, according to John Barbirolli. The dark-haired, diminutive and alert conductor of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, heard every Sunday over WABC and the 110 stations of the CBS network, has a soft spot in his heart for his unseen public.

Confident of an ultimate British victory, Rear Admiral Clark Howell Woodward, retiring Commandant of the Third Naval District and of the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, believes that the United States could "very easily give another fifty destroyers" to Britain.

Topics concerning children of all ages are on the Spring calendar of courses and lectures of the Child Study Association of America, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street. Next Tuesday evening Dr. Alice V. Keliher, assistant professor of education, New York University, will talk on "Youth Attitudes and National Issues."

IN the eyes of the general public, view or "studio" cameras have always represented the most stuffy and formalized type of photography. This, in part, has been due to their large size, the fact that they require the constant use of a tripod, and that one can hardly operate them without a focusing cloth.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A new tool for research, electronic and light microscopes combined into a single instrument, is the subject of a patent (No. 2,233,286) awarded to Ladislaus Marton of Collingswood, N.J.

War relief drives, contrary to opinion held in some quarters, have not overshadowed normal appeals of local welfare institutions, Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, president of the Federation for the Support of the Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York, said yesterday in announcing that this year's fund campaign is "already the most successful drive in history."

THE means is often as important as the end, and the debate on the lease-lend bill has focused popular attention not only on the issue of aid to the democracies but equally on the issue of Presidential power. Does the bill concentrate excessive powers in the Executive? Does it represent an abdication of the legislative?

The city filed yesterday with the State Tax Commission in Albany a formal complaint signed by Mayor La Guardia against the tentative assessment equalization rates for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1942. The valuation of special franchises in the five counties of New York City is based upon these equalization rates.
The State Income Tax Bureau, unaccountably, is getting busy very early this year, six weeks before the deadline for filing 1940 returns, it was reported yesterday.

FEW things have done so much to help the ordinary man to realize the disturbance caused in the publishing world by the war as the fact that he could not get his copy of Whitaker's Almanack until the end of January.

TORONTO, March 1 (AP) -- The Leafs and Bruins fought to a scoreless tie in seventy minutes of bruising hockey tonight. Toronto thus protected its 2-point margin over Boston at the top of the National League. The game attracted the largest crowd of the year here, 14,865 paid admissions.

VARIOUS arrangements and orchestrations of works originally written for other instruments have been made recently, the principle being the subject of much lively discussion. Georg Szell has just arranged the orchestration of the celebrated string quartet in E minor of the Czech composer Bedrich Smetana, for the concert of the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra which he will conduct on next Saturday evening.

EXERCISE Roughly speaking, there are two kinds of exercise -- the kind people do for fun and the kind they do because they feel it will be good for their hips, waistlines and souls, and will permit them to feel virtuously that they are keeping themselves from going to pieces. The second kind has certain advantages.

GHOST towns do not often come to life, except through the pen of some particularly gifted author. The exception that proves the rule is Long Branch, the New Jersey seaside resort that came into national fame during the second half of the nineteenth century, subsided into desuetude for more than a decade, and then -- to coin a phrase -- did a phoenix toward an even more worthwhile career.

OWEN LATTIMORE went with two comrades -- a Mongolian lama and a Chinese-born Swede -- into the troubled, unfamiliar lands beyond the Yellow River to the Festival of Jenghis Khan. He took part in a ceremony which, so far as he knows, has never even been witnessed by any other stranger.

IT is no small advantage to a novelist to have served an apprenticeship to poetry. One has noted this often before. But the observation strikes with fresh impact in the case of Josephine Pinckney, whose reputation to date rests mainly on her verse.

Tax officials and legislators of seven Northeastern States conferred yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt on a bill designed to set up a procedure for States to compromise disputes over taxes on large estates when the question of residence is in doubt.

VISITOR: The Egyptian flag, seldom seen in New York harbor, flew last week at the stern of the liner Zamzam, in port after a two months' voyage from Alexandria. The most prominent member of the crew appeared to be the bartender, Mahoumed Saleh. He told of the many drinks he knew how to mix and told of an American drink he wanted to learn about.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The freighter Exmouth, 8,000 tons, has been chartered by the American Red Cross from the American Export Line to carry a $1,250,000 cargo of food, clothing and medicines to unoccupied France, it was announced today.

ALBANY, March 1 -- The difficulties of income taxpayers in preparing returns are eased somewhat by new amendments to the tax law, Cortland A. Wilber, director of the Income Tax Bureau, stated today. The amendments apply to returns due April 15. One is concerned with the execution of returns.

A slight increase in consumer response to advertised merchandise in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles was noted last week, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

THE Eastern tournament enters its second day today at the Park Central Hotel. Nonmaster pairs will play two sessions, at 2 and 8:30 P.M., for the trophy given by Mrs. Herman Liberman. Simultaneously, the two final rounds of the Goldman Trophy open-pair event will be played by those who qualified yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1 -- Columbia's varsity basketball team, now second in the race for the Eastern Intercollegiate League title, easily topped Harvard, 36 -- 18, in a return game tonight.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 1 -- In a historic ceremony this afternoon The Stars and Stripes were raised on Tucker's Island signalizing its transfer with Morgan's Island to be sites of United States naval and air bases in the new crescent of defenses leased on British territory from Newfoundland to Trinidad.

COFFEE SOAP -- A soap made of fresh, roasted crushed coffee beans, tallow oil, coconut oil and neutralizing alkali has been developed by Dr. R.B. Brown. He says that his soap has a softening and smoothing effect on the skin and that it rapidly removes grease, grime, ink and other dirt in either hot or cold water.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 (AP) -- The future existence of Italy and Japan depends upon the freedom of the seas which the United States and Great Britain have maintained since the time of President Monroe, Senator Thomas of Utah declared tonight.

MIAMI, Fla -- Next Sunday's boxing matches, in which some of the ring's well-known contenders will meet in Biscayne Fronton, Miami, to aid the British-American Ambulance Corps, are claiming the attention of members of the colony here.
ROME, March 1 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

NO one should like such an irresponsible, deceitful gentleman as Timothy Martin. He was a gentleman, with a nice sense of polite living. He went to his office every day, and his partners and his secretary rather marveled at his skill in business, for they never saw him do any work.

New rules relating to the religious education classes conducted in the New York City school system, to prevent proselytizing and the introduction of the religious question into the classroom, have been urged upon the Board of Education by the Citizens Union.
LONDON -- At Tetton House, a regency country manor near Taunton in Somersetshire, an American woman has established a refuge for expectant mothers from London's East Side.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Recent increased war activity in Africa and tension in the Far East are reflected in the monthly report of the State Department, covering licenses for the export of arms, ammunition and implements of war during January.

THE Articles of Confederation were our first Constitution. Under them the American people lived for eight years -- from 1781 to 1789 -- and out of them emerged the Federal Constitution of 1787. They furnished, then, the transition from the unorganized union of the Continental Congress to the highly organized union of the Federal system.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- An implication that the Federal Government might like to regiment the fantastic hats which women wear nowadays and get the feminine headgear situation more down toward normal is seen in a bulletin issued today by the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 -- Captain Johnny Cobb's scoring spree in the last few minutes carried Yale to a 48-44 triumph over the Manhattan quintet tonight in a fast contest featured by exceptional shot-making.

The author of the delightful "Mrs. Meigs" stories was a little girl in a soldiers' home at the turn of the century. What is more, she lived there for twenty-five years; and she thought, and continued to think, that it was "just the nicest place in the world."

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Erratic fluctuations ruled in the wheat market here today on the Board of Trade, with the extreme range running to 7/8 cent. Most of the trading was of a professional character except just after the opening, when some of the leading operators were on both sides of the market.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Administration went on the radio tonight to call for an end to "this delay, this dawdling" as the second week of Senate debate on the lease-lend bill closed with the discussion following a now familiar pattern of opposition speakers engaging in a series of colloquies with their colleagues.

This is the best of Miss Patterson's growing list of romances. She gives you San Francisco in the fog and rain, with her young heroine, Robin, working hard and liking it, but hoping that some day things will be different and better.

ROME, March 1 -- Bulgaria's adherence to the tripartite pact today is regarded here as an event that should among other things, warn Washington against interfering in a Europe asserted to be solidly aligned with the Axis.

Although early gains were somewhat pared, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange in the short session yesterday continued to show firmness, and final quotations were unchanged to up 5 points. The distant months held relatively firmer than the near positions since the latter had to absorb some hedge sales on the scale-up.

The problem of delivery became acute in the wholesale market last week, it was reported yesterday in a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. Fabric mills asked from three to four weeks for delivery on merchandise, and manufacturers were unable to obtain certain fabrics.

LONDON, Feb. 1. QUITE apart from the normal routine of film production, there have been considerable comings and goings among screen celebrities recently. The Oliviers arrived home chased by a German airplane. Ann Dvorak came to town in a taxicab.

THE child who spells out words by the time he is 3, who stumps the family with questions about the solar system when he is 6, and would rather curl up with an atlas than with "Jack and the Beanstalk," may be thought annoying or odd, or "old-fashioned," according to the grown-up point of view.

HAVANA, March 1 -- The Giants still are easy pickings for the Dodgers. Today Colonel Bill Terry's men took it on the chin for the second time this year. The score, 10 to 5, was more decisive than in yesterday's 4-to-3 game. A crowd of 4,500 saw the contest in Tropical Stadium.

The Silverthorn brother and sister were the quietest, most dignified and well-behaved young people at the wedding. She was just out of college, and he was not much older, but they glowed with the pious qualities which Mrs. Hill bestows on her favorite characters, and some of the other boys and girls thought the Silverthorns were disgustingly serious.

ROME, March 1 (AP) -- The Italian High Command told in detail today of a victory over an "imposing" British force that, it was said, went to great pains to seize the tiny Italian island of Castellorizzo, off Turkey's southwest coast, only to be ejected.

Industry and labor will cooperate loyally on preparations for national defense, Clarence Francis, president of the General Foods Corporation, and Clinton S. Golden, Northeastern regional director of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, declared yesterday in speeches at the Saturday afternoon forum of the National Democratic Club.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 1 (AP) -- Germany occupied Bulgaria today -- the eleventh sovereign State she has overrun since 1938.

The State of Nebraska, through its recently created Consumers Public Power District, has gone a long way toward solving many of the problems involved in public ownership and operation of electric power facilities, it is believed in financial circles.

In two months or a little more the youthful president of the New York Stock Exchange will slap hasty signatures on a last sheaf of papers, shake hands all around with associates, turn in his key at the Yale Club and march off to be fitted for an army suit at government expense.

A nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion indicates that Wendell Willkie has probably now achieved a wider degree of popularity with the rank and file of American voters than he did at any time during the Presidential campaign of last Fall, Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director, reports.

Under a new two-year schedule introduced this semester in the mathematics department of Hunter College, students in that major may select their courses several semesters in advance, and thus insure an integrated program throughout their college course, Professor Jewell Hughes Bushey, chairman of the department, announced yesterday.

THOSE interested in medieval music have awaited for many years something better than the ordinary general history of music, with its brief and partially accurate summary in the opening chapter. The first two volumes of the Oxford History of Music (we agree with the author's remark on Page xii) are a masterwork; but they are not easy to read and are forty years old, a hoary age as musicology moves now.

TO see Mr. Behrman's newest play, "The Talley Method," is to be reminded of Mr. Behrman's last play, "No Time for Comedy." "The Talley Method" illustrates the point of "No Time for Comedy." Two years ago Mr. Behrman was frivolously discussing the dilemma of a writer of fashionable comedy who wanted to do something profound.

Modern history follows the old voyages of mythology as the Italians bomb Corfu, where the wise Odysseus was washed ashore and where he found Nausicaa bathing among her maidens; as the British seize Lemnos and the island speck of Castellorizzo, not far from Rhodes of the ancient, fabulous civilization; as blockading ships move cautiously among

APACHES are on the warpath again -- not along the wild trails of Arizona but in the dark crooked alleys of Paris. The police of the occupied capital have banned the sale of large clasp and hunting knives, the type the denizens of the city's underworld know how to employ with deadly skill.

Magazines, both old and current, have been placed on exhibition at the New York Public Library in celebration of the 200th anniversary of the introduction of this form of periodical in America in February, 1741. Copies of Benjamin Franklin's The General Magazine of that date are included in the exhibit, which remain open through May.

PARTICIPATION in the defense program by the automobile industry on a very broad front was described last week by Alvan Macauley, president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association. In summary, Mr. Macauley reported that airplane engine production, now at 350 per month at one plant, will be multiplied many times very soon.

World activity in chemical research has slumped about 13 per cent since the outbreak of the European war in September, 1939, according to a report by Professor E.J. Crane, of Ohio State University to the American Chemical Society. The decline, as reflected in the scientific, technical and trade publications of all nations, compares with a drop of about 24 per cent in the year following the beginning of the World War in 1914.

ALTHOUGH the music composers, authors and publishers have lately been at odds with most of the broadcasting companies, there still has been music in, and on, the air. In such a time of musical drought, the public warbler who cannot sing the new songs without making due requital to the copyright holders sings the old songs instead.

THAT fine statement of his faith in the American way of life -- a faith which took full count of the difficulties involved -- which Whitman set forth in "Democratic Vistas" is worth turning to in these times. Whitman knew that democracy, to endure, must be deserved by a people who have possessed themselves of it.

Several thousand members of special committees of the Catholic Daughters of America, by means of the 1,500 courts, or local units of this organization in various parts of the country, will aid youths in military training camp areas and transient families and individuals in industrial centers.

LONDON, March 1 -- The British authorities had no recent official information from Bulgaria today, but professed to be not particularly concerned. The British are quite ready to believe the reports that armed uniformed Germans are actually in Bulgaria but they have left in the hands of the British Minister in Sofia.

BACH'S "Peasant Cantata" will receive a staged presentation conducted by Otto Lehmann Tuesday night, March 11, at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel, with Florence Hurst, soprano, and Frederic Jencks, baritone, as soloists.

DURING the European war's first eighteen months, ended last Friday, at least 780 major and minor varieties of stamps were issued as the direct or indirect result of military or political developments. When the censorship curtain is lifted further, it is believed, information regarding other pieces of postal paper occasioned by the conflict will be received.

ONE of the deepest and darkest mysteries popped up the other day when the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America (Hays office) issued its annual statistical review of the state of the motion-picture industry in 1940.

To advance its many philanthropic projects and its extensive preparedness program, the Carroll Club of New York again has taken over the gala opening performance of the eighth annual Figure Skating Carnival of the Skating Club of New York, on the night of March 28 at Madison Square Garden.

"HELLZAPOPPIN'," crackled and sputtered to a zany finale at the War Department Theatre here Monday night when the proscenium arch fluttered to the stage in the final scene. Tangled in the folds, Ole Olsen told the Army audience it had not only witnessed a theatrical performance but a miracle.

LONDON, March 1 (UP) -- King George VI tonight gave United States Ambassador John G. Winant a personal welcome "somewhere in England" as a personal and unprecedented gesture of Anglo-American good-will.

WATERTOWN, Conn., March 1 -- As never before, the American student has become keenly interested in the world around him and aware of the necessity to equip himself to handle the problems which face his generation. Paul Cruikshank, headmaster of the Taft School here, declared today.

The West Side Hospital and Dispensary, a small voluntary hospital that has served the workers and residents of the West Thirties and Forties since it opened in 1872, was reopened yesterday after extensive repairs and renovation of its building and equipment at 446 West Forty-third Street.

Six hundred industrial corporations that have announced results of operations in 1940 show an increase of 25.1 per cent in profits over 1939. The aggregate net income of the group for the year was $1,322,073,771, or $265,089,343 over the $1,056,946,428 reported for 1939, according to a compilation made by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A steady stream of callers last week went in and out of the White House executive offices. Most of the callers -- among them were Senators, high-ranking Administration advisers and Army and Navy chiefs -- came to talk about lease-lend plans. Franklin D. Roosevelt, back in the capital after a Hyde Park holiday, seemed anxious for the swift passage of the bill that was introduced in Congress seven weeks ago.

TWO group exhibitions similar in theme are now on the local roster: "England," at Knoedler's (until April 5) and "Outdoor England," at the Century Club (until April 1). Most of the canvases assembled in the Century Club show are sporting paintings by artists such as Abraham Cooper, John Ferneley, Francis Hayman, Charles Cooper Henderson, Sir Edwin Henry Landseer, Ben Marshall, James Pollard, George Stubbs, James Ward and Alfred J. Munnings.

LEO SOWERBY'S symphony in F sharp minor will receive its premiere at the concerts to be given this Thursday night and Friday night by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, under Frederick Stock, in Chicago. The work was written for the orchestra in honor of its current fiftieth anniversary celebration.

Cardboard boxes filled with shirting, bleached and unbleached muslin and wool of all kinds, lengths and colors, have been loaded onto the Ellis Island ferry boat by the dozens during the last week. They were destined for the storeroom in the island's Immigration Building whose supplies are provided by the National Society, Daughters of the American Revolution.

Trading in stocks yesterday was so small that the share list was unable to establish any definite trend and most prices moved within fractional ranges. Not since Aug. 24, last, has the turnover on the Stock Exchange retreated to so small a total, with the day's transfers at only 141,190 shares, compared with 404,030 shares on Feb. 15, the last previous Saturday for a short session.

Stricter self-regulation by installment sellers for the protection of users of consumer credit, and specific changes in existing State laws to exert compulsion on irresponsible dealers who ignore ethical standards, feature legislative recommendations on installment selling which will be introduced this week in Albany under the sponsorship of business and quasi-public agencies.

The House of Representatives lost no time last Tuesday in passing Bill H.R. 3531, to be known as the "Excess Profits Tax Amendments of 1941," introduced on Monday by Mr. Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. Now before the Senate Finance Committee, the bill is expected to be speedily reported out of committee and adopted by the Senate.

ATHENS, Sunday, March 2 -- More than 19,000 persons were said to be homeless today in Larissa as a result of a violent earthquake that shook Northern Greece yesterday. Reports from the earthquake zone said Larissa was wrecked, buildings tumbling down as the earth moved.

ROME, March 1 (AP) -- King Victor Emmanuel ordered three days' mourning in the Italian court for Alfonso XIII of Spain today, while Queen Elena knelt in prayers beside the late monarch's body at the Grand Hotel.

DETROIT, March l -- Social, health and police agencies are combining forces in Southeastern Michigan to combat the threat to the public peace, health and safety caused by the influx of 60,000 "boomers."

THE author of this book, Mr. Robert H. Newman, is only 24. He has served as an ambulance driver, first in Finland, then in France. He has seen the brave little nation of the North stand up against the might of Soviet Russia.

THIS Spring more than ever the tailor-made -- skirt and jacket or the ensemble -- is the cornerstone of the smart woman's wardrobe. Tailor-mades have passed from the strictly masculine into decidedly feminine style, except casual sports tweeds. Jackets are "draped," having easy fullness over the bosom. Their waistlines are slipping ever so little, barely enough to be perceptibly lower. You'll note that the fitted ones have a slender look through midriff and hips.

Despite constant efforts on the part of utility managements and State regulatory commissions to provide consumers with utility services at progressively lower rates, the mounting burden of taxation on the revenues and earnings of utility enterprises has reached the point where further rate reductions in the immediate years to come seem highly improbable.

STOCKTON, Calif., March 1 (UP) -- A new self-liquidating certificate plan, somewhat similar to the "ham and eggs" proposal, was disclosed today as the State Commissioner of Corporations directed the National Finance Trust to cease operations.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- Mrs. Elizabeth Dilling of Chicago, leader of "the mothers' crusade against Bill 1776," took advantage of a week-end recess in her trial for disorderly conduct to tell Senator Glass that she regarded him as "an overaged destroyer of American youth."

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted permission today to the Adams Express Company to buy a maximum of 37,000 shares of its common stock from the British Government at a price to be the lower of either the net value or the market price of the shares on the New York Stock Exchange and without the payment of any brokerage commission by the company.

Pioneer medals will be presented to Mrs. Parker O. Griffith and Mrs. William H. Brown at the Spring conference of the eighth district of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs, to be held Wednesday at the Wesley Methodist Church in Belleville.

ROCKLEIGH, N.J., March 1 -- Led by George Oliver, the Pegasus polo team tonight won the fourteenth annual invitation tournament of the New York Athletic Club. Taking four goals on handicap, which they never needed, they turned back the Midtown Club of New York, 21 to 13.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 1 (AP) -- British Army Headquarters issued this communique today:

New York City's 280 local selective service boards have been called upon to furnish 7,840 men for the sixth call, beginning tomorrow morning and ending on the evening of March 14, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Director of Selective Service announced yesterday.

The last few years have seen a marked tendency on the part of home-owners to follow the practice of leading landscape architects in so designing small-property plantings as to get a "two level" effect.

This is the throbbing story of Gail Quentin, social secretary to a fashionable London lady, and her matrimonial adventures. Gail was certainly not an adventuress. She was young and filled with ideals, she had a handsome pair of eyes, and she hoped modestly that a suitable man would come along some day and marry her.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., March 1 -- Seton Hall closed its basketball season with its second victory by a one-point margin in two days and its forty-second consecutive triumph when it defeated Baltimore University, 45 -- 44, in Setonia gym tonight. A capacity crowd of 6,000 watched the game.
MOSCOW, March 1 (UP) -- The newspaper Red Fleet, organ of the Soviet Navy, reported today that Japan has been secretly building up a fleet for use in event of a United States-Japanese war.

Your "Business Jitters" editorial of Feb. 22 implied that among today's "most ill-advised of existing labor regulations" is one recently enunciated by the Supreme Court -- "exempting unions from anti-social practices forbidden to every one else." This probably refers to the Feb. 3 decision sanctioning the carpenters' quarrel with the machinists by refusing to intercede when picketing and boycotting occurred.

THE permanent residents of Reno like to believe that the town's prosperity is not dependent upon One Thing. And be that as it may (Max Miller shows reason for skepticism on this point of local faith), this highly picturesque book certainly finds something else to emphasize.

The pamphlet report of Spiegel, Inc., installment mail-order house, and its subsidiary for 1940 shows a net profit of $1,791,446 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes, employes' profit-sharing plan and other charges. This is equivalent, after dividends on the company's $4.50 preferred stock, to $1.05 each on 1,275,658 shares of common stock and compares with $1,751,092, or $1.02 a share, in 1939.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 1 -- There are many indications this week that a full-fledged propaganda campaign aimed at the United States may be launched in the not too distant future by the Axis powers. Up to very recently, Axis resentment with American policy of all-out aid to Great Britain and its generally hostile attitude has been shown only by occasional outbursts almost exclusively in the Italian press.
VIENNA, March 1 -- From a wartime prison as an interned enemy alien to concert stage celebrity in an "enemy country," is the unique experience of a young Australian singer, Lorna Sydney.

AMERICA, with added vigor and effect, is aiming its powerful international radio artillery at listeners in Europe. Collectively, international broadcasting stations in the United States now hurl across the Atlantic upward of fifty hours of programs daily in more than six languages.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- For those who may be disposed to read far-reaching historical significance into the happenings of the day, a special note perhaps should be made of a meeting this week in Washington. It took place in the Board Room of the new Social Security Building on Independence Avenue, being occupied during the defense emergency by the Office of Production Management.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull indicated today that this government would freeze Bulgaria's credits and balances in the United States as soon as German troops occupy that country. The Secretary said the Treasury would take up the matter as it did when German troops occupied Rumania.

Thousands of Vienna Jews, threatened with deportation to Poland, are sending cablegrams to relatives and friends here imploring them to go to the local offices of the Hapag Lloyd and deposit money to cover the cost of transporting them to the United States.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- A large field is expected for the Seminole Club's fifth annual pro-amateur classic to be held on the club course on Thursday. Leading amateurs will be paired with the professionals, the former playing from scratch and the latter under handicap.

AMERICAN folk-dancing is resurgent. Since records follow the news, disks celebrating the revival of folk-dancing are to be expected. A new album has appeared on the scene. It is Swing Your Partner, which contains square dances or quadrilles played by Bill Dickinson's Tuxedo Colonels.

OTTAWA -- The Philatelic Division of the Postoffice Department has begun competition with dealers in the sale of high-value stamps in used condition. Items available include the 20c, 50c and $1 of the 1930 pictorial series; the 13c of the 1935 issue, and the 50c and $1 of 1938.

VIENNA, March 1 (AP) -- The basic provision of the pact signed by Bulgaria today is that the signatories pledged mutual support to each other in the event that any one of them should be attacked by a power not at the time involved in the European or Oriental wars.

THE first casualties caused by the consent decree which the government will enforce against the motion picture industry this Summer have occurred in the reorganization of four film companies: RKO, Paramount, Twentieth Century-Fox and United Artists.

NATCHEZ, Miss. -- Natchez will harken to its past again today when it begins the tenth of its annual pilgrimages. The day marks the opening of a long series of Spring tours and pageants not only here but throughout the lower Mississippi Valley, which looks to Natchez for its cue.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Those defense workers who have been recruited from the groups outside organized labor conclude pretty soon after they have settled down to their tasks in Washington that the Government of the United States is a labor government. With few exceptions, most of them queried on the point have stated this conclusion.

Two out of three Columbia varsities met defeat in home engagements yesterday, the swimmers dropping a non-league meet to Cornell, 44 -- 31, and the matmen losing to Syracuse by 21 -- 11, while the fencers defeated Pennsylvania, 16 -- 11.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 1 -- Formerly the most exuberant of the Scandinavian people, the Danes have transformed themselves since the German occupation into a "nation of icicles," writes a special correspondent of the Nya Dagligt Allehanda.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A report on how America's man power is being mobilized for defense production, made public today by Sidney Hillman, associate Director General of the Office of Production Management, covers the activities of the National Defense Advisory Commission's Labor Division under the title "Labor Speeds Defense."

The 1941 Eastern Bridge Championships, one of the oldest contract tournaments in the country, opened at Hotel Park Central yesterday with eighty pairs, the largest field in several years, entered in the competition.

LONDON, March 1 -- The shipping shortage is the chief factor in Britain's strained food position. Because of this a scheme was prepared this week for faster unloading of turnround ships in their home ports. The scheme should prove valuable in economizing on the available shipping but in view of the enormous requirements for war materials food supplies are not likely to benefit.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Great care must be taken in selecting men for military service so that the national defense production program shall not be impeded, Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, deputy director of Selective Service, said today.

NEXT Tuesday will be Town Meeting Day in Vermont. But it will be more than that. It will be the 150th anniversary of the day on which the Green Mountain Republic formed a permanent association with the greater Republic which for nearly fifteen years had been its close neighbor. Or, if one likes, one may say that March 4, 1941, will be the 150th anniversary of Vermont's admission to the Union.

PARIS, Feb. 25 (Delayed; via Berlin) -- Although French red tape has somewhat delayed the departure of Americans being repatriated by the Red Cross, 101 United States citizens have left Paris in the last six days.

With their mathematical chances of earning a play-off berth in the National Hockey League still alive, the Americans will seek to improve their status at the expense of the Canadiens of Montreal when the teams collide at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The Jewish Culture Foundation of New York University is sponsoring a benefit concert on Saturday evening, March 15, in the Theresa Kaufmann Auditorium, Young Men's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 1 -- Princeton's undefeated swimming team went into undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League race today by taking the 400-yard free style relay and vanquishing Dartmouth, 39 -- 36, in Brokaw Pool.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 1 -- A light but fast Princeton hockey team brought Old Nassau its first Quadrangular League championship in history by routing Dartmouth, 7-2, before a crowd of 1,500 in the Hobey Baker rink tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Signs of growing impatience on the part of many Senators at the long speeches by opponents of the lease-lend bill in the past two weeks, caused the Senate to decide late today to convene every day at 11 o'clock, instead of noon, as usual, until the bill is disposed of.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 1 (AP) -- Mrs. James J. Walker told Circuit Judge Arthur Gomez today that her health would be ruined if she continued to live with her husband, the former Mayor of New York. Decision on her application for divorce on the ground of extreme cruelty was delayed until the record was read by the judge.

INVITATIONS to learning were an everyday affair with the ancient Greeks, who held banquets and parties as an excuse for dissertations on literature, philosophy and the arts. Every Tuesday night WABC invites the radio audience to listen in to three learned men discuss in a friendly spirit the great literary and philosophical works of all time.

ONE class of men that contributed, incalculably, to the improvement of cattle-raising in Texas, New Mexico and Arizona has remained unsung, for seldom, if ever, have the innumerable English and Scotch adventurers and younger sons who rode our range been featured on the silver screen or as heroes in the pulp magazines.
MADISON, Wis., March 1 (AP) -- The powerful University of Wisconsin Badgers triumphed over Minnesota tonight, 42 to 32, to capture their first undisputed Big Ten basketball title since 1918.

ANGELA THIRKELL'S new novel is, as its subtitle indicates, a wartime book straight from the home front, the "home" being, as before, the territory annexed from Anthony Trollope and in previous, successive narratives kept up -- or should it be brought down? -- to date.

The people of the United States look southward these days more than they used to. They see Mexico, the tangle of Central America, the Canal, the sprawling mass of South America, with its diversity of climates, civilizations and peoples. They don't know too much of these nations, but they do wonder about them.

LONDON, Sunday, March 2 -- Bombers of the British Royal Air Force struck again at the invasion coast across the Channel last night, after twenty-four hours of steady attacks on Nazi bases from the German North Sea ports to Brittany.

Progress of the bill to extend the date on which all nurses in the State must be licensed, served last week to encourage professional organizations in the hope that the amendment to the Nurse Practice Act would finally succeed in passing.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Some members of the House Judiciary Committee exhibited little enthusiasm today for the proposal by William S. Knudsen, defense production chief, to require a thirty-day "cooling-off" period before a strike in a defense industry became effective.
Arthur Eilenberg's letter in THE TIMES last Sunday concerning the mystic ubiquity of the number seven moves me to materialistic demurrer.

A campaign to improve the parks and playgrounds used by New York City's 1,000,000 school children, by providing more adequate supervision and guidance, has been started by the United Parents Associations. Teachers, welfare, social and recreational groups are cooperating with the parents.

NOT yet at the alarming stage, Hollywood's refugee problem is nevertheless giving some concern to certain people here. The facts are not easy to get at and would hardly, in any case, be open to a one-man investigation.

OFFICE-TIED husbands whose wives disappear into the North every Friday evening and hostesses who cannot get enough people together for a Saturday-night pub crawl are probably aware by now that skiing is a very popular pastime. But they don't realize that it is in a fair way to become the national sport.

TUESDAY night is a good night on the air for comedy. For ninety racing minutes beginning at half-past 9, Fibber McGee and Molly, Bob Hope and Uncle Waiter's Dog House pass before WEAF's microphone at halfhour intervals, each selling a different kind of humor.

GENEVA, N.Y., March 1 -- Fears that the program of education for responsible citizenship at Hobart and William Smith Colleges would be discontinued after this year were dispelled this week with a one-sentence, communication from a special committee of the college faculty.

The Metropolitan is looking over the repertory of comic operas in search of revivals next season for Salvatore Baccaloni, the Italian basso buffo who has made such a hit this year in "Don Pasquale," "La Fille du Regiment," "Il Barbiere di Siviglia" and other works.

Twenty-nine hours from Lisbon to New York -- time enough for three murders in the Clipper, intricacies of international plots and personal scandal-mongering, threat and romance and a solution of all the puzzles with still an hour to go.
More and more women of social prominence are enlisting these days in the great army of war relief workers, the tide rising mightily as the Lenten period further turns thoughts away from self.

The Federal surplus food stamp program, in effect in Brooklyn since last Sept. 3, was extended throughout the city yesterday when it increased by 50 per cent the food-purchasing capacity of 200,000 families receiving some kind of relief.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Although net income earned by American railroads in 1940 was less than one-fifth of the 1929 figure, industrial expansion last year brought about heavier traffic, larger revenues and improved income, Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, announced today.

"THIS book," say the publishers, "will take its place as the complete and definitive biography of Dean Swift." On the contrary, it will take its place as the most fictional and inadequate biography of Dean Swift ever written.

THIS study of the effects of reading has a social and academic rather than a literary connotation and appeal. It is an examination of factors in the "social psychology of public influence by print" and of ways in which that influence may be gauged.

In connection with the exhibition of American Indian Art at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, the American Association on Indian Affairs will hold an institute on "The Future of the American Indian" at the museum, beginning Tuesday evening.

The accomplishments of the 300 European refugee settlers in Sosua, in the Dominican Republic, were praised yesterday by James N. Rosenberg, president of the Dominican Republic Settlement Association, and George L. Warren, executive secretary of the President's Advisory Committee on Political Refugees, who have just returned from an inspection trip to the colony.

IT is nearly fifty years since General Oliver Otis Howard's biography of Zachary Taylor, the twelfth President of the United States, was published as one of the "Great Commander" series. In the book here reviewed we have the first of a two-volume life of Taylor, based on extensive research and long study of contemporary letters and records, many of them hitherto unused in respect to Taylor.

Columbia University students have set up a campus radio station to serve the 950 residents of Hartley, Livingston and John Jay Halls with entertainment from 8 P.M. to midnight Monday through Friday during the academic year. The station, CURC, which is named for the Columbia University Radio Club, began its regular broadcast schedule last week over the university's electric wiring system, with reception limited to the three men's residence halls.

AN enormous triumph has been gained by the Nazi regime. The German Chancellor, perhaps advised against the course he took by his military experts, nevertheless decided on ordering the violation of the Rhineland and the destruction of the Locarno treaty. He has succeeded -- it is no good blinding ourselves to it -- his troops are there, and who is to say that they will be removed?

Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder reserved decision yesterday until tomorrow on the application of Eugene P. Connolly for an order to require the Board of Elections to validate his nomination for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District by the American Labor party and place him on the ballot with Dean Alfange, Democratic candidate, and Joseph Clark Baldwin, Republican nominee.

A call for national spiritual preparedness was issued by Rabbi David de Sola Pool in the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Central Park West and Seventieth Street, yesterday. Other topics of rabbis included the lease-lend bill, a German Government in exile, the world's sin, national unity and American democracy.

Virtually all the groundwork has been laid for a comprehensive standardization of parts, equipment and methods in the aircraft industry. Final ratification of the program by all interested parties, which may be secured at any moment, will permit manufacturers and subcontractors to proceed immediately with the changes and additions in plants and shops that will be required to bring the program into actual operation.

On the basis of three years' experience with the four-semester course in contemporary civilization required of Queens College students, the division of social sciences this semester has taken the first step in a complete reorganization of the work, both in context and method.

DIPLOMATIC ACTIVITY: The diplomatic set in uneasy Sofia had something to talk about last week in addition to Bulgaria's relations with the Axis. There had been a cafe rumpus. The principals were George H. Earle, American Minister to Bulgaria, and Dr. Karl Becker, German business man.

THE author of "Salt of the Earth" is a newspaper man who -- in this age of bylines on weather stories -- prefers to hide himself behind a pen name! And as if this fact alone would not call him at once to the attention of all who write for deadlines, he confesses also to having inherited $12,000.

SAY Kansas to the average American who is not a Jayhawker, and he thinks of prairie farms covered with wheat and corn cut by long straight roads, of hot Summers and cold Winters, of chinch bugs and grasshoppers, of dust storms and cyclones, of droughts so intense the trees run after the dogs.

Dr. Earl C. Kelley, superintendent of secondary schools in Detroit and Professor of Education at Wayne University, told a gathering of 200 college leaders yesterday that the preservation of good government depended upon their ability to "invent new ways of living together."

George Szell, Czecho-Slovak conductor, made his New York debut last night with the first of four guest appearances as leader of the NBC Symphony Orchestra at Radio City. The 44-year-old director, who has held important posts as orchestra and opera director in many parts of the world, was accorded a rousing welcome in a program well devised to display his talents as batonist in the classic, romantic and modern fields.

For the first time in the city's history copies of the rules and regulations and manual of procedure of the Police Department are to be made available to the public, it was revealed yesterday in the March issue of the Civil Service Bulletin, official publication of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 1 -- Fort Dix was digging itself out of the snowdifts today. The storm abated about 8 o'clock this morning after more than twenty-four hours. A howling north and northwest wind piled the snow up into six and seven foot drifts in spots and left other areas entirely bare.

Negotiations between the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Company and representatives of its union employes, on strike for the past month, were broken off yesterday and a request was made to Mayor La Guardia to intervene in an attempt to achieve a settlement.

Charles B. Harding, chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange, has summoned the members to a special meeting after the close of the market on Wednesday. It will he held in the board of governors room and William McC. Martin Jr., the president, will discuss the progress of the last three years and the important problems which remain for solution.

HENRY MORLEY was a skillful but personally inconspicuous dentist, and Mabelle Sainsbury Seale was a scatterbrained spinster who had once taught elocution and done mission work -- why should the death of one and the disappearance of the other seem to be bound up with threats at England's stability and other machinations of agitators and spies?

Two notable figures in the canine world will be honored Wednesday evening at the Nelson House in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. On that date service clubs and civic organizations will give a dinner for Herman E. Mellenthin and his famous black cocker spaniel, Champion My Own Brucie.

A DIARY has the virtue of mirroring the secret soul of the author, but ordinarily it is of ques tionable propriety to publish that of a public man for years after he and his contemporaries have passed from the scene.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- At the suggestion of Secretary Perkins, officials of the International Harvester Company and the C.I.O.'s Farm Equipment Workers Organizing Committee will meet in Washington at 2 P.M.
