Monday in an effort to settle the strike which has made more than 13,090 employes idle at four plants of the company.

MOST of our contemporary Jay Goulds and Jim Fisks, manipulators of pools, shady stock promotors, big-game hunters of the Wall Street breed whose traps yielded fine pelts through the Indian Summer of the roaring Twenties, tightened their belts in the succeeding decade and sadly tested the sharp edges of their skinning knives now so rarely in use.

BOSWELL was the great biographer. He wrote: "There is an imperfection, a superficialness, in all my notions. I understand nothing clearly, nothing to the bottom. I pick up fragments, but never have in my memory a mass of any size.

Frantic efforts of manufacturers to store up huge stocks of raw materials and rising prices requiring a heavier than usual investment in commodities are providing the two chief credit problems at the present time, credit managers and factoring house executives reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON -- As special nutritional consultant on Civilian Defense Coordinator Paul V. McNutt's staff, Dr. Helen Mitchell heads the organizing unit and clearing house for information and advice in one of the most extensive and ambitious nation-wide health training programs ever attempted in this country.

No more emphatic indication of the need of thorough defense planning has been given than the admissions made by the Army before the House Appropriations Committee. Transcripts of testimony show that the Army's estimates of the construction costs of its cantonments were wrong by about one-third, and that the camps will cost some $338,000,000 more than had been thought.

The Spring campaigns opened last week as Bulgaria joined the Axis powers and Germany, Italy and Great Britain mobilized their strength for the impending, and possibly decisive, operations of 1941. The war of bullets and the war of nerves continued on all fronts, but for the moment the Balkans, where the Reich won a diplomatic victory in Bulgaria, was the most important theatre of action.

ALTHOUGH Henry the Navigator lived to his sixty-sixth year, he was known as the Infante all his life. This Prince of Portugal was one of the heroes of history. It was he who first organized and directed continuous discovery by sea, and it was to his energies that Portugal owed much of its maritime pre-eminence and extraordinary colonial enterprise.

Reflecting the spirit of helpfulness animating women's groups in a time of national preparedness, organizations of young women are showing a similar trend toward serious interests and shaping their programs according to the country's needs.

NO one wishes merely to smile at our burdened world of today. That would be inhuman and cruel beyond all cruelty. Nevertheless, must one not smile at the strange obsession that we are the first age of the world to undergo elemental agony ?

MONT TREMBLANT LODGE, Quebec, March 1 -- The United States and Canada shared honors today in the opening half of their second annual international ski competition, highlight of the North American schedule, on snow mantled Mont Tremblant in the Laurentians.

A SAD spectacle was afforded recently at a piano recital given by a young boy who should have been out playing baseball by a fond mother who sat with two extremely immature offspring in the row just in front of this chronicler.

Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Commercial and Cultural Relations Between the American Republics, asserted last night that the twenty-one American republics would cooperate after the war in "conquering the peace for democracy," and in "assuming leadership in the reconstruction of the world."

The problem of "labor-stealing," which cropped up in the first World War and became a major consideration in computing costs, has begun to develop in the present defense effort, and personnel men considering the situation last week said they had arrived at no iron-clad solution.

After racing 19,000 miles by airplane and train from Palestine, a 20-year-old German refugee was in Mount Sinai Hospital last night awaiting an operation for a brain tumor that has nearly blinded him.

H. Harris Robson, a director of the United Fruit Company and a veteran shipping man on the Atlantic Coast, has been named director of a new Maritime Commission department to be known as the Division of Emergency Shipping, which will handle the important task of coordinating ocean transportation with the needs of the national defense program.

Wonderlands of enchantment are the azalea and camellia gardens of Houston, Texas, which are attracting thousands of beauty-loving visitors to the annual Azalea Trail tour of the River Oaks Garden Club. Today is the second of the two days of pilgrimage this year.

IT isn't often that this corner has good reason to bang a gong and holler "Hurry, hurry, hurry!" As a matter of fact, it is all too rare indeed that we have even moderate provocation to mark a wonder of the cinematic world. Too many of the films on which we comment boil down to woeful mediocrity, and too many of the people who make them betray a depressing weariness.

The twenty-fifth annual Salvation Army "Prison Sunday" will be observed today in the eleven States included in the Eastern Territory of the Salvation Army. Arrangements for the observance have been made by Colonel William F. Palmer, prison secretary for this territory.

MIAMI, Fla., March 1 -- Despite the fact that his team is loaded down with uncertainties, Bill Terry appears surprisingly confident that he will bring his players to the opening of the coming season in condition to make a strong bid for a berth in the first division.
LONDON, March 1 -- One thing Adolf Hitler said in his speech early this week of which the British took notice was his threat of unrestricted submarine warfare.
LONDON, March 1 -- British sources said tonight that the Royal Air Force "is just as likely to bomb German troops in Sofia as in Wilhelmshaven," repeatedly raided Nazi North Sea naval base.

Exhibitions announced by the Yale Art Gallery include work by the alumni in architecture and students in the School of Fine Arts, until March 10, and work by the faculty of the School of Fine Arts, in a new room just opened. Persian textiles from the Robert Moore collection, and color reproductions of modern fantasies, until April 1; printed textiles from the Garvan collection, March 4 to 81.

NEXT time you visit friends who have just had a second child, you might remember to make a little fuss over the older offspring before going into transports over the baby. When fathers come home at night, they too might remember to play first with the older child.

TUCSON, Ariz. -- The vivid yellow blooms of the palo verdes soon will raise the curtain on one of nature's most beautiful and stupendous spectacles, one of the greatest flower shows on earth, that of the American desert lands.

Exhibitions announced by the Yale Art Gallery include work by the alumni in architecture and students in the School of Fine Arts, until March 10, and work by the faculty of the School of Fine Arts, in a new room just opened. Persian textiles from the Robert Moore collection, and color reproductions of modern fantasies, until April 1; printed textiles from the Garvan collection, March 4 to 81.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- Dudley Sharpe's 70-foot yawl Gulf Stream, carrying all working sail in a good 19-mile-an-hour northwest wind, was leading a fleet of eight yachts tonight sixty-two miles from the start of the St. Petersburg-Havana race.

NEXT time you visit friends who have just had a second child, you might remember to make a little fuss over the older offspring before going into transports over the baby. When fathers come home at night, they too might remember to play first with the older child.

TUCSON, Ariz. -- The vivid yellow blooms of the palo verdes soon will raise the curtain on one of nature's most beautiful and stupendous spectacles, one of the greatest flower shows on earth, that of the American desert lands.

THE graphic arts section of the 115th annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design, which opens at the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street on March 11, will comprise 200 prints and drawings selected from about 2,000 entries sent in to the Print Committee by more than 500 artists throughout the country.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 1 -- New York University's basketball team defeated Rutgers tonight by a 78-55 count in the Rutgers gym before a crowd of 4,000. It was the twelfth victory for the Violets, while the Scarlet suffered its tenth defeat of the campaign.

The first "transfusion trailer" built in the United States as a traveling blood bank to aid British air raid victims will be shipped abroad "some time next week," Refugees of England, Inc., 511 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday.

A broader priorities program which would include the needs of hemisphere relations as well as national defense was urged unofficially here last week by spokesmen for foreign trade interests. Exporters, who already feel the pinch which booming domestic business has imposed upon the volume of goods they can persuade their principals to turn out for established foreign customers abroad, foresee the danger that eventually priorities will be invoked to freeze out customers in Latin-American nations.

BERLIN, March 1 -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's Essener National Zeitung, in a dispatch from The Hague, dated Feb. 28, asks whether the "Jewish question" in the Netherlands is about to receive a "total solution" that will make it impossible in the future for even a single Jew to be in a position "to sow hate and dissension in the Netherlands, to beat up Netherlanders and incite to cowardly machinations."

CAIRO, Egypt, March 1 -- The British-dominated territory in Italian Somaliland was increased today after the occupation of Bardera, a road center on the Juba River 120 miles north of Jelib. The next towns to fall, it appeared, will be Lugh Ferrandi, farther north, and Iscia Baidoa, 110 miles to the northeast.

Jefferson had many undeserved distresses, but at least he didn't know when he died that his ample acres and his Palladian house would pass from his family. The February report of Mr. Stuart Gibboney, president of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation, shows that the last cent of mortgage on Monticello has been paid.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 1 -- In spite of the handicaps of a restricted budget and inadequate physical facilities, interest in the section of music of Princeton University has shown a rapid development in the last five years, according to the fifth anniversary report issued today by Professor Roy Dickinson Welch, head of the section.

IN the month just closed, trade improved its gains over the 1940 figures. Department store sales probably ran about 13 or 14 per cent above last year, when, in January, the increase was 10 per cent. Automobile sales have shown less seasonal slackening and new records have been hung up in the appliance lines.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Feb. 22 amounted to 261,783,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represents an increase of 835,000 barrels in the week, consisting of an increase of 1,054,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude oil, but a decline of 219,000 barrels in stocks of foreign crude.

The Merchants Association of New York is urging Congress to re-enact the National Daylight Saving law of 1918 as a means of furthering national defense and conserving health, John Lowry, president of the organization, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- The Treasury announced today that 90 per cent of the holders of $1,222,000,000 of government bonds and notes had agreed to exchange them for new taxable securities. The exchange offer was made on Tuesday. The maturing securities consist of $677,000,000 of 3 3/8 per cent bonds, and $545,000,000 of 1 1/2 per cent notes.

THE recent ruling of the State Department that travelers going to British territory in the Western Hemisphere where the United States is building naval and air bases require passports does not apply to persons on ships "in transit." In other words, passports are not required of individuals while their ships are in port on continuous voyage touching at these places.
THE mischief which agents of foreign interests might possibly commit as fifth-column radio operators is currently being spotlighted in Congress.
WILMINGTON, Del., March 1 -- The bill repealing the Sunday "blue laws," following its defeat in the House of Representatives, was restored to the calendar of the House yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 1 -- Cornell converted a string of free throws in the closing minutes to defeat Princeton, 33 -- 27, in their first Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League meeting of the season tonight.

WOMEN have played a comparatively small part in Swiss literature. The only Swiss woman of letters to enjoy an international reputation was Maria Waser, who died a few years ago. Her Begegnung am Abend ("Encounter in the Evening"), based on the life of Constantin von Monakov, the great Russian brain specialist, is rightly considered one of the best biographical novels in the German tongue.

The New York Football Giants will meet the Eastern College All-Stars of 1941 in the sixth annual Fresh Air Fund game at the Polo Grounds on the night of Sept. 3 orI 4. The Giants yesterday accepted the invitation of The New York Herald Tribune to play the All-Stars for the sixth straight time.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -- Dartmouth not only neared its fourth straight Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League championship by beating Penn at the Palestra tonight, 65 -- 57, but set a new team scoring record for the circuit.

The report for 1940 of the American Tobacco Company, released for publication today, shows a net income of $28,311,782 after all charges and taxes, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $5.55 each on the 4,528,692 combined common and common B shares.

Works by six young American composers were introduced yesterday afternoon in Room 213 of the New York Public Library at the second young-composers concert of the season sponsored by the League of Composers. Five of the composers were present.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- On Feb. 15 in more than 4,300 work shops of the National Youth Administration, scattered from coast to coast, were 204,118 children of the depression -- young men and women from the ages of 17 to 24 -- learning trades in the traditional American fashion, by working at them, and contributing materially at the same time to the American defense program.

OTTAWA, March 2 -- Many misunderstandings and false impressions were tracked down and laid to rest during last week's sitting of Parliament and the business of getting on with the war seems likely to get ahead to a fresh start.

NEWCASTLE-ON-TYNE, England, Monday, March 3 (Canadian Press) -- The censor today lifted the ban on the story of the north of England's worst snowstorm in years, which occurred in mid-February and left six trains buried deep in drifts five miles from this city.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Senate debate on the lease-lend bill will enter its third week tomorrow with Administration leaders voicing "hope" for a final vote by the end of the week and with the opposition predicting that the measure will be under consideration for at least another fortnight.

BERLIN, March 2 -- The German Air Fleet was reported to have sunk during yesterday and today at least eight British ships totaling 49,000 tons and damaged seven others so that they were probably lost.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., March 2 -- Mr. and Mrs. Abram Linford Hackman of this place will sail Wednesday with their daughter, Miss Amelia Margaret Hackman, for Barranquilla, Colombia, where Miss Hackman will be married March 15 in the chapel of the American School in that city to Dr. Gabriel Hernando Cortes of Bogota, Colombia.

AMSTERDAM, March 2 -- Financial quarters here no longer sense any paradox in the United States business boom against the background of stock-market dullness, because of the large number of political, economic, financial, social and taxation factors that are counteracting the effects of the business activity.

The British holdings of eleven additional stock issues and six bond issues have been entirely liquidated since Feb. 1, according to an announcement by T.J.C. Gifford, special agent of the British Treasury in charge of the sale of British-owned securities in this market.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Monday, March 3 -- The vanguard of Germany's on-rushing Balkan army, speeding across Bulgaria from bases in Rumania, was reported to have reached the Greek frontier at four points early today.

VICHY, France, March 2 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain was back in Vichy tonight from a two-day tour of inspection that took him to the industrial section around Saint-Etienne and the agricultural section around Le Puy.

Five Broadway film houses will bring in new shows this week, starting with two openings today. These are the French "Pepe le Moko," directed by Julien Duvivier and featuring Jean Gabin, Mirielle Balin, Charpin and Dalio, which will have its American premiere at 8:45 P.M. at the World Cinema, and "A Dangerous Game," a Universal melodrama with Richard Arlen and Andy Devine, opening this morning at the Rialto.

The 1940 annual report of the New York Telephone Company, made public yesterday by James L. Kilpatrick, president, puts net income of the company for 1940, after all expenses and charges at $34,429,223. This was equal to $8.17 a share on the company's 4,213,000 shares of common stock outstanding, and compares with a net of $35,370,798, or $8.40 a share, earned in 1939.
THE first letter has to do with the risks of riding in autos at high speed. It runs as follows:

By turning back the New York Americans in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, the Montreal Canadiens virtually eliminated the losers from a play-off berth for the post-season competition. The red-jerseyed skaters came from behind twice to tie their local rivals in the first two periods and in the final session forged into the lead that brought them the victory, 3 to 2.

An investment deal in the block diagonally opposite Macy's and just north of Pennsylvania Station has been made with the resale by the Drymar Realty Corporation of the two buildings on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 430-34 Seventh Avenue, adjoining the southwest corner of Thirty-fourth Street.

LISBON, Portugal, March 2 (AP) -- Ten of the forty American seamen rescued from the 8,982-ton Standard Oil Company tanker. Charles Pratt, torpedoed and sunk in December by an unidentified raider off Freetown, a British African possession, arrived here today aboard the Portuguese steamer Joao Belo.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Senator Norris told reporters today that he thought the lease-lend bill's present language could not be interpreted as authorizing the sending of troops to help Britain or any other country.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith opened the diocesan appeal for the 1941 drive of the New York Catholic Charities at a communion breakfast yesterday for the Archbishop's Committee of the Laity. He said he was confident that, despite the increased cost of living and higher taxes confronting the average contributor, the total of $1,153,000 that was raised last year would be surpassed in the current appeal.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 2 (UP) -- Partial returns in today's general Congressional election gave the parties of the Left a slight majority over their opponents.

City College players started off with a victory in the first round of the annual series for the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League at the Empire City Chess Club yesterday, the score being 5 1/2 -- 4 1/2.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 2 -- While the green-gray uniforms of German officers and soldiers mingled with the varied costumes of the Bulgarians in the streets outside, the Sobranje [Parliament] convened in extraordinary session at 6 P.M. today and ratified Bulgaria's adherence to the Three-Power Pact signed by Premier Bogdan Philoff in Vienna yesterday.

Both proponents and opponents of the lease-lend bill seriously confuse the issue and hurt their own causes by appealing to our sympathies and antipathies in a matter which is essentially one of national interest. We may admire the British and hate Hitler.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 2 -- "Positive action" to defend our ideals of government was urged by Dr. Charles Seymour, president of Yale University, in a talk this afternoon at Christ Protestant Episcopal Church at a special service on behalf of the Greenwich branch of the British War Relief Society.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 2 (UP) -- Russia was reported by diplomats tonight to be moving toward "improved relations" with Britain and support of Turkey, which might even lead to Soviet armed assistance if the Turks resist Germany's eastward push across the Balkans.

Last week's slow continuance of recovery on the Stock Exchange could not be ascribed to war news. Such news was hardly favorable; it certainly indicated that Germany was about to strike, in one place if not another, and the week ended with announcement of the forced uniting of Bulgaria to the Axis.

TOKYO, March 2 -- Japan's first "no-party" Diet, assembled as a unique parliamentary experiment to help the government cope with the "super-emergency" confronting the nation, has completed its work in the record time of thirty-seven days and has adjourned until its official closing date on March 24.

A DOZEN of the country's great waterways have now been diverted between book covers in the Rivers of America Series. The twelfth to undergo this verbal engineering is the Kaw. The Job has been done by Floyd Benjamin Streeter, who calls his book "The Kaw: The Heart of a Nation."*

LONDON, March 2 (UP) -- "Free French" forces operating in the South Libyan desert yesterday captured the oasis of Kufra and seized 1,000 Italian prisoners and valuable war material, the London headquarters of General Charles de Gaulle announced tonight.

Breaking 96 out of 100 targets, A.L. Cornwell won the high-overall scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In the handicap shoot the trophy was taken by J. Nida, only gunner with a full card of 100.

LONDON, Monday, March 3 -- The British Royal Air Force pressed the offensive over the week-end, delivering big blows at Germany and Nazi-occupied regions, while Britain suffered comparatively little from the aerial warfare.

The New York Committee on Interstate Cooperation has sponsored a bill which would strengthen the State Traffic Commission. Under it the commission would receive a modest annual fund which should enable it to resume some useful studies of highway marking and regulation which were abandoned when appropriations for this purpose dried up.

As chairman of Local Draft Board 198, Brooklyn, I desire to express chagrin and disappointment at the alarming number of strikes and other tie-ups in the industries engaged on national defense contracts.

About 800 lots in the central section of Palisades Park, N.J., have been bought by a syndicate headed by Arthur Cutler, New York operator and builder. Resale of the property is pending for improvement with one-family houses. Plans for an apartment house on part of the site also are under consideration.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 2 -- Mr. and Mrs. Theodore D. Buhl entertained with a cocktail party at their new residence today for Mr. end Mrs. John Ringling North, their week-end guests from Saranah

When Signor Virginio Gayda, the Duce's counterpart of our own Charlie McCarthy, hails a new economic accord between Italy and Germany as the "coagulation" of the two countries, it does seem that either he or his Edgar Bergen has stubbed a verbal toe.
LONDON, March 2 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 2 -- The severance of British-Bulgarian diplomatic relations appeared imminent tonight, according to late telephone reports from Sofia, as George W. Rendel, the British Minister to Bulgaria, called on King Boris to demand an explanation of the arrival of German soldiers and warplanes in Bulgaria.

The New Friends of Music presented its sixteenth and last chamber music concert of the season late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. For this culminating event a program had been prepared consisting of Schoenberg's First quartet, Op. 7, in D minor, and Schubert's quartet in G major, Op. 161, performed by the Kolisch Quartet, and a group of Schubert songs, sung by William Horne, tenor.

Recently statements have appeared to the effect that there are hopes tuberculosis will be brought under control by 1960. At the present time tuberculosis is the chief killer of persons between 15 and 35. It has long been recognized that every case of tuberculosis arises from infection from another case, and if it is to be brought under control, every tuberculous person needing hospitalization must be provided for.

LONDON, March 2 -- The securities markets here still are reflecting a period of investment and speculative stagnation with its resultant slump in turnover. Eyes now are being turned toward the Balkans and the Far East, with the former receiving the more attention.
BERLIN, March 2 (AP) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

The committee on taxation of the New York State Chamber of Commerce in a report made public yesterday charged that no serious effort has been made in the tentative 1941-42 State budget to reduce the expenditures of New York State. The committee urged that departmental operating costs, which show sizable increases in the new budget, should be cut in the interests of economy.

The Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate that declares it has a membership of 27,000 on the subway, street car and bus lines operated by the Board of Transportation, is picketing the homes of forty-seven of these members who have discontinued payment of dues, it was disclosed yesterday.

ROME, March 2 (AP) -- The German troops sent to Libya to strengthen faltering Italian forces there have taken an oath to "make the greatest effort for a joint victory" of Germany and Italy, the official Italian news agency Stefani reported today.

Americans have been made aware so repeatedly of suffering in the war-torn countries that they seem to be growing callous to it, the Rev. Ralph W. Sockman declared at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, yesterday, the day designated by the Methodist Church as the "Day of Compassion" for relief of war sufferers.

Elsewhere on this page Dr. Kingsley Roberts comments on the failure of the public to take advantage of the various voluntary health insurance plans which have been launched since they were sanctioned on a non-profit basis by an amendment of the State insurance laws in 1939.

There is more hatred of war, oppression and injustice in the world today than ever before in the history of mankind, the Right Rev. Paul Matthews, retired Bishop of New Jersey, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 85.9 to 86.0. Changes were slight in most groups, the greatest being the decrease in the farm products index, which fell 0.7 per cent, because declines in livestock outweighed the rises in grains, fruits, cotton and eggs.

"Winged Warfare," a discussion! of fighting planes, of aerial warfareI and national defense, by Major Gen. I. I-L. Arnold, chief of the Air Corps, and Colonel Ira C. Eaker, I will be published on Thursday by Harper. The book will carry a dedication to the Royal Air Force.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 2 -- Caught in Vancouver, Wash., after a nineteen-year search, Harry J. Mullin arrived in police custody here today to stand trial on a charge of embezzling $42,500 from the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company of Jersey City, which is now defunct.

Courtney Burr's production of "The Night Before Christmas" will arrive here on April 10, according to Nick Holde, general manager for the comedy. It will be staged by Romney Brent, and perhaps be tried out in Boston at the Wilbur Theatre the week of March 31.

While members of his family and friends denounced the alarm sent out Saturday by Rye, N.Y., police to the effect that Dr. Otto Klemperer, internationally renowned conductor, was a "dangerous and insane" fugitive, the musician was being held last night, with no charge against him, in a cell at police headquarters in Morristown, N.J.

The pattern of last week's foreign exchange market was cut to the style which prevailed in the preceding fortnight -- strength in the Hong Kong and Canadian remittances, to which was added a modest rally in the free pound sterling. Otherwise there was little feature to the business and fluctuations in the other currencies.

ROME, March 2 -- Bulgaria's armed intervention in the European conflict is hinted at today in the Italian press, which also emphasizes that the conditions necessary for an Axis Spring military offensive in the Mediterranean and the Near East have now been created.

JERUSALEM, March 2 -- Expressing the hope that Palestine might be enabled to play a larger part than at present in the defeat of the "powers of evil," Douglas Gordon Harris, high administration official, who has just been appointed chairman of the country's new War Supply Board, tonight outlined the functions of that body.

The China Emergency Relief Committee, an affiliate of the American Bureau for Medical Aid to China, which is endeavoring to raise $1,000,000 for the purchase of medical supplies urgently needed in China, announced yesterday the receipt of a number of unusual gifts. Among them were a portrait in oils of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek donated by Robert Bauer, an American artist; an eighteenth century Chinese embroidered bedspread, and a sapphire and diamond ring.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 2 -- More than 500 persons were arrested for "breaking the Sabbath" in Delaware today as police enforced the State's ancient blue laws in an attempt to force repeal or amendment.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick issued yesterday a new form of his annual report on the city's finances designed to help not only the tax- payer, but also the city official who wants to or must find specific information in the report. The archaic form used for over fifty years has been revised and shortened, and new material has been added in the "hope that this volume will become the ABC of city finances."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 2 -- In the first sailing regatta of this notorious bluster-wind month, Long Island Sound today was as mild and beautiful as could be wished for on a mid-Summer day. There was a fine northwest breeze, and twenty-eight dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club had two long sessions of superb racing.

Arthur Tauber, N.Y.U., who holds the intercollegiate foil and epee fencing championships, yesterday added the All-Eastern intermediate epee crown to his collection in a round-robin on the Salle d'Armes Vince strips. With a record of six victories and two defeats, the Violet southpaw finished ahead of John Bech, unattached, the former M.I.T. captain.

Promising to make the city's investigation into charges that the administration of home relief is dominated by Communists the most searching ever conducted by his department, William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, disclosed yesterday that every relief official with a voice in promotions, demotions, transfers or dismissals was being examined under oath to determine whether political affiliations had been permitted to influence personnel policies.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- A contention that so many separate government agencies deal with the farmer and his problems that they cause "unnecessary duplication of effort, waste, extravagance and confusion," came today from the American Farm Bureau Federation.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The American Federation of Labor warned the nation today that steps should be taken at once to avert mass unemployment and economic collapse when the European war and the United States defense program come to an end.

Attempting to hold the powerful Baltimore Orioles in check is akin to keeping a cageful of lions at bay. The New York Rovers found that out yesterday as they dropped a 5-to-1 decision to the Marylanders in the Eastern Hockey League struggle at Madison Square Garden. It was the first setback in the last four home clashes for the New Yorkers.

"Carnival in Rio," a benefit performance for the Bethlehem Day Nursery, was presented last night at the Copacabana, 10 East Sixtieth Street. Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti and Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, were co-chairmen of the event, which was under the sponsorship of the "American Way" committee, headed by Brooks Mendell.

ATHENS, March 2 -- A slight improvement in the weather permitted the Greek forces to advance their lines at various points along the Albanian front, according to tonight's Press Ministry announcement. All the Greek attacks appear to have been made mainly in the central sector. They were described as "local in character."

DETROIT, March 2 -- The chief prize at the twenty-sixth annual all- breed fixture of the Detroit Kennel Club, which closed tonight, was won by the old English sheepdog Merriedip Bob-A-Long, owned by Dr. George R. Wiseman Jr. of Amherst, Ohio, and shown by Billy Lang. Alva Rosenberg of New York City judged.

The season at the Metropolitan Opera House will enter its fifteenth week, the next to the last, next Monday. For the first time since the season opened on Dec. 2, the week will not introduce a new opera. However there will be a first appearance of the season by Dusolina Giannini, who will sing Santuzza in "Cavalleria Rusticana" on Saturday night, March 15.

MOSCOW, March 2 (UP) -- The official Russian Army organ Red Star asserted today that Great Britain would be "compelled to provide considerably increased aid to Greece," while the Moscow press printed the text of Bulgaria's adherence to the Axis tri-power alliance.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 2 -- Acquisition of a 15,000-volume medical library, said to be the most complete of its kind in the world, was announced tonight by Dr. C. Charles Burlingame, psychiatrist in chief of the Neuro-Psychiatric Institute.

David van Vator's "Overture to a Comedy" and Nicolas Miaskovsky's Concerto for Violin, with Mishel Piastro as soloist, received their second performances in this city at the concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, John Barbirolli conductor, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.
CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) -- The resourceful Boston Bruins climbed back into a tie for the National League hockey lead tonight with a 4-to-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks before 17,569 spectators:

The recent report of Commissioner Pink to the Legislature on voluntary health insurance plans emphasizes a lag in their development. To achieve successful insurance plans, adjustments must be made by doctors and patients alike. Therefore I wish to raise this question:

Mrs. A.M. Sobel of New York City and Charles Goren of Philadelphia, national open pairs bridge champions and winners of the national tournament at Philadelphia last December, won the Goldman open pairs competition in the 1941 Eastern bridge championships at the Park Central Hotel last night.

CHUNGKING, China, March 2 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek told the People's Political Council yesterday that China should do her part to defend every island and city in the South Seas against Japan's southward expansion because "China's life-line is in the South Pacific."

The Pennsylvania Railroad increased its nonoperating income by $4,471,425 in 1940, largely as a result of a dividend credited at $5,000,000 received in securities from the Pennsylvania Company, wholly owned subsidiary, M.W. Clement, president, said in his annual report made public today.

Large tracts of vacant land in the vicinity of airplane activity in Queens have been purchased by a syndicate headed by Nathan Wilson, operator, for improvement with one and two story factory units for prospective tenants.

Intermittent radio disturbances on some overseas short-wave circuits were reported throughout the day yesterday, but radio and wireless communications for the most part were back to normal following the radio "blackout" caused by magnetic storms Saturday.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., March 2 -- For some time we had been meaning to spend a day with Henry Riggs of Fairfield, who had contracted to prove that the crow shooting in this area was as good as that found anywhere, so yesterday we called on him to fulfill his promises.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 2 -- The complete fiasco of the Danish National Socialist party and its leader, Fritz Clausen, is described by a special correspondent of the newspaper Dagligt Allehanda in a series of articles from Denmark.

An example of the degree to which the Government today controls the money market is afforded by the decision of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to purchase the entire $136,330,557 of refunding bonds of the State of Arkansas, thereby completely excluding from the operation a banking syndicate which was prepared to participate.
Two transatlantic clippers, carrying a total of fifty-two passengers, were en route yesterday to La Guardia Field.

I was shocked to read recently of the proposal to build a highway from the George Washington Bridge that would slash through the heart of Bear Mountain Park, and even more surprised to learn that this proposal appeared to have the support of the Interstate Park Commission.

TOKYO, Monday, March 2 -- Armed with instructions from Vichy that were decoded only Saturday night, Charles Arsene-Henry, the French Ambassador, saw Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka yesterday. The result is that fears of a rupture seemed this morning to have disappeared.

The unsuspected artistic efforts of a wall washer on Columbia University's custodial staff will win recognition today when five of his works go on display with the art of professors and their wives in the university art gallery in East Hall, Amsterdam Avenue and 117th Street.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Army Engineers reported to Congress today $22,514,500 could be "profitably expended" during the next fiscal year to improve New York rivers and harbors, provide for flood control and maintain existing works. For the same purposes in New Jersey they set $10,570,900.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 2 -- With several Montclair clubwomen and members of the Unity Players attired in costumes depicting the period from 1860 to 1910, an exhibition, "From Hoops to Hobbles," opened this afternoon at the Montclair Art Museum.

Simultaneously Bulgaria has been forced to become a member of the Axis and Vichy has capitulated to the Japanese demands on Indo-China. Thus two more "bloodless" victories have been attained by the Axis. The mere ease with which such victories are now achieved may lead one to underrate them.
LONDON, March 2 -- While in principle the City agrees that in stopping the publication of many economic indices the government has acted wisely, it feels that the censorship is being overdone.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Total assets and deposits of national banks in the continental United States, Alaska, Hawaii and the Virgin Islands of the United States on Dec. 31, 1940, were some 7 per cent higher than on any previous call date, it was reported today by Controller of the Currency Preston Delano.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Two organizations expressed concern today over current situations in the defense program. The National Economy League and the American Federation of Investors, non-governmental groups, urged paring down of non-defense items in the national budget.
Michael Priano of the Flatbush Boys Club won the New York State senior men's A.A.U. 100-yard free-style swimming championship in the 75-foot pool of the Hotel Shelton yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Lard prices held within relatively narrow limits last week, with buying induced by strength in cottonseed oil and grains offset to a large extent by seasonal hedging sales attributed to packers. Consumption off lard and hog meats during Lent is usually smaller than normal and further accumulation of supplies is likely in the next five weeks.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 2 -- Mr. and Mrs. William M.F. Magraw of New York were hosts at a luncheon at the Surf Club today to Elizabeth, Lady Decies, who is visiting in Palm Beach. After luncheon the guests went to Villa Lucia, the Magraw home, where an informal reception was held.

The British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue, received $1,050,000 in cash contributions during February, making it the most successful month in the history of the society, Winthrop W. Aldrich, president, announced yesterday. To date the society has received $6,225,221.

A campaign to raise $5,000,000 by July 31 for relief and rehabilitation work in China was begun yesterday by a new organization known as United China Relief, Inc., formed by a group of distinguished citizens to coordinate the appeals previously made independently by seven agencies serving medical, charitable, educational and economic needs in China.

BUZZARDS BAY, Mass., Monday, March 3 (AP) -- The Coast Guard reported that the agent of the American President Lines informed them that the liner President Hayes, which went aground last night at the Buzzards Bay entrance to Cape Cod Canal, floated under her own power early today.
There should be no doubt as to what area Foreign Minister Matsuoka referred when he called for a cession of "Oceania." Speaking in Japanese to the Deputies, he most probably used the word "Nanyo."

LONDON, March 2 (AP) -- Britain was expected momentarily tonight to announce that her diplomatic relations with Bulgaria had been broken off. This would be Britain's first concrete reaction to Germany's military penetration of the Balkan kingdom, and it may come by tomorrow.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 2 (UP) -- German mechanized troops raced across Bulgaria today to the Greek frontier to enforce a virtual "ultimatum" that Adolf Hitler is understood to have served on the Greeks, giving them only a few days to make peace with Italy.

Grete Stueckgold, the Metropolitan soprano, gave her first local recital in five years yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Miss Stueckgold, who was in excellent vocal form and as comely as ever, delighted a large and ardently appreciative gathering with a series of interpretations that once again demonstrated her superior gifts as a Lieder singer.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., March 2 -- Former Senator Ernest W. Gibson Jr., national chairman of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, here at his home town to preside as Moderator of the Town Meeting on Tuesday, today accused Senator Wheeler of making an unfounded charge that his committee is the tool of international bankers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 -- Fred MacMurray will be co-starred with Errol Flynn in Warner's "Dive Bomber," which will go before the cameras in ten days with Michael Curtiz directing, the studio has announced.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., March 2 -- New Zealand further tightened her defenses yesterday when National Service Minister Robert Semple announced the mobilization of all unmarried reservists who are not liable for drafting overseas.

The report for 1940 of the Pure Oil Company shows a consolidated net income of $8,718,057 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal after preferred dividend payments, to $1.21 each on the 3,982,031 common shares outstanding. For 1939, the company had reported a net income of $8,290,418, or $1.11 a common share.

A program for a "spiritual Pan-Americanism," to combat the "challenge" of "Leftist, Marxist activity in the Latin-American sphere," was outlined yesterday by Dr. Joseph F. Thorning, professor of sociology at Mount St. Mary's Roman Catholic College, Emmitsburg, Md., in an address at the Knights of Columbus forum at the clubhouse of the Columbus Council, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

BERLIN, March 2 -- The German High Command announced tonight that German troops had been marching into Bulgaria since this morning. The announcement of the occupation described the action as a counter-measure against anticipated moves by Britain.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 2 (AP) -- British General Headquarters isisued this communique today:

ATHENS, March 2 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, accompanied by General Sir John G. Dill, Chief of the Imperial General Staff; Air Vice Marshal T.W. Elmhirst and a staff of assistants, arrived in Athens from Ankara, Turkey, by air early this afternoon.

LONDON, March 2 -- It is becoming increasingly apparent that London is turning her eyes to the United States for guidance as to what line should be taken in postwar reconstruction. Opinions expressed by leading men of local and national government a few days ago suggest that the solutions of their problems will be found between the Atlantic seaboard and the shores of the Pacific Ocean.

MONT TREMBLANT, Quebec, March 2 -- Dartmouth's crack skiers once again established their supremacy over McGill University, while an Eastern Canadian women's team upset an Eastern United States group in the second annual international good-will meet that finished today.

For more than forty years Henry Davison Williams, now 78 years old, has quietly committed himself to the accomplishment of civic reforms. Yesterday he received the Grand Street Boys Association medal for unselfish service to the City of New York.
ALBANY, March 3 -- Members of the Legislature from the metropolitan area voted on important legislation last week as follows:

The recent upswing of cotton prices was extended further last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts registered net advances of 13 to 20 points. In the previous week, they had made gains of 12 to 24 points.

DETROIT, March 2 -- The Detroit Red Wings overcame a two-goal deficit tonight to smother the New York Rangers, 4 to 2, in an over-time National Hockey League game before 10,848 spectators. The victory returned Detroit to sole possession of third place in the standings.

Doubling of its advertising appropriation for this year, addition of newspaper space to its schedule and resumption of newspaper advertising on its theatrical cold cream, after a lapse of many years, have been announced by Miner's Inc., claimed to be America's oldest cosmetic makers.

Holding that nations that call Russia a friend "cannot say they are fighting for the kingdom of God," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen declared yesterday that with two exceptions the countries of the world today belong to Satan.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 2 -- The British forces attacking Cheren, Eritrea, from the north yesterday smashed through an important pass covering the approach to the town, British headquarters announced today. British bombers continued to raid Italian positions in the Cheren region.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A sharp increase in building-permit valuations for January, 1941, over January of last year was noted by the Department of Labor today. Secretary Perkins reported that the increase was more than 48 per cent.

PITTSBURGH, March 2 -- Important news to the steel industry here last week was the complete substantiation of its stand on the ability of current capacities and facilities under construction to take care of British defense needs, this country's national defense program, and ordinary commercial requirements.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 2 -- Ottar Satre of the Salisbury Outing Club, who is a ski maker in his more serious moments, showed his proficiency in the recreational side of the sport today when he won Class A honors in the annual tournament of the Swedish Ski Club on the Bear Mountain State Park's hill today.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Action of the corn market last week was largely determined by the fluctuations in wheat and, while trade broadened to some extent, the business was largely of a professional character. Cash interests were reported on both sides of the futures market on a small scale, but, as has been the case for many weeks, the shipping sales and the purchases to arrive were not fully reflected in pit operations.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, March 2 -- The probability that Yugoslavia soon would sign the Axis three-power pact was reported in authoritative quarters tonight. These sources said that this probability had resulted from conferences between Prince Paul, the Yugoslav Regent, and Viktor yon Heeren, German Minister to Belgrade.

An advantage of the City Planning Commission's scheme for a new civic center for Brooklyn is that the plan is not visionary. It is considerably more than a hope. The project would consist mainly of vital improvements which are either under way or in the planning stage, improvements which are mostly the fruits of years of effort by civic groups and public officials.

VICHY, France, March 2 -- The French press is only now allowed to report the provisional release from "administrative interment" of Charles Pomaret and Abraham Schrameck, both former Ministers and both prominent members of the former Radical Socialist party.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 2 -- Lawson Little, the national open champion, and sharpshooting Jimmy Demaret bowed out of the $5,000 international four-ball golf tournament today, the victims of a 50-to-1 team, as golf's leading professionals showered the Miami Biltmore course with birdies in the thirty-six-hole first round.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 2 (AP) -- Featuring many articles offered to foreigners in the export trade, but forbidden to Germans, the 700-year-old Leipzig Fair opened today with a call from Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels for Germany to lead Europe into a "new order" of economics.

America's vital interest in the Far East today is to sustain the morale of the Chinese people in the face of Japanese aggression. With 50,000,000 refugees streaming from the battle zones, the sum of human misery in China is almost inconceivably great, but fortunately there is no country in the world where American dollars will do so much to relieve it.

LONDON, March 2 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 103.0 on Feb. 18, compared with 102.5 on Feb. 4 and Jan. 21, 91.9 on Feb. 27, 1940, 70.3 at the end of August, 1939, and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

A thorough overhauling of the museums that occupy city park property or are in part maintained at the expense of the taxpayers is recommended by Park Commissioner Robert Moses in a report to Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday.

CLEVELAND, March 2 (AP) -- Although steel sales "are at around 150 per cent" of the industry's capacity, "there is possibility of an impending falling-off in orders," the magazine Steel wrote today in its weekly summary of the industry.
FORT DIX, N.J., March 2 -- In the Army since last October, Private Leland Earl, temporarily assigned to headquarters battery, Sixty-ninth Field Artillery Brigade, will get his first pay next Monday.

Efrem Zimbalist, violinist, and Jose Iturbi, pianist, both members of the American Guild of Musical Artists, have joined the American Federation of Musicians, it was announced yesterday by Henry A. Friedman, attorney for James C. Petrillo, A.F.M. president.
FORT DIX, N.J., March 2 -- In the Army since last October, Private Leland Earl, temporarily assigned to headquarters battery, Sixty-ninth Field Artillery Brigade, will get his first pay next Monday.

Although there was still ice in the Hudson River yesterday and some dirty snow on the streets, thousands of New Yorkers responded to the warmest day this year by visiting parks and beaches and driving into the country.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Definite progress has been made on two of the principal problems confronting the Legislature -- the State defense program and the question of whether to transfer grade crossing funds to highway use. The third principal problem, that of the State budget, will be taken up in conferences of the Republican leadership, starting tomorrow.

HYAK, Wash., March 2 (AP) -- Making the longest jump in his life, Torger Tokle of New York won the national ski-jumping championship on Olympian Hill today with a 288-foot leap that bettered the North American record.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 2 -- Another achievement in splitting atoms of the kind upon which science pins its hopes of obtaining atomic power was reported today by Dr. Emilio Segre, physicist, and Dr. Glenn Seaborg, chemist, of the University of California.

Efrem Zimbalist, violinist, and Jose Iturbi, pianist, both members of the American Guild of Musical Artists, have joined the American Federation of Musicians, it was announced yesterday by Henry A. Friedman, attorney for James C. Petrillo, A.F.M. president.

VICHY, France, March 2 -- Deprivation of French nationality enacted on July 23 for those who fled the country between May 10 and June 30 "to evade duties incumbent upon the national community" is now extended to embrace those who "outside the metropolis betray their trust and by acts, speeches or writings, whether public or private, engage in propaganda calculated to hinder national reconstruction."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 2 (UP) -- Private advices reaching here today said that 1,500 European refugees were stranded at Dakar, French West African port on the Atlantic, and described them as being ravaged by tropical fevers and undernourishment.

The trend to capes for the Spring season became more pronounced last week with increased demand noted for both separate capes and cape suits. Another interesting development last week was the greater popularity of dressy suits and coats, which were far outselling any other items in the ready-to-wear market.

VICHY, France, March 2 -- The French-German talks that have been taking place in Paris for an accord over the division of raw materials already have had positive results in certain domains. In others, it is hoped to reach a possible solution through exchanges of views to follow.

WILMINGTON, N.C., March 2 (UP) -- The Wilmington Building Trades Council, A.F. of L., tonight called a strike for tomorrow at Camp Davis, Army anti-aircraft firing range under construction at Holly Ridge, near here.

A special service commemorating the birthday anniversary of Thomas G. Masaryk, "father" of the Czecho-Slovak Republic, and its President until his death two years ago, was held yesterday at the Jan Hus Presbyterian Church, 351 East Seventy-fourth Street.

The newly organized German-American Congress for Democracy held its first national conference yesterday in the Hotel Piccadilly to launch a loyalty movement among Americans of German birth or German ancestry.

One aspect of Mr. Culbertson's new revision of bidding in contract bridge that has received insufficient attention is the effect it may have on domestic relations. This effect appears likely to be good, so we commend the liberalized bidding rules regardless of what they do to the game itself.

ATHENS, March 2 (UP) -- Heavily protected against any surprise Italian air attack, British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden arrived in Athens this afternoon aboard a huge Sunderland flying boat for emergency consultations on means of meeting any German attack through Bulgaria.

VICHY, France, March 2 -- The financial administration is not in any way altered by the new organization of the Cabinet, but important changes are introduced into the economic services. Them are all put under the authority of the Minister of National Economy and Finances, who henceforth assumes direction of the whole economic policy of the government and of the empire.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 2 -- The Turkish Navy Ministry announced tonight that the strategic Dardanelles had been closed to all ships except those having special permits and employing Turkish naval pilots. The ruling went into effect tonight.

God is not the dictator of the details of a man's life, but the designer of man's destiny, said the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers in his sermon yesterday in the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.

HAVANA, Monday, March 3 -- The sixty-four-foot yawl Good News, owned by Robert W. Johnson of New Brunswick, N.J., was first to cross the finish line off Morro Castle at 1:29:09 A.M. today in the twelfth St. Petersburg-to-Havana yacht race.

In the absence of its pastor the congregation of the Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue and Ninety-first Street, observed yesterday morning the fifteenth anniversary of the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Farber's pastorate.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Numerous influences combined last week to result in an extremely nervous wheat market, but the undertone was relatively strong, and at one time prices were in new ground since late in January and showed a recovery of around 7 cents a bushel compared with the low level on Feb. 18.
The government further reduced last week the amount of shipping tonnage available to the merchant marine with the purchase of two new cargo vessels from private operators, it was disclosed yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 -- Coincident with a change for the better in the weather, the Yankee population at this windblown training base was increased by two arrivals today. Tommy Henrich, baby-faced guardian of right field, and Mike Chartak, Newark candidate for a varsity berth, checked in.

Establishment of a National Defense Labor Party Policy Committee, with its chairman appointed by President Roosevelt and the other members selected in equal numbers by the national organizations of labor and management, was recommended yesterday by a special committee of the Twentieth Century Fund surveying defense labor problems.

A "mobilization for democracy," with church-goers as soldiers "equipped to fight with the weapons of right," has been started at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, under the direction of its rector, the Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, it was announced yesterday.

HAVANA, March 2 -- Larry MacPhail's emotions were a bit mixed today. He was happy because Mickey Owen signed his contract this morning after an amicable conversation, and exuberant because his Dodgers mopped up the Giants for the third straight time.

BERLIN, March 2 -- Germany's increased economic help to Italy constitutes the outstanding feature of last week's trade agreement expected to lift the German-Italian foreign trade turnover to 2,000,000,000 marks a year. The Mediterranean Axis partner thus will top the list of the Reich's foreign trade partners, with Sweden and Russia a close second and third.

HAVANA, March 3 -- Gulf Stream, the seventy-foot yawl owned by Dudley C. Sharp of Houston, Texas, was officially declared the winner on corrected time both in the fleet and the yawl division in the twelfth annual St. Petersburg to Havana race this afternoon.

ROME, March 3 (AP) -- The Italians conceded today the loss of the garrison that had defended the Kufra oasis district of Eastern Libya, and its capture apparently left the isolated fort of Jarabub as the last Fascist position in the Cyrenaican Desert.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., March 3 -- General Sir Hugh Dowding, British Air Chief Marshal, conferred with the staff of the Northeast Air District and spoke to some officer personnel of the post in a three-hour visit here today.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Debits to deposit accounts (except inter-bank accounts), as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Feb. 26, aggregated $8,785,000,000.

The lngers and Red Wings, virtual certainties to meet in the Series B hockey play-offs, will clash in a league encounter at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Wings have clinched the season's honors between the teams, with three victories, three ties and one setback.

A very interesting concert, though one not without its elements of fetichism, was given by the Bach Circle of New York, now in its fourth season, last night in Town Hall. A small string orchestra, with soloists upon stringed and wind instruments, and two harpsichords which served for the performances of concertos and at other times supplied, with low-stringed instruments, the harmonic parts known as the "continuo" in ensembles, were the forces engaged.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 3 -- Gene Sarazen, the golfing farmer from Brookfield, Conn., came up with another of his great shots today for an eagle on the first extra hole and sent his team into the semi-finals of the Miami Biltmore's $5,000 international four-ball tournament.

We need to be reminded that there are Germans, both inside Germany and outside it, who hate nazism. Those inside Germany are imprisoned, outlawed or otherwise silenced. Those outside can still speak, as some of them did in this city on Sunday at an all-day meeting of the newly organized German-American Congress for Democracy.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 7 per cent for the week ended March 1, in comparison with the like period a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HANAVA, March 3 -- President Fulgencio Batista fixed today Cuba's sugar crop for 1941 at 2,000,000 long tons in accordance with the restriction plan which is being followed by this island republic. Of the crop, 958,891 tons will be for shipment to the United States this year; 500,000 will be retained for United States use; 99,963 for other countries; 291,146 as a reserve for world markets and 150,000 tons for domestic consumption.

Unstable radio reception resulting from intermittent magnetic storms was forecast for this month yesterday by RCA Communications, Inc., as radio disturbances of varying intensity continued following the severe electric storm Saturday. Reports of fluctuating short-wave reception also were received from other communications companies.

Members of the thrift shop committee for the Children's Village gave their annual bundle luncheon in behalf of that organization yesterday at the Kungsholm Restaurant. Miss Jane Cowl, a star of the current Broadway production, "Old Acquaintance," was the guest of honor and later spoke informally on the theatre of the present day.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 3 -- The Everglades Club was filled tonight for the Rule Britannia Ball for the benefit of Bundles for Britain and the British War Relief Society. Milton W. Holden was entertainment chairman and Hugh Dillman general chairman. The event was open to the public.

KANSAS CITY, March 3 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted fifteen persons, fourteen corporations and an association today on charges of conspiracy to violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Law by fixing prices on standard millwork in Missouri, Kansas, Oklahoma and Arkansas.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The Children's Wear and Allied Trades' Sub-group, encouraged by the reception given its first collection in New York, has decided to show an Autumn range in the United States and Canada. The collection will be presented by the Reciprocal Trade Corporation, of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Ten fruit and vegetable canning corporations which do 45 per cent of the business made 13 per cent in 1939 on stockholders' equity after provision for income taxes, according to a report today by the Federal Trade Commission.

The final bracket in the annual metropolitan squash racquets doubles championship was filled yesterday as David McElroy and W.B. Adsit Jr., of the University Club, and the two Haskins, Stanley G. and Lathrop S., of the Harvard Club, triumphed at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

The Illinois Company of Chicago and associates bought yesterday $6,568,000 of tax-anticipation warrants of Cook County, Ill. Par was paid for $2,025,000 at three-quarters of 1 per cent and the balance -- $4,543,000 -- similarly went at 1 per cent.

BERLIN, March 3 -- There is a suspicion in some quarters here tonight that efforts are being made by interested parties to effect a settlement of the Italo-Greek conflict through mediation on the part of a neutral Southeastern European State.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- "To meet unforeseen defense-industry demands at the earliest possible date," President Roosevelt today requested Congress to appropriate $10,900,000 for expediting construction of the Bonneville power project.

About the middle of March, 1940, after poring over some private analyses of employment statistics, this department ventured to inquire "whether the administration and its political opponents are not aware that unemployment is probably millions below the number usually assigned, and are ignoring the fact because it embarrasses both groups?"

City realty trading yesterday ranged from the Chelsea area, where a large loft near Sixth Avenue changed hands, to East Harlem, in which section two tenement properties went into new ownership. In another transaction, two buildings on East Fifty-seventh Street were traded.

FOR some years Manager J.J. Dykes of the White Sox was around saying rather contemptuously that anybody could play first base. Then he hired Zeke Bonura. With great gusto the amiable but blundering Bonura proved to J.J. Dykes that not everybody could play first base.
New York's Spring week of custom-made designs got off to a running start yesterday afternoon when Jay Thorpe offered a preview of its styles.

MONT TREMBLANT, Que., March 3 -- Rugged Mont Tremblant, highest mountain in the Laurentian range, whose upper part is a Provincial park, possessed only two ski trails, the Taschereau and Kandahar racing descents, three years ago. Today, it boasts a $1,100,000 skiing resort, comparable with the best to be found in North America or on the Continent.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board shall limit its cease and desist orders to unfair labor practices actually found to exist, and to practices reasonably related to them, the Supreme Court ruled today. The opinion was written by Justice Stone.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Roosevelt canceled all engagements because of a severe head cold, but kept in touch with legislative leaders by telephone; he signed the Urgent Deficiency Appropriation bill and "blanketed in" under the Civil Service specified employes of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

Faced with the prospects of a further spreading of the war area as Nazi troops moved further into the Balkans, the stock market backed down further yesterday, with values impaired as much as 2 points, in the steel shares. The war news also served further to limit transfers in stocks and the volume on the Exchange proved to be the fourth dullest of the year, amounting only 333,480 shares, against 405,880 on last Friday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., March 3 (AP) -- The Rev. Charles E. Lillis, director of athletics at Seton Hall College, said tonight that University of Baltimore officials were "in error" in charging that Seton Hall "did not win a legitimate victory" in defeating Baltimore's basketball team, 45 to 44, Saturday.

Plans were filed yesterday in Manhattan for a twelve-story apartment house to be erected at a cost of about $500,000 on the southeast corner of Eighty-first Street and East End Avenue, in the Yorkville section, and for a three-story business building at 135-41 West Thirtieth Street to cost $50,000.

DOVER, Del., March 3 -- With many residents of the State indignant over the 500 arrests in yesterday's effort to enforce the 200-year-old Sunday blue law, the House of Representatives unanimously adopted here today a resolution denouncing Attorney General James R. Morford, who ordered the enforcement campaign.

According to word received here by the American-Swedish News Exchange 40 per cent of the Swedish merchant marine is now outside the Skagerrak blockade. A wireless message to the exchange from the Swedish Royal Board of Trade discloses also that more than 2,000 non-Swedish seamen are sailing on 404 Swedish ships now in foreign waters.

ATHENS, March 3 -- As new earth shocks occurred today in the provincial city of Larissa, a large part of which was destroyed in an earthquake Saturday, Italian planes bombed the stricken area for the second time in two days, it was officially announced tonight, but all five of the raiders were brought down.

The New York Historical Society registered yesterday the most vigorous protest of all the city's museums and kindred institutions criticized by Park Commissioner Robert Moses as too "musty," "sacred" and in need of revivification.

The Prudential Insurance Company sold the apartment house at 523-25 Thirty-fourth Street, Union City, N.J., to the Steinar Investment Company of Newark. The four-story building occupies a site 68 by 104 feet, contains twenty-four apartments, and is reported to have a yearly rental of $10,448.

The whole Balkan area seethes with a new crisis. Turkey calls up more reserves and mines the Dardanelles. Russia, perhaps merely for propaganda purposes, more likely through genuine fear of German power at the only gate to the Black Sea, protests formally to Bulgaria against the occupation of that country by the German Army.
LONDON, March 3 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

In our admiration for the scientific achievements of modern times we are hardly compelled to rehearse an erroneous version of medieval history. Least of all would we expect a distortion of historical truth at a meeting convoked to promote brotherly love as well as good-will.

A survey that reveals the rapid expansion of bank loans in connection with national defense, most of which do not require the assignment of government contracts as security, was announced yesterday by the American Bankers Association.

Here is a line of thought for Jane O'Ryan, whose letter appears in THE TIMES, and for others who may have been offended by Senator Clark when he said that "the nazism of Germany, the fascism of Italy, the communism of Russia, and the imperialism of Great Britain are but the same thing underneath."
Out of possibly 2,500 Americans now in Britain at least half are desperately anxious to get back to the United States. Many of these Americans describe themselves as constituting a "lost column."

With three morning and two evening papers registering declines, advertising lineage in eight New York newspapers dropped 2.0 per cent in February, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. A total of 6,956,921 lines was carried last month as against 7,103,638 in the like month of 1940.

MONTREAL, March 3 -- (Canadian Press) -- With National Hockey League teams down to their last half-dozen games or less, Boston's Bill Cowley increased his margin atop the league scoring race last week, aided by an injury to Syl Apps of Toronto.

Among the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday was one signed by Safair, Inc., for space on the ground floor of the R.C.A. Building, Rockefeller Center, for an office and the sale and display of airplanes.

The American Mutual Liability Insurance Company reported yesterday admitted assets of $43,314,642 on Dec. 31, 1940, an increase of $2,062,206 in the year. Cash and United States Government bonds amounted to more than 73 per cent of admitted assets.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3 -- With High One the winner of the six-furlong Spring Inaugural Handicap, the Gables Racing Association began its meeting today with a record betting figure for Tropical Park. On the eight races $570,714 passed through the totalizator, surpassing the previous high of $505,565 set March 6, 1940.

Elmer Rice's play "Flight to the West" will receive a new lease of life this evening at the Royale Theatre under the joint auspices of Louis Schaffer, executive director of Labor Stage, the cultural offshoot of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and Lee Shubert.
HAWAII may be the paradise of the Pacific to tourists but to Joseph Barber Jr., it is one of the problems of the Pacific. He tells all about his findings in his book, "Hawaii: Restless Rampart."*
The demand for cotton diminished yesterday and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved listlessly within a narrow range to close unchanged to 3 points lower than on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Three proponents of the lease-lend bill, Senators Tunnell, Smathers and Bridges, accused the opposition in their speeches today of playing into the hands of the Axis powers.

ROME, March 3 -- Former King Alfonso of Spain was buried this morning with a simple ceremony in the Spanish Church of Monserrat, where he must lie until either the monarchy is restored in Spain or ceases to become a political issue. Then the body will go into the last regal tomb of the Escorial.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A George Washington University five struck with new-found power tonight and in its finest performance of the season put St. John's of Brooklyn to unexpected rout, 59 -- 42, before more than 3,000 fans in Riverside Stadium.

Net profit of Parke, Davis Co. and its subsidiaries in 1940 was $8,187,712 after deductions for depreciation, amortization, Federal and foreign income taxes, provision of $100,000 for Federal excess profits tax and $140,000 for foreign profits not transferred to the United States, the concern reported yesterday.

The present conflict is essentially one of movement. This does not mean merely territorial movement but includes bewilderingly rapid changes in strategy, tactics, technology and weapons. The war is being fought in new ways. Our own army would be preparing in the dark if it were not for the keen eyes of our soldier observers on the battlefields.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A plan by which next year's graduates in engineering may be available for participation in the defense program several months in advance of normal college schedules will be presented for consideration at a special meeting here of the Committee on Engineering Defense of the United States Office of Education.

Waldorf J. Gutmann, 48 years old, who last July was made a partner in the Merrill Lynch, E.A. Pierce Cassatt curb brokerage house, one of the largest in the country, following his rise from a messenger boy for one of its parent concerns, was arrested yesterday in District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office for alleged thefts of $28,000 from the concern.

Billy Soose, the Farrell (Pa.) middleweight contender who will oppose Ernie Vigh of Newburgh, N.Y., in a twelve-round return bout at Madison Square Garden Friday night, worked out at Stillman's Gymnasium yesterday and, after boxing three rounds with Young Kid McCoy, weighed 161 pounds.

Mrs. Elizabeth Jensen, 34 years old, was found strangled to death at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon on a couch in the living room of the cellar apartment at 507 East 179th Street, a six-story apartment house in the Bronx, where she was janitress.

Following the determination by a New Jersey hospital psychiatrist that Dr. Otto Klemperer was "temperamental and unstrung," but that there was no reason for his detention, the internationally known conductor was freed by Morristown police shortly after 2:30 P.M. yesterday, and soon started for New York with his wife, son and daughter.
According to the newspapers, Commissioner Moses wishes to resolve the disposal of the Aquarium. Make no mistake about it, Mr. Moses is as effective as Hitler in razing landmarks!
The four-family apartment house at 2141 Chatterton Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Antal Krajnick to John Antoni, a client of Anton Keppel, broker. Lester A. Kent was the attorney for the seller.

A. Fleming MacLiesh and Cushman Reynolds have written a summary of the material resources and defense strength of the Western Hemisphere called "Strategy of the Americas." Duell, Sloan Pearce is putting it through for March 21 publication.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Treasury reported today that early income tax payments were running 58 per cent ahead of a year ago under the new defense tax system which requires more Americans to pay more taxes than ever before.
BOSTON, March 3 (AP) -- The new $3,000,000 liner President Hayes returned here today a few hours after running aground near the Cape Cod Canal -- fifty miles out on a 29,000-mile maiden voyage.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Soviet Russia's surprise statement of policy on the German military move into Bulgaria was interpreted in some quarters here tonight as a possible warning to Berlin to keep hands off Turkey and the vital Dardanelles.

Reporting record gross operating revenues of $1,174,322,517 and a high record of 17,484,000 telephones in operation in 1940, the annual report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company system released yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, president, declares that the Bell System is fully prepared to meet all national defense requirements and has even progressed to the point where major installations for defense purposes are being completed two years ahead of schedule.

ATLANTA, March 3 -- Governor Talmadge announced today that he had "washed his hands" of $48,000 in debts left by the New York World's Fair Commission of the preceding State administration of Governor Rivers despite the threat of a New York hotel to prosecute officials and employes of the commission on charges of owing a hotel bill and issuing bad checks.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 3 (AP) -The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:
The Celanese Corporation of America had net income of $6,376,896 in 1940, Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president, announced yesterday. Earnings in 1939 were $6,374,100.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- Bids were opened at the Army Quartermaster Depot here today on 8,000,000 units of underwear 50 per cent wool and 50 per cent cotton, equally divided between drawers and undershirts. Thirty-three mills participated, offering approximately 6,512,000 undershirts and 5,514,000 pairs of drawers at prices showing little variation from those prevailing at the last bid openings on similar merchandise some weeks ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 3 -- A resolution pledging cooperation to the State Board of Social Welfare in its pending survey of relief expenditures in Westchester County was adopted this afternoon by the Board of Supervisors, although one member said he doubted the efficacy of an inquiry by the State board into work that is already under its close supervision.

Thirty names were suggested to the nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday for the slate to be voted on at the annual election on May 12. The meeting was the first of three to be held. The others will he held on March 10 and 17.

The American Federation of Labor has issued a warning that steps should be taken at once to avert mass unemployment and economic collapse when the European war and the United States defense program end. The fear of a post-defense depression is, in some respects, an indication of confidence in an ultimate victory for the democratic countries.

Joseph M. Schenck, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation executive, will go to trial in Federal Court tomorrow before Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, it was disclosed yesterday. With Schenck on trial will be Joseph Moskowitz, who is accused of helping the executive to cheat the government on income taxes.
