MIAMI, Fla., March 3 (AP) -- A five-year quest ended triumphantly today for Tommy Glennon, 32-year-old West Chester, Pa., power boat enthusiast, who won the $5,000 Judge Emil S. Auerbach Memorial Trophy after four unsuccessful attempts.

VICHY, France, March 3 -- No Frenchmen of military age are allowed to cross from the occupied zone into the unoccupied. This decision has been taken in consequence of the discovery in the occupied zone of a well organized system of recruiting volunteers for General Charles de Gaulle's "Free French" forces.

Government officials, native business interests and the representatives of United States companies in Peru, Chile, Colombia, Argentina and Brazil are all keenly interested in getting technical guidance from experts here for the development of the natural resources of the countries mentioned, Maurice Holland, secretary of the National Research Council, asserted yesterday on his return from an extensive trip to the five Latin-American nations.

An assertion that the revised program of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, which it adopted following the decision of the Circuit Court of Appeals here last Summer, "has not been outlawed by the decision of the United States Supreme Court and the guild will continue to function under it," was made by the guild last night.

Yesterday's trading was only fair to slow, but prices showed little change from last Friday. Steer hinds and ribs were about steady, cow beef barely steady, bull beef steady, veal weak, lamb steady to firm and fresh pork cuts about steady. Early kosher trade was slow, with steer chucks and plates opening at steady prices, veal foresaddles barely steady and lamb fores strong to $1 higher.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Senator Glass of Virginia suggested today that the Senate impose cloture -- a procedure under which no Senator can speak more than once or more than one hour. "There have been too many speeches already," he said of the lease-lend debate.

The Southern California Edison Company, Ltd., reported yesterday for 1940 a consolidated net income of $12,368,722, after all expenses and charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.29 each on 3,182,805 shares of common stock outstanding and compared with a net of $12,670,238, or $2.38 a share, in 1939.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau announced today that 94 per cent of the holders of the $1,122,000,000 worth of 3 3/8 per cent bonds and 1 1/2 per cent notes due on March 15 had exchanged their securities for the Treasury's new taxable issue of 2 per cent seven to nine year bonds and three-quarter of 1 per cent notes.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Permission for the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line interests, represented by the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line, to intervene in the government anti-trust suit against the Columbia Gas and Electric Company was granted by the Supreme Court today.

SHANGHAI, March 3 -- With virtually the entire world either engaged in active hostilities or hovering on the brink of open warfare, Soviet Russia has been quietly yet none the less surely extending her activities through the entire Far East with the intention of sovietizing all Asia.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Dr. Friedrich Ernst Auhagen, called a Nazi propagandist by the Dies Committee, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of failing to register as a paid publicity agent for the German Government. A 1938 statute requires registration by all agents disseminating propaganda for foreign principals.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 97.5 per cent of capacity, a new high mark as to rate since June, 1929, and a new high mark for the history of the steel industry from the standpoint of output, estimated at 1,573,500 net tons of ingots and steel for castings.

LONDON, March 3 -- The Russian radio announced tonight that the Bulgarian Minister to Moscow had been told that Russia did not support Bulgarian acquiescence to the entry of German troops and deplored that acquiescence as tending to spread the European war.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 3 -- Turkey's two-weeks-old accord of non-aggression with Bulgaria has been "nullified," and the Turks will take action alongside Great Britain if Germany's Balkan army attacks either Greece or Turkey, semi-official quarters said today.

The number of airplane crashes during recent months has instigated some serious investigations by the management of airlines as well as public aeronautical authorities. The most recent crash near Atlanta has even evoked a proposal for a Senate investigation of the causes of these serious mishaps.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The Temporary National Economic Committee, commonly known as the monoply committee, made public today a study of corporation finances which, Chairman O'Mahoney said, showed that more than half of American corporation dividends went to 1,000,000 individuals.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Cummins will give a luncheon for more than 100 persons at the Surf Club, Miami Beach, tomorrow. Mrs. Charles I. Corby will entertain at the Wednesday luncheon fashion revue at the Surf Club.

HANOVER, N.H., March 3 -- Dorothy Thompson, writer, urged an audience at Dartmouth College tonight to help break "the chains of this Washington bureaucracy that kills a spirit and a hope and a free enterprise of democratic youth."

Josef Hofmann and Egon Petri, pianists, and Mischa Elman, violinist, have decided to join the American Federation of Musicians, it was announced yesterday by James C. Petrillo, president. The American Guild of Musical Artists, with which the federation has been fighting over the status of instrumental virtuosos, said that Hofmann and Petri were not Guild members, but that Elman was.

Charging that the Federal Trade Commission is "persecuting" his client, Gilbert H. Montague, attorney for the Biddle Purchasing Company, yesterday asked the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here not to name the FTC as a special master if the court grants a government motion compelling the respondent to show cause why the company should not be held in contempt for alleged violation of a consent decree involving brokerage.

The new high record for steel production this week appears to reflect the dispelling of strike possibilities and the completion of concentrated repairs. The industry has operated at better than 97.5 per cent on a few occasions, but with the substantially larger capacity now available, compared with all previous years, the tonnage produced at this rate will eclipse by a substantial margin the best output for any week in any previous year.

New Jersey, although retaining its lead as the State in which the largest dollar volume of defense contracts have been let, reduced its margin over New York State in the first half of February, according to a compilation of data issued by the Office of Government Reports yesterday.

Because of improved methods of clearing away the debris left by German bombing raids, London "looks better now than it did last October," and "the morale of the people is as high as it possibly could be," David K.E. Bruce, representative of the American Red Cross in Great Britain, reported yesterday upon arriving here aboard the Dixie Clipper.

The Columbia quintet, trailing Dartmouth's defending champions by a game and a half in the Eastern Intercollegiate League, meets Princeton tonight in another of the Lions' crucial stretch games. The contest is schedlled for 8:30 in the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

LONDON, March 3 -- Developments in the Balkans had an unsettling effect on the Stock Exchange here today. The Middle East oils were especially sensitive to the Bulgarian affair. Anglo-Egyptian oils along with the Anglo-Iranians also were marked down moderately.

Lewis L. Strauss, a partner of Kuhn, Loeb Co., New York banking concern, and a director of many corporations, has been called from the Naval Reserve to active service, it was learned yesterday. He is a Lieutenant Commander and probably will be stationed in Washington in the Bureau of Ordnance.

Anna Sokolow last night presented a dance concert with her group at the Mansfield Theatre, dedicated to the Mexican composer, Silvestre Revueltas, three of whose ballets were included on the program. This was Miss Sokolow's first appearance here in three years.

ANKARA, March 3 (London Times Dispatch) -- News of Bulgaria's adherence to the Tripartite Alliance was received in Ankara with a shrug of the shoulders. At its meeting yesterday, the Cabinet apparently decided that it was unnecessary to do more for the time being than take note of the Bulgarian decision.

VICHY, France, March 3 (AP) -- Japanese circles here said tonight that Tokyo had sent a third proposal for settlement of the border dispute between French Indo-China and Thailand. The French Ministers were said to have accepted the proposal except for a few minor details.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 3 -- Rightist parties have lost control of Congress for the first time in Chile as a result of yesterday's elections, according to official estimates given out late this evening which give the government a majority in both the Senate and the lower house.

LONDON, March 3 -- John G. Winant started his first working day as United States Ambassador by granting newspaper men an interview in which he declared American aid to Great Britain was increasing daily.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Restraints imposed by a group of dress manufacturers on the copying of their styles by other producers were declared illegal today by the Supreme Court. The court acted similarly against a group of millinery makers.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 3 -- The small "Free French" force that captured the Kufra oasis district marched 500 miles from its base before it began the month of raiding, shelling and other harassing action that resulted in the defeat of the Italian garrison.

The New York City Housing Authority had eight low-rent housing projects, accommodating 10,233 low-income families, in operation at the end of 1940, it was announced yesterday in the Authority's seventh annual report.

An invitation preview of a benefit art exhibition at the Turtle Bay Music School, 244 East Fifty-second Street, will be given with a tea on Saturday for art patrons and sponsors of the exhibit, which will be open to the public from Sunday through March 29.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The war is filling Davy Jones's locker with mail from the United States.

Max Rosen, violinist, who has been away from the New York concert stage for several seasons, returned last night at Carnegie Hall in a program for the benefit of Norwegian Relief. It was pointed out that Mr. Rosen had lived for a period in Norway, spoke the language of the country and was deeply attached to its people.

Mrs. Samuel L.M. Barlow gave a cocktail party yesterday afternoon at the Barberry Room in East Fifty-second Street for a group of artists who will participate in the concert in behalf of the Emergency Rescue Committee and the International Committee to Aid the Internees in Unoccupied France, to be held on Thursday night in the Hunter College Assembly Hall.

The management of the Cincinnati Union Terminal provided another milestone on the road which apparently is leading the railways toward the goal of competitive bidding for the better class of securities by authorizing yesterday the acceptance of bids for $3,000,000 of bonds which it proposes to sell.

Orders and reorders for women's Spring apparel and accessories increased here yesterday as retailers placed additional commitments to peak pre-Easter stocks by March 20 to 25. Reports indicated the next two weeks will see heavy purchasing in the wholesale markets and that pre-Easter sales of manufacturers will run well ahead of last year, despite the slow start occasioned by the later Easter this year.

TRENTON, N.J., March 3 (AP) -- George A. Hamid, owner of the Trenton State Fair Grounds, presented to the State Racing Commission today plans to spend $300,000 on the property to develop a $1,500,000 horse race track for operation with pari-mutuel betting.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Congress entered its third month today with three major bills enacted, five more passed by the House but blocked in the Senate by lease-lend debate, and only more taxes and appropriations marked "certain" on its future slate.

Requiring the payment of an insurance premium by the borrower from the proceeds of an automobile loan is contrary to the State Banking Law, the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court ruled yesterday in reversing a Municipal Court's decision.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Navy Department has awarded contracts totaling $42,036,000 for construction of naval aviation facilities in British insular possessions in this hemisphere.

Max Gordon has sold the screen rights of "My Sister Eileen," current Broadway comedy success, to Columbia Pictures for $225,000. According to the terms of the deal, Mr. Gordon will produce the film version of the play and also will make himself available to Columbia as a producer on other pictures during the tenure of a term contract which he signed with the studio.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., March 3 -- Many members of society in the north and south shore colonies are serving on the committee making plans for an evening program of the Nassau Philharmonic Society on March 21, to be given in the auditorium of Hofstra College, Hempstead.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 -- The first-base problem of the Yankees was solved today.

Golden Gloves champions in all divisions from flyweight to heavyweight, in open and subnovice classes, were crowned at Madison Square Garden last night, where the fifteenth annual competition was staged before 17,217 enthusiastic spectators.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board has laid "the groundwork for improved industrial relations," H.A. Millis, chairman of the board, said today, giving figures in the agency's fifth annual report to show that the board's facilities were used last year to settle an increasing number of disputes.

The girls branch of the Public Schools Athletic League will be aided by a card party to be held on the afternoon of March 15 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. It has been reported by Miss Dorothea McIlvaine, chairman of the patroness committee for the benefit, that already many tables have been reserved for the event.

Spring may be around two or three corners but the trout fishermen seem to be exhibiting an early interest this year, for the queries began coming in with March. The ranks of this brotherhood, if the letters are a true indication, are going to be increased to an even greater extent this year, and let us hope there will be enough open water and enough trout to encourage them.

People very seldom now speak of Mother Earth. The words have a quaint Gay-Nineties sound. They would have passed out of fashion in the course of time in any case. The process was hastened perceptibly by the fact that after the World War and the sweep of Freud all mothers fell under suspicion.

MILWAUKEE, March 3 (UP) -- A second apparent settlement of the six-week-old strike of the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers against the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company collapsed tonight with the abrupt breaking off of negotiations and a union charge that the company has resorted to "plain trickery."

ROME, March 3 -- The general opinion here today is that Germany will deliver an ultimatum to Athens in the hope of obtaining a settlement without fighting. Greece and Germany are formally friendly nations, for they have not even broken off dipomatic relations.

Add to the list of films scheduled to open this week Twentieth Century-Fox's "That Night in Rio," which will have its world premire at the Roxy on Saturday. The picture, which has a South American setting, stars Alice Faye, Carmen Miranda and Don Ameche ....

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 3 -- Edmund H. Driggs Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., former metropolitan and New York State amateur champion, scored 35, 35 -- 70, one under par, less a handicap of 3, for a 67, to take the medal in the first midwinter Florida invitation golf tournament today.

Four works of Greek inspiration were performed last night at the fourth concert of the season of the Orchestrette Classique at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Frederique Petrides, the founder and director of the ensemble, conducted, and one of the works, "Hellenic Suite" by Julia Smith, was dedicated to her.

A "perfect, uninterrupted parallel" between the policies of the New York Teachers Union, Local 5 of the American Federation of Teachers, under its present administration, and those of the Communist party is charged in a twenty-six-page report of the federation, made public yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, March 4 -- Continued use by the Chinese of small ports in the provinces of Chekiang and Fukien to bring in military supplies and export commodities, despite the Japanese blockade, is reflected in the report here last night of mass raids by Japanese planes on coastal points between Shanghai and Hong Kong. Japanese naval fliers are said to have carried out repeated attacks in the last three days.

In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Horace T. Hunter, publisher of The Financial Post of Toronto, Canada, takes issue with a recent statement of C.D. Howe, Canadian Minister of Munitions and Supply, that The Financial Post was the "No. 1 saboteur" of the war effort in Canada.

VICHY, France, March 3 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain early this morning was again occupied with affairs of state after two days' absence during which he visited Saint Etienne and Le Puy and conversed with men and women in all walks of life.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The Republican leaders in the Legislature made sufficient progress at a budget conference this-afternoon to call conferences of the Republican members of each house for Wednesday afternoon. The party's budget plan will be made public at the end of these conferences.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3 -- A bedraggled band of Giants managed to struggle back from the disastrous Havana invasion to its training base today and, after emerging from the tedious customs inspection, immediately cracked head-on into its fourth straight beating.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Thomas D. Campbell, wheat specialist, who gave Russia expert advice for the first Five-Year Plan, will fly to England this week on a secret mission.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 3 (AP) -British imperial forces, pursuing their clean-up in Italian Somaliland, have struck on eighty miles northeast of Mogadiscio, along the coast of the Indian Ocean, to occupy Villagio Duca degli Abruzzi, Middle Eastern headquarters announced here today.

ST. LOUIS, March 3 -- The testing period of the smoke elimination ordinance ended tonight with the Weather Bureau reporting a 71 per cent decrease in hours of smoke in the first Fall and Winter under the new law.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Blue surplus food stamps issued by local authorities with the cooperation of the Surplus Marketing Administration of the Department of Agriculture added more than $7,000,000 worth of farm products in January to the diets of nearly 3,000,000 members of families eligible to receive public assistance.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The War Department announced today that it had placed "educational" orders with five companies for the manufacture of low-cost civilian gas masks.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Major Gen. James L. Collins, now commanding the Second Division at Fort Sam Houston, Texas, has been assigned to command the Puerto Rican Department, with headquarters at San Juan, and will sail from New York April 12 for his new post.

The proposal for turning the government's raw cotton surplus into fabrics for use by relief agencies for war victims, for a reserve supply of Army and Navy goods, and perhaps at the close of the war as an economic weapon with which to fight the expected foreign trade war, has won support in the four major groups which would be affected, it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The House began consideration today of the 1942 fiscal appropriation of the Agriculture Department, which was made to show a book saving of $4,927,934 from Bureau of the Budget estimates and $193,023,502 from the 1941 fiscal year allowances.

Frank A. Brennan, director of the New York chapter, Knights of Columbus track meet, which will be held at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, tried hard to avoid going out on a limb again as he addressed members of the Track Writers Association at the Hotel Capitol yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Export Control Administration today cut through red tape to expedite the shipment of goods to Britain.

Most of the leading foreign currencies closed lower in quiet trading yesterday. The Canadian dollar ended at the day's low of 85.43 cents, off 19 points. The free-market quotation on the pound sterling finished at $4.03 1/2, off 1/4 cent.

Smith, Barney Co. and associates are expected to offer to the public after the close of the Stock Exchange some afternoon this week a block of at least 200,000 shares of common stock of the United States Steel Corporation. It is understood that the proposed offering represents British-owned stock.

A one-man show of paintings by Manuel Tolegian of California opened yesterday afternoon in the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue. Tolegian, although still in his early thirties, has had several shows in New York ere this, the last previous one having been held three years ago.
LONDON, March 3 -- Japan and Germany are rushing to strengthen their battle fleets by launching men-of-war totaling upward of 230,000 tons, the new volume of Jane's Fighting Ships revealed tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The National Youth Administration, says Administrator Aubrey Williams, has two tasks to do for national defense. One is to bolster the industrial and military front by training semi-skilled workers and by producing defense materials. The other is to protect the morale of the "home" front.
ROME, March 3 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

Milton B. Logan, who is being tried for the theft of $65,000 from art consignors to the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., of which he was president, was warned ten months before he was indicted that the company was losing money, according to the testimony of an accountant yesterday in the Court of General Sessions.

Governor Lehman has renewed his request, first made last year, for an amendment to the Banking Law reducing the legal rates of interest that may be charged by licensed lenders on small loans. In so doing he has raised a difficult but important question which deserves the most careful study of the Legislature.

WILMINGTON, N.C., March 3 (UP) -- Members of the Wilmington Building Trades Council, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, voted at a mass meeting tonight to continue the strike which started at 8 A.M. today at the Army's $13,000,000 anti-aircraft firing range at Camp Davis.

Drawings By Patsy DeVito, 26-year-old wall washer at Columbia University, who is exhibiting for the first time in the fifth annual faculty art show, were pronounced "considerably above the average" of the faculty's entries yesterday by Frank Mechau, director of the Columbia School of Architecture's division of drawing, painting and sculpture.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 4 -- The Japanese Government has presented a new final mediation plan in the dispute between Indo-China and Thailand, and it contains "some slight but not radical changes" of the last previous Japanese proposal, Koh Ishii, spokesman for the Government Information Board, announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Bulgarian credits in the United States were frozen by President Roosevelt through an executive order that he signed tonight.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 3 (UP) -- Greek defiance of Adolf Hitler's alleged "last chance" demands for an immediate Italo-Greek peace today brought an estimated 200,000 German mechanized troops into positions along the Greek-Bulgarian frontier barely sixty miles from Salonika, according to reports reaching Sofia.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had approved the proposed $125,000,000 financing program of the Georgia Power Company, a unit in the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation system.

Every time I come to the office on my lawful occasions The Boss assails me. "Why don't you do something about the frightful overheating in the theatres?" he growls, flexing the muscles in his arms. Without waiting for an answer he then shifts to another line of attack.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Another attempt of Administration forces to expedite Senate consideration of the lease-lend bill failed today when Senator Clark of Missouri objected to the request of Senator George, in charge of the bill, for unanimous consent to limit each Senatorial speech beginning tomorrow to one hour on the bill and thirty minutes on each of the thirty or more amendments.

Lilac has been chosen as the theme of the Spring collection selected by the Grand Duchess Marie for the fourth time for the Woman's Shop at Lord Taylor. At a showing at the store yesterday not only did print dresses feature purple lilacs on a white background or white lilacs on black, but the colors of coats, suits, evening dresses and negligees were keyed to the lilac tones.

Indications that the food stamp plan, which went into effect throughout the city last Saturday after a trial period of several months in Brooklyn, would be favorably received were seen yesterday by Department of Welfare officials when it was found that 2,346 persons already had bought $57,336 in stamps.

This year's coach of the Eastern College All-Star football team that will meet the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds either Sept. 3 or 4 will be James H. Crowley of Fordham. Selection of the Ram mentor and former Notre Dame backfield star was announced yesterday by The Tribune Fresh Air Fund, sponsor of the contest.

Eugene P. Connolly was declared yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder to be the legal American Labor party candidate in the special election to be held next Tuesday to fill the Seventeenth District Congressional seat made vacant by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson, Republican. His nomination had been ruled void by the Board of Elections.

Aldo Spoldi, 139 1/2, West Side, scored a technical knockout over Frank Velez, 144 1/4, Puerto Rico, in 1:40 of the fourth of a scheduled feature eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Palace before a crowd of 3,500 last night. Spoldi upset Velez with a right to the jaw shortly before the end of the third and when Velez came out for the fourth he was an easy target.

CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- Hog trading closed slowly today but managed to keep 5 to 15 cent gains from early activity. The top reached $8, 5 cents higher than last week's late close, and choice 180 to 240 pound bogs brought $7.60 to $8. Steer trade was slow and steady to 25 cents lower as outside demand continued narrow.

MOSCOW, March 3 -- Soviet Russia today informed Bulgaria in a formal note that Germany's military occupation of that Balkan State threatened "extension of the war" and that Russia refused to give support to Bulgaria's new Axis-dominated policy.

The Civilian Mobilization for the Salvation Army launched a campaign to raise $375,000 for the Army's work in New York City in 1941 at a dinner at the Hotel Pierre last night, at which 400 volunteer campaign workers heard the work of the Army praised by Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister to the United States, and other prominent speakers.

The six-story apartment house on a plot 102 by 124 feet at 78 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Adolph Kaufman, Ivor B. Clark and Henry Hetkin, as trustees of Series B-1, New York Title and Mortgage Company certificate investments, it was announced yesterday.

Air conditioning was made a factor in women's fashions at a show held yesterday during the luncheon hour at the New York Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. Sheer woolen gowns were featured and recommended both as cool to wear and as a preventive against ill effects from suddenly cooling temperatures encountered during the hot weather months.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The conditions statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 26:
LONDON, Tuesday, March 4 -The British Royal Air Force renewed its pounding of the invasion ports along the French coast last night.

Standing beside a pile of canceled green checks representing $24,999,874.50 in payments to hospitals, Dr. S.S. Goldwater, president of the Associated Hospital Service, presented yesterday a check for $125.50 to former Governor Alfred E. Smith.

ALBANY, March 3 -- A bill to limit the liability of banks for forged checks or unauthorized endorsements to two years was passed tonight by the Assembly and sent to Governor Lehman. Under the present law there is no time limit on bank liability.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aarch 3 -- The advance guard of the British Legation staff in Sofia arrived here tonight and the final evacuation of all Britons from Bulgaria appeared under way as Sofia reports forecast the rupture of Anglo-Bulgarian relations tomorrow.

Erwin Rudolph won twice from George Kelly in the world pocket billiard tournament at Doyle's Academy yesterday. Rudolph took the afternoon match, 125 to 54, in eight frames. He had a high run of 39 to 19 for the loser. In the night game, decided in twenty-four innings, the score was 125 -- 124, the winner having a cluster of 37, seven more than his rival.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook granted an application yesterday to require the Truck Drivers and Chauffeurs Union to submit to arbitration the question of the fitness to work as a truck driver of a union member whose discharge on Jan. 8 led to a forty-five-minute strike by drivers of the United States Trucking Corporation.

The Guaranty Trust Company, agent, is effecting the redemption of scrip certificates for fractional interests in fifteen-year convertible debentures of American Type Founders, Inc., at the rate of $1.27956 for each $1 principal amount of debentures represented by scrip certificates upon the surrender of such scrip certificates to its Corporate Trust Department.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 3 -- The spectacular arrival this morning of the German freighter Lech after running the British blockade from Bordeaux, France, brought crowds to the docks to see her this afternoon.
BERLIN, March 3 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique follows:

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., March 3 -- Captain Granville Conway, director of the Maritime Commission in New York, told the New Britain Traffic Association tonight that the commission and private operators were making every attempt possible to meet the country's emergency by supplying ships and well-organized schedules of sailings to handle private cargoes and defense needs.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 3 (UP) -- Captain Eddie Rickenbacker, seriously injured in an airplane crash last week, "improved this afternoon and his general condition now is good," an attending physician said after visiting him at 5:30 P.M., Central standard time.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, urged today the establishment of an agency similar to the National War Labor Board of 1918 to mediate labor-industry disputes in the defense industries so as to minimize strikes.

Reporting to stockholders for 1940, Edgar M. Queeny, president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, said yesterday that although domestic sales increased 18 per cent to a new high record of $45,607,600, net income increased only 5.6 per cent to $5,519,289.

Other yacht clubs having started the ball rolling by making up schedules for next Summer, including an ocean contest and a cruise, Larchmont came into line yesterday with the dates for its Race Week, always the feature of Long Island Sound competition, and its expressed intention of again staging its customary five championship regattas along with the Sunday specials.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- In another move to reserve first call on essential materials for defense industries the Office of Production Management imposed a mandatory priority today on the producers of magnesium.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday he was willing to attempt to settle the strike of the Retail Drug Store Employes Union, C.I.O. affiliate, against drugstores of the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation "if both sides agree to arbitration."

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Prices of wheat fluctuated today in an uneasy manner within a range of 1 1/4 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel. Aside from a brief flurry in the market soon after the opening, when short covering and buying, attributed mainly to mills, caused a sharp upturn, trading was colorless and mainly of a professional character.

The widely known American portrait painter, Eugene Speicher, is having his first one-man show in seven years at the Rehn Galleries, 683 Fifth Avenue. It opened yesterday and will remain current through March 29.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- Bob Burns, who was dropped from the Paramount contract list in 1939 after a long sojourn at the studio, was signed today by Paramount for the leading role in "The Goodfellow," a play written by George S. Kaufman and Herman J. Mankiewicz in 1926.

James M. Cox and John W. Davis, former Presidential nominees, and ten other prominent Americans signed a telegram to Senator Barkley, majority leader, declaring that every day's further delay "will be paid for by the blood of those who are fighting to stop Hitler beyond the Atlantic." The telegram was made public last night by the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies.

ATHENS, March 3 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Britain, after having made official calls and gone on a brief sight-seeing tour during which he was cheered by Athenians, began today a round of private talks whose results will determine the importance of his visit here with General Sir John G. Dill, Chief of the British Imperial General Staff.
MADRID, March 3 -- With Generalissimo Francisco Franco and his entire Cabinet in attendance, a funeral mass was sung this morning in the Church of San Francisco el Grande for former King Alfonso.

MONTPELIER, Vt., March 3 -- Vermonters were searching attics today for calico dresses and stovepipe hats to help them turn back the clock a hundred and fifty years in celebration tomorrow of the sesquicentennial of the State's admittance to the union, an anniversary which falls on "Town Meeting Day."

The team of the Cavendish Club of New York led the field in the first qualifying round in competition for the Reisinger Cup for open teams of four in the Eastern bridge championships at the Hotel Park Central last night. The Cavendish Club won twenty-one and a half of a possible thirty boards.

HAVANA, March 3 -- With the departure of the Giants, both the weather and the Dodgers returned to something approaching normalcy today. Not that anybody blames Colonel Bill Terry's men for the unseasonable weather that attended their visit, but that's the way it happened to be.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Wednesday, March 5 -- Great Britain broke off diplomatic relations with Bulgaria today. The break came a few minutes after 10 A.M. [3 A.M. in New York], when British Minister George W. Rendel read a declaration to Bulgarian Foreign Minister Ivan Popoff, and then asked for his passports.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 4 (AP) -- Steve Belloise, a leading contender for the middleweight title, had to put forth his best efforts tonight to win an eight-round decision from Vince Fratello, a comparatively obscure fighter from Hackensack, N.J., at the Westchester County Center.

Possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League team standing, and possibly the championship, will hinge on the outcome of the meet between Princeton and Yale in the Eli tank tonight. The contest will go a long way toward deciding the champion.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 4 -- Many entertained at the Sweepstakes Dinner tonight at the Seminole Club before the annual pro-amateur golf tournament there, which will open Thursday.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Roosevelt, starting today his ninth year in office, described the international crisis facing the United States as graver than the domestic crisis in which the country was involved when he first took office on March 4, 1933.

Abstraction is much in evidence just now. The big American Abstract Artists annual at the Riverside Museum has closed, but three one-man shows of work in various abstract idioms opened this week; the third phase of the surrealist exhibition continues at the New School for Social Research; and next week, held jointly by the Buchholz and the Willard Galleries, there is to be a Lyonel Feininger retrospective, lasting until March 29.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- In diplomatic circles here several theories are entertained concerning the basic and ultimate policy of Soviet Russia in this war. On none is there any considerable body of agreement. The mask of Moscow lifts briefly and occasionally, as when Vice Commissar Vishinsky reproved Bulgaria for the German occupation.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- The venerable Gene Sarazen scored another eagle as he and little Ben Hogan paraded today into the final of the $5,000 international four-ball golf tournament on the Miami Biltmore course, but handsome Horton Smith stole the semifinal show, even in defeat.

Most of the commentators on Vermont's 150 years in to the Union seem to be interested only in the 150 years. People write as if in the year 1791 it was a well-established custom for new States to be admitted into the Federal Union and Vermont was following the fashion.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 4 -- An urgent message from Reichsfuehrer Hitler intimating, according to highly placed persons, that the Nazis wanted to look after Turkey's "interest and well-being," was delivered dramatically to President Ismet Inonu today.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 4 -- The Misses Clara Dommerich and Louise Schierenberg of the home club showed the way into the semi-final round of the annual women's squash racquets doubles tournament of the Field Club of Greenwich today when they turned back Mrs. Eric Lamme and Mrs. Robert Merrill of Apawamis, 12 -- 15, 15 -- 10, 18 -- 17, 15 -- 7.
Both the East and West sides of the midtown section shared in the commercial renting activity reported by brokers yesterday.

As a part of the drive of seven public and private city agencies to stop the "junking" of dilapidated buildings by juveniles, which causes the loss of thousands of dollars to New York property holders each year, letters and posters warning against this practice will be sent out this morning by Justice Stephen S. Jackson of the Domestic Relations Court to principals of every public school in the city.

Ground-breaking ceremonies will be held on Saturday at 3 P.M. on the site of Clason Point Houses, the first low-rent public housing project in the Bronx, under the auspices of the New York City Housing Authority.

Plans for the extension of the system of savings banks life insurance, which was started in Massachusetts thirty-three years ago and adopted in New York State two years ago, are now being considered in legislative circles in Connecticut and New Jersey.

A slackening of selling permitted the share list to make a moderate advance yesterday, although there was no enlargement of volume associated with the mild recovery. Volume on the Stock Exchange was, in fact, the second smallest since mid-September last, as trading fell off to 307,890 shares, against the Monday total of 333,480.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 4 -- Mobilization orders appeared on the streets of Belgrade and provincial capitals of Yugoslavia today for the first time since the outbreak of the European war in 1939. Huge white posters warned:

GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., March 4 (AP) -- With the halfway mark of the national field trials finally passed and better weather promised, the race for the coveted 1941 bird-dog championship apparently remained wide open today.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced the adoption, under the Investment Company Act of 1940, of Rule N-23 C-1, relating to the repurchase of their own outstanding securities by closed-end investment companies registered under the act.
ATHENS, March 4 -- The situation on the Albanian front is described tonight in a Press Ministry communique as "developing successfully and according to plan."
Stewards of the Jockey Club, in session yesterday, appointed officials for New York tracks for the coming season and granted eighty-three licenses to trainers and eleven to jockeys.

Establishment of a ceiling price on mixed aluminum scrap by the price stabilization division of the National Defense Advisory Commission practically brought an end to trading in the scrap market yesterday. Scrap metal dealers decided to "sit tight" until at least Monday and not to engage in any buying or selling until ceiling prices were established on all grades of scrap aluminum.

Mrs. Helen S.K. Willcox in her letter published in THE TIMES of March 1 makes a strong case against the real estate tax upon the farmer. It is essentially the case against all capital levies which, in good times, often result in undertaxation, and, in bad times, in confusion.

Directors of the Dennison Manufacturing Company declared yesterday a dividend of $6 on its prior preferred stock, payable on April 1. Another dividend of $1.50 also voted on the prior preferred, payable on May 1, represents the two quarterly dividends of 75 cents each payable on the issue in the first half of the year 1941.

Forty water-colors by child artists are being shown at the New York City Information Center, Pershing Square. They were done in the New York City WPA art classes throughout the five boroughs and will be on view until April 15.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 4 -- With Smiley Quick and Tommy Goodwin, favorites in opposite brackets, leading the way, most of the first-round matches in the men's annual championship of Palm Beach today at the Golf Club ran true to form.
LONDON, March 4 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:
The annual report of the Glens Falls Insurance Company shows total admitted assets on Dec. 31, 1940, of $19,880,249, against $19,378,813 at the close of the previous year.

Settling down in the second half, Columbia vanquished Princeton, 41 to 33, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League battle in the Lions' gymnasium last night and kept alive the Light Blue's hope of overhauling Dartmouth in the championship chase.

After witnessing a convincing demonstration yesterday of the ability of a Seeing Eye dog to guide its blind master, members of the City Council voted unanimously to request the Board of Transportation to allow such dogs to ride on sub-way trains.

Spring and Summer fashions displayed yesterday by Saks Fifth Avenue featured prints and woolens. Henri Bendel offered innovations in silhouette based on flaring peplums and pockets that stood away from the hips.

The 203,127 common shares of the United States Steel Corporation offered on behalf of the British Government by a nation-wide group headed by Smith, Barney Co. at 3:40 P.M. yesterday was 50 per cent oversubscribed at 3:40 P.M., when the books were closed, it was announced by the bankers.

A contract bridge team from the Cavendish Club, consisting of Edward Hymes Jr., Sam Fry Jr., Howard Schenken, Benedict Jarmel and J. J. Dreyfus, won the qualifying honors in the team-of-four competition for the Reisinger Trophy at the Eastern bridge championships at the Park Central Hotel last night.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- United States exports in January reached $325,000,000, an increase of $3,000,000 over December but a slight decline compared with the average of the last six months of 1940, the Department of Commerce announced today.
The Republican party is dead. The maladies which racked its body were many, but three were chiefly to blame for its demise. They were:

Part of the Rumanian coastline on the Black Sea has been declared a dangerous area for shipping by the Rumania Government in an announcement made here yesterday through the Navy Hydrographic Office at 90 Church Street.

Five thousand day workers in the BMT division of the city's rapid transit system, members of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, adopted at a meeting last night a resolution demanding that the Board of Transportation negotiate a new contract with the union for city transit employes.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Nineteen of the more important electrical machinery and apparatus manufacturing corporations of the country had a 1939 combined sales volume of $806,335,939, or about half of the value of all such products manufactured in 1937, according to Census Bureau statistics, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- The wheat market showed a firm undertone today and prices held within a range of about 3/4 cent a bushel. Houses with Eastern connections were fair buyers of the May early, regarded as in the way of covering sales made last week, but the balance of the business was of a professional character.
Tami Mauriello, 164, of the Bronx, knocked out Harry Ginsberg, 161, of Brownsville in the fourth round of a scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Bronx Coliseum last night.

BERLIN, March 4 -- An official German spokesman said today for the first time that Germany's relations with Greece "are not good," although it was denied that any Nazi demands had been served on the Greeks to conclude a speedy peace with Italy under threat of a German attack through Bulgaria.

BERLIN, Wednesday, March 5 -- The official German news agency reported today that British naval forces had carried out a surprise attack on an island off Northern Norway yesterday morning and captured "several Germans and a Norwegian fish erman" before they withdrew.

MONTPELIER, Vt., March 4 -- The people of Vermont celebrated the 150th anniversary of the State's admittance to the Union today at town meetings throughout the State where, amid pageantry and merrymaking, they translated into formal resolutions exhortations from President Roosevelt and Governor Wills to rededicate themselves to the ideals of freedom and unity held by Ethan Allen and his successors.

The outlook for education is darkened by the four cults of "skepticism, presentism, scientism and anti-intellectualism," which "can lead us only to despair, not merely of education, but of society," Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, declared last night at the annual meeting of the Phi Beta Kappa alumni at the Ambassador.

For the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, tickets will be sold to an auction of 100 objects of art from the William Randolph Hearst collection at Gimbel Brothers on Tuesday night, March 25, it was announced yester day.

CHICAGO, March 4 (AP) -- Despite moderate supply of 14,500 head, including 11,000 salable arrivals, hog prices slipped as much as 10 to 15 cents today after a slow opening. Extreme top was $8.05, with the bulk of choice 180 to 240 pound hogs bringing $7.70 to $8.

The Ballet Theatre last night opened the fourth and final week of its present engagement at the Majestic Theatre with an excellent program, a spirited performance and an audience that never missed a point from curtain to curtain.

LAC BEAUPORT, Que., March 4 -- Back in 1937 Emile Allais, two-time world champion and winner of the Arlberg-Kandahar races, stirred up a controversy in skiiing circles when his parallel technique was adopted as the official school of skiing in France.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced the filing by the Wheeling Steel Corporation of a registration statement covering $30,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent, first mortgage, sinking fund bonds, Series B, due on March 1, 1966.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 4 -- Asking more than twice their current wages, 150 longshoremen went on a spontaneous strike today, refusing to unload the 200-ton cargo of the United States freighter Alcoa Pathfinder, carrying material for the construction of the naval base on Tuckers and Morgans Islands, or to load the Alcoa Ranger.

The 1940 annual report of the Wisconsin Electric Power Company, released yesterday by S.B. Way, president, shows a net income for the year of $2,764,434, compared with $2,702,015 in 1939. Gross operating revenues of the company, which is a unit in the North American Company system, aggregated $23,063,080 for the year, against $21,700,220 in 1939, an increase of 6.3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Negotiations looking to the consolidation of hemispheric defense have been extended to include the United States and Mexico. The fact that conversations are under way here was formally announced tonight in identical statements issued by the State Department and the Foreign Office in Mexico City.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- A noble experiment was given its first trial in the Yankee training camp today. Joe Gordon, who had been a flash at second, had his first workout at first base. And, while the initial step in the conversion of the Rock satisfied Manager Joe McCarthy, it must be recorded that Joe wasn't exactly a Hal Chase, or even a Babe Dahlgren, in his new position.

That two men purchased the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., in 1938 with $65,000 they had borrowed previously from the corporation itself was brought out yesterday at the General Sessions trial of one of them, Milton B. Logan, who became the president of the galleries, for alleged thefts of $65,000 from some of its patrons.

Having determined the excess profits net income for each of the base period years (line 27 of Schedule A of the return (Form 1121)), the next step is to calculate the "net aggregate" amount for the entire base period (Section 713(b)).

LONDON, March 4 -- A strong force of Canadian troops carried in several great liners has arrived in Britain under an elaborate naval escort without encountering the Germans in any way at all, it was reported today. Completion of this job keeps intact the Royal Navy's record of not losing a single man or ship in transporting soldiers from the dominions since the war began.

LONDON, March 4 -- In the future more than fifty British industries will be required to concentrate their manufacturing in a few plants and turn over all the others and their labor to war work. This decision -- perhaps the most drastic one concerning industry yet taken -- was approved yesterday by the War Cabinet and announced in the House of Commons today by Oliver Lyttleton, President of the Board of Trade.

DETROIT, March 4 -- The United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) presented today to James F. Dewey, Federal labor conciliator, a list of its demands on the Ford Motor Company, and at the same time Harry H. Bennett, Ford personnel manager, released a letter to Governor Murray D. Van Wagoner, which asserted there was no dispute between the company and its employes, and branded the union as "Communist-led and influenced labor agitators."
The new United States liner America, the largest merchant ship ever built in this country, returned here yesterday from her first voyage to the Pacific Coast.

One of the most important considerations in the sale of industrial properties has become the availability of skilled labor, and community programs for filling vacant plant space should include as one of their primary activities detailed studies of the number of workers readily available and the types of skill and training they possess, according to Leonard C. Yaseen, New York manager for Fantus Factory Locating Service.
Upsets marked the quarter-final round of the national Class B squash tennis championship at the City Athletic Club yesterday, three highly favored players bowing in the course of the day's play.

Three thousand women crowding the ballroom of the Hotel Commodore yesterday for the opening campaign rally of the United New York Appeal of the Joint Distribution Committee and the National Refugee Service heard Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt hail their organization as one of the agencies to which she turns for information or assistance with the problems brought to her in 800 letters daily.

Because of the priority list established by the government in its defense program, the Board of Education must postpone the opening of its newly built $2,000,000 East New York Vocational High School, James Marshall, president of the board, disclosed yesterday.

The four-story garden-type apartment house on a plot 60 by 100 feet at 111 Sagamore Road, Tuckahoe, Westchester County, was sold by the West Side Savings Bank to an investing client of Daniel A. Brener Co.

LONDON, March 4 -- Great Britain, which has been on daylight-saving time throughout the Winter, will have still more daylight saving beginning May 3 and lasting until Aug. 9. Herbert Morrison, Minister of Home Security, announced in the House of Commons today that between those dates "Summer time," as Britons refer to daylight saving, will be two hours ahead of standard time.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 5 -- German planes bombed widely separated parts of this country early today and last night within twenty-four hours after making a terrific fire raid on Cardiff, where churches, schools, stores and homes were destroyed.

Trustees in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation informed security holders of the $1,000,000,000 utility system in a special letter yesterday that there are four key problems which must be solved before complete reorganization of the A.G. system can be consummated.

LONDON, March 4 -- Michael Redgrave, stage and film star, and a number of others prominent in the entertainment sphere, have been banned from making British Broadcasting Corporation broadcasts because of their favorable views toward the organization known as the People's Convention which advocates a "people's" peace with the German masses and closer cooperation between Britain and Soviet Russia.

A short time ago a very dear friend of mine was killed. His life was an epic, his name, Sir Frederick Banting of Toronto. It is unnecessary to go into his major discovery of insulin, but it is pertinent to bear in mind that there are approximately 1,500,000 diabetics in the United States.

Tuesday there will be a special election in the Seventeenth Congressional District to choose a Representative in Congress to succeed the late Kenneth Simpson. The Republicans nominated Joseph Clark Baldwin, the Democrats Dean Alfange, the Left-wingers of the American Labor party Eugene P. Connolly, New York County chairman of that party.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 4 -- The Germans' entry into Bulgaria has brought the Mediterranean pot to a boil. The Eastern Mediterranean is set for battle as it has never been since Napoleon got the dust of Egypt out of his eyes.

Willie Mosconi, leader in the tournament for the world pocket billiard title, and Johnny Irish split two games at McGirr's Academy yesterday. Mosconi won in the afternoon, 125 -- 99, in eleven frames, but bowed in the afterpiece, 125 -- 14, in two.

Jobs for 25,000 dress workers were found during the last eight months by the State Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance, it was announced yesterday by Milton O. Loysen, executive director.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick plans to be in the market in about two weeks with approximately $40,000,000 of New York City serial bonds, for various purposes, it was learned yesterday. This borrowing, it is understood, will take care of all of the city's financial requirements for 1941.

Tuberculosis still stands at the top of the list of causes of death in the age group between 15 and 45, the group "most directly vital to defense," A.J. Altmeyer, Chairman of the Social Security Board, told a gathering of physicians and public health workers yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Roosevelt made it clear today that he expects to conduct personally the accelerated program of national defense and allied aid which he will be empowered to put into force upon enactment of the lease-lend bill.

Visiting buyers reported in the market last week numbered 924 as against 1,026 in the previous week and 660 in the like period last year, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES listings. Yesterday's arrivals were 413 which compared with 334 for a week ago.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Administration leaders in the Senate, on assurances from opponents of the lease-lend bill that the general debate on the measure would not be prolonged beyond today, abandoned plans to sit out what they had come to regard as an incipient filibuster and made arrangements to start the consideration of amendments tomorrow.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 4 (AP) -- A British General Headquarters communique said today:

ROME, March 4 -- The flat statement that Eastern Thrace will be restored to Bulgaria by the Axis, giving her an outlet in the Aegean, was made today by the newspaper Piccolo. Political circles continue to insist that there is no question of an Italo-Greek armistice and that, so far as Rome is concerned, only an armed solution of the conflict between the two combatants is possible.

In what was described as a bold attempt to revive the Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania vice ring in this city, two men were held yesterday in the Felony Court on compulsory prostitution charges and twenty-four women were committed to the House of Detention as material witnesses, following nine raids by police and attaches of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office on Monday night.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 -- Forty-four hosiery manufacturers offered a total of 29,259,500 pairs of light wool socks at the Army Quartermaster Depot today at the opening of bids on the Government's request for 17,000,000 pairs.

The Edison Electric Institute, statistical, fact-finding and service organization for the $14,000,000,000 electric power and light industry, will register with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, it was learned yesterday.

A torpedo slicing through the water at fifty miles an hour destroys with its impact a vessel that required several months of work by several hundred men to build. Since Sept. 3, 1939, when the Athenia went down off the coast of Scotland, the tons of shipping destroyed by torpedoes and bombs have mounted into the millions.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Officials were inclined to believe today that the Russian denunciation of Bulgaria was without great significance and probably not directed at the Turkish question.

LONDON, March 4 -- One of the few bright features in today's stock markets was the better tendency in leading oil issues. Iron and steels also rose. The favorable earnings report of Cammell Laird was responsible for the latter rise. The company declared a final dividend of 6 per cent making the total 10 per cent for the third consecutive year.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, March 4 -- The consolidated report of the American Rolling Mill Company for 1940 will show a net profit of $7,642,713, after provision for interest, depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes, etc., equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.98 a share on the common stock, Calvin Verity, vice president and general manager, said today.

Creation of a Federal administrative tribunal for design protection in fashion and industrial fields was advocated here yesterday by Lowell M. Birrell, attorney, for the Millinery Creators Guild, as an aftermath of the Supreme Court decision against that organization and the Fashion Originators Guild of America.

Early returns show that Federal income tax payments this year are running 58 per cent ahead of last year, compared with an estimated increase of 46 per cent forecast in the budget. This is the combined result of last year's larger income plus the higher rates and the widening of the income tax base resulting from the reduction in personal exemptions.

LONDON, March 4 (UP) -- An official British warning that the German Army in Bulgaria might spring first upon Turkey rather than Greece and attempt to seize the Dardanelles was made today as reports reached London of a massing of Nazi troops at Turkey's Thracian border.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Republican-controlled Senate passed today by a vote of 26 to 17 and sent to the Governor the Wilson bill establishing the legal celebration of Thanksgiving in the State on the last Thursday in November.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,632,250 barrels daily, an increase of 2,600 over the 3,629,650 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was only 3,350 barrels more than the estimated requirements of 13,628,900 daily for February made by the Bureau of Mines.

VICHY, France, March 4 -- Details of the arrangement by which the famous Bor copper mines in Yugoslavia will pass from French to German control were published today in the Fournier Agency's financial broadsheet French Economy and Finances.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Congressional resentment over War Department silence on aspects of the defense program crystallized today when the House Military Committee voted to summon Secretary Stimson and General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, for questioning on Thursday.

AMSTERDAM, March 4 -- A very irregular tone developed on today's Bourse. At the opening Royal Dutch was keenly requested but later reacted, influenced by rather heavy selling in Philips Lamps and A. K. U. Toward the close allround strength developed and the turnover increased.

Benjamin F. Hernandez, 46 years old, ex-convict and freight forwarding agent, who went on trial last week in General Sessions, accused of participating last year in frauds totaling $108,000 against the Fidelity and Casualty Company, pleaded guilty yesterday to two grand larceny counts.

Abbott Laboratories, in its preliminary statement for 1940 issued yesterday, announced record earnings of $2,239,408 for the year after all deductions, including Federal income and excess profits taxes.

DUBLIN, March 4 -- "Mr. Frank Aiken, Minister for Coordination of Defensive Measures, is leaving tomorrow for the United States for the purpose of examining the possibility of purchasing arms and supplies from that country," it was announced tonight.

J. Cheever Cowdin, chairman of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., and of the Universal Corporation, announced that the directors of both, at special meetings yesterday, authorized the drawing up of contracts covering the employment of their senior operating executives for a seven-year period from Jan. 1, 1941.

A 6,000,000-unit replacement business in tires in the Greater New York area was predicted yesterday by Harold Duryea, district manager for the B.F. Goodrich Company, at a regional conference of 100 independent jobbers and distributors held by the company at the Hotel New Yorker.

Drastic changes in foreign-trade technique will be required to meet post-war competition, regardless of the outcome of the present European conflict, according to views expressed by individual exporters yesterday at the regular luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

About eight million American voters lean toward some sort of international federation of countries either along the League of Nations principle, or on some variation of that principle, as a means of maintaining peace after the war, surveys by the American Institute of Public Opinion have indicated, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.

HAVANA, March 4 -- Today, at the close of a long and strenuous workout at Tropical Park, during which Manager Leo Durocher gave his Dodgers their first drill on the cut-off play, young Pete Reiser dashed up the steep incline leading to the clubhouse, stepped on a loose rock and turned his right ankle.

Plans were announced yesterday for a six-story apartment building on the southwest corner of Tenth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, known as 885-9 Tenth Avenue, where the Ministers and Missionaries Benefit Board of the Northern Baptist Convention sold a plot 75.5 by 100 feet to the Tri-State Agency, Lawrence Malawista, president.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 4 (AP) -- Bay View and Mioland are going to run it over again, this time for $50,000, to settle all arguments whether the 4-year-old gelding owned by Mrs. Anthony Pelleteri was a fluke winner in last Saturday's $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 4 -- Rex Flag, who used to win stake races for Mrs. Louise Viau and now runs for the Warbern Stable, earned his first triumph of the year in the Palm Beach Purse, one of the twin features on the program at Tropical Park today.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Steingut bill validating the lease by the City of New York of 250 buses to take the place of trolley cars on Fulton Street in Brooklyn, thus paving the way for demolition of the Fulton Street elevated line, became law at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

Sol Kaplan, 21-year-old Philadelphia pianist, who gave his third annual recital at Carnegie Hall last night, has enormous natural gifts. His fingers are so well trained that they can do almost no wrong, and he plays with a gusto and poise that are breath-taking.

ALBANY, March 4 -- Appeals against any discrimination because of race, color or creed in the employment of workers on defense contracts was voiced today at a public hearing sponsored by the Assembly's Labor and Judiciary Committees on the eleven anti-discrimination bills now before the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Mrs. Sara V. Montgomery, head of the Washington Chapter of the American Peace Mobilization, defied the Dies Committee's subpoena today to produce minutes of meetings, financial records and membership and mailing lists on the ground that the request was an invasion of her constitutional privileges.

Charles B. Harding, chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange, has notified the nominating committee that he would not be a candidate for re-election, the Exchange announced yesterday. He gave as his reason the possibility that he would be called for naval service.

Edgar Stillman-Kelley's musical miracle play, "The Pilgrim's Progress," originally composed for the Cincinnati May Festival in 1918, was performed last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria by seven soloists, an orchestra of eighty musicians and a chorus of 125.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 5 -Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka has requested a clear-cut reply from France by noon today on the terms of the proposed settlement of her Indo-China border dispute with Thailand [Siam], the newspaper Asahi understands.

The Holland-America Line freighter Edam, an 8,800-ton ship engaged in the British North Atlantic supply service, arrived in port yesterday carrying twenty-nine passengers and a general cargo that included a small shipment of "sample" ammunition brought here for examination by American authorities.

An apartment of fourteen rooms and six baths in 120 East End Avenue has been leased for a long term by Frederick C. Wappler, president of American Cystoscope Makers, Inc., from Vincent Astor. Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers.

ALBANY, March 4 -- On the eve of the publication of the Republican budget plan, Republican and Democratic leaders in the Assembly united today in defeating a move to have the State income tax made payable in four equal instalments. Such action would have involved deferment of income to the State of $12,000,000 to $20,000,000, in the making up of next year's budget, it was asserted.

A. Karagheusian, Inc., announced yesterday that prices on its rugs and carpets would be increased on March 17, but declined to reveal the extent of the advance. This led to speculation among buyers that the Karagheusian advance would be more than that of other companies, whose increases up to now have averaged 5 per cent.

Three civil suits seeking permanent injunctions to restrain twenty-three corporations and twenty-nine individuals from continuing a city-wide paving racket that has defrauded the taxpayers of more than $1,000,000 were filed yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen.

George Cvek, 23 years old, of Bressler, a suburb of Harrisburg, Pa., confessed to District Attorney Samuel Foley and to the Bronx police at daybreak yesterday that he strangled Mrs. Catherine Pappas in her apartment at 1035 Grand Concourse last Feb. 4.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 4 (AP) (via Berlin) -- German authorities decreed compulsory State service for Netherlanders today and drafted many citizens to do guard duty over German Army signposts to prevent their defacement by Netherland youths.

The six-story apartment house on a plot 186.7 by 100.9 feet at 3504 Hull Avenue, northeast corner of Gun Hill Road, the Bronx, has been sold by the Equitable Life Assurance Society to a client of Henry S. Salamon, attorney.

ANKARA, Turkey, Wednesday, March 5 -- Publication of the statement by Andrey Y. Vishinsky, Russian Foreign Vice Commissar, condemning Bulgaria's action in permitting the Germans to march in, shared attention today with the delivery to President Ismet Inonu of a letter from Reichsfuehrer Hitler.
MONTREAL, March 4 -- President Frank Calder of the National Hockey League said tonight it was "possible" the New York Americans would be dropped from the circuit next season. "

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, has informed Sidney Hillman, associate director general of the Office of Production Management and head of the labor section of the National Defense Advisory Council, that the C.I.O. strongly opposes creation of a labor defense mediation board to handle disputes in defense industries.

Sixteen librarians at City College, receiving salaries between $1,800 and $4,780 a year, filed four separate suits in the Supreme Court yesterday to compel the Board of Higher Education to grant to them pay increases ranging from $150 to $600 a year.

Two of the teams strongly in the running for berths in the forthcoming annual national invitation basketball tournament will collide at Madison Square Garden tonight when Long Island University and Toledo meet in the second game of the college double-header.

VICHY, France, March 4 -- Eighty thousand graves of French soldiers killed in the war last Spring have been located in France, and at least 20,000 soldiers are missing. One hundred and twenty thousand wounded have been listed. Thirty to thirty-five per cent of the dead and wounded were officers.

All but a few of the American doughboy expatriates in Paris, numbering several hundred soldiers of the A.E.F., who married French women and reared families in France, have now returned home after an absence of twenty-three years, according to members of the latest contingent, who arrived here yesterday on the American Export liner Exeter.

MIAMI, Fla., March 4 -- The possibility of Hank Leiber, who once was Bill Terry's problem child No. 1, returning to the Giants in a deal that might involve Harry Danning, currently out of favor with his employers, loomed today to snap the local baseball colony out of its routine training grind.

An official Communist party report that declared that there were "many hundreds" of members of the party in the New York Teachers Union, "more than is necessary'' for the political purposes of the Communist fraction within the union, is one of several pieces of evidence that the executive council of the American Federation of Teachers is preparing for circulation among its more than 35,000 members, it became known yesterday.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 4 -- Medalist Eddie Driggs of Bronxville, N.Y., won his opening-round match in the Florida midwinter invitation golf tournament over the Ormond Beach course today, defeating Fred Gretsch of Forest Hills, L.I., 4 and 3.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Davisson gave a dinner last night at Larue for Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, former United States Minister to Norway. Mimosa blossoms and pink roses were used in the decorations. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Train, Mr. and Mrs. J. Harlin O'Connell, Mr. and Mrs. Archibold van Beuren, Mrs. Oliver Eaton Cromwell, Richard Lounsbury and Albert Z. Gray.
BERLIN, March 4 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

A generally slow trade featured yesterday's market on all classes of traefer meats. Supplies of steer hinds and ribs were fully normal; veal hindsaddles, moderate; lamb, light to moderate, and pork, normal. The market on steer hinds and ribs displayed further weakness. Kosher steer chucks and plates were strong.

BOSTON, March 4 -- The Boston Bruins ruined one of the best goaltending exhibitions in National Hockey League history when they defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 13 -- 2, before 11,000 at the Boston Garden tonight to break their first-place deadlock with the idle Toronto Maple Leafs.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 4 -- Among those who are entertaining guests in anticipation of tomorrow's luncheon fashion revue at the Surf Club are Mrs. Lindsey Hopkins Jr., Mrs. William L. McKnight, Mrs. George E. Crandell, Mrs. Robert G. Lassiter and Miss Blanche Peters.

Recovering from the irregularity of Monday's session, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange developed moderate strength yesterday and closed unchanged to 4 points up. The widest gains were registered by the newcrop months.

Disapproval of the site in Flushing Meadow Park that has been given to the American Museum of Health was expressed in a telegram sent to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by the Park Association of New York City, Inc., through its president, Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 4 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos of Lake Hopatcong, N.J., led the qualifying field in the Florida East Coast women's golf championship on the St. Augustine Links today. Mrs. Hockenjos carded a 42, 39 -- 81 on a wind-swept course that made low scoring difficult.

Estimating that the city would have between 40,000 and 50,000 cases of measles this year, Dr. Samuel Frant, director of the bureau of preventable diseases of the Health Department, reported yesterday that during the 24-hour period ended at 9 o'clock yesterday morning there had been 1,008 new cases of the disease.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 4 (AP) -- A British communique issued here today said:

Ed Wynn will wind up his run in "Boys and Girls Together" on March 15 at the Broadhurst Theatre, with a total of 191 performances. On Monday of last week the admission scale was lowered from a high of $4.40 to $3.30, reductions applying also to other sections of the house.

BERLIN, Wednesday, March 5 (UP) -- D.N.B., official news agency, said today that since early last night heavy German bombers had been raiding military objectives on the west coast and a harbor in England.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The War Department is engaged in a showdown with the American Federation of Labor unions at Wright Field, Dayton. Yesterday it ordered a contractor employing five members of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to proceed with work on a small contract, and as a result the American Federation of Labor unions at the field struck in a body today.
There seem to be two slogans on the battle flag of the sportsmen these days, "Make the Striped Bass a Game Fish" and "Kill the Firearms Registration Bill."

After hearing arguments for more than an hour yesterday on the merits of Isteg steel bar, a patented article, Mayor La Guardia said he was undecided on whether to sign legislation that would eliminate preferential treatment for the steel in the city Building Code.

Salonika is one of the great prizes at stake in the war of manoeuvre in the Balkans. Whether it falls eventually into British or into German hands, it will remain a vital strategic center. For the British it would be the key to the back door of Europe. For the Germans, possession of the port would block the British and open a sea and air approach for an attack on the Suez Canal.

Defense loans, agricultural and consumer credit, and public relations will be the principal topics today and through Friday at the Eastern Regional Conference on Savings and Commercial Banking. Sessions will be at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, and more than 1,000 bankers from twelve Eastern and New England States are expected to attend.

In his current report on museums in New York City Park Commissioner Moses bears down hard on the relics of snobbery and aristocracy which he believes to be still existent in them. For him there is nothing "occult, esoteric or sacred about these institutions.''

The House has begun consideration of the 1942 fiscal appropriation of the Agriculture Department. The over-all figure for the fiscal year to end June 30, 1942, is $1,421,000,000, compared with $1,477,000,000 for the 1941 fiscal year. The saving -- if, when present estimates are turned into actual expenditures, it should turn out to be a saving-would be less than 4 per cent.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, March 4 -- Turkey's role in the present Balkan situation, coupled with an expression of the Islamic East's solidarity with Turkey, with whom it has a common destiny, formed the keynote of a personal statement by Emil Abdullah Ibn Hussein, ruler of Trans-Jordan, made today when he received this correspondent in his Winter camp at Eshuneh, in the Jordan Valley not far from the frontier of Palestine.

A youth who lied while making out his questionnaire under the Selective Service Act was in Federal Court yesterday. United States Attorney John T. Cahill warned that this sort of offense, like any other meddling with the draft law, would bring speedy prosecution.

BOSTON, March 4 -- Prices ranging from 5 to 10 per cent higher than at this time last year are being quoted by manufacturers who are displaying 475 lines at the Boston Furniture Show this week. Nevertheless, buyers, attending in larger numbers than usual, with few exceptions are not anticipating their needs any further in advance than has been customary in years past.

The New York Rangers played like the world champions they are last night. Frank Boucher's Blue Shirts, flashing the stream-lined passing game that brought them the Stanley Cup last April, overwhelmed the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden, and in so doing caused their stock in the approaching play-offs to rise considerably.

CHICAGO, March 4 (UP) -- Mrs. Grace R. Comiskey became the first woman to head an American League team and the second woman ever to hold the reins of a major league organization when she was elected president of the Chicago White Sox Baseball Club late today.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 4 (AP) -- The Italians in Ethiopia faced invasion from virtually all frontiers tonight after the British had announced a new thrust in a northwestern direction in Italian Somaliland.

The first arrest in this city of a member of a draft board on a charge of taking money from a registrant in return for a promised deferment occurred last night in Brooklyn after the draftee had reported the board member to Federal authorities.
