There will be six entries in the famed Casey 600 that will be one of the features of the Knights of Columbus track and field meet at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, it was officially announced yesterday by Meet Director Frank Brennan.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4 -- Theodore Dreiser's film adaptation of his "My Brother Paul," a biography of his brother, Paul Dreiser, was acquired today by Twentieth Century-Fox under the title "My Gal Sal" for approximately $50,000.

Monogram has scheduled a program of twenty-six feature productions and twenty-four Westerns, eight of which will be reissues, for the 1941-42 season, according to W. Ray Johnston, president. Mr. Johnston made the announcement yesterday afternoon at a reception in the Warwick Hotel in honor of W.J. Gell, managing director of Pathe Pictures, Ltd., of London, which releases Monogram films in England.

VICHY, France, March 4 -- Vice Premier Francois Darlan left here for Paris by automobile early this morning, accompanied by Mme. Darlan. He is expected to stay at least until Thursday for talks with both French and German representatives.

The church property on the southwest corner of Avenue C and Fourth Street, once the home of Holy Cross Protestant Church and mission and now the temporary place of worship of the National Polish Catholic Church, has been sold by the St. John the Baptist Foundation to the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of America.

Drastic changes in the city and State tax structure, to raise $27,000,000 additional yearly, partly by city income tax, were proposed yesterday in a report submitted by a special committee created two years ago by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.
The America First Committee has issued a statement saying that it has no objection to making public the names of its supporters.

NEWARK, N.J., March 5 -- The fourteenth annual report of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, made public here today, disclosed that operating revenues in 1940 amounted to $53,218,392, compared with $50,456,965 in 1939, but that increased expenses, including taxes, caused a reduction of $331,071 from the $9,661,006 in income available for interest and dividends in 1939.

It does not seem to me that the Aquarium, or Castle Garden, is quite as ugly and hopeless a structure as Mr. Moses thinks, even though it very probably is not very well suited to the Aquarium. I feel that, regardless of any incidents connected with this building in the past, it might be very desirable to preserve it as a landmark, because, to millions of people, it is something characteristic of lower Manhattan.

THE verdict is a cinch. Joe Gordon is standing trial as a first baseman for the Yankees. He will be found guilty. A good infielder can play any position on the diamond. Of course, he might not have a good curve ball if sent to the mound and he might not be enthusiastic about going behind the plate and playing squat-tag for a wild left-hander on hot days.

LONDON, March 5 (AP) -- The British Government told Parliament today that Germany had "a considerable number" of soldiers and technicians in French Morocco, within 150 miles of the Strait of Gibraltar.

VICHY, France, March 5 -- A reform which the Leftist parties in France have fought for ineffectually for many years was introduced by the Petain government today with a law abolishing stock shares to bearer and requiring that hereafter all stock shall be issued in the name of the holder.

LACONIA-GILFORD, N.H., March 5 -- One of North America's most attractive skiing areas is located here on the rugged terrain of the Belknap Mountains, overlooking Lake Winnipesaukee. Five years ago this WPA project got under way, and today one finds a million-dollar enterprise that lacks nothing in the way of appeal for novice or expert skier.
PANAMA, March 5 -- Following is the text of the manifesto issued today by President Arias:

Ninety-one refugee families were established on farms in 1940 by the Jewish Agricultural Society, Inc., of 301 East Fourteenth Street, according to the annual report of Gabriel Davidson, general manager, made public yesterday. The society settled 158 families in all, representing a total of 750 persons, during the year.

BERLIN, March 5 -- The question of a more intimate German-Rumanian military -- and more particularly air -- cooperation in the event of an emergency in the Balkans was believed to be the chief topic at today's surprise meeting in Belvedere Castle in Vienna between Reich Marshal Hermann Goering and General Ion Antonescu, the Rumanian Premier.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 5 -Favorites battled their way into the semi-finals of the men's annual championship of Palm Beach today at the Golf Club. But Smiley Quick, the medalist, had to make a sensational rally to avert defeat, winning at the twentieth hole.

JERSEY CITY, March 5 -- A preliminary injunction restraining the Silver Rod Stores of 14 Journal Square from selling eighteen standard brands of cigarettes at cut prices was issued today by Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan pending a final hearing.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 -- The first intraclub game of the 1941 Yankees went into history today with results that came near being ruinous to that sensational second-base combination, Scooter Phil Rizzuto and Jerry Priddy.

There was little or no change in general market conditions in yesterday's trading. Demand for most classes continued slow. The steer hind and rib market was barely steady; veal weak, lamb uneven, but generally steady; pork steady. The market on kosher steer chucks and plates opened slow, with asking prices steady to stronger.

A major film transaction took place yesterday when David O. Selznick, producer of "Gone With the Wind," acquired the screen rights to Rose Franken's play, "Claudia," and, in addition, to the thirty stories she wrote around the Claudia character, for a total consideration of $187,000.

BERLIN, March 5 (UP) -- A German spokesman tonight denied as "absolutely false" rumors abroad that the Goering -- Antonescu talk in Vienna today was a result of a Russian ultimatum on Rumania demanding the surrender of Black Sea ports to the Soviet.

After a lapse of twenty years, the directors of the United States lubbet Company declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, payable, on April 30 to stock of record of April 16. The directors also ordered payment of $2 a share on the 8 per cent noncumulative preferred stock, payable on March 28 to stock of record of March 21.

Every man, woman and child in Britain is enlisted for the duration of the war. As devotedly as the armed forces, the civilian population is fighting and working in the shambles made by German bombs in British streets. The magnificent morale of these resolute millions is the final assurance of victory.

ROME, March 5 -- The culminating phase of the Italo-Greek conflict has arrived, according to belief in Rome today. It is thought the hopelessness of the situation from the Greek viewpoint will be obvious, not only because of the presence of the Germans on the Bulgarian-Greek frontier, but also because a genuine military defeat will be facing soldiers who have been defending their country for more than four months.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 -- Directors of the American Friends Service Committee, after hearing a first-hand report on conditions in Great Britain from the committee's vice president, D. Robert Yarnall, voted today to underwrite half the cost of social service activities conducted by English Quakers in bomb shelters and rest centers of that country.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 5 -- Faithful reproduction of a British air-raid shelter, probably the first of its kind in this country, was announced here today by the Stamford unit of the British War Relief Society.

In an unusual academic suit, Professor Gray Truitt of Hofstra College yesterday demanded $50,000 damages from New York University, alleging a degree of Doctor of Education had been withheld from him, although he had met all the university requirements.

As a writer greatly indebted to the many free services of the New York Public Library at Forty-second Street, I should like to register my protest against the criticism of Commissioner Moses. Having worked in the great libraries of Great Britain, France and Greece, I can honestly say that nowhere else have I found such unfailing courtesy; nowhere else have I been able to do my work so smoothly and simply.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 5 -- The British Minister to Yugoslavia, Ronald Ian Campbell, will call on Prince Regent Paul tomorrow to demand a clear statement of Yugoslav policy toward Great Britain.

Mayor La Guardia reproved yesterday the "scorners" who are causing "this attack on our public schools" at a special assembly at the Needle Trades High School, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street, held to award a $500 prize to Miss Jean Mazzarella, 17 years old of 225 Avenue B, winner of first place in a national contest in fashion design.

The Indian population has made progress under the health program provided by the Federal Government but needs to show more widespread cooperation in the educational and sociological fields, according to reports presented yesterday at an institute on the future of the American Indian held under the auspices of the American Association of Indian Affairs, Inc., at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

The metropolitan open championship, one of golf's oldest events, has been shelved by the Metropolitan Golf Association. The reason, according to Walker L. Trammell, president of the M.G.A., is lack of public and player support.

The American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation and its domestic subsidiaries had a net profit last year of $7,349,011, according to the preliminary statement issued yesterday. The profit includes $533,056 income from foreign subsidiaries, and also is after deductions for interest, depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and other charges.

Father and Son Night will be introduced to hockey fans at Madison Square Garden tonight, when the Americans and Red Wings meet for the last time this season in a National Hockey League game. For the price of one admission, a father may obtain an additional seat for his son.

The Manhattan College swimming team closed its season yesterday by suffering its Seventh setback in nine meets as the University of Delaware swept every first place to gain a 68-7 triumph in the Park Central Hotel pool. Manhattan lost both relays but took third place in each of the seven individual events.

The first major step looking toward corporate simplification of the underlying structure of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation was taken yesterday when trustees in reorganization of the corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a recapitalization plan for the General Gas and Electric Corporation.

Herbert Janssen, the German baritone, whose singing at the Metropolitan has brought him well-deserved acclaim, gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall. Mr. Janssen's voice, which refused to become sufficiently focused to take on quality unless used at the full, was too bereft of color to cope successfully with the demands of the program of German Lieder presented, even had he sung with far more imagination than proved the case.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has booked defense orders from the United States Government alone that are almost 50 per cent larger than the total value of munitions and ships built by it for the United States and the Allies during the entire World War, according to the annual report to employes issued yesterday simultaneously with the annual report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull described American foreign policy in the Far East today as aiming at equality of opportunity, respect for national sovereignty and faithful observance of treaties as the bases of a really durable international order.

More than 1,000 volunteer workers from the metropolitan area will start a nation-wide campaign for $10,000,000 to meet the increasing needs of English civilian air raid victims at a meeting and luncheon today at the Hotel Plaza.

Long Island University completed its regular basketball campaign before 12,654 at Madison Square Garden last night with so fine and polished a performance against a good Toledo team that it can be stated as a certainty that the Blackbirds will have some post-season dates to fill in the immediate future.

Seventy-nine students in Columbia College have won King's Crown keys for their participation in nine extracurricular activities on the campus, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin A. Hubbard, director of the undergraduate activities program.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Despite appeals from a number of farm State legislators, the House today defeated four proposals to increase the $212,000,000 farm parity payment fund that President Roosevelt has requested from Congress.

Communities throughout the United States are to be enlisted in a campaign for funds for the relief of dependents of British fliers killed or disabled in war service, according to plans of the Royal Air Force Benevolent Fund of the U.S.A., Inc., 515 Madison Avenue, announced by Colby M. Chester, chairman.

"High labor rates" in the building industry are preventing a high annual income for workers in this field and are one of the most important factors in checking efforts to bring down the cost of construction of housing, Gerard Swope, honorary president of the General Electric Company and chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, told the members of the New York Building Congress yesterday.
MADRID, March 5 -- Former King Carol of Rumania and his companion, Magda Lupescu, who had been detained in Spain ever since their arrival nearly seven months ago, are now "somewhere in Portugal."

Robert G. Harris, 22-year-old senior in the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance at New York University, has been voted the most popular student in the Class of 1941, following in the footsteps of his father, Professor Gould L. Harris, who has been named most popular faculty member for the third successive year, according to the annual poll of The Violet, senior yearbook, released yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 5 -- The yearly survey by the Finnish Foreign Minister was presented today to the Finnish Parliament. It dwells at length on Finnish-Russian relations during 1940, since these constituted the chief problem of "external reconstruction."

As the German Army placed its swastika standards on the Greek mountain passes, it was evident that sea power -- the navies of the world already built and the navies still building -- would play a large part in the war's final decision.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 5 -- Running within three-fifths of a second of the track record, P.L. Kelley's Float Away brought about an upset today at Tropical Park when he was just up to win by a head from Speed to Spare in the Dania Handicap, at five and one-half furlongs.

Russian diplomacy has developed a genius for ostentatiously locking the stable door after the horse has been stolen. At any time in the last few months, to go no farther back, the Russian Government could have stated publicly, clearly and unambiguously what its attitude would be toward a German occupation of Bulgaria.
ROME, March 5 (AP) -- A clash of British and German expeditionary armies for Salonika, key to the back door of Europe, was envisaged by observers here tonight.

Within three hours yesterday afternoon two pairs of armed robbers held up two young women cashiers in elevators of buildings in which they were employed and escaped with payrolls amounting to $2,777. In one instance the thugs struck and injured a cashier and an elevator operator with the butts of their guns.

ALBANY, March 5 -- In an attempt to gain up-State Republican support for the proposal to divert $60,000,000 from the grade-crossing fund for highway-parkway improvements, Senator Dunnigan, Bronx Democrat, and Assemblyman Stephens, Putnam County Republican, introduced today "a compromise" bill calling for the elimination of ninety-one grade crossings in twenty-five up-State counties and Long Island.

As servants of the state, Italians, once regarded as lovers of pleasure and the arts, have been taught to live austerely. Their table has to be frugal. Their luxuries are cut off. Their staples of life are rationed. Now a new and curious sacrifice has been imposed upon them. The cafe tables on street and square, those pleasant posts of observation and conversation, are forbidden just as Spring is almost in sight.

Most home wares lines have continued active at retail, although the sharp upswing in furniture volume during January did not hold through the closing weeks of February, according to reports in merchandizing circles here yesterday. Confidence was strong that home furnishings would be a star performer at retail for the year as a whole, with the gain over 1940 ranging to 20 per cent or more.
Labor strife stalked yesterday into the millinery shop of Lilly Dache at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street.

While comment in the toilet goods trade has held that the Supreme Court decision in the Bunte case places demonstrators, "push" or promotion money and the like beyond the jurisdiction of the Federal Trade Commission, this is not the case, according to an analysis issued yesterday by Hugo Mock, counsel to the Toilet Goods Association.

PITTSBURGH, March 5 -- The judging of the fourth annual all-breed dog show of the Western Pennsylvania Kennel Association, which opened this morning at the Hunt Armory, got under way with the handling of the cocker spaniels, largest entry in the show. A total of ninety-nine in this group was judged by Mrs. Morgan Churchman of Whitemarsh, Pa.
Merle Martz, 13-year-old newsboy of Summerville, in the Western Pennsylvania farm country, is going to get a horse from the New York Central Railroad.

ALBANY, March 5 -- A thirteen-bill program designed to "modernize" installment buying in the State and protect the consumer and also the seller was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Feinberg of Plattsburg and Assemblyman Holley of Manhattan.

Laboring under the smallest turnover in six months, the stock market reacted yesterday and the gains scored on Tuesday were erased. Proceeding with such caution as to again emphasize the nervousness of security holders, the volume on the Stock Exchange sank to 286,990 shares, compared with the previous day's dealings of 307,890 shares to produce the lightest and narrowest session since Aug. 29 last.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 5 -- All the favorites advanced today in the first round of the Florida East Coast women's golf championship on the St. Augustine links, the medalist, Mrs. William Hockenjos of Lake Hopatcong, N.J., routing Mrs. W.L. Pierce of Jacksonville, Fla., 8 and 7.
ROME, March 5 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:
Total admitted assets of the American Insurance Company, Newark, increased to $32,680,959 on Dec. 31, 1940, from $31,104,996 a year earlier.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 6 (UP) -- A basic understanding has been reached in the French Indo-China-Thailand peace negotiations, it was announced today. Some details remain to be settled, but these are expected to be cleared up shortly.
ALWAYS think of something I might have said some ages after the occasion for the retort has been gathered to the bosom of antiquity.

Irving Schiller, a real estate man, living at 960 East Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, was released from Federal court, Brooklyn, at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon after supplying $1,000 bail for a hearing on March 19 of charges that as a member of local Draft Board 182 in Brooklyn he had accepted a $100 bribe to obtain a deferment.
BERLIN, March 5 (AP) -The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 28 shows the following changes for the week, in thousands of marks:

ROME, March 5 -- The first result of the campaign of hatred against Great Britain urged by Premier Mussolini in his speech of Feb. 23 was seen today when the official newspaper of the Italian Catholic Action of the University Students was seized and suspended for one month because it printed an article condemning hatred as "the base feeling."

For five years, while he was on the staff of City College, Morris U. Schappes admitted yesterday, he was active in the Communist party under the alias of "Alan Horton," and recruited three other faculty members into the campus unit. About a year ago, he said, he resigned in order to devote more time to an anthology he was writing.

BERLIN, March 5 -- The German newspaper in the Netherlands declares "irresponsible wirepullers" employed the recent disturbances in the Amsterdam Jewish quarter to incite the Netherland population against German occupation officials.

BERLIN, March 5 -- Type faces used in printing several leading German newspapers and magazines are being changed gradually from the elaborate sharp-pointed German black letter, often puzzling to outlanders, to easy-to-read Latin characters.
The first medical research bureau to be established by any municipality in the United States will be set up soon as part of the city Department of Health, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.
VICHY, France, March 5 (AP) -- General Maxime Weygand, commander of the French armies of Africa, arrived in Vichy tonight ahead of schedule.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 5 -- One of the most remarkable tributes ever paid to a man and a dog was that tonight to Herman E. Mellenthin of this city and his famous black cocker spaniel, Champion My Own Brucie, winner two years in succession of best in show at the Westminster Kennel Club exhibition in Madison Square Garden and also best in show in 1939 at Morris and Essex, the world's largest canine competition.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- Judge Arthur Gomez denied a divorce today to Mrs. James J. Walker from the former mayor of New York.

The banks of the nation are making an effort to participate in financing the defense program, cording to P.D. Houston, president of the American Bankers Association. There is a growing awareness among bankers, he said here yesterday, that the survival of the private banking system is bound up with adjusting themselves to present conditions, whatever they may be.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Wheat showed a firm undertone in the early trading today but pressure increased late in the session and the close on the Board of Trade here was at the bottom with losses of 5/8 to 1 cent a bushel, the May leading the decline.

Replying yesterday to a published report that he was affiliated with Communist party units, Clifford T. McAvoy, Second Deputy Welfare Commissioner, said the report was "unconscionable and grossly unfair."

A nation-wide underwriting group headed by Glore, Forgan Co. and Bonbright Co., Inc., will offer to the public today $16,000,000 of first mortgage, series A, 3 1/4 per cent bonds of the Public Service Company of Oklahoma, and the unexchanged portion of 83,500 shares of new 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value.
ATLANTA, March 5 -- Two measures that would impose drastic restrictions on labor unions in the State were presented in the House of Representatives today.

SOFIA, Thursday, March 6 (AP) -- Germany's field army in Bulgaria was concentrated today at Black Sea ports and on the Greek frontier as the Nazis deployed for the great Balkan war so long expected and seemingly all but begun. Nearly all Bulgarians of military age marched off toward the Turkish frontier.

Many thousands who visited the Medicine and Health Building at the World's Fair must have been impressed by the helpful way in which the science of healing could tell its story in public exhibits. The plan to do this by means of a permanent institution open to every one has been set on foot by the organizers of the new American Museum of Health.

TOKYO, March 5 -- Although Japan will be faithful to the Three Power Pact [the Axis-Japanese alliance], the Japanese Government does not regard that agreement as constituting any reason for war against Britain. This assurance was conveyed to Prime Minister Winston Churchill by Japanese Ambassador Mamoru Shigemitsu in London yesterday, according to the Japanese press reports of Mr. Churchill's second interview with the Japanese Ambassador.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 5 -- Six of the German Army's seventeen divisions on the Danube were inside Bulgaria tonight and rolling toward Greece in solid miles of men and equipment, according to authoritative information from military sources in Sofia.

The Columbian Mile will be limited to five starters at the Knights of Columbus Games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Meet Director Frank Brennan. However, there will be only two in the test generally accorded chances of winning, Walter Mehl and Leslie MacMitchell.

Led by the new-crop months, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved steadily upward and final quotations showed net gains of 2 to 12 points. The distant months advanced 11 to 12 points beyond their previous seasonal highs, while July was even with the peak in January.

Concealment of big gambling winnings, claims for fake stock losses, and the deduction of "business expenses" that included $53 spent to buy his sister-in-law a mattress, were listed yesterday as devices by which Joseph M. Schenck, moving picture producer, allegedly cheated the government of $412,045 in income taxes.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 5 -- The many skills of this part of the necticut Valley, of which Hartford ford is the center, are being mobilized in a defense effort which, at full blast, will easily outstrip any previous effort, including that of the World War.

ATHENS, March 5 (AP) -- Greece rejected mounting German pressure for a separate peace with Italy tonight and announced she was standing firmly beside Britain, having "agreed on all aspects of the situation" in Southeast Europe with the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden.

In an urgent plea for cooperation and understanding between business and government and the necessity for unity of effort during the present emergency, Sam Rayburn, Texas, Speaker of the House of Representatives, warned yesterday that during the next twelve, twenty-four or even sixty months "the very existence of the things we all love are at stake."

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The appeal of Princess Stefanie Hohenlohe Waldenburg-Schillingsfurst from an order for deportation was refused by the Board of Immigration today and it was informally announced that she would have to leave the United States "as soon as possible."

BOSTON, March 5 -Harvard and Dartmouth played to a 3-3 overtime tie in a quadrangular Hockey League game at the Garden tonight By a minute and 32 seconds the Indians maintained their record of never having lost to Harvard during the regime of Coach Eddie Jeremiah.

ALBANY, March 5 -- Widespread approval of the Page-Anderson Automobile Financial Responsibility Bill was expressed today by representatives of bar associations, insurance companies and business and civic groups at a public hearing on the measure before the Senate and Assembly Insurance and Motor Transportation Committees.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Alice Crockett, former wife of a United States Army officer, alleged in a Federal Court complaint today that Consul General Fritz Wiedemann headed a German espionage ring in the Americas and ordered his agents to obtain secret information beneficial to Germany in its "conquest of the Western Hemisphere."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 5 -- Yale easily disposed of Princeton's threat for the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League laurels tonight by routing the Tigers, 53 -- 22. The victory was the twelfth straight for the Elis, who replaced the Tigers as the pace-setters with their fifth successive triumph in the title race.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Office of Production Management today settled several labor disputes affecting the defense program, obtained postponement for forty-eight hours of a strike order affecting a Michigan power company and had several mediators at conferences seeking settlement of other disputes.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman will head the list of honorary sponsors of the artists committee auction of paintings for British - Norwegian War Relief, to be held at the Vendome Galleries the week of March 24.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Bipartisan attempts to increase farm parity payments by $425,000,000 and $875,000,000 were defeated in the House today after leaders on both sides, alarmed lest the privately expressed desires of the farm bloc to "get ours" might adversely affect the defense program and send the country into an era of inflation, worked strenuously among their colleagues.

The Atlantic Refining Company is planning the construction of a plant for the manufacture of 100-octane super-aviation gasoline for military use at its Point Breeze refinery, it was announced yesterday by Robert H. Colley, president, in his annual report to stockholders.

Milton B. Logan, 50 years old, testified yesterday at his trial in General Sessions in the alleged theft of $65,000 from patrons of the defunct American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., when he was its president in 1939.He denied responsibility for the thefts.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy and three companions took off from Washington Airport at 10:05 A.M. (Eastern standard time) today on a 28,000-mile Inter-American Escadrille air tour of the American republics.

CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- Moderate receipts of 19,000 hogs, including 12,000 salable arrivals, was too heavy for demand today partly in view of the continued weakness of dressed pork prices. Prices dropped 10 to 15 cents, with extreme top quoted at $7.90. and paid sparingly. Pork loins continued at a 15 1/2 to 16 1/2 cents a pound level.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Three more licenses for frequency modulation broadcast stations were granted today by the Federal Communications Commission, making forty-two such awards to date for this new type of service.

Jack Schneider, 44 years old, business agent of the Joint Council of the International Fur Workers Union, received an indeterminate sentence in the penitentiary from Judge Owen W. Bohan yesterday in General Sessions, as the result of a conviction on a charge of coercion in June, 1937.

During an uneventful week on Broadway there is no reason why a theatregoer should not drop in at the Apollo in Harlem to see what goes on up there. For the Apollo, a convivial theatre in 125th Street, has an anoient reputation for dusky frivolity on the stage and easy enjoyment in the auditorium.

LONDON, March 5 (UP) -- The British-German struggle for Yugo slavia, last Balkan neutral, became a diplomatic race today as reports reached London that Prince Regent Paul might go to Germany at any hour to settle matters with Reichsfuehrer Hitler.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 5 -- The breaking off of relations Between Great Britain and Bulgaria had an echo in the Canadian Parliament today when Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King announced that Bulgaria and also Hungary henceforth would be considered "proscribed areas," which means that all transactions with them will be subjected to the regime of the trading with the enemy regulations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 -- Jackie Cooper and Susanna Foster will play the leads in "Paramount on Parade," a musical picture with a Hollywood background, the studio announced today. Bradford Ropes and James Gow are writing the scenario, and Sol C. Siegel will produce.

Bookings of steel companies in February ran from 10 to 25 per cent over those of January, according to Iron Age, which says the orders were considerably above production and shipments during the month, "resulting in further building up of backlogs and extension of deliveries."

Several hundred physicians, representing almost every nationality, crowded the amphitheatre of the New York Polyclinic Medical School and Hospital last night at the first joint meeting of its kind, called under the auspices of the International Medical Club of New York.

AKRON, Ohio, March 5 (AP) -- The Goodyear Aircraft Corporation announced today that construction would start almost at once on a plant to employ about 5,000 persons on building tail surfaces, wings and fuselages for Martin bombers.

HAVANA, March 5 -- Possibly with the idea of instilling a bit more of the competitive spirit into his "Esquivadors de Brooklyn," Leo Durocher today enlivened the exercises at Tropical Park with a four-inning ball game, in which the second team outscored the regulars, 3 to 2.

LONDON, March 5 (UP) -- Speaking in support of the navy estimates, Captain Alec Stratford Cunningham-Reid told the House of Commons that Germany was rushing construction of little "suicide sub-marines" that are expected to "get as far as our coasts but are not expected to return."

SHANGHAI, Thursday, March 6 (UP) -- A large Japanese expeditionary army which was landed Monday at six places on the South China coast was driving inland today, apparently with the double purpose of closing Chinese munitions routes and forcing French Indo-China to accept a Japan-sponsored settlement of the border conflict between that French colony and Thailand.

LONDON, March 5 -- Britain has started work remodelling her old cities -- gingerly feeling her way through the municipal labyrinths of Coventry, Bristol and Birmingham as the first step in stream-lining them all, including London, after the war.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Coincident with the occupation of Bulgaria for the purpose of controlling the entire Balkan area, Germany is sending troops in force into Libya, where the British have recently won conspicuous victories over the Italians.
The big game anglers with itching feet are heading toward Peru these days, and according to a report received yesterday at least one of them found what he went after.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The Republican majorities in the Legislature presented a fiscal program today calling for a net reduction of $1,586,709 in Governor Lehman's budget of $385,693,453, including eliminations of $1,271,000 in the defense category, and thereby started a first-class political row.

Reports that the value of new plants and facilities certified as essential to the national defense in order to provide a five-year amortization of costs thus far have amounted to $256,000,000 for 200 companies mean that a tax savings of about $9,500,000 a year under the normal income tax and an indefinite but substantial savings under excess profits taxes will result.

The new 479-foot cargo vessel Robin Locksley, the first of six vessels ordered by the Robin Line for the New York-South African trade, was delivered by the builders yesterday at the yards of the Bethlehem Steel Company at Sparrows Point, Md.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The United Corporation has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval of a proposal that it relinquish control of the voting stock of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and the United Gas Improvement Company, according to an announcement today by the Federal agency.
EXETER, N.H., March 5 -- Andover defeated Exeter by a narrow margin in their dual track meet today, beating the home squad by a score of 42 1-3 to 38 2-3.

Paul Hollister, vice president of J. Stirling Getchell, interjected a new note into current discussions of diversion of excess taxes to advertising when he declared yesterday that "advertising will cut its own throat" if it embarks on any campaign of tax evasion.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The 250th anniversary of the formation of the Supreme Court of New York State is to be observed in May. A bill offered today by Senator Feinberg and Assemblyman Reoux proposes an appropriation of $2,500 and a temporary State commission to handle the details of the observance.
If the British should eventually win the war, and win it decisively, what kind of peace terms would the Germans receive?
Strikes were holding up production last night at twenty-five defense industries plants and interfering with construction of experimental equipment important in air force development.

Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt, mother of the President, and Mrs. William Howard Taft, widow of the President and mother of the Ohio Senator who is a leading opponent of the lease-lend bill, joined yesterday with twenty-nine other prominent women in protesting against "a filibuster -- declared or undeclared -- on the lease-lend bill or on any proposed amendments."

EDGEWATER, N. J., March 5 -- The local plant of the Aluminum Company of America, engaged almost entirely in the production of defense materials, is facing a strike threat as a result of the management's refusal to meet what it described as "peremptory demands" by members of the Aluminum Workers of America, C. I. O. union.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 5 (AP) -- Following is the text of British Minister George W. Rendel's note today to the Bulgarian Government:

WASHINGTON, Mach 5 -- Expenditure in the 1940 fiscal year of $3,395,000,000 of Federal and sponsors' funds on projects of the Federal Works Agency was reported to Congress today by John M. Carmody, administrator.
The New York Athletic Club Class A squash tennis team brought the metropolitan interclub series to a close last night by adding another victory to its list.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Favorable and unfavorable factors in current world trade developments, as reported by cable and radio to the Commerce Department by its foreign attaches, were listed by the department today as follows:

A strong possibility exists that the present labor agreement in the ladies' garment industry, made last Summer after a strike, will lapse and another serious disruption occur before the Fall season, Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, warned association members at their annual dinner in the Hotel Astor last night.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Not all the national defense bottlenecks are in machinery. There is one which extends from the American farmer's corn-crib to his pigsty. It is a matter of concern to the British as well, since it is a deterrent to the production of one type of food they require to maintain stamina for their resistance to the Axis.

A lease for an apartment of twelve rooms and five baths in 1125 Fifth Avenue has been arranged with Mrs. J.D. Murray for Pease Elliman, Inc., by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers. The latter firm also reports rentals with Boyden Roseberry in 40 Fifth Avenue, Anthony Fried in 25 East Eighty-sixth Street and Harold J. Bosko, through Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., in 115 East Ninetieth Street.

The Borden Company will centralize its distributing and warehouse activities in the St. John's Park freight station on the West Side where it has leased 50,000 square feet of space from the New York Central Railroad. The terminal is at West, Washington, Clarkson and Spring Streets and the lease was arranged by William A. White Sons, brokers.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Sales of independent retailers in January, reported by 22,929 concerns in nearly every field except department stores, were 15 per cent higher than in January, 1940, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

Pacific Mills announced yesterday changes in its discounts on percales resulting in net advances of 1/4 to 3/8 cent a yard. The action followed an earlier announcement by Pepperell Manufacturing Company. Pacific deliveries are offered through July 26.

I wish to challenge the soundness of the major contentions advanced by Dr. Mordecai Ezekiel, economic adviser of the Department of Agriculture, before the Temporary National Economic Committee, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 25.
AYER, Mass., March 5 (AP) -- Five civilians were killed instantly early today in a collision involving an automobile and two bus loads of Fort Devens soldiers.

Two thrilling P.S.A.L. basketball games, one deciding a borough championship and the other divisional honors, kept a crowd of 8,000 persons in turmoil as Andrew Jackson conquered Newtown, 31 -- 29, and De Witt Clinton turned back James Monroe, 33 -- 31, at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5 -- In a move as startling as it promises to be revolutionary, Manager Bill Terry calmly announced today that the Giants, without so much as swinging a deal or making the slightest alteration in their roster, had come up with a new outfielder.

A prize novel contest was announced yesterday by the publishing firm of Robert McBride for the "best book of the American scene, past or present." This further development in the ever-increasing attention of publishers to all things American offers as a prize a $1,500 advance against royalties.

George Joseph Cvek, 23-year-old confessed slayer of Mrs. Catherine Pappas, was questioned yesterday for four and a half hours by Bronx District Attorney Samuel J. Foley in connection with the strangulation of Mrs. Elizabeth Jensen on Monday in her basement apartment at 507 East 179th Street, the Bronx, but the prisoner denied any knowledge of the killing.

SHANGHAI, March 5 -- The Japanese official news agency, Domei, reports today that in a series of swift landings, which were virtually unresisted, Japanese troops have occupied the cities of Kwonghoi, Yeungkong, Tinpak, Huitang and Toishan, the entire Luichow Peninsula and the city of Pakhoi, which is a foreign treaty port.

LONDON, March 5 -- The number of ships in most classes of the British Navy -- "and especially in the destroyer classes" -- now ready for action is greater than at any time since the war started, A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, told the House of Commons today in presenting a token estimate for the navy.

TRENTON, N.J., March 5 (AP) -- Governor Charles Edison, moving for early settlement of New Jersey's railroad tax problem in the interest of national defense, industry, the public and labor, submitted to the Legislature today an unofficial committee report urging reductions in taxes on the carriers.
ALBANY, March 5 -- A determined drive to end the nine-year-old mortgage moratorium is under way in the Legislature, and is receiving the support of many Republican leaders.

It can scarcely be said that the proposals of the committee of New York City economics teachers have contributed much of a practical character toward the solution of the city's financial problems. The central proposal of the committee is a revival of the recurrent suggestion for a city income tax.

Several hundred Communists in a teachers' union with 7,000 members were too many Communists, in the opinion of one observer. Who was he? He was the author of a report on Local 5 New York, submitted to the Communist party convention three years ago. The writer practically says there were so many Communists in the teachers' union they got under your feet.
Election of Dean Alfange, Democratic nominee for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, was urged last night by Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. as a tribute to his father.

HANOVER, N.H., March 5 -- Paced by Captain Gus Broberg and Jim Olsen, center, Dartmouth's basketball team won its ninth Eastern Intercollegiate League game tonight by defeating Harvard, 63 to 47. The Indians, with only one defeat in ten starts, tightened their grid on first place.

It is to be hoped that the Board of Transportation will accede to the request of the City Council, made by unanimous resolution, that blind-leader dogs be permitted to accompany their masters on subway trains. After witnessing a convincing demonstration of the uncanny abilities of a Seeing-Eye German shepherd dog in guiding her master through City Hall, the Council learned that no accident had ever resulted from the presence of such dogs in public vehicles.

One point stood out, among a number worth thinking over, in the address which Chairman Gerard Swope of the New York City Housing Authority delivered yesterday before the Building Congress. New York City's own housing program, which is separate from the programs using Federal or State aid, will provide housing for 2,000 families at a cost of $500,000 a year.

PILOTTOWN, La., March 5 -- Responding to unfailing instincts, Louisiana's Winter colony of several million wild geese have begun to depart for their Summer nesting grounds in Arctic Baffin Island. By next week they will be in full flight northward along the Mississippi River with the first full stopover at James Bay, the southern outlet into Hudson's Bay.

PANAMA, March 5 -- President Arnulfo Arias issued a manifesto today, signed by all Cabinet Ministers, giving assurance of the cooperation of Panama in the erection of defense sites in territory of Panama outside the Canal Zone.
LONDON, March 5 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique tonight:

ATHENS, March 5 -- In a message addressed to the Greek people and made public a short time after he had left tonight for Egypt with the members of his mission, Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, frankly forecast a period of trials and difficulties but promised Britain's unflinching aid to her ally until the attainment of ultimate success.

"Andy Hardy's Private Secretary," the latest film in Metro's "Hardy family" series, will open this morning at the Capitol. Mickey Rooney is again featured as the scion of the family, with Lewis Stone, Fay Holden, Ann Rutherford and Sara Haden again cast in the chief supporting roles.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 5 -- Taking the attitude that Delaware's 200-year-old blue laws were "just as flexible as they need be for this life," Judge Henry R. Isaacs of the Wilmington Municipal Court dismissed today fifty-four of sixty seven defendants who appeared before him for violating the statutes Sunday.

Piling up a tremendous margin over their rivals in a field of thirty-eight pairs, Mrs. Barbara Collyer Cook and Mrs. Edith Russell Seligman won the Wainwright Cup emblematic of the women's pair championship at the Eastern Bridge Tournament at the Park Central Hotel yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Thursday, March 6 -- The Air Ministry said early today that two German bombers were destroyed Tuesday night and seven German fighters were "probably" shot down during yesterday's sweep over Northern France by the Royal Air Force -- an operation said to have cost the British three planes.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Chairman Dies declared today the House Committee on Un-American Activities had information indicating that Hitler plans to "invade South America from within" and already has German business men and others there organized into military units.
Officials of Malden, Mass., yesterday awarded to Leavitt Co. $500,000 of tempoary-loan notes at 0.313 per cent. The obligations, dated March 6, 1941, will be payable on Jan. 15 and Feb. 17, 1942.
Deals involving loft buildings featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 5 -Scoring heavily in the foils and pde, Columbia's fencing team doxvned Princeton, 15 -- 12, tonight In University Gunnasium.

Mrs. Ralph F. Barry gave a luncheon yesterday at the Beekman. Her guests included Mrs. William W. Hall, Mrs. Harold B. Legg, Mrs. F. Gordon Ketcham, Mrs. Louis F. Bruno Jr., Mrs. Edson Nichols Jr., Mrs. Walter E. Goepel, Mrs. William Linkroum Jr. and Miss Evelyn Barry.
Pig-iron production, according to The Iron Age, declined slightly in February. The month's total was 4,197,872 net tons, compared with 4,663,695 for January.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Senator Downey of California, whose position on the lease-lend bill had not previously been stated publicly, released tonight a letter to his son, Richard Downey, 17, who had asked how he was going to vote. In the letter he explained why he intends to vote for the measure.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 5 -- The German war machine rolled through Sofia's blacked-out streets tonight amid a nationwide mobilization against any sudden British air attack after a parting warning by! British Minister George Rendel that Bulgaria "may suffer" for her capitulation to Adolf Hitler.

The people of this country must accept equal burdens and equal sacrifices, if the hazard of a destructive post-war collapse is to be avoided, George A. Sloan, Commissioner of Commerce, declared last night at the dinner session of the 1941 Conference of the Graphic Arts, held at the Hotel Biltmore.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Authoritative sources said today that Germany was increasing its funds in the United States rapidly to permit her to turn some of them over to hard-pressed Japan.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- A bill designed to halt "the surreptitious importation" of German-made goods in containers so marked as to indicate that they were made in Japan was introduced in the House today by Representative Bloom of New York, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee.

Events tonight: "Goetterdaemmerung," Metropolitan Opera House, 7:30 o'clock; PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli, conductor; Italo Aontemezzi, guest conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Ada Belle Files, song recital, Town Hall, 8:30; Benefit concert for internees in unoccupied France, Mack Harell, Emanuel Feuerrnann, Lotte Lehman, Moriz Rosenthal, Karin Branzell and Armand Tokatyah. Hunter College Auditorium, 8:30.
Your editorial "Marine Park" is so perfect an apologia for the neglect of this huge parcel of land that it could not have been better written by Commissioner Moses himself.

Robert James, 2 1/2 years old, who has been the object of an intensive police search since his disappearance last Sunday, was found sobbing on a tenemen-house roof at 301 East 120th Street at 9:30 A.M. yesterday by a young waitress who had gone there to air her dog.
Earnings of the New York Central Railroad in 1941 should exceed those of 1940, which were the best since 1930, F. E. Williamson, president, said yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.
ALBANY, March 5 -- The following Statement, was issued today by the Republicans following conferences on the budget:

ATHENS, March 5 -- British Hurricanes and Gladiators escorting bombers in two attacks on Italian warships in the Adriatic off Khimara yesterday encountered a large formation of Italian fighters and shot nine of them down and damaged others, according to a Royal Air Force communique today.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $881,275,708 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price a share of all listed stocks on Feb. 28 was $27.08, compared with $27.68 at the end of January.

A radio research center intended to be the largest in the world will go into construction almost immediately at Princeton, N.J., for the Radio Corporation of America, it was announced yesterday by David Sarnoff, president of the organization.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 5 -- A broken Italian column retreated today along trails through the scrub and high grass of the mountainous Gojjam area of Ethiopia, which has taken on a sinister atmosphere for the Italians. Each tree and stone may hide a native patriot sniper and each ravine a band of guerrillas.

In a fighting speech in which he severely criticized the make-up of the Securities and Exchange Commission, urged a smaller paid board of governors for the New York Stock Exchange and prophesied that public opinion would swing back some day to the side of free markets, William McC. Martin Jr., president, addressed the membership of the Exchange yesterday.

Bergdorf Goodman at a gala showing last night projected styles that will give the fashion-conscious something to think about. They were incorporated in the 300 original costumes seen and in the dashing millinery that gave them a lift.
A large apartment house, recently completed in Bensonhurst, figured in one of the leading Brooklyn deals announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Senate adopted seven amendments to the lease-lend bill today and reached the first controversial one, on which it is expected a vote will be reached tomorrow.

VICHY, March 5 -- In official circles here there is nothing to give currency to the many rumors that General Weygand's visit has aroused. It is absolutely normal that the proconsul, who is directly responsible to Marshal Petain and to him alone, should make a report in person after several months of inquiries into the possibilities of colonial defense.

The Schools Motion Picture Com'mittee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and i high :schools ecommends as suitable for children between he ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- National observance of daylight saving time from the last Sunday in March to the last Sunday in October was proposed to Congress by Representative Donald H. McLean of Elizabeth, N.J.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 5 -- Little Ben Hogan gave a miraculous exhibition of shot-making down the home-stretch today as he and the ever-colorful Gene Sarazen won the $5,000 international four-ball golf tournament on the Miami Biltmore course.

HAVANA, March 6 -- It's not an original thought, because a great many Flatbush fans already have voiced it, but what could be a Spring edition of the 1941 world series will be unveiled at Tropical Park tomorrow.

VICHY, France, March 6 -- Imperial questions were undoubtedly uppermost in the conferences General Maxime Weygand had today with Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and General Charles L.C. Huntziger, the War Minister. These talks will be continued with other government leaders.

Coal gas seeping from the cellar of a five-story apartment house at 610 West 163d Street yesterday caused the death of a woman and her two children. Four other occupants of the building were overcome by the fumes, three of whom were taken to a hospital.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 6 -- Mr. and Mrs. Everett Colby were luncheon hosts today at the Bath and Tennis Club. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Charlton Yarnall, Captain and Mrs. John H. Gibbons, Mr. and Mrs. John Sargent Pillsbury, Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer, Mrs. W. Laurence Le Page, Lawrence Smith Butler, Alexander Philips. J. Robert Hewitt and Guy H. Scull.

Commercial loans of the sixteen reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City jumped $33,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York revealed yesterday. This was the largest weekly gain since the week ended on Sept. 11, and brought the total outstanding to $2,022,000,000, the highest level since the Nineteen Twenties.

London cast doubt yesterday on reports from Washington that a Nazi Army of 100,000 men and 1,000 tanks had been transported to Libya, although it was revealed in England about a week ago that there were large German land and air concentrations in Southern Italy and Sicily, apparently awaiting transport to North Africa.

Reporting to stockholders for the year 1940, George M. Moffett, president of the Corn Products Refining Company, said that the company and its two domestic subsidiaries had a net income of $9,581,054 after all charges, including provision of $160,000 for estimated excess profits tax.

Plans have been formulated by Billy Rose to present "Clash by Night," which he is producing by arrangement with the Group Theatre, during the week of April 6, probably at the Lyceum Theatre, Mr. Rose said last night. Mr. Rose wants to open the Clifford Odets play early in April because he optimistically thinks it will win the Pulitzer Prize.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -The Maritime Commission has sent word to Congressional leaders that it would like authority to take over on a charter basis thirty-six Danish ships which have been tied up in United States ports since the German occupation of Denmark, it was revealed tonight.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 6 (UP) -- The government tonight mobilized all physicians and surgeons for military and civilian defense and conscripted medical supplies after a conference between King Boris and German military leaders expert in the technique of invasion and occupation.

TOKYO, March 6 -- Vichy's latest communication was conveyed to Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka today and it accepted all the principal points in Japan's plan for settling the Thai border question. Mr. Matsuoka subsequently visited the French Ambassador, Charles Arsene-Henry, and discussed some details remaining to be settled.

MOSCOW, March 6 (UP) -- The Russian Army paper, Red Star, today quoted "foreign observers" as stating that Turkey might join the war if Germany took Salonika, permitting British warships to pass through the Dardanelles and British troops to operate from Turkish soil.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The first deficiency bill of the session, carrying $193,913,093 in funds and contract authorizations, of which 80 per cent were estimated to be for national defense purposes, was reported to the House today by the Appropriations Committee.

Formal bids were issued yesterday to three teams for the national invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden on March 18, 19, 22 and 24. They are Long Island University, with a record of 22 and 2; Rhode Island State, 21 and 3, and Seton Hall, 19 and 0 for this campaign and forty-two straight over a three-year span.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Secretary Ickes approved today the transfer to Great Britain of about 500,000 cubic feet of American helium gas originally sold to France in May, 1940, for research and medical purposes.

When the State Insurance Law was amended in 1939 to sanction non-profit voluntary health insurance, the question of selling it was not considered. Since the health organizations which were incorporated under the amended law were not in any sense commercial, they were exempt from State, county and municipal taxes.
LONDON, March 6 (AP) -- A joint communique issued by the Admiralty and the Norwegian refugee government today said:

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- An assertion that the existence of monopoly conditions in industry has invariably led to government controls and, in the case of Germany, to totalitarianism, is made in a report issued by the Temporary National Economic Committee dealing with the regulation of economic activities in foreign countries.
Directors of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation voted yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share. Last year the company paid 25 cents on April 1.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 -- The lone survivor of the Yankee hold-out brigade surrendered today. Joe DiMaggio, who hit thirty-one home runs in the ill-fated campaign of 1940, drove in 143 runs and batted a modest .352, finally accepted terms, Manager Joe McCarthy announced following a telephone conversation with President Ed Barrow in New York.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 6 -- The New Zealand air-training plan is now operating at its maximum, Prime Minister Peter Fraser disclosed in a review of this country's effort in the first eighteen months of the war. Rapid expansion was possible because the framework existed before the war, he said.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 6 -- Interrupted telephone reports from Sofia, Bulgaria, today disclosed that the German General Staff, headed by General Field Marshal Sigmund List, called upon Premier Bogdan Philoff at the Foreign Office and made a visit to the Bulgarian War Office in moves interpreted as tightening the Bulgarian-German political and military liaison preparatory to action against Greece.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 6 -- William F. Baker, field director of the Red Cross here, outlined its program today. The Red Cross, he said, will be of service to the men in three ways: Personal contacts with relatives and friends, advice and assistance in financial matters, including deserving loans, and investigation and assistance in affairs at home where the soldier feels responsibility.

"American Artists in the Brooklyn Museum's Print Collection" is the title of an exhibition of graphic work by American artists opening today at the Brooklyn Museum and to be continued through April 20. Arranged by the print department, it presents outstanding examples of work by George Bellows, Mary Cassatt, Pop Hart, Winslow Homer, Whistler and Pennell.

The New York State Bankers Association went on record formally yesterday as opposed to any legislation that would permit savings banks in this State to engage in the personal-loan business. The announcement was made by Orie R. Kelly, chairman of the association's legislative committee, who is president of the Lawyers Trust Company.

Complete elimination of the assumed funded indebtedness of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation was announced yesterday by the utility holding company in a program of simplification and streamlining of its corporate structure.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- Liquidation developed in wheat futures in the early trading today and the decline was not checked until prices had receded around 1 cent a bushel from Wednesday's finish. Mills and shorts bought on the dip and later there was fairly general short covering on the strength in securities.

Other Affiliated Union Groups Charge That Rivals Do Not Give Majority View Five thousand members of the C.I.O., packing Manhattan Center last night at an "anti-war" and "pro-peace" rally in opposition to the lease-lend bill, cheered repeated charges by speakers that the preservation of democracy is not at stake in the present war and booed mention of President Roosevelt and British Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

Today's events: "Don Giovanni," revival, fifth performance in the matinee cycle, 2 P.M., and "Der Rosenkavalier," 8, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Saida Knox, contralto, Town Hall, 8:30; The Village Singers, Brevoort Hotel, 8:30.

Counsel for Joseph M. Schenck and Joseph H. Moskowitz scoffed yesterday at the government's charge that Schenck fraudulently evaded $412,045 income taxes in 1935, 1936 and 1937, and charged that actually Schenck paid more than $165,000 too much. He is now trying to get this back.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 6 -- It is learned that a brief reply has been drafted from President Ismet Inonu to the message from Reichsfuehrer Hitler, brought here by plane by five Nazi emissaries. The reply will be presented by the Turkish Ambassador in Berlin.

Resolutions urging the Swiss Government to buy whatever ship tonnage is available to establish a schedule of regular freight shipments between that country and the United States via Genoa, were adopted here yesterday at a meeting of the Swiss Trade Council, Inc., at the Hotel Commodore.

Much confusion exists concerning what Congress will do in the matter of farm legislation at the present session. For several months there has been some agitation by the Secretary of Agriculture and others for an income certificate plan, actually a processing tax, for certain domestic crops.
SEVILLE, Spain, March 6 (AP) -- Friends of former King Carol of Rumania said tonight he and Mme. Magda Lupescu possibly would fly from their Lisbon refuge to the United States soon.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 6 -- Official comment on the practical effect of the Court of Appeals ruling today on Nassau County's 1941 budget was unavailable, but unofficially it was said that the decision placed the fiscal affairs of the county in a serious position.
A new national survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion has shown that men of draft age favor the lease-lend bill by a large majority, Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director, reports.

A banking group headed by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and including Colyer, Robinson Co., Inc.; MacBride, Miller Co., Inc., and Walter, Woody Heimerdinger will offer today $388,000 city of Clifton, N.J., 2 3/4 per cent bonds, dated Feb. 1, 1941, and maturing on Feb. 1, 1942 to 1971.

The celebration of Thomas Garrigue Masaryk's birthday today has a special poignancy for citizens or residents of Czecho-Slovak derivation. It should mean something to every American. Thomas Masaryk, first President of the Czecho-Slovak Republic, had close ties with the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Cancellation of plans for a 100-unit defense housing project at Harrison, N.J., because of an "uncooperative" attitude on the part of the town, and the enlargement in consequence from 200 to 300 units of another defense housing project in Newark, N.J., were approved today by John M. Carmody, Federal Works Administrator.
At a meeting of the board of stewards of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association yesterday sanctions were approved for steeplechasing at four tracks during the coming season.

In an effort to "satisfy those who read while they run, as well as those who seek to understand more completely the financial status and operations of the company in which they have taken out protection," Lewis W. Douglas, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, has divided into two parts the ninety-eighth annual report, which is being mailed to its 850,000 policyholders.
ROME, March 6 (AP) -- The Italian High Command today issued the following communique:

The Ohrbach A. A. basketball team gained its third straight metropolitan A. A. U. crown by defeating Local 102, I. L. G. W. U., 35 to 26, at the Manhattan Center last night. It was the sixteenth victory in a row for the champions, who will head for Denver, Colo., next week for the national A. A. U. tourney.

With "Strawberry Blonde" entering its third and final week at the Strand today, no new films are scheduled for Broadway theatres. Off Broadway, however, there will be two openings: "Napoleon Ist An Allem Schuld," a German importation, at the Eighty-sixth Street Casino Theatre, and "Nativa," an Argentine film, at the Teatro Latino. . . .

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The National Association of Securities Dealers announced today that its proposed rule governing the sale and repurchase of shares of open-end investment companies had been approved by a 3-to-1 vote of its membership.

THE lightweight champion of the world, according to the edict of the New York State Athletic Commission, is Lew Jenkins of Sweetwater, Texas. The lightweight champion of the world, according to the edict of the National Boxing Association, is Sammy Angott, who now claims Pittsburgh as his home town. "You pays your money and you takes your choice."

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 6 (UP) -- The German Todt organization is rushing work on at least forty military airports in Bulgaria and Rumania, including bases close to Rumania's northern frontier with Russia, advices from Bucharest said tonight.

NEWARK, N.J. March 6 -- A one-day work stoppage at six plants of Thomas A. Edison Industries will be called Monday morning by the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers C.I.O. affiliate, unless the management makes concessions to union demands to be presented tomorrow.

AMSTERDAM, March 6 (via Berlin) (AP) -- Hollanders were warned today in a military court, which had heard a striking account of a secret organization for espionage and sabotage all over the Netherlands, that any one who conspired, even in thought, against the German Army was playing with a death sentence.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- After four days or debate the House passed and sent to the Senate today the 1942 fiscal appropriation for the Agriculture Department, carrying in all $1,420,977,559.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Department store sales showed a slight rise during February and the seasonally adjusted index of the Federal Reserve Board advanced to 102, based on the 1923-25 average, compared with 101 for January and December, and with ninety for February, 1940.

Mrs. Ethel S. Epstein, labor relations secretary to Mayor La Guardia, will endeavor at a City Hall conference this morning to re-establish industrial peace in the millinery shop of Lilly Dache at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street. A strike was called at the shop Wednesday by the Millinery Workers Union, an A.F. of L. affiliate.

The estate of Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, is insolvent, according to an affidavit accompanying the estate tax appraisal of the estate of his wife, Mrs. E. Eurana Schwab, which was filed yesterday by Deputy State Tax Commissioner Jacob Manicoff.

ALBANY, March 6 -- The Republicans in the Legislature stood firm today behind their plan to trim $1,271,000 of proposed defense appropriations from Governor Lehman's budget, despite the Governor's protests that they were crippling his efforts to prepare the Saate for any and all emergencies.

The advertising allowance policy of the White Swan Uniform Company, challenged in a complaint by the Federal Trade Commission, was described by three retailers yesterday as one in which any retailer stocking and distributing the company's first line might participate.

ATHENS, March 6 -- An attack by a Greek submarine upon Italian shipping, described in a Ministry of Marine communique tonight, took place Feb. 23 in the Adriatic Sea, it was revealed here. The submarine was the Nireus, commanded by Brasidas Rotas.

Between forty and fifty faculty members at City College belong or have belonged within recent years to the campus units of the Communist party and use the classroom to indoctrinate students with Bolshevik ideology, William Martin Canning, a history instructor and former party member, charged yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- These are the major amendment proposals which the Senate must dispose of before reaching a final vote on the lease-lend bill:

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- Following an upward trend in pork loin prices, which reached the best level in two weeks, hog prices rose 10 cents today. Most of the advance was shown on choice medium weights and heavy butchers, but all classes opened generally steady in active trading. Top was $7.85, with the bulk of choice 180 to 240 pound hogs bringing $7.60 to $7.80.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 6 (AP) -- Georgia Lamar Shanton, the former Mrs. Marshall Heminway, and H. Townsend Bradley Martin, New York banker, were married at the Hotel Utah here today by the Salt Lake County Marriage License Clerk.

Controller Morris S. Tremaine made public yesterday the essential features of New York State's financial condition as of Feb. 1, last, in anticipation of the sale next Tuesday of $19,600,000 of long-term serial State bonds for low-rent-housing purposes.

The 3,500 drivers and mechanics employed by the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, the New York City Omnibus Corporation, the Madison Avenue Coach Company, Inc., and the Eighth Avenue Coach Corporation will take a strike vote tonight at a mass meeting called yesterday by officers of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate.

Ada Belle Files, contralto from Kansas City, Kan., gave her first New York recital last night in Town Hall. The program, which opened with the aria, "Ah, rendimi," from Francesco Rossi's "Mitrane," contained other operatic excerpts by Massenet, Thomas, Tchaikovsky and Rimsky-Korsakoff, as well as Italian, French, Russian and English songs.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Billy Conn passed another way station on the heavyweight build-up trail tonight by knocking out Danny Hassett of Philadelphia in the fifth round. Conn weighed 181 pounds, Hassett 204 1/4.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- New York City concerns, headed by the First Boston Corporation, obtained underwriting participations in 1940 amounting to $1,104,469,000, or 68.2 per cent of the total, compared with 65.6 per cent in 1939, the securities and exchange division announced today.

Norbert Setzler and Tony Bertolotti, both professionals at the Racquet and Tennis Club, came through to the final of the open racquets tournament for the Clarence C. Pell Cup yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

HANOI, French Indo-China, March 6 (AP) -- An extension "without limit" of the armistice between this French colony and Thailand was announced today by the Indo-China Government, but arrangements have been made for either party to end it upon advance notice.

As the Nazi forces gather strength on the Bulgarian frontier, the odds against the Greeks are formidable. A little country of 7,000,000 souls, with a comparatively ill-equipped army, already battling against the forces of a nation of 45,000,000, is now threatened by a nation of 80,000,000, with the most powerful land and air forces in the world.

A new one-day record for the induction of registrants into the Army was set yesterday in the Second Corps Area, when 1,231 entered the service, Colonel Lloyd B. Magruder, in charge of recruiting, announced last night. This was 231 above the quota set for the day, and brought to 3,334 the number of men inducted in the area during the sixth draft requisition, which began Monday and will continue to next Friday.

The New York State Chamber of Commerce urged the Mayor and the Board of Estimate yesterday to place the city transit fares on a self-supporting basis. In a resolution adopted at its monthly meeting at 65 Liberty Street, it was pointed out that unless the fares are increased to meet expenses, the city's finances cannot be placed on a sound footing.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Although the Federal Government, due to the defense program, has now become the largest single buyer in the country, loose Federal purchasing polices have resulted in the payment of top prices for most of the things it buys, it is asserted in a monograph on this subject released today by the Temporary National Economic Committee.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 6 -Frank Hayes, former Lieutenant Governor and five times Mayor of Waterbury; Daniel J. Leary, former Waterbury Controller, and Thomas P. Kelly, Hayes's secretary, together with seven other defendants in a conspiracy to loot Waterbury of more than $1,000,000 lost their ap peals from prison sentences in the Supreme Court today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Defense officials are speculating on the possibility of a combined steel and coal strike threat on April 1 which would involve 750,000 workers and would cripple defense production. The situation may be disclosed in two important conferences in which affiliates of the CIO will participate.

LONDON, March 6 -- There were indications tonight that there might be a lull in the Balkans for a few days or even a few weeks while the Germans try to persuade Turkey that they do not want to attack Greece and at the same time try to offer Greece an "honorable peace."

FORT DIX, N.J., March 6 -- Sergeants of the Forty-fourth Division in the first three grades, who were disgruntled last Fall because they were not receiving rental allowances, were informed today that they probably would receive the allowance of approximately $22.50 a month for quarters on their next pay day.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 6 -- The Chief Regent, Prince Paul, summoned the Regency, the War Minister and the Chief of Staff to a Palace conference with Government leaders today to decide whether Yugoslavia would resist, compromise or capitulate to Germany.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 6 -- The British threat to Harar and Addis Ababa communications with their port of Jibuti was intensified today as African forces, after the occupation of Ferfer, drove northward along the Shebeli Valley roads.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Charges by William McC. Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, that members of the Securities and Exchange Commission were "ignorant" and "without fundamental concept of the broad picture of a market" were replied to tonight by the commission.

Rising 15 per cent over a year ago, home furnishings departments led all other department store sections in January in percentage of sales increase, according to the newly inaugurated report giving a breakdown of departmental sales on a national basis, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 6 -- Jockey Conn McCreary, leading rider at Hialeah, scored his first victory at Tropical Park today when he piloted Devil's Crag home first in the Florida City Purse to equal the track record. The 4-year-old son of Diavolo, who carries the colors of James B. Campbell, came powerfully at the end under McCreary's handling to score easily by four lengths in 1:41 4-5 over a fast track.
AMSTERDAM, March 6 -- After a depressing opening, small all-round buying developed on today's Bourse.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A special House investigation into all phases of the defense program was proposed today by the House Rules Committee in a resolution sent to the House. None of the information obtained in the investigation would be made public.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The United States has asked the Italian Government to restrict the movements of its consular officers and agents in this country to their own districts and to close its consulates in Newark, N.J., and Detroit, it was announced today.

BERLIN, March 6 (UP) -- German spokesmen warned today that it might be "extremely dangerous for Greece" if the Athens Government accepted proposals reported to have been made by British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden. The spokesmen said they were unaware of the exact nature of Mr. Eden's proposals, but last night Mr. Eden said in Athens that Britain and Greece would fight on side-by-side "until final victory is won."
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- An investigation of commercial air line accidents which have resulted in fifty-five deaths in the last eight months was ordered by the House today.

Martha Foley, who with Whit Burnett has edited Story Magazine for more than ten years, has resigned that post to become the editor of "The O'Brien Memorial Best Short Story Yearly Anthology," which will be published by the Dial Press of New York.
BERLIN, March 6 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique:

The Esso Tanker Men's Association, an independent union, defeated the National Maritime Union, a C.I.O. affiliate, in a run-off election conducted by the National Labor Relations Board, it was announced last night after a count of the vote, at the Labor Board offices.
The New York University girls' swimming team defeated the Savage School of Physical Education team, 40 -- 15, in the Evangeline House pool yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The National Aeronautics Association today called for a re-examination of civil aviation administration and an inquiry into methods to remedy the causes of many of the recent air fatalities.

In the eight months since the defense program began about $12,400,000,000 of contracts have been awarded by the Government. Actual expenditures for national defense, however, have totaled only about $2,850,000,000. This is considerably below the rate of defense spending scheduled in the budget.

The 1940 annual report of Stone Webster, Inc., and subsidiaries, made public yesterday by George O. Muhlfeld, president, showed a consolidated net income of $1,354,147, equal to 64 cents each on 2,104,391 shares of capital stock, compared with a net of $1,024,082, or 49 cents a capital share, in 1939.

Milo J. Warner, national commander of the American Legion and head of the four-man group that spent a month in England studying civilian defense efforts, announced yesterday that as a result of observations in the British Isles recommendations would be made to the national executive committee of the veterans' organization as to the best ways of implementing the Legion's resolved policy of lending aid to Great Britain.
