LONDON, Friday, March 7 -- Scattered raids by German aircraft covering a wide territory for a long time took place yesterday and last night on the east and southeast coasts of Great Britain. They included one brief attack on London. The number of casualties was small, though the planes dropped bombs and strafed towns with machine guns.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York, speaking as chairman of the United States Conference of Mayors, told the House Public Buildings and Grounds Committee today that cities and towns involved in the defense program were in urgent need of expanded public facilities.

Savings bankers at the Eastern Regional Conference of the American Bankers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria were told yesterday by Justin Hartzog, assistant coordinator of Federal Defense Housing, that the government expected the banks to invest in small home mortgages that can be obtained by workers in defense industries.

If national advertisers have any intention of throwing large sums of excess profits into advertising, it hasn't shown up in media figures since the start of the year. Whatever gains developed have been moderate and some losses were shown in the first two months of this year.

ROME, March 6 -- All Italy is on edge today waiting for the great news which, it is hoped, will prove the beginning of the end of the unhappy Greek adventure. The Germans have made the first squeeze on Greece and time is pressing. Out of deference to their Axis partner they must wait, but they cannot afford to wait long.

Bank clearings in the twenty-three leading cities of the United States in the week ended on March 5, amounted to $6,776,662,000, or 21.5 per cent more than the $5,579,268,000 for the similar week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation will vote at their annual meeting at Wilmington, Del., on April 8, on an amended pension plan, adopted recently by the board of directors. It has more liberal provisions than the present plan.

Preparations for the Greater New York Fund campaign opening April 14 were begun in several fields throughout the city yesterday. In Brooklyn the quota for the industry division was raised from last year's total of $47,000 to a new high of $68,000.

With 597 photographs of subjects ranging from the King and Queen of England to a snow scene in downtown New York, the eighth International Salon of Photography, sponsored by the Pictorial Photographers of America, opened yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- The Army Quartermaster today awarded negotiated contracts for the manufacture from government materials of 865,000 field jackets, out of 1,036,000 asked for on Feb. 17. Contracts also were awarded today for the manufacture of 150,000 mosquito bars, for 100,000 Turkish terrycloth bath towels for the Civilian Conservation Corps and for 12,000 cotton waists for Army nurses.

ALBANY, March 6 -- The Court of Appeals invalidated unanimously today the Nassau County budget for 1941 and ruled that J. Russel Sprague, County Executive, and the Board of Supervisors were wrong in enacting the $17,000,000 budget in lump-sum form.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor is the President's source of information that strikes in defense industries in 1940 resulted in lost time equal to only one-fourth of 1 per cent of the total defense effort.

LACONIA-GILFORD, N.H., March 6 -- Skiing prospects over the week-end, generally speaking, will be the best in several weeks for Northeastern United States and Canada, while the metropolitan area, the Berkshires, Catskills and Poconos have little to offer, which is not unusual for this time of the year.

TOKYO, March 6 -- Rumors that Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka will shortly visit Berlin, with a stopover in Moscow en route either going or coming or both, though still officially unconfirmed, have acquired greater solidity from the apparently imminent conclusion of Japan's mediation between French Indo-China and Thailand and the departure of the German Ambassador, Major Gen. Eugen Ott, for Berlin.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- In a 128-page Spring sales "flyer" catalogue sent out here to mail-order customers, Montgomery Ward Co. today cut prices on a number of items in tire, plumbing, apparel and accessories, hardware, automobile battery and electric refrigerator lines. The sharpest reductions applied to closeouts of 1940 items.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Mitchell, a writer of army textbooks and former professor at the West Point Military Academy, held the Distinguished Service Medal and the Croix de Guerre with Palm and was an officer of the Legion of Honor.

SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, March 6 (AP) -- Army, navy and air force exercises based on the assumption that war with an imaginary foe is to break out Saturday got under way today, tied up with orders for a partial blackout of this British Far Eastern stronghold the next two nights.

With the special election to elect a Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson coming next Tuesday, supporters of the three candidates increased their activity yesterday.
LONDON, March 6 (AP) -- A substantial increase in note circulation and private deposits and a corresponding drop in reserves was shown in the weekly statement of the Bank of England today.

Hattie Carnegie's is a fashion palette brilliantly spotted with color. Red, magenta, poison green, pink -- all took a strident place amid sober black and navy, calm gray and beige in the widely divergent collection advanced yesterday morning in the East Forty-ninth Street shop.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 6 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Government deposits increased $9,209,000 to $62,933,000 in the week ended yesterday, it was shown today in the weekly statement of the Bank of Canada.

ATLANTA, March 6 -- The Mexico Silver Sleeper of the Eastern Air Lines was flying "unusually low" just before it crashed in a pine thicket near here early Thursday morning, an investigator and residents near the scene testified today at a Civil Aeronautics Board hearing.

One of the best discussions we ever read on winds and tides and their influence on Long Island surf fishing is between the covers of the new Long Island Fishing Guide, the publication of the East End Surf Fishing Club.

Although new-crop months yesterday set new seasonal highs for the second consecutive day, price movements on the New York Cotton Exchange held within narrow limits and final quotations showed net gains of 1 to 2 points. The defeat of amendments to the agriculture appropriations bill which would have provided higher parity payments to farmers caused some liquidation, but this was absorbed by a heavy trade offtake.

The untimely death of Kenneth Simpson, who represented the Seventeenth Congressional District in Washington, has placed a heavy responsibility on the voters in that mid-Manhattan slice of this metropolis. On Tuesday they must elect Mr. Simpson's successor.

Al Blozis of Georgetown will go about the business of officially breaking the world shot-put record all over again at the Knights of Columbus games in Madison Square Garden tomorrow. The human howitzer tossed the ball 56 feet 6 inches, the second longest heave in history, at the intercollegiate championships last Saturday, but used an outdoor shot instead of the leather-covered indoor ball.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Justices of the Supreme Court were asked in arguments today to decide whether the Federal Government could sue as "a person" under the Sherman Anti-Trust Act to collect treble damages of $1,053,474 from seventeen automobile tire makers accused of collusive bidding in sales to the government.

Contributions of $132,000 toward a fund of $10,000,000 for the relief of air-raid victims in Great Britain were announced yesterday at the opening meeting of the money-raising drive sponsored by the British War Relief Society of 730 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The War Department will request legislation at this session of Congress to extend by six to twelve months the year's training authorized for the National Guard providing the international situation remains the same or grows worse.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Administration leaders in the Senate, in an attempt to allay fears of Senators who hesitate to vote for the lease-lend bill because they say they believe it might authorize the use of the armed forces of the United States on foreign soil, presented a compromise amendment today which the leaders hope will cause the withdrawal of a dozen restrictive amendments already proposed.

Planning has begun on the reconstruction of war-damaged British cities. Preliminary reports on Coventry, Birmingham and Bristol will be submitted in a few weeks. The starting point is the belief, universally held in Britain, that Germany will be defeated.
A RECENT cartoon in The New Yorker, you may remember, showed a skier who had just taken off from a tremendous slide soaring unhappily into the lower reaches of the stratosphere.
LONDON, March 6 -- The British today described as "fantastic" reports from Washington that the Germans had 100,000 troops in Libya.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Before approving Subsection c, Section 3, of the lease-lend bill, the Senate engaged in a very interesting debate which was not dwelt on in the news dispatches. Subsection c is the Senate Committee's revision of the Dirksen amendment in the House which sought to provide that, by passing a concurrent resolution at any time, Congress may terminate the additional executive powers granted in H.R. 1776.

Billy Soose, the Farrell (Pa.) middleweight who has decisions to his credit over two claimants to the 160-pound title, will risk his status as the outstanding challenger for the crown when he opposes Ernie Vigh of Newburgh at Madison Square Garden tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., March 6 -- Giulio Pascucci Righi, vice consul, who has been in charge of the Italian Consulate here for only four days, closed his office at 4:30 P.M. today without having received notification from his superiors about the State Department's action.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6 -- The delicate and complicated operation of converting Harry Danning from a catcher into a left-fielder began today with a flourish and considerable moaning and groaning by the subject, who wasn't ready for the ordeal but finished the day's work with some success.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 6 -- While legislators at Dover wrangled today over the Sunday blue laws a further judicial interpretation of the statutes here led to the freeing of fifty-three milkmen arrested in the enforcement campaign Sunday, but Maurice Katz, a bath house proprietor, failed to convince the Municipal Court that either a Turkish or a Russian bath was a necessity and was fined $4.50.

The concert given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society last night in Carnegie Hall was signalized by the first American performance of Italo Montemezzi's tone-poem after the romance of Saint-Pierre, "Paolo e Virginia," with the composer as guest-conductor of his work.

ALBANY, March 6 -- The idea of immediate legislation to enforce a mandatory "cooling-off period" before a strike can be called, or a lockout put into effect, was opposed today by the Ives Committee on Industrial and Labor Conditions in its annual report to the Legislature.

LANSING, Mich., March 6 (AP) -- Voicing a threat to declare "a state of emergency" in Michigan, Governor Murray D. van Wagoner obtained an agreement today for arbitration of a dispute which had threatened to shut off gas and electric service in 900 Southern Michigan communities tomorrow.

SHARON, Vt., March 6 -- The experimental Camp William James was divided into two sections today as twenty-four men, including Harvard and Dartmouth graduates, received honorable discharges from the Civilian Conservation Corps and set up a new camp in Tunbridge.

I am in full accord with your editorial on medical insurance. The hospitalization plan is the best available. By it the public can obtain the highest type of medical services at the lowest cost. Patients do not have to be hospitalized to be able to avail themselves of much needed periodic check-ups and treatment in the dispensaries and out-patient departments of the various hospitals.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., March 6 -- An air "attack" today on this Army airport, the bulwark of the metropolitan area's air defense, met with "disaster" for the twenty-one "invading" twin-engined bombers on a surprise tactical mission from Langley Field, Va.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., March 6 -- Otto Sippel, Acting Mayor of the Village of Elmsford and one of the most widely known village officials in Westchester County, was arrested this afternoon by Port Chester police and Westchester County deputy sheriffs on a charge of book- making at his stationary store at 210 Westchester Avenue, here.
GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., March 6 (AP) -- Still any dog's race, the national field trials, dotted with several fancy exhibitions of bird and field work, moved into the homestretch today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 6 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today signed Ernst Lubitsch to a producer-director's contract to go into effect as soon as he finishes one more picture for United Artists. It was believed that Lubitsch would return to Metro, where he made "Ninotchka" and "The Shop Around the Corner," when he left United, but the Fox deal will give him autonomy and the privilege of choosing his own stories.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The text of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's note to Prince Ascanio Colonna, the Italian Ambassador, follows:

Endowed with tremendous vitality, Gutzon Borglum often seemed an artist, out of a novel or play. His explosions, quarrels, lawsuits were in line with the tradition of his part. The long list of his works attests to his great industry. His devotion to the colossal, which he seemed to believe the truly American form of art, left its largest monument in the Black Hills of South Dakota.

The pamphlet report of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company for 1940, released yesterday by Clifford E. Paige, chairman of the board and president of the company, showed a net income of $1,802,426, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, compared with $1,802,591 in 1939.

HONG KONG, March 6 (AP) -- Japanese declared today that their landings at six Chinese coastal points on the Gulf of Tongking had nullified United States aid to the Chinese Government and, as an army spokesman at Canton put it, "the doom of Chiang Kai-shek's regime is sealed."

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The defense savings bonds, stamps and certificates which the Treasury plans to sell to the public in large numbers will go on sale on May 1, Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Work on most of the sections of the Army Medical Center in this city was halted today as 250 employes of one contractor, members of the American Federation of Labor, struck because a non-union contractor had obtained a portion of the work.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The United Gas Improvement Company gave fresh indication today that it would test in the courts the "death sentence" of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

PITTSBURGH, March 6 -- Champion Flornell Glamorous, whippet from the Mardormere Kennels of Glen Head, L.I., and handled by Percy Roberts, captured the special for best in show at the annual fixture of the Western Pennsylvania Kennel Association tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- As a set-off against the gradual destruction of the Italian Empire in Africa, Germany strives to hold Western Libya (Tripolitania) with her own forces and to compel General Maxime Weygand of France to toe the line, to give up any remnant of independent power and military strength that he may still retain.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- Gutzon Borglum's son, Lincoln, reported that his father had finished work on the heads at Mount Rushmore before he left the site about Feb. 1, and that, in keeping with a previous understanding, he (Lincoln) planned to smooth the rough stone around the coats and hands of the figures.

VICHY, France, March 6 -- Vice Premier Francois Darlan, who went to Paris this week to reopen negotiations with the German authorities, finished his preliminary conversations today and is expected to return to Vichy tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- An appeal to Americans regardless of church, faith and sect was made by William C. Bullitt, former Ambassador to Russia, tonight for contributions for the replacement of holy vessels and other articles stolen in recent depredations from the Roman Catholic Church of St. Louis in Moscow.

"If I am going to eat, I have to have a job." This was the explanation given yesterday by Charles G. Rubin, 32-year-old chemist of 1844 Crotona Avenue, the Bronx, who filed an application for a $15-a-week laundry job after remaining in line twenty-two and a half hours.

A temperamental stock market staged a strong recovery yesterday, with values increased 1 to 3 points. The ability of United States Steel common to hold firm and even to advance after stabilization operations had been terminated inspired a better participation in trading throughout the share list, while the absence of any appreciable pressure produced some public buying.

An agreement by the management and employes of the Consumers Power Company of Lansing to arbitrate their dispute removed yesterday the threat of a power shutdown at many Michigan plants working around the clock on national defense orders.

LONDON, March 6 -- Without a single raider killed or wounded, an amphibious British-Norwegian expedition landed in the Lofoten Islands, off Narvik, destroyed fish and whale oil plants and captured 215 Germans and 10 Quislingists.

MONTREAL, March 6 (AP) -The struggling Canadiens tonight achieved their first hockey victory of the year over Toronto, with the help of the rookie goalie, Paul Bibeault, who had been signed from the amateur ranks only a few hours earlier.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Roosevelt received the new Polish Ambassador, Jan Ciechanowski, who presented his credentials. Restricting his calling list again because of a cold, he also received Secretary Morgenthau, Norman Davis, president of the American Red Cross, and Representative Joseph A. Gavagan of New York.

A few Swedish platina foxes brought a top of $325 at the sale conducted yesterday by Lampson, Fraser Huth. Canadian platinum foxes sold up to $190. White face pale silver foxes met a strong demand, reaching $135. The top prices obtained on other silver foxes ran as follows: Full, $125; three-quarter, $50; one-half, $31; one-quarter, $20, and darks, $13.

The Special Gifts Committee of the Archbishop's Committee of the Laity of the New York Catholic Charities has obtained donations totaling $31,000 to date in its appeal for funds from special groups in business and the professions, it was reported yesterday at its weekly meeting at the Empire State Club.

The Board of Estimate cleared the way yesterday for construction of a $100,000 barracks for Navy student fliers by turning over part of Floyd Bennett Field to the Navy for a five-year period at nominal rent of $1 a year.

This bulletin is posted here to draw attention to an experiment in theatre at popular prices. Elmer Rice's "Flight to the West" is now on view at the Royale at a top price of $1.10 for all performances, except those of Saturday and Sunday evenings, when the top price will be $1.65.

LONDON, March 6 -- Trading in gilt-edge securities featured business in today's stock markets so far as turnover was concerned and further fractional rises were scored in prices. War Loan 3 1/2 s, at 103 7/8, reached the highest level since July, 1938.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Radio speeches tonight found Senators Hatch of New Mexico and Wallgren of Washington, both Democrats, supporting the lease-lend bill.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 6 -One major change in the technique of warfare involved in mechanization promotes the machine gun from the role of defensive weapon to the most versatile weapon of attack.

Your editorial "Medical Insurance," commenting on Dr. Kingsley Roberts's letter evaluating voluntary health insurance plans, strikes an important note when it calls for more education on the advantages of such insurance.

An American gift of twenty-five desert warfare ambulances for Australian-New Zealand troops in Africa was presented yesterday noon in Madison Square Park by the British-American Ambulance Corps to the Anzac War Relief Fund for immediate shipment to Egypt.

It is an old-fashioned idea that academic graduates should go into the professions and a "false notion" for them to think "it is unbecoming to take up a skilled trade," Mayor La Guardia said yesterday in urging a group of high school seniors to enter aviation where jobs are plentiful because of the defense program.

The Blue Ribbon contract bridge team, consisting of Bertram Lebhar of New Rochelle, Sam Katz of Maplewood, N.J., and Oscar Brotman and Louis Newman of Washington, won its way into the semifinals of the team-of-four championship at the Eastern Bridge Tournament yesterday by defeating by 1,170 points a team made up of Jesse Slutt, J. Horace Block, Harold D. Ziman, Julius Tilles and Seymour Kaplan.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- Mrs. Elizabeth Dilling of Chicago was fined $25 and Mrs. Clara H. Nibberich of St. Louis $15 today on disorderly conduct charges arising from their participation in a demonstration against the British-aid bill.

Dr. Frank D. Graham, Professor of Economics and Social Institutions of Princeton University, told members of the Commodity Club of New York at a dinner meeting yesterday in the Park Central Hotel that this country must meet the prospective slump after the peak of the armaments boom is passed resolutely or "we may expect social upheaval, since people are no longer willing to starve for the gold standard."

Robert Nathan, speaking of his forthcoming novel, "They Went on Together," says it is an attempt to picture bitterness that falls short of becoming despair. The story is of a family in a small community, forced to evacuate its home along with other townspeople.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The general level of wholesale prices, although fluctuating within a very narrow range, rose in the week ended on March 1, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 80.5 for the week ended on March 1, compared with 80.4 on Feb. 22, 80.5 on Feb. 15 and 78.4 on March 2, 1940.

An index listing importers and wholesalers of British-made goods and the stocks they have on hand in the United States will be issued on April 1 by the import committee of the British Empire Chamber of Commerce, 587 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Captain George V. Richardson, of the liner Manhattan, was held chiefly responsible for the grounding of the vessel off the Florida coast on the night of Jan. 12, and his license was suspended for eight months by R.S. Field, director of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation, in an order made public here today.
I think it is about time that laymen should be reminded that physicians are human beings and must eat and pay taxes.

With Modere Bruneteau beating Earl Robertson for four goals, the Red Wings smothered the New York Americans' chances for survival in the National Hockey League race last night. Jack Adams's speedy puck-chasers tallied twice in every period to beat the Dutton athletes, 6 to 1.

The 1,292 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $54,225,045,912 par value as of Feb. 28, had a total market value of $50,277,456,796, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Jan. 31, there were 1,292 issues, aggregating $54,139,182,757 par value which had a total market value of $50,374,446,095.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A Treasury official recommended to the Temporary National Economic Committee today that a Federal agency receive authority to pass on mergers of all corporations with assets larger than $5,000,000, for example.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- A howling cross-wind from Tampa Bay blew the Yankees down to a defeat by the Cardinals today in their first exhibition game of the year at Waterfront Park. The score was 4 to 2. The game attracted 5,119 spectators.
Sweeping as the social and economic changes that the war is bringing to Britain will be, they will be gradual and evolutionary if Britain wins rather than violently revolutionary.

CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) -- Hog prices broke today after a 10-cent rise at the opening, with classes 230 pounds and above losing practically all of the advance. Top was $7.95 with choice 180 to 240-pound hogs bringing $7.65 to S7.90. Pork loin prices remained firm at 16 to 17 cents a pound, however.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Manufacturers' new business, both for durable and consumers' goods, rose to a new high record in January, substantially exceeding the December peak, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Writing "as enemy planes are overhead," Arthur P. Young of the Ministry of Labor and National Service, London, declared that "the spirit of the British people is excellent" in a letter received yesterday at the headquarters of the Episcopal Church, 281 Fourth Avenue.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 7 -- Jockey Wendell Earls, crack apprentice rider, suffered severe injuries in a first-race spill at Tropical Park today. Removed unconscious to a hospital, the boy was too ill to be X-rayed.

The week-end's approach, which holds the threat of a new thrust by the Nazi forces and the possibility of Turkey's being forced into the war, tempered down the recovery spirit of Thursday and the stock market adopted yesterday a more passive attitude.

Applause from more than 3,500 miles away echoed yesterday in the Rainbow Room in Rockefeller Center, where a score of small girls, refugees from England, joined with young Americans in circling the room in cotton frocks depicting the latest styles for juveniles from both countries.

MEXICO CITY, March 7 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla told the Senate today that if any foreign force should attack "any American nation," Mexico would assist in defense of the American continent.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- President Roosevelt today denounced jurisdictional strikes which are hampering defense production, and said that he might establish a board in Washington to deal with mediation and with long-range problems of many types involving labor.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Senate, in its first night session during the debate on the lease-lend bill, moved swiftly tonight toward probable passage of the measure tomorrow, with the Administration forces apparently in control of the situation, but facing obstacles when work is resumed tomorrow.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 7 -- Reprisals have been planned and already partly carried out by German authorities against the inhabitants of the Norwegian island in the Lofoten group which was raided by British forces and almost 10 per cent of whom voluntarily accompanied the British to England, it is learned here.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A denial charge of price fixing and combination or conspiracy to destroy competition has been entered with the Federal Trade Commission by the Wire Rope and Strand Manufacturers Association, three of its officers and sixteen member companies making about 95 per cent of the country's wire rope, the commission announced today.

Asserting that William M. Canning was an "impostor," Morris U. Schappes, a tutor in English at City College who has admitted that he was a member of the Communist party from 1934 to 1940, challenged the Rapp-Coudert committee yesterday "to prove that Mr. Canning ever was a member of the Communist party."

The appearance of the first sizable corporate loan in about a month lifted the volume of new bond financing to reach the public this week to $23,017,000, the largest total since the period ended Feb. 7, last. This compares with only $9,950,000 placed on the market last week and with $25,450,000 offered during this week a year ago.
Mayor La Guardia's Board of Disaster Control has made comprehensive plans for control of incendiary fires as a leading phase of the city's defense against aerial attack, it was learned yesterday.

The exhibition of paintings by Max Weber, which has been current at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, has been rehung on a slightly smaller scale and will continue on view through March 15.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 7 -- A German attack on Greek Macedonia and Thrace within forty-eight hours was predicted tonight by some neutral military observers.

The 1941 William H. Nichols gold medal of the New York section of the American Chemical Society, one of the high honors in chemical science, was presented last night to Dr. Linus Pauling, head of the division of chemistry and chemical engineering at the California Institute of Technology, Pasadena.

The decisive majorities by which the supporters of the lease-lend bill voted down amendments to that measure yesterday and last evening show clearly enough what the final result of the long debate will be. The bill will be passed, with votes to spare, and, as the Presiident has urged, without any restrictions which hamper effective aid to Britain.

ANKARA, March 7 (UP) -- Reports of an impending German attack across Turkey to Iraq and Britain's rich Mosul oil fields, attributed to the boasts of German Army officers in the Balkans, were brought to Ankara today by travelers.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 (AP) -- The Matson Navigation Company reported today that the high demand for ships in 1940 sent net income up to $5,372,843, or $3.24 a share, from $2,315,650, or $1.40 a share, in 1939.

With the new-crop months still in the lead, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday 4 to 17 points before profit-taking set in, resulting in final quotations showing net gains of 4 to 9 points. For the third successive day the distant positions established new seasonal highs, while the near months were within striking distance of their previous record set in January.

If the synopsis given to the press of the majority report by the Senate Campaign Expenditures Investigating Committee of its inquiry into the New Jersey elections of 1940 is correct, the signers are safe from any accusation of excessive intellection. There was a good deal of evidence of past irregularities and frauds but none of importance in regard to frauds of last year.

The spirit of the stolid Dutch burghers who withstood the might of Spain lives again in Amsterdam. For half a century Spain's steel-clad men-at-arms, as formidable and as feared in their day as are Hitler's tanks and bombers now, held the Low Countries. Again and again, under one leader after another, the Dutch fought and were defeated, rebelled and were suppressed.

Coming at a time when the life-insurance business is being subjected to critical examination by the Temporary National Economic Committee, the first annual report to policyholders issued by Lewis W. Douglas, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, is of more than routine in terest.
The new firm of Roberts Co. was organized yesterday by Dudley D. Roberts Jr., A. Hawley Peterson and Herbert R. Washer.

Thirty-three matches passed without a single major upset as the metropolitan senior A.A.U. wrestling championships opened in the gymnasium of the West Side Y.M.C.A. last night. All the defending champions and leading contenders won their encounters as the stage was set for the final rounds of competition tonight.

ATHENS, March 7 -- Tonight's General Headquarters communique announced that in the central sector in Albania the Italians had been dislodged from "naturally and artificially fortified positions" and that 1,050 prisoners, including officers, had been captured.

Strikes were called yesterday at the plants of the Moline Iron Works, Moline, Ill., and the Federal Motor Truck Company, Detroit, increasing to twenty-three the number of defense plants thus affected. Construction work at four Army projects also was disrupted by strikes.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Defense Commission announced tonight that a schedule of maximum prices for scrap iron and steel would be established soon at rates below current quotations.

ALBANY, March 7 -- A bill which would take the naming of the commissioners of elections for New York from the county committee members from Manhattan and Brooklyn and put it in the hands of State committee members from those boroughs has been introduced in the Assembly.

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in February totaled $25,171,449,682, a decline of 13.3 per cent from the preceding month but a gain of 10.2 per cent over February, 1940, and the largest for that month since February, 1937.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 7 -- After spending two days with the Atlantic Fleet in Vieques Sound, East of Puerto Rico, Secretary Knox said here this afternoon that the sound would be the fleet's new base. He revealed that during his tour yesterday he submerged to a depth of 55 feet in one of the Navy's latest submarines.

LACONIA-GILFORD, N.H., March 7 -- The greatest array of skiers in the nineteen-year history of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association was marking time tonight for the annual divisional championships scheduled for the $1,000,000 Belknap Mountain Recreation Center this week-end.

From surveys conducted by the British Institute of Public Opinion it has been learned that if the Axis is defeated the rank and file of the British public would like to see an invitation to the peace table go out to the United States, according to a report by Dr. George Gallup, director of the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Oliver A. Gottschalk, who succeeded Brig. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell as head of the WPA in this city last November, disclosed yesterday that he was leaving the Federal relief agency to serve under General Somervell in the construction division of the Army Quartermaster Corps.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The French Ambassador, Gaston Henry-Haye, revealed today that the British Government had refused to permit 300 tons of oatmeal to be carried through the blockade to unoccupied France aboard the Red Cross ship Exmouth being loaded at Jersey City.

LONDON, Saturday, March 8 (UP) -- More than 300 fugitives from the German occupation of Norway, together with some Nazis and a dozen Norwegian Nazi sympathizers captured Tuesday in the British raid on the Lofoten Islands, arrived in London by train about midnight.
ROME, March 7 -- Virginio Gayda, chief Fascist spokesman, announced today that "new British reinforcements are about to arrive on Greek territory despite the denials of the Greek and British radios."

LONDON, March 7 -- The Admiralty announced tonight that during the British Army's advance in Italian Somaliland the Royal Navy, in addition to bombarding Italian positions ashore, was able to inflict heavy shipping losses on the enemy.

The government's charges of fake stock sale losses, and a mysterious $100,000 loan to William Bioff, union leader, as factors in income tax frauds attributed to Joseph M. Schenck and Joseph H. Moskowitz were developed yesterday at their trial in Federal Court.

The Guild of Independent Schools, Hugh Ross conducting, gave its annual festival program at Carnegie Hall last night. The schools taking part were Allen-Stevenson, Barnard School for Boys, Barnard School for Girls, Birch-Wathen, Brearley, Browning, Buckley, Calhoun, Chapin, Collegiate, Dalton, Fieldston, Friends Seminary, Hewitt, Horace Mann School for Girls, Lenox, Nightingale-Bamford, Riverdale Country School, Riverdale Country School for Girls, St. Agatha, St. Bernard, Spence and Trinity.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 7 -- The first public hearing in the State Board of Social Welfare's inquiry into relief expenditures in Westchester County was held here today in the county office building, but the county supervisors who had been most caustic in criticizing "relief racketeers" and "relief floaters" failed to accept invitations to appear and testify.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 7 (AP) -- Under the big headline "Yugoslavia Refuses Help From Roosevelt," the Nazi newspaper Magyarsag printed a dispatch under a Washington dateline today purporting to disclose that the President had attempted to keep Yugoslavia out of the Axis.

BELGRADE, March 7 (UP) -- Yugoslavia was said in highly reliable quarters tonight to have agreed to a friendship and non-aggression pact with Germany, clearing the way for a German attack on Greece, unless that country capitulated to a dictated peace.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 7 (AP) -- It will be Bay View, Tony Pelleteri's surprise package of the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap, against the field tomorrow in the $50,000 San Juan Capistrano Handicap.

Reporting earnings of $7,582,617 for the year ended on Dec. 31, or 3.5 per cent of sales of $216,795,850 in the United States, Canada and export markets, Theodore G. Montague, president of the Borden Company, told its 47,396 stockholders and 27,080 employee in the company's eighty-third annual report, that last year's net was $397,220 less than in 1939 when profits were 3.8 per cent of sales of $208,789.250.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Rumors that much higher government loans on the 1941 wheat crop were in prospect upset the grain markets today, and with aggressive buying credited to short covering and reinstating of lines, plus increased commission house support, prices moved up readily with the close at the top.

BALTIMORE, March 7 (AP) -- Big Al Blozis and Mortimer Alnwick, Georgetown University team-mates, sent the University of Maryland-Fifth Regiment indoor track and field games off to a spectacular start tonight by setting new meet records in the shot-put and the 440-yard dash. All told, eight records were set.

Retail trade advanced seasonally this week and held a substantial gain over last year, despite the earlier date of Easter in 1940, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Wholesale activity was unusually good, as forward buying expanded over last year as much as 50 per cent. Production continued at record levels, while backlogs were increased further.
BERLIN, March 7 (UP) -- Newspapers today reported extensive British sabotage in Yugoslavia -- the same press technique that preceded German dominance of Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 7 -- To the 12,000 enlisted men and officers garrisoned here will be served standard menus, starting April 1, a month before the entire Army is scheduled to go on a three-month trial of the field ration system.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 7 -- The Turkish Parliament will reassemble Monday in the usual course after the Winter recess. It is believed that on Monday Foreign Minister Shukru Saracoglu will give a resume of recent political events to the government party in private session.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 7 -- The British forces north of Ferfer, having crossed the Italian Somaliland line on Wednesday, were driving into Southern Ethiopia today. Although a few Italians were retreating northward along the Shebeli Valley ahead of the British, resistance was slight and the British were moving rapidly even for an unopposed army.

The other night we attended the annual dinner of the Connecticut Ducks Unlimited boys, and although the reports given at the meeting indicated that the contribution fell off a bit during 1940, it was very apparent that the enthusiasm for the cause was as high as ever.

I was a spectator at the basketball game between Seton Hall and Baltimore University last Saturday at Seton Hall. I have no connection with either institution but merely attended in the role of one interested in seeing a good match between an undefeated team and another apparently strong quintet.

LONDON, March 7 (AP) -- British airmen sank a 2,500-ton German supply ship and blasted at the harbor of Den Helder, the Netherlands, today in a renewal of the North Sea thrusts which, the Air Ministry said, already have virtually crippled Germany's Kiel Canal.

Administration of the Securities and Exchange Commission has been geared into the national defense effort, Sumner T. Pike, a member of that body, told the New York Security Dealers Association at its fifteenth annual dinner last night in the Hotel Commodore.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an average increase of 11.6 per cent for February in comparison with the like month of last year, according to a compilation yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The percentage rise was smaller than that for January, when a gain of 12.2 per cent was reported.

C.E. Groesbeck, chairman of the board of the Electric Bond and Share Company, informed stockholders of the company yesterday in his annual report for 1940 that the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act present "serious problems" to the company and its affiliated units.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Assemblyman Barrett of Suffolk introduced a bill which would make New York State a party to the proposed Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Compact. The bill is sponsored in the Senate by Walter Stokes of Cooperstown. Mr. Barrett is chairman of the subcommittee on fisheries of the legislative committee on Interstate Cooperation.

The first performance of "Don Giovanni" this season, given yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House under Bruno Walter's direction, was the finest interpretation of Mozart that the writer has witnessed in this lyric theatre. It made history for the institution and did honor to its traditions.
It may be unfair to suggest that the writer of Topics of The Times should be held accountable for his facts. One with so light a touch should perhaps enjoy a broad license in his references.

VICHY, France, March 7 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain after a conference today with General Maxime Weygand, defender of France's African colonies, let it be known that he had renewed his full confidence in the Delegate General.

The Udell Stationery and Printing Company has leased new quarters in the building at 683-5 Broadway, and soon will terminate a tenancy of more than half a century at 82 Bleecker Street, according to Frederick Fox Co., Inc., who arranged the rental, which calls for a store and basement.

Commemorating the ninety-first anniversary of the birth of Thomas Garrique Masaryk, first President of the Czecho-Slovak Republic, about 2,000 men, women and children of the Czecho-Slovak colonies in the metropolitan area gathered at two meetings here last night to sing, watch patriotic tableaux and listen to talks in praise of the dead leader's ideals.

HITLER'S most successful secret weapon was "Mein Kampf." In it he told the world precisely what he planned to do yet the appeasing statesmen who should have opposed him allowed him to go right ahead with his plans until well after ("Peace in our time") Munich. They professed not to believe he was as bad as he said he was.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 -- Conflict over the appearance of Lillian Gish in the screen version of "Ladies in Retirement" at Columbia broke out today, with the statement by Lester Cowan, who will produce the film in association with Gilbert Miller, that Miss Gish has agreed verbally to play one of the Creed Sisters in the picture if she approves the scenario.

The first instance of a definite curtailment in a civilian goods line demanded as necessary to national defense developed yesterday when E.R. Stettinius Jr., director of priorities, Office of Production Management, issued an order to makers of mechanical refrigerators limiting the number of aluminum ice trays in refrigerators.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 8 (UP) -- French and Japanese negotiators still were wrangling over the phraseology of a peace treaty to end the border conflict between French Indo-China and Thailand but it appeared today that a final agreement would be reached during the week-end.

ROME, March 7 (UP) -- Virginio Gayda, principal spokesman for Premier Benito Mussolini, asserted today that Britain had at least 50,000 troops in Greece, "with new reinforcements arriving steadily," but that Greece's Bulgarian flank was unprotected against a German attack.

A strike of drivers and mechanics employed on the bus lines of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation, effective some time Monday morning, was unanimously voted last night by 2,500 day shift workers at a mass meeting held under the auspices of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, in Royal Windsor Hall, Sixty-sixth Street and Columbus Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- W. Averell Harriman made his final call on President Roosevelt today before departing for London. He left the White House with a personal letter to the British Government, and the assurance that two assistants would follow him to Britain.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- In 55 per cent of tests of the relative efficiency of large, medium and small business which were conducted by the Federal Trade Commission for the Temporary National Economic Committee, medium businesses were the most efficient, the committee reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Moving again in its policy to preserve first call on vital materials for defense industries, the Office of Production Management today imposed formal industry-wide priorities on nickel and neoprene, a form of synthetic rubber.

The Western Electric Company will care for its expanding business as a result of the leasing of a one story structure with 60,000 square feet of space on West Grand Avenue, Roselle, N.J. The property was leased from the Industrial Realty Corporation of Philadelphia through J.I. Kislak, broker, and will be used for storage purposes.

The New York University women's swimming team defeated the Temple co-eds in the Evangeline Pool yesterday, 33 to 23. The closest struggle developed in the 40-yard breast-stroke race, which was won by Miss Helene Rains of N.Y.U. Miss Beulah Buek and Miss Eleanor Vogt, both of Temple, pressed the victor all the way and trailed in the order named.

HAVANA, March 7 -- During the dangerous days of several years ago cautious Cubans were wont to respond to any query concerning the political question with "Vamos a hablar de pelota!" or more crisply, "Hablamos de pelota!" which means "Let's talk about baseball."

CAIRO, Egypt, March 7 (AP) -- The final conquest of Italian Somaliland was proclaimed today by a military spokesman at British General Headquarters. He said that all the Italian troops who had not surrendered or fallen in combat were fleeing into Ethiopia.

President Roosevelt yesterday endorsed Dean Alfange, Democratic candidate for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, after Mr. Alfange had called upon him at Washington. After the President had talked with Mr. Alfange he authorized the following statement, which was made public here at the Alfange campaign headquarters, 2181 Broadway:

Two runners will be making their first start in the Columbian Mile tonight, but so rapidly does the track picture change that Leslie MacMitchell and Walter Mehl are the magnets that will draw a capacity gathering of 15,000 to Madison Square Garden for the Knights of Columbus meet, climax of the indoor track season.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7 -- Recognition of the possibility of a processing tax and a concession of the right of mills to add this to invoice prices on defense purchases of cotton goods were seen yesterday in an announcement by the War Department that a clause in bids would provide for such addition to invoices.

Father Divine, Harlem cult leader who is known to his followers as "God," was under technical arrest in the New York County Sheriff's office for an hour and forty minutes yesterday as a result of his failure to pay a $5,949 judgment obtained against him last year.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Feb. 22 was 2,019,860 shares, compared with 2,880,780 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The proportion of total round-lot trading represented by transactions for member account was 16.61 per cent, against 14.13 per cent.

A total of 2,271 registrants from New York City were inducted into the Army during the first week of the sixth draft call, which ended yesterday. Of this number, 605 were sent to camp from the two induction centers yesterday. During the week, 2,715 were examined and 444 were rejected.
BERLIN, March 7 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:
An 11-point spurt late in the final half swept Manhattan College's cagers to a 54-to-47 victory over Fordham before 2,200 basketball enthusiasts in the latter's gymnasium last night.

The Russian Student Fund is now in its twenty-first year. It began as a friendly aid to the young nationals of a revolutionary Government, but after the overthrow of that Government by Lenin continued as an educational refuge for victims of Soviet terror. It has so functioned ever since, and in the process has developed some useful contributors to American progress.
The annual report of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, issued yesterday, reveals a net profit for 1940 of $2,334,261 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges.

Lessons to be learned from the penitential season in a war-torn world will be discussed by pastors in sermons tomorrow, the second Sunday in Lent. Protestant clergymen will quote from a pamphlet issued by the Presbyterian denomination entitled "A Lenten Tryst -- 1941: It all depends on me: I depend on God."
I had been a sport reporter for the "Express Illustrowany" and "Republica" and correspondent of the "Trzeglad Sportowy" and some other Polish and foreign newspapers.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor joined the Congress of Industrial Organizations today in opposing the Dirksen bill giving shipmasters the final say in hiring seamen and providing for compulsory arbitration of maritime labor disputes and rigid control of subversive propaganda at sea.

Billy Soose, the Farrell, Pa., middleweight, had a much easier job subduing Ernie Vigh last night than he had with the same opponent a month ago. Scoring a knockdown in the first round and boxing expertly enough to earn seven more rounds by a clear margin, the Pennsylvanian gained the unanimous decision over the Newburgh, N.Y., battler in the twelve-round battle that featured the card at Madison Square Garden.

PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, March 8 -- Nearly 5,000 employes of the Midvale Steel Company voted by about two to one in favor of a proposal to put all three working shifts on a seven-day, fifty-six hour week, with time and a half pay for overtime, "in the interests of the national defense emergency," it was announced early today.

Milton B. Logan, 50 years old, the president of the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., formerly at 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, which became bankrupt in the latter part of 1939, was found guilty last evening by a General Sessions jury of defrauding nine of its patrons of $65,000 that had been paid into the concern by purchasers of their art objects at auction sales.

Brooklyn Museum has an answer to the charge made by Park Commissioner Robert Moses that museums are musty in an exhibit of streamlined headgear, described by museum authorities as both "fabulous and functional."

ROME, March 7 (UP) -- Don Juan, in his first public speech since he became pretender to the Spanish throne on the death of his father, Alfonso XIII, asserted today that "when the day comes -- as it will soon," he was ready to return to Spain and re-establish the monarchy.

BERLIN, March 7 -- There are now reports received here from Balkan capitals that President Roosevelt in February sought to influence the government of Yugoslavia against any further rapprochement with the Axis powers, and that he offered to guarantee the integrity of the Yugoslav State in the event that it would resist efforts to bring it into the Axis sphere of influence.

With activity in the new-issue market for corporate loans dependent largely upon the day-to-day condition of the market, investment interest will center early next week on the competitive sale of $19,600,000 New York State serial housing bonds.

In his sharp criticism yesterday of jurisdictional strikes, and in making it clear at his press conference that he is becoming more convinced of the necessity for establishing some new form of over-all Federal mediation to avert strikes on the defense program, the President incidentally revealed that the strike situation, in his opinion, is more important than the recent minute percentage figure cited by him might imply.

If Hitler should win the war the situation of the Jews in Europe will become increasingly serious and Jews in other parts of the world will be under additional pressure, Wendell L. Willkie said in an interview given to Joel Slonim of The Day, Jewish daily, in today's issue of that paper.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 7 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos of Lake Hopatcong, N.J., went down to defeat today at the hands of 17-year-old Miss Georgia Tainter of Fargo, N.D., 3 and 1, in the semi-final round of the Florida East Coast women's championship on the St. Augustine Links. Miss Mary Agnes Wall of Menominee, Mich., subdued Miss Louise Suggs, Georgia State champion, 2 and 1, in the other match.

The plea that Harriet Mitchell of Chicago made last week for the inclusion of women's track events in the Pan-American Games leaves this correspondent completely stunned. The lady from the Midwest said that women track athletes are as interesting to watch as men. Shade of Mercury!

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Many changes in Marine Corps officer commands, involving mainly the Fleet Force in the Pacific, the Fourth Marines on duty at Shanghai and Guam, and the marine base at San Diego, were reported today.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 7 -- Conspicuous among the plants in this area doing extensive defense work is the United Aircraft Corporation, which has expanded production in its engine and propeller works sixfold in two years.

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $3,000,000 of unemployment relief bonds of Providence, R.I., on a bid of 101.209 for 2s. The bonds, dated April 1, 1941, and maturing serially on April 1, 1942 to 1961, were re-offered to yield 0.30 to 2 per cent, according to maturity.

Judge Saul S. Streit in General Sessions revealed yesterday that psychiatrists at Bellevue Hospital had reported William and Anthony Esposito, the ex-convict brothers who are awaiting trial on first-degree murder indictments in the hold-up shooting of a civilian and Traffic Patrolman Edward F. Maher last Jan. 14, at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, are not insane.
BOSTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Boston Olympics broke even in a two-game series with the New York Rovers by overwhelming their Eastern Amateur Hockey League rivals, 6 -- 1, tonight at the Boston Garden.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 7 -- War Minister Peter Pesitch and Vice Premier Vladimir Matchek returned to the palace late today while Belgrade political and diplomatic circles seethed with rumors of a new government crisis and desperate efforts by Regent Prince Paul to find a new Premier for an emergency government.

Since the inception of the Adolescent Court in Brooklyn on Jan. 8, 1935, the Brooklyn Big Brother Movement has served as a cooperating social agency for supervision of Protestant boys referred to us by the court. Of the 169 cases thus far that have come into our program from this source, it has been necessary to send only one to a correctional institution.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for sale next week by thirty-eight municipalities aggregates $26,707,469, compared with $18,547,339 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date stands at $36,689,963.

TOKYO, March 7 -- Believing that the "settlement" of the Indo-Chinese-Thai dispute marks an end to the recent "Pacific crisis," political and financial circles today regained some of their lost buoyancy. Shipping and textile shares rose moderately and the Tokyo Stock Exchange shares, which are the market's favorite gambling counter and the most reliable barometer of its sentiment, gained 3 points.

By taking away a little here and adding a little there the Republicans at Albany have whittled a bookkeeping saving of $1,486,769 and an actual saving of $181,791 out of Governor Lehman's budget. The bookkeeping item which makes the difference between these two figures represents a transfer of grade-crossing funds from a dormant to an active account.

Reading that a shortage of many kinds of skilled labor has been developing because of the defense program, I am wondering if a particularly promising supply of really skilled workers is not being overlooked. I refer to the farm workers; and don't smile at my classifying them as skilled.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 7 (UP) -- The semi-official Hungarian news agency said tonight that the reported Yugoslav-German accord would entail Yugoslav submission to the following demands, among others:

National educational activities regarding food and nutrition as factors in defense soon will be in operation on a scale comparable to that of the World War and may lead to permanent establishment of a national food and nutrition administration, M.L. Wilson, director of extension work of the Department of Agriculture, declared yesterday.
LONDON, March 7 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:
CAIRO, Egypt, March 7 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

More than 1,000 members and guests of the American Bankers Association applauded their president, P.D. Houston, as he publicly pledged their cooperation yesterday to the Treasury in the emergency financing plans of the government even in advance of their formulation.

Sales of the Weco Products Company, makers of Dr. West's toothbrushes, in January and February achieved a new all-time high, it was reported yesterday at the company's twenty-first annual sales convention for distributors, attended by about 450 representatives at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A blinding snowstorm that hit the city from the South shortly after 7:30 o'clock last night and had deposited more than seven and one-half inches of snow by 1:30 A.M. today reached blizzard proportions, grounding airplanes and hampering transportation.

AMSTERDAM, March 7 -- Today's Bourse rallied under the influence of the Indo-Chinese Thailand settlement, Wall Street's overnight strength, and the declaration by Amsterdam Trading of a 12 1/2 per cent interim dividend.

Today's events: "Alceste," 2 P.M., and "La Boheme," 8:30 P.M., Metropolitan Opera House; Josef Hofmann, piano, Carnegie Hall, 3 P.M.; Hugo Balzo, piano, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P.M.; Williams College Glee Club, Town Hall, evening; Sidney Sukoenig, piano recital, under the auspices of Kappa Mu Epsilon, Hunter College Auditorium, 8:30 P.M.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Some proposed new naval auxiliary vessels, such as cargo ships and tank-

Two strong teams of four emerged last night from the semi-finals of the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy match to play off tonight for the championship of the Eastern Bridge Tournament in the Park Central Hotel.

For the fourth consecutive month Germany has shipped United States currency to New York -- currency that it had gathered in Europe and shipped here to swell its dollar balances. This was revealed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly report on exports and imports of United States currency.

The quick tempo of the imagination of one who has not dealt with dress design as a profession was brought to bear upon the suits and dresses displayed at the opening of the new shop of Chez Ninon yesterday morning. The work was that of Jean Schlumberger.

ROME, March 7 -- The departure of Count Dino Grandi, former Italian Ambassador to London, for army service was disclosed today with the announcement that Premier Mussolini had removed him from his duties as Minister of Justice.
DOVER, Del., March 7 -- The Delaware Legislature repealed tonight the State's 200-year-old Sunday blue laws and adopted a liberalized substitute.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, will fly to Europe on a good will preaching mission in England and Scotland, it became known yesterday. A leave of absence for this purpose was granted him by the session of his church at a special meeting Thursday evening.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Senator Tobey of New Hampshire, filing statements apart from the report of the committee investigating campaign expenditures, asked a Congressional investigation of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, N.J.; charged that Oliver A. Quayle, Democratic national committee leader, had "lied brazenly and unhesitatingly" to the committee; questioned $300,000 lent to Democrats by R.J. Reynolds, and criticized primary expenditures by Senator Radcliff, Democrat, of Maryland.

BOSTON, March 7 -- Although buyer attendance at the Boston Furniture Show this week was 15 per cent greater than during last year's Spring market, buying on the average was only slightly better and did not measure up to the expectations of the 225 exhibitors.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 7 -- Mr. and Mrs. Angus Duncan Mackintosh, who are visiting her mother, Mrs. Woods Plankinton, gave a barbecue dinner tonight at Casa de los Ensuenos. A trio played for dancing.
The prize racquets match of the year is scheduled for 2 o'clock this afternoon at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

LONDON, March 7 (AP) -- Britain is speeding enough captured Italian military supplies to Greece to equip an entire army corps and some of this equipment already is in use against its former owners in Albania, a neutral military source said today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Ohio Power Company of Canton, Ohio, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement and application covering $15,000,000 of first- mortgage bonds due in 1971 and 202,403 shares of cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value.

Despite the fiscal situation created by the defense emergency program there is little likelihood that Congress will enact legislation to remove the tax exemption from State and municipal bonds, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Municipal Bond Club, held at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 7 (UP) -- Threats of a "token bombing" of Salonika by German planes to force Greece into a quick peace with Italy was foreseen tonight as great masses of Nazi troops, tanks and mechanized units moved to the Turkish and Greek frontiers.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Deaths of infants less than 1 year old, exclusive of still births, were 108,846 in 1939 as compared with 116,702 in 1938, the Census Bureau reported today.

WITH the holding of the K. of C. meet at Madison Square Garden tonight, the indoor track season will be on its last leg, the anchor leg. The twin stars of the board floor and banked turn campaign have been Leslie MacMitchell, the 20-year-old junior at N.Y.U., and Greg Rice, a distinguished alumnus of Notre Dame.

In one of five leases for quarters in the building at 365 West End Avenue, Osias Ganz, diamond dealer, formerly of Belgium, has taken an eight-room suite through the Kempner Realty Corporation, managing agents. The same firm also rented units there to Philip Rothman, Michael Ferman, Harry Pressman and Morton Becker.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 7 (AP) -- Syracuse's favored forces fortified their position tonight in the opening session of the annual Eastern Intercollegiate Boxing Association tourney by placing six men in tomorrow afternoon's semi-finals and a seventh in the finals at night.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., March 7 -- The Twenty-seventh Division News this week published three letters which show the high esteem in which Alabamians hold the officers and men from New York who are training at Fort McClellan.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 7 (AP) -- John P. Altwater, vice president, said tonight that the Moran Transportation Company would file suit for $150,000 against C.I.O. leaders and seek an injunction restraining them "from interfering with the company's business."

Saida Knox, Scotch-American contralto, was heard in her first local recital last night in Town Hall. Miss Knox, who is a soloist at St. Bartholomew's Church, won a $5,000 prize in an Atwater Kent nationwide vocal contest ten years ago, but with commendable constraint waited until she was competent to make a New York debut before venturing on that ordeal.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, inspected yesterday a mobile tea kitchen, which was brought here recently by the British War Relief Society after having seen six months of service in the war areas of Britain. At a ceremony in front of City Hall, Mr. Morris presented a large bronze medal to the driver of the vehicle, which will be taken on a tour of the country.

One hundred and thirty-three students at City College have been appointed to command the college Reserve Officers Training Corps, which is the largest voluntary unit in the nation, it was announced yesterday by Colonel Oliver P. Robinson, Professor of Military Science and Tactics.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Two doctors and two medical organizations, on trial for violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act by hampering Group Health Association, Inc., were cleared today through a directed verdict by Justice James M. Proctor in the District of Columbia Federal court.

People must have often found themselves wondering whether the Communist party does not consist almost entirely of persons who live by clipping coupons, collecting rents and similar agreeable and easy occupations. To this conclusion people must have been driven by the fact that one so very rarely found a Communist engaged in one of the regular trades or professions.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the Coudert bill, which would have helped Republican chances in the special congressional election in the Seventeenth Congressional District by eliminating an early morning voting hour and adding two extra hours in the evening.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 7 -- A report from Washington this morning that Congress might take legislative action to keep the National Guard in the Federal service for more than twelve months came as no surprise to New York and New Jersey National Guard officers on duty here with the Forty-fourth Division, federalized last September.
Has any one explained why it is the armories of New York State have been closed to athletic events they housed in the past?

MIAMI, Fla., March 7 -- A long workout of offensive and defensive manoeuvres today concluded Manager Bill Terry's preparations for resumption of the Giants' exhibition schedule. Games are booked for tomorrow and Sunday with Joe Cronin's Red Sox.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- The National Association of Retail Druggists has answered the repeal request of Thurman W. Arnold, Assistant United States Attorney General, with a seventy-eight-page formal brief in defense of the Miller-Tydings Fair Trade Enabling Act, it was learned at headquarters here today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Congress may be asked soon after April 1 to increase taxes on incomes and excess profits to meet defense costs in 1942 as far as possible out of current revenue, according to reports today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Some of the proposed naval auxiliary vessels in the 200,000-ton increase proposed in the pending Vinson Bill may be destined for the British Navy under the lease-lend bill, Rear Admiral R.E. Ingersoll, Assistant Chief of Naval Operations, admitted today under questioning by the House Naval Affairs Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Ten ways to strengthen the Hatch act and other corrupt practices law were suggested by the Committee on Campaign Expenditures in its report to the Senate today. The report recommended that these suggestions be studied by the Committee on Privileges and Election, with a view of submitting amendments to the existing laws.

Several automobile showrooms will open displays of cars in Spring colors today to launch their Spring sales campaign. Special vehicles and other exhibits will be displayed against floral backgrounds at the shows.

LONDON, Saturday, March 8 -- While uniformed men of all branches of the British armed forces maintained their incessant guard against German invasion -- the threat of which looms more menacing as Summer weather approaches -- millions in this country slept peacefully early today when Nazi war planes once again failed to deliver raiding blows.

With sales comparisons now affected by the earlier Easter a year ago, smaller percentage gains are reported for this week by department stores here. Estimates indicated the week's sales are running about 3 per cent ahead of the like period in 1940, with final figures to be governed by the volume today.

Twenty more members of New York college faculties, sixteen of them on the City College payroll, were named yesterday as belonging or having belonged to the Communist party, and were charged with using their academic positions to instill communistic doctrines into the minds of their young students.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The House passed today without a record vote the $193,913,093 first deficiency bill after writing into it a provision making it a criminal offense for any person advocating overthrow of the government to receive one penny in compensation for services.

Three shows will depart from the Broadway scene tonight. In order of their longevity they are "It Happened on Ice," 180 performances; "Cabin in the Sky," 156 performances, and "Twelfth Night," 129 performances. The three attractions will be sent on tour.

Twentieth Century-Fox's "That Night in Rio" will have its world premiere this morning at the Roxy. Alice Faye, Don Ameche and Carmen Miranda head the cast of the musical romance, which has a South American background. J. Carrol Naish, S.Z. Sakall, Curt Bois and Leonid Kinskey are some of the supporting players in the technicolor production. . . .

The market on steer hinds and ribs was unsettled yesterday and demand was limited. Veal hindsaddle prices also were weak. Lamb and fresh pork values were generally steady, as were the markets on cow and bull beef. In the kosher trade, supply of steer chucks and plates as well as veal and lamb foresaddles was below normal for Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- One plan for aid to Great Britain when the lease-lend bill becomes law calls for the handing over of Britain's direct investments in this country to the United States Government as collateral against the defense materials furnished to her.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 7 -- The political tendency for the moment is decidedly toward the left in the first readjustment after last Sunday's Congressional elections.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., March 7 -- Captain William T. Hudnell Jr. of the Eighth Pursuit Group here received today a Distinguished Flying Cross at last. For more than a month Army officials have been trying to make the presentation, but something always intervened. Four times previously the event was scheduled for a Saturday.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- President Roosevelt said at a press conference today that he was opposed to jurisdictional labor strikes which hamper the defense program and that some form of an over-all Federal mediation mechanism might be created to handle the problem. He criticized Congressional delay in passing the lease-lend bill. He conferred with Secretary Wickard and with W. Averell Harriman.

The executive committee of Local 16, Aluminum Workers of America, was empowered yesterday by a poll among the employes to call a strike at the Edgewater plant of the Aluminum Company of America if the management refuses to grant demands of the union. The vote was 1,641 in favor of the strike authorization and 65 opposed.

VICHY, France, March 7 -- The beginnings of a form of economic collaboration between the French and Germans were laid down during Vice Premier Francois Darlan's visit to Paris, it was learned upon his return here today.

In THE TIMES of March 1 your Berlin correspondent reported on an article by General Paul Hasse in the Oestdeutsche Beobachter, in which an attempt is made to build up a Bulgarian case on portions of territories lost as a result of her joining Germany in the World War.

As a tribute to the Greater New York Fund, which starts its annual campaign next month, the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, will open on Tuesday an exhibition entitled "This Is Our City." The exhibition will include oils, water-colors, drawings and prints.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The War Department issued the following statement today with reference to a Washington dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES of this morning, which also appeared in The Washington Post.

I see that Manager Bill Terry lately has been bemoaning the fact that the Giants have neither the money nor the trading material to acquire new players. I'll admit they have no trading material, but as for the money -- pish, tush, etc.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- A Federal Power Commission trial examiner asserted today that "ill advised political adventures" of five Oregon and Washington utilities had "not surprisingly alarmed public opinion in the Northwest."

Two hours after he had been indicted by the Bronx grand jury for the first-degree murder of Mrs. Catherine Papas, George Joseph Cvek submitted yesterday at his own request to an interview by newspaper men in the office of District Attorney Samuel J. Foley.

PITTSBURGH, March 7 -- The United States Steel Corporation was notified today by the Steel Workers Organizing Committee of the rejection of the corporation's offer to increase the wages of 261,000 employes, by 2.5 cents an hour provided that steel operations remained above 85 per cent of capacity.

The General Exchange Insurance Company in its annual statement as of Dec. 31, 1940, reports total admitted assets of $37,297,091, compared with $36,255,808 at the close of the previous year. The assets include bonds at book value of $12,861,105, compared with $13,866,844 at end of 1939; stocks of $6,461,876, against $7,582,281; cash and deposits of $14,502,512 were increased from $10,770,597.
Mr. Perkins's letter replying to Borough President Isaacs's protest regarding the proposed road through Palisades Interstate Park is far from convincing to me.

AIX EN PROVENCE, France, March 7 -- A visit to the shelter center for foreigners in France, established at Milles near Gere, gives evidence of the active efforts that are being made to improve the situation of the foreigners interned in France.

THE wild geese have started to fly from the South to the Arctic, and that means that it is time to take Spring coats under serious consideration. Here are facts worth knowing about the wrap to wear in town.

The plan for reorganization of the Florida East Coast Railway proposed by the trustees of the estate of Alfred I. du Pont not only would forestall the dilution of security values but will provide needed working capital, it was said yesterday by W.H. Goodman, vice president and trust officer of the Florida National Bank, of Jacksonville, Fla., and a trustee of the estate.

THE stage appears to be set for another stirring act in the long and turbulent drama of the Dardanelles. The Straits -- collective name for the Dardanelles, the Sea of Marmara and the Bosporus -- link the Aegean arm of the Mediterranean to the Black Sea, divide Europe from Asia, and have been a prize of empire from time immemorial.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Roosevelt declared in a radio address tonight that "the democratic way of life" in the United States could not survive "the death of democracy over the rest of the earth."
LONDON, Sunday. March 9 (AP) -Londoners were killed, wounded or trapped in piles of debris last night and early today in the Nazis' first heavy night air raid on the British capital in weeks.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 8 -- Despite trends toward other sports that vary with the seasons, aquatic pastimes remain perennial favorites here. Colonists spend long hours in the water and on the beaches for both health and pleasure.

A new addition to the group of commodity exchanges in New York, a market for American-type Sumatra tobacco, will take up headquarters in the "free trade zone" on Staten Island in April. According to Carel Goldschmidt, one of the brokers who is responsible for the establishing of the market, a building equipped with humidifying apparatus and special lights is now being constructed in the foreign trade zone to house the exchange.

"One of the most horrifying series of murders in modern times," the first-person narrator calls the crimes in "The Longbow Murder." It seemed to him, indeed, that he must be back in the Dark Ages: "I could scarce believe that such things could happen in the twelfth century."

The parasol ants up at the Bronx Zoo got into the newspapers the other day by the simple expedient of refusing to eat anything except hothouse roses at 90 cents a throw. Fallen petals and leaf clippings weren't good enough. When they were offered them the ants got mad and ate each other instead.

Sponsored by the British-American Ambulance Corps, a "Dress for Britain" cocktail party and fashion show will be held Friday afternoon at the Sherry-Netherland. Spring and Summer dresses, hats, bags, play suits and blouses made from forty different patterns employing British symbols or slogans will be modeled by a committee of debutantes under the leadership of Miss Hope Carroll.

A STORM of controversy is raging over the proposal to abandon New York's Battery Park Aquarium and construct a new one in the Bronx Zoological Park. The outcome of the proposal remains in doubt, but if there is a new aquarium it is likely to draw inspiration from Florida's unique Marineland at the sea's edge eighteen miles south of St. Augustine.

Those who are up betimes of a Summer morning get the most out of their gardens. For one thing, the lie-abeds miss the first flush of the beauty that members of the large convolvulus (morning-glory) family bring with the rising of-the sun.

The coming air battles in Europe will depend on quality of planes as well as upon quantity. It is certain that the Germans have improved some of the types that bore the brunt of the battles of last year, and may have in production startling new models, though little is known about them.

As preparations were under way for the first rally to stimulate enrollment of reserve nurses for Army and Navy service, heads of professional groups were concerned last week with the question of how to expand educational plans to provide a still greater number thought to be essential for the defense program.
