ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 8 -- Miss Georgia Tainter of Fargo, N.D., captured the Florida East Coast women's championship on the St. Augustine links today by defeating Miss Mary Agnes Wall of Menominee, Mich., in a thrilling extra-hole final, 1 up.

ONE of the major photographic events of each year is the Pictorial Photographers of America exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History. The eighth annual salon is now being displayed in Education Hall at the museum and will remain through March 28.

THE original Colonies had been settled and the forms of cultural life there, including architecture, had been established before men crossed the mountains to make their homes in the wilderness beyond. But to Kentucky there went, not long after the pioneers, men and women of the same sturdy substance as those who had built great plantation homes in Virginia and the Carolinas.

THE death of the former Spanish sovereign, Alfonso XIII, at Rome on Feb. 28, removed a figure whose likeness was on the postal paper of his kingdom for forty-two years. Few faces have been more familiar to collectors than that of Alfonso.

The new Spring shoes deserve a certain amount of raving. They are perfectly lovely in the hand, they are flattering to the foot and there is practically none of the outlandish stuff around that used to look so marvelous in a fancy store window and so deformed on the foot.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 8 -- Training of the Forty-fourth Division's experimental ski patrol was so successful that the commander, Lieutenant Eric Wikner, may recommend transfer of the twenty-man patrol as a single unit to Fort Lewis, Wash.; Fort Douglas, Utah, or one of the Alaskan garrisons to continue year-round training.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 8 -- A fast and elusive Yale five toppled Harvard, 54 -- 40, in the Harvard gym tonight in the first of the annual two-game series.

MADRID, March 8 -- Although the Italian Embassy has announced that, despite numerous and increasing requests, Spaniards will not be permitted to volunteer "in Italy" for service in the Italian Army, there is not exactly a tidal wave of enthusiasm here for such enlistment in Italy or elsewhere.

"CHARLEY'S AUNT" will go on tour this Spring, since tickets now are on hand only until the end of the month, but may be ordered through Easter. The idea would be that the revival wander around for eight weeks or so, and then settle down for a Summer's run in Chicago, where all road shows seem to be headed.

The question of mobilizing women for work in the case of an emergency will be discussed at a luncheon to be given on Saturday by the College and University Women's Center at the Hotel Biltmore. The event will launch officially the center's Volunteer Service Bureau, recently set up to register college women for work they are best equipped to do.

Bulgaria, occupied by the German army last week, becomes No. 12 in the list of countries Adolf Hitler has overrun or brought under his domination during the last three years. By Blitzkrieg methods or by threat of them he has added to a Germany which covered 182,471 square miles, with a population of some 70,000,000 at this time three years ago, a controlled and dominated area four times as large.

NEW is a smooth, creamy, yellow cheese soup in a can. It is accented by the sharp, dry flavor of celery . . . If housewives, hearing of quick-frozen orange juice, already well known in hospitals and in some restaurants, are disappointed not to find it in New York retail stores, they may be happy to learn that most of the limited supply went to Camp Dix.
WHEN Toscanini recently conducted "Voices of Spring" waltz he put in some quick speed-ups in a rather hop-skip-and-jump manner for which there seemed to be no necessity.

Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran warned yesterday that he would feel impelled to abolish the 5-year-old Adolescents Court in Brooklyn should the Legislature fail to pass pending bills to permit establishment of such a court in Manhattan.

BERLIN, March 8 -- Germany's prohibition of American movies is justified as a "necessity forced on us by America and demanded by our national honor and political self defense" by Fritz Hippler, head of the cinema department of the Reich Ministry of Propaganda.

BOOM days have returned to the nursing profession -- relatively speaking. Conscription alone might not have brought them. Nor perhaps could the current prevalence of mild forms of "flu." But conscription and influenza together created a current acute shortage of trained personnel.

THE rugged-looking gentleman, measuring six feet two, was slouched deep in the easy chair and had a contented expression on his tanned face. He looked like a leading contender for the heavyweight title, well pleased on that morning after the victory of the night before.

ALMOST any day now strange new radio calls will begin to flash through the New York air. The calls will resemble nothing previously heard on the radio. In fact, they will differ so markedly in phonetic resemblance from ordinary radio call letters that casual dialers might suspect some interplanetary Buck Rogers exploit.

It is not possible at the hour of writing to say as much about the remarkable performances of Mr. Szell as they deserve. He is evidently a conductor of high rank. As much was manifest at his first concert with the NBC Symphony Orchestra of a week ago, when he gave an eclectic program.

ROME, March 8 -- Virginio Gayda today, for the second time in succession, writes that the Italians, by their resistance in Albania, are holding the entire Greek Army nailed to that front, leaving the Bulgarian frontier unguarded for the Germans.

A gift to buy toys for the day nurseries of England, to replace those destroyed by "enemy action" and to replace others now classed as luxuries was forwarded last week from the National Association of Day Nurseries. A fund of $700, the first installment of contributions made by member units across the country, was cabled to its sister organization, the National Society of Day Nurseries of Britain.

WORK by newcomers as well as by artists already familiar to local gallery goers played a part in the newly opened shows last week. The range of offerings extended all the way from the brashest of modernism to placid academism, and included painting, sculpture and prints.
"BUT we have gone through the most painful phases of our expansion program," the Chief of Staff says in his confidential, persuasive, fluent phrases.

Every one who has enjoyed the familiar dream of flying should find pleasure in seeing the dream come true. Probably not all the sleep-flying readers would use the gift as Ruddy did, but they would all surely feel the same marvelous sensations. This chap did not sprout wings on his shoulder blades but simply took a deep breath, grew rigid and took off.

BERLIN, March 8 -- Ever since that historic day in August, 1939, when Communist Russia concluded a ten-year nonaggression pact with National Socialist Germany and then proceeded to garner more than the lion's share of the spoils as an imperialist power, speculation abroad has been rife as to just how firm the bonds between Moscow and Berlin really are.

LONDON, March 8 -- London has now swept up all the bricks, glass, wood and stone strewn on the streets during the Blitz which eased off after mid-January. One can number on one's fingers the thoroughfares still blocked by bomb craters.

WHILE discussion as to what part the woman airplane pilot might play in the war goes on wherever fliers meet, at least one woman has got beyond the discussion stage and is already busy with a flying job. The pilot is Miriam Jarvis Johnson of Hempstead, L.I., member of the Women Flyers of America and the 99 Club.

AS one of your faithful readers, may I belabor some of your valued space with howls of protest at Brooks Atkinson's review and Sunday column about S.N. Behrman's "The Talley Method?" At least that's my general idea.

LONDON, March 8 -- Two officers who have been fighting in the Libyan desert have told newspapermen what their experiences were. One served with heavy tank forces and the other was a squadron leader of a famous cavalry regiment that has been mechanized for some years with light tanks.

The Alcoa Steamship Line, an affiliate of the Aluminum Company of America and known also as the Aluminum Line, announced yesterday that negotiations for the charter of the two passenger liners Acadia and St. John from the Eastern Steamship Company had been completed, and that a new passenger route would be started with the ships late this month.

Sleek Piedmont of Rapidon; the learned French poodle Mister, that can tell the difference between French and German airplanes; a haughty ribbon-snatcher known to the American Kennel Club registry as Champ Rana and fifty others leading names of the canine aristocracy graciously shelved their pedigree claims yesterday to seek novel titles for the sake of charity.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., March 8 -- The board of managers of Swarthmore College has approved recommendations for a committee of faculty and board members, to gradually reduce the size of the college to 700 students and stabilize it at that figure, it was announced by John Nason, president of the college.

HANYA HOLM will feature a new experimental composition for group on her program at the Mansfield Theatre on March 17. This will be a surrealist work called "The Golden Fleece, an Alchemistic Fantasy," for which the painter, Kurt Seligmann, has supplied the theme and designed the costumes.

THE current issue of Nature Magazine contains an article by W.L. McAtee entitled "What Do You Call Them?" It is a study of local names for various members of the animal and vegetable kingdoms. From it we learn, for example, that pine needles are known in different parts of the United States as spills, pins, needles, diddledees, shats, tags, twinkles and straws.

A GROUP of water-colors of the New York World's Fair, by Margaret Huntington, may be seen this week at the Marie Sterner Galleries. The artist is contributing both pictures and frames, full proceeds to go to British War Relief, and the galleries are contributing the time and space for the show.

BERLIN, March 8 -- The legal position of Jews who have been drafted for work in Germany -- and their number includes practically every Jewish man between the ages of 16 and 65 capable of working -- still awaits clarification. It is expected, however, that a law covering their status will shortly be promulgated according to a recent statement on this subject issued by the Reich Ministry of Labor.

THE Falcon was anything but a swift ship, and she was ugly as well, a dirty little tramp freighter that should have been sent to the junk yard before ever she left port on that final harrowing voyage. Whether Mr. Larsson wishes us to identify Sten the coal-passer with himself is not quite clear.

Past the Sugar Loaf Mountain and the Chico, which flank the mile-wide entrance to Rio de Janeiro's bay, slipped last week the 3,290-ton Lech, a trim ship built in 1939. The freighter dropped anchor in one of the world's best and most beautiful natural harbors.

VICHY, France, March 8 -- The news that the British had refused passage of foodstuffs from the United States to France has added fuel to the campaign favored on the other side of the demarcation line against the British blockade. The newspaper Matin today, in Paris printed an editorial in which it demanded that the French Government should order French naval vessels to convoy food shipments to France in the future.

Yachtsmen from New York and vicinity, and especially those with practical offshore experience who have often dropped moorings, left their club anchorages behind and cruised out of sight of land where sextants and celestial navigating must be used, are urgently needed as commissioned officers in the government's newest militarized force.

SERVICE to the nation in national defense and promotion of Pan-American friendship are foremost on the calendar of the Girl Scouts as they celebrate their twenty-ninth birthday week, beginning next Wednesday. Inspired by last year's encampment, a Western Hemisphere Center recently has been established at 670 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Nine patents were granted to eight women inventors this week. Plant Patents Nos. 458 and 459 were issued to Josephine D. Brownell of Little Compton, R.I., for new varieties of hybrid tea roses, characterized by their resistance to Winter injury, continuity of florescence and resistance to black rust defoliation.
Straight-game victories enabled four members of the seeded list to enter the third round yesterday in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C singles championship at the Downtown A. C.

Berlin announced yesterday that Herr Hitler had invited Yosuke Matsuoka, Foreign Minister of Japan, to come to Berlin to see him and that Matsuoka was coming. Tokyo also announced that Matsuoka was going to Berlin to discuss cooperation under the Berlin-Rome-Tokyo Axis.

ON a survey made from Nov. 10, 1940, at which date "Tobacco Road" took the first Sunday plunge, through Feb. 2, eighteen plays gave a total of 101 Sunday performances, of which eighty-eight were evening and thirteen matinee performances.

The financial community again looks to Washington, as it has become accustomed to look in recent years, for decisions in the near future on two important phases of the securities business which promise materially to affect its "way of life."

A "yardstick" to warn the public against appeals for charity that border on racket types or otherwise merit no support was set up on behalf of the Contributors Information Bureau yesterday. The distinguishing marks of "undesirable" charitable appeals were made known coincidentally with the announcement that the bureau had been placed under general direction of a citizens' advisory committee appointed by the Welfare Council of New York City.

THE fourth annual Wyoming Valley Bach Festival will he held March 27-30, in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., under the direction of Paul Gies. Participants include the Wyoming Valley Bach Chorus, Temple Chorus of Scranton, Boys' Choir of St. Stephens, Wilkes-Barre-Scranton Sinfonietta, a quartet of recorders, and instrumental and vocal soloists.

"EGGS are a bargain package of food at any time," says Dr. Lela E. Booher of the Federal Bureau of Home Economics. They will probably actually be what we mean by "bargains" during the next three or four months, for, although egg production can scarcely be called a seasonable occupation, this happens to be one of the busiest times of the year for the hens.

AMHERST, Mass., March 8 -- Completing the Winter season, Amherst teams captured Little Three titles in three sports today, but trailed in the New England intercollegiate wrestling meet at the close of two days of competition.

CLINTON, N.Y., March 8 -- First results are now available covering a threefold effort by President W.H. Cowley to maintain Hamilton College's high standard of academic proficiency and at the same time reduce the number of freshmen obliged to leave college because of scholastic failure.

Richard Hull is an extremely ingenious writer -- and something of an enfant terrible among authors of whodunit tales. For Mr. Hull -- who is best remembered for "The Murder of My Aunt" and "My Own Murder" -- is never easily held within whodunit conventions; and he can be trusted to give us a surprise of some new sort at the end.

For the benefit of the layman and in the interest of setting the record straight, I should like, as an engineer, to comment on the article appearing in THE TIMES recently based on a release of the Federal Power Commission and headlined "Power Shortages in Defense Feared."

Harvard's Winfield Alberts overcame a 3-2 deficit in the final saber bout to defeat Columbia's Norman Blackman and clinch a fencing match for the Crimson, 14 -- 13, on the Lions' strips yesterday. The Blue and White built up a 10-8 lead by virtue of 5-4 decisions in the foil and epee bouts, but fell before the visitors' strong saber trio, 6 -- 3.

IN the midst of constant increases in horsepower and the wide acceptance of eight and twelve cylinder engines, with six cylinders as the almost universal minimum base in American passenger cars, it is interesting to observe meritorious performances being made in its own particular field -- that of maximum economy of operation -- by the one American production car of standard tread, which sticks to the four-cylinder engine.

LISBON, Portugal, March 8 (AP) -- In the first interview he has granted the press since he abdicated the throne of Rumania last September, former King Carol asserted today he was very grateful to Portugal for giving him asylum.

Light snow or freezing rain today in the New York City area was predicted by the Weather Bureau last night as the city and the Eastern Seaboard, from Virginia north, shoveled to get out from under the biggest snowstorm of the Winter.

A plea was sent out recently to leading industrial designers for aid in modernizing the occupational therapy work in city hospitals. The result is a collection of streamlined designs contributed by men and women who have been responsible for the smooth line of modern railroad trains, the interiors of large commercial buildings and the minor revolution which has shown its effect in the color and design of fabrics.

THE inevitable, recurrent pattern of human life becomes ever more apparent. Over a thousand years ago the Great Wall of China -- 1,500 miles long -- was built to keep out the Mongols, and failed; yet the French built the Maginot Line to keep out the Germans.
BOSTON, March 8 -- Yale's fast-skating and smooth-passing hockey team defeated Harvard at the Boston Garden tonight, 8 to 2, for the second time this season.

LONDON, March 8 -- Concentration of production by British industries by closing down superfluous works was discussed in British commodity trade circles this week. Second thoughts were the reverse of the first impression that the move may restrict the consumption of raw material.

LONDON, March 8 -- Three hundred Norwegians -- eight of them women -- who took advantage of the British attack on the Lofoten Islands to join the "free Norwegian forces were welcomed to London today". King Haakon.

DETROIT -- Clamping down by the priorities board on the use of aluminum for other than defense purposes may result in some rather quick and far-reaching changes in automobiles of the future. It is understood here I that some companies already have made provisions for substitutes for certain essential parts, and the question now is whether they will shift back if the priorities are modified.

Those writers who of late have expressed their pet word hates are merely declaring in black and white their ignorance of the history of language. Their constant outcry against each poor, innocent neologism is symptomatic of their belief in a static language whose status is dependent on authoritarian dicta.

Shipping facilities are expected to play an increasingly important part in the prices of commodities for the duration of the war. With the expected acceleration of the campaign against shipping by Germany in the Spring, the difficulty in obtaining ships to carry on the ordinary commerce between nations, particularly items that may be classed as not entirely essential for military operations, is expected to force an upward movement in many imported staples.

Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, mother-in-law of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, in a radio address yesterday urged immediate passage of the lend-lease bill "without weakening amendments or strangling clauses." Her talk was broadcast over Station WABC and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

ROME, March 8 -- The Italian press, like the German, prints today the story that President Roosevelt offered to help Yugoslavia to prevent her from joining the Axis pact. The alleged dispatch to the Budapest Magyarsag upon which the story is based furnished an opening for some powerful editorial attacks against the United States.

CRITICS have for long been qualifying favorable notice of Alec Waugh's books with regret that so good a writer should not have produced more compellingly outstanding work. He has been writing a long time. In 1919, when he was 21, he wrote "The Prisoners of Mainz" from his own World War experience.

The concert to be given by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra on the night of April 19 at Carnegie Hall, an all-Tchaikovsky program with Vladimir Horowitz, pianist, as guest soloist, will be a benefit for the welfare fund of the New York Junior League, according to an announcement by Mrs. Armitage Crawford, president of the league.

One of the rare paintings by the seventeenth-century French artist Louis Le Nain, called "Peasants in Front of Their House," exhibited here several years ago, has been given to the California Palace of the Legion of Honor in San Francisco.

KAREN DE WOLF looks like a movie star herself, and writes with authority about Hollywood, where she writes for the studios; but this first novel of hers is surely not going to be turned into a picture unless the regulations on morality have been suddenly altered.

HERR RAUSCHNING made it clear in his earlier books that although Hitler's gospel of nihilism and destruction is the chief threat to our Western civilization Hitler is not the ultimate menace. Behind him is a great body of circumstance, to use a phrase of Woodrow Wilson's, which made Hitler possible.

This is an excellent example of the newer type of handicraft book, for it has an idea behind it which makes it more than mere entertainment or training in manual dexterity. The dolls when they are dressed show typical costumes of eleven periods in American history, from Priscilla of 1620 through Jonathan and Dolly of 1776, Amy of 1850, Lucinda and Mac of 1862, and others, until we come to Barbara of today.

About three out of every four of the 17,540 men examined in New York City during the first three draft calls were found physically fit for some military service, according to a report made yesterday by Colonel Samuel J. Kopetzky, chief of the medical division of the city's Selective Service Administration, to Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, director.

The annual all-star entertainment and fashion revue in aid of the Israel Orphan Asylum will be held next Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. Mrs. Gustave Hartman, widow of the institution's founder, City Court Justice Hartman, is now president of the beneficiary.

WHEN one invests a million dollars or more in a venture one likes to be sure -- even in films where, at best, the element of hazard is enormous. Thus, the film producers, like the old alchemists in search of the golden formula, have repeatedly tried to find methods of knowing a picture's merits or demerits before committing it to the ruthless public.

Judging his pace beautifully all the way, thrice beating back challenges and closing with a burst of power, Walter Mehl defeated Leslie MacMitchell by four yards in the Columbian Mile before 15,000 roaring fans in Madison Square Garden last night.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- With the Kefauver bill to differentiate in the Federal tax between non-beverage and beverage alcohol introduced in Congress and referred to the House Ways and Means Committee, the Flavoring Extract Manufacturers Association of the United States, the National Association of Retail Druggists, the National Manufacturers of Soda Water Flavors, and other interested trade groups began a campaign here this week to obtain its passage.

HAILE SELASSIE is one of the most extraordinary figures of these troubled times. Five years ago Fascist armies drove the frail, sad-eyed, black-bearded Emperor of a vast African domain in midnight flight from his golden throne in Addis Ababa. He became the ghost of international morality, haunting the corridors of the League of Nations, embarrassing the conscience of the Western world with his pleas for aid against aggression.

Josef Hofmann evidently was in a rhapsodical mood during his recital at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. Never before had the eminent pianist been so completely a law unto himself in his interpretations, or played in so improvisational a manner.

Two orchestral concerts of uncommon significance were given in succession last night in this city. The first was that of the Philharmonic-Symphony, John Barbirolli conductor, in Carnegie Hall, which gave an all-American program consisting of three works new to this city by native composers, and the performance by the American pianist, Beveridge Webster, of the Schumann concerto.

THE Ballet Theatre has decided, after all, to close its season tonight, but it has already begun to think about next year. In its programs these last few evenings it has been distributing a little questionnaire to the customers "for reference" in planning for the Fall.

"THE days of America's privately owned treasure houses are over. They are gone with the wind as inevitably as the great Southern plantations of before the Civil War." Thus, in his informal personal history, "Without Drums," P.A.B. Widener 2d says goodbye to his family's great art collection, given recently to the public.

The war crisis and the increasing importance of the merchant marine as a vital factor in national defense is placing fresh emphasis on what a modified governmental control of shipping may mean in such an emergency.

The celebration of the twentyninth anniversary of the founding of the Girl Scout movement in the United States by half a million Girl Scouts in all parts of the nation will begin next Wednesday. For the following week, a series of birthday celebrations are scheduled, placing emphasis upon Girl Scout service to country and community and upon the organization's effort to strengthen friendship between the countries of the Western Hemisphere.

EARLY music of varied provenance and new contemporary compositions by Americans and residents in this country will be presented at the sixth annual Three Choir Festival of New York, to be held March 28 and 29 at Temple Emanu-El.

IN memory of Frank Bridge, the English composer, the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation in the Library of Congress will sponsor a concert devoted to his works, Tuesday night, at the library. The program, which will include the string quartet in G minor, sonata for violin and piano, and sextet for strings, will be presented by the Coolidge Quartet, Rebecca Clarke, viola; Sterling Hunkins, 'cello, and Frank Sheridan, piano.

THE lumber lords of Minnesota have found a champion in Evelyn Voss Wise. Her new novel, "Wheels in the Timber," not only has one of them, Alexander Rogers, for its hero, but presents him as a man, not merely of driving power, but also of exceptional integrity, sturdy, self-reliant, generous and intelligent.

LONDON, Sunday, March 9 -- London last night had the sharpest aerial attack for many weeks -- a searing raid marked by a heavy rain of fire bombs and high explosives from early evening until after midnight.

IT is cause for gratification that the list of recordings in which Arturo Toscanini has a part continues to grow. That is not the least of the gains made by the world of the music when Samuel Chotzinoff succeeded some years ago in his mission to persuade the maestro to return to this country.

MONTREAL, March 8 (AP) -- Goalie Johnny Mowers, Detroit's candidate for the Calder rookie trophy, turned in his fourth shut-out of the National Hockey League season tonight as the Red Wings defeated the sixth-place Montreal Canadiens, 4 to 0, before 8,863 spectators.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 8 -- The Russian sphinx has spoken at last. Although official circles deprecate making much of it, for the Turkish public it is an event overshadowing the delivery of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's message to Turkey despite Nazi efforts to advertise the latter by the dispatch of a special airplane.

"I NEED not worry for China. She was bomb-proof," writes Anor Lin proudly, remembering how the family's house in the remote little town of Peipei had been hit and the town by this time almost demolished.

VICHY, France, March 8 -- General Maxime Weygand's talks with government leaders continued here today and will probably result in a general revision of colonial adminstration and other measures for tightening the defense of French overseas possessions.

IT is not often, barring circumstances resulting from actual involvement in war, that the United States Government refuses to deliver mail to any corner of the world. At this moment, however, there are some spots where neither ships nor air service can carry mail from the Americas.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 8 -- The unique method of instruction in the course in American folk literature at Cornell University is stimulating an interest in American history and laying the groundwork for American literature. In charge of the course is Harold W. Thompson, professor of English and author of the New York State saga, "Body, Boots and Britches," who is now undertaking a study of the folklore of the more recent immigrants.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Here is the text of the Senate-approved British aid bill, the matter inserted by the Senate in the House-approved bill being inclosed in double parentheses:

SAN QUENTIN, Calif., March 8 -- James B. McNamara, labor agent serving a life sentence for the 1910 bombing of the Los Angeles Times Building in which twenty-one persons were killed, died in prison today. He was 59 years old.

The investigation of air transport accidents which has been ordered by the House of Representatives will be of value if it is conducted in a constructive spirit. The inquiry has been undertaken because of the five airline crashes since last August, which have resulted in fifty-five deaths.

THIS is definitely a civilian's book about the Army -- in no sense an official publication, as its author makes plain in his foreword. It has been prepared in recognition of the need for creating a "close, harmonious and cooperative relationship between the citizen and the Army," and in realization that such a a relationship can be established only on the basis of clear and simple understanding.

VICHY, France, March 8 -- The appointment of a general commissariat to deal with "the Jewish question" was decided today by the Cabinet. The action, taken after Vice Premier Admiral Francois Darlan's conversations in Paris with the German authorities, can be considered as a preliminary to the tightening of the enforcement of the status of Jews in the unoccupied territory.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- More than 250,000 children will have to change schools because of population movements resulting from the defense program, Army and Navy authorities said today in asking Congress for $115,000,000 to help local school boards meet the problem.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 8 -- A strike of 2,400 employes working on national defense orders at the South Plainfield plant of the Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation was voted last night by members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A.F. of L. affiliate.

WAYS, Ga., March 8 (AP) -- Henry Ford said today that he believed unions were "losing ground" and that he had no intention of recognizing them as bargaining agencies for employes of the Ford Motor Company.

IN the crowded oval room in the White House where the President works, talks and relaxes in the hours he does not spend in the executive offices there is a long shelf holding an odd and interesting assortment of unpublished volumes. They are books written for him within the past eight years and consist for the most part of studies, surveys and blueprints of projects he has considered or hoped to realize.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- While several million American residents are toiling over their personal and corporate income tax returns this coming week, the fiscal experts of the National Government are expecting this year's statements to provide some of the best news they have had in a long time.

The accelerated pace of retailing is now reflecting itself in wholesale market activity, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Orders for Fall goods are more numerous than usual at this time of the year.

GASOLINE JAG -- Dr. A.C. Corn-sweet (University of North Carolina) finds that gasoline vapors have much the same intoxicating and exhilarating effect as alcohol vapors. Experiment with white rats showed that purified gasoline vapors were better than ether, chloroform or nitrous oxide gas (used by dentists) and inferior only to cyclopropane.
A new experimental honors course in the social sciences has been instituted this semester for gifted seniors in the various social science fields at Queens College.

The question of whether the voluntary controls which have been in operation for many months to prevent prices of dry goods lines from running away can withstand the pressure of increasing shortages received a good deal of attention last week in Worth Street.

OMAHA, Neb., March 8 -- The Methodist Church is withdrawing its missionaries from Japan and occupied Chinese areas in fear of "conflict in Asia" between Japan and the United States, Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, formerly of Omaha, now of the Boston Methodist area, said on a visit here yesterday.

BRUNO WALTER will be back as a conductor at the Metropolitan next season. The management would like to have him for the entire season, but that seems to be out of the question, because he has commitments to appear as guest leader of some of the orchestras he conducted this season.

ROME, March 8 -- General Sir Archibald Wavell's Army of the Nile has suffered a setback and British and Greek forces are being transferred from Greece to Egypt to save it, Virginio Gayda said in the Giornale d'Italia today.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Following is the vote in the Senate today on the Walsh amendment to the lease-lend bill to restrict the transfer of naval vessels and aircraft:

Endorsement by Mayor La Guardia of City Councilman Joseph Clark Baldwin, Republican candidate for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, was the main development yesterday in the contest for the House seat made vacant by the death of Kenneth F. Simpson.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 8 -- The variety of exhibits and pronounced international note are outstanding, although partly superficial impressions that a visitor retained after wandering through the twenty-four buildings accommodating Leipzig's second Spring Fair of war time that closes its doors yesterday.

On the fiftieth anniversary of the New York University School of Education this year, Dean E. George Payne yesterday foresaw a decided trend toward the teaching of vocational subjects in all educational institutions. This trend will affect not merely those interested, he said, but will impress itself upon all students.

With the cooperation of six metropolitan hospitals, Columbia University will establish in September an accredited three-year course in occupational therapy for the first time in New York City, it was announced yesterday by Professor James C. Egbert, director of the university extension, where the course will be given.

Interior decorators are beginning to show greater consideration for more recent family heirlooms -- those old sofas, tables and chairs which at first sight seemed to be passe rather than antique. Of a respectable mid-Victorian vintage or even dating from the latter part of the nineteenth century, these reminders of a not-too-distant past can, it is shown, be combined with a few good reproductions to produce an individual and homelike effect.

HOBOKEN, N.J., March 8 -- The purchase of a five-story, sixteen-family brick tenement at 600-02 Adams Street here by Mrs. Anna Scutellaro, wife of Joseph Scutellaro, former relief recipient who served eighteen months in State prison at Trenton for the slaying of Poormaster Harry L. Barck in 1938 was disclosed today with the recording of a $20,070 bank mortgage on the property.

THE galleries of New York offer just now a rather exceptional opportunity to study phases of expression that range all the way from complete nonobjective abstraction to something relatively paralleling this very near the opposite, or naturalistic, end of the gamut.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- Having just completed the first two weeks of the training season, the team which Manager Joe McCarthy hopes to lead to another pennant is beginning to take shape. The last Yankee hold-out capitulated the other day when Joe DiMaggio agreed to terms, and the star outfielder is expected here in the near future.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange continued their upward movement in the short session yesterday and final quotations showed net gains of 1 to 10 points over Friday's closing levels. At the highs for the day the new-crop months, which have made new seasonal peaks in the last four sessions, stood 32 to 42 points above last Monday's lows, with October showing the greatest gain.

Details of Lord Taylor's new store at Manhasset, L.I., the first suburban unit to be opened by this Fifth Avenue establishment, were announced yesterday by Walter Hoving, president. Present plans call for the opening of the store, at the southwest corner of Northern Boulevard and Shelter Rock Road, some time in May.

With the Tammany Tiger stalking the 1941 Mayoralty election as the theme, the Inner Circle, an organization of political writers and past and present City Hall and legislative correspondents, presented its annual stunt show-dinner at the Hotel Astor last night.

Decca has turned up first with recordings from the Broadway hit, Lady in the Dark. Hildegarde is the singer, with Robert Hannon on one disk and with an orchestra and chorus under the direction of Harry Sosnik. The tunes by Kurt Weill, with slick Ira Gershwin lyrics, are The Saga of Jenny, My Ship, One Life to Live, This Is New and Girl of the Moment.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 8 -- Herman Friedberg's Montsin won Tropical Park's $3,650 Pan American Handicap today with Jockey Conn McCreary getting one of the more obscure starters home in front. It was a day of rain and mud, a tropical downpour in the morning cutting the attendance to 5,838 and the resultant sloppy track causing many horsemen to withdraw their charges.

THE fabulous prices paid by movie studios in recent months for Manhattan stage properties, many of which are considered to be of questionable value to the screen, has aroused suspicion in some quarters that Hollywood is the victim of Broadway logrolling.

JOHN KLEMPNER, who will be remembered for "No Stork at Nine," has written another story about young and moderately young people in New York. This novel too is witty, moving and entertaining, with a deeper searching undercurrent than the earlier book.

With the appearance of several new outstanding varieties, the garden of the viola enthusiast will be enriched indeed in this year of 1941. All of the introductions offered are decided improvements on or interesting diversions from the habit, form or flower colors of the sorts which have been availiable.

The work of the National Refugee Service in facilitating the resettlement of refugees in communities away from the large cities on the Eastern Seaboard was characterized by President Roosevelt as "most constructive" and "especially significant" in a letter made public yesterday by William Rosenwald, president of the organization.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- Big Bill Hasslinger's 23 points helped Columbia defeat Pennsylvania at the Palestra tonight, 48-34, and gain a half-game on Dartmouth's champions in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race.

Various entertainments designed as means to raise funds for the advancement of war relief projects continue to elicit the support and cooperation of men and women prominent in society and artistic circles. Among the events in this category scheduled for the near future and subsequent weeks are three arranged to aid respectively the work of Polish, Greek and Anglo-French relief committees.

The first announcement of the "exhibitors' show," the annual exhibition of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club, to be given Saturday, May 31, on the polo field of Giralda Farms in Madison, N.J., gives the names and judging assignments of more than sixty amateur and professional experts.

For many years children from 4 to 7 have loved James S. Tippett's "I Live in a City," "I Spend the Summer" and "I Go A-Traveling." This latest volume of verses, like the earlier ones, catches the spirit of childhood and concerns itself in natural and spontaneous fashion with the things that boys and girls do and see every day.

Hugo Balzo, Uruguayan pianist, made his New York debut yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall. His recital was sponsored by the Union de Mujeres Americanas (the United Women of the Americas) as part of the organization's program for fostering better cultural relations between North and South America.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Increased appropriations, statistical and informational controls which do not now exist, and administrative reorganization are recommended for the Library of Congress by Archibald MacLeish in his first annual report as librarian.

ON Feb. 20 Lynn Riggs read "Cream in the Well" to a group of twelve of us in Santa Fe, one month after its Broadway premiere. We had read Mr. Atkinson's criticism in which he asked why it was written, pointed out that nothing happened; and said that the subject of incest at the end came as anticlimax.

MOGADISCIO radio, in Italian Somaliland, is the first important Italian radio outpost to be captured by the British. The giant beam from this spot, which once carried both telephonic and telegraphic communications to the central Italian government, is silenced now for Axis service.

In 1918 when the country's industrial machinery was throbbing night and day, just as it is now, an engineer wrote on "A Reaction Against Oslerism" for The American Machinist and acclaimed the trend toward employing older mechanics. The virtues of the man over 40 were extolled. He was a good teacher of apprentices; he was dependable, mature, loyal, experienced.

In announcing 112 nominations for the sixty-seventh Kentucky Derby to be run at Churchill Downs, Louisville, on May 3, Colonel Matt J. Winn declared yesterday that "there is no outstanding candidate, but there are at least thirty from which the winner may come."
MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Big-league baseball training games, championship pistol tournaments and horse and yacht racing are scheduled for the late-season sports program in this area.

The adventures befalling a young Harvard University graduate in his endeavors to manage a resort hotel in Salt Lake City will be depicted in "One on the House," the ninety-fifth annual production of the Harvard Hasty Pudding Club, which will be presented on the night of March 29 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Hans Schmidt's letter in your edition of March 2 seems to be full of serious contradictions.

Even though City College may have a "small percentage of undesirables," that should not be used to descredit a "great institution of higher learning," Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday, commenting on the Rapp-Coudert committee's investigation of subversive activities in the local educational system.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 8 -- Mioland got a rich revenge today.

MELBOURNE, Australia. WHILE war in Britain has decimated the theatre there, Australian audiences are enjoying a boom in productions. It might be expected that this boom would fall into the musical comedy-revue class, but instead producers have found a market for straight plays.

Copland: Music for the Theatre. Eastman-Rochester Symphony Orchestra conducted by Howard Hanson. (Victor, three twelve-inch records, $3.50.) A new recording of a work by a living American is always welcome. Aaron Copland's score, which was written in 1925, has an appealing quality.

HARTFORD, March 8 -- Recent dispatches to THE YORK NEW TIMES describing the factory and industrial equipment phase of Connecticut's participation in the national defense program inspired today a statement from the State Development Commission, which takes exception to some statements and conclusions published.

WASHINGTON -- The magnetic promise of aviation has led Mrs. Phoebe Omlie through the hectic barnstorming days of the old open cockpit jennys and a great deal of constructive pioneering to an appointment unique among women in the government.

SO extensively was Joseph A. Gainard, captain of the United States freight steamer City of Flint, exploited through the press some months ago that he needs no introduction. Lest some, however, may have forgotten, it was the City of Flint which picked up the survivors of the torpedoed Athenia in September of 1939, was later captured by the Germans, was taken into Murmansk, Russia, within the Arctic Circle, and finally released.

VISCOUNT CECIL'S long-awaited book, "A Great Experiment," is in one respect a disappointment. It was heralded in advance as an autobiography and that is how it is described in its sub-title. But the autobiography proper is only an introductory section of forty-six pages, followed by 300 on the League of Nations, though with an autobiographical thread running through them.

The full support of the American Federation of Labor was thrown behind the executive council of the American Federation of Teachers yesterday in its effort to revoke the charters of two locals in New York City and one in Philadelphia on charges of Communist domination.

THE curious creatures who cavort through the pages of this very curious novel are dwellers in a Manhattan which is more legendary than real. Their world is bounded on the one hand by bohemia, on the other by Cafe Society; their range is from the purlieus of the Village to the glitter spots and penthouses of the upper East Side.

The letter of Hans Schmidt is unquestionably most timely and no doubt he advances thoughts which are in the minds of many, especially those who know Europe and, what is still more important, the German people. No question that "we must be bold," that "we should be aware that at no time in the modern age have masses of suffering people been more ready, more anxious, more hungry for broad-beamed objectives than today."
CLEMENTON, N.J., March 8 -- Three stakes were completed today at the annual Spring trials of the Jersey Irish Setter Field Dog Club, over the course at near-by Hidden Lakes.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- A rookie, Jerry Priddy, today pointed the Yankees on the victory trail. The Kansas City graduate said it with his war club as the former champions buried the Cardinals under an 8-1 landslide at Waterfront Park before 2,055 fans.

SENTIMENTALISTS have long held to the notion that America was a country of vast untapped sources of melody that could be brought to full flower if some worthy soul with imagination and money would only recognize the fact.

Mrs. Howard Ogden Wood has organized an invitation committee for the luncheon and fashion show entitled "Spring Fever," which will be given in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on April 16 as a benefit for the Generosity Thrift Shop.

I NOTED with interest Georg Szell's comments on his recent orchestral transcription in last Sunday's music pages. Mr. Szell, in defending his orchestration of Smetana's quartet "From My Life," unfortunately does not quote with complete fidelity from the composer's letter to his friend, Joseph Srb-Debrnov.

Sandra fell in love with Bradley the first time she saw him, and his whole family fell in love with her. They saw at once how steady and sensible she was, and they thought that Bradley, with his usual superficial view, would see only that she was a little beauty.

L'Union Alsacienne of New York, the oldest Alsatian mutual aid society in the United States, will hold its seventieth annual ball and midnight supper Saturday night in the roof garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania, maintaining a tradition carried through the years since the society was established in 1871.

THE exhibition "Functions of Color" current at the Phillips Memorial Gallery in Washington, D.C., was scheduled to close on March 23 but has been extended to remain through March 30. The gallery reports the exhibition to be the most popular ever held there.

Recent dispatches in THE NEW YORK TIMES have told of mass deportations of helpless people, robbed not only of their property and their liberty, but often of their very lives. A number of victims of the dictators are Jews, and I should like to call attention to the manner in which the needs of many of these Jewish refugees are being met in Palestine -- a home for the Jews guaranteed by international law.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 8 -- The enlisted men of the old Seventh Regiment of New York, the 207th Coast Artillery, will have the chance to compete for admission to an officers training school which is to open at Camp Stewart about July 1, Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, commanding officer, announced today.

On Jan. 10, 1941, church bells pealed long and loud in Athens, for the Greeks had captured strategic Klisura. In Moscow an "enlarged economic agreement" with Germany was announced. Britain's R.A.F. on that day was carrying out the war's largest daylight raid on the "invasion ports."

The girls branch of the Public Schools Athletic League will be aided by a card party to be held on Saturday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. It has been reported by Miss Dorothea McIlvaine, chairman of the patroness committee for the benefit, that already many tables have been reserved for the event.

FOR the third time in the memory of men now living, yachting is doing its bit for the Navy -- not only that yachting represented by the amateur who spends Summer week-ends playing with white wings in coastal waters but that of the big steam and Diesel craft which in peacetime pursue the fine weather from ocean to ocean the world over.

TORONTO, March 8 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs went into a tie with the idle Boston Bruins for the National Hockey League leadership tonight when they routed the last-place New York Americans, 6 to 1. Defensemen played a big part in the victory, scoring four of the six Toronto goals.

SAN JOSE -- The Costa Rica postal authorities announce that a limited special issue of stamps commemorating the Association Football Championship Matches to open here on May 8 will be placed on sale while the games are in progress.

The Standard Oil Company of Ohio in 1940 had new high record earnings, according to the annual report issued yesterday by W.T. Holliday, president. Net profit of the company and its subsidiaries amounted to $6,209,008 after depreciation, obsolescence, interest, Federal income taxes and provision of $960,000 for the excess profits tax.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A "dimple" method for quickly riveting together the thin metallic skins which cover airplane wings, fuselages and other parts of aircraft has been developed by the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., Santa Monica, Calif., it is revealed in a patent (No. 2,233,820) issued to Vladimir H. Pavlecka of the same city.

ATHENS, March 8 -- The Greek armies are now carrying out a violent offensive on the entire central sector of the Albanian front and it is declared that all is going more than well. Within forty-eight hours more than 2,200 prisoners have been taken and authorities have not stopped counting.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Abbot Low Moffat, chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, announced today that he would introduce on Monday a bill providing for the escheating of funds now on deposit with Federal courts in the State.

This non-technical account of the building of the Norris Dam has been written with conciseness, clarity and enthusiasm. The author speaks with first hand knowledge, for she had a job with the Tennessee Valley Authority during the building of the dam.
Now, when seed lists are being made up, the lesser known annuals are not to be overlooked.

Seven American agencies for relief in China have joined under the chairmanship of James G. Blaine to raise $5,000,000 by the end of July -- less than 2 cents apiece for the inhabitants of the unoccupied portions of the Chinese Republic. The money will go for medical aid, ambulances, food, education, work among children and the financing of the cooperatives on which the Chinese people are increasingly relying for the manufacture of essential goods.

AT the Robin Hood Dell this Summer a special type of program will be offered regularly on each day of the concert week. Symphony programs will be offered on Monday nights; soloists will appear on Tuesday nights; popular music, including concert versions of operettas, will be presented on Thursday nights, and talented young Philadelphia musicians will be heard on Friday nights.

APPARENTLY it is impossible to satirize Hollywood. It has been tried repeatedly, usually by those whose acquaintance with life in the film capital has been brief and bitter. Plenty of good writers whose pens are sharp enough in other causes have failed dismally in the attempt to make the motion picture business funnier or more bizarre than it already is in sober fact.

Academic honors for scholastic achievement during the Fall term have been accorded to 186 students at Manhattan College, it was learned this week upon publication of the Deans' List. First honors went to forty-nine undergraduates, the School of Arts and Sciences leading with twenty-nine.
Berlin once more serves notice that 80,000,000 people fighting for their national existence will never hesitate to take all necessary measures to insure that end.

"THESE Englishmen are tough babies, and don't let any one tell you otherwise." Such is the opinion of Harvey Klemmer, attache of the American Embassy in London from 1938 to 1941, and such is the conclusion that the reader of his book is bound to draw if he has not done so already.

A YOUNG Englishman, Desmond Hawkins, who was born in Surrey and educated at Holyrood House and Cranleigh, resigned from an inherited but unsympathetic business of hardware and electrical engineering so that he could devote his entire time to writing -- an avocation that had gradually absorbed his interest over a period of years.

A greater diffusion of profits this year among industrial companies, with a substantial gain in gross earnings but a reduction in net, was predicted here yesterday by accountants following analyses of 1940 showings. Major portion of the gains in 1940 was restricted to companies in the aviation, automotive and metal industries, with many other industries showing only small increases or actual declines in net earnings from the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A proclamation calling for celebration of Army Day on April 7 and requesting Governors of the various States to make similar pronouncements was issued today by President Roosevelt.

Sixteen stories about good old Scattergood and his works in Coldriver carry on a formula which seems to be satisfactory to Mr. Kelland and his readers. If you are familiar with the shrewd old man's previous deeds of justice tempered by mercy, you know the set-up for this latest collection.

Some years ago Van Campen Heilner, who has probed many of the world's dark corners in search of game and fish, dropped a plug on an isolated stream in Cuba and found he had stumbled on one of the finest tarpon rivers he had ever fished.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Federal Power Commission denied today the application of a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Aluminum Company of America to discontinue without prejudice a hearing on a permit for construction of a $37,000,000 hydroelectric plant on the Little Tennessee River for the production of power to make aluminum for defense.

Captain James Mackenzie, commodore of the Seas Shipping Company, operator in the New York-South African trade, has been named master of the new cargo carrier Robin Locksley, which has just been completed at the Sparrows Point yards of the Bethlehem Steel Company in Maryland.

ALBANY, March 8 -- A plea to watchful citizens to report possible subversive activities to State, Federal or local authorities, rather than attempt to investigate on their own account, was made today by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., in a letter to Governor Lehman.

In your issue of March 2, 1941, Hans Schmidt tells us that we fail to use a potent weapon with the German people in not announcing, in some detail, our peace aims. He tells us also some things that we Americans need to know about the attitude of certain ostensibly liberal anti-Nazi Germans in Germany.

There seems to be some hope that as a result of the City Council's action, New York may permit blind-leading dogs to accompany their masters on subway trains. It is to be hoped that this action will be followed generally. The argument is, of course, that the Seeing-Eye dogs are needed by their owners to take them about.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Following is the detailed vote on the passage of the lease-lend bill by the Senate early this evening:

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High's athletes captured the senior team championship for the eighth year in a row at the fourteenth annual running of the city C.H.S.A.A. track and field games at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

AMID the pall of wickedness that hung over the theatre three months ago this department injudiciously observed: "A nice idea sometimes would be for some one to write a tender play about kind people." No one can say that "Claudia" is not a bountiful answer to that rebellious prayer.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The statement that Italy and Germany are delaying the sailing from New York for France of the Red Cross relief ship Exmouth was made today at the White House.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 8 -- Syracuse easily won the Eastern Intercollegiate Boxing Association championship tonight, carrying off five of the eight individual titles to score 28 points.
Spring apparel was active in all three of the "test" markets, New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, last week, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

Twelve business women will give advice on employment problems to younger career women at a meeting to be held on Wednesday at 8:30 P.M. at the American Woman's Association. Miss Helen Fuller, vocational counsellor of the Community Service Society, will act as chairman of the session to be held at the club's headquarters in the Henry Hudson Hotel, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

SINGING songs and reciting rhymes, listening to and telling stories, exploring pictures, building and making things, drawing, pasting, playing language games, are among the experiences a child gets at home or in kindergarten, and on these hang much of his later learning: reading in particular.

SINCE the first white man found the tip of Manhattan Island a place to "commodiously come a-land" 417 years ago, what is now the Battery has been New York's front door. It is where the sea ends and the river begins; where every ship bound to or from the city must pass.

HAS any one seen some good short subjects lately or the idea for one? That is the nub of a good deal of chatter presently to be heard above the din in Times Square, or even at Hollywood and Vine. Daily the question becomes more frantic.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- An innovation will be the auction under the auspices of the Four Arts tomorrow and Tuesday at the Embassy Club. The club, long closed, has been reopened and lent to the Four Arts for the occasion by Colonel Edward R. Bradley.

CLIMB three rickety flights of stairs at 51 East Fifty-fifth Street and knock on the door. "Come in, please." You enter a bit fearfully, expecting to be dazzled by the glitter of spangles; to play blind man's buff through rows of hanging costumes and stumble about a floor littered with drawings.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- Many unsuspecting residents of little Delaware discovered last Sunday, to their consternation, that their next-door neighbors, or their friends over in the next block, were a bunch of criminals.

THERE are three separate literatures in Yugoslavia, corresponding to the three peoples of the kingdom, the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes. The Slovenes speak a language quite distinct from the Croats and Serbs. Whether there are distinct Serbian and Croatian lan guages is a moot point.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Germany's war-time bill in the early months of 1941 is apparently running at the enormous annual rate of 72,000,000,000 marks, which is 72 per cent of the national income of 100,000,000,000 marks, the Commerce Department reported today.

DANVILLE, Vt., March 8 -- In recent years the recognition has been dawning on educators that the small rural school offers several unique potential advantages as a place for giving to children an education conceived in the modern spirit. There is opportunity for close contact with nature.

LESLIE STEPHEN pointed out some time ago that there was a great deal of Samuel Johnson that Boswell did not see. And since that time, as Hugh Kingsmill has noted, many readers of Boswell have come to feel that his Johnson is "too static, a character and an oracle rather than a human being whose life changed from year to year, and whose nature felt desire and experienced frustration."

LAKELAND, Fla., March 8 -- Dedication of a chapel on the campus of Florida Southern College tomorrow afternoon, in honor of Mrs. Annie Pfeiffer of New York City, will end the institution's fifty-sixth Founders Week program. The dedicatory address will be delivered by Bishop Arthur J. Moore of the Methodist Church.

THE naivete expressed by Watkins E. Wright in his letter asking why there are not more cheap seats to shows is amusing. There aren't more cheap seats to the successful plays because the producers can get any price they choose to ask.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Wheat prices advanced 1 3/4 to 2 5/8 cents today following an upturn of 1 cent to 1 1/2 cents on Friday with the general public coming in on the buying side of futures in the broadest way for several weeks.

IF this musical season has emphasized any one thing it has been the value of the conductor. Vitalizing interpretation is a first necessity when music is sounded. Such interpretation, where large ensembles are involved, cannot be secured without the presence of a musician of sound knowledge, intuitive perception and the unifying will of a leader.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 8 -- Rutgers took top honors in the twenty-first annual Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association championships in the Rutgers pool today. The Scarlet tallied 48 1/2 points to take the crown for the first time since 1938.

ATHENS, March 8 (AP) -- Adolph Hitler was told by the controlled Greek press today that Greece was prepared to fight in Thrace as she has in Epirus and would "show the world how to die as she has shown it how to fight."
In an effort to establish regional "pooling" of armament industries, the National Association of Manufacturers soon will initiate a series of "defense clinics" throughout the nation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 3 -- A vast shipping plan for Brazilian ships, covering almost the entire American Continent, was unfolded today by Major Napolean Alencastro Guimares, assistant to the Minister of Communications, while discussing the scope of the Merchant Marine Commission created last night by President Getulio Vargas.

The name of Harry F. Wolf, outstanding player of the amateur ranks, was missing from the list of contestants yesterday as the National amateur squash tennis championship got under way at the Columbia University Club.

If Robert Louis Stevenson were alive today he might wish to write an additional footnote to his account of the troubles in Samoa. His candidate for King was Mataafa, who distinguished himself by defeating a force of German marines. This was in 1888. Eleven years later Mataafa, now on the German side, was nearly the cause of a war in which Britain and the United States would probably have sided against Germany.

EDGAR SNOW'S reputation as the most adventurous and enterprising newspaper man in China was established by his best seller "Red Star Over China," which gave the first eyewitness account of Soviet China.

DURING the last decade symphony concerts in Rio de Janeiro have come and gone. At the beginning of the Thirties Burle Marx conducted a series of symphony concerts. However, when he left for the United States years ago the Philharmonic Orchestra founded by him was discontinued.

TELEVISION'S outlook will be crystallized for some time to come after March 20, the opening date for the Federal Communications Commission's scheduled hearing to formulate rules governing the art's scientific, artistic and commercial aspects.

AS a theme the story of the sophisticated white man trying to "escape" into primitive life has been worn threadbare. Each new attempt at its narration must have creative power and insight behind it if it is to be more than another travel book.

The Regency Club team-of-four, led by Oswald Jacoby, yesterday captured the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy, defeating the Blue Ribbon foursome in the final round of the Eastern Bridge Tournament at the Park Central Hotel.

NEWS from the Virgin Islands is of a busy Winter season, with more vacationists than for several years. The new cottages on St. John are all rented and the hotels on St. Thomas have had few vacancies during the last three months.

Since the Selective Service Act was placed in operation last October, the United States Government, through its National Service Insurance section, has issued more than $500,000,000 in new policies. Trainees passing through various induction centers throughout the country are told of the benefits of this new insurance, its low rates and the opportunity to convert it into ordinary or twenty or thirty payment life insurance after one year.

Addressing several hundred delegates representing 1,000 Jewish fraternal and communal organizations at a rally last night at Cooper Union, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey asserted that Palestine represents a significant example "of living democracy," which has earned the approval and support of Congress and Presidents since Woodrow Wilson.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- For a variety of reasons proponents of the President's lease-lend bill for all-out aid to Great Britain and her allies could not win over the large minority against it and achieve the unity urged by Mr. Willkie. The opposition was unable to carry most of the restrictive amendments, or pass a substitute, for another set of reasons, also various.

New York will do its full share in preparation for national defense and there will be no shortage of machines or men to run them in this State. Governor Herbert H. Lehman declared yesterday in a speech at the Saturday Afternoon Forum of the National Democratic Club.

OTTAWA, March 8 -- How much Canada is spending on the war and what is being done with the money has been greatly clarified this week by the question and answer method in Parliament and the equally democratic method of press criticism which has called for government reply.

IN Dr. Stiedry's recent explanation of his aims and methods in presenting the St. John Passion "as much as possible as the Cantor of Leipzig himself may have performed it," there are one or two statements that may lead to mistaken inferences.

IT has been said that most men kiss and do not tell, but that George Moore did not kiss but told. It must have been upon some such principle as has been applied to George Moore that Mr. John Erskine has recast a number of experiences with women related by that arch-lover, Casanova, in a mood more nearly corresponding to the spirit of our time.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Opponents spoke against the British aid bill for 44 hours and three minutes during the Senate debate on the measure while administration speakers held the floor for 14 hours and 10 minutes.

HAVANA, March 8 -- A "ceiling zero" that gave the air clippers some trouble and a driving rain that descended upon Havana today postponed the second game between the Cleveland Indians and the Dodgers. This failed to dismay President Larry MacPhail of the Brooklyn club, who is never at a loss for a few thousand words or a lot of ideas.

"ALWAYS move on at the moment when present good begins to fade" was Anne Preble's motto and the motive for her resolution to move her family from ancestral Boston to New York. At the time she was in her middle forties and her husband, twenty-three years her senior, verging upon 70.

What matters in the negotiations to settle the Thailand-Indo-China conflict is not the specific concessions that may be imposed on France by Japan but the new advanced position Japan is winning in its march by stages to the south. This counts for more in Japan's eyes and in the effect on the world struggle now in progress than the intrinsic value of the territorial acquisitions and economic priorities Japan is likely to win.

Columbia's swimmers won their first meet in nine starts last night, downing Pennsylvania, 44 to 31, at the Morningside Heights pool and moving out of a tie with their Philadelphia rivals for last place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

Any well-rounded program of disease-control must have a starting point. In attempting to insure a healthy garden the best place to start is with the seed. In the past, home gardeners often have been disappointed with the poor germination of the flower and vegetable seeds they planted.

The name of Mrs. Guy Percy Trulock has been presented to the nominating committee of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs as a candidate for president to succeed Mrs. Rudolph M. Binder, whose two-year administration closes in May.
THE stout manager of the Detroit Red Wings, Mr. Jack Adams, was deeply impressed with the 6-0 trimming the Rangers recently handed his team.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 8 (UP) -- A high Turkish political source said tonight that Germany might attack this country and added that Turkey, with British aid, would act at the precise moment when she could make the best defensive use of her army and geographical position.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Proceeding on the theory that discipline must be built upon the intelligence, sportsmanship, individuality and group cooperativeness of the men in the ranks, the Army today announced the abandonment of the rule requiring saluting of officers off post and made other changes in custom in a new manual of military courtesy and discipline.

THEY used to say it takes an earthquake to wake some people up, and the truth of that blunt aphorism is sharply apparent today. For there are still a great many folks who are just now getting hep to the fact -- just now when the world and our poor minds are in a frightful state of upset -- that the motion pictures are much more than a mere and barely mature form of amusement.

The long weeks of hearings and debate on the lease-lend bill have left Congress and probably a good part of the American public tired and angry. An original difference of opinion as to what ought to be done to protect this country and its institutions developed into a turmoil of moral indignation.

A warning that further extension of the radio into classrooms as a medium of instruction holds "great danger of propaganda" was given by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, at the annual conference of the High School Teachers Association and High School Principals Association yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

WHEN Prime Minister Churchill was asked whether the women of Britain should be allowed to take part in the actual fighting of the war he observed "after expressing repugnance for the idea" that history never blamed Boadicea for leading her warriors and that every one would have thought better of Cleopatra if she had insisted on Antony's staying to fight it out at the Battle of Actium instead of running away.

IN "Cheers for Miss Bishop," the rah-rah is out. There is no pretty heroine who is the dean's daughter; no hero who plays quarterback and sings tenor with a snappy campus combo; no songs by Rodgers and Hart; no snake dances in the moonlight with chorus routines around a bonfire; no putting a cow in the dean's office.

THE Hudson Valley squire of these fifty-year-old memories was a colorful individual whose exploits can still incarnadine the picturesque scene of a vanished day; and "colorful" and "picturesque" are the adjectives which beckon to entertainment in this tirelessly vivacious -- not to say occasionally preposterous -- book.

A large executive committee under the chairmanship of Mrs. Messmore Kendall, with Mrs. Grover Whalen, Mrs. Frederic W. Ecker and Mrs. William R.K. Taylor Jr. as co-chairmen, has been formed to assist with plans for the benefit performance of George Bernard Shaw's "The Doctor's Dilemma" on the night of March 17 at the Shubert Theatre.

A recital by Kirsten Flagstad, soprano, of the Metropolitan Opera, will be given on the afternoon of April 14 at the home of James Speyer, 1058 Fifth Avenue, as a benefit for the New York Women's League for Animals. The recital will represent the third occasion on which Mme.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 8 --National defense bottlenecks "can be very nearly eliminated" by "proper timing of allocation and production." says Bernard M. Baruch, who served in the World War as chairman of the War Industries Board.

Speakers in the field of education have been emphasizing the importance of national morale as a critical factor in any conflict. President Hutchins of the University of Chicago did so recently in addressing the annual meeting of the American Association of Junior Colleges.

Kaarlo Kuusamo, Finnish Consul General in New York, sailed yesterday on the American Export liner Exeter for Lisbon, accompanied by his wife. The liner left Pier F in Jersey City at 2:30 o'clock, carrying 105 passengers and a general cargo. Sixty-four of the passengers were booked only as far as Bermuda, the ship's first port of call.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 8 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

Here we read of the first oil well; how oil is found; why and how dynamite is used in prospecting for oil; the tools and instruments and methods of modern drilling; oil wells on production, with photographs and descriptions of "the Christmas tree," oil and gas separators, a pumping unit and other machinery. Storage, transportation, and refining of oil, round out the picture.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Favorable House action Tuesday on the Senate amendments to the lease-lend bill appeared almost certain tonight when Speaker Rayburn indicated that the Administration desired that the legislation be put before President Roosevelt quickly.

TRADE is now entering the period when sales are compared with the busy Easter shopping time of last year. For another two weeks, therefore, the increases over 1940 will not be so large. Due to the later holiday this year retailers will bulk their March and April sales for comparison purposes.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- The Swiss Alps, the fjords of Norway and our own Adirondacks, all rolled into one -- this is the impression a United States traveler carries away with him after touring the lake region of Southern Chile, where Summer travel is now at its height.

An extra-collegiate dramatic group, with 125 of Hunter College alumnae as members, has been organized as the Hunter Alumnae Players for post-graduate work in dramatics, Mrs. Janet Mears Nurick, president of the group, announced yesterday.

ASYMPHONIC series designed to offer the best creative efforts of contemporary composers of this country will be introduced Tuesday at 10:30 P.M. on WJZ's network. The thirtyminute programs, to be known as "Our New American Music," will be presented by an orchestra under the direction of Frank Black.

THROUGH all the exigencies of "total" war the British people must still live normal human lives, with human weaknesses and passions still inherent and problems of human relations still to be solved: under changing conditions the human being's spiritual needs and hope remain much the same.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 8 -- A year ago, during the night of March 12-13, Finnish plenipotentiaries signed in Moscow the peace terminating three months of Finnish-Russian war. The year has been spent in healing the wounds inflicted by war and dancing on the tightest political rope to keep the country out of further external embroilment.

Larissa, bombed by the Fascists the day after it was shaken by earthquake, is one of many names that in this war almost make the classical atlas a rival of the latest modern maps. Larissa is an old "Pelasgian" name said to mean "citadel." Besides the old fortress on the Peneus, there was another Larissa, surnamed Cremaste, in southeast Thessaly, a city of Achilles.

The long-standing fight of the United States Government against monopoly has now reached out to include such apparently skittish matters as the length and silhouette of a woman's dress, and the tilt and trimming of her hat.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- The final Pirate Class race of the Royal Nassau Sailing Club's series for the King's Cup and the final Flamingo Class race for the Sir Frederick Williams-Taylor Cup are scheduled to be sailed on Montagu Bay today.
BERLIN, March 8 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

The Department of Labor's report on employment in January emphasizes the continued activity in trade, converging especially on defense industries. The department's factory employment index, 115.2 per cent of the 1923-25 average, compares with 116.2 in December; but it is the highest of any January on record, and was overtopped only twice by any other month as far back as 1920.
Passage of the lease-lend bill by the Senate was acclaimed on the British radio last night as "America's answer to Mr. Churchill's message to 'give us the tools and we will finish the job.'"

PRINCETON, N.J., March 8 -- Cornell stayed in the battle for second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League by out-pointing Princeton, 37 -- 31, before 1,000 enthusiastic spectators tonight.
Robert Grant 3d completed another season of absolute sway in racquets yesterday when he regained the Clarence C. Pell Cup at the Racquet and Tennis Club before a capacity gathering.

The Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, whose 3,500 members employed on the bus lines of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation have voted to strike at an undisclosed hour tomorrow, pressed forward yesterday their plans for the walkout, while Mayor La Guardia was making futile efforts to avert the threatened tie-up of 95 per cent of the franchised bus facilities in Manhattan.

A PHOTOGRAPH of the stamp Italy proposes to issue to symbolize her solidarity with Germany in the Axis was made available last week by The Associated Press. It is a 50-centesimi, color not announced, presenting profile portraits of Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini, with two soldiers in the background.

A record entry and the new point-scoring system have combined to create unprecedented interest in the 1941 Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championships, scheduled at the Columbia University gymnasium next Friday and Saturday.
