INTRODUCTORY tours of the Metropolitan Museum are available every day (except Sundays) at 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. Groups assemble in the Main Hall. Free lectures will be given today at the museum, including, at 2 o'clock, "Gothic Sculpture" by Harry D.M. Grier; at 3 o'clock, "Cathedral Windows," by Harry D.M. Grier and, at the same hour, "Design in Dress: Italian Renaissance Models," by Grace Cornell.

ENGINEERS working on gun designs, chemists seeking better and more powerful explosives and designers planning pursuit planes are exerting enormous pressure on the men who conceive and build the big bombers fighting for mastery of the air over Europe.

OLIVER WENDELL HOLMES THE YOUNGER was born 100 years ago yesterday. Nine years ago the rich red draperies of the old Supreme Court chamber in the Capitol fell behind his black-robed figure for the last time. Six years ago he died. But today he is alive on the bench.

The following letter from a young woman living in London to an aunt who is a New York school teacher, indicates in a measure, the manner in which the younger generation is bearing up under present conditions.
PITTSBURGH, March 8 -- Officials of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, C.I.O., acted today to obtain a new agreement on wages from the United States Steel Corporation.

OF making books on the American Presidency there seems no end, but the recent crop disproves the biblical warning that "much study is a weariness of the flesh." Of the several volumes which the Presidential election, the third term and the ever-enlarging authority of the President combined to make timely, Professor Corwin's treatise is by all odds the most comprehensive.

THAT young expert in old books, Henry Gamadge, may now be counted a regular member of the choice company of the best fiction sleuths. In the latest Gamadge chronicle he is called in as book expert to solve a puzzle of attempted fraud with which a volume of Byron's poems is strangely connected.

The State Employment Service is endeavoring to convince employers in the defense industries that it is easier, cheaper and more effective to use the facilities of the State organization than to "steal" skilled workers from other employers, Richard C. Brockway, director of the employment service, disclosed yesterday.

Maurice Garreau-Dombasle, political representative in the United States of General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Free French forces, charged yesterday that Germany was violating the terms of the Franco-German armistice by preparing to start aircraft factories in unoccupied France to offset aid coming to the British from this country.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Women belonging to the "American Peace Mobilization" made in the Senate and before the White House today what they described as "last-ditch" demonstrations against the lease-lend bill.

The stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation rather than its employes bore the brunt of the depression between 1929 and 1933, according to an analysis of the company in a monograph on the "measurement of the social performance of business" issued last week by the Temporary National Economic Committee.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 8 -- Yugoslavia will sign a pact of nonaggression with the Reich within the next week, this correspondent was informed tonight by sources close to the government.

Enlisted men assigned to Jersey shore stations of the United States Coast Guard are complaining because their ration allowances have been reduced from $1 a day to 82 cents and in some cases to 72 cents, according to protests received from Cape May and other points where guard units are established, it was revealed yesterday.

A pool of oil or gasoline suggests mother-of-pearl in its surface colors. Almost any solution on which a film floats is iridescent. The color of a film depends on its thickness. One which has a thickness of 47/10,000,000 of an inch looks purple in reflected white light.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- White-haired Jacob Walz (the Apaches called him Snowbeard) spun a silver dollar in the air and swallowed a tumbler of whisky before he caught it again in his thorny hand one day in 1867. He laughed in the direction of the sand-and-sunburnt single-blanket Jackass prospector elbowed down among his whiskers at the end of the rough mesquite wood bar in the 'dobe saloon.

While there has been no official indication that the government contemplates taking over supplies of aluminum in private hands, fear of such a possibility led many manufacturers last week to speed the processing or cutting up of material in stock, reports yesterday indicated.

Retail trade here continued active last week, although recent percentage gains were reduced in comparison with a year ago because of the early Easter in 1940. Department store volume was estimated as about 3 per cent ahead, which was considered a good showing in view of rising pre-Easter sales last year.

Units of Adolf Hitler's armies passed last week over Bulgarian plains that thudded fifteen centuries ago to the march of Attila the Hun. The green-clad Germans had entered mountainous Bulgaria without firing a shot. In Berlin's words the units were part of "the army of Balkan security," an army whose bayonets, tanks and machine guns were ready for use against any disturber of Bulgarian peace.

The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York will give a dinner on Friday at the Town Hall Club honoring Irving Berlin, who has donated royalties from his song "God Bless America" to Boy and Girl Scouts in Greater New York. Mrs. Ogden White, chairman of the Girl Scout fund drive for 1941, will preside.

CARL VAN DOREN has written 125,000 words of a manuscript that probably will throw more new light on the American Revolution than has any book published in the last hundred years. In his study on Central Park West -- a room lined with source books of American history -- he talked for two and one-half hours of the book that he is now writing and that probably will be published in October.

FOR those who know and love Vermont hills or, for that matter, any hills, "Light on a Mountain," Gerald Warner Brace's new novel, will be a heart-warming experience. He knows his country and the characters who people it; he knows the contours and the temper of the land throughout the seasons of the year and the effects they bring.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- While Congress has been debating the lease-lend bill President Roosevelt and his advisers have been actively pursuing plans to carry out its main objectives. These aims, as officially expressed, are to promote the defense of any country the survival of which the President deems vital to the defense of the United States.

UNLIKE most foreign film stars arriving in this country, Jean Gabin debarked from the liner Exeter last Tuesday morning to discover that a film he made five years ago -- "Pepe le Moko" -- had only enjoyed its American premiere the night previous at the World Cinema.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska -- Working with all speed and spending some $50,000,000, both the Army and the Navy are engaged in great construction programs in Alaska, strengthening the nation's outlying defenses in the Pacific. The mainland and the islands are of immense strategic importance, commanding as they do a vast sector of the ocean and being at one point only fifty miles from the tip of Siberia and 700 miles from Japan.

POSSIBILITY that Germany may out the cables between England and the United States and then try to disrupt radio communication between the two countries by "jamming" the wavelengths is foreseen by Gerald C. Gross, chief of the international division of the Federal Communications Commission.

With Miss Anne DeWitt Pell as chairman, a junior committee has been formed for the Waltz Ball to be given on April 18 at the Ritz-Carlton to advance the work of the National Orchestral Association. This group is now assisting with preparations for the ball, along with the general benefit committee, headed by Mrs. Henry A. Schroeder.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 8 -- South American countries are revising their attitude toward the war as the result of Adolf Hitler's recent diplomatic victories in the Balkans, the extension of German influence in Europe and reports of the renewal of submarine warfare against British shipping.

In ordinary parlance, any policy issued by a life insurance company, the principal amount of which is payable upon the death of the insured, has been considered a "life insurance policy." The United States Supreme Court holds that a "single premium life policy," issued in conjunction with an annuity contract, does not come within the estate tax exemption of life insurance.

Yesterday's brief session on the New York Stock Exchange did nothing to alter the picture of the week's trading. The week ended dull, with prices mixed. Trading was the second smallest for a Saturday in six months. The total was 153,290 shares, compared with 141,190 on the preceding Saturday.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on March 1 amounted to 263,176,000 barrels, according to data reported to the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the preceding week, the stocks represented an increase of 1,393,000 barrels, comprising a rise of 1,450,000 in stocks of domestic crude but a decline of 57,000 in stocks of foreign crude.

Convinced that in the present confused "thinking," dependence on propaganda and snap judgments formed from casual reading of headlines and listening to commentators there is nothing more necessary than a reiteration of the first principles of logical behavior, Fordham College has intensified its program of applied philosophy, especially in the junior classes.

MIAMI, Fla., March 8 -- Tropical rain cracked down with unabated fury today on this gay Winter resort, deluged the ball park, confounded civic authorities and washed out the first of two games booked between the Giants and Red Sox.

With a record of nine victories in ten engagements, Miss Dorothy Hudson of the Riverdale Country School for Girls took first place in the metropolitan interscholastic girls' invitation fencing tournament on the Salle Santelli strips yesterday.

The auditorium of the Museum of Modern Art resounded with a din of soprano war whoops, yells and screams yesterday morning and the hair of 400 young heads shot upward as eight Tewa Indians from the Tesuque Pueblo in New Mexico menacingly hopped and gesticulated throughout the performance of several of their traditional war dances.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 8 (UP) -- Premier Ion Antonescu revealed today that Rumania had given Reichsfuehrer Hitler, Premier Mussolini and Reich Marshal Hermann Goering veto power over all Rumanian economic agreements or contracts with foreign countries.

MEXICO, land of flowers, is to be visited soon by garden club members from all over the United States. The Texas clubs, following their State convention in Harlingon, in the Lower Rio Grands Valley, March 12-14, will conduct their sixth annual pilgrimage to Mexico, March 14-24.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The lease-lend bill, with its potential billions in munitions, ships and food for the aid of Britain, was passed tonight by the Senate in exactly the form desired by the Administration. The vote was 60 to 31.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The 1941 season, expected to be in some respects the greatest the Sandhills have ever known, is rapidly reaching its peak. For forty years golf has been, and still is, the major activity of the entire Sandhills region throughout the Winter tourist season.
THE annual Eastern championships come to a close today at the Park Central Hotel with a two-session contest for mixed pairs, Play will begin at 2 and 8:30 P.M.

TO the information published in Paris in 1470 that John, known as of the Good Mountain, or Gutenberg, invented printing and printed a Bible at Mainz, it has been said that little of any importance has been added in the intervening years of speculation and controversy.
A number of special displays are to be held by galleries at New York flower show time, March 17-22.

THERE is a disarmingly natural, but by no means unimaginative, plain realism in this story of a mushroom town of the gold-dust country of '49 and '50. Unromantic in a common sense of the word, since the reader is not minded to identify himself with any individual, it has yet a personal appeal in its unforced naturalness.

MORE than $100 in cash and a number of merchandise prizes will be awarded in a new photographic contest just announced by Pequot Mills. The entries must illustrate the phrase "Sleeping Beauty." Full details may be obtained by writing Pequot Mills, "Sleeping Beauty" Contest Editor, Tenth Floor, 29 West Fifty-seventh Street.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., March 8 (AP) -- Indiana ended Michigan's seven-year stretch of Western Conference indoor track and field championships tonight.

Books should play a more important part in the expanding vocational school program, Russell Munn of the Cleveland Public Library, who has just completed a study of the use of books in vocational training for defense, suggested yesterday.
IF this war continues very much longer German women may be called upon to play a role comparable in importance to that of their fathers, husbands and brothers in the front line.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The advisability of continuing engineering courses through the Summer vacation to advance the 1942 graduation of engineers for participation in the national defense program was the subject of all-day discussions here today by the members of the Advisory Committee on Engineering of the United States Office of Education.

Many and varied problems have faced the $14,000,000,000 utility industry since the enactment of the Public Utility Holding Company Act in 1935. Not a few of them arose out of the activities of utility holding companies in the halcyon days of the late Twenties; not the least conspicuous in this regard was the United Corporation -- the "all-time super-super" holding company organized by the Morgan-Bonbright-Drexel interests in January, 1929.

Miss Perry, whose "Milk Production" (written with Celeste Slauson) appeared last year, writes about national industries in a way to give grade school pupils a realization of their importance and magnitude. This book describes valuable food fishes, methods of catching, including line fishing, otter trawling, seines and nets, traps for salmon, lobster and crab pots, oyster production, marketing fish and conservation of food fishes.

MUCH illuminating material about drivers and the fitness of applicants for license to drive is being developed at the second annual training course for license examiners of the Motor Vehicle Bureau, which opened its sessions for the New York City area last week.

JEAN HOLLOWAY, a 20-year-old girl full of romantic dreams, comes to the big city on vacation from college, writes some of her thoughts on paper, has them produced as a play, and within a few months finds herself earning large fees as the successful author of "big time" radio dramas.

Mrs. Olmsted Houghton of 1 East End Avenue will give a tea on Tuesday at her home for members of the benefit committee working for the success of the special performance to be given by Ruth and Paul Draper on the night of March 30 at the Guild Theatre, in aid of the Kips Bay Boys Club.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 8 -- Problems of public relief in New Jersey will be studied by fifty Princeton University upper-classmen in the School of Public and International Affairs this Spring, it was announced today by Dana G. Munro, director of the School of Affairs.

OCEAN CITY, Md., March 8 -- After one rescue boat had been capsized by a giant wave, the captain and twenty-seven of the crew of the Norwegian freighter Olaf Bergh, which is in the war service of Great Britain, were taken today from the vessel which ran aground here yesterday morning.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 8 -- The 70-foot yawl Gulf Stream, out of Houston, Texas, scudded across the turbulent Florida straits to a hairline corrected-time victory in the Havana-Key West race early today, giving Skipper Dudley C. Sharp a half-share in the most coveted trophy of the Winter ocean racing season.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 8 (AP) -- British South African forces, veering inland after their conquest of Italian Somaliland, struck deep into Southeastern Ethiopia today in a drive that, British military men said, was pointed toward Addis Ababa.

MIDNIGHT, the black stallion of the story, was born wild and never tamed. His mother was Lady Ebony, Major Howard's thoroughbred, who was enticed away by the big chestnut, the leader of a band of wild mares.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- Plans to install an electron microscope as an addition to the research equipment of the Eldridge R. Johnson Foundation for Medical Physics at the University of Pennsylvania were announced tonight by Dr. Alfred Newton Richards, vice president of the university in charge of medical affairs.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Roosevelt still is regarded as the "world's busiest man" in the "toughest job on earth," despite the addition to his staff in the last two years of five executive assistants, those men he specified should have "a passion for anonymity."

I HAD hoped that some one known as an authority on the Constitution would offer comments on Professor Commager's review of '"The Struggle for Judicial Supremacy," which recently appeared in your columns. In the absence of such a volunteer, is it in order for a layman to speak?

WHETHER or not American troops enter the war, there is no doubt that the energies of this country will be concentrated increasingly to achieve the downfall of Hitler. We shall do more than make the machines and munitions.

Details of the new plan to feed the Army under a centralized "commodity allowance" system instead of the present "money allowance" system whereby each Army post buys its own rations, were revealed yesterday by John A. Martin, chief of the Subsistence and Supply Branch, Division of Purchases of the OPM.

THE next time a motorist wishes to orient himself in the scheme of his 31,500,000-vehicle nation, he should drive slowly by a traffic-counting mechanism set at the roadside. There were 532 of these silent telltales in use last year in the United States, an average of better than eleven each in forty-six States excepting Delaware and New Jersey.

BERLIN, March 8 -- German speedboats are reported today to have taken an active hand last night in the German counter-blockade of Britain. Attacking a convoy off the southeast English coast, they sank two British destroyers and ten merchant vessels totaling 45,600 tons and then returned unscathed to their bases, the Germans assert.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., March 8 -- Founded to vitalize the study of economics, a student corporation at Upsala College here is putting its big-business counterparts to shame by earning huge profits on its investment.

Design patents as a means of protecting styles came to the fore in the fashion industries last week following the Supreme Court decisions against the Fashion Originators Guild of America and the Millinery Creators Guild, but the development left many with the belief that new avenues of fashion and design protection in many lines, particularly Federal legislation, are probably due for more intensive exploration.

IT was suggested here last week that our thinking about democracy today might find sustenance and direction in the pages of Whitman's "Democratic Vistas." For that word which comes to our lips so often now needs to be clarified in our minds.

Under the direction of the American Association for Adult Education, new techniques in the writing of books, to make them both readable and instructive, have been evolved. During the last five years a series of experimental studies have been conducted in a special "Readability Laboratory" at Teachers College.

EDINBURGH, March 8 -- We were glad to see the end of February. That usually wet month, with a little breath and promise of Spring, belied its seasonal offering this year. The papers tell us the snow and blizzards in these parts were the worst for forty years.
The few questions that remain to be answered in college basketball will be answered this week.

With the development of modern education theories, which are fixing more attention on individual pupils than on subject-matter, programs of teacher training and the improvement of teachers already in service have been affected by a consequent "greater emphasis on the techniques of applied psychology," it was reported last week by Max L. Hutt, director of the educational clinic at City College.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 8 -- Six railway carriages occupied by Bulgarians passed through Yugoslavia today bound for Germany, according to information from a Yugoslav railway official tonight.

LOS ANGELES -- United States Army Air Corps tacticians, who have great hopes for the future as a result of the new 120-man high-altitude flight course under way at Wright Field, last week turned their attention to a little shack alongside the runways at Union Air Terminal, Burbank, Calif., where theory has been translated into grim reality.
ATHENS, March 8 -- The Greek Government proclaimed openly tonight its determination to refuse any and all offers of peace or armistice with the Axis powers.
The epidemic of measles which began in the city about Jan. 1 continues to spread, according to figures made public by the Department of Health yesterday.
CLEVELAND, March 8 -- the silver anniversary show of the Western Reserve Kennel Club opened today with an entry of 1,103 dogs.

TOKYO, March 8 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka was understood tonight to be planning to leave tomorrow for Moscow and Berlin on a mission that he hoped would result in a Russo-Japanese non-aggression treaty and a clarification of Japan's relations with her Axis partners.

LACONIA-GILFORD, N.H., March 8 -- A record field of forty star athletes competed today in a raging snowstorm in a grueling 18-kilometer cross-country race, the first half of the nineteenth annual United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's championships.

The high-spirited young lady who tells this adventurous tale is a poor relation; and when Sue Carter and her aunt are invited to be house guests through the festivities of a rich cousin's wedding she doesn't guess that the delightful surprise is itself part of a grim mystery.

The customs of burial in Bermuda gave the murderer hope of getting away with an ingenious new means of sudden death. But this story has been under way a long time when that murder occurs. And the most important crime is not a murder but a kidnapping.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- If the President signs the lease-lend bill on Wednesday, the Navy and War Departments will take steps to make it immediately operative.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 9 -- Champion Blakeen Eiger, spotless white standard poodle owned and handled by Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of the Blakeen Kennels of Katonah, N.Y., tonight gained the title of best in show at the silver anniversary event of the Providence County Kennel Club.

VICHY, France, March 9 (AP) -- The quotation of industrial shares on the Paris Stock Exchange, which it has been announced will begin on March 17, was interpreted by financial observers today as marking an acceleration of German-French economic cooperation, with the Germans likely to buy heavily into French enterprise.

Belief in God means belief in a plan for all the world, in universal principles that shall guide nations and peoples into a brotherhood of righteousness and Justice, the Right Rev. Harry T. Moore, Bishop of Dallas, Texas, said yesterday in his sermon as guest preacher at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.

WITH THE GREEK FORCES, on the Central Albania Front, March 9 -- Premier Mussolini made an unheralded inspection tour of Fascist defenses around the besieged city of Tepeleni early last week, captured Fascist officers disclosed today.

Regardless of the fact that we are living in solemn and tragic times, which scarcely permits us to think of other things, it is the duty of every Christian to remember that his first and greatest allegiance is to Jesus Christ, the Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill, pastor emeritus of the Brick Presbyterian Church, said yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

A survey just completed by the Real Estate Board of New York shows a jump in the percentage of vacant old-law tenement dwelling units in Manhattan during 1940, following a substantial increase of such vacancies in 1939.

PITTSBURGH, March 9 -- Although steel consumers are concerned more over deliveries than the impending second-quarter price announcements, the schedules of quotations may be delayed further pending the outcome of wage negotiations between the Steel Workers Organizing Committee and the Carnegie Illinois Steel Corporation, the principal subsidiary of United States Steel.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 9 -- More than 1,000,000 pieces of clothing and equipment valued at $2,000,000 have been issued to the 25,855 draftees who have arrived at the Fort Dix recruit reception center since the first draft call Nov. 26.

MEXICO CITY, March 9 -- El Magnifico, the fallen idol of the bull ring, was downed by the first bull he tackled today in his comeback campaign from "supreme disgrace," but he recovered and dispatched three bulls before retiring in some doubt as to whether he had won back his public.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The British Government cannot accept the theory that it should lift its blockade of Europe to permit the feeding of natives of the German-occupied territories, holding that this would only "postpone the day of victory and the restoration of the conquered peoples to physical and spiritual freedom," the British Embassy said in a statement issued here today.

The C.I.O. can win a company-wide election in Tom L. Girdler's Republic Steel Corporation any time it decides to ask the National Labor Relations Board to hold one, David J. McDonald, secretary-treasurer of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, told 500 memberg of the Association of Catholic Trade Unionists at their fifth annual communion breakfast yesterday at the Hotel Capitol.
Democracy needs a flaming zealot to meet the menace of fascism, the Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton, pastor of the Broadway Methodist Temple, 174th Street and Broadway, said yesterday in his sermon.

The report for 1940 of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $12,603,970 after charges, taxes and reserves for depreciation, but before mine depletion. The net was equal to $2.49 each on the 5,071,260 capital shares.

A message from 129 Americans of Irish descent to President De Valera urging him to grant Great Britain the bases in Eire necessary to protect the shipping lanes between Great Britain and the United States was made public yesterday. The message was signed by a number of persons widely known in educational circles, on the bench and in the theatrical world.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 9 (AP) -- British General headquarters issued this communique today:

The program presented by the American Ballad Singers, under Elie Siegmeister, at their second annual concert last night in Town Hall, provided about as comprehensive a survey of native ballads and folksongs of this country as could be packed into one evening's entertainment.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 9 (via Berlin) (AP) -- Several carloads of Russian wheat arrived here today to help in relieving an acute food shortage. It was the first shipment arranged under the Belgian-Russian trade deal, with Germany acting to speed up deliveries.

Columbia University's School of Law experimented last year with a student "problem seminar" engaging the talents of practicing attorneys and judges in New York, and the result points toward a development of "major significance" in legal education, Dean Young B. Smith declared yesterday in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 9 -- Yugoslavia and Soviet Russia are expected to issue a joint declaration of friendship simultaneously this week with the signature of a Yugoslav-German non-aggression pact and statement of amity with Germany, it was disclosed to this correspondent today by circles close to the government.

HAVANA, March 9 -- The Dodgers were involved in two splits today. They split a double-header with the Indians, and Van Lingle Mungo, the perennial bad boy from Pageland, S.C., split with President Larry MacPhail.

Four Negro singers and Spencer Odom, accompanist and arranger, who have been performing over the radio for more than ten years in a group known as the Southernaires, late yesterday afternoon made their New York concert debut at Town Hall.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 9 (UP) -- The appearance of German Stuka dive-bombers on the island of Rhodes within sight of Turkey's southern coast and arrival of more Nazi troops at the Thracian frontier tonight hastened wartime measures bringing Turkey close to a state of emergency.

VICHY, France, March 9 (UP) -- Great speculation was attached here today to reports from Nazi-held Paris that the immobilized French fleet might go into action against Britain unless the British blockade was relaxed to permit needed foodstuffs to reach France.

BOSTON, March 9 (AP) -- Boston's high-powered Bruins gave Paul Bibeault, the National Hockey League's newest goalie, a blistering welcome tonight when they overwhelmed the Montreal Canadiens, 8 -- 0, before a 10,000 crowd at the Boston Garden.

Although kilowatt hours sold in 1940 by the United Illuminating Company rose 17 per cent and operating revenues increased 8.8 per cent, net Profit for the year was almost exactly the same as in 1939, according to the annual report by James W. Hooks, president. Net profit was $3,614,319, or $5.80 a share, against $3,609,146, or $5.79 a share, in 1939.
LONDON, March 9 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -- Stars from six Pacific Coast League baseball teams beat those from four major league clubs, 6 to 4, in an exhibition game today.

George H. Hodges, 65 years old, of 17 East Ninety-fifth Street, died yesterday in his apartment as the result of a shotgun wound that the police said was self-inflicted. Near his body was found the gun, from which the shell had been exploded.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Sears, Roebuck's "Spring value demonstration" 116-page booklet, now in the mails, confines its price-cutting chiefly to close-outs of 1940 and odd-lot merchanise. Tires and sheetings are featured at the same prices as in the big 1941 Spring and Summer catalogue and, as in the Ward bargain booklet of earlier this week, a number of new Spring apparel lines are introduced.

CHUNGKING, China, March 9 (UP) -- The Chinese Communist party has presented two sets of demands to the People's Political Council, which Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek has described as "just like the demands served on the government and the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] by the Japanese" prior to the opening of the Chinese-Japanese conflict in July, 1937, it was revealed tonight.

It is interesting that some of the most poignant and moving contributions to the literature of this war have been written by people of no literary pretensions. A notable example is the letter of a young British war pilot written to his mother just before his death in battle.

A special benefit performance of George Bernard Shaw's "The Doctor's Dilemma," with Katharine Cornell and Raymond Massey in the leading roles, will be held under the auspices of the Volunteer Workers' Committee of the Social Service Bureau on Thursday evening at the Shubert Theatre.

Election of Joseph Clark Baldwin, Republican candidate for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, as a step toward national unity on foreign policy and a check on the Roosevelt Administration on domestic policies, was urged last night by Wendell L. Willkie in a radio speech from station WOR and in letters sent to the Republican and independent voters of the district.

The Girl Scout 1941 Fund Drive for $85,000 will be launched today by 600 volunteer workers, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Ogden White, general chairman of the drive, which will continue to March 31.

Throw away your old hunting boots, discard the worn-out hunting jacket, toss out the empty shell boxes and don't bother to keep empty cartridges, but send your 1940 Duck Stamp to Ducks Unlimited and help carry on the work of this organization.

After having broken records for the number of entries in all regular events, the fifteenth annual Eastern Bridge Tournament came to an end at Hotel Park Central last night with spirited competition in a mixed pairs contest for the George Reith Memorial Trophy.

AN EASTERN CANADIAN PORT, March 9 (Canadian Press) -- A war which made him a German prisoner for four days and gave him a leading role in the drama of Dakar brought Captain George d'Argenlieu to this British Dominion today to explain to Frenchmen in Canada and French-Canadians the objectives of the Free French movement of General Charles de Gaulle.

Sherwood Anderson's literary career was the result of a frustration. A thoughtful, dreamy man, he spent his early years knocking about the country, doing almost any sort of work he could get in factory or farmyard. Finally, approaching middle age, he found himself the proprietor of a fairly prosperous paint factory in Elyria, Ohio.

LONDON, March 9 -- Ernest Bevin, the Minister of Labor, has launched a vigorous recruiting campaign for women workers, adopting for his slogan the old cry of the last war for "the first hundred thousand." Moreover, he wants them within two weeks, which is before the time that the organization for handling them will be perfected.

Several unaccountably neglected compositions by Mozart figured on the program devoted to works by that composer presented by the orchestra of the New Friends of Music, under Fritz Stiedry, late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall with Nathan Milstein, violinist, as soloist. In addition the schedule contained the familiar "Prague" symphony in D major.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 9 -- The attitude of the Turkish press continues firm in face of the Germans' increasing concentrations in Bulgaria. Much attention has been aroused by the article written by Falih Rifki Atay, which was published in today's Ankara newspaper, Ulus, which, like editorials in other newspapers summarized last week, urges firmness in face of the German war of nerves.

The first annual report of the Community Service Society of New York since its establishment by the merger of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor and the Charity Organization Society has been made public by Walter S. Gifford, chairman of the board, and Barklie Henry, president.

From time immemorial one of the few mitigating circumstances of war has been the respect of the soldier for a valorous enemy. Defenders of cities have been allowed to march out with drums beating and flags flying because they had fought bravely. Grant would not take Lee's sword and he let the Confederates ride their horses home "for the Spring plowing."

VICHY, March 9 -- Three important laws have been approved by the Council of Ministers, which, according to unofficial information, were designed by the Minister of Finance to help to reduce note circulation or at least to prevent it from rising.

A great finish to a great indoor season was the verdict of the fans as they left Madison Square Garden Saturday night after the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, meet had rung down the curtain. World records in the classic Casey 600, the pole vault and the shot-put, grand competition and some of the most exciting relays of the campaign helped make the program the big success it was.

The criteria by which to judge texts used in schools and colleges should be their basis in truth, their relevance and their perspective, Joseph Jablonower of the board of examiners of the Board of Education, said in an address yesterday morning at the meeting of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, at the St. Felix Street Playhouse, near Lafayette Avenue.
AS a result of a failure in Washington to make a supplementary appropriation for NYA, 7,000 NYA workers were recently dismissed from employment and 6,000 others are slated to go by July.

Further improvement in the advertising and selling practices of retail establishments in metropolitan New York is revealed by the Better Business Bureau of New York City in a report on the bureau's activities in the merchandise field during 1940.

THIS recent death of Gutzon Borglum, the man who carved mountains, brings to mind a few of his forgotten works. What became of them deponent sayeth not. Perhaps some reader can clear away the mystery.

Events tonight: "The Bartered Bride," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 o'clock; Jan Peerce, song recital, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Martha Lipton, song recital, assisted by Ernst Victor Wolff, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; Blanche Raisen, violin recital, MacDowell Club, 8:30; concert under auspices of the Composers Press, Haubiel Studios, 853 Seventh Avenue, 9; free concert of music for ancient instruments, New York Public Library, 8:30; Aubrey Pankey, baritone, and Abbey Simon, piano, joint recital, Brooklyn College, 8:30.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -- Patricia Morison will be suspended from salary at Paramount tomorrow for her refusal over the weekend to accept a loan-out assignment to Republic's "Singin' Hills" with Gene Autry. To replace the actress Paramount has lent Virginia Dale to Republic for the Autry film.

If the United States is to be the molder of the future, it must be a moving part in the creation of a federation of States for the new order that will arise from the chaos of today, Dr. Frank Kingdon told the congregation of the Free Synagogue at Carnegie Hall yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Following is the text of a statement on blockade policy issued tonight by the British Embassy:

In the ceremonies that marked the celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the city's Health Department the Mayor advocated the creation of a municipal medical research bureau -- the first proposed in the country. His reasons must appeal to every physician as well as to the public.

DETROIT, March 9 (AP) -- Officials of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., announced completion today of plans for a strike of 1,700 workers at the Midland Steel Products Company starting at 11 A.M. tomorrow.

Activity in the wholesale market continued brisk last week despite shortages and slow deliveries. Volume orders were placed on all types of dressy untrimmed coats and suits. Action in the popular-priced field reached peak proportions, and certain items had to be cancelled because of insufficient materials.

LONDON, Monday, March 10 (AP) -- The German Air Fleet smashed three times at London last night and early today and sent its bombers roaring over Britain in a spurt of widespread raiding such as Britons had not seen for weeks.

Hallgarten Co., bankers, for the last twenty-one years at 44 Pine Street, have leased large space in 44 Wall Street, northwest corner of William Street, and will occupy about May 1 after alterations. Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agents of the building, arranged the lease.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Paul Runyan, former P.G.A. champion from White Plains, N.Y., clipped four strokes from par for a 67 to take a one-stroke lead in the opening round of the fifty-four-hole West Coast open golf tournament today.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., March 9 -- Complete satisfaction with the 207th Coast Artillery, the Old Seventh, in the first two weeks of its thirteen-week intensive training program was expressed today by Captain Leslie O. Stewart, plans and training officer of the unit.

Mrs. Margaret J. Livingston, who was born in Armagh, Ireland, five days after General William Henry Harrison of "Tippecanoe and Tyler too" fame had been inaugurated as President of the United States, celebrated her one hundredth birthday anniversary yesterday at a party given by her eldest son, Henry S. Livingston, at his home, 2600 Arlington Avenue, Spuyten Duyvil.

HONG KONG, Monday, March 10 (AP) -- Chinese troops in vigorous counter-attacks recaptured the Kwangtung Province cities of Tinpak and Shuitung from Japanese soldiers, Chinese sources reported today in direct opposition to Japanese reports that the area had been evacuated quietly by their men yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9 -- A C.I.O. union strike committee today ordered a walkout tomorrow morning of the 1,500 production and maintenance employes of the J.G. Brill Company, which has $418,661 in national defense contracts.
A recent letter to THE TIMES discussed traffic problems and the oft-recurring matter of bus versus trolley cars. Some of the remarks do not seem to be borne out by fact nor experience.
Your editorial "City Income Tax" raises a pertinent question. Just how could a city income tax relieve real estate?
BERLIN, March 9 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner K.M. Landis disclosed tonight he had rescinded a ruling which prevented major league clubs from sending purchased players back to the minors without first obtaining waivers.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Sharply higher ocean freight rates on imported vegetable oils and fat, strength in cottonseed oil and rumors that shipping space would not be available until later in the season for the movement of palm oil from the Far East to this country had some effect on the lard market last week.

Twenty-four hundred listeners who gathered yesterday afternoon in historic Plymouth Church, now known as Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, to hear 300 singers in seven choirs, brought reminiscences of the crowded congregations seen there each Sunday in the days when Henry Ward Beecher preached.

Persons who have had to do with the publication today of William Davey's first novel, "Dawn Breaks the Heart," are quick to mention Thomas Wolfe when they speak of the book. Early last year Madeleine Boyd, literary agent, cried "discovery" and brought to Howell, Soskin an 800,000-word manuscript.

Mayor La Guardia mingled a warning to racketeers with congratulations to merchants yesterday as he officially opened the new freight house and loading platforms of the Bronx Terminal Market, 149th and Exterior Streets, before 2,000 produce men and Bronx residents.

The ultimate success of most strikes is to some extent dependent upon public sympathy with and support of the strikers. This is especially true in the field of transportation, where strikes inevitably mean hardship and inconvenience to the public and are certain, under the best circumstances, to stir up a good deal of resentment.

The New York Life Insurance Company, in its annual report for 1940, issued for release today by George L. Harrison, president, reveals that the company paid $204,394,345 to policy holders or beneficiaries. Of this sum, $135,015,066 was paid to living policy holders and $69,379,279 to beneficiaries.

The Community Service Society of New York is only a year old, but it is the largest private family welfare organization in the world. It represents a merger of two of the most efficient and trusted charitable enterprises in the city -- The Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor and the Charity Organization Society.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices declined to 85.9 from 86.0. The principal group rise took place in textile products, where increases in silk, print cloth, and other components caused the group index to rise 1.6 per cent to 82.8. In the farm products group there were nine decreases compared with three increases, but the increases, the largest being in potatoes, offset the decreases, which were chiefly in livestock.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 9 (UP) -- The German Minister in Athens was reported tonight to have given the Greek Government a "last chance" to make peace with Italy, and unconfirmed rumors circulated that King George might abdicate to make way for a peace government.

Today is varnishing day at the National Academy of Design. The 115th annual exhibition, installed in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, will be open to academicians, associates, exhibitors and fellows this morning from 9 o'clock until noon, and there is to be a preview reception this evening at 8:30.

The program of the sixteenth and final week of the Metropolitan Opera Association was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager. The opera which will close the season on Saturday evening, March 22, will be Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung."

MIAMI, Fla., March 9 -- The Giants today were still striving to solve that elusive piece of business of winning an exhibition game in the South, but found themselves no more successful than on their Cuban invasion a week ago.

A two-story building and four acres at 574 to 600 Ferry Street, Newark, N.J., were sold by the Bassick Company to the Robert-shaw Realty Company of Montclair for investment. It was used to manufacture casters and furniture hardware until the seller consolidated operations in Bridgeport, Conn., about ten years ago. The David T. Houston Company was the broker.
CHICAGO, March 9 -- The Chicago Black Hawks clinched fifth place in the National Hockey League tonight with a 2-2 tie game against the New York Americans before 13,982 spectators.

The champion team of the Manhattan Chess Club, although in a triple tie with City College and the Steinitz Chess Club in the match record, leads by half a point in the game score as a result of its victory by 61 1/2 -- 3 1/2 over Empire City in the second round for the Metropolitan Chess League title yesterday.

Leading the list of the week's five new film arrivals is the Frank Capra-Robert Riskin production "Meet John Doe," co-starring Gary Cooper and Barbara Stanwyck, which will have its world premiere Wednesday night simultaneously at the Rivoli and Hollywood Theatres.

Chiding Americans who "want to keep the country just as it is," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the faculty of Catholic University declared yesterday in the second in a series of Lenten sermons at St. Patrick's Cathedral that "the American way of life is not something to be saved but to be amended."

Thirty-three faculty members at City College and Brooklyn College who have been accused of communism in testimony before the Rapp-Coudert Committee appeared yesterday afternoon at a mass meeting at Mecca Temple at which three of their number, as spokesmen for the rest, denounced the testimony as false and assailed the committee as unfair.

CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- The Stewart-Warner Corporation today reported for 1940 consolidated net profit of $1,470,804, equal to $1.18 a common share, compared with $553,224, or 45 cents a share, in 1939. Sales in the year amounted to $29,272,000, an increase of 13 per cent over those of the previous year.

After a week of diplomatic manoeuvring and German military activity, the zero hour in the Balkans seems close at hand. Hitler may strike at any time. Turkey has been temporarily quieted by threats and worthless promises. A non-aggression pact with Yugoslavia is prepared.

LACONIA-GILFORD, N.H., March 9 -- Torger Tokle, 22-year-old Norwegian, proved today to 6,000 who braved blustery weather and a snowstorm that he is the mightiest ski jumper in the history of the sport.

ON his one-man expedition to the Arctic, the Vicomte Gontran de Poncins collected a store of unusual experiences which he has converted into an unusual book, with the collaboraton of Lewis Galantiere. It is called "Kabloona."* Mystifying as that word sounds, it means nothing more formidable to Eskimo ears than "the white man."
American planes will play a larger and larger part in the air battles over Europe this Spring as the year's campaigns spread from the Balkans to other theatres of war.

VICHY, France, March 9 -- France's determination to defend her own colonies in Africa against any outside aggression was publicly proclaimed once more today after a conference of French military, naval and aviation chiefs with the defender of French Africa, General Maxime Weygand.

Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr., Ambassador to the exiled governments in England, and W. Averell Harriman, ordered to London by President Roosevelt as special defense liasion official, will leave by Clipper this morning from La Guardia Field for Lisbon, instead of on Tuesday morning, as they originally had planned.
MIAMI, Fla., March 9 -- Secretary Knox said President Roosevelt had indicated to him in a thirty-minute telephone conversation last night that he would sign the lease-lend bill on Wednesday.

THE TIMES of March 1 laments the retirement of Rear Admiral Woodward in times like these, as "a waste of valuable human material. * * * When experienced officers are so badly needed in the fighting services it is an anachronism that a more or less routine following of retirement regulations should deprive the Army and the Navy of their services.'"
The steamship Argentina is due today from Rio de Janeiro and in her holds is another large shipment of Argentine grapes, pears, plums, peaches and honeydew melons.

ROME, March 9 -- The Axis intention to prepare its peoples for President Roosevelt's future decisions in favor of Britain, now that the lease-lend bill has been approved by the Senate, was seen today as perhaps the main motive behind the campaign now being waged against the United States Government.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- With the normal international flow of wheat either greatly reduced or nonexistent grain traders are forced to rely on other factors as a price-making influence. As a result numerous conflicting reports keep the market in a highly nervous condition.

With only the intracity and Eastern League titles remaining to be settled, the selection committee for the fourth annual national intercollegiate invitation basketball tournament, to be held in Madison Square Garden on March 18, 19, 22 and 24, now has almost all the data it needs to fill out the eight-team field.

Prices on the Stock Exchange were all but motionless last week. Only one day did five-hour trading exceed 400,000 shares, and on Wednesday it fell to 286,000, lowest since early Autumn. Both in London's market and in ours there was no incentive to a movement of prices, either up or down.

TOKYO, Monday, March 10 (UP) -- A peace agreement ending the border conflict between French Indo-China and Thailand probably will be initialed here today, clearing the way for Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's departure for Berlin, Rome and Moscow, reliable informants said today.

Three openings of plays are scheduled for next week on Broadway. "Native Son," produced by Orson Welles and John Houseman, will appear on March 17 at the St. James; "My Fair Ladies," the Arthur Jarrett-Marcel Klauber comedy, on March 20 at the Hudson, and "Gabrielle," the Leonardo Bercovici dramatization of the Thomas Mann story, "Tristan," on March 21 at Maxine Elliott's.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 -- The Yankees concentrated so much fire in one big seven-run inning at Waterfront Park today that they were powerless against the Cardinals for the remainder of the game. But in that lone chapter the McCarthymen wrought so much damage that they bagged their second straight from the Missouri Red Birds and gained a one-game edge in the series.

A trend in packaging toward greater convenience in use without increased cost to the consumer is shown by the fifty-nine containers chosen from more than 30,000 entered in the tenth annual All-America Package Competition sponsored by Modern Packaging Magazine.

A plea for unity among Protestant groups was made by the Rev. Dr. C. Ivar Hellstrom of the Riverside Church yesterday afternoon at the annual religious meeting of the Protestant Teachers Association, an organization of 7,000 public school teachers, principals and officials.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The program for the coordination of American ocean shipping, designed to make the most efficient possible use of available tonnage, is now under way as the Division of Emergency Shipping, created this past week, has begun to function.

The upward trend of cotton prices, which started in the middle of February, was continued last week. Spot cotton and near-by futures contracts showed relatively moderate gains, but new-crop contracts advanced sharply. On the New York Cotton exchange the near positions recorded net advances for the week of 9 to 14 points, while the new-crop deliveries showed gains of 32 to 36 points.

The first example of the work of Carl Milles, Swedish-American sculptor, to be represented in the collection of modern sculpture of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will be placed on view today in the main entrance hall of the museum.

BARCELONA, Spain, March 9 -- The American Red Cross ship Cold Harbor sailed this afternoon for Marseille on the last leg of her voyage with supplies of food for hungry children. Captain Albert Moore expected to reach Marseille tomorrow afternoon and to leave on his return trip around March 14.

CLEMENTON, N.J., March 9 -- Pointers accounted for three of the four Places in the open shooting dog stake held by the Jersey Irish Setter Field Dog Club on the second day of its annual Spring trials on the course at Hidden Lakes, but a little black English setter, Merry Mary, owned by Dr. Sherman Ames of Easton, Pa., and handled by Bud Shaffer of Upper Black Eddy, took first prize today.

Professor Spahr's letter of March 5 raises important questions with regard to the savings theory of depressions. Hearings before the Temporary National Economic Committee during May, 1939, brought forth many facts and figures supporting this theory. The eminence and authority of the testifying economists, Dr. Hansen of Harvard, Dr. Currie of the Federal Reserve Board, Ralph W. Manuel, president of the Marquette National Bank, among many others, are not to be so quickly thrown aside.

After ten years of cynicism and materialism a definite trend toward a return to religion began five years ago, the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Farber, pastor of the Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue at Ninety-first Street, declared in his fifteenth anniversary sermon yesterday morning.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 9 -- The inner patio of the Everglades Club was the setting today for a large cocktail party at which Mr. and Mrs. Ira Follett Warner were hosts.
BERLIN, March 9 (AP) -- At least 28,000 tons of British shipping were claimed by the High Command today as victims of Nazi air and undersea raiders.

The New York Rangers had little trouble beating Turk Broda as they humbled the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Leaf goalie, well ahead in the running for the Vezina Trophy, saw his chances dwindle most unexpectedly in the face of a steady Ranger attack that netted an 8-to-5 triumph.

COPENHAGEN (German-Occupied Denmark), March 9 -- Premier Thorvald Stauntng last night made a speech of rather decisive character in the Students Union outlining the whole European situation and stressing the necessity for Denmark to adjust herself to present and future conditions in the new German-governed Europe.

LONDON, Monday, March 10 -- German raiders struck at London again the past night, as over Saturday night, in unbroken succession for many hours, dropping flares and incendiary and high-explosive bombs.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 9 -- A remarkable account of conditions in Italy is given by a thoroughly reliable though disillusioned Italian who has just arrived from a three-week tour of Northern Italy.

LONDON, March 9 -- Developments in the Balkan war situation in some respects add and in others diminish the City's perplexities in attempting to form some clear idea of what is likely to happen in the next few months.

The regular college basketball season here will end with a flourish tonight as City College and New York University settle the intracity title in the feature of a doubleheader at Madison Square Garden and Columbia opposes Dartmouth on the Lions' court in a contest likely to decide the Eastern League race.

GRANITE CITY, Ill., March 9 (AP) -- Manufacture of a "blitzkrieg can," similar to a type reportedly used by the Germans to land gasoline supplies undetected in their invasion of Norway, was begun last week by the National Enameling and Stamping Company under government contract.

LONDON, March 9 -- Martinus Poulsen, a well-known restaurateur associated with the Cafe de Paris and the Cafe Anglais, died last night as a result of enemy action. He was 47 years old. Before the war he was said to have controlled a chain of night clubs and restaurants worth more than 250,000.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., March 9 -- With a snowstorm raging a second day, Harry Hillman, brilliant ski teacher from Woodstock, Vt., made two superb slalom runs at Adirondack Loj today to win the second annual wilderness races of the Adirondack Mountain Club.

VICHY, France, March 9 (UP) -- The Japan-sponsored peace conference in Tokyo has reached a complete agreement for settlement of the frontier dispute between French Indo-China and Thailand on the basis of a second compromise plan formulated by Japanese Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka, it was announced tonight.
Miss Mildred O'Donnell of the Women's Swimming Association won the metropolitan A.A.U. senior women's 100-yard free style championship in a W.S.A.-sponsored meet in the London Terrace Pool yesterday.

The foreign exchange market last week developed little business and less in the way of important price changes worthy of that term, which reflects the fact that except at a month-end, when maturing contracts, have to be adjusted, the stabilization boards operating in the various currencies have things pretty much under control.

LONDON, March 9 -- Despite the breaking off of diplomatic relations with Bulgaria, and the strongest possible evidence that the Balkans soon may become the focus of Germany's attack on Great Britain, the stock markets here have continued to reflect an undiminished tone of confidence, with the gilt-edge securities again setting the pace.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Adoption by the Legislature of the 1941-42 budget, as revised by the Republican majority, is scheduled for Wednesday, to be followed by a drive for adjournment of the session before the Easter holidays. Only actual entrance of the United States into the war would interfere with the plans of the leaders, they have declared definitely.
Taxes wiped out all profits of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company in 1940, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Walter F. Brown, chairman of the board.

ATLANTA, March 9 (AP) -- Reading of depositions from injured passengers and testimony that motors were running at cruising speed and the radio tuned to a landing beam brought to a close today the Civil Aeronautic Board's public hearing on the recent crash of an Eastern Air Lines sleeper plane near here.

Proposals to merge the Celanese Corporation of America and its subsidiary, the Celluloid Corporation, will come before the annual meeting of the former company on April 9. Celluloid Corporation stockholders will vote on the matter at a special meeting on the following day. Proxies asking authorization for the move have been mailed.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- After discussing with Speaker Rayburn the procedure for final House action on the lease-lend bill, passed last night by the Senate, Chairman Bloom of the Foreign Affairs Committee said today that in the interests of speed he probably would seek House acceptance of the Senate draft on Tuesday, with the hope of laying the completed measure on President Roosevelt's desk that evening.

Yesterday was Ty Andersen Day at Madison Square Garden. But the New York Rovers decided to make a day of it themselves to the extent of walloping the Boston Olympics, 5 to 3, in the Eastern Hockey League struggle featuring an amateur double-header in the afternoon before 8,614 fans.

With a strike of 2,400 workers on national defense orders scheduled to become effective this morning at the South Plainfield, N.J., plant of the Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, announced last night that she would confer with Octave Blake, president of the company, today on plans for an employe election at the plant.

A great debate in the Congress of the United States has now been ended with results which are reassuring. It has been shown that Congress is aware of the gravity of the present situation. It has been demonstrated that democracy, no less than dictatorship, can function effectively in a time of crisis.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A nation-wide appeal to Catholics of this country for funds for the relief of the suffering and distress abroad will be sponsored this Spring by the Bishops' Relief Committee, it was announced here today. Heretofore, as the need for aid became apparent, special appeals have been made in behalf of particular relief needs.

The music and figures of "The, Lady Goes Round the Lady and the Gent Goes Round the Gent," danced by grandfathers and grandmothers of the present generation in the old homesteads of New England and pioneer cabins of the West, were a feature yesterday of the March meeting of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Three of the thirteen members of the national executive committee of the Socialist party have resigned in protest against the party's continued policy of isolationist opposition to large-scale material aid to Great Britain, as presented to the public by Norman Thomas, national chairman, and the official publications and statements of the party.

New ideas and broader views are taking hold in the life-insurance field. Close upon the frank report to policy holders of Mutual Life's new president, Lewis W. Douglas, comes an equally frank report from New York Life's even newer president, George L. Harrison. Mr. Harrison lays stress upon the obligation of insurance companies to employ their assets not merely to produce a return but to advance economic and social progress.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 9 -- Ten of the Larchmont Yacht Club dinghy fleet went out today for three open races. Bill Dodge, with his Class X boat Moth Ball, took the first two, and Howie Walden with the Tripple X the other.

ASPEN, Col., March 9 (AP) -- Austrian-born Toni Matt, who said he probably would be serving in the Axis forces if he hadn't left his native Tyrol, won the national combined ski championship at storm-shrouded Roch Run today.

Plans for a three-day observance of the part played by the Port of New York as a great industrial and commercial center and its role in the nation's preparedness program will be outlined at a meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt on Wednesday, it was announced yesterday by representatives of the Port of New York Authority.
BERLIN, March 9 -- There was no indication here tonight that official German calm had been in any way ruffled by the United States Senate's passage of the lease-lend bill yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, March 9 -- The second fire in a month at Frankford Arsenal wrecked the interior of a powder-mixing building today.

BERLIN, March 9 -- A plethora of deposits was the outstanding feature of the bank reports for 1940 as published last week, indicating that the accumulation of idle funds as the result of the restriction of private consumption and the impossibility of industrial replacement during the war continues unabated.
Faced with the task of removing 12,000,000 cubic yards of snow from New York's streets, the Department of Sanitation placed its faith yesterday in its own regular force of workers, and in a thaw.

AMSTERDAM, March 9 -- The securities markets of the smaller Continental European countries again responded divergently last week to the political and military developments in the Balkans but in no case was there any serious perturbation on an exchange.

Under the joint auspices of Union Theological Seminary and the National Religious Publicity Council, a conference will be held tomorrow at 3:30 P.M. at the seminary, Broadway and 120th Street. This will be the first time in the ten-year history of the council that an open conference has taken place and the first time that members of the staff of the secular press have been invited to speak.

Changes in New York Stock Exchange organization are likely and they may not be long delayed. Sentiment within the institution is definitely for change and the governors are understood to favor in principle the reduction in the board, the elimination of four committees and the payment of salaries to the remaining governors which William McC. Martin, Jr., retiring president, recommended in his valedictory last week.

CLEVELAND, March 9 -- Champion Crackley Striking of Wildoaks, wire foxterrier owned by Mrs. R.C. Bondy of Goldens Bridge, N.Y., and handled by Mac Silver, won the special for the best in show at the close of the Western Reserve Kennel Club all-breed exhibition tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 9 -- Reports of travelers just arriving from Norway emphasize that no single event since the end of the Norwegian war has made such an impression on the minds both of Norwegian patriots and Quislingists as the British attack on one of the Lofoten islands.
The text of Herbert Hoover's statement in behalf of the Executive Committee of the National Committee on Food for the Small Democracies follows:

ATHENS, March 9 -- What appears to be developing into the bloodiest battle of the Albanian war is now raging on the central sector of the front, and despite contentions that Italy is employing the largest masses of troops used in any operation until now the Greek armies are retaining the initiative.

Declaring that what was at stake in the war was the very existence of "a truly modern and progressive civilization," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the Carnegie Endowment of International Peace, declared yesterday in a report that "from the point of view of an American it can only once more be repeated that to speak of this war as a European war is childish."

CAIRO, Egypt, March 9 -- The British forces that entered Southern Ethiopia from Italian Somaliland have driven more than 140 miles since crossing the border and have occupied Gabredarre, on the main road between Mogadiscio, Somaliland capital, and Harar, Ethiopia, the British announced today.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Melio Bettina of Beacon, N.Y., former light-heavyweight champion, knocked out Buddy Knox of Dayton, Ohio, in the fifth round of a feature bout tonight for the benefit of the British-American Ambulance Corps.

Formation of the New York Dress Institute to organize and conduct the dress industry's $1,500,000 promotion of New York as the world's style center was announced for publication today by Samuel Zahn, who has been elected chairman of the organization.

The twelfth annual metropolitan invitation Catholic high schools basketball tournament got under way on the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, court yesterday with twelve of the sixteen teams seeing action in the first round.

The strike of the 3,500 employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation, called by the Transport Workers Union at 5 A.M. yesterday, completely immobilized the 1,305 buses operated by the two companies and deprived Manhattan of 95 per cent of its surface transportation facilities.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- National defense is "the No. 1 problem of law enforcement" in a world "beset not by war alone but by revolution," Attorney General Jackson told United States attorneys gathered from the forty-eight States for their third annual conference here today.

Two members of a four-man mission that went to England to study civil defense said on their return yesterday on the American Export liner Excalibur that the United States must send physicians, nurses and material aid to the British as soon as possible.

Stockholders of Merck Co., Inc., have been called to a special meeting at Rahway, N.J., on March 28 to vote on a proposal to split up the present 300,000 common shares on a three-for-one basis and to increase authorized shares after the split-up from 900,000 to 1,200,000 shares, in view of the contemplated sale of 100,000 shares of the new common stock.
LONDON, March 10 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique today stated:

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Howard O. Hunter, as acting Commissioner of Works Projects, today authorized a forty-eight-hour work week on WPA-certified defense projects, consisting mainly of airports, access roads and building construction at Army and Navy posts.

LACONIA-GILFORD, N.H., March 10 -- When bigger jumping hills are constructed, there's one man who will break records. Torger Tokle of Brooklyn's Norway S.C. convinced the ski world by his standard-smashing achievement in the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's championship here yesterday that he is the greatest figure in the sport.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 10 -- Refugees from Austria arriving here today gave a depressing picture of conditions there. The refugees in question include Socialists, Clericals, Communists and Monarchists, and the most outstanding feature noted in conversations with them was the abandonment of normal political differences in the desire to see a reversal of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's coup of 1938.

CINCINNATI, March 10 (AP) -- An American Airlines DC-3 transport with eight passengers aboard skidded in a ground spin and struck a levee wall at Lunken Airport tonight, but none of the passengers was hurt seriously, J.R. Merrill, district sales manager for the line, said.

LONDON, March 10 -- The British Navy has dealt another blow to the already attenuated Italian Fleet, the Admiralty announced today. A British submarine has torpedoed and "almost certainly sunk" an Italian light cruiser of the Condottieri class, it was asserted.

JERUSALEM, March 10 -- The United States Senate's passage of the lease-lend bill is bound to have an incalculable influence on the situation in Syria and Lebanon, in the view of a well-informed traveler who has just made one of his periodic visits to that territory.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 10 -- The Embassy Club, long closed but reopened and loaned by Edward R. Bradley, is the setting today and tomorrow for an auction under the auspices of the four arts for the benefit of the British War Relief Society, Bundles for Britain and the British American Ambulance Corps.

Charges of "conduct unbecoming a member of the staff" will be preferred this week against Morris U. Schappes, a tutor in English at City College, who has admitted that he was an active member of the Communist party for five years, it was announced yesterday by a special committee of the Board of Higher Education, which was appointed to investigate alleged subversive activities in the city's four municipal colleges.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Faced with the probability that the United States may soon be called upon to transfer to the British thousands of tons of merchant ships needed to transport vast quantities of war supplies, the government has begun a survey of American shipping resources.

While thousands of citizens hoped that nature would speed the process, New York City appeared yesterday to be winning its $1,500,000 gamble that a thaw will help clear the 11.6-inch snow that began blocking the streets last Friday.

TOKYO, March 10 -- The realization that the United States, as well as Japan, will become a "high-powered defense State," and that Japan's position in the Pacific will be profoundly affected by that, are the leading ideas of the first Japanese comments on the United States Senate's passage of the lease-lend bill.

Sixteen American composers issued "A Declaration of Musical Necessity" over the week-end defending the National Youth Administration Symphony Orchestra of New York, which has survived the first cut of 7,000 persons from NYA rolls but may be jeopardized by the order that 6,000 more must be dismissed by June 30.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Nicholas Roerich, New York artist and scientist, failed today to obtain a Supreme Court review of a decision hold that his failure to file a Federal income tax return for 1934 was due to fraud with intent to evade the assessment.
Bonnets for Easter were depicted in tableau style yesterday at Lord Taylor's, where models, in seven settings, wore millinery designed to shame the simple, unadorned hat.
ALBANY, March 10 -- A bill validating the lump sum budgets of Nassau County for the last three years was introduced in the Legislature tonight by Senator Thompson, Nassau County Republican.

Antanas Smetona, President of Lithuania until the night in June, 1940, when what he calls "the bandits" of Russia swarmed over the border to absorb the Baltic republic, arrived here yesterday morning on the American Republics liner Argentina.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 98.8 per cent of Capacity, the highest rate of production since June, 1929, indicating an output of 1,594,500 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the highest in the history of the industry. This is 21,000 tons more than last week, when the rate was 97.5 per cent of capacity, the previous high mark.

BERLIN, March 10 -- Beyond taking cognizance of the passage by the Senate of the lease-lend bill, authoritative quarters here today maintained an unruffled silence. The status quo, they repeated, will not be altered until such time as the bill becomes law, which the Germans assume will be shortly.

BERLIN, March 10 -- The National Socialist War Veterans Union has forbidden its members to attend religious meetings of any kind in closed formations except in the case of funeral services for fallen soldiers or deceased members of the Veterans Union.

As Milgrim's exhibition of custommade clothes from its designing room proceeded yesterday afternoon it strengthened the impression received during the past week, when six of New York's important houses with custom-made departments showed, that designers have concentrated on wearability rather than extravagances.

The surge of patriotic feeling has moved the stylists to delve into the picturesque past of this country to find a creative impetus in step with the mood of the day. Bloomingdale's is the most recent convert to the Americana bandwagon.

Hymie Caplin, prizefight manager, was sentenced yesterday to five to ten years in Sing Sing Prison by Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato. Caplin, who has managed five world's champions, was convicted Feb. 15 of grand larceny as the head of a card sharper ring that was reputed to have fleeced victims of $2,000,000 in ten years.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 10 -- Nearly 6,000,000 worth of food will be stored in Australia as rations for the civil population in an emergency. Retailers will be asked to store supplies for three months.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 10 -- State welfare officials were accused this afternoon at a meeting of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors of attempting to intimidate the Supervisors and establish a welfare dictatorship by insisting that the county board members testify in the current State inquiry into Westchester relief costs and explain their charges that a "relief racket" exists in the county.

After three weeks out of town, "The Doctor's Dilemma," the season's first major revival, will be inspected by first-nighters this evening at the Shubert Theatre. It will mark Katharine Cornell's eleventh production as an actress-manager and her third appearance in a Shaw revival.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- With the deadline for income tax returns only five days away, receipts to date are "running ahead of estimates," Secretary Morgenthau said today.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The French threat to convoy food ships, if Great Britain does not permit their passage through the blockade, was regarded here today as tending to throw relations between the former Allies into a new phase, but it wins not believed it would precipitate war between the two countries.

The Illinois Central Railroad was operated in 1940 with a view to probabilities in 1941, 1942 and 1943, J.L. Beven, president, said in his annual report to employes for 1940. The report, which is headed "This is a team and we all are players on it," includes statements on its condition by different officers of the company.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 10 -- Approval of the lease-lend hill by the United States Senate has received marked attention by Chileans, but most newspapers refrain from extended comment.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Greg Rice made it seventeen victories in a row when he led Mel Trutt home tonight by five yards in the two-mile race of the eighth annual Catholic University indoor track meet at Uline Arena in 9:01.7.

TRENTON, N.J., March 10 -- Republican leaders renewed talk today of putting the road department under a three-member board, instead of continuing a single commissioner, as the Jersey Legislature reconvened after a three-week recess.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 10 (AP) -- Threats of sabotage against a huge Mahoning Valley reservoir imperil millions of dollars worth of national defense contracts in the region's steel mills, the Ohio Senate was informed tonight.

LONDON, March 10 -- A 43-year-old navy sailor who pulled a 100-pound time bomb from a house where it had lodged during the German raids Saturday and carried it to a dump some distance away while his son walked ahead of him shouting a warning to every one to get out of the way, was fined 3 today for his act of heroism.

HAVANA, March 10 -- The Affaire Van Lingle Mungo became a temporarily closed incident today when that unhappy young man boarded the clipper for Miami on what was supposed to be the first leg of his journey back home to Pageland, S.C.

JERSEY CITY, March 10 (AP) -- Counsel for petitioners seeking to reopen litigation over a stock allotment plan of the American Tobacco Company told Vice Chancellor Charles M Egan today that the company spent $942,000 for an out-of-court settlement of the suit in 1933.

Mr. Hoover put a terrible question to the British Government when he asked it to allow his committee to pass food through the blockade for children and destitute adult civilians in the Nazi-occupied countries. The statement issued by the British Embassy in Washington on Sunday testifies to the reluctance with which Britain said no.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 10 -- The first big party of diplomats and refugees from Bulgaria arrived here this afternoon. They included the Netherland, Belgian and Polish Ministers and their staffs. There were also a few Britons on the train, but the main body of the British will arrive with their Minister tomorrow.

A group composed of the First National Bank of Chicago, Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and the City National Bank and Trust Company of Kansas City received yesterday the award of $750,000 of airport bonds of Kansas City, Kan., on an interest cost basis of 1.61 per cent.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- With the lease-lend bill out of the way, the Senate gave swift approval today to various bills designed to strengthen the country's sea defenses.
