VICHY, France, March 10 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain received the American correspondents of Vichy in his private apartments here today to ask their support for his appeal to the United States Government and indirectly to Great Britain for food to stave off a desperate wheat famine in France.

Two unions of workers in the field marine drafting announced in a joint statement last night that they planned to form a united front against the attempt of Navy officials to "freeze" shipyard wages and working conditions at their present levels.

Many times since last Summer the Vichy Government threatened to have its supply ships convoyed to France and instructed the French Fleet to resist by force any British attempt to enforce the blockade. In that respect, therefore, Vice Premier Francois Darlan's statement to the American correspondents is not new, except that what was said formerly in muffled tones is now rather resoundingly expressed.

Vincent Furno of the home club caused a major upset as he eliminated Thomas D. Flynn of the Bayside Tennis Club, third seeded player, from the national amateur squash tennis championship at the Columbia University Club last night. The scores were 15 -- 9, 15 -- 12.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a plan of reorganization for the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad Company which included authorization to borrow $4,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

As chairman of the Niagara Frontier Planning Board, I wish to associate myself with Dr. T.H. Hogg, chairman of the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario, in the statement he made in his address to the Empire Club of Canada at Toronto last April, when he said in reference to the St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project:

The most disquieting news from China in recent weeks has not been of military reverses, for the Chinese have suffered none, but of continued friction between the Nationalist Government, or Kuomintang, headed by Chiang Kaishek, and the so-called Communists. Fighting took place some weeks ago between the Communist Fourth Army and Chiang's troops, with several thousands of casualties, and the Fourth Army commander, General Yeh Ting, is a prisoner.
ATHENS, March 10 (UP) -- A four-day-old Greek offensive is hurling back the Italians with "staggering losses" along the entire Albanian front, it was said officially tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A drive for the fullest possible standardization of war equipment among the armed services of the United States and between our services and the British is being intensified in anticipation of the "single order" system of defense production which the Administration has set as one of its goals under the lease-lend program.

Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw gave a dinner last night at her home, 60 East Sixty-sixth Street, for Dr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin, taking her guests later to the performance at the Metropolitan Opera House. The other guests were Dr. and Mrs. Harley Grenville-Barker, Mr. and Mrs. Dana Converse Backus, Mrs. Frank N. Doubleday, Dr. John Lyon and Major Thomas Chamberlain.

The North American Company announced yesterday that it had taken a further step toward ultimate divestment of its control over the Washington Railway and Electric Company by declaring the current quarter's dividend on North American common stock payable in participating units of the Washington company's common stock.

Net profit of National Dairy Products Corporation and subsidiaries for 1940 amounted to $11,094,406, equal after preferred dividends to $1.66 a share for the common stock, comparing with $12,494,803, or $1.88 a share, in 1939. All foreign operations are excluded from the consolidated report for the first time, the report says, and 1939 figures are restated to give effect to this change.

HAVANA, March 10 -- Public hearings on proposed tax legislation with which the Cuban Government hopes to increase its revenue sufficiently to meet the huge deficit that is already apparent began tonight.

If you can close your eyes to the narrow-gauge blizzard of the past week-end and accept the forecast of the Long Island Railroad Fishing Information Bureau you may expect the balmy air of Spring in about two weeks. Yes, the fisherman's special is due to leave for its initial 1941 excursion on March 30, and may the rails be free of ice.

With the leasing of an apartment in the Southmoor at 230 Central Park South to M. Clay that sixteen-story and penthouse structure is now 100 per cent rented, Wm. A. White Sons, agents, announced yesterday.

Plans for coordinating the activities of labor organizations that are helping British trade unionists in their fight against the dictatorships will be discussed at an Aid British Labor Conference to be held by New York unions and fraternal organizations at 8 o'clock tonight at the Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue.

Declaring that the Council investigation of the Municipal Civil Service Commission had uncovered three violations of law by the commission, Councilman James A. Burke renewed his demand yesterday that a representative of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey be asked to attend future sessions in the inquiry.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 10 -- Signature of the Yugoslav-German pact of nonaggression has been deferred until Saturday, according to information tonight from sources close to the government. German semi-official circles here also indicated a postponement; they suggested that a further extension of time was necessary for last-minute touches to the pact.

BAYONNE, N.J., March 10 -- Officials here tonight were awaiting arrival of the naval training ship U.S.S. Newton with a complement of marines to assume police powers over the port terminal, where constructions of a super drydock is scheduled to get under way April 1.

Jan Peeree, New York tenor, who first attracted public notice at the Radio City Music Hall and made his debut as a solo recitalist last season at Town Hall, gave his second solo recital in this city last night at Carnegie Hall. He was reeted by a large audience, which insisted on encores at the end of each group and five at the end of the program.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 10 -- Mr. and Mrs. George A. Bell and Mr. and Mrs. Finis P. Ernest Jr. were hosts to a company of 200 at a cocktail dance at the Surf Club yesterday.

Leopold Stokowski will not appear next season with the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, it was learned here yesterday. It will be the first season he will have missed in twenty-nine years, for since his resignation as musical director in 1936 he has continued to make guest appearances with the orchestra.

In commenting upon the recent sale of the fifteen-story Butterick Building, at 161 Sixth Avenue, by the Bowery Savings Bank to a syndicate headed by Samuel Wasserman and Michael J. Shagan, Charles F. Noyes, whose firm negotiated the deal, said yesterday that the transaction was significant because it indicates that investment capital is available for the purchase of properly selected income-producing business properties.

Miss Anne Ross of the St. George Dragon Club, the New York State and Metropolitan indoor and outdoor champion, won the National A.A.U. junior 3-meter diving title last night at the St. George pool in Brooklyn.

CHUNGKING, China, March 10 (UP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek today appealed for national unity for the sake of victory over Japan. He spoke at the closing session of the People's Political Council.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 10 -- British forces in Southern Ethiopia continued to advance northward today and although their exact position was not reported, estimates based on previous progress place the column within 150 miles of Harar.

Preparations were being made yesterday for the enlistment of 25,000 young men for training as Naval Reserve aviators to man the expanding forces of the two-ocean Navy. Authorization for the recruiting was announced Sunday by the Bureau of Navigation.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- There are many signs in the Capital today that the political opposition to the lease-lend bill will join heartily with its supporters in achieving the stated objects of the measure as promptly and efficiently as possible. No rancorous note was heard as the House prepared to consider the Senate amendments en bloc and, in all probability, quickly concur.

Farmers charged with supplying us with Winter fruit and vegetables, plagued by unfavorable weather, have been having a difficult time of it recently. But over the week-end, while New York's worst storm in six years set us rummaging through closets for long-neglected galoshes, their luck turned.
ROME, March 10 (AP) -- A deter mined air assault upon Greek forces in Albania -- considered the preclude to a major drive this Spring -- was reported today by official Italian sources.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 11 -- Strong formations of Royal Air Force bomber and fighter planes, after raiding the hostile shores of the English Channel three times during daylight yesterday, attacked Nazi bases there harder than ever in the moonlight last night.

The consolidated net profit of the Studebaker Corporation amounted to $2,124,628 in 1940, against $2,923,251 reported for 1939. Last year's profit is equal to 96 cents a share on the common stock outstanding at the year end, against $1.31 a share earned on the common in 1939.

The four-story apartment at 319,321 Summit Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., has been sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark to Morris Feiger. The building contains twenty-one suites and is reported to have a monthly rental of $860.

MARSEILLE, France, March 10 -- Flying both the Stars and Stripes and the Geneva Red Cross flag, the American freighter Cold Harbor of Philadelphia attracted much interest as she took her mooring this morning in Marseille harbor. She brings 1,500 tons of milk, vitamins and clothing for French children in the free zone.

VIENNA, March 9 (Delayed) -- With the slogan "more and better machines for the farmer and more beautiful clothing for every one," Vienna today opened the first of her semi-annual trade fairs for 1941 -- the fortieth such since, as capital of the former Austria, she began to duplicate the famous Leipzig institution two decades ago.

Although government priorities on metals may affect production of some playthings later this year, the theme of "toys as usual for as long a period as possible" dominated the opening yesterday of the American Toy Fair at the Hotel McAlpin and the Fifth Avenue Building.

It may be the wrong, day to mention it, but Appleton-Century will bring out a week from Friday a history of public passenger transportation called "Fares, Please." The author is John Anderson Miller, editor of Transit Journal, who points out that in 1825 New York had no public conveyances at all.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Supreme Court upheld today an Interstate Commerce Commission contention that it had the power to prescribe minimum freight rates higher than necessary to produce a profit, if such action promoted the prosperity of the carriers "by preventing a ruinous rate war."

Two of the three Marx Brothers were co-featured on the witness stand in Federal Court yesterday with the former master of Joseph M. Schenck's yacht. Perhaps because the movie comedians' clothes and manners were toned down to court room style, the captain got the most laughs.

Spurred on by the expectations that the lease-lend bill passage would bring a further stepping up of tempo in industry, the stock market had yesterday its heaviest trading session in almost a month as values were enlarged 1 to 3 points.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company experienced in 1940 the "greatest expansion in business in its fifty-five years of existence," A.W. Robertson, chairman of the board, declared yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.

The specifications for two new multi-family houses, one in the Bronx and the other in Brooklyn, were filed yesterday with the Department of Buildings. Queens filings largely comprised groups of small homes in scattered sections of the borough.
The railroads achieved new records in operating efficiency in 1940, according to complete figures issued yesterday by J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads.

Production of "urgently needed" housing for defense has been delayed for several months because of the failure of any governmental agency, except the Navy, to use the building industry's prefabrication facilities the Architectural Forum Magazine declares in its March issue out today.

City College hurdled New York University last night and gained both the mythical metropolitan basketball championship and a place in the national invitation tournament. The Beavers, recovering in the second half after a severe case of stage fright, vanquished the Violet, 47 to 43, before a capacity gathering of 17,886.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Debits to deposit accounts (except inter-bank accounts), as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 5, aggregated $10,329,000,000.

James A. Farley, former Postmaster General and ex-chairman of the Democratic National Committee, returned to New York yesterday on the American Republics liner Argentina, ending a two-month tour that took him through the West Indies, down the West Coast of South America and across the Andes to Buenos Aires.

Three tenement properties, two in the Yorkville area of the East Side and the other on the West Side of midtown, have just been disposed of by the Central Savings Bank. Two of the parcels have already undergone alterations or fire-retarding and the third will be extensively renovated by the new owner.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 10 -- Public hearings on changing the Puerto Rican law limiting corporate holdings of sugar-producing land to 500 acres were opened at the capitol here today, by Rexford Guy Tugwell, New York City Planning Commissioner.

The Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies decided yesterday to wait no longer for its opponent, the America First Committee, to accept a challenge to publish full list of all contributors of $100 or more.

The Johns-Manville Corporation, in its annual report for 1940 released to stockholders last night by Lewis H. Brown, president, showed consolidated net earnings of $5,882,071, compared with $4,127,691 for 1939. After payment of preferred dividends, last year's earnings equal $6.35 a share on the common stock.

The wholesale meat markets were somewhat irregular yesterday. Steer beef holdings were liberal and prices weak to lower under a slow trade. Traefer veal cuts also showed some weakness. The lamb market was strong to a shade higher and fresh pork cuts were steady to higher. The kosher markets opened about in line with last Friday's closing prices.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- Bids were opened at the Army Quartermaster Depot today on 2,000,000 blankets, and thirty-two mills offered a total of 2,699,000 at prices which indicate a unit increase of close to 25 cents over those purchased a few months ago.

At a time when Columbia needed victory most, the law of averages caught up with the Lions last night and Dartmouth bagged a 39-to-33 decision in the Morningside Heights gymnasium to capture its fourth straight Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League championship.

Active buying, both for near-by and later deliveries, developed yesterday at the first day of a trade showing of drug sundries at the Hotel Pennsylvania, sponsored by the Druggists Supply Corporation for its member wholesalers. Buyer attendance was described as larger than in recent years, and producers' exhibits occupied two floors at the hotel.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 10 -- As a heroic means to a noble end, Colonel Bill Terry took his Giants for a 275-mile bus ride today in the hope that this novel method of preparation would produce his club's first exhibition victory of the training season.

Memories of the near-blizzard of March 8, 1941, will differ in one notable respect from memories of the real thing in March, 1888. The answer is obvious. This is the mechanical age, and when people in the year 1994 start in on the snowstorms they have known it will be chiefly about machines.

Advertising's primary contribution to society in this country lies in its support of 13,000 newspapers, 6,400 magazines and 800 radio stations, Paul Hollister of J. Stirling Getchell, Inc., declared last night before members of the survey of advertising course conducted by Advertising Women of New York.

The lease-lend bill will come before the House of Representatives today for a final vote. Its adoption is a foregone conclusion. The only remaining question is what the Republican party will do when the roll is cared.

President Roosevelt will soon transfer national defense price-stabilization activities to the control of the Securities and Exchange Commission and elevate Leon Henderson to the chairmanship of that agency, a high Washington source told The United Press yesterday.
The Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies made the following available here yesterday as the full list of all contributors of $100 or more.

RICHMOND, Va., March 10 (AP) -- A new operation to restore speech, involving a rearrangement of the muscles and nerves in the neck to provide a new control for a paralyzed larnyx, was reported today to the Southeastern Surgical Congress.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 11 (AP) -- The Cabinet Information Bureau announced today that Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka and his eleven-man suite would leave at 10:35 o'clock tonight for Berlin and Rome via the Trans-Siberian Railway.
WASHINGTON, March 10 - William C. Bullitt was asked by Representative Hobbs today if his experience in France might have a tendency "to make you gun-shy."

Armin H. Mittlemann, 57 years old, of 112-15 Seventy-second Road, Forest Hills, with an office at 500 Fifth Avenue, surrendered yesterday to Sheriff Maurice A. FitzGerald of Queens. Surrogate James A. Delehanty signed, last Thursday, a warrant for his commitment for contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Farmers and ranchers in 1940 paid 30,300 Federal Land Bank and Land Bank Commissioner loans in full in advance of the time when due, A.G. Black, governor of the Farm Credit Administration revealed yesterday. This is the greatest number of loans paid in advance in any year since the Farm Credit Administration was created and brings to more than 141,000 the number paid off in this way since 1933.
BERLIN, March 10 (AP) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A series of White House conferences today cleared the decks for final legislative and administrative action on the lease-lend program. Meanwhile, two Senate Republicans who voted against the aid-to-Britain measure appealed for unified national support of the program.

DETROIT, Mich., March 10 -- Tie-ups in defense industry in this area spread today when a strike of 1,700 members of the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers closed the plant of the Midland Steel Products Company, which supplies automobile frames for Chrysler, General Motors and the Ford Lincoln division and is said to make parts for Army trucks.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 10 (AP) -- A communique of the British Middle East Command said today:

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Byron Nelson of Toledo, Ohio, and Horton Smith of Oak Park, Ill., tied for first place in the fifty-four-hole West Coast open golf tournament today with seven under par 206s, and will play off tomorrow.
